title: Stadium Plan May Fall Victim to Quake
description: An 85-year-old survivor of the 1906 earthquake is making an impassioned plea on the radio here that voters approve a ballot measure to allow construction of a new baseball stadium that would keep the Giants in San Francisco.

title: Terrorist Taking of Ship Subject of Adams Opera
description: Six cultural institutions in the United States and Europe announced yesterday that they have jointly commissioned a new opera by the creators of ''Nixon in China,'' John Adams (composer), Alice Goodman (librettist) and Peter Sellars (director). Entitled ''The Death of Klinghoffer,'' the opera takes as its subject the terrorist attack in 1985 on the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Midler Case Stirs Debate On 'Alikes'
description: THE jury decision on Monday favoring Bette Midler in her suit against Young & Rubicam Inc. is seen by advertising and entertainment lawyers as a precedent that will have a significant effect not just on the use of music but also on the imitation of celebrity voices and other characteristics in advertising.

title: GIULIANI DISCOUNTS COLOR AS AN ISSUE
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, in an appeal largely directed at white New Yorkers, declared yesterday that yearnings for racial peace should not become the deciding factor in his campaign against David N. Dinkins, the city's first black major-party candidate for mayor.

title: A Stevenson Tale Of a Plotting Heiress Is Found and Printed
description: One hundred years ago, Robert Louis Stevenson, the Scottish author of ''Treasure Island,'' ''Kidnapped'' and ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,'' sailed from Hawaii to Samoa, where he would spend the last five years of his life. He was accompanied by his American wife, Fanny, and his stepson, Lloyd Osbourne. While at sea aboard the Equator, he wrote a 27-page story - in pencil in a 7-by-9-inch notebook - and called it ''A Singular Marriage.'' Then he crossed out his original title and decided on ''The Enchantress.''

title: Help for Shoppers In the Postal Pantry
description: IT'S fortunate that the people who deliver the mail rarely carry it in shoulder bags nowadays. The proliferation of glossy full-color catalogues might give the letter carrier a decided tilt.

title: Acme Electric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $443,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: How Yonkers Can Move Forward
description: General election contests for mayor and the City Council give voters in Yonkers, N.Y., clear choices between the past and the future.

title: Ford Completes Associates Deal
description: The Ford Motor Company completed a $3.35 billion acquisition of the Associates First Capital Corporation from Paramount Communications Inc. Ford said Dallas-based Associates, the nation's third-largest independent finance company based on total assets, would operate as an independent affiliate in the Ford Financial Services Group. Associates has assets of about $14 billion and has business in real estate-secured loans, credit cards, direct installment and revolving-credit loans and mortgage banking.

title: 2 From Hong Kong Expelled From Chinese Charter Panel
description: China today expelled two Hong Kong members from a committee drafting a constitution, known as the basic law, for the British colony after it returns to Chinese rule in 1997.

title: J.A.M.  Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Judson Branch, 82; Led Allstate
description: Judson B. Branch, former chairman of the Allstate Insurance Companies, died Monday at Glenbrook Hospital in Glenview, Ill. He was 82 years old and lived in Northfield, Ill.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions in some copies yesterday about Republican women who support abortion rights reversed the identities of the two women at the right. At the top was Representative Olympia Snowe; at the bottom, Representative Claudine Schneider.

title: New Corporate Effort to Aid Innovative Schools
description: Officials of RJR Nabisco Inc., the huge food and tobacco company, said yesterday that the company's foundation would spend $30 million to spur innovative and sometimes risky programs in schools throughout the United States.

title: SWEPT INTO SEA IN NAVY ACCIDENTS
description: In the third and fourth accidents since Sunday involving Navy ships, four sailors were swept overboard early today, three in the Atlantic Ocean and one in the Pacific.

title: Lecture on Revolution
description: A free lecture, ''The French Revolution as World Historical Event,'' will be given by Eric Hobsbawn, an author and professor emeritus at the University of London, on Nov. 15 at 6 P.M. at New York University, D'Agostino Hall, 110 West Third Street. The lecture is part of a series commemorating the bicentennial of the revolution. Mr. Hobsbawn is the author of ''The Age of Revolution'' and ''The Age of Empire: 1875-1914.'' Information: 998-2191.

title: 67 Arrested In Rampages On Halloween
description: More than 100 youths moving in packs rampaged through parts of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday, attacking pedestrians, robbing stores, and slashing one man with a knife, the police said.

title: Nipsco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
International Totalizator Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom Earnings Up
description: The Omnicom Group said its earnings rose by 54 percent, to $5.6 million, in the third quarter of this year, from $3.6 million in the period last year. Its earnings per share jumped by 47 percent, to 22 cents a share, from 15 cents a share in 1988. For the first nine months of 1989, Omnicom's net income grew by 26 percent, to $29.6 million, from $23.5 million. Omnicom, whose holdings include BBDO Worldwide, DDB Needham Worldwide and Tracy-Locke, said its acquisition of the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership and the Thomas A. Schutz Company increased its revenues.

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Conference on Plan to Meet Gorbachev at Sea
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Soviet Managers in U.S.
description: Sixteen Soviet executives began learning capitalist skills this week at a management training program at Northeastern University. During the three-and-a-half-month program, billed as the first of its kind, the 16 will be exposed to American business management methods in areas like international marketing, business strategy, the art of negotiation and management of executive stress. The program includes internships at United States corporations.

A Gay Rights Law Is Voted in Massachusetts
description: After a legislative battle of almost two decades, Massachusetts is about to become the second state to pass a law prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing, credit and public accommodations.

title: Murphy Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $7.1 million of unusual gains for the quarter and gains of $17.8 million from asset sales and settlement of a U.K. tax dispute and take-or-pay obligations in the United States for the 9 months.

title: Pacific Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its 1989 results reflected the acquisition of TRT Communications Inc. in December 1988.

title: West Bank Town Elated but Poorer As Israel Ends Six-Week Tax Siege
description: Israeli soldiers cleared roadblocks today, ending a six-week state of siege here, and the residents of this Palestinian town cheered.

title: Plan Canceled For New Courts In Manhattan
description: After three years of feuding, New York State and New York City have given up on plans to convert a state-owned building in lower Manhattan to new court space, city and state officials said today.

title: Cubs' Zimmer Is Honored
description: Don Zimmer, a manager of three other teams in the major leagues before winning his first title this season with the Chicago Cubs, was named National League manager of the year yesterday, collecting 23 of 24 first-place votes.

title: Kirby Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $500,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $1.6 million, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $203,745 for the quarter and $994,941 for the 9 months, and extraordinary credits of $300,000, or 1 cent a share, and $32,388,853, or $1.35 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: American Western Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Included $875,000, or 17 cents a share, from cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said the latest quarter's results included $2.9 million in pretax expenses associated with the planned acquisition of the company by Carlisle Plastics Inc., and a $215,000 writedown of real estate held for sale.

title: Battle Mountain Gold reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $4.4 million in additional tax expense in connection with a one- time deferred tax adjustment for earnings at the Pajingo Mine through June 30.

title: In Seattle Mayoral Race, a Sense of the Possible
description: If this city is America's most livable metropolis, as two publications recently concluded, there is scant evidence in its first wide-open campaign for mayor in 12 years.

title: FFP Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Included $331,000 one-time credit from redetermination of unemployment tax rates for prior years.

title: EATING WELL
description: WHY do friends who know you have no self-control insist on sabotaging your dietary plans with irresistible gifts of food during the holidays? The calories and fat count just as much in December as they do in June.

title: Fund for Injured Player
description: The University of Mississippi established a trust fund yesterday to help supplement the lifetime care needed by Roy Lee Mullins, who was paralyzed in a game against Vanderbilt on Saturday. Mullins, a 6-foot, 170-pound freshman defensive back, fractured the third, fourth, fifth and sixth vertebrae of his neck when he took a blow on the top of his head while making a tackle. (AP)

title: In British Radio, Beatles And Beethoven Coexist
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avery Inc., a maker of specialty chemicals and synthetic rubber, completed the sale for $800 million of its Uniroyal Chemical Holding Co. to UCC Investors Holding Co., which was formed by members of Uniroyal senior management.

title: Boeing Seeks a Deal With the Japanese To Build New Plane
description: Seeking financial help to develop its next important aircraft and hoping to sell more planes in Japan's booming market, the Boeing Company has invited Japan's three largest aerospace companies to join it in a $4 billion project to build a 300-seat passenger plane.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Seiniger Advertising, a Los Angeles-based motion picture agency acquired last month by the WPP Group, has established a New York office at the headquarters of Ogilvy & Mather, another WPP holding.

title: Cencor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,560,000, or 24 cents a share.

title: Who Makes What in the Major Leagues
description: The 1989 baseball incomes for players who were on major league rosters or the disabled list Aug. 31. The figures were obtained from management and player sources and include base salary, pro-rated share of signing bonus, other guaranteed money (such as payment for trades), bonuses earned during the season and all post-season awards except for most valuable player and Cy Young awards, which have not been determined. In cases where money was deferred without interest, the amount is discounted to reflect present-day value.

title: Lebanon in Limbo
description: LEAD: The political charter signed in Saudi Arabia recently by Lebanon's parliamentarians -rival Moslems and Christians - is a promising step toward ending the civil war that has ravaged the country for nearly 15 years. But it is only a step. Lebanon's civil war has become so enmeshed in the larger complexities of the Middle

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE sweet-hot complexity of a well-made curry can be wonderfully invigorating. The term curry is really a catchall Anglicism that means little to Indian cooks. It is a word that British colonials applied to all the spice mixtures typically found in Indian cooking. The equivalent would be calling all French sauces hollandaise.

title: Rockefeller to Head Washington TV Station
description: The board of directors of WETA, the major public television and radio station in Washington, voted unanimously on Monday to name Sharon Percy Rockefeller as the station's president and chief executive. She is to succeed Ward B. Chamberlin Jr. in December, when he is to become vice chairman of the station.

title: FPI Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $600,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,600,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $1,100,000, or 7 cents a share, and $8,100,000, or 50 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The sales for the latest 9 months and both year-ago periods were not available. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Easter at the Music Hall
description: For the first time in 11 years a live Easter show, featuring the Rockettes, is to be presented next year at Radio City Music Hall. Beginning today, tickets are on sale for the show, called ''Easter Extravaganza,'' which is to run from April 11 to April 18. Tickets are $27 and $30. Information: 247-4777.

title: Frank L. Mingo Dies at Age 49; Led Ad Agency
description: Frank L. Mingo, chairman and chief executive of the Mingo Group Inc., one of the nation's largest black-owned and minority-oriented advertising agencies, died of heart failure Monday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Stamford, Conn. He was 49 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Lynch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jesuits Discuss Future 'Age of Laity' at Their Colleges
description: The presidents of the nation's 28 Jesuit colleges and universities met at Fordham University last week to discuss the future of their institutions in the face of a dramatic decline in the number of Jesuit priests.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN the dim recesses of the past I worked for a newspaper that prided itself on its ability to ''repackage the product.'' It worked something like this: a reporter covering some event would file a bulletin for the company's news service, then return to the office and write up the same event for the next day's paper. Then, too, it was fondly hoped, he would write a page 1 article on the event's broader implications.

title: Willcox & Gibbs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said sales for its latest third quarter included a total of $24,102,000 from Clark Consolidated Industries, acquired January 1989, and Datanet and Dataspan, acquired in November 1988.

title: Faulty Records Costing Dinkins Matching Funds
description: David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign yesterday was denied, at least temporarily, $95,142 in public funds by the city's Campaign Finance Board because of inadequate accounting of contributions.

title: Wheelabrator Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods reflected the Aug. 24 merger of the company's Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. predecessor and Wheelabrator Group Inc. to form the present Wheelabrator Technologies Inc.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co. promoted Bonnie J. Stedt to executive vice president of human resources.

title: Kansas City Life Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books of The Times; Nancy Reagan Tells Her Side of the Stories
description: My Turn The Memoirs of Nancy Reagan By Nancy Reagan with William Novak Illustrated. 384 pages. Random House. $21.95.

title: Reviews/Theater; A New, Nonviolent Ending for 'Lisbon Traviata'
description: With his new, nonviolent ending to ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' Terrence McNally recognizes that life is not grand opera. In the final scene, Anthony Heald is called on to internalize his anguish over his lover's departure rather than to melodramatize it as he did in the earlier version of the play. In the end, he is alone, without life support, a victim of self-abandonment. As a result, the denouement -and the play itself - has become more moving.

title: About New York; A Fishy Epic: Not-So-Old Man Versus the Sea
description: There was a point, late in his career, when people thought Hemingway might be slipping. Then he wrote ''The Old Man and the Sea'' and won the Nobel Prize for literature. The book's cover says the story of an elderly man's fight with a big fish has ''the simplicity of a fable, the significance of a parable and the drama of an epic.''

title: Sales of New Homes Off by 14%; Prices Up 0.2%
description: Sales of new homes fell 14 percent in September, but analysts said the outlook for the housing industry was better than the figures indicated.

title: We Need a Federal Disaster Relief Fund Veteran Police Reserve
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the purchase of a controlling interest in the Sansui Electric Company by Polly Peck International P.L.C. referred to the deal incorrectly. It was not the first foreign purchase of a Japanese company traded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange; in 1983 Merck & Company acquired control of the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company.

title: The Only Reasonable Charter Choice
description: New Yorkers will vote next Tuesday on a dramatic revision of their constitution, the City Charter. It's a conscientious, reasonable proposal that deserves support. Besides, there isn't much choice.

title: Wetterau Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Robert Louis Hodapp, Bishop, 79
description: Bishop Robert Louis Hodapp, a former bishop of Belize and a Roman Catholic missionary in that country for nearly 50 years, died on Thursday. He was 79 years old.

title: Review/Music; Dancing Along With David Byrne
description: The closer they get to a dance floor, the better David Byrne's newest songs sound. Five years after his last tour with Talking Heads, Mr. Byrne has assembled a 14-piece touring band of mostly Hispanic and Brazilian musicians, playing the songs from his new album, ''Rei Momo'' (King of Carnival). By the end of his set at Roseland on Monday, the start of a three-night stand, the band's salsa and samba rhythms had carried the audience into motion.

title: Sandinistas Delay a Decision on Cease-Fire
description: The Nicaraguan Government's self-imposed deadline for deciding the future of its cease-fire with rebels passed without a decision today as Sandinista leaders appeared to be deeply divided on the issue.

title: Uni-Marts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from Saturday, Oct. 28.

title: House Would Extend Smoking Ban on U.S. Flights
description: The House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a Senate-House conference agreement to ban smoking on all commercial airline flights within the continental United States and on most flights to Alaska and Hawaii. Approval came on a voice vote. The ban was part of a compromise measure that would provide $12 billion for transportation programs for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 and $3.2 billion for anti-drug efforts. On a roll-call vote, the House approved the compromise transporation measure 394 to 21. The Senate voted 77 to 21 last month to ban smoking on all domestic airlines. But in August the House had voted, 259 to 169, only to continue the current ban on smoking aboard flights of two hours or less. House and Senate conferees reached their compromise two weeks ago.

title: USX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax income of $312 million from asset sales. c-Included $71 million related to the positive outcome of a federal tax issue. Year-ago figures are restated.

title: Article 067189 -- No Title
description: Price Stern Sloan Inc., the book publisher based here, said today that it had lost $8 million in the third quarter and had retained an investment banking firm to help it consider a sale, merger or recapitalization.

title: Journalist's Role for Charity Questioned
description: Albert R. Hunt, the Washington bureau chief of The Wall Street Journal, has come under criticism from members of his staff for his role in a recent charity fund-raising event that included soliciting Washington lobbyists to buy tickets.

title: Imperial Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago net figures included a gain of $2,212,000, or 37 cents a share, from restructuring of a retirement plan.

title: Par Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOOD NOTES
description: Pre-Marathon Pasta On Saturday evening, more than 10,000 participants in the New York City Marathon are expected to do their carbo-loading at Tavern on the Green at the annual pasta party sponsored by Ronzoni Foods Corporation. They will dine on three dishes selected from more than 60 recipes submitted by restaurants last week in three categories: traditional, cold salad and vegetarian.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Needle Attacks Spreading Fear on West Side
description: Many women on the Upper West Side said yesterday that they were staying home or asking friends to escort them on the street because of a recent series of attacks in which women were jabbed with needles or pins.

title: Francis C. Miller, Executive, 88
description: Francis Charles Miller, a retired advertising executive, died yesterday at the Moorings Park Health Center in Naples, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Naples.

title: Judge Overturns Chicago Statute on Flag
description: A Cook County Circuit Court judge ruled today that a Chicago ordinance banning flag desecration violates the free speech provisions of the Constitution and cannot be used to prosecute artists whose works make use of the flag.

title: Beatrice Forced to Reduce Size of 'Junk Bond' Offering
description: The Beatrice Company yesterday priced $250 million in ''junk bonds'' but was forced to scale back the offering by $100 million from the planned $350 million.

title: Control Resource Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $494,000 and $5,015,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Hydrogen: Is It the Clean Fuel of the Future?
description: When all the coal, natural gas and oil have been burned, or the world does not dare burn any more because of global warming, what will be used for fuel, especially for cars, trucks and buses?

title: Stock Trading Rules to Be Studied
description: The New York Stock Exchange plans to re-examine its rules for coordinated halts in trading in the market, known as circuit breakers, John J. Phelan Jr., its chairman, said yesterday.

title: Soviets, in Bid to Borrow, Set Up Banking Office in New York
description: The Soviet Union has quietly established its first banking presence in the United States, a New York office of Moscow's Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs, American and Soviet officials say.

title: 'Interim' Sessions
description: Saying he does not want to ''miss something'' in the rapidly shifting terrain of East-West relations, President Bush announced today that he would meet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in December for two days of unstructured talks.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 21 about the Polish government in exile in London mistranslated a Latin inscription on a bust of Gen. Jozef Pilsudski. The inscription, ''Summus Polonorum Dux,'' means ''Supreme Leader of the Poles.''

title: Further Study of Possible Tritium Thefts Is Urged
description: The Energy Department's inspector general says three investigations to find missing tritium, the radioactive gas used in nuclear bombs, have failed to adequately weigh the possibility of theft or diversion.

title: Turk Premier Voted President
description: Parliament elected Prime Minister Turgut Ozal President today for a seven-year term, opening the way for a change of government under a new Prime Minister he will select.

title: Danville, Vt.
description: WHEN is a cranberry not a cranberry? When it is a high-bush cranberry (Vibernum trilobum), also known as the American cranberry bush. Botanically speaking, it is not a cranberry at all but a member of the honeysuckle family. But whatever botanists say, Christine Wakefield insists that the translucent scarlet berries she picks each fall make a jelly whose flavor is ''more cranberry than cranberries.''

title: Insituform Southeast Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Galveston-Houston reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $441,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $964,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $242,000, or 2 cents a share, and $742,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Economic Scene; What Crisis In Productivity?
description: SHAKEN by the latest jeremiads from economists? Wait a while; they are bound to change their minds. The latest target for revisionism is the productivity crisis, the declining rate of growth in output per worker that, some argue, is transforming America into a nation of poorly paid burger flippers and Toyota salesmen.

title: Lydall Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $39,000 for the quarter and a loss of $2,542,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Ellen L. Buell, 84, a Times Editor
description: Ellen Lewis Buell Cash, former children's books editor of The New York Times Book Review, died yesterday in Chattanooga, Tenn. She was 84 years old.

title: Vikings' Vaunted Defense Bows to Giants
description: In his pregame speech to the Giants on Monday night, Coach Bill Parcells was a prophet.

title: Accounting Rule Dispute
description: Upset by a decision that would limit the jurisdiction of the Governmental Accounting Standards Board, nine organizations representing state and local government officials said yesterday that they would withdraw their financial support from the board and start their own rule-making body.

title: Florio, Acting Assured, Rehashes Old Themes
description: Visiting with students and elderly voters today, Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for governor, sounded a reprise of some of the main themes of his campaign: the need to fight drugs and crime and to provide opportunity to all New Jerseyans.

title: FEMA: Bureaucratic Disaster Area
description: LEAD: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has not distinguished itself in recent natural disasters. Part of the problem is that the actual role of the agency has been subtly changing over the last decade. FEMA used to provide direct, tangible support and supplies to disaster areas, and took an active role in restoring normal services and order.

description: b-Net income

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Findings Suggest Jet's Flaw Was Visible Before Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board released metallurgical findings today that raise the possibility a small crack that led to the United Airlines DC-10 crash here in July may have been detectable before the accident.

The 9 months also included an accounting adjustment gain of $5,191,000, or 5 cents a share, from credit from cumulative effect of an accounting change for income taxes.

Read Their Lips! Soviet Legislators Vote No to Proposal for New Sin Taxes
description: The Soviet legislature approved the 1990 economic plan and budget tonight, but not before overwhelmingly rejecting a proposal to increase the prices of cigarettes, beer and delicacies.

title: BP Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $652,000, or 2 cents a share, and $2,491,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,789,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Thomas Will Try a Comeback
description: Kurt Thomas, the United States' greatest male gymnast, who is nine years removed from his last competitive back handspring, is trying to make a comeback at the age of 33. He wants to compete in the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, where he debuted his trademark ''flair'' move on the pommel horse 14 years ago.

title: Senna Fined $100,000
description: Ayrton Senna, the defending world driving champion, was fined $100,000 yesterday by an auto racing tribunal, which rejected an appeal of the Brazilian's disqualification in the Japanese Grand Prix. With only the Australian Grand Prix left on the 1989 schedule, the ruling assured that the Formula One driving title would go to Alain Prost of France, a teammate of Senna on the McLaren-Honda team. Senna finished first in Japan on Oct. 22 but was disqualified after cutting past a curve after a collision with Prost. (AP)

title: In Boston, No-Nonsense With Style
description: For 10 years, Boston's dining scene has been stirring to life. The city's Yankee clubs and old-style French restaurants got a wake-up call from nouvelle cuisine when L'Espalier opened in 1979. In the early 80's, during the era of the ''new American cuisine,'' Panache, Seasons at the Bostonian Hotel and the Colony became headquarters for the New England component.

title: The Worst World Series Ever Played
description: Tonight there will be no seventh game of the World Series. Tonight there will be no Mr. November for the seventh game. Tonight, on what would have been the evening of the seventh game had the Series gone that far, the teams are resting. Until spring. The Series ended, of course, on Saturday night, after the Oakland A's drubbed San Francisco in four straight games, in the longest short series in baseball history, and at once the dullest but most dramatic World Series ever.

title: Better Relations Depend on U.S., Deng Tells Nixon
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, met with former President Richard M. Nixon today and told him that it was up to the United States to take steps to improve relations with China.

title: Downey S&L Assoc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Charlotte Neuville Softens the Edges
description: CHARLOTTE NEUVILLE has pared down her act for spring but retained the essence of her style. While the models look less androgynous - the oversize ''boyfriend'' jacket has been cut down to a woman's size - the tailoring is still impeccable.

title: BSN Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $46,264, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $4,909,716, or 96 cents a share, for the 9 months, and an extraordinary gain from early retirement of debt of $1,344,924, or 27 cents a share, for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Bausch & Lomb At Sales Peak
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said it would give its employees a day off to celebrate passing the $1 billion sales level. Dec. 22 will be a paid holiday for the eye and health care company's 12,400 employees worldwide. The company achieved $1 billion in sales for 1989 for the first time in its history last week.

title: Palestinian Suicide Bombing Wounds 3 on an Israeli Boat
description: A Palestinian guerrilla blew up his booby-trapped fishing boat in a suicide attack on an Israeli patrol boat on Monday night, killing himself and wounding three Israeli soldiers, the Israeli military reported today.

title: Artistic Greetings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patriots Release Eason
description: Tony Eason, who went from starting quarterback to fourth-stringer in just 19 days, was released yesterday by the New England Patriots after he refused to take a substantial pay cut.

title: Article 043089 -- No Title

title: Armstrong Selling Carpet Business
description: Armstrong World Industries agreed in principle to sell its carpet operations to Shaw Industries for an undisclosed amount of cash. Armstrong said it was divesting the carpet business because the segment did not generate adequate returns. In 1988, the business contributed $368.3 million to the company's worldwide sales of $2.68 billion.

title: Injury Is Not Likely to Idle Simms
description: Phil Simms was limping today and his sprained right ankle was swollen. Coach Bill Parcells, however, gave his starting quarterback ''a pretty good chance to play'' Sunday against the Cardinals in Phoenix, although he said Simms would miss practice Wednesday.

description: Colleen Dewhurst, Charles Busch, Brad Davis and D. W. Moffet will be featured in a special reading of Larry Kramer's play ''The Normal Heart'' on Nov. 13 at 7:30 P.M. at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place. Proceeds will benefit the AIDS Treatment Registry, a service organization that provides information on experimental drugs. Tickets are $25, $50 and $100. Information: 268-4196.

title: New Quake in Armenia
description: An earthquake shook the southern Soviet republic of Armenia today, but no casualties or damage were reported, Tass said. The press agency said the epicenter of the earthquake, which measured between 5 and 5.5 on the Soviet 12-point scale, was near the town of Gukasyan, in the same area hit by a catastrophic quake last Dec. 7. That quake, which measured about 10 on the Soviet scale, killed an estimated 25,000 people.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I just didn't want to, in this time of dynamic change, miss something, something that I might get better first-hand from Mr. Gorbachev. I don't want to have two gigantic ships pass in the night because of failed communication.'' - President Bush. [ A18:1. ]

title: 2 More Bodies Found in Ruined Highway's Rubble
description: Workers searching the wreckage of Interstate 880, where more than a mile of roadway collapsed in the earthquake two weeks ago, found the bodies of a woman and a man in separate vehicles, a police spokesman said today.

title: Sea Containers Plans Sale of Half Its Assets
description: The board of Sea Containers Ltd. announced a plan today to sell half its assets and use some of the proceeds to buy back seven million of its common shares for $70 each.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Post for Services At Backer Spielvogel
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc. said yesterday that it had named Alvin A. Achenbaum to the new position of vice chairman for professional services, effective Nov. 13.

title: Prison Accounts for Inmates
description: Prison officials said today that they had accounted for all inmates at the riot-torn state prison here and attributed an earlier report that five prisoners were missing to paperwork errors. Hundreds of inmates who slept outdoors for three days were returned to cells at the prison near Harrisburg, where scores of people were injured and half the buildings gutted or damaged by fires set Wednesday and Thursday in rioting that stemmed in part from overcrowding.

George Nassar, 79, Arab-American Leader
description: George Nassar, a leader in the Arab-American community in Westchester County, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Yonkers. He was 79 years old.

description: The Hillerich & Bradsby Company, noted for its Louisville Slugger bats, charges in a lawsuit that Don Mattingly of the Yankees has violated a contract he signed in 1980 as a 19-year-old minor league player.

description: A masked gunman shot a son of Philadelphia's imprisoned mob boss tonight as he was dining at an Italian restaurant, the police said.

Bombing at Salvadoran Leftists' Office Kills Eight
description: Eight people, including one of El Salvador's most outspoken leftist organizers, were killed today and 35 others injured when a bomb exploded in the headquarters of a labor confederation here.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about drug education programs misstated the amount spent by New York City annually on drug education. It is $34.5 million, not $34.5 billion.

title: Market Place; Minnesota Banks Go Different Ways
description: FOR decades, First Bank System Inc. and the Norwest Corporation, two large banking companies based in Minneapolis, were so similar that they were often referred to as the Minnesota twins. But these days, the twins are by no means identical. ''They're kind of like Arnold Schwarzenegger and Danny DeVito,'' said Ben Crabtree, a banking analyst at Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis, referring to a movie comedy last year about twins with strikingly different physiques and personalities.

title: The Return of History
description: The extraordinary cascade of transformations roiling what must still be called the Soviet bloc is revealing that the ideological battles of the last half-century were a parenthesis. Their demise in favor of liberal democracy is not the end of history, as has been suggested, but the return of history in the eastern part of Europe.

title: Many Japanese Wary On Mitsubishi U.S. Deal
description: During the last few years, as Japan's larger real estate companies poured billions of dollars into overseas investments, the prestigious Mitsubishi Estate Company stood apart, being content to collect rents from its vast holdings at home and to watch their value soar.

title: Prices of Farm Products Increase Slightly in Month
description: The prices that farmers received for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in October from September levels, leaving the monthly index seven-tenths of 1 percent higher than in October 1988.

title: Utility in Florida Pleads Guilty in Political Contributions
description: The Gulf Power Company, the major supplier of electricity in northwestern Florida, pleaded guilty today to conspiring to make secret illegal campaign contributions to political candidates.

title: Traffic in Cocaine Reported Surging Weeks After Colombian Crackdown
description: Weeks after the Colombian Government's crackdown reduced illicit cocaine shipments to the United States to a trickle, smuggling has climbed back to near-normal levels, Federal narcotics experts say.

title: Gorbachev's U.S. Summits
description: Geneva Nov. 19-21, 1985 Agenda: Discussions on arms control and other issues. The first summit meeting in more than six years. Result: Accords on revival of cultural exchanges and enhancement of air safety. No arms control agreements. Reykjavik, Iceland Oct. 11-12, 1986 Agenda: Provide momentum for arms control talks. Result: Intitial agreement on the elimination of all European-based medium-range missiles and equal limits of 100 on warheads outside Europe. Accord snags over American plans for a space-based missile defense system and Soviet insistence on linking all arms control issues. Washington Dec. 8-10, 1987 Agenda: Discussions on strategic arms, including human rights, regional conflicts and trade. The first visit to the American capital by a Soviet leader since 1973. Result: Signing of a treaty eliminating medium-and shorter-range nuclear weapons based on land. Moscow May 29-June 2, 1988 Agenda: Discussions on human rights, arms control, nuclear testing. Result: Agreements on arms control, student exchanges, nuclear research and other matters (fisheries, search and rescue, radio navigation). Discussions on human rights and regional conflicts in Angola and Namibia. United Nations Dec. 6-8, 1988 Agenda: No formal agenda. Result: In a speech to the United Nations, Gorbachev proposes a unilateral reduction in Soviet conventional forces and promises to broaden human rights in the Soviet Union. Administration avoids calling the meeting a summit; talk between Gorbachev and Reagan produces nothing substantive.

description: When Benjamin Nichols is on the campaign trail in his quest to become the next mayor here, he talks about issues rarely discussed in central New York: taxing developers to pay for affordable housing, the possibility of rent control and legislation that would enable gay couples to register as domestic partners.

title: Fatal Heart Attack at Opera
description: A 70-year-old man suffered a fatal heart attack last night at the Metropolitan Opera at Lincoln Center during a performance of Verdi's ''La Traviata,'' officials said. The man, Samuel Weiss, of 351 East 84th Street, collapsed in his seat at 9:22 P.M. Mr. Weiss regained a pulse after several physicians in the audience administered cardio-pulmonary resuscitation for about 20 minutes, officials said, but was pronounced dead shortly after being taken to Roosevelt Hospital.

title: 9 Guards Plead Not Guilty In Assaults at Meadowlands
description: Nine security guards at the Meadowlands Sports Complex were arraigned today on charges of assaulting people during and after Grateful Dead concerts two weeks ago.

title: U.S. Issues Finish Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were unchanged to slightly higher in seesaw trading yesterday as dealers sifted through conflicting reports on the economy.

title: Kimberly-Clark reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vermont Is Combating Illiteracy Among Adults
description: Ed McAuley had some advice for Vermont's Commissioner of Education: ''Put all your money, all your best teachers, into the first six grades. No one should leave the sixth grade without learning how to read.''

title: Dallas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $843,000 and $755,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago results are reclassified for discontinued operations.

title: We Need a Federal Disaster Relief Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Theater; A Gershwin-Wodehouse Spoof of Prohibition
description: Early in the second act of the Goodspeed Opera House revival of ''Oh, Kay!'' comes a moment of delicious fun, when Duke (Stanley Wayne Mathis), a happy-go-lucky young bootlegger, succumbs to an ailment that a Gershwin song identifies as ''Fidgety Feet.'' With his legs tugging him about the stage, Mr. Mathis flails and gyrates in a funky acrobatic Charleston that is so infectious it instantly galvanizes the ensemble into a lurching, tapping frenzy. The fever doesn't subside until everyone is nearly breathless.

title: World Series Fails In ABC's Ratings
description: Low ratings and few games combined to make the World Series, which ended with the fourth game on Saturday, a financial disappointment for ABC and a ratings boon for the competition. The series had an average rating of 16.4 and about a third of the audience, far below last year's scores, when NBC's broadcasts of the games averaged a 23.9 rating and 39 percent of the audience.

title: Champions on Auction Block
description: Would you buy a used horse from D. Wayne Lukas?

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about the Oakland Athletics' domination of the World Series gave incorrect run totals for 1928. In that Series, the New York Yankees outscored the St. Louis Cardinals in four games by 27-10, not 30-10.

title: U.S. Healthcare reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Top Tokyo Executive To Oversee Firestone
description: The chairman of Japan's biggest tire company, the Bridgestone Corporation, will come to the United States next year to supervise the affairs of the company's North American unit, Bridgestone/Firestone Inc.

title: Albuquerque Journal; Carving Out an Identity In the Land of 'Anglos'
description: When Katherine Preonas was a young girl shopping with her mother in downtown Albuquerque, she was often criticized for speaking bad Spanish. In fact, she was speaking fluent Greek.

title: Barrister Information reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $417,000, or 14 cents a share. c-Included tax credits of $1,425,000, or 32 cents a share.

title: Plan of Unocal And Venezuela
description: The Unocal Corporation said it would spin off nearly all its operations in the Middle West, including an oil refinery and several hundred service stations, into a joint venture with the Venezuelan state oil company.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints' Day, alternate-side parking rules are suspended today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: U.N. Chief Favors Norwegian in Refugee Post
description: The United Nations Secretary General has told representatives of member nations that he is ready to nominate a former Norwegian official as the next United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

title: Roy Shuts Out the Faltering Islanders
description: If the Islanders' fans look hard enough, they might find a few positive points to stress about their team's 3-0 loss to the Montreal Canadiens tonight at the Nassau Coliseum. For instance: The Islanders never stopped trying, skating hard toward the Montreal end until the final buzzer.

title: No Praise on Panama
description: To the Editor:

title: Science Also Benefits From the Women in It
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Offer a Deal On Gains Tax in Senate
description: In a move aimed at breaking a logjam on Capitol Hill, Democratic Congressional leaders today offered Republicans a deal that would permit prompt passage of a debt limit bill and allow a Senate vote on cutting the capital gains tax.

title: Datascope Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Jersey Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1988 year results included a gain equaled to 9 cents a share on sale of certain real estate properties.

title: James R. Albano, Accountant, 48
description: James R. Albano, a partner in the accounting firm of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, died of lung cancer on Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 48 years old and lived in Woodbury, L.I.

title: Castle & Cooke Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 7
Mexico's Drive on Graft Snares High Official
description: For the first time, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's drive against corruption in government has focused on a prominent member in good standing of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party.

title: William W. Laird, a Financial Adviser, 79
description: William Winder Laird, a financial adviser, philanthropist and a former director of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, died Oct. 20 at his home in Wilmington, Del. He was 79 years old.

title: Western Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bhutto Faces Crucial Assembly Vote Today
description: In an atmosphere tinged with menace, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto faces a crucial parliamentary vote Wednesday that will determine whether she will continue to lead Pakistan at the head of a fragile parliamentary coalition.

title: Warner and Sony Talks
description: Warner Brothers Inc. and Sony USA Inc., embroiled in litigation over the planned defection of two Hollywood producers to Sony's new movie studio, said today that they had restarted private negotiations to reach a settlement. The companies said they had agreed to postpone an appearance on Thursday in Los Angeles Superior Court so they can have ''further discussions.'' The Sony Corporation, which recently agreed to acquire Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., wants to hire the producers Peter Guber and Jon Peters to be the studio's co-chairmen. But they have a five-year contract with Warner. After talks in September and October broke down, Warner sued Sony, Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters to prevent the defection. Sony countersued, arguing that the pair's contract would allow the move.Time Warnerd(Warner Bros.)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 2 Shadwick Purchases
description: Shandwick P.L.C. yesterday continued its policy of growth by acquisition, buying two agencies on opposite sides of the globe. The British public relations conglomerate said it would pay up to $:5 million, or about $7.9 million, for PR Consultants Scotland Ltd., Scotland's largest agency; and up to $:9.5 million, or about $15 million, for Presko, an agency based in Bangkok, Thailand. Peter Gummer, Shandwick's chairman, said the acquisitions bolstered its presence in Britain and the Pacific Rim.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: FOR many people, cooking with a microwave oven has become the norm. Even when it is not much quicker than conventional cooking, it is still cooler, cleaner and often provides better results.

title: Unum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Indicators Rose 0.2% In September
description: In a sign of continued but slow growth, the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge inched ahead two-tenths of 1 percent in September for its second straight monthly advance.

title: Lessons
description: Prophets frequently go without honor in their own country. So can educational innovators in their own school districts.

title:
EDUCATION;
Education Researchers Vexed by Lack of Impact
description: LEAD: When medical researchers announce that a low-cholesterol diet might lower the risk of a heart attack, the public clamors for oat bran muffins and quits eating eggs. But what happens when educational researchers announce that they have proved that a special tutoring program has long-lasting positive effects on students' reading ability?

title: Florida Coach Retires At School's Request
description: The University of Florida's basketball coach, Norm Sloan, retired at the school's request yesterday, leaving a program that has been under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for more than 18 months. Hired as interim coach was Don DeVoe, who resigned last March at Tennessee, where in 11 years his record was 204-137.

title: Greiner Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Union Exploration Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Unocal Corp. and its subsidiary, Union Oil Co. of California, own about 95 percent of Union Exploration's outstanding units.

title: Thatcher Urged to Tie Pound to Other Currencies
description: Nigel Lawson, who resigned as Chancellor of the Exchequer last week, challenged Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher openly today to swallow British national pride and let the pound be tied more closely to the other currencies of the European Community as soon as possible.

title: Scottsdale, Ariz.
description: JOSEPH GUTIERREZ, a burly Basque who is the chef at Marquesa, a Catalan restaurant in the Scottsdale Princess Hotel near Phoenix, sees to more than just food. In his spare time he has become an interior decorator.

title: Brown & Sharpe Manufacturng Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Rates Up a Bit At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose slightly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. It was the second consecutive rate increase at the auction and the third in the last four weeks.

title: Bank Board Record Belies Charge Against Glenn
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Spira, 99, Leader of Bluzhov Hasidim
description: Rabbi Israel Spira, who as the Grand Rabbi of Bluzhov was the spiritual leader of a Hasidic branch in Brooklyn and Israel, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 99 years old and lived in Brooklyn's Borough Park section, where his synagogue was situated.

title: Review/Television; Portrait of a Missouri Artist: 'Hard-Drinking Tough Guy'
description: Critics may disagree on the value of Thomas Hart Benton's paintings, but Ken Burns's illuminating documentary about the Missouri artist leaves no doubt that his life is worth a look. ''Thomas Hart Benton,'' at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 and 10 P.M. on Channel 49, presents the muralist as a ''hard-drinking tough guy who happened to be an artist'' and ''a sophisticate who pretended to be simple.''

title: Restraint From Calvin Klein, Youthful Chic From Ellis
description: CALVIN KLEIN, who has been known for paring his clothes to the bare minimum, got to the roots this time. Marc Jacobs, who has had a difficult time filling the shoes of the late Perry Ellis, has solved the problem by being himself. Arnold Scaasi, who always claims he wants nothing more than to make pretty dresses, succeeded in doing just that. Eleanor P. Brenner gave four intimate showings in her showroom instead of an extravagant one in a hotel and gave the money she saved to help battered women; her casual clothes also won plaudits.

title: A.H. Robins Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures for 1988 have been restated to reflect adoption of SFAS 96, sale of pet-care business and change to FIFO inventory method.

title: The Summit: Just a Photo Op?
description: The White House modestly describes the Mediterranean rendezvous between Presidents Bush and Gorbachev as a get-acquainted meeting that will merely set the stage for a full-scale summit meeting next summer. But it would be a mistake, and probably impossible, to settle for a photo opportunity summit session in December.

title: Run for the Money Doesn't Always Pay
description: By finishing first in the Los Angeles Marathon seven months ago, Art Boileau of Canada and Zoya Ivanova of the Soviet Union each won $26,385 and a Mercedes-Benz worth more than $30,000. Those same prizes are available to the first-place finishers Sunday in the New York City Marathon, and if Boileau and Ivanova are first again, they would qualify for a $300,000 bonus for winning both races. Or so it seems. As a citizen of a market-economy nation, Boileau is entitled to any prize he wins. That is not yet the case for Ivanova.

title: Eldon Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 7
description: The company said share earnings for the 9 months and 1988 have been restated to give effect to a 4-for-3 stock split in June.

title: Famous Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 8
Charges Against Youth Dropped at Jogger Trial
description: Criminal charges against a youth arrested in the beating and rape of a jogger in Central Park were dismissed yesterday, and a lawyer for the one of the six remaining defendants said he expected that the youth would become an important witness for the prosecution.

title: Whittaker Sells A Plastics Unit
description: The Whittaker Corporation said it had sold its Duall/Wind plastic extrusion business to the American Filtrona Corporation, Richmond, for an undisclosed price. The sale is part of a series of divestitures Whittaker has made under a plan made in response to an unwelcome takeover attempt.

title: Halsey Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Careplus Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $124,000, or 3 cents a share, and $410,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Terrano Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canfor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $9,400,000, ot 40 cents a share, for the quarter and $78,000,000, or $3.43 a share, for the 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Candela Laser reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter included a tax loss carryforward benefit of about $299,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Leonard Cohen, Sports Reporter, 87
description: Leonard Cohen, who worked for 48 years as a reporter, feature writer, columnist and sports editor for The New York Post, died on Monday of a heart attack in Lauderdale Lakes, Fla., where he had lived since his retirement in 1974. He was 87 years old.

title: Review/Music; 2 Schools of Country, at Marlboro Festival
description: The Marlboro Country Music Festival on Sunday night at Madison Square Garden offered two visions of country music. The first, represented by Ricky Van Shelton, Merle Haggard and George Strait, is deep in the honky-tonk tradition, part of the new traditionalist movement that looks to the hard-rocking country stars of the past for their legitimacy. The second, represented by Alabama, the hugely successful band that closed the show, uses country music as flavoring for its utterly bland, pop-derived songs.

title: Borden Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charges of $404,400,000 and $507,649,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for reconfiguration and restucturing programs. c-Net income

title: Joan M. Cohen, Volunteer, 55
description: Joan M. Cohen, a volunteer who was a trustee of the United Jewish Appeal - Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, died of cancer Monday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan and Greenwich, Conn.

title: Anne Frank Benefactor Hailed
description: West Germany has awarded its highest civilian medal to a Dutch woman who hid Anne Frank from the Nazis, the West German Embassy said today. The woman, Miep Gies, is being given the Federal Cross of Merit First Class for her ''crucial role'' in hiding Miss Frank and her family, the embassy said. Mrs. Gies, 80 years old, was a secretary in the Amsterdam house where the Frank family took refuge from 1942 to 1944. She and her husband, Henk, smuggled food to them, keeping their presence secret for two years.

title: Day of the Dead Feeds Body and Soul
description: AS much as food is a part of life, in many cultures it is also essential to the rituals of death and mourning. The feasting at an Irish wake, the funeral pies of the Pennsylvania Dutch, the custom among the Jews of bringing food during shiva, the week of mourning, and leaving the favorite foods of the deceased in the tombs of ancient Egypt are among the traditions connecting food and funerals.

title: QED Exploration reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: The company said that losses were due to non-cash writedowns of $575,000 in 1989 and $2,682,241 in 1988 in oil and gas properties. The 1989 writedown, which occurred in the first quarter, resulted solely from lower prices. The 1988 writedown resulted from a combination of a lower reserve base and lower prices.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Jeffrey W. Clapp Jr., former chairman of MacNamara, Clapp & Klein, has joined Stan Merritt Advertising as chairman.

title: Auto-Trol Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $988,000 relating to a write-off of capitalized software. c-Net income

title: Alpheus Mason, An Ex-Professor And Author, 90
description: Alpheus Thomas Mason, McCormick Professor of Jurisprudence Emeritus at Princeton University and one of the country's foremost judicial biographers, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J., after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: Britain Eases Curb On Jaguar
description: Paving the way for an all-out fight between the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company for Jaguar P.L.C., the British Government said today that it was willing to lift a restriction barring anyone from buying more than 15 percent of Jaguar's shares until the end of the next year.

title: New England Business Servce Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $525,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. c-After a loss of $238,000 from discontinued operations. There were 13 weeks in the latest quarter, compared with 14 weeks in year-ago period.

title: A Director's Race With AIDS Ends Before His Movie Opens
description: When the director Howard Brookner died of AIDS on April 27, he left two statements. The first was 8,100 feet of celluloid called ''The Bloodhounds of Broadway,'' starring Madonna, Matt Dillon, Jennifer Grey and Randy Quaid. The second, written in the sardonic manner in which he handled his illness, was taped to his refrigerator during the last year of his life: ''There's so much beauty in the world. I suppose that's what got me into trouble in the first place.''

title: Del Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: The company said all share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 6 percent dividend distributed Sept. 15, 1989.

title: Gen-Probe Agrees To Chugai Offer
description: Gen-Probe Inc., a medical products company based in San Diego, agreed to be acquired by the Chugai Pharmaceutical Company of Japan for $6.25 a share, or about $100 million. Gen-Probe's stock soared $2.75 a share today, to $6, in over-the-counter trading. Its 84.6 percent rise was the best of the day.

title: Foes and Backers Begin Ads on Charter Revision
description: A graphic television commercial showing several dozen worms crawling out of a can - and urging New Yorkers to prevent the can from being opened by voting against the proposed city charter - is to be broadcast beginning today by a coalition opposed to the revised charter.

title: East Europe as Catalyst
description: Eastern Europe has not been on the formal agenda of a Soviet-American summit conference since World War II, but it will certainly be a major topic when George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold their shipboard summit meeting in December.

title: Hudson Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $10,855,146, or 82 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: Hathaway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Betz Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Inspiration Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said year-ago figures included a gain of $26.7 million, or 40 cents a share, from the sale of the net assets of its U.S. copper subsidiary in July 1988. The latest quarter results were adversely affected by charges related to the cleanup of a chemical fire at a contract manufacturer; a recall and product damage claim, and a $4.2 million increase in income tax provisions related primarily to its Canadian mining unit.

title: Negative Race Disgusts Many Voters in New Jersey
description: The negative campaigning by the candidates for governor of New Jersey is troubling many people who are expected to vote on Nov. 7.

title: A Mere Pittance Or Two
description: Why all the fuss about Ron taking $2 million from a Japanese corporation for two 20-minute speeches? It's just sour grapes, I say.

title: Cleaning the Soil After a Gasoline Leak
description: There are an estimated two million underground gasoline tanks in this country, at service stations and industrial plants, and at least a quarter of them are thought to be leaking. Owners of these sites are obliged to clean up contaminated soil to prevent gasoline from fouling supplies of drinking water.

title: Pleats? Cuddly Cardigans? Brooks Brothers Unbuttons
description: Brooks Brothers, the staid, sedate, venerable, buttoned-down and buttoned-up clothing retailer, is taking the first step toward loosening its rep tie and cruising into the 90's. A $7 million facelift has added shiny escalators and bright lights to its flagship Madison Avenue store at 44th Street.

title: Valhi Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $100,000 and $2,400,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $1,100,000, or 1 cent a share, and $8,700,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest third-quarter and year-to- date results included pretax gains on the disposition of business units of $32.3 million and $38.6 million, respectively.

title: Florida East Coast Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Composers Win Awards At the Kennedy Center
description: Four composers have received this year's Friedheim Awards from the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The top prize, a $7,500 award, was shared by George Tsontakis and Chinary Ung; $1,000 went to David Lang, and $500 was awarded to Michael Daugherty.

title: Review/Music; New York Debut By Finnish Trio
description: The Trio Finlandia did well to bring a substantial contemporary work from its homeland as the centerpiece of its New York debut at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening: the Piano Trio (Op. 49) by Pehr Henrik Nordgren, a prolific composer little heard here.

title: Brown Transport Files Chapter 11
description: The Brown Transport Company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because it could not reach an agreement for renewal of its insurance coverage. The trucking company, which operates in the Southeast, also said its units filed for protection from creditors while it reorganizes.

title: Anger With Ortega Unites Policy Makers in U.S.
description: Bush Administration officials and members of Congress from both parties condemned President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua today for his decision to end a 19-month cease-fire with Nicaraguan guerrillas supported by the United States.

title: General Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $100,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included an extraordinary loss of $3.3 million and a gain of $18.3 million, or $2.13 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Phillips Plant Will Reopen
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said today that it would resume production of two plastics used for packaging at its petrochemical plant in Pasadena, Tex.

title: Chicago Exchange Alters Rules on Halting Trading
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it had tightened the rules for market trading halts, known as circuit breakers, at times when prices drop sharply.

title: Review/Music; From Yale, Russian Works
description: Yale Music Spectrum, an ensemble of faculty members and graduates of the Yale University School of Music, is playing four programs, each built around a specific theme, at Merkin Concert Hall this season. The first, which the players offered on Saturday evening, was devoted to Russian music.

title: Franklin Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Accounts
description: * Dakin Inc., a maker of stuffed animals, to Mandelbaum, Mooney, Ashley Inc., San Francisco, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Travelers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results for the latest quarter and 9 months included investment gains of $31,000,000 and $41,800,000, respectively. Results for the year-ago quarter included an investment gain of $10,000,000 and an investment loss of $351,300,000 for the 9 months. The company said the net effect of Hurricane Hugo was to reduce income by $40 million in this year's third quarter.

title: Dow Rises 0.82, to End Session at 2,645.90
description: Stocks ended mixed yesterday on moderate volume, failing to build on the strong rally of the previous session.

title: Motherhood's Better Before 30
description: LEAD: Recently, a 36-year-old colleague giddily announced her first pregnancy. It struck me - 27 years old and three years married - that I am of a decidedly different generation than this late-30's crowd haunted by amniocentesis and the tick-tock of biological certainty.

title: National Westminster Shuffles Management
description: The National Westminster Bancorp announced a management reorganization yesterday at the bank holding company and its chief bank, National Westminster Bank USA.

title: Chart House Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,525,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $213,000, or 4 cents a share for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the extraordinary items are due to early retirement of debt, less related income taxes of $975,000 and $137,000, respectively, for the 1989 and 1988 periods. Year-ago quarter and 9 months results are reported on a historical basis to include operations of Luther's Bar- B-Q, which was sold in December 1988. The company also reported results on a pro forma basis, as if the disposition of Luther's had occurred on Jan. 1, 1988 and as if the proceeds from the disposition were used to retire debt. On that basis, revenue for the 1988 third quarter and 9 months was $35,316,000 and $98,524,000, respectively, while third quarter and 9 months net income was $1,205,000, or 24 cents a share, and $2,968,000, or 59 cents a share, respectively.

title: Flagship Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
University Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest periods' earnings included pre-tax gains of $786,000 for the quarter and $3,763,000 for the 9 months, from the sale of mortgage servicing rights, compared with $1,545,000 and $3,422,000 for same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Congressional Panel Urges That Underground A-Tests Be Revealed
description: The Federal Government should abandon its policy of keeping some underground nuclear explosions secret, a Congressional report said yesterday, because the practice needlessly raises public fears over the extent of radiation leaks into the atmosphere.

title: Costa Rica Breaks the Mold
description: Costa Rica has announced what could be a dramatic breakthrough in stalled efforts to reduce the bank debt of third world countries. The plan could serve as a model for negotiations between creditor banks and other debtor nations.

title: Burt, a Former Giant, Is Signed to 49er Pact
description: The San Francisco 49ers signed Jim Burt, the former Giant nose tackle, yesterday to fill the void created when Michael Carter suffered a right foot injury in the 49ers' 23-10 victory over the Jets on Sunday.

title: Federal Panel Recommends Temporary Sites for A-Waste
description: Facing lengthy delays in establishing a permanent storage site for highly radioactive waste from the nation's nuclear power plants, a Government commission yesterday recommended setting up two small temporary locations.

title: Mud vs. Sludge in New Jersey
description: What do a poodle wearing sunglasses, the cast of ''The Wizard of Oz'' and convicted murderers have in common? They are all being used to attack candidates in what many are saying is New Jersey's slickest, and maybe nastiest, election for the State Assembly.

title: Amoco Penalty Recommended
description: The Amoco Corporation should pay about $100 million for damages incurred when its Amoco Cadiz tanker ran aground, spilling 68 million gallons of crude oil off the coast of France in 1978, the judge who presided over a lengthy trial has decided.

title: Bush Seeks An Edge on Gains Tax
description: Seeking to regain a tactical advantage in his fight for a cut in the capital gains tax, President Bush is seriously considering proposals to make permanent the $16 billion in automatic spending cuts that took effect on Oct. 16, Republican Congressional leaders said today.

title: Courter Suggests Loan Program To Aid Students
description: Declaring that every qualified high school graduate in New Jersey who wants to attend a state college or university should be able to do so, Representative Jim Courter said today that if elected governor he would establish a $120 million tuition-loan fund.

title: Avondale Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $622,000 and $2,543,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Calendar: Modernism Exhibition
description: 1860 to 1960, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street; 212-777-5218.

title: Stein Criticizes Schools On Purchases of Paint
description: The New York City Council President, Andrew Stein, said yesterday that the Board of Education wastes up to $10 million a year by providing the wrong paint to custodians who paint school buildings.

title: Horizon Fincl Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Healthsouth Rehabilitation reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Goodyear Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Despite New Twist, No Arrest in 6-Year-Old Murder on S.I.
description: As twilight faded, Stanley Gardiner - a man known for his modesty, quick smile and conviviality - was seen driving into his Staten Island garage.

title: Vincent Appoints Greenberg as Deputy Commissioner
description: Steve Greenberg, a player agent and the son of Hank Greenberg, was named deputy commissioner of baseball yesterday, effective Jan. 1.

title: Dollar and Deficits Walk the High Wire Together
description: To the Editor:

title: B&H Ocean Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects one-time fees of $2,788,395 relating to initial bridge loan financings. Year-ago 9-month figures are not available because the company began its operations upon completion of its initial public offering on Aug. 17, 1988; year-ago quarter share earnings was also not available.

title: The New Soviet Oppression: 15 Days in Jail
description: The human rights watch in the Soviet Union has switched from celebrated cases of oppressed individuals to a myriad of disorderly conduct arrests of ordinary people testing the limits on free speech and assembly.

title: Georgia Gulf Given NL Offer
description: The corporate investor Harold C. Simmons today renewed his quest to acquire the Georgia Gulf Corporation by making a conditional offer to buy the Atlanta-based chemicals company for $50 a share in cash, $5 less than what he proposed to pay two months ago.

title: Tests by Residents Turn Up Asbestos In Gramercy Park
description: Asbestos has been found on the outer walls and roof of a Gramercy Park building, a lawyer for the residents said yesterday, even though Consolidated Edison has completed its cleanup of the building's exterior.

title: People
description: * Diane G. Frank has been named marketing director, Paulette Keffas has been named advertising manager, and Sondra Gage has been named New York advertising manager of Child magazine.

title: Edo Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $5,016,000, or 79 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Brooklyn Youth Slain After Halloween Fight
description: A Brooklyn youth was fatally shot outside a Bensonhurst church just before midnight on Halloween, two hours after he was embroiled in a donnybrook that started when a group of teen-agers threw eggs at a passing limousine, the police said.

title: Safety Agency Seeks Record Fine Against USX for Job Violations
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration proposed a record $7.3 million fine against the USX Corporation today after concluding that the giant steel company had violated regulations on safety, health and record keeping.

title: Regulator Defends Role in Savings Unit Failure
description: M. Danny Wall, the nation's top savings and loan regulator, today defended his handling of the costliest savings and loan failure to date. He asserted that his office lacked sufficient proof in 1987 that the $6 billion Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., was insolvent.

title: In a Washington Show House, a Special Place for the Disabled
description: There's a surprise on page 78 of the guidebook to the Decorators' Show House sponsored by the Women's Committee for the National Symphony Orchestra.

title: Niagara Mohawk Power Corp reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Included a $77.9 million writeoff of disallowed Nine Mile Unit 2 costs, which is equivalent to 60 cents a share.

title: Israel to Stop Using Arab Reporter's List Of Contacts in Gaza
description: A military investigator was ordered today to stop using telephone numbers in a personal phone book confiscated from a Palestinian journalist to round up the reporter's professional contacts for interrogation.

title: Great-West Lifeco reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Teacher Is Arrested On Drug Charges
description: A Queens intermediate school teacher was arrested yesterday after the police assigned to the Commission on Integrity in the Public Schools saw her buying and using cocaine and found marijuana in her purse, a commission spokeswoman said.

title: Revised City Charter Will Save Money, and It's Constitutional
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in an Attack On 2 Officers Is Killed
description: A suspect in the shooting of two Newark police officers was shot dead in southern Alabama and his companion was in custody after his capture in a swamp, the authorities said today.

title: Slur Touches Off Storm in Houston Council Race
description: Less than a week before Election Day, a City Council member here is facing calls for his resignation because of a racial slur.

title: John Condon Didn't Miss A Syllable
description: In the moments before the Knicks open their Madison Square Garden season Saturday night, the memory of John F. X. Condon, the voice at the public-address microphone for more than 42 years, will be honored. When the Knicks take off their warm-up suits, their uniforms will display a black patch. And when the Knicks' fans bow their heads, they will remember how in all those years he never missed a syllable.

title: Coalition Opening Ad Drive to Stem Drug Abuse by Young Blacks
description: A nonprofit anti-drug coalition representing news organizations, business and advertising has opened a $90 million public service advertising campaign aimed for the first time at black youths and their parents.

title: Ethiopian Calls for Mobilization to Counter Threat
description: Ethiopia's President, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, facing a serious military threat to his already flagging army, has called for increased military readiness and a halt to all development projects in the country.

title: STUDY CITES LACK IN PRENATAL CARE
description: A newly released study of prenatal health care in the United States has found that from 1984 through 1986, 16 percent of American women who gave birth each year had inadequate prenatal care, either by starting care in the fifth month of pregnancy or later, or by making fewer than half the recommended number of visits to the doctor.

title: Saudi Diplomat Is Slain in Beirut; Pro-Iranians Take Responsibility
description: Gunmen killed a Saudi diplomat and wounded his driver today in Muslim West Beirut.

title: Tidewater Stake
description: The Hong Kong investment arm of New Zealand investor Sir Ronald Brierley has lowered its stake in Tidewater Inc. to 9.6 percent, from 11.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the concern, Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd., gave no reason for the sales. Industrial Equity had requested a seat on the board of Tidewater, a New Orleans-based compressor and marine equipment concern. Tidewater closed unchanged at $11 a share on the New York Stock Exchange today, giving the company a value of $246.4 million.

title: Maxus Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $70 million reflecting changes in accounting for income taxes.

title: U.S. Eases Threats of Sanctions
