description: Because South Korea, Taiwan and Saudi Arabia have started cracking down on pirated versions of American films, records, pharmaceuticals, software and other products, the United States eased a threat of trade sanctions against them. But Washington left five other countries on its priority watch list: Brazil, India, Mexico, China and Thailand.

title: James A. Attwood, 62, Ex-Insurance Executive
description: James A. Attwood, a former chairman and chief executive of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, died of acute anemia Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Close to Home
description: SEVERAL years ago a man was murdered out in Utah. His demise occasioned two books and from them two television dramas. It also sold a lot of paperbacks. I read both books, saw both television dramas and from this total immersion in his life and death retain only one thing. He loved meat loaf, ate it every day in fact. His chroniclers and his wife thought that very odd. I thought it very sensible. I can understand a person who doesn't want to stretch his palate. I can understand him because I live in a place where stretching the palate is what one does for exercise.

title: Valley Federal S&L Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an $89.9 million non-cash pretax charge which included a $62 million write-off of capitalized servicing at the association's mobile home financing subsidiary, All Valley Acceptance Co.; the addition of $18 million to real estate loan reserves; and the elimination of the association's $9.9 million of goodwill. The after-tax effect of these charges is $65.7 million. c-Net income

title: Court Backs the N.F.L. in Antitrust Challenge
description: The battle over free agency between the National Football League's players and its management remains a labor dispute and not an antitrust question, a Federal appeals court in St. Louis ruled yesterday.

title: Block Drug reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Azima Considers Braniff Purchase
description: Farhad Azima, founder of the defunct Global International Airways Corporation, said he was considering the possibility of buying Braniff Inc. Mr. Azima said that if he was successful, the airline could operate 60 to 80 flights a day from Kansas City, its main hub, to about 30 cities.

title: South Korea Surplus
description: The Bank of Korea said Monday that September's current account, which covers trade in goods and services, produced a surplus of $714 million, the biggest monthly surplus in 1989, after a shortfall of $79 million in August. The central bank said that according to provisional figures, exports grew 4.5 percent, to $44.5 billion, in the first nine months of this year from the corresponding 1988 period.

title: Samuel Weiss Is Dead; Investment Banker, 72
description: Samuel Weiss, an investment banker and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died of cardiac arrest at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Tuesday night after collapsing at the Metropolitan Opera House. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan and Warwick, N.Y.

title: Progress Reported in Opera Strike Talks
description: After intensive bargaining Monday through yesterday, the New York City Opera and its orchestra said yesterday afternoon that they had made substantial progress in settling the orchestra's six-week-old strike.

title: More Antitrust Challenges Are Expected Under Bush
description: The Bush Administration will be challenging many more large mergers and suing more companies for false advertising than the Reagan Administration did, Administration officials and antitrust experts are predicting.

title: Notes and Bonds Rise Modestly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved modestly higher in moderate trading yesterday, as signs of continued softness in the economy persuaded some market participants to buy securities.

title: East German Chief in Moscow
description: The new East German Communist leader, Egon Krenz, said in Moscow that the protests in his country were a healthy sign of change. Page A11.

title: Blair Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
President of Random House Out Abruptly After 23 Years
description: The book publishing industry was stunned yesterday by the news that the man who has headed Random House for 23 years would step down at the end of the year and that no successor had been chosen.

title: Berkley (W.R.) Corp(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter results included an investment loss of $23,000 and the 9 months included an investment gain of $303,000; the year-ago quarter and 9 months results included investment gains of $114,000 and $257,000, respectively. The company said losses from hurricane Hugo reduced net income by 10 cents a share. The net income for the third quarter included 18 cents a share in 1989 and 6 cents a share in 1988 from ''fresh start'' tax benefits.

title: Lincoln National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $61.7 million for the restructuring of certain health maintenance organizations. Lincoln National said its third quarter earnings included after-tax losses of $19 million from hurricane Hugo.

title: Warner Accord Seen Near
description: A settlement expected soon involving Sony, Guber Peters Entertainment and Time Warner could be worth $400 million, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: U.S. Regulation Urged for Money Exchanges
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said today that he was preparing legislation to regulate thousands of small businesses through which recent immigrants send money to relatives and also through which vast sums of illegal drug money are laundered.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters in Business Day on Tuesday about the merger of the North American printing businesses of Quebecor Inc. of Montreal and the Maxwell Communication Corporation misstated the terms of the deal. Quebecor will pay $500 million to Maxwell.

title: Two Champions' Main Challenge: Outrunning the Past
description: If winning is everything, as some say, everything sometimes includes a sense of burden. Gelindo Bordin of Italy noticed the phenomenon shortly after he won the Olympic marathon in Seoul, South Korea, last year. All of a sudden he began to wonder if his first name was not Gelindo, but Olympic Champion.

title: U.S. Wins Nations' Cup for 2d Year in a Row
description: The National Horse Show's most dramatic international competition, the Bank of Montreal Nations' Cup, was contested by teams from the United States, Canada, Britain and the Netherlands tonight, and for the second consecutive year, it was captured by the United States.

title: Bolar Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Western Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary loss of $2,121,345 from a penalty on early retirement of FHLB advances for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Stockholder Sues Unisys
description: A Unisys Corporation stockholder has filed a class-action lawsuit, accusing the company's board of using misleading and false information to persuade shareholders to vote in favor of a measure backed by the board in 1988. Henry L. Housman of the

title: Genus Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $83,000 for the quarter and $113,000 for the 9 months, and after extraordinary credits of $1,013,000, or 9 cents a share, and $2,234,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included a loss of $283,000 for the quarter and income of $144,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary credits of $555,000, or 8 cents a share, and $599,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Growth Still Modest, Fed Report Says
description: The nation's economic growth continued to vary from slow to moderate early this fall, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest economic survey, but it did not mention any inflationary problems.

title: 5th Accident in 4 Days Prompts Navy to Defend Its Safety Record
description: Hours after five sailors were injured in the Navy's fifth accident in four days, the service insisted in a statement today that the week's incidents were unrelated and that its safety record had improved throughout the 1980's Senator John W. Warner, a Virginia Republican who is a former Navy Secretary, said at a news conference today that he did not believe that the accidents were caused by a lack of training or money. He said he had been assured by senior Navy officials that the week's succession of accidents had ''no common thread.''

title: Broad Inquiry Is Started On Fujitsu
description: Fujitsu Ltd., the world's second-largest computer maker, has plunged into deeper trouble after disclosures that it had won at least four substantial Government computer contracts with bids ranging from three quarters of a cent to $71.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about payments made by a Lincoln Savings and Loan executive to himself and his family misstated the participation of Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. in meetings on proposed disciplinary actions against Lincoln. Senator Riegle attended the second of two meetings with the regulators; four other senators attended both meetings.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Requiem for a Landlady
description: The cab driver tried hard to find the Pulaski Bridge but we arrived at the funeral home in Brooklyn's Greenpoint section just as the priest ended his wake service for Grace Liotta.

title: Savin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results for latest quarter included a charge of $8.7 million for organization restructurings, a charge of $8.8 million related to changes in marketing and operational strategies and a charge of $6 million for adjustments related to a 1988 dealership acquisition. Latest-quarter results from operations included provisions totaling $8.2 million from asset valuation adjustments and losses on contract renewal delinquencies. These provisions are partially offset by a $2 million gain on sale of joint venture investments. Year-ago 9-month results included a gain of $24.4 million from extinguishment of debt.

title: Irvin Kovens, 71, Dies; Political Fund-Raiser
description: Irvin Kovens, a Baltimore businessman and political fund-raiser who was convicted of mail fraud and racketeering with former Gov. Marvin Mandel and four others in 1977, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at Sinai Hospital in Baltimore. He was 71 years old.

title: Backer Adds Depth With New Official
description: BY naming Alvin A. Achenbaum, a marketing-services specialist and occasionally acerbic critic of agencies, as its vice chairman for professional services, Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide is positioning itself to capture more of the marketing-service business that is beginning to outshine advertising growth.

title: New England Electric Drops Bid for Utility
description: Outbid by two rivals, the New England Electric System formally withdrew its $2 billion bid yesterday for the assets of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which is under bankruptcy protection.

title: Bhutto Survives as No-Confidence Vote Falls Short
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's governing coalition staved off defeat today when a no-confidence motion failed by a 12-vote margin, ending a challenge that had threatened to unseat Pakistan's first fully civilian Government in more than a decade.

title: Judge and Legislator Are Slain in Colombia
description: Gunmen killed a Colombian federal judge in the city of Medellin and a member of Congress here in the capital tonight in the latest wave of violence to strike Colombia since the Government declared war on drug traffickers.

title: Review/Television; A&E's Bow To Theater: A Series Of One-Acts
description: Tonight at 9 o'clock, cable's Arts & Entertainment Network begins making a monthly bow in the direction of live theater and, while modest, the effort is admirable. ''American Playwrights Theater: The One-Acts'' is getting under way with ''Third and Oak: The Pool Hall,'' written by Marsha Norman ('' 'Night, Mother''). The stars are James Earl Jones and Mario Van Peebles. The series, whose host is Anthony Quinn, is a General Motors Mark of Excellence presentation, which deserves note because each play will be interrupted only once for commercials.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: DAYS or even hours after their children are born, parents reach conclusions about their temperaments. They may describe their babies as fussy or easygoing, sensitive or curious.

title: WARNING ON BOMB HINTED BY PAN AM
description: Pan Am has raised the possibility in court documents that the United States was tipped off in advance by Israeli intelligence about the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. Administration officials categorically denied the assertion today.

title: Acme Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,010,000, or $2.47 a share.

title: Fall in Nation's Manufacturing Slows in October
description: The manufacturing sector of the nation's economy continued to decline for the sixth consecutive month in October, but at a lesser rate, according to an index published yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Rockwell International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $104 million, or 40 cents a share, from the sale of the company's measurement and flow control division. c-Included 18 cents a share from a one-time favorable tax adjustment and 14 cents a share from higher B-1B program earnings for the quarter; the year included a favorable tax adjustment of $198 million, or 74 cents a share. The company said that the year-ago quarter results benefited from earnings of divested businesses, including a gain from the sale of the company's industrial sewing machine business.

title: Grumman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of about $1.6 million, or 5 cents a share, from a tax rate adjustment. c-Included $4.5 million for the expected recovery of product improvement costs on several F-14 contracts reported in the second quarter. d-Included an after-tax benefit of $11.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment, for the quarter and 9 months. Grumman said its 1989 earnings included a $4 million charge in the third quarter and a $7.5 million charge in the 9 months for the closing of its Tachonics subsidiary.

title: Campbell Soup Chief to Retire Early
description: The chief executive of the Campbell Soup Company said yesterday that he would take early retirement. His responsibilities were quickly divided between two top executives of the company, and its stock jumped on the news.

title: Prosperity Seen After Pain of Quake
description: These days, getting a table at the Washington Square Bar and Grill is easy. Ed Moose, the owner, says business at his usually bustling North Beach establishment is off at least 20 percent since the Oct. 17 earthquake.

title: Americans Again Defying S. Africa Ban
description: For the second time in a year, a group of American athletes has defied a boycott of South Africa by returning to the country for a series of track meets.

title: Big Board Chief Backs Increasing S.E.C. Role
description: John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, gave conditional support today to a proposal to give the Securities and Exchange Commission the power to suspend program trading in the stock and options markets if the market drops by a certain amount.

title: Breeders' Card Grows Tougher As 2 Favorites Draw the Rail
description: A tough card of Breeders' Cup races got tougher today when the two heaviest favorites for the seven championship races Saturday both drew the tricky inside post.

title: Oil Stockpile Discussions
description: A team of experts from the United States will tour the Persian Gulf next week to discuss how the big oil states in the region could contribute to the United States Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Moore Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Report Clears Judge Of Bias in Remarks About Homosexuals
description: A Dallas judge who said he gave a lighter sentence to a convicted murderer because the victims were homosexuals has been cleared of bias charges.

title: Bell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hudson Bay Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is wholly owned by Inspiration Resources Corp. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Currents; At a San Antonio Theater, The Forecast Is Cloudy
description: WHEN it opened its doors 60 years ago, the Majestic Theater in San Antonio was one of the theater architect John Eberson's most enthralling picture palaces. Built in Moorish and Spanish Revival style, the theater epitomized Hollywood magic, with small twinkling bulbs for stars, lights that simulated sunrise and sunset, and a machine that wafted clouds across a Mediterranean-blue ceiling.

title: Domino's to Trim Jobs and Benefits
description: Domino's Pizza Inc. said it would trim jobs and reduce health benefits in a cost-cutting effort that was accelerated when its founder, Tom Monaghan, said recently that he might sell the pizza delivery company. The company will lay off nearly 100 employees at its Ann Arbor headquarters and 13 offices throughout the country, a spokesman, Ron Hingst, said. Costs of health-care benefits, now paid by the company, will be shared by employees, said Mr. Hingst, who added that he did not know how much the employees would have to pay.

title: Premature on Sludge
description: To the Editor:

title: Bogota Reporters Reveal Fears at Frontline of the Drug War
description: In tones ranging from anguish to helpless rage, five Colombian journalists told yesterday of how the threat of death by drug traffickers has transformed their lives as professionals, often forcing them to betray their most fundamental instincts as reporters and editors.

title: 4 Vandals Ordered To Judaism Classes
description: Four youths who admitted spraying swastikas and anti-Semitic slurs on a rabbi's house and other buildings owned by Jews must take lessons in Jewish culture and perform 50 hours of community service as punishment, a judge ruled on Tueday.

title: Nine Players Are Fined
description: Three days before the start of season, Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president of operations, handed out $11,500 in fines yesterday for fights in two exhibition games.

title: Crossland Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the losses in the latest periods were primarily the result of the writedown of about $143.6 million in goodwill related to its acquisitions of Crossland Savings FSB of Salt Lake City, Utah; Crossland Mortgage Corp., and Specialized Management Support Inc.

title: Yale Advocates Of Gay Rights Protest Arrests
description: About 100 advocates for gay and lesbian rights, shouting slogans and waving pink- and lavender-lettered signs, rallied outside the office of Yale University's president today to protest the arrest of nine men last week in a confrontation with campus and city police officers over a sexually explicit poster.

title: Soft Tech: The Feel of Things to Come
description: BEFORE he was asked to design one, Christopher Alviar, a 27-year-old industrial designer in Beaverton, Ore., had not paid much attention to squeegees. To him, a bathroom squeegee was akin to a toilet-bowl plunger, ''something that you wanted to keep out of sight,'' he said.

title: Currents; Subtlety That Sells
description: FOR those to whom package design means a visual assault at the supermarket, the work of the Japanese graphic designer Shin Matsunaga will probably be a revelation.

title: Why I Ended The Cease-Fire
description: On Feb. 25, 1990, Nicaragua will celebrate free, fair and democratic elections. The president, vice president and legislature elected then will take office, with full constitutional powers, on April 25, 1990.

title: Hostetler Is Confident Filling In for Injured Simms
description: Phil Simms, the Giants' injured quarterback, continued to show progress with his sprained right ankle today, but he did not take part in practice. So for the first time this season, Jeff Hostetler, a career backup, took all the snaps with the first-team offense.

title: Ralston Purina Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $71.3 million, or $1.12 a share, which included an after- tax gain of $70.2 million, or $1.10 a share, on the sale of Van Camp seafood division. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5.5 million, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $24.4 million, or 35 cents a share, for the year. Both latest periods' results included a pre-tax charge of $31.4 million for the restructuring of certain manufacturing and administrative operations.

title: Coal Miners in the Ukraine Defy Official Ban on Strikes
description: Thousands of coal miners in the Ukraine defied an official ban and staged warning strikes today in the Soviet Union's largest coal field. Unrest also spread in the Siberian mines.

title: 75 Flights Added By Eastern Air
description: Eastern Airlines added 75 flights, increasing its schedule to 775 daily. The company resumed service to five Caribbean destinations and added nonstop flights from Miami to Los Angeles, San Francisco, Toronto, Chicago, Newark and other cities. Eastern added 29 daily departures from its Miami hub, giving it 65 flights from there.

title: Montana Power reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lauren, de la Renta and Roehm Show Fresh Looks for Spring
description: THREE distinguished collections introduced yesterday raised the ratings of the New York spring fashion openings and helped put into focus the special vision of American designers.

title: President of Mexico Awaits Action on Debt
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said today that Mexico is still waiting for most of its commercial bank creditors to decide how they plan to carry out July's historic debt reduction agreement, and he also expressed concern that the Mexican economy may be overheating.

title: First World Cheese reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: General Re Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $36.5 million from discontinued operations. The latest third quarter included ''fresh start'' tax benefits from the Tax Reform Act of 1986 equaled to 8 cents a share, compared with 2 cents a share, for year-ago period.

title: Continued Growth Is Seen
description: The economy, which is about to enter its eighth year of expansion, is likely to continue growing at least until 1991, a poll of leading business executives has found.

title: Nureyev and Head Of Paris Opera Hold A Peace Conference
description: ''It is easier to speak to God,'' Rudolf Nureyev recently said of Pierre Berge, the president of the Paris Opera, with whom he has been feuding over his role as director of the Paris Opera Ballet. Mr. Berge, for his part, has suggested publicly that it is difficult to speak with a ballet director who is so rarely in Paris.

title: For One Collector, Decorating Comes as Naturally as the
description: DECORATING and collecting often go hand in hand. Sometimes, though, more so than others.

title: Panic Can Be Suicide Omen
description: People who suffer recurring panic attacks are 18 times as likely as people with no mental disorders to try to kill themselves, researchers have found.

title: Orders to U.S. Factories Hold Steady
description: Orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods remained steady in September, but would have fallen had it not been for the second-largest increase in military orders in history.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Matagorda County Navigation District One of Texas is offering $70.3 million in 30-year collateralized pollution-control revenue bonds for a Houston Lighting and Power Company project through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: About New York; Borough Leaders And the Charter: A Winding Road
description: Since the changes in New York City's government proposed by the Charter Revision Commission represent the most fundamental shift in more than 90 years, it is not surprising that the plan has set off howls of protest from the southern tip of Staten Island to the northern reaches of the Bronx.

title: Transamerica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Restated to reflect accounting adjustments of $9,527,000, or 13 cents a share, in accordance with new requirements for accounting for income taxes, certain life insurance contracts and investment transactions. c-Included charge of $36,869,000 to reflect change in accounting for income taxes. Also, figures were restated in accordance with new requirements for accounting for income taxes, certain life insurance contracts and investment transactions. Third-quarter results included after-tax capital gains from sales of securities of $10.2 million in 1989 and $6.4 million in 1988. For the 9 months, the company reported after-tax capital gains from the sales of securities of $40.2 million in 1989 and $9.3 million in 1988. Third-quarter results included the first full quarter of earnings from its investment management subsidiary, Transamerica Criterion Group, which was acquired in June. The company said its property and casualty insurance operations reported about $6 million in after-tax losses from Hurricane Hugo. It said it expected that losses from the San Francisco Bay area earthquake will not exceed $6 million after taxes.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Babi Yar' Symphony in Its Directness and Simplicity
description: Shostakovich's Symphony No. 13 (''Babi Yar'') is 17 years old, but it seems as fresh as today's front page. The five-section work, less a symphony than a dramatic cantata or oratorio, foreshadowed with uncanny accuracy the changes that were about to shake Soviet society. Listening to the Philadelphia Orchestra's performance at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, one was struck anew by the prophetic directness of the Yevgeny Yevtushenko texts and the bardic simplicity of the music that Shostakovich devised to illustrate them.

title: New Delhi Weapons Scandal: Who Knew What, and When?
description: As he steps up his campaign for re-election in balloting this month, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is being jolted by charges that he was personally involved in an effort to cover up bribes paid to obtain a $1.4 billion howitzer gun contract between the Indian Defense Ministry and a Swedish company.

title: Review/Music; Howard Shelley, a Pianist
description: Howard Shelley, a pianist with what appears to be a substantial career in Britain, played his first New York recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Shelley brought little in the way of repertory that would provoke much imagination or curiosity; rather he seemed content to use familiar pieces as a way of measuring his talents.

title: In Plastic, A Model Colonial
description: From the Jacuzzi bubbling in the bedroom to the boot dryer whirring in the mud room, the house of the future may be molded from high-performance plastics that are literally a snap to put together. That was the message last week when G.E. Plastics executives unveiled their Living Environments Concept House at the division's headquarters here.

title: Money Fund Yields Down
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday, but not as much as those on certificates of deposit.

title: 3 Shows And a Talk On Crafts
description: There will be crafts events this weekend from Philadelphia to Orange County, N.Y., some with a specific focus and some including many styles with works by artisans and crafts workers from all over the United States. Here are a few of the events.

title: Ms. Radomsky, News Aide, Weds
description: Rosalie R. Radomsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Radomsky of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Marco K. McCormick, a son of Prof. Diana Festa Peyre of Westport, Conn., and Prof. E. Allen McCormick of South Egremont, Mass. Probate Judge Earl F. Capuano officiated at the Westport Town Hall.

title: Undercover Police Officer Kills Queens Drug Suspect
description: A 62-year-old Queens man was shot and killed by an undercover police officer last night during a buy-and-bust operation in Queens Village, the police said.

title: Fire Chief Under Investigation
description: A team of state and Federal officials has been assembled to investigate allegations that St. Paul's longtime fire chief has ties to arson and insurance fraud.

title: United Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Six Troopers Indicted In Turnpike Beating
description: Six state troopers have been indicted on charges of official misconduct and other crimes in the beating of a motorist on the New Jersey Turnpike in September 1988, Attorney General Peter N. Perretti Jr. said in a statement on Tuesday.

title: Giving War a Chance
description: For accommodationists, this week was the best of times and the worst of times.

title: Cherry Very Critical About Soviet Players
description: Don Cherry, the former coach of the Boston Bruins and the Colorado Rockies, is an opinionated and influential commentator for Canadian television's ''Hockey Night in Canada.'' In some respects, he is to hockey in that country what Howard Cosell was to football in the United States.

title: Q&A
description: Moldy Shingles Q. The peaked roof of my country house is covered with asphalt shingles that have a sand finish. On the shady side a gray-green mold or fungus is growing on the shingles. I sprayed it with a fungicide that I use on my roses, but it did not seem to help. Can this moss damage the roof, and how can I get rid of it? A. Aside from being unsightly, if the moss is allowed to accumulate it will hold moisture, which can seep into the structure under the shingles; this could be destructive in time. To remove it use a stronger fungicide, like the kind used around swimming pools.

title: Exabyte Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $1,250,000 from tax carryforwards. c-Included an extraordinary gain of $68,000 from utilization of income tax carryforwards for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Retiring SUNY Board Chief Sees a Need for 'New Money'
description: Donald M. Blinken sees a tough choice ahead for the State University of New York, as he steps down after 11 years as chairman of the Board of Trustees.

title: Currents; A Museum For Lovers Of Modern Furniture
description: QUIETLY and without fanfare, the Swiss-born Rolf Fehlbaum, director of the Vitra furniture company in Basel, has spent six years amassing one of the premier collections of modern furniture in the world. With Alexander von Vegesack (who sold large parts of his collection to Mr. Fehlbaum) as curator, the Vitra Design Foundation has acquired some 250 pieces from the estate of the late Charles Eames, the personal library of George Nelson and the private collection of the Danish designer Verner Panton, to name a few.

title: Reviews/Music; Frankfurt Orchestra, Led by Eliahu Inbal
description: In his 15 years as music director of the Frankfurt Radio Symphony Orchestra, the Israeli conductor Eliahu Inbal has made an extensive series of recordings that have brought his ensemble some international attention. Last season, Mr. Inbal resigned his post with the idea of becoming a freelance guest conductor. But because the orchestra has not yet found his successor, he agreed to lead the Frankfurt players for one more season.

title: Arx Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Is Investigating Reports That Crib Monitors Failed
description: Federal officials are investigating the manufacturer of a monitor intended to prevent crib deaths. They are apparently trying to determine whether the company disclosed all fatalities that may be linked to the device.

title: Citing Abortion, U.S. Extends Ban On Grants for Fetal Tissue Work
description: The Bush Administration today extended a 20-month-old ban on Federal financing of research using transplanted fetal tissue, overriding recommendations by medical panels that such work go ahead because of its promise for treating diabetes and other diseases.

title: TNP Enterprises Inc reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
American Steel & Wire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Relocation Plan By Comprehensive
description: The Comprehensive Care Corporation said it planned to sell nine small California hospitals and move its headquarters from Irvine, Calif., to St. Louis. Last week, the company reported a $4.7 million loss and said its deal to be acquired by the First Hospital Corporation, Norfolk, Va., had collapsed.

title: Aritech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $4 million on the sale of the company's North American distribution division, which increased net income by $2.3 million for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article yesterday about the appointment of Sharon Percy Rockefeller as president and chief executive of WETA in Washington misstated the timing in some copies. She was appointed on Monday, not yesterday. Another brief report on the appointment, inadvertently published elsewhere in the paper, identified WETA incorrectly; it is a public television and radio station, not just television.

title: Olsten Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split declared Aug. 2, 1989.

title: Coors (Adolph) Co(O) reports earnings for 16wks to Oct 1
Schools See Empty Desks On Halloween
description: Tens of thousands of students stayed away from New York City's high schools on Halloween, fearing the sprees of terror and violence that occurred after school, officials said yesterday.

title: Computer-Trading Outcry Forcing Changes
description: The outcry on Wall Street and Main Street over computerized stock trading, often blamed for accelerating the market crash of October 1987 and the recent share-price gyrations, has become so great that new market rules are being adopted and others appear imminent. The rule changes come as even investment houses that once championed the practice are abandoning the business in droves.

title: Dominion Textile reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Parolee Convicted of Killing Pratt Student in a Robbery
description: A Brooklyn man was convicted yesterday of killing a Pratt Institute art student last year in a street robbery near the school's campus a week after she moved to New York City from Little Rock, Ark.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Media Business pages on Friday about The New York Post's decision to drop its Sunday paper referred incorrectly to the resignation of Peter O. Price, who had been publisher. His departure was not linked to problems with the Sunday paper and he was not removed from the job; he resigned in April to help start The National, a daily sports newspaper that is to begin publication soon. At the time, The Post had published only four Sunday issues.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in late editions on Saturday (reprinted in some copies on Sunday about a Vermont farm where marijuana was found growing last year misstated the number of plants involved. The state police found 12 plants, not 200, on the farm, owned by Robert Machin and Joann Liddell.

title: Polonia Released Early
description: After having served 27 of the 60 days he was sentenced to for having had sexual relations with a 15-year-old girl, Luis Polonia of the Yankees was released yesterday from the Community Correctional Center in Milwaukee. Circuit Judge Thomas Doherty denied a motion to modify Polonia's sentence to the time served, but said he would stay the balance of the sentence.

title: Senate Opens Trial of Another U.S. Judge
description: Twelve days after it removed one Federal judge from the bench, the Senate today began floor action in the impeachment trial of another.

title: Sombrero Chic and Witty Minimalism
description: GORDON HENDERSON, a skin diver for fashion pearls, headed down Mexico way for his spring 1990 collection.

title: Shearson Ends Index Trade
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., a unit of the American Express Company, has become the latest Wall Street firm to discontinue index arbitrage.

title: Brazil Inflation Rises
description: Brazil's inflation rate for October rose to 37.6 percent, the second-highest monthly rate on record, the Government statistics office said this week. The increase follows September's rate of 36 percent and was exceeded only by the 70.3 percent figure for January. An official of the Government statistics office said consumer prices had risen 1,303.8 percent in the last 12 months.

title: Novelty Fades For Vodka Ad
description: With great fanfare, Absolut Vodka has introduced its annual Christmas print advertisement, which it bills as the world's first talking ad for a consumer product.

title: Mace Is Used to End Protest by Inmates
description: Jail officials sprayed Mace on seven inmates yesterday at the Bronx House of Detention to put down a protest in the maximum-security area, a spokeswoman said.

title: Ted Dalton, 88, Dies; Retired Federal Judge
description: Theodore Roosevelt Dalton, a retired Federal judge who in the 1950's paved the way for the emergence of the Republican Party as a force in Virginia politics, died of complications of pneumonia Monday at Radford (Va.) Community Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Radford.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALUMINUM combination storm windows, consisting of upper and lower glass panes and a screen, are ordinary features on many homes. Installation is usually not too difficult. To find the size you need, measure the length and width of the window frame on the outside. If the window has blind stops - strips of molding around the perimeter that hold the upper sash in place - select storm windows that can be set into the opening and fastened to the stops. If not, select windows that overlap the outside window trim.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Basic Crookedness of Docudramas
description: Let me make one thing perfectly clear: the only good docudrama is an unproduced docudrama - even if it's about Richard M. Nixon. ABC's three-hour version of ''The Final Days,'' based on Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein's version of the collapse of the Nixon Administration, is but the latest appearance of a form that seems designed to do to television journalism what Hurricane Hugo did to South Carolina. There is no insurance against these ungodly acts. The viewer is on his own, left to figure out whether what he is watching is a reasonably accurate account of an important hour in the nation's history or just a show.

title: Waxman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest-quarter sales included operations of Ideal Plumbing Group Inc., acquired in May 1989.

title: Joseph Charla Jr., 65, Savings Bank Official
description: Joseph Charla Jr., executive vice president of the East River Savings Bank, a division of River Bank America of New Rochelle, N.Y., died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: JET's FLAW TRACED TO TIME OF A CHECK
description: A crack in an engine disk that broke apart, apparently causing the fatal crash of a United Airlines jetliner in July, probably existed in February 1988 when mechanics conducted the last full inspection, an expert witness testified today.

title: Dinkins and Giuliani Agree to a TV Debate
description: The New York City mayoral campaign took another bitter turn yesterday. David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed to two televised debates, but Mr. Dinkins said last night that he might not take part in one after he was shown the text of a commercial released by the Giuliani campaign. Mr. Dinkins described the advertisement as scurrilous. ''I am not obliged to present myself for this scurrilous attack as opposed to a discussion of the issues,'' he said.

title: 'Traviata' Interrupted By Heart Attack
description: A man attending ''La Traviata'' at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night had a heart attack during the second act and died later at Roosevelt Hospital. Richard Woitach, the conductor, halted the performance, and the house lights came up to allow doctors in the audience to administer cardiopulmonary resuscitation for about 20 minutes until an ambulance arrived.

title: Notebook; St. John's Hoping for Playoff Spot
description: While bowl-game speculation has begun at the major college level, playoff talk is also rife at the small college level. Does St. John's, with an 8-0 record for the first time in its football history, stand a chance? What about Montclair State (6-1-1) and Trenton State (7-0-1)?

title: Ortega Ends Truce With Rebels, But Calls for New Peace Talks
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today ended a 19-month cease-fire with United States-backed rebels. But he left open the possibility of restoring the truce through new negotiations on demobilizing the rebel army.

title: BNH Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9-month results included charges of about $300,000 relating to the merger of its Bank of New Haven subsidiary with New Haven Merchants Bank.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe Advances: Third-seeded John McEnroe struggled to a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Jonas Svensson of Sweden in the opening round of the Paris Open yesterday. In second-round matches, Michael Chang routed Henri Leconte of France, 6-3, 6-2; Aaron Krickstein beat Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4, and second-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden edged Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-4. Mats Wilander was eliminated by Alberto Mancini of Argentina, 7-6, 6-4, in a first-round match. (AP) Pfaff Upsets Zvereva: Unseeded Eva Pfaff of West Germany upset fourth-seeded Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, 5-7, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the Virginia Slims of New England tournament in Worcester, Mass.(AP)

title: Oilers Tie Devils, 6-6
description: Mark Messier scored with 6 minutes 19 seconds left in the third period tonight to give the Edmonton Oilers a 6-6 tie with the Devils.

title: Baton Broadcasting reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $798,000 and $1,556,000 for the latest year and year- ago period, respectively, and an extraordinary special gain from company's sale of Graphic Products Group of $2,475,000, or 9 cents a share, for the latest year and an extraordinary charge of $985,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Campaign Profile; Dinkins: Tenacity in a Deliberate Style
description: His opponents say David N. Dinkins plays a steady game of tennis. They say he never loses his temper, allowing himself at most an ''Oh, David'' when he double-faults or misses a return. But mostly they remark on his reliable forehand and his punctilious observance of the courtesies of the game.

title: GAIN IS REPORTED IN CONDUCTIVITY
description: Scientists have overcome an important obstacle in their efforts to develop wires capable of carrying large electrical currents without resistance at relatively high temperatures.

title: A.L. Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Milan Huebl, 62, Head Of '68 Prague College
description: Milan Huebl, who headed Czechoslovakia's Communist Party Academy in the 1968 reform period known as the Prague Spring and who later joined the independent human rights group Charter 77, was found dead in a Prague building on Saturday. He was 62 years old. The cause of his death was unknown. Mr. Huebl was a major ideologist behind the liberalization started by the Czechoslovak leader, Alexander Dubcek, before the Prague Spring was crushed by a Soviet-led invasion. He was director of the Communist Party Academy, in effect a Communist political college, in that period of a few months.

title: Asylum for Vietnamese Refugee
description: A Vietnamese man who escaped his homeland by riding for two days on the rudder housing of a Cypriot tanker that docked here Monday has been granted temporary asylum in the United States.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: While adults usually see themselves as teachers of children, when it comes to living with serious illness, children may have a thing or two to teach adults.

title: Public Service Co. of New Hampshire reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Latest 9-month results included charges of $66,775,000 related to the Seabrook Nuclear Plant.

title: Construction Spending Unchanged in September
description: Construction spending was unchanged in September after surging in August, reflecting continued weakness in that segment of the economy.

title: Gaylord Container reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Coast Savings Financial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Coast Savings attributed the third quarter loss primarily to one-time charges associated with its restructuring. During the quarter, the company charged $46 million against earnings to reduce goodwill and charged $5.7 million against earnings for debt conversion. The company also cited increased additions to its general loan loss reserve and establishment of a $30 million lower cost or market valuation reserve for its high yield bond portfolio as factors contributing to third quarter losses.

title: Top Yield of 7.45% In California Issue
description: The Santa Ana Community Redevelopment Agency, California, is offering $107.03 million in tax allocation bonds with a maximum yield of 7.458 percent for an issue due 2019 through underwriters led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: Customedix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vandeweghe Disabled
description: The Knicks are expected to reach the 12-player roster limit today by placing Kiki Vandeweghe on the injured reserve list. The move, when it is officially made, would idle Vandeweghe for a minimum of five games, until at least the Nov. 14 game against the Trail Blazers in Portland, Ore.

title: Landmark Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Estonian Test
description: ''Polls show it,'' Marju Lauristin said. ''It's the will of the Estonian people to be an independent country.'' Then she laughed and added, ''Now the only problem is how to fulfill this will.''

title: KEY RATES
American Integrity reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net realized investment gains of $454,000, or 6 cents a share, for both quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss and included an extraordinary credit of $148,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $1,480,000 for the 9 months, both extraordinary items relates to the settlement of a class action suit.

title: Advanced Telecommunicaions Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $660,000, or 4 cents a share, from net operating loss carryforwards.

title: The 2 Ships of Statecraft Will Meet Off Malta
description: The White House said today that next month's shipboard meetings between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union would be held off the coast of Malta in the Mediterranean, and that the theme would be minimalism.

title: New Oil Wells Are Down 29%
description: Oil-well completions fell by 3,100, or 29 percent, in the first three quarters of this year compared with the same period last year, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Market Place; Overstated Value In 'Junk' Funds
description: AFTER the commotion in the ''junk bond'' market in recent weeks, the value of bonds in many high-yield mutual funds is overstated because of the way the funds price these issues.

title: USF&G reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit representing utilization of tax credit of $10,500,000, or 13 cents a share, and $15,300,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income

title: Seoul and Warsaw Establish Full Relations
description: South Korea and Poland established full diplomatic relations today, the Foreign Ministry announced.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it is unfair, without knowing the substance of my work, to say that I am a hard-liner. I am a Communist, and a Communist works so that things in our country move forward. That means change.'' - Egon Krenz, the East German Communist leader. [ A11:6. ]

title: U.S. Dismay Remains a Fact, Nixon Tells China
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon today gave Chinese leaders one of the toughest assessments of their crackdown that they have heard from any visitor, but he coupled it with a plea for a move toward rebuilding Chinese-American relations.

title: National Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $3.4 million for the quarter and $15 million for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax benefits from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $5.6 million and $13.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. National Steel is a joint venture owned by National Intergroup Inc. and NKK Corp. of Japan.

title: Handling Gorbachev: A Debate Among Skeptics
description: President Bush's announcement on Tuesday that since July he has secretly been planning a summit conference with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev raises a question: If the President was working on such a high-profile get-together with Mr. Gorbachev for all these months, why were senior officials in his Administration speaking in so many contradictory voices about the dangers of doing business with the Soviet leader?

title: At Bloomingdale's, Even the Props Sell
description: Some years it's India or China. This year it happens to be France.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brendle's Inc., Elkin, N.C., a discount retail chain, named Jim Eversole executive vice president of marketing.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES The book publishing industry was stunned by the news that the man who for 23 years has headed Random House, the nation's largest publisher of general-interest books, would step down at the end of the year. Robert L. Bernstein described his departure as a resignation; S. I. Newhouse Jr., whose family owns Random House, said Mr. Bernstein had retired. [ Page A1. ] Sudden change in a Newhouse-owned property has become predictable. [ D20. ] Campbell Soup's chief executive will take early retirement. His responsibilities were quickly divided between two executives. [ D1. ] The Los Angeles Herald Examiner will cease publication today, Hearst said, leaving the nation's No. 2 city with just one metropolitan paper. [ D21. ] A pending settlement involving Sony, Guber Peters Entertainment and Time Warner could be worth $400 million. [ D20. ] New England Electric formally withdrew its $2 billion bid for the assets of Public Service of New Hampshire. [ D5. ] Harold C. Simmons renewed his quest for Georgia Gulf, making a conditional offer for the chemicals company. [ D5. ] A $7.3 million fine against USX has been proposed by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. [ A18. ] THE ECONOMY M. Danny Wall defended his handling of what could be the costliest savings and loan failure on record. [ A1. ] President Bush is considering making permanent the $16 billion in spending cuts that took effect on Oct. 16. [ D1. ] The Bush Administration is expected to challenge more large mergers than the Reagan Administration did. [ D1. ] The manufacturing sector declined for the sixth consecutive month, but at a lesser rate. [ D8. ] Orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods remained steady in September. [ D9. ] Construction spending was unchanged in September. [ D9. ] The nation's economic growth continued to vary from slow to moderate early this fall, the Federal Reserve said. [ D8. ] INTERNATIONAL

title: Jets Claim An Unwilling Eason Off Waivers
description: The Jets made one of their boldest player moves in recent history today by claiming the quarterback Tony Eason off waivers, only to find that Eason does not want to join the Jets because the team's quarterback is his best friend, Ken O'Brien.

title: Dinkins and Giuliani Agree to Debate
description: David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani finally agreed yesterday to two televised debates in the last days of their eight-week mayoral campaign. But within hours Mr. Dinkins said he might not attend one of the debates because of a new Giuliani television commercial that Mr. Dinkins described last night as ''scurrilous.''

title: Tokyo Journal; Prime Minister's House: A Most Unstately Home
description: The first crisis to face the new Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu last summer started in the hallway around the corner from his office here, in an aging, squat building near Parliament that one would pass by without noticing if it was not surrounded by guards.

title: SSMC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,100,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $1,000,000, or 15 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: Piniella Talks Money
description: Lou Piniella says he wants to be paid as much to manage the Cincinnati Reds as he gets for not managing the Yankees.

title: International Telecharge Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The 9-month loss included a $1.2 million writedown of inventory, a $2.8 million writedown of receivables and a larger-than-expected operating loss in the second quarter.

title: First Constitution Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $730,000, or 7 cents a share, from the cumulative of a change in accounting. c-Net income

title: U.S.-Japan Discussion
description: Senior officials of the United States Treasury Department and Japan's Finance Ministry will meet next Wednesday in Washington to discuss broad financial market issues, a ministry official said today. The meeting will be the first of the newly established United States-Japan working group on financial markets, an extension of previous talks on the yen-dollar exchange rate, he said. David Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury, and Vice Finance Minister Makoto Utsumi will lead the meeting.

title: A Surgeon General Nominee; Antonia Coello Novello
description: Dr. Antonia Novello, who was formally chosen today by President Bush to be Surgeon General of the United States, is a pediatrician who combines compassion and humor as an advocate of children's issues.

title: Dollar and Deficits Walk the High Wire Together; Piper Must Be Paid
description: To the Editor:

title: Belding Heminway Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,933,000, or 95 cents a share, on the sale of cellular investments for both the quarter and 9 months, and losses from its equity in real estate partnerships of $554,000 and $2,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included income of $340,000, or 17 cents a share for the quarter and $567,000, or 27 cents a share for the 9 months, both from its equity in real estate partnerships, and the 9 months also included a gain of $43,000, or 2 cents a share, on the sale of cellular investments.

title: C.I.A. Would Have Appalled George Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15 A rush of hundreds of East Germans to the West German Embassy in Prague occurred hours after East Germany lifted a travel ban. Many more were reported to have crossed into Czechoslovakia. Page A1 East Germany's Communist leader, Egon Krenz, described the mass protests in his country as a healthy sign of change. He spoke at a press conference in Moscow after a meeting with President Gorbachev. A11 News analysis: Policy differences have produced many conflicting pronouncements about the Soviet Union, reflecting in part a White House that is trying to appease Democrats and Republicans. A10 The two ships of statecraft will meet off Malta A10 The new Soviet oppression: 15 days in jail A12 Nicaragua ended a cease-fire but President Ortega left open the possibility of restoring the truce between his Government and the United States-backed rebels through new talks. A1 Anger with Ortega unites U.S. policy makers A12 Mexico President awaits action on debt D1 A mobilization of Ethiopia's forces, along with a halt of all development projects, was called for by the country's President, whose army is facing a serious military threat from rebel groups. A3 South Africa alerted its forces after intercepting messages by U.N. monitors in Namibia saying that up to 600 rebels had infiltrated from Angola, its Foreign Minister said. A3 A Saudi diplomat was shot to death in Muslim West Beirut. A shadowy pro-Iranian group took responsibility, saying the killing was in retaliation for the execution of 16 Kuwaiti Shiite Muslims by Saudi Arabia. A8 Warning on bomb hinted by Pan Am A9 Pakistan's government survived by staving off defeat on a no-confidence motion by a 12-vote margin. A15 Weapons scandal jolts Gandhi A14 U.S. dismay is a fact, Nixon tells China A13 U.S. eases threats on country's pirating products D1 National A18-26, B14-19 A ban on aid to fetal tissue research will continue, the Bush Administration said, despite medical panels' recommendations that such research has promise for treating diabetes and other diseases. A1 The nation's top savings regulator defended his handling of what could be the costliest savings and loan failure on record, saying his office lacked sufficient proof that Lincoln Savings was insolvent in 1987. A1 More antitrust challenges are expected under Bush D1 The head of Random House resigned. Robert Bernstein, will leave his position at the end of the year, S.I. Newhouse, the company's owner, announced. Analysts say such a move could have a monumental effect on electoral politics. But presently, certain businesses are suffering severely. He has a calm and deliberative manner, and his cultural preferences have included Frank Sinatra and ''MASH.''
