Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828.

title: Perkins Family Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected a one-time gain related to the sale of eight Perkins restaurants to a franchisee. The company said its one-time gain on the sale was partially offset by costs associated with other property transactions and by costs related to operating nine recently-acquired restaurants in the Orlando area which are being converted to Perkins Restaurants. Share earnings are in units.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Ah, Romance

title: Drexel Reduces Jobs in Division
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. laid off more than 100 employees yesterday in its taxable fixed-income sales division. As of last week, the firm had more than 860 employees working in the division.

title: The Hall Deserves The Pearl
description: Earl Monroe was the only basketball shooter I ever saw whose ball would deflate when it hit the rim. Then it just flopped through the net, like a dead fish.

title: A Canadian Clears 7-1 to Win the Puissance
description: Ian Millar, lanky and professorial and the perennial shepherd of the Canadian National Team's most promising show jumpers, is tall enough that Puissance walls do not dwarf him. Once atop an equally lanky horse, Millar typically has the best chance of staring a Puissance wall down to scale of any of his equestrian peers.

title: Washington National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Figures for 1988 have been restated for an accounting change.

title: REPUBLICANS DROP EFFORT IN SENATE TO CUT GAINS TAX
description: With the reluctant agreement of the Bush Administration, Senate Republicans today effectively abandoned their effort to win a cut in the capital gains tax this year. They did so by giving up their plans to attach the measure to the three major spending bills under consideration.

title: Porta Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2% Cut in Agencies' Budgets Is Ordered by Cuomo Administration
description: The Cuomo administration ordered a 2 percent cut in the operating budgets of state agencies today, saying the reduction was needed because the state had overestimated tax revenue and faced a potential deficit of almost $300 million this year.

title: Tanzania Must Not Fence In the Proud, Cattle-Herding Masai
description: To the Editor:

title: Ladd Furniture Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WHAT'S UP THERE, ANYWAY?

title: For Turkey's Kurds, Fragile Gains
description: A recent trip to Paris has made a haze of Ismail Hakki Onal's political future.

title: After Sharp Debate, Senate Votes To Let North Collect His Pension
description: The Senate tonight agreed to a change in Federal law that would allow Oliver L. North, a central figure in the Iran-contra affair who was a highly decorated veteran of combat in Vietnam, to receive his Navy pension despite his conviction for shredding Government documents.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the credit markets referred incorrectly to the saving to be realized by New York City in a debt reorganization that includes a new bond issue. The saving, of $161 million in the 1990 fiscal year and $101 million in 1991, will result from lower payments of principal and interest, not just interest. The article also quoted a consultant who misstated the duration of the city's payments.

title: New Remics Issue From Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced two separate real estate mortgage conduit securities, totaling $800.2 million.

title: Sierra Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Charter One Financial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago 9 months' net included $1,070,000 from tax-loss carryforwards. Year-ago 9 months' per share earnings not available; company went public in January 1988. Latest third-quarter net included a gain of $1.8 million from the sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock and a charge of $767,000 for costs associated with mergers. Latest 9 months' net included a gain of $4.4 million from the sale of Federal Home mortgage stock, while year-ago period included a gain of $422,000 from the sale of such stock. Figures are restated to reflect the merger of First Federal Savings of Akron and Western Reserve Savings Bank, which occurred in August. Year-ago quarter share earnings are based solely on earnings of Charter One and are not restated to reflect shares issued in August to effect mergers.

title: MBIA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lesson of the Senate Five
description: What will it take to change the odious way Con=gressional campaigns are fananced? The answer could be $1.3 billion. That's one estimate of what the Government's delay in taking over the Lincoln Savings & Loan Association has cost taxpayers - a delay that followed campaign contributions from the chairman of the mismanaged California thrift, Charles KeKeating.

title: Museum to Open Series Of Gary Cooper Films
description: ''Desire,'' a 1936 film featuring Gary Cooper and Marlene Dietrich, will open a three-day film series devoted to Gary Cooper today at 3 P.M. at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Rock From Senegal
description: Youssou N'Dour, a Senegalese rock singer, is to lead his 12-piece band Sunday night at 10 at the Ritz, 254 West 54th Street (541-8900), with Blues Traveler opening at 9 P.M. Tickets are $20.

title: St. Paul Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $2,643,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Newmont Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Newmont Gold is 90 percent-owned by Newmont Mining Corp.

title: 10 Teen-Age Girls Held in Upper Broadway Pinprick Attacks
description: Ten teen-age girls were arrested last night and charged with jabbing women with pins in dozens of unprovoked attacks on the Upper West Side over a one-week period.

title: Century Telephone reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Reunification of Germany Doesn't Frighten Mitterrand
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France, ending talks with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today, said he was not afraid of a reunified Germany.

title: Cominco Resources Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bethlehem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $191,000 on sale of trucking subsidiary. c-Net income

title: Asset Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $5,200,000, or 37 cents a share, recovery of all previous charges to operations for carrying amount adjustments. The company said the latest third quarter and 9 months earnings were adversely impacted by collateralized mortgage obligations repayments, sharply higher interest rates, and increased long-term borrowings.

title: Armenian Philharmonic Begins Tour This Month
description: The Armenian Philharmonic Orchestra will make its American debut on Nov. 29 in Boston and will also appear in Washington and New York. Loris Tjeknavorian, the first American conductor appointed to a principal conducting post in the Soviet Union, will lead the orchestra.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Calendar column of The Home Section on Thursday misstated the admission policy for ''Modernism: A Century of Style and Design,'' a show at the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan next Thursday through Nov. 12. Regular admission is $10; children under 16 will be admitted free.

title: 4,000 Layoffs by Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation today announced the layoffs of 4,000 workers in a series of moves that ended production of two subcompact cars in Detroit, eliminated a shift at a car-making plant in St. Louis and closed a supply plant in Wisconsin.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Pocket-Size Stereos
description: It has been 10 years since the Sony Corporation introduced the Walkman, a pocket-sized tape cassette player without speakers, designed to provide high-quality sound through headphones. Now, there are hundreds of such ''personal stereos'' on the market (nearly 50 from Sony alone), from dozens of manufacturers, at prices from under $40 to above $400. How do you choose?

title: Alfred Finkel, 68, Dies; Former Steel Executive
description: Alfred Finkel, a retired steel-company executive and philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Thursday at Tisch Hospital-University Hospital of New York University. He was 68 years old and lived in Woodmere, L.I.

title: Nebraska Is Colorado's 'Game of the Century'
description: To this point, the Colorado Buffaloes have worked conscientiously and with few errors to create the kind of dream football season that would produce a Big Eight Conference title, a trip to the Orange Bowl and the crowning glory of a national championship.

title: John L. Wilson Jr., 91, Architect Of Harlem River Houses, Is Dead
description: John Louis Wilson Jr., an architect who designed several public buildings in New York City, died of cancer Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Computer Language Research reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included pretax gain on sale of assets of $1,458.

title: Cadmus Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentucky Central Life Insurnce Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mesa Posts Loss in Quarter
description: Mesa Limited Partnership this week reported a loss for the third quarter ended Sept. 30, its second consecutive quarterly loss.

title: Jones Spacelink reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
New York Marine & General Ins reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Views, Spare to Frilly
description: Spare and bare, the ''tribute'' collection for Giorgio di Sant'Angelo, shown in New York Thursday, managed to capture the spirit of the late designer's look while continuing a trend toward simplification in his final collection.

title: EAST GERMANS' NEW LEADER VOWS FAR-REACHING REFORM AND URGES AN END TO FLIGHT
description: Two days after conferring with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow, Egon Krenz, the new East German leader, returned home and pleaded with his citizens today to stop fleeing the country, promising far-reaching reforms and announcing the dismissal of five senior Politburo members.

title: Shanghai Journal; New Challenges for a City of Hope and Past Glory
description: Below the reconstructed Long Bar, where the foreign taipans, or big bosses, used to sip their pink gins and chat about the women with gowns slit up the leg past the waist, or about rogues of the underworld like Big-Eared Du and Pockmarked Huang, a symbol of the new Shanghai is taking shape.

title: New Method to Remove Oil From Tar Sands
description: John S. Rendall, founder of the Solv-Ex Corporation in Albuquerque, N.M., has patented what he said is an environmentally safe method of removing oil and useful metals from tar sands.

title: Review/Music; Philharmonic With Goode In Schumann Concerto
description: This week's New York Philharmonic program at Avery Fisher Hall offers a sort of world premiere and Richard Strauss's ''Don Quixote,'' which makes a mighty noise and serves as a showcase for a solo cellist, various other instrumentalists (the violist especially) and the orchestra as a whole.

title: Enron Oil & Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pre-tax gains of $10 million from the sale of property for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air Midwest, Inc., Wichita, Kan., said it received an unsolicited acquisition offer from TransWest Air, St. Louis, for $6.55 a share. Air Midwest said its board would consider the offer.

description: b-Included tax credits of $300,000, or 6 cents a share, and $1,239,000, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $62,000, or 1 cent a share, and $318,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest-quarter results included pretax gain of $1 million from sale of powdered metal products division.

title: Chicago School Control Shifts to Parent Councils
description: More than 5,400 parents, community residents and teachers took an oath of office Thursday night, swearing to ''represent the interests of our children's education with respect and dignity'' in the most radical school decentralization plan ever attempted in the United States.

title: Ford-Jaguar Tie Seen by End of '89
description: The Ford Motor Company could complete its $2.5 billion acquisition of the British luxury car maker Jaguar by the end of the year, the head of Ford's European arm said today. L. Lindsey Halstead, chairman of Ford of Europe Inc., said in a video news conference from Britain that a Jaguar shareholders meeting could be called by the end of this month. The transaction could be completed within days after that if shareholders approved the deal.

description: b-Net loss

title: Garan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Thousands in Bulgaria Rally
description: Thousands of demonstrators in Bulgaria today mounted the first large pro-democracy rally in the country's postwar history, a diplomat said. Estimates of the number taking part ranged from 4,000 and 9,000. They were demonstrating on the last day of a 35-nation environmental conference in Sofia, the capital. The envoy said the police ringed the National Assembly, but a group of demonstrators managed to deliver a petition.

title: Arnold Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,322,329, or 20 cents a share, from cumulative effect of adoption of FASB 96. c-Included an after-tax gain of $1.8 million, or 28 cents a share, on sale of investment in Viking Freight for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Christian Commander Bars Beirut Parliament Meeting
description: Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian military leader, declared Parliament dissolved today in an attempt to foil a presidential election and an Arab peace plan that he considers inadequate.

title: INSIDE
description: Stable Jobless Figures Calm Fears of Recession

title: Review/Film; This Phantom Has His Lair In London, but Travels
description: The newest adaptation of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' is the Freddy Krueger version, a concept that results in all the terror and suspense of Charlie Brown in ''Macbeth.'' Robert Englund, who is the murderous Freddy in the the Nightmare on Elm Street series, plays the lovestruck, murderous Phantom here with much the same vile makeup and smirky manner.

title: American Filtrona Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Atlantis Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Right to Life Candidate Sees Moral Ills
description: In preparation for today's mayoral debate, Henry R. Hewes took the day off from work yesterday. He spent the day at home sleeping, eating well and only occasionally considering campaign issues.

title: Synex International reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $190,000 from a write-off of costs incurred in attempted acquisition. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Opera; A Parable, With Simple Ritual
description: Benjamin Britten's church parables - short operas that drew their inspiration from Noh drama, medieval mystery plays and contemporary concerns - remain among his most telling creations. They are not exactly upbeat, and in the wrong hands they can plod self-importantly. But with their artfully innocent simplicity, sparse but telling daubs of instrumental color and refined intensity of expression, they count among the finest works of modern-day musical theater.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a dispute over charitable fund raising by The Wall Street Journal's Washington bureau chief referred incorrectly to Jerald F. terHorst of the Ford Motor Company. He is director of national public affairs with responsibility for media relations and issue analysis, not a lobbyist.

title: Stronger U.S. Antitrust Action Vowed
description: In their first major policy statements, President Bush's two top antitrust officials said today that they would strengthen enforcement policies and singled out the airline and health-care industries for scrutiny.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $727,853, or 27 cents a share, on disposal of Executone Information Systems Inc. stock for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $516,169, or 19 cents a share, which included $932,436, or 35 cents a share, operating loss from disposed customer bases and related assets and a gain of $1,448,605, or 54 cents a share on disposal. d-Included income from discontinued operations of $181,644, or 6 cents a share, which included $1,266,961, or 52 cents a share, operating loss from disposed customer bases and related assets and a gain of $1,448,605, or 58 cents a share on disposal.

title: Albanian Unrest in Serbia
description: Security forces clashed today with a crowd in Podujevo and moved to quell other protests by people of Albanian stock in this southern region, where at least three people died in unrest this week. The protests in Podujevo, in Kosovo province, Yugoslavia's poorest region, center on the trial of a popular former Communist chief, Azem Vlasi, and 14 other leaders of the province's ethnic Albanian majority. They are accused of counterrevolutionary activities and of opposing changes that would limit the autonomy of Kosovo, a Serbian province in which 85 percent of the population is of Albanian descent.

title: City Gets Color and Cash Infusion
description: It may not have been Halloween, but midtown Manhattan was ablaze in colorful costumes yesterday and more hazardous than usual.

title: 76ers Sign Mahorn To Multiyear Deal
description: After rejecting the Minnesota Timberwolves and the Glaxo team of Verona, Italy, Rick Mahorn at last came to a decision about his basketball future yesterday when he signed a multiyear contract with the Philadelphia 76ers. The 31-year-old forward-center, who helped the Detroit Pistons win the National Basketball Association championship last season, came to Philadelphia earlier this week from the Timberwolves for a No. 1 draft choice in 1990 and No. 2 choices in 1991 and 1992.

title: Bush Takes Stump In Virginia Contest, Stressing His Themes
description: Carefully skirting the political minefields of abortion and race in the Virginia contest for governor, President Bush stumped southern Virginia today to show the Republican Party's standard in behalf of its candidate, J. Marshall Coleman.

title: Rosalind Miller, Reporter, Weds
description: Rosalind R. Miller, a freelance television reporter, and George M. Sparks Jr., a marketing representative for Macro 4, a computer software company in Mount Freedom, N.J., were married yesterday at the Church of the Open Door in Brooklyn. The Revs. Walter S. Keiller and Michael Sykes, Baptist ministers, performed the ceremony.

title: Gains on Interleukin 3 And Formation of Bone
description: Researchers at Genetics Institute Inc., a biotechnology concern in Cambridge, Mass., have obtained the world's first patent on genetically engineered interleukin 3, a protein that stimulates growth of human blood cells.

title: O'Connor Proposes Order of Nuns To Fight Abortion and Euthanasia
description: John Cardinal O'Connor has proposed establishing an order of nuns dedicated specifically to ending abortion and euthanasia. He said the order, to be called the Sisters of Life, would include physicians and lawyers.

title: Braniff Announces Additional Layoffs
description: Braniff Inc. cut about 100 jobs in a further effort to reduce costs as the carrier struggles to emerge from bankruptcy for a second time. The layoffs, mostly of administrative personnel in Braniff's Orlando headquarters, come about five weeks after the airline filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors and announced plans to lay off about 2,900 workers.

title: First Capital Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Scrap Iron And Rockettes
description: A lot of Americans are cross about Japan buying Rockefeller Center. They seem to be afraid Americans aren't smart enough to do business with Japanese wheeler-dealers.

title: Senate Convicts U.S. Judge, Removing Him From Bench
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to remove Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. from the bench by finding him guilty on two of three articles of impeachment.

title: City Opera Negotiations
description: Negotiations between the New York City Opera and its orchestra continued last night in an attempt to reach a tentative contract agreement that can be submitted to the full orchestra for ratification.

title: Colombia Judges and Their Aides Go on Strike to Demand Protection
description: Colombian judges and court workers went on strike today, demanding greater protection against a surge of violence related to the drug trade. President Virgilio Barco Vargas renewed his pledge to keep fighting the traffickers.

title: Northrop On Payments
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it was the victim, rather than the culprit, in a purported fraud involving payments made in South Korea to encourage that country to buy its fighter aircraft.

title: Topics of the Times; An Overdue Remedy
description: New York voters Tuesday will encounter the wholly sensible Ballot Proposal 1, to make counties responsible for the official acts of their sheriffs.

title: Davis Rejects Offer
description: Mark Davis has rejected the latest contract offer from the San Diego Padres, who are eager to retain the services of the free-agent relief pitcher. The Padres had reportedly proposed a three-year guaranteed contract worth $7 million to Davis. The left-hander led the major leagues last season with 44 saves. Davis's agent, Alan Hendricks of Houston, said he may delay any contract decision until at least Nov. 14, when all other teams are allowed to enter the negotiations.

title: Anaren Microwave Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Net earnings in the year-ago 9 months included earnings from the company's former United Kingdom unit, which was sold in December 1988. Net income for the latest 9 months included investment income earned on the proceeds from the sale.

title: Pace of New Jobs Calms Recession Fears
description: The Labor Department reported today that the economy created new jobs at a brisk pace in October, calming fears that it might have begun to skid toward recession. In addition, factory employment stabilized after plunging in September.

title: U.S. Panel Finds No Evidence of Cold Fusion
description: A panel of experts convened by the Federal Government said yesterday that there was no convincing evidence that low-temperature nuclear fusion would lead to useful sources of energy.

title: Merrill Rejoins Clippers
description: Stump Merrill, who managed the Columbus Clippers to the International League pennant in 1984, will return to manage the Yankees' Class AAA farm club next season, a Columbus radio station, WBNS, reported yesterday. Merrill, who also managed the Clippers in 1985, will replace Rick Down, who took over Columbus in August when Bucky Dent was named manager of the Yankees. (AP)

title: 2 Nuclear Plants Closed; Pipes Held Substandard
description: The Department of Energy has closed two nuclear processing factories in Idaho on which it has spent hundreds of millions of dollars in the last few years because the underground pipes carrying highly radioactive and poisonous wastes do not meet the safety standards of a 1976 environmental law.

title: Breeding Success And Bettors
description: It is called the Breeders' Cup because the $10 million being given away today in seven championship races at Gulfstream Park comes from the pockets of the nation's horse breeders. The breeders, though, are just the most recent link in the great chain of racing money.

title: GTE Settles Dispute With Home Shopping
description: The GTE Corporation, which earlier this year was awarded $100 million in its legal battle with Home Shopping Network Inc., announced today that it had agreed to a settlement with the television retailer for an undisclosed cash payment.

description: Scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have patented the genetic coding to reproduce an important part of the human immune system.

OPEC Output Called High
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pushed oil production in October past its target, to the highest level all year, according to estimates released today The surge in production came as major producers staked out bargaining positions before a crucial meeting later this month, analysts said.

title: Amvestors Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9 months included investment losses of $83,323 and $2,387,798, respectively; and the year-ago quarter included an investment gain of $383,328 and the 9 months included an investment gain of $350,730.

title: Lethal Loophole for Poison Gas
description: Does President Bush want to ban chemical weapons? He tells the U.N. he does. But he lets the Pentagon keep making new ones. His waffling won't hasten a treaty to ban these weapons or help persuade other states to sign it. Third world states, fearful that rivals may make chemical weapons, may want to make them, too. But firm agreement by the U.S. and Soviet Union to halt production could speed up treaty negotiations and encourage self-restraint by others.

description: LEAD: What does a grandson of Mohandas K. Gandhi do when faced with a moral dilemma? Does he go ahead, regardless of family opinion, stubbornly following his instinctive understanding of his grandfather's philosophy?

description: Viewers of television news this week saw Rudolph W. Giuliani on the attack, striking out at his opponent, David N. Dinkins, on issues ranging from being ''afraid to debate'' to using the appearances of prominent Democrats to prop up his campaign.

Banner Industries Gets 9% of McGill

Steiner, has acquired a 9 percent stake in the McGill Manufacturing Company and said it is interested in exploring ''the possibility of a transaction'' with the Valparaiso, Ind., anti-friction bearings manufacturer. McGill has been trying to stave off a hostile offer of $72 a share, or $104 million, from SKF A.B., a Swedish concern.

description: The turmoil in Britain after last month's resignation of Nigel Lawson as Chancellor of the Exchequer has focused attention on the European Monetary System - or more precisely, on Britain's reluctance to join it.

title: MEM Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.T.&T. Venture
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories and Hampshire Instruments said they plan to collaborate on several areas of X-ray lithography development, an advanced technique for manufacturing semiconductors. Hampshire is a Marlborough, Mass., semiconductor equipment maker that is developing a new class of tools that use X-rays instead of light to etch ultra-fine circuits on semiconductor chips. Hampshire is using a different approach to generate X-rays than I.B.M., which two weeks ago opened a new cneter for X-ray lithography research and development. I.B.M. uses a synchrotron storage ring to develop exceptionally bright X-rays, while the Hampshire approach involves using a less powerful and less expensive X-ray source.

description: b-Included an $8.3 million loss on asset sales. c-Included $15.6 million gain from natural-gas contract settlements.

As stated elsewhere in the article, they were a bill to raise the national debt ceiling, one to modify the Medicare catastrophic-coverage program and one to repeal tax rules against discrimination in employer-paid health insurance. They were not spending bills.

The auction will benefit the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, a lobbying organization. Items to be auctioned, which include works by David Hockney, Annie Leibovitz, Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol and Francesco Scavullo, will be on view from noon to 3 P.M. Admission is $5. Information: 989-1114.

title: General Magnaplate reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The 40 Who Fell in the Turbulence Of the U.S. Battles for Civil Rights
description: A civil rights memorial to be dedicated Sunday includes the names of the 40 people killed in the movement. The list, in chronological sequence, gives the date and circumstances of the person's death as described on the memorial. LEE, the Rev. George, killed May 7, 1955, for leading a voter registration drive in Belzoni, Miss. SMITH, Lamar, 63 years old, slain Aug. 13, 1955, for organizing black voters in Brookhaven, Miss. TILL, Emmett Louis, 14, slain Aug. 28, 1955, for speaking to a white woman in Money, Miss. REESE, John Earl, 16, slain Oct. 22, 1955, by nightriders opposed to black school improvements in Mayflower, Tex. EDWARDS, Willie Jr., killed Jan. 23, 1957, by the Ku Klux Klan in Montgomery, Ala. PARKER, Mack Charles, 23, taken from a jail and lynched April 25, 1959, in Poplarville, Miss. LEE, Herbert, 50, voter registration worker, killed Sept. 25, 1961, by a white legislator in Liberty, Miss. DUCKSWORTH, Roman Jr., taken from bus and killed April 9, 1962, by the police in Taylorsville, Miss. GUIHARD, Paul, a European reporter, killed Sept. 30, 1962, in a riot at University of Mississippi in Oxford, Miss. MOORE, William Lewis, slain April 23, 1963, in a one-man march against segregation in Attalla, Ala. EVERS, Medgar, 28, civil rights leader, assassinated June 12, 1963, in Jackson, Miss. COLLINS, Addie Mae, 14, killed Sept. 15, 1963, in the bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala. MCNAIR, Denise, 11, killed Sept. 15, 1963, in the Birmingham church bombing. ROBERTSON, Carole, 14, killed Sept. 15, 1963, in the church bombing. WESLEY, Cynthia, 14, killed Sept. 15, 1963, in the church bombing. WARE, Virgil Lamar, 13, killed Sept. 15, 1963, in a wave of racist violence in Birmingham, Ala. ALLEN, Louis, witness to the killing of a civil rights worker, assassinated Jan. 31, 1964, in Liberty, Miss. KLUNDER, the Rev. Bruce, killed April 7, 1964, protesting the construction of a segregated school in Cleveland. DEE, Henry Hezekiah, 19, killed May 2, 1964, by the Klan in Meadville, Miss. MOORE, Charles Eddie, 20, killed May 2, 1964, by the Klan in Meadville, Miss. CHANEY, James, 21, civil rights worker, abducted and slain June 21, 1964, by the Klan in Philadelphia, Miss. GOODMAN, Andrew, civil rights worker, abducted and slain June 21, 1964, by the Klan in Philadelphia, Miss. SCHWERNER, Michael, 24, rights worker, abducted and slain June 21, 1964, by the Klan in Philadelphia, Miss. PENN, Lemuel, 48, killed July 11, 1964, by the Klan while driving through Colbert, Ga. JACKSON, Jimmie Lee, civil rights marcher, killed Feb. 26, 1965, by a state trooper in Marion, Ala. REEB, the Rev. James, march volunteer, beaten to death on March 11, 1965 in Selma, Ala. LIUZZO, Viola Gregg, 39, killed March 25, 1965, by the Ku Klux Klan while transporting marchers on a highway near Selma, Ala. MOORE, Oneal, 34, black deputy, killed June 2, 1965, by nightriders in Varnado, La. BREWSTER, Willie Wallace, 38, killed July 18, 1965, by nightriders in Anniston, Ala. DANIELS, Jonathan, 26, seminary student, killed Aug. 20, 1965, by a part-time deputy in Hayneville, Ala. YOUNGE, Samuel Jr., student civil rights worker, killed Jan. 3, 1966, in a dispute over a whites-only restroom in Tuskegee, Ala. DAHMER, Vernon, black community leader, killed Jan. 10, 1966, in a Klan bombing in Hattiesburg, Miss. WHITE, Ben Chester, 67, killed June 10, 1966, by the Klan in Natchez, Miss. TRIGGS, Clarence, slain July 30, 1966, by nightriders in Bogalusa, La. JACKSON, Wharlest, 37, civil rights leader, killed Feb. 27, 1967, after promotion to ''white'' job in Natchez, Miss. BROWN, Benjamin, 22, civil rights worker, killed May 12, 1967, when the police fired on protesters in Jackson, Miss. HAMMOND, Samuel Jr., 18, killed Feb. 8, 1968, when highway patrolmen fired on protesters in Orangeburg, S.C. MIDDLETON, Delano, 17, killed Feb. 8, 1968, in the Orangeburg shootings. SMITH, Henry, student killed Feb. 8, 1968, in the Orangeburg shootings. KING, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther Jr., 39, assassinated April 4, 1968 in Memphis.

title: Classify 'Shvartzer' Among Loaded Words
description: To the Editor:

title: NuVision Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Same Nixon, Different China
description: In China, where leaders are thought young at 76 and political disgrace can be a passing phase, Richard Nixon is respected as a strategic thinker, an unsentimental realist and the American who opened the door to good relations with China.

title: ETHICS COMMITTEE ASKING 5 SENATORS ABOUT SAVINGS TIE
description: The chairman and vice chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee have asked five Senators whether large campaign contributions they received from the chairman of a failing savings and loan association prompted their intervention with Federal regulators on its behalf.

title: U.S. and Soviets Vow U.N. Amity
description: In a new sign of their improving relations, the United States and the Soviet Union said today they would work together to strengthen the United Nations and its agencies around the world.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-6 East Germany's chief urged citizens to stop fleeing the country and to ''put trust in our policy of renewal'' as he announced the retirement of five senior Politburo members. Page 1 East Germans at Bonn's Embassy in Prague say they believe they are leaving a society on the brink of economic ruin. Emigration, they say, is creating a labor shortage of crisis proportions. 1 Cheers, jeers, hymns and demands echoed of the medieval walls of a castle church in Wittenberg, East Germany, where 3,000 people gathered this week in one of many protests. 6 Hungary's ruling party is in trouble. Almost four weeks after the Communist Party changed its name to Socialist Party and asked its 720,000 members to register anew, only about 30,000 have done so. 5 Lithuania moves to allow votes on its future 5 Soviets televise Dubcek interview on the ''Prague Spring'' 5 U.S. and Soviet support for the U.N. grew as the superpowers announced plans to submit a resolution calling for the United Nations to play a greater role in maintaining peace and fostering world cooperation. 3 Debate over Britain's ties to Europe and its role in the single market of 1992 has emerged from Prime Minister Thatcher's reluctance to join the European Monetary System. 33 Colombia's judges went on strike, demanding greater protection against a new surge of drug violence. President Barco renewed his pledge to keep fighting the traffickers. 4 Iran marked the 10th anniversary of the U.S. Embassy takeover in Teheran with a large demonstration. Diplomats saw it as an effort by militants to upstage President Rafsanjani. 3 Lebanon's Parliament was blocked by the Christian leader from meeting today in a villa on Beirut's dividing line. An Arab League mediator said plans were being made to hold the session elsewhere. 3 National 7-9, 26 An ethics panel asked 5 senators if campaign contributions prompted their intervention to aid the failing Lincoln Savings and Loan. 1 The impact of oil and gas drilling off California and Florida coasts cannot be assessed by the Government because it lacks data, the National Academy of Sciences has said. 1 The Senate voted to remove a judge, Walter Nixon Jr., from the bench after finding him guilty on two of three articles of impeachment. 7 New jobs sprung up at a brisk pace in October, calming fears of a recession. Factory employment stabilized, and the overall unemployment rate remained 5.2 percent. 9 Drop in U.S. auto sales begins to moderate in late October 33 New rules for young air travelers are being drafted by the F.A.A. One rule would prohibit children under two years old from traveling free on an adult's lap without a restraint. 26 Tough antitrust action was pledged by two U.S. officials. They said the airline and health-care industries would receive special scrutiny. 33 Swift agreement on deficit reduction within Congress was predicted by Senate leaders. The plan would restore $16.1 billion that was automatically cut last month. 8 Some 5,400 Chicago school leaders took an oath of office, transferring power to parent-led councils in the nation's most radical school decentralization plan ever. 8 A new civil rights memorial in Montgomery, Ala., commemorates the victims of the racial violence and terror of the civil rights era. 7 Those killed in the movement 7 Two nuclear processing factories in Idaho have been closed by the Energy Department because underground pipes carrying radioactive wastes do not meet safety standards. 8 No proof exists to support cold fusion as being a potentially useful source of energy, a Federal panel said. It recommended against special money for more research. 9 A chief of police has been arrested in Brockton, Mass., for stealing cocaine from his department's evidence room. He has admitted to using cocaine for five years. 7 The Government-teamsters pact reached last March was backed by a Federal judge, who reaffirmed the broad powers of court-appointed officers to discipline union officials. 8 Money managers of pension funds vowed to ignore the New York Stock Exchange's latest attempt to curb computerized program trading. 33 Regional 27-31 A barrage of negative campaign ads in the New Jersey race for governor left both campaign staffs arguing over charges of distortion and racism, bringing tensions between the candidates to their highest. 1 Car insurance: the issue that won't go away in New Jersey 28 Two new Giuliani commercials sharply critical of David Dinkins went on the air for the final weekend of the New York City mayoral campaign. Both candidates crammed for debates tonight and tomorrow. 27 On TV, the final week of the race for mayor seemed to show Mr. Giuliani on the attack and Mr. Dinkins continuing in his mild-mannered way. 29 Dinkins's team mixes old hands and newcomers 29 Giuliani's staff hits stride 29 Right to Life candidate sees moral ills 29 Mott Haven's election priorities: fighting drugs and crime 27 The killing of a talented youth last Sunday has upset his Hollis, Queens, neighborhood. The 17-year-old youth, Donald White, had planned to take the College Board exam today. 1 Ten black girls were arrested and charged with jabbing white women with pins in dozens of unprovoked attacks on the Upper West Side over a one-week period. Investigators said the girls did it for fun. 27 An order of nuns against abortion and euthanasia was proposed by Cardinal O'Connor, who said, ''I'm just floating my idea.'' The order, which would include physicians and lawyers, would be called Sisters of Life. 31 Random drug tests are to be given to subway motormen, bus drivers, maintenance workers and thousands of other public employees in ''safety sensitive'' jobs in New York City's transit system. 31 A prisoner who fled a hospital on Wednesday and is suspected of raping a woman three hours later was arrested in the Bronx when he went to his brother's apartment, investigators said. 30 About New York: psychiatrists ply trade at city marathon 27

title: Pretoria Asserts Hoax in Reports on Namibia
description: The South African Government said today that it may have been the victim of a hoax when it made public what it said were intercepted radio messages asserting that black nationalist guerrillas were entering Namibia.

title: Cordis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $94,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Copter Pursuing a Boat Crashes in the Florida Keys
description: A Customs Service helicopter that was used to chase boats suspected of carrying drugs crashed in the Florida Keys while pursuing a speedboat Thursday night, and one of those aboard was still missing today.

title: MacLean Hunter reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1.3 million, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the New York City Marathon, these streets will be closed to traffic in Manhattan for much of tomorrow morning and afternoon: First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge, Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 102d Street and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Broadway. In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge, the Madison Avenue Bridge and the Verrazano Narrows Bridge will be closed.

title: Excel Industriess Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent dividend paid Jan. 23, 1989.

title: General Trustco Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in Canadian funds.

title: Car Insurance: The Issue That Won't Go Away in New Jersey
description: Like a steady soaking rain, the automobile-insurance mess in New Jersey continues to seep into the gubernatorial campaign, even as the race enters its final days.

title: Home Beneficial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Massachusetts Police Chief Quits, Accused of Stealing Cocaine From Evidence Room
description: The Chief of Police in Brockton, a small city 25 miles south of Boston, has been arrested on a charge of stealing cocaine from his department's evidence room and has resigned.

title: A Correction
description: The omission of a word altered the meaning of a letter Oct. 21 by the Rev. Theodore S. Horvath on Louis (Lajos) Kossuth. The sentence should have read: ''Flora Lewis (column, Sept. 24) pays tribute to Lajos Kossuth, the Hungarian patriot and statesman, for proposing in the 1850's that the Austro-Hungarian Empire be transformed into a Danubian Confederation to provide autonomy, even sovereignty, for the minorities without destroying their cooperative links.''

title: Healthcare Compare reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $695,000 related to an arbitration ruling for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Shifts at American City
description: The president of American City Business Journals Inc., which operates 21 local weekly business publications, is stepping down, and the company is moving its headquarters to Charlotte, N.C. Michael K. Russell, American City's president, who founded the company in 1982 with his longtime business partner, William H. Worley, said this week he was stepping down, effective Nov. 30. Shaw Publishing Inc., a Charlotte-based publishing company, owns 30 percent of American City and has agreed to purchase an additional 25 percent from the E. W. Scripps Company in 1990. Mr. Russell said American City's headquarters was being moved to Charlotte to consolidate administrative operations with Shaw Publishing.

title: New York City Retail Sales Dip
description: Several of New York's largest retailers reported that their sales declined an average of 1.6 percent in the city in October, while rising an average of 2 percent in the overall metropolitan area compared with October 1988, a spot-check found yesterday.

title: Giuliani Still Jabbing In Last Days of Race
description: Worried that his campaign is flagging, Rudolph W. Giuliani unleashed two commercials that he hoped would damage David N. Dinkins on the final weekend of the New York City mayoral race.

title: DIALOGUE: REINVENTING CITY GOVERNMENT  Charter Revision: Yes or No?; Government That's F;ir
description: While most attention next Tuesday will focus on the mayoral contest, New Yorkers face another decision that is just as important: whether to adopt a new set of rules for city government.

title: Dr. Gordon K. Moe, 74, Ex-Medical Researcher
description: Dr. Gordon Kenneth Moe, retired director of the Masonic Medical Research Library in Utica, N.Y., died Oct. 27 at St. Luke's Hospital in Utica after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Barneveld, N.Y.

title: Ranks Thin Out in Hungarian Party
description: Almost four weeks after the Communist Party changed its name to Socialist and asked its 720,000 members to signify their adherence by registering anew, its following has nearly vanished.

title: Prisoner Seized After an Escape From a Hospital
description: A prisoner who escaped from a Brooklyn hospital on Wednesday and is suspected of raping a woman three hours later was arrested yesterday in the Bronx when he went to his brother's apartment.

title: International Rectifier reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chariot Renews Bid for Synalloy
description: Chariot Holdings Ltd., a New York investment firm, has renewed its quest to acquire the Synalloy Corporation, by offering $12 a share in cash, or a total of $45.6 million, for the Spartansburg, S.C., chemical concern. Chariot has unsuccessfully sought to acquire Synalloy since it first bought a 20 percent stake in the company last year. Chariot holds three seats on the company's eight-member board.

title: Florida Employers Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chavez Bout Is Set
description: Julio Cesar Chavez, the World Boxing Council superlightweight champion, will defend his title against Sammy Fuentes on Nov. 18 in Las Vegas, Nev. The bout will be part of a championship doubleheader that includes a title defense by Julian Jackson, the World Boxing Association junior-middleweight champion, against Troy Wortham.

title: Gainsco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
East Germans Now in Prague Speak of Crisis and Hardship
description: Thousands more East Germans crowded into the West German Embassy here today, and many said their homeland was on the brink of economic collapse as emigration brings labor shortages in the East to crisis proportions.

title: Home Shopping Network reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year included $28 million in special pre-tax non-recurring charges, including the writeoff of goodwill related to the purchase of certain subsidiary businesses, the cost of discontinuing or reducing the operations of certain subsidiaries and the writeoff of the company's investment in Canadian Home Shopping Network Inc. The latest and year-ago quarters included extraordinary gains of $100,000 and $900,000, respectively, from repurchase of debt. The latest and previous year included extraordinary after-tax gains of $7.1 million, or 8 cents a share, and $883,000, or 1 cent a share, respectively, from the repurchase of long-term obligations.

title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule; Stockpiled Supplies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; A Russian Rite and a Cubist Parade In a Diaghilev Evening at the Joffrey
description: Over the years, the Joffrey Ballet has enriched its repertory with works that once epitomized the early 20th-century avant-garde in music and dance; virtually all were produced by Diaghilev's Ballets Russes.

title: John Ford Clymer, Painter, 82
description: John Ford Clymer, a Western artist who painted scores of covers for The Saturday Evening Post, died Thursday after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Iran Notes Anniversary Of Fall of U.S. Embassy
description: Iran will mark the 10th anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran with a large demonstration organized by one of country's most militant politicians.

title: Forest Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Atico Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $243,000. c-Net income The company said third quarter results included $35.3 million in restructuring charges, of which $33.9 million is for the charge off of intangible assets, mostly goodwill.

title: Slavery and Colonialism Make Up the True Legacy of Columbus; Hispanic Parade
description: To the Editor:

title: Testimony Has Youths Joyous After Assault
description: The youths who raped and beat a jogger in Central Park last April celebrated after the attack, one of the six defendants said in a videotaped statement played in court yesterday.

title: Caveats on Ordering by Phone
description: At a time when millions of consumers are starting to do their holiday shopping from home by telephone, few of them realize that the Federal Government does not provide them with the same safeguards as those who order by mail.

title: Ackerley Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results in the latest 9-month period reflect the January acquisition of radio station WBOS-FM in Boston.

title: For Supreme and Civil Court
description: Tuesday's judicial contests in New York City serve notice again of the need to reform judicial selection, now largely controlled by party leaders who help determine which candidates get on the ballot. The Democratic slates sure to win include high-caliber candidates but also a disappointing number of mediocre choices - underscoring the need for true merit selection.

title: Grand Finale: Beene, Karan and Mizrahi
description: In the venerable vaudeville tradition, the New York fashion shows save the best for last. Yesterday Geoffrey Beene presented his elegantly designed clothes, which would be considered inventive in any fashion capital. He was followed by Donna Karan, who continues to broaden the meaning of sportswear. On Thursday night, Isaac Mizrahi showed he has moved beyond being a cult figure and into the wider fashion arena.

title: Fairfield Communities Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $555,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $555,000, or 6 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Their Schools Are Small, but Their Goals Are Big
description: He pressured the C. W. Post quarterback three times, sacked him once, batted down a pass, caused a fumble, and made five tackles, one in the Post backfield. His team lost last Saturday, but for all that, Horacio (Poppy) Moronta won a weekly award for the best defensive performance. Moronta is a 277-pound defensive tackle for Wagner College.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe to Meet Becker: John McEnroe beat Michael Chang, 6-3, 3-6, 6-2, yesterday and Boris Becker was forced to a third-set tie breaker for the second consecutive day before defeating Wally Masur, 6-7, 6-4, 7-6, in the quarterfinals of the Paris Open. McEnroe will play Becker in the semifinals.(AP) Martinez Upset: Unseeded Anne Smith scored her second successive upset at the Virginia Slims of New England tournament with a 6-3, 3-6, 6-2 victory yesterday over fourth-seeded Conchita Martinez of Spain in Worcester, Mass.(AP) Maleeva Gains: Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria beat Natalya Medvedeva of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 6-3, and Amy Frazier, a 17-year-old amateur, defeated Halle Cioffi, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the Virginia Slims of Indianapolis tournament.(AP) HOCKEY Whalers 4, Red Wings 3: Jimmy Carson missed a penalty shot and Ray Ferraro of the Whalers scored with 1 minute 36 seconds remaining last night to give Hartford the victory in Detroit.(AP) Capitals 2, Maple Leafs 1: Don Beaupre stopped 28 shots and the Capitals held their opponent to one goal for the fourth consecutive game in defeating Toronto in Landover, Md. (AP) Oilers 5, Flames 2: Mark Messier had a goal and two assists and Grant Fuhr made 33 saves as Edmonton made the most of their 15 shots to beat visiting Calgary.(AP) HORSE SHOW Canadian Entry Wins: Ian Millar of the Canadian Equestrian Team and his mount, Pamino, showed their versatility by winning the Gambler's Choice speed competition last night at the National Horse Show at the Meadowlands. Fresh from a victory Thursday night in the Puissance event in which they demonstrated power and strength by jumping 7 feet 1 inch, Millar, the reigning World Cup champion, and the mare zipped over the 10 fences without a knockdown in 50.14 seconds. With the clock stopped, they then cleared a 200-point bonus fence for a total score of 1,180.

title: Dent Is Rewarded
description: Richard Dent, the 6-foot-5-inch, 265-pound defensive end, yesterday signed what is believed to be one of the most lucrative contracts in Chicago Bears history. Financial details of the five-year agreement were not announced, but Chicago papers reported the contract to be worth about $6 million. ''I think he's pumped up and excited,'' said Coach Mike Ditka. ''I think it will motivate him to go out and get 20 or 30 more sacks until the end of the season.'' (AP)

title: Topics of the Times; The Finish Line
description: New York's mayoral campaign is sputtering to a messy finish. Rudolph Giuliani and David Dinkins have finally agreed to two televised debates, exquisitely timed to get as little attention as possible. And Mr. Dinkins's campaign records are in such disarray that the Campaign Finance Board has withheld $95,000 in public matching funds.

title: Emcon Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
About New York; At the Marathon, Aches and Pains Of a Mental Sort
description: On the eve of New York's marathon five years ago, this column chronicled comings and goings at the La-Z-Boy Showcase Shoppe in Flushing, Queens. It was reported that those in the market for La-Z-Boy recliners shared a belief that marathoners were crazy.

title: As Sales Slip, a Model Plant Suffers
description: If ever an automobile plant was an unlikely candidate for idling, the jewel of General Motors' modernization strategy here was it.

title: Gateway Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Damon Biotech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a charge of $2,367,070 from disposition of production facility. c-Included a charge of $2,577,070 from disposition of production facility and a gain of $1,272,281 from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Looking to the Next Mayor to Fight Crack and Build Hope
description: Up to four times a month, burglars break into the Blue Diner, using a sledgehammer to crash through walls and ceilings, taking anything in sight, from the cash register to meat.

title: Indiana Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Prince, the Architects And a Question of Influence
description: Almost everyone who matters in British architecture was there - except the man who these days seems to matter most, Prince Charles.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Put trust in our policy of renewal. Your place is here. We need you.'' - Egon Krenz, the East German leader. [ 1:6. ]

title: SOVIETS TELEVISE DUBCEK INTERVIEW
description: Alexander Dubcek has appeared in a Soviet television interview for the first time since he was deposed as Czechoslovak leader when Soviet-led forces crushed the movement known as ''Prague Spring'' in 1968.

title: Gap to Close 9-Store Unit
description: The Gap Inc. said today that it would discontinue operations at its Hemisphere unit by the end of the fiscal year, resulting in a one-time expense of 25 cents a share in the fourth quarter.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Nature's Black Gold
description: Autumn's leaves should never be discarded. Decomposed leaves and garden debris are nature's black gold, the crumbly stuff that improves soil and makes plants grow better. And now that landfills are running out of space and burning leaves adds to air pollution, the best way to handle garden debris is to recycle it as compost. Here are seven steps to the perfect compost pile.

title: Hein-Werner Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Wittenberg, Cries for New Reformation on Date of Old One
description: It was difficult to imagine what Martin Luther, lying in his tomb under the cold stone floor, might have thought of the throng that packed every medieval inch of the castle church on the anniversary of the day in 1517 when he tacked his 95 theses to the door and so began the Reformation.

title: John Courtney Ivey, A Retired Lawyer, 86
description: John Courtney Ivey, a retired lawyer, died yesterday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 86 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: LaBarge Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $74,400 for the latest first quarter and $187,900, or 1 cent a share, for year-ago period.

title: Prohibition Was a Triumph for Minority Rule; Witness to the Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Bio-Rad Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net gain of 10 cents a share from a $1,800,000 gain from a litigation settlement, offset in part by a non-recurring $500,000 charge for the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: 5-Year Term In Texas Fraud
description: A Federal judge on Thursday sentenced Patrick G. King, the former president of Vernon Savings and Loan Association, to five years in prison and ordered him to pay $65,771 in fines for using the institution's money to pay for female escorts and illegal campaign contributions.

title: Ferocity of Final New Jersey Ads Angers Staffs of Both Candidates
description: As New Jersey Republicans welcomed the President and Barbara Bush to a pair of rousing campaign rallies today, a last-minute barrage of negative television and radio commercials left the staffs of both candidates for governor arguing over charges of distortion and racism.

title: IFR Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giuliani's Staff Matures In the Months of Combat
description: After spending much of his candidacy leading one of the most turbulent campaign organizations in New York in years, Rudolph W. Giuliani is nearing the close of his quest for the mayoralty with a relatively stable group of staff members, consultants and strategists.

title: California Deal By Qintex Lapses
description: The Qintex Group of Australia missed a payment this week on land in Southern California, allowing another deal in the United States to collapse. The entertainment and real estate company said it would not exercise an option to buy 115 acres in Dana Point, Calif. Qintex already owns nearby land and a golf and tennis club.

title: Midway Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,174,000, or 11 cents a share, from the utilization of net operating loss carryforward. c-Net income d-After extraordinary credits of $899,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,425,000, or 22 cents a share, for the 9 months, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: Strauss's 'Friedenstag' To Be Sung in New York
description: The New York premiere of Richard Strauss's opera ''Friedenstag'' will be presented by the Collegiate Chorale on Nov. 19 at 7:30 P.M. at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and West 57th Street. The one-act opera, which has a libretto by Joseph Gregor, will feature soloists and members of the New York City Gay Men's Chorus.

title: Dinkins's Team: Old Hands Join a Few Newcomers
description: The people working for David N. Dinkins's mayoral campaign, both inside and outside its Manhattan headquarters, may provide a clue to what a Dinkins administration might look like - a mix of reform and regular Democrats, labor leaders, lawyers and business executives and a smattering of newcomers to politics.

title: Capital Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $24,120,000, or 53 cents a share for the quarter, which reflected investment gain of $30,041,000 and amortization charge of $5,894,000, and $45,051,000, or $1.00 a share for the 9 months which reflected investment gain of $55,033,000 and amortization loss of $9,982,000. c-After extraordinary charges of $5,914,000 for the quarter which reflected investment loss of $8,687,000 and amortization gain of $2,773,000, and $3,891,000 for the 9 months which reflected investment loss of $6,421,000 and amortization gain of $2,530,000.

title: Ramada Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $4,314,000 and $2,633,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $563,000, or 1 cent a share, for both periods. c-Net income

title: B&H Ocean Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and reflected one-time fees of $2,788,395 relating to initial bridge loan financings. Year-ago 9-month figures were not available because the company began its operations upon completion of its initial public offering on Aug. 17, 1988. Corrected from Thursday, Nov. 2.

title: Ronson Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $85,000 related to a 1986 grant by Ronson Metals Corp. of a non-exclusive licensing agreement for Neodymium Technology and $398,000 from the settlement of a long-term receivable which had been reserved. c-Included a gain of $92,000 from an abatement of interest and penalties for prior years' taxes for both periods, and the 9 months also included net from operations which included $77,000 from the reversal of prior legal expense accruals. d-Net income

title: Salvador Asks Renewed Talks
description: President Alfredo Cristiani said tonight that leftist rebels had broken their word by announcing that they would withdraw from negotiations, but he reiterated his determination to find a political settlement to the Salvadoran civil war.

title: U.S. Car Sales Dropped 2.5% In Final 10 Days of October

title: 97 Missing in Capsizing
description: An American-owned oil drilling ship with 97 people aboard capsized early today after a typhoon swept through the Gulf of Thailand with 100-mile-per-hour winds. Barry Lane, a spokesman for the Los Angeles-based Unocal oil company, said six survivors had been rescued in heavy seas about 270 miles south of Bangkok, but that they were Thai fishermen, not crew from the capsized Seacrest drilling vessel. No survivors of the Seacrest had been found by late this morning.

description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary charge of $8,097,000. The year-ago figures have been restated.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds Decline on Job Data
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dropped and Treasury bill rates climbed yesterday, partly because of a larger-than-expected rise in nonfarm employment last month and partly because of a Congressional stalement over legislation that would raise the national debt ceiling.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST, SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Panel Concludes U.S. Lacks Data To Assess Offshore Drilling Impact
description: In a setback to supporters of offshore drilling, a panel of the National Academy of Sciences has concluded that the Government lacks enough information to assess the environmental consequences of oil and gas drilling off the coasts of California and Florida.

title: CAE Industries Studying Changes

Toronto-based CAE bought the four companies that make up the CAE-Link Corporation of Washington from the Singer Company for $560 million in August 1988.

title: Have We Forgotten About the Bomb?

description: b-Included a pretax charge of $3,100,000 for anticipated expenditures in connection with various environmental matters. c-Net income

title: Review/Theater; Love and Loss and the Salve of Time
description: In the final play of Reynolds Price's trilogy, ''New Music,'' a father reveals a closely guarded family secret to his son. The moment is both intimate and wryly amusing - and it is followed by other personal intimations. After almost six hours in the company of an extended family in a small North Carolina town, we come to recognize the characters as old friends and to feel the tautness of the bonds of blood, marriage and acquaintanceship.

title: New Lead Is Reported In Etan Patz Mystery
description: The unsolved case of Etan Patz, who disappeared at the age of 6 from a street in Manhattan's SoHo section a decade ago, has developed a new lead focusing suspicion on a convicted child molester now in custody, WNBC-TV reported yesterday.

title: Bird Scores 32 in Return
description: Larry Bird scored Boston's first 6 points and had 32 over all last night as the Celtics beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 127-114, for their 11th consecutive opening victory at home. Bird, who played six games before undergoing heel surgery last Nov. 19, got 13 of the Celtics' first 17 points and made his first 3-point attempt. Bullets 116, Hornets 96

description: New York City needs a strong, streamlined government to deal with the challenges it faces in the next decade. description: The Nicaraguan contras said today that they could not attend peace talks with the Nicaraguan Government in New York next week.

title: Swift Action Is Predicted on a Congressional Plan to Cut the Deficit
description: Senate leaders said today that they expected swift Congressional agreement on a deficit reduction plan that would restore $16.1 billion in spending that was eliminated when automatic budget cuts went into effect last month.

description: Donald White, a 17-year-old honors student, dreamed of going to the University of North Carolina and had planned to take a college entrance examination today. Instead, he will be buried, a victim of random violence.

title: Robec Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are pro forma. The company had been a subchapter S corporation through Sept. 30, and was not responsible for federal and certain state income taxes at the corporate level. Pro forma net income was calculated as if such taxes had been insurred.

title: Giuliani Ads Remain Harsh In Last Days
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, confronted by public opinion polls that suggest his effort to upset David N. Dinkins is flagging, unleashed two commercials yesterday for the final weekend of the New York City mayoral campaign that are sharply critical of Mr. Dinkins.

description: Subway motormen, bus drivers, maintenance workers and thousands of other public employees in ''safety sensitive'' jobs in New York City's transit system will soon be subject to random drug tests, the Transit Authority announced yesterday.

title: Stephen Edlich, 45, Artist, Dies
description: Stephen Edlich, a painter admired for his deft re-combination of elements from the classic era of European modernism, was found dead yesterday in his studio in Manhattan. He was 45 years old. A police spokesman said the cause of death had not been determined.

title: Corrections
description: The Washington Talk column on Thursday about California's place in the Presidential primaries referred incorrectly to California's allotment of delegates to Presidential nominating conventions. While Republicans have apportioned them winner-take-all, the Democrats have split them among the candidates since 1976.

title: Skaters' AIDS Benefit
description: World and Olympic champion figure skaters will perform on Monday, Nov. 6, at 8:15 P.M. at the New York State Armory, Lexington Avenue at 26th Street, in ''Skating for Life,'' a benefit for the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS. The skaters include Tai Babilonia and Randy Gardner, Judy Blumberg, Robin Cousins, John Curry, Scott Hamilton; JoJo Starbuck and Ken Shelley. Beneficiaries will include the St. Vincent's Hospital Care Program and a fund for skaters and other athletes with AIDS. Tickets for the performance alone are $62.50 and $125 and may be purchased at the door. Single tickets for the performance, a cocktail reception and a gala dinner-dance range from $350 to $1,000. Information: 727-3100.

title: DATA UPDATE: November 5, 1989
A Masterpiece in Maryland
description: WITH a payment of $200,000 to a Confederate general on July 9, 1864, the officials of Frederick, Md., saved their hundreds of antebellum buildings from being burned to the ground. The general, Jubal Early, called the payment a contribution, but his subsequent burning down of Chambersburg, Pa., proved extortion was a more accurate term. Frederick officials borrowed the money from five local banks, which financed the loan with bond issues, the last payment being made on Oct. 1, 1951. Senator Charles McC. Mathias of Maryland estimated that the $200,000-plus interest compounded annually since 1864 at 4 percent amounted to almost $14 million, but he never succeeded in persuading Congress that the Government was obligated to reimburse Frederick ''for value received by the Union.''

title: Officials See String of Navy Accidents as Random
description: Current and former Navy officials insist that the succession of accidents this week was more a random illustration of the dangers of life at sea than a sign of deficiencies in training or maintenance.

title: Hiring of Women by U.N. Falls Short of Goal

title: Review/Music; String Quartets in Three Idioms
description: At once compatible and contradictory were the first two items on Wednesday's program by the Tokyo String Quartet at the 92d Street Y. Mozart - whose Quartet in G (K. 387) began the evening - was perhaps the first of our confessional composers. This confiding, commiserating tone established an intimacy between musician and listener that became the modus operandi of 19th-century music. It is an inheritance that passed to Shostakovich in our own time and survives in his Seventh String Quartet, which followed the Mozart on Wednesday.

title:

description: LEAD: The Miami Heat brought out the good and the bad in the Knicks last night.

title: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER
description: About the first paragraph in Peggy Noonan's article, the one is which she imagines ''cradling'' President Reagan's ''beautiful'' foot ''wagging merrily.'' Did anybody else think that was somewhat weird? Or is it just me? THOMAS HACKETT Brooklyn

title:
SPECIAL REPORT: THE AVERAGE STUDENT;
Call of the Bard
description: LEAD: In the George Washington School auditorium in White Plains, N.Y., parents held their breath, skeptical siblings hushed and a stage spot came up on a little boy decked out in a fur-trimmed red robe and crown. ''If music be the food of love, play on,'' commanded Dennis Brady, age 9, in a clear, strong voice.

title: Touchstone Has A Recognizable Touch
description: ''The Bear,'' as it might have been made by Touchstone Pictures: Bart, the 2,000-pound grizzly, would not star. Bart is high-priced and makes a lot of demands - e.g., six whole chickens and a lot of fruit punch every day - so his more accommodating understudy, Doc, might be a better idea. The British Columbian scenery, which was actually filmed in the Bavarian Alps, need not be quite as authentic; it could be augmented by studio-built sets. Jean-Jacques Annaud, the French director who devoted vast amounts of expensive effort to this project, is far too much of a perfectionist. Perhaps Leonard Nimoy would be available.

title: The Actor's Art In TV Commercials
description: LEAD: SO you want to be in commercials. Joanne Ritchie and Mary Denham might be able to help.

title: Review/Theater; Neil Simon's Dismal New York City
description: To be sure, life in New York City has its drawbacks. Crime is rampant, pollution is everywhere and nothing works: if the hospitals or the garbage men aren't on strike, the water is turned off. But it could be worse. You could have Mel Edison as a neighbor.

title: Quebec's French-Speakers Worry Less Now
description: A pattern that has disturbed Quebec's French-speaking population for two decades - a plunging birth rate that has threatened to undermine the province's place as the last French-speaking bastion in North America - appears to be easing.

title: Prospects; An Even Slower Economy
description: The economy grew by 2.5 percent in the third quarter, and the unemployment rate for October was virtually unchanged from the month before at 5.3 percent. But employment did soften in the manufacturing sector as sales of American-made autos plummeted. So where is the economy headed? Four economists offer their views. Walter Joelson Chief economist, General Electric Company.

title: Reviews/Dance; From Joffrey, Pop Music And Some Kinetic Steps
description: Entertainment for a general audience has always been basic to the Joffrey Ballet's artistic policy, and Friday night's program offered a good example - an accent on popular music and on the kinetic aspect of classical dancing.

title: Montauk
description: To the Editor: The story about Montauk by David Laskin (''History at the Tip of Long Island,'' Travel, Aug. 27) raised fond memories dating back more than 50 years. In those days Montauk was a landscape serene, beautiful and unspoiled by suburban sprawl. And I recall that the Long Island Rail Road had a Fisherman's Special from Penn Station. One point in the history of Montauk was overlooked, however, namely that Carl Fisher envisioned Montauk as the terminus for trans-Atlantic liners. Passengers would board or disembark at their option in Montauk, making the rest of the journey by rail. A seven-story office building was erected for this purpose. It was intended to house Customs and Immigration Service offices as well as the offices of steamship lines and other travel-related businesses. ERICH A. MARX Elmhurst, Queens

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Injuries in The N.F.L.?
description: Yes; players are bigger, stronger and faster, but the philosophy of coaching remains the same: ''Hit or get hit, hurt or get hurt, maim or get maimed, intimidate or get intimidated.'' CHRIS SWEENEY Northport, L.I.

description: LEAD: THE students of Ridgefield High School have spoken: they don't want the now-famous mural of the rock star Jimi Hendrix removed from their school's wall.

description: LEAD: CARIBBEAN By James A. Michener. 672 pp. New York: Random House. $22.95.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK is the nation's largest university system, with 389,544 students spread over 64 campuses. New York, the country's second most populous state, is also home to 332 other colleges and universities, the most of any state in the union. California comes in second with 314 colleges and universities, followed by Texas with 171. Wyoming, the most sparsely populated state, is tied with Nevada for the fewest institutions of higher learning; both have nine. - United States Department of Education

title: HELPING CONSTITUENTS OR THEMSELVES?
description: In defending their role in helping a financially shaky savings and loan, five Senators appear to be offering a dramatically broadened definition of ''constituent service.''

title: Pennies to Pay Fines Do Not Please Court
description: Three motorists given speeding tickets each sent the St. Clair Circuit Court clerk $50 in pennies to pay for the fines, and the clerk says he will not accept them.

title: On Language; Nice, Bossy
description: SODA JERKS (NOW called >fountain attendants) know that a >black cow is a root beer float. What of >cash cow? ''It is apparent that [ Mortimer ] Zuckerman has improved the magazine during a very difficult period for newsmagazines,'' wrote Eleanor Randolph of The Washington Post about the owner of the competing U.S. News & World Report. But, ''On the business level, the magazine is no longer the >cash cow it once was.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: When the 0-8 Dallas Cowboys take the field against the Washington Redskins today, the starting Dallas quarterback will be Steve Walsh, not his fellow rookie, Troy Aikman, according to Coach Jimmy Johnson, who said that Aikman had not made enough progress in recovering from a finger injury to reclaim the job. . . . Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Maverick forward who disappeared before a game a week ago, passed a drug test given after his return to the team, according to the medical director of the N.B.A. players after-care program.

title: Island Haven For Wildlife In Georgia
description: GEORGIA'S last family-owned barrier island and a wilderness resort, Little St. Simons, about halfway between Savannah and Jacksonville, Fla., is not to be confused with neighboring St. Simons, a 15-minute boat ride away, which it caps like a beret. St. Simons has sleek golf and tennis resorts, condominium colonies and shopping malls. Little St. Simons is essentially a 10,000-acre wildlife preserve, abounding in deer, birds, rabbits, alligators, sea turtles, rattlesnakes, armadillos and countless other species benign and malign.

title: Bus Shelter on Wrong Corner to Be Moved
description: Life in New York City, Stephen H. Feinberg has learned the hard way, is tough.

title: Two at Security Agency Face Drug Charges
description: An Air Force lieutenant colonel and his wife, both psychologists assigned to the National Security Agency, were arrested on drug-selling charges Friday when police officers raided their house in the Washington suburb of Crofton, Md.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: Collectors are so accustomed to coins that are round and flat that anything else seems a little bit silly. But some coins evolved into shapes other than disks and these exotic shapes made a lot of sense in their times.

title: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
description: You may or may not agree with the pharmaceutical heir's testament, but it was his last will and desire to make his wife of 12 years the heir of his fortune (''Lech's American Angel,'' by David Margolick, Oct. 8).

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. After a shower, water accumulated in the tub to a depth of seven inches. After several hours, I removed the drain stopper and tried a 3-foot-long snake, but this did not help. Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine. I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet. After about 1 1/2 gallons had been dipped out, the water in the tub slurped out rapidly. What happened?

title: Miss Cohen Wed To R. S. Bernard
description: Anne Terry Cohen and Russel Samuel Bernard were married last evening at the Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Melvin Sirner and Cantor Lawrence Avery officiated. The bride is the daughter of Pearl A. Cohen of Hartsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Alan I. Cohen. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Bernard of Great Neck and Remsenburg, L.I.

title: MORE AIR ROUTES FOR U.S. AND JAPAN
description: Japan and the United States have reached agreement on a major expansion of airplane flights between the two countries, the Bush Administration said today.

title: Choosing the Site For a Firehouse
description: In the well-balanced coverage of the Ridgewood firehouse controversy (''Village Needs a New Firehouse but Cannot Settle on a Site,'' Oct. 1), one point needs clarification.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Buxton, Me.; A Lesson For Novices
description: THE first time Joel Gold saw the old chicken barn on five acres of rolling meadow in this southern Maine town, he thought ''terrific investment.'' Now, almost three years later, his thoughts may be unprintable.
