title: Shedding Light on Evil Men and a Sinister Time
description: One of the more alarming chapters in recent American history is an often overlooked episode from the 1920's. The wonder is that a time so filled with evil men and frightening doings has remained in obscurity; that it didn't scare Americans half to death. And that such an episode has only now been given dramatic re-creation, in a two-part NBC mini-series, ''Cross of Fire.''

title: Statement to Davis Trial Jury
description: Already sentenced to up to 15 years on a weapons conviction and still facing separate charges of murder, kidnapping, assault on correction officers and automobile theft, Larry Davis went on trial last week on murder charges in the fatal shooting of a Harlem drug dealer.

title: High Flyers
description: INEXPENSIVE air charters for college students on holiday, begun in the 1960's in the spirit of backpacks and Europe-on-$5-a-day, have gone sharply upscale in recent years. Today they are a profitable way for alumni associations to cultivate and maintain close ties to wealthy graduates.

title: A 1917 Police Ledger Shows Nothing's New
description: LEAD: AT first glance, the large yellow pages, inscribed in sprawling, old-fashioned handwriting, convey the quaintness of a simpler era. The recently uncovered ''Daily Record, Jamesburg Police'' chronicles events in the town for several years, beginning in 1917, three years before the New Jersey State Police came into being and 51 years before a full-time force began in surrounding Monroe Township, in which tiny

title:
INVESTING;
Single-Country Funds Ascend
description: LEAD: In recent months, shares of single-country funds have leaped wildly, leaving many investors baffled. But analysts say fund prices have been pushed up in a speculative frenzy that has little relation to fundamental values.

title: For Hindus, a Temple of Their Own
description: FOR 10 years, Hindus in Connecticut have worshipped in a community center and a school cafeteria or traveled out of the state. Now, they have a temple of their own, the first of its kind in the state.

title: FLASHCARD
description: ONE in six public-school teachers works at an outside job for additional income during the school year. Almost a fifth work outside the school system during the summer. Of teachers who moonlight, just over a quarter do so only during the school year, 36 percent only during the summer recess and another 36 percent throughout the year.

title: High Hopes: A Roundup of Opinion
description: In our Catholic school system, that's mostly what we have - normal average students, for whom parents and educators should have very high expectations. They should be encouraged in their critical thinking skills. They should be opinionated yet open to different opinions.

title: Venetian Glass: Ancient Designs, Modern Accents
description: ''The Venetians: Modern Glass 1919-90,'' the largest exhibition of post-World War I Venetian glass vessels ever mounted in New York, now fills the Muriel Karasik gallery, 1094 Madison Avenue, at 82d Street. It will remain through Dec. 2.

title: Computer Trading Put on a Leash
description: Curbs on computerized trading of stocks are being established by the Big Board in an effort to reduce market volatility. The New York Stock Exchange chairman, John J. Phelan, said investor confidence was being eroded by violent swings in stock prices. Pressure for such a move has been mounting in reaction to the 190- point plunge in the market on Oct. 13 and the volatility in subsequent days. In the last two weeks most big Wall Street firms, under prodding from large clients, said they would cease index arbitrage for their own accounts. The Big Board's changes include asking large traders to refrain from trades that ''destabilize'' the market and curbing the use of a computerized order system when stock prices are falling. The first limit on program trading, a 15-minute delay on orders, would be imposed when the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 30 points. *

title: Cameron C. Adams and John J. Soroko Are Wed
description: Cameron Colket Adams and John Jeming Soroko were married yesterday at the Cathedral Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Robert Schenkel Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Where a Marching Band Is Like a Walking Organ
description: WHEN the 61 young men and 8 young women of the United States Merchant Marine Academy's band had taken seats and Capt. Kenneth Force started them into their 7:15 A.M. rehearsal, a visitor at the rehearsal heard a familiar, endearing sound.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ROSEANNE: My Life as a Woman. By Roseanne Barr. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) By now, Roseanne Barr's fabulous climb to fame - from cocktail waitress who insulted her customers to Johnny Carson ''discovery'' to the star of the country's most-watched television show - is familiar. And so, as befits any bona fide phenomenon, she has written a book.

title: TALKING: Sanctions; Making Residents Obey Rules
description: DOES a condominium association or co-operative corporation have the right to fine a resident who repeatedly leaves his umbrella and galoshes in the corridor, in violation of the house rules? And what if that person is also tardy in paying regular monthly charges? Does the board have the right to assess a late fee?

title: Reviving The Dormant Shellfish Industry
description: LEAD: IN a remote corner of West Harbor, the major marine thoroughfare on Fishers Island, Steve Malinowski is working hard to keep his aquaculture company solvent.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: VIVIEN LEHMAN;
A Campaign For Chinese Liberty Grows
description: LEAD: IT has been more than six months since Vivian Lehman got angry. The 22-year-old Bedford woman said that after watching television reports of the clash between Chinese students and the Chinese Government, she felt compelled to do something.

title: Power Lines and Battle Lines
description: IN the 1960's, the phrase ''power to the people'' called to mind protest marches and gatherings at Woodstock. In 1989, it has taken on a new meaning for the 70,000 residents of Middletown, where my colleagues and I are leading a fight against the power lines proposed by a public utility.

title: Spain Shifts Toward Right Edge Of the Socialist Order
description: AT a time of ideological confusion on the European left, with both Communists and social democrats struggling to redefine their philosophies, the re-election of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party last Sunday raised a fascinating question: Was this a victory or a defeat for socialism?

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We need to take short-term action to prove that the markets are not becoming pools of speculation. We have declared war on excess volatility.'' John J. Phelan Jr., chairman, the New York Stock Exchange.

title: At a Carousel Show, Hand-Carved Ferocity and Gaudy Charm
description: LEAD: FLASHING lights rotate beneath a curved red and white striped canopy at the entrance to Carousel Menagerie, the exhibition on view through Jan. 7 at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: Did Bigotry Block a Medal That Valor in Battle Earned?
description: Army investigators will decide this month whether to recommend the Medal of Honor for a Jewish veteran who is said to have killed more than 500 Japanese soldiers in a single furious encounter in World War II but to have been denied the nation's highest military decoration because of anti-Semitism.

title: The Comics As Basic Skill
description: COMIC STRIPS and cartoons, first ridiculed by scholars and arbiters of high culture and then exploited by them in pop art, are gradually broadening their influence in the classroom.

title: DO DRUG MAKERS GIVE MAIL HOUSES A SPECIAL DEAL?
description: The protests of retail pharmacists have not slowed the rapid growth of prescriptions sold by mail - at least not yet.

title: Jennifer Schultz Plans to Marry Bruce Demaree
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Schultz of Scarsdale , N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Lockhart Schultz, to Bruce Allan Demaree, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan T. Demaree, also of Scarsdale. A June Wedding is planned.

title: Nether Regions
description: To the Editor:

title: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
description: Your article on Basia Johnson gave me a sense of deja-vu; she seems so much like that other immensely wealthy ''queen'' who has been in the news lately. Who knows, she may be able to do for Polish shipbuilding what Leona Helmsley has done for the New York hotel business. Even if the Gdansk shipyard venture fails, she still gets a tax write-off. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Lexington, Ky.

title: ADVANCE GUARD FOR THE Y.M.C.A.
description: GOLDEN INCHES The China Memoir of Grace Service. Edited by John S. Service. Illustrated. 346 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $19.95.

title: An American Accent for Teachers From Abroad
description: DURING a class at Syracuse University this fall, Athanasios Captanis kept looking at himself in the mirror and talking just to hear the sound of his own voice. As his teachers were quick to point out, this was no exercise in narcissism for Mr. Captanis, a 24-year-old doctoral student in chemical engineering from Greece. He was striving to improve his pronunciation of English - and doing very well.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WAR BABIES. By Frederick Busch. (New Directions, $15.95.) This short novel explores several ambitious themes: war and its aftermath, the nature of evil, the corrosive power of guilt. In the fall of 1984, a 35-year-old American lawyer, Peter Santore, travels to London in order to find Hilary Pennels, whose father died in a Korean prisoner-of-war camp.

title: Carolyn G. Duffus Married
description: The marriage of Carolyn Geary Duffus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Duffus of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Michael John Mulrain, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Mulrain of Worcester, Mass., took place yesterday at Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church in Centerville, Mass. The Rev. Joseph Marcotte officiated. The bride, 29 years old, is an interior designer in Marblehead, Mass. Mr. Mulrain, 30, is a senior manager in Boston for the New York accounting firm of Touche Ross & Company.

title: Kean's Successor to Face Lean Times
description: New Jersey's new governor will inherit a state budget that has doubled to $12 billion in eight years but is now static and teetering on uncertain revenue projections.

title: Sisters With Mission to Accomplish
description: These are siblings without a rivalry.

title: Hair-Raising Policies
description: AS AMERICAN educators labor under the perception of rapidly deteriorating schools, many administrators are turning to dress codes and hair-length restrictions in what they say is an attempt to improve the environment in which students study and learn.

title: U.S. Challenges New York's Retirement of Judge
description: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has brought a lawsuit challenging a New York State constitutional provision that prevents judges from serving beyond the age of 76.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LOVERS AND FRIENDS. By Camille Marchetta. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) With ''Lovers and Friends,'' the novel as reference book comes into its own. Readers anxious to improve their social standing by adopting the right way of dress or the proper lunch venue have long had many sourcebooks available to them.

title: EX MACHINA: Computer Redux
description: THE TEACHERS and administrators of William B. Travis High School in Austin, Tex., have a vision: they want to transform Travis into a world-class school with an emphasis on the study of global issues, using computers and other advanced technology.

title: Sandlot Sentencing
description: As big-time athletes go, Deion Sanders, the Yankee outfielder turned Atlanta Falcon cornerback-kick returner, would seem to be an especially appropriate role model for American youth. As Jesse Rechtenwald, the president of the East Fort Myers Little League Association in Florida, put it: ''Here's a guy who doesn't do drugs, who doesn't smoke, who doesn't drink. He's never done any of that stuff.''

title: From Headphones to the Record Business
description: Why would an audio manufacturer that has thrived for more than three decades on prudent specialization (stereo headphones) suddenly choose to enter the classical-record market in a time of glut and confusion? To hear Michael J. Koss, the president of the Koss Corporation and now the executive producer of Koss Classics, tell it, the motive was idealism pure and simple.

title: Payday in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: A Baritone Who Isn't Bound to Opera
description: LEAD: TIMOTHY NOLEN, the noted baritone who shifts effortlessly between musical theater and operatic stages, has a pet theory that could change the way Americans perceive both art forms.

title: POSTINGS: East Side Air Rights; Town House Shell Game
description: In a city in which real estate projects tend toward the mammoth, one under way on the Upper East Side might easily qualify as the smallest of the year. Developers have bought for $750,000 the shell of a 17-foot-wide house at 344 East 72d Street, near First Avenue, and are turning it into a single-family, four-story town house to be marketed for $2.5 million. The unusual project stems from the sale of the air rights of the property. To maximize the volume that was transferred to the adjoining Le Chambord condominium before it was built, the developers of the larger property, St. James Properties, removed the front 10 feet of the smaller building before selling it. The result was a 2,700-square-foot shell without a facade. KMS Partners of Manhattan, which is renovating the remains, is rebuilding the house to the rear with 3,200 square feet containing four bedrooms, four bathrooms, a dining room with a cathedral ceiling and an elevator.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the New York City Marathon, these streets will be closed to traffic in Manhattan for much of this morning and afternoon: First Avenue from 59th Street to the Willis Avenue Bridge, Fifth Avenue from 136th Street to 102d Street and Central Park South from Fifth Avenue to Broadway. In addition, some traffic lanes on the Queensboro Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge, the Madison Avenue Bridge and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge will be closed.

title: FLASHCARD
description: TWO in three college professors in a recent poll said that the schools where they teach ''spend too much time and money teaching students what they should have learned in high school.'' In addition, 75 percent of the professors in the poll said undergraduates were seriously underprepared in basic skills. - Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching

title: U.S. in Crucial Qualifier
description: The United States soccer team needs 3 points from two games to qualify for the World Cup finals in Italy next summer and it is expected to get 2 of them Sunday against El Salvador.

title: Test
description: Are you average? Find out using the Scholastic Aptitude Test, the college etrance exam. These questions were answered correctly by the majority of average-scoring S.A.T. test-takers several years ago. According to the Educational Testing Service, which writes the exam, the average adult or high school senior today should do equally well, since test scores have remained fairly stable in recent years. MATH

title: Concerns About Growth Raise Interest in Local Races
description: VOTERS in 158 municipalities will go to the polls on Tuesday to elect first selectmen and mayors, but in Fairfield, Westport and a number of other towns the contests for local zoning boards are attracting as much attention as the races for the top office.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
In St. Paul, Workers Take Kindergarten With Them
description: LEAD: TWENTY-THREE parents with jobs downtown in Minnesota's capital of St. Paul now have something extra to drop off on their way to work - their children.

title: Shanghai's Mayor Gains Credit as Pragmatist
description: When a foreigner asks young Chinese to name the leaders that they respect, the usual response is a long silence. But a few names do spark some enthusiasm, and one that comes up most regularly is Zhu Rongji, the boss of Shanghai.

title: Need a Lawyer For a Few Hours? Hire a 'Temp'
description: LEAD: SHELLEY WALLACE, a lawyer who lives in West Hartford, knew she was not the only working mother feeling the stress of too much time at the office and too little time at home with her children. So she expected to hear from others like herself in 1987 when she started an employment agency, the Wallace Law Registry, specializing in finding temporary work for lawyers and paralegals.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED IN SCIENCE WITHOUT REALLY CHEATING
description: CANTOR'S DILEMMA By Carl Djerassi. 230 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: MY LIMO OR YOURS?
description: THE STARK TRUTH By Peter Freeborn. 304 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: More Than Just Another Dr. Kildare
description: From Dr. Ehrlich to Dr. Kildare, from Paul Muni to Richard Chamberlain, from yellow fever to black lung, medicine and entertainment have long been bedfellows. By now, the medical drama tends to run as predictable a course as the common cold. The dedicated young doctor sets out on the road to the cure for something dire; he works hard, makes personal sacrifices, meets rebuffs, almost despairs - then succeeds.

title: Fashions; The Fashion in Getting Fit
description: The impact of the fitness craze on ready-to-wear styles is apparent in the leggings and cropped tops seen on the street. But exercise clothing is also led by fashion trends, like layering, component dressing, seasonal colors and animal prints.

title: Helen Elizabeth Finkenstaedt Is Wed
description: Helen Elizabeth Finkenstaedt, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Harry Seymour Finkenstaedt of Cambridge, England, was married yesterday to Joseph Emile Coleman 3d, a son of Mrs. Frederick Birney Finkenstaedt of Washington and Mr. Coleman Jr. of Clifton, N.J. The Rev. Elijah B. White 3d performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour at the Oatlands estate in Hamilton, Va.

title: Tracing Doctors Who Err
description: UNDER a new Federal program, doctors and dentists who accumulate a long list of malpractice decisions and disciplinary actions will no longer be able to hide from their past simply by moving to another state. But critics of the program complain that it will not serve those who need it most - patients.

title: Metrotech
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER RATES
Accidents Do Not 'Just Happen'
description: I am responding to ''Say 'Be Careful,' Hope They're Safe'' [ Westchester Opinion, Oct. 15 ] by Paul Levine. He says of a girl's death in a traffic accident: ''No one was drinking. It wasn't anyone's fault. It just happened.''

title: Edith Wharton, Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Oysters With an Oriental Flavor
description: The 10th annual National Oyster Cook-Off, held each year in Leonardtown, Md., produced several wonderful prize-winning dishes on Oct. 21. Oysters Oriental took first place in the main-dish category for Dana Beer Gunnels, a native of Great Neck, L.I., and now a resident of Richmond.

title: Dropout Effort Is Expanding
description: LEAD: A PROGRAM to keep young people from dropping out of school, established by a consortium of corporate and educational partners, is expanding its efforts into five additional schools because of a recent state grant of $258,000.

title: General's Move to Dissolve Parliament Imperils Lebanese Accord
description: A fragile accord that held some hope of ending Lebanon's 14-year civil war appeared at risk of collapse tonight after Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian military leader, announced the dissolution of the Lebanese Parliament.

title: Adventuring In the Cloud Forests Of Ecuador
description: THE cloud forest of Ecuador sounded so gentle. It is, after all, jungle, that is to say, rain forest, but at altitudes high enough to eliminate the sweltering heat, ants, mosquitoes, malaria and even poisonous snakes. Its mountainous inclines make it perfect for trekking, more or less.

title: Playing One For Bucknell
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Cosmonauts to Caviar in the Soviet Union

title: Progressive Before Its Time
description: BY 1914, 30 years into a teaching career that began in a one-room schoolhouse, Caroline Pratt had developed serious doubts about her profession.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MACHIAVELLI IN HELL. By Sebastian de Grazia. (Princeton University, $39.95.) Sebastian de Grazia's book is an intellectual biography, an account of Niccolo Machiavelli's thought coupled with occasional forays into his life and times. The author, a professor of political philosophy at Rutgers University, seeks to demolish the popular notion of an evil, Machiavellian Machiavelli by arguing that he should be evaluated in political, rather than moral, terms.

title: Sunday Silence Turns Back Easy Goer
description: Sunday Silence grittily held off a desperate late charge by Easy Goer to win the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic by a neck today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Philanthropy for the 21st Century
description: The fourth-generation Rockefellers are confronted with their own mortality. As most of these heirs to one of the nation's wealthiest dynasties step deeper into middle age, they are searching for a meaningful way to leave their imprint.

title: Woman Fills Yard With Potatoes for Poor
description: LEAD: EACH month, a tractor-trailer from Maine fills Cynthia Kelly's backyard with 50,000 pounds of potatoes. The potatoes are usually gone in 24 hours, hauled away by poor people who flock to her house in New Haven with empty baby carriages and grocery carts to carry the 50-pound bags.

title: Veterans of Unpopular Wars Form Bonds
description: LEAD: WHILE backpacking in the Tien Shan Mountains in the Soviet Republic of Uzbekistan, a Tewksbury lawyer, Michael K. Heaney, learned that veterans of unpopular wars have similarities that transcend nationality, generation and political ideology.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Oct. 21 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $3 million 3 East 94th Street 5-story, 7,800-sq.-ft. single-family, Georgian town house; elevator, 10 fireplaces, spiral staircase, c/a, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $18,000 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Greenwich Village $375,000 3 Bedford Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,150-sq.-ft. condo in a 2-year-old building; dining area, marble bath, fireplace, balcony, c/a; common charge $322, taxes $1,596 (Broker: Corcoran Group) NoHo $448,000 330 Lafayette Street (Bleecker St.) 2,150-sq.-ft. open loft condo in a prewar building; 13 windows, high-ceilings, 3 exposures; common charge $498, taxes $4,076 (Broker: Sinvin Realty/Court Realty) Upper West Side $422,500 258 Riverside Drive (98th St.) 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,700-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining room, maid's room, library, maintenance $720, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Bellmarc Realty) Washington Heights $75,000 854 West 181st Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; large kitchen, hardwood floors; maintenance $370, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: Stein-Perry Real Estate) West Side $560,000 50 West 67th Street (Lincoln Park Towers) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; manned-elevator, maid's room, 2 fireplaces; maintenance $1,083, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Nancy R. Sweetser Real Estate) BRONX East Bronx $200,000 1892 Daly Street 3-family, detached, brick house; 4 bedrooms on third floor; 3 bedrooms in second; 2 bedrooms in first floor unit; 1 bath, large kitchens in each; 3-car garage; 25- by 150-ft. lot; taxes $1,300 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) Van Cortlandt Park Area $169,000 3829 Cannon Place 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, brick house; dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 69-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Charles G. Brophy & Associates) BROOKLYN Park Slope $273,000 118 8th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $860, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Brooklyn Properties of 7th Avenue) Prospect Park Area $235,000 44 Prospect Park West 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, Prospect Park view; maintenance $570, 33% tax-deductible (Broker: Warren Lewis Realty) QUEENS Forest Hills $435,000 78-12 Kew Forest Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached house; dining room, fireplace, solarium, finished basement, 1-car garage, 66- by 80-ft. lot; taxes $2,000 (Broker: Garden Plaza Realty) Kew Gardens $119,000 125-10 Queens Boulevard (Silver Towers) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 840-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, terrace; maintenance $507, includes gas and electricity, 47% tax-deductible (Broker: Rhona Realty) STATEN ISLAND Port Richmond $190,000 31 Tabb Place 2-family, detached, brick Cape Cod; 2 bedrooms in primary unit, 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; 1-car garage, 41- by 90-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Rand Properties) St. George $142,500 20 Bay Street Landing (Bay Street Landing) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,737-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining room, library, Manhattan view; maintenance $636, 58% tax-deductible (Broker: J.P. Walsh)

title: Chemical Makers Are Cleared in Lawsuit by Textile Workers
description: A Circuit Court jury has cleared three chemical manufacturers in a lawsuit brought by textile workers who claimed that exposure to a toxic material gave them a crippling lung disease.

title: Columbia Finds A Way to Lose
description: The memory of their 44-game losing steak faded last season when the Columbia Lions won twice. But the pressure of expectations has weighed heavily on the Lions this season. And with each loss, the load increases.

title: Musical Minds Of the Elderly
description: NEAR 91st Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, a motorist really needed to get someone's attention. The driver honked the horn - first a steady blare, then staccato beeping, then a fretful combination of the two.

title: Mexican President's Use of Army Draws Concern
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's use of the armed forces to deal with political, labor and crime problems has become a matter of growing concern as he nears the end of his first year in office.

title: CAN A NOVELIST SAVE PERU?
description: THE SMALL TWIN-ENGINE PLANE had pierced the layer of thick fog that blankets Lima each winter, and beyond the portholes there lay only an engulfing nothingness the color of unbleached bed linen. I was sitting next to the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, who had been making a half-hearted attempt to read a book he had brought along, but who was looking out now at the fog, thinking things.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; Where Even the Ivy Is Ivy-Covered
description: The last stretch of road to Princeton University winds through trees, past tilled fields and over Lake Carnegie, a body of water perfectly shaped - by design - for the sport of rowing. If, as on one Sunday in autumn, the lake is full of delicate boats powered by young people with considerable muscle definition, cheered on by banner-waving fans, the perfect collegiate moment may be experienced.

title: Review/Dance; BarriersIn Reveries Of Waiting
description: These people might have been trapped indoors on a rainy Sunday. From the looks of them, it was easy to believe they had been cooped up together for a whole month of rainy Sundays. What was there for them to do? Not much. So they waited. They twitched. They bickered. And calmed down.

title: New State Rule Limiting Medicaid Visits Is Causing Concern
description: In a Brooklyn neighborhood of gutted apartment buildings where homelessness and drug abuse are widespread, a community health clinic stands like a rampart against a long catalogue of urban woes.

title: A Case of Puppy Love
description: JUST the other day, while walking our new puppy, I was confronted by a car swerving across the road toward us as though it were intent on running us down. The driver, a well-dressed matron, rolled down her window in haste, stuck her head out and announced, ''I want to give him a big kiss on the nose.'' And she proceeded to do just that.

title: LifeStyle; Intimate Diplomacy: The Bra Talks
description: This just in from the SALT talks: The American representative, Irv Duchowny, says all signs point to a Soviet reduction in frumpiness and frowziness. The Americans are considering urging more lace and better elastic.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. After a shower, water accumulated in the tub to a depth of seven inches. After several hours, I removed the drain stopper and tried a 3-foot-long snake, but this did not help. Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine. I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet. After about 1 1/2 gallons had been dipped out, the water in the tub slurped out rapidly. What happened?

title: That Dammed Hercules By Bruce Weber
description: PAINTED ON THE FACE OF THE Tignes Dam, which is 250 meters long and 180 meters high, the portrait of Hercules by Jean-Marie Pierret is likely the world's largest fresco. A Herculean project in itself, it's also a reasonably apt symbol for the Olympic Games, which will arrive nearby, in Albertville, France, in the winter of 1992. Lent to Pierret for use as a canvas by EDF, the national electric company, the dam, at the northern end of Lake Chevril, is about a 50-mile southeasterly meander down the Isere River from Albertville.

title: THE TOAST OF PARIS, AND THEN SOME
description: LEAD: JAZZ CLEOPATRA Josephine Baker in Her Time. By Phyllis Rose. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York. Doubleday. $22.50.

title: Doreen Shulman Marries
description: Doreen F. Shulman and Richard L. Garelick, both graduates of Brooklyn Law School, were married last evening by Rabbi Stuart Geller at the Water's Edge Restaurant in Long Island City, Queens. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Howard Shulman of Hewlett, L.I., and Mrs. Sam Garelick of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Garelick. The bride, 27 years old, is an associate at the law firm of Fish & Neave. Mr. Garelick, also 27, is an associate at the law firm of Coti & Flicker, both in New York.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MAN WITHOUT MEMORY. By Richard Burgin. (University of Illinois, $14.95.) ''How justified are my fears? Does objective reality justify them or are my reactions more subjective than I realize?'' wonders an AIDS-obsessed woman in one of the nine stories that compose Richard Burgin's first collection, ''Man Without Memory.

title: Exxon Skipper Fails to Gain Immunity From Prosecution
description: The captain of the Exxon tanker that caused the worst oil spill in American history failed in a Federal court here Friday to halt the State of Alaska's criminal-mischief case against him.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: San Antonio
description: The first thing you notice about San Antonio is that it's so old. It was settled in 1718, and the buildings on the narrow streets seem to vibrate with history. This is true not only of the Alamo, which is the spiritual and physical center of downtown, but also of 18th-century missions scattered about the city, the gingerbread homes of the King William historic district and the bustling Mexican Market Square.

title: Review/Music; A Concert of New Music 'In Celebration of the Soloist
description: One approaches a new music concert called ''A Celebration of the Soloist'' and containing a piece called ''Narcissus'' with some suspicion. One of the minor illnesses of postwar composition has been the instrumental solo as scientific experiment, whereby acoustical and mechanical properties are stretched and music is lost in the performer's self-absorption.

title: Campus Life: Rhode Island; As Budget Is Cut, Library Cancels Its Newspapers
description: Starting Jan. 1, students at the University of Rhode Island will no longer be able to go the campus library to read current issues of their favorite domestic and foreign newspapers.

title: They Tried to Give Beethoven a Bad Name
description: When Richard Sterba died at the age of 91 the other day in Grosse Pointe, Mich., the obituary duly noted that ''Dr. Sterba specialized in the psychoanalytic study of artists, publishing biographies of Beethoven and Michelangelo.'' From that terse description one might not have gathered that this was the same Dr. Sterba whose posthumous psychoanalysis of Beethoven scandalized at least half of the music world in the 1950's and, while no longer the subject of hot debate, is still a cornerstone of musical psychobiography. The very name of Sterba with its morbid, Germanic overtones, became oppressive to many music appreciators who had learned all they knew about Beethoven from pious program notes and standard iconographies that often were no more than reverential rewrites of Thayer's 19th-century documentary classic.

title:
ART;
Printmaking as Exploration
description: LEAD: WHEN obsessed with an idea that seems valid, artists like to test and probe, exploring different steps as they carry out their thoughts.

title: Indispensable Witness to High Drama
description: Touring the majestic exhibition of paintings and drawings by Jacques-Louis David that has just opened both in the Louvre and in the Chateau de Versailles, this critic remembered what happened a year or two ago when curators all over the world were wondering how best to mark the bicentennial year of the French Revolution of 1789. The talk was halted every time by just one little question: ''What are we going to do about David?'' It is through David's eyes, above all, that those who live by art have always seen the French Revolution.

title: Black Politicians Are Leaning Against Some Old Barriers
description: THE transformation of American politics that began 24 years ago with the passage of the Voting Rights Act may be about to enter a new era.

title: Save Your Praise
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FROG IN LOVE Written and illustrated by Max Velthuijs. Translated by Anthea Bell. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 3 and up)

title: Campus Life: Dickinson; Rushing Halted While a Death Is Investigated
description: Pending an investigation of the death on Sept. 29 of a freshman who fell out a bedroom window at Alpha Chi Rho, the Dickinson College faculty has suspended fraternity and sorority rushes.

title: Q and A
description: Getting a Code Copy

title: Quake Jars Western Nevada
description: A mild earthquake centered in rural Alpine County, Calif., shook western Nevada and parts of the Sierra Nevada on Friday. There were no reports of injuries or damage. The quake registered 4.3 on the Richter scale of ground movement, said Pat Jorgenson of the United States Geological Survey in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Review/Dance; A Debut at the Joffrey In Billy the Kid's Role
description: Douglas Martin made his debut in the title role of Eugene Loring's ''Billy the Kid'' at the Joffrey Ballet's performance on Wednesday night at the City Center Theater. His portrayal was notable for many details.

title: Tokyo String Quartet
description: The Tokyo String Quartet is to play an all-Beethoven program at Washington Irving High School, 16th Street and Irving Place, at 8 o'clock tonight. The program includes the Quartet No. 6 in B flat (Op. 18, No. 6), No. 13 in B flat (Op. 130) and No. 8 in E minor (Op. 59, No. 2). Tickets are $3. Information: 586-4680.

title: Concern Over the Costs Of Malpractice Liability
description: ''A CHILD falls off a swing and bumps his head,'' Dr. Otis R. Bowen, a physician and former Secretary of Health and Human Services, used to tell visitors. ''In the old days, you'd tell him to go home and put ice on it. Now you give him $100 worth of X-rays and maybe a CAT scan, and then you tell him to go home and put ice on it.''

title: Review/Pop; Some Good Dirty Fun
description: In a series of mock violent skits by the group Gwar at the Rapp Arts Center on Monday night, heads rolled, blood spurted into the audience, a mutant animal wrestled with a Roman centurion and oversize sex organs appeared in various forms.

title: Stephanie Kossar Weds Jan Stuart
description: The marriage of Stephanie Joyce Kossar and Jan Stuart was performed by Rabbi David N. Posner in New York last evening at the Plaza hotel. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard R. Kossar of Palm Beach, Fla. Her husband is a son of Norma Siegel of Floral Park, Queens, and William R. Siegel of Bellrose, Queens.

title: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER
description: Let's face it, Peggy Noonan is a genius (along with Ronald Reagan's public relations magicians).

title: POSTINGS: City Affordables; Show and Tell
description: It might have escaped the attention of many New Yorkers, but some affordable housing has been built throughout the city in the last few years in spite of all the problems of financing, design and land acquisition.

title: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER
description: The feminist movement served Ms. Noonan well, as is clear from more than just her presence in the White House.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ENGLISH HOUSES

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Posing With Pumpkins

title: Carson on the Move in Major Ways
description: Jimmy Carson, a precocious talent, did this week what professional athletes can't always do, especially at the age of 21, especially in hockey and especially after only three seasons in the big time.

title: Japan's Foreign Aid Problem
description: Yoshito Kimura has a $23.5 billion headache.

title: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER
description: Peggy Noonan paints a rather bleak picture of the pervasive White House milieu - one in which staff members are encouraged to be ''average'' and where, thanks to speechwriters, the Administration ''got invented every day.''

title: FLASHCARD
description: THREE-QUARTERS of the class of 1986 with bachelor's degrees had full-time jobs within a year of graduation. An additional 11 percent were employed part time, and almost 3 in 10 had continued their education beyond a bachelor's degree. Eighty-five percent of the 1986 degree recipients in business and management found full-time employment by 1987, the most likely field of study to do so. However, they were also the least likely majors to have gone on for additional formal training. Conversely, fewer than half the graduates with degrees in biological sciences were employed a year later, but more than 60 percent had continued their education. - National Center for Education Statistics

title: PITCHING DOCTORS
description: THE SUDDEN DEATH LAST JUNE OF JOHN Matuszak, once a defensive lineman for the Los Angeles (formerly Oakland) Raiders, was initially ascribed to cocaine, but later was declared by the Los Angeles County Coroner to be the result of an accidental overdose of a prescription drug. Matuszak had been relieving chronic back pain with Darvocet, a form of propoxyphene. Ironically, the pain relief provided by propoxyphene is limited - no greater than that of aspirin - and its potential to cause death by overdose is well known.

title: ADVISERS TO ARTS DISCUSS NEW LAW
description: Twenty artists and art supporters who advise the National Endowment for the Arts gathered here this weekend to discuss the recent Congressional debates over pornography and new restrictions on Federal financing of the arts.

title: Hundreds of Albanians Fight Serbian Police
description: Hundreds of people of Albanian descent battled the security forces today in violent demonstrations against the trials of 15 Albanian separatists.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Say Anything 1989. CBS/Fox. $89.98. Laser disk, $39.98. 1 hour 40 minutes. Closed Captioned. PG-13. Can a nice guy named Lloyd (John Cusack), who has no plans for college, win the love of the beautiful ice princess (Ione Skye), who happens to be class valedictorian, over the objections of her father (John Mahoney)? The romantic comedy was written and directed by Cameron Crowe, who also wrote ''Fast Times at Ridgemont High.'' The film's predictable surface is ''constantly being cracked by characters who think and talk like real people.'' Basically, it's ''all charming performances and grace notes, but there are plenty of worse things to be.'' (Caryn James) Scenes From the Class Struggle in Beverly Hills 1989. Virgin. $89.95. LD. $39.95. 1:43. CC. R. Newly widowed Clare (Jacqueline Bisset) is simultaneously planning her husband's funeral and her own return to TV. Her house servant (Ray Sharkey) makes a bet with her neighbor's (Robert Beltran) on which of them can seduce the other's boss first. The plot is based on the clear and cynical assumption that the underclass is almost as greedy, callous and silly as the overclass. Paul Bartel's mordant satire ''is one long smile with an occasional belly laugh . . . full of funny lines that are delivered with a pleased self-consciousness that defuses the rudeness.'' (Vincent Canby) Scrooged 1988. Paramount. No list price. LD, $24.95. 1:41. CC. PG-13. As Frank Cross, the ratings-mad program chief of the IBC television network, ''Bill Murray's contemporary Scrooge is a joy as long as he's making life miserable for everyone around him. When, finally, Frank sees the error of his ways, the movie succumbs to its heart of jelly.'' This updated version of ''A Christmas Carol'' works in fits and starts. The mundane demands of the sentimental story keep interrupting what are, essentially, revue sketches, a few of which are hilarious. (Canby) The Navigator 1988. Trylon. $89.95. 1:32. PG. In his dark, thrilling fantasy, the New Zealand film maker Vincent Ward tells the story of a group of 14th-century English villagers who are threatened with the Black Death and travel through time to a New Zealand city in 1988 to find a cure. ''The director takes every artistic risk his bizarre premise allows. . . . Despite his artistic ambition, Mr. Ward always opts for adventure over social comment.'' (James) Dead Calm 1989. Warner. $89.95. LD, $24.98. 1:36. CC. R. In this watery adventure tale, the Australian director Phillip Noyce offers ''an unsettling hybrid of escapist suspense and . . . pure trash.'' John and Rae Ingram (Sam Neill and Nicole Kidman), a husband and wife alone on their yacht in still waters, are joined by a classic intruder, the mysterious stranger (Billy Zane), who doesn't arrive nearly soon enough. The film rises above its shoddy beginning but often sinks back and ultimately becomes disturbing for all the wrong reasons. (James) Miss Firecracker 1989. HBO. $89.99. 1:42. CC. PG. In this film, based on an Off Broadway play by Beth Henley, Holly Hunter plays Carnelle, a young woman who, as part of a campaign to change her image as the tramp of Yazoo City, Miss., enters the Fourth of July Miss Firecracker beauty pageant. It's a ''superficial and sporadically witty piece aimed at such easy targets as family squabbles, small-town folk and beauty contests. But even someone as talented as Ms. Hunter cannot give her character the depth Miss Henley's script does not.'' (James)

title: Priscilla Brooke Fisher Is Wed to J. E. Fields
description: At the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan, Priscilla Brooke Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Dore Fisher of New York, was married last evening to Jonathan Edward Fields, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jon Jacob Fields of New York. Cantor Jacob Yaron officiated.

title: COLD FUSION CONFUSION
description: I was amused, then not so amused by ''Symptom No. 2: The 'discoverers' are outsiders.'' The ridicule of outsiders in their quest for truth is the hallmark of orthodoxy. The function of orthodoxy, however, is to preserve the status quo. Creativity comes from outsiders, like two bicycle mechanics from Dayton, or a lonely patent clerk in Switzerland. STEPHEN WARD, M.D. Abington, Pa.

title: The Reversals of History
description: Former President Jimmy Carter is back in the capital for an informal reunion with staffers from his Administration and a symposium in which he'll report on his mediation efforts in eastern Africa, Central America and elsewhere.

title: As Projects Crumble, Brazil Is Thinking Small
description: After the state electric company here ran out of money this month, 3,300 workers walked off the construction site of Xingo dam, one of the country's largest public works projects.

title: Adele Filson Weds Dr. Kenneth Dunn
description: Adele Filson and Dr. Kenneth Dunn were married in New York yesterday by Judge Paula J. Omansky of New York County Civil Court at the Faculty Club of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. The bride, 30 years old, is the daughter of Mrs. Abraham Spector of New York and the late Daniel H. Filson. Her husband, 36, is the son of Dorothy Dunn of Fremont, Calif., and Richard Dunn of Grants Pass, Ore.

title: Tyson to Hit The Books
description: For someone who has what amounts to a doctorate in the sweet science, Mike Tyson has some glaring gaps in his formal education. He never completed junior high school. Now the heavyweight champion has apparently decided to make up for lost time. According to officials of Central State University in Wilberforce, Ohio, Tyson plans to fill in his gaps through a study program leading to a general equivalency degree, considered a substitute for a high school diploma.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Steakhouse With a Rich Club Setting
description: LEAD: IN these days of cholesterol paranoia, it is surprising that a substantial investment should be made in a steakhouse. But for those who equate dining out with a thick, juicy hunk of red meat, Throckmorton's is the new place to go. The three-month-old establishment in the Union County town of Westfield has the rich look of a gentlemen's club with mahogany paneling, handsome oil paintings and carpeting the color of old money.

title: Playboy Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: For Volunteers, It's a Seller's Market
description: ''IF anything as terrible as the San Francisco earthquake had hit Westchester, we would have been ready to spring into action,'' said Barbara Rose, assistant general manager of the county chapter of the Red Cross.

title: List of Candidates in Tuesday's Vote
description: Following are candidates for Nassau County offices as their names and party affiliations are listed on the Nov. 7 ballot. Asterisks denote incumbents. The abbreviations are:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh, Pa.;
One More Mall One Too Many?
description: LEAD: THE prospective opening of a $20 million, 145,000-square-foot strip-shopping complex called Holiday Centre in about a month is giving new force to a drive against additional commercial development in one of Pittsburgh's suburbs, Monroeville. The community, with 30,000 residents, is 10 miles east of the city.

title: Caroline S. Sharfman, An Executive, Marries
description: Caroline Sharp Sharfman and James Edmund Bacon were married yesterday at Christ and St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Joseph Zorawick officiated. Mrs. Bacon, a graduate of the University of Michigan with an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mahlon S. Sharp of East Lansing, Mich. She is on leave as a vice president at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York. Her father retired as a gynecologist in East Lansing.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: The first bridge match between the Senate and the House of Representatives was played 11 days ago and is expected to be an annual series. It is believed to be the first head-to-head clash between the two branches of Congress in any sport or recreation.

title: James Sheridan, Executive, 86
description: James Sheridan, a retired chemical company executive, died yesterday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital after suffering complications from a stroke. He was 86 years old and lived in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Katherine Carpenter, a TV Producer, And Peter Schulte Wed in Delaware
description: Katherine Revell Reynolds Carpenter, a producer of television documentaries, and Peter Martin Schulte, an investment banker, both in New York, were married yesterday in Greenville, Del. The Rev. Adam Lewis officiated at Christ Episcopal Church. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot of Locust Valley, L.I., and Edmund N. Carpenter 2d of Wilmington, Del. Her husband is the son of Sarah E. Schulte of New York and Venice and Anthony M. Schulte of New York.

title: Tigers Swamp Quakers
description: Judd Garrett, who holds all the rushing records at Princeton, led the Tigers to a smashing 30-8 triumph over Penn today at Franklin Field before 38,106 spectators, the Ivy League's largest crowd of the season.

title: A Week to Hear American Composers
description: AMERICAN music is being celebrated this week with a Presidential proclamation and numerous events in the United States and abroad. In Connecticut, at least half a dozen programs this week will include intriguing pieces of Americana.

title: Iceland
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from two weeks in Iceland, we enjoyed ''A Chunk of Lava in the Sea.'' However, we disagree with the description of the land: ''not a single plant among all the brave and graceful Icelandic grasses, mosses and wildflowers has yet been able to climb the volcano Eldfell for new life. On this side of the island all is still black, abstract, bleak and eerily beautiful.'' It was that way when we visited 10 years ago, but this summer we were delighted to notice how much vegetation had returned to the lower slopes of the volcano - indeed, in the same area where the tour leader invited us to feel the still warm lava. We made a point of photographing some of the plants because their presence seemed so miraculous - such a sign of life and hope. NED HASTINGS SUE HASTINGS Warwick, R.I.

title: Lifestyle; Laughter as Remedy to Ignorance on AIDS
description: In an hour-and-a-half montage of music, comedy, audience participation and frank discussion, Suzi Landolphi has broached with thousands of college students across the nation two subjects that many people would rather not discuss in public - sex and AIDS.

title: No More
description: The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, once the largest afternoon newspaper in the country, died at home last week after a long illness. It was 86 years old. In its heyday, the newspaper had more than 700,000 readers and was known to keep a safe full of cash on the premises to finance the whims of the founder, William Randolph Hearst, or bail too-enterprising reporters out of jail. The Herald Examiner had already seen its best days when it was hit by a bitter 10-year strike, beginning in 1967, from which it never fully recovered. Its circulation dwindled to one-third of its peak and it was hemorrhaging $18 million a year - common ailments among afternoon papers. Though it had improved its journalitic quality lately, experts agreed the paper was doomed. ''It has been a losing business but a winning paper,'' said a Hearst executive as the staff prepared the final issue. The Herald Examiner is survived by 831 employees, many of whom will be gathering for a ''wake'' tonight at the Los Angeles Press Club.

title: Housing Development Over Aquifier Opposed
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER seeking permission to construct 21 houses on 16 acres in Westhampton has run into opposition from a homeowners' association and environmental groups. They say that such housing density should not be allowed over a sensitive water-recharge area.

title: Surprise Ending
description: It would doubtless overstate the case to call S. I. Newhouse the George Steinbrenner of publishing. But like the Yankee's owner, he has shown a real flair for making abrupt changes in top management. In 1986, William Shawn, the longtime editor of The New Yorker, got the unexpected ax. Last year, it was Grace Mirabella, the editor of Vogue. Last week, catching the publishing industry by surprise, came the announcement - sans explanation - of the imminent departure of Robert L. Bernstein, who has been head of Random House for 23 years. Not only was it unclear why Mr. Bernstein was leaving as of January, but it was also unclear what sort of leave-taking it was. Mr. Bernstein called it a resignation, and said his decision to go ''evolved out of talks'' with Mr. Newhouse. Mr. Newhouse called it a retirement. Further mystifying the industry, there was no mention of a successor. Mr. Bernstein, who at 66 yeas old is one of the most powerful figures in book publishing, said only that it was ''the right time'' to leave Random House and that ''there was no serious disagreement between Si and myself.''

title:
BLACKBOARD;
Lab School On the Boil
description: LEAD: THE Corinne A. Seeds University Elementary School at the University of California at Los Angeles has become a testing ground for some of the hottest theories in teaching over its 107-year history. It has also become a lightning rod for controversy.

title: Plan to Halt Drugs on Roads
description: THREE HUNDRED police officers from all of Westchester's 44 municipalities met in Valhalla last week to begin training in a special Highway Drug Interdiction Program. The program is sponsored by the county and could double the number of drug-runners and drug-impaired drivers apprehended on county and local roads.

title: FLASHCARD
description: ALMOST all freshmen college students from Arizona remain in their home state. Ninety-seven percent of Arizonans in college for the first time in 1986 enrolled in campuses within the state. Close behind is California, with 95 percent of students registering at colleges in their native state. Just over half of students from New Hampshire remain in the Granite State for their college education, which is the lowest proportion in the country. - United States Department of Education

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SHADOW WARRIOR. By Felix I. Rodriguez and John Weisman. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Felix Rodriguez, implicated in the renegade supplying of Nicaraguan rebel forces during the Iran-contra affair, now tells the story of ''my private battles against Castro and communist totalitarianism.'' Shortly after leaving Cuba with his parents in 1959, Mr.

title: St. John's Passing Beats Georgetown
description: Scott Scesney threw five touchdown passes, four of them to Denis McDermott, as undefeated St. John's, ranked third in the East in Division III of the N.C.A.A., outlasted Georgetown, 42-26, yesterday afternoon at Kehoe Field in Washington.

title: Left High and Dry on a Package Tour
description: AT the Sydney Inter-Continental Hotel in Australia on Oct. 17, Helga Schley, a tour manager for the Hemphill Harris Travel Corporation, received a faxed message from the corporation's home office in Encino, Calif. It was directed to her and the eight Americans she was escorting on the deluxe Tour PX-908, South Pacific Highlights. It said that Hemphill Harris was involved in a dispute with its local tour subcontractors and ''to avoid further anguish,'' South Pacific Highlights was being terminated as of Oct. 16.

title: Mall Is Forfeited in Drug-Trafficking Case
description: A mini-mall owned by a businessman who is accused of running a drug-trafficking ring has been seized in what a Federal prosecutor said was the largest such property seizure in Connecticut.

title: Will They Go For the Strong, Silent Type?
description: Is this a time to keep silents? Sensing a surge of interest among collectors, MGM/UA, Paramount, HBO and some other video distributors have been releasing large numbers of classic silent films. Earlier this year, MGM/UA issued the first and silent ''Ben Hur'' and ''The Big Parade.'' Paramount released ''The Ten Commandments'' and several other titles. And on Wednesday, HBO will release ''The Thief of Bagdad'' with Douglas Fairbanks, ''Broken Blossoms'' with Lillian Gish and ''The Eagle,'' starring Rudolph Valentino.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title:
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Film Production;
Major Expansions Under Way By 2 Queens Studios
description: LEAD: MAJOR expansions by Silvercup Studios and Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens are bringing to New York City the kind of film complexes more commonly associated with Hollywood and Burbank, Calif. - facilities where the production of motion pictures and television features, from creative idea to post-production work, can all happen in one place.

title: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: SENATE

title: Margaret Jackson Is Wed in Atlanta
description: The marriage of Margaret Shannon Jackson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Olin Jackson of Atlanta, to Eric Ward Dannemann, a son of Mrs. Henry Frederick Dannemann of Portsmouth, R.I., and the late Mr. Dannemann, took place yesterday at St. John's United Methodist Church in Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. Reynolds Greene officiated, assisted by the Rev. Daphne Burt, a Lutheran minister.

title:
ART;
Cornucopia of the Gilded Age
description: LEAD: BEFORE it was a haven for commuters to New York City, Bronxville was the Utopian community: it was built into its design that visual artists would be especially prominent. ''The Artists of Bronxville: 1890-1930,'' at the Hudson River Museum chronicles this unusual artists colony - one with subtle visual delights and a proximity to the New York

title: Record Milk Prices Are Expected to Rise Further
description: The price of milk rose to a record 75 cents a quart in the New York metropolitan region in October and is likely to rise even more before the end of the year, New York State milk marketing experts said this week.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE QUEEN OF MEAN: The Unauthorized Biography of Leona Helmsley. By Ransdell Pierson. (Bantam, Paper, $4.95.) Ransdell Pierson depicts Leona Helmsley as a cross between Marie Antoinette and the Wicked Witch. He chronicles her career from receptionist to billionaire hotel queen to 69-year-old convicted felon. From his account, her favorite pastimes are terrorizing her employees and abusing the power of her husband, Harry, the real estate tycoon. Born Leona Mindy Rosenthal in Brooklyn in 1920, Mrs. Helmsley married and divorced twice, although her second marriage was omitted from her subsequent resumes. Also hidden, according to the author, was her insatiable desire for free merchandise from hotel suppliers and her campaign to supplant the long-time first Mrs. Helmsley (which she did in 1972). Mr. Pierson, a reporter for The New York Post, quotes extensively from relatives, ex-husbands, colleagues, friends, ex-friends, managers, drivers, butlers, maitres d'hotel, waiters, housekeepers and advertising agency staffers. Many of these people were fired by Mrs. Helmsley and seem happy to recount the corruption that led to her conviction on 33 felony counts, including conspiracy to defraud the Internal Revenue Service and evading $1.2 million in taxes. (Mrs. Helmsley is scheduled to be sentenced on Nov. 14.) Enemies, former employees of the Helmsleys and students of bizarre behavior will enjoy this glitzy, fast-paced account of the New York real estate queen's fall from power.

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Injuries in The N.F.L.?
description: Yes. Why? Is it because the steel-hard plastic (blastic?) helmets and bonecrushing, ligament-tearing shoulder pads can't yield but can only mash mortal flesh?

title: The Museum That Theory Built
description: A medium-sized museum in a medium-sized city that has been underwritten by a rich retailer and designed by an architect who has never before built a museum would seem like a prescription for total irrelevance. And the fact that the museum will open without a single picture on its walls might seem to render it not only irrelevant but laughable.

title: A 'Shareholder' Wants Dividend
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: Some of the oldest openings seem innocuous, but beware that impression - it may mean only that you are too young to have seen them in their heyday. Then they were tested in battle after battle and analyzed to the hilt because they were once the cutting edge, the focus of the avant-garde ideas about strategy.

title: POSTINGS: Words and Pictures; A TriBeCan History
description: In a bid for support in its drive to have large tracts of TriBeCa landmarked, the public-interest group leading the fight has published a 64-page architectural history of the area of southwestern Manhattan titled ''The Texture of TriBeCa.'' The softcover book, with more than 75 pictures and drawings of structures in the neighborhood, was written by the architectural historian Andrew Scott Dolkart. It gives details of buildings that illustrate the history - indeed, the romance - of the irregularly shaped area south of Canal Street between Broadway and the Hudson River and north of the Financial District. Copies of the book, which took two years to produce at a cost of about $50,000, may be bought for $12.50 from the TriBeCa Community Association, 42 Hudson Street, New York, N.Y. 10013. The association is one of the leaders of a coalition of groups seeking to have much of the area formally landmarked to preserve the stock of old buildings that still remain there, many of them 100 to 150 years old. Private redevelopment and urban renewal have destroyed hundreds in the last 25 years.

title: In Pisa, a Jewel of a Museum
description: FREQUENTLY dusty, dim and grimy showcases, Italian museums have been much criticized of late. They are often closed for sciopero (strike), restauro (restoration), and even, in the case of museums run by a religious order, for lutto (mourning) if one of the order's members has died.

title: Baker and Australians Urge Fiji to Reach Ethnic Accord
description: The United States and Australia urged Fiji today to find a solution to its political problems that would be acceptable to all ethnic groups in the South Pacific island chain.

title: Long Beach Limits House Pets to 10
description: LEAD: HOW many pets in one home are enough?

title: Hers; All That Glitters Is the Tub
description: THE MOMENT I hear that someone will be dropping by my apartment, I find myself draped over the side of the bathtub, a can of Ajax in one hand and a sponge in the other. It doesn't matter who's coming, how long the person will stay or what I happen to be doing at the time. I hang up the phone and head straight for the bathroom.

title: Ski Area Changed by Tornadoes
description: LEAD: THE thousands of people who ski at Mohawk Mountain in Cornwall each winter are in for a surprise when the resort reopens on Nov. 24. Skiers will find the terrain markedly changed after the tornadoes that slammed into the mountain on July 10, causing $1.7 million in damage.

title: Profile: Albert Shanker - Where He Stands
description: ALBERT SHANKER is a man of a thousand surprises.

title: Review/Recital; The Organ Music of Spain and Portugal
description: Donald Joyce, an organist who in recent years has been exploring some interesting out-of-the-way repertory, gave a recital of Spanish and Portuguese music on Wednesday evening at St. John's in the Village, an Episcopal Church.

title: Dealers Bestow Their Laurels
description: As an attempt to pinpoint superior design, it's rather like the Miss America contest. Dealers from every part of the United States vote for their favorites in video equipment, and this ballot forms the basis for the annual Grands Prix awarded by Audio-Video International, a major trade journal.

title: The Best Antidote for Political Poison
description: Alarmed by what seems to be a crescendo of negative political advertising, some members of Congress now propose to regulate television ''attack ads.''

title: U.S. and Soviet Sisters Meet at Last
description: Separated for decades by the Iron Curtain, daughters of an American tap dancer who found fame in the Soviet Union met today in a kitchen glowing with quiet laughter, hugs and happy exclamations.

title: Mayoral Candidates' Campaign Ads Reflect Their Different Styles
description: The round of campaign commercials broadcast in the last few days reflects not only the separate strategies of New York City's mayoral candidates but also their different backgrounds and personal styles.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Suffolk Rentals Are 'Weakest in 15 Years'
description: LEAD: RENTALS in Nassau County are as hard to come by as ever, but in Suffolk the weak housing market and a softening economy have led to concessions to new tenants and only modest rent increases.

title: 'Iguana's' Lyricism Shines in Madison
description: JUST as the lights fade on the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival production of ''The Night of the Iguana,'' Ellen Barry, as the weary Hannah Jelkes, entreats God to put an end to her seemingly endless wanderings with Nonno, her ''97 years young'' grandfather, ''the oldest living and practicing poet on earth.'' And then Nonno, having finished his last poem, takes his last breath.

title: PERFECT FAMILY SELF-DESTRUCTS
description: LEAD: ORDINARY LOVE & GOOD WILL Two Novellas. By Jane Smiley. 197 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
Sushi and Starters Featured in Harrison
description: LEAD: THERE are times, and this is one, when a restaurant reviewer wishes for a rating system with more nuance. To say that Momiji is a ''good'' neighborhood restaurant hardly expresses the fact that we would return there in a minute for its wide selection of superior appetizers and sushi, both deserving of a more enthusiastic rating.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: Remember Art Linkletter's comment that ''Kids say the darndest things?'' Well, readers of this column can say the darndest things, too. Sometimes a letter arrives that points to a real picture-taking problem.

title: The Rewards of Taming a Captive Hawk
description: LEAD: COMMUTERS driving on I-684 may catch sight of the hawks spiraling far above the Arthur Butler Memorial Sanctuary here during the birds' seasonal migration.

title: WEEDS ARE US
description: Ralph Waldo Emerson, who as a gardener really should have known better, once said that a weed is simply a plant whose virtues we haven't yet discovered. ''Weed,'' that is, is not a category of nature but a human construct, a defect of our perception. This kind of attitude, which draws on an old American strain of romantic thinking about wild nature, can get you into trouble. At least it did me. For I had Emerson's pretty conceit in mind when I planted my first flower bed, and the result was not a pretty thing.

title: Navigator to Pilot: 'We're Lost!'
description: LEAD: HOW come, every time we go on a car trip, I get to spend the entire journey with a map on my lap?

title: Colorado Edges Nebraska to Reach 9-0 Mark
description: At the end of an afternoon that may never be forgotten at the base of the Rocky Mountains, J.J. Flannigan, the senior tailback at the University of Colorado, had to return to the football field for one more look.

title: Making College Ends Meet: Terms of Endearment  A Guide to Useful Tuition Tools
description: THERE'S a wealth of investments available for financing college, and the choice doesn't end with selecting an investment.

title: Review/Pop; Love With Metaphors
description: ''And I'm off to hibernate somewhere for the nuclear winter of another love affair,'' sings Shawn Colvin in the title song of her debut album, ''Steady On.'' In the same lyric, the folk-pop singer and songwriter also tells of ''feeling imploded,'' of consuming love ''like cereal'' and discovering ''it was something like shrapnel.'' In a different song about a relationship, Ms. Colvin declares, ''I'm riding shotgun down the avalanche,'' then asks her lover to ''step lightly on this mountain of new-fallen snow.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: WALKING TOUR

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Musing on the Museum

title: Education In Congress  Roundup of Bills from a Full Agenda
description: While President Bush and the nation's governors have gone public with their concern about upgrading American schools, Congress has been quietly -- and in some instances not so quietly -- churning away at education-related legislation. Herewith, highlights of the lawmakers' calendar . . . Community Collaborative for Childhood Development Act of 1989 (S.123)

title: Miss Mateer Wed To G. Y. Hessler
description: Carol Anne Mateer, a law student at New York University, and George Yonetsu Hessler, a securities executive in New York, were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Urbana, Ohio, by the Rev. Carl Robinson.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. After a shower, water accumulated in the tub to a depth of seven inches. After several hours, I removed the drain stopper and tried a 3-foot-long snake, but this did not help. Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine. I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet. After about 1 1/2 gallons had been dipped out, the water in the tub slurped out rapidly. What happened?

title: Review/Music; 'The Creation' by Haydn
description: From this distance, it is hard to disentangle the seminal music of earlier centuries from its progeny, and particularly difficult in the case of Haydn's oratorios, which all but disappeared under the weight of ponderous and stultifying successors. Perhaps that accounts for the modest crowd Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra attracted to Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening to hear Haydn's ''Creation,'' a work they presented there with some success in 1981.

title: Feeling Like an Onlooker As a Baby Is Awaited
description: OF all the landmarks in the unique relationship between mother and daughter - first day at school, first date, high school prom, wedding - the most meaningful and overwhelming is the time when a daughter becomes pregnant.

title: Dimwit Jocks: Maybe Not
description: IN THE stereotypical world of high school athletics, good grades are harder to come by than good hands. However, a national study of 14,000 high school athletes by a Buffalo researcher concludes that the image of the dull-witted athlete is a false one.

title: Swing for Dancing
description: George Kelly's Jazz Sultans are to play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society today at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090). Doors open at 7 P.M., with music beginning at 8; tickets are $8, $4 for the elderly.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: In Some Towns, Good Books Make Good Neighbors
description: LEAD: EVERY fourth Monday, Jeanne Gnuse comes home from her job as a dietician and does a little homework before going out. In the course of the evening, she may want to recall a particularly telling passage from ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' or link a theme in ''Love in the Time of Cholera'' to an event in the life of Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

title: THEIR MERITS IN DISPUTES, DRUG CARDS FALL FORM FAVOR
description: Nestled in the wallets of an increasing number of Americans are plastic cards that require their owners to pay only a small fee of $1 to $5 for a prescription. Without filling out any forms, their employers and insurers pick up the remaining cost.

title: Incumbents Fear a Taxpayer Backlash
description: LEAD: NAME recognition among voters, a goal for Long Island elected officials who want to stay in office, seems, on the eve of Tuesday's election, to have turned into a target pinned to the breast of every incumbent.

title: Here Comes the Fiber-Optic Home
description: A team of telephone installers from the GTE Corporation is busy at work in this affluent suburb south of Los Angeles stringing fiber-optic cables into 600 homes, replacing the traditional copper wires that have been used since the invention of the telephone. The experiment - one of many being conducted around the country - will usher in what communications experts see as a new information age in the United States in which fiber-optic cables vastly increase the amount of audio, video and computer data that can flow in and out of the home.

title: Computer Center Fights for Aid
description: LEAD: RESEARCHERS and legislators are trying to save the John von Neumann National Supercomputer Center, which is faced with possible closing after the decision of a Federal agency not to renew its grant.

title: Program Trading Is Not the Culprit
description: Program trading bashing has become as fashionable today as attacking Communists was during the McCarthy era. Ban program trading -or so the argument goes - and stock market volatility will dissappear, the Dow Jones Industrial Average will stabilize and the small investor will return to the market. It is an appealing argument, consistent with the feel-good, forget-reality philosophy that has been pervasive in the country since 1980.

title: Lord Keynes Had It Right the First Time
description: Few would deny that America's spending and borrowing must be brought under control if our gigantic international trade and financial imbalances are to be corrected. But in a seamless, global economy this is only half of the picture. What about the responsibilities of Japan and Germany, both of which have staggering surpluses?

title: He Always Bites the One He Loves
description: ALTHOUGH the BayWay Arts Center in East Islip is billing its current play under the title ''Dracula,'' this is not the successful 1977 Broadway version of Bram Stoker's classic novel adapted by Hamilton Deane and John L. Balderston.

title: The View From: Albertus Magnus College; A Small College Undergoes A Metamorphosis
description: IN the House of Bollstadt, the campus pub, faculty and students engage in a game of Jeopardy. Elsewhere, a young woman swims laps in a six-lane pool. Up on Prospect Hill, a soccer game is in progress adjacent to a tennis court where male and female students play doubles. Though typical for many college campuses, at Albertus Magnus College in New Haven such scenes are a novelty.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: NEVER SAY GOOD-BYE. By Gloria Vanderbilt. (Knopf, $18.95.) Gloria Vanderbilt's first novel is a middling soap opera about beautiful women in love with worthless men in New York in the mid-1980's. The women in ''Never Say Good-bye'' are connected to one another through the men they love. Jess, a widow with a young daughter, is the lover of Billie's husband, Mac, and once had an affair with Grafton, the lover of the other two women, Jane and Garnet.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section today and the section's cover drawing, about the new production of ''The Threepenny Opera,'' depict Maureen McGovern in the role of Polly Peachum. After the section went to press, it was announced that because of a vocal cord injury, Ms. McGovern would not perform for several weeks. Her understudy, Nancy Ringham, is to appear in the play, opening tonight at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: The Peace Plan Wears Thin in Nicaragua
description: WHEN five Central American presidents signed a peace plan two years ago, critics dismissed it as a utopian vision bound to fail in a violent land. But the plan's author, President Oscar Arias

title: SEIZURE OF COCAINE IS CALLED LARGEST IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Federal authorities confiscated thousands of pounds of cocaine from a Queens warehouse yesterday in what they described as the largest drug seizure in the city.

title: Steel Makes Better Sense Than Concrete in Earthquake Zones
description: To the Editor:

title: Emigres Are Given Passage to West
description: Four weeks to the day after a few thousand East Berliners took to the streets to demand political change, at least a half million demonstrators jammed the heart of the East German capital today for the largest rally so far in what one speaker called a ''revolution from below.''

title: Scientists In Waiting
description: IN A LABORATORY at Trinity University in San Antonio, Luis Martinez Jr. works these days as part of a team of scientists trying to produce for the first time certain members of a class of molecules, called carbodications, whose structure has been described in theory but not observed. It is among the most basic of inquiries, aimed at expanding the understanding of nature: the painstaking but riveting sort of hunt in which thousands of graduate students and their postdoctoral mentors engage every day.

title: A Bit of California in Connecticut
description: CAPERS in Brookfield, with several airy and pleasingly decorated dining rooms, is not only attractive but also intent on pleasing its customers. And the menu, full of California-inspired dishes, offers something for virtually every palate.

title: Miss Hirsch Wed To Wayne Becker
description: The marriage of Leslie Joan Hirsch, a daughter of Mrs. Jack E. Rotman and Robert H. Hirsch, both of Westport, Conn., to Wayne Bryant Becker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul I. Becker of Westport, took place yesterday at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Shannon Bernard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Becker, a graduate of the University of Maryland, is an account executive at the National Broadcasting Company in New York. Her father is the president of Brooks Hirsch Stores in Westport, owner of women's clothing shops in Connecticut. Her stepfather is the president of the Industrial Marking Company, a packaging and printing services company in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: In Quest of Turkey's Majestic Rugs
description: EVEN when the Aegean sun is most intense, there's a freshness to the air behind the giant stone walls of the 17th-century caravansary in the center of Kusadasi, in southwestern Turkey. This renovated Ottoman inn, known in its modern Turkish incarnation as the Kervansaray, has shady palms and flowering trees in the central court and cushioned chambers along the side and is an irresistible place to while way the hours admiring a vast array of brightly colored carpets.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
17th-Century Farm Heads for 20th Century
description: LEAD: WITH its 17th-century manor house, roadside market and fruit and vegetable fields, Sickles Farm has long been an anomaly in Little Silver, a mostly residential community in east-central Monmouth County.

title: Making College Ends Meet: Linnyette Richardson
description: Income: $21,000 (Single parent); Children: Age 1 * Change life insurance * Join savings plan with matching employer contribution * Invest in taxable not tax-deferred instruments

title: Ms. Storrs Weds R. G. DeLaMater
description: Kristen Anneliese Storrs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lee Storrs of Simsbury, Conn., was married yesterday in New York to Robert Griffin DeLaMater, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Dean DeLaMater of Weirton, W. Va. The ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral was performed by the Rev. Robert Malone, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted by the Rev. Charles E. McCallister, an Episcopal priest. Mrs. DeLaMater, a graduate of Simmons College, received an M.B.A. from Fordham University. Her father is a pension manager at United Technologies Corporation in Hartford.
