Her mother, Margaret O'Meara Storrs, is a trustee of Skidmore College and a director of the Hartford Stage Hands, the financial arm of the Hartford Stage Company.

title:
GARDENING;
The Easy Magic of Forcing Bulbs
description: LEAD: FOR the winter blues, a pot or two of spring bulbs on the windowsill is the next best thing to an extended vacation in Rio or the Caribbean. One can buy the bulbs in bloom from a florist, but half the fun is in the forcing. The time to start is now.

title: Jazz at Winter Garden
description: The jazz singer Betty Carter is to perform at 2 P.M. today at the World Financial Center's Winter Garden, in Battery Park City, in the block between West Street and the Hudson River and between Liberty and Vesey Streets. Admission is free; information, 945-0505.

title: New Twists in Retirement Planning
description: The complex rules governing retirement plans are continually refined by the courts, the Internal Revenue Service and Government regulators. In these judicial decisions and rulings, individual taxpayers can find guidelines for shaping their own transactions. What follows are explanations of recent developments affecting holders of Individual Retirement Accounts, college and university employees and retirees who sign on as consultants with their former employers.

title: Would We Suffer in Silence?
description: Daniel Ortega has a talent for provocation. Repeatedly over recent years, just when there was hope of easing United States assaults on his country, the Nicaraguan President has acted in a way that aroused American outrage.

title: National Issues Rare in Tuesday Voting
description: Voters will head to the polls on Tuesday to choose governors in New Jersey and Virginia and mayors in scores of cities from Seattle to New York.

title: Ms. Quigley Weds A. J. Tschinkel Jr.
description: Frances Kerrin Quigley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. Quigley of West Palm Beach, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Andrew Joseph Tschinkel Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tschinkel of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The Rev. George G. Maley performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PITTSBURGH;
One More Mall One Too Many?
description: LEAD: THE prospective opening of a $20 million, 145,000-square-foot strip-shopping complex called Holiday Centre in about a month is giving new force to a drive against additional commercial development in one of Pittsburgh's suburbs, Monroeville. The community, with 30,000 residents, is 10 miles east of the city.

title: Who's Voting, and Why
description: In today's Greek elections, the main parties are the conservative New Democracy headed by Constantine Mitsotakis; the socialist Panhellenic Socialist Movement led be Andreas Papandreou, and the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress, headed by Harilaos Florakis.

title: Jets' Fans Asking, Who Is to Blame?
description: Everything is going wrong these days with the Jets, whose 1-7 record is the worst in the American Conference, who can't get a backup quarterback to report for $68,750 a game, whose head coach's closest assistant screams at him and punches windows and kicks doors.

title: Japanese Wives in U.S. Are Portrayed in 'Tea'
description: THE five native Japanese women in ''Tea'' at the Whole Theater represent a cross section of Army wives who married American soldiers of different races between 1946 and 1960. How quickly American dreams dissolved when they were ''exiled'' to Junction City, Kan. - ''land of great white plains and narrow minds'' - where their husbands were stationed.

title: Barbara Carlson Weds
description: The marriage of Barbara Anne Carlson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Carlson of Oshkosh, Wis., to John Kelly Cameron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Cameron of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Philadelphia. The Rev. John A. Smart performed the ceremony. Mrs. Cameron, 37 years old, is a legal assistant at the law firm of Blank, Rome, Comisky & McCauley, and Mr. Cameron, 29, is a vice president of the investment banking firm of Mann & Company, both in Philadelphia.

title: MOST OF IT IS TRUE, THE REST IS SHOW BUSINESS
description: ALL MY BEST FRIENDS By George Burns with David Fisher. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95

title: Iceland
description: To the Editor: So Iceland's Heimaey island (''A Chunk of Lava in the Sea,'' Travel, Aug. 20) has 4,800 inhabitants now.

title: The Elephant Didn't Seek the Limelight
description: Your Oct. 15 article regarding Gildah, an Asian elephant [ ''Anywhere She Wants,'' Long Island Journal ] , was rather misleading.

title: Kathryn L. Danes Marries J. G. Cohen
description: Kathryn Leonora Danes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lamont McFadden of San Antonio, was married yesterday to Jonathan Graffman Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Cohen of New York, at the Stanhope Hotel in New York. The ceremony was performed by Justice Stanley Parness of State Supreme Court in New York.

title:
INVESTING;
For a Bargain, Buy at a Discount
description: LEAD: Most analysts advise against buying closed-end funds at significant premiums. Discounted shares offer the best potential for long-term gains, they say, because high premiums tend to disappear over time. ''It's possible to invest in good funds without paying a premium,'' said Thomas J. Herzfeld, president of an investment firm that specializes in closed-end funds.

title: Candidates Push to Woo Hispanic Vote
description: In the battle over New York City's Hispanic vote, the two major candidates for mayor have carefully selected their weapons: David N. Dinkins, the Democrat, has the backing of elected and union Hispanic officials, while Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican, has the support of Carlos Hernandez, the Brooklyn man whose wife was shot and killed last summer after the couple tried to rid their neighborhood of drug dealers.

title: Tax Increase Voted in California For Earthquake Repair and Relief
description: The California Legislature, heeding political and legal constraints on spending, today passed and sent to the Governor a temporary increase in the state's 6 percent sales tax by a quarter of 1 percent to pay for earthquake damage repairs and provide relief to victims.

title: Knight Extension
description: If there was a sense of urgency when the Indiana University board of trustees met last week, it was understandable. In Bloomington, where basketball looms large, it must have appeared that the Hoosiers' renowned coach, Bob Knight, was practically on the verge of packing his bags. That's because it dawned on someone that Knight's 10-year contract was about to expire. After all, it had only eight more years to run, and 1997 was just around the corner.

title: Miss Handel Wed To Michael Baker
description: The wedding of Karen A. Handel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton E. Handel of West Hartford, Conn., to Michael S. Baker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis K. Baker of Cumberland, R.I., took place yesterday. Judge Samuel Freed of Connecticut Superior Court officiated at the Marriott hotel in Farmington, Conn.

title: The Special Role Of Parochial Schools
description: The article on parochial schools (''About New Jersey,'' Sept. 24) states well the need for concern over inadequacies in financing schools in New Jersey cities as opposed to their suburban counterparts. It also highlights clearly the financial needs of the Catholic schools in the cities. However, several generalizations about these schools need to be clarified.

title: STREETSCAPES: Central Park Transverses; Neglected and Abused Crosstown Roads
description: THEY are by far the most visited sites in Central Park and generally are conceded to be among its most significant features. But as millions of dollars are spent restoring Central Park, its four transverse roads receive little attention, sometimes even abuse.

title: Holyfield Stops Stewart in 8th
description: Evander Holyfield, No. 1-ranked heavyweight contender of all three major governing bodies, had a struggle of it but he stopped Alex Stewart of Brooklyn at 2 minutes 51 seconds of the 8th round of a scheduled 12-round bout tonight.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Starrett Proposal; Giving Housing a Push in Spring Creek
description: THE occasional visitor to Starrett City, the 5,800-unit rental development near the Shore Parkway in southeastern Brooklyn, might be puzzled by the wording of the welcoming sign. It no longer says Starrett City. It now reads ''Welcome to Starrett at Spring Creek.''

title: Susan Updegrove Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Updegrove of Huntingdon Valley Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Allison Updegrove, to Glenn Waller Crafford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Crafford of Williamsburg, Va. A December wedding is planned.

title: Even More East Germans May Now Leave for West
description: Western diplomats said today that the new, relaxed East German emigration policy would almost immediately result in an accelerated rush of East German citizens fleeing to West Germany through Czechoslovakia.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
The Sizzle Goes Beyond Steak
description: LEAD: THE restaurants of Buenos Aires offer many delights taken from the great cuisines of Europe - spicy, Spanish-style shrimp grilled in garlic and oil; delicate ravioli and lasagne revered by the millions of Argentines who trace their roots to Italy - but these derivative dishes are overshadowed by the

title: Advice on Doing Business in Japan
description: LEAD: AS more American businesses look to Japan as a possible market for exports, the executives who hope to do business there find themselves in the market for advice on how to proceed.

title: Ingrid Bergman Had It Easy
description: ADMITTEDLY, Ingrid Bergman had problems getting out of Casablanca. Escaping the implacable resolve of Major Strasser was no easy task.

title: CRIME
description: Those wonderfully clever but trouble-prone young barristers whose misadventures so amused us in Sarah Caudwell's earlier mysteries (''Thus Was Adonis Murdered'' and ''The Shortest Way to Hades'') return for another great lark in THE SIRENS SANG OF MURDER (Delacorte, $16.95). To the chagrin of the narrator, Hilary Tamar, a learned Oxford professor of legal history who dotes on these irrepressible puppies, one of their number, young Cantrip, has skipped off to the Channel Islands to advise an international tax-planning firm on a complicated trust fund case. From the exuberantly composed telexes Cantrip sends back to Lincoln's Inn, it becomes clear that the amiable youth has not only waded beyond his professional depth, but has also become dangerously infatuated with a married woman who might be marked for murder.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
MUSIC;
A Celebration Of American Works
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY musical organizations will figure prominently in a nationwide celebration of American music, which will begin tomorrow and run through next Sunday. Demonstrating a broader scope this year than it has in its previous four years, American Music Week, as celebrated in New Jersey, will include performances as diverse as single works and full festivals as well as radio broadcasts.

title: Lynn Matthews Plans Marriage
description: December wedding plans have been announced by Moira T. Matthews of Brooklyn for her daughter, Lynn Patricia Matthews, and Wlliam Angus Douglass 3d, the son of Mrs. Robert P. Devecci of New York and Mr. Douglass 2d of Turnbridge Wells, Kent, England. The prospective bride is also the daughter of Richard J. Matthews of Honolulu.

title: What Tax Lawyers Do Mustn't Be Seen as Sin
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER
description: In describing her first face-to-face meeting with Ronald Reagan, Peggy Noonan writes: ''There was a quizzical look on his face as he listened to what was going on around him, and I realized he doesn't really hear very much, and his appearance of constant good humor is connected to his deafness.''

title: POSTINGS: Near Princeton; 64 Homes, 100 Acres
description: West Windsor Township in central New Jersey is the site of Princeton Pointe, a new development of 64 four-bedroom houses at asking prices of $405,000 to $461,000. Each home in the 100-acre area in Mercer County about two miles south of the Princeton Junction train station is set on about one acre, with 35 acres dedicated to the township as open space. Five homes already have been sold.

title: A Natural Toothpaste From Maine Seeks Its Niche
description: LEAD: Can a natural toothpaste succeed outside health food stores? Many marketing experts doubt it, but Tom Chappell, president of Tom's of Maine disagrees, and is backing his view with a $1.3 million dollar advertising campaign.

title: Arthur Kopit's ''End of the World...''
description: A PLAYWRIGHT (the real Arthur Kopit) sets out to write a play about the end of the world. What he comes up with is a play about a playwright (the fictional Michael Trent) who is writing a play about the end of the world.

title: Hotel Building Still on a Roll
description: A $185 MILLION convention hotel with 1,125 guest rooms has gone into construction in Chicago's Cityfront Center development, extending the city's dowtown hotel-building surge. Six have been completed in the last two years and three others are under way.

title: Volatility Is Causing Investors to Flee
description: Recently I went to Washington to visit with the Securities and Exchange Commission. I met with three commissioners and their staffs the day before the S.E.C. was to approve the New York Stock Exchange's request to permit trading of the new basket of stocks based on the Standard & Poors 500. I was there to make a last minute appeal to delay this attempt to experiment with our securities markets because I believe the basket will increase volatility. But my attempt to stop this form of basket trading failed and the basket was approved the day after my visit.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FRENCH PROGRAM

title: The Antithesis of a Neighborhood Bar
description: THE restaurant is called Allisters, but its owners are Don and Robin McAllister. Why the name change? My guess is that McAllisters sounds a lot like an Irish pub, the kind of place known for burgers and beer. This Oakdale restaurant is the antithesis of a casual neighborhood bar.

title: Notre Dame Collects No. 21
description: Top-ranked Notre Dame tied a school record today with its 21st consecutive victory, beating Navy, 41-0. The victory was also Notre Dame's first shutout in six years.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; An Oasis of Affordables in Litchfield County
description: DRIVING through Torrington recently, Brian and Christine McEntee, newlyweds from Ohio who moved to Connecticut last summer, noticed a sign offering single family houses for $129,500.

title: Pan Asian Theater
description: ''A Song for Shim Chung,'' a play based on a Korean folk tale, is to be presented with music and puppets by the Pan Asian Repertory Theater on Tuesday at Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street. The play, directed by Duyee Chang and Scheduled to run through Dec. 2, is the first of three the company will offer this season. The second production, as yet unchosen, is to run from March 20 through April 7 and the last - ''F.O.B.,'' by David Henry Huang - from May 8 through June 2. Tickets for each are $22; a series subscription is $44. Information: 505-5655.

title: A Tantalizing Return to the Scene of the Crime
description: ''When i first heard this play, I hated it,'' says Israel Horovitz of ''The Widow's Blind Date.'' It was more than a decade ago, and his play was being read at the Public Theater. ''I was sweating,'' he says. ''The knees of my trousers were soaked. I put the thing away.''

title: Miss O'Shaughnessy Wed in Maryland
description: Megan O'Shaughnessy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. O'Shaughnessy of Potomac, Md., was married there yesterday to Patrick John Keough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Keough of Atlanta and Sea Island, Ga. The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president emeritus of the University of Notre Dame, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. William C. Metzdorf.

title: Cynthia A. Coulson, Executive, Wed To Fred Drasner, Head of Magazine
description: Cynthia A. Coulson and Fred Drasner, the president and chief executive officer of U.S. News & World Report, were married in New York yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson.

title: In the Final Hours, Pete Rozelle Reflects
description: The words still stick in Pete Rozelle's craw. At a 1975 meeting of National Football League club owners, he sat there and listened as Carroll Rosenbloom challenged his reign as commissioner. Several months earlier, Rosenbloom, then the owner of the Los Angeles Rams, had signed Ron Jessie, a wide receiver who was a free agent after having exercised the option clause of his contract with the Detroit Lions. Under the Rozelle Rule, as it was known, the commissioner awarded the Lions what Rosenbloom considered to be excess compensation: the Rams' first-round draft choice and a promising fullback named Cullen Bryant. Now, in concluding his tirade, the Rams' owner turned to Rozelle.

title: Israeli Policy Goes Beyond Die-Hard Ideologues
description: To the Editor:

title: Juilliard Orchestra
description: The Juilliard Orchestra, conducted by James DePreist, is to present the second in its series of concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway and 65th Street, in Nov. 15 at 8 P.M. ON the program are Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 19 in F, Richard Strauss's Heldenleben and Vincent Persichetti's Night Dances. Tickets are $5 and $8 (students and the elderly, free.) Information: 874-6770.

title: Lincoln Park Journal; Airport and Borough Disagree on Future
description: WHEN the weather is fine, the small airfield in this Morris County borough is a private pilot's delight. But the airfield and its proposed improvement have become sources of disagreement among its owners, borough administrators and state environmental officials.

title: Step by Step Toward Creating 'My Left Foot'
description: The familiar thud of another unsolicited script coming through his letter box left Daniel Day-Lewis cold. He was suffering the somewhat sour aftertaste of becoming a star, the anticlimax that followed the rapid succession of films - ''My Beautiful Laundrette,'' ''The Unbearable Lightness of Being,'' ''A Room With a View,'' ''Stars and Bars'' - that had quite suddenly marked him as one of the most extraordinary British actor of his generation. He was adrift, depressed, refusing all offers of work. He opened the envelope and looked at the first page of the script. It described a man putting a record on a turntable - not, in itself, a remarkable or arresting opening. What was remarkable was the fact that he was putting the record on the turntable with his foot.

title: THEIR OWN BEST BIOGRAPHERS
description: FABRICATING LIVES Explorations in American Autobiography. By Herbert Leibowitz. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: How the Cocaine Is Coming In This Time
description: AMERICA loves a showdown between good and evil, and when President Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia launched a surprise attack on cocaine traffickers on Aug. 18, the United States stood up and cheered. Then came the hurricane, the earthquake and the World Series, and the nation turned its attention elsewhere.

title: 'GO BE A KING IN A FIELD OF WEEDS'
description: LEAD: GOD HUNGER By Michael Ryan. 78 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95. NURTURE By Maxine Kumin. 63 pp. New York: Viking. Cloth, $17.95. Penguin Books. Paper, $8.95. ANNONCIADE By Elizabeth Spires. 67 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Hard-Fought Campaigns Await Voters' Verdict
description: VOTERS will finally get their chance Tuesday to settle one of the hardest fought County Executive election contests in recent years, choosing between the two-term Republican incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, and his Democratic challenger, Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky.

title: On-Line Reviews
description: To the Editor:

title: Nina Reetz Sets Wedding Plans
description: December wedding plans for Nina Katherine Reetz and Gregory Peter Richter have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Gay Edwards Reetz of Bronxville, N.Y., and John Henry Reetz of Bradford, Pa. Mr. Richter is a son of Elisabeth Richter of Ridgewood, N.J., and Kurt G. Richter of Little Silver, N.J.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
The Teacher Corps: Once More Unto The Breach
description: LEAD: IN AN EFFORT to raise the quality and quantity of teachers, Federal and local legislators are reviving a teacher-recruiting program first developed by the Kennedy Administration: the Teacher Corps.

title: Karen Judlowe, Lawyer, Married
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York, Karen Toby Judlowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Judlowe of Murray Hill, N.J., was married last evening to Spencer Gary Smul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford G. Smul of New York. Rabbis William Horn and David Lincoln performed the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A review in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday of the ABC television drama ''The Final Days'' transposed the names of two government agencies. The passage should have read: ''When he [ J. Fred Buzhardt ] finds the 'smoking gun' in the tapes, a conversation in which Nixon and Haldeman discuss a plan to have the C.I.A. keep the F.B.I. out of the Watergate investigation, it is clearly the cue for most viewers to realize that the President is finished.''

title: More Help Sought for Compulsive Gamblers
description: LEAD: AT a time when the number of people suffering from gambling-related problems appears to be on the rise in New Jersey, health officials and gambling experts say that education and treatment efforts have been lagging because of the state's failure to provide adequate funds to address the negative effects of its successful gaming industry.

title: Do Housing Covenants Intrude on Rights?
description: FOR a quick glimpse at the housing frontier, consider the garage doors in a development planned by Bernard Bossom in Easton, Conn., and the plants on the deck of Stephen E. Barton's home near Berkeley, Calif.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-22

title: WHERE DOES A WRITER'S FAMILY DRAW THE LINE
description: ''I have brought an article from The Times that I thought might interest you,'' my mother told me soon after she had arrived at our summer house in Maine for an August visit last year. She was right. The article entitled ''The Fate of Joyce Family Letters Causes Angry Literary Debate'' interested me, and in fact both of us, more than a little. In it, Caryn James, a cultural reporter for The New York Times, described the furor caused by James Joyce's grandson, Stephen, when he announced that he had destroyed many letters written by Joyce's daughter, Lucia.

title: Even the Language Is Taken Away
description: ''No one,'' wrote the Times critic Frank Rich when he reviewed Harold Pinter's ''Mountain Language'' at the National Theater in London last year, ''could mistake the atmosphere of vague, linguistically fueled menace for the creation of any other playwright.''

title: Rental Cars
description: To the Editor: This summer I had an experience with a car rental agency that your readers should know about. I rented a Chevrolet Corsica from Dollar Rent a Car in Orlando, Fla. The car was stolen six days later in Miami. Not only did Dollar refuse to provide me with another car, but they also informed me that I would be liable for the price of the car - even though I had paid extra for the collision damage waiver. The CDW only covers an automobile accident - there is no theft insurance, they said. After investigating other car rental liability policies, I have concluded that Dollar is the only major chain that does not offer theft liability. BRETT M. LEWIS New York, N.Y. Editor's note: The car that Mr. Lewis rented was found a few days after it was reported missing. Mr. Lewis said that he was charged for the period that the car was missing and that he had to pay for renting another car for one day from another agency. Mr. Lewis said he wrote to Dollar headquarters in Los Angeles and to the Orlando and Miami offices of Dollar. Asked about Mr. Lewis's letter, Bob Jacobson, the public relations director in Los Angeles, said that the matter had to be settled in Florida since the operation there was a franchise. He declined to comment about Dollar's policy regarding theft at any location. In late October, Mr. Lewis said, he was advised by Sundance Carriage Corporation of Tampa, the Florida licensee, that his credit card was being credited for the extra rental days and the extra one-day car rental.

title: Tanker-Free Zone Sought Off Coast
description: LEAD: ABOUT a dozen foreign oil tankers entering or leaving Long Island Sound each week shoot the Race, a poorly marked 1.5-mile-wide chute amid the 12 miles of shoals between Block Island, R.I., and Montauk Point, to shave 11 miles and one hour off their trans-Atlantic voyages.

title: Ethiopian-Israeli Accord Eases Jewish Emigration
description: Ethiopia's renewal of diplomatic relations with Israel after a 16-year break signals a recognition, though not formally stated, that the Addis Ababa Government is allowing the emigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel.

title: A Coach Counts on Her Teams
description: LEAD: JOAN GAUTHEY, the coach for the girls' field hockey team at Shepaug Valley Regional High School in Washington, has known the taste of victory during her three decades of coaching the sport, but she agrees that her 300th win was the sweetest.

title: Making College Ends Meet: Frank and Karen Riley
description: Income: $40,000 (combined); Children: Ages 8, 7, 3 * Invest children's accounts aggressively * Increase investment in matching employer contribution plan * Plan on eventual home equity loan

title: Glamour-Pusses With Talent
description: To the Editor:

title: Gadfly Puts His Views in a Newsletter
description: EVERY week, David Grainger spends about 40 hours of his spare time on a project he hopes will help people to influence their legislators' votes on issues like gun control and apartheid.

title: COMPROMISE ON JET IS WELCOMED ON L.I.
description: An unusual compromise agreement in Congress to build 18 F-14 fighter jets on Long Island before the program is canceled buys time to reduce the Island's dependence on defense spending, officials and business leaders officials said today.

title: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
description: David Margolick captured perfectly the contradictions in Basia Johnson's persona. Her history is riddled with irony. To wit, after nearly a decade fighting the Princeton Township tax assessor over the value of her estate, which she put at around $4 million (the litigation earned my former law firm several hundred thousand dollars for representing the township), and having finally settled the suit, your article now speaks of her ''$30 million mansion.''

title: The Cradle of Western Art (Not Greece)
description: To the Editor:

title: Marrow Transplants Become More Available
description: LEAD: AGAIN and again, the doctors pushed long, sturdy needles deep into the man's lower back, filling syringes with ruby-colored marrow from his pelvic bone. With spinal anesthesia, the patient felt only slight pressure each time. But it was a grueling two hours for the doctors at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical

title: Surviving Incest: the Lingering Effects
description: LEAD: JOE was almost 9 years old, living in a Brooklyn neighborhood where, he said, ''the tough guys stood around on street corners and eventually all ended up with bullets through their heads.''

title: Miss Stall to Wed Dr. E. J. Kaplan
description: A December wedding is planned by Zerlina Stall and Dr. Edward J. Kaplan, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Seymour R. Stall of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have announced. Dr. Kaplan is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold L. Kaplan of Beacon, N.Y.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE average school district in the United States contains five schools with a total of almost 150 teachers and just over 2,500 students. There is considerable diversity in the actual size and range of American school districts. The largest, in New York City, includes 993 schools employing more than 50,000 teachers and accommodating more than 900,000 students. By contrast, 2,400 school districts in the nation have student populations of fewer than 150. - National Center for Education Statistics

title: This Tuesday, to Vote Is to Sin
description: LEAD: Whom should New Yorkers support for mayor? This is not a happy question.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Savory Pork: Marinade Is the Trick
description: It is not true that you must give up pork if you are on a low-fat diet. Pork tenderloins are not only tender, they are also very low in fat. It is easy to compensate for that lack of fat with a savory marinade, which adds immeasurably to the flavor of the meat. The longer it is allowed to sit, the deeper it penetrates.

title: 'Girl With Curious Hair'
description: With this collection of stories, David Foster Wallace, the author of the novel ''The Broom of the System,'' proves himself a dynamic writer of extraordinary talent, one unafraid to tackle subjects large and small. Ever willing to experiment, he lays his artistic self on the line with his incendiary use of language, at times seeming to rip both the mundane and the unusual from their moorings, then setting them down anew, freshly described.

title: Vincent's Appointments Are Fostering a Positive Atmosphere
description: With months of talk about lockouts and strikes, a delay to the start of next season or an interruption once the season begins almost seems inevitable. But two new factors have entered the labor situation in the last few weeks that could put a more positive tint on the picture.

title: BLACKBOARD: Quiz; The Things You Know You Know
description: These are the questions that try men's and women's souls; the ones to which you absolutely, positively know the answers - until someone asks you. Then your brain seizes up, your mind goes blank and your mouth splutters out vague phrases that serve as a stalling tactic -something original like ''Just a minute, it's on the tip of my tongue.'' Sometimes it works; sometimes, well . . .

title: Susan Shagrin Weds D. J. Pitkowsky
description: Susan Hilary Shagrin, the daughter of Sandra Zahn-Oreck of Washington and Don Marshall Shagrin of Los Angeles, was married last evening to Daniel Jay Pitkowsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Pitkowsky of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Ammiel Hirsch at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Maeve Richardson Weds
description: Maeve Catherine Richardson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Richardson of Mahopac, N.Y., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist to Robert Lawrence Cunningham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Cunningham of Woodside, Queens. Bishop James P. Mahoney, an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of New York, officiated. Mrs. Cunningham, 29 years old, is a sales assistant in the investment service department at the First Boston Corporation in New York. Mr. Cunningham, 29, is a vice president at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York and a member of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 'Consumer Debt Is What You Owe'
description: BEVERLY TUTTLE calls the combination lethal: the growing number of material temptations and credit cards available coupled with a general lack of money management skills. In other words, more spending and less saving.

title: 'LOVE IS A FEDERAL HIGHWAY'
description: GIRL WITH CURIOUS HAIR By David Foster Wallace. 373 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $17.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Injuries in The N.F.L.?
description: Absolutely. The average career of an N.F.L. player is 3.8 years. It is the only sport, including hockey and boxing, in which United Press International puts out a weekly injury list. In other words, the N.F.L. is one day a week of playing and at least six days of recovering.

title:
THE NOVEMBER REPORT;
Making College Ends Meet
description: LEAD: COLLEGE COSTS are now so well publicized that parents who have not yet priced crib mattresses can figure out what Harvard will cost 18 years from now.

title: Silent Majority
description: Time was when being average was, well, the norm, and the norm was something that people could live with. Beaver Cleaver could bring home C's without his parents running to a psychiatrist - or sending him to one - and the principal never transferred Dennis the Menace to a class for learning-disabled students.

title: Adding Context On Landfill Issue
description: I am writing to object to statements attributed to me in the article ''Foul-Smelling Landfill in Harrison Brings Recrimination, but Not Removal'' [ Oct. 8. ] . While I understand it is the role of reporters to seek out information, as someone infrequently placed in the position of having to provide such information, I would expect the reporter to ''report'' rather than ''distort'' for the purposes of promoting her own editorial bias.

title: Indians No More? John Jay Vote Rejects School's Symbol
description: WHEN Chief Katonah, sachem of the Ramapo Indians and the main proprietor of the lands about Bedford, agreed to sell a parcel to the white men in 1680, he asked for blankets, coats and wampum - not tomahawks and spears.

title: Therapy for Phobics Gains Ground
description: LEAD: FIFTEEN years ago, Jane Miller, a therapist at the Branford Counseling Center, was about to travel to Africa with her husband. ''I was looking for a book on Africa and I found a book called 'Agoraphobia,' '' Ms. Miller recalled. ''I picked it up and suddenly realized that this was what one of my clients had.

title: Trading Off Independence for a Man
description: THERE was a time when, if not necessarily simple, my life had been at least clear and direct. I went to parties and dances, met a boy, fell in love, got properly engaged, and in due time my parents gave us a lovely wedding. We went to Bermuda on our honeymoon, and on our return we moved into our own new apartment. I became a young matron.

title: A Macheath for the 90's?
description: Seated in the first row of the orchestra at the National Theater in Washington, a few blocks from the White House, John Dexter, the Tony Award-winning director of ''M. Butterfly'' and ''Equus,'' is rehearsing Sting, Maureen McGovern and other cast members in Act I, Scene 2 of ''3 Penny Opera.'' It is Thursday afternoon Sept. 28, two weeks since the show, in town for a pre-Broadway run, was blasted by the local critics, who belittled Sting's acting ability, said his singing voice was barely audible and described the production as murky, boring and poorly directed.

title: Elizabeth Cohen: Acoustical Engineer
description: Shaping sound is both science and art. For Elizabeth Cohen, 35 years old, becoming an acoustical engineer resolved a tough choice. ''I was torn between a career in music and one in science,'' said Ms. Cohen, who has fine-tuned the basses, trebles and everything in between in concert halls, at outdoor performances, in recording studios and on film. ''Acoustics combines the two.''

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: The next Panama crisis is coming in exactly eight weeks. Under the treaty, the term of the American administrator of the Canal Company expires on Dec. 31. He must be replaced by a Panamanian. Further, the new head is to be nominated by the Government of Panama, appointed by the President of the United States and confirmed by the Senate.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: The most comprehensive and perhaps the oldest organization of nations is a group that few have ever heard of: the Universal Postal Union.

title: THE REGION: Mayor of a Troubled City; For New York, Two Who Would Be Different
description: ON Tuesday, New York City voters will elect either the first black mayor for the nation's largest city, where blacks account for about a third of the population, or the first Republican in a generation in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans 5 to 1.

title: Bands Audition for Wedding Dates
description: LEAD: AUDITIONS make most performers nervous, and these musicians were no exception. They had reason to be nervous, for, as they adjusted their tuxedos and took final puffs on cigarettes in the lobby, they were facing a particularly tough audience today - prospective brides and bridegrooms hunting for the perfect musical accompaniment for their wedding receptions.

title: Adoptive Parents of Boy, 2, Held in His Beating Death
description: The adoptive parents of a 2-year-old boy have been charged with beating the child to death in August, less than two months after they adopted him.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; 5 Choices For Varied Appetites
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Akbar

title: A Soviet Hoopster In the Promised Land
description: Sarunas Marciulionis, the first Soviet ever signed to a National Basketball Association contract, is lying face down across a trainer's table in the basement of the New England College gym in Henniker, N.H. It's late summer, the beginning of preseason rookie camp for Marciulionis's new team, the Golden State Warriors, and, after a workout, he is being treated for a strained lower back. As electrical impulses fire into the muscles, he has to twist his head, with its prominent cheekbones and deep-set eyes, to speak. With emphatic gesticulations of his huge hands, he spews a torrent of sibilant Lithuanian at Rimas Kalvaitis, the translator hired by the team.

title: Fashion: On the Street; On the Street Cozy, but Not Smothering, Dresses
description: Making sense of the weather is never easy, but at no time of the year is it trickier than now. The lined trench coat is back from storage and ready for duty, and the muffler and gloves are standing by in the hall closet, along with the boots. Unless someone has made a grievous error, this is November. So what do we get? Indian summer.

title: Sports of The Times; Rose's 'Story' Comes Up Blank
description: ''They haven't heard my side of the story yet,'' Pete Rose, then the manager of the Reds, said to this writer last July, when it was mentioned that most of the country believed he was guilty of gambling on baseball, and possibly the Reds.

title: HEARTBREAK IN HARTSDALE
description: THE WATERLINE By Joseph Olshan. 307 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Daniel Ortega: Our Man In Managua?
description: LEAD: Daniel Ortega . . . a double agent . . . working for the C.I.A.?

title: A New Look At Middle School
description: LEAD: THE Pleasantville School District is taking the lead in considering how to restructure middle schools to meet the needs of young adolescents, a topic of increasing interest to many educators in the county.

title: THE PARADOX OF SLAVERY
description: WITHOUT CONSENT OR CONTRACT The Rise and Fall of American Slavery. By Robert William Fogel. 1539 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: Sidney Irving Kohn Professor, 76
description: Dr. Sidney Irving Kohn, retired chairman of the department of pediatric dentistry at the College of Dental Medicine at Fairleigh Dickinson University, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 76 years old.

title: 'Lawrence' Restored - Alas, in Miniature
description: With all due respect to the lovingly restored LAWRENCE OF ARABIA, the version that played so thrillingly in theaters earlier this year and is newly available on cassette (1962, RCA/Columbia Home Video $29.95), the decision about which if any version to watch at home isn't entirely simple. There are arguments to be made for each side of the issue.

title: How Bush Will Prepare To Be Loose At a Summit
description: IN announcing plans for his Mediterranean summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Bush repeatedly emphasized last week that this meeting will have no agenda and will not decide anything. If history is any guide, it is precisely such agenda-less get-togethers that can be the most interesting - but not without dangers.

title: Costs of the Intifada
description: On the brown velvet sofa in the living room, the father gestures at the street, silent except for the occasional rush of an Israeli jeep. Suddenly, his three boys tumble downstairs, their dark eyes big with alarm: ''Come quick, come quick! There's a big machine!''

title: URUGUAY ELECTION LOOKS AT ECONOMY
description: Uruguayans are preparing to choose a new President and Congress in elections that are focused on the country's economic stagnation and lack of opportunity for workers and the young.

title: Alabama on Rise In 23-10 Victory
description: Siran Stacy ran for 149 yards and Gary Hollingsworth passed for 151 today as Alabama defeated Mississippi State, 23-10, and moved closer to its first Southeastern Conference title since 1981.

title: Hollywood Bound The Hoboken Way
description: TWO young women rested against a police barrier in a Hoboken parking lot as they watched the filming of a movie. They ignored the director's shouts of ''Quiet please!'' and they did not seem to notice the spectacular Manhattan skyline on a clear, moonless night.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: CROTON POINT PARK COMPOST SITE;
When the Leaves Pile Up The Pleasure Quotient Rises
description: LEAD: JAMES HOGAN is proud of the county compost pile. He keeps little bags full of compost, samples taken from the demonstration yard-waste composting site near Croton Point Park here. He likes to show off the samples to visitors, to prove what good stuff the composting process yields.

title: Not Too Old For Reading
description: GEOF HEWITT, a Vermont poet and writer, led a book discussion recently, sparking a lively exchange on topics such as theme, plot conflict and the use of colloquialisms in literature. His text: Vera Williams's ''A Chair for My Mother,'' an illustrated children's book. His audience: men and women, average age 38, in the Family Reading Project.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Berlin, Conn. $145,000 823 Lower Lane 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 19-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, sun porch, 101- by 155-foot lot; taxes $1,862. Somers, Conn. $190,000 50 Springfield Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 150-year-old landmarked colonial; former parsonage, wide floorboards, beehive oven fireplace, 1 acre; taxes $1,631. Southington, Conn. $170,000 86 Meeker Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 19-year-old ranch; c/a, family room, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,688. Armonk, N.Y. $540,000 18 Windmill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split-level; fireplace, wet bar, new eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, 1.2 acres; taxes $5,969. Mamaroneck, N.Y. $500,000 129 Carleon Avenue 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 48-year-old colonial; fireplace, sun room, den, playroom; taxes $10,021. South Salem, N.Y. $445,000 East Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 171-year-old farmhouse; 3 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen/pantry, den, outbuildings, 12.1 acres; taxes $3,276. OTHER AREAS Lakewood, N.J. $104,900 79 Camellia Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old ranch; patio, Florida room, c/a, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,759. Maplewood, N.J. $178,000 191 Parker Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 46-year-old colonial; fireplace, porch, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,825. East Meadow, L.I. $201,000 2776 Grove Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old high ranch; dining room, den, 2-car attached garage; taxes $4,200.

title: COLD FUSION CONFUSION
description: The remarks of Robert P. Crease and N. P. Samios, in their article ''Cold Fusion Confusion'' (Sept. 24), add to a long history of scientific ''spin control'' - attempts by established science to protect its professional solidarity from outside threats, real or imagined. Brookhaven National Laboratory is an important center of conventional fusion research. As its director and its historian, your authors have an obvious stake in Dr. Pons's and Dr. Fleishmann's being exactly wrong about their fusion-in-a-bottle experiments. The ''mixture of excitement and skepticism'' with which they say they followed the story no doubt stemmed, in part, from anxiety over new and possibly powerful competition. ''There were scientists who had seen as early as the original press conference that something was amiss,'' they write. The smug we-knew-it-all-along tone betrays their relief that, as it seems, cold fusion has fizzled. WADE ROUSH Cambridge, Mass.

title: Miss Morris WedTo A. R. Konowitz
description: The Harvard Club in New York was the setting yesterday evening for the wedding of Stacey Robyn Morris, a daughter of Arthur Morris of Fort Lee, N.J., and Mona Morris of Tenafly, N.J., to Adam Richard Konowitz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bertram Konowitz of Syosset, L.I. Rabbi David Fass officiated.

title: Nets Keep Calm To Edge the Magic
description: There was nothing magical about the Nets' victory tonight. They earned it. The Nets won because they stood up to an emotional effort from the expansion Orlando Magic, which was making its National Basketball Association debut before a festive and vocal sellout crowd.

title: Deborah McAlister, Consultant, Weds
description: Deborah Ellen McAlister and Christopher M. V. Jones were married yesterday in New York at Trinity Episcopal Church by the Rev. Craig D. Townsend. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Andrew C. Hilton of New York and Weston, Conn., and Dr. Edward Hays McAlister of Rochester. Mr. Jones is a son of Prof. and Mrs. Gareth Jones of Cambridge, England.

title: Sick Schools
description: PARENTS once worried about simple, traditional diseases in their children's school lives, like flu and measles. Nowadays their concerns are about bugaboos with symptoms less visible and effects more threatening: asbestos fibers in the air, lead sipped at the drinking fountain and radon gas seeping through classroom floors.

title: Bill on Graduation
description: A bill that would require colleges to disclose graduation rates of student-athletes was approved by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee last week and sent to the full Senate. The measure, which is backed by Sen. Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, and many others, also has wide support in the House, although no action is expected there this year.

title: Ms. Michel Weds James Greenberg
description: The marriage of Julie Marlane Michel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Michel of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to Dr. James Adam Greenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Greenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place last evening at the Colonial Terrace in Peekskill, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Arnold officiated.

title:
THE NOVEMBER REPORT;
Building Futures
description: LEAD: NATHANIEL CRAIG likes to talk about the attack-dog business he plans to own someday, but knows there are a few obstacles he has to overcome: Mr. Craig is homeless and illiterate, which is why he attends reading and math classes at a shelter for the homeless in San Francisco.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DONALD GOLDMAN;
An Optimistic Voice in the AIDS Fight
description: LEAD: DESPITE mounting evidence that the AIDS epidemic may reach staggering proportions - and even though New Jersey ranks fourth in the nation with nearly 7,000 reported cases of AIDS - Donald Goldman is optimistic.

title: Good Riddance
description: To the Editor:

title:
BLACKBOARD;
College Journal's Lessons In Literature
description: LEAD: SEVENTEEN undergraduates at Beloit College in Wisconsin who want to be writers are seeing the world of fiction from an unusual perspective: They constitute the editorial board of a literary journal.

title: Justice Department Studying U.S. Role in Coups
description: The Justice Department has completed a legal opinion under which American intelligence officials may be able to play a greater role in supporting violent coups than was possible in recent years, Administration officials said today.

title: T. L. Cassidy Jr. Weds Moira Head
description: Moira Anne Head, a daughter of Mrs. Daniel Head of Harrington Park, N.J., and the late Mr. Head, was married in Harrington Park yesterday to Thomas Louis Cassidy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cassidy of New Canaan, Conn. Bishop Edward D. Head, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Buffalo and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victories Church.

title: Trotting Hearing
description: It's been three months since Park Avenue Joe and Probe trotted across the starting line at the Meadowlands for the final heat of the Hambletonian, harness racing's most prestigious event. Now, with the Hambletonian trophy and more than a quarter of a million dollars in prize money still at stake, the finish line seems to be in sight. Officials say they expect the winner to be determined in early January.

title: Pharmacies Fight Off New Competition
description: There is a drug war in America today that has nothing to do with crack dens and money laundering. Pharmacies are fighting to keep what was once their exclusive domain: the retail market for prescription drugs. Since 1985, health maintenance organizations, doctors and mail-order houses have cornered a growing share of that business and last year sold 15 percent of the nation's $28 billion in prescription drugs.

title: Miss Bryant Wed To Patrick Lynch
description: Katherine Elizabeth Bryant, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Bryant of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection to Patrick Winston Lynch, a son of Mrs. Dale Dickerson of Basking Ridge, N.J., and the late Anthony Lynch. The Rev. Michael O'Connor officiated. Mrs. Lynch, 25 years old, is known as Kathy. She was presented at the Westchester Cotillion in Rye and graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall and Georgetown University. She was until recently a customer support representative at Thomson Financial Networks, a computer services company for financial institutions in New York. Her father is the senior natural resources adviser at the Caithness Corporation, a natural resources exploration and production company in New York.

title: Hip-Hop Meets the Modernists
description: ''Megatop Phoenix,'' the new album by the English band Big Audio Dynamite, opens with a snippet that sounds as if it were stolen from an old movie. It cuts directly into a sample from a funk record, moves into what sounds like tape from a live show, then into music with garbled, found talk running through it in spurts.

title:
GARDENING;
The Easy Magic of Forcing Bulbs
description: LEAD: FOR the winter blues, a pot or two of spring bulbs on the windowsill is the next best thing to an extended vacation in Rio or the Caribbean. One can buy the bulbs in bloom from a florist, but half the fun is in the forcing. The time to start is now.

title: In the Footsteps of a Marathon Veteran
description: On the occasion of the 20th New York City Marathon, I think it's only fair that nouveau runners be told how it used to be in the old days when the race was confined to Central Park. The tune from ''Rocky'' had not yet serenaded runners. There were two Port-a-Johns and no waiting. The rallying cry of the underdog, as reflected in the ''Rocky'' metaphor, has been the marathon's most compelling theme. Let's face it: When it comes to the marathon, except for the East Africans, we are all underdogs.

title: Xavier Goes to Great Lengths to Play
description: There has been no Metro Bowl, pitting the best teams from the Catholic High Schools Football League against the best from the Public Schools Athletic League, since 1986. So Xavier and Fordham Prep had no reason to believe there would be added significance to their annual Thanksgiving Day clash this year, no worry that the winner would qualify to play the public school champion.

title: Vote for Legislature Tests Party Control
description: LEAD: ITS 18 seats divided evenly between 9 Democrats and a coalition of 7 Republicans and 2 Conservatives, the Suffolk County Legislature has been controlled by no one political party during the last two years.

title: Wendy Goldberg Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Goldberg of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Lynn Goldberg to Derek Nicholas Pew, a son of Richard Glenn Pew of San Diego and Lydia Geacintov of Springfield, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Texas Instruments Gets Personal
description: Texas Instruments Inc. last week added its name to the growing list of companies that are offering impressive portable computers and personal laser printers. Well known as a maker of semiconductors, industrial automation and control systems, military electronics and powerful calculators, T.I. has in recent years offered few products that the average consumer of business computers might buy off the shelf. Most T.I. products are sold directly to large corporations or by specialists.

title: Pastimes: Gardening; High Praises for A Showy House Plant
description: Clivias are almost too good to be true. Just when everyone is deeply entrenched in wintertime doldrums, clivias gush forth with unabashed umbels of fiery flowers. They are therapeutic plants. Their blossoms come to the rescue just when you need color the most. They brighten your life for a month or more during the darkest days of the year.

title: If It Ain't Broke. . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Bakker Gets Prison Transfer
description: Jim Bakker, the television evangelist who was convicted of fraud and conspiracy last month, was transferred Friday from a prison in Alabama to the Federal Medical Center here. The transfer of Mr. Bakker, sentenced to 45 years in prison, had been previously announced by the Government, which said he would serve his term here as part of the center's general population.

title: Erica Robb and Warren Thaler Wed
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston, Erica Robb, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Moore Robb of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Warren Sears Thaler, a son of Mrs. Vincent G. O'Gorman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Richard Winston Thaler. The Rev. Spencer Morgan Rice performed the ceremony. Anne Hinton Rosenfeld was the maid of honor. Richard Winston Thaler Jr., the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

title: College Presidents Prepare to Police Sports
description: AFTER an investigation into the cocaine-induced death of Len Bias in 1986 revealed woefully low levels of academic achievement for many University of Maryland basketball players, college presidents began a drive to regain control of their athletic programs. Fearing that a similar situation might exist at their own institutions, they organized a reform movement that, in many cases, has placed them at odds with their coaches.

title: Thomas R. C. Hood, Textile Executive, 71
description: Thomas R. C. Hood, a retired textile executive, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: His Distinguished Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Making College Ends Meet: Gayle and Sally Fitzsimons
description: Income: $30,000 (self-employed); Children: Ages 16, 12 * Shift from high-risk to conservative investments * Prepay mortgage * Hire the children

title: Article 305289 -- No Title
description: Marin Alsop, the music director of the Eugene(Ore.) Symphony Orchestra, is the recipient of the Koussevitzky Conducting Prize, given by the Tanglewood Music Center in Lenox, Mass. The prize, established in 1954, carries a $1,000 cash stipend. Past recipients have included Claudio Abbado, Seiji Ozawa and Michael Tilson Thomas.

title: Sarah E. Biggs Marries Nathan Hoyt
description: The marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Biggs, a designer with the New York interior architectural firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox Conway, to Nathan Charles Benedict Hoyt, an associate partner with the New York architects Davis, Brody & Associates, took place in New York yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Rev. S. Dayton Dewey, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: His Honorarium
description: After a dozen years of amateur philosophizing and scolding, Edward I. Koch has decided to turn pro. The Mayor, whose offer to serve a fourth term was declined by New York voters, said last week that when he leaves office in January he will hit the lecture circuit and maybe even hire out to do a few product endorsements. ''I have served 12 years at a vastly reduced income than I might have otherwise made,'' said Mr. Koch. Now he figures to make ''a lot of money.'' The company that will book his speaking engagements, the Harry Walker Agency, handles the likes of Henry Kissinger and former President Gerald R. Ford. Mr. Koch, who is expected to be among the select few who command $20,000 to $25,000 per appearance, said he would give 30 lectures a year on topics like drugs, AIDS, foreign affairs and the press. Mr. Koch said he would continue taking such engagements ''until I wear out my welcome.'' Meanwhile, the Mayor's lawyer is dickering with the William Morris Agency to line up a few commercials for Mr. Koch. The Mayor didn't say what sort of products he might pitch for, but added, ''Whatever I do will be done because I believe in it.''

title: Limits on Death
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER
description: It was on the night of George Bush's acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention that my fondness for Peggy Noonan turned to fan worship (''Confessions of a White House Speechwriter,'' Oct. 15). When George placed his hand over his heart and began to lead the delegates in the Pledge of Allegiance, I unashamedly began to screech and cry like a teeny bopper, realizing that the liberal Dukakis surely would be trounced.

title: Are Moderately Priced Gifts Passe?
description: CALL me cheap, but I think people expect you to spend too much on gifts for them. I recently needed to buy a wedding present for a friend. When asked what she wanted, she gave me the name of the department store where she was registered and cheerily said, ''Their computer has my complete listing.'' Thinking that would be helpful, I went down to pick out something nice.

title: Program Trading's Other Ills
description: Behind the program trading battle raging on Wall Street is more than a concern that computerized trading techniques are scaring away investors by triggering wild price swings.

title: FLASHCARD
description: PUBLIC-SCHOOL teachers are more likely to feel respected and decently paid now than they were five years ago. Just over half, 53 percent, of the 2,000 public school teachers nationwide who were surveyed by telephone last spring by Louis Harris & Associates agreed that ''as a teacher I feel respected in today's society.'' In 1984, only 47 percent agreed. There has been a more significant change in how teachers perceive their salary, the survey found. Five years ago, only 37 percent agreed that their job allowed them ''opportunity to earn a decent salary.'' Teachers agreeing with that statement increased to 48 percent in 1989. Differences of four percentage points or more between figures from 1984 and 1989 are significant. - The Metropolitan Life Survey of the American Teacher 1989

title: F.D.A. PLANS ACTION ON AN ANIMAL DRUG
description: The Food and Drug Administration is moving against a widely used, powerful animal drug because it contaminates supplies of milk and pork. The F.D.A. could either ban the drug outright or impose dosage limits that would make it impractical to use.

title: THE WORLD'S WARS
description: This is a coffeetable volume of 75 war photographs, and since they depict the conflicts of the 1980's they are all in color; the mangled flesh is red and the flames are orange. These are strong, evocative pictures reminding us that a guerrilla's vengeful rage or a child's poignant grief are just as affecting in little wars - Nicaragua, Northern Ireland, Lebanon and the like - as they were in earlier wars that slew millions. To an older generation of combat photographers, DEEDS OF WAR (Thames and Hudson, $35), a collection of work by the magazine photographer James Nachtwey, is a startling reminder of the technical progress that has been made in photography. Newspaper and magazine readers viewed the mayhem in the Somme trenches, the Tarawa landings, the Pusan perimeter and even the fall of Saigon mostly in black and white, for a simple reason: To catch the fleeting vignettes of war often requires high-speed film as well as fast reflexes, and color film used to be too slow for much of the lightning action of battle. But no longer. Among the eye-catchers in Mr. Nachtwey's book is a picture of a Northern Irish partisan hurling a gasoline bomb at an armored British tow truck as it attempts to move a burning car. Everything in this remarkable picture - vehicles, fires, projectile and man - is in violent motion, and yet the details are almost as crisp as one might expect in a static landscape photographed at leisure. There are some who prefer war in black and white. Perhaps Robert Capa's celebrated 1937 snapshot of a falling Spanish Loyalist soldier at the instant of death would not have been as memorable if its hues and tints had been spelled out in true color. Perhaps the reek of war is sometimes better suggested by the impressionist's charcoal stroke than by the master realist using a full palette. Be that as it may, Mr. Nachtwey's vivid collection is one of the best of its kind to come along in quite a while.

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Injuries in The N.F.L.?
description: I once asked Carl Banks of the New York Giants why there were so many injuries. Was it the Astroturf? Equipment? The training, or lack of it? His answer was simply, ''Everybody is just too big!''

title: In Defense Of Notre Dame A 'Shareholder' Wants Dividend Playing One For Bucknell
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Their Trash Can Be Our Treasure
description: I RECOGNIZED the symptoms shortly after we were married: a chronic need to drive slowly through neighborhoods on trash day and an uncanny ability to find treasure in someone else's discards.

title: A Chronicle of Accord And Ambiguity
description: A series of agreements among Central American leaders have sought an end to Nicaragua's civil war through disbanding of the contras and the holding of free elections.

title: This Is Serious Band Music (Don't Expect Marching)
description: CALL it a band, a symphonic band or a wind ensemble, but don't call it an orchestra. The orchestra sound is dominated by violins, and there are no violins in the Hudson Valley Wind Symphony.

title: The Power of Baseball's Commissioner Is a Myth
description: More than 20 years ago, Leonard Koppett of The New York Times wrote ''The Thinking Man's Guide to Baseball,'' a knowledgeable book that demolished numerous myths about baseball. Among these was the folk tale of the power of the office of the commissioner.

title:
GARDENING;
The Easy Magic of Forcing Bulbs
description: LEAD: FOR the winter blues, a pot or two of spring bulbs on the windowsill is the next best thing to an extended vacation in Rio or the Caribbean. One can buy the bulbs in bloom from a florist, but half the fun is in the forcing. The time to start is now.

title: FLASHCARD
description: GROWING numbers of college students are balancing school and work. Last year almost half the full-time college students between the ages of 16 and 24 were employed. Half of these worked between 15 and 29 hours a week, and 10 percent were employed full time, working at least 35 hours a week. Sixteen years ago only 37 percent of the full-time students in that age group were part of the labor force. - American Council on Education

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SEARCHING FOR ROBERT JOHNSON. By Peter Guralnick. (Dutton, $14.95.) Few musicians so unquestionably deserve to be called legendary as Robert Johnson, king of the Mississippi Delta blues singers. This mysterious figure, who died on Aug. 16, 1938 - poisoned by a jealous husband - lived a mere 27 years and recorded just 29 songs.

title: Defense Boosts Penn St.
description: Ray Tarasi kicked a career-high four field goals and the defense forced six turnovers as Penn State defeated West Virginia, 19-9, today before 85,911 spectators, the fifth-largest crowd in Beaver Stadium history.

title: Review/Music; Guitarist From Japan In Debut
description: Anri Shibata, a guitarist from Japan, studied his instrument in Spain with some well-known players (Narcisco Yepes and Regino Sainz de la Maza among them) and won prizes in a few European competitions. But his performance at his New York debut recital on Thursday evening did not live up to the expectations his background may have fostered.

title: 'I'M GOING TO LIVE A DIFFERENT LIFE'
description: LEAD: GEORGIA O'KEEFFE A Life. By Roxana Robinson. Illustrated. 639 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $25.

title: Sherlock Holmes's Mail: Not Too Mysterious
description: Nikki Caparn is Sherlock Holmes's secretary. Yes, that Sherlock Holmes.

title: Acting Out The Work of Government
description: ONE OF three teen-age defense attorneys, wearing blue jeans, sunglasses and a lawyerly black coat with tails, approached the bench, preparing to argue his first Supreme Court case. ''Doesn't this publication present a clear and present danger to national security?'' asked an equally precocious young justice, citing Oliver Wendell Holmes's famous 1919 caveat about the limits to free speech.

title: A Hard Look At Software
description: A RECENT Gallup Poll found that one in four American college seniors - seniors, mind you - did not know that Columbus's voyage to the New World was made before the year 1500. Nearly half could not place the American Civil War in the period 1850-1900.

title: Global Lukewarming
description: George Bush's campaign pledge to pay more attention to the environment was good news coming after eight years of Reagan indifference. His early appointments were generally sound, his proposals challenging, his words bullish. ''Those who think we're powerless to do anything about the greenhouse effect,'' he trumpeted, ''are forgetting about the White House effect.''

title: Jeffrey Lauterbach and Vicki Baron Are Planning to Marry in December
description: The engagement of Victoria Baron to Jeffrey Robert Lauterbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Lauterbach of Pittsburgh, has been announced by her parents, Pamela Stearns Baron of New York and Richard W. Baron of New York and Shelter Island, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor: I was pleased to see the article on Scotland with the photo of Portpatrick Harbor (Travel, July 16). Unfortunately, in reviewing places to stay in that quaint seacoast village, you left out the Carlton House, which was in the center of the photo. This immaculate, pleasant guest hotel, which is run by Penny Harvie, is the place to stay if you want to relax with interesting guests while only spending about $28 a night for bed, breakfast and a scrumptuous dinner. VALERIE L. LONG Hicksville, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Weekend on Friday about a choral performance today at St. Peter's Church misidentified the choir. It is the Madchenchor Hannover, not the the Madchenchor Hamburg.

title: IN THEIR FIRST DEBATE, DINKINS AND GIULIANI GO AT IT, GENTLY
description: David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani mirrored the messages of their candidacies in largely gentle but unrelenting jousting last night in the first of two televised debates on the final weekend of their New York City mayoral campaign.

title: Fashion; An Early Success For 2 Young Designers
description: The design team of Badgley Mischka took its torch-singer sultry evening clothes to the Fashion Institute of Technology Thursday night and came away with the second annual Mouton-Cadet Young Designer Award.

title: Contras Turning to Younger Leaders
description: After eight years of war against the Nicaraguan Government, the contra army commanders in the field have little in common with the English-speaking politicians and C.I.A.-picked veterans of the deposed military dictatorship who once dominated the rebel movement.

title:
FOCUS: Coachella, Calif.;
San Diego Builders Looking Eastward
description: LEAD: FRUSTRATED by growth restrictions and rising land prices in San Diego County, San Diego developers are turning to this Riverside County desert area, where new development is welcomed.

title: Campus Life: Massachusetts; Where Students Live and Work As Firefighters
description: A week before final exams last December, Christopher Hookway spent part of a Friday evening in an ambulance, trying to dress the wounds of a drunken student who had shattered a plate-glass dormitory window with his fist.

title: Shakira Caine: Jewelry Designer
description: When she visited an exhibition of fashions from India at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York a few years ago Shakira Caine, whose parents came from Kashmir, was enthralled by the Mogul jewelry.

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Make compost. Keep raking leaves. Finish planting shrubs, perennials and bulbs. Clean and store the mower if the lawn has been cut short, one inch or so, for the last time. Acid/Alkaline

title: High British Aide Suggests Talks With I.R.A. Political Wing
description: The Government says its policy in Northern Ireland has not changed, but a top official has shaken the province by suggesting talks with the political wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Harriet BialstockTo Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Bialstock of Delray Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Joy Bialstock, to Jerome Theodore Dorfman, the son of Lillian Dorfman of Guttenberg, N.J., and the late Abraham Dorfman. A May wedding is planned.

title: Dracula and Other College Courses
description: A RECENT report by the National Endowment for the Humanities expressed concern that more colleges do not have core curriculums that are heavy on history and languages.

description: Louis Saavedra, former president of a technical school here, has been elected Mayor in a runoff election with a landslide victory over fellow Democrat, Pat Baca.

description: To the Editor:

title: Couple's Sex Conviction Stirs Town
description: It is not as if this place has ever lacked for sex scandals. The historian for Southampton Town, Robert Keene, says the first entry in its long records deals with a certain George Wood, who was fined $:20 in 1641 for fathering an illegitimate child.

title: FLASHCARD
description: IF 4- to 6-year-old children could choose their teacher from among Roseanne Barr, Big Bird, George Bush, Bill Cosby and Michael J. Fox, more than half would select the Sesame Street character, according to interviews conducted by Playskool Inc. The toy manufacturer questioned 200 preschoolers at shopping centers in Charleston, S.C., Milwaukee, New York, San Francisco and Tulsa, Okla. during the month of July.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.
