title: School Was to Be Great for Spike, but Spike Had A Different Idea
description: Sometimes, like all parents, I wonder if I truly know what is best for my young son. William -- or Spike, as he has come to be called -- has generally gone along with my plans for him over the last two-and-a-half years with a certain agreeableness. But this year he put he brakes on and taught me a lesson I will not forget.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; Nonprofit Trust Shapes Growth
description: A NONPROFIT real estate concern founded by a Quaker textile-mill owner is having a determining influence on the pace and form of commercial growth on a principal interstate highway outside Wilimington.

title: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
description: I have read Mr. Margolick's perceptive and adroitly written article.

title: The Age Of Egalitarianism Takes a Toll
description: THIS morning, my 8:20 commuter train to New York was canceled at the last minute. There was an announcement that those of us waiting on the platform should walk to the New Haven side of the tracks, where a train would pick us up in 10 minutes. Since I am seven months pregnant, the idea of folding up my newspaper, recapping my warm cup of decaffeinated coffee and walking up and down two sets of stairs with a heavy briefcase was somewhat daunting.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINIONRoar of the Pigskin, Smell of the Crowd
description: LEAD: AUTUMN: The time of year that separates families, threatens marriages, imbues placid, easygoing men with aspects of beastliness and turns soft-spoken, gentle wives into women only Harry Helmsley could love. Meaning, of course, that football season is here.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons 95, Bullets 93: Isiah Thomas scored 20 of his 28 points in the second half last night and made a last-second steal for Detroit at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md. Washington had two chances to tie in the final minute before losing to the Pistons for the eighth consecutive time dating to March 20, 1988. Jeff Malone, who scored 9 of his 19 points for Washington in the fourth quarter, missed an off-balance 15-foot jumper with 28 seconds to play. The Bullets then forced the Pistons into a 24-second violation but, after each team called a timeout, Thomas intercepted an inbound pass from the side by John Willliams. Joe Dumars scored 6 of his 17 points in the final 3:43 for the Pistons, who won their second consecutive game. Detroit won its first eight games last year en route to the National Basketball Association title.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 3, Bruins 3: Rick Vaive and Christian Ruuttu scored less than two minutes apart midway through the third period in Boston last night as Buffalo extended its regular-season unbeaten streak against Boston to 10 games. Boston appeared to be en route to victory after Garry Galley made the score 3-1 by taking a pass from Randy Burridge and beating Daren Puppa from 25 feet 6 minutes 31 seconds into the third period. But Buffalo struck quickly to earn the tie. Vaive, set up by Ruuttu, made the score 3-2 as he shook off Glen Wesley and slid a shot from the right circle past Andy Moog at 9:11. Ruuttu tied the score at 11:06 with his first goal of the season. (AP) Tennis Becker Turns Back McEnroe: Boris Becker used booming serves at crucial times yesterday to down John McEnroe and advance to the final of the Paris Open indoor tournament. Becker eliminated McEnroe by 7-6, 4-6, 6-3 in a semifinal in which McEnroe was penalized twice for outbursts. Becker, who beat McEnroe a fifth consecutive time, will play Stefan Edberg in the final. Edberg defeated Aaron Krickstein, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2.(AP) Navratilova Moves to Final: Martina Navratilova defeated Anne Smith, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday to move into the final of the Virginia Slims of New England tournament in Worcester, Mass. Today, Navratilova will play the winner of the semifinal last night between Gabriela Sabatini and Zina Garrison.(AP) Reggi Advances: Rafaella Reggi of Italy won 15 of the final 17 points last night to defeat Ronni Reis, 6-2, 6-2, and earn a shot at the defending champion, Katerina Maleeva, in today's championship match at the Virginia Slims of Indianapolis tournament. In the other semifinal, Maleeva overcame three service breaks in the opening set to defeat an amateur, Amy Frazier, 6-4, 6-3.(AP) Golf U.S. and Europe Gain: The United States, led by Chip Beck, beat Japan yesterday and Europe defeated Australia-New Zealand to advance to the championship round of the $1.03 million Four Tours World Championship of Golf at Inagi, Japan.(AP) Crosby Leads by 2 Shots: Elaine Crosby shot a bogey-free 64 yesterday to take a two-shot lead after two rounds of the Mazda Japan Classic. Crosby who started the round four shots behind the co-leaders, Laura Davies and Cindy Rarick, carded eight birdies. She has completed two trips around the 6,543-yard, par-72 Seta Golf Club Course, at Shiga, Japan, in nine-under-par 135. (AP)

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. After a shower, water accumulated in the tub to a depth of seven inches. After several hours, I removed the drain stopper and tried a 3-foot-long snake, but this did not help. Drainage in the bathroom sink and basement sink seemed fine. I started to scoop water out of the tub and pour a chemical drain cleaner into the toilet. After about 1 1/2 gallons had been dipped out, the water in the tub slurped out rapidly. What happened?

title: Heidi Olson Wed To R. F. Duffy Jr.
description: Heidi Marie Olson, the special assistant to the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, and Roger Francis Duffy Jr., an associate partner in design at the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, both in New York, were married yesterday at the All Souls Unitarian Church. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church officiated.

title: Colombian Extradited On U.S. Drug Charges
description: A Colombian described by the American authorities as a member of the Cali cocaine trafficking ring was handed over to United States marshals in Bogota today and flown here.

title: New Music America Still Won't Be Pigeonholed
description: What is ''New Music,'' and how does it differ from any other music that is made now, not to speak of that composed yesterday or the day before? Those are questions that concerned the organizers of the forerunner of the New Music America festival, which was held at the Kitchen in New York in 1979 and called New Music New York. At the time, the organizers knew they wanted to put on a festival of what has been called ''downtown'' music, meaning frisky and experimental and centered in lower Manhattan, as opposed to earnest and modernist and highly rational ''uptown'' music.

title: Giuliani and Dinkins Income Reports Put Them in New York City's Top 2%
description: While neither the Democratic nor the Republican candidate for mayor appears to enjoy a lavish style of living, their incomes put them comfortably in the top 2 percent of taxpayers in New York City.

title: Venezuela's Andean Hideaway
description: ALL year long, Caracas and Margarita Island swell with tourists from Latin America, Europe, the United States and Canada. But Venezuelans who want to get away from it all travel to the country's most treasured hideaway - the Andean city of Merida.

title: Mark T. Walsh Weds Meg Long, Financial Analyst
description: Florence Margaret Long, a senior financial analyst with the General Motors Corporation, and Mark Thomas Walsh, a management consultant with Touche Ross & Company, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J. The Rev. Michael G. Rokos officiated. Mrs. Walsh, who is 28 years old and is known as Meg, is the daughter of Mollie R. Bucy of St. Petersburg, Fla., and David P. Long of Millersville, Md. She graduated from Johns Hopkins University and received an M.B.A. degree from the University of Pennsylvania, as did her husband, 27, a graduate of Brown University. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Walsh of London and Naarden, the Netherlands.

title: Erin C. Williams Is Married
description: Erin Colleen Williams, a staff assistant at MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings in New York, the owner of Revlon and other companies, was married yesterday to James A. Brennan, a vice president at J. P. Morgan Investment Management Inc. in New York. The Rev. Gregory Paul officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of SS. Joseph and Michael in Union City, N.J.

title: DATA BANK, Nov. 5, 1989
All the Answers
description: (Fold back to page 24.)

title: For the U.N., New Thinking on The Third World
description: THREE decades ago when President Kennedy called for the United Nations to launch a decade of development for the third world, he spoke of raising a ''banner of hope'' for the poor and hungry.

title: BLACK UNIVERSITIES: IN DEMAND AND IN TROUBLE
description: GARFIELD SWABY LEANS BACK IN A BARE METAL CHAIR BEHIND his beat-up desk, next to a file cabinet that neither opens nor shuts properly. A large, barrel-chested young black man with closely cropped hair, Swaby is sitting in a tiny office on campus that is reserved for the president of the student association, underneath a campaign photo of himself and posters of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Jesse Jackson. He is musing on his decision four years ago to turn down Yale and attend Howard University, one of the nation's largest black colleges. ''Choosing Howard,'' he says, ''was the best decision I could have made. Now I can chill on a corner with the brothers, or walk into a business meeting and know how to act. At Howard, you learn how to do both.''

title: Campus Life: California; Reports of Rape Rise by 33 Percent On Irvine Campus
description: The Women's Resource Center at the University of California at Irvine has received reports of 40 rapes and 40 other sexual assaults this year.

title: Giants' Success Is Surprising
description: At the midpoint of the National Football League season, the Giants have been more successful than even their most ardent supporters could have hoped.

title: In Mediterranean Cooking, Olive Oil Is Even in Dessert
description: MEDITERRANEAN cooking refers to the cuisines of Italy, Spain, southern France, Greece, Turkey, Israel and the North African countries that border the sea. Their dependence on olive oil accounts in part for their current popularity.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are some people who have only to open their mouths to be real downers. They are not insulting and they are not necessarily complainers about life, marriage, children or finances - they're not even negative in the traditional sense. They merely bring out the not-so-nice characteristics in others, and one of those characteristics is an almost irresistible urge to give them a good swat.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Weekender Guide column of Weekend on Friday about a piano recital by Glenn Jacobson today gave an incorrect time. The performance, in Merkin Concert Hall, is at 3 P.M., not 8.

title: No Copying
description: Lots of entertainers are called inimitable, but Bette Midler is the first to be so designated by a Federal court. Three years ago, Ms. Midler accused Young & Rubicam Inc. of perpetrating a ''ripoff'' when the advertising agency used as background music for a Ford Motor Company commercial a recording of ''Do You Wanna Dance'' that sounded mighty like Ms. Midler's well-known 1971 version of the song. The singer sued. Along the way, Ford was dropped as a defendant in the case, but last week the jury found that Young & Rubicam had ''appropriated what is not theirs'' in using an imitation of Ms. Midler's voice -they had actually hired one of the backup singers who worked with her on the original recording - and awarded the singer $400,000. The advertising industry, which has heretofore used ''sound-alike'' music with impunity, was in a tizzy. One entertainment lawyer predicted a flood of new lawsuits curtailing the use of ''sound-alikes.'' Young & Rubicam contended that the ruling would have a ''chilling'' effect on the creative process, but the company seemed relieved that the award had not been closer to the $10 million Ms. Midler originally sought. In a statement, the company called the decision ''unfortunate but bearable.''

title: Joining the Community of Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Audrey Smaltz: Dresser Supplier
description: Audrey Smaltz has just finished one of her busiest weeks in the year, unseen by the audiences at the spring fashion collections in New York but nevertheless actively involved in nine of the major shows, including those of Carolyne Roehm, Donna Karan, Arnold Scaasi, Rebecca Moses and Adrienne Vittadini.

title: Evening Hours; The Joys Of Fashion, Science, And Art
description: The 18th century glowed again at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Monday night and at the Fashion Institute of Techonology Tuesday. At the Metropolitan the opening of the Canaletto exhibition attracted a black-tie crowd that lingered over the scenes of Venice, delaying dinner for an hour. The host was Henry Racamier, president of Louis Vuitton. At F.I.T., an exhibition called ''Revolution in Fashion'' showed 18th-century European court costumes.

title: Soviet Poll Finds Deep Pessimism Over Gorbachev's Economic Plan
description: The Soviet public is deeply pessimistic about the prospects of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic program and confused about whether to continue it, according to an extensive poll commissioned by Mr. Gorbachev's chief economic adviser.

title: Return Crates, Milk Industry Says
description: THEY are used as bookcases, file boxes and record bins. Plumbers carry tools in them, students store their clothes in them and children pack them full of favorite toys.

title: Lines of Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Defenses Are on the Blitz
description: Whether it was the Eagle, the Spinner or the 46, National Football League teams in the first half of the season have created catchy monikers for their defenses with a primary goal in mind: line maneuvers up front that created havoc and provided pressure on quarterbacks.

title: Modern Dances of Bones Rather Than Flesh
description: The loneliness that wells up in Susanne Linke's extraordinary performance of Dore Hoyer's dances is so extreme that the pain distilled in these powerful solos seems hardly capable of healing. Hoyer, an exponent of the German ''Expressive'' (Ausdruckstanz) dance before and after World War II, did, in fact, commit suicide in 1967.

title: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
description: David Margolick's article might have provided insight into this unusual woman of great initiative. He speaks of Basia Johnson's story as ''the American dream come true.'' But, as her story demonstrates, women in America are not guaranteed lasting happiness simply by marrying the American dream. Women may be driven by aspirations and agendas that need not be centered around the men in their lives. In this light, Mrs. Johnson might be understood more clearly. KATE G.LEVIN New York, N.Y.

title: Employers in the Suburbs Try Commuter Management
description: AS American urban centers continue to become decentralized, more and more workers find themselves commuting between suburbs instead of to jobs in the city. The resulting suburban gridlock has produced loud complaints and little action. Few local and county governments have the money or wherewithal to untangle the problem. But now some employers that cause the congestion are getting into transportation management themselves.

title: Students Say Best Death Is a Late One
description: ''LIVE HIGH, die young and leave behind a good-looking corpse,'' a slogan among college students of the 80's that was popularized by an article in Rolling Stone magazine, has met its own early demise. Most students want to live long, prosper and die painlessly at an old age, according to a survey of more than 200 students at the Rochester Institute of Technology. The students were polled by Brian Barry, an associate professor of sociology and psychology at the institute.

title: The Highway Collapse: Some Columns and Some Assumptions
description: Block-long gaps now appear in the collapsed Nimitz Freeway in Oakland, as workers dismantle the structure a section at a time, carting off crumpled concrete and clumps of mangled steel bars.

title: Brazil's Atlantic Playground
description: DWARFED by the transoceanic behemoths of Air France and Varig, a small blue-and-white propeller plane scoots every day past Recife's imposing international air terminal. Once airborne, the plane leaves behind Brazil's northeastern bulge and heads out to sea, in the direction of Africa.

title: A Moral Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTORS PROFIT FROM MEDICINES YET BEAT RETAILERS' PRICES
description: To Dr. Arnold D. Panzer, dispensing prescriptions simply makes good business sense. ''I have a seven-day-a week, walk-in, primary care practice, so dispensing medicine is in line with the focus of my practice - convenience,'' he said. ''My patients don't have to schlep over to a pharmacy.''

title: Kathleen McGahan Is Wed
description: Kathleen McGahan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George McGahan of Mineola, L.I., was married yesterday at St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church in Williston Park, L.I., to Stephen O'Leary Shay, the son of Ann Shay of New York and the late J. Burke Shay. The Rev. Robert F. Condron officiated. Mrs. Shay, 30 years old, is a marketing consultant at Meditech, a medical software company in Westwood, Mass. The bridegroom, 32, is a private investor. He and the bride are graduates of Boston College.

title: End Paper: Letters from China; They Misjudged The Dragon
description: MOST OF MY 240 graduate and undergraduate students at the Beijing Institute of Chemical Technology were witty, wise, sweet and highly intelligent - sometimes brilliant. They were patriotic, with a deep-rooted love of their homeland, its ways and its people.

title: MARY CAME ALONG AND CHANGED EVERYTHING
description: THE GODWINS AND THE SHELLEYS The Biography of a Family. By William St. Clair. Illustrated. 572 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $32.50.

title: Miss Sullivan Weds M. C. Sanford Jr.
description: The wedding of Jennifer Corcoran Sullivan, an associate at Lazard Freres & Company, and Marshall Clement Sanford Jr., an associate at the Chemical Realty Corporation, both in New York, took place yesterday at Christ Memorial Chapel on Jupiter Island, Fla. The Rev. Leo O'Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest and the president of Georgetown University, performed the ceremony.

title: Let's Say Life Begins With Brain Waves
description: To the Editor:

title: Eileen Hawthorn Engaged to Wed T. J. Rooney Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert William Hawthorn of New Rochelle, N.Y., have made known December wedding plans for their daughter Eileen Mary Anne Hawthorn and Timothy James Rooney Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rooney of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Voters to Make Choices Tuesday for Governor and Assembly
description: AFTER watching a bitter campaign for governor between James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate, and Jim Courter, the Republican nominee, voters will have their say on Tuesday, when they will also decide party control of the 80-member State Assembly and the fate of five public questions that call for $590 million in proposed spending. Polls will be open from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Jane Burgio, the Secretary of State, estimates that 60 percent of the state's 3.8 million registered voters will cast ballots. In 1981, the last time there was no incumbent governor running, the turnout exceeded 64 percent.

title: Hold That Comment
description: When he said last week that Denver and Tampa-St. Petersburg had the edge over New Orleans for the two expansion franchises being considered by the National League, Avron Fogleman, the co-owner of the American League Kansas City Royals, was speaking out of turn. That was the word from the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent.

title: 'Storytellers' Gather to Honor Knopf
description: LEAD: THE late Alfred A. Knopf, founder of the publishing house of the same name and former Purchase resident, will be honored at Westchester Community College's fifth yearly literary symposium to be held at the college Nov. 19.

title: Miss Levine Wed To Evan Merberg
description: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., Deborah Beth Levine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Levine of Roslyn, L.I., was married last evening to Evan Lewis Merberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Merberg of Manhasset Hills, L.I. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated.

title: Special Today
description: Education Life/Section 4A

title: Wisdom From a Music Box
description: IT had been a tiring day. I wanted nothing more than to kick off my heels, fix a salad, pay a few bills and go to bed. When I arrived home, my husband greeted me at the door.

title: Penrod, Scattergood and Jeeves
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret MacL. Medlock Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Margaret MacLennan Medlock and Thomas Sean Fitzgerald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Fitzgerald of Port Washington, L.I., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Medlock, also of Port Washington. A December wedding is planned.

title: Pound Ridge Learns It Has a Civil War Hero
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS here are hailing a Civil War hero they didn't know they had - an Irish-born infantryman who fought at Gettysburg and other major battles and won the Congressional Medal of Honor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He's learned a lot, he's gaining pace, but I'm not sure whether he's quick enough to keep up with events. He must become more bold.'' - Jens Reich, an opposition leader, speaking of Egon Krenz, the East German Communist chief. [ 17:1. ]

title: Sheri D. Lesser and Dr. Myles R. Samotin Married
description: Sheri Denise Lesser and Dr. Myles Rubin Samotin were married in New York last evening at the Carlyle by Rabbi Judah Nadich, assisted by Rabbi Morton Bauman and Cantor Ephraim Biran.

title: Jets' Ryan Is Activated
description: The Jets activated Pat Ryan yesterday, giving them a proven alternative to Ken O'Brien at quarterback for the first time this season.

title: Howard Rusk, 88, Dies; Medical Pioneer
description: Dr. Howard A. Rusk, who became a pioneer in the rehabilitation of the physically disabled in the United States and many other countries after finding new ways to help badly wounded airmen in World War II, died of a stroke yesterday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan, which he entered three months ago. He was 88 years old.

title: WHITE HOUSE SPEECHWRITER
description: Peggy Noonan remembers exactly what President Reagan said to her when they were introduced: ''Well, it's so wonderful to meet you.'' One wonders who wrote it for him. After all, she had to compose something for him to say when he received the teacher of the year.

title: Sarah R. Arndt Is Married
description: Sarah Randolph Arndt and Jeffrey Scott Johnson were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn., by the Rev. Allan House O'Neil. Mrs. Johnson, 25 years old, is a daughter of Mrs. W. Page Wodell of Old Lyme, Conn., and Willis C. Arndt of West Hartford. A graduate of Denison University, the bride is an account executive at the Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson advertising agency in Boston, where her husband is an account supervisor. The bridegroom, 30, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Johnson of Falmouth, Mass. He is a graduate of Babson College.

title: COLD FUSION CONFUSION
description: Your authors contend that ''good'' scientists always try to ''kill the discovery.'' That is straight out of Karl Popper's philosophy of falsification, and it simply doesn't describe the behavior of real scientists. No scientist kills his own discovery - you verify it to your own satisfaction, publish it and let the skeptics do their worst. If the discovery holds up, well and good. If not, tough. The fact is that only a very small fraction of published discoveries hold up to long-term scrutiny. ROBERT ROOT-BERNSTEIN East Lansing, Mich.

title: HE LIKES HIS DEALS BIG AND HIS NEWS HAPPY
description: CONFESSIONS OF AN S.O.B. By Al Neuharth. 372 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Ms. Jenkins Wed To M. G. Lanes
description: The marriage of Dominique Pascale Jenkins and Matthew Gordon Lanes took place in New York yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel on the campus of Columbia University. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Henry Fehienbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the interfaith ceremony.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Upper Saddle River
description: LEAD: THERE is no better place to catch up on local gossip, say Upper Saddle River residents, than Elmer's Country Store on West Saddle River Road in the heart of the village. There, they say, you can chat with Joe Dobias, one of Elmer's three owners - the others are Dave Ballingall and Don Kahrer, all borough residents - while eating a homemade doughnut and drinking a cup of coffee, which sometimes is on the house.

title: The Legends of Kibbutz Country
description: OVERSEEN by the brooding heights of Mount Tabor and Mount Gilboa, the Jezreel Valley resonates with memories of ancient Israelite kings and warrior-judges. In modern times, the same area was the scene of the Zionist movement's pioneering efforts in land reclamation, agriculture and self-defense. To Israelis these achievements, and the people of the Jezreel, like Moshe Dayan, have almost mythic significance.

title: Falcons Take Prize And a Rush Record
description: Dee Dowis, a senior quarterback, threw for two touchdowns, ran for another touchdown, and set a national record for rushing today as the Air Force Falcons overwhelmed Army, 29-3, to win the Commander-in-Chief's Trophy and a sure bowl appearance.

title: Kelly Ann Sides Weds John Lawler 4th
description: The marriage of Kelly Ann Sides, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Sides of Houston, to John Aloysius Lawler 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawler 3d of Wellesley Hills, Mass., took place yesterday at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Joseph J. Driscoll performed the ceremony.

title: FICTION
description: ASHES OF IZALCO. By Claribel Alegria and Darwin J. Flakoll. Translated by Darwin J. Flakoll. (Curbstone Press/Talman, Cloth, $17.95; Paper, $9.95.) A political polemic presented in the form of a novel is a tricky hybrid. To be persuasive while balancing the message with the medium is no mean feat. ''Ashes of Izalco,'' which was originally published in Spanish in 1966 and is now appearing in a workmanlike translation by Darwin J. Flakoll, accomplishes this with varying degrees of success. The story focuses on two central characters: Carmen Rojas, an upper-class Salvadoran who returns in the mid-1960's to her native village, Santa Ana, for her mother's funeral; and Frank Wolff, an emotionally bankrupt American alcoholic who comes to Santa Ana in 1931. The connection between them is revealed when Carmen reads an old diary and discovers that her mother, Isabel, had an affair with Frank. Carmen is the observer, seeing and commenting on everything: the smug, materialistic American, the frivolousness of the Salvadoran upper class and the inhuman abuse suffered by the exploited peasants. Frank, on the other hand, is the self-absorbed American who, while desperately trying to grasp happiness through Isabel, isn't even aware of the revolutionary turmoil that is taking place around him - until he witnesses the massacre of thousands of peasants in the town of Izalco. The story, whose violent climax is based on actual historical events, is rich with the sights and sounds of a Salvadoran village, with energetic, sometimes humorous insights into the lives and attitudes of the stratified population, even as the Salvadoran writer Claribel Alegria and her husband, Mr. Flakoll, make points, from their perspective, about the behavior and attitudes of North Americans in Latin America. Cinematic-style fast cuts, employed by the authors to move the reader through rapid transitions, although occasionally confusing, are generally deftly handled in this selectively enlightening novel.

title: U.S. Thinks Twice About Armenian Measure
description: Opposition is mounting in Congress and in the Bush Administration to a resolution before the Senate to declare a national day of remembrance for the widespread killings of Armenians by Ottoman Turks during World War I. President Bush increased Administration efforts to defeat the resolution last week by writing letters to Senator Bob Dole, the Republican minority leader and chief sponsor of the measure, and other congressional leaders.

title: Navy Finding on Iowa Blast Is Drawing Criticism
description: The Navy's conclusion that the gun turret explosion aboard the battleship Iowa was probably the deliberate act of a despondent and suicidal sailor is coming under increasing criticism from Congressional investigators and family members of some of the 47 men who died in the blast.

title: Europe's Buyout Bulge
description: The mergers and acquisitions movement that started to snowball in Europe three years ago has grown into an avalanche that is remaking the Continent's corporate landscape. That avalanche will likely continue to thunder as companies rush to prepare for the more competitive era that will result as the European Community scraps internal trade barriers by the end of 1992.

title: Bush Says He Plans to Keep Quayle on '92 Ticket
description: In an interview to be published Sunday, President Bush says he would ''absolutely'' keep Vice President Dan Quayle on the Republican ticket in 1992.

title: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL
description: Basia Johnson is using her wealth to help the Lenin Shipyard workers keep their jobs, while boosting Poland's image as a place worthy of American investment. As a fellow immigrant Pole, I salute her faith in a vital, working Poland. Barbara Piasecka Johnson has the unique opportunity to make a difference, and she's doing it on a grand scale. MARIE DYBCZAK SOMERS South Orange, N.J.

title: SOUND
description: ''No, I don't want a sound system. All I want is a radio. Just a radio. But one that sounds good.''

title: N.C.A.A. Hears Wolfpack Officials
description: North Carolina State officials answered questions from the N.C.A.A.'s infractions committee for four hours Friday, and later said the hearing was thorough and nonconfrontational.

title: How to Surprise Beethoven
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Are Routed by Flames
description: Jiri Hrdina scored two goals as the Calgary Flames skated to a 7-3 victory over the Devils tonight and remained unbeaten at home.

title: Iran Opens Former U.S. Embassy On 10th Anniversary of Its Seizure
description: The authorities opened the former American Embassy to the public today and paraded seven Iranian suspects accused of spying for the C.I.A. before television cameras as Iran marked the 10th anniversary of the embassy's seizure.

title: Rangers Perk Up, but Canadiens Cruise
description: The modus operandi is by now familiar. The Montreal Canadiens, relaxed to the point of apparent laziness, suddenly find life and then proceed to spend the remainder of a game squeezing it out of their opponents.

title: 'DON'T ASK. ACT'
description: DIARY Volume Two (1957-1961). By Witold Gombrowicz. Edited by Jan Kott. Translated by Lillian Vallee. 239 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $12.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF.;
Gilding The Lily
description: LEAD: THE steel frames of the Two Rodeo Drive buildings - an opulent shopping district within an opulent shopping district - have been completed and its developers say that more than half of the 135,000 square feet has been leased.

title: What's Notable: A Book of Wondrous Trees
description: THE biggest known moss cawara cypress tree in New England stands in a Greenwich cemetery. One of the largest elms in Connecticut is in the middle of a street in Norwich. And Gen. George Washington is believed to have met with his officers beside a white oak in the Gaylordsville section of New Milford.

title: Reston, Retiring at 80, Still Looks Up the Road
description: James Reston, who retired from The New York Times on Friday, his 80th birthday, said in a farewell interview that President Bush should do more, at this potentially pivotal moment, ''to help along'' the political and economic evolution in the Soviet Union.

title: Pollution In Glen Cove
description: With reference to ''Glen Cove Acts to Update Environmental Laws,'' Oct. 22, anent environmental ordinances recently passed in Glen Cove, I hasten to point out that the most important development here is the cleanup of the industrial polluted areas. This was pushed for some years by the previous Suozzi Administration, and aided by our legislative representatives, especially Assemblyman Lewis Yevoli and Representative Robert J. Mrazek. Finally, during the past period the cleanup has begun, with both the State Department of Environmental Protection and the Federal Environmental Protection Agency involved.

title: Farewell To a Friend I Barely Knew
description: I REMEMBER the night I first met David. Sue had phoned me two days earlier. ''We've got a buddy for you. When can you meet him?'' As soon as possible, I said.

title: Small Steps Toward Acceptance Renew Debate on Gay Marriage
description: SINCE the early 1970's, when seven states, including New York, rejected the idea of allowing homosexual couples to marry, the issue has been all but dormant. But recently the debate has been revived. Among the most significant reasons for the renewed interest, gay-rights leaders say, is the AIDS epidemic, which has brought questions of inheritance and death benefits to many people's minds.

title: LONG DELAY IS SEEN ON U.S. RIGHTS POST
description: Three months after President Bush's nominee for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job was rejected by the Senate Judiciary Committee, Bush Administration officials say it is unlikely that the Justice Department post will be filled before January.

title: Henry V Returns As a Monarch For This Era
description: The American producer Joseph Papp still likes to recall the day when, as a theater student recently discharged from the wartime Navy, he and his friends first saw Laurence Olivier's movie version of ''Henry V.'' They charged en masse down Hollywood Boulevard shouting, ''God for Harry, England and St. George!,'' infecting the afternoon strollers with their exhilaration.

title: Lisa Smith Is Married
description: Lisa Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey E. Smith of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Arnold Markowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Markowitz of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ephraim Wolf performed the ceremony at the Great Neck Synagogue. The bride, 32 years old, will keep her name. She is an account executive with D.I.R. Broadcasting in New York. Mr. Markowitz, 31, is a sales manager with Sussex Semiconductor in Branchville, N.J.

title: The Candidates Vying in Tuesday's Elections
description: HERE are the candidates in Tuesday's election who are seeking countywide office, Board of Legislators seats, Town Supervisor positions and city mayoral posts. Asterisk (*) indicates incumbents.

title:
FOCUS;
Frustrated San Diego Builders Looking Eastward
description: LEAD: Frustrated by growth restrictions and rising land prices in San Diego County, San Diego developers are turning to this Riverside County desert area, where new development is welcomed.

title: Question Of the Week; Are There Too Many Injuries in The N.F.L.?
description: Excessive injuries will continue until teams return to playing on real turf in all nondomed stadiums. JACK CHVAT Maplewood, N.J.

title: Precautions With Wood Stoves
description: IF you are planning to get a wood-burning stove, there are several things to consider before making a choice. First check with your building inspector or fire marshal to find out whether installing a wood stove is permitted where you live and what restrictions and requirements apply.

title: THE REGION: A Governor for Harder Times; For New Jersey, Two Who Stress Differences
description: THE next governor of New Jersey will inherit a state that has seen boom times but now faces harder days. Presided over for eight years by Thomas H. Kean, a popular Republican who by law is barred from a third term, New Jersey's economy has expanded. Now the state is facing a budget squeeze as it deals with some of the results of development like traffic and environmental problems while trying to eradicate the decay of Newark and Camden.

title: When Does Six Minutes Add Up to Two Years?
description: ''I'm not a fingers person. The single most intimidating thing is writing for 10 fingers.'' Oliver Knussen was on the phone from London giving reasons why, after a year, his six-minute piano piece, due to be delivered in three weeks, wasn't finished. He tried another excuse. ''I'm ridiculously overcommitted - if Peter Serkin weren't so nice I wouldn't even have started.''

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: NOT much had changed where high school fashion was concerned, I noted, or else during the 20 years I haven't been looking, styles have come full circle.

title: Ronnie Gilbert
description: Ronnie Gilbert, a singer formerly with the Weavers, is to perform at 3 P.M. today at the Prospect Park Picnic House, near Prospect Park West and Third Street, in Brooklyn. Tickets are $5; information: (718) 965-8950.

title: IT'S NOT EASY BEING MEDIOCRE
description: THE FUR HAT By Vladimir Voinovich. Translated by Susan Brownsberger. 122 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Miss Cattani Married To Alfred C. Trivilino
description: Andrea Lee Cattani, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert V. Cattani of New York, was married yesterday to Alfred Charles Trivilino, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Trivilino of Jamaica Estates, Queens. The Rev. Henry Boyle and the Rev. Fred Betti officiated at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Paula S. Fritz, Actress, Weds
description: Paula Susan Fritz, an actress, and Colman Robert Andrews, a food and wine writer, were married yesterday at St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church in Santa Monica, Calif., by Msgr. Lloyd A. Torgerson.

title: Review/Dance; Variations on the Theme Of the Sounds of Tap
description: The program presented by the Anita Feldman Tap company on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater was like a quietly enjoyable evening spent with friends preoccupied with variations on an interesting theme. Ms. Feldman is interested in exploring the sounds one can make with tap -blessedly, without a lot of intrusive electronic equipment. The dance seems almost to come last, however, and there were times when it seemed Ms. Feldman could have reached a good deal further.

title: New York Marathon
description: They regard themselves less as competitors than as blessed symbols of endurance, perseverance and luck. Of course, each would like to record his personal best time today in the 20th running of the New York City Marathon, and if in so doing, one beats the other two, so much the better.

title:
BLACKBOARD;
College Nightclubs Now On A Dry Run
description: LEAD: ALICE DRUM, the dean of students at Franklin & Marshall College, in Lancaster, Pa., speaks for many college administrators across the nation when she says, ''For much of the college-age generation today, social life is equated with alcohol.'' Whether or not this is widely true - and many students and administrators feel students are not nearly so focused on drinking as they are on finding a good place to socialize - the recent tightening of alcohol laws in many states has spurred many colleges to capitalize on it.

title: Coming of Age
description: What is the average student like as a grown-up? Generally average, social scientists say, but you never can tell.

title: FICTION
description: THE GLITTER AND THE GOLD. By Fred Mustard Stewart. (NAL Books/New American Library, $19.95.) In his latest novel, the author of ''Century'' and ''Ellis Island'' proves once again that he knows how to spin a compelling yarn. Fred Mustard Stewart's enjoyable tale of a San Francisco family features an interesting cast of characters, a lively sense of humor and an impressive ability to blend historical fact and popular fiction. Emma de Meyer, daughter of Frankfurt's leading jeweler, comes to America in 1849 after her mother is killed in an anti-Semitic riot. A love affair en route to California with a man wanted for bank robbery leaves her pregnant, but a marriage of convenience to a wealthy ship's captain turns into a love match and a good business arrangement as well. Emma's American descendants, the Collingwoods, become one of California's wealthiest families, and Mr. Stewart traces their fortunes through the 1906 earthquake to the present. Like many multigenerational sagas, ''The Glitter and the Gold'' sags somewhat as time marches on. None of her children and grandchildren are as appealing as the dashing Emma, and the final section, which involves a modern-day Collingwood's attempt to fend off sinister Hong Kong gangsters intent on acquiring the family ranch, falls decidedly flat. In addition, Mr. Stewart is a trifle cavalier with his characters; disasters befall the Collingwoods in such abundance that it eventually becomes rather funny - surely not what the author intended. These flaws are more than counterbalanced, however, by this entertaining novel's sheer vigor and charm.

title: Grounded Cargo Ship Is Freed From a Reef
description: A Yugoslav cargo ship that ran aground in the Florida Straits on Monday was freed Thursday night from a coral reef.

title: FLASHCARD
description: DEFAULTS on guaranteed student loans are expected to cost the Federal Government about $2 billion in fiscal year 1990. The 1987 default rate for federally guaranteed student loans was 17 percent, down from 21 percent the previous year. (The 1987 default rate was calculated using the percentage of borrowers who joined the repayment ranks in 1987 and then defaulted in fiscal years 1987 or 1988.) For-profit trade schools had the highest incidence of nonpayment, at 33 percent. Private and public four-year institutions have the lowest incidence of student loan default, at 7 percent. - United States Department of Education

title: 2 New York City Races Seem Virtually Decided
description: Andrew J. Stein and Elizabeth Holtzman seem assured of winning New York City races that can be stepping stones to higher offices.

title: Making College Ends Meet: Walter and Lisa Havey
description: Income: $69,000 (combined); Children: none * Take full advantage of eomplyer tuition reimbursement * Consolidate student loans

title: Review/Piano; Canadian Plays Contemporary Music
description: The Canadian pianist Marc-Andre Hamelin won first prize in the Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition four years ago, and since then he has proven an eloquent spokesman for contemporary piano music, European as well as American. The program he played on Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall was pianistically demanding and stylistically varied, with an accent on the cerebral.

title: Southwest Landscapes And Guyana Abstracts
description: AT Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison, the Phyllis Rothman Gallery is fairly pulsating with a show on Paul Brach. The elements that toned down the exterior of this foam temple have not affected the interior, which is still fluorescently white, and most of the show's 10 works are canvases painted in purples and brilliant reds.

title: F.B.I. Will Purge Files of Names of Protesters
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation says it will purge its files of thousands of names of people and organizations collected during its controversial investigation of Americans who protested United States policy in Central America.

title: Greek Composer, Once Communist, Joins the Right
description: For years Mikis Theodorakis sent his thundering chords across concert halls and movie theaters everywhere and was widely lauded as the heroic Communist who endured torture, prison and exile for his ideals. Now the master of Greek music has again stunned his followers by becoming an ambassador of conservatism in Greece.

title: Female Rappers Strut Their Stuff In a Male Domain
description: In most rap songs, there are only two kinds of women - those who say yes, to become pliant and ornamental sex objects, and those who say no, to be reviled as coldhearted money-grubbers. That's because, well beyond its first decade, rap has been an almost exclusively male domain. Although the first wave of rap records in the late 1970's included a female group, the Funky Four Plus One, among the hundreds of rappers making records during the 1980's, there have been barely enough female performers to be counted on both hands.

title: 17-th Century Japan and Brady Photos
description: THE 17th century was a time of rebirth for Japan, much as the 15th century had been for Europe and, like its predecessor, was marked by social and political change. After a century of civil strife, order had been established by the new Togukawa shogunate, which remained in control until 1868, when power was restored to the emperor.

title: Judith Schlump, A Baker, Is Wed
description: Judith Angela Schlump and John Kirke Sneath were married yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. Alphonse Arminio. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Arthur Schlump of San Juan, P.R. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin Gerlach Sneath of Norristown, Pa.

title: Getting to The Heart of An Image's Power
description: The French critic Roland Barthes, in his book ''Camera Lucida,'' used the word punctum to describe the element in a photograph that stimulated in him an emotional resonance. Barthes was unable to put his finger on precisely why he experienced a certain rush of sympathy when he noticed, for example, the strapped pumps on the feet of a black woman in a 1926 family portrait by James Van der Zee.

title: Class Actions
description: Most school children would rather be called jerks, dweebs or nerds than nothing at all. ''The teacher remembers the kids who play cards when they're not suppposed to and the kids who fight, better than she remembers the other kids -except the smart ones,'' said 9-year-old Matthew Henkel, a fourth-grader at the Immaculate Conception School in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 24 about the Vermont-Quebec border area referred incorrectly to three towns in the area. They are North Hatley (not North Hately), Ayers Cliff (not Aye's Cliff) and Katevale (not Kateville).

title:
GARDENING;
The Easy Magic of Forcing Bulbs
description: LEAD: FOR the winter blues, a pot or two of spring bulbs on the windowsill is the next best thing to an extended vacation in Rio or the Caribbean. One can buy the bulbs in bloom from a florist, but half the fun is in the forcing. The time to start is now.

title: INSIDE
description: Sunday Silence Wins

title: Behind Pink Satin Shoe Are Years of Dedication
description: LEAD: THE pink satin pointe shoe is perhaps the most recognizable and romantic icon of ballet. It is essential equipment to ballerinas who rely on its square toe box, flat heel and ribbons for balance, flexibility and support through intricate dance steps.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE MAN WHO KNEW CARY GRANT, by Jonathan Schwartz. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) The son of a composer with a cast of famous friends finds that his only successful relationship is with his father. ''It is in his portrayal of the past as an abiding presence that Mr. Schwartz excels,'' Janet Kaye said here last year. This novel ''captures the ineffable sadness of lost time.'' WALDHEIM: The Missing Years, by Robert Edwin Herzstein. (Paragon House, $12.95.) After spending two years following a trail of documents from Washington to London, Belgrade and Vienna, a historian tries to close the gaps in the life of Kurt Waldheim, the former Nazi officer who rose through Austrian politics and became Secretary General of the United Nations. Last year our reviewer, Shirley Hazzard, said Robert Edwin Herzstein wasn't hard enough on Mr. Waldheim or his protectors. But she called the book ''a new threshold in the drama, for its volume of pertinent facts and for the portrait of Kurt Waldheim. . . . The reader emerges incredulous that any man could deny such experience.'' MIDNIGHT SWEETS, by Bette Pesetsky. (Ivy, $3.95.) Working in the ephemeral medium of cookie dough, Theodora elevates baking to an art and establishes an empire. ''If it's possible to create a novel whose structure is based on cookies, [ Bette Pesetsky has ] done it,'' David Leavitt said here last year. ''I'm only sorry there aren't recipes.'' FASTING GIRLS: The History of Anorexia Nervosa, by Joan Jacobs Brumberg. (Plume/New American Library, $9.95.) Anorexia is on the rise, the writer argues, because ''the cult of diet and exercise is the closest thing our secular society offers women in terms of a coherent philosophy of the self.'' Last year our reviewer, Eileen Simpson, called this study ''comprehensive and readable.'' THIS IS YOUR LIFE, by Meg Wolitzer. (Penguin, $7.95.) The two daughters of Dottie Engels, a fat stand-up comedian, know their mother mostly from her appearances on the television screen. ''Ms. Wolitzer knows how to draw characters who are trapped in childhood, who feel the pain and novelty that come with fresh experience,'' Kit Reed said here last year. ''Swift and accurate, bristling with detail, 'This Is Your Life' does not so much describe growing up as demonstrate what it's really like.'' AN EMPIRE OF THEIR OWN: How the Jews Invented Hollywood, by Neal Gabler. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) Spurned by East Coast high society, entrepreneurs like Adolph Zukor, L. B. Mayer, the Warner brothers and Harry Cohn established their own fantasy land in Southern California. Last year our reviewer, Molly Haskell, said Neal Gabler ''has a Balzacian zest for financial data, for how deals and fortunes are made and unravel, and a novelist's eye for the way success and failure are prefigured in character.'' A RECENT MARTYR, by Valerie Martin. (Vintage, $7.95.) In New Orleans an unhappily married woman named Emma becomes tangled up in a sadomasochistic threesome. ''This is a striking book, one with as much depth as the reader dares to plumb,'' Carolyn Banks said here last year. CHASING THE GLORY: Travels Across America, by Michael Parfit. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) A journalist and pilot retraces Charles Lindbergh's flight around America to see how the landscape has changed. This book is ''an elegy for what has been lost and a celebration of what remains unspoiled in America - both in the land and in the people,'' John Byrne Cooke said here earlier this year. ''It is also a pleasure to read.'' PACO'S STORY, by Larry Heinemann. (Penguin, $7.95.) A veteran with nightmares of Vietnam moves to a small town in Texas to lose himself in the meditative repetitions of a simple, mindless job. In 1987 our reviewer, Christopher Benfey, said this ''carefully crafted, oblique narrative'' suggests that the horrors of war ''may be as forcefully conveyed by a haunting scene in a greasy spoon as by the tearing of human flesh.'' The novel won a National Book Award. THE FLOATPLANE NOTEBOOKS, by Clyde Edgerton. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The patriarch of a North Carolina family, who fancies himself an engineer, believes that according to the principle of ''natural suspension,'' even a family stricken by the tragedy of Vietnam can be uplifted. ''So perfect is the author's control that each voice, like an individual bell in a handbell choir, rings true,'' Barbara Kingsolver said in The Book Review last year. ''Mr. Edgerton's gift is for dialect that places its speaker squarely - not only on a geographical map, but a psychological one.'' THE QUESTION OF HU, by Jonathan D. Spence. (Vintage, $8.95.) In early 18th-century France, a curious visitor from China found that in the context of European culture his exuberant behavior qualified him for incarceration in an insane asylum. Jonathan D. Spence's ''delicate but nevertheless ambitious approach makes him one of the most original and exciting historians writing now,'' Angeline Goreau said in these pages in 1988. A SOCIAL HISTORY OF MADNESS: The World Through the Eyes of the Insane, by Roy Porter. (Dutton/Obelisk, $8.95.) In this collection of case studies, the history of the asylum is told from the point of view of the inmates. ''Often the eloquence and cogency of the testimonies are striking,'' Marina Warner said here last year. ''Pugnacious yet soft-spoken, the book gives us new ears to listen to the so-called ravings and gibberish of the mad.''

title: Beth Heinsohn, Editor, Marries
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Wadsworth Heinsohn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Heinsohn of State College, Pa., to Andrew Bennett Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Cohen of Phoenix, took place yesterday at the Singer Building in Manhattan. The Rev. William F. Starr, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

The club conducts a weekly duplicate, at 6:45 P.M. each Thursday in Suite 510 of the Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place in Manhattan. Play is open to all comers.

description: Rival Tamil guerrilla groups fought today for the first time since Indian troops withdrew from Ampara district in Eastern Province in Sri Lanka and 31 people, including 3 civilians, were killed, residents said.

description: The first major United States exhibition of paintings by the modern Soviet artist Kasimir Malevich will be shown in Washington, Los Angeles and Manhattan starting next September.

The most casual approaches to waterfowling involve nothing more than positioning oneself in a likely spot and waiting for the birds to fly by within shotgun range, or poking along the edge of stream, river, lake or marsh, hoping to get close enough to birds resting or feeding on the water.

description: A 47-year-old homeless man who was burned over 75 percent of his body in a fire set by a woman in a makeshift shelter in Tompkins Square Park early Saturday died 12 hours later at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, officials said yesterday.

Baker 3d's plan for promoting Israeli-Palestinian talks. But they cautioned that it was too soon to say whether Washington could provide all the assurances that the Israelis were demanding before they entered negotiations.

Last season, his David Gordon/ Pickup Company presented the first installment of ''United States,'' a collection of dances about American life and history. On Saturday night at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College at Purchase, his troupe staged two new pieces from that work. They concerned phenomena that can be found in every corner of the country: weather and birds.

description: ''We want to give all citizens the opportunity without restrictions to travel wherever they want.'' -Friedrich Dickel, Interior Minister of East Germany. [ A10:3. ]

title: Question Box
description: The Winning Pitcher Q. In Game 2 of the National League playoff last month, the Cubs led San Francisco, 6-2, in Chicago, when the Giants put two runners on base with two out in the fifth inning. With the dangerous Will Clark, a left-handed batter, coming up, Manager Don Zimmer removed his starter, Mike Bielecki, a right-hander, and replaced him with the left-handed Paul Assenmacher, who retired Clark to end the inning. But the switch deprived Bielecki of the victory, since he never pitched the required five innings for a starter. If Zimmer had instead moved Bielecki to the outfield, displacing the left fielder, for example, for one batter, then had returned him to the mound in the sixth inning and inserted a new outfielder, would Bielecki have been eligible for the victory after he retired one batter? A. Not as a starting pitcher, but certainly as a reliever if he had gone on to hold the Giants at bay the rest of the way, as Les Lancaster did for Chicago. Moving a starting pitcher to the outfield ends the pitcher's role as a starter, even if it's just for one batter. When he moves back to the mound, he's a relief pitcher, subject to the conditions of qualifying for the victory that apply to any relief pitcher. So Bielecki could not have got credit for the victory as a starter, even though he would have never left the lineup, because he was not used in the role of a starter for the first five innings. But he could have earned the victory in relief if the Cubs had remained ahead and the official scorer had determined that Bielecki was the most effective Chicago pitcher from the bullpen. More Rizzuto vs. Reese Q. An answer two weeks ago that compared Phil Rizzuto of the New York Yankees and Pee Wee Reese of the Brooklyn Dodgers during the six World Series they played against each other was confined to how they did as hitters. What about their fielding, which is often considered the real value of a shortstop to a team? A. Though Reese swung the bat better and more productively in their total Series matchup, when it came to gloves, Rizzuto had the upper hand, hands down. Over the 37 Series games they had in common from 1941 through 1955, Rizzuto wound up with more putouts (73 to 63), more assists (98 to 93) and fewer errors (3 to 8) than Reese. The Yankee shortstop also came out ahead in three other categories that involved neither hitting nor fielding the ball: stolen bases (7 to 6), walks (18 to 9) and winner's checks cashed (5 to 1). Blaik at Dartmouth Q. When Earl (Red) Blaik coached football at Dartmouth before coaching at West Point, how many Ivy League titles did his teams win? A. None, and for one perfectly good reason: there was no Ivy League title to win until 1956 and Blaik coached at Dartmouth from 1934 through 1940. By the time Yale, Harvard, Columbia, Penn, Cornell, Princeton, Brown and Dartmouth were formally formed into the Ivy League, Blaik was winding down his Hall of Fame career as Army coach.
