title: Doctor Who Billed Millions Is Cut by New York Medicaid
description: At Dr. Giovanni del Gizzo's storefront office in East Harlem, patients began lining up as early as 5 A.M. They sat for hours in a crowded, smoky lobby for what was often only a 30- to 45-second consultation with the doctor, who almost invariably handed them a prescription for a battery of drugs worth $150 or more. The state, under Medicaid, picked up the entire tab.

title: Nova Corp of Alberta reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Topics of The Times; Antidote for School Patronage
description: Tape-recorded conversations of New York City school officials openly discussing patronage and jobs in District 27 point to the predominance of political cronyism over education in the city's decentralized school system. There is an obvious antidote: more parental involvement. A good time for parents to administer it is now, during Open School Week.

title: Topics of The Times; Stop Dawdling on Dye No. 3
description: Federal law requires the Food and Drug Administration to outlaw cancer-causing food dyes. Yet the agency has for years postponed action against Red Dye No. 3, despite evidence that the dye, widely used to brighten cosmetics and foods, induces thyroid tumors in animals. The latest extension ends Jan. 29. So should the dawdling.

title: British Rail Shelves Plan
description: The state-owned British Rail said Friday that it had shelved for a year plans to build a high-speed line from London to the English entry point of the Channel Tunnel.

title: Women's Group Backs Charter on Pay Equity
description: To the Editor:

title: Plum Creek Timber Co L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it began operations June 8. The partnership said it earned $9,365,000, or 59 cents a fully- diluted share, on revenues of $126,211,000 from June 8 to Sept. 30.

title: 'Revisionist' Influence Seen in Japan Talks
description: Even though Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, finds the idea of managed trade repugnant, she has a number of outside advisers, principally from the business community, who argue that the closed nature of Japan's economy thwarts classical free-trade solutions for correcting trade imbalances.

title: Shira Lookstein, a Teacher, Is Married
description: Shira Lookstein, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Haskel Lookstein of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Lawrence Baruch, a son of Gladys Baruch of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late David Baruch. The bride's father performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbis Joseph Grunblatt and Hershel Schachter, at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York.

title: Journey's End Corp reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Pittsburgh & W. Va. Railroad reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cerner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dinkins's Vote-Getter in Brooklyn Has Big Army
description: Ed Miller, the man charged with turning out every David N. Dinkins voter in Brooklyn, should be bouncing off the walls these days.

title: Electronic Arts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credit of $120,000, representing net operating loss carryforward.

title: Gang Wars Are Waged With Paint On Walls
description: For two years, Hex and Slick had been eyeing each other warily as their turfs intersected on the streets of Los Angeles. Their showdown last summer, in the old rail yard at Glendale and Second Avenue, quickly became a legend.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Vladimir Horowitz, Titan of the Piano, Dies
description: Vladimir Horowitz, the eccentric virtuoso of the piano whose extraordinary personality and skill overwhelmed six decades of concert audiences, died suddenly early yesterday afternoon at his home in Manhattan, apparently of a heart attack. Though standard biographies list his birth date as Oct. 1, 1904, Mr. Horowitz recently celebrated what he called his 86th birthday.

title: Easy Victories Expected in Four Borough Presidency Races
description: Democratic candidates appear to be heading toward easy victories in four of the five borough presidency races in heavily Democratic New York City.

title: False Landmark in Kansas City
description: Can a Federal court levy taxes? When the question is put that way, as the state of Missouri is trying to do in the Supreme Court, the obvious answer is no. But it would be foolish for the Court to deal with this controversy in Missouri's stark terms.

title: Vicki L. Been Wed to Richard Revesz
description: Vicki L. Been, an associate professor of law at Rutgers University, and Richard L. Revesz, an associate professor of law at New York University, were married yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi Margaret Wenig.

title: Doman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $5,575,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,817,000, or 32 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said sales figures for the latest quarter and 9 months were not immediately available.

title: Disney's High Hopes for Afternoons
description: Executives at the Walt Disney Studio say ''the second golden era of animation'' has begun.

title: Review/Opera; Pavarotti and Vocalism Star in Met's 'Rigoletto'
description: If there is such a thing as a singer's opera, ''Rigoletto'' qualifies. With its inexhaustible stream of familiar arias, duets and larger ensemble numbers, culminating in the famous quartet, it is the Verdi work most likely to attract the fancier of pure vocalism, the operagoer who votes only with the ear. Those single-issue fans had plenty of reason to cheer at the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening, when a new production of ''Rigoletto'' paired Luciano Pavarotti with a newcomer to the company, June Anderson.

title: Israeli Cabinet Approves Baker Plan, With Conditions
description: After weeks of debate, the Israeli Cabinet said today that it had formally approved a plan by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for Israeli-Palestinian talks on elections in the occupied territories. But in doing so, the Cabinet asked the United States to commit itself to several difficult conditions before the talks can take place.

title: Former Chief of Prime Heads Software Maker
description: Joe M. Henson, who left Prime Computer Inc. as president and chief executive last year, is trying his hand at running a small computer software company, the Legent Corporation, in Vienna, Va.

title: Trouble Beyond Earthquakes and Hurricanes
description: To hear many at Lloyd's of London tell it, Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake are only the latest and not necessarily the biggest problems to hit the three-century-old insurance market.

title: Contractors' Role at Energy Dept. Called Pervasive
description: The Energy Department's reliance on contractors and consultants for basic Government functions is pervasive but largely outside public scrutiny, raising questions about its institutional abilities, a Senate subcommittee staff report says.

title: Liechtenstein Hostile To Money Launderers
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; A Viennese Operetta Changes the World
description: Thunder at Twilight Vienna 1913-1914 By Frederic Morton 385 pages. Illustrated. Charles Scribner's Sons. $22.50.

title: People
description: * Robert E. Hall has been named senior vice president of J. Walter Thompson/Chicago.

title: INSIDE
description: No Majority in Greek Vote The conservative New Democracy Party led the balloting but failed to gain enough votes for a parliamentary majority. Page A8. Route Closes for Emigres Washington has closed off an important immigration route sooner than many Soviet Jews hoping to use it had expected. Page A9. Israel Backs Election Plan The Israeli Cabinet approved a plan for Israeli-Palestinian talks on elections in the occupied territories, but with several conditions. Page A3.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Congress has lost its enthusiasm to regulate leveraged buyouts and ''junk bonds,'' in part because the market for such transactions has weakened. But there are political reasons as well. [ Page D1. ] Paper-products companies are wrestling with whether this is a good time to acquire a paper company, since an industry downturn is expected in the next year. [ D1. ] A number of Carla A. Hills's outside advisers argue that the closed nature of Japan's economy thwarts classical solutions for correcting trade imbalances. Their views will be heard as talks on lowering trade barriers enter a second round this week. [ D2. ] Lawyers for the Hunt brothers say their bankruptcy proceedings are inching forward. A resolution is unlikely until 1990. [ D3. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The Tokyo Motor Show has attracted huge crowds to look at ''concept cars'' that park themselves, that unlock by reading fingerprints and that pump jasmine through the air-conditioner. [ D1. ] A British court has ruled that interest-rate swap contracts arranged by a local government in London were not legal and should be voided, causing large losses for banks that arranged them. [ D6. ] Lloyd's of London has been flooded with disaster claims while struggling to cope with tougher international competition, new technology, disgruntled investors and still-undetermined liabilities in lingering cases. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Compaq is expected to introduce a desktop computer that combines the most powerful microprocessor currently available and a new internal ''highway'' that greatly speeds operations. [ D3. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Two issues of Ms. magazine have been canceled and its owner intends to transform it into a subscriber-supported bimonthly that will carry no advertising, editorial employees said. [ D1. ] ''The second golden era of animation'' has begun, Walt Disney executives say. Warner Brothers and Fox Broadcasting plan to join Disney in producing more cartoon programming. [ D1. ] For many in the publishing community, the weekend was filled with questions and rumors about why Robert L. Bernstein's 23 years as head of Random House had ended last week. [ D8. ] Concerns about mounting costs and sagging profits have led to low morale at many publishing companies. Publishing. [ D8. ] Critics have accused Tip O'Neill of becoming too much of a tout. The former House Speaker has appeared in seven advertising campaigns, three of which began in recent weeks. [ D8. ] Coca-Cola is encouraging children to write Santa Claus, in an ad campaign with the Postal Service and Toys for Tots. For each letter received, Coke will donate 5 cents to the charity for needy children. Advertising. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Stock-index futures trading has almost certainly raised, not lowered, stock prices in the last seven years - a telling point obscured in the furor over program trading and index arbitrage. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] Interest rates could be pushed higher because of an avalanche of new Treasury securities and a sense that the Federal Reserve Board may not move quickly to ease monetary policy. Congress' continuing debate on the debt ceiling makes it likely that today's auction of Treasury bills will be postponed. Credit Markets. [ D7. ] The Financial Accounting Foundation's decision to limit the jurisdiction of the Governmental Accounting Standards Board has embittered state and local government groups, nine of which may break away from the foundation. Business and the Law. [ D2. ]

title: Ahletes Gearing Up For Special Olympics
description: THE starting gun sounds, the crowd erupts with cheers and the five Olympic runners sprint toward the finish line of the 50-meter course. A runner trips and falls. Another runner stops to help him up as the rest of the pack surges ahead.

title: Jane Goldstein Is Married
description: Jane Goldstein, a certified public accountant in Englewood, N.J., and Dr. Joel Rakow, a radiologist in Hackensack, N.J., were married yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Azriel Fellner officiated. Mrs. Rakow, a graduate of Rutgers University, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Goldstein of Livingston, N.J. Dr. Rakow, the son of Renee Rakow of Hackensack and Dr. Raymond Rakow of New York, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Oakley Is Off and Rebounding
description: Every shot at the basket carries with it a basketball coach's prayer, but each missed shot causes an even more fervent wish. Coaches love a rebounder. ''Getting those second and third shots is what the game is often all about,'' Chuck Daly, the Detroit Pistons' coach, said the other day. ''To run, you need rebounds. With them, you win; without them, you lose.''

title: A Weak 3d Period Undoes Islanders
description: The Islanders dropped to the bottom of the Patrick Division standing tonight after losing, 3-2, to the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: Higher Interest Rates Seem Likely
description: Interest rates could be pushed a bit higher over the next few weeks because of an avalanche of new Treasury securities and a growing sense among market participants that the Federal Reserve Board may not move quickly to ease monetary policy, credit analysts contend.

title: Business and the Law; A Bitter Schism In Accounting
description: THE recent decision by the Financial Accounting Foundation to limit the jurisdiction of the Governmental Accounting Standards Board has produced a far-reaching outcry in the accounting profession and the agencies affected.

title: National HMO Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Pancho's Mexican Buffet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Coral Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Baltic States Should Have Independence
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Foot Forward, or Close
description: The National Horse Show concluded its debut at the Meadowlands tonight with a familiar trill from the huntsman's horn and the $50,000 Big Apple Grand Prix, an ironic link to the show's former home site of the last 105 years.

title: Horses' Handlers Still Dueling
description: On the morning after the race of the decade, the winners insisted that their victory was an ultimate triumph, while the losers conceded only that they had lost one particular race by a neck.

title: Over an Eventful Weekend, The Emigres Find New Lives
description: East Germans, with a few belongings packed into tiny rattling automobiles, are swarming through a narrow neck of northwestern Czechoslovakia to new lives in the West.

title: Charger Re-Kick Upsets Eagles
description: Chris Bahr can thank a jumpy James FitzPatrick for a second attempt at a game-winning field goal, even if the false start added 5 yards to the attempt.

title: Wellington Leisure Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Sweat
description: A deeply held belief, usually acquired from childhood memories of castor oil, holds that no medicine can really be effective unless it tastes horrible. It follows that no exercise can really be of benefit unless it brings aches, agony and sweat.

title: Review/Television; College Student Raped by an Acquaintance
description: Originally scheduled for broadcast a few weeks ago, the made-for-television CBS movie ''When He's Not a Stranger'' was pre-empted by the earthquake in California. It's now scheduled for tonight at 9. The subject is acquaintance rape, which seems to be preoccupying the networks this year. At least two daytime dramas geared to younger audiences have tackled the subject.

title: Late Kick By Leahy Saves Jets
description: A cast of unknowns named Werner, Dressel and Epps made their first catches as Jets today, a symbol of how far this club has scrambled for healthy performers.

title: Allied Security Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $476,045 from a cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Showbiz Pizza Time reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $3,547,000 and $2,216,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The extraordinary item in the latest quarter included a charge of $4,521,000 related to the planned closing of up to 26 Monterey House restaurants, partially offset by a gain of $974,000 from tax credits. The latest 9-month item included the charge related to the closings, partially offset by a $2,305,000 tax benefit. c-Net income d-Included an extraordinary credit from tax credits of $315,000, or 7 cents a share, and $716,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Communications Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
News Summary
description: International A3-10 East Germans fled to the West by the thousands, while East Berlin said that new laws making it relatively easy for citizens to travel West would be ready by Christmas. Page A1 Scenes of sorrow and anguish were evident in a Czechoslovak border town, where East German parents carried the bags of their children, some still only teen-agers, up to the border and bade them farewell. A1 News analysis: Tear down the wall? As thousands of East Germans continue to go through Czechoslovakia's open border, Europeans have begun to ponder that question. A10 The Lebanese Parliament met in a remote mountain village and elected a new President, Rene Moawad. He is a Maronite Christian described as commanding the respect of many factions in the civil war. A1 Man in the News: Rene Moawad A7 Israel formally approved a U.S. plan for Israeli-Palestinian talks on elections in the occupied territories. But the Cabinet asked Washington to commit itself to several conditions before the talks. A3 U.S. lauds Israel but remains noncommital A3 A Greek conservative party won the largest share of votes in general elections, but it failed to get enough votesto gain a parliamentary majority and form a government. A8 Prime Minister Thatcher was quoted as saying that she was likely to step down from leadership after her next term of office if she wins the next election. It was her first disclosure that she saw an end to her term. A5 Trouble at Lloyd's of London D4 Washington has closed immigration for many Soviet Jews sooner than they had expected by cutting off the immigration flow through Vienna and Rome. A9 Namibia is to choose an assembly on Tuesday that will draft a constitution before the land becomes independent next year. Swapo is expected to win a majority of the ballots. A10 Innovations at the Tokyo Motor Show have attracted 1.7 million people since it opened 10 days ago. While the show has become an important stage for auto makers, G.M. barely made an effort to show its wares. D1 Alipur Journal: Poorest of Indian poor still yearn for vote A4 National A12-21 The boom in poultry production, created by Americans' growing appetite for chicken, has also meant an increase in worker injuries at plants in dozens of towns in the South. A1 The Virginia race for governor, in which a black candidate is leading in the polls, has demonstrated the new South, the changing role of race in politics and the sudden emergence of abortion as an electoral issue. A12 Washington at Work: The Bush style is reflected in the ''little summit'' planned for December. To foster candid views, Mr. Bush likes to cut out bureaucracy and formality. A14 The Energy Department is reliant on contractors and consultants, and that raises questions about its abilities, a Senate report says. A21 Academic performance has dropped among undergraduates, according to a survey of professors by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. A18 Catholic bishops marked a birthday before plunging into a four-day conference. Two hundred years ago, the nation's initial Roman Catholic bishopric began in Baltimore. A16 What happened to junk-bond rules? After early enthusiasm for new regulations on junk bonds and leveraged buyouts, lawmakers have lost interest, partly for political reasons. D1 Disney is reviving animation. It has produced enough cartoons for a planned 3-to-5 P.M. block of syndicated children's programs - the ''Disney Afternoon.'' D1 Using spray paint cans as weapons, two young men in Los Angeles fought a duel that lasted four days and covered 130 feet of a rail yard wall. Some see this battle of art as a desirable substitute for gang fighting. A12 Perhaps too visibly, O'Neill becomes an ad spokesman D8 Regional B1-8 In the final Dinkins-Giuliani debate, the candidates sparred over integrity and job qualifications and traded charges of distortion. Then they perfunctorily shook hands. A1 In two mayoral debates, some charges are short on evidence B7 Dinkins's Brooklyn vote-getter has a bigger army than rival B8 Easy victories are expected in four borough chiefs' races B6 New Yorkers facing ballot issue on liability of sheriffs B4 A1 New Jersey voters face a choice in tomorrow's gubernatorial election between a Democrat who wants a return to activist government and a Republican who promises to battle big government, taxes and crime. B1 News analysis: Budget problems in New York State have become so pervasive that analysts wonder whether officials are willing to face the state's long-term fiscal problem. B1 Land-use rules have been criticized in the debate over New York City charter revision. Critics of the charter say the proposed rules would give too much power to non-elected officials. B8 After a record cocaine seizure Friday in a Queens warehouse, Federal officials said that they are looking for a man from Peru, his Colombian wife and at least three others. B1 Art is starting to appear in subways in New York City. Since 1985, $350,000 has gone for art projects. Twelve have been permanently installed; another 21 are in progress. B3

title: Scientific Measurement reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Voters Facing A Ballot Issue Over Sheriffs
description: The Governor has it. Mayors have it. Members of city councils and school boards have it. In fact, every public official in New York State has it, except for county sheriffs - and now even they will get it if more people vote ''yes'' than ''no'' in the only statewide proposition that will appear on ballots in Tuesday's election.

title: Top Women Find Benefit in Obstacles
description: Breathing problems, pre-race exhaustion and cramps may not be a prescription for road running success, but in varying doses they did the trick for Ingrid Kristiansen and Kim Jones yesterday as the Norwegian legend and the new American sensation finished first and second in the women's division of the 20th New York City Marathon.

title: Coda Energy reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $3,563,756, or 81 cents a share. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary tax credit of $348,819, or 12 cents a share.

title: Intermet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Military Set in Motion
description: Few institutions of higher learning have as great a football tradition as the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y. So when Steve Sabol, president of National Football League Films, set out to do a historical video about Army football he was surprised at the paucity of available film footage about the Black Knights.

title: Cowboys' Drought Comes to an End
description: The Dallas Cowboys had suffered so much misery during their long losing streak that toiling at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium tonight might have seemed like a relatively easy task. Dallas had dropped all eight of its games this season and had won only one of its last 20 games. Its last victory? At R.F.K., in Week 15 last season.

title: Summing Up: Closing Words From 3 Mayoral Candidates
description: Following is a transcript of the closing statements by New York City's mayoral candidates, Rudolph W. Giuliani, David N. Dinkins and Henry Hewes, at a debate yesterday on WNBC-TV, as recorded by The New York Times: Mr. HEWES

title: Nilan Is Out For 8 Weeks
description: Chris Nilan, the veteran right wing for the Rangers who is as important for his leadership in the locker room as his policing on the ice, went crashing into the Montreal net in the third period of Saturday night's 3-2 loss to the Canadiens, breaking his right arm. He will be out for eight weeks.

title: Reading by Stoveside
description: Poor Paul Dickson. As the compiler of ''The Dickson Baseball Dictionary,'' he should be cooking with gas about now.

title: Review/Opera; New Violetta and Germont in Met's 'Traviata'
description: Operagoers who managed to tear their eyes away from Franco Zeffirelli's extravagant new sets might have noticed a few changes in Saturday afternoon's cast of ''Traviata'' at the Metropolitan Opera. Karen Huffstodt was the new Violetta. Sherrill Milnes took over the role of Germont.

title: Eco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Allis-Chalmers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $2,336,000 and $1,073,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said results from continuing operations in 1989 and as reclassified for 1988 consist primarily of the machine repair subsidiary, Houston Dynamic Service Inc. discontinued operations relate to businesses that were sold in 1988 and costs associated with voluntary bankruptcy proceedings, from which Allis-Chalmers emerged on Oct. 31. The latest 9-month income from continuing operations included investment income of $313,000.

title: Moto Photo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in its latest 9 months reflected first-quarter losses incurred from 49 acquisitions made in 1988.

title: 2 Americans Looking Strong
description: The second-place finishes by Ken Martin and Kim Jones at the New York City Marathon yesterday may not signal an end to America's long-distance drought, but they made followers of United States marathoning proud.

title: Empi Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a tax benefit of $9,000.

title: Entertainment Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $835,000 which reflects cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Greek Conservatives Lead in Votes But Fail to Win Majority of Seats
description: The conservative New Democracy Party won the most votes in general elections today, but it failed to get enough votes to gain a parliamentary majority and form a government.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker Beats Edberg: Boris Becker, his leg muscles feeling tight after playing almost 14 hours in four days, handily defeated Stefan Edberg, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday to win the Paris Open. But fatigue from three grueling matches earlier in the tournament forced Becker to bandage his thigh midway through the two-hour contest and take chances to end the match quickly. Becker defeated Guy Forget, Wally Masur and John McEnroe in three long sets each before the final. Becker had 19 aces and 14 service winners.(AP) Navratilova Wins: Martina Navratilova continued her dominance of Zina Garrison with a 6-2, 6-3 victory to capture the Virginia Slims of New England in Worcester, Mass. The victory was Navratilova's 26th in 27 meetings with Garrison, whose only victory came in the quarterfinals of the 1988 United States Open. In the opening set, Navratilova rifled a pair of winning forehands to the corners to gain a third-game service break. She then broke serve again in the seventh game with a cross-court forehand and a well placed drop-shot beyond a chasing Garrison. She continued her dominance in the second set, using a strong serve and volley game.(AP) SOCCER Fairleigh Dickinson 6, L.I.U. 3: German Quijano scored two goals in just over a minute in the first overtime yesterday to lead the Knights to the Northeast Conference tournament championship in Teaneck, N.J. With the victory, Fairleigh Dickinson, ranked 11th nationally, receives an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, which begins next weekend. Quijano, a sophomore midfielder from Jersey City who was selected the tournament's most valuable player, scored in the 96th and 97th minutes to erase a 3-2 deficit. Faisal Ahmad added two goals for the Knights, who are now 17-3. L.I.U. is 9-8-1. Connecticut 3, Seton Hall 1: Rob Lindell had a goal and an assist and Tom Foley made 11 saves as the Huskies stopped Seton Hall, a three-time defending champion, in the Big East Conference championship at Storrs, Conn. Foley, the senior goalkeeper, was selected the tournament's outstanding player after making 17 saves in two matches. Connecticut (12-4-5) advances to next week's N.C.A.A. tournament. Ian Hennessy scored the only goal for Seton Hall (10-7-1). DOG SHOW Pointer Named Best: A German shorthaired pointer, Ch. Lieblinghaus Here's to Freedom, who is called Flair and is owned and handled by Ruth Freer, was named best of 1,200 dogs at the 63d all-breed show of the Union County Kennel Club yesterday in Elizabeth, N.J. The 4-year-old bitch gained her first top award, defeating five dogs in the final who had been previous best-in-show winners. FOOTBALL Stothard Leads St. Francis Prep: Chris Stothard completed 13 of 19 passes for 174 yards and threw two touchdown passes to Frank Franklin, and Dino Kalesis kicked a 35-yard field goal to lead St. Francis Prep, the defending champion, to a 24-13 victory over Nazareth in the quarterfinals of the Catholic High Schools Football League playoffs yesterday in Brooklyn. AUTO RACING Points Race Going Down to Wire: Rusty Wallace's misfortune here yesterday set the stage for another Nascar stock-car last-race showdown. The Winston Cup points race came back to Mark Martin and Dale Earnhardt after Wallace was bumped from behind by Stan Barrett, knocking Wallace out of the lead with just 57 laps remaining yesterday in the Autoworks 500 at Phoenix International Raceway. While Bill Elliott went on to win the race, Martin and Earnhardt finish in the top six, closing in on Wallace in the points standing with only one race left.(AP)

''That's why we play so much new music, and commission so many new works. We want to play music with expanded tonal possibilities - music that is more powerful and has a wider range of sounds than people traditionally associate with a wind quintet.''

Review/Theater; 'Threepenny Opera,' With Sting
description: After emerging from the inert gray mass that is Broadway's ''Threepenny Opera,'' the first thing you want to do - assuming you don't drink - is run home and listen to any available recording of its score. The reason is not to revisit the evening's high points - there are none - but to make sure you are still among the living. How could these scathing songs, forged in the crucible of the century's apocalypse, sound as numbing as they do from the stage? One would have to be lobotomized not to respond to the blasted fusion of jazz, classicism and political rage with which Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht first rocked Berlin in 1928.

New Polish Devaluation
description: Poland devalued the zloty today by 14.3 percent. It was the fourth devaluation since the Solidarity-led Government took office in September. The devaluation is part of a program to narrow the large gap between the free market and official rates of the currency against the dollar. The National Bank set the new rate at 2,800 zloties to the dollar, compared with 2,400 on Friday. The free market rate is a bit less than 7,000.

title: A Draft Law Grants East Germans the Right to Travel or Emigrate
description: East Germany today published the draft of a law that declared for the first time that every citizen has the right to travel abroad or to emigrate. But against the weekend backdrop of yet another surge of emigration to West Germany, the measure seemed to attract little excitement.

description: Dr. Juergen Tonndorf, a professor emeritus of otolaryngology at the Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, died of kidney failure on Friday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 75 years old.

description: Vivian Mercier, an Irish literary critic and teacher whose published works included a major study on the work of Samuel Beckett, died Saturday in London, The Irish Times reported today. He was 70 years old. The cause of death was not announced.

description: Robinson Nugent Inc. said it had asked its advisers to explore a possible merger or sale of the company as well as potential acquisitions. Shares of Robinson Nugent rose 87.5 cents a share today, to $5.875, in over-the-counter trading. Its 17.5 percent rise was the fifth best among Nasdaq issues. Robinson, which is based in New Albany, has almost 5.3 million shares outstanding and is worth about $31 million at its present price.

description: The White House was not exactly trumpeting it to the world, but Richard M. Nixon was back in the Presidential residence Sunday night, giving his former protege in the world of Chinese-American relations a firsthand report on his trip to China.

title: Braniff, Citing Lack of Cash, Ceases Passenger Service
description: Braniff Inc. said today that it was ceasing all passenger service immediately because a severe cash shortage doomed its bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: AIDS and Children: Longer, but Troubled, Life
description: Celeste Carrion, a Bronx girl infected with the AIDS virus since birth, died last month at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. She was buried in the rain in a white coffin with her two favorite teddy bears by her side.

title: Debt Ceiling Delays Sale By Treasury
description: The Treasury was forced to postpone its scheduled weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday because Congress failed to pass legislation raising the debt limit.

title: Bank Choice On Mexico
description: Mexico has received replies from 42 percent of its foreign creditor banks on a debt renegotiation plan, and 90 percent of them are opting to reduce principal and interest rather than grant new loans, the official news agency Notimex said today.

title: TALKS AT BOEING APPEAR STALLED
description: Five weeks into a strike that has virtually shut down airplane production at the Boeing Company and cut a $2 billion annual payroll in half, this city is starting to get jitters over the prospect of a walkout that could last through Christmas.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical Electronics Inc., Dallas, a medical equipment manufacturer, said Charlie H. Pulley had announced his retirement as executive vice president.

description: Using techniques and insights gleaned over the last two decades,geologists have made great strides in their ability to make long-term predictions about earthquakes.

title: Michigan Utility Eager to Switch Shoreham to Gas
description: The only company ever to convert a failed nuclear reactor to a generator fueled by natural gas said yesterday that it was eager to do the same at the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, and seven other companies said they would like to study such a conversion for the Long Island Power Authority.

title: Sag Harbor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: BISHOPS INTENSIFY FIGHT ON ABORTION
description: The national conference of Roman Catholic bishops is working to re-energize the anti-abortion movement, conference members said today.

title: Our Towns; A Small Crime And a Big Game Divide a School
description: It was by no means the most shocking of crimes in an age when some 16-year-olds shoot each other. Just a prank. Nobody was hurt. ''But I think it's very serious, and we're definitely taking it seriously,'' said Capt. James Watson, the amiable acting police chief of this suburb of 14,500 that prides itself on its small-town values and the prowess of its high school's football team, the Wolcott Eagles.

description: The latest periods included one- time $800,000 loss due to revision of state tax.

title: Troops Raid Campus in Peru Looking for Leftist Guerrillas
description: Police and army troops raided the campus of Peru's largest university in search of Maoist guerrillas today, less than a week before nationwide municipal elections that the guerrillas have vowed to disrupt.

title: Services for Horowitz
description: The body of the pianist Vladimir Horowitz, who died of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan on Sunday afternoon, will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street, tomorrow afternoon, with visiting hours from 4 to 7. Mr. Horowitz was 86 years old. The pianist's wife, Wanda Toscanini Horowitz, will fly to Milan, Italy, with her husband's body on Thursday. Mr. Horowitz is to be buried near Mrs. Horowitz's father, the conductor Arturo Toscanini, in the Toscanini family plot at the Cimitero Monumentale in Milan.

description: Greeks awoke today to a sight that astonished even this land of cantankerous politics: the country's two most powerful men deadlocked, each claiming the right to govern but neither with enough seats in Parliament to take the reins of power.

The agreement calls for the merger of BellSouth's domestic cellular holdings with those of Lin. Lin's shareholders must approve the deal. McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. has made a hostile offer for Lin.

The latest periods per share earnings applicable to common shares was reduced due to an imputed dividend payment on preferred stock issued by the company's lead bank to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

title: Critic's Notebook; Day 3,650: Looking Back at the Hostages Crisis
description: The seizure of the United States embassy in Teheran by Iranian revolutionaries on Nov. 4, 1979, and the capture of 65 staff members created a foreign policy emergency for Washington, a political disaster for President Jimmy Carter and an opportunity for television to demonstrate its power. Now, 10 years later, the networks are replaying those strong pictures of blindfolded Americans and raging Iranians. They remind viewers how television exacerbated public reaction to the event, contributed to the demolition of the Carter Presidency and raised questions about the effects of the incessant attention on so emotion-stirring an event.

title: Kumerow Is Arrested
description: Eric Kumerow, a reserve defensive end for the Miami Dolphins, faces two felony counts of assaulting a police officer after reportedly punching a policeman Sunday night outside a sports bar in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that is operated by a former Dolphins safety, Mike Kozlowski. Kumerow and his sister, Cheryl, were arrested after the police were called to the bar, Koz's, because of a fight inside the establishment. They were released after posting bond.

title: Tent Jail Closes in New Jersey
description: Hudson County's tent jail closed today after a battle between state and county officials over the need to find more room for inmates. The last 23 inmates were transferred to the county's new jail in Kearny, closing a chapter in New Jersey's struggle to reduce prison overcrowding. Of the 12-tent jail, set up in an old quarry, a Corrections Department spokeswoman, Pat Mulcahy, said: ''It was very successful. We feel we proved it can be done.''

description: Jack Chernus, a retired psychiatrist and medical writer, died of colon cancer on Oct. 18 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 77 years old.

He did not elaborate. The 32-square-mile island in the Malaysian state of Sabah is a free port, which houses a shipyard and a gas complex.

The merger agreement calls for Vipont, based in Fort Collins, to sell Colgate all of its outstanding common shares, at $14 a share. Vipont will also spin off to its shareholders on Dec. 1 a total of 65 percent of the outstanding shares of Vipont Research Labs Inc.

title: The Joke Factory and the Wall
description: A year ago, even six months ago, nobody could have sanely predicted what is happening in Berlin, Budapest and points east. How baffling for true believers in the cold war, West or East, when the unthinkable becomes commonplace - and yesterday's whispered joke is today's headline.

description: The rush of East Germans fleeing through Czechoslovakia to West Germany showed little sign of abating today.

description: Not so long ago, the possibility of organ transplants was the stuff of ''Frankenstein.'' The notion that a baby could be conceived in a petri dish was far-fetched. Today, both are realities.

description: This riverfront city of old textile mills and factories has always drawn immigrants by the thousands. First there were the Irish and the Italians, then the Greeks and Poles. Most recently, Latin Americans and Southeast Asians have migrated here for jobs.

Chuck Jones on Life and Daffy Duck
description: It was raining. Horns were honking. Chuck Jones, the 77-year-old animator, was sitting calmly in a hired black stretch limousine, asking a reporter if he had ever heard about the nefarious doings of the Anti-Destination League. ''You never heard of them?'' he asked, with the hint of a smile. ''Well, they're all over the place, the members of the Anti-Destination League.''

Total Health, based in Great Neck, L.I., owns and operates health maintenance organizations with about 115,000 members and had revenues for the first half of 1989 of $51.8 million. It has about 6.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Surgery for Mel Allen
description: Mel Allen, a long-time Yankees announcer, has undergone successful triple-bypass heart surgery, the club announced yesterday. The Yankees said Allen underwent the operation last Wednesday at the University of Alabama Hospital in Birmingham and was expected to be released from the hospital next week.(AP)

title: Manila Stocks at High
description: The main Philippine stock market reached a record high today after investors overcame weekend jitters caused by street demonstrations and President Corazon C. Aquino's departure for the United States. The composite index rebounded 2.9 percent to close at 1,348.16 points. The previous high was 1,337.47 on July 21, 1987.

title: Critic's Notebook; Romanticizing Hollywood's Dream Factory
description: Hortense Powdermaker could be a screen name concocted by some mischievous junior press agent, giddy from a long day of inventing names to rival Rock Hudson or Tab Hunter. But Miss Powdermaker was a real and serious anthropologist who spent 1947 doing fieldwork in Hollywood and emerged with a study that defined the central paradox of studio-controlled movie making. Her book, ''Hollywood: The Dream Factory,'' presented the unromantic picture of an industry churning out mass-produced dreams with all the cold efficiency of a Detroit auto plant.

title: Mack Sentence Reduced
description: Kevin Mack, the Cleveland Browns' running back who was sentenced to a six-month prison term on Oct. 3 for cocaine possession, was released in Cleveland yesterday after serving one month of his sentence. He was granted a two-year probation by Judge Richard J. McMonagle of Cuyahoga County Common Pleas with the provision that he undergo periodic tests for drug use.

title: U.S. Agrees to Reimburse Iran
description: The United States has agreed to the return of $567 million to Iran from an account providing for claims by American banks, United States officials said tonight. About $243 million from the account would be retained for settling remaining claims.

title: Coca-Cola to Donate $50 Million to Education
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its private foundation would distribute $50 million over the next decade to support educational institutions and programs throughout the United States.

title: INSIDE
description: Lebanese Christians Attack Christian hard-liners stormed the Maronite patriarch's residence near Beirut to demonstrate opposition to a peace accord. Page A3. Braniff Shuts Down The airline ceased all passenger service this morning, saying a severe cash shortage had doomed its bankruptcy reorganization plan. Page D1. Oakland's Silver Lining Taking stock after last month's earthquake, Oakland has found unexpected promise from a refurbished public image. Page A18. Rushdie, 9 Months Later Salman Rushdie, the British author who has been in hiding for nine months after Iranian threats, is reported ''in good spirits.'' Page A4.

title: Compaq Redefines High End
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation today introduced two new products that redefine the high end of personal computer performance and are likely to change the landscape of office computing in the 1990's.

title: Scientists Grow Antibodies in Plants
description: Scientists have developed a technique for using plants to grow monocolonal antibodies, important proteins widely used in medicine to diagnose and treat diseases.

description: The strike that has virtually shut Boeing's airplane production for five weeks is starting to hurt the economy of the Seattle area. Page A16.

title: Israelis Kill a Fleeing Palestinian Militant
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian militant today as he tried to flee to Jordan, the army said.

title: Columbia and Hartwick Receive N.C.A.A. Bids
description: Columbia and Hartwick are back in the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament after a four-year absence, but Adelphi and Long Island University, who had legitimate hopes, were left out when the bids for the Division I tournament were announced yesterday.

title: Lubec Journal; As Small Town Burns, Its Tight Fabric Frays
description: Marylyn Curtis had planned to spend Thanksgiving with her daughter in Chicago, but a recent series of suspicious fires in this seaside town, including one in an abandoned church next door to her home, have changed her plans.

title: Isolated Desert Community Lives by Skinner's Precepts
description: WHEN the psychologist B. F. Skinner wrote his utopian prescription ''Walden II'' some 40 years ago, he probably did not have in mind an isolated ranch in the barren desert of northern Mexico. But 16 years after its founding, the Comunidad los Horcones has come to represent the most sustained and complete effort to apply to real life the behaviorist principles contained in Dr. Skinner's novel-cum-textbook.

title: Talks Continue On Unix Issue
description: The two camps in the computer industry dispute over the direction of the Unix operating system said yesterday that they were expanding discussions to find areas of cooperation.

title: Chapter 7 Is Ordered For Hunt
description: Frustrated by the inability of two creditors to reach a compromise in the 14-month-old bankruptcy case of William Herbert Hunt, Federal Judge Harold C. Abramson said today that he would order a Chapter 7 liquidation of Mr. Hunt's assets on Nov. 20.

title: P&F Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Boeing has agreed to plead guilty to two felony charges of illegally obtaining Pentagon documents, Government officials said. A guilty plea by Boeing raises the possibility that the company could be barred from bidding on military contracts, but the Pentagon said such a restriction ''would not be automatic.'' [ Page A1. ] The strike that has virtually shut Boeing's airplane production for five weeks is starting to hurt the Seattle economy. [ A16. ] Braniff said it was ceasing all passenger service immediately because a cash shortage doomed its reorganization plan. [ D1. ] Southland agreed to sell the remaining 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation to Venezuela's oil company. The deal would make Venezuela the first OPEC member to own all of a large American oil refiner and marketer. [ D1. ] Shearson Lehman Hutton warned its employees to brace for more layoffs in the next few weeks. [ D5. ] A Federal judge ordered a Chapter 7 liquidation in the bankruptcy case of William Herbert Hunt because two creditors are unable to reach a compromise. [ D5. ] About $5.4 billion in Sears, Roebuck debt is being reviewed by Standard & Poor's for a possible downgrading of its ratings. [ D17. ] The Los Angeles Times is trying to attract readers of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, which has ceased publication. [ D21. ] Compaq Computer introduced two new products that sharply expand the high end of personal computer performance. [ C14. ] A Michigan utility wants to convert the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island to a power generator fueled by natural gas. But Lilco is now skeptical that the Shoreham plant is needed. [ B2. ] MARKETS The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 47.34 points, to 2,582.17, as waves of futures-related trading battered the stock market. The Dow is about 13 points above the level it reached on Oct. 13, when it plunged 190.58 points. [ D1 ] . The Treasury was forced to delay its auction of three- and six-month bills because Congress failed to raise the debt ceiling. Meanwhile, prices of notes and bonds fell in very light trading. [ D1. ] 'Junk bond' prices made slight gains in light trading. [ D17. ] Jail terms were given to the managing partner of Princeton/ Newport and the five other defendants convicted of creating illegal tax losses through fraudulent stock trades [ D1. ] Precious-metal futures prices rose, with gold gaining $2.80 to $3.10 an ounce. [ D18. ] The dollar closed higher against most leading currencies in quiet, uninspired trading. [ D18. ] THE ECONOMY The Supreme Court cleared the way for the reorganization of A. H. Robins and the payment of up to $2.5 billion in damages to women injured by the Dalkon Shield. [ D6. ] Nine state and local government groups are discussing the formation of a new body to set accounting standards, one that would be independent of the Financial Accounting Foundation. [ D2. ] Regulators announced more stringent financial standards for savings institutions and reported another heavy loss for the industry in the July-September quarter. [ D9. ] The House Banking Committee postponed for two weeks the testimony of Charles H. Keating Jr., the former owner of the collapsed Lincoln Savings. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Pepsico and Southwestern Bell are reporting success in their efforts to control their medical costs. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Freeport-McMoran Energy Partners attracted investors with a tempting offer: a guaranteed 10 percent yield, with much or all of it free from Federal taxes. But the high dividends have not been enough to offset the falling value of the partnership units. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D10. ] The California State Lottery has narrowed the candidates for its $50 million advertising account to four. Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Colorado Is New No. 1
description: After their convincing 27-21 victory over the Nebraska Cornhuskers on Saturday, a result that almost certainly assures them the Big Eight Conference championship, the 9-0 Buffaloes of Colorado yesterday moved to the top of The New York Times's computer ranking of the nation's leading college football teams.

description: b-Included a charge of about $180,000 relating to consolidation of Quaker Sealants & Coatings operations in Oklahoma. The company added that unfavorable foreign currency fluctuations penalized net income in excess of $525,000 for the latest 9-month period. Also negatively affecting operating results are business development expenses in the Quaker Sealants & Coatings group. Corrected from Saturday, Nov. 4.

title: Philippine Debt Is Rescheduled
description: The Philippines and the United States have agreed to reschedule payments on $362.2 million of Manila's debt, the Philippine Finance Secretary, Vicente Jayme, said Sunday.

title: Reviews/Music; Edita Gruberova in Recital
description: The Czechoslovak soprano Edita Gruberova made her Metropolitan Opera debut 12 years ago in a production of ''Die Zauberflote'' and is currently singing Violetta in the company's new production of ''La Traviata.'' She has also appeared intermittently in other Met productions over the years, and her recordings are plentiful. But she had not given a song recital in New York until Sunday afternoon, when she offered a brief but affecting program of German and Czechoslovak works at Alice Tully Hall.

title: 400 at Metropolitan Museum Fondly Recall the Vreeland Touch
description: Famous faces from the worlds of fashion, art, publishing and society gathered at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday to pay tribute to the the legendary fashion figure Diana Vreeland, who once said, ''I loathe nostalgia.''

title: Chrysler Changes
description: The Chrysler Corporation is changing its corporate structure, disbanding its four-year-old holding company structure. Under the change, the Chrysler Motors Corporation, the car-making arm of the company, will cease to exist on Jan. 1. ''We're merging Chrysler Motors into the Chrysler Corporation, and the legal entity of Chrysler Motors goes away,'' a company spokesman, Steve Harris, said. ''The move is purely technical, legal and tax-oriented. It will not have any impact on people or titles and will not change the company's internal or external operation in any way,'' he added. Mr. Harris declined to say how much in taxes the company expects to save because of the move.

description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest third quarter was largely due to one-time costs of the planned acquisition of marketing and manufacturing rights to a package of proprietary products. Year-to-date expenses, including those costs, increased to $26.6 million from $14.9 million last year.

title: Granato's Scoring and Passing Lead Rangers to a Big Victory
description: He has not been in the headlines much this season. The goals have not come in the bunches they did last year in his rookie season, and so the crush of microphones and cameras in front of his locker has not formed as it almost always did. Less conspicuous a star, Tony Granato has become a more fleeting presence in the locker room.

title: New Jersey Questions Superfund Priority
description: After a robust start in the early 1980's, New Jersey's cleanup of Superfund toxic waste sites is grinding along behind schedule. With years of costly work ahead, the state's environmental commissioner is asking if the expense is justified.

description: The emotion and relief evident in the Dallas Cowboys' locker room after their 13-3 victory over the Washington Redskins Sunday night was what one would expect from a team that had just done away with the ugly specter of a 0-16 season.

title: Pittsburgh Official Convicted
description: Ben Woods, acting president of the City Council, was convicted today of racketeering and extortion charges hours after he resigned. Mr. Woods was accused of accepting $19,600 in payments from a businesman, Michael Hartman, in exchange for influence and $36,727 from another businessman, Joseph Wozniak. Following Mr. Woods's resignation, the Council elected Eugene (Jeep) DePasquale acting president.

title: Schoenfeld Dismissed As Coach Of Devils
description: The Devils dismissed Jim Schoenfeld as their head coach yesterday and replaced him with John Cunniff, who had joined the team as an assistant coach last May.

title: By Design; Beyond Pedal Pushers
description: If there was any question that fashion is traveling up from the streets rather than the other way around, there certainly is not now. One of the strongest style statements to surface at the recent Paris showings of ready-to-wear clothes for next spring was the high styling of typical Manhattan bicycle messenger gear.

title: Reviews/Music; Najma Akhtar in U.S. Debut
description: Najma Akhtar, a British singer of Indian descent, has made herself comfortable between two worlds. In her United States debut, on Friday at Town Hall, she turned ancient poetry into cross-cultural songs, using Eastern and Western instruments to give the underpinnings of Western pop to Indian-inflected melodies.

Source Perrier is the mineral-water giant based in France. ''We have taken this action to safeguard our market position, which has, in fact, shown consistent decline over the past 10 years and to protect the future of our brands given the enormous growth potential of the French soft drink market,'' Pepsico said.

title: Itel Seeks to Buy Interest in Ryder

Ryder's board believes it is in the Miami-based company's best long-term interest to continue as an independent company, said M. Anthony Burns, Ryder's chairman, president and chief executive.

description: New York City Parks Department workers tore down about 20 tents and confiscated the belongings of 25 homeless people in Tompkins Square Park yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Potomac Politics On Kapital Hill
description: LEAD: As we took our seats in the gallery, the parliamentary session was being called to order for a debate on a property rights bill proposed by the Government. The deputies put aside their newspapers, stopped chatting with their colleagues and searched for copies of conflicting drafts of one of the most important pieces of legislation to be considered in the recent history of the country.

title: From the Libretto of the Mayoral Campaign, Selected Verses
description: If the New York City mayoral race has been filled with sour notes, it has also produced its share of sweet music. Partisan poets of both camps have composed a veritable album of campaign songs - all of them unofficial, many of them unsolicited and most of them unheard.

title: Dinkins 'Willing to Accept' Error in Not Reporting Trip
description: David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate for mayor, said last night that he would amend a city financial disclosure form today to report that a family friend and campaign contributor helped pay for a vacation in the south of France last year.

title: Timoci Bavadra, 55, Ex-Premier of Fiji
description: Timoci Bavadra, who was Prime Minister for one month in 1987 before being ousted in the South Pacific nation's first army coup, died of spinal cancer Friday. He was 55 years old. In 1987, Sitiveni Rabuka, then a lieutenant colonel, stormed Parliament with a small band of masked soldiers, capturing Mr. Bavadra and his ministers and putting him under house arrest. When Colonel Rabuka had the country under military control, he released Mr. Bavadra.

Court Rejects Challenges to Dalkon Accord
description: The Supreme Court, turning down two final challenges, cleared the way today for the reorganization of the A. H. Robins Company and the payment of up to $2.5 billion in damages to women injured by the Dalkon Shield, the company's defective contraceptive device.

title: Federal Screw Works reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alcohol Can Be a Dead End for Teen-Agers
description: To the Editor:

title: Carolian Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bio-Medicus Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Carolina Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shearson Warns Staff More Cuts Are Likely
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. warned its employees yesterday to brace for another round of layoffs in the next few weeks, and officials said privately that the number of those dismissed could be as high as 700 to 800 people.

title: Cynthia Northrop, 39, A Nurse and a Lawyer
description: Cynthia Ellen Northrop, a nurse, lawyer and educator, died of colon cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 39 years old. Ms. Northrop, who was in private practice in New York, was also an adjunct professor at Teachers College and at the Graduate School of Health Services at New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y. She received a law degree from the University of Baltimore after studying nursing at the University of Maryland and working as a public health nurse in Laurel, Md. She decided to study law after being called to testify in many cases involving child abuse.

title: Concorde Career Colleges reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JB's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Included after-tax charge of $1.6 million for the writeoff of deferred license rights associated with the ''Big Boy'' trade name.

title: Families Placed In Welfare Hotel With Lead Peril
description: City officials have moved 250 homeless families into a midtown welfare hotel with unlawfully high levels of lead paint, Legal Aid Society lawyers said at a hearing yesterday.

title: Review/Theater; 'Closer Than Ever,' Revue From Maltby and Shire
description: ''Closer Than Ever,'' a revue of songs by David Shire and Richard Maltby Jr. that opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theater, offers a gallery of contemporary people struggling with the usual dilemmas. They're all here: men who can't commit to women, women who wish they could do without men, two-career couples who are too busy to stay home with the baby when the au pair gets sick. After spending an evening with them, however, they immediately fade, like faces we've encountered at a cocktail party and can only dimly remember the next day.

title: D'Amato Acknowledges Plea for a H.U.D. Grant
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato acknowledged yesterday that his office had asked Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. in 1986 to approve $5.9 million in grants for an upstate project being represented by his brother's law firm and developed by one of his campaign contributors.

title: Continental General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $1.5 million, or 35 cents a share, gain from cumulative effect of a change in accounting. Latest quarter and 9 months results included realized investment gains of $76,560 and $160,522, respectively, and the same year-ago periods' results included realized investment gains of $7,832 and $62,925, respectively. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Piedmont Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods' per share earnings were restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend.

title: 2 Champions Deliver Their Best Shots
description: The first impulse was denial: Sunday Silence had beaten Easy Goer, so something must have gone wrong.

title: Giuliani and Dinkins Sprint to the Finish
description: David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani capped New York City's most contested mayoral race in 20 years yesterday with impassioned finales that epitomized their contentious campaigns to succeed the three-term incumbent, Edward I. Koch.

title: Survival Technology reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sallie Mae Notes Are Priced at Par
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced for offering through various securities dealers a $500 million issue of short-term floating-rate notes due May 10, 1990.

title: Abortion Foes Drop Candidate
description: The Right to Life Party has withdrawn its endorsement of a candidate for State Supreme Court who serves as the lawyer for a Buffalo abortion clinic. Joseph McLaughlin, chairman of the Erie County Right to Life Party, said late Sunday that the lawyer, Philip M. Marshall, would not have the party's backing in his race against Justice James B. Kane and City Comptroller Robert E. Whelan for two of three available seats.

title: A Judge Acquits 2 Police Officers Of Beating Man
description: In the last of five cases involving accusations of brutality against white officers in the 113th Precinct in Queens, two police officers were acquitted yesterday of charges that they had beaten a man and subjected him to racial abuse.

title: Patterns
description: Mizrahi's Doodles Designers get their inspiration everywhere: from art exhibitions, ethnic traditions, sports and streetwear. For his spring collection, Isaac Mizrahi delved into graphics design.

title: Halifax Developments reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: 10 Youths Attack 8 in Queens Bias Incident
description: A group of 10 black teen-agers threw bottles and yelled, ''Get whitey!'' as they attacked and robbed eight white people yesterday in Rego Park, Queens, the police said.

title: Datron Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pride Petroleum Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included non-recurring restructuring charges of $60,000 for the quarter and $560,000 for the 9 months.

title: BMC Software reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Attack On Beirut Patriarch Is Reported
description: Thousands of hard-line Christians stormed the seat of the Maronite Catholic church late Sunday and reportedly beat and humiliated its 68-year-old Patriarch.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Today voters will choose New York City's next mayor, New Jersey's next governor and other important officials. Polls are open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. in New York State, 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. in New Jersey. Here is a summary of our endorsements: NEW YORK CITY MAYOR David Dinkins (Democrat) CITY COUNCIL PRESIDENT Andrew Stein (Democrat-Liberal) COMPTROLLER Elizabeth Holtzman (Democrat-Liberal) NEW YORK STATE AMENDMENT

title: Insituform Gulf South Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; Hollow Promises On Yields in Oil
description: IT was only a few years ago that independent oil and gas producers, having gone from Wall Street darlings to doormats, discovered that one way to raise cash was to promise high yields on the investment, with the added incentive that some or all of the yield would escape taxation.

title: Consolidated Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company said the year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: Auberge Des Gouverneurs reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Washington Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: International Paper
description: The International Paper Company, the world's biggest paper manufacturer, will buy a majority stake in the West German paper maker Zanders Feinpapiere A.G. The deal will proceed as soon as the Federal Cartel Office grants permission. A representative of International Paper assured the supervisory board of Zanders, which employs about 4,000 workers, that it would win new markets in the United States. International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., has a work force of almost 60,000 and annual revenue of about $10 billion.

title: Results Plus
description: HORSE RACING Private Theatrics Wins: Ogden Phipps's Private Theatrics won the $32,000 Tarquinia purse for fillies and mares 3 years old and up yesterday at Aqueduct. Love Is Love was second in the field of six. Private Theatrics, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. and carrying 115 pounds, covered a mile on the fast track in 1:37 2/5 to earn $19,200. He paid $7.40 for $2 to win.(AP) N.H.L. Blues 3, Canadiens 3: Russ Courtnall scored two fluke goals off the skates of St. Louis defenders late in the game last night, lifting Montreal to a tie. Mats Naslund also scored for the Canadiens. Scoring for the visiting Blues were Rod Brind'Amour and Adam Oates.(AP) Maple Leafs 2, North Stars 1: Tom Fergus scored Toronto's winning goal midway through the second period. Rob Ramage also scored for the Maple Leafs. Steve Churla scored for the visiting North Stars.(AP) Flames 5, Oilers 1: Doug Gilmour scored two goals for Calgary at home. Gary Roberts, Joe Nieuwendyk and Al MacInnis also scored for the Flames. Steve Smith scored for Edmonton.(AP)

title: Excerpts From Speech By Dinkins: A New Link
description: Following are excerpts from the victory speech of Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Carlo Verri, 50, Head Of Italian State Airline
description: Carlo Verri, the chairman of Italy's state-owned airline, was killed Monday when his car collided with a city bus, the authorities said. He was 50 years old.

title: C.D. Yields Mostly Down For Week
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly off for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Rating Hot Peppers: Mouth vs. Computer
description: HOW hot is hot?

title: Review/Music; How African Rock Won the West, And on the Way Was Westernized
description: It was almost too good to be true. In just 10 days, 4 pre-eminent West African bands came through New York City: Youssou N'Dour from Senegal on Sunday at the Ritz, Tabu Ley Rochereau from Zaire for a three-night stand Thursday through Saturday at Kilimanjaro, King Sunny Ade from Nigeria the previous Monday and Tuesday at SOB's and, on Oct. 26, Papa Wemba from Zaire at SOB's.

title: Losing Sleep
description: To The Living Section:

title: Audits Faults Billing By Parking Bureau
description: The Parking Violations Bureau comtions Bureau computer system has double-billed and collected fines from thousands of motorists who already had paid what they owed, state audits have found.

title: The Mayor
description: New York City, whether melting pot or mosaic, has now conferred its collective respect on another branch of the American family. By electing David Dinkins as Mayor, New York has released a wave of pride in its citizens of African-American heritage and a sense of unity among the many white voters who rallied to his cause. His triumph is not as black New York's first Mayor, or as New York's first black Mayor but as New York's Mayor.

title: Books of The Times; Churchill's Biographer Tells the Story of a War
description: The Second World War A Complete History By Martin Gilbert Illustrated. 846 pages. Henry Holt. $29.95.

title: Abbado Said to Have Jilted New York
description: Shortly before his surprise election on Oct. 8 as new chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, Claudio Abbado made a verbal agreement to succeed Zubin Mehta as music director of the New York Philharmonic, music executives in New York and London maintain.

title: Tosco Looking For a Buyer
description: The Tosco Corporation placed itself on the selling block, saying it had retained Bear, Stearns & Company to evaluate offers. The Santa Monica, Calif., oil company said it had been approached by three multinational corporations interested in acquiring the concern or its Northern California refinery.

title: Citicorp Rates Post 3d Gain
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday rose for the third straight week, but the increase was slightly lower than that of the previous weeks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about safety rules for children on airplanes, and a front-page reference to it, misstated the current practice in some editions.

title: Stock Prices Up on Hopes of Lower Rates
description: Stocks prices rose yesterday on hopes for lower interest rates although continuing concern over disappointing corporate profit reports kept the advance in check.

title: Honduras Shifts; Will Attend Nicaragua Talks; U.N. to Send Observers
description: In an effort to shore up the faltering peace process in Central America, the Security Council voted unanimously today to send a small team of unarmed military observers to the region.

title: Education; Classes the Year Round Pass the Test for Many
description: Jennifer Rainey used to think of summer vacation as three long months of boredom.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page on Friday about Justice Sandra Day O'Connor misidentified the law school attended by one of her clerks, Sandra S. Ikuta. It was the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: Margot Seitelman, Executive, 61
description: Margot Seitelman, executive director of American Mensa Ltd., a society of people with high I.Q.'s, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 61 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Retail Mall on 34th St. Set for Auction Today
description: The Herald Center, the 10-story vertical mall that sits across 34th Street from Macy's, will be auctioned this morning in a court-approved foreclosure action by Security Pacific Mortgage and Real Estate Services, the property's mortgagor.

title: On Election Day, A Shepherd For 'the Humble'
description: ''Yo, that's a wild bike!'' the homeless man exclaimed as he walked to the end of the bread line as the sun rose yesterday.

title: WILDER SEEMS VIRGINIA WINNER, FLORIO IN; VOTERS, 5-4, APPROVE NEW YORK CHARTER; First Black Mayor
description: David Norman Dinkins, the 62-year-old mainstream Democrat who hailed the disparate people of his hometown as a ''gorgeous mosaic,'' fitted enough of the pieces together last night to achieve victory as New York's 106th mayor and the first black to preside over the nation's largest city.

title: New Rules Sought on Shipping Toxic Material
description: With only 28 full-time inspectors to oversee the 1.1 million carloads of hazardous materials shipped by rail each year, the Federal Railroad Administration cannot guarantee that railroads and chemical companies are adhering to safety regulations, the General Accounting Office said in a report today.

title: AIDS Rulings Help the Falsely Accused
description: Recent decisions in three cases charging AIDS-related discrimination are being hailed as important precedents that broaden protections in New York City and New York State. The law is now said to cover people who are mistakenly believed to carry the virus that causes the disease and people who have the virus but are not yet ill.

title: Weaver Returns To His Old Form
description: It took Manager Earl Weaver less than a week to be ejected from a Senior League game.

title: Release of Aged Convicts Needs Much Planning; Women Behind Bars
description: To the Editor:

title: Results Plus
description: HORSE RACING Trans Banner by a Neck: Casetta Farm's Trans Banner rallied into the stretch and won the $97,950 Knickerbocker Handicap yesterday for 3-year-old's and up at Aqueduct. Soviet Lad, who contended throughout, lost by only a neck in the field of 12. Impersonator was third by a half-length. Trans Banner, with Jean-Luc Samyn up, ran the mile and three-eighths on the soft turf course in 1:53 3/5, earning $58,770 and returning $11.20 for $2 to win.(AP) TENNIS Wilander Wins: Eighth-seeded Mats Wilander came back to beat Udo Riglewski, 5-7, 6-2, 6-2, in the second round of the Stockholm Open. Also moving into the third round were three Americans: Andre Agassi, Aaron Krickstein and Jim Courier.(AP) Fernandez Eliminated: Mary Joe Fernandez became the third seeded player to be eliminated in the first two days of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament, losing to Gretchen Magers by 6-3, 7-5 yesterday. Hana Mandlikova, scheduled to play last night against Ann Hendricksson, withdrew because of an ear infection. (AP) Berger Gains: Top-seeded Jay Berger breezed past Danilo Marcelino of Brazil, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Sao Paulo Grand Prix tournament in Brazil.(AP) Volkov Beats Connors: Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union wore down and beat Jimmy Connors, 3-6, 6-4, 7-6, last night in the first round of a tournament in Wembley, England. Brad Gilbert crushed Pieter Aldrich of South Africa, 6-0, 6-1, one point away from a shutout. (AP)

title: Serkin Concert Canceled
description: Rudolf Serkin has canceled his Dec. 6 Carnegie Hall recital because of illness. The concert will not be rescheduled. Refunds for tickets purchased at the hall are available at the box office during regular business hours, Monday through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., and Sunday, noon to 6. Tickets purchased by mail or through Carnegie Charge must be returned by mail, no later than Dec. 15, to Serkin Refund, Carnegie Charge, 881 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y., 10019. Information: 247-7800.

title: Deals
description: Hockey DEVILS (NHL) - Named Tim Burke assistant coach. MONTREAL (NHL) - Recalled Ed Cristofoli, left wing, from Sherbrooke of the American Hockey League. Sent Tom Chorske, left wing, to Sherbrooke. RANGERS (NHL) - Sent Mike Richter, goaltender, to Flint of the International Hockey League. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Recalled Kelly Chase, right wing, from Peoria of the I.H.L.

title: Kroger Ends Deal
description: The Kroger Company said its plan to sell eight food businesses had failed because the buyer could not obtain financing. The nation's second-largest retail grocery chain had put 11 businesses up for sale in January, saying it expected to get about $260 million. Kroger has already sold three of the businesses for undisclosed terms.The remaining units were to be sold to a group led by the New York investor Eli Jacobs and the Engles Capital Corporation of Dallas.

title: Ups and Downs of '89 New York Harvest
description: Markus Riedlin, a wine maker, is excited. Gene Pierce is pleased. Cesar Baeza is glum. And Ray Blum is grateful that his vineyards escaped destruction by Hurricane Hugo. Their moods seem to reflect the variations in the 1989 New York harvest.

title: World Bank Lending Study
description: The World Bank's president, Barber B. Conable Jr., said today that the organization would be less willing to lend funds to certain countries if the bulk of their spendings are on the military.

title: Times, Citing an Ad Slump, Will Close a Printing Plant
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that advertising volume had declined so much in the last two years that it would shut its northern New Jersey printing plant by the end of next year as part of its overall strategy to reduce costs.

title: Arum a Witness to an Evolution
description: Bob Arum, who is promoting the last big fight of the 1980's - Sugar Ray Leonard versus Roberto Duran on Dec. 7 in Las Vegas, Nev. - has been making matches since 1966, when he was a lawyer with the Manhattan law firm of Louis Nizer.

title: Corrections
description: A map of East Germany on Saturday, showing sites of demonstrations for change, located the city of Wittenberg incorrectly. It is 55 miles southwest of Berlin. (On Sunday, with an article about East Germans' departures for the West, the same map was used erroneously in some copies, in place of a map showing other cities.)

title: Senate Debates Independent C.I.A. Inspector
description: After a sharp debate over whether Congress has handcuffed the Central Intelligence Agency, the Senate tonight approved a bill that would create an independent inspector general at the agency.

title: Conferees Struggling for Accord on Medicare
description: House and Senate negotiators struggled to reach an agreement today on the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, with both sides seeking to reconcile different approaches to curtailing the law's expanded health benefits to the 33 million Medicare beneficiaries.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Fifth Amendment Is Pitted Against Child's Welfare in Abuse Case
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today in a child-abuse case that requires the Justices to balance two competing interests: a parent's right against compelled self-incrimination and the Government's ability to investigate suspected child abuse.

title: Karl D. Bays, 55; Led a Conglomerate Through Revamping
description: LEAD: Karl D. Bays, chief executive of the Whitman Corporation of Chicago, a consumer products conglomerate, died of a heart attack Monday at Lake Forest Hospital in Illinois. He was 55 years old and lived in Lake Forest.

title: Japan's Looking Glass
