description: The manuscript that is the rage of Washington, ''The Japan That Can Say 'No,' '' is beginning to cross the Atlantic. Europeans who know of it are appalled, though it is not about Europe and a lot of the America-bashing points are endorsed by European businessmen.

title: Watsonville, Calif., Hit Hard by Quake
description: To the Editor:

title: Brockton Journal; Chief Loses His Image, And a City Loses Hope
description: It has been a long and steady downward spiral for this onetime center of shoe factories and thriving shops 25 miles south of Boston.

title: Campbell-Mithun-Esty Names New Executives
description: Campbell-Mithun-Esty shuffled the chairs in its executive suite yesterday, bringing in a former agency chief to be vice chairman. C. Anthony Wainwright, who last month resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Bloom Companies, was named corporate vice chairman of Esty, which is a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi. Mr. Wainwright, 56, will be based in New York.

title: Eastern Says It's $200 Million Short
description: Eastern Airlines has told the law firm for its creditors that it is short $200 million and will seek to amend its plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, a person involved in Eastern's bankruptcy case said yesterday.

title: Ex-Regulator Tells of Pressure by Senators
description: A former top Federal regulator testified today that four United States Senators had tried to persuade him to drop a tough regulation affecting a California savings institution whose owner gave the Senators more than $1 million in campaign funds.

title: Their Lucky Day
description: I am in the forgiving vein today.

title: P.L.O. to Israel: Face Facts
description: LEAD: There are two principles basic to all negotiations: Each side must choose its own representatives and neither side has the right to gag the other's delegates.

title: Nets Feel Pressure In Home Opener
description: Whatever momentum the Nets had built by winning their first two games evaporated tonight.

title: Giuliani, Shouting for Quiet, Fights to Concede Graciously
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani was gracious in defeat, calling on New Yorkers to pray for the man who beat him, David N. Dinkins, and to unite behind him. Yet from the reaction of many in the crowd of Giuliani supporters gathered to hear his concession speech last night, unity may be an elusive goal.

title: Education: Lessons
description: Bryan Mayhann, a 16-year-old senior at Wewahitchka High School, had always imagined that a college education was beyond his reach. ''My father works in the paper mill, and it seemed like there was no way to pay for it,'' he said.

title: U.S. Silver Production
description: The United States is expected to become the world's top silver producer as labor disputes keep Mexicans away from the mines while prospectors extract more metals in the United States, the Silver Institute said today. United States output this year should rise to 65.80 million ounces from 54.50 million last year, according to the institute, a worldwide association of miners, refiners, fabricators and manufacturers. Mexican production is projected to decline to 59.20 million ounces in 1989 from 63.30 million in 1988.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top-Level Shifts Made At 7-Eleven Chain
description: LEAD: In a bid to improve the performance of its 7-Eleven convenience store chain, the Southland Corporation has announced several management changes in its core business.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Financial Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misidentified the company that is offering 1.25 million shares at $20.25 a share through Tucker, Anthony Inc. It is the Marietta Corporation of Cortland, N.Y., not the Martin Marietta Corporation of Bethesda, Md.

title: Review/Skating; A Celebration of Romance And Bravura on the Ice
description: The growth of skating as an art form was manifest again on Monday night in ''Skating for Life - A Celebration of Champions,'' a benefit performance that included Olympic champions as disparate in style as John Curry and Scott Hamilton. An unexpected treat was a rare appearance by Oleg and Ludmilla Protopopov, Soviet defectors who were Olympic gold medalists in 1964 and 1968.

title: Shaw & Landey Active
description: Shaw & Landey, a small New York agency with annual billings of $35 million, garnered much new business in the last six weeks, with total billings of more than $7 million. The accounts are: an assignment from the Hearst Corporation to promote an advertising package for Good Housekeeping and Redbook magazines; the golf wear division of the Hickey-Freeman Company; Charles Chips; the DMC Corporation, a needle-product manufacturer, and the Illinois Bronze Pa

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ELSIELESE THROPE, researching Charlotte Bronte, went to her local library in Rye, N.Y., to check out what its computer had to say about the writer. An angelic-looking little girl, about 5 years old, had just been using the machine. When Ms. Thrope took her place in front of the screen, she saw - oh, no! - a four-letter word printed out. She tried to delete it from the screen. No luck. She pressed a dozen or so keys in an effort to make the screen go blank. The word refused to scram. Unmovable. Unflinching. Other people were lining up to use the computer. Other people who peeked at the screen saw The Word.

title: Secord Reportedly Agrees To Enter Guilty Plea Today
description: Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force general who brokered arms deals that figured in the Iran-contra affair, has agreed to enter a guilty plea as part of a deal with prosecutors to resolve the criminal charges against him, sources said tonight.

title: Hostetler Accepts His Role As the No. 2 Quarterback
description: The latest adventure in Jeff Hostetler's career is over, hardly a week after it began.

title: Report of Research Curb By Bush Stirs Criticism
description: A bitter controversy has been touched off by reports that the Bush Administration plans to scale back the Pentagon's role in several technology-development programs intended to help American industries compete internationally.

title: THE 1989 ELECTION: Westchester; Housing Foe Elected Mayor In Yonkers
description: Yonkers voters, in a narrow but stunning upset, elected City Councilman Henry Spallone as mayor. Mr. Spallone had campaigned on a pledge to continue the city's resistance to a Federal desegregation order requiring it to build low-income housing in white neighborhoods.

title: Chrysler Imperial Joins Cutthroat Car Market
description: The Chrysler Corporation will introduce on Thursday its Imperial sedan, a luxury car that the auto maker hopes will appeal to affluent buyers and help to check its slipping sales.

title: Apathy Was the Norm at New York Board of Ed
description: To the Editor:

title: East Germany's Cabinet Resigns, Bowing to Protest and Mass Flight
description: The entire East German Cabinet resigned today in testimony to the scale of the crisis that has seized the state under the pressure of mass demonstrations and mass flight.

title: Tunisian Couscous
description: To The Living Section:

title: Market Place; New Tokyo Seats, But Price Is Steep
description: THE Tokyo Stock Exchange says it is ready to permit a third wave of new memberships for foreign securities firms, but the firms will have to pay close to $10 million for the privilege of doing business on the world's largest exchange. At current exchange rates, seats will cost 20 times the $470,000 price on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Volatility Study Urged
description: The head of a leading Wall Street firm said today that the New York Stock Exchange should undertake a thorough study of computer-driven program trading to determine its impact on the volatility of the stock market.

title: Emmerling Is Picked
description: The United Weight Control Corporation, an operator of weight-loss programs based in Englewood, N.J., has chosen John Emmerling Inc. for its agency. The account, which industry reports have placed at $1 million in annual billings, had been at Tarlow Advertising since January.

title: CAPITAL UNRUFFLED AT CRACK CHARGE
description: It was business as usual today in the District of Columbia: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was closeted in meetings with city officials, the City Council was debating a rise for city employees and a grand jury was investigating the accusation that the Mayor had used crack.

title: Hughes Official To Step Down
description: Donald H. White will retire as president and chief operating officer of the Hughes Aircraft Company on Dec. 1 and will not be replaced immediately, the company announced today.

title: Overhaul of New York City Charter Is Approved, Polls Show
description: New Yorkers yesterday approved the most thorough overhaul of the municipal government since the Greater City of New York was created in 1898.

title: Lavinia Williams Service
description: A memorial service for Lavinia Williams, a dancer and teacher of modern and Caribbean dance, will be held at 7 P.M. tonight at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Miss Williams, who performed with the Von Grona American Negro Ballet and with Katherine Dunham and Ballet Theater, died of a heart attack on July 19 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, at the age of 73.

title: Jordan Gets 40 Points As Bulls Top Pistons
description: Michael Jordan connected on a slam dunk after Scottie Pippin stole the ball from Isiah Thomas with 1 minute 5 seconds remaining in the game, breaking a tie and lifting the Bulls to a 117-114 victory over Detroit, their first victory over the Pistons here since Jan. 16, 1988.

title: Braniff Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: Braniff Inc., which suspended all passenger flights on Monday night, has put itself up for sale. But only small investors have shown an interest in buying the company. And several analysts said yesterday that it appeared unlikely that Braniff's hub city, Kansas City, Mo., would soon find another large carrier to fill the void, although several airlines are adding flights there.

title: Amanda Blake Died of AIDS, Doctor Says
description: Amanda Blake, the actress who played Miss Kitty on the long-running television series ''Gunsmoke,'' died of AIDS-related complications and not, as a hospital and her friends reported at the time, of cancer, her doctor says.

title: Universal Health Stake Is Increased
description: An investment group led by Perry R. Bass of Fort Worth, raised its stake in Universal Health Services Inc. class B common stock to 8.8 percent from 6.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said that it had acquired the shares as an investment. Between Oct. 16 and Nov. 6, the Bass group purchased 210,000 shares for prices ranging from $8.25 to $9.38 a share. The stock closed today at $8.50, up 50 cents, in over-the-counter trading. Universal Health is an acute-care hospital concern based in King of Prussia, Pa.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization Nov. 3 Oct. 27 Nov. 4 1989 1989 1988 Gasoline production, daily 6.9 6.8 7.0 Distillate production, daily 3.0 2.9 2.9 Gasoline stocks 221.92 23.2 213.7 Distillate stocks 120.6 118.7 128.0 Crude imports, daily 5.9 6.9 6.1 Product imports, daily 2.3 2.1 2.7 Crude stocks 341.4 345.4 339.3 Crude production, daily 7.5 7.5 8.0 Refinery utilization (%) 87.1 86.6 82.5 Source: American Petroleum Institute

title: WINE TALK
description: ONE of the less spectacular but ultimately more useful events of the Wine Experience this year was a tasting of wines under $20. The Wine Experience, which took place in New York on Oct. 28 and 29, is an annual celebration of the grape that gathers platoons of wine makers and regiments of wine drinkers for three days of tasting, drinking, eating and mingling on a scale more usually associated with a major political convention.

title: William Morris Jr., Agency Head, 90
description: William Morris Jr., a former president of the William Morris Agency, died of intestinal complications on Friday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 90 years old.

title: Education; Modest Gains Seen in Improving Schools
description: States have had only modest success in improving public education, although there has been a greater effort in the 1980's than ever before, a consortium of universities says.

title: Bronx Symphony Plans Free Opening Concert
description: The Bronx Symphony Orchestra is to open its 10th season at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx with a free concert conducted by its new director, Michael Spierman, on Nov. 19 at 3 P.M. Mr. Spierman, the director of the Bronx Opera Company, was director of the orchestra from 1968 to 1980.

title: WILDER SEEMS VIRGINIA WINNER, FLORIO IN; VOTERS, 5-4, APPROVE NEW YORK CHARTER; FLORIO VICTORIOUS IN JERSEY BATTLE
description: Representative James J. Florio swept to a lopsided victory yesterday in the race for governor of New Jersey as voters rejected the campaign of his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, who promised to fight crime, taxes and big government.

title: Book Notes
description: Random House

title: FAI Raises Share In Foremost Corp.
description: The FAI Traders Insurance Company of Australia raised its stake in the Foremost Corporation of America to 6 percent from 5.1 percent and said it was seeking ''to discuss the management of the company and the value of the common stock'' of the Grand Rapids, Mich., insurance concern.

title: Bolshevik Rally And Anti-Rally In Soviet Streets
description: Thousands of political dissenters staged an audacious alternative parade today on the 72d anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, a major holiday that has traditionally been a celebration of monolithic Soviet rule.

title: Bhutto Survives Nearly a Year in Office, but a New Era Still Proves Elusive
description: A year ago, as Benazir Bhutto campaigned across Pakistan describing herself as ''the poor people's sister,'' she seemed to millions of supporters to promise a new era, one in which a popularly elected government would finally tackle a legacy of poverty, corruption and violence.

title: Fannie Mae Sets Offering Of $2.3 Billion in Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $2.3 billion in three-year and 10-year debentures through various securities dealers.

title: Israel Requests Police Trials in West Bank Killing
description: An Israeli police commander recommended today that six Israeli Arab policemen be tried for fatally shooting a West Bank Palestinian at close range two weeks ago and then falsely reporting that he was shot when he ran a roadblock near Bethlehem.

title: Board of Examiners Still Doing Its Job
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Board of Estimate; A Generation Of Ex-Critics Gains Power
description: The New York City elections yesterday brought a new generation to the top of city government, putting at the center of power on the Board of Estimate some political figures who have built their reputations by second-guessing the system from the side.

title: Court in Los Angeles Gives 'Night Stalker' Death in 13 Killings
description: Richard Ramirez, who killed 13 people in the ''Night Stalker'' attacks that terrorized Southern California in 1985, was sentenced today to death in the gas chamber.

title: Sports People:HOCKEY; Richter Goes to Minors
description: The Rangers yesterday sent the second-year goaltender Mike Richter, a former United States Olympian, to their minor league affiliate in Flint, Mich. Richter had started just one of the team's 16 games this season, compiling a goals-against average of 2.12. His National Hockey League debut was in the team's 4-3 loss to the Penguins in the Rangers' last playoff game last spring.

title: Bridge
description: After nearly a year of double knockout play, two New Jersey events were decided in late October. The North Jersey Bridge Association's title went to Bob Garofalo and Sandy Burns, both of Englewood, N.J., Eva Scatassa of West Nyack, N.Y., Greg Rosoff of Leonia, N.J., and Robb and Linda Gordon of Manhattan.

title: D'Jaris Watson, 61, Mayor's Aide
description: D'Jaris Hinton Watson, an administrator for three New York City mayors, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What kind of pluralism is there in that well known Red Square when we in the opposition have no chance to speak?'' - Telman Gdlyan, a Soviet legislator. [ A12:1. ]

title: U.S. Scholars Say East Berlin Can't Turn Tide
description: While they say the consequences of the sudden and mounting demonstrations in East Germany defy precise prediction, American scholars specializing in German and European affairs generally agree that the mass marches have gone beyond the point where force could be used to quell them.

title: Stinging Words From a Native Princess
description: My L.A.-born and -bred sister who now lives in San Francisco was calling in a tizzy. ''Did you see what Candice Bergen said in Playboy about Los Angeles?'' she complained. ''Honestly. I can't believe people are still doing this. Especially someone like her.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Richard M. Nixon's visit to the White House, where he discussed his recent trip to China, misidentified the President who sent George Bush to Beijing as chief American diplomat. It was Gerald R. Ford.

title: Review/Music; St. Luke's Is Conducted By Composers of 2 Pieces
description: Early in his composing career, John Adams became infatuated with Minimalism and, despite his belief that he has moved beyond its simpler formulas, continues to travel on a narrow-gauge track. His ''Fearful Symmetries,'' which the Orchestra of St. Luke's presented at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening under the composer's direction, chugged along for 25 minutes without passing through interesting country, let alone arriving at a station.

title: Illinois Prosecutor Asks Role in Negotiations in Abortion Case
description: Concerned that state officials are pushing to settle a major abortion case before it can be heard by the United States Supreme Court, a county prosecutor will ask a Federal judge on Wednesday for permission to intervene in the negotiations.

title: Washington Talk; Amid Winds of Change, A Summit Conference
description: President Bush is meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union early next month, he says, to get to know the cut of his jib as the two leaders face together the hurricane of history that is blowing across Europe.

title: The 1989 Elections: Nation's Mayors; Young Survives Race in Detroit; It's Easier in Miami and Houston
description: Voters returned incumbents to City Halls in Miami, Detroit and Houston yesterday while electing a new generation of mayors in New Haven and Cleveland.

title: 'Chicken Soup' Is Canceled By ABC After 7 Shows
description: ABC abruptly canceled ''Chicken Soup'' yesterday, the highest rated new program of the television season. The series, starring Jackie Mason, had its final telecast last night.

title: Gerald M. Jennings, 70, Wheelchair Maker
description: Gerald M. Jennings, chairman of Everest & Jennings International Ltd., the nation's leading manufacturer of wheelchairs, died of heart disease Sunday at the University of California Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 70 years old.

title: TLC Offers 35% Stake To Public
description: TLC Beatrice International Inc., the international food company controlled by the Wall Street investor Reginald F. Lewis, said yesterday that the company would sell a 35 percent stake to the public to raise as much as $194 million.

title: Nigerian Effort Praised
description: Nigeria's efforts to turn around its economy, battered by declining oil prices, were praised by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund at a meeting of aid donors, a World Bank official said today. At a meeting in Paris, Caio Koch-Weser, director of the World Bank's West African department, ''commended the Nigerian Government's determination in pursuing its structural adjustment program,'' the official said. These sentiments were said to have been echoed by the International Monetary Fund's representative at the meeting.

title: Bonds Rise On Sign of Fed Easing
description: A sign that the Federal Reserve Board might be easing monetary policy sent prices of Treasury securities surging yesterday.

title: Hundreds of Admirers and Friends Pay Tribute to Vladimir Horowitz
description: Hundreds of admirers of Vladimir Horowitz, who died of a heart attack on Sunday at the age of 86, reverently filed past the pianist's open coffin yesterday afternoon. The body was on view yesterday and is to be again today, from 4 to 7 P.M., at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street.

title: Islanders Add an Injury and a Defeat
description: This Islanders defeat, their fifth in the last six games, was not one of those tepid ones, decided at the halfway mark, with quiet fans leaving the building throughout the third period.

title: The 1989 Elections: Long Island; Gulotta Defeats Korn for Nassau Executive
description: Thomas S. Gulotta easily won his first full term as Nassau County Executive yesterday, defeating his Democratic challenger, Richard Korn.

title: Lebanon Cabinet Talks Begin Despite Protest by Christians
description: Lebanon's new President, Rene Moawad, started consultations today on the selection of a Cabinet to serve as a ''government of national entente,'' but his rival, Gen. Michel Aoun, gave no sign that he was ready to relinquish power.

title: Vitesse and Fujitsu In Chip Agreement
description: The Vitesse Semiconductor Corporation reached an agreement for Fujitsu Ltd. to be a second manufacturer of Vitesse's large-scale integrated circuit chips made of gallium arsenide, offering higher speed than silicon. Fujitsu, which also makes gallium arsenide products, will manufacture the chips in Japan..

title: Excerpts From the President's News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS Return of Assets to Iran Q. Mr. President, the United States is returning $567 million in frozen assets to Iran but says the action is not related to the plight of the eight Americans held hostage in Lebanon. Nevertheless, in mind of your comment that good will brings good will, do you hope that this will encourage Iran to help win the hostages' release? Do you think that this could be a catalyst Mr. Rafsanjani -- A. I don't know. It's a very good question and I don't know the answer to that. They owe money, you know, they, we have accounts that where they owe American interests money and vice versa. And I'd like to get this underbrush cleaned out now. I think they, they have made some positive statements. . . . I hope that they will do what they can to influence those who hold these hostages. We're continuing behind the scenes to try to follow certain rabbit trails there and so far they've ended up a dead end. East Europe Initiatives Q. Despite your aid packages to Hungary and Poland and so forth, President Carter says you've really been slow on the uptake on one of the most transforming political events of our times. You have failed to show the leadership. You've failed to put the U.S. ahead of the curve on these things that are happening. And you are going to the summit without any initiatives at all. I mean this is boasted about. Why don't you have some new ideas of what to talk -- A. Now Helen, that is not a kinder and gentler way to phrase your question. We have done plenty. And the fact that some critics are out there equating progress with spending more money doesn't bother me in the least. Look at the dynamic changes that are taking place around the world. And - well, I'd like to hear some specific suggestions other than triple the spending on every initiative. We are working closely with our allies. We are trying to facilitate the change. I don't hear complaints coming out of our allies or indeed out of Hungary or Poland or Eastern Europe. We've got a seasoned team that are - that's evaluating the change. I will have a wonderful opportunity to discuss the change with Mr. Gorbachev. But I can't be all concerned when, when people jump up and say the answer is to spend more money. Accord on Budget Q. On the budget, there's some question as to whether when Congress finally, if it does, sends you the reconciliation - that is to say, the budget-cutting bill - what it will take for you to sign it. Are you prepared to go beyond the agreement that - that you have reached with the members of Congress or the leaders of Congress? Are you going to require a more stringent budget-cutting measures? Something equal, for example, to the sequester, the cuts that have already gone into effect in order to satisfy you and get you to sign it? A. If we get a clean reconciliation bill - and I'll know that when I see it - I'd be glad to sign such a bill. If it gets the kinds of real reductions that we want, I think the range was $14 billion. But if not, why we have to follow, follow the law. . . . But if they - if they don't send it down here in clean form, if it's all loaded up with a lot of special projects, I will not sign it. . . . Commitment to Quayle Q. Why did you commit to Dan Quayle so early for '92? You're thought to be such a cautious, prudent man. Why did you shut off your options so early? A. I thought that was a prudent and right thing to do. Q. Well, all right, are you saying Dan Quayle is your choice right now A. Well, I'm not saying I'm running. Q. Are you saying he's your choice right now but you leave your options for -- A. No, I said he's my choice. Period. Krenz Leadership Q. When Egon Krenz first came to power in East Germany, you said it was way too early to say whether he represented more of the same -which seemed to be your sense at the time - or whether he represented the leading edge of further reform. Seeing the dramatic events unfold in East Germany, what is your conclusion about Egon Krenz, his intentions and his direction? A. I think it's still too early to sum it up entirely, but some of what he has said about political reform is quite encouraging and really contradicts the very early - I would say global -assessment of the man. In other words, the early predictions were that he's a hard-liner, in the mode of Mr. Honecker. And now, some of what he is saying is quite different from that. And Mr. Honecker's not there anymore. So you're seeing some changes. . . . Change in East Europe Q. Mr. President, do you feel that things have now gone too far in East Germany, Poland, Hungary, the Soviet Union, for the clock to be turned back for a Tiananmen Square-type crackdown? And do you feel any need to assist the West Germans in all of this. A. Well, the West Germans have not requested assistance, and I am in very close touch with the Federal Chancellor. Quayle on Soviets Q. I'd like to return to Vice President Quayle for a minute. On Sunday, the Vice President said that the Soviets retained expansionistic attitudes in Central America, Afghanistan and several other parts of the world. He suggested that Gorbachev was a Stalinist and also suggested that the Soviet defense budget is growing while ours is declining. Do you agree with those three assessments? A. That their defense budget is growing? Yes. Q. And that Gorbachev -- A. I'd like to see - find a way to reverse that and out of the challenge that lies ahead to both Gorbachev and me, perhaps there will be a way to reverse it. One way to do that I think is through prudent arms control. The best way to do it is to do it through success in the conventional force in Europe talks, C.F.E. talks, because that's - that's dollar-intensive or ruble-intensive, if you will. . . .

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, articles yesterday and on Monday about the use of contractors by the Energy Department misstated the time of Energy Secretary James D. Watkins's appearance before a Congressional committee. He testified in April this year, not in 1988.

title: BankAmerica's Plan for Mexico
description: The BankAmerica Corporation will participate in a proposed debt refinancing for Mexico by mostly converting debt to bonds, but it will also provide new money, the company's chairman, A. W. Clausen, said today.

title: In Pursuit of the Wild Truffle, Let Your Nose Be Your Guide
description: TRUFFLES are trophies. Like gems and furs, they are the badges of the masters of nature. The capture of these subterranean fungi is riddled with intrigue. Their processing is imbued with mystique; their flavor inspires gastronomic hyberbole.

title: Hearty, Wholesome Vegetables That Fend Off Winter's Chill
description: PITY the poor parsnip. And the turnip and rutabaga, as well. They do not get much respect. Often neglected and unfairly maligned, these homely root vegetables, along with winter squashes and post-frost greens, are now fresh and plentiful and tempting not only for their flavor and texture but also for their vivid greens and bright oranges.

title: China Cracks Down on Private Work
description: In a sweeping nationwide crackdown on nonstate enterprises, China has shut down more than a million rural industrial collectives and forced the demise of 2.2 million private enterprises, the Government announced today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 The East German Cabinet resigned in testimony to the scale of the crisis that has seized the state under the pressure of mass demonstrations and mass flight. A1

title: India Leftists Hope to Gain A Bigger Role
description: For the Indian left, national elections this month offer the chance of winning a crucial power broker's role in the next government.

title: Bush Hopes to Settle Iranian Assets Issue
description: The Bush Administration is eager to resolve financial disputes with Iran to improve relations in the post-Khomeini era and possibly pave the way for the release of American hostages in Lebanon, senior Administration officials said today.

title: East Bloc Runs Low on Hard-Liners
description: For a while now, the Communist leaders of Czechoslovakia have regarded the political changes in Poland and Hungary as avoidable aberrations and looked instead to another neighbor, East Germany, for confirmation of their own policies of tight control. Now, as East German protests mount and East German leaders resign, doubts here are rising.

title: After Stunning Loss, Knicks Look for Some Magic of Their Own
description: The morning after the Magic upset the Knicks in only their second National Basketball Association game, the page 1 headline in yesterday's Orlando Sentinel read: ''You Just Have to Love These Guys.''

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: The Virginia Contest  MAN IN THE NEWS: Lawrence Douglas Wilder; From Confrontation to Conciliation
description: The story of L. Douglas Wilder is the story of a provocative outsider to a pragmatic insider, and in the process made history.

title: The Voting, 1989
description: Coverage of elections in the New York metropolitan area is on pages B1 and B6 through B10; around the country, pages B10 and B11.

title: Food Notes
description: Mushroom-Herb Source On Leonard Street in TriBeCa, in a block between Hudson Street and West Broadway that is lined with loading docks and warehouses, one window displays bunches of dried herbs and a bright, welcoming pumpkin. It is the new headquarters of Aux Delices des Bois, a wholesaler of exotic mushrooms, and Fines Herbes, which sells fresh herbs and baby lettuces to restaurants and shops.

title: In Japan, It's Costly to Be a Consumer
description: Japanese consumers are paying about twice as much as Americans for electric shavers, floppy disk drives and camera lenses and three and a half times as much for spark plugs, a survey conducted by Japanese and American Government agencies showed today.

title: Richard C. Bond Is Dead at 80; Retired Wanamaker Chain Head
description: Richard C. Bond, a Philadelphia civic leader and retired head of the John Wanamaker department store chain, died of pancreatic cancer and a cerebral hemmorhage Saturday at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 80 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Next Rutgers Obstacle: Major Harris
description: It is Rutgers's turn to take on West Virginia and the Mountaineers' Major Harris. The game is at Morgantown on Saturday. The timing is less than perfect for the Scarlet Knights, who did not play last Saturday and have had two weeks to think about the mercurial Harris.

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Mayor-Elect  MAN IN THE NEWS: David N. Dinkins; Groundbreaker Bound by Tradition
description: David N. Dinkins comes to the office of mayor after three decades of loyal, quiet service to the Democratic Party - making him a man who is a groundbreaker and very much bound by tradition.

title: Pisa Journal; Rome Leans on the Tower; the Tower Just Leans
description: This may not come as hot news, but there are Italians who worry that the Leaning Tower of Pisa is falling.

title: Sports People:BASEBALL; Olson Is Rookie of Year
description: Gregg Olson, a relief pitcher who helped to lead the Baltimore Orioles to one of the greatest turnarounds in baseball history, was voted the American League's rookie of the year yesterday. He is the first relief pitcher to receive the honor in the American League.

title: A Welcome Inch in the Mideast
description: The Arab-Israeli peace process has operated at two speeds - big leaps like the sudden flight to Jerusalem by President Sadat of Egypt in 1977, or microscopic steps that usually wind into circles. This week Israel has offered a welcome new inch. The Israeli Government now says the smallest possible yes to Secretary of State Baker's plan for initiating Palestinian-Israeli talks. For this, Prime Minister Shamir deserves the praise, appropriately qualified, of the State Department.

title: Review/Film; A Down-to-Earth 'Henry V' Discards Spectacle and Pomp
description: Kenneth Branagh has done it. Who is Kenneth Branagh? He's the young Belfast-born actor and director, best known here for his recent appearance in the ghastly ''Fortunes of War'' mini-series on television, who has transformed what initially seemed to be a lunatic dare into a genuine triumph. Mr. Branagh has made a fine, rousing new English film adaptation of Shakespeare's ''Henry V,'' a movie that need not apologize to Laurence Olivier's 1944 classic.

title: The Pop Life
description: Jeff Beck and Company When Jeff Beck and Stevie Ray Vaughan perform together at Madison Square Garden on Saturday evening, rock guitar aficionados will have an unusual opportunity to hear two virtuosos and their bands each play 75-minute sets back-to-back. Mr. Beck's appearance, moreover, is his return to the concert spotlight after a nine-year absence.

title: City Opera and Musicians in Tentative Pact
description: Negotiators for the New York City Opera and its orchestra, which has been on strike since Sept. 13, reached a tentative agreement for a new contract late last night.

title: New York Art Exhibition To Test Federal Restrictions
description: A potentially controversial art exhibition is providing the National Endowment for the Arts with its first test of how to enforce last month's legislation to restrict Federal financing of artwork regarded as ''homoerotic'' or ''obscene.''

title: Moves by Sterling
description: Sterling Drug Inc., a unit of the Eastman Kodak Company, yesterday shuffled its advertising accounts, switching two products from N.W. Ayer to Slater, Hanft, Martin. The company assigned Slater its Neo-Synephrine and Nasal brands, which have billings of between $3 million and $5 million, according to the agency. N.W. Ayer will retain three Sterling brands - Phillips' Milk of Magnesia, Haley's M-O and PhisoDerm -and the company's new products.

title: Cutbacks at GTE
description: The GTE Corporation said it would lay off 800 workers, close two Massachusetts plants and 17 warehouses nationwide in a restructuring of its distribution system. The GTE light bulb plant operations in Salem will be moved to Pennsylvania. The operations of GTE's Fall River fixtures plant will be moved to Toronto.

title: EXECUTIVES CHANGES
description: * Commonwealth Edison Co., Chicago, a utility, elected retired Vice Adm. Lando W. Zech Jr., former chairman of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission, to its board.

title: A New Leaf for Tates Locke; Indiana State Hopes He'll Revivify the Basketball Program
description: ''Simply, I had gotten tired of losing. I didn't cheat because the Joneses did, or because it made me a big man. I did it because I didn't want to get my brains beat anymore. That's all.'' - Tates Locke

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: JUST because the leaves have fallen, there is no reason to forsake barbecues, even if they have to be simulated indoors with a kitchen broiler. A good hot broiler can approximate the cooking technique of an outdoor grill. Of course, you will not get any of the woody nuances possible with open flames and wood chips, but the results can be delicious nonetheless.

title: The 1989 Elections; Houston Councilman Out
description: Jim Westmoreland, a Houston City Council member who provoked widespread outrage here by making a racial slur, was defeated for re-election tonight by a political newcomer.

title: 4 New York Races Won By Incumbent Mayors
description: Incumbent mayors in upstate New York's four largest cities won re-election yesterday, with three mayors facing either no opposition or just token pressure.

title: KEY RATES
6 Convicted in Motor Vehicles Scheme
description: Six people, including five clerks who worked in the Queens office of the Department of Motor Vehicles, were found guilty yesterday of turning the office into a racketeering enterprise that allowed drug dealers and others to obtain fraudulent automobile registrations and fake drivers' licenses.

title: A New Coating Thwarts Chip Pirates
description: Several years ago, clever high-technology pirates removed a chip from a satellite-television descrambling device made by the General Instrument Corporation, electronically siphoned out hidden decryption software and studied it to figure out a way to receive clear TV signals.

title: EAST GERMAN FLOW TO WEST CONTINUES
description: The tide of East Germans flooding through Czechoslovakia into West Germany continued to rise today, and it showed no sign of ebbing, the border police said.

title: Supermarket Merger Deal
description: The California State Attorney General, John Van de Kamp, announced an agreement today with American Stores to modify a court order blocking the merger of the Alpha Beta and Lucky grocery store chains while he pursues an antitrust challenge to the merger. The United States Supreme Court agreed last month to hear that challenge.

title: Checking Your Watch For Messages, Too
description: The first wristwatches with paging beepers are expected to be introduced early next year, a significant advance in the miniaturization of complex radio communications technology.

title: Man to Stand Trial In 3 Stabbing Deaths
description: A 36-year-old Derby, Conn., man will stand trial on murder charges in the stabbing deaths of three people in August, a state judge ruled yesterday.

title: Judge Reassures Suspect in Officer's Murder
description: In an unusual court hearing yesterday, a Federal judge patiently and painstakingly sought to allay concerns of Howard (Pappy) Mason that he would not receive a fair trial. Mr. Mason is accused of ordering the murder of Police Officer Edward Byrne.

title: Guards' Lawyer Asks Counts Against Fans
description: The lawyer for nine guards charged with beating fans at the Meadowlands Sports Complex last month says countercharges have been filed against five patrons ''to keep a proper perspective.''

title: L.I. Killer Gets 33 Years to Life
description: A marksman who shot and killed one man and wounded another, apparently because he thought they owed him money, was sentenced yesterday to 33 and one-third years to life in prison.

title: Honduras Shifts; Will Attend Nicaragua Talks
description: In a reversal, the Government of Honduras has announced that it will take part as an observer at new talks between the Nicaraguan Government and contra leaders this week at the United Nations.

title: 'Junk Bonds' Surge in Moderate Trading
description: Prices of ''junk bonds'' climbed sharply yesterday in moderate trading by dealers and investors, traders said.

title: Release of Aged Convicts Needs Much Planning; Old, Sick and Free
description: To the Editor:

title: First Lady Discusses Abortion
description: Barbara Bush said today that she was not taking a public stance on abortion because speaking out would create controversy ''whichever way I go'' and detract from her work on illiteracy, the homeless, hunger and AIDS. ''I think that should be left to the people who are courageous enough, No. 1, to run for office, and No. 2, who can do something about it,'' she told three reporters at a White House reception for disabled winners of an award.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: WILDER SEEMS VIRGINIA WINNER, FLORIO IN; VOTERS, 5-4, APPROVE NEW YORK CHARTER; First Black Governor, If Recount Upholds Vote
description: L. Douglas Wilder appeared to have eked out a narrow victory for the governorship of Virginia today, on the basis of almost complete but unofficial returns.

title: Prospects for Pact on Long-Range Arms Next Year Called Difficult
description: A senior Administration official suggested today that it was unlikely that Washington and Moscow could conclude a strategic arms treaty next year.

title: Brother Abdon Lewis, Teacher and Dean, 73
description: Brother Abdon Lewis, a former dean of Manhattan College, died of a stroke Sunday at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Yonkers. He was 73 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Reliance Capital Chief Seeking a New Project
description: Having completed the sale of Days Inn of America Inc., Henry R. Silverman says he will be casting about for another acquisition. Mr. Silverman likes to keep two projects - but no more than two - going at one time.

title: Bush Nominates Watt II
description: George Bush, who not so many years ago was justly critical of Ronald Reagan's ''voodoo economics,'' has become past master of an even more illusory art form: voodoo politics.

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: City Council; Council Virtually Unchanged, Except for New Powers
description: The City Council that will have broad new powers next year under the new City Charter will be virtually unchanged, as all its incumbent members on the ballot won re-election last night.

title: Bishops Warn Politicians on Abortion
description: In a message intended for Roman Catholic politicians who personally oppose abortion but do not want to restrict the choice of others, the country's Catholic bishops warned today that Catholics could not use the idea of choice to defend legal access to abortion.

title: Discovery of a Major Oilfield Is Announced by the Saudis
description: Saudi Arabia has announced the discovery of a major oilfield that has the variety of light crude in most demand around the world because it can be refined into products like gasoline with relative ease.

title: Rig Count Rises to 1,042
description: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas rose by 32 last week, to 1,042. The total was well above the 942 reported a year ago, Baker Hughes Inc. said Monday. The weekly rig count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas, not those producing oil and gas.

title: Review/Television; Moyers and Academics Bemoan TV's Side Effects
description: In his latest series, ''The Public Mind,'' Bill Moyers uses television to take on television and its image-peddling accomplices in advertising, public relations, opinion polls and disguised forms of propaganda. His concern is the debasement of public discourse, the blurring of the line between truth and fiction, the manipulation of the citizenry. The case is not unfamiliar and the tone is somewhat agitated, but the argument remains cogent and deserves attention.

title: Bonds Are Priced By Pennsylvania
description: Pennsylvania yesterday priced $177 million in general obligation bonds through competitive bidding, with the issue being awarded to underwriters led by Citicorp Securities Markets Inc.

title: Businessland to Carry NCR Line
description: The NCR Corporation and Businessland Inc., the nation's largest personal computer retailer, said yesterday that Businessland would add NCR's personal computers to its product line.

title: 2 Israeli Soldiers Are Killed Testing Howitzer in Arizona
description: A explosive charge for propelling an artillery projectile detonated during testing at the Yuma Proving Ground on Monday, killing two Israeli soldiers inside a tanklike vehicle, Army officials said today.

title: For a London Cafe, A Rolling Stone Gathers Mementos
description: ''What can a poor boy do, except sing in a rock-and-roll band?'' Open a restaurant, of course, as Bill Wyman, the Rolling Stones' bass guitarist, did in May in west London.

title: Greek Conservative Gets Coalition Deadline
description: Constantine Mitsotakis, leader of the conservative New Demacracy Party, received a presidential go-ahead today to try to form a new government, but party officials say he faces a difficult time.

title: In World of Style, Animals Now Rule
description: A SMALL sculpture of an owl sits on a smooth branch jutting out from a stark black lamp. A black, long-sleeved T-shirt shows a subtle pattern of white strokes that on closer inspection turn out to be cats. On a soft, wrap-style coat, white polar bears parade across a black background.

title: New Jersey Towns Face a Fall Compost Crisis
description: The disposal of autumn leaves, usually not considered a problem for towns and cities, could become a costly one for 35 Bergen County communities that have been ordered by state environmental officials to shut down a composting operation.

title: Economic Scene; Trade Law's Tangled Web
description: IT seemed like a legal loophole begging to be closed: if foreigners were caught dumping, say, color televisions in the United States, why let them get around the law by bringing in the picture tube and chassis and then slapping together the parts in some dockside warehouse in Seattle?

title: Vietnam to Export Rice
description: Vietnamese officials said today that farming reforms had produced a dramatic recovery in rice production and three good crops this year meant it had ample supplies for export. ''For the first time in several decades, Vietnam is back again on the list of rice exporters,'' the Vietnam News Agency said in a dispatch.

title: Eason Agrees to Join Jets
description: Tony Eason, the Jets' reluctant new quarterback, agreed to join the team yesterday, six days after he was claimed on waivers from the New England Patriots.

title: Eagleton Quits Post at Merc
description: Thomas Eagleton, the former United States Senator, resigned today as a public governor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, accusing the world's second-biggest futures exchange of favoritism.

title: Commodore Reports Loss
description: Commodore International Ltd. today reported a loss of $6.5 million in its first fiscal quarter, citing decreased demand for its computers.

title: 'The Cosby Show' Bumps 'Roseanne' Out of No. 1 Spot
description: ''The Cosby Show'' returned to the No. 1 position in the ratings last week, displacing ''Roseanne'' for only the second time this season. Last week also saw the season premiere of ''L.A. Law,'' which jumped back into the top 10 and was the reason ''Prime Time Live,'' which is shown at the same time on Thursday night, lost more than a full rating point from the previous week.

title: Why I Won't Run in the Marathon
description: You see a lot more people than usual wobbling along the streets of New York lately. You see them limping, as if they've been kicked in the shins, or listing to the left or right, as if they've been battered in the ribs. Sometimes, they'll clutch a lamp post to steady themselves, then slowly move on up the avenue.

title: Agreement On Raising Debt Ceiling
description: After weeks of political maneuvering that brought the Government to the brink of financial default, Congress tonight approved legislation raising the national debt limit to $3.12 trillion through Sept. 30, 1990.

title: EATING WELL
description: JUICE cocktails, juice drinks, juice punches, fruit coolers, juice blends, juice ades. Every year more and more of these diluted fruit-juice drinks appear on the market, and this is about the only certain thing that can be said about them.

title: Paging Plan in Europe
description: The 12 European Community nations agreed today to start a European radio messaging system after 1992 to enable business executives and other users of beepers to page each other across national borders. At present, each country operates its own national paging system and very few systems operate across borders.

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Transition; Changing of the Guard: Goal Is Slow and Easy
description: The style and tone with which David N. Dinkins will confront some of the most serious problems New York City has ever faced will be more reminiscent of former Mayor Robert F. Wagner - slow and easy - than of Edward I. Koch - fast and frenetic, Dinkins associates agree.

title: Stake Raised In Carolco
description: Carolco Pictures Inc. said today that one of its co-chairman, Mario Kassar, had agreed to acquire the 36 percent share in the motion picture company controlled by the other co-chairman, Andrew Vajna, for about $100 million.

title: Release of Aged Convicts Needs Much Planning
description: To the Editor:

title: Kitty Dukakis Goes To Hospital for Care After Illness at Home
description: Kitty Dukakis was in a intensive care unit today under observation for nausea and dizziness after admission to the hospital Monday. Doctors refused to say if her ailment had any connection to previous problems with drugs and alcohol.

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Mayoral Election; Win by Dinkins Prompts Dancing and Skepticism
description: Carol White's eyes were wet with excitement as she stood in the middle of 50 people dancing on a Harlem sidewalk celebrating the victory of David N. Dinkins last night.

title: Real Estate; Business Aid For Districts In 5 Boroughs
description: EIGHTEEN New York City neighborhoods have formed Business Improvement Districts, in which assessments paid by commercial properties and businesses support a variety of services and programs. Ten such districts, called BID's, are being developed and 18 others in all five boroughs are considering forming such local civic groups.

title: Education: About Education
description: ''Those in power want only to perpetuate it,'' Associate Justice William O. Douglas once said. By now, those who contend that giving teachers greater power is the way to improve education know how difficult it is to persuade those in power - the principals, superintendents and school boards - to share that power.

title: Kellogg Drive Hails Psyllium
description: Responding to the growing popularity of oat bran, the Kellogg Company has begun a $40 million advertising campaign extolling the health qualities of psyllium, a grain that Kellogg hopes will become as attractive as oat bran to health-conscious consumers. Ads in Time, Newsweek and

title: N.F.L. Players Union Seeks Decertification
description: The National Football League Players Association, acting in the aftermath of a court decision unfavorable to it, said today that it would surrender its collective-bargaining rights for the league's players.

title: Consolidated StockSale Is Off
description: An investment group led by Sol A. Shenk, the founder of the Consolidated Stores Corporation, and Charles H. Shenk, Consolidated's president, said it had called off its plan to sell its 16.7 percent stake in the company as a single block. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Shenk group gave no reason for the decision.

title: Education; Potential Donors Figure In Entry to Vermont U.
description: Officials of the University of Vermont, which has benefited significantly in recent years from the enrollment of out-of-state students, have said they sometimes admit a few of these students partly because their families are wealthy and likely to give money to the university.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adrien Arpel Inc., a cosmetics business, retained Wertheim Schroder & Co. as a financial adviser for possible sale of the company.

title: Two Offices Are Merged By Rowland
description: ROWLAND WORLDWIDE, Saatchi & Saatchi's public relations subsidiary, said yesterday that it was merging its two London offices to create the third-largest public relations firm in Britain. But Herbert L. Rowland, chairman of the company, believes the announcement has more than local significance.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF DEFENDS ACTS ON LIBRARIANS
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that he had been unaware that the F.B.I. had routinely checked the backgrounds of people whose help it had sought in identifying Soviet use of American technical libraries.

title: Sports People: BASKETBALL; Manning Nears His Return Date
description: The Los Angeles Clippers forward Danny Manning, who has been working out on his own and with the team in a limited fashion to rehabilitate his injured left knee, has been cleared for full practices beginning next Wednesday, Elgin Baylor, the team's general manager, said Monday night.

title: Review/Theater; A Variation on the High School Reunion
description: At ''The Widow's Blind Date,'' the Israel Horovitz play that opened last night at the Circle in the Square Downtown, audiences may wonder what they're seeing: is this an attempt to explore the deepest roots and causes of misogyny, or a gratuitously violent and sexually titillating revenge fantasy in the manner of an early Charles Bronson movie?

title: Senator D'Amato's Denials
description: Where the Department of Housing and Urban Development is concerned, Senator Alfonse D'Amato more and more resembles a child who, despite crumbs all over his face, reflexively denies he has been near the cookie jar. When will the Senate Ethics Committee show some interest?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY Four Senators tried to persuade a regulator to drop a regulation that would have stopped Lincoln Savings and Loan from making the risky investments that eventually led to its demise, the former head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said. [ Page D1. ] The Senate and House agreed to raise the Treasury's borrowing authority above $3.12 trillion. The legislation was approved by voice vote in the Senate and by a 269-to-99 margin in the House and sent to President Bush. His signature would prevent the Government from running out of cash tomorrow. [ D1. ] American consumers slowed their taking on of new debt in September, adding only $606 million in what analysts said was new caution about buying cars and other expensive items. [ D2. ] A bitter controversy has been touched off by reports that the Bush Administration plans to scale back the Pentagon's role in a variety of technology development programs. [ D8. ] COMPANIES

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Legislative Race; Democrats Win The Assembly In New Jersey
description: Democrats recaptured control of the New Jersey Assembly yesterday the same way they lost it four years ago: in a landslide victory by a candidate for governor.

title: The 1989 Elections; First Black, but Not Quite
description: L. Douglas Wilder's apparent victory today would make him the first black elected governor in the United States. But if the likely recount that tight race confirms his electoral triumph, he will not be the first black politician ever to serve as a governor.

title: Cunniff Hoping to Instill Leadership
description: The common description of John Cunniff as a ''hockey man'' is a perfect way to portray the new coach of the Devils.

title: David A. Neuman, Executive, 61
description: David A. Neuman, an advertising executive, died of lung cancer Saturday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Tabard Farms
description: A small potato chip company, whose product sells in expensive stores, is in talks aimed at setting up a joint venture to make chips in the Soviet Union. Edward Cohen, president of the privately held Tabard Farms Potato Chips, said that if the negotiations were successful, an agreement would be signed in January with two Soviet cooperatives.

title: U.S., Japan and Soviets Prevent Accord to Limit Carbon Dioxide
description: Objections by the United States, Japan and the Soviet Union at an international conference here thwarted endorsement today of a specific timetable for curbs on emissions of carbon dioxide.

title: Rise in Consumer Debt Slowed in September
description: American consumers dramatically slowed their taking on of new debt in September, adding only $606 million in what analysts said was new caution about buying cars and other expensive items.

title: Senators Sought Deal, Savings Official Says
description: A former top Federal regulator testified yesterday that four United States Senators who received more than $1 million in campaign funds from a California savings executive had tried to persuade the Government to drop a tough regulation.

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Connecticut; New Haven Picks First Black Mayor
description: State Senator John C. Daniels, a Democrat, was elected New Haven's first black mayor today, while a little-known Republican real estate agent, Mary C. Moran, scored a stunning upset in Bridgeport, defeating the two-term Mayor Thomas W. Bucci by a wide margin.

title: 4 Arrested at Supreme Court
description: Four people were arrested today when they disrupted oral arguments at the Supreme Court to protest the Court's ruling last July that enhanced the states' power to restrict abortions. In a brief outburst in the ornate courtroom, each of the protesters rose, denounced the ruling and was immediately taken into custody. They were identified as Michael Madewell, 27 years old, of Athens, Ga; Benjamin Troxell, 26, of Cleveland Heights, Ohio; Sandra Lines, 41, of Jersey City, and Michelle Pahl, 27, of New York.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Black Success With Measured Approach
description: Black candidates demonstrated in the elections yesterday that a deliberate approach, ample experience in office and a knack for turning minority status into a political asset could constitute a formula for electoral success.

title: More Futures Charges Seen
description: Federal prosecutors said today that they would charge more traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Swiss franc futures pit as a result of their investigation of illegal trading.

title: Precious Metals Prices Rise Mainly on Foreign Demand
description: Precious metals prices continued to climb yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, largely on an increase in overseas demand. Dealers attributed the overseas buying, much of it from the Mideast, to the diversion of assets from securities portfolios as well as an increase in domestic speculative interest in gold.

title: Stealth in the Stacks
description: Truly clever deceptions in the Federal budget are the ones that never come to light, but now and then a lulu makes the news. Example: Pentagon procurement officers laundering consultants' fees through the Library of Congress.

title: Accounts
description: * Commerce Drug Co., Plainview, L.I., to Sullivan & Brugnatelli, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Tourism Accounts
description: Sunny skies and sandy beaches will warm two advertising agencies this winter, if only from a distance. HDM Los Angeles and AC&R Advertising won tourism accounts this week. The Aruba Tourism Authority awarded its $3 million account to AC&R yesterday. The tourism board for Los Cabos, a Mexican resort community, awarded its $4 million account to HDM Los Angeles.

title: Rothschild Unit Officers Named
description: The Rothschild banking operation plans to set up a merchant bank in Toronto headed by H. Garfield Emerson, a Canadian lawyer who has specialized in substantial corporate finance deals.

title: Review/Pop; An NRBQ Retrospective
description: It didn't take long for NRBQ to reach a state of euphoria at the Bottom Line on Friday night. About halfway through the first tune, ''Rocket in My Pocket'' - pushed on by the fluid rhythm section and a crushing backbeat - Terry Adams, the group's pianist, delivered a solo full of cascading clusters and jarring upper register tinkles that had the crowd cheering loudly.

title: People
description: * Peter B. Hubbell and Linda L. Stack have been named senior vice presidents of N.W. Ayer.

title: Milestone in Africa: Namibians Vote Their Future
description: Namibians turned out in large numbers today to vote in elections clearing the way to independence for this territory, ruled illegally by South Africa for 23 years.

title: Never Undervalue Nurses in Prenatal Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Supermarket as Theater, Service as Star
description: AT the four-month-old Wegmans store in Greece, N.Y., shoppers are not greeted at the door by a row of checkout counters and aisle upon aisle of packaged goods. Instead, their first impression is of a farmers' market, with enormous displays of fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: WILDER SEEMS VIRGINIA WINNER, FLORIO IN; VOTERS, 5-4, APPROVE NEW YORK CHARTER; Charter Revision Wins Approval, Shifting Many Powers to Council
description: A proposal for the most sweeping revision of the New York City Charter in nearly a century was approved yesterday.

title: THE 1989 ELECTIONS: Governor-Elect  MAN IN THE NEWS: James Joseph Florio; Careful and Determined
description: One day last month, a tired James J. Florio was jogging with a longtime friend in Central Park when the two middle-aged men pulled around a curve to face a sharp incline in the road. The friend stopped to rest. Mr. Florio broke into a sprint.

title: J.C. Street, Physicist, Dies at 83; Discovered Muon, Atomic Particle
description: Dr. J. C. Street, a co-discoverer of a fundamental particle of matter known as the muon, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Charleston, S.C. He was 83 years old.

title: B&H Maritime Carriers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included initial financing costs of $394,357. The company has no comparable figures because it began operations in February.

title: ASHLAND ACCEPTS OIL SPILL ACCORD
description: Ashland Oil Inc. agreed to pay $30 million to settle 20 class-action civil suits from a diesel fuel spill nearly two years ago that polluted two rivers and threatened drinking water supplies in three states.

title: Pete Rose: Telling Lies Or Truth?
description: rrIn other years, wherever Pete Rose went in Cincinnati he drew a crowd. Now he scatters a crowd. Not long ago the Reds' former manager was observed having lunch at a counter in Cincinnati with three empty stools on each side. Such is life when you've been banned from baseball even when you're Pete Rose, perhaps especially when you're Pete Rose. Such is life even with the right to appeal for reinstatement next Aug. 24, one year after having signed an agreement with Bart Giamatti, then the baseball commissioner.

title: New Turner Book Unit
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said today that it was creating a division, Turner Publishing Inc., that will develop book publishing possibilities related to the parent company's other interests.

title: Hall (Frank B.) & Co (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $50 million from discontinued operations.

title: Cablevision Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a one-time gain of $103,214,000 on the sale of interests in the company's programming businesses to National Broadcasting Co.

title: Arts Endowment Withdraws Grant for AIDS Show
description: The National Endowment for the Arts yesterday withdrew its sponsorship of a New York City art show about AIDS that includes images of homosexual acts and criticizes public figures. It was the first such decision by the agency since a law was passed this fall that will curtail Government financing of artwork considered obscene.

title: Norcen Energy Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: An Eye for Telescopes and Binoculars
description: IN a city where the stars are seldom seen and wildlife is not abundant, a surprising number of New Yorkers use binoculars and telescopes. Some may zoom in on the Brooklyn Bridge; others may view across Central Park. All is fine until an instrument breaks; then finding a shop where it can be repaired can make a person see double.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Heavy U.S. Debt Sales Awaited
description: Dealers in the credit markets are scrambling to cope with a rapid-fire succession of Treasury auctions.

title: From Protest to Politics
description: A generation ago, what happened in Tuesday's elections would have been inconceivable. As recently as a year ago, even a Las Vegas bookmaker probably wouldn't have given odds on the results. Even now those results look much closer than had been expected. No matter. They certify a remarkable shift in American politics.

title: New Republic of 60's a Voice of Conscience; The Turn to the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Copperweld Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $6.9 million in second quarter restructuring costs. The company said share results reflect the company's exchange of preferred into subordinated debentures in June 1989, and the resulting tax deductibility of the interest charges.

title: Pan Am Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included for the quarter a gain of $18.4 million from the finalization of the sale of a division of Pan Am World Services earlier this year; the 9 months included a gain of $110.5 million as a result of the sale of Pan Am World Services.

title: BROAD DISPARITIES IN VOTES AND POLLS RAISING QUESTIONS
description: Voter surveys for the elections Tuesday in Virginia and New York City produced widely divergent and largely inaccurate results, leaving poll takers divided over whether the survey methods were flawed or people simply lied about voting for a black candidate to avoid seeming biased.

title: Q&A
description: Layers of Shingles Q.The asphalt shingles on my gabled roof are 22 years old, and new shingles must be installed soon. I had planned to cover the old shingles with new building paper and then lay the new asphalt shingles on top. But I have been told that if I do so, the new shingles will last only half as long because of heat buildup; two layers of shingles, I was told, will not allow proper cooling between the attic and the top layer. What is your opinion? A.Applying a second layer of asphalt shingles over old shingles, assuming only one layer is already in place, is a common practice, and in most cases there is nothing wrong with this. The idea of heat buildup is new to me and frankly does not make much sense; if the attic gets very hot, as most do in the summer, then it should be ventilated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the oil company Petroleos de Venezuela misstated aspects of the agreement to add the Southland Corporation's 50 percent stake in Citgo Petroleum to the 50 percent it already owned. Petroleos paid $290 million, not $400 million, for the stake that it bought in 1986. Southland says it is ahead of schedule in paying off $1.54 billion in bank debt due in 1993; it has not said it expects to become profitable by that year. Because of an editing error, the article also misattributed an estimate of the cash Southland would receive. The company did not provide a figure; $500 million was The Times's estimate, based on available information.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net income

title: Central Louisiana Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Milgray Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Officials Clash at Hearing On Power to Seize Fugitives
description: A Bush Administration official and a Democratic Congressman clashed today over a recently disclosed Justice Department memorandum that says the President may order the seizure of fugitives in foreign countries without the host governments' consent.

title: Orlando Wins Again
description: Sam Vincent and Reggie Theus scored 6 points apiece in overtime tonight as the Orlando Magic overcame an early 25-point deficit to beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 117-110.

title: Compromise Is Sought On Expiring Tax Breaks
description: House tax writers are seeking a compromise with their Senate counterparts that would allow extension of a variety of popular tax breaks scheduled to expire at the end of the year.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS McEnroe Advances: Top-seeded John McEnroe beat Scott Davis, 6-3, 6-3, last night in a Grand Prix tournament in Wembley, England. Joining him in the second round was second-seeded Michael Chang, who beat Dan Goldie. The defending champion, Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland, lost to Martin Strelba of Czechoslovakia.(AP) Lendl Wins: Ivan Lendl beat Mikael Pernfors, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the Stockholm Open. Boris Becker, the defending champion, beat Jim Pugh.(AP) Sukova and Maleeva Gain: Helena Sukova and Manuela Maleeva won their second-round matches yesterday at the Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. Sukova beat Rosalyn Fairbank. Maleeva beat Lori McNeil.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 6, Whalers 3: Phil Housley and Pierre Turgeoneach had a goal and two assists in a contest in Hartford between two of the hottest teams in the Adams Division.

title: In Savings Debacle, Many Fingers Point Here
description: To his critics, Charles H. Keating Jr., the Phoenix financier who built and lost the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, represents all that is wrong with a political system in which wealth grants access and influence. To his defenders, Mr. Keating is simply a hard-driving entrepreneur who is being made the fall guy for the savings industry's plight.

title: Airtran Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Friends' Words and Her Own, Mary McCarthy Is Remembered
description: Friends, relatives and colleagues of Mary McCarthy gathered at the Pierpont Morgan Library yesterday afternoon to celebrate the novelist, critic and essayist, who died of cancer last month in New York at the age of 77.

title: Prudential-Bache Move
description: Theodore V. Fowler, the co-head of investment banking at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., yesterday resigned from the firm because of a dispute over its future strategic direction, Prudential Bache announced. Mr. Fowler, 42 years old and a director and member of the firm's executive committee, will pursue other interests, a spokeswoman said. The resignation is considered a setback to the firm's investment banking arm, which has been struggling since 1986 to become a major player on Wall Street. James F. Crowley, co-head of the department, will continue as president and head of investment banking, the company said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: How We Can Help Gorbachev and Ourselves
description: To the Editor:

Logicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Metro Datelines;
description: A Brooklyn jury awarded $61 million yesterday to a young man whose legs were severed at the knees in 1985 when he fell from a subway platform and into the path of an oncoming train.

description: Results for 1989 included the results of 9 former Masco Industries businesses, acquired effective Oct. 1, 1988. Results for 1988 are pro forma, reflecting the acquisition of the Masco Industries units as if it had occurred on Jan. 1, 1988. The company had actual earnings of $1,510,000 in the year- earlier third quarter on sales of $14,820,000. It had actual earnings in the year-ago 9 months of $5,870,000, on sales of $47,370,000.

title: Walter Tkach, 72; Served as the Doctor To Three Presidents
description: Dr. Walter Robert Tkach, a former White House physician who served three Presidents, died of heart disease Nov. 1 at his home at Scripps Ranch. He was 72 years old.

title: 7 Killed on L.I. And 8 Are Hurt In Crash of Van
description: Seven people were killed today when a van carrying 15 people skidded out of control, slammed into a tree and burst into flames along the Northern State Parkway here.

title: Closing 'Window of Time' When Life Began
description: In a new analysis of Earth's first billion years, scientists have defined what they believe is the ''window in time'' when existing life forms gained their initial foothold.

title: Homestyle Buffet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 11
description: Homestyle said 1989 share earnings reflected sale of 821,250 shares in a public offering completed in July.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20 Bonn would provide East Germany with ''comprehensive'' aid if it allowed free elections and made fundamental changes in its economy, Chancellor Kohl said. Page A1

The 1989 Elections: Yonkers; From Housing Rebel to Mayoral Victor
description: Henry Spallone, who rode his passionate opposition to a court-ordered housing desegregation plan into the Mayor's office on Tuesday, was seen in Yonkers by his supporters today not as an obstructionist, but as a courageous defender of this city.

description: John Cunniff admitted he was nervous in his debut as coach of the Devils tonight because of the opponent's long losing streak.

title: Co-Anchor Going From Channel 4 to 5
description: Jack Cafferty, a co-anchor of the Channel 4 early-evening news program ''Live at Five,'' will become the anchor of a new late-night news program on Channel 5, the two stations announced yesterday. In an interview, Mr. Cafferty said that his last appearance on ''Live at Five'' would probably be tomorrow. The new program, as yet unnamed, will have its premiere in January.

title: Dixie Yarns Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $162,000, or 1 cent a share, from the sale of two plantss to Kondo Cotton Spinning Co. Ltd.

description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary credit of $6,500,000, or 73 cents a share. Restructuring charges consisting of $825,000 for an indemnity payment on an aircraft disposition and $365,000 to write down the value of a retired maintenance facility were taken during the quarter.
