description: The share earnings reflected adjustment for a 2-for-1 stock split Sept. 12, 1988.

title: Man Is Sentenced in Killing Of Boy, 7, Who Taunted Him
description: A man convicted of killing a 7-year-old boy because he was making faces at him was sentenced today to 20 years to life in prison.

title: Money Funds Off in Week
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Walton Top Rookie In National League
description: Jerome Walton, the center fielder whose bat, glove and speed helped the Chicago Cubs win the National League East title, was voted the league's Rookie of the Year yesterday. Walton, the first Cubs player to be so chosen since Ken Hubbs in 1962, got 22 first-place votes and 2 seconds for 116 points from a 24-member panel of the Baseball Writers Association of America. He was the only player named on every ballot.

title: Businessman Arrested in Sale of Jet Fighters
description: A businessman from the Philippines has been arrested on charges of selling two jet fighters abandoned by American forces in Vietnam to undercover customs agents, a prosecutor said today.

title: Wal-Mart Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Torchbearer for Change Is Recruited From Dresden
description: When Hans Modrow moved to Dresden in 1973 to assume the post of party chief, he immediately caught the attention of local residents by moving into a three-room apartment, rather than an official villa.

title: Nuclear Waste Job Is Reported Going To a Top Engineer
description: President Bush intends to nominate a former nuclear engineering executive, John Bartlett, to head the Energy Department's office of high-level nuclear waste management, Congressional and other sources said today.

title: Anti-Abortion Groups Barred From Blocking Capital Clinics
description: A Federal district judge today ordered opponents of abortion not to block entrances to six clinics in the Washington area as part of an effort planned over the next two weekends to prevent women from obtaining abortions here.

title: Inglis Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an unusual pre-tax gain of $2.8 million related to the sale of the Stoney Creek, Ont., facility for the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Metro Datelines; Smoke-Alarm Law Extended by Koch
description: All garden apartments and one- and two-family homes will be required to have smoke alarms under a bill signed yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: Million-Dollar Player Weds in Millionaire Style
description: Diego Maradona, who came out of a Buenos Aires shantytown to earn millions as an international soccer star, was married Tuesday in an all-night bash for 1,100 people with champagne, caviar, salmon, entire tables of cheese, seafood and desserts, and an 8-foot-7-inch cake.

title: Graco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: The year-ago results were restated to reflect change in accounting principle.

title: Textbooks to Suit Every Whim and Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Morgan to Retire; His Successor Is Selected
description: Lewis T. Preston, chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company through the 1980's, said yesterday that he would take early retirement at the end of the year and named Dennis Weatherstone as his successor.

title: Full Translation Is Required In Immigration Proceedings
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that interpreters at immigration proceedings must translate all of those proceedings, and not just part of them, if the alien involved does not understand English.

title: American Indemnity Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: A.T.& T. Is Suing Intellicall on Data
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Dallas, accusing Intellicall Inc., which makes pay telephones for private ownership, of illegally obtaining billing information owned by A.T.& T. The suit contends that Intellicall, based in Carrollton, Tex., has designed and programmed its phones to obtain information from A.T.& T.'s credit-card validation system. The system, part of A.T.& T.'s long-distance network, verifies that the telephone credit-card number provided by the customer is valid.

title: Equitable of Iowa Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $9 million from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $11,555,000, or $1.39 a share.

title: 'Junk Bonds' Advance For Third Day in a Row
description: Prices of ''junk bonds'' extended their rally for a third day yesterday. Bonds rose an average of three-quarters of a point, or $7.50 for every $1,000 face amount, and some zero-coupon bonds climbed more than 2 points.

title: Right Stuff Puts Yale On Verge
description: In early September, Carm Cozza, the Yale football coach, supposed that the Bulldogs might turn into a good team provided that every expectation, every promise, every dream came true.

title: Religious Party Presses Israeli Coalition
description: One of Israel's small religious parties said today that it would leave the governing coalition for two months to try to force Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to fulfill promises to the party.

title: Chandler Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: The 1989 Elections: Charter; Putting New Government in Place Will Take Time
description: Despite the approval of a sweeping revision of the New York City Charter by voters Tuesday, it will take months and in a few instances years before the new municipal government will be in place.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: THERE are twins in my building, little girls alike only in their amiability and their very red hair. I seldom see them, so when I heard their chortles in the hall one night last week I opened my door for a chat. They were side by side in a stroller, waiting with their mother for the elevator, and delighted to see the diversion that was me. I admired their new teeth and the cut of their overalls; they responded with solemn stares and shy smiles.

title: Prime Motor Inns L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated as a result of increased depreciation.

I.Q. Is Not Everything
description: To The Home Section:

title: Manila Journal; From a Life of Privilege, a Woman of Substance
description: Daughter of one of the Philippines' most respected men and the sister of another, Leticia Ramos Shahani has had a privileged life. It has also been one of extraordinary accomplishment and self-discovery.

title: New Republic of 60's a Voice of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: How France Is Providing Child Care To a Nation
description: AS the debate on how to meet the growing need for child care intensifies in Congress, corporate headquarters and communities across the nation, a panel of experts says the United States should look to France for ideas.

title: Fear in Paris: Ties to Bonn Will Be Hurt
description: Having learned to live with its historical enemy over the last 30 years, France is beginning to worry that the rapid pace of change in Eastern Europe will unavoidably damage its relationship with West Germany.

title: Marten Transport reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included an accounting adjustment of $748,000, or 22 cents a share, from a change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 1 about Alpheus T. Mason, an emeritus professor of jurisprudence at Princeton University and biographer of judges, misidentified Harlan F. Stone, the subject of a Mason biography. He was Chief Justice of the United States, having earlier been an Associate Justice.

title: Campaign Matters; Dinkins Poses New Problems For the Governor
description: For 12 years, Edward I. Koch has played Fred Allen to Mario M. Cuomo's Jack Benny. But what happens now that one of the most open political rivalries in the state has been consigned to history? Who gets the gag lines when the Great Negotiator meets the Great Conciliator?

title: Doskocil Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,170,000 and $6,089,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $269,000, or 5 cents a share, and $1,268,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said included are pre- tax charges of $8,228,000 in the latest quarter and 9 months from a delay in the sale of the assets of a division of Wilson Foods Corp. The proposed buyer of the assets couldn't arrange financing and the sale was subsequently terminated. The company also said the increase in sales and pre-tax income is due to the acquisition of Wilson Foods in the 1988 fourth quarter.

title: Richard Vorisek, 71, Film Sound Director
description: Richard J. Vorisek, who received an Academy Award nomination for sound direction for the 1981 film ''Reds,'' died at Stamford Hospital on Tuesday after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: Minimum Wage Rise Wins Final Senate Vote
description: The Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill raising the minimum wage to $3.80 an hour next year and to $4.25 an hour in 1991. The increases would be the first since 1981.

Fiserv Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Allwaste Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Midwest Grain Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; A Pinter Double Bill of Evil and Bleakness
description: Though written three decades apart, Harold Pinter's first full-length work, the 1958 ''Birthday Party,'' and his latest play, the 20-minute ''Mountain Language,'' build to the same grotesque conclusion: a defenseless man is reduced to a quivering, speechless wreck by properly dressed thugs serving an unnamed organization. Mr. Pinter hasn't changed that much in 30 years, but neither has the world around him. This is still a century in which terror can arrive with a stranger's knock at the door. The silence that follows -the deadly silence of abject fear - is the ultimate Pinter pause.

title: Sun Electric Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $2,632,000 related to restructuring of U.S. operations. c-Net income

title: Chamorro Meets Bush and Vows to Reduce Army
description: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the opposition candidate for President of Nicaragua, met today with President Bush and said she would sharply reduce the size of the Nicaraguan Army if she wins the election scheduled for February.

title: Zenith National Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $198,000, or 1 cent a share, and $1,099,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $1,453,000, or 7 cents a share, and $3,640,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The extraordinary items included the effect of capital gains or losses and tax benefits.

title: More Free-Agent Filers
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the Los Angeles Dodger left-hander who was among the top National League pitchers in the 1980's until experiencing arm problems the last two seasons, filed for free agency yesterday. Valenzuela, who has a 128-103 record, fell to 5-8 in 1988 and 10-13 last season.

title: Piniella Staff Forming
description: Lou Piniella, the Cincinnati Reds' new manager, named three persons to his coaching staff yesterday. A former Reds star, Tony Perez, will return as hitting coach and first-base coach. Jackie Moore, who was with Montreal the last three seasons, will be bench coach and will work with catchers and outfielders. Sam Perlozzo, dismissed by the Mets last month, will be third-base coach and will work with infielders.(AP)

title: 4 Arrested at Supreme Court
description: Four people were arrested Tuesday when they disrupted oral arguments at the Supreme Court to protest the Court's ruling last July that enhanced the states' power to restrict abortions. In a brief outburst in the ornate courtroom, each of the protesters rose, denounced the ruling and was immediately taken into custody. They were identified as Michael Madewell, 27 years old, of Athens, Ga; Benjamin Troxell, 26, of Cleveland Heights, Ohio; Sandra Lines, 41, of Jersey City, and Michelle Pahl, 27, of New York.

title: Industries in U.S. and Japan Form Alliance on New TV Technology
description: In an unexpected alliance, American computer chip makers have agreed to work with Japan's biggest electronics companies in designing and producing crucial components for high-definition television, the next generation of video technology.

title: A Portrait of New York City Voters
The 1989 Elections: The Governor-Elect; Transition and Insurance Come First, Florio Says
description: A jovial Governor-elect James J. Florio met with reporters today to declare that his first priorities in office would be to bring down high automobile-insurance premiums and to insure a smooth transition from the administration of Gov. Thomas H. Kean.

title: Rose Is Being Treated for Gambling Problem
description: Pete Rose said today that he was getting psychiatric help for a gambling problem that became apparent to him only after he was banned from baseball.

Ortega Offers Deal to Dismantle Contra Bases
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that his country would stop receiving weapons from foreign nations until late April if contra leaders agree immediately to begin dismantling their bases in Honduras.

title: The 1989 Elections: G.O.P. Post-Mortem; The Loser Is Faulting D'Amato
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani assigned at least part of the blame for his narrow loss in the New York City mayoral election to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday, saying Mr. D'Amato would have to ''take responsibility'' for the damage caused by a divisive Republican primary.

title: Daughter May Plead Insanity in Mother's Killing
description: A teen-ager accused of plotting her mother's murder has filed notice that she might use an insanity defense.

title: Panel Told Chip Effort May Falter
description: The American effort to regain supremacy in manufacturing semiconductors is being jeopardized by serious deterioration of the industry's suppliers, the top official of Sematech, a federally aided industry research consortium, warned today.

title: Stocks Up on Signs That Fed Eased Policy
description: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday, on signs that the Federal Reserve had eased its monetary policy.

title: Kitty Dukakis's Illness Tied to Rubbing Alcohol
description: Kitty Dukakis's doctor said today that she was hospitalized after drinking a small amount of rubbing alcohol.

title: J.E. Hanson, 44, Dies; Started Culture Center
description: Joseph E. (Patrick) Hanson 3d, a founder of the Cultural Center of Southampton, L.I., and director of public relations for the Record World/Square Circle music store chain, died on Monday at the home of his parents in Summit, N.J. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Elegant Mundanities: The Chiclet and Others
description: LEAD: CLUTTER and ugliness seem inevitable parts of the commercial world. Yet as Owen Edwards makes clear in his book ''Elegant Solutions'' (Crown, $15.95), many objects that are taken for granted are beautiful, efficient and economical.

title: Bantam's 'General' Brings a Legacy of Discipline
description: Alberto Vitale's eight lieutenants at Bantam Doubleday Dell refer to the 55-year-old chief executive as ''The General'' for his leadership in bringing financial discipline to the publishing company where he has served as a senior officer for 14 years.

title: 5 Sentenced in Beatings as Gay-Rights Advocates Yell 'No Justice!'
description: The sentencing of five men for an attack on two men who they believed were homosexuals ended in a raucous outburst yesterday in a Manhattan court. Several demonstrators screamed, ''Shame! Shame!'' at the prosecutors and ''No justice!'' at the judge.

description: Harold Greenstein, a former assistant New York attorney general, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: Democratic celebration over the apparent election of L. Douglas Wilder as Governor of Virginia was tempered today by the recognition that a significant number of white voters supported white Democratic candidates while shunning Mr. Wilder, who is black.

title:
CURRENTS;
Reinventing The Teapot Yet Again
description: LEAD: TEA drinking is not usually considered an all-American pastime. Yet the teapot is re-invented constantly by designers, artists and even architects. To show how steeped the teapot is in the consciousness of craftsmen, the Ferrin Gallery at Pinch Pottery in Northampton, Mass., mounts an annual exhibition, ''A Tea Party.

title: Stress on Quality Lifts Xerox's Market Share
description: Each day, every assembly-line worker at the Xerox Corporation's copier manufacturing plant here, near Rochester, receives a report on all defects found in the previous day's production. The message is clear: Quality counts and everybody is involved.

title: 182 Studios, 182 Slices Of New York Reality
description: THEY sleep on sofa beds and futons, Murphy beds and Hollywood beds. They chop carrots in their dining rooms, eat dinner in their living rooms and turn dressing rooms into nurseries. Efficient creatures, these studio dwellers.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: TO most American teen-agers, the symbolic value of a driver's license goes far beyond the legal right to drive. It is a token of their power and independence, an opportunity for privacy and romance and a sign of increased status that can separate them from younger friends and siblings.

title: The 1989 Elections: Dinkins's Strategist; 'Rumpled Genius' Who Guided Mayor-Elect's Race Savors Its End
description: Bill Lynch sat slumped on a couch in his office yesterday, relief covering his face.

title: Rams' Problems Mirror Everett's
description: Early in the season, Jim Everett of the Los Angeles Rams was statistically the leading passer in the National Football League. Now he ranks 11th in the league and the Rams, a preseason favorite to reach the Super Bowl, have lost their last four games.

title: CONGRESS TO LIMIT BUSH ON SPY FUNDS
description: Defying a veto threat from President Bush, House and Senate negotiators agreed today on legislation that would sharply restrict the President's power to solicit funds from foreign countries to carry out intelligence operations and other activities overseas.

Little Bistro in Chicago
description: LEAD: ''THE restaurants in Chicago are always too huge and noisy,'' said Paul Fortune, an English designer based in Los Angeles. To show Chicago an alternative, Mr. Fortune has just completed the two-level Mirador - restaurant downstairs, lounge upstairs - at 1400 North Wells Street.

CURRENTS;

description: LEAD: THE Israeli architect Zvi Hecker turned to the spiral when designing an eight-unit condominium building in Ramat Gan, outside Tel Aviv. Photographs, drawings and models of this and other buildings are on view in Manhattan at the Storefront for Art & Architecture, 97 Kenmare Street, at Lafayette, until Nov.

title: U.S. Fears That Chinese May Again Sell Missiles
description: A senior Administration official said today that the United States is concerned that China may drop its commitment not to sell medium-range missiles or the technology to make them.

title: I.B.M. Chip Is Licensed To Micron
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, in a further effort to bolster the American semiconductor industry, said today that it would license the technology for making its most powerful computer memory chip to Micron Technology Inc.

Poor Mothers, Poorer Babies
description: One day last week a group of very young mothers holding toddlers and infants lined up outside a Manhattan welfare hotel. When their numbers were called, they went to the back of a truck where helpers handed them milk and packaged meals. Any number of circumstances conspired to produce those girls' poverty. That they had babies while still children themselves is certain to prolong it.

title: Democrat Wins in East Orange
description: Cardell Cooper, a Democrat, easily won the mayoral race Tuesday and will succeed John C. Hatcher, who is under indictment and did not run for a second term. Mr. Cooper, 37 years old, got 11,587 votes, compared with 1,064 for the Republican, Kyle Mann, who had unofficially withdrawn his candidacy in September.

title: Genicom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Reflected operating expenses which included a one-time, pre-tax restructuring charge of $6 million. c-Net income and after an accounting adjustment gain of $4.3 million, or 37 cents a share.

title: Pistons Recall Old Era In 95-74 Loss to Pacers
description: The defending champion Detroit Pistons tonight were held to their second-lowest point total since the National Basketball Association went to the 24-second clock in 1954, losing to the Indiana Pacers, 95-74.

title: Texas Air Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results included the operations of Continental Airlines, Eastern Air Lines and System One Corp., as well as Texas Air itself. Results for 1989 included third quarter costs of $13.5 million directly related to the Eastern Air Lines reorganization process, and a $34.1 million pension curtailment charge. Latest quarter and 9-month results included nonrecurring gains of $11.3 million and $79.2 million, respectively, from the sale of assets by Continental. The year-ago quarter and 9-month results included Continental asset sale gains of $9.2 million and $28.6 million, respectively. The 1988 9-month operating loss included an adjustment of $131.0 million made by Continental relating to an accounting adjustment associated with the reestimation of its air traffice liability. The company said that loss per share assuming full dilution is the same as primary loss per share; although certain preferred stock, warrants and stock options are considered common equivalent shares, they were not included in the computation since their inclusion would be antidilutive.

title: Castro Laments 'Sad' Events
description: President Fidel Castro of Cuba, apparently referring to pressures for reform in the Soviet bloc, has warned that ''very sad things'' are happening in other Communist nations and that Cuba could face serious difficulties if those countries do not solve their problems. He spoke at the inauguration of a factory near Havana on Tuesday.

title: Whittle Plans TV Service In Doctors' Waiting Rooms
description: Whittle Communications plans to offer television programs specially created for 100,000 doctors' waiting rooms across the nation.

title: Police, in Force, Raid A University in Lima
description: Four hundred police officers surged onto the campus of San Marcos University's medical school today. The police reported seizing bombs and leftist propaganda and detaining hundreds of people as soldiers sealed off the area.

title: Georgia-Pacific
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, which last week offered to buy the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation for $3.1 billion, said the Interstate Commerce Commission would allow it to proceed with the proposed acquisition. The deal would create the nation's largest forest-products company. Nekoosa, based in Norwalk, Conn., has not responded formally to the bid. Georgia-Pacific, based in Atlanta, said it had secured an exemption that allowed it to acquire railroads controlled by Nekoosa.

title: Midwinter Color, Sans Spray Paint
description: MY friend Edith Eddleman, the curator of one of the nation's finest and largest borders of herbaceous perennials, at the Arboretum of the University of North Carolina at Raleigh, takes great delight in color.

title:
CURRENTS;
New Store For MOMA Favorites
description: LEAD: GEORGE III silver and Charles X chairs go quickly at auctions. But modern design still sells well in stores. At least the Museum of Modern Art has found this true. Last week its design store expanded into new quarters at 44 West 53d Street, across the street from the museum itself. The MOMA Design Store supplants the Museum Store Annex, a shop in a brownstone at 37 West 53d Street, and augments the MOMA bookstore at the east side of the museum lobby.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chief of Telemedia Inc. Takes Year's Sabbatical
description: Telemedia Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief executive, John van de Kamer, had resigned to take a one-year sabbatical. The Canadian broadcast and publishing company immediately appointed R. James McCoubray, the director of Young & Rubicam's Canadian, African and Australian divisions, as president and chief executive.

title: Kohl Is Due in Poland Today as Agenda Widens
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl is to arrive here on Thursday for a five-day visit focusing on the Polish economy. But as protests in East Germany grow and the country's leaders fall from grace, the talks are expected to take in the tumult in Central Europe and the prospect for German reunification.

According to Garbage magazine, half of the volume, and about 30 percent of the weight of this collective trash, is packaging: all those containers and wrappers, often alluringly designed, that tend to be thrown away.

The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that it would require spending $79 million over the next five years.

description: New Jersey voters, leaving no doubt about their choice for governor, elected Representative James Florio over Representative Jim Courter by a 24-point margin. The outcome was a triumph of Democrat over Republican, of an activist philosophy of government over a minimalist view. Mostly, though, it was an expression of a widespread desire for continuity and moderation.

title: Review/Television; 'McCloud' Joins the Ranks Of Prime-Time Revivals
description: On network prime time, hunks and teen-agers' idols are as common as commercials, from Ken Wahl in CBS's ''Wiseguy'' to Richard Grieco in Fox's ''Booker.'' There is no dearth of pretty faces, young and youngish, trying to attract the 18-to-39-year-old women coveted by advertisers. But a different kind of television hero is quietly emerging. This is the type who might be referred to, diplomatically, as a gentleman of a certain age. Sixty is often the lower end of his age scale.

title: Monteverdi's 'Ulisse,' Problematic and Rare, Is Newly Popular
description: Claudio Monteverdi's first opera, ''L'Orfeo'' is performed frequently, and his last one, ''L'Incoronazione di Poppea,'' has its advocates too. But ''Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria'' the only other surviving opera by the composer, who was one of the genre's founders, has posed so many problems for musicians and musicologists that until recently, productions have been few and far between.

title: BONN TIES MORE AID FOR EAST GERMANY TO FREE ELECTIONS
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl told Parliament today that Bonn would be ready to provide ''comprehensive'' aid to East Germany if it allowed free elections and made fundamental changes in its state-planned economy.

title: New York State Seeks $76 Million In Fines Over Fresh Kills Landfill
description: New York State's top environmental official filed a civil complaint against New York City today accusing it of ignoring his orders to clean up its huge Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island. He is seeking $76 million in fines. The official, Thomas C. Jorling, the Environmental Conservation Commissioner, also threatened to obtain a court order to close the dump by the summer of 1991.

title: Federal Report Criticizes Signs In Bridge Crash
description: The warning signs posted by the City of New Haven near a closed bridge where four East Lyme friends died a year ago failed to conform to highway-safety guidelines, a Federal investigator said in a preliminary report.

title: Rebuilding Buoys Hopes For Hospital in Harlem
description: Several years ago North General Hospital was on the verge of closing. But after bucking a trend that has seen many financially troubled inner-city hospitals shut their doors, the hospital in Harlem began a rebuilding program last month that will make it the area's largest private development.

title: Review/Pop; A Country Music Outsider
description: Dwight Yoakam's long, confident and slightly nasty show at the Ritz on Saturday night was an indication that the performer, who has consistantly positioned himself as a country music outsider, is fulfilling his own myth. Where other new-traditionalist country singers - Randy Travis, George Strait, Ricky Van Shelton - offer a polite version of country music, Mr. Yoakam, fronting a hard-boiled, rocking band, blasts away with rock energy and rock performance standards.

title: 2 of Bolshoi's Best Are Touring U.S.
description: Soviet ballet is personified, for many American dancegoers, by Vladimir Vasiliev and Yekaterina Maksimova, two of the Bolshoi Ballet's longtime stars. Miss Maksimova is now 50 years old and Mr. Vasiliev is 49. But they still dance with the kind of technique and emotional commitment that made them audience favorites at the company's American debut in 1959, when they were regarded as ''the babies of the Bolshoi.''

title: Talking Deals; Japanese Move Into Stock Swaps
description: STOCK swaps, a technique commonly used for financing acquisitions in the United States, may become more prevalent among Japanese companies as a result of the recent deal by the Kyoto-based Kyocera Corporation to acquire the AVX Corporation, the Great Neck, L.I., manufacturer of electronic capacitors, through an exchange of stock.

title: Bridge
description: Thousands of players converging on Lancaster, Pa., for the Fall Nationals beginning tomorrow will have mixed feelings. Many will be happy that the organizers have succeeded for once in avoiding Thanksgiving, a clash that has kept many away in the past. But many of those from distant areas will lament the choice of a venue far from any major airport.

title: Congress Passes a Bill To Pay U.S. Internees
description: The Senate today completed Congressional action on legislation guaranteeing future restitution for Japanese-Americans interned in World War II.

title: Arrests Unnerve Neighbors of Montana Sect

title: Metro Datelines; Chlorine Fire Routs 300 Jersey Families
description: A chlorine fire yesterday morning forced the evacuation of about 300 families and sent at least five police officers and three firefighters to the hospital to be treated for inhaling fumes, the police said.

description: rrSome hunters still have little faith in the steel-shot loads that are now required for waterfowling throughout most of the nation.

description: LEAD: Pegs have been used to strengthen furniture joints for more than 2,000 years. The practice continued until the middle of the 17th century, when more sophisticated methods of joinery were developed, including the use of glue. Pegs are still used in reproductions.

title: Mesa-Air Midwest

Gary Risley, Mesa's vice president for corporate affairs, said that the companies had decided to end the talks and that Mesa had withdrawn its cash and stock offer for Air Midwest's outstanding shares. Air Midwest's board in June rejected a $31 million buyout offer from Mesa Airlines.

title: Doping Conceded
description: East German officials, acknowledging drugging cases for the first time, said 14 athletes were caught taking banned substances last year, the East Berlin newspaper Junge Welt reported yesterday. The newspaper, official organ of the nation's Communist youth organization, said that starting next year the country would publish the names of athletes who test positive for drugs.

title: Why Giuliani Only Came Close
description: Early in the year, polls showed that the race for mayor of New York City was Rudolph Giuliani's to lose, with the former Federal prosecutor holding convincing leads over Mayor Edward Koch, David Dinkins and the City Council President, Andrew Stein. Yet David Dinkins is headed to Gracie Mansion and Mr. Giuliani is headed, at least temporarily, for private practice.

title: Morocco Trade Deficit
description: Morocco's trade deficit grew more than 60 percent in the first half of this year, according to official figures published today. Officials attributed the increase to costlier oil and wheat imports and the loss of a 500,000-ton phosphoric acid contract with India. The cost of imports soared 16.6 percent for the first six months, to $2.6 billion, while exports fell 4.6 percent, to $1.5 billion. The trade deficit rose to $1.13 billion, compared with $700 million in the first six months of 1988.

title: Bomb in Beirut Kills 4 As New Leader Arrives
description: A car bomb exploded in West Beirut today, killing 4 people and wounding 16, the police said. The bomb went off shortly before the newly elected President, Rene Moawad, arrived in the predominantly Muslim sector of the capital to hold talks on forming a new cabinet, The bomb heavily damaged buildings and shops in a neighborhood a few blocks from the villa where Mr. Moawad is to stay. There was no indication as to whether the bombing was directed at the President-elect, although leaders of a militant Christian faction in Lebanon have opposed his election.
