title: House Passes Amendment on Spill Liability
description: The House of Representatives voted today to preserve the authority of states to determine how much companies must spend to clean up oil spills. The vote, on an amendment offered by several members, set the stage for passage of comprehensive oil spill legislation that has been debated off and on for 14 years.

title: Honesty Tests Given to Job Applicants Aren't Lie-Detector Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Centocor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included about $3.4 million related to services provided for Repligen Corp. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Yusaku Matsuda, 39, Japanese Movie Actor
description: Yusaku Matsuda, an award-winning actor who played a murderer in the film ''Black Rain,'' died of bladder cancer on Monday at a hospital in Tokyo. He was 39 years old and had been hospitalized since Oct. 7.

title: Random House Gets New Chief
description: After almost a week of speculation about who would be chosen to head Random House Inc., the nation's leading publisher of books of general interest. Alberto Vitale was named yesterday as its chairman, president and chief executive.

title: Cornerstone Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits from the repurchase of debentures of $18,000, or 1 cent a share, and $84,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits from the repurchase of debentures of $14,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $146,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months, and 9 months also included a pre-tax loss of $1,079,000 from the sale of securities.

title: Chesapeake Utilities Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Datakey Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $483,000, or 13 cents a share. c-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $339,000, or 10 cents a share, and $889,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

LEAD: Historic Deerfield, a museum comprising a dozen 18th- and 19th-century rural New England homes filled with 20,000 pieces of American decorative art, has received an $8 million bequest from one of its founders. The gift, one of the largest to a museum in the last decade, will almost double Historic

title: Kissinger, in Beijing, Seeks to Mend Fences
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with three Politburo members and China's Foreign Minister in the first of a series of talks that both sides hope will help ease the strains between China and the United States.

title: Review/Music; Hogwood's Academy in All-Beethoven Concert
description: The small pool of crack period-instrument performers in London that Americans keep hearing about has evidently become a sizable lake. For Christopher Hogwood's Beethoven concert with his Academy of Ancient Music on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, the program listed 47 players. Only 11 of them were among the London Classical Players, 65 strong, who performed here recently with Roger Norrington. These are superb ensemble players, and it is wonderful to hear them achieve the same crisp precision in larger bands that characterized their work in the smaller groups deployed for older music.

title: 2 Design Innovations, Forging a New Metal Age in Furniture
description: THEIR backgrounds could not be further apart, and their furniture designs have little in common except for their choice of material: metal. One is a brooding showman whose exuberant overscale pieces reflect his own dense muscularity; the other is a spinner of fables whose fanciful constructions transform metal into a nearly ephemeral material.

title: The Iran-Contra Figures
description: Joseph F. Fernandez: Former C.I.A. station chief in Costa Rica has been charged with lying about his role in helping Oliver L. North establish a network to send supplies to the contras. He faces two counts of obstruction and two counts of making false statements to the agency's inspector general and the Tower commission. His trial was to have begun last July, but it has been delayed because the Justice Department fears that sensitive information would be disclosed. Albert A. Hakim: Iranian-born arms dealer and partner of Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, in a company that helped arrange arms sales to Iran. In March 1988 along with Mr. North, Rear Adm John M. Poindexter, and Mr. Secord, Mr. Akim was indicted on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by illegally providing the contras with funds from weapons sales to Iran. No trial date has been set. Robert C. McFarlane: In March 1988, the former national security adviser to President Reagan pleaded guilty to four misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress about the Reagan Administration's secret efforts to assist the contras. In March 1989 he was fined $20,000 and ordered to serve 200 hours of community service. Oliver L. North: The former Marine lieutenant colonel, who served as a staff member of the National Security Council, was convicted in May on charges of aiding and abetting obstruction of Congress, destruction of National Security Council documents and accepting an illegal gift. He was fined $150,000, given two years of probation and ordered to serve 1,200 hours of community service. He has appealed. John M. Poindexter: President Reagan's national security adviser from December 1985 to November 1986 is accused of five criminal charges, including conspiring to obstruct a Congressional inquiry and making false statements to Congress about the Iran-contra affair. Trial is scheduled to begin Jan. 22. Richard V. Secord: Former Air Force major general organized a clandestine operation that shipped arms to Iran and supplies to the contras. He was indicted with North, Poindexter and Hakim and yesterday he pleaded guilty to one charge of making a false statement to Congress. Sentencing date has not been set.

title: How Many Divisions?
description: While Americans strain to name the forthcoming meeting of the superpower leaders (from the ''Saltwater Summit'' to the ''Seaborne Summit'' to ''the last cruise of the Love Boat''), a summit session of more historic proportions is being ignored: the first meeting of the leader of what used to be called ''godless Communism'' with the Holy Father of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Woolworth Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Cliffs Drilling Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $5,057,000 on the sale of assets acquired from Marlin Drilling Co. in January. The company said share earnings reflect preferred share dividend requirements.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk; A Strict and Efficient Scholar
description: Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati explained how he came to write ''Twelve Tough Issues,'' a book that sets forth Roman Catholic teaching on subjects like abortion, contraception, ordination of women, conscience, capital punishment and warfare - all in 83 pages. ''If what the Catholic

title: Without Braniff, Nebraska City Suffers
description: Of all the cities served by Braniff, this city of 45,000 people in central Nebraska now has a distinction no one wanted.

title: South African Puzzle
description: The South African Government has taken astonishing steps in recent weeks, releasing important political prisoners and allowing them to hold a huge rally under flags of the African National Congress. President F. W. de Klerk has created a widespread impression that he is heading toward negotiations for, as he puts it, ''a new South Africa.''

title: Bel Fuse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included special provision of $983,000 in connection with a possible Federal Income Tax liability. c-Net income

title: Secord Is Guilty Of One Charge In Contra Affair
description: Richard V. Secord, the former Air Force major general who organized the clandestine shipping of arms to Iran and supplies to the Nicaraguan rebels, pleaded guilty today to making a false statement to Congressional investigators in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Central Reserve Life reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BT Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects a reduction of $352,000, or 12 cents a share, from changes in state bank shares tax.

title: Shuttle Launching Is Set
description: NASA on Tuesday set Nov. 20 as the date for the next space shuttle flight, in which a secret military payload is to be launched. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the shuttle Discovery would be launched between 6:30 P.M. and 10:30 P.M. This would be only the third shuttle to be launched at night. Industry analysts believe the Discovery will carry a signal intelligence-gathering spacecraft.

title: North Carolina Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mercury Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: BCE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-earlier figures have been restated to reflect the $206 million refund paid by wholly owned Bell Canada and the adoption of a new accounting method by 49 percent owned Encor Inc. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Almost Lost at the Wire
description: David N. Dinkins nearly lost New York City's mayoral election on Tuesday because wavering Democrats surged to Rudolph W. Giuliani in the volatile closing days of a campaign that revealed deep racial divisions among the voters.

title: Pacificorp Makes Bid for Utility in Arizona
description: Pacificorp, an aggressive utility company based in Portland, Ore., said today that it had offered $1.7 billion in cash to the troubled Pinnacle West Capital Corporation for its Arizona Public Service electric company unit.

title: Bull & Bear Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary credits of $84,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $167,000, or 12 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: New Job for Williams
description: The Bengals' linebacker Reggie Williams, savoring his election Tuesday to the Cincinnati City Council, said yesterday that he was leaving the door open to a full-time career in politics when he retires from the National Football League at the end of the season.

title: Ford Lifts Rebates And Sets Layoffs
description: Responding to increased competition and slower sales, the Ford Motor Company increased buyer incentives on certain car and truck models and plans to lay off up to 350 workers at a truck plant. The company said its 1990 and 1989 models of the Escort would now carry cash rebates of $700, up from $600, while buyers of the 1990 Probe GT will receive $1,000, a $200 increase. Some versions of the 1990 and 1989 Ford Mustang with automatic transmissions have been added, with rebates of $500, and Ford said cash allowances would continue on most other 1990 and 1989 models.

title: New Politburo in East Germany
description: Egon Krenz, 52, Politburo member since 1983, was responsible for security matters until he became General Secretary on Oct. 18. Son of a tailor, he joined the party in 1955 and attended a party school in Moscow between 1964 and 1967. For many years led the Communist youth organization. Retained seat. Hans-Joachim Bohen, 59, party member since 1945, party chief in Halle. Retained seat. Werner Eberlein, 70, party leader in Magdeburg, member of Politburo since 1986. Named on Wednesday to head party's control commission. Retained seat. Wolfgan Herger, 54, Central Committee member since 1976. Security expert expected to become security chief. New member. Werner Jarowinsky, 62, a secretary of the Central Committee and a Politburo member since 1984. Retained seat. Heinz Kessler, 69, army general, Minister of Defense since 1985. Retained seat. Siegfried Lorenz, 59, party leader in Karl-Marx-Stadt, and a Politburo member since 1986. Retained seat. Hans Modrow, 61, party chief in Dresden since 1973 and a leading reformer. Studied in the party school in East Berlin. Became a Central Committee member in 1967. New member. Wolfgang Rauchfuss, 57, an economist who has been a member of the Central Committee since 1967. New member. Gunter Schabowski, 60, East Berlin party chief since 1985 and was the first Politburo member to talk to oppostion leaders. A trained journalist, he is expected to become propaganda chief. A Politburo member since 1984. Retained seat. Gerhard Schurer, 68, in Central Committee since 1963, promoted to full member of Politburo from candidate, or non-voting member. Since 1966, he has led the state planning commission. Candidate, or Non-Voting, Members Johannes Chemnitzer, 60. New member. Inge Lange, 62. Retained seat. Margarete Muller, 58. Retained seat. Gunter Sieber, 59. New member. Werner Walde, 63. Retained seat. Hans-Joachim Willerding, 37. New member.

title: Books of The Times; Before the Fall and Behind the Mythology
description: Nixon The Triumph of a Politician 1962-1972 By Stephen E. Ambrose Illustrated. 736 pages. Simon & Schuster. $24.95. Richard Milhous Nixon The Rise of an American Politician By Roger Morris Illustrated. 1,005 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $29.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have less reason than ever to be resigned to the long-term division of Germany into two states.'' - Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. [ A1:6. ]

title: Mediagenic reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax loss of $2,558,000 from product line restructuring for both periods. c-Net income

title: Code-Alarm Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Offshore Logistics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Greyvest Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RPS Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loan loss reserve of $2,300,000 and extraordinary income of $1,661,757, or 6 cents a share, both of which were recognized in the third quarter.

title: Commodore International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Infant Born to Slain Mother Dies Two Weeks After Attack
description: The infant boy born to a pregnant shooting victim died today, two weeks after his mother was shot to death and his father wounded when they were held up outside a childbirth class.

title: The Endowment vs. the Arts: Anger and Concern
description: Prominent members of the arts community reacted with anger and concern yesterday to the decision by the National Endowment for the Arts to withdraw the agency's sponsorship of an exhibition about AIDS. The criticism came as the agency's new chairman elaborated on why he had withdrawn the endowment's support on the ground that the exhibition was more political than artistic.

title: Diagnostek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the increase in revenues is from HPI Health Care Services which was acquired Aug. 1, the company's hospital pharmacy operation, and increased revenues from HCS, the company's mail service prescription drug division.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Harry Gray to Lead American Medical
description: LEAD: Harry J. Gray, who built United Aircraft into the United Technologies Corporation, the industrial giant, has assumed command of a new empire.

title: Don't Put All Your Nest Eggs in a Federal Basket
description: To the Editor:

title: Crestbrook Forest Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Tokyo Journal; From the U.S. Envoy, Salvos of 'Friendly Advice'
description: Japan and the United States may be engaged in economic warfare, but why do Japanese newspapers always use battlefield imagery to describe their relationship? At least that was what Ambassador Michael H. Armacost wanted to know recently at the Japan National Press Club.

title: Canandaigua Wine Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss and included cumulative effect of adoption of the liability method of accounting for deferred income taxes effective Sept. 1, 1989 for both the quarter and year.

title: Clamor in the East; Electronic Barriers Removed At Hungary Western Border
description: Hungary has completed the dismantling of the electronic barrier along its westernmost border, an official said today.

title: Alco Standard reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $58,000 for the quarter and a gain of $56,742,000, or $1.31 a share for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,256,000, or 6 cents a share, and $10,006,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Hindus Rally at Disputed Shrine in Show of Power
description: Hundreds of thousands of Hindu militants gathered today near a shrine disputed by Hindus and Muslims to assert their growing power.

title: Cooper Tire President Promoted to Top Post
description: The Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, one of two remaining publicly held domestic tire companies, said yesterday that it had named Ivan W. Gorr chairman and chief executive.

title: Palestinian Rock
description: Sabreen, a Palestinian rock group from Jerusalem, is to perform at 7 P.M. on Sunday at the Triplex Theater, 199 Chambers Street. Tickets are $10 and $20; information, 385-4843.

title: Entergy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included writedowns exceeding $1 billion associated with costs and writeoffs of investments on the company's Grand Gulf nuclear generating plant, units 1 and 2. c-Net income

title: Turkish President Sworn In And Appoints a New Premier
description: Turgut Ozal, Prime Minister for the last six years, was sworn in as President today in a Parliament ceremony boycotted by opposition parties. He named Yildirim Akbulut, Speaker of Parliament, as Prime Minister.

title: Review/Art; At the Whitney, 100 Works From the Last 30 Years
description: The question posed by ''Image World: Art and Media Culture'' is why the Whitney Museum of American Art has gone to such lengths to say so little about something so obvious.

title: Lone Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1.1 million for the quarter and $2.8 million for the 9 months. c-Included net from discontinued operations of $1.4 million for the quarter and $1.9 million for the 9 months.

title: Head of Bantam Doubleday To Emphasize Continuity
description: Jack Hoeft, the new president of the Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group, said on Wednesday that he had wished his departing boss, Alberto Vitale, ''good luck, but not too good.''

title: Strathfield Oil & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Preferred-share dividends in both periods amounted to $140,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: East Berliners Explore Land Long Forbidden
description: The 28-year-old Berlin wall opened up Thursday and by midnight thousands of East Berliners - of all ages, from every way of life - were walking, biking and driving to crossing points in the wall and entering the western half of the city, a place they could only gaze at just hours before.

title: In The NATION; An Elusive Dream
description: To a gathering of French and American scholars pondering the questions of human nature and human rights, Prof. Jacques Roger of the University of Paris recently recalled the French biologist Jean Rostand's definition of man: ''the great-grandson of a snail who invented the calculus and dreamed of justice.''

title: A Hapsburg 'Reunion'
description: LEAD: A significant ''reunion'' will take place in Budapest this weekend. The deputy prime ministers and foreign ministers of Austria, Italy, Hungary and Yugoslavia will meet to try to improve common commercial, cultural and other interests. Their countries are four of the heirs of the Hapsburg Empire, whose collapse helped trigger World War I.

title: Bank of Japan In Loan Move
description: The Bank of Japan is likely to start lending funds at the discount rate to foreign commercial banks operating in Japan, probably early in December, the central bank's governor, Satoshi Sumita, said Wednesday.

title: Gas Pipeline Plan
description: The Pacific Gas Transmission Company reached agreement with customers and natural gas producers to build a $1.2 billion pipeline between British Columbia and California. The agreement, filed with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, will speed up the 864-mile project, scheduled to begin in 1993. The company, a subsidiary of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, said the pipeline will carry 755 million cubic feet of natural gas daily.

title: Deaf Player Released
description: The Continental Basketball Association's Albany Patroons have released Willie Brown, sidetracking his attempt to become the first deaf professional basketball player.

title: Treasury Sells $10 Billion of Notes
description: Securities dealers yesterday placed bids on $10 billion worth of new three-year Treasury notes as prices of most notes and bonds ended the day lower in fairly light trading.

title: DENG IS RESIGNING LAST FORMAL POST WITH CHINA PARTY
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, has resigned from his last formal post in the Communist Party leadership, marking another milestone in his 65-year party career.

title: Wang Cuts More Jobs In Major 'Reordering'
description: Declaring that computers no longer represent a boom industry, the president of Wang Laboratories Inc. announced today that his company would undergo a ''fundamental reordering'' and cut 2,000 more workers from its payroll.

title: Maud Russell, 96; Aided Chinese
description: Maud Russell, who spent a quarter of a century in China as a welfare worker and teacher for the Young Women's Christian Association and lobbied for American recognition of the Chinese Communist Government after World War II, died of lung cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96 years old.

title: Washington Talk; Remorseless Dozing Gets Presidential Nod
description: Sometimes, even with all that adrenaline and power pulsating through the White House, you have to close your eyes and grab a few winks. Just for a minute. Just until you catch yourself crashing head-first into the bowl of flowers on the President's coffee table in the Oval Office.

title: Trans World Airlines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The losses in the latest periods reflected increased interest expenses, while the year-ago period reflected a non-recurring gain in 1988 from the Hughes litigation. The latest period results do not include about $98 million in unrealized gains as of Sept. 30, 1989 in T.W.A.'s investment portfolio.

title: Review/Music; Djavan's Brazilian Pop-Jazz
description: Brazil borders on California in the music of Djavan, a leading Brazilian songwriter, who performed last Friday night at the Ritz. Djavan has pitched his recent repertory at the place where jazz-influenced Brazilian pop overlaps jazz-tinged, Brazilian-influenced American pop - the glossy, gently percolating pop-funk that has come out of Los Angeles since the mid-1970's.

title: Topics of The Times; Bushlock in Greenwich
description: President Bush went to Greenwich, Conn., last Sunday to visit his mother. Thousands of people in two states were stopped dead on two highways and several streets to provide for his safety. Is this really necessary? Local police officials, following the Secret Service's instructions, stopped traffic for up to a half-hour on the Hutchinson River and Merritt Parkways, miles from Mr. Bush's destination. Traffic on King Street, which borders Greenwich and Port Chester, N.Y., was stopped too, as it was on several streets feeding into King Street.

title: Equitable Resources Inc. reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $6.7 million as a result of a court decision disallowing deferred gas costs incurred in prior years.

title: The Talk of New Haven; Ex-Athlete Revisits City Hall, but as Mayor
description: Richard Lee remembers the moment well. It was 1954. He was mayor. And one afternoon, a black teen-ager named John Daniels arrived in his office. He was a bright high school football star who had been selected the city's ''Boy of the Year.''

title: Review/Film; Little Bitty Extraterrestrials And Their Jolly Chosen One
description: Whitley Strieber's ''Communion,'' an account of Mr. Strieber's first-hand experiences with extraterrestrials, is probably the only book that concludes with lie-detector test transcripts and a psychiatrist's statement attesting to the author's sanity (''He is not hallucinating in a manner characteristic of psychosis . . . He appears to me to have adapted very well to life at a high level of uncertainty''). This may be a classic case of protesting too much.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY 2 BY 2

title: Bamberger Polymers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Unocal to Close Texas Refinery
description: The Unocal Corporation said it would suspend operations at its refinery here next year because the plant, built in 1924, is no longer profitable. The operation, 45 miles northeast of Houston, has 462 employees, including 337 represented by labor unions, according to a statement from the Los Angeles-based company.

title: Sweden's Loan For Saab-Scania
description: Sweden's Government made a substantial loan to Saab-Scania A.B. to make a new airliner, the Saab 2000 commuter plane. But analysts said the cash advance, for up to 1.2 billion kronor, or $188 million, did not mean the company's troubles were over.

title: Rules Are Eased In Ford Jaguar Bid
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission relaxed certain takeover rules in the Ford Motor Company's $2.5 billion bid for the British luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C. Ford sought exemption from a requirement that shares tendered in a takeover offer be purchased as soon as all bid conditions are met. In Britain, tender offers remain open for 14 days after conditions are fulfilled.

title: Elegy Premiere
description: Paul Zukofsky will conduct the Juilliard Symphony Orchestra in the world premiere of Kenneth Fuchs's ''Reconciliation Elegy,'' a work inspired by a Robert Motherwell painting, at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8. The program also includes Igor Stravinsky's ''Apollon Musagete.'' Admission is free, but tickets are required. Information: 874-7515.

title: 2 Are Indicted in Landfill Case
description: Two New York City men have been indicted on charges that they allowed pollutants to leak from an illegal landfill into the Neversink River, officials said today. The men, Thomas Gambino, 45 years old, and Dominick Dercole, 59, will be arraigned in Sullivan County Court on Nov. 20, the officials said. A county grand jury indicted the two men on counts of illegal discharge of pollutants and failing to cover the dump. The two are free on $2,500 bail. They could be fined up to $50,000 each and jailed up to four years.

title: Review/Art; Portraits That Speak Out For Subjects and Their Time
description: ''Face Off'' at the Edward Thorp Gallery is an amusing and resourceful anthology of what painters have done with, and about, the human face over the last 75 years. The anthology is primarily American in scope, with distinctive examples by painters from Joseph Stella and Alfred Maurer all the way to Fairfield Porter, Alex Katz, Al Leslie and Eric Fischl.

title: Finding a Home With the Raiders
description: Imagine it is 1985. Imagine then that you knew what you know now. You are making the Kansas City Chiefs' first-round draft pick, which happens to be the 15th overall selection. Do you pick Ethan Horton, a North Carolina running back, or, say . . . Jerry Rice, who is still available? Ethan who? ''Oh, yeah, I've heard all the jokes,'' said Ethan Horton, a quiet, unassuming player who exemplifies the Los Angeles Raiders' newfound spirit. ''They've called me a bust, a mistake, all of that stuff. I tell myself I still have a few things to prove. I still have to prove I can play.''

title: Metro Datelines; 4 Youths Indicted In School Shooting
description: Four teen-agers were indicted yesterday for attempted murder in the May 30 shooting of a custodian and a student at East Orange High School.

title: House Adopts Bill on Oil Spills
description: After defeating a tough provision that it had approved only 24 hours earlier, the House of Representatives today passed a liability bill that provides extensive environmental protection in the event of oil spills.

title: Rep. Markey to Press Fight on Index Arbitrage
description: Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, vowed today to press legislation through Congress this year mandating that regulators suspend index arbitrage and possibly other forms of computer-assisted program trading in the stock and options markets at times of volatility.

title: Argentine Composer
description: John Daly Goodwin will conduct the New York Choral Society in music by the Argentine composer Ariel Ramirez at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening at 8. The works on the program include the ''Misa Criolla,'' ''Navidad Nuestra'' and excerpts from the ''Misa por la Paz y la Justicia.'' Mr. Ramirez will also perform in the concert with his Solistas de Argentina ensemble. Tickets are $10 to $30. Information: 247-7800.

title: Hoechst Celanese Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Hoechst Celanese is a subsidiary of Hoechst AG of West Germany.

title: U.S. Catholic Bishops Adopt Stand on Palestinians
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of the United States unanimously approved a major policy statement today, declaring that Palestinians have a right to an independent homeland but adding that it should be balanced against Israel's right to secure borders.

title: Patrick Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $125,000 gain from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Traffic Cases Can End if Police Miss Court
description: Drivers in New York City and parts of western New York can have their traffic tickets dropped if the police officer who wrote them does not show up for court, the State Department of Motor Vehicles said today.

title: For East Germany, Change Points to Survival
description: To the Editor:

title: Rams' Defense Will Be Tested by Giants
description: The Giants are 8-1, tied with the San Francisco 49ers for the best record in the National Football League. They lead their division by two games. In their last three games, all victories, their defense has allowed 13, 14 and 13 points.

title: Cross (A.T.) Co.  (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
At P.S. 262, 2 Principals Now Occupy One Post
description: The new principal reported for duty at Public School 262 in Brooklyn yesterday, but the acting principal he was sent there to replace refused to vacate the principal's office. The acting principal even made the morning announcements on the public address system.

title: Clamor in the East; U.S. Worry Rises Over Europe's Stability
description: President Bush hailed East Germany's opening of its borders today as a ''good development,'' but privately his Administration is growing concerned that the postwar European order is coming apart before any new stable structure has been established.

title: Shiite Says Assets Won't Free U.S. Hostages
description: A senior pro-Iranian religious leader here said today that an American decision to release some frozen Iranian assets would not bring freedom for hostages in Lebanon.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co.'s latest periods were $1.24 for the quarter and $5.84 for the 9 months, compared with $1.56 and $4.71 for the year-ago periods, respectively. The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings for the latest periods were 69 cents for the quarter and $3.25 for the 9 months, compared with 88 cents and $2.63 for the year- ago periods, respectively. Sales represents sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rudolf von Bennigsen, German Executive, 63
description: Rudolf von Bennigsen-Foerder, chairman of the giant West German conglomerate Veba A.G. and one of his country's most prominent executives, died of pneumonia Oct. 28 in Dusseldorf, West Germany.

title: Universal Foods Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
For Knicks, Boos Turn Into Cheers
description: The Knicks rallied from a 16-point halftime deficit and defeated the Nets, 107-105, last night in a game in which they took their first lead on a dunk shot by Patrick Ewing with 1 minute 23 seconds remaining.

title: Irate Koch Jabs At State Threat To Shut Landfill
description: Vowing to fight any effort by New York State to close the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday denounced the state's environmental chief as the ''Colossus in Albany,'' a ''hanging judge'' and ''zealot'' whose tactics were ''insane'' and ''most vicious.''

title: Denver Bans Assault Weapons
description: The City Council voted 9 to 4 on Tuesday to ban semiautomatic assault weapons. The legislation is to take effect as soon as it is signed by Mayor Federico Pena and then published, probably next week. Residents who already own assault weapons will be able to keep them but will be required to register them within 60 days.

title: House Backs $305 Billion Military Bill
description: The House approved a $305 billion military programs bill today, but many members complained that Congress had failed to make tough decisions on cutting politically popular weapons programs.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''PLAY BALL, AMELIA BEDELIA AND OTHER STORIES,'' a musical revue of children's stories, presented by Maximillion Productions, 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $8, $12. Information: 415-5450. ''SOUVENIRS OF OLD NEW YORK,'' six actors and singers portraying moments in the lives of famous New Yorkers, 2 P.M. Sundays, through Nov. 26, at the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: students and the elderly, $6; others, $8. Information: 769-4143. ''MEET THE MAESTRO,'' a Lolli-Pops Concert for ages 3 to 5, 10:15 and 11:30 A.M. tomorrow, and 1:15 and 2:30 P.M. Sunday, by the Little Orchestra Society, at Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street. Tickets: $25. Reservations: 704-2100. ''NORTHERN LIGHTS,'' a puppet show by Ron Soplya, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''FOOTPRINTS ON THE MOON,'' a musical celebrating the 20th anniversary of man's first steps on the moon, presented by Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. tomorrow and 10:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $12 and $15. Reservations: 677-5959. ''GOLDILOCKS AND THE THREE BEARS,'' a play by the Little People's Theater Company, directed by Robert Stark, 1:30 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, and ''The Three Little Pigs,'' 3 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: 765-9540. ''THE EARLY SHOW,'' a cabaret for children by children, with singing, dancing and other entertainment, with brunch at noon and a show at 1 P.M. every Saturday, at Steve McGraw's, 158 West 72d Street. Cover charge, $6; $6 minimum. Information: 595-7400. ''PETER PAN MEETS THE WICKED WIZARD,'' a program of music and comedy by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1 P.M. Sunday, and ''Rumpelstiltskin,'' at 2:30 P.M., at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Admission: $4.50. Information: 772-9180. ''THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES,'' an opera by Judy Spencer, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays through Nov. 18, at Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: $6. Information: 666-1716. ''ROCKET AND FRIENDS,'' a show by the Puppet Company, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays through Nov. 12, at 31 Union Square West, Loft 2B. Tickets: $5. Reservations required: 741-1646.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can't believe I'm here. This is what we have dreamed of all these years.'' - An elderly East Berliner as he crossed into the west. [ A1:4. ]

title: Militant Muslims Gain in Jordan Voting
description: Muslim fundamentalists have registered unexpected and sweeping parliamentary gains in Jordan's first general elections in 22 years, unofficial results showed today. The victory brought consternation to Government officials alarmed by the display of Islamic fervor.

title: NBC to Pay N.B.A. $600 Million For TV Rights
description: NBC announced yesterday that it would pay the National Basketball Association $600 million for the right to broadcast professional basketball games in the United States for four years, starting in the 1990-91 season.

title: Dekalb Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $173,000 for the quarter and income of $16,416,000, or $1.57 a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $438,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $3,464,000 for the 9 months, both primarily from extinguishment of debt.

title: Clamor in the East; MOSCOW PRAISES GERMAN CHANGES
description: The Soviet Union today praised the sweeping changes affecting the Communist Party in East Germany and reiterated Moscow's intention to let its ally run its affairs ''on its own terms.''

title: Opposition to Charter Change Diverse
description: All spring and summer, the Charter Revision Commission struggled to build a consensus among New Yorkers for its vision of a new city government. The voters approved the commission's plan on Tuesday, but by a relatively small margin, demonstrating that the dissension that plagued the panel for the last seven months still simmered on Election Day.

title: McElligott To Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo named Tom McElligott executive creative director yesterday, confirming rumors that the creative star would join the agency. Mr. McElligott, a founder of Fallon McElligott, the acclaimed Minneapolis agency, will oversee Chiat/Day's creative efforts in New York, Toronto and London.

title: How Small Firms Compete Amid Merging Giants
description: In the increasingly competitive world of law firms, growing numbers of small and mid-size firms are forming loose networks to compete with the big firms created by mergers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, the parent of American Airlines, named James O. Singer president of its AMR Services Corp. unit.

title: Behind Rockefeller Center's Allure
description: Rockefeller Center is more than half a century old but office space there is still very hard to get and it rents for as much as that in brand new buildings just around the corner. And the sale last week of a controlling interest to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan suggests that Rockefeller Center will continue to be a very good business.

title: BMA Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 9 months results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Historians Carrying More Weight in Court
description: When law firms need historical research for a trial, they usually call on their paralegals. But a growing number are turning to historians for both evidence and testimony because of their special qualifications.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong, said it would purchase two 747-400 freighters from Boeing Co., Seattle, and that it had secured options for two additional 747-400's. The contract for the firm orders is $285 million.

title: Nordiques End Slide While Islanders Sink
description: In a sloppy but exciting game filled with poor checking, uncertain puck-handling, inconsistent goaltending, mental mistakes and lots of shots, the Quebec Nordiques beat the Islanders, 7-5, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Jet Plows Into Apartments in Georgia
description: A Navy fighter jet preparing to land at Dobbins Air Force Base here plummeted into an apartment complex and burst into flames tonight, injuring at least four people.

title: Stolen Picasso Artworks Recovered
description: Investigators have recovered the $17 million in artworks stolen from the granddaughter of the artist Pablo Picasso. The works were found today at the home of a restaurateur, who was then arrested, the police said.

title: New Orleans Bears Brunt of Flooding in the South
description: A few years ago, musing about their dream house, Scott and Carol McPherson wished for a place either on a golf course or on the ocean. They chose the golf course.

title: Kansas City Power & Light reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Member of the Medellin Ring Gets Prison Term of 15 Years
description: Five years after he was convicted here in absentia, a member of the Medellin cocaine trafficking ring who was extradited from Colombia last month was sentenced by a Federal court Tuesday to 15 years in prison and a $25,000 fine.

title: Setback for Yonkers
description: More than anything, the city of Yonkers, N.Y., needs to put a divisive housing desegregation controversy behind it and deal with pressing issues of economic development, crime and drugs. Yet on Tuesday, the city's voters elected a new Mayor and City Council that are likely to continue the housing distraction. That creates a new challenge for outside officials like Gov. Mario Cuomo and the Westchester County Executive, Andrew O'Rourke.

title: USG Names Top Officers
description: The USG Corporation said today that it had promoted Eugene B. Connolly to president and chief executive.

title: Amgen to Give Drug to Needy
description: Amgen Inc. said this week that it would give free supplies of genetically engineered erythropoietin to several thousand kidney dialysis patients who do not have Government or private health insurance.

title: Topics of The Times; The Answerers
description: The New York Public Library has just published an imposing 836-page Desk Reference of miscellany that someone somewhere wants to know. Based on the four million questions people ask the library's researchers each year, the work is a cross between an almanac and an encyclopedia, and then some.

title: Economic Scene; Budget Woe Goes Beyond Gimmicks
description: AS Washington's current battle of the budget demonstrates, more than a month into the new fiscal year, the effort to stay under the Gramm-Rudman deficit ceiling has worsened public confusion and increased the use of budget gimmicks. For instance, Government payments are shifted to a different fiscal year or goods are paid for not in cash but through certificates or by pushing outlays ''off budget.''

title: Finishing Touches: Williams College Aims at History
description: Excitement pervaded the air Wednesday at the weekly luncheon of the Sideline Quarterbacks Club at The Log tap room on Spring Street.

title: Andrew E. Ullmann, Lawyer, Is Dead at 63
description: Andrew E. Ullmann, a lawyer and retired chairman of the Stony Brook Council, a policy-making body of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, died of cancer Tuesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Curb on '900' Calls Offered in Connecticut
description: State utility regulators today approved a plan by the Southern New England Telephone Company to put devices on phones to block expensive calls by children to so-called 900 numbers.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Because of Veterans Day tomorrow, New York City municipal offices will be closed today, as will state offices in New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Farres P. Mattar, Physicist, 41
description: Dr. Farres P. Mattar, a senior research physicist at New York University, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: East Germany's Great Awakening
description: Physically, the Berlin wall still stands. But its capacity to divide a country and a Continent seems at an end. East Germany's hastily reshaped politburo now promises its people what even two weeks ago was still unthinkable: unrestricted travel to the West; free elections; market-oriented economic reforms. Deathbed conversions are always suspect. But what Marxists call objective realities suggest this great awakening will endure.

title: Invacare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Many Voices of New Music America '89
description: It spreads across New York City like an invading army. Shock troops take strategic points - the Knitting Factory, Performance Space 122, the Kitchen, the World, the Brooklyn Academy of Music - and settle in. And for the next 16 days, music lovers, experimentalists and insomniacs can rejoice: New Music America '89, which is taking over 23 spaces for 120 shows, turns off for about 10 hours a night, just enough time to read the paper, pay a few bills and grab something to eat. This weekend, the festival begins with an extraordinary selection that attempts to redefine new music as anything standing outside the mainstream, with a special attempt to include minorities and women.

title: Bucks Defeat SuperSonics In 5 Overtimes
description: Tony Brown's 3-point shot with 1 minute 10 seconds left in the fifth overtime tonight put Milwaukee ahead for good as the Bucks defeated the Seattle SuperSonics, 155-154, in the longest game since the National Basketball Association adopted the 24-second clock 35 years ago.

title: Screening Out Incompetent Envoys
description: Diplomacy is too important to become the exclusive preserve of Foreign Service officers, and far too important and complicated to be turned over increasingly to inexperienced political appointees.

title: Clamor in the East; The Twain Meet: Unease for Bonn
description: Hours before a high East German Communist Party official declared today that East Germany's borders would be opened to any citizen who wanted to leave, the West German Interior Minister, Dr. Wolfgang Schauble, appealed to Germans on the other side to ''think twice'' before they headed West.

title: Limited Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Heck's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months reflected two items relating to the company's reorganization proceedings: a charge for professional fees of approximately $700,000 before taxes, and a charge resulting from an adjustment of about $1.1 million, before taxes, to the store closing provision. Year-ago second quarter included a pre-tax credit of $2.6 million from adjustments to the provision for store closings. Year-ago 6 months' loss included $10.3 million, before taxes, which was attributable to the provision for store closings. Latest financial statements have been adjusted to reflect the changes resulting from the reorganization proceedings, including debt forgiveness of about $84 million. Certain adjustments have been made to prior quarters for reclassifiations of store closing expenses and other items. Heck's emerged from bankruptcy proceedings on Sept. 28.

title: INSIDE
description: Signs of Subdued Inflation

title: Corrections
description: A table yesterday listing election results in New York and New Jersey misstated the vote received by Sal F. Albanese, the Democrat-Independent Vote candidate for City Council in the 31st District in Brooklyn. He won with 26,147 votes.

title: Chip Measure Up in October
description: The chip industry's leading indicator moved up slightly in October, as United States semiconductor shipments declined but orders increased, a trade group reported this week. The Semiconductor Industry

title: Joseph Venditto, Deputy Fire Chief, 52
description: Joseph Venditto, deputy chief of the New York City Fire Department, died of cancer yesterday at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 52 years old and lived in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

title: Judge Accepts Insanity Plea In '88 Drowning of Infant
description: As some spectators in the courtroom wept, a distraught Brooklyn mother told a judge yesterday how she drowned her colicky infant son in a bathtub while she was suffering from severe postpartum depression.

title: Baldwin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest shares outstanding included 980,844 common stock equivalents available upon the exercise of stock options and other operating incentives. Share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 15.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Carroll Returns

title: Producer Prices Post 0.4% Gain
description: Further evidence of subdued inflation emerged today as the Government reported a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent rise in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods in October and no increase at all for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production.

title: Lancaster Colony Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dataproducts' Response to Offer
description: The Dataproducts Corporation said it would not oppose an unsolicited $10-a-share tender by the DPC Acquisition Corporation if DPC can obtain financing. But the chairman of Dataproducts, Jack C. Davis, said DPC has not yet begun discussions with financing sources and he therefore urged shareholders to reject DPC's offer. ''If DPC can obtain the financing for its offer, the board will not stand in its way,'' Mr. Davis said.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misstated the day on which Paine Webber Inc. used computerized trading programs to buy a large amount of stock. It was Oct. 24.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-19 East Germany ended limits on travel and emigration yesterday, and thousands of East Germans swarmed across the Berlin wall in a mass celebration of freedom. Page A1 East Berliners of all ages, and from every way of life, walked, biked and drove to crossing points in the wall last night, entering the western half of the city that they could previously only gaze at. A1 Wall's symbolic importance is starting to crumble A15 A chronology of the upheaval A16 Chancellor Kohl might end his visit to Poland to return to West Germany to deal with the ''dramatic situation'' after the opening of East Germany's borders. A1 News analysis: As West Germany worries about how to assimiliate its new citizens, it is seeking a policy that promotes change in East Germany but doesn't alarm allies worried about a reunited Germany. A16 U.S. worry rises over Europe's stability A16 Moscow praises German changes A16 Deng Xiaoping has resigned from his last formal post in the Communist Party leadership. Jiang Zemin, Mr. Deng's intended heir as China's paramount leader, was named the head of the military. A1 India's low castes turn the tables A12 President Aquino seeks aid from U.S. business A3 In Jordan's first election in 22 years, Muslim fundamentalists have registered unexpected gains. Government officials are alarmed by the display of Islamic fervor. A3 Palestinians deserve a homeland, Catholic bishops say A6 Columbia's war on drugs has turned into a chase for two men regarded as the most powerful and violent leaders of South America's illegal drug operations. A10 TV host's presidential bid in Brazil is rejected A7 Contras reject new Nicaragua truce offer A19 Labor in Uruguay set for a battle A5 British nuclear plants cannot be sold, Government decides D1 U.S. says lasers strike its planes A17 Nominee as envoy meets Senate roadblock A8 National A20-29 Republicans who are worried that abortion issue may hamper some candidates say the party should give more ''running room'' to those who favor abortion rights. A1 Wilder is big winner in the old neighborhood A24 Alzheimer's may be more common than previously estimated, particularly in the very old, according to a new study. A1 A reference to evolution as a ''scientific fact'' will be removed from new textbooks in California, the State Education Board decided. This concession to religious fundamentalists could affect the teaching of science nationwide. A1 The Producer Price Index rose modestly in October, the Government reported, providing further evidence of subdued inflation. D1 A new type of anwering service is being offered by telephone companies. The service allows a caller to leave a message if the number dialed is not answered, or if the line is busy. D1 A National Archive pact with a cigarette producer that allows the company to use the Archives' name has set off a dispute over how far Federal agencies may go to supplement their budgets. A20 Military bases in Colorado and across the country are being scoured by the Administration as sites to temporarily store radioactive waste. A27 House backs $305 billion military bill A22 Ex-aide is outraged by a Justice Dept. ''misconduct'' report A29 H.U.D. suspending business ties with ex-Reagan aid A23 Washington Talk: Top officials need their rest too, and some, like Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, will nap almost anywhere, including the White House. A22 A Navy fighter jet preparing to land at an Air Force base near Atlanta plummeted into a crowded apartment complex and burst into flames, injuring at least four people. A20 Heavy rains cause flooding in south A26 Freeway that failed faces ''slow-motion'' quake A25 Regional B1-4 A Connecticut lawyers' association has filed a suit charging that the state police illegally recorded telephone calls between lawyers and their clients for nine years. B1 In New Haven, ex-athlete revisits City Hall as Mayor B1 Mayor-elect David Dinkins traveled to Washington and joined Democratic leaders there in proclaiming that his victory was a sign of the party's renewed strength. B1 News analysis: The charter plan was approved by only a slim margin, a reflection of its large, diverse opposition that included political figures, evironmentalists and some minority civic groups. B3 A Brooklyn elementary school in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section is at the center of an ongoing battle for control that has involved school administrators, parents and local residents. B1 Cuomo attacks U.S. efforts to block deal on Shoreham B2 Officers cleared in drowning of suspect B2 Koch jabs at state threat to shut landfill B3 Judge accepts insanity plea in drowning of infant B3 ''Pretty party'' makes lions of the grubby B2 Park attack witness arrested in robbery attempt B4

title: Miami Bank, Prodded by State, Says It Has Sold Its Art
description: In response to legal action taken by Florida bank regulators, the Centrust Savings Bank, a Miami savings and loan institution, announced yesterday that it had sold ''substantially all'' of a collection of Old Master paintings and sculptures that the regulators had cited as a ''nonearning asset'' and ''speculative.''

title: Restaurants
description: Chelsea Central

title: Wary of the 'Dramatic Situation,' Kohl May Curtail Visit to Poland
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl left open the possibility tonight that he might break off a visit to Poland to return to West Germany and deal with what he described as a ''dramatic situation'' after East Germany's decision to open its borders with the West.

title: Review/Film; Making The Best Of Being Terminal
description: Bancroft (Timothy Dalton), the terminally ill lawyer who is the hero of ''Hawks,'' regards his own mortality as a bad joke and is determined to respond in kind. Decker (Anthony Edwards), the terminally ill American football player who winds up as Bancroft's roommate in an English hospital, becomes the lawyer's willing protege. Together, they embark on a series of rebellious escapades tailored to Bancroft's unusual wit.

title: Lawyers Who Bear Risks of Loss Earn Their Contingency Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Arkla Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $656,000 and $2,088,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income The company said the latest third quarter and 9 months losses reflected the previously reported $179 million after-tax writedown taken in connection with its restructuring plan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY Producer prices rose 0.4 percent in October and there was no increase for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production. The index rose a bit more than expected, but most analysts considered the overall report encouraging. [ Page D1. ] Donald T. Regan said he met with Charles H. Keating Jr., the savings executive, when Mr. Regan was White House chief of staff to talk about Mr. Keating's desire to get his friend Lee Henkel Jr. nominated to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Telephone companies have begun to offer a service that takes the place of a telephone answering machine. The service allows a caller to leave messages if the number dialed is not answered, or if the line is busy. [ D1. ] A law passed half a century ago to protect consumers and investors from utility company fraud is hurting consumers by barring big companies from the emerging business of competitive power generation, electric company officials said. [ D1. ] NBC will pay the National Basketball Association $600 million for the right to broadcast professional basketball games in the U.S. for four years, starting in the 1990-91 season. [ D17. ] Borden plans to spend $650 million during the next two years to expand and modernize plants around the world. [ D4. ] Wang Laboratories will undergo a ''fundamental reordering'' and cut 2,000 more workers from its payroll. [ D4. ] Philip Morris sold its 29 percent stake in Rothmans International for $860 million. [ D4. ] Centrust Savings Bank has sold ''substantially all'' of a collection of Old Master paintings and sculptures that Florida bank regulators had called ''nonearning assets'' and ''speculative.'' [ D17. ] INTERNATIONAL British nuclear plants will not be included in the planned sale of the power industry, the Government decided. The move was another blow to the Thatcher privatization program. [ D1. ] A new bilateral trade pact is being worked on by American and Soviet officials. Such an agreement could end a half century of trade discrimination but also set a framework for expanded investment and technology transfers. [ D2. ] Moody's Investors Service downgraded China's long-term credit rating. [ D2. ] MARKETS Representative Markey has vowed to press legislation through Congress that mandates that regulators suspend index arbitrage in the stock and options markets at times of volatility. [ D6. ] Stock prices declined and trading volume fell. The Dow dropped 19.67 points, to end the day at 2,603.69. [ D6. ] Securities dealers placed bids on $10 billion worth of new three-year Treasury notes. [ D12. ] Even though prices of ''junk bonds'' rose for the fourth day in a row, underwriters of high-yield bonds said the improvement was not great enough to reschedule postponed bond offerings. [ D7. ] The dollar rose against most major currencies except the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar. [ D13. ] Copper prices surged on the New York Commodity Exchange amid investor concerns about labor conditions in Chile. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Eliminating budget gimmickry is only the beginning of what needs to be done to clean up the Federal budget process. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The Japanese stock market has been a laggard this year, a sharp reversal from the leading role it played for much of the 1980's. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] Time magazine has a new slogan that uses its name twice: ''Make time for Time.'' Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D5. ]

title: Beatles and Record Label Reach Pact and End Suit
description: The Beatles and their record label, EMI-Capitol, have reached an agreement that is to end 10 years of legal wrangling between the group and EMI Music Worldwide. The agreement was reached out of court, and one provision is that neither side can discuss the terms publicly. The settlement clears the way for the release of some previously unissued Beatles recordings and videotapes.

title: Chemical Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit from tax loss carryforward of $112,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Cogeco Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $471,000 for the latest year and $273,000 for the year-earlier period. Year-earlier earnings have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sutton Holding Bids for DeSoto
description: DeSoto Inc., a paint company based in Des Plaines, Ill., received a takeover offer of $50 a share in cash from the Sutton Holding Corporation, a New York concern owned by investors and led by William Spier and Michael Zurawin. Sutton, which said it would begin a tender offer within five business days, already owns about 14.6 percent of DeSoto.

title: LABOR IN URUGUAY SET FOR A BATTLE
description: The Communist leadership of the Uruguayan labor movement is preparing for a showdown with the country's mainstream political leaders over whether to espouse a more market-oriented economy with foreign investment.

title: Court Nominee Questioned on Exclusive Club
description: A hearing held today on the nomination of a San Francisco lawyer for a Federal judgeship became a forum on whether membership in clubs that have excluded blacks and women should disqualify a nominee for the bench.

title: KEY RATES
Our Towns; Birds in Danger: When Man Preys On the Predators
description: Dr. Alan Peterson held the hooded bird, a struggling osprey, on the radiology table while a technician clicked off the X-rays. They were completed and developed within minutes.

title: Trade Officials to Meet On U.S.-Soviet Accord
description: Top commercial officials of the United States and the Soviet Union will meet next week in Washington to begin work on a new trade pact, Administration officials said today. It is to be similar to an agreement nullified by Moscow in 1975, after Congress demanded freer Soviet emigration.

title: More Afflicted With Alzheimer's Than Was Thought, Study Finds
description: Alzheimer's disease, the dementia that robs the elderly of their memory and self-reliance, may be much more common than previously estimated, particularly in the very old, according to a new study by Harvard Medical School researchers.

title: An Unmarried Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Nonprofit Gallery in TriBeCa Finds Itself at Storm's Center
description: While two young men quietly spackled and whitewashed the walls at Artists Space for an exhibition about AIDS that is to open on Thursday, Susan Wyatt, the director of the nonprofit gallery in TriBeCa, frantically fielded phone calls yesterday and tried to cope with an onslaught of attention.

title: What, Where And How Much
description: ''Modernism'' can been seen at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. today and tomorrow and 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $10; children under 16 years of age accompanied by an adult are admitted free. Information: 535-9707. Here is a list of the objects and works mentioned in the accompanying article and their prices. INGLETT-WATSON: 1941 Continental Coupe redesigned by Raymond Loewy, $250,000. LUNN LTD.: desk and four chairs by Frank Lloyd Wright, 1955, $35,000. FIFTY-50: Price Tower chair by Frank Lloyd Wright, $35,000; Venetian glass vases, $450-$12,000; Berndt Friberg ceramics, $500-$2,000. KURLAND-ZABAR: George Hunsinger rocking chair, 1878, $3,500; Marcel Breuer chaise longue, 1936-37, $25,000. MARGOT JOHNSON GALLERY: Renaissance Revivial cabinet, no price available. BARRY FRIEDMAN LTD.: Gerrit Rietveld chair, $25,000; Rene Herbst aluminum desk, $55,000; Suprematist painting by Anna Kogan, $115,000. ARK ANTIQUES: Maria Zimmermann candelabra, $28,000. SILBER-KELLER: Austrian silver candelabra, $50,000. GALLERY VIENNA: Two August Angethum sideboards, $55,000 for the pair. D. J.'s - THE ARTS AND CRAFTS SHOP OF THE WEST COAST: Green & Green fireside table and three chairs, $245,000; Green & Green lamp, $250,000; Gustav Stickley bedroom bureau, $12,500. MAISON GERARD: Eric Baggue bedroom set, $38,000; Pico Neptune mural, $48,000. GALERIE MODERNE LTD.: Rene Lalique vases, 1900-30, $1,000-$75,000. MURIEL KARASIK GALLERY: Venetian glass vases, $1,000-$5,000; Venetian glass bead jewelry, $800-$2,000. HISTORICAL DESIGN COLLECTION: 1947 painting by George Wettlings, $28,000. JANET MARQUSEE FINE ARTS: Late 20's watercolors by Donald Deskey, $5,000-$5,500. KELMSCOTT GALLERY: Balustrade from Louis Sullivan's Stock Exchange, $24,000; Frank Lloyd Wright architectural drawings, $24,000; Aalto desk, $4,500. ROGER R. RICCO/FRANK MARESCA: Hollow copper columns, $16,000 for a set of four; iron gate, $18,000; Chicago Prairie School windows, $12,500 for the pair; weathervane, $38,000.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Urge Softer Line About Abortion
description: Stung by election losses on Tuesday and hoping to defuse the abortion issue in the 1990 campaign, Republican officials said today that the party must be more tolerant of Republican candidates who back abortion rights.

title: Gap Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
To Punch Is Not Quite To Kiss
description: One night recently this reporter was watching an evening newscast when the sports came on with, of course, its routine footage of hockey players trying to simulate a car crash. Some local sportscasters believe that unless they show a hockey fight on television every night, people won't be able to fall asleep.

title: Agency Is Assailed on Deal With a Cigarette Company
description: An agreement by the National Archives to accept money from a cigarette manufacturer and allow the Archives' name to be used in an advertising campaign has set off a dispute over how far Federal agencies may go in efforts to supplement their budgets.

title: Tough Draw for Sabatini In Virginia Slims Tourney
description: Gabriela Sabatini, the defending champion of the $1 million Virginia Slims championships, did herself few favors yesterday as she helped unveil the draw for this year's tournament, the finale on the women's calendar.

title: British Banks Lift Reserves
description: Two major British banks put aside money yesterday to protect them against bad third world loans, together adding more than $2 billion to their reserves following similar moves by United States and Canadian banks.

title: Don't Be Fooled; Expect a Shootout
description: No matter which runner is hot, Jets-Dolphins affairs turn into shootouts that send scorekeepers searching the record books. The page-turning could continue Sunday when the clubs meet at Giants Stadium.

title: Senator Moves to Block Approval Of Fund-Raiser Chosen as Envoy
description: President Bush's nomination for Ambassador to Barbados was thrown into jeopardy today when Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat, charged that she had been chosen for the job solely because of her substantial financial contributions to the Republican Party in the Presidential campaign last year.

title: Blue Arrow Fraud Charges
description: The police today charged 10 individuals and their employers in connection with irregularities in a 1987 sale of $1.3 billion worth of stock of Blue Arrow P.L.C.

title: Times Mirror Campaign
description: Times Mirror Magazines, the publisher of Field & Stream, Outdoor Life, Popular Science and five other magazines aimed at men, takes to the trades on Monday for the start of its first national corporate advertising campaign. The $1 million campaign, created by FCB/Leber Katz Partners, promotes the company's group advertising plans enabling marketers to purchase ads at discounted rates in four or more of the publications.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: About Real Estate; Central Park West Gets Luxury Condominiums
description: Even though the construction of super-luxury condominums has been growing at a rapid clip in Manhattan over the last few years, Central Park West has been glaringly absent from this flurry of activity - despite its obviously appeal to affluent buyers -because virtually no sites have been available for redevelopment.

title: Knicks Legends Game
description: A team of former Knick players, led by Walt Frazier, will oppose a team of former National Basketball Association players in the first Knicks Legends Game on Nov.21 at Madison Square Garden. The game, at 6:45 P.M., will precede the Knicks-Houston Rockets contest.

title: Sweeney Scores 3 Goals As Bruins Rout Oilers, 6-2
description: Bob Sweeney had the first three-goal game of his National Hockey League career and Ken Linseman scored in his first game back from injury as the Boston Bruins beat the Edmonton Oilers, 6-2, tonight.

title: Review/Film; Family Portrait From Small Town, U.S.A.
description: Lee Grant's ''Staying Together'' is the kind of small-town comedy-drama that gives middle-class Middle Americans exactly the sort of idealized picture of themselves that many would like to believe is true. It's about the loving marriage of Eileen (Melinda Dillon) and Jake McDermott (Jim Haynie), their three almost-grown sons, and the big and little problems with which they all cope to become better, more feelingful members of a society that never seems entirely plausible.

title: A Self-Doubting Monster Fights the Forces of Evil
description: In ''The Toxic Avenger Part III: The Last Temptation of Toxie,'' the newest installment in what its producers now call the ''Toxic Ring,'' the mutated title character is full of self-doubts. ''I was 25,'' he says on the sound track, ''but who was I? What was I?''

title: Aon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
India Election Panel Decides Against a Computerized Vote
description: The Indian Election Commission decided Wednesday that it would not introduce computerized voting in the national elections to be held from Nov. 22 to 26.

title: Brown Retains Title With Defeat of Santana
description: Simon Brown retained his International Boxing Federation welterweight title tonight when he battered Luis Santana to win a 12-round unanimous decision.

title: Review/Photograpy; Witness to History
description: IT is no exaggeration to say that photojournalists have shaped our view of the 20th century. Rendering the world of public events and private suffering with an unstable mix of reportage and artistic motives, they provide the front-line fodder of history.

title: Wilder Is a Big Winner In the Old Neighborhood
description: A lot of things are still unclear about what happened in Virginia's nip-and-tuck gubernatorial election on Tuesday, not the least being whether Lieut. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's slim, unofficial lead will hold up and put him into the Governor's Mansion come January.

title: Colombia Turns Drug War Into a Long Chase
description: The Colombian Government's war on drugs has essentially turned into a chase for Pablo Escobar Gaviria and Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, regarded as the two most powerful and violent leaders of South America's illegal drug operations.

title: Sizeler Property Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Prairie Oil Royalties reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Text of the Announcement
description: Following is the text of East Germany's announcement today on allowing its citizens to travel abroad or emigrate, as translated by Reuters:

title: Costco Wholesale reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,856,000, or 11 cents a share, which included gains of $1,160,000 from retirement of subordinated debentures and $1,696,000 from utilization of a net operating loss carryforward. The company said the change in inventory accounting methods, from FIFO to LIFO, effected in the latest year reduced net income $3.4 million, or 10 cents a share. Latest quarter results included a $1.9 million pretax LIFO charge and a $1.5 million provision to cover expenses related to the closing of three warehouses in May 1988. On an after- tax basis, these two charges reduced fourth quarter net income by $2.2 million, or 7 cents a share.

description: Madeline's

title: Indictment in Killing Of a Cornell Student
description: A suspended Ithaca College student has been indicted in the death of a Cornell University student after a fight.

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Refuses to End Suit Against Killer's Parents
description: A judge has ruled that the victims of a woman who shot six students at an elementary school last year can go forward with their lawsuit against her parents because they may be partly responsible for her violence.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Surrenders In 9-Year-Old Slaying
description: Overcome by remorse and saying he was ''trying to get his life together,'' a Queens man surrendered to the police Wednesday, telling them that he fatally stabbed a woman nine years ago in a robbery, the police said yesterday.

title: Telephone Companies' New Foray
description: Telephone companies have begun to offer customers a service that takes the place of a telephone answering machine.

description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $5,712,000, or 23 cents a share. c-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $3,242,000, or 14 cents a share, and $7,189,000, or 30 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: b-Included after-tax gain of $2,465,000, or 26 cents a share, on the sale of Tokyo property partially offset by provisions for non-recurring expenses.

title: Arthur Holland Mayor of Trenton For 26 Years, Dies of Cancer at 71
description: Arthur J. Holland, the Mayor of Trenton for 26 years and a former president of the United States Conference of Mayors, died of cancer yesterday at the St. Francis Medical Center in Trenton. He was 71 years old.

title: An American Story
description: On the day New Yorkers chose a black Mayor and Virginians a black Governor, white and black citizens of Charleston were also asked to show their belief in a common bond.

title: China's Credit Rating Downgraded by Moody's
description: Signaling uncertainty about China's political stability, Moody's Investors Service Inc. today downgraded the country's long-term credit rating.

title: Dynascan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax accruals of $400,000 and $800,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for Dynascan Audio Group's move to Chicago.

title: AIDS Panel Urges Support of Bleach Study
description: The National Commission on AIDS has asked Congress to reverse its opposition to Federal financing of studies on whether giving drug addicts household bleach helps control the spread of AIDS.

title: Carmike Cinemas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Freeway That Failed Faces 'Slow-Motion' Quake
description: Engineers of the University of California at Berkeley will use hydraulic jacks and other heavy equipment later this month to rock the Nimitz Freeway slowly back and forth as they try to determine why it collapsed in the earthquake.

title: Walshire Assurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share net for all periods adjusted to reflect a 10-percent stock dividend paid Oct. 30.

title: Cyclone Kills 50 in India
description: A cyclone churned across the coastal areas of south India today, killing at least 50 people and sweeping away crops, power lines and mud-and-straw houses, news reports said.

title: H.U.D. Suspending Business Ties With Ex-Election Aide to Reagan
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has barred the chief lawyer for Ronald Reagan's 1984 Presidential campaign from doing business with the department in eight Southern states because of allegations of ''irregularities'' in a federally assisted housing project in Georgia.

title: Salant Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Park Attack Witness Arrested in Robbery Attempt
description: Jermain Robinson, the 15-year-old who pleaded guilty in the rampage in Central Park last April and who has agreed to be a witness against the other suspects, has been arrested in connection with an attempted armed robbery of an East Harlem bakery, the police said yesterday.

title: Cipher Data Products reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest first quarter results included $3,803,000, or 26 cents a share, in restructuring reserves.

title: Coeur D'Alene Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Junk Bond' Rally Continues But New Issues Are Lacking
description: Prices of ''junk bonds'' rose again yesterday, and even though the market's rally entered its fourth day, underwriters of high-yield bonds said the improvement was not great enough to reschedule the bond offerings that were postponed last month.

title: Officers Cleared in Drowning of Suspect in Bronx
description: An investigation into the drowning of a suspect in the Bronx River 19 months ago has found that despite comments like ''Drown him'' and ''Let him die'' that were broadcast over a police radio frequency, officers made a ''good-faith and intensive'' effort to rescue the man.

title: Devon Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income and included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $3.9 million, or 61 cents a share.
