description: 'A Normal Nice Girl'

title: Swapo Says a Rival Is Desperate
description: The South-West Africa People's Organization, the front-runner in Namibia's pre-independence election, today accused its main rival of ''acts of desperation'' as the five-day voting period passed its halfway point.

title: Applied Bioscience InternaFtional reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cade Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; Winners and Losers in a Black 'Big Chill'
description: ''The talented tenth,'' in W. E. B. Du Bois's memorable phrase, were those exceptional blacks who were destined to save their people from ''contamination and death.'' In Richard Wesley's ambitious, unwieldy new play, ''The Talented Tenth,'' his present-day equivalents of this leadership class are black urban professionals obsessively dedicated to their own self-interest.

title: Sale of British Industries Runs Into Nuclear Snag
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's long-running program to turn state-owned industries over to the private sector suffered another blow today when her Conservative Government decided it could not include nuclear plants in its planned sale of the power industry.

title: Conoco Well In Production
description: Conoco Inc. said Wednesday that it started production two weeks ago here at the world's deepest offshore production platform, extending the industry's reach farther into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Blues at Tramps
description: Melvin Taylor, a blues singer and guitarist, is to perform tonight at Tramps, 45 West 21st Street, on a double bill with Felix and the Havanas. Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M.; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Evolution Theory's Foes Win Textbook Battle in California
description: In a concession to evangelical Christians that could affect the teaching of science nationwide, the California Board of Education adopted new textbook guidelines today that delete a reference to evolution as ''scientific fact.''

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 478 money market mutual funds increased by $3.92 billion, to $363.81 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 146 institutional funds increased by $2.27 billion, to $87.26 billion. The assets of the 235 general-purpose funds were up by $1.49 billion, to $119.15 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased by $164.8 million, to $157.40 billion, the institute said.

title: Camor in the East; The Berlin Wall: A Monument to the Cold War, Triumphs and Tragedies
description: It was a monument to political control, a scene of gunfire and drama and tragedy, the stuff of spy novels and a physical and psychic barrier that divided Berlin, Germany and Europe. For 28 years, the Berlin wall has been the foremost symbol of cold war and East-West confrontation.

title: 'Pretty Party' Makes Lions Of the Grubby
description: Speaking for the New York Public Library's two guardian lions and for ''all of us two-footed creatures who work here,'' the Rev. Timothy S. Healy welcomed a black-tie crowd of 225 to the ninth annual Literary Lions dinner last night.

title: Exotic Sound of One-of-a-Kind Instruments
description: Harry Partch lived either before his appointed time or else 2,000 years too late. In his solitary art, music served a larger experience, one in which seeing, feeling and hearing joined together and erased the line between the sensual and the intellectual. Partch believed that the music around him thought too much, or at least thought to the exclusion of the rest of the body. Music, as he put it, ''was afraid of, and suppressed, anything that happened below the neck.''

title: Shamir Invited, at Last, To Meeting With Bush
description: The White House issued a last-minute invitation today to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel to meet with President Bush next week.

title: Wiser Oil Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Milton Stern, 77, Retired Perfume Executive
description: Milton Stern, a retired perfume marketing specialist, died of cancer Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: MBNA Offers $500 Million In Asset-Backed Certificates MBNA Credit Card Trust 1989-B is offering $500 million in asset-backed certificates, with an estimated average life of three and a half years, through Prudential-Bache Capital Funding. The trust was established by

title: Review/Art; Ferrer's Caribbean World Of Sensuality and Mystery
description: Rafael Ferrer paints a Caribbean world in which immediacy and sensuality exist, mystery is everywhere and innocence is impossible. His paintings at the Nancy Hoffman Gallery are both unfailingly romantic and relentlessly self-conscious. Their conflict between bitter and sweet, north and south, pleasure and disorder, is miasmic and mesmerizing.

title: Random House Chief Led Rushdie Efforts
description: To the Editor:

title: Town Votes for English As Official Language
description: A nonbinding ballot question declaring English the official language of Lowell has passed overwhelmingly over the objections of minority groups that say it could jeopardize Federal funds.

description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; The City Is Sweet and Muggers Are Merry
description: ''Prince of Central Park,'' the new musical at the Belasco, is a numbing evening of such guileless amateurism that it will probably have a future as a Harvard Business School case study, whatever its fate in the annals of drama. Even modest Broadway shows like this cost more money than the gross national product of some third world nations. People put up this money. As long as there are people as gullible as the sponsors of ''Prince of Central Park,'' the theater need never fear for its survival.

description: Thomas K. Gilhool holds degrees in philosophy, political science and law from Yale. He was a Fulbright Scholar in town planning at the London School of Economics and Political Science. For the last two years, he was the Pennsylvania Secretary of Education.

title: Philip Morris's Rothmans Sale
description: The Philip Morris Companies today sold its 29 percent stake in Rothmans International Ltd., the British tobacco concern, for $860 million. The sale created a huge profit for the United States tobacco giant and ended speculation that it might take over Rothmans.

title: Walt Disney Net at Peak
description: The Walt Disney Company today reported record earnings and revenues for the fourth quarter and the fiscal year, based on the continued strength of the company's parks and film and video operations.

description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

The company changed its name from LFP Holdings Inc. at the time of the acquisition. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: The Gap Inc. today reported record revenues and earnings for the third quarter, which ended Oct. 28.

title: U.S. SAYS LASERS STRIKE ITS PLANES
description: The Pentagon said today that Soviet ships were suspected of aiming laser beams at four American military aircraft in the Pacific, possibly injuring an eye of one crewman.

title: Brazil-Chile Incident Still a Mystery to FIFA
description: LEAD: There were 20 minutes left in the game between Brazil and Chile when the flare made its dramatic appearance. It dropped softly to earth in front of the Chilean goal, dying quickly with a burst of light and smoke.

title: TV Weekend; A Mistaken-Identity Farce by Ayckbourn
description: One of Britain's more prolific and popular playwrights, Alan Ayckbourn travels far better on television than in stage productions. On Broadway, his ''Norman Conquests'' was moderately interesting. The BBC production of the same play was brilliant. Quintessentially English, Mr. Ayckbourn seems to require not just a British cast but a made-in-Britain production. And that's what he gets in tonight's ''Great Performances'' presentation of ''Relatively Speaking.'' It's on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. The play, first produced in 1967, is a mistaken-identity farce, which is not immediately apparent. In the first scene, Greg (Michael Maloney) wakes up in an apartment belonging to Ginny (Imogen Stubbs), whose previous lover was an older man. He has known her for only a month but is seriously proposing marriage. With a typical Ayckbourn waffle, Ginny assures Greg: ''I love you very much, more than I ever loved anybody, I think. And I'll probably say yes, but not now.'' She leaves, telling him she is going to visit her parents. He follows, determined to win them over.

description: Georgia O'Keeffe A Life By Roxana Robinson 639 pages. Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row. $25.

description: When Ben McDonald was selected yesterday as the winner of the Golden Spikes Award, presented annually by the United States Baseball Federation to the top amateur player, it capped a year to remember.

description: b-After a gain of $55,829,000, or 57 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting; the adjustment reflected adoption of SFAS 96. The income before adjustment included a loss of $150 million from the sale of a subsidiary. The 1988 revenues and earnings restated for new life insurance accounting rules (SFAS 97). The effect of this change was to reduce net income by $6.2 million, or 6 cents a share, for the third quarter and by $26.4 million, or 27 cents a share, for the 9 months. The income before adjustment which was equaled to a loss 17 cents a share reflected preferred stock requirements. The share earnings are fully diluted.

description: ''My Left Foot'' was shown as part of the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 23. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza 1, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: AQUINO SEEKS AID FROM U.S. BUSINESS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines met with President Bush, senior Administration officials and Congressional leaders today as she sought to encourage American investment in and American imports from her island nation.

title: Becton Dickinson & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $55,594,000, or $1.40 a share, which included income of $10,936,000, or 28 cents a share, from operations and a gain of $44,658,000 on disposal from Edmont Industrial glove business. c-Included income from discontinued operations of Edmont Industrial glove business of $2,980,000, or 7 cents a share, and $13,087,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said Edmont Industrial glove business was sold in the 1989 third quarter.

title: Market Place; Why Japan Likes Lower U.S. Rates
description: FOR most of 1989, the Japanese stock market has been a laggard, a sharp reversal from the leading role it played for much of the 1980's. But it was Japan that stemmed the tide of the mini-crash that rocked most world markets in mid-October, and this week it was Japan that reacted most enthusiastically when the Federal Reserve seemed to signal it wanted to ease credit.

title: Review/Dance; Mortal and Sprite in Joffrey's 'Sea Shadow'
description: The ocean wove a spell on Tuesday night when a new cast appeared in the Joffrey Ballet's production of Gerald Arpino's ''Sea Shadow'' at the City Center (131 West 55th Street).

title: India's Low Castes Turn the Tables
description: The caste system, always a major force in Indian society, may be growing in importance as disadvantaged groups use their numbers and solidarity to win a larger share of power. It is likely to play a pivotal role in national elections this month, particularly if the contest is close, Indian politicians say.

title: Halogen Glow Will Envelop Grand Central
description: A group of midtown Manhattan merchants and property owners announced plans yesterday to ring Grand Central Terminal with 185 powerful halogen floodlights both to highlight the landmark station and to reduce the potential for street crime around it.

title: Champion Parts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from an accounting adjustment of $510,000, or 14 cents a share. c-Net income and the 9 months included an extraordinary credit of $99,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Regan Says He Met Keating But Denies Backing Friend
description: Donald T. Regan, White House chief of staff in the Reagan Administration, said today that in 1986 he met with Charles H. Keating Jr., then owner of a California savings and loan, and that they had talked about Mr. Keating's desire to get his friend Lee Henkel Jr. nominated to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

description: b-Net loss

title: Topics of The Times; All in the D'Amato Family
description: The New York Foundation for Senior Citizens complains, fairly, that we erred in our Wednesday editorial about Senator Alfonse D'Amato and the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

description: Tumbleweeds tossed by 50-mile-an hour winds buried streets and houses in this Missouri River town.

title: Kisio Hospitalized
description: Kelly Kisio, the center and captain of the Rangers, was admitted to Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday for treatment of a badly bruised thigh muscle. Kisio suffered the injury in Wednesday night's 3-2 loss to Montreal. Kisio, who has already missed a handful of games this season because of a recurring back injury, was listed by the team as day to day.

title: U.S. Seeks to Store Nuclear Waste at Army Bases to Save Plutonium Plant
description: The Bush Administration has begun a quiet scouring of military bases in Colorado and across the country for a site to temporarily store radioactive wastes.

title: Dinkins Celebration Goes to Washington
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins traveled to Washington yesterday and joined Democratic leaders there in proclaiming that his victory Tuesday was a sign of the party's renewed strength throughout the country.

title: Wyse Bid Planned By Taiwan Group
description: A Taiwan consortium said it would bid for the United States computer company Wyse Technology. Wyse, based in San Jose, Calif., said Wednesday that it was discussing being acquired by an unidentified party at a proposed cash price of $10 a share. Securities industry sources in Taipei said the consortium was prepared to pay up to $14 a share.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Political Harmonies

title: Hecla Mining Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $352,000 and $200,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively. The extraordinary credit for the latest quarter included a $337,000 gain from a debt to equity conversion and a $15,000 tax credit. The year-ago credit is a tax credit.

title: Cuomo Attacks U.S. Efforts To Block Deal on Shoreham
description: Arguing against the newest attempt to block the closing of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told Congress and the Federal Government today to stay out of New York State's affairs.

title: Nicaragua Talks Are Off on a Bumpy Road
description: The United States-backed Nicaragua contra rebels today demanded an immediate cease-fire in Nicaragua as well as the right to base their fully armed forces in special security zones inside the country while free elections are prepared.

title: I.B.M. in Purchase
description: The International Business Machines Corporation agreed to acquire the Lockheed Corporation's CADAM Inc. subsidiary, which makes software for computer-aided design and manufacturing applications. I.B.M. did not disclose terms for the deal, which is expected to close within 60 days.

title: Review/Jazz; A Clarinetist Leads a Band With Potential
description: The opening set of the Buddy DeFranco and Terry Gibbs group at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night was hobbled by lack of rehearsal. The rhythm section, noisy and uncoordinated, didn't always swing, and the group rarely used arrangements that adequately set off the two musicians' talents.

title: EAST GERMANY OPENS FRONTIER TO THE WEST FOR MIGRATION OR TRAVEL; THOUSANDS CROSS
description: East Germany on Thursday lifted restrictions on emigration or travel to the West, and within hours tens of thousands of East and West Berliners swarmed across the infamous Berlin Wall for a boisterous celebration.

title: Police Sued On Taping In Connecticut
description: An association of 200 criminal-defense lawyers from across Connecticut charged in a Federal lawsuit today that the state police illegally recorded telephone conversations between lawyers and their clients for nine years in violation of the United States Constitution.

title: Hammers Fall and Prices Soar
description: IMPRESSIONIST and modern art -works by Pablo Picasso, Vincent van Gogh, Edouard Manet, Claude Monet and Edgar Degas - is in place at New York's major auction houses for Round 2 of the November sales. The sessions began with contemporary art on Tuesday and will end on Nov. 18.

title: Expansion Is Planned By Borden
description: Borden Inc., putting muscle into its move away from the dairy business, said yesterday that it plans to spend $650 million over the next two years to expand and modernize its plants around the world. It will also spend an additional $75 million to $100 million on advertising and marketing.

title: Ex-U.S. Worker Angry at Justice Dept. 'Misconduct' Report
description: A Justice Department political appointee with a high security clearance resigned last year after being investigated for the possibility that he had disclosed classified information to a foreign government, according to a departmental report issued today.

Who's Playing And Where
description: The New Music America '89 festival opens this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section (718-636-4100), its nearby Majestic Theater, 651 Fulton Street, and other locations around New York City. The festival ends on Nov. 18. Schedule information: 669-7740. For additional information, call the individual clubs and halls. Here is a schedule of events this weekend. Today BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC, a round robin of musical theater in three theaters at or near the academy - the Playhouse, the Majestic and the Opera House - featuring Kip Hanrahan, David Lynch and Angelo Badalamenti and Lester Bowie, 7 and 8:15 P.M. Tickets, $28 and $35. THE KNITTING FACTORY, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Miracle Room, 9 and 11 P.M. Tickets, $10. Tomorrow BALDWIN PIANO AND ORGAN COMPANY SHOWROOM, 205 West 58th Street (245-6700). Conlon Nancarrow and Trimpin, pieces for four computer-controlled pianos, noon and 2 P.M. Free. Also Sunday at same times. THE NEW MUSEUM OF CONTEMPORARY ART, #583 Broadway, below Houston Street (219-1222). Christian Marclay installation, 3 P.M. Admission, $3.50. BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC, Opera House, David Byrne, 8 P.M. Tickets, $12 to $25. THE KITCHEN, 512 West 19th Street (255-5793). Heiner Goebbels/Heiner Muller, ''The Man in the Elevator,'' with Fred Frith, Arto Lindsay, Ditmar Diesner and Charles Hayward, 8 P.M. Tickets, $12. Also Sunday and Monday at 8 P.M. THE KNITTING FACTORY, Zahar, 9 and 11 P.M. Tickets, $10. THE WORLD, #254 East Second Street (477-8677). No Safety, Miniature, Ned Sublette, 11 P.M. Tickets, $12. title: Metro Datelines; Vandals Halt Service To Phone Customers
description: Telephone service to 361,000 customers in southeastern New York was disrupted yesterday, a result of the worst case of vandalism since a strike against the Nynex Corporation began three months ago, telephone company officials said.

title: Mildred Bennett Dead; Cather Expert Was 80
description: Mildred Bennett, an authority on the novelist Willa Cather, died of lung cancer on Tuesday. She was 80 years old.

title: For Time, New Slogan And a Feat
description: HAVING wrested Time magazine's advertising account from the agency that owned it for more than half a century, George Lois has ingratiated himself with the publisher by fulfilling every client's fondest dream: creating a slogan that names the product not once, but twice.

title: Uncle Deadbeat Stiffs the U.N.
description: If you're serious, a hard-boiled American maxim advises, put your money where your mouth is. By this standard, the U.S. is profoundly unserious about the United Nations. This country is not merely the host but the main architect of the U.N. It is also the main deadbeat - a fact shamefully reconfirmed by a recent Senate decision to cut $123 million from President Bush's request for regular dues owed the U.N. and its agencies and for America's share of peacekeeping operations.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS McEnroe, Chang and Gilbert Gain: John McEnroe, Michael Chang and Brad Gilbert earned quarterfinal berths yesterday in the Wembley championship in England. McEnroe beat an erratic Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-4, 6-1. Gilbert beat a fellow American, Leif Shiras, 7-5, 6-3. Chang beat another American, Paul Annacone, 6-2, 1-6, 6-0. Annacone committed 13 double faults. Also reaching the quarterfinals was Wally Masur of Australia, who beat Martin Strelba of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-1.(AP) Becker Loses: Unseeded Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden stunned the defending champion, Boris Becker, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday in a third-round match of the Stockholm Open. Gunnarsson had a nearly flawless serve-and-volley game and was never broken by the second-seeded Becker. Ivan Lendl crushed Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-0, 6-2. Andre Agassi, seeded fourth, beat another Swede, Jonas Svensson, 6-3, 6-1.(AP) PRO BASKETBALL 50 From Shaw and Ferry: Brian Shaw scored 32 points and Danny Ferry scored 18 as Il Messaggero Roma beat Arimo Bologna yesterday, 90-69, in Milan, Italy. After eight weeks, Dan Caldwell, playing for Viola Reggio Calabria, leads the Italian league in scoring with an average of 31.7 points per game. Shaw, at 25.5, and Ferry, at 22.5, are sixth and ninth, respectively.(AP) GOLF Hammond Leads by Three: Donnie Hammond shot a second-round five-under-par 67 yesterday for two-day total of 131 and a three-shot lead in the Kapalua International tournament in Hawaii. Hammond, who is 13 under par, leads Craig Stadler, with Steve Pate and Robert Wrenn another shot back.(AP)

title: 2 Landmark Utility Laws Stir Debate
description: A law passed half a century ago to protect consumers and investors from utility company fraud is hurting consumers by barring big companies from the emerging business of competitive power generation, electric company officials told a Senate committee today.

title: Dow Drops 19.67 Points, To 2,603.69
description: Stock prices declined yesterday and trading volume fell.

title: Magdeleine de Jesus, Founder of Nuns' Order, 91
description: Sister Magdeleine de Jesus, author and founder of an order of Roman Catholic nuns, died Monday at the order's headquarters in Rome. She was 91 years old. Born Magdeleine Hutin at Montigny-les-Metz in eastern France on April 26, 1898, she founded the Fraternite des Petites Soeurs de Jesus - the Little Sisters of Jesus - in 1939, in the Saharan outpost of Touggourt, Algeria. The order, which has 1,400 nuns of about 60 nationalities on five continents, is devoted to the contemplative life. Its members share the poverty and social conditions of manual laborers in slums and shantytowns around the world. She wrote two works, ''From One End of the Earth to the Other,'' and ''From the Sahara to the Whole World.''

title: Liqui-Box Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
3 Westbound Lanes to Open On Fire-Damaged Interstate
description: Three westbound lanes of Interstate 78, damaged by a trash fire under an elevated portion of the road, will reopen Friday in time for the evening rush, officials said today.

title: Control Data Sale
description: The Control Data Corporation agreed to sell its Ticketron sports and entertainment ticketing division to the Carlyle Group, a private merchant banking firm in Washington, D.C. Terms were not disclosed. Control Data said it would retain Ticketron's automated wagering services and that the sale is expected to be completed in 30 days. Ticketron sold more that 19 million tickets last year with about $450 million in gross receipts and $41.4 million in revenue.

title: Berlin Border Guards Stunned by the News
description: The East German border police at the Checkpoint Charlie crossing point in the Berlin wall were stunned today to learn that citizens could now travel through to the West freely.

title: From a Bold but Still Couth Era
description: IF you like your modernism on the early side, mostly from the 19th century or the first decade of the 20th, then the fourth annual ''Modernism'' show at the Seventh Regiment Armory is just the thing. This fair of 68 American and European dealers specializing in furniture, design objects, architectural remnants, ceramics, glass and silver, as well as posters, prints, photographs, paintings and books, remains on view at the armory through Sunday.

title: Legal Aid Society blends Madison Avenue and idealism in an unusual appeal for recruits.
description: Slip the videocassette into the machine, push ''play,'' sit back and watch. The person coming onto the screen is Dan O'Donnell, an intense, bearded young lawyer from the New York Legal Aid Society, and he is in a familiar role.

title: TV Host's Presidential Bid in Brazil Rejected
description: Brazil's electoral authorities ruled tonight that a popular television host cannot compete in presidential elections here next week.

title: Rose's Explanation
description: Pete Rose said yesterday that he had never declared his race-track winnings on his income-tax returns - as required by law - because he always lost money in the long run. During a telephone conversation, the former Cincinnati Reds manager, banned from baseball on Aug. 24, said he had had no recent discussions with Federal prosecutors conducting the grand jury investigation of his taxes.

title: Bergen Brunswig Notes Are Priced
description: A $410 million face-amount financing by the Bergen Brunswig Corporation of Orange, Calif., was priced yesterday, with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as the underwriter.

title: Accugraph Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Del Taco Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income and included an after- tax gain of $6,520,000, or 76 cents a share on the sale of the company's Applebee's restaurant business in March 1988.

title: CNS Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kelly McGillis Leaves Shakespeare Troupe
description: Kelly McGillis has withdrawn from the company of the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger in Washington because she is expecting a child in June. Ms. McGillis is starring as Viola in the company's current production of ''Twelfth Night'' and was to have appeared in ''Mary Stuart'' and ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' later this season.

title: American Power Conversion reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 split paid in June 1989.

title: U.S. ENTHUSIASTIC, BUT HAS CONCERNS
description: Like the rest of the world, Washington is scrambling to keep pace with the changes unfolding by the hour in Eastern Europe. But in contrast with the pivotal role the United States played 40 years ago in shaping the postwar European order that now seems to be coming apart, Washington finds itself more of a bystander - astonished, enthusiastic and concerned.

title: Books of The Times; Novelist Turns His Eye To the Realities of Israel
description: The Slopes of Lebanon By Amos Oz Translated by Maurie Goldberg-Bartura. 240 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: Armand Hammer in Hospital
description: The industrialist Armand Hammer underwent surgery on Friday to have a heart pacemaker implanted and was later reported in good condition. A spokesman for the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, where the 91-year-old Mr. Hammer is chairman, said doctors expected him to be released from the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in a few days and to return to normal activity.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;
With Ironing
description: LEAD: Few household tasks inspire such procrastination as ironing. One source credits a Dutchwoman who immigrated to England with inventing the practice of ''smoothing,'' but she figured out a way to weasel out of the chore: she finagled an appointment as Elizabeth I's principal court laundry inspector.

title: Rev. Gene Bartlett, 79; Led Divinity School
description: The Rev. Dr. Gene E. Bartlett, president emeritus of Colgate Rochester Divinity School, died of a heart attack on Nov. 3 at Genesee Hospital in Rochester, where he lived. He was 79 years old.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Firefighters Cancel Flag Rite
description: Firefighters have abandoned plans to burn worn-out flags at a Veterans Day ceremony on Saturday, fearing they would have been drawn into the controversy over the rights of protesters to burn flags as a form of free speech.

title: B. Altman Bid Deadline
description: The L. J. Hooker Company, whose parent, the Hooker Corporation of Australia, is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, filed a petition with the bankruptcy court yesterday for a deadline of next Friday to consider bids for its seven B. Altman & Company stores. Hooker is also seeking to liquidate B. Altman if a satisfactory offer is not received by the deadline.

title: Koch Resists Ideas Backed By Dinkins
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch issued a 10-point warning yesterday about the future of New York City, one that seemed to be directed largely at positions and ideas endorsed by David N. Dinkins, the Mayor-elect.

title: Little Gold in Coloring Old Films
description: When color versions of such vintage black-and-white films as ''Yankee Doodle Dandy'' and ''Topper'' began appearing on television in 1986, executives in the color-converting business thought they saw a bright new industry emerging.

description: The latest year's results included those of Lamina Inc., acquired on the last day of fiscal 1988. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

Canada Southern Pete reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: KEY RATES
Despite Pledge, Homeless Still in Hotel
description: There are only two single beds in the room at the Times Square Hotel where Kimberly Andrews, her husband and their 5-year-old son, who are homeless, have been living since September. The paint is peeling so badly from the walls onto the stained carpeting that Ms. Andrews routinely sweeps twice daily. The family's room, on the 12th floor, does not have window guards or a smoke detector.

title: Houses That Trap Humidity May Unleash Health Problems
description: A lesson about household air quality is unfolding at the Passamaquoddy Indian reservation on the rocky coast of northeastern Maine. Dozens of children there suffer from respiratory problems, including asthma-like conditions.

title: Why I'm Fighting Gorbachev for My Job
description: LEAD: I write this with mixed emotions. On the one hand, it is clear what happened: I was asked to resign as editor just at the moment when I could not because the stakes were too high. The issue is not my own future, or even that of the weekly. The paper will live on without me and without those who work there now.

Apogee Robotics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Virginia Connolly Mitty, Pediatrician, 70
description: Dr. Virginia Connolly Mitty, a pediatrician in Manhattan for more than 40 years, died of a stroke on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center. She was 70 years old.

title: Magic's Center Out
description: The Orlando Magic learned yesterday that Dave Corzine, their starting center, would be sidelined 6 to 12 weeks with a tear of a ligament in his left knee. The 6-foot-11-inch Corzine, 33 years old, was injured Wednesday in the first quarter of the Magic's 117-110 victory over Cleveland.

Israel and Japan Edge Closer
description: In a small step toward improving relations, Israel and Japan have decided to establish a committee to explore areas of economic and technological collaboration, officials of the two countries said today.

title: Spear Knebel, Priest, 87
description: Spear Knebel, a former Episcopal priest and youth counselor in New York City, died of heart disease Monday at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Canaan, N.Y.

Bridge
description: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon and will continue for 10 days. Initially the focus will be on two events restricted to experienced players: the Life Master Men's Pairs and the Life Master Women's Pairs.

title: Death Toll Now at 2 in Crash of Navy Jet in Georgia
description: A pregnant woman died tonight of burns and searchers found the body of a man in the debris of an apartment complex where a Navy fighter plane crashed Thursday night.

Kellogg, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Results for 1989 reflected the consolidation of Pneumo Abex Corp. on June 1. title: Kitty Dukakis Recovering
description: Kitty Dukakis remained hospitalized today, recovering from the effects of drinking rubbing alcohol, and there was no word on the date of her release. Sue Kaplan, a spokeswoman for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, said only that Mrs. Dukakis would not be released today from Brigham and Women's Hospital. She was admitted Monday night after drinking what her doctor said was a small amount of rubbing alcohol. Mrs. Dukakis was treated for alcoholism earlier this year.

title: Iowa's Sailors Looted After Blast, Paper Says
description: A published report said today that sailors on the battleship Iowa were stealing possessions last April 19 after an explosion that killed 47 other sailors in a forward gun turret.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Oct. 8 about Bette Davis credited her incorrectly with a distinction held by another actress.

title: Venmar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: PITTSTON TO OPEN TALKS WITH U.M.W.
description: The United Mine Workers and the Pittston Company will begin intensive bargaining next week in an effort to resolve the seven-month strike against the coal company, the Government's mediator says.

title: Winfield Stakes Claim On Yankee Right Field
description: Even though he has not swung a bat in a game since the summer of 1988, Dave Winfield vowed yesterday that he would return to the Yankees next spring in top condition, ready to come back from back surgery and ready to win back his job in right field.

title: Photography Center's New Horizons
description: The International Center of Photography arrived at a new stage in its evolution yesterday with the opening of ''In Our Time: The World as Seen by Magnum Photographers'' at its new midtown quarters. For the first time, the photography center can present a large museum-scale show with as many as 300 images.

description: b-Net loss Latest full year results include: after-tax gains of $2.5 million, or $1.36 a share, from sale of a 50 percent stake in a business; and $1.7 million, or 92 cents a share, from termination of non-union pension plan; and after- tax charges totalling $800,000 for deferred compensation and restructuring expenses related to reductions in the work force at a U.K. unit.

description: b-Included a provision of $335,690,000 for estimated loss on sale of assets and termination fee.

title: For Bad Checks, A Second Fee
description: Consumers always pay their banks a fee when a check bounces. But increasingly, retailers and companies that collect on bad checks are asking consumers to pay the fee that banks charge them when a check fails to clear.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Lining Up for Visas; Where Brutality Reigned, The Police Turn Mellow
description: At the Immanuel Kirchstrasse Police precinct in East Berlin's Prenzlauer Berg district, thousands of East Germans lined up today to receive visas allowing them to travel freely to the West.

title: Deng Hints at Keeping a Large Role in China
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, suggested today that he might continue to play a significant role in Chinese affairs, despite his resignation from his last formal post in the Communist Party leadership.

description: b-Net income

title: Data Measurement reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bonray Drilling Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said earnings for the quarter were adversely affected by the expenditure of $183,000 to mobilize three mothballed rigs.

title: Some Tips For a New Mayor
description: David Dinkins's first job in New York is to restore civility. Here are some ways to start: 1. Tax limousine riders back onto the subway. The town already levies staggering ''occupancy'' taxes on people renting hotel rooms. Put a murderous ''occupancy'' tax on people who rent limousines.

title: Tootsie Roll Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ferocity of Youth Violence Is Up, a School Official Says
description: Victor Herbert, the chief official of the city's public high schools, has been meeting with principals and teachers in recent days, warning them that ''the level of potential violence'' among young people ''is higher than I've ever seen it before.''

title: Atlantic Suit Is Dismissed
description: A state court judge in Massachusetts has dismissed a lawsuit by a group of former stockholders of The Atlantic magazine who contended that Mortimer B. Zuckerman owed them additional payments from his acquisition of the publication in 1980.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Dunkin' Donuts Inc., Randolph, Mass., which has been resisting an uninvited takeover offer, extended until Wednesday its deadline for receiving proposals for its possible acquisition.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: China; Disgust With the West Is Reported, But Beijing Ignores the Wall's End
description: Newspaper readers in China learned of the remarkable resignations of East German leaders this week, but they also picked up another bit of news: two East Germans who had fled more than a month ago to the West found the new society too disorderly and so returned home.

title: Burnham Pacific Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months figures reflect a one-time capital gain of $2,635,000 resulting from the sale in June of the Town & Country shopping center for $4,801,500.

title: Sunshine-Jr. Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.O.P. Women Tie Their Support to Abortion Issue
description: They have been stalwart Republicans for decades, but three prominent women who have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for the party have announced that they would withhold their support from candidates who oppose the right to an abortion. They said they would form a political action committee to aid Republicans who support abortion rights.

title: Cem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Hartford, Drug Wars May Broaden Concern
description: Little more than a mile from the glass skyscrapers of downtown and the gold-leaf dome of the state Capitol, teen-age gangs are locked in what the police say is the city's worst blood feud since the cocaine business took root here.

title: Tridont Health Care reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge for unusual items of $5.4 million and a provision for future losses of $3 million. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Hearing Granted on Lawsuit by Keating
description: A lawsuit filed by Charles H. Keating Jr., contending that Federal regulators wrongfully seized the insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, will apparently get a full hearing in court.

title: Harold A. Knapp, Nuclear Test Expert, Dies at 65
description: Harold A. Knapp, a Defense Department analyst who uncovered risks from fallout in nuclear testing in the 1950's and initiated the reversal of a rape conviction of three black men in the 1960's, died of a form of cancer that attacks the spine on Wednesday at his home in Germantown, Md. He was 65 years old.

title: Columbia S&L Assoc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter reflected an accounting loss of $130.2 million from a lower of cost or market adjustment for net unrealized losses which effects the company entire portfolio of high-yield corporate and treasury securities.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Ripples in Poland; KOHL DELIVERS AID AND RETURNS HOME
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany told Polish leaders today that he was interrupting a five-day visit to their country for 24 hours, but not until he had signed accords granting Poland the largest amount of economic aid it has yet obtained from a Western nation.

title: Tobacco Town Smoking Ban Laid to Shopper's Complaint
description: This tobacco town now has North Carolina's toughest ban on smoking, largely because a pregnant woman grew angry about having smoke blown in her face in the check-out line at her neighborhood supermarket.

title: Enzo Biochem reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a provision of $1,968,100 for a doubtful research contract receivable and related legal fees. c-After an extraordinary credit of $420,000, or 4 cents a share. The latest periods included results of Bio-Health Laboratories which was acquired at the end of April 1989.

title: Anti-Castro Cuban Gives Up Fight Against Being Deported From U.S.
description: A Cuban-born pediatrician who has been in jail here for almost two years while the Justice Department has been seeking to deport him as an anti-Castro terrorist will drop his fight against being sent to another country, his wife says.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1989
description: Companies

title: Sunshine Mining Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said production at the Sunshine Mine totaled 3.6 million ounces of silver for the 9 months, versus 1.3 million ounces for the first 9 months last year. The Trixie Mine produced 6,000 ounches of gold and 200,000 ounces of silver for the 9 months, an increase of about 41 percent for gold and 94 percent for silver over 1988. The production improvements at the mines were partially offset by lower silver prices, which averaged $5.54 per ounce for the first 9 months of 1989 versus $6.63 per ounce in the same period in 1988.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Sabres 4, Canucks 2: Buffalo, last in the league on the power play, scored on three of four power-play opportunities last night to remain unbeaten at home this season (7-0-1). The Sabres have six victories and a tie in their last seven games. Dave Andreychuk, Aleksandr Mogilny, Pierre Turgeon and Scott Arniel scored for Buffalo. Greg Adams and Garth Butcher connected for Vancouver. The Buffalo goaltender, Daren Puppa, made 26 saves and Kirk McLean of Vancouver stopped 16 shots.(AP) Bruins 5, Capitals 3: Bobby Carpenter scored two goals and Boston netted three of its first seven shots against Washington last night in Landover, Md.(AP) Whalers 4, Jets 2: Dave Tippett made his first goal of the season a game-winner for Hartford. Tippett picked up a rebound off the end boards and beat the Jets goaltender Daniel Berthiaume with 2 minutes 39 seconds left in the third period to snap a 2-2 tie. Mike Tomlak added an empty-net goal with 43 seconds left. After six games without a point, Dale Hawerchuk scored two goals for Winnipeg.(AP) TENNIS McEnroe Reaches Semifinals: John McEnroe clawed his way out of a web of confusion yesterday to edge Miloslav Mecir, 2-6, 6-4, 6-3, and reach the semifinals of a tournament in Wembley, England. The top-seeded McEnroe, beaten by the deceptive Mecir in their two previous meetings, screamed at line judges who called six foot faults on him, but held on to win in 2 hours 20 minutes. McEnroe started slowly, winning only six points in the first five games as the eighth-seeded Mecir raced to 5-0 lead, confusing McEnroe with a series of unorthodox winners. But McEnroe persisted with his serve-and-volley game, and by the end, Mecir was spraying as many errors as winners around the court. McEnroe was joined in the semifinals by his 17-year-old compatriot Michael Chang, who beat Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 6-4. Chang's speed and shot selection wore down Chesnokov in a battle of baseliners. In another quarterfinal match, Robert Seguso lost, 7-5, 6-3, to Guy Forget of France. In the other quarterfinal, Wally Masur of Australia upset Brad Gilbert, 7-6, 3-6, 6-3. Forget will meet McEnroe in the semifinals, and Masur will play Chang.(AP) Lendl Faces Edberg: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, continued his mastery of Tim Mayotte, beating the American, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to set up a semifinal match against Stefan Edberg in the Stockholm Open. Lendl, playing in Stockholm for the first time since 1978, ended the match with an ace for his 15th victory in 15 matches against Mayotte. Edberg held off Jim Courier, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, to join his fellow Swedes Magnus Gustafsson and Mats Wilander in the semifinals. Gustafsson, a wild-card entry ranked 92d in the world, upset fourth-seeded Andre Agassi, 6-2, 7-6. He will meet Wilander, who scored a 6-3, 6-0 victory over Jan Gunnarson of Sweden.(AP) HORSE RACING Victory After Long Layoff: Lions Head Farm's Champagneforashley, idle since racing to a 14 1/2-length victory on July 17 in his debut at Belmont Park, drew away through the stretch and scored a seven-length victory yesterday in the $95,250 Damon Runyon Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct. Fifteen Gold Stars, the favorite, was runner-up in the field of 10, 2 1/2 lengths ahead of Applebred. Champagneforashley, carrying 117 pounds and ridden by Jacinto Vasquez, posted a stakes record time of 1:35 3/5 for the mile. He earned $57,150 and returned $6.40 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: Barrincorp Industries Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

The proposed sale is for $60 million in cash plus return of shares of Ohio Mattress owned by Mr. Wulinger.

description: Brazil has uncovered an international web of currency fraud totaling up to $360 million, involving the staffs of big local and foreign banks, Brazil's Justice Minister said today.

title: Bush Offers Housing Plan to Aid Poor, Homeless and New Buyers
description: President Bush today proposed a $7 billion, three-year package of housing programs and tax breaks to aid low-income families, first-time home buyers and the homeless ''who live a nightmare in the midst of the American dream.''

title: East German Events Seen Lifting Dollar
description: The dollar rose yesterday against the West German mark and other European currencies in gains traders attributed to the opening of East Germany's borders.

description: West German politicians and newspapers today hailed the reopening of East Germany's borders as a turning point in history, but many ordinary citizens here seemed apprehensive about how their lives might be affected by a new influx of East German immigrants.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Sofia's New Leader; A Friend of Kremlin Policy Open to 'Different Opinions'
description: Petar T. Mladenov took over as Bulgaria's Communist leader today by telling his party that it had ''to find its new place in the new atmosphere of the country.''

description: Unilever, the British-Dutch food and consumer products giant, said today that its profit rose 15 percent in the third quarter, partly because of a strong contribution from newly acquired businesses.

description: Church bells pealed, long-separated friends and family members fell into each other's arms, people wept for joy and complete strangers pressed money into newcomers' hands or offered them rides to wherever they wanted to go.

title: Inventor Wins Hot Wheels Case
description: Hot Wheels contests are more likely to last 12 seconds than 12 years, but then seldom are millions of dollars at stake.

title: Nassau County Proposes to Cut Property Taxes
description: Nassau County, under fierce pressure from homeowners to lower property taxes, proposed today a $1.62 billion budget for next year that would reduce county property taxes by almost 3 percent.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: NATO and the Warsaw Pact; As Threat of War Recedes, U.S. and Soviets Face Pressure for Troop Cuts
description: The political unheaval in Eastern Europe is raising the prospect of change in the military balance in the region, putting pressure on Moscow and Washington to substantially reduce their forces there.

title: Review/Music; VibraphonistWith Pianist And Bassist
description: Over the last half-century, the ranks of outstanding jazz vibraphonists have grown slowly. One or two each decade seems to be the norm - Lionel Hampton and Red Norvo in the 1930's (although Mr. Norvo was playing xylophone at that time), Milt Jackson and Terry Gibbs in the 1940's, Gary Burton in the 1960's. The apparent gap in the 1950's was actually filled by Warren Chiasson, a Canadian vibraphonist who joined George Shearing's quintet in 1958 and who has been a quietly provocative presence on the instrument ever since.

description: After examining barrels of lye in a warehouse in Long Island City, drug agents said yesterday that they had seized more than five tons of cocaine, one of the five largest seizures of the drug in the country.

description: The administration at Georgetown University, one of Washington's two major Roman Catholic schools, has barred publication of an abortion rights advertisement in the student newspaper, leading the editors to cancel publication of today's issue.

description: To the Editor:

title: Jordan Is Held to 26 Points as Nets Beat Bulls
description: When Dennis Hopson arrived at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, he knew Michael Jordan would be there, too. Two seasons ago, Hopson would have been rattled. Tonight, he was ready. ''I would've been out of it before the game started,'' said Hopson, the Nets' third-year shooting guard. ''Now I'm enjoying myself on the floor. Confidence, that's the main difference in my game, and in this team. Win or lose this year, we feel we can compete with anybody.''

title: Biotechnica International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Avon Discloses Stake Held by Investor Group
description: Facing its fourth possible takeover assault in six months, Avon Products Inc., the door-to-door cosmetics company, disclosed yesterday that a partnership made up of Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc., the Getty oil family and the Fisher real estate interests of New York had acquired more than 5 percent of its stock.

title: Holiday Today
description: Because of the Veterans Day Parade, Fifth Avenue between 24th and 39th Streets will be closed today from 9 A.M. to noon.

title: Sarwo Edhie, Indonesian General, 62
description: Lieut. Gen. Sarwo Edhie, retired, who led army troops in suppressing a Communist coup attempt in 1965, died on Thursday of a stroke. He was 62 years old. He joined the army in 1943 when he was 16 to fight for independence from the Netherlands. He also was a member of Parliament, from which he resigned in 1988.

title: Digital Microwave Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patents; Algorithm Ruling May Aid Software
description: In a ruling that computer experts believe will help developers of software, a Federal appeals court this week liberalized the rules for patenting mathematical algorithms.

title: Mafia Reported To Be Seeking New Trash Sites
description: Two organized-crime families are so worried about running out of landfill space for their waste-hauling companies in the New York area that they are seeking to gain control of valuable dump sites in Pennsylvania, law-enforcement officials say.

title: Pledge Sought On Oil Rights
description: Oil companies should be guaranteed the right to produce oil they find in authorized offshore explorations, Ken T. Derr, the chairman of the Chevron Corporation, said Thursday.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: The biggest mystery about ''Best of the Best,'' a listless formula sports movie about an American tae-kwon-do team that travels to South Korea for an international competition, is what attracted actors like Eric Roberts, James Earl Jones, Sally Kirkland and Louise Fletcher to such a project.

title: Columbia Gas System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bids for Dollars by Soviets
description: Soviet state enterprises on average paid 15 times the official bank rate to buy dollars at the first foreign currency auction held here, with dollar bids far outweighing offers, the Tass press agency said today.

description: b-Net loss

title: L.S.U. Hoping to Settle Old Score
description: Forget Alabama's unbroken string of victories, its high national rankings, its acclaimed quarterback, Gary Hollingsworth, and its intimidating defense led by the menacing linebacker Keith McCants.

title: Sikh Extremists Raid School, Killing 19 Sleeping Students
description: Suspected Sikh extremists stormed an engineering college before dawn today, killing 19 students sleeping in a dormitory, the police said.

title: Review/Music; A Contrast Of Extremes From Mehta
description: If there exist compositions more dissimilar than the two Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic are presenting this week at Avery Fisher Hall, they do not come to mind. Franz Schubert's Symphony No. 5 (1816) and Gustav Holst's ''Planets'' (1916-17) may represent extremes of musical Romanticism, from the most chaste to the most grandiose, but this trivial historical observation gains nothing in the demonstration. Unlike juxtapositions that prove instructive or stimulating for their very dissimilarity, when one work sheds unexpected light on another, this one simply jars. Throughout the peaceable Schubert, the listener is uncomfortably aware that ''Mars, the Bringer of War'' lurks nearby.

title: Manhattan Fire Halts Stock Exchange Openings
description: The opening of trading at stock exchanges throughout the country was delayed for an hour yesterday because of a fire in the Manhattan building that houses many of the computers that process stock trades.

title: Namath Pessimistic About Jets' Prospects
description: Joe Namath, the first Jets player to reach pro football's Hall of Fame, provided a historical perspective on the state of the 1989 Jets today and their chances to salvage the season, and it wasn't a favorable one.

title: Crop Genetics
description: Crop Genetics International, an agricultural biotechnology company in Hanover, Md., said plants inoculated with its genetically engineered corn vaccine had reduced corn borer damage by more than 80 percent in greenhouse tests. The company said it was the first time that a plant had been able to grow its own pesticide in its vascular system. ''Our Incide vaccine is environmentally more attractive than synthetic chemical pesticides,'' John B. Henry, chairman and chief executive of Crop Genetics, said in a news release. The new vaccine it scheduled for field trials in Maryland next summer.

title: Banks Aggressively Moving Into Mutual Fund Business
description: After years of watching mutual funds attract money that might have gone into bank deposits, bankers are aggressively counterattacking.

title: Deep Divisions Emerge in Congress on Ways to Expand Aid for Child Care
description: With Congress seeking to fulfill a pledge to increase Federal child care assistance, deep divisions have emerged over how much money should be spent and on whom, and to what extent the Federal Government should be involved.

title: First Victory for Wolves
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves won their first game ever tonight, beating the Philadelphia 76ers, 125-118, in overtime as Tony Campbell capped a career-high 38-point performance with 4 points in the final minute and 57 seconds.

title: London Journal; Pageantry And Pomp And Lots Of Old Boy
description: The new Lord Mayor of London takes office on Saturday with a daylong show of horse-drawn carriages, dignitaries in their finest livery and commercialism worthy of a Macy's parade, all on the 800th anniversary of elected municipal government.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the sentencing of five men for an attack in Carl Schurz Park in Manhattan, on two men whom they believed to be homosexuals, misidentified a victim.

title: How to Clear Up the H.U.D. Scandal
description: Frustrated by Samuel Pierce's refusal to testify, Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee have asked for an independent counsel to pursue the scandal in the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who responded by intemperately charging the Democrats with playing politics, will now be forced to give an accounting of his own investigation - or let an independent counsel take it over.

title: Ann Luce Wed to Jonathan Auerbach
description: Ann Gardner Luce and Jonathan Auerbach were married yesterday at the Sky Club in New York by Don Robert Johnson, the senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Luce of Westport, Conn. Mr. Auerbach is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Auerbach of Boston.

title: Comair Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fall's Compensations
description: A week ago we mourned the death of daylight, and the refusal by those in charge of setting the world's clocks to extend daylight time for another month. Darkness falls too soon, we said, and going home under a lowering sky is a dreary business. True, there's light at the other end of the day, for those who are awake to see it. But each year their numbers diminish. Milkmen seldom make rounds anymore; and the diaper services, famous for their dawn arrivals, are almost out of business.

title: Retail Groups' Merger Backed
description: The executive committees of the American Retail Federation and the National Retail Merchants Association this week approved in principle a merger of the two organizations into one unit to be known as the National Retail Federation. The consolidation must still be formally approved by both boards in January.

Review/Dance; The Essential Ashton By the Joffrey
description: New York does seem to be the dance capital of the world on occasions like the Joffrey Ballet's all-Ashton program on Thursday night at City Center. Where else on a single evening could one see three vintage pieces by Sir Frederick Ashton, one of the great choreographers of the 20th century, performed by a company that clearly cherishes the dances? And who else but the Joffrey would present a program that so suggested Sir Frederick's many facets?

title: U.S., Mexico in Tax Pact
description: Mexican and United States officials have agreed to share income and tax information in an effort to help each other find tax evaders, the Finance Ministry said Thursday. The ministry and the United States Treasury have reached an agreement to provide each other with data about individuals' incomes and any evidence that they may be evading taxes, a ministry statement said. The agreement will take effect once it has been approved by the Mexican Senate, the statement said.

title: Don't Minimize the Dinkins Victory
description: Many commentators have seized upon David Dinkins's surprisingly narrow margin of victory in the mayoral campaign to make two points: that the vote reflected the city's deep ethnic and racial divisions and that Rudolph Giuliani's negative campaign, however distasteful to most New Yorkers, was highly effective.

title: Atari Is Selling 26 Federated Stores
description: The Atari Corporation, the computer and video game maker, agreed to sell 26 of its struggling Federated Group consumer electronics stores to Silo Inc., a Philadelphia-based electronics retailer. The tentative agreement Thursday calls for Silo to take over 21 Federated stores in Los Angeles and Orange counties and five in San Diego. Terms of the deal were not announced. Silo already operates 10 stores in San Diego.

title: Review/Music; Looking for Differences With the Classical Band
description: The Classical Band, which made a premature and inauspicious debut earlier this season in the acoustically dead Kathryn Bache Miller Theater at Columbia University, wrote the second page of its history on Thursday evening with a concert at Carnegie Hall. A report on the group's progress would have to read: some, but not enough to cheer about.

She will appear in the Rosenkavalier section of ''Vienna Waltzes,'' in a role created for her by Balanchine in 1977.

title: 'Powerless' In the Face Of Gambling
description: A number of years ago there was a fellow I knew who was believed to have everything. He was smart, good-looking, well liked, athletic, confident, ambitious and grew up in a comfortable home. He became a lawyer, and married. His father died and left a considerable amount of money to him and his mother. As the story would unfold, he gambled and lost all the money he had, as well as money that his mother and clients had entrusted to him. He fell deeply and hopelessly into debt.

title: Your Money
description: People who pay for child care or who pay household workers like maids and gardeners face special tax reporting and withholding requirements. And they should be sure they have complied with the requirements within 1989 - not wait until next spring when filing their tax returns.

title: Craig R. Hall Wed To Margaret Fink
description: At St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Margaret O'Brien Fink, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Johnson Fink of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Craig Robert Hall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Hall of Richfield, Utah. The Rev. Martin B. Hitchcock performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. William T. White.

title: The End of the War to End Wars
description: Crowds of young Germans danced on top of the hated Berlin wall Thursday night. They danced for joy, they danced for history. They danced because the tragic cycle of catastrophes that first convulsed Europe 75 years ago, embracing two world wars, a Holocaust and a cold war, seems at long last to be nearing an end.
