title: Corrections
description: A headline in Sports Pages on Nov. 3 misstated reasons for the resignations of two head coaches at the University of Florida. Norm Sloan, the basketball coach, left after being accused of improperly paying a recruited player's air fare. Galen Hall, the football coach, left after he admitted having improperly paid two assistant coaches in secret salary supplements. Neither coach was accused of paying players.

title: Gleason Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $690,000 and $2,498,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and 9 months also included a gain from sale of Gleason Power Systems division in June of $7,725,000, or $1.35 a share. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $2,505,000 for the quarter and $5,515,000 for the 9 months. The company said because of the planned sale of its components group, it restated its third quarter and 9 months resultss as required by accounting rules.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Redefining Europe; As the Revelry Goes On, Politicians Ponder The Ramifications of Changes in Germany
description: By the simple act of forcing their Communist rulers to open the Berlin wall and allow them to go wherever they wish, the people of East Germany have irrevocably changed the way Berlin, Germany and all of Europe have defined themselves for more than 40 years.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-9 East Berliners went through the wall in an unending celebration, while West German leaders proclaimed this the moment Germans had yearned for through 40 years of division. Page 1 Friends fell into each other's arms, people wept for joy and strangers put money into newcomers' hands as hundreds of thousands of East Berliners entered West Berlin. 6 News analysis: The Berlin opening has altered assumptions about the division of Germany, irrevocably changing the way all of Europe has defined itself for more than 40 years. 1 Washington scrambled to keep pace with the changes unfolding in Eastern Europe. While only bystanders now, U.S. officials are rethinking the Bush-Gorbachev summit in December. 1 A possible shift in the power balance in Europe has put pressure on Moscow and Washington to substantially reduce their forces. 7 Moscow reacts calmly, but says border must stay 8 West Germany hails a turning point, but apprehension grows 7 Kohl delivers aid to Poland and returns home 7 In Western Europe, spreading ecstasy and calls for caution 8 East German events seen lifting dollar 35 Beijing ignores Berlin wall's end 8 Bad times for spy writers: a story without the wall? 9 Bulgaria's 78-year-old chief resigned after 35 years of guiding the country with old-line orthodoxy. Todor Zhivkov was replaced by his longtime foreign minister, Petar Mladenov. 1 New leader says Party must ''find its new place'' 9 King Hussein pledged more freedom for the press, two days after his country's first general election since 1967. He also hinted at the possibility of broader liberalization, including restoration of political parties. 3 Israel and Japan edge closer 4 Namibians have embraced their vote for a new assembly as proof of emancipation from more than a century of colonial rule, first by Germany and then by South Africa. 3 The contras will not lay down arms before the Nicaraguan elections scheduled for February, the new contra leaders said. The Sandinistas have insisted on a Dec. 5 deadline. 4 Deng sees continued role in China 5 National 10-13, 28 Some $7 billion in housing aid over three years was proposed by President Bush. It would provide mortgage aid for low-income families, tax breaks for first-time home buyers and expanded assistance to homeless people. 1 A bill to help pay for child care is making headway in Congress. But the issue has been complicated by divisions over who should be helped, who should be in control and how much money should be spent. 12 A study of women in their 30's showing a precipitous decline in marriage prospects is being revised, the authors say, because of misinterpreted data. 10 Searchers found the body of a man amid the charred debris of a apartment complex in Smyrna, Ga., nearly 24 hours after a Navy fighter plane crashed into it. 10 Sailors on the battleship Iowa were stealing possessions last April 19 as 47 other sailors died in an explosion in a forward gun turret, a published report said. 11 Catholic bishops issued a statement Thursday calling for sexual abstinence outside marriage rather than the reliance on condoms to avoid AIDS. 10 Georgetown has barred publication of an abortion rights advertisement in the university's student newspaper, leading the editors to cancel publication of today's issue. 11 A state's toughest smoking ban has been established in Greensboro, N.C., largely because a pregnant women grew angry about having smoke blown in her face in supermarket check-out line 13 Ford Motor chairman to retire 35 U.M.W. and Pittston to open intense talks in strike 11 Baby's death makes Boston case a double suicide 28 Fire halts stock exchange openings 46 Banks aggressively moving into mutual fund business 35 Little gold found in coloring old films 35 Regional 29-32 Senator D'Amato urged H.U.D. and its former secretary, Samuel Pierce, to approve a grant of several million dollars to two of the Senator's key upstate New York fund-raisers, a newly obtained document shows. 1 Mayor Koch seemed to be criticizing the ideas and positions of the Mayor-elect, David Dinkins, in a 10-point warning he issued about the future of New York City. 29 G.O.P. women tie their support to abortion issue 31 250 families are in a welfare hotel in Manhattan, living in roach-infested rooms and under exorbitant rates, only 15 months after New York City announced it would stop using welfare hotels by July 1, 1990. 29 Organized crime is expanding into Pennsylvania as a way to control new garbage-dump sites outside the New York City area, the authorities say. 29 Youth gangs are at war in Hartford, highlighting the worlds of rich and poor at the center of Connecticut's society. The police say that it is the city's worst feud since the cocaine business took root there. 29 Voting machines were impounded in Yonkers after a partial recount of returns in the mayoral election showed a vote shift to the loser, Mayor Nicholas Wasicsko. 30 The public high school chief in New York City, Victor Herbert, has been meeting with principals and teachers to warn them that ''the level of potential violence'' among youths ''is higher than I've ever seen.'' 31 Nassau County proposes to cut property taxes 30 Police in Brooklyn arrest man sought in robbery-killings 30

title: Comprehensive Care reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said the quarter was negatively impacted by continued poor utilization of its freestanding facilities and behavioral medicine contracts, and by costs of about $1.5 million associated with the proposed reorganization with First Hospital Corp.

title: Ford Motor Chairman To Retire
description: Donald E. Petersen, the executive who helped bring the Ford Motor Company from the edge of financial disaster to a ranking as the most profitable of the Big Three auto makers, said he would retire on March 1 as chairman and chief executive, about a year and a half earlier than expected.

title: Triangle Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary loss of $197,000 for both periods which reflected premium paid on refunding of IDBS, and included in the 9 months was an accounting adjustment gain of $238,000, or 9 cents a share, which reflected cumulative effect of the adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 96. The company said results for the latest third quarter were substantially less than expected primarily because of manufacturing problems at its hand tool operations which significantly reduced scheduled hand tool shipments and increased production costs.

title: Hofstra Halts the Redmen's Dream Season
description: The St. John's Redmen had waited six years for the chance to avenge a 1983 loss to Hofstra that prevented them from gaining a playoff berth, but last night, in ugly, heart-throbbing fashion, they let that chance slip away.

title: Louisiana General Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,280,000, and also included is a one-time charge of $11,372,000 for provision for discontinued operatons. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $692,000 and $2,327,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said 1988 net income was restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Bulgarian Chief Quits After 35 Years of Rigid Rule
description: Todor I. Zhivkov, Eastern Europe's longest-serving leader, resigned today as Bulgaria's President and Communist Party leader, after 35 years of guiding the country with old-line orthodoxy.

title: Quietly, Giants' Collins Is Gaining Recognition
description: For a cornerback, Mark Collins is comparatively flamboyant on the field, but cornerbacks seldom create a stir unless they give up a big pass completion.

title: Yonkers Vote in Doubt; Machines Are Seized
description: The voting machines used in Tuesday's election were impounded today after a partial recount of the mayoral race showed a 1,663-vote shift to the apparent loser, Mayor Nicholas C. Wasicsko.

title: Saab-Fiat Venture Seen
description: A venture between Saab-Scania of Sweden and Fiat of Italy could be agreed upon before the end of the year, Sweden's Industry Minister was quoted as saying today.

title: Nycom Information Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Richard T. Daly, Physicist, 64
description: Richard T. Daly, a nuclear physicist who helped develop the first commerical laser, died of cancer on Nov. 3 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived in Castine, Me.

title: Police in Brooklyn Arrest Man Sought In Robbery-Killings
description: A man who is wanted in two killings and several robberies and who escaped from a Brooklyn station house more than four months ago was arrested early yesterday after the police received an anonymous tip.

title: Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Damiani Bout Canceled
description: A World Boxing Organization heavyweight title fight scheduled for Nov. 25 between the champion, the unbeaten Francesco Damiani of Italy, and Pierre Coetzer, a challenger from South Africa, was canceled yesterday.

title: Couple Found Dead in Park After Burglary at Their Home
description: A General Motors executive and his wife were shot to death today and left in a park, apparently by intruders who robbed them and ransacked their house, the police and Federal agents said.

title: Bliss & Laughlin Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $132,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: D'AMATO BACKED SUPPORTERS' BID FOR H.U.D. MONEY
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato urged the Federal Housing Secretary to approve a grant worth several million dollars for a Buffalo housing-renovation project run in part by two of the Senator's supporters, according to a newly obtained document.

title: DOW UP 21.92 TO 2,625.61, ON RATE HOPES
description: Buoyed by a positive outlook for interest rates and the dollar, stock prices made broad gains yesterday.

title: Bishops' AIDS Policy Urges Abstinence
description: Seeking to put a dispute over AIDS policy behind them, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops have issued a statement calling for reliance on sexual abstinence outside marriage to prevent the spread of the disease.

title: Abatix Environmental Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Evelyn V. Exley, Executive, Weds
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, Evelyn Victoria Exley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Exley Jr. of Dayton, Ohio, was married yesterday to Peter E. Guernsey Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew officiated.

title: Free-Agent List Grows
description: Five more players filed for free agency yesterday, bringing this year's total to 89, matching a record set in 1977. The five are Robin Yount of Milwaukee, Rich Gossage of the Yankees, Darrell Evans of Atlanta, Rick Horton of St. Louis and Doug Bair of Pittsburgh.

title: Datron Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Namibian Voting Is Heavy and Eager
description: An official bilingual notice was posted at the local school explaining how to cast a ballot in Namibia's elections, but the goat ate it.

title: Citizens Security Groups reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Accel International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $17,000 and $137,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After an extraordinary tax charge of $23,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $33,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months included investment gains of $81,000 and $194,000, respectively, and the year-ago quarter included an investment gain of $52,000 and the 9 months included an investment loss of 115,000.

title: JOYOUS EAST GERMANS POUR THROUGH WALL; PARTY PLEDGES FREEDOMS, AND CITY EXULTS
description: As hundreds of thousands of East Berliners romped through the newly porous wall in an unending celebration, West German leaders today proclaimed this the moment Germans had yearned for through 40 years of division.

title: Atlantic American reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Leon Hall, 42, Dies; A Civil Rights Worker
description: Leon W. Hall, a director of community and consumer affairs for Atlanta and a veteran of civil rights campaigns, died of a heart attack Monday at Southwest Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived in Atlanta.

title: Yanks' Cycle of Change Meets Stabilizing Force
description: In a series of letters he wrote to George Steinbrenner seeking a job with the Yankees, Harding (Pete) Peterson stressed one element he believed was necessary in creating a winning team: stability. He got the job.

title: PRICES OF TREASURY ISSUES UNCHANGED
description: Prices of Treasury securities were essentially unchanged yesterday as the market marked time awaiting next week's auction's of nearly $46 billion of bills, notes and bonds.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Western Europe; A Sense of Delight, Tempered by Pleas for Caution
description: Countries in Western Europe were almost universally ecstatic today in welcoming the opening of the Berlin wall, but many struck a cautionary note about the possible effect of rapid changes in East Germany on the postwar European order.

title: Kossuth Was More the Guest Than the Prisoner of the Turks; Silent on Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Soviet Union; The Kremlin Reacts Calmly, But Says Border Must Stay
description: With a studied calm, the Soviet Union today welcomed East Germany's opening of the Berlin wall as a positive move, but emphasized that East Germany's borders were inviolable until radical changes were made in East-West military alliances.

title: There's More to a Diamond Than Glitter
description: More couples become engaged in December than in any other month.

title: Baby's Death Makes Boston Case Double Homicide
description: The death of the infant born prematurely to a fatally wounded mother has been ruled a homicide, a spokesman for the Suffolk District Attorney's office said today. The baby died Thursday at the age of 17 days.

title: Review/Music; For the Cherubini, Unity Out of Diversity
description: The bearers of the sunny Italianate name - Cherubini String Quartet -turn out to be four young West Germans. Together, they made their debut at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night playing quartets by Mendelssohn, Webern and Schubert.

title: Expeditors Intl of Washington Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $79,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $155,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 9 months, from utilization of operating losses of foreign subsidiaries.

title: Don't Dismiss the Dangers of Incinerator Ash; Westchester's Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Coherent Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Robert Gerringer, 63, Stage and Film Actor
description: Robert Gerringer, a stage, film and television actor, died of complications resulting from a series of strokes Wednesday in Cove's Edge Hospital, Damariscotta, Me. He was 63 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Newcastle, Me.

title: Flach Out Also
description: Two days after tearing ligaments in one of his feet in a first-round match, Ken Flach was forced to withdraw yesterday from the doubles competition at a tournament in Wembley, England.

title: Smartcard International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comdata Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are adjusted to reflect the December 1988 acquisition of American Facsimile Systems Inc. as if that acquisition had occurred at the beginning of each period presented. The company said the net loss for the latest quarter reflected primarily non-cash amortization expense related to goodwill, acquisition costs and debt discount.

title: Alberta Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $15.3 million, or 28 cents a share, for both the quarter and 9 months. The year-ago special gain of $15.3 million was from the sale of the company's interest in Ipsco Inc. The company said year-ago revenue figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Television; Election Drama That Polls and Viewers Missed
description: Remember the secret ballot? The way it worked was you checked off your choices on a piece of paper or pulled the lever behind the curtain and nobody knew you were a closet Vegetarian. And not only was the vote each citizen's private secret; it was also the nation's secret. That made for a long evening of excitement sitting by the radio or before the tube and following the election results, sometimes into the small hours. Would Staten Island go for John F. Kennedy? Compelling programming.

title: Assix International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
E'town Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The net income figures provided are earnings available for common shareholders. Other figures were not disclosed.

title: Review/Theater; Guilt and Retribution Overtake Nebraskans
description: ''A Dance Lesson,'' by David Wiltse, begins as a gently amusing genre piece about an average Nebraska family in the mid-1950's. As the work unfolds (at the Long Wharf Theater's Stage II), it is evident that the author has something more sobering in mind - a bitterly regretful play dealing with guilt and retribution.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLDGuidepost; Enough Turkey for All
description: Calculating portions for Thanksgiving dinner will cut down on confusion at the grocery and anxiety at the carving board. It can also help you build in the amount of leftovers you desire. The chart below provides generous servings; if you want turkey sandwiches all week, just increase the amount accordingly. $ FOOD AMOUNT PER SERVING Turkey 1 pound (Figure slightly less for turkeys over 12 pounds.) Stuffing 1 cup (Figure about 1 cup per pound of turkey.) Cranberries 1/4 cup (One 12-ounce bag of cranberries makes about 3 cups of cranberry sauce, or 12 servings.) Sweet potatoes 1/2 pound (about 1 medium-size potato) Pie 1/6 of a 9-inch pie

title:
THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE;
A Specific Guide to Single-Minded Shopping
description: LEAD: New York shoppers can be a very demanding bunch - particularly during the holiday season, when even casual consumers take shopping seriously. But the city usually comes through. For those with highly specific needs or powerful obsessions, New York offers a variety of stores selling one type of merchandise - from music boxes to military memorabilia, kites to pickles.

title: Babbage's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income and in the 9 months preferred dividend requirement exceeded net income.

title: Hussein Pledges a Freer Press in Jordan
description: Two days after his country's first general election since 1967, King Hussein today promised greater press freedom and hinted at the possibility of broader liberalization, including the restoration of political parties.

title: About New York; A Promise Kept: 'A Commissioner For All Species'
description: Mr. Henry J. Stern Commissioner of Parks and Recreation

Xyvision Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 6-month results included a $2.2 million restructuring charge for severance costs, writeoff of equipment, and writedown of capital assets not expected to contribute to future operations.

title: Thackeray Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,404,000, or $1.06 a share, which included a gain of $6,595,000, or $1.29 a share, from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,559,000, or 30 cents a share, and $1,597,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net loss

title: The Editorial Notebook; Restoration in Hungary
description: Restoration, not revolution, is the right word to describe the remarkable changes in the Republic of Hungary, as it now calls itself. This recent visitor was intrigued to learn exactly what's being restored in this age of glasnost -and why.

title: Builders Transport Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brooklyn Principal Still Refuses a New Post
description: The standoff continued yesterday between the Board of Education and Gloria Simmons, the acting principal of Public School 262 in Brooklyn, who has refused reassignment to another school.

title: Marriage Study That Caused Furor Is Revised to Omit Impact of Career
description: Three researchers who provoked anger and anxiety among women with a 1986 study that forecast a precipitous decline in the marriage prospects of well-educated women in their 30's are publishing a revised paper that omits those findings.

title: Burlington Coat Factory reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Connecticut Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Isomet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Critic's Notebook; A Sorry Chapter for Smiley's Kind: What's a Spy Story Without a Wall?
description: ''They were almost at the wall when the beam darted to the north, leaving them momentarily in total darkness. Still holding Liz's arm, Lemas guided them forward blindly, his left hand reaching ahead of him until suddenly he felt the coarse, sharp contact of the cinder brick. Now he could discern the wall and, looking upward, the triple strand of wire and the cruel hooks which held it. Metal wedges, like climbers' pitons, had been driven into the brick. Seizing the highest one, Lemas pulled himself quickly upward until he had reached the top of the wall. He tugged sharply at the lower strand of wire and it came toward him already cut.''

title: American Management SysFtems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the results for the latest quarter and 9 months included a gain of about $883,000, or 8 cents a share, from sale of its micrographics business and the expected sale of part of its summons-processing business.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a beautiful day after a long voyage, but we are only at a way station. We are not at the end of our way.'' - Willy Brandt, former West German Chancellor. [ 6:3. ]

title: TALKING: Windows; To Repair, Restore or Replace?
description: FROM almost every source - television, radio, direct mail and print ads - homeowners are being bombarded with promotions for thermal-pane replacement windows. A homeowner with an aging house and no restrictions on exterior modifications can find all this quite tempting.

title:
GARDENING;
Fallen Leaves and Autumnal Tasks
description: LEAD: NOW that the leaves have fallen, many gardeners still face the task of cleaning up. All too often that involves raking the leaves by hand, packing them into plastic bags and placing them by the curb to be picked up and hauled to a landfill. Not only does this contribute to the problem of diminishing space in landfills, but it is also ecologically unsound and, for the most part, unnecessary.

title: One Man's Crusade Against Smoking
description: LEAD: DAVID GOERLITZ used to be the ''Winston man,'' one of a handful of ruggedly handsome models used in an advertising campaign for cigarettes.

title: Getting in Gear For the Slopes
description: EVERY year ski resorts boast of the millions they spend sprucing up their lifts and trails for winter. Less often, but still at considerable personal expense, skiers must undertake capital improvements of their own, replacing or upgrading their skis, boots, bindings or poles so that the equipment matches their skill and magnifies their pleasure. This year, outfitting from scratch with new gear will cost between $300 and about $1,200.

title: OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR
description: Did the people and the press turn on Richard Serra because of government incitement? Not really. Government merely responded to citizen outrage. And people, I think, simply sensed the contempt hammered into Mr. Serra's sculpture and returned that contempt to its source. STANLEY N. KURTZ Cambridge, Mass.

title: Dinkins and the Unions That Supported Him Face Fiscal Bad News
description: STARTING six months after David N. Dinkins's Jan. 1 inauguration as New York City's 106th Mayor and continuing for most of the next six months, contracts with dozens of unions representing the city's 330,000 workers expire, group by group.

title: Shake-Up in Bulgaria Brings Cautious Optimism
description: On the day after the first change in national leadership in 35 years, Bulgarians spoke today with hope but without clear conviction that they stood on the brink of genuine political and economic change.

title: Coping With Teen-Age Suicide Stanley Lependorf and Nancy McWilliams; Stanley Lependorf, Ph.D., is a psychologist at Princeton University. Nancy McWilliams, Ph.D., is a psychologist at Rutgers University and is vice president of the Flemington-Raritan Regional Board of Education.
description: FACED with the alarming rise in suicides by high school and college students, New Jersey educational leaders have reacted with apt consternation and a flurry of efforts to cope. By disseminating all available and appropriate information about the circumstances of the suicide, offering support groups and providing to distressed members of the community ready access to counselors, school officials are seeking both to ease the grieving process and to prevent suicides by other young people.

title:
Franklin Township Journal;
Township Council Members to Guide Developer's Foundation
description: LEAD: AS part of an overall community-relations program embracing all four of his industrial parks in New Jersey, Isaac Heller, a developer, has established a special foundation for charitable and nonprofit organizations here.

title: The Heyday of Rococo in Central Europe
description: The subject of the new decorative arts rooms in the Metropolitan Museum - ''Central Europe: 1700-1800'' - is one as to which I must declare an interest. That place and that time have been dear to me since infancy. I love the plump, unchanging countryside. I love the way the air in high summer cuts like double cream. I love big, broad, chesty backdrops like the castle in Coburg called the Veste. I feel for the early 18th-century staircase in the Neue Residenz in Passau the way other people feel for the staircase of the giants in the Doge's Palace in Venice. And - not least - I love the country houses that speak for a robust, unregimented curiosity and a readiness to stick with one's own taste and build upon it.

title: At the Front in the Battle Over Unix
description: Even though the Unix operating system is 20 years old, it seems as if the battle over the one ''true'' Unix has been going on since the Crusades. The war is far from over, but in recent weeks the field has narrowed to two major versions of the operating system. One is controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and supported by an advisory group called Unix International; the other, scheduled for delivery next year, is being developed by a group called the Open Software Foundation, whose goal is to come up with something not controlled by A.T.&T.

title: The 'Painless' Way to Build a Nest Egg
description: Many Americans find thrift a difficult virtue to cultivate.

title: Diary of an 'Indie's' Hard Sell
description: Artistry is fine, inspiration grand, but Robin Armstrong says the key to Hollywood success is much more mundane: ''In this town, no matter what else you do - write, direct, act - in addition you must be a salesman.''

title: Review/Theater; Infidelity And Love On Tape
description: ''Your Handsome Captain,'' Simone Schwarz-Bart's drama at the Ubu Repertory Theater, is less a play than a poetic dialogue for two voices, one of which is only heard offstage in a simulation of a recording. The play is the first by Ms. Schwarz-Bart, a novelist from Guadeloupe. It relies primarily on its incantatory language and repetitious imagery to create a dreamlike portrait of a couple struggling to maintain a long-distance relationship. But the story is too vague and the characters too unformed for a deep chord to be struck.

title: Arab Groups Fear Israeli Curbs on Donations
description: Eight years ago, five Israeli-Arab doctors troubled by deficient health-care services in Arab villages in Galilee decided to take matters into their own hands. They raised money from church-based European welfare agencies and established the Galilee Society for Health Research and Services.

title:
ART;
Bane of the Nazis On View in Roslyn
description: LEAD: THE ''Degenerate Art'' exhibition, which opened in Munich July 19, 1937, was the Hitler regime's official vilification of Germany's esthetic vanguard. The primary group ridiculed in the exhibition was the Expressionists, whose bold experiments in color and form during the previous 30 years had helped to revolutionize painting, sculpture and graphics.

title: No. 4: Echt and Eclectic Source
description: Fairway Fruits and Vegetables, the echt Upper West Side market a couple of blocks up Broadway from the Ansonia Hotel, says that 60,000 customers a week cruise through its packed aisles of produce, delicatessen, dairy goods and you-name-it (Kirbys, anyone?). Of those 60,000, probably 40,000 are little old ladies who wield their shopping carts, dawn to midnight, the way a matador brandishes a cape. At Fairway's famous neighborhood rival, Zabar's, your mother, in the form of an insistent barker with a microphone, keeps nudging you to eat a little something, preferably the daily special. At Fairway, you can get revenge by battling the many mother surrogates in an unofficial game of market-aisle bumper carts.

title: Officer, 25, Is Arrested In Robbery in Brooklyn
description: A 25-year-old New York City police officer was arrested yesterday in the robbery, while off duty, of a burglary suspect on Wednesday at a Brooklyn shopping center where the suspect was showing off his $48,200 booty, the police said.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
THE RHYMES OF AN ANCIENT RODENT
description: LEAD: POEMS OF A. NONNY MOUSE Selected by Jack Prelutsky. Illustrated by Henrik Drescher. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. (Ages 5 and up)

title: The Census: How a Head Count Grew and Grew
description: THE first United States census was taken almost two centuries ago. It was designed as a simple head count to regularize the composition of the House of Representatives, with one seat for every 30,000 citizens. (Excluded were American Indians not paying taxes.) No one dreamed that by 1990 the tabulation would blossom into a vast statistical analysis, both reflecting and regulating much of our economic life.

title: Working to Feed the City - the Butcher, the Baker ... the Marketplace Maker
description: THE FOOD DAY BEGINS shortly before midnight at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx. It is a militaristic-looking complex in a wasteland of auto wreckers and junkyards. Convoys of semi-trailers pass through a toll-booth opening in the barbed-wire and corregated-tin wall that surrounds the grocery compound. They unload, they load. Last year, five million pounds of fresh fruits and vegetables were sold from the gargantuan warehouses here, primarily to grocery chains and huge wholesale buyers. Meat, packaged fish, dairy goods, canned and frozen food are also sold, about $7 billion worth a year. Almost everything comes in packages; almost nothing is sold retail.

title: WHO LEFT THE DAGGER IN JOY SINCLAIR?
description: PAYMENT IN BLOOD By Elizabeth George. 312 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $16.95.

title: Miss Kissinger Becomes Bride
description: Jennifer Suzanne Kissinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Samuel Kissinger of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Parish of Christ the Redeemer in Pelham, N.Y., to Marcus Anthony Bordiere, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus H. Bordiere of New Britain, Conn. The Rev. David S. Hoag officiated, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Piedmont, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Privatizing Will Make Life Worse
description: I attended the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington last month. When the meetings ended, I was left with the impression that no further writedowns would be forthcoming for Latin America's debtor countries unless they followed the lead of Mexico. To do this, countries like Brazil and Argentina would have to sell off their public utilities, some potentially profitable industrial corporations and some service industries like airlines.

title: OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR
description: The only issue of any importance in the ''Tilted Arc'' controversy was obscured by Richard Serra's bullying counterattack on any criticism of his assaultive sculpture and by his success at turning the debate into a simple artists-against-Philistines conflict (''Our Most Notorious Sculptor,'' by Deborah Solomon, Oct. 8). One might argue, instead, that only a Philistine - a rude barbarian, expert on assaults - could make or love the ''Arc.'' But this is a silly argument, all name calling and huffing about credentials. The real issue is: to whom does the public space belong in a democracy? The answer is: the public.

title: ZIPPING OPEN THE RED SEA
description: DOES GOD HAVE A BIG TOE? Stories About Stories in the Bible. By Marc Gellman. Illustrated by Oscar de Mejo. 88 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95. (All Ages)

title: The Top 20
description: 1 U.N.L.V. Last Season: 29-8. Key Losses: George Ackles, forward, out until February with a broken wrist; David Butler, center, academically ineligible until mid-December. Returning starters: Greg Anthony, junior guard; Stacey Augmon, junior forward; Anderson Hunt, sophomore guard. Best Newcomer: Larry Johnson, 6-7 power forward from Odessa (Tex.) J.C.; Prognosis: In Johnson, Jerry Tarkanian finally has the unstoppable player to go along with the fast-paced style of play that has made U.N.L.V. one of the nation's most entertaining teams. Syracuse Last Season: 30-8. Key Losses: Sherman Douglas, all-America point guard; Matt Roe, shooting guard. Returning Starters: Derrick Coleman, senior forward-center; Stephen Thompson, senior guard; Billy Owens, sophomore guard-forward. Best Newcomers: LeRon Ellis, 6-10 junior forward, transfer from Kentucky; Conrad McRae, 6-10 freshman center from Brooklyn. Prognosis: If Thompson can handle the point guard responsibilities, Jim Boeheim has his best shot at an N.C.A.A. title. 3 Michigan Last Season: 30-7, N.C.A.A. Champions. Key Losses: Glen Rice, all-America forward; Mark Hughes, power forward. Returning Starters: Mike Griffin, senior guard-forward; Terry Mills, senior center; Rumeal Robinson, senior guard; Loy Vaught, senior forward. Best Newcomer: Michael Talley, 6-1 freshman guard, 1989 Michigan Mr. Basketball. Prognosis: Robinson holds this team together. He'll have to push Mills and Sean Higgins to a higher level. 4 Georgetown Last Season: 29-5. Key Losses: Charles Smith, guard; Jaren Jackson, guard-forward; John Turner, forward. Returning Starters: Alonzo Mourning, sophomore center; Dwayne Bryant, senior guard. Best Newcomer: David Edwards, 5-10 freshman guard from Queens. Prognosis: Mourning and Dikembe Mutombo form an awesome shot blocking combination. Key here is simple: Can Dwayne Bryant and Mark Tillmon replace the point production of Smith? 5 Arizona Last Season: 29-4. Key Losses: Sean Elliott, all-America forward; Anthony Cook, power forward; Ken Lofton, point guard; Returning Starters: Jud Buechler, senior forward; Matt Muehlebach, junior guard. Best Newcomer: Brian Williams, 6-11 sophomore center. Prognosis: How fortunate can a coach be? Lute Olsen loses all America Elliot and gets Williams, the 6-10 transfer from Maryland who is on the way to being an all-American. 6 L.S.U. Last Season: 20-12. Key Loss: Ricky Blanton, forward. Returning Starters: Chris Jackson, all-America sophomore guard; Wayne Sims, junior forward; Vernel Singleton, sophomore forward. Best Newcomers: Shaquille O'Neal, 7-1 freshman center from San Antonio; Stanley Roberts, 7-foot Proposition 48 sophomore center. Prognosis: The Tigers have an extremely young squad but Jackson is the nation's best guard. 7 Illinois Last Season: 31-5, Final Four. Key Losses: Nick Anderson, forward; Kenny Battle, forward.Returning Starters: Stephen Bardo, senior swingman; Kendall Gill, senior guard. Key Newcomers: Rodney Jones, 6-8 center-forward, junior college transfer from New Mexico J.C.; Andy Kpedi, 6-8 center, junior college transfer from Kankakee (Ill.) C.C. Prognosis: Bardo and Gill form excellent backcourt, but loss of Anderson and Battle may be too much to overcome. 8 North Carolina Last Season: 29-8.Key Losses: J.R. Reid, forward; Jeff Lebo, point guard; Steve Bucknall, guard. Returning Starters: Scott Williams, senior center; Kevin Madden, senior guard-forward. Best Newcomers: George Lynch, 6-7 freshman forward from Flint Hill (Va.) Prep; Henrik Rodl, 6-7 freshman guard-forward from West Germany. Prognosis: With Reid gone, it's a step-up year for the Tar Heels. 9 Arkansas Last Season: 25-7. Key Loss: Keith Wilson, guard. Returning Starters: Mario Credit, senior center; Todd Day, sophomore guard-forward; Lenzie Howell, senior forward; Lee Mayberry, sophomore guard. Key Newcomer: Ron Huery, 6-6 junior forward, back from a year's suspension. Prognosis: With four starters returning, Nolan Richardson's Hogs should rule the Southwest Conference. 10 Missouri Last Season: 29-8. Key Losses: Byron Irvin, guard; Gary Leonard, center; Mike Sandbothe, forward. Returning Starters: Doug Smith, junior center-forward; Lee Coward, senior guard. Key Newcomer: Chris Heller, 6-10 freshman center. Prognosis: Coach Norm Stewart, returning from illness, has an all-American in Smith. 11 Pittsburgh Last Season: 17-13. Key Losses: None. Returning Starters: Brian Shorter, junior forward; Jason Matthews, junior guard; Bobby Martin, junior center; Sean Miller, junior guard; Darelle Porter, junior forward. Key Newcomer: Darren Morningstar, 6-10 sophomore center, transfer from Navy. Prognosis: Now that Shorter has a season under his belt, the Panthers, with three three-year starters on board, are another Big East threat. 12 Notre Dame Last Season: 21-9. Key Loss: LaPhonso Ellis, sophomore forward, academically ineligible until mid-December. Returning Starters: Joe Frederick, senior guard; Jamere Jackson, senior guard, Tim Singleton, junior guard; Keith Robinson, senior forward-center. Key Newcomer: Kevin Ellery, junior forward, back from academic suspension during last year's second semester. Prognosis: Once Ellis is declared eligible, the Irish will become a force. 13 Indiana Last Season: 27-8. Key Losses: Jay Edwards, all-America guard, NBA hardship; Joe Hillman, guard; Todd Jadlow, center. Returning Starters: Lyndon Jones, junior guard; Eric Anderson, sophomore forward. Key Newcomers: Five Indiana all-staters led by Pat Graham, 6-5 freshman guard, 1989 Indiana Mr. Basketball. Prognosis: With 7 freshmen, look for Indiana to come on strong late in the year. 14 Temple Last Season: 18-12. Key Loss: Mike Vreeswyk, shooting guard. Returning Starters: Mark Macon, junior point guard; Duane Causwell, junior center; Mik Kilgore, junior guard; Ernest Pollard, junior guard. Key Newcomers: 3 Prop. 48 casualties of a year ago - Donald Hodge, 7-0 center; Chris Lovelace, 7-0 center; Mark Strickland, 6-9 forward. Prognosis: After an off-season (for him), Macon will benefit from a refurbished, although young, front line. 15 Duke Last Season: 28-8, Final Four. Key Losses: Danny Ferry, all-America forward; Quin Snyder, point guard. Returning Starters: Robert Brickey, senior forward; Phil Henderson, senior guard; Christian Laettner, sophomore center. Key Newcomers: Bobby Hurley, 6-0 freshman guard from top-ranked St. Anthony High School of Jersey City. Prognosis: Solid defense and precise execution will carry Blue Devils a long way, but Duke needs freshman Hurley to get good in a hurry. 16 U.C.L.A. Last Season: 21-10. Key Loss: Jerome (Pooh) Richardson, point guard. Returning Starters: Trevor Wilson, senior forward; Darrick Martin, sophomore guard; Don MacLean, sophomore forward; Kevin Walker, senior center. Key Newcomers: Tracy Murray, 6-8 freshman forward from Glendora, Calif. Player of the year in California, led nation in scoring with 44.3 avg. Prognosis: Coach Jim Harrick, a former assistant to John Wooden, is on the verge of leading U.C.L.A. back to national prominence. 17 Oklahoma Last Season: 30-6. Key Losses: Stacey King, Mookie Blaylock, guard; Tyrone Jones, forward. Returning Starters: William Davis, senior forward; Tony Martin, senior center-forward. Key Newcomers: Smokey McCovery, 6-2 point guard, junior college transfer from Midland (Tex.) J.C. Prognosis: Coach Tubbs's Sooners are small but lightning quick, and they will score a bunch of points. 18 Florida Last Season: 21-13. Key Losses: Clifford Lett, guard. Returning Starters: Dwayne Schintzius, senior center; Livingston Chatman, junior forward; Dwayne Davis, junior forward; Renaldo Garcia, junior guard. Key Newcomers: B.J. Carter, 5-7 guard, junior college transfer from Arizona Western J.C. Prognosis: Don DeVoe takes over the Gator program amidst a scandal that resulted in Norm Sloan's resignation. The Gators have an outstanding front-court, though the 7-2 Schintzius's intensity is subject to question. 19 Minnesota Last Season: 19-12. Key Losses: None. Returning Starters: Willie Burton, senior forward; Kevin Lynch, junior guard; Melvin Newbern, senior guard; Richard Coffey, senior forward; Jim Shikenjanski, senior center. Key Newcomers: Nate Tubbs, 6-6 freshman forward from Fort Wayne, Ind. Prognosis: The Golden Gophers and Clem Haskins return the entire starting line-up from last year's sweet-16 finalist. 20 Louisville Last Season: 24-9. Key Losses: Pervis Ellison, all-America center-forward, top-pick in N.B.A. draft; Kenny Payne, forward. Returning Starters: LaBradford Smith, junior guard; Tony Kimbro, senior forward; Keith Williams, senior guard. Key Newcomer: Jerome Harmon, 6-4 sophomore guard. Prognosis: Coach Crum needs to get more out of Kimbro, who was the nation's top prep player four years ago.

title: EVERYONE'S DAD WORKED THERE
description: NO STAR NIGHTS By Anna Egan Smucker. Illustrated by Steve Johnson. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Booksellers and Homicidal Maniacs
description: To the Editor If Carol Brenner, owner of the Murder Ink. mystery bookshop in New York. ''pasted paper over an offending torture scene in a book before she put it in the shelf of her store'' (as Marilyn Stasio reports in her Oct. 15 essay, ''The Homicidal Maniac: A Novelist's Best Friend''), she ought to be drummed out of the noble profession of bookselling. She certainly has the right to choose not to sell a book, but how can she justify defacing and censoring one? JANE HOEFFEL OTTE Belmont, Mass.

title: Ann R. Munigle To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Munigle of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mr. Munigle's daughter, Ann Radcliff Munigle, to Robert McAllister Lierle, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Lierle of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Delray Beach, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: Unplug Yourself And Tune In Nature Instead
description: PEOPLE don't really listen anymore. Not to nature, anyway. We just stuff our ears with wires as we jog along, or head for work. We tune out our neighbors, and, most of all, we tune out ourselves.

title: A SPECTACULAR FAILURE AT 13
description: THE QUEEN OF OCTOBER By Shelley Fraser Mickle. 301 pp. Chapel Hill, N.C.: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $15.95.

title: Emily Citrin Wed To Mark Glasberg
description: Emily Sara Citrin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Citrin of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Mark Jeffrey Glasberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Glasberg of Needham, Mass., were married last evening at the Fresh Meadows (Queens) Jewish Center. Rabbis Jerome Berkowitz and James Perman officiated.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: The Comrade on the Street; Russians See an Omen Of Their Own Progress
description: Soviet citizens hailed the end of the Berlin wall today as an omen, if not an outright prod, for even faster Soviet progress toward genuine democracy and economic recovery.

title: Post Office Fire in May Remains a Mystery
description: POSTAL INSPECTORS are seeking new leads in a puzzling case in which the Ossining Post Office was burglarized and set afire last May.

title: REAGAN'S DOMINOES
description: CROSSROADS Congress, the Reagan Administration, and Central America. By Cynthia J. Arnson. 275 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $27.95. Paper, $13.95.

title: Heather McClelland Wed
description: Heather Jean McClelland and Ross Evan Ampel, Dartmouth College graduates, were married yesterday at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton. Mayor Bernard Kettler of Woodcliff Lake officiated. Mrs. Ampel, 22 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Craig McClelland of Saddle River, N.J. Mr. Ampel, 23, is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Louis Ampel of Northbrook, Ill. He is a manufacturers' representative for Lewis Associates in Northbrook.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Happy Campers

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Student Co-op Votes to Close Dorm With a Past
description: Of all the houses owned by the University Students' Cooperative Association, Barrington Hall has attracted the most attention. Home for many University of California students who seek an alternative life style, the walls of its hallways are covered with bright murals painted by past generations of Barringtonians.

title: The World of Wearable Art
description: BORDERS BETWEEN the arts tend to be vague in New York. It's quite common to find the same artist moving from painting to sculpture and on to jewelry design. That range suggests the parameters of today's jewelry artists, who are fabricating complex, one-of-a-kind objects that translate the concerns of mainstream art into the language of silver and gold.

title: Bus Safety and Maintenance Scrutinized
description: A RECENT accident on the Garden State Parkway involving an Atlantic City-bound bus in which 38 passengers were injured and one was killed has focused attention on how well buses are maintained and how safely they are driven.

title: THE CRUSADE OF DR. ELDERS
description: Dr. Elders, the director of public health for the state of Arkansas, and Dr. Edith Irby Jones, the first black graduate of the University of Arkansas School of Medicine, have gracefully overcome enormous obstacles. As a young black female surgeon, I understand the difficulties they have faced and was delighted to see them honored by Steve Barnes's article. YVEDT L. MATORY,M.D. Chief Resident in Surgery Harvard-New England Deaconess Hospital Boston

title: Basins and Bowls From the Palaces Of Imperial China
description: Sir Percival David's 40-year pursuit of ceramics made from the Tang through Ching dynasties took him to Beijing several times in the 1920's and 30's. There he acquired extraordinary 10th- to 18th-century treasures installed for centuries in the palaces of China, some of which are on view in ''Imperial Taste: Chinese Ceramics From the Percival David Collection'' at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts. The show of 56 items remains here through Dec. 10 and will then travel to the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

title: Drug Agency Faults Customs in Cocaine Case
description: A week after Federal agents seized more than five tons of cocaine packed in barrels of lye in a Queens warehouse, no one had been arrested yesterday and Federal law-enforcement authorities said the search for at least five suspects had been hampered by a lack of communication between the Customs Service and the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: On-the-Job Training for Marathon Runner
description: RUSS JONES may be the fastest letter carrier in the nation, but that does not mean that people along his 10-mile route in East Camden get their mail delivered any sooner.

title:
MUSIC;
New Museum Hall Ready for Concerts
description: LEAD: AFTER three years without concerts, the reopening of the newly expanded Newark Museum will make it possible to resume a lively calendar of musical events in the museum's new Billy Johnson Auditorium. The auditorium, which was designed by the architect Michael Graves of Princeton, will have its debut as a concert hall next Sunday at 3 P

title: 'Another' Mascagni Work to Be Heard
description: IN company with a number of composers whose fame essentially rests on a single work (for example, Humperdinck with ''Hansel and Gretel'' or Leoncavallo with ''Pagliacci''), Pietro Mascagni is today remembered exclusively for his 1890 prize winner, ''Cavalleria Rusticana.''

title: Elizabeth Nesi Marries
description: Elizabeth Ann Nesi and Rodrigo Sierra Jr. were married last evening at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers. Mrs. Sierra, 25 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Nesi of Chalfont, Pa. A graduate of Sarah Lawrence College, she is a freelance translator. Mr. Sierra, 29, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rodrigo Sierra of Los Angeles. An undergraduate at New York University, he is the manager of computer operations for the Capital Cities/ABC Radio Network.

title: WHO NEEDS TCHAIKOVSKY?
description: SWAN LAKE By Mark Helprin. Illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. 80 pp. Boston: Ariel Books/Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95. (All Ages)

title: Jets' New Receivers Are in the Spotlight
description: Even with scorecards, fans at Giants Stadium today won't be able to tell much about all those new Jets' receivers wearing uniform numbers that start with ''8.''

title: THE CRUSADE OF DR. ELDERS
description: As a certified nurse-midwife, I, too, have come face to face with the heartbreak of early teen-age pregnancy. Many times, I've sat with young girls who have been hugging teddy bears or sucking their thumbs throughout labor. And often I've had to discharge their newborns, forcing myself not to ponder the kind of life that lies in store for them.

title: The Exotic Gardens Of New Zealand
description: LEAD: IN the last century, when New Zealand was being settled by the British, colonists set aside vast areas of newly plotted towns for parks and gardens. This was in keeping with a tradition that sent expeditions across the globe in search of colorful botanic specimens for the great public and private gardens of

title: Can the Rich And Famous Talk America Out of Drugs?
description: IN a speech last spring that was barely noticed in the capital but echoed loudly off the Hollywood Hills, President Bush blamed the entertainment industry's ''glorification or humorous treatment of narcotics'' for accelerating the national drug epidemic. Industry leaders anticipated another bashing recently when William J. Bennett, the Federal drug policy director, visited Hollywood.

title: NONFICTION
description: A MIND OF MY OWN: The Woman Who Was Known as Eve Tells the Story of Her Triumph Over Multiple Personality Disorder. By Chris Costner Sizemore. (Morrow, $19.95.) Chris Costner Sizemore was the subject of ''The Three Faces of Eve,'' the gripping book and movie about multiple personality disorder. In ''A Mind of My Own'' she recounts her events and tells how she met the challenge of living after the drama and spectacle of her mental illness were over. Not three but 22 separate entities had inhabited her body, three at a time, each with its own distinct voice, handwriting and personality. On the day in 1974 that she achieved ''unification'' after 44 years of illness, all 22 had been done away with. But she was then far from the integrated, energetic and effective woman she is today; she had no idea how to be herself, she missed her ''alters'' like Purple Lady and Strawberry Girl terribly and she felt guilty about her long-suffering family. Though her children were devoted, her husband was a silent stranger who felt used and angry over the poverty and other burdens her illness had placed on them. In the best part of her book, she tells of remaking the intimacy of her marriage and of learning, slowly, to be a mother her children could be proud of. She became a sought-after lecturer, painter and consultant to people with multiple personalities and a force in getting multiple personality disorder recognized as a bona fide mental illness. Ms. Sizemore's book brims with the fullness of the life she and her faithful family have made; it is a warmly satisfying end to a fascinating story.

title: PLAY BOOLANOOLA BALL!
description: THE ARABOOLIES OF LIBERTY STREET By Sam Swope. Illustrated by Barry Root. Unpaged. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: HE'S NO WILD MAN, HE'S MY BROTHER
description: VALENTINE & ORSON Written and illustrated by Nancy Ekholm Burkert. Unpaged. New York: A Floyd Yearout Book/Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Troubled Condo Started in New Rochelle
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION has begun at a former industrial site in New Rochelle on a once-troubled, scaled-down condominium development that now will include 84 units and 52 boat slips.

title: Chamber Musicians Put to Test
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH chamber music by any other name usually is still chamber music, a new series opening at 3 P.M. today at the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville may defy the sometimes somber, stuffy stereotype.

title: Evening Hours; Celebrating At Parties With A Purpose
description: Two extravaganzas dominated the social week.

title: WE COULD HAVE WON VIETNAM
description: LOST VICTORY A Firsthand Account of America's Sixteen-Year Involvement in Vietnam. By William Colby with James McCargar. Illustrated. 438 pp. Chicago: Contemporary Books. $22.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 10-year-old kitchen countertop is covered with plastic laminate in a butcher block pattern. The surfaces near the sink have become rough and feel coarse, and there are water stains on the surface. How may these areas be restored to their original condition?<

title: Auctioning Off the National Patrimony
description: Although world attention is focused on the drama of Communist reform, the statist systems of Latin America are undergoing an ideological restructuring that is no less radical than perestroika. New leaders like Argentina's Carlos Saul Menem and Mexico's Carlos Salinas de Gortari are bent on privatizing their economies and opening them to the international market. The fierce nationalism that once led the Latin American states to close their borders is giving way to the hope, not unlike Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's, of fully joining the world economy in order to develop.

title: Putting a Price on the Priceless in Manhattan
description: THE first thing would-be apartment buyers want to talk to brokers about is what their new place must have - a fireplace for coziness, big windows for light, views for pleasure and prestige, a location with cachet.

title: No Headline
description: PLEASURES OF A TANGLED LIFE By Jan Morris. 209 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title: Lisa A. Richter Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lawrence Richter of New York and Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Audrey Richter, to Jeffrey Asher Hagler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Hagler of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: Auschwitz Revisionism: An Israeli Scholar's Case
description: AT Auschwitz, it is inscribed in stone: four million people died in the Nazi camps. But Yehuda Bauer, one of the foremost historians of the Holocaust and a sworn enemy of those who deny its reality, says that the number of victims was less than half that.

title: Link Sought for a Medication And Surge of a Rare Disease
description: Experts are looking into the possibility that a surge of cases of a rare blood affliction in six states may be related to the dietary supplement L-Tryptophan, taken for premenstrual syndrome and sleeping disorder.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND CHILD ABUSE BUREAU;
Where the Abused Are Comforted, Privacy Is Not a Luxury
description: LEAD: OFFICE redecoration is generally considered a luxury, but when the office belongs to the Domestic Violence and Child Abuse Bureau of the County District Attorney's office, the physical layout takes on a more substantive importance.

title: Finding 'Generic Americans' for Television
description: LEAD: EMPLOYEES at the new office building at 300 Atlantic Street in Stamford were no doubt surprised to find on morning recently that they had to pay a 10-cent toll to use the walkway connecting the garage to the building where they worked.

title: ...And for the Environment And the Beauty of Nature
description: I WAS settled comfortably into a seat on the New Haven train to Pelham after having spent a day in New York City when the man next to me did something that shocked me. He finished a cup of frozen yogurt and then put the dirty spoon and empty container on the floor.

title: G.O.P. Retains Dominance in Nassau
description: LEAD: IN elections marked by upsets, Long Island voters last week reconfirmed Republican dominance in Nassau County and gave a Republican and Conservative coalition a one-vote majority in the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: Giants' Receivers Are Lost in Rush
description: A year ago, the Giants rushed the ball 49 percent of the time. This year, with an 8-1 record, they are rushing 60 percent of the time.

title: Wilde's 'Earnest' With a Rarely Staged Episode
description: ''IT is perfectly phrased!'' declares a Victorian gentleman, Algernon Moncrieff, in defense of an epigram he has just tossed off. ''And quite as true as any observation in civilized life should be.'' In ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' the perfect phrase is all. Style is substance. Ergo, it is facile to dismiss Oscar Wilde's masterpiece of high artifice as frippery for the delectation of dilettantes.

title: Youth Vote: Sleeping Giant of Politics in India
description: Seasoned party bosses who have dominated Indian politics for decades have a new task in 1989. They must compete for the votes of a new electorate of 35 million or more voters from 18 to 21 years of age, enfranchised under a law passed this year.

title: CAN CAPITAL FROM WALL STREET BUOY MINORITY VENTURE POOLS?
description: A vital source of venture capital for minority companies is shrinking. Minority Enterprise Small Business Investment Companies, which lend to and invest in minority-owned ventures with money raised from private investors and borrowed from the Small Business Administration, have invested a total of more than $750 million in nearly 9,000 companies since 1978, including the buyout of McCall Pattern Company by Reginald Lewis and, more recently, Emerge, a black magazine that made its debut in September.

title:
FOCUS: Philadelphia;
City Seeks to Channel Growth With Zoning
description: LEAD: CITY planners here are putting the finishing touches on zoning changes that would encourage developers to build office space along the business district's northern edge while making large development in its southern section less attractive. It would be done by regulating the width and height of buildings.

title: Foreign Inroads Aside, Manhattan Is Still American
description: DESPITE the purchase of a hefty share of Rockefeller Center, the citadel of one of America's great business dynasties, by a Japanese company, foreign investors are still far from pushing Americans off the real estate map of Manhattan.

title: Two Archbishops, Old and New, Symbolize Conflict in the Brazilian Church
description: Several years ago, during a crowded meeting at the bishop's palace here, Helder Camara, then Recife's Roman Catholic Archbishop, persuaded a weary peasant to sit in the only empty seat - the bishop's throne.

title: FORGIVING THE POPULAR PAINTINGS
description: PAINTINGS IN THE MUSEE D'ORSAY By Robert Rosenblum. Illustrated. 686 pp. New York: Stewart, Tabori & Chang. $95.

title: CAmpus Life: Penn; 'Tigers' Attacked, And Princeton Gets an Apology
description: Investigations and apologies have followed an attack on Princeton University tiger mascots by more than 30 University of Pennsylvania fans last weekend at a football game here.

title: SPEECHWRITERS AND POLITICIANS
description: One of my rules is never to buy a ''kiss and tell'' book. I figure that when one is being paid to do a job, then loyalty and trust are part of the package. However, I feel inclined to bend my rule after reading your excerpt from Peggy Noonan's book. The lady can really write, and I found her honest, albeit irreverent, observations a delight. I'll be especially vulnerable if I spot a book jacket with her mischievous eyes looking back at me. MAURICE L. KELLEY JR. Sewickley, Pa.

title: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF COCTEAU AND DRACULA
description: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF ANDY WARHOL By Victor Bockris. Illustrated. 392 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95. WARHOL By David Bourdon. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $49.50.

title: Lazy Days in a Baja Town
description: OUTSIDE Rubens restaurant in San Felipe, a town of 18,000 people in Baja California, stands a hand-lettered sign in English - ''The only way to live happy in San Felipe the months of July and August is crazy drunk and nude.'' The local constabulary frowns on such behavior, but they have no quarrel with the sentiment. Temperatures can climb to 120 degrees.

title: BEYOND DAMNATION OR DEFENSE: THE MIDDLE YEARS
description: NIXON Volume Two: The Triumph of a Politician, 1962-1972. By Stephen E. Ambrose. Illustrated. 736 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $24.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ON HER OWN. By Naomi Bliven. (Grove, $19.95.) '' 'Ah, Mother,' Alida cried, 'you never understand me!' '' It's the summer of 1975 and Alida Waterman Kelly, the heroine of Naomi Bliven's enjoyable first novel, has left her unfaithful husband and gone home to Mother - and to the embracing womb of Mother's spacious Connecticut estate.

title: Review/Pop; A Duo's Way With Wit
description: In pop songwriting, a little humor can do wonders, especially for material that has a political point of view. Timbuk 3, a folk-blues duo from Austin, Tex., and Phranc, a feminist songwriter from Southern California, who appeared together at the Bottom Line on Monday evening, understand the value of keeping a light touch. Both write and perform socially concerned songs that have enough irony and self-effacing wit to avoid sounding sanctimonious or didactic.

title: Major Promoters Vying For Jones Beach Shows
description: LEAD: A DAVID and Goliath showdown is looming over who will get a license to book entertainment at the Jones Beach Theater in the 1990's.

title: For Florio, Fiscal Issues Top Agenda
description: GOVERNOR-ELECT James J. Florio will not have much time to savor his victory on Tuesday. Just ahead is the transition period when he said he hoped to begin his promised audit of state spending.

title: Miss Sidd Weds Hendrik Kopperl
description: At the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y., Patricia Joan Sidd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Sidd of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Hendrik Delano Kopperl, a son of Paul Burger Kopperl of West Stockbridge, Mass., and New York, and Mrs. Henry Safrit of San Francisco. Judge Robert Friedman of White Plains City Court officiated.

title: ARAB GIRLS' VEILS AT ISSUE IN FRANCE
description: The question of whether girls may wear Iranian-style veils to school has become a heated political controversy in this most secular of Western European countries.

title: No Shortage of Takers as Indians Start Trade Talks on Carter
description: Joe Carter did not hit a home run, drive in a run or even swing a bat; he wasn't even on the premises. Yet he was clearly the star of the general managers' annual fall meetings here last week.

title: Striking Workers Held in Phone Vandalism
description: Two employees on strike from the New York Telephone Company have been arrested on charges of preparing to set fire to a telephone cable box at Seaford High School, the police said today.

title: From Seas Around the World
description: ''WITH its brilliant greeny-blue back marked with dark curving lines, its metallic sides and white belly, the mackeral is a handsome fish. One might almost describe it as flashy in appearance, noticing that the French name maqueraeu also means 'pimp' and that in the past mackeral was a term for dandy in England.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Manchester, N.H.;
Rejuvenating Stalled Projects
description: LEAD: TROUBLED residential condominium projects have become commonplace here since the hot real estate market of the mid-1980's cooled off. But two of these projects have been taken over by a former equity partner and a lender, who are rejuvenating them.

title: Notre Dame Reaches 22d and a Record
description: Notre Dame surpassed a school record today with its 22d consecutive victory, a 59-6 rout of overmatched Southern Methodist University.

title: January Wedding For Miss Brodkin
description: Dr. and Mrs. Roger Harrison Brodkin of Short Hills, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Brodkin, to Hugh Jonathan Brauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Brauer of Convent Station, N.J., and Aspen, Colo. A January wedding is planned.

title: Finance Law Called a Partial Success
description: New York City's campaign-finance law, one of the first in the nation, has emerged from its first test graded only a partial success and may undergo changes before the next municipal election.

title: U.S.-German Pair Lead Bridge Tournament
description: A West German woman has a good chance of becoming the first player from that country to win a major contract bridge title on this side of the Atlantic. Going into the two final sessions of the Life Master Women's Pair Championships here this afternoon, Sabina Zenkel, now living in Chicago, headed the field with Rhoda Walsh of Encino, Calif.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Reunion in West Berlin; For All, East and West, A Day Like No Other
description: The great reunion party was not limited to East Germans. While the ''Ossis'' romped through the shopping boulevards and department stores, ''Wessies'' and tourists gathered at the wall they had decorated so brightly over the years with layer upon layer of bright graffiti to sing, stare and often to chip off a piece to take home.

title: Couple Found Dead in Park After Burglary at Their Home
description: The bodies of a General Motors executive and his wife were found Friday in a park in nearby Pontiac, where they had apparently been dumped after being shot several times by intruders who robbed them and ransacked their house here in early morning, the police and Federal agents said.

title: Children Bring Magic to the Arts
description: THE Kidz Kompany, a musical and theatrical company of 8- to 16-year-olds that evolved from the Westport presentation last year of the composer Paul Hindemith's musical play for children, ''Let's Build a Town,'' has set four shows for the Westport Arts Center at 2 and 4 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Scouting Elevators
description: In one of the few moments he stopped scurrying round the lounge, the lobby and the grounds of the Doubletree Resort last week, Roland Hemond shrugged and said: ''That's always been my style. I can't change. You just try to make things happen.''

title: THAI CHIEF CANCELS TRIP OVER TYPHOON
description: The Thai Prime Minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, has canceled state visits to the United States, Japan and Denmark so that he can deal with the aftermath of a typhoon that has left nearly 400 people dead, with another 400 still missing.

title: Get Somebody Else to Do It
description: For people who love to shop, New York City is the promised land. If it exists, you can probably find it here. But for those who hateshopping - or who do not have the time to trudge from store to store battling crowds - it's even better. There's no place where it's easier to get somebody else to do it for you. The city offers a wide range of services designed to save you stress, and even money.

title: IN THE WAKE OF THE GREAT WHITE WHALE
description: JOURNALS By Herman Melville. Edited by Howard C. Horsford with Lynn Horth. Illustrated. 683 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press and the Newberry Library. Cloth,

title: Balboni Stays
description: Evidently, he provided enough blasts from the past to make him something of a fixture for the immediate future, so yesterday the Yankees signed their designated hitter Steve Balboni to a two-year contract, and retained an option on the deal for the 1992 season.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Hudson Valley Wind Symphony misidentified a player and his instrument. He was Jim Baughman; he played a baritone, not a tuba.

title: Lost Lessons: Regard for Others...
description: RECENTLY, I watched a man in a neatly pressed suit finish his newspaper and morning coffee just as the train pulled into Grand Central Terminal. He placed the newspaper on the seat and deposited the stained coffee cup, now stuffed with a crumpled napkin, on the floor in the aisle. As the train lurched to a stop, he got up to leave and never once looked badk at the clearly visible trash he had left behind.

title: Faye Rosedietcher Married
description: Faye Rosedietcher, a co-owner of Impact Recruiting, a Manhattan personnel agency, and Alan Bazilian, the owner of Bazilian's Department Store in West Hartford, Conn., were married last evening at the Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Orkland officiated. Mrs. Bazilian, 33 years old, is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rosedietcher. She graduated cum laude from the State University of New York at Oneonta. A graduate of the University of Connecticut, Mr. Bazilian, 43, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bazilian of West Palm Beach, Fla. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Review/Dance; New Works From 4 Choreographers
description: The Salon Project, organized by Susan Osberg and Joan Duddy, is an admirable attempt to provide choreographers with opportunities to show new works in varied styles. Last Sunday night at the Dia Art Foundation, four choreographers participated in a program under the project's auspices, and their dances ranged from depictions of physical and mental instability to commentaries on survival and enlightenment. The dances about managing to stay on one's feet proved more satisfying than the ones about falling apart.

title: To the Rescue of America's Silent Films
description: It could only happen in America. When moviegoers in 1923 fainted while watching Harold Lloyd dangle from clock hands high atop a skyscraper in ''Safety Last,'' some theaters did the only sensible thing: they hired a nurse.

title: POLICEMAN'S TRIAL STALLED IN MIAMI
description: The manslaughter trial of a white police officer who shot a black motorcyclist to death last January has ground to a halt over a defense challenge to the seating of a black juror.

title: Review/Pop; Wrenching Songs Of Love
description: Courtly, exalted, dangerous love -an all-consuming passion whose bearers burn and suffer and risk death -fills the songs of Isabel Pantoja, a Spanish pop singer who performed to an adoring crowd on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater. Song after song, audience members proffered flowers; admirers handed her notes, and photographers mobbed the stage.

title: Happy Trails: 13 Racers' Favorite Runs
description: WHAT is your favorite ski trail? Without hesitation, 13 top ski competitors from the past and present answered that question and described their favorite alpine run, slope or trail. Although a few of these great skiers have returned to their selected trail, many remember the place for the moment, the feeling, the environment, the challenge of one run or one day. All of them recall the beauty of the mountain experience and the pleasure of simply being there to ski the trail. ANDREA MEAD LAWRENCE First American woman to win two Olympic gold medals, in the slalom and giant slalom - in the l952 Games. MAMMOTH MOUNTAIN, CALIF. Paranoid Flat Length of Trail: 2.5 miles Vertical Drop: 2,300 feet

title: Sibelius, and Those Other Fellows From Finland
description: There is more to Finnish music than the substantial output of Jean Sibelius, and several recent releases offer an encouraging view of his successors without taking anything away from the stature of the man himself. But the master's own works continue to be popular in the recording studio, with two new performances of his Violin Concerto, for example, having been released recently.

title: Fred J. Howard, Banker, 69
description: Fred J. Howard, executive vice president of Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, died of a heart attack Friday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Are Hostile Acts by Youth on the Increase?
description: LEAD: A YOUNG man involved with drugs regularly broke into his mother's house to steal from her. One night, his mother was home when he arrived, and so he beat her, took her money and left.

title: John Burlingame Weds Bebe Irish
description: The marriage of Mary Brigham Irish, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Irish of Chatham Township, N.J., to John Myover Burlingame, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Homer Burlingame 3d of South Orleans, Mass., took place yesterday at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bay Head, N.J. The Rev. Peter Krebs officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. John Wilson, a Congregational minister. Mrs. Burlingame, known as Bebe, is a graduate of the University of New Hampshire. She is an administrative coordinator at the law firm of Katten Muchin & Zavis in Chicago. Her father is a partner at Alex Brown & Sons, investment bankers in New York. Her mother, Joan Irish, is a sales associate with Burgdorff Realtors in Chatham.

title: THE CRUSADE OF DR. ELDERS
description: Joycelyn Elders's crusade is motivated by an experience many years ago, when she failed to help a young girl who was being sexually abused by family members (''The Crusade of Dr. Elders,'' by Steve Barnes, Oct. 15).

title: CONSUMER RATES
Q and A
description: New Year's Eve in Paris

title: Kathryn Foerst Weds R. C. Bill
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York yesterday, Kathryn Judith Ann Foerst, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John George Foerst Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., was married to Robert Charles Bill, a son of Robert Edmund Bill of Garden City, L.I., and Judith Ann Bill of St. Louis.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HOPES AND IMPEDIMENTS: Selected Essays. By Chinua Achebe. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Throughout this brilliant collection, the Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe seems, in a quiet way, to fancy himself continental Africa's answer to the American cultural critic James Baldwin. ''Hopes and Impediments'' opens with a clearly worded examination of Joseph Conrad's ''Heart of Darkness'' that hammers the author for perpetuating ''comforting'' - and racist - myths about Africa.

title: Global Warming Means New Global Politics
description: UNTIL recently, politicians who wanted to avoid the issue of global warming could duck behind the scientific uncertainties. Now, with soaring public concern for the environment and wide scientific agreement about the nature if not the timing of the problem, the debate has shifted. The question is no longer whether the threat is real, but rather how fast it needs to be countered and at what expense.

title: A Cub Correction
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: JUST ANOTHER NIGHT ON CRACK STREET
description: THE HEAVYSET UNDERCOVER POLICEMAN pushed me across the ice-cream counter, spreading my legs and poking me around the groin. As he came dangerously close to the bulge in my right pocket I hissed in his ear, ''It's a tape recorder.'' He snapped backward, releasing his grip on my neck, whispering a barely audible, ''Sorry.'' Apparently he thought I was an undercover cop from another department. Before I could get a close look at him, he had left the bodega, a grocery store-cum-numbers joint.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 5 about the Nicaraguan Government's cancellation of its cease-fire with the contras incompletely paraphrased a statement by Paul Reichler, a Washington attorney for the Sandinistas. He said that the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, had to improve the preparedness of the Sandinista armed forces in the face of ''an intolerable military situation.''

title: Reports From a Broadway-Bound Gypsy
description: The 30th-anniversary production of ''Gypsy,'' with its now-legendary music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Stephen Sondheim and book by Arthur Laurents, hit the road April 23, after a four-week rehearsal period in New York City, with Mr. Laurents as director. The 15,000-mile road tour would take the company of 34 performers, 24 musicians and 46 crew members to 14 cities over the next six months.

title: Lifestyle; For Wardrobes, the Revolving Door Turns Anew
description: Carla Mikell's clothes are back from summer camp, so to speak, and are scattered like unwelcome guests all over her small one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Education Priorities Seem Destructive
description: Concerning ''Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education'' (Sept. 24), as a concerned mother of three who have gone through the public school system, Oh boy, are we paying the price! And not only financially.

title:
GARDENING;
Fallen Leaves and Autumnal Tasks
