description: LEAD: NOW that the leaves have fallen, many gardeners still face the task of cleaning up. All too often that involves raking the leaves by hand, packing them into plastic bags and placing them by the curb to be picked up and hauled to a landfill. Not only does this contribute to the problem of diminishing space in landfills, but it is also ecologically unsound and, for the most part, unnecessary.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week end Oct. 28 MANHATTAN Chelsea $245,000 456 West 23d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 980-sq.-ft. prewar co-op in a brownstone; dining area, fireplace, hardwood floors, rear garden; maintenance $877, 53% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Greenwich Village $320,000 299 West 12th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. prewar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining foyer, sunken-living room, windowed kitchen; common charge $375, taxes $2,064 (Broker: Kanelba & Robilotti) Upper West Side $410,000 12 West 72d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, renovated kitchen, terrace, Central Park view; maintenance $1,200, 62% tax-deductible (Broker: The Halstead Property Group) Upper West Side $1.275 million 322 Central Park West (92d St.) 3-bedroom, 4-bath, 2,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining room, maid's room, fireplace, large, windowed kitchen, Central Park view; maintenance $1,800, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) Washington Heights $155,000 255 Cabrini Boulevard 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,080-sq.-ft. prewar condo; part-time doorman, renovated kitchen and baths, Hudson River view; common charge $321, taxes $574 (Broker: Simone Song Properties) BRONX Gun Hill Road Area $170,000 747 Bartholdi Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, brick house, dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $800 (Broker: Tryax Realty) Riverdale $275,000 2727 Palisade Avenue (High Point) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, terrace, pool, Hudson River view; maintenance $906, 40% tax deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) BROOKLYN Kensington $73,500 179 Ocean Parkway 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 720-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining area, renovated kitchen and bath, hardwood floors; maintenance $286, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Brooklyn Properties of 7th Avenue) Park Slope $239,500 117 Sterling Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2,625-sq.-ft. prewar duplex co-op; dining area, fireplace, high ceilings, renovated kitchen and bath; maintenance $753, 75% tax-deductible (Broker: Warren Lewis Realty) Prospect Heights $114,000 34 Plaza Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, hardwood floors; maintenance $353, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: John P. Barry Real Estate) QUEENS Corona $370,000 106-29 49th Avenue 3-family, attached brick house; dining room, balcony in upper-floor units; 2 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths, large kitchen in each; 2-car garage, 22- by 80-ft. lot; taxes $740 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) Hollis $159,000 89-35 185th Street 2-family, detached, aluminum-sided house; 2 bedrooms, 2 baths, large kitchen in both units; full basement, 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $960 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) STATEN ISLAND Randall Manor $240,000 4 Brentwood Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached broadside ranch; dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $1,380 (Broker: Salmon Real Estate) Travis $140,000 37 Meredith Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, enclosed porch, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $226 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency)

title: Organ Transplants Are Now Performed at Medical Center
description: IN the early-morning hours of Oct. 8, Bruce H. Richards, a White Plains resident, underwent a kidney transplant operation his doctors described as ''routine'' and ''uneventful.''

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Last call to set out bulbs. Keep up with leaf raking and composting. Mow the lawn short - about one-inch; clean, store and cover the mower. The Meadow

title: Living With Style; Crumbs in the Covers
description: IT MAY CONJURE UP IMAGES OF A PRIM WHITE WICKER tray, a rose in a bud vase, neatly trimmed toast and well-polished silver - all the fantasies of a hotel advertisement. In fact, eating in bed is a precarious activity. Crumbs are an obvious hazard. So are tippy soups, wayward sauces and small, slippery morsels. But those who relish their meals in bed face these challenges fearlessly.

title: Impossible Brew
description: To the Editor:

title: Gauging the Aftershocks Of Disaster Coverage
description: Now that some time has passed since the recent California earthquake, one can see more clearly how television has remade the cultural landscape. Nowadays, disasters happen twice - first live, then on television. As with assassinations, hostage crises and other unscripted traumas, television immediately crowds into experience and reshapes it. Even victims become voyeurs.

title: Maryland Kick Ties Penn State
description: Maryland ended a 24-game losing streak against Penn State when Dan DeArmas kicked his second field goal of the game, a 26-yarder with 58 seconds to play, to lift the Terrapins into a 13-13 tie with the Nittany Lions.

title: Like His Team, Tarkanian Is Always on the Run
description: ''Athletically we are not a bandit school, we are not an outlaw school. We're good academically, that's been documented. We've made mistakes, like other people. But we're not outlaw, we're not crooked.'' - Dr. Robert Maxson, president, University of Nevada-Las Vegas.

title: Ms. Zimmerman Becomes a Bride
description: At the Metropolitan Club in New York, Jamie R. Zimmerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin D. Zimmerman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Geoffrey D. Chazen, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Eric Chazen of Nashville. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky officiated.

title: Tips for the Thwarted Consumer
description: THE $68 WALKING SHOES were just six months old when the sole of the left one cracked across the ball of the foot. A few days later, sales slip in hand, I returned to the shop where I bought them. The same clerk who had sold me the shoes offered a store credit for the defective pair and said they would be returned to the manufacturer. I looked around for a replacement pair, but when I couldn't find any I liked the shop manager suggested that I wait for a new shipment, due in about four weeks. I agreed.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
A 'Gateway' Cranks Up
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION on a 10-story office building and site preparation for other structures has begun on the Portals, the largest public-private commercial project ever undertaken in the District of Columbia.

title: Silver Pieces With Elegant Pasts And New Uses
description: IT all started with room service 25 years ago, Ginger Kilbane said. ''I was on business in Italy and stayed at the Excelsior Hotel in Rome,'' she recalled, ''and this chunky little coffee pot was on my breakfast tray every morning. I had to buy that pot.''

title: If Rules Aren't Broken, Don't Fix Them
description: The question coaches always ask is, ''Am I responsible for every student that I bring to the campus?'' What about the youngster who decides to transfer to another school, or the youngster who comes to college and after a year or so decides this is not what he wants to do? The important thing is that the graduation rates should be monitored on the basis of whether the youngster actually gets a degree, not whether it took four years, five years, or six years.

title: Williams Perfect For First Time
description: The ball lay on the 11-yard line, the clock read 57 seconds, and history was an arm's length away. Ken Dilanian picked up the football, cradled it to his chest and guaranteed that Williams College would not let its historic moment slip.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: The White House; Exchange With Gorbachev Leaves Bush Hopeful
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has sent President Bush a message supporting the changes taking place in East Germany and expressing hope that the situation will remain ''calm and peaceful,'' the White House spokesman said today.

title: Docudramas Are No Worse Than TV News; Mystery Source
description: To the Editor:

title: Equal Time For Atheists
description: To the Editor:

title: Tempos That Tell More Than Time
description: Three recent albums of almost nonstop brilliance by the pianist Andrew Hill, 52 years old, the alto saxophonist Frank Morgan, 55, and the flugelhornist Art Farmer, 61, are good examples of how, for jazz musicians, age amplifies control. The critic Hugh Kenner once wrote that art is the accumulation of detail; in jazz, detail derives from constant playing and the experience that comes with age.

title: Women Win Quiet Victories In Equitable Pay
description: PAY equity victories have been and will continue to be won at the negotiating table rather than in the courts.

title: Nobody Lives Happily Ever After
description: To the Editor:

title: Relief Group in Salvador Reports Repression
description: At the headquarters of the National Union of Earthquake Victims here, the holes the soldiers made when they smashed in walls, ceilings and windows are still visible months later. Out in the patio, damaged food, medicine and clothing, some of it showing burn or water marks, remains piled up, awaiting distribution.

title: FICTION
description: OUTLAW. By Warren Kiefer. (Donald I. Fine, $19.95.) Lee Garland, the narrator and title character in Warren Kiefer's fourth novel, has a cowboy drawl and his saga of some 90 years begins, circa 1894 in the New Mexico Territory, with tales of a hoof-pounding, hair-raising, cattle-rustling adolescence that's the stuff of boyhood dreams. But this novel in the form of an autobiographical monologue moves beyond its milieu to link traditional Western themes with the breadth of American experience. At the outbreak of the Spanish-American War, Lee and an assortment of rowdy frontier characters are thrown together with the privileged sons of Eastern millionaires and stockbrokers in a regiment led by Col. Teddy Roosevelt, soon to be famed as the Rough Riders. Mr. Kiefer vividly re-creates the battlefield heroics of these men, even while conveying the strong impression that, given the incompetence of their generals and the sheer misery inflicted by disease, lack of food and barbarous weaponry, it's amazing any of them survived. After brief postwar flings with New York high society and Albuquerque banking, Lee heads for adventure in the oil-rich jungles of Tampico, Mexico. Although much of the energy in ''Outlaw'' comes from this remarkable era in history, when risk-takers and visionaries reaped astonishing rewards, the crises of Lee's domestic life are treated with perspective; adventures with exploding oil rigs and Mexican revolutionaries, though numerous, are not allowed to overshadow the tragic loss of a child. The narrative pace falters somewhat in the last hundred pages, but throughout his ups and downs Lee remains a rough-humored, itchy seeker of self-defined justice, hell-bent on living an authentic life. As such, he is an appropriate narrator for this keenly American adventure tale, a saga that stirs the imagination and satisfies the heart. REBECCA SINGLETON

title: WHO HAS TIME FOR SELF-DOUBT?
description: RIGHT PLACES, RIGHT TIMES Forty Years in Journalism Not Counting My Paper Route. By Hedley Donovan. Illustrated. 463 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $27.95.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Goals of the Newcomers; A Search for Work and for Housing As the Emigres Get Their Bearings
description: There were no speeches, champagne or applause at Bonn-Beuel station this morning, just cups of hot coffee handed out by Red Cross volunteers to revive the tired bodies of some 900 East Germans who traveled here overnight from Czecholovakia.

title: Miss Fallek Wed To Keith Locker
description: Stacey Sharon Fallek, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fallek of Roslyn, L.I., was married last evening to Keith Michael Locker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Locker of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahn officiated at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Royal Couple Of the King Of Instruments
description: In May of 1975, Maurice Durufle and his wife, Marie-Madeleine Durufle Chevalier, might have been one of the world's happiest couples. They had shared 22 years together, and plenty of professional success: Each was renowned as a virtuoso organist, and their joint recitals on both sides of the Atlantic had drawn raves from critics and other organists. Durufle had also achieved renown as a composer: his Requiem is one of the most-loved choral works composed in the 20th century and helped to make his name far more familiar than his lifetime output of only 13 compostions would seem to warrant.

title: HOME ENTERTANMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Wagner: 'Parsifal' Excerpts, 'Siegfried Idyll' Bayreuth Festival Chorus and Orchestra conducted by Karl Muck (Acts I and II excerpts, ''Idyll''; Columbia, 1927). Gotthelf Pistor, tenor; Cornelis Brongeest, baritone; Ludwig Hofmann, bass; Berlin State Opera Chorus and Orchestra conducted by Muck (Act III; Electrola, 1927-28). Opal CDS 9843; two CD's only. The performance of Act III, virtually complete, dates from the early years of electric recordings, but in some ways has never been surpassed. The sound is remarkably good despite inevitable surface noise. Muck's Wagner, a wonderful combination of flowing melody, intensity and precision, is still a model for ''Parsifal'' interpreters. Hofmann brings a nobility to Gurnemanz that puts one in mind of Hans Hotter in his prime. Muck's ''Parsifal'' is less solemnly paced and not so murkily mystical as more recent versions modeled on the Hans Knappertsbusch recordings from Bayreuth. But for a ''Parsifal'' enthusiast this historic collection, bringing together every scrap of the work Muck ever recorded (nearly two hours), is enough to justify the CD revolution. - Donal Henahan Richard Strauss: 'Metamorphosen,' 'Duett-Concertino,' 'Capriccio' Prelude New Stockholm Chamber Orchestra conducted by Esa-Pekka Salonen. CBS MK 44702; CD and cassette. It is an almost subversive idea to entrust the last creative breaths of Richard Strauss to a 31-year-old conductor. Esa-Pekka Salonen's hot-blooded surges of tempo and heavily emphasized caesuras represent perhaps the antithesis of Strauss's inspired weariness. On the other hand, they also say things of value about how life passes from the old back to the young. Strauss's music here uses dense textures to create the impression of simplicity. The ''Duett-Concertino'' seems a pointed reference to Mozart, the ''Capriccio'' music is delicately wistful, and the great ''Metamorphosen'' breathes with nostalgia and regret. The Stockholm strings play very well. - Bernard Holland Dvorak: Violin Concerto (Op. 53); 'Romance' (Op. 11) Kyung-Wha Chung, violin; Philadelphia Orchestra conducted by Riccardo Muti. EMI/Angel 7 49858; CD and cassette. Midori, violin; New York Philharmonic conducted by Zubin Mehta (with ''Carnaval''). CBS Masterworks MK 44923; CD and cassette. Whether you consider the truncated recapitulation of the concerto's first movement a novel expedient or a structural blunder (as did the violinist Joseph Joachim, who refused to perform it after offering Dvorak considerable advice on its composition), you can't deny the luscious beauty of the work as a whole. Kyung-Wha Chung's interpretation, though thoroughly engaging at first hearing, seems restrained next to Midori's. Midori's full-blooded playing and exquisitely pliant tone are intoxicating, especially in the second movement, where her phrasing and coloration truly touch the heart. Moreover the higher volume level and generally more open sound of the CBS disk add to the overall sense of aural presence. - Barrymore L. Scherer Puccini: Songs, Hymns Placido Domingo, tenor; Julius Rudel, piano, organ. CBS Masterworks MK 44981; CD and cassette. Michael Kaye, the author of the valuable study ''The Unknown Puccini'' (Oxford University Press, 1987), has provided texts, translations and helpful annotations for this interesting release. Included are two religious hymns with organ accompaniment, a sketch for an operatic scene (''Mentia l'Avviso''), the bombastic ''Inno a Roma'' and several brief rarities written for various occasions. For the most part, they are early efforts. The winners are the Tosti-like ''A Te,'' the charming lullaby ''E l'Uccellino'' and the ardent ''Solo e Amore,'' which eventually found its way into the third act of ''La Boheme.'' When the range is comfortable, Placido Domingo is his warm-toned, manly, confident self. But some of his sustained notes are uncharacteristically wavery, and the top is sometimes effortful. - George Jellinek Britten: 'War Requiem' Lorna Haywood, soprano; Anthony Rolfe Johnson, tenor; Benjamin Luxon, baritone; Atlanta Symphony Chorus and Orchestra conducted by Robert Shaw. Telarc 80157; two CD's only. Composed for the 1962 consecration of the new Coventry Cathedral in England (which replaced a medieval building destroyed in World War II), this work is rivaled perhaps only by Penderecki's ''Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima'' as the most searing musical indictment of warfare. Unlike Berlioz and Verdi, who contemplate the spiritual majesty of death, or Brahms and Faure, who celebrate the peace of eternal rest, Britten juxtaposes the Latin Requiem text with poetry by Wilfred Owen to address not so much death as the horror of man's useless killing. Britten's own recording of the work has long been the standard, but this performance by the elder statesman of choral conductors is as vital and as moving. Telarc's sound is superb. - B. L. S. POP/JAZZ Miriam Makeba: 'Welela' Mercury 838 208; all three formats. Revitalized after her magnificent 1988 album of traditional South African songs, ''Sangoma,'' Miriam Makeba mixes old and new on ''Welela,'' using a polished modern production to carry recent and traditional songs. Over rolling vamps steeped in South African pop (and, for one song, in Mexican pop), Miss Makeba looses her grainy, indomitable voice, sometimes riding the harmonies of a hearty chorale. Miss Makeba's repertory is pointedly political alongside her traditional songs, but she puts melody ahead of preaching. The lilt of ''A Luta Continua,'' a tribute to Mozambique, makes it one of the most infectious agitprop songs of the decade. - Jon Pareles Michael Feinstein: 'The M-G-M Album' Elektra 9-60893; all three formats. From musicologist to cabaret performer to Broadway entertainer to old-fashioned pop crooner, Michael Feinstein's musical identity has added many layers in the last five years. On ''The M-G-M Album,'' a collection of songs introduced in M-G-M musicals between 1929 and 1969, he shows he has found a comfortable balance between heart-on-the-sleeve cabaret singing and the rather chilly pop crooning of his last album, ''Isn't It Romantic.'' While he lacks the projection to chew the scenery with numbers like ''That's Entertainment,'' his ballad singing, especially Leslie Bricusse's ''You and I,'' is strong and heartfelt. And Ian Bernard's orchestral arrangements offer a confident stylistic hybrid of movie-musical soundtracks and 50's studio pop. - Stephen Holden The Rev. Lonnie Farris: 'Vocal and Steel Guitar' Eden Records 3-200; LP only (available from Down Home Music, 10341 San Pablo Avenue, El Cerrito, Calif. 94530). Recorded in Los Angeles in the early 1960's, the album captures an American oddity in action. The Rev. Lonnie Farris, a thunder-voiced gospel singer who could sing sweetly, also plays steel guitar. To hear him, backed by an ambling and slightly disheveled gospel rhythm section, the Gospel Flames, is a treat. ''All right, guitar,'' he calls to himself before quivering his way through the melody on guitar, mixing the sound of Hawaii with deep blues and gospel. He is joined by other singers, and an occasional full and robust tenor saxophone as well. - Peter Watrous 'Get With the Beat: The Mar-Vel' Masters' Rykodisc 20126; CD and cassette. From 1949 to 1966, Mar-Vel' Records in Calumet City, Ill., recorded the music of rural Southerners who had recently migrated north, paralleling black blues musicians in nearby Chicago. To judge by the 27 songs on ''Get With the Beat,'' Mar-Vel' brought out a loopy humor, sometimes verging on dementia, in its roster of obscure Midwestern rockabillies. Ginny Carter in ''Seven Lonely Days'' manages to weep and yodel simultaneously; Bobby Sisco's ''Honky Tonkin' Rhythm'' has a steel-guitar solo worthy of a 1980's Lower East Side noise band. Twangy guitars and songs about itchy feet and hot lips and jumpin' all night summon not oldies nostalgia, but astonishment at American music's wild-eyed abundance. - J. P. The Lilac Time: 'Paradise Circus' Polygram 838 641; all three formats. Gentleness can be deceptive. The Lilac Time's lulling acoustic-guitar strums, brushed drums and tender harmonies dress their folk-pop in irresistible softness; the vocalist Stephen Duffy sings the word ''love'' like a 17-year-old in the first blush of it. But his lyrics have an understated wittiness that belies the la-la lushness of the songs: ''I love you through the diesel fumes,'' he pledges in ''The Girl Who Waves at Trains,'' as if even soot couldn't cloud his rosy vision. The title track is an accordion instrumental taken from Wim Wenders's film ''Wings of Desire'' - this Birmingham (England) trio has an affinity for sounds that are sweetly melancholic. - Karen Schoemer

title: 'Out of the Cold'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT
description: LEAD: FICTION THE CHYMICAL WEDDING. By Lindsay Clarke. (Knopf, $19.95.) There is something old-fashioned and surprising about a contemporary novel like ''The Chymical Wedding,'' which undertakes to solve the crises of materialism, sexism and nuclear destruction through a sweeping, sincere and unironic examination of the regenerative powers of love and the arcane quests of alchemy.

title: Where Does Sports Fit In the Curriculum?
description: In ''Should a School Athlete Pay to Play?'' (Opinion page, Oct. 15), Norman S. Winnerman raises the same old complaints: athletics are an important part of a school curriculum and therefore student athletes should not have to pay fees to play. Actually athletics can only be defended in public schools as a way of promoting health and (a more tenuous point) teaching kids cooperation, sportsmanship and such values.

title: Jacqueline V. Cosgrove Married to Paul Heyrman
description: Jacqueline Virginia Cosgrove, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Cosgrove of Middle Village, Queens, was married last evening to Paul David Heyrman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Heyrman of Evanston, Ill. The Rev. Rudolph Bierberg officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-27

title: Cuddling as Therapy For Sick Babies
description: LEAD: AMID the incubators, monitors, lights and high-tech equipment that fills the neonatal intensive care unit at the Norwalk Hospital sit two rocking chairs, one white, one yellow, both a little worse for the wear.

title: Court Postpones Medicaid Fraud Rules for New York
description: A major New York State initiative intended to reduce Medicaid fraud has been postponed indefinitely and faces an uncertain future after suffering two legal setbacks in Manhattan courts.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: 'CALL ME ETHEL'

title: A Roundup of Ski Trends in East and West
description: FEARS among ski areas that the growth of skiing is tapering off are prompting programs this season aimed at attracting new skiers and encouraging the occasional skier to get on the slopes more frequently.

title: Okoye Helps Fans Get Sunday Cheer
description: Today is Okoye. That means that nearly everyone here will be looking for the Nigerian Nightmare to break loose once again.

title: No. 2: Encounters With a Hostile Clerk
description: I'M NOT MUCH OF A SHOPPER. There are few material possessions I long for. Just a working typewriter and a word processor and lots and lots of clean, white paper. And books. I must have books. I had got hold of a complete set of Will Durant's ''Story of Civilization.'' Almost complete. Ten volumes. Volume 2, dealing with ancient Greece, was missing. So, of course, I had to have it. I had to!

title: Q and A
description: Rights of a Co-op Renter

title: INSIDE
description: China's Internal Battle: How the Hard-Liners Won

title: A Call From Air Force One
description: NOT long ago, Ruth V. Washington received what she described as ''the phone call of a lifetime.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CAPTAIN BUTTERFLY. By Bob Leuci. (NAL Books/New American Library, $17.95.) Bob Leuci's third New York thriller is as good as they come: nervy, smooth and dead-on convincing. The setting is the Red Hook section of Brooklyn, where an ambitious precinct captain is rising to political power on the basis of a series of showy vice arrests.

title: Review/Dance; Life's Absurdities as Seen by Practitioners of Tap
description: The engaging free spirit of New York tap dance, Jane Goldberg, presented an evening of tap on Nov. 4 at the New York Marxist School that was a model of its kind. Called ''Topical Tap,'' the program was essentially 90 minutes of ''rhythm and schmooze,'' as one number was called, expertly performed by Ms. Goldberg, Sarah Safford and Dorothy Wasserman.

title: A 'Yellow Brick Road' Brightens a Museum
description: What's the future of a fine museum in a faded urban setting on the wrong side of the Hudson? Bright, predicts Samuel C. Miller, director of the Newark Museum and chief plotter of its just-completed $21 million renovation-expansion. The revamping has not only tuned up the physical plant of this once-drab inner-city institution but - with gallery space nearly doubled, to 60,000 square feet - has also enabled it to reveal the depth and excellence of its hard-won holdings.

title: Brazil Appreciates Its Reintroduction To Democracy
description: AS they vote for president on Wednesday, Brazilians will be bringing their Latin American homeland one step closer to becoming the world's third most populous democracy.

title: CHINA UPDATE: HOW THE HARDLINERS WON
description: HU YAOBANG ALWAYS TRIED TO DO things his own way, from the day at age 14 when he ran away from home to join the Communists to the time in 1986 when, as party leader, he suggested that maybe it was time for Deng Xiaoping to retire. This year, after he had his heart attack - embarrassingly, 40 minutes into a Politburo meeting - the doctor ordered him to spend a week in bed. But Hu, 74, was impatient; in particular, he was tired of bedpans. In the early morning of April 15, on the seventh day after the heart attack, Hu raised his lithe, 5 foot, 3 inch frame from the bed and stepped toward the bathroom. It was too much for him. Hu Yaobang suffered a seizure, collapsed and died. Hu's seizure was a prelude to China's. His death triggered weeks of massive protests, giddy days last April and May when throngs of more than a million filled the streets of Beijing, criticizing the growing corruption, and in general demanding more of the democracy that Hu had come to symbolize. And then, after seven exhilarating weeks, it all came to a sudden end. In the early hours of June 4, as the world watched in horror, the tanks of the People's Liberation Army rolled toward Tiananmen Square and troops fired on the crowds, killing hundreds and wounding thousands.

title: Migrants' False Claims: Fraud on a Huge Scale
description: In one of the most extensive immigration frauds ever perpetrated against the United States Government, thousands of people who falsified amnesty applications will begin to acquire permanent resident status next month under the 1986 immigration law.

title: The Contributions Of Craft Artists
description: The Oct. 1 article ''Three-Day Fair to Open'' showed the high caliber of craft artists currently at work in the Garden State.

title: Why Must Women Pay for the Men's Mistakes?
description: The N.C.A.A. Presidents' Commission has proposed changes in the length of the basketball season as well as changes in freshman eligibility. These rules, if approved, would apply to women's as well as men's basketball.

title: Social Events
description: Seeking a Cure

title: Stuck in a Ditch With a Stream Of Memories
description: JUST after I celebrated my threescore-and-tenth birthday, I fell into a ditch.

title: Review/Theater; 3 Interwoven Romance In a 1632 English Comedy
description: The period between the end of the Renaissance and the beginning of the Restoration has provided little more than a footnote in the history of the English-speaking theater. Marlowe, Shakespeare and Jonson were gone, and in their place such playwrights as Richard Brome, William D'Avenant and James Shirley took over London's stages in the years just before the Puritans closed the theaters.

title: LOW TALES OF THE HIGHBORN
description: IN THE EASE OF A KENSINGTON EVENING, Kenneth Rose is dressing for dinner - the private birthday dinner for Lord G., master of an Oxford college. The phone rings impertinently; it is Sir H.S. (a leading advocate, once a Cabinet minister), who would like Mr. Rose to come sailing in Cornwall. Mr. Rose must decline, from pressure of work. ''But frightfully kind of him,'' he says. ''Remarkable he is still sailing so vigorously at 87.''

title: Prospects; Second-Guessing the Fed
description: On Tuesday, the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System will hold its monthly closed-door policy meeting, and possibly decide to alter the Federal funds rate. This rate, the amount charged to commercial banks, was lowered to 8.5 percent last week, from 8.75 percent. Four economists speculate on what the Fed might do. Andrew F. Brimmer President, Brimmer & Associates and former member of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
description: Only to the extent that the myth of the unbeatable Graf becomes a script for tournaments and paralyzes other players is her dominance damaging. The myth, created by the media and consumed by the public, is enacted by the players in a self-fulfilling prophecy.

title: POSTINGS: Hoboken Conversion; 1890's Luxury
description: Work has begun on transforming an 1890's businessmen's club in Hoboken, N.J., into four upscale condominium apartments. Expected to be completed in six months, the renovation involves the Columbia Club, at 1101 Bloomfield Street, a gabled building erected in 1891 for the use of 100 of the city's wealthiest residents. The building later became a Masonic lodge, then a church and, three years ago, was bought for $650,000 by a real estate investment group composed of Morgan Cline and Ben D'Onofrio.

title: 'HEY HIROKO, ARE YOU LOCO?'
description: SAYONARA, MRS. KACKLEMAN Written and illustrated by Maira Kalman. Unpaged. New York: Viking Kestrel. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: WHO SAID IGNORANCE IS BLISS?
description: I, too, made a midlife switch into communications, as Alice Furlaud did - in my case, print journalism (Hers: ''Who Said Ignorance Is Bliss?'' Oct. 8). The young people I worked with - and loved - were astonishingly ignorant, though two were honors graduates of a respectable university.

title: FIGHTING AIDS ALL THE WAY
description: One can offer only sympathy to Larry Josephs in his continuing battle against AIDS. But it's beyond understanding that he can speak of ''safe'' sex with his friend Craig. It smacks of self-destruction on both sides. ''Safe'' is not absolutely safe. EUGENE W. FELDMAN, D.M.D. Lewistown, Pa.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 29 about refugees in Mozambique described foreign support for the Mozambican guerrillas incorrectly. The United States Government is not known to have armed and aided the rebels.

title: THE CLAMOR IN THE EAST: The Mood in East Berlin; A City Where Everyone Is Away for the Holiday
description: East Berlin's city center looked nearly empty today as hundreds of thousands of people headed for West Berlin, most of them just for the day.

title: Love Animates The Universe
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing Mayor of Erie Resigns
description: After nearly 24 years in office and more than a year of an incurable disease, Mayor Louis J. Tullio is stepping down. In a letter delivered to the Erie city clerk Friday, the Mayor, who is 73 years old, said he had appointed Patricia Liebel, an assistant, as Acting Mayor. Mr. Tullio has suffered since May from amyloidosis, a rare terminal illness that produces proteins that destroy vital organs.

title: Saturday Night Fever, Famine and Pestilence
description: ''Konbit'' (A & M CS 5281; all three formats), an album of music from Haiti, produced and compiled by the film director and Haitiophile Jonathan Demme, is one of those hair-tearing projects laden with good political intentions but so-so music. Haitian pop is among the best dance music in the world today, and the collection Mr. Demme has assembled, meant to be broad and political, shows how a literal interpretation of the politics can get in the way of a more useful sense of cultural engagement.

title: Style Makers; Gene Meyer: Fashion Designer
description: When Gene Meyer opened his own fashion business in New York last week, he showed custom-made styles. He decorated an aerie on 57th Street in robin's-egg blue and invited small groups of fashion followers and potential clients to seven fashion shows. Among the visitors was the designer Geoffrey Beene.

title: Columbia Manages Its First Victory
description: The Columbia football team, which snapped a record 44-game losing streak last season, ended one of eight games today. The score was 25-19 and the victim was Cornell at Schoellkopf Field.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: CRISIS IN CONGRESS;
Don't Kill Low-Cost Housing
description: LEAD: As Congress contemplates ways to bring down the budget deficit, one of the rarest of government creations may be sacrificed in the process - a housing program that really works. The low-income housing tax credit, part of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, has served the diverse housing needs of urban and even suburban households in large to mid-sized communities in all parts of the country.

title: Her Style Is Imitable, but It's Her Own
description: Bette Midler struck fear into the hearts of advertisers with her recent legal victory over Young & Rubicam. The agency had bought rights to use ''Do You Wanna Dance,'' which Ms. Midler had remade into an early-1970's hit, for a Ford commercial. When Ms. Midler refused to participate, it hired one of her former backup singers to imitate her. Ms. Midler sued, and in a precedent-setting decision, a Federal District Court jury in Los Angeles awarded her $400,000 in damages.

title: Orchestra Adds Technology to a Classic
description: LEAD: WHEN Christopher Keene takes the podium at Tilles Center Saturday to lead the Long Island Philharmonic in its latest concert, he will have more to keep an eye on than the customary orchestra and soloists.

title: And Now, the Aftershock
description: UNTIL last month, it was merely an amusing footnote to history that when the Great Earthquake of 1906 struck San Francisco, the tenor Enrico Caruso ran in his nightshirt from his room at the Palace Hotel shouting, ''I'll never come back!''

title: What Brought Out the County's Voters
description: EVEN when they could not recall the names on the ballot, county residents entered voting booths in large numbers last week and often had a particular candidate or issue in mind, and the belief that their opinions mattered.

title: Emily A. Chien, Executive, Weds
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York, Emily Anmei Chien, the daughter of Mrs. Robert T. Chien of Urbana, Ill., and the late Dr. Chien, was married yesterday to Thomas Henry Mahoney 4th, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas H. D. Mahoney of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Leonard P. Mahoney, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Fashion; Vivid Scarf Motifs Aren't Just for Scarfs Anymore
description: Scarf prints have become a lot more than something to wrap around your neck. The luxurious textures and vivid designs from Hermes and other companies now exert an influence on contemporary style that goes beyond the casually flung accessory.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;
Fancy Leaves to Grow Without Sunlight
description: LEAD: Each successive year after taking the house plants inside for winter, the plants appear to have a harder time thriving. The trees around the house had grown. My once sunny windows were no longer sunny. Not only evergreens had grown, but so did the dedicuous trees. Even without leaves, they filtered out some of the nurturing sun.

title: Lifestyle; On Christmas Cards, Tradition Still Abides
description: Beverly Monroe looked up and down the rows of greeting cards at a Manhattan gift shop one recent evening. She had started shopping for Christmas cards a few weeks ago, planning to buy about 25 individual cards and several dozen boxed ones.

title: Militant Palestinian Group Accuses Arafat of Treason
description: Abu Musa, leader of a breakaway Palestinian group opposed to the aims of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that his group would try the group's leader, Yasir Arafat, for treason.

title: The Controversy Over Mapplethorpe
description: Now that the venerable Atheneum in Hartford is mounting the Mapplethorpe photographs (''The Venerable Atheneum Braces for That Show,'' Oct. 8), a few comments may be in order concerning the controversy caused by the Corcoran Gallery in Washington when it canceled that same exhibit.

title: Election Day Shows What the Opinion Polls Can't Do
description: POLITICIANS, pollsters and pundits often strain to find significant trends in far-flung elections, but the history that was made Tuesday was unmistakable:

title: Janszen '4 for 4'
description: The chief accuser in the gambling scandal that led to Pete Rose's banishment from baseball said the former Cincinnati manager had contradicted himself and lied about not betting on baseball games during a series of broadcast appearances promoting sales of his book.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: CHARLES WANG;
Software Vendor Is No. 1, Trying Harder, Having Fun
description: LEAD: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES of Garden City, with more than $1 billion in annual sales, is the world's largest independent vendor of software, numbering among its clients most of the Fortune 500 companies.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
description: Yes, for two reasons. Because everyone is chasing after Graf, the level of women's tennis will be raised. Eventually someone will dethrone her. Also, women's tennis benefits from having a star. Because she is so easily recognized, more people are drawn toward the sport. DENNIE BERNS Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Sarah B. Havens Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Sarah Britton Havens, a daughter of Dr. Leston L. Havens of Cambridge, Mass., and Nancy T. Gerlach of Wynnewood, Pa., to Gregg Stephen Sando, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Sando of Merion, Pa., took place yesterday at the Union Theological Seminary in New York. The Rev. John Hendrickson, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bride, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Tyrrell, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: THE BANKER WHO ROBBED BANKS
description: LEAD: One balmy morning last April, a short, round, white-haired man named Lawrence Pope stood at a downtown bus stop in Austin, Tex. Suddenly, he gasped for breath, teetered on his cane, struggled briefly beneath the weight of a plastic bookbag stuffed with documents, fell to the sidewalk and died.

title: Senators and Administration Reach Pollution Pact
description: The Bush Administration and the Senate Democratic leadership have reached a compromise on acid rain legislation that would require stricter standards on some pollutants than the President had originally proposed, would speed the deadlines for meeting the standards and would give six Western states credit for efforts to clean up power plants.

title: Opera (Or Whatever) Shows Life
description: Those who keep fever charts on the health of contemporary opera report that the patient may be taking a turn for the better. That would be welcome news for concerned friends who have been standing outside the recovery room for years, wringing hands and silently composing funerary tributes. A recent article in Opera News, the Metropolitan Opera Guild's magazine, cited optimistic figures from the Central Opera Service: during the 1988-89 season, American companies produced more than 60 world premieres. By contrast, a similar canvas in 1983-84 disclosed only one world premiere, Peter Schickele's ''Abduction of Figaro,'' by Minnesota Opera Theater.

title: Two Cabaret Artists Check Into 'Grand Hotel'
description: When ''Grand Hotel'' opens tonight at the Martin Beck Theater, it will be performed not as a center-stage love story with a secondary plot - the traditional and vanishing structure of musical comedies - but as an ensemble musical. Based on the 1929 novel by Vickie Baum and set in a luxury hotel in Berlin in 1928, it will present an interplay of characters, seven major ones, best described as contrapuntal.

title: Defending Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Pop; Tension Through Irony From Eurythmics at Ritz
description: In pop music, the distance between the implications of the music and a lyric is often where meaning lies. An optimistic-sounding tune paired with a pessimistic lyric can often create a fascinating tension.

title: Tenant Sought For Coindre Estate
description: FROM the rolling lawn to the seawall, the view from Coindre Hall in Lloyd Harbor stretches across Huntington Harbor and Huntington Bay through to Long Island Sound and the southern coast of Connecticut.

title: Walter I. Garms, Educator, 64
description: Walter I. Garms, a retired dean of the University of Rochester's Graduate School of Education and Human Development and a professor emeritus of education, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 64 years old.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. ROBERT DICUIO;
Treating Casino Employee Stress
description: LEAD: AS director of the Institute for Better Living here, Dr. Robert DiCuio treats casino employees suffering from stress and its related problems. These problems, especially when they occur among dealers, the largest group of employees Dr. DiCuio treats, manifest themselves in anorexia and bulimia, panic attacks and substance abuse.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Little Andorra Sets Sights On the U.S.

title: South Korea
description: To the Editor: In his article about the royal palaces of Seoul (Travel, Sept. 17), Richard Halloran writes that the ghosts of the Yi Dynasty, whose kings ruled Korea from 1392 to 1910, still haunt their former residences. However, not all of the Yi Dynasty inhabitants of Seoul's palaces are ghosts. The son of Korea's last Crown Prince has a residence inside Changdok Palace.

title: Promising Prospects Despite Recent Setbacks
description: Black Americans in recent years have made powerful political strides. Their business successes have been less brilliant, but many civil rights activists hope that blacks can push into the economic mainstream in the 1990's. And recent changes in Federal assistance programs for minority-owned businesses and President Bush's campaign pledge to help these companies could fuel their cause.

title: THE YEAR'S BEST ILLUSTRATED BOOKS
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from The Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1989. Since 1952, The Book Review has annually asked a panel of three judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published each year. The judges this year were Amy Kellman of the Carnegie Library in Pittsburgh, Karla Kuskin, an author and illustrator whose last book was ''Jerusalem, Shining Still,'' and R. O. Blechman, an animator and illustrator. As a matter of note, Warwick Hutton has been a winner twice before and Oscar de Mejo once before. Olson's Meat Pies. Written by Peter Cohen. Illustrated by Olof Landstrom. (R&S Books, $12.95.) The Dancing Skeleton. Written by Cynthia C. DeFelice. Illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. (Macmillan, $13.95.) How Pizza Came to Queens. Written and illustrated by Dayal Kaur Khalsa. (Clarkson N. Potter, $13.95.) Does God Have a Big Toe? Stories About Stories in the Bible. Written by Marc Gellman. Illustrated by Oscar de Mejo. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Whales. Written by Seymour Simon. With photographs. (Thomas Y. Crowell, $14.95.) The Heartaches of a French Cat. Written and illustrated by Barbara McClintock. (David R. Godine, $14.95.) Turtle in July. Written by Marilyn Singer. Illustrated by Jerry Pinkney. (Macmillan, $13.95.) Peacock Pie: A Book of Rhymes. Written by Walter de la Mare. Illustrated by Louise Brierley. (Henry Holt, $17.95.) Nicholas Cricket. Written by Joyce Maxner. Illustrated by William Joyce. (Harper & Row, $12.95.) Theseus and the Minotaur. Retold and illustrated by Warwick Hutton. (Margaret E. McElderry Books, $13.95.)

title: Donald Albert to Marry Dory Briggs in December
description: The engagement of Dorothea Payne Briggs to Donald Lawrence Albert, a son of Mrs. G. Robert Peterson of Brigantine, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Briggs of Stamford, Conn. A December wedding is planned.

title: The Mixed Message Of Mother Goose
description: FOR my daughter Kate's first birthday, I gave her an oversized baroquely illustrated collection of Mother Goose rhymes. That evening, with Kate's tiny body enfolded in the crook of my arm, I opened the book to begin sharing the pulsing and playful rhymes. Surely the nursery, awash with pale yellow light, would be transformed by the words and aglow with magic. I read:

title: LOVE WITH THE PERFECT DOG
description: ACKERLEY A Life of J. R. Ackerley. By Peter Parker. Illustrated. 465 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor: In answer to the reader (Q & A, Aug. 20) who wanted to see Australian wildlife in December, please note that one of the most delightful sights is the fairy penguins (none taller than 15 inches) coming ashore at dusk on Phillip Island (about a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Melbourne). They can be seen only at this time of year, when they come to nest in burrows in the sand.

title: Say, Aren't You Andy...
description: THE eternal questions have always haunted humanity. What is the meaning of life? Is death the end of all existence, or does some sort of spiritual substance linger on, surviving throughout eternity?

title: Attack at Soviet Monument
description: Two people were killed and two injured in an unsuccessful attempt to blow up a monument at the joint border of Armenia, Georgia and Azerbaijan, the Moscow radio said today. A spokesman for the Azerbaijani Popular Front said the incident, involving a monument to friendship between the Soviet Union's Caucasian peoples, occurred Wednesday and involved Armenians. At least 120 people have been killed in the past two years in clashes between Armenians and Azeris over the disputed Azerbaijani region of Nagorno-Karabakh.

title: Susan Ginkel and Christopher Lee Wed
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Susan DeLand Ginkel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred O. Ginkel of Muskogee, Okla., and Rochester and Canandaigua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Hoiles Lee, a son of Mary H. Lee of Silver Spring, Md., and Maurice E. Lee of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Carl B. Nelson officiated.

title: The Models and the Glamour Trade
description: THE SEARCH FOR ''THE look,'' the magic that will make lipsticks jump into pocketbooks and magazines walk off newsstands, is endless and truly global. Start with the lips. Lips are big right now. Today's hot models - Cordulla, Christy, Michaela, Naomi - all have full, seductive lips. It used to be the eyes that did the selling, but now the fashion magazines send out big wet kisses to the unsuspecting passerby.

title: A NEW MANDATE AT THE S.B.A.
description: At her Senate confirmation hearing, Susan Engeleiter received a stern message from Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat of Montana. ''Entrepreneurs want to get results now,'' he told Ms. Engeleiter, who took charge of the beleaguered Small Business Administration in April.

title: Miss Waters Wed To Andrew Lese
description: Susan Elizabeth Waters, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward G. Waters Jr. of Little Silver, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew Shain Lese, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Lese of Rye, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smolover and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Channel Club in Monmouth Beach, N.J.

title:
reviewDINING OUT;
Innovative Touches in Italian Cuisine
description: LEAD: IN these days of increasingly expensive and elaborate restaurants, each one seemingly trying to outdo the others, it's very pleasant to come across a simple but charming little restaurant serving honest food at a reasonable price. The Harlequin Cafe, which is opposite St. Mary's Church in Wharton, is just such a place.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 10-year-old kitchen countertop is covered with plastic laminate in a butcher block pattern. The surfaces near the sink have become rough and feel coarse, and there are water stains on the surface. How may these areas be restored to their original condition?<

title: Divorce Mediation: A Cooler Approach
description: LEAD: COUPLES filing for legal separation or divorce have traditionally approached parting with an adversarial approach akin to tag-team wrestling: he and his lawyer in one corner meet her and her lawyer for a fight to the finish. Often the only winners are the lawyers.

title: WILD AND WOOLLY
description: WILL'S MAMMOTH By Rafe Martin. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. Unpaged. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95. (Ages 3 and up)

title: Diner Betrays His Preoccupations
description: I am deeply concerned about Mr. Lettis after reading his article [ ''Who Gets The Liver? The Gaffes of Waiters,'' Opinion, Oct. 22 ] . He seems to be preoccupied with order. Perhaps he should reread his own article. Mr. Lettis refers to the waiter query of ''All done?'' as ''Mommy's question when I was being toilet trained.''

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. C.I.A. Oversight: Vote to kill an amendment that would strike a provision from the 1990 intelligence agencies spending bill that replaces the C.I.A.'s existing inspector general with an official nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. Approved 64 to 34, Nov. 7. 2. Minimum Wage: Vote on passage of a bill raising the minimum wage to $3.80 an hour next year and to $4.25 an hour in 1991. Approved 89 to 8, Nov. 8. $ 1 2 Connecticut Dodd (D) Y Y Lieberman (D) Y Y New Jersey Bradley (D) N Y Lautenberg (D) Y Y New York D'Amato (R) Y Y Moynihan (D) Y Y House 1. Debt Ceiling: Vote to raise the national debt limit to $3.12 trillion through Sept. 30, 1990. Approved 269 to 99, Nov. 7. 2. Oil Spill Liability: Vote on an amendment to a comprehensive oil spill measure that preserves the authority of states to determine how much companies must spend to clean up oil spills. Approved 279 to 143, Nov. 8. 3. Military Bill: Vote on passage of a $305 billion military programs bill that sets spending limits for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Approved 236 to 172, Nov. 9. 1 2 3 Connecticut 1. Kennelly (D) Y Y Y 2. Gejdenson (D) Y Y Y 3. Morrison (D) A Y Y 4. Shays (R) N Y N 5. Rowland (R) Y Y Y 6. Johnson (R) Y Y Y New Jersey 1. Florio (D) A A A 2. Hughes (D) A Y N 3. Pallone (D) N Y N 4. Smith (R) A Y N 5. Roukema (R) Y Y N 6. Dwyer (D) A Y N 7. Rinaldo (R) N Y N 8. Roe (D) A A A 9. Torricelli (D) A Y Y 10. Payne (D) A Y A 11. Gallo (R) A Y N 12. Courter (R) A A A 13. Saxton (R) A Y N 14. Guarini (D) A Y Y New York 1. H'brueckner(D) Y Y Y 2. Downey (D) N Y Y 3. Mrazek (D) N Y Y 4. Lent (R) Y N Y 5. McGrath (R) Y Y Y 6. Flake (D) A Y N 7. Ackerman (D) A Y Y 8. Scheuer (D) Y Y Y 9. Manton (D) A N Y 10. Schumer (D) A Y Y 11. Towns (D) A Y N 12. Owens (D) A Y N 13. Solarz (D) Y Y Y 14. Molinari (R) A A A 15. Green (R) Y N N 16. Rangel (D) A Y N 17. Weiss (D) A Y N 18. Garcia (D) A A A 19. Engel (D) Y Y Y 20. Lowey (D) Y Y Y 21. Fish (R) Y Y Y 22. Gilman (R) N Y Y 23. McNulty (D) Y Y Y 24. Solomon (R) N N Y 25. Boehlert (R) Y Y Y 26. Martin (R) Y Y Y 27. Walsh (R) Y Y Y 28. McHugh (D) Y Y Y 29. Horton (R) Y Y Y 30. Slaughter (D) Y Y Y 31. Paxon (R) N Y N 32. LaFalce (D) Y Y Y 33. Nowak (D) Y Y N 34. Houghton (R) Y N Y KEY: Y Yea; N Nay; (A)Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

title: LAUGHTER, TEARS AND THE PERFECT MARTINI
description: AR. GURNEY JR. IS AT HIS FAVORITE kind of party - the kind where they don't read the reviews. The occasion is that after 370 performances of the Off Broadway hit ''The Cocktail Hour,'' Keene Curtis, the actor who has been playing the father, is leaving the show.

title: Campus Life; Students Go for Pop Music, Pop Novels, Pop Tarts
description: What do Madonna, Tom Clancy, the Macintosh computer and Pop Tarts have in common? All are hot items on campuses these days, interviews with 300 students at 20 colleges and universities indicate.

title: New York Pops Tour
description: The first tour of the New York Pops will begin on Dec. 2 with a performance at the Mann Performing Arts Center in Fort Myers, Fla. The tour, sponsored by the J. S. Karlton Company, will include three other stops in Florida, Melbourne, Sarasota and Miami Beach, and a stop in Columbia, S.C. The orchestra, led by its founder and music director, Skitch Henderson, will play works by Grieg, Debussy, Smetana and Gliere, as well as a selection of songs from three Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals, with the soloists the soprano Patti Wilemon and the baritone Lothar Bergeest.

title: No. 5: Strategies For an Anti-Shopper
description: As a general rule, men shop but women go shopping. That is to say, if a man requires a new shirt, he goes to the appropriate store with a clear idea of what he wants. If his specific need cannot be met, he returns home and faces the world in an old shirt and a rage. To men, money is something not to be spent but to be held and fondled; to men, checkbooks and safe deposit boxes are fetishes; they dream about these sacred objects, and their prayers are all in numerals. Women, it would seem, cannot love money with this pure, spiritual flame; they prefer to convert abstract wealth into tangible objects. To this end, they go shopping. If they set out to purchase a raincoat but do not see what they had in mind, they return home with a scarf, a purse, a pair of boots.

title: NECESSITIES OF LIFE AND DEATH
description: HUMAN WISHES By Robert Hass. 86 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $17.95. THE INNER ROOM By James Merrill. 95 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95. VARIABLE DIRECTIONS The Selected Poetry of Dan Pagis. Translated by Stephen Mitchell. 153 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Familiarity: Worth the Risk
description: I WOULD be inclined, temperamentally, to say ''right on'' to Richard Elman, whose provocative article of Oct. 8 [ Opinion, ''Familiarity Breeds Mayhem'' ] was like a whiff from the ammonia bottle, clearing the sinuses in its originality. Yet I felt enormous pain to hear his analysis of how we must live, because of what he thinks we are.

title: Swimmer Is in a Coma
description: Victor Davis, a swimming gold medalist while representing Canada in the 1984 Olympic Games, was in a coma in Notre Dame Hospital today after being struck by an automobile, an official with Swim Canada said.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MUSICAL GENERATIONS

title: From Cash Cow To Cash Machine
description: Romeo J. Ventres knows exactly what he wants Borden Inc. to be when he retires in December 1991. He wants it to be the lowest-cost producer of all its products, from milk to pasta to plastics to glue. He wants it to have a decent mix of national and regional brands. He certainly wants it to be independent - a year ago, he and Borden's top 25 managers agreed to quit simultaneously in the event of a hostile takeover. But most important, he wants Borden to be a ''perpetual cash machine.''

title: Rise in Drug Arrests Is Reported in New York
description: Drug-related offenses continue to account for a growing share of crimes reported in New York City, the latest crime statistics compiled by the state show.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Having a Good Scoff

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not 1941. The war was horrible for us, but there is no Fascist country left there now.'' - Vasily F. Simonenko, a Soviet veteran of World War II who is following German events. [ 22:1. ]

title: Despite Rebel Threats, Peru Proceeds With Election
description: On the steep roads that wind through the Peruvian Andes and in the vast slums of Lima, leftist guerrillas have been stopping buses and threatening to kill those who vote in nationwide municipal elections on Sunday.

title: The New Europe
description: In the disorder of our stunned reactions to the drama playing out in East Germany, we can scarcely begin to see the consequences. But one is clear. Political stability in Europe is going to depend more than ever on the European Community.

title: Builders Hit Hard by the Housing Downturn
description: JACK R. KALMAR of Bridgeport has been in construction for 25 years, but in 1987 he decided to phase out his home-building business.

title: Missed Chances and Goaltending Hurt Devils
description: Failure on the power play and uninspired goaltending by Chris Terreri led the Devils to a 7-5 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Islanders Lose a Clash of Opposites
description: Shortly after the Islanders lost, again, at the Nassau Coliseum tonight, one of their players shuffled through the quiet dressing room and snatched a yellow, post-game statistics report from a table.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''To allude to a program trader as an investor is akin to calling a shark a gourmet diner.'' Lawrence G. Kirshbaum, chairman, Prescott, Ball & Turben.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FISH WHISTLE: Commentaries, Uncommontaries and Vulgar Excesses. By Daniel Pinkwater. (Addison-Wesley, $16.95.) This is a collection of 73 short humor pieces, many of them originally written as commentaries for National Public Radio's ''All Things Considered.'' In print, unfortunately, the fun is on a par with the titles these pieces, most of them autobiographical, have been saddled with: ''In the Land of the Rising Pickle,'' ''Iguana Be Alone'' and ''The Schmo of Kilimanjaro'' are some of the corniest offenders.

title: Chicago's Mayor Pursuing Quiet Quest to Win Trust of Blacks
description: It would usually be considered quite an honor to be invited to City Hall to have breakfast with the Mayor. But for some black Chicagoans, dining with Richard M. Daley in his office is not necessarily something to boast about.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ENCOUNTERS. Edited by Kai Erikson. (Yale University, $19.95.) ''What then is an encounter - narrative, autobiography, history, hagiography, anti-hagiography?'' asks the psychologist Jerome Bruner after describing a lovely Alpine afternoon with Jean Piaget. ''Encounters'' - a marvelous collection of 18 descriptions, originally published in The Yale Review, of meetings between the well-known in the arts and the social sciences - does not answer but rather illustrates the question.

title: AT the Boston Post, ''The Boys Next Door''
description: LUCIEN P. SMITH is a middle-aged man whose mental capacity falls ''between a 5-year-old and an oyster,'' he tells us in a moment of sudden lucidity. ''I am damaged. I will not go away,'' he continues. ''Without my crippled, shattered brain, you will never be frightened by what you might have become, or by what your future might make you.'' And then, when the imaginary interlude of eloquence is over, Lucien goes on with his customary childlike chattering.

title: Installing Adjustable Wall Shelves
description: ADJUSTABLE wall shelves, the kind featuring metal standards that are slotted to accept brackets sold with them, are versatile, easy to obtain and relatively inexpensive. They are also easy to install, but there are a few pitfalls.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ROBERT I. WOLF;
Therapist Works With Mental Palettes
description: LEAD: WHEN Robert I. Wolf, a psychotherapist, wants to find out what is really on the minds of his patients, he is more apt to give them a crayon or camera than ask them to lie down on a couch. When Mr. Wolf's students are giving a presentation, the listeners are encouraged to doodle rather than pay rapt attention.

title: Mayoral Victors Break New Ground But Face Old Woes
description: WHEN State Senator John C. Daniels was elected Mayor of New Haven last week, the retiring Mayor, Biagio DiLieto, felt a tinge of pity for his celebrated successor, the first black to occupy the city's top executive post.

title: Vladimir Horowitz: Thunder, Lightning and Awe
description: When Vladimir Horowitz played, he generated electricity, thunder and lightning and displayed demonic technical control that always threatened to get out of hand but never did. Then he would turn around and play, simply, purely and ravishingly, a Chopin mazurka or waltz. He was more than a pianist. To the public and to his colleagues, he generated awe.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Geneva
description: One of Europe's most cosmopolitan cities, Geneva has an upscale clientele all year: diplomats attending international conferences, oilmen, visitors to trade shows in the modern Exhibition Palace (PAL-EXPO) near the airport, conventioneers, collectors or dealers bidding at one of the frequent art or jewelry auctions, and unobtrusive guests who arrive to nurse their numbered accounts in some palatial bank near the lakefront. As for Geneva's 160,000 residents, one out of three is a foreigner.

title: 20 Hanged for Drugs in Iran
description: Twenty drug smugglers were hanged in five Iranian provinces today as part of a campaign to curb addiction, the Teheran radio reported in a broadcast monitored in Cyprus. More than 1,000 accused drug traffickers have been hanged in Iran in the last 10 months under a law requiring the death sentence for anyone caught possessing even small quantities of narcotics.

title: PENTAGON SEES NATO REVISIONS
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that political change in Eastern Europe may eventually allow NATO to scale back its plans for defending Europe.

title: Teen-Agers Escape From Correction Center
description: Seven teen-agers, including one charged with murder, were being sought today after escaping from Long Lane School, a youth correctional center, a correction official said.

title: Paul Briggs, 76, Dies; Led Cleveland Schools
description: Paul W. Briggs, who was Superintendent of Schools in Cleveland when a Federal judge ordered busing for desegregation 11 years ago, died of a brain hemorrhage Friday. He was 76 years old.

title: 'CHUG, CHUG, CHUG' AND OTHER GREAT FIRST LINERS
description: Time flies by, but the words and images from favorite children's books remain perennially fresh. The following first lines are from a dozen American children's books that appeared before 1950, but they will be familiar to children, parents and grandparents. See if you can match them with the accompanying illustrations and, if you can, guess the year they were published. Answers on page 59. 1.

title: Maureen Bezuhly Plans May Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bezuhly of Old Forge, Pa., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter, Maureen Bezuhly, an associate at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, and Gregory Eugene Galterio, an associate at Jaffe & Asher, both New York law firms.

title: One Last Chance for Coach at Clinton
description: Ask Joe Prezioso about the games he remembers and the memories all seem to meld into one for the football coach at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx.

title: WARHOL THE WORKINGMAN
description: LEAD: As Nat Finkelstein comments in ANDY WARHOL: The Factory Years 1964-1967 (St. Martin's, Paper, $19.95), ''Andy Warhol's greatest work of art was Andy Warhol.'' Surrounded by an entourage that included Edie Sedgwick, Baby Jane Holzer, Lou Reed and other members of the Velvet Underground, Warhol staged a drama of supreme narcissism.

title: Dr. Bernice Parisi Marries
description: Dr. Bernice M. Parisi, an orthodontist in Reading, Pa., and Dr. Robert W. Baker Jr., an orthodontist in Ithaca, N.Y., both graduates of the University of Pennsylvania Dental School, were married yesterday at the Sacred Heart Church in Reading. The Revs. Joseph Czaus, a Roman Catholic priest, and Raymond Brubaker, a Presbyterian minister, officiated. The bride, 29 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent A. Parisi of Wyomissing, Pa. She graduated from Villanova University. Dr. Baker, 33, is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Baker of Ithaca. He graduated from Colgate University. The bride and bridegroom's fathers are orthodontists.

title: In Congress, Fingers Begin to Point
description: LITTLE in recent years has created more tension among members of Congress than its investigation into the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, for the House Banking Committee has not been able to avoid looking at the role of five Senators who intervened with Federal regulators on behalf of Lincoln's owner.

title: Review/Music; Lost Love and Revenge
description: Jessie Mae Hemphill's show at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture on Tuesday night, as part of the Benson & Hedges Blues festival, was a decent example of Delta blues. But while the show was fair enough musically, it was also an example of what sort of concessions and misunderstandings rural performers labor under when performing for an urban audience.

title: Off to the Slopes With the Kids
description: NURSING mothers receive a color code from the nursery at Bromley ski area in Vermont. When baby is hungry, a piece of construction paper of the mother's assigned color is pasted on the window facing the ski slope.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 10-year-old kitchen countertop is covered with plastic laminate in a butcher block pattern. The surfaces near the sink have become rough and feel coarse, and there are water stains on the surface. How may these areas be restored to their original condition?<

title: POLITICAL HUMOR
description: No Crisis Too Grave

title: Shifting Borders: Conquest, Defeat and Division
description: Imperial Germany, 1914

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 15 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the film ''Valmont'' misattributes the authorship of the screenplay of ''Amadeus.'' It was written by Peter Shaffer.

title:
COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Leaseholds vs. Land Owning;
Buying the Underlying Property Is Gaining Favor
description: LEAD: BEFORE the Rockefellers sold 51 percent of the Rockefeller Group, owner of Rockefeller Center, to the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Tokyo, they bought the land under the buildings from its longtime owner, Columbia University.

title: South Korean Riot Police Raid a University
description: About 3,000 riot policemen backed by armored vans and using tear gas stormed a university campus today to break up a protest by about 1,000 students calling for the overthrow of President Roh Tae Woo.

title: Tales of Success
description: A SALESWOMAN hovers in the doorway of Volity Narayan Prakash's office in his jewelry store in Jackson Heights, Queens. She has a problem. A customer is buying a $2,400 gold chain for cash, but he is $100 short. Mr. Prakash strides out to the counter and speaks to his customer in the south Indian dialect he learned as a child in Bangalore. They shake hands and the customer leaves with his purchase.

title: THE LITTLE SYNAGOGUE THAT COULD
description: THE OLD SYNAGOGUE Written and illustrated by Richard Rosenblum. Unpaged. Philadelphia: An Edward E. Elson Book/ The Jewish Publication Society. $12.95. (Ages 6 and up)

title: Bruce W. Hurd And Lucy Reich To Wed in April
description: April wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Reich of Savannah, Ga., for their daughter Lucy Elizabeth Reich and Bruce Ward Hurd, both 1984 graduates of the University of Vermont. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Daniel Hertz of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Richard Hurd 3d.

title: Arabs Say Deadly Power Struggle Has Split Abu Nidal Terror Group
description: The Abu Nidal terrorist organization has been ripped by a murderous internal power struggle in which more than 150 members of the group, including more than 20 of its leaders, have been killed, according to dissident senior leaders of the group, officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Arab diplomats.

title: JUNIOR'S GONE DOWN THE DRAIN
description: THE TUB PEOPLE By Pam Conrad. Illustrated by Richard Egielski. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: FIGHTING AIDS ALL THE WAY
description: Larry Josephs has told a story that is similar to one I could tell: I, too, tested positive for the AIDS virus in 1987 (''Fighting AIDS All the Way,'' Oct. 8). As Mr. Josephs explained, one of the key indicators of approaching illness is a patient's T-4 cell count. Like Mr. Josephs, I sought immediate treatment (as soon as I got over the shock of learning about my status). I began taking AZT while my T-cell count was above 200, and I have maintained a fairly consistent T-4 cell count since then - with the help of AZT.

title: DATA BANK: Nov. 12, 1989
Campus Life: Claremont McKenna; Striptease At Salad Bar Provokes Protest
description: A freshman, Phuong Nguyen, was enjoying a Halloween lunch in the Claremont McKenna College cafeteria with 500 other students until the meal was interrupted by a woman who began dancing and disrobing near the salad bar.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Making the Most of the Lowly Bean: One Recipe That Yields Two Others
description: Years ago, Senator Everett Dirksen of Illinois, who failed in his effort to have the marigold named the national flower, was more successful in putting bean soup on the menu of the Senate Dining Room. In ''The Complete Bean Cookbook,'' by Victor Bennett (Prentice Hall, 1967) the Senator, who was known for his florid oratory, wrote a homage to the bean.

title: Lasting Effect of Quake: Quality of Life Is Shaken
description: The beguiling landscape here looks just as it did a month ago, the skyline is largely intact and the city is up and running. But appearances are deceiving. For millions of Bay Area residents, most of them far from the manifest ruin of Oct. 17, life after the earthquake is vastly different from what it was before: an unnerving sequence of annoyances, none of them traumas in themselves, but deeply unsettling when put together.

title: IN NIGERIA, OHIO IS EXOTIC
description: ISARA A Voyage Around ''Essay.'' By Wole Soyinka. 262 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: This rich volume chronicles the birth and evolution of the popular comic strip ''The Far Side,'' with excerpts from the sketchbooks of its creator, Gary Larson; samples of flawed, controversial and remarkably tasteless cartoons; more than 200 of Mr. Larson's favorite published panels; and abundant annotations that afford a glimpse into the crafting of the cartoons and the workings of his funny, brilliant, bizarre mind.

title: Frank Gehry's Village of Geometric Forms at Yale
description: There have been studies, investigations, and researches of all kinds, but in the end no one is really sure what kind of environment best suits people with serious mental illness. It is known that certain things do not work - buildings that are willfully eccentric, for one thing, or buildings that are too flexible and changeable, both of which deny the order, stability and constancy that many emotionally disturbed people feel most comfortable with. What the average person might interpret as serene is almost surely preferable to what the average person would find overstimulating. But beyond that, neither the medical nor the architectural profession is quite sure if there is any way at all to design buildings that will not hinder the process of curing the severely disturbed.

title: Review/Dance; Odd Events at a Picnic, From Senta Driver
description: Usually, there is nothing puzzling about picnics. They allow people to relax, eat and, if they wish, frisk about. Nevertheless, Senta Driver made a picnic a puzzling - and intellectually stimulating - occasion in ''The Grand Duchesses Laughing,'' which received its New York premiere Thursday night on the program Ms. Driver's company, Harry, offered at the Joyce Theater.

title: BEYOND DAMNATION OR DEFENSE: THE EARLY YEARS
description: RICHARD MILHOUS NIXON The Rise of an American Politician. By Roger Morris. Illustrated. 1,005 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $29.95.

title: LOOKING AFTER THEIR INVISIBLE FRIENDS
description: AFTERNOON OF THE ELVES By Janet Taylor Lisle. 122 pp. New York: Orchard Books. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Gonorrhea in Seattle Stirs Concern on AIDS
description: An outbreak of gonorrhea among homosexual men in Seattle could indicate that some gay men are abandoning sex practices that protect against the transmission of the AIDS virus, health officials have warned.

title: 20 Years of Man And Woman at Yale
description: LEAD: WHEN Amoret Cardiero was in elementary school in the early 1960's and carried her father's old notebooks from Yale University, other children taunted her, pointing out that she could not go to Yale because it was only for men. But when Ms. Cardiero was a senior in high school, Yale announced that it would become co-educational the next year, and she happily applied.

title: STUDENT WANTS F.B.I. FILE PURGED
description: A college student who became the subject of an F.B.I. investigation because he wrote to foreign governments as part of a sixth-grade project continues to uncover new F.B.I. files bearing his name, his lawyers say.

title: 'The Shadow Box'' Explores Mortality
description: ''The Shadow Box,'' the 1977 Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Michael Cristofer now being presented by the Great Neck Theater Guild in New Hyde Park, is about death.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newport, R.I.;
A New Project For the Needy
description: LEAD: THIS oceanfront resort known as a playground for the wealthy, with manyhomes priced above the means of most of its permanent residents, is working on plans for yet another of the projects that have made it second in the state only to Providence in its proportion of subsidized housing units.

title: Amy E. Liipfert Becomes the Bride Of John Vliet Lindsay Jr. in Vermont
description: At the Stowe (Vt.) Community Church, Amy Elizabeth Liipfert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Liipfert of New York, was married yesterday to John Vliet Lindsay Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lindsay of New York. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Milton H. Murray, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, and the Rev. Bruce S. Comiskey, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Cobbler's Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CRUSADE OF DR. ELDERS
description: The right-to-life movement opposes making sex education and effective contraceptives available to high-school students - the very measures that would reduce the need for teen-age abortions.

title: Defusing Anger Allows Joint Custody Decision
description: LEAD: LUKE and Camille Palladino were well aware of the potential minefield. Their prime concern was how their divorce would affect their 6-year-old daughter, Erica, who wanted to live with each of her parents.

title: Bishops Endorse Rite for Parishes Without Priests
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops have authorized a Sunday prayer service for parishes without priests, one of several actions at last week's meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops reflecting the growing shortage of Catholic clergy in many areas.

title:
GARDENING;
Fallen Leaves and Autumnal Tasks
description: LEAD: NOW that the leaves have fallen, many gardeners still face the task of cleaning up. All too often that involves raking the leaves by hand, packing them into plastic bags and placing them by the curb to be picked up and hauled to a landfill. Not only does this contribute to the problem of diminishing space in landfills, but it is also ecologically unsound and, for the most part, unnecessary.

title: Swimming Duel
description: The first showdown flopped when Tom Jager's dive beat everything, including the starter's gun, and so they will try it again on Dec. 2. Jager, holder of the world record in the 50-meter freestyle, will meet Matt Biondi on that date as a special feature of a college invitational meet.

title: Protests Greet Removal of Top AIDS Officials
description: New York City's Commission on Human Rights is investigating the removal of the top two officials in its AIDS Discrimination Division.

title: Little Pigs That Act Like Real Hams
description: LEAD: THINGS can get a little harrowing in the four-room house at Movado farm in Durham. On very cold nights, Louisa Fedora and Tricia Carlton have been known to invite in five little pigs which like nothing better than to keep company with the seven Doberman pinschers. Unfortunately, there's hardly any room left for the horses.

title: Dinkins's Transition Won't Be Rushed
description: As Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins prepares to choose the people who will help him run New York City, he faces the twin tasks of quickly filling important posts to create confidence in his stewardship, while searching out dozens of other appointees to fulfill his pledge to represent the city's diverse communities.

title: Eagleburger Won't Disclose Kissinger's Client List
description: The Deputy Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, and his lawyers have determined that disclosing the names of all the clients of the two consulting firms headed by Henry A. Kissinger cannot be done without violating confidentiality agreements between Mr. Kissinger and his clients.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
description: Has the question ever been asked, ''Is Mike Tyson's dominance good for boxing?'' The question appears to be sexist. But let me answer it: ''Yes.'' Steffi Graf, by her example of excellence, is raising the level of all players. HAROLD BELMAR Brooklyn

title: Peggy Rich and S. C. Trowbridge Wed
description: Peggy Lea Rich and Stephen C. Trowbridge were married yesterday at the Perkins Chapel at Southern Methodist University in Dallas by the Rev. Dr. Edwin E. Sylvest, a Methodist minister.
