The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Robert Dellis Harris of Dallas and the late Mr. Harris. The bridegroom is a son of Alexander B. Trowbridge of Washington and Nancey H. Trowbridge of Southport, Conn.

title: 13 Counts Of Murder
description: The tone of the prosecution in the case of Richard Ramirez might be characterized as one of regret that Mr. Ramirez had but one life to give for his crimes. Mr. Ramirez was found guilty two months ago of killing 13 people and committing dozens of other felonies in the 1985 wave of ''Night Stalker'' attacks in Southern California. He was notably brutal as he entered unlocked houses late at night to kill, rape and maim, in one case gouging a victim's eyes out. Last week, before he was sentenced to death in the gas chamber, the 29-year-old Mr. Ramirez delivered a rambling statement about his crimes. ''You don't understand,'' he said. ''You are not capable of it. I am beyond good and evil. Repeat not the errors of the Night Prowler and show no mercy.'' The convicted murderer then proclaimed, ''Lucifer dwells within us all.'' Said the prosecutor, P. Philip Halpin: ''Baloney.'' He added, ''I wouldn't want anyone to listen to what he has to say because he is a pathetic human being who is grasping at some structure in his life.'' Under California law, the death sentence will automatically be appealed.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ERNIE'S AMERICA: The Best of Ernie Pyle's 1930s Travel Dispatches. Edited by David Nichols. (Random House, $21.95.) Forget Ernie Pyle, the war correspondent famed for his straight-to-the-soul pieces about G.I.'s on the front lines, far from home in the heartland. Forget the grief when a sniper's bullet took his life on April 18, 1945, on a tiny Pacific island.

title: Training Program For Waiters
description: There is a training program for waiters on Long Island. The adult program of the Great Neck Public Schools, in cooperation with the Greater Great Neck Restaurant Association, is offering a course on ''The Waiter as a Professional.'' In eight weekly sessions, Alan Reyburn, a Manhattan-based executive recruiter and consultant for the hospitality industry, is helping staff from several North Shore restaurants sharpen their professional skills. Guest lectures will discuss restaurant fire safety and demonstrate the Heimlich maneuver. The course has been funded by the Long Island Regional Education Center for Economic Development, with a modest grant from the New York State Education Department.

title: West Virginia Defeats Rutgers
description: Major Harris rushed for a career-high 160 yards and completed two touchdown passes to Reggie Rembert as West Virginia edged Rutgers, 21-20, today.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE COURT JESTERS. By Avigdor Dagan. Translated by Barbara Harshav. (Jewish Publication Society, $15.95.) In the manner of Gunter Grass or Milan Kundera, the Israeli novelist Avigdor Dagan has created a modern fairy tale to explore some of the important philosophical questions arising from the Holocaust: Is there a God?

title: Voices From Different Times, And Both Sides Of the Wall
description: In the early morning of Aug. 13, 1961, East Germany began building the Berlin wall to stop the westward exodus of its people across the open border. In the 28 years since, this most visible symbol of the cold war has inspired thoughts ranging from the ludicrous to the sublime. Here is a sampling.

title: THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE
description: 1. TACK. H. Kauffman & Sons, the oldest horse boutique in town (1875), offers ''everything for the horse and rider except hay.'' Saddles, new or antique, sell for $500 to $30,000.

title: Miss Bowe Wed To R. S. Kricheff
description: Daphne Anne Bowe and Robert Saul Kricheff were married yesterday at the Central Unitarian Church in Paramus, N.J. The Rev. Dr. John W. Young officiated.

title: Jane Foster Lorber Wed To Nathaniel Treat Reece
description: Jane Foster Lorber, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Giraud van Nest Foster of Lenox, Mass., was married yesterday at her home in New York to Nathaniel Treat Reece, a son of Mrs. Jose L. San Carlos de Pedroso of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late John B. Reece. The ceremony was performed by Chief Judge Charles L. Brieant Jr. of Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Salvador Rebels Mount Attacks Across the Capital
description: Guerrillas carried out a wave of attacks throughout the capital today, killing two children and injuring at least eight other people, officials and witnesses said. [ The residence of President Alfredo Cristiani was among the targets attacked by the rebels, Reuters reported, quoting radio reports. Two policemen were wounded by gunfire at Mr. Cristiani's house in a residential neighborhood but it was unclear if the President was inside the house at the time, the agency said. ] Gunfire and bomb blasts could be heard tonight throughout the capital as the rebels hit military targets including the first infantry brigade and the police academy, radio reports said.

title: Judith Bury Smith Married to James A. Edgar 3d
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Judith Bury Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Bury Smith of Tokyo, and James Alexander Edgar 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. William Veinot performed the ceremony.

title: Christine Twomey Weds J. A. Cadley
description: Christine Elissa Twomey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil F. Twomey of Wyckoff, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to John Alfred Cadley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Cadley of River Edge, N.J. The Rev. Robert J. Norris performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE CRIME OF THE CENTURY. By Kingsley Amis. (Mysterious Press, $16.95.) The prolific novelist, poet and critic Kingsley Amis wrote ''The Crime of the Century'' in 1975 as a serial for The Sunday Times of London. With one previous detective novel to his credit, Mr. Amis was making his first attempt at a large-scale thriller involving, as he relates in his introduction, ''hundreds of coppers, top political and professional brass .

title: EAST GERMANS FLOOD THE WEST, MOST TO REJOICE, THEN GO HOME; KOHL AND KRENZ AGREE TO MEET
description: A million East Germans streamed into West Berlin and West Germany today on foot and by car, subway and train, many passing through border crossings so new that the paint was not yet dry. More important for East Germany, most were going back.

title:
THE ULTIMATE MARKETPLACE;
The Anatomy of a Shopping Jag
description: LEAD: EVERY TIME I'M ASKED ABOUT MY HOBBIES OR special interests, I am tempted to say white-water rafting, Etruscan vase painting or good old stamp collecting. But the truth is that one abiding passion has remained constant from my high school days to the present. Shopping. I am a shopper. There is no department store, specialty shop or even supermarket that doesn't whisper to me, ''We're open.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; From Gotham to the Sea, Chelsea to Chinatown
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Chelsea Central

title: Naomi Friedman Wed To Martin Lindower
description: Naomi Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sy Friedman of Amherst, Mass., was married there last evening at the Jewish Community of Amherst to Dr. Martin Lindower, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lindower of Brooklyn. Rabbi Yechiel Lander performed the ceremony.

title: Yale Gets A Share Of Title
description: Another episode of the remarkable serial ''Yale Bulldogs Win Ivy Championship'' was wrapped up here today at Princeton's Palmer Stadium. In a tumultuous fourth quarter, the 11 Bulldogs on defense held off the Tigers, so Yale won the schools' 112th game, 14-7.

title: New York Telephone Seeks a Rate Increase
description: A telephone rate freeze announced with much fanfare by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the New York Telephone Company in 1987 appears to be thawing a year ahead of schedule.

title: A Third Freighter Runs Aground Off Keys
description: A 470-foot Greek freighter ran aground late Friday night on a fragile coral reef off the Florida Keys, where two other ship groundings in the last three weeks have done substantial damage to coral.

title: The Serapis Captured n the Revolution
description: In William Zimmer's review of the exhibition ''Realism and Romanticism in 19th-Century New England Seascapes'' at the Whitney Museum in Stamford (Oct. 15), he writes: ''Next to this epic is hung James Hamilton's 'Capture of the Seramis by John Paul Jones,' another look at the War of 1812, this time from the vantage point of 1854.''

title: Parisian Traffic: Out of Hand or Out of Sight?
description: To resolve a growing traffic crisis, city officials are considering an ambitious new plan that could well be called ''Journey to the Center of the Earth.''

title: Powerboaters Head For Florida Sequel
description: Offshore powerboat racers will have a chance to redeem themselves this week after the disastrous world powerboat championship last month in Atlantic City.

title: Fashion; What They're Wearing In Bed
description: A bit of highly unscientific research among the fashion set discloses that designers who spend their waking hours conjuring up great style statements are just like everyone else when it comes time to turn out the lights. An awful lot of them like to take it all off. ''Nothing,'' states CALVIN KLEIN. ''I have robes and pajamas and all that, but I never wear them -even when I travel.'' CAROLYNE ROEHM loves beautiful lingerie.

title:
DINING OUT;
There's a Touch of SoHo in Dobbs Ferry
description: LEAD: DESIGNERS of this restaurant's space must have taken their cues from SoHo eateries (also off Broadway): exposed ductwork asserts itself overhead in vivid plum and a front wall of unencumbered windows, soon to be cozily curtained for winter, connects diners within and street activity without, where customers can enjoy gentler seasons at sidewalk tables.

title: Style Makers; Kaffe Fassett, Knitting Designer
description: In the highly structured craft of hand-knitting, Kaffe (rhymes with safe) Fassett has made his mark as a revolutionary, overthrowing the tyranny of complex techniques, single-dye lots and orderly patterns.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: It is reasonable to teach a beginner that against silent opponents he should head for game in no-trump, if he cannot find a major suit fit. This is, of course, an over simplification compounded by the reluctance of duplicate players to play in five clubs or five diamonds.

title: No. 1: That Unexpected Object of Desire
description: I STOPPED TO SAY ''HI'' TO HIM every morning when I went to the corner for the paper. He gave me the once-over, and I saw approval in his shiny black eyes. ''Hey, ol' buddy. Hey, ol' buddy,'' I said. He bobbed his head again and again. I bobbed my head again and again. As far as I was concerned, we were in love.

title: Amy Brownfeld Wed To David T. Fannon
description: Amy Elizabeth Brownfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Brownfeld of Paradise Valley, Ariz., was married in Phoenix last evening to David Timmins Fannon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Fannon of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Sanibel, Fla. Rabbi Bernard Kleigfeld performed the ceremony at the Arizona Biltmore Hotel.

title: Protecting a Child Can Go Too Far
description: It is not Shane who has been maligned in the controversy initiated by his mother, Cindy Soehner, concerning home schooling. He is probably a ''nice, quiet boy,'' as his mother's friend claims in her Oct. 22 letter.

title: STREETSCAPES: Williamsburgh Savings Bank; Resolving the Case of Missing Muntins
description: THE biggest violation ever of New York City's landmarks law has been settled by a compromise and the Williamsburgh Savings Bank in downtown Brooklyn has begun to alter the 906 windows it installed without the approval of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Special Today; New York, New York: Magazine, Part 2
description: A special focus on New York as the ultimate marketplace for everything from fashion to finance.

title: SPEECHWRITERS AND POLITICIANS
description: Clearly, a modern President hasn't time to craft speeches in the manner of Lincoln on the train to Gettysburg, so we should expect the White House to employ writers. But that oratory can be ordered up as casually as lunch - devoid of a President's participation in the development of theme, tone and nuance - gives us not statesmanship, but artifice and public-relations hokum. JONATHAN HOUSE Richfield Springs, N.Y.

title: Margaret Kinnard Weds
description: Dr. Margaret Fern Kinnard and Dr. Robert Stephen O'Shea Jr., both residents in internal medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, were married yesterday at the Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel in Moorestown, N.J. The Rev. James J. McGovern, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. O'Shea is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Kinnard of Moorestown. Her husband is a son of Dr. and Mrs. O'Shea of Snyder, N.Y.

title:
ART;
2 Voyages on Gallery Walls
description: LEAD: THE gallery equivalent of armchair traveling is provided by the Bronx Museum of the Arts and the corporate offices of Krasdale Foods. Much space is given to art from Argentina at the museum, while the hallways at Krasdale are lined with work from the Dominican Republic. The two voyages provide diverse experiences.

title: Hopes Are Rising For Lower Rates By STEVE DODSON
description: The credit market took hope from signs of an easing in Fed monetary policy. On Tuesday the Fed added money to the banking system when the Federal funds rate was at 8 11/16, bringing the rate down to 8 1/2 percent. But when the rate went below that, to 8 3/8, the Fed acted to drain money from the system, leading analysts to conclude that the easing would be limited. Southwest Bank of St. Louis, a small institution that often is the first to move on rates, cut its prime rate to 10 percent, from 10.5 percent, but no big banks immediately matched the cut. The Fed's actions came in a confusing week, with the Treasury forced to delay its auctions while awaiting Congressional action on the national debt. But once the debt ceiling was raised to $3.12 trillion, the auctions began, and they confirmed a lowering of rates. The three-year notes sold at an average yield of 7.77 percent, the lowest since February 1988. *

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
DESERT FLOWER
description: LEAD: SHABANU Daughter of the Wind. By Suzanne Fisher Staples. 240 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. (Ages 12 and up)

title: More Opportunities For Women
description: Sharon White Taylor writes in her article ''For Women, a New Age of Choices'' (Opinion page, Oct. 8) that she was tracked into a brief career in nursing after she graduated from high school in 1958. She is happy that the women of her daughters' generation have more options than she did.

title: Deng Is Ex-Chairman But Not an Ex-Leader
description: DENG XIAOPING gave up his last office in the Communist Party last week, but it remains to be seen whether he will give up power. Mr. Deng's authority has come not from his titles, but from his eminence and from the Confucian-style respect that other leaders give him. The 85-year-old Mr. Deng has not surrendered this status with his job as chairman of the party's Central Military Commission.

title: Carolyn Anderson and William Kimberly Wed
description: Carolyn Barr Anderson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton Jay Anderson Jr. of Weston, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Oliver Kimberly, the son of Mrs. Oliver Adams Kimberly of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mr. Kimberly. The Rev. Henry C. Galganowicz performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: American Ballet School Names New President
description: The School of American Ballet has announced that Robert Lindgren has been appointed its president. He succeeds Lincoln Kirstein, co-founder of the school with George Balanchine. Mr. Kirstein retired in September as the school president and the general director of the New York City Ballet.

title: Politics Among the Ruins
description: BETWEEN PAST AND PRESENT Archaeology, Ideology, and Nationalism in the Modern Middle East. By Neil Asher Silberman. 285 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $24.95. q

title: Joe Namath, Joe Louis and the Berlin Wall
description: The Berlin wall, which, spiritually if not physically, has been reduced to rubble in the last several, stunning days, has always been associated in my mind with the 1972 Olympics, and Joe Louis.

title: Campus Life: Illinois; American Indians Seek to Retire Chief Illiniwek
description: American Indian groups and a handful of University of Illinois students are calling for the ''Fighting Illini'' to retire their Chief Illiniwek symbol, charging that it is a racist figure.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: Collecting new issues from the United Nations has fallen somewhat out of favor with those who call themselves ''serious'' collectors. The organization has adopted the philosophy espoused by a number of smaller stamp-issuing entities (and big ones, too, like the United States): Stamps are no longer merely receipts for postal services; they are a commodity. If a stamp can be sold without having to provide the service, the income is almost pure profit.

title:
FIVE QUINTESSENTIAL EXPEDITIONS;
No. 3: Quest For a Metaphor
description: LEAD: In the November frost of 1981 I set out from my flat in the far West Village to gather all the materials I would need to build a metaphor in honor of my daughter, Savannah. I was going to create an environment in the Basement Workshop in Chinatown and fill it with symbols of her total African-American heritage, making it someplace where we could all go and discover what she came from, who her people were, how she was our destiny - Savannahland.

title: Lebanon's Christians Are Torn Over Peace
description: THE members of the most powerful Christian clan in Lebanon, the Maronite Catholics, were at each other's throats last week, barely a few weeks after their parliamentary representatives agreed with their Muslim counterparts on a formula for ending Lebanon's long civil war.

title: Intoxicated by My Illness
description: SO MUCH OF A writer's life consists of assumed suffering, rhetorical suffering, that I felt something like relief, even elation, when the doctor told me that I had cancer of the prostate. Suddenly there was in the air a rich sense of crisis, real crisis, yet one that also contained echoes of ideas like the crisis of language, the crisis of literature, or of personality. It seemed to me that my existence, whatever I thought, felt or did, had taken on a kind of meter, as in poetry, or in taxis.

title: Ms. Cayer Wed In Los Angeles
description: Susan Miranda Cayer and William Carlyle Foutz Jr., 1983 graduates of the Harvard University Law School, were married yesterday at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles. Justice Robert Feinerman, who retired as a presiding justice of the California Court of Appeals, officiated.

title: Miss Manik Wed To W. B. Welch
description: Karen Lynne Manik and William Brisbin Welch were married yesterday at St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Marlboro, N.J., by the Rev. Kevin Keelan.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ST. LOUIS;
Airport Growth Imperils Suburb
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the airline hub system - Trans-World Airlines flights radiate from St. Louis - has been a boon to Lambert Field here, the airport's growth has exacted a price from surrounding suburbs.

title: POSTINGS: Once a Saddlery; 16 Condos In TriBeCa
description: A saddle-maker's shop built in 1861 at 55 White Street at the corner of Franklin Place in TribeCa has been converted and enlarged into a 16-unit condominium with two duplex penthouses.

title:
THEATER;
Angels Rally to 'Good Men'
description: LEAD: Once upon a time a novice playwright with only two one-acts to his name - one of which had never been staged - sent his first full-length drama to a well-known Hollywood producer. The producer arranged to buy the screen rights and also agreed that before making the film he would buy the stage rights and present the play on Broadway.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $255,000 149 Gerritson Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, fireplace, c/a, 1-car garage, walking distance of beach; taxes $4,500. Bluepoint $128,000 70 Maple Street 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 75-year-old colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,700. Massapequa $352,000 400 Cameo Drive 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 28-year-old farm ranch; Florida room, den, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $7,200. Miller Place $291,000 8 Samuels Path 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 4-year-old contemporary; finished basement, 2-car garage, pool,; taxes $4,800. Shoreham $210,000 4 Locust Circle 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old ranch; den, fireplace, c/a, 1 acre, deeded beach rights; taxes $2,900. Wading River $189,000 7 Frost Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 0.5-acre, inground pool, 2-car garage; taxes $3,000. OTHER AREAS Southington, Conn. $215,000 89 Kingswood Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; inground pool, 0.67 acre; taxes $2,009. Somers, N.Y. $315,000 Edgewood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, workshop, 2-car garage, pool, 1.9 acres; taxes $4,971. Haskell, N.J. $149,900 9 Second Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, pool, full basement; taxes $2,800.

title: Not Just One German Question But Many
description: OF all the startling images on the night of Nov. 9, perhaps the most gripping was the sight of Germans streaming from both sides through the brightly illuminated Brandenburg Gate.

title: Reducing Prejudice Is Goal Of Project
description: LEAD: A YEARLONG project of lectures, educational and cultural programs, workshops and symposiums aimed at reducing prejudice began last month in New Haven. The cornerstone of the project is an exhibit entitled ''Anne Frank in the World: 1929-1945,'' which will be on display from Nov. 27 to Dec. 27 at the Southern New England Telephone Company Building on George Street.

title: Lebanese Leader Struggles to Form Cabinet
description: A week after being elected President of Lebanon, Rene Moawad remains a leader without a government despite intense efforts to draw his countrymen into a coalition cabinet.

title: Lobbyist Linked to Sex Case Is Found Dead
description: Craig Spence, a lobbyist linked to a homosexual escort service under Federal investigation, was found dead in a hotel room here, the police said today.

title: Making Policy of the Inevitable, Gorbachev Accepts Wide Change
description: Any doubt that Mikhail S. Gorbachev is prepared for a fundamentally new order in Eastern Europe has been largely erased this week, as Soviet officials calmly applaud the crowds pouring through the newly perforated Iron Curtain.

title: Review/Music; 2 Brands of Originality
description: Two pieces on the New York City Symphony's program at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night were new to this city; one was altogether new. This is standard operating procedure for an orchestra that has survived its ups and downs since 1926, but has always managed to extend its hospitality to American composers.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Out of the Swamp, A Classic Is Reborn
description: The alligator handbag, all the rage three decades ago, has returned - but with a few differences.

title: Computer Role in War on Drugs
description: LEAD: THOSE fighting to prevent drug and alcohol abuse and suicide in the county now have a new tool - a computer network that serves as a clearing house for information on resources and developments.

title: O Muse! You Do Make Things Difficult!
description: Dame Edith Sitwell used to lie in an open coffin for a while before she began her day's writing. When I mentioned this macabre bit of gossip to a poet friend, he said acidly, ''If only someone had thought to shut it.'' Picture Dame Edith, rehearsing the posture of the grave as a prelude to the side shows on paper she liked to stage. The straight and narrow was never her style. Only her much-ridiculed nose was rigid, though she managed to keep it entertainingly out of joint for most of her life. What was it exactly about that dim, contained solitude that spurred her creativity? Was it the idea of the coffin or the feel, smell, foul air of it that made creativity possible?

title: EVERYBODY'S FAVORITE SWINE
description: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS By Jon Scieszka. Illustrated by Lane Smith. Unpaged. New York: Viking Kestrel. THE THREE LITTLE PIGS AND THE FOX By William H. Hooks. Illustrated by S. D. Schindler. New York: Macmillan. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 8) THE THREE LITTLE PIGS Retold and illustrated by James Marshall. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers.

title: Boys of Winter
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. LINKS TEHERAN TO TERROR SQUADS
description: Every few weeks, a heavily laden plane flies from Iran to Syria with a cargo of weapons, food and other supplies. The material is then trucked across the border and distributed to various Shiite terrorist groups in Lebanon.

title: JAPANESE INCREASE DONATIONS IN U.S.
description: As Japanese companies increase their holdings in this country, many are multiplying their contributions to American charities, but a leading figure in Japanese corporate philanthropy says donations are not growing commensurately with investments.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
AMERICAN TREASURE HUNTS
description: LEAD: THE GREAT AMERICAN GOLD RUSH By Rhoda Blumberg. Illustrated. 135 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up) GOLD! The Klondike Adventure. By Delia Ray. Illustrated. 90 pp. New York: Lodestar Books/E.P. Dutton.

title: How Government Is Changing Dentistry
description: A FOND remembrance of childhood is the reward found under the pillow after the loss of a tooth. While inflation has taken its toll on parental indulgence (the going rate is a dollar a tooth in my house), there is no doubt that the tradition still flourishes.

title: POSTINGS: Reverse Mortgages and Repairs; New Help for Older Homeowners
description: Two government programs announced this month offer loans and grants to older homeowners having low incomes or housing problems or both. In Washington, the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, made available for the first time about $200 million in guaranteed funds for 2,500 so-called reverse mortgages to be insured by the Federal Housing Administration. In Albany, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal made available $750,000 for emergency home repairs.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: I put on my reporter's shoes last week and headed off to Photo Expo, a trade fair of mostly professional photography equipment that takes place every fall in New York City. I anticipated wallowing in new and useful photo goodies both from major camera companies and from one-man, one-product speciality firms.

title: Fernandez Offers Post to 'Spy' Superintendent
description: Colman Genn, the Queens superintendent who secretly tape-recorded conversations with patronage-seeking community school board members, has been invited to serve in the administration of the incoming Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez.

title: Tailgate Terrorists: Another Aspect
description: I read with interest Lydia Rosenfeld's letter to the New Jersey editor (Oct. 15) concerning ''tailgate terrorists,'' but she failed to mention the primary cause for that problem, i.e., the driver who tries to ''control'' traffic by driving 55 M.P.H. in the left and center lanes, instead of staying to the right.

title: Review/Music; Quintet's Taste for Adventure in Art
description: Of the five woodwind works the Quintet of the Americas presented at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening to celebrate its 10th anniversary, one in particular seemed to typify its adventuresome and self-effacing approach to its art. In C. Bryan Rulon's ''Quintet Too Plus One,'' written for the group in 1987, the players virtually disappeared amid the tangle of electronic paraphernalia that littered the stage, while the composer dominated the scene with his synthesizer and a conductor, Joel Sachs, kept order.

title:
FOCUS;
Philadelphia Trying to Channel Growth With Zoning
description: LEAD: City planners here are putting the finishing touches on zoning changes that would encourage developers to build office space along the business district's northern edge while making large development in its southern section less attractive. It would be done by regulating the width and height of buildings.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: Even though the 500th anniversary of the discovery of America is three years away, a slew of commemoratives is starting to appear. Belize and the Cayman Islands have both issued one and an organization called the Columbus Quincentennial Group has come out with another.

title: Breeding Doesn't Tell
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Bistro That Is Not Just Any Old Bistro
description: LETTERS, I get letters. And the majority of those letters this past year have lauded one restaurant. After visiting Michael's - A Bistro in Roslyn, I understand what all the fuss is about.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SAN FRANCISCO;
From Bullion To Briefs
description: LEAD: WHEN the Government opened its new Federal Reserve Bank building on Market Street at the edge of this city's financial district in March 1983, it put up for auction the small building four blocks away that had been its home since 1924.

title: School Economies Are Essential
description: Reading the three letters flailing Mr. Gerber for daring to suggest that economies can be made in school budgets [ ''Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education,'' Sept. 24 ] without impacting adversely on the education of children makes me despair of finding a basis for dialogue between the education establishments and the people of their communities. I define the establishment as school board, administration, and PTA.

title: Bonn Seeks to Allay Fears of Poland and Hungary
description: As Eastern Europe struggles to grasp the breadth and depth of the events at the Berlin wall, West Germany is trying to calm apprehension among the Eastern European governments most inclined to liberalization that Bonn's renewed fixation with East Germany might deflect attention from their own needs.

title: Defiance Wins Again in Yonkers Vote
description: ANGELO MARTINELLI, a Republican, lost the mayoralty here two years ago because his once firm opposition to a court-ordered housing desegregation plan had softened. The winner was City Councilman Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a 28-year-old Democrat who had urged continued opposition to the plan.

title: DAT Recorders For Home Use Finally Arrive
description: After about four years of anticipatory tizzy, American audiophiles can now walk into a store and walk out with a DAT recorder. DAT, as initiates know, stands for Digital Audio Tape; and the first digital tape recorder for home use is now officially on sale in this country. This is unquestionably a milestone, and the price is correspondingly hefty: $11,000.

title: DRIFTING FROM LOUT TO LOUT
description: ANCESTORS By Robyn Davidson. 299 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: FIGHTING AIDS ALL THE WAY
description: Larry Josephs points out in his article that AZT is a highly toxic drug that with prolonged use can cause bone-marrow depression, anemia and deterioration of large muscles. More information is needed before doctors prescribe AZT too readily for those who are HIV positive but have not yet been diagnosed with AIDS.

title: A Recount Deprives Spain's Socialists of a Majority
description: Spain's governing Socialist Party lost its majority in Parliament today when a provincial electoral committee ruled that a seat initially awarded to the Socialists in elections last month rightfully belonged to the United Left, a Communist-dominated coalition.

title: On Language; Chop on, Chop at, Chop-Chop
description: THE UNITED STATES Secretary of State, a man long familiar with bureaucratic slang, was explaining to reporters how Israel, the United States and Egypt would decide on which Palestinians would attend a meeting to arrange for elections in the disputed territories.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
description: Athletes who dominate their sport raise the standards for others to follow, inspire younger players, and bring in fans. The Celtics of the 60's, Steelers in the 70's, Edwin Moses for what seemed an eternity, were all dominant. I don't recall people asking if they were ''good'' for their sport.

title: Joan Siederer Is Married
description: Joan Ellen Siederer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Siederer of Highland Park, N.J., was married last evening to Eric James Stern, a son of Joanne Stern of Chester, N.J., and Marc Stern of Allentown, Pa. Rabbi Z. David Levy officiated at Temple B'nai Or in Morristown, N.J. Mrs. Stern, 27 years old, graduated from Rutgers University and received a master's degree in public health from the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, where her husband, 30 and a magna cum laude graduate of Moravian College, received an M.D. degree. He is a senior radiology resident at the University of Medicine and Dentistry, and Mrs. Stern is an assistant professor of radiation sciences there.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Price Leads Cavaliers Past Celtics
description: Mark Price returned from a sprained foot and scored 19 points, including three 3-pointers, as the Cleveland Cavaliers won their first game of the season by beating the Boston Celtics, 104-101, tonight.

title: Wrong on the Wall, and Most Else
description: The Soviet Union embarks on a second revolution and reaches out for peace with the West; East Europeans demand freedom and democracy; East Germans tear down the Berlin Wall and flee their country. These and other amazing changes erupt in world politics, and not one of America's foreign policy gurus comes within a country mile of predicting them. In fact, most foreign policy elites have spent the last few years explaining them away and counseling the West to do nothing. It has been a long and rocky road for America's foreign policy elite since Mr. Gorbachev came to power in March 1985. Not since Copernicus, perhaps, have so many been so wrong so frequently with so little humility.

title:
ART;
A Sweeping View of History
description: LEAD: THE Squibb Gallery has never looked as august as it does for the current exhibition, ''A Pleasant Likeness: Portraits and Landscapes of Central New Jersey, 1770-1920,'' organized by the Historical Society of Princeton.

title: THE EVOLUTIONISTS AT WORK ... AND AT WAR
description: LUCY'S CHILD The Discovery of a Human Ancestor. By Donald Johanson and James Shreeve. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: Some of what is interpreted to be stubbornness or excessive persistence may be made up of heavy doses of wishful thinking. When we see a prominent grandmaster return to a favorite defense that has never given him anything but headaches - and do so on only the flimsiest pretext that his new move is really a valuable improvement that rescues his line of play from disaster - one must wonder what is going on in his head.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Academics Ask, What's Next?; Joy for Germans, With a Few Caveats
description: Specialists on Germany and other European countries have expressed surprise and pleasure at the latest events in East Berlin and East Germany. But they warned that the far-reaching changes promised there could also bring problems and pain.

title: Vanderbilt's Mausoleum
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Carriage Houses; New Home For Ballet
description: Ten years ago the Ballet Hispanico of New York, a minority-oriented dance group that was gaining a foothold in the entertainment world, formally asked New York City officials if it could convert two former carriage houses in the West Side Urban Renewal Area into a permanent headquarters for the company and its school with studios, dressing rooms and office space.

title: All Work and Little Play Are Too Often Dad's Fate
description: I HAVE a vivid memory as a small boy, no more than 7 or 8, of playing outside my home late one afternoon and seeing my father return from work. I ran over to him with the excitement of a small boy who wants his father's love and approval to gleefully ask him about his day at work. I do not remember his words verbatim, but they were something to the effect that ''work was work.'' It was something that you had to do.

title: Going Back to School to Exercise And Chat
description: LEAD: HOW much does it cost to work out on state-of-the-art exercise machines and to be professionally supervised while doing so? For those who live in the boroughs of Allendale or neighboring Upper Saddle River, it's free.

title: Mylene S. Hodgson To Wed in December
description: December wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Raphael W. Hodgson of New York and Fairfield, Conn., for their daughter Mylene Sheridan Hodgson and John Talbot Curtis 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Curtis of Fairfield.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
description: You bet it is! So accustomed are we to seeing Graf win that the rare victory by her opponent takes on mythic proportions. Could any of us soon forget Aranxta Sanchez Vicario's victory over Graf in the French Open this year? Or not love the game that makes possible so unlikely and gutsy a triumph? DAVID KOLKEBECK Northampton, Mass.

title: Hot on the Trail of Missing Masterpieces
description: MARGARET I. O'BRIEN was on the phone again, this time talking to a man who had just received an exclusive, red-hot art tip. He was leaving momentarily to meet an art collector offering terrific deals on genuine Egyptian art - either modern art or some of that Pharaoh stuff, he wasn't sure which. The man wanted Ms. O'Brien to tell him if the art was stolen. He had no photos. He had no descriptions, no title papers. Ms. O'Brien explained that the cabinets in her Upper East Side office are stuffed with 30,000 files documenting stolen art cases and she would need more information from him. She also expressed her belief that it's best to know what millennium you're in when buying art.

title: Gold Leaf Adds Unity To Variety
description: GOLD, gold, gold - the glitter and the glow of it unify the diversified work of Sage Reynolds.

title: Equating Alcohol With Illegal Drugs
description: The New York Times did its readers a disservice by publishing unchallenged the Opinion page piece by Henry Schissler, chairman of the Substance Abuse Coalition in Cheshire (''Alcohol Lurks as a Gateway to Other Drugs,'' Oct. 22).

title: IT NEVER HURTS TO HAVE A FEW ENEMIES
description: LET THEM CALL ME REBEL Saul Alinsky - His Life and Legacy. By Sanford D. Horwitt. Illustrated. 595 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: The Great Real Estate Rush of '89
description: They are the dogs of real estate.

title: Corrections
description: An article headed ''Silent Majority'' last Sunday in the Education Life section, about evolving definitions of the ''average'' student, misidentified the director of guidance who described course identification numbers at Greenwich (Conn.) High School. He is John Whalen.

title: TV's Black World Turns - But Stays Unreal
description: There is a telling moment in the 1986 film ''Soul Man'' when a young man explains to a friend why he has decided to down a bottle of tanning pills and turn himself black. The friend is skeptical: What's it actually going to be like, being black?

title: Officer Is Slain; Suspect Arrested
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was stabbed to death yesterday in a fight over a minor traffic accident in Brooklyn as he returned home from a fund-raiser for the family of a fellow officer who was shot earlier this year, the police said. The police arrested a suspect in the slaying last night.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ANNUAL PARADE

title: IT'S SO MUCH EASIER TO WRITE ABOUT THE RICH
description: During the discussion after a recent talk I gave at a school, a sixth grader asked me, ''Why are people poor?''

title: Jeanne Moreau, Indestructible And in Demand
description: ''Usually when a woman is 60, it's over,'' says Jeanne Moreau, sipping Evian in her dressing room at the Theatre National de l'Odeon here. ''But now it begins again. During rehearsals I am confronted by things very mysterious. I have terrific fights with inner demons, and it's more painful than it ever was.''

title: A B C's at the E.P.A.
description: HE LOOKS A LIKE A FOOTBALL player at an alien training camp. But the creature at left is actually a student in New Jersey. The scene is from a class in Hazardous Material Incident Response Training, a program administered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and operated, in Cincinnati and Edison, N.J., by a private enterprise called N.U.S. (The acronym comes from Nuclear Utility Services, the name by which the company was previously known.) Paid for out of allocations from the Superfund legislation enacted in 1980 to address hazardous waste cleanup, the training program serves employees of government agencies on state and local levels, as well as E.P.A. personnel.

title: Brazil's Economic Crossroads
description: On the eve of its first direct presidential election in nearly 30 years, Brazil, the giant of Latin America, stands frozen at an economic crossroads. Frustrated by a decade of economic stagnation, Brazil's 82 million voters will now decide the path the Western world's eighth-largest economy will take in the 1990's.

title: No Rematch for Mom
description: According to Minna Wilson, the other shoe won't drop. Ever. Wilson, who attracted considerable notoriety when she climbed into a boxing ring in Southhampton, England, in September and beat her son's opponent over the head with her shoe, said she would not attend the ordered rematch between Tony Wilson and Steve McCarthy.

title: Campus Life: Fairfield; Students Find Their Beach Life Is Threatened
description: For the last 20 years Fairfield University juniors and seniors, at times as many as 800 of them, have enjoyed life on the beach. They have rented privately owned houses two miles from campus on some of the most expensive real estate in the nation.

title: Docudramas Are No Worse Than TV News; The Viewer's Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Masai Women Should Benefit From Changed Way of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: PUTTING ONE OVER ON HARRODS
description: SWEET ALICE By Coral Lansbury. 208 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: Review/Dance; A Comedy and a Mystery Intertwine
description: Linda Mussmann calls her new work, ''Little Stumps and Real Conversations,'' a comedy. It certainly was funny. But funny can mean peculiar as well as amusing. And Ms. Mussmann's multimedia piece was very peculiar.

title: At a Carousel Show, Hand-Carved Ferocity and Gaudy Charm
description: LEAD: FLASHING lights rotate beneath a curved red and white striped canopy at the entrance to Carousel Menagerie, the exhibition on view through Jan. 7 at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: HOW WE MAKE IT
description: COMMERCE. BUYING AND SELLING. MONEY - IF you can make it here, you'll make it anywhere. That's one of the most powerful images of New York City: this is the big time. Seven of the 10 largest banks in the United States are headquartered here, along with 6 of the top 10 financial institutions and 4 of the 6 largest insurance companies. New York Harbor is the most active in the country, moving 2 million tons a year. Over 1.5 million workers belong to 550 union locals in New York.

title: Joint Chiefs Must See Beyond Battlefields
description: To the Editor:

title: Potrait of a Wall Street Lady
description: ''GENTLE DRAGON Lady.'' That's the phrase Alice Young chose to describe herself for a profile commissioned by the Dewar's Scotch people. Ms. Young, 39, was recently selected by the liquor manufacturer as one of 50 youngish, accomplished New Yorkers, a ''Do-er.'' She accepted the honor, although she never touches the stuff.

title: NASSAU UPDATE
description: LEAD: EROSION PROJECT

title: SPEECHWRITERS AND POLITICIANS
description: Do we really need to hear how Peggy Noonan mingled with the great minds of America in the mess hall at the White House? Isn't the essence of her political thought encapsulated in her mastery of grand phrases, such as ''a thousand points of light,'' which somehow resonate without making waves? KATHLEEN O'NEIL New York, N.Y.

title: Talk to My Agent
description: CONSIDERABLY EARLIER IN THE CENTURY, A THEATRICAL producer telephoned an agent and said he needed an actor of some reputation who could play an elderly Jewish father and speak Yiddish.

title: Stacey R. Kaplan Plans a Wedding
description: The engagement of Stacey Robyn Kaplan to Gary Evan Schreiber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Schreiber of Sands Point, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Philip Kaplan of Bay Shore, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis McEnroe Is Upset: Unseeded Guy Forget of France slammed 11 aces and upset top-seeded John McEnroe, 6-4, 7-6, yesterday to reach the final of the Wembley indoor championships in England. Forget, who returned to the circuit in September after a five-month injury layoff, overpowered the unusually listless McEnroe, winning the tie breaker, 7-3. In the final today, Forget will face the French Open champion, Michael Chang, who is seeded second. Chang defeated unseeded Wally Masur of Australia, 7-6, 6-1.(AP) Lendl-Gustafsson Matchup: Ivan Lendl defeated Stefan Edberg, 6-0, 2-6, 6-3, and Magnus Gustafsson shocked his fellow Swede, Mats Wilander, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday to gain berths in the Stockholm Open final.(AP) Savchenko in Final: Unseeded Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union upset third-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 6-4, yesterday and advanced to the final of the Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. Today, Savchenko will play Zina Garrison, who defeated Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-3, 4-6, 6-1. (AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 4, Canucks 2: Guy Lafleur reached another milestone when he scored his 544th career goal with 4 minutes 54 seconds remaining last night in Quebec, giving the Nordiques a victory over Vancouver. The goal moved Lafleur, who spent most of his career with Montreal, into a tie for eighth place on the career goal-soring list with Maurice Richard, who retired from the Canadiens in 1960 as the National Hockey League's career leader in goals. Peter Stastny and Marc Fortier also scored for the Nordiques, who won for the second consecutive time after an eight-game losing streak. Vladimir Krutov and Greg Adams replied for the Canucks. (AP) Oilers 5, Capitals 3: Craig McTavish scored twice and Esa Tikkanen snapped a third-period tie as Edmonton defeated Washington in Landover, Md. Also scoring for the Oilers were Kevin Lowe and Craig Simpson. Scoring for the Capitals were Dino Ciccarelli, Yvon Corriveau and Dale Hunter.(AP) Soccer Chelsea 1, Everton 0: Steve Clarke scored early in the second half yesterday, giving first-place Chelsea a victory at Everton in English play while the slump continued for perennial power Liverpool. The Queens Park Rangers, battling to stay out of the first-division cellar, scored a 3-2 home victory over Liverpool, its fourth loss in five games. Arsenal, the defending league champion, moved into second place with a 2-1 victory at Millwall.(AP) Golf Benepe Ties Record: Jim Benepe of the United States tied the course record with a 65 yesterday and gained a share of the lead with Peter Senior of Australia after three rounds of the Australian P.G.A. championship. Benepe carded 7 birdies and 11 pars for a seven-under-par 65 in his third trip over the 6,950-yard Riverside Oaks course. He and Senior, who shot his second successive 68, were at 13-under 203.(AP) Coody Takes Lead: Charles Coody, who has not won on the Senior PGA Tour this season, shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the Las Vegas Classic. Coody birdied three holes on the back nine, including two in a succession on putts of 12 and 20 feet, to turn an even-par round into a one-stroke lead over Al Geiberger and Tom Shaw. Several players remained in contention for top prize money of $45,000 in the $300,000 tournament. Geiberger and Shaw were at 137 and the tour's leading money winner, Bob Charles, was at 138. Chi Chi Rodriguez, Lee Elder and Dave Hill stood at 139.(AP) Horse Racing Packett's Landing Wins: Packett's Landing, ridden by Craig Perret, registered a half-length victory yesterday in the $119,400 Gen. Douglas MacArthur Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Whodam, with Angel Cordero up, was second in the field of 10, two lengths ahead of Whiz Along. Packett's Landing covered the mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:48 2/5 and returned $7.40 for $2 to win. (AP)

title: Boston College Surprises Army
description: Army's outside chance for an invitation to the Liberty Bowl was dealt a severe blow today when Boston College rallied from a 14-7 deficit to upset the Cadets, 24-17.

title: Of Antibiotics And Concertos
description: To the Editor:

title: Docudramas Are No Worse Than TV News
description: To the Editor:

title: Office Space Surplus Is Seen as Easing
description: DESPITE what many believe is the region's largest surplus of office space in a decade, Henry W. Fries, the new president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said the vacancy rate in the county was no cause for alarm.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
The 'Roots' That Often Upset Developers
description: LEAD: TO those who have traced its roots and documented its occupants, an 18th-century house at 361 Half Hollow Road in Half Hollow Hills represents an important segment of local history. The house, built by the Carman family in 1718, was awarded local landmark status in July, which means it cannot be torn down without the approval of the Huntington Town Board.

title: RELIGIOUS SECT FIGHTS L.I. SCHOOL DISTRICT OVER CLASS ON AIDS
description: The Plymouth Brethren, a small religious order that shuns newspapers and television as ''pipelines of filth'' and rejects computers as ''paving the way for the Antichrist,'' is fighting to keep its children from attending AIDS prevention classes that are mandated by New York State.

title:
GARDENING;
Fallen Leaves and Autumnal Tasks
description: LEAD: NOW that the leaves have fallen, many gardeners still face the task of cleaning up. All too often that involves raking the leaves by hand, packing them into plastic bags and placing them by the curb to be picked up and hauled to a landfill. Not only does this contribute to the problem of diminishing space in landfills, but it is also ecologically unsound and, for the most part, unnecessary.

title: SNEAD AND NICKLAUS, COBB AND THE BABE
description: When a $625,000 bonanza in the recent Nabisco Championships vaulted Tom Kite ahead of Jack Nicklaus and Tom Watson on the PGA Tour's career money list, the curly-haired 39-year-old Texan acknowledged golf's distortion of dollars in relation to dominance.

title: Setting the Record Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: The Business of Earth Day
description: It began as a suggestion in 1969 by Senator Gaylord Nelson of Wisconsin for college teach-ins on environmental problems, but by the time the first Earth Day was celebrated on April 22, 1970, it had erupted into a nationwide patchwork of demonstrations and community activities that attracted 20 million Americans.

title: Laurie L. Minniece Marries in Houston
description: Laurie Louise Minniece, a daughter of Marian Fowlkes Minniece of Houston and John Gresham Minniece 3d of Marfa, Tex., was married in Houston yesterday to John Harold Schlesinger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Harold Schlesinger of North Haven, Conn. The Rev. Claude E. Payne performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church.

title: Glad to Be Back In New Jersey
description: Evelyn B. Gray's Opinion page article, ''Let's Just Pick Up and Leave'' (Oct. 8), struck a chord with me. In response I can only advise: don't leave!

title: It's Not Just Window Dressing
description: SIMON DOONAN, THE vice president and creative director of Barneys New York, stands before one of his Seventh Avenue windows and purses his lips slightly. He points at the sleeve of a jet-black Ronaldus Shamask jacket, where a stray white thread has been carelessly abandoned. ''That,'' he says, all firm and British, ''is not supposed to be there.''

title: A Recycling Authority Of Wide Repute
description: LEAD: DAVID BIRKBECK peered from under his red and white Ready-Mix cap and surveyed his domain. Speaking with the pride of a lord of the manor, Mr. Birbeck described North Stonington's resourceful effort to recycle trash, which he directs and which has brought national attention to the town of 4,400.

title: East Is East, and West Is West
description: BY now the parkas have been ransomed from the cleaners, the spare condominium key found and the snow tires rotated. You've remembered that a sleeping loft and the living room beneath it cannot be used simultaneously. Westerners are ready to exchange the Rockies, Sierras and entire Wasatch front for a glimpse of Berkshires ablaze with dazzling leaves. Northeasterners, remembering a nearly dry 1988 season, have an eye on the high annualsnowfall figures of the West and are making plans accordingly. Though the West has leaves and the East has snow, there are virtually no Westerners who go East to ski or Easterners who drive up our coast to see foliage. Call it tradition; comparisons often cause hurt feelings. Perhaps just say that the East has the edge in autumn, the West in winter.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Town-House Rentals; East Side Project Back in Construction
description: ''IT'S the biggest bargain in New York!'' said Monica Dalton, casting an admiring glance upwards toward the dazzling skylight in the one-family town house she is trying to rent out for the owner. The skylight covers the entire room. It swoops down from a height of 45 feet, halting 17 feet above the living room floor.

title: The Giddy Minimalism Of Jim Jarmusch
description: ''It's a sad and beautiful world,'' says Roberto (Roberto Benigni), a slight, sunny-natured, prematurely balding Italian emigre, to his two cellmates in Jim Jarmusch's 1986 comedy, ''Down by Law.''

title: College Coaches' Brief Encounters
description: Outside the office window of the new basketball coach at Arizona State University, it was difficult to tell what point of the season Bill Frieder had reached. At many places, a day like this, with the sun shining and the temperature high enough for students to wear shorts to class, would signal the end of winter and the middle of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Which in recent years at Arizona State has meant the end to the Sun Devil season.

title: 'Fathers Tend to Play More Than Teach'
description: FATHERS who play an active part in their children's development lead more fulfilled lives both emotionally and socially, according Dr. Kyle Pruett, a clinical professor of psychiatry at the Yale Child Study Center in New Haven. As well, the children of these nurturing fathers are more resilient and tend to have a broader range of problem-solving skills.

title: Gaffes of Waiters, Grumblings of Diners
description: Not quite 20, barely shy of 6 feet, just enough muscle from disciplined workouts, he looks so elegant in his spotless white tuxedo shirt and bow tie! For the next 12 hours (straight), he will leave physics, calculus, chemistry and all those exciting electives one hour's drive behind at Stony Brook University, and share his sunny disposition with the staff and diners of the rather elegant Long Island restaurant where he is employed part-time.

title: CHARITY THAT STRANGLES THE POOR
description: LORDS OF POVERTY The Power, Prestige, and Corruption of the International Aid Business. By Graham Hancock. 234 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: In Cambodia, It Can Happen Again
description: LEAD: When the U.N. was created out of the ashes of World War II and the Holocaust, one purpose was implicit: It will never happen again. This week, that promise is to be tested by a U.N. resolution on a Cambodian political settlement that, if passed, will give a green light to Pol Pot and his army to continue their offensive until they reach Phnom Penh and plunge

title: Two Tyrannies
description: Historic. Now there's a word journalists love. But what other word is there for democracy's advances last week on German streets, and in the American elections? The dominating demons of our lifetimes are Communism and racism; what is it but historic when the first tyranny shudders and the second continues, visibly, to soften?

title: A Life Afloat, Bound to the Tide
description: IT is fall, the beginning of my 10th year afloat. Six eager gray-brown cygnets are clacking their bills against my houseboat's catwalk, demanding their midday snack. They are nearly as large as their graceful swan parents, but adolescent-gangly, lacking their parents' elegant ease.

title: Docudramas Are No Worse Than TV News; Abolishment Will Do
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CHRISTMAS TREE FESTIVAL

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: West/Southwest; Southern Cal Wins Pacific-10 Title
description: Ricky Ervins's 151 yards rushing put him over 1,000 yards this season and helped Southern California beat Arizona today, 24-3.

title: Eastern Europe's Changing Face
description: SOVIET UNION

title: Missing Inmate Used Fake I.D.
description: A man jailed on felony drug charges escaped by impersonating a man facing lesser charges, the police said. The Rochester police said the man, Curtis Walker, 37 years old, was missing from the city jail early Friday. He and another prisoner, Gerald Smith, were waiting to be booked at about 1:30 A.M. when deputies called for Mr. Smith. He had fallen asleep and Mr. Walker answered for him, said Sgt. Louis D'Angelo. Mr. Walker telephoned an acquaintance and had him pay Mr. Smith's bail, Sergeant D'Angelo said. Officials said they thought Mr. Walker overheard information that allowed him to convince jailers that he was Mr. Smith. Mr. Smith had been charged with selling fake narcotics, a misdemeanor.

title: Double Indemnity
description: The United States Navy says the death of 47 sailors aboard the battleship Iowa last April was no accident, but the Amex Life Assurance Company apparently feels otherwise. Navy investigators suspect that the explosion in one of the Iowa's huge gun turrets was intentionally set off by Clayton Hartwig, a sailor who carried a $50,000 life insurance policy that named his shipmate, Kendall Truitt (pictured with wife, Carole) as beneficiary. Last week, the insurance company decided to pay off the $100,000 benefit due under the accidental-death clause of the policy, with part of the payment going to Mr. Hartwig's family. Amex maintained that the payment had been delayed only because of a dispute between the Hartwigs and the Truitts. But Mr. Truitt's lawyer said payment had been held up while the company decided whether Mr. Hartwig had committed suicide. ''If the insurance company thought he had committed suicide, they would not have paid,'' the lawyer said. In any case, the Navy continued to stand by its two-month-old report, which found that Mr. Hartwig had ''most likely'' deliberately caused the explosion.

title: SPEECHWRITERS AND POLITICIANS
description: Peggy Noonan's article ''Confessions of a White House Speechwriter'' (Oct. 15) is instructive because it describes what many Washington insiders already know: politicians are detached from the words they speak and the ideas they communicate because other people do the writing and thinking for them.

title: Finding Value in a Software Slowdown
description: BY many measures, 1989 has been a rough year for computer software companies. Several major vendors were late in shipping updates of key programs. Distributors have been forced to take write-offs because of inventory surpluses and have not ordered as much new inventory as vendors expected. What is more, sales of personal computers have flattened.

title: OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR
description: Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc'' is described as ''nearly the length of a city block.'' It ''stuck up from the plaza like a shark's dark fin.'' I do remember it as being very long, but that romantic description reminds me of the fish I caught last summer: it, too, was nearly the length of a city block. The point is to use the imagination to see. Seeing is not a passive activity, like sleeping.

title: Bhutto Rewards Opponents Who Helped Her Win a Vote
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government awarded ministerial jobs today to three opposition politicians who switched sides in Pakistan's Parliament to help her narrowly survive a no-confidence motion two weeks ago.

title: BIG BUSINESS REACHES OUT TO BLACK SUPPLIERS
description: With the nationwide dismantling of set-aside programs that guarantee a percentage of public contracts to minority-owned companies, black businesses are looking increasingly to the private sector.

title: U.S. Agencies Twist as Budget Cutbacks Linger
description: The possibility, no longer remote, that across-the-board cuts in Government spending might stay in effect for the entire fiscal year is causing consternation in many departments and agencies.

title: HOME ENTERTANMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR
description: You ask, in your article, why the French love the sculptor Richard Serra while Americans recognize him for the fraud he is. For that matter, why do the French love Jerry Lewis? They obviously have some odd ideas regarding talent. EVE GOLDEN Secaucus, N.J.

title:
ART;
The Aldrich Fills Its Rooms With Expansive Sculptures
description: LEAD: IN the late 1970's and early 1980's, installations were the thing. Essentially, they are an expansion of sculpture. But whereas sculpture shapes space, installations essentially fill it up, furnishing it with diverse objects. With this license, installations could become more daring than other art forms.

title: CLASH IN MOLDAVIA BRINGS CRACKDOWN
description: A day after thousands of angry citizens stormed the Interior Ministry building in the Soviet republic of Moldavia during six hours of clashes with the police, the authorities there have banned public meetings, ordered the confiscation of privately held weapons and stationed extra troops in Kishinev, the capital.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Chappaqua, N.Y. $530,000 80 Annandale Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, eat-in kitchen, family room w/cathedral ceiling, wet bar, flagstone patio, 1.48 acres; taxes $8,098. North Tarrytown, N.Y. $450,000 4 Hardwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 62-year-old Norman Tudor; 2 sun rooms, terrace, playroom, 3,000 square feet; taxes $6,796. Somers, N.Y. $315,000 Edgewood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, workshop, 2-car garage, pool, 1.9 acres; taxes $4,971. Brookfield, Conn. $284,000 4 Guernsey Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; library/office, family room w/cathedral ceiling and skylights; taxes $2,838. East Haddam, Conn. $93,500 110 Lakeside Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old seasonal lakefront cottage; private beach, 50- by 160-foot lot; taxes $566. Southington, Conn. $215,000 89 Kingswood Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; pool, 0.67 acre; taxes $2,009. OTHER AREAS Bluepoint, L.I. $128,000 70 Maple Street 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 75-year-old colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,700. Massapequa, L.I. $352,000 400 Cameo Drive 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 28-year-old farm ranch; Florida room, den, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $7,200. Haskell, N.J. $149,900 9 Second Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old Cape Cod; pool, full basement; taxes $2,800.

title: Achilles' Shield
description: To the Editor:

title: Kammi Goldberg Married in Capital
description: Kammi Lynn Goldberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Goldberg of Potomac, Md., was married last evening at the Grand Hotel in Washington to Brad Michael Reiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Reiss of New York and Redding, Conn. Rabbi David Bochman performed the ceremony.

title: Alabama Winner Despite Obstacles
description: On a night of imperfections, the Crimson Tide of Alabama preserved their perfect season. The Tide overcame six turnovers in a 32-16 victory over Louisiana State to clinch at least a tie for its 19th Southeastern Conference championship.

title: MANY ARE ARRESTED AT ABORTION CLINIC
description: Scores of protesters seeking to block an abortion clinic were arrested today, setting a confrontational tone as thousands of people began arriving here for an abortion rights rally scheduled for Sunday.

title: Joan Miles Wed To Clifford Bob
description: Joan Mary Miles, the daughter of Richard J. Miles of Glen Spey, N.Y., and Ludmila Miles of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Clifford Allan Bob, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. Bob of Jamestown, N.Y. The Rev. Harris Riordan, a Unitarian minister, officiated in the rotunda of the administration building at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our 10-year-old kitchen countertop is covered with plastic laminate in a butcher block pattern. The surfaces near the sink have become rough and feel coarse, and there are water stains on the surface. How may these areas be restored to their original condition?<

title: TRUE GRIT
description: HOW IT FEELS TO FIGHT FOR YOUR LIFE Written and photographed by Jill Krementz. 132 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $15.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: Leftover Change
description: To the Editor: In her article on converting currency (Practical Traveler, Sept. 3), Betsy Wade, in offering a solution for using leftover foreign currency, was probably unaware that Change for Good is the registered trademark of our organization in the United States. We collect foreign money, which we convert into U.S. dollars. We use this money to fund the Partners in Education, which we created in conjunction with the Potomac Area Council of the American Youth Hostel. The program brings together disadvantaged and handicapped youth groups with young people from around the world who are staying at youth hostels in the District of Columbia, Gettysburg and Baltimore for one- and two-day outings as well as events at the Kennedy Center and other local programs. One hundred percent of the money collected goes for the program. Other expenses are funded by private and corporate donations.

title: DATA UPDATE: November 12, 1989
description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS *2*(Residential in millions of dollars) Sept. 89 Sept. 88 Change New York 156.2 117.3 +33% New Jersey 180.3 261.8 -31% Connecticut 114.1 160.7 -29% *4*(Source: F.W. Dodge Division, McGraw-Hill Information) *4*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.13 10.15 10.47 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.70 8.73 8.16 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 9.90 9.95 10.25 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.51 8.49 8.11 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.02 10.03 10.41 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.63 8.64 8.46 Co-ops (N.Y.) Treasury security 7.89 7.81 8.10 National Mortgage Contract Rate 9.82 9.82 8.98 *Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes. (Source: HSH Associates)

title: Sarah McNally Married in Rye
description: Sarah McNally, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McNally of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to William H. Lynn 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lynn of Atlanta, Rye, N.Y., and Scotland Cay, the Bahamas.

title: Children to Meet Authors
description: LEAD: DURING Children's Book Week, tomorrow through next Sunday, many youngsters will have the opportunity to meet their favorite authors. And they will discover that even writers who travel to far and exotic places are happy to return to their hometowns, the very places they share with their readers.

title: SPEECHWRITERS AND POLITICIANS
description: I have read Peggy Noonan's article. I read ''First Big Stupid Thing I Did'' and then ''Second Big Stupid Thing I Did'' and ''Third Big . . .'' etc., etc. I'm still waiting to read one of the ''Bright Things'' she did.

title: A Savings Failure That Illustrates Everything Wrong With the Industry
description: THE collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in California has come to represent a microcosm - in the extreme, to be sure - of the failure of hundreds of other thrift institutions at a cost to taxpayers of more than $100 billion.

title: South Carolina Hurricane Loss Is $3.7 Billion
description: In the first comprehensive portrait of how Hurricane Hugo ravaged one state, a report by state and Federal agencies and private businesses puts the total losses in South Carolina at more than $3.7 billion.

title: Architectural Forgery
description: To the Editor:

title: G. H. Schweitzer, 79, A Painter and Sculptor
description: Gertrude Honig Schweitzer, an artist whose works are in collections at several prominent museums, died Friday after a brief illness, at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. She was 79 years old and lived in Colts Neck, N.J., Palm Beach, Fla. and Santa Fe, N.M.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Haskell $149,900 9 Second Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, pool, full basement; taxes $2,800. Jersey City $60,000 7 Stevens Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; front garden, close to mass transit, full basement; taxes $1,092. Livingston $223,500 14 Birchtree Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; 1-car garage, w/w carpeting, c/a, dining room; taxes $2,891. Marlboro $314,900 2 Secretariat Square 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 5-year-old colonial; patio, family room, c/a, 2-car garage; taxes $4,200. Short Hills $560,000 11 Hickory Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 46-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, den, 2-car garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $7,209. West Orange $385,000 75 Wildwood Way 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 48-year-old colonial; fireplace, 2-car garage, patio; taxes $5,071. OTHER AREAS Wading River, L.I. $189,000 7 Frost Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 0.5-acre, inground pool, 2-car garage; taxes $3,000. Southington, Conn. $215,000 89 Kingswood Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 14-year-old raised ranch; inground pool, 0.67 acre; taxes $2,009. Somers, N.Y. $315,000 Edgewood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, workshop, 2-car garage, pool, 1.9 acres; taxes $4,971.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Even Past Its Prime, Wine Is Excellent for Cooking
description: Bill Plante, CBS State Department correspondent and well-known enophile, confessed recently to a little experiment he conducted with leftover wine: he put it in the freezer. When he took it out, he put it in a microwave oven to thaw. It was, he said, quite drinkable, and since his first experiment he has continued to store and thaw leftover wine this way.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Graf's Dominance Good for Tennis?
description: Certainly, if Steffi Graf continues to dominate women's tennis it will be denied the excitement generated by a great rivalry like Evert-Navratilova. But for tennis fans, Graf more than makes up for this with the beauty of her game. She is an exceptional athlete whose renowned power game is complemented by graceful court movement and a first-rate volley.

title: Reviews/Music; American Chamber Works
description: The Chelsea Chamber Ensemble's all-American program last Monday night at Weill Recital Hall, part of American Music Week, offered a mixed bag of accessible 20th-century American music. Too accessible, sometimes, in that blandness replaced challenge and innovation, but still mostly pleasant and well played.

title: The People Take Over
description: It took three and a half hours to get back through Checkpoint Charlie.

title: Review/Music; Chamber Orchestra In Debut
description: Gene Forrell, a conductor who has led several New York-based chamber orchestras, has formed a new band, which he is calling the Vivaldi Traveling Circus. At its debut concert, on Thursday evening at Florence Gould Hall, the orchestra included one Vivaldi work among its offerings. There was nothing circus-like or even indecorous in its stage demeanor. As for travel, touring figures in Mr. Forrell's plans.

title: After the Flood, Art
description: There is a picturesque example of nature and art imitating each other in a lower corner of Central Park, where a sculptured zoo meanders along the paths between the real-life menagerie and the duck pond. It is called Noah's Art, and it harbors beasts that the ark never took aboard - steel lions and stone birds, a bald eagle with an alabaster head, and a concrete tiger that looks like an animal cracker walking down a gangplank.

title: ENSLAVED BY THE KING OF SIAM
description: YUL The Man Who Would Be King. A Memoir of Father and Son. By Rock Brynner. Illustrated. 252 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: F.A.A. Orders Broader Inspections of 747's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has directed airlines to expand previously ordered inspections of Boeing 747's to the entire nose section of all 747's that have made 15,500 or more flights.

title: A Taste of the World in a Melting Pot
description: LEAD: NORTHERN New Jersey is a melting pot of ethnic populations offering an intriguing glimpse into the world's cultures. Despite the suburban reputation of homogeneity, ethnic neighborhoods thrive, helping preserve centuries of tradition.

title: BEST SELLERS: November 12, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 THE DARK HALF, by Stephen King. (Viking, $21.95.) After a writer of horror tales kills off his pseudonym, the deceased goes on a murderous rampage. 2 2 11 CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $21.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords. 3 3 4 FOUCAULT'S PENDULUM, by Umberto Eco. (Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $22.95.) Ancient documents and arcane codes produce astonishing results when thrown into a computer. 4 6 4 TALES FROM MARGARITAVILLE, by Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) Short stories set on a mythical Caribbean island. 5 5 8 JIMMY STEWART AND HIS POEMS, by Jimmy Stewart. (Crown, $9.95.) Verses by the venerable motion picture star. 6 11 3 SOME CAN WHISTLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A middle-aged writer meets the daughter he has never seen. 7 4 9 THE PILLARS OF THE EARTH, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $22.95.) The lives of men and women whose fortunes are linked by the construction of a cathedral in 12th-century England. 8 7 9 CALIFORNIA GOLD, by John Jakes. (Random House, $19.95.) A young man from Pennsylvania makes his fortune in 19th-century Los Angeles. 9 9 3 POODLE SPRINGS, by Raymond Chandler and Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $18.95.) The private eye Philip Marlowe discovers the dark underside of an exclusive southern California desert mecca. 10 10 5 THE MINOTAUR, by Stephen Coonts. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The hunt for a mole in the Pentagon who is giving defense secrets to the Russians. 11 8 9 OLDEST LIVING CONFEDERATE WIDOW TELLS ALL, by Allan Gurganus. (Knopf, $21.95.) A 99-year-old woman reflects on her past. 12 16 4 FOREVER FIFTY: And Other Negotiations, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) Poems celebrating the pains of growing older. 13 * 13 32 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) What happened to the crew of the Enterprise after its five-year ''Star Trek'' mission. 15 1 SURE OF YOU, by Armistead Maupin. (Harper & Row, $18.95.)
