Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 8 2 MY TURN, by Nancy Reagan with William Novak. (Random House, $21.95.) The former First Lady's memoir of her White House years. 3 2 8 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays. 4 3 5 ROSEANNE, by Roseanne Barr. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) The autobiography of the television comedian. 5 4 11 AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder. (Todd/Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A year in the life of a fifth-grade teacher in Holyoke, Mass. 6 5 4 CONFESSIONS OF AN S.O.B., by Al Neuharth. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The experiences of the founder of USA Today. 7 7 82 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 8 6 5 I WANT TO GROW HAIR, I WANT TO GROW UP, I WANT TO GO TO BOISE, by Erma Bombeck. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Fifteen stories of children surviving cancer. 9 9 23 IT'S ALWAYS SOMETHING, by Gilda Radner. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The late comedian's memoir describes her battle with ovarian cancer. 10 15 2 EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) The author recalls the places he visited and the books he read in his youth. 11 * 17 2 CHILI DAWGS ALWAYS BARK AT NIGHT, by Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $17.95.) Essays on politics, religion, sex, golf, etc., by the syndicated columnist. 12 10 9 THE WRITING LIFE, by Annie Dillard. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) A writer describes and reflects on the creative process. 13 * 1 WONDERFUL LIFE, by Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $19.95.) What the contents of a small quarry in the Canadian Rockies have revealed about the past and about scientific methods. 14 1 DRIVE, by Larry Bird with Bob Ryan. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The autobiography of the Boston Celtics basketball star. 15 1 LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $18.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed and participated in by a young bond trader. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 42 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 2 4 2 MARTHA STEWART'S CHRISTMAS, by Martha Stewart. (Potter, $18.95.) Advice about cooking, decorating and entertaining during the holidays. 3 2 21 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Norton, $18.95.) A new regimen for weight loss. 4 3 3 LIGHT HIS FIRE, by Ellen Kreidman. (Villard, $17.95.) Ways by which a woman can retain a man's love. 5 18 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AnD BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) ORDINARY LOVE & GOOD WILL: Two Novellas, by Jane Smiley. (Knopf, $17.95.) Twinlike, mutually resonant fictions on the theme of domestic happiness - one through the eyes of a mother, the other from a father's perspective - are shaped with a sympathy for humanity's tendency to destroy its own best visions. GEORGIA O'KEEFFE: A Life, by Roxana Robinson. (Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row, $25.) This portrait of the artist whose simplicity seemed to signal a deeper connection with the world also explores the intricacies of her marriage to Alfred Stieglitz. THE WATERLINE, by Joseph Olshan. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A child's drowning and a family's disintegration are at the center of this novel, a small-scale tragedy of suburban New York whose finale packs a solid emotional charge. JAZZ CLEOPATRA: Josephine Baker in Her Time, by Phyllis Rose. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A life of the wildly famous nightclub performer who mesmerized Paris in the 1920's, displaying the biographer's wit, panache and gift for the tangential. CANTOR'S DILEMMA, by Carl Djerassi. (Doubleday, $18.95.) The search for scientific truth is the subject of a comedy of academic manners about a cancer researcher's aim for stardom. THE STORYTELLER, by Mario Vargas Llosa. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) Mr. Vargas Llosa's intellectual, political, ethical and artistic concerns meet in this novel about Western civilization's expansion toward a tribe of Amazonian Indians. AND THE WALLS CAME TUMBLING DOWN: An Autobiography, by Ralph David Abernathy. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) A colorful, earthy, sometimes even humorous account of the civil rights movement, told by a man who was right at its center.

title: What Cracked the Wall
description: Westerners who venture into East Germany quickly discover a major source of the popular explosion that is toppling the Berlin wall. It can be described as the unbearable tedium of being.

title: Egyptian Leader Outlines Economic Changes
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt outlined plans for economic changes today in a policy speech.

title: Review/Theater; In a West Texas Setting The Reprise of a Miracle
description: Robert Schenkkan's ''Heaven on Earth'' (at the WPA Theater) is a minor, miracle play of limited scope and familiar intent. Over the playwright's shoulder is the shadow of deja vu, as he tells the story of how the tiny town of Waylon briefly became the Lourdes of West Texas.

title: Open-Faced Immortality For Tuckahoe Lawyer
description: LEAD: SHELDON HOROWITZ of Tuckahoe is soon to be immortalized on a menu. Mr. Horowitz, a lawyer who works in Manhattan, has earned a historic distinction: he is the first non-celebrity to have a sandwich named for him at the Stage Delicatessen in Manhattan.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: NATURAL OBSESSIONS: Striving to Unlock the Deepest Secrets of the Cancer Cell, by Natalie Angier. (Warner, $14.95.) A journalist becomes resident anthropologist in a molecular biology lab, chronicling the search for genes that cause cells to become malignant. Natalie Angier ''admirably dispels any thought that the ivory tower of research is a haven for selfless nerds and drudges,'' Eric Lax said here last year. ''The people in her book are as attractive and as complex and even as quirky as their subjects.'' DICTIONARY OF THE KHAZARS: A Lexicon Novel in 100,000 Words, by Milorad Pavic. Translated by Christina Pribicevic-Zoric. (Vintage, $9.95.) Until their disappearance a millennium ago, the Khazars lived in a land where the seasons were marked by calendars that flowed in both directions and it was possible to read colors as though they were words. Milorad Pavic's novel about this fictional tribe is as malleable as the Khazars' worldview: flipping back and forth among alphabetized, cross-referenced entries, readers can assemble a do-it-yourself narrative. Last year our reviewer, Robert Coover, said he found the book ''rather light and airy,'' but he praised ''the structural novelty and the comic inventiveness of the imagery.'' SEEDS OF FIRE: Chinese Voices of Conscience. Edited by Geremie Barme and John Minford. (Noonday/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) In a new foreword, Orville Schell tells how this collection of works by dissident Chinese writers foreshadowed the recent events in Tiananmen Square. In January, The Times's Richard Bernstein said the book ''fills a yawning gap'' in the West's knowledge of human rights in China. ''It thrusts a candle of illumination into the dark shadow of ignorance that has long cast itself over the world's most populous country.'' THE HIGH ROAD, by Edna O'Brien. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) An Irish expatriate shatters the languid calm of a Spanish island when she has an affair with a local peasant girl. ''The language here is often infused with an intense energy,'' Marilynne Robinson said here in 1988. THE DARK SIDE OF THE UNIVERSE: A Scientist Explores the Mysteries of the Cosmos, by James Trefil. (Anchor/Doubleday, $9.95.) The author of ''A Scientist at the Seashore'' explains why physicists have come to believe that 90 percent of the matter in the universe is invisible. James Trefil ''shows once again that he can describe the history and philosophy of science humorously, anecdotally and yet profoundly,'' David Perlman said here last year. ''He can also make a persuasive case for the pure esthetics of physics and astronomy.'' THE AGE OF GRIEF: A Novella and Stories, by Jane Smiley. (Ivy, $3.95.) In the title piece of this collection, the marriage between two dentists becomes so strained that they can talk to each other only about teeth. In 1987 our reviewer, Anne Bernays, said the book ''is artless in the best sense, a triumph of the craft of narrative, for we believe that all written here really happened.'' THE RITES OF AUTUMN: A Falconer's Journey Across the American West, by Dan O'Brien. (Anchor/ Doubleday, $9.95.) A biologist teaches a tamed peregrine falcon how to survive outside civilization. ''We are absorbed not only in the falcon's struggle to regain her place in the wild, but also in the almost symbiotic relationship that develops over time,'' Harry Middleton said here earlier this year. ''It is as if Mr. O'Brien too is somehow participating on a last and desperate migration, a migration to steep himself in what is left of the once great wilderness lands of the American West.'' BROTHERS IN ARMS, by Michael Carson. (Plume/ New American Library, $8.95.) While coming to terms with his homosexuality, an English schoolboy decides to join a seminary. ''The attitudes and motivations of the characters are rendered with precision, yielding what seems to be a realistic depiction of gay rites of passage,'' Richard C. Skidmore said here last year. THE FIRST SALUTE, by Barbara W. Tuchman. (Ballantine, $11.95.) By retelling a selection of favorite stories, Barbara Tuchman puts the American Revolution into the context of 18th-century European politics. She ''chronicles these events with her customary skill,'' John Gross said in The Times last year. ''She rises to the heroic and tragic aspects of the drama, but she can be drily amusing, too.'' SUMMIT, by D. M. Thomas. (Washington Square/ Pocket Books, $4.95.) An actor turned President shows up at a European summit conference with a strategic antimatter defense system (Independent Unilateral Defense, or I.U.D.) that was inspired by a computer game invented by his grandson. Last year Michiko Kakutani said in The Times that D. M. Thomas is ''so adept at using his gifts for mimicry to parody diplomatic double talk that even his wildest scenarios sparkle with a kind of crazy logic.'' THE ESSENTIAL GESTURE: Writing, Politics and Places, by Nadine Gordimer. Edited by Stephen Clingman. (Penguin, $9.95.) In a collection of essays, articles and speeches, the South African novelist tells how she can keep living under a regime that is a ''pact of capitalism and racism.'' Last year our reviewer, William Boyd, called the book ''stimulating and timely.'' AN ARTIST OF THE FLOATING WORLD, by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Vintage, $8.95.) Living in disgrace after World War II, a Japanese artist remembers how as a young man he decided to use his talents to glorify the imperialist movement. Last year our reviewer, Kathryn Morton, said Kazuo Ishiguro's novel ''is the kind that stretches the reader's awareness, teaching him to read more perceptively.''

title: Commack Comedian Tells It Like It Was
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH many young comedians her age are just struggling to carve a niche for themselves, Rosie O'Donnell, a 27-year-old native of Long Island, already has made the ''big time'' nationally.

title: Survey Finds Many Alone on the Commute
description: MORE people in lower Fairfield County drive to work alone than do drivers in the rest of the state, according to a recent survey, and nearly half of the Fairfield drivers think that commuting has become worse in the last year or two.

title: Ewing Honored
description: The Big East yesterday named Patrick Ewing, who led Georgetown to three appearances in the N.C.A.A. Final Four and to a national championship in 1984, as its men's basketball player of the decade. Ewing, the center for the Knicks the last four seasons, went on to become the first player taken in the 1985 National Basketball Association draft.

title: Sad but Loyal
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 5 Senators Reportedly Under F.B.I. Scrutiny
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an inquiry into the role played by five Senators who intervened on behalf of a troubled savings and loan, The Washington Post reports in its Sunday issue.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: It's all very well if you're a Mary Smith, William Jones, Michael O'Neal or Alice Goldsmith. It's pretty hard to mispronounce those names, although the world being what it is, and people being what they are (well, some people anyway), it probably does happen.

title: Faulty Work Cited At a House
description: EACH time it rains, Anita Safarowic looks out the window of her four-year-old house here and wonders if this could be the moment it slides down the steep hill.

title: A 'Butterfly' Caught Up in a 'Tempest'
description: ''Approach, my Ariel, come, '' commands Frank Langella as Prospero in a new production of ''The Tempest.'' Music plays. From stage left, a creature in silky black pants and sandals flies in, chest bare, long hair in outlandish braids. He lights on a rock. Perched, eyes fixed on the distance, he offers raptly, ''To fly/ To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride/ On the curled clouds'' for his master Prospero. He sails across the stage again, supported not by wires but through what appears to be an innate capability of flight, and lands as if on a current of air. He floats. His knees slowly bend and straighten; his arms gradually, just perceptibly, rise and fall on the invisible breeze. It seems more or less coincidental that his feet are in contact with the ground.

title: Article 200589 -- No Title
description: The authorities seized about 64 pounds of cocaine valued at $3 million that was flown aboard an Air Force cargo plane from Panama to Dover Air Force Base and arrested two men, Federal officials said today.

title: Virginia McGraw Planning to Marry Charles Seaverns
description: The engagement of Virginia Snyder McGraw to Charles Bushnell Seaverns has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Virginia A. Parker of Weston and Chatham, Mass., and James H. McGraw 3d of Short Hills, N.J., and Hobe Sound, Fla. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Appleton Hillyer Seaverns of Suffield, Conn., and Hobe Sound, and the late Jeanice H. Seaverns. A January wedding is planned.

title: Lujan Tries to Counter Drive Against Offshore Oil Wells
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., who has played a low-key role in the Bush Administration, has mounted an aggressive campaign to counter growing opposition to offshore oil leasing and production.

title: Style Makers; Ritchie Jackson, Chair Designer
description: Two years ago, Ritchie Jackson, an architectural technician from South Africa, took up chairmaking as a hobby. Last summer, a sleek, high-backed armchair he created in black leather and brushed steel won first prize in an international design competition co-sponsored by the Connolly Brothers, a leather-making company here, and Joseph, the chain of design and fashion shops owned by Joseph Ettedgui.

title: An Evening of Writing By Raymond Carver
description: ''If You Call That Love (You Can Have It),'' an evening devoted to the writing of Raymond Carver, is planned for Nov. 20 at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Mr. Carver died last year at the age of 50.

title: In Splendid Isolation On the Tetons's Far Side
description: WE skied in the west last winter, partly to check on a rumor. Four of us - my wife, Holly, our 7-year-old daughter, Hilary, our friend Susan and I - began our mid-January holiday with three days at Jackson Hole, the great Wyoming resort that I'd skied before and wanted to introduce the others to. But at home in Connecticut, we'd decided to take advantage of a combination deal that would also give us a taste of Grand Targhee, a resort a little over an hour away from Jackson Hole, on the other side of the Tetons. Word had filtered through that this obscure area in the Targhee National Forest - in Alta, Wyo., but accessible only through Driggs, Idaho - combined some of the West's best powder and deepest snowfall (an average of 500 inches a year) with the kind of low-key atmosphere that's all but disappeared from the big mountains of the American ski scene.

title:
FILM;
Milos Forman Takes a New Look at Old Loves
description: LEAD: On a wet, gloomy morning, Milos Forman, wreathed in a cloud of smoke from an expensive cigar, sits in his apartment 30 stories above the mist-shrouded sprawl of Central Park, exuding calm, confidence and generous bonhomie. Why is this man smiling?

title: Teaching Teen-Agers to Control Violence
description: ''MY boyfriend didn't like what I was wearing today. He told me to change, but I said no. So he grabbed me and threw me up against the wall.''

title: 5 Trials Down, 3 to Go
description: As the court system disposes of indictment after indictment, the Iran-contra affair seems to be turning into a sort of crime without a perpetrator. Of the four people sentenced so far in connection with the illegal sale of arms to Iran to raise money for illegal contributions to the contras, none has been found guilty of actually selling the weapons and none has gone to jail. It appeared last week that Richard V. Secord had made a bid to join the community service corps when, days before his trial on 12 felony charges was to begin, he pleaded guilty to a single count of lying to Congressional investigators. Mr. Secord, a former Air Force major general, could get up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. But he also agreed to testify in coming Iran-contra trials and his sentencing was delayed. Mr. Secord is expected to be helpful in the prosecution of the remaining defendants: John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, whose trial is to begin Jan. 22; Albert A. Hakkim, an Iranian-born arms dealer, whose trial date has not been set; and Joseph F. Fernandez, a former Central Intelligence agent, whose trial has been postponed.

title: Defending Quality
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: IT is a wee bit early to start thinking about Representative James J. Florio's place in history, but the occasion of his election as governor gives us an excuse to look at the 48 other white males who have served in that office since New Jersey became a state in 1776.

title: Fashion; Flannel, for Counting Sheep Cozily
description: Come winter, fashion sense selectively hibernates and function sense takes over, especially at bedtime. Silky wisps and briefs may be banished in favor of comfortable grandmother-approved night clothes.

title: Outdoors; Field and Stream and Coffee Table
description: I can think of no reading that would better sustain the fly fisherman in the wintry months ahead than that provided by Frank Sawyer's ''Keeper of the Stream'' (Pueblo Publishing Company, $14.50, paperback). This is the first American edition of the book, which was originally published in England in 1952.

title: THE EVOLUTIONISTS AT WORK ...
description: THE HOMINID GANG Behind the Scenes in the Search for Human Origins. By Delta Willis. Introduction by Stephen Jay Gould. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95.

title: Namibian Election Turnout Over 90%
description: Namibia's first election in its transition to independence wound up tonight with a turnout by voters that has surprised and pleased election observers.

title: Could Cadence Catch Mentor?
description: Shorter product life cycles have forced product design cycles to shrink, making software tools to automate electronic design a necessity in industries like semiconductors, computers and consumer electronics. At the same time, a wave of acquisitions and mergers over the last two years has reduced the number of players in the electronic design automation software industry to four top companies.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Redeveloping Newark's Grimy Waterfront
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH modern office towers have sprouted around it for the last 10 years, Newark's Passaic River waterfront has remained a grimy industrial tract of rubble-strewn lots and squat brick factories, many of them empty.

title: THE MAIDEN ALWAYS GETS HER MAN
description: THE EGYPTIAN CINDERELLA By Shirley Climo. Illustrated by Ruth Heller. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 8) TATTERCOATS Collected and edited by Joseph Jacobs. Illustrated by Margot Tomes. Unpaged. New York: Putnam's Sons. (Ages 5 to 9) PRINCESS FURBALL Retold by Charlotte Huck. Illustrated by Anita Lobel. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Sloatsburg
description: WHEN George Washington stopped at Sloatsburg, an old Rockland County joke has it, he told the residents not to change a thing - and they haven't.

title: SHE IS REAL AND SHE IS SERIOUS
description: THE IRON LADY A Biography of Margaret Thatcher. By Hugo Young. Illustrated. 570 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: Miss Martin Wed To Robert Irwin
description: Thene Mishon Martin and Robert Pettit Irwin were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert W. Griggs at the Lynnhurst Congregational Church in Minneapolis. The bride, 26 years old, is the daughter of Mrs. Clyde A. Martin of Edina, Minn., and the late Mr. Martin. The bridegroom, 27, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney R. Irwin of Westfield, N.J.

title: Jean Dyer, Investment Officer, Is Wed
description: Jean Murray Dyer and Barclay Gibbs Jones 3d were married yesterday in SS. Philip and James Roman Catholic Church in Baltimore by the Rev. James V. Hobbs. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexius A. Dyer of Baltimore. Mr. Jones is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y.

title: The Best Beds
description: Where people sleep says a lot about them. While other rooms in the house are more in view, bedrooms are intimate settings, places in which the occupants can really relax. Here are peeks at a special few. Camping out in Manhattan.

title: Montclair St. Wins
description: Ed Baffige threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to John Walker in the second quarter yesterday afternoon and Montclair State went on to defeat Glassboro State, 20-12, and clinch the New Jersey State Conference title at John Page Field in Glassboro, N.J.

title: Healing Comes Slowly to Woods and Streams Where Hurricane Left Death
description: From the Virgin Islands to Puerto Rico to South Carolina, Hurricane Hugo left a legacy of environmental destruction that is just now being catalogued and will take some areas years to overcome.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: A Day Trip Through the Wall; Family Says Of the West, 'It's a Dream'
description: In the midst of the carnival fever that seized West Berlin today, 4-year-old Gregor Stephan stretched out on a bench in a small inn just off the Kurfurstendamm where his family was having lunch, put his head in his father's lap and fell asleep.

title: Parking Spaces
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Rescue Nothing Like Panama Coup
description: To the Editor:

title: Country French in a Revamped Setting
description: AFTER a fire destroyed Stonehenge, an old farmhouse turned inn in Ridgefield, it emerged from the ashes, completely rebuilt, and re-opened its doors last May. A first-time visitor would never know that anything had ever been amiss. But former patrons will miss the large, homey entrance lounge and note changes in the downstairs configuration and decor.

title: Comings and Goings
description: EARL CURETON, a veteran of five National Basketball Association teams, signed yesterday with Philips Milan, the champion Italian club he left in 1983. Cureton, who played six games for Philips Milan in 1983 before breaking his contract and returning to the N.B.A., will reportedly be paid $300,000, with an option for another year.

title: A Sour Anniversary for Brazil's Monarchists
description: As candidates crisscross Brazil in executive jets in the final days before presidential elections on Wednesday, some Brazilians advocate turning the clock to a more antique form of government: the monarchy.

title: A HOT STREAK FOR DEMOCRACY
description: DEMOCRACY AND ITS CRITICS By Robert A. Dahl. 397 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press.

title: The Joffrey Performs a Masterpiece Masterfully
description: Whatever the reason, the Joffrey Ballet is dancing at a peak this season at the City Center, where its repertory has been shrewdly scattered over several programs to appeal to different audiences.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: NEWPORT, R.I.;
A New Project For the Needy
description: LEAD: THIS oceanfront resort known as a playground for the wealthy, with many homes priced above the means of most of its permanent residents, is working on plans for yet another of the projects that have made it second in the state only to Providence in its proportion of subsidized housing units.

title: Joan Harting Wed to Dennis Barham
description: Joan Lancaster Harting, a daughter of the late Shirlie Harting and the late Dr. Hugh Richard Harting of St. Louis, and Dennis Malcolm Barham, the son of Ellen Barham of London and the late Robert H. Barham, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley.

title: Election Victory Casts Spallone in a New Role
description: A poster titled ''Yonkers News'' said it all for placard-carrying supporters of Henry Spallone on election night: ''Yonkers to Wasicsko: Goodbye.'' Now the city is preparing to consider the consequences of ''Yonkers to Spallone: Hello.''

title: Sarah L. Watchman Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Surtess Watchman Jr. of New York and Remsenburg, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Link Watchman, to Thomas Francis Burchill 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burchill 3d of Garden City, L.I., and Westhampton Beach, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Charles Blake, Educator, 78
description: Charles Blake, a retired teacher in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a founder of the Academy of Lifelong Learning, a continuing education program for the elderly in Wilmington, Del., died of congestive heart failure Thursday at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del. He was 78 years old and lived in Wilmington.

title: Jill Wolfe Weds Mitchell Roberts
description: Jill Kathryn Wolfe and Mitchell Jonathan Roberts were married last evening at Le Meridien hotel in Boston. Rabbi Samuel Chiel officiated, assisted by Cantor Charles Osborne.

title: 2 Easy Winners
description: Where is the best place to prepare to run the New York City Marathon? Why, Colorado, of course. That is where Juma Ikangaa of Tanzania, who broke the course record by 12 seconds last Sunday, and Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway, the winner of the women's division, trained for the race through the city's five boroughs. Mr. Ikangaa, a 29-year-old Army officer and a world-class runner with a reputation for not winning the big ones, normally trains near his home in Arusha, not far from Mount Kilimanjaro. For New York, however, he moved to Alamosa, Colo., which is flatter but twice as elevated as his home. ''Running there is very difficult because the air is so thin,'' he said. When Ms. Kristiansen, who is 33 years old and who ran the entire marathon in front, returned to her home in Boulder, Colo., in September, she wanted to withdraw from the race. She was exhausted from a bout with bronchitis and a taxing European competition. But after a week's layoff and thinking about what she could accomplish in New York, the only major marathon she had not won, Ms. Kristiansen resumed training, saying to herself, ''I will go for it.''

title: ANTI-DRUG FUNDS AROUSE CONFLICT
description: Even as the nation's mayors and governors push President Bush to provide more resources for the war on drugs, they have been waging a civil war over whether the cities or the states ought to control the new Federal funds pledged to the battle.

title: Walesa Visits Niagara Falls
description: Lech Walesa visited Niagara Falls today, where the Solidarity leader became another tourist attraction. In the rain, Mr. Walesa was surrounded by about 100 people trying to get a glimpse of him. On the second day of a four-day Canadian trip, he is trying to encourage investment to support the Solidarity-led Government's programs in Poland. He is to fly to Washington Monday. After meeting Niagara Falls' Mayor, Bill Smeaton, Mr. Walesa said he doesn't want to run for office. ''I prefer to be a small boss,'' he said.

title: Docudramas Are No Worse Than TV News; Truth and Facts
description: To the Editor:

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Taking Chowder Personally
description: LEAD: ASK any New Englander where to find the best chowder in town, and chances are good he won't recommend a clam bar down the street, or a fish house up the coast, or any of the big restaurants with the big names in Boston or Providence. The best, he'll tell you, is served right in his own home.

title: Critics' Carping Follows Sabatini
description: Gabriela Sabatini is just 19 years old, but she has already earned over $2 million, and tomorrow, she will make her fifth appearance in the invitation-only Virginia Slims championships at Madison Square Garden, where this year she is the defending champion.

title: Keeping the Spirit of the 60's Alive
description: LEAD: LIVING in Spokane, Wash., and raising two young sons, Gladys Glass did not go to Woodstock in 1969. She was working as a nurse and selling craft items while her husband, Harvey, a dermatologist, served in the Air Force. Bu Woodstock is a journey she has been taking ever since.

title: Prospect of a Mall Stirs Colorful Debate
description: PEOPLE heading into Watertown should consider the colors they wear. A red baseball cap might indicate support for a proposed multimillion-dollar regional shopping mall, while the flutter of a bright orange kerchief would place someone in the opponents' camp.

title: Healthco Intl Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months included 39 weeks, compared with 40 weeks in the year-ago period.

title: Pacific Economic Group Makes Progress at Meeting
description: The inaugural Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting, attended by representatives of 12 countries last week, achieved modest progress.

title: Ortega Move May Break U.S.-Nicaragua Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Rangers Cautious Despite Good Start
description: JOHN VANBIESBROUCK, who as a goaltender in the National Hockey League is quite used to being put in awkward positions, agreed without complaint to take part in a hypothetical situation.

title: Alisa Wilson Becomes Bride
description: Alisa Wilson, a daughter of Kirke P. Wilson of San Francisco and Gail Harnett of Mill Valley, Calif., was married yesterday to F. Sutton Cunningham Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Foster S. Cunningham of Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Charles McLain, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Old St. Hilary's Church in Tiburon, Calif.

description: Listed below are the release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Retail Sales ... Oct. Industrial Production ... Oct. Prior to the offering, the company was a wholly owned subsidiary of Kinder-Care Inc.

title: Trial Forces Miami to Confront Its Legacy of Racial Tensions
description: When testimony begins this week in the trial of a police officer accused of two killings that set off a riot in January, this city will again confront some of its rawest concerns - race relations, immigrants and police conduct - and, if the officer is acquitted, the fear of another riot.

title: Adjustments Expected in Mexico Pact
description: Mexico is getting far less in new loans than it hoped for when it worked out a debt agreement with its bankers in July. Because of this, bankers involved in the agreement say that some difficult last-minute adjustments are likely to be necessary.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is where the old heart of Berlin used to beat, and it will beat again.'' -Mayor Walter Momper of West Berlin, greeting Mayor Erhard Krack of East Berlin at Potsdamer Platz. [ A1:6. ]

title: Gold Found in Greenland
description: Danish and Canadian geologists have discovered a huge gold deposit in Greenland, reportedly one of the largest ever found, a Danish newspaper reported today.

title: L.A., Ever Evolving, Goes Square
description: LEAD: Several months ago, I left New York temporarily to become a producer of a television show in Los Angeles. Here, then, is an update on the state of L.A., and it isn't pretty: L.A. has become aggressively normal.

title: Dolphins Deflate Jets, 31-23
description: In this season of failure, the Jets today not only fell to Dan Marino's passing arsenal, but on their faces as well.

title: Graham Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains from sale of real estate of $757,000 and $498,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and included $338,000 in charges of discontinued operations and disposal of Graham Hobal Ltd. for the quarter and the 9 months included $1,386,000 of charges for discontinued operations and disposal of Grahan Hobal Ltd. adn gain of $347,000 for an accounting change.

title: Andrea Z. Goldberg Is Married on L.I.
description: Andrea Z. Goldberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Goldberg of Long Beach, L.I., and David Aboulafia, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Aboulafia of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday by Rabbi Asher Murciano at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: Dolores Ibarruri, 'La Pasionaria' Of Spanish Civil War, Dies at 93; An Indomitable Leftist
description: Dolores Ibarruri was better known at home and abroad under her battle name, La Pasionaria, the Passion Flower. A Basque left-winger who was a founder of the Spanish Communist Party, she won international renown during the Spanish Civil War for her indomitable stand.

title: Jack Lipson, Lawyer, 45
description: Jack Lipson, the chief of operations of the Federal defender services unit of the Legal Aid Society for the last decade, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Port Washington, L.I. He was 45 years old and lived in Port Washington.

title: Hers and His Backpacks
description: Backpacks in sizes for men and women, to account for the sexes' difference in torso length and waist contour, are being put on the market for 1990.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 3 about the Boeing Company's partnerships in Japan misidentified an aerospace specialist at the Harvard Business School. She is Heather Hazard.

title: Living on the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Merryl Freedman Wed To Dr. R. L. Schechtman
description: Dr. Merryl A. Freedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Freedman of Woodmere, L.I., and Dr. Richard L. Schechtman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schechtman of Forest Hills, Queens, were married yesterday by Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Omi Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $5,502,000. Share earnings reflected the payment of dividends on preferred stock.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Sabres Win With :001 Left: The Sabres squandered their second two-goal lead late in the third period but beat Edmonton, 6-5, in Buffalo on a goal by Dave Andreychuk with 1 second remaining.

title: Worldcorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIGHTING IS FIERCE
description: In their largest coordinated attack in almost a decade, leftist rebels today besieged dozens of targets across the country and in the capital, including the President's private home and his formal residence.

title: Westchester Homeless Linger in a Connecticut Hotel
description: Linda Powell was puzzled when Westchester County social workers sent her family from a welfare hotel in Putnam County, N.Y., to a hotel for homeless people in this Connecticut city, instead of somewhere in Westchester. The officials promised Ms. Powell it would be for just one night.

title: Harlem Youth Is Slain; 17-Year-Old Arrested
description: A dispute between two teen-agers on a street corner in Harlem yesterday afternoon ended with one shot to death and the other arrested for murder, the police said.

title: Has O'Brien Lost Nerve?
description: OVER his six seasons as the Jets' quarterback, Ken O'Brien has earned a reputation as one of the National Football League's toughest competitors. He's been sacked as much as any truckload of Long Island potatoes, but he's always stood his ground against the assault of opposing pass rushers. He's not nimble afoot, but when he's had to scramble he churned his legs for an extra yard.

title: Decisions By GATT Accepted
description: The United States is moving to conform with several recent decisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international body that oversees world trade and issues rulings on disputes.

title: Abortion, the Voters and the Court
description: Voters in Tuesday's elections confirmed a new and startling political truth about abortion: The issue, once seemingly a winner for right-to-life candidates, can now punish these candidates at the polls. It can turn or swell the tide for pro-choice candidates like James Florio in New Jersey, Douglas Wilder in Virginia and David Dinkins in New York City. Energized by a hostile Supreme Court, the defenders of a woman's right to choose are no longer on the defensive.

title: Varco International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the revenue increase is mainly due to the acquisition of the BJ Machinery division from Baker Hughes Inc.

title: New York Post's Owner Is Optimistic
description: In the 20 months that the real estate developer Peter S. Kalikow has owned The New York Post, he says it has cost him about $80 million and some prized friendships.

title: Tokyo Journal; Sex Harassment: Glare of Light on a Man's World
description: Six months after joining a publishing company in southern Japan as a clerical worker, Miss H. heard the first office rumors about her supposed affairs. A senior editor, she learned later, found her behavior ''coquettish'' and was spreading false gossip.

title: Broncos Win on Late Kick
description: Fifty-two seconds were left, and during the timeout, the Kansas City Chiefs' defense huddled and discussed ways it could stop John Elway and the Denver Broncos. The game was tied at 13-13, and Denver was at the Chiefs' 39 facing third and 8.

title: Lawyer Says His Case Pits Ethics vs. Right to Dismiss
description: With rare exceptions, employees in New York can be dismissed for just about anything and have no legal recourse. But now, a Manhattan lawyer is asking whether it was legal for his firm to dismiss him for what he says his profession ethically demands: blowing the whistle on a colleague he says was dishonest.

title: Argentina to Get $1.4 Billion
description: Argentina has received approval for a $1.4 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Combustion Engineering Inc., Stamford, Conn., a maker of energy products, named Robert K. McClammy and David L. Nelson vice presidents.

title: Old-New Anti-Semitism
description: LEAD: Anti-Semitism is on the rise in Europe again. Since Israel's invasion of southern Lebanon in 1982, anti-Jewish headlines and articles have appeared in mainstream newspapers and magazines. Before 1982, anti-Semitic letters would have been thrown in the waste-basket. Now they are published. Before 1982, denying the Holocaust or trivializing it by cheap comparisons would have been unacceptable in the media.

title: U.S. Calls Attacks in Salvador Desperate Acts
description: Bush Administration officials today called a wave of attacks in El Salvador moves of desperation by insurgents who are becoming increasingly isolated from the population and said that the offensive posed no threat to the United States-backed Government.

title:
Sports World Specials: BASEBALL;
The Greatest of the Greats
description: LEAD: Shrouded in as much secrecy as the Academy Awards but probably with more lively debate, the greatest moment in the history of baseball - at least, one group's opinion of the greatest moment - has been decided.

title: Browns Top Seahawks, 17-7
description: Bernie Kosar passed 17 yards to Lawyer Tillman for a third-quarter touchdown, and Matt Bahr kicked a 29-yard field goal in the fourth quarter as Cleveland, the leader in the American Conference Central Division, beat the Seattle Seahawks, 17-7, today. It was the Browns' fourth consecutive victory.

title: INSIDE
description: La Pasionaria Dies Dolores Ibarruri, the president of the Spanish Communist Party and the fiery orator who, during the Spanish Civil War, came to be known as ''La Pasionaria,'' died in a Madrid hospital at the age of 93. Page B15. Peruvians Vote Peruvians turned out in large numbers for municipal elections as threats by leftist guerrillas to disrupt the voting failed to materialize. Political leaders said the turnout was a setback for the guerrillas. Page A3. Rallies for Abortion Rights Tens of thousands of people gathered in Washington and other cities, celebrating political victories and vowing to make the right of choice a central issue in the future. Page A14. U.S. Switch on Trade Hoping to strengthen international rules, the White House has accepted several decisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that differed with American law. Page D1. Tragedy at Ole Miss Since a Mississippi football player was paralyzed Oct. 28, the response of sentiment and financial support has been great, but the shock won't go away. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television; On Cable, Battle for Laughs, Audiences and Profits
description: WHEN Home Box Office announced its intention to create the first all-comedy channel on cable television, the company's chairman, Michael J. Fuchs, offered an insight: ''Funny is money,'' he said.

title: Public Service Co of North Carolina reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMMUNISTS CALL CONGRESS; 2 East Germans Back Home Because 'Our Life Is Here'
description: Thorsten Rohr, a 21-year-old masonry worker, is seven years younger than the Berlin wall. Like hundreds of thousands of other East Berliners, he and his wife, Ursel, have spent most of the last three days wandering around West Berlin for the first time in their lives. This afternoon they came back home.

title: Sports World Specials: COLLEGE FOOTBALL; 75 Years in the Stands
description: The 75th anniversary of the opening of the Yale Bowl is Saturday, when Yale plays Harvard for the 106th time. Since the bowl opened on a cold day in 1914, 479 games have been played there and Al Ostermann has seen all but one.

title: Bridge
description: The result of the Life Master Women's Pair Championship here Saturday had two remarkable aspects. The victory by Sabine Zenkel was the first national title to be won by a player from West Germany, and the first in memory to be won by a player making a debut at this level.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * JWP Inc., an electronics company, to Brouillard Communications, a unit of J. Walter Thompson, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Broken Heart of Berlin Is Coming Back to Life
description: Just three days ago, Potsdamer Platz was a no man's land of scraggly meadow and a few forlorn buildings with boarded-up windows. The busiest junction of Western Europe's roads and rails before Berlin's division, its transit traffic had dwindled over the years to rabbits, rodents and people walking their dogs.

description: The Soviet Union appears to have adjusted its program for building long-range nuclear arms in anticipation of a strategic arms treaty, Bush Administration officials said today.

Also, the 1989 quarter included other income of $229,000 from the sale of marketable equity securities, representing $14,000 in realized gains and a $215,000 decrease in previously recorded unrealized losses.

title: Ms. Wilkerson And R. J. Watts Wed in Maryland
description: Isabel Alexis Wilkerson, a correspondent in the Chicago bureau of The New York Times, and Dr. Roderick Jeffrey Watts, an assistant professor of psychology at DePaul University in Chicago, were married yesterday at Oxon Hill Manor in Oxon Hill, Md. The Rev. Dr. Yvonne K. Seon, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: New York Area on Foot
description: New York City is the walking capital of the United States, with more than 75 walking clubs and 60 guided walking tour organizations for the city's varied terrains and landscapes. For information on walks, contact the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, 2 Columbus Circle, New York, N.Y. 10019. The bureau's telephone number is (212) 397-8222. Also contact the New York/ New Jersey Trail Conference, 232 Madison Ave., Room 908, New York, N.Y. 10016. Telephone: (212) 685-9699.

title: Man Kills His Wife And Stabs Himself
description: A Maryland man stabbed his estranged wife to death Saturday night at her parents' home in Queens, wounded his father-in-law and stabbed himself, the police said yesterday.

title: Review/Pop; Whimsy Imbued With a Beatles Presence
description: Of the many English pop bands whose sound derives directly from the pre-psychedelic Beatles, Squeeze ranks as one of the most accomplished. Led by the songwriting team of Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrook, the quintet, which performed at Madison Square Garden on Friday evening, even has its own Ringo Starr-like musical personality in its cutup keyboardist, Julian Holland, who recently rejoined it after an unsuccessful solo sabbatical.

title: High-Stakes Poker at the Berlin Wall
description: LEAD: Germany may be one nation, but it remains two separate states. In human terms, the German people are reunited. But on the political level, what is happening in the two states is not a first step toward reunification. Rather, we are witnessing a high-stakes game of poker in which the effective leveling of the

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Berenter Gets Car Dealers Job
description: Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster has graduated from Matchbox cars to the real thing with its appointment by the Chevrolet Dealers of the New York A.D.I. to handle their $5 million to $6 million account. (The initials in the group's name come from the television term area of dominant influence.) Part of Berenter's presentation to the dealers was a small box whose cover stated that the agency has sold more Fords than J. Walter Thompson, more Pontiacs than D.M.B.&B., more Mercurys than Young & Rubicam and so on. Opened up, the box showed five Matchbox toy cars and the claim that the agency could apply the same skills to Chevrolet. Berenter's president, Barrie

title: Lions Upset F.D.U.
description: Two brothers, Chris and Nick Ziadie, teamed for three goals and an assist yesterday as unranked Columbia upset 13th-ranked Fairleigh Dickinson, 4-1, at Baker Field in the first round of the N.C.A.A. Division I men's soccer championships.

title: Untouchables Gain the Help Of a Brahmin
description: It was his determination to free poor Indian scavengers from a life of carrying away buckets of excrement on their heads that turned Bindeshwar Pathak, an academic social scientist, into a full-time crusader against the humiliations of untouchability. It also made him a celebrity among the poor.

title: Ferrofluidics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Laurel Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company attributed the earnings decline to an absence of a gain on the sale of investment securities due to unfavorable market conditions. Such gains accounted for $118,000 in income a year earlier.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Media Rates
description: Family Media Inc. announced a series of magazine advertising rate increases last week. Discover magazine will increase its rates 6 percent while expanding its rate base by 10 percent, to 1.1 million. There will also be rate increases of 7 percent at Savvy; 10 percent at Golf Illustrated; 10 percent at Taxi; 7 percent at World Tennis; 10 percent at Model and 5 percent at Health. The increases will take effect in February.

title: First Marathon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Television; HBO Using More of Its Own Programming
description: Something new has been popping up recently on network prime time: a big, glossy $50 million advertising campaign for Home Box Office. The country's biggest pay-cable service has taken to promoting itself heavily on competitive channels even while promising its own subscribers that HBO presentations will never be interrupted by commercials. There is method, even urgency, in HBO's tactics.

title: A Pioneer in Residential Drug Treatment Reaches Out
description: In a sunny atrium near the famous sprawl of the United Nations, experts in the treatment of drug and alcohol addiction met last week for an international conference. They had come to New York from places like Thailand, Canada, Argentina and Australia. Many had come, they said, because of one man: Msgr. William B. O'Brien.

title: Pain and Generosity at Ole Miss
description: IF football is the religion of the South, this is one of its most evocative temples, a place where the game blends into the dense history of a school that has often played out the richest and darkest passions of the region.

title: Treasury Sales to Be Concluded This Week
description: The Treasury's quarterly refinancing, which was postponed for a few days last week as a result of Congress's delay in increasing the nation's debt ceiling, will be concluded this week. Only the three-year note auction was held last week.

title: Crimes Up in Early '89, F.B.I.'s Statistics Show
description: A 7 percent increase in robberies paced a 5 percent increase in violent crime during the first half of this year, according to statistics released today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Destroyer and Merchant Ship Collide, Killing a U.S. Sailor
description: A Navy destroyer collided with a merchant ship off Malaysia early today, and one American sailor was killed and four were injured, a Navy spokesman said.

title: Ortega Move May Break U.S.-Nicaragua Ice; Contra Violations
description: To the Editor:

title: Dealing With the Sudden Shock of Freedom
description: ''I'm dizzy from the events in Berlin,'' the East German playwright Heiner Muller announced in prefacing the American premiere of ''The Man in the Elevator,'' his music theater collaboration with the composer Heiner Goebbels that was presented as part of the New Music America Festival.

title: Elizabeth J. Hahn Wed in Scarsdale
description: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., Elizabeth Jane Hahn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Hahn of Scarsdale, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard H. Dyckman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Dyckman of Briarwood, Queens. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Stage Seems Set for Lower Rates
description: The positive tone in the credit markets that has largely prevailed since mid-year is apt to remain in place well into 1990, analysts said, setting the stage for further reductions in interest rates.

title: Satellite Studying the Sun Is Falling Out of Orbit
description: There will be no saving Solar Max this time.

title: Elizabeth Goldberg Wed in Connecticut
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Jane Goldberg, a daughter of Barbara Goldberg of Manchester, Conn., and the late Jack Goldberg, to Peter James Granath, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Granath of Darien, Conn., took place yesterday at the Inn at Long Shore in Westport, Conn. Sanford Glassman, a justice of the peace, officiated. Mrs. Granath, 25 years old, graduated from the Loomis Chaffee School and Boston University. She is an associate at Grey Advertising in New York. Her mother, Barbara Goldberg, is an English instructor at the University of Hartford; her father was a founder of Stone-Goldberg, a real-estate development firm in Manchester.

title: Savings Official's Ties In Senate Investigated
description: The inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into possible criminal charges against Charles H. Keating Jr., former head of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., has been expanded to include Mr. Keating's dealings with five United States Senators, Government officials said today.

title: IDB Communications Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said revenue increases in the quarter and 9 months were due to the acquisition of Hughes Television Network and substantial growth in Data-Voice and International Television Transmission Services.

description: The share earnings are in units.

title: General Metal & Abrasives reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fluke (John) Mfg.  Co(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: The company said latest full year results included a net gain of $7.6 million, including gain from the sale of land, partially offset by investment writedowns.

title: Mcorp Deal Is Delayed
description: The Banc One Corporation has announced a two-month delay in closing its deal to acquire Mcorp's failed banks from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation because it is taking longer than anticipated to review Mcorp's loan portfolios.

title: Governing Long Island: A Jurisdictional Jumble
description: On Old Country Road, a busy four-lane thoroughfare in Nassau County, the speed limit westbound is 30 miles an hour, but the speed limit eastbound is 40. The reason says a lot about why many Long Islanders are challenging the way their local government operates.

title: Flossmoor Journal; For Pickup, No Parking In Its Own Driveway
description: When they pass Jim Minx's driveway, some people scoff and roll their eyes. Others lament the decline of standards. One resident became so incensed that he took pictures of the awful sight to Village Hall, demanding action at once.

title: This Weekend, Walk, Don't Run
description: BOTH tourists and city-dwellers are finding that weekend walking is the best urban sport. City walking, divided into five sports styles -strolling, hiking, climbing, brisk, and long-distance - offers a variety of places and ways to stay active. And walking during a weekend means you'll have the extra time to enjoy your outing, whether within the city limits or in nearby wilderness.

title: Nu-Gro Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company had only four months of operations during the previous year, when it had earnings from operations of $77,000, or 4 cents a share, on sales of $2,613,000 for the period ended June 30. A $930,000 special charge made final net loss for the year-ago four months $853,000, or 45 cents a share.

title: Jersey Woman Fatally Shot Driving Car Through Harlem
description: A New Jersey woman was shot and killed early yesterday in what appeared to be a pre-dawn robbery while she was driving through Harlem with her 4-year-old son, the police said.

title: Choreographer Awards
description: The National Corporate Fund for Dance has announced five recipients of the third annual American Choreographer Awards. They are David Dorfman, Miriam Mahdaviani, Sara Pearson and the choreographic team of Danial Shapiro and Joanie Smith, all of New York, and Liz Lerman of Washington. The awards, underwritten by the General Electric Foundation, carry a cash prize of $5,000 for each winner and are given in recognition of talented emerging choreographers.

title: Election in Namibia Worries Whites
description: As the elections held this week bring home the prospect of black majority rule for Namibia, the white inhabitants of this northern mining town are worried.

title: Nevada Goldfields Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said that in the latest first quarter, the Kingston Mine, which accounted for over 60 percent of the company's gold production during the previous fiscal year, was placed on standby.

title: Hamilton Oil reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,394,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,906,000, or 24 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Hammer Home After Surgery
description: Armand Hammer went home today, two days after he received a heart pacemaker at U.C.L.A. Medical Center. The 91-year-old chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation ''feels great'' and expects to be back in the office on Tuesday, said an Occidental spokesman, Frank Ashley Mr. Hammer, who has had heart trouble for more than 20 years, received the pacemaker on Friday.

title: Asserting Involvement, Deng Calls on Army to Obey Party
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, called on the army today to obey the Communist Party and suggested he would remain involved in national affairs despite his formal retirement last week.

title: COMMUNISTS CALL CONGRESS; Square is Mobbed
description: With a shower of sparks and the creak of cranes in the darkness, East German workers today pierced the Berlin wall at what had once been the city's core, and the Mayors of East and West Berlin were among the first to meet at the new opening.

title: Let Freiheit Ring
description: After five years of failing half-measures, Mikhail Gorbachev is gambling in the most daring way the modern world has seen.

title: Fate of Bush Housing Plan Depends on Resolving Larger Tax Issues
description: The fate of President Bush's proposal for a multibillion-dollar housing package to assist low-income families, first-time home-buyers and the homeless will hinge largely on how Congress and the Administration resolve the broader political battle over the budget and taxes, lawmakers and housing experts said today.

title: Accounting's Era of Change Brings Growing Conflicts
description: The changing nature of the accounting profession and the workplace is bringing on a growing array of conflict-of-interest problems for accountants and is forcing them to make hard choices to keep clients.

title: Reflectone Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $768,000 on sale of assets.

title: Kohl, Visiting Land Lost to Poles, Attends a Mass of Reconciliation
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today became the first West German leader to visit the former German lands that were given to Poland at the end of the last war, as he attended Mass in a small Silesian town with Poland's non-Communist Prime Minister.

title: Vivian C. Pliner Wed To Richard A. Josephs
description: Vivian Catherine Pliner, an editor for the United Nations, and Richard Alexander Josephs, an investment banker in New York for the Union Bank of Switzerland, were married yesterday at the Highlawn Pavilion in West Orange, N.J. The Rev. John Browne, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Sunday in the Park: A Satisfying Victory
description: With a new strategy and an old score to settle, Brad Kearns traveled coast to coast to participate in the NAYA-BASF United States Biathlon Federation national championship yesterday in Central Park.

title: Police Official In Connecticut Forced to Quit
description: Connecticut's top public-safety official, Lester J. Forst, whose department has been accused in a major Federal lawsuit of illegally taping telephone conversations between defendants and their lawyers at police barracks across the state, resigned today under pressure from Gov. William A. O'Neill. His resignation came as an inquiry into the taping and its implications continued to widen.

title: All Is Forgiven, Say Alabama Fans
description: At the University of Alabama, where the 1980's shelf in the trophy case is considered half-empty rather than half-full, it is possible that never had so many crimson-clad fans been eager to celebrate a six-turnover game.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Seeking Out Opportunities In U.S.S.R.
description: FOR advertising agencies, perestroika seems to be a little bit like the New York State Lottery: To play, all they need is a dollar and a dream. And so it is that the Soviet Union's economic reorganization has attracted to Moscow not only giant American advertising agencies like Ogilvy & Mather, but even squirts like the Parsons Friedmann Stephan & Rose agency of Boston.

title: Outdoors: A Fickle Ending to a Hunting Dream Come True
description: EVER since I first saw Anticosti Island from the air more than 20 years ago, I wanted to set foot on it. That desire was fulfilled a short while ago when Paul Fuller of Durham, N.H., invited me there on a deer hunting trip.

title: Review/Theater; Tune's Swirling Vision of a 'Grand Hotel'
description: The director and choreographer Tommy Tune may have the most extravagant imagination in the American musical theater right now, and there isn't a moment, or a square inch of stage space, that escapes its reach in ''Grand Hotel.'' The musical at the Martin Beck Theater is an uninterrupted two hours of continuous movement, all dedicated to creating the tumultuous atmosphere of the setting: an opulent way station at a distant crossroads of history in Berlin - that of 1928. Think of a three-dimensional collage - or a giant Joseph Cornell box two tall stories high - filled with the smoky light, faded gilt fixtures, dirty secrets, lost mementos and ghostly people of its time and place. Then imagine someone shaking the whole thing up as if waves were tossing around the Titanic. That's Mr. Tune's ''Grand Hotel.''

title: Fears of Neighbors Frustrate a Drug-Care Center
description: Residents of Arverne, Queens, describe Daytop Village as a good neighbor. In the five years that the residential drug-treatment program has been in their neighborhood, the residents say, no incidents of crime or vandalism have been linked to the center. And, they concede, their fears that the center would lead to a drop in property values have proved unfounded.

title: Chicago Milwaukee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $1,760,000, or 82 cents a share and $12,628,000, or $5.57 a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $2,000,000, or 82 cents a share for the quarter and $7,787,000, or $2.92 a share for the 9 months.

title: In Bulgaria, Dissidents Emerge Very Carefully
description: By the recent standards of other Communist-bloc countries, they are hardly overwhelming, either in their numbers or their daring.

title: Nevada Lands Are Searched for Stray Navy Bombs
description: For years, Navy pilots accidentally dropped hundreds of bombs on public land outside a military bombing range in central Nevada, and now Gov. Bob Miller is angry that he was never told about it.

title: Bids for Hofstra, Montclair St.
description: Hofstra and Montclair State were both selected yesterday to play in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III football tournament, which will begin Saturday. The two will meet in a first-round game at Montclair, N.J., starting at 12:30 P.M.

title: More Aid for Addicts on the Job
description: Hundreds of American employers, angry and frustrated about drug-related losses in productivity, accidents, absenteeism and surging medical expenses, have begun offering counseling programs to addicted employees in recent months in an intensified campaign against drug abuse in the workplace.

title: Thermo Instrument Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Theater; Holiday Is Off and Running In the Music Hall's Tradition
description: With the reliability of the holiday it celebrates, ''The Christmas Spectacular'' rolled into Radio City Music Hall Friday night and will be ensconced there through Jan. 3. For those who feel the need to cling to eternal verities, like Coca-Cola that is less than classic, the reassuring news is that this year's production is virtually the same as the one last year.

title: Miss Gannat Wed To Bryan J. Miller
description: Mireille Gannat, a daughter of Ramon Santigosa de Mata and Josette Gannat, both of Blois, Loir-et-Cher, France, was married yesterday to Bryan J. Miller, the son of Dorothy Butkus of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Albert J. Miller. Judge Joseph J. Waters of the town of Rhinebeck, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Rhinebeck Town Hall.

title: Dolores Ibarruri, 'La Pasionaria' Of Spanish Civil War, Dies at 93
description: Dolores Ibarruri, the president of the Spanish Communist Party and a fiery orator who came to be known in the Spanish Civil War as ''La Pasionaria,'' died in a hospital here tonight after a long illness. She was 93 years old. Party officials said after an emergency meeting that her body would be put on public display at party headquarters here beginning Tuesday and that burial would be Thursday. Delegations were being invited from Communist parties around the world, they said.

description: Car advertising may never be the same again.

description: As friendships go, it seemed improbable: George Bernard Shaw, the Nobel Prize-winning literary lion, and Sean O'Casey, the gaunt, fiery young playwright from the slums of Dublin.

title: Youth Rearrested Following Escape
description: A 17-year-old high school dropout charged with killing a Queens honor student and robbing him of $12 was hospitalized yesterday after a brief escape, the police said.

title: Hungary to Get Playboy
description: A Hungarian version of Playboy magazine will reach the newsstands at the end of this month, Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced last week.

description: Negotiations between striking telephone workers and the Nynex Corporation have been suspended for a week because the talks have stalled, an official of the telephone company said today.

description: An internal investigation by NBC has failed to determine the cause of a critical half-hour delay in the distribution of live reports of the Oct. 17 earthquake in northern California.

description: President Bush's plan to reduce acid rain by limiting pollutants from the smokestacks of electric utility plants is drawing criticism from some of the nation's cleanest utilities as well as the dirtiest.

description: In the emotional debate over what is causing the stock market's recent gyrations, an image has emerged of trigger-happy program traders, hooting and hollering as they ride the market up and down with each tinkle of their computer keyboards.

title: Rangers Capitalize on Islander Penalties
description: One after another, the Islanders were sent off to the penalty box. And so, one after another, the shots on goal for the Rangers began to pile up. For the Rangers, it was a numbers game as good as rigged.

title: New-Music Festival; Machines as Performers: Pulleys, Belts and All
description: Disappointed by the means and methods they have inherited, a number of composers have turned - like most of the rest of us - to machines. The triumphs of 18th-century Enlightenment and the Romantic ascendancy of the individual have not held up well. Machines do things more quickly, powerfully and accurately and still comfort us with the belief that it is we who turn them on and off and tell them what to do.

title: Soviet Grain Figures Up
description: The Agriculture Department said last week that the Soviet Union's 1989 grain harvest turned out larger than predicted but that Moscow must still import huge amounts of grain in the year ahead. The department now expects the Soviet harvest to total 208 million metric tons, an increase of three million tons from the previous forecast. That total would compare with 195.1 million tons in 1988 and would be the fifth-largest Soviet harvest on record, but still considerably short of the 237.4 million tons in 1978.

title: The P.L.O. Cannot Be Ignored
description: LEAD: The time is surely here for President Bush to end the fiction that has surrounded his Administration's approach to the Arab-Israeli peace process.

title: New-Music Festival; Drama and Reverie Punctuate the Sounds In 3-Concert Opening
description: New Music America, an annual festival dedicated to diversity and category-busting, had an appropriately multifarious opening night. It brought a ''round robin'' triple bill to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday - three productions on three stages, each presented for audiences who crossed paths in a crowded lobby. A loose link among the shows was that each tinged its music with drama.

title: Anni Salomons, Designer, 90
description: Anni Salomons, a designer who founded and owned Anivo, an international fashion house that specialized in hand-crocheted and hand-knit custom-designed women's wear, died of heart disease Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jordan, McGrath Gets Fisher Nuts Account
description: New business and a high-level appointment kept the offices of Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor bustling late last week. The agency expanded its relationship with Procter & Gamble on Friday by winning the advertising account for its Fisher line of snack nuts.

title: Rallies for Abortion Rights Span Nation
description: Tens of thousands of people rallied in the nation's capital today on behalf of abortion rights, celebrating recent political victories and vowing to redouble their efforts in battles to come.

title: New Link to 'Lifetime' Engine
description: IT is a long way from diapers to diesels, but Culley Davis has made the leap.

title: Arthur Andersen Officer Joining Wisconsin Toy
description: Steven J. Appel, after 25 years with Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, is switching to the toy industry, as president and chief operating officer of a fast-growing closeout operation called the Wisconsin Toy Company.

title: East German Leader Assails Honecker Rule
description: In a major speech to East Germany's Communist leadership, the party official who is expected to be named Prime Minister on Monday has criticized the 18-year rule of Erich Honecker, the ousted East German leader, in the bluntest terms heard so far from the top of the party structure.

title: Metro Matters; List of Promises From Dinkins: Checking It Twice
description: Somewhere between the poles of consistency and expediency lie valid reasons to break campaign promises.

title: Keptel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Israelis Speak of Misgivings Over German Reconciliation
description: While much of the rest of the world rejoices, Israelis are watching events in Germany with a wariness born of bitter memories.

title: Chang Tops Forget For Wembley Title
description: Michael Chang hardly made an error as he crushed Guy Forget, 6-2, 6-1, 6-1, today to win his first tournament since his French Open title in June.

title: Ship That Hit Reef Is Seized
description: The authorities today seized a Greek freighter that smashed into a coral reef off the Florida Keys, and they accused its owners of negligence in the third grounding of a cargo vessel in the area in less than a month.

title: Morden & Helwig reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Thorn EMI's Strategy
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C., the British music and electronics company, said on Friday that it was looking for possible joint ventures and mergers for its military electronics unit after failing to find a buyer in the last five months. A Thorn spokesman, Colin Woodley, said the company had not received an offer that ''reflects the true value of the business.'' Thorn EMI said in June that it wanted to sell its three British military subsidiaries and its Systron Donner Corporation unit in the United States. People in the industry said the company had hoped to receive about $:300 million, or $473.2 million.

title: Ask Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An entry in the Finance Briefs listing of Business Day on Friday misstated the reason for a review of the Chrysler Corporation's debt rating by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Teachers' Leader Ready to Reap Gratitude
description: As the president of the United Federation of Teachers, New York City's teachers union, Sandra Feldman is one of the most powerful figures in the city's public sector.

title: Guerrillas Fail to Hinder Voting in Peru
description: Peruvians in the nation's largest cities and towns voted in large numbers today as threats by guerrillas to disrupt municipal elections failed to materialize.

title: A Temple Turning 50 Is Hopeful
description: For Congregation Habonim, a Reform Jewish temple on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, these are bittersweet days.

title: Tribal Colleges Are Fighting For Survival, New Study Says
description: American Indian tribal colleges are struggling to survive because of policy failures and a lack of Federal money even though they play a vital role in education and stability in their communities, the Carnegie Foundation said today.

title: Richard Barrie Fragrances reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: This is the company's initial first quarter.

title: The Old Berlin: A Culture of Spies and Symphonies
description: There were moments this weekend that recalled the years before the wall when there was a lively mingling between the people of the two sides of this divided city, and even a breath of the era when Berlin was the imperial German capital.

title: Everett And Rams Jolt Giants
description: There was nothing complicated about the 31-10 thrashing the Giants took from the Los Angeles Rams at Anaheim Stadium today. The Giants said they were not surprised by anything the Rams did; nor had they been hurt by spending a week of training in Phoenix.

title: Market Place; New York Banks Replenish Capital
description: WHEN a company needs more equity capital than it can generate internally from profits, it has two basic choices. Either it can ask its shareholders to buy more stock, or it can hire a securities firm to find new investors.

title: Review/Music; Partch's 'Revelation,' on His Instruments
description: In the world of contemporary composition, eccentrics and original spirits are by no means unusual; but even in that context, Harry Partch holds a special place. In the late 1920's, before he was 30 years old, he began altering orchestral instruments in search of new timbres, and in the mid-1930's, he explored tuning systems that freed him from the constraints of the 12-note Western scale.

title: Business and the Law; Uncertain Future For RICO Cases
description: ALTHOUGH Federal prosecutors say reports of the demise of Wall Street racketeering prosecutions are highly exaggerated, defense lawyers relish the rulings last Monday by a Federal district judge who gave unexpectedly light sentences in the first Wall Street case to use the onerous racketeering law. The sentences against six defendants in the Princeton/Newport Partners case ran from three to six months.

title: Knicks Stay Alive With Bold Moves
description: Rod Strickland versus Mark Jackson. Strickland is the better playmaker. Trade Strickland for another big body. Play them together.

title: Battered Redskins Set Back Eagles, 10-3

description: Administration officials said today that in view of the recent events in East Germany they are studying every ''way-out scenario'' imaginable for Europe, NATO and the Warsaw Pact, but for the moment they intend to sit tight, let the dust settle and not do anything that will be regretted later.

title: U.S. TV Producers Seek More Foreign Partners
description: Television, which once seemed as American as the Statue of Liberty, is increasingly becoming global.

description: In a move that reflects growing confidence in Angola's economic future, Belgian engineers are preparing to reopen the war-torn Benguela railroad, once the main artery into Central Africa's rich mineral reserves.

description: Susan Hecht Feer and Robert L. Tofel were married yesterday at their home in New York by Rabbi David M. Posner.

description: United States Analysts have concluded that Soviet military spending has slowed, as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised. Spending for 1989 will take up a smaller share of gross national product, they say.

title: Meredith Adds a Title
description: The Meredith Corporation, Des Moines, announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement to acquire the magazine Golf for Women from its founders, Debra and Woody Brumitt, who will continue to edit the magazine from its office in Oxford, Miss. No terms were announced. The year-old bimonthly publication will have a circulation rate base of 200,000 as of its April 1990 issue. It joins Meredith's stable of magazines that includes The Ladies' Home Journal, Sail and Better Homes and Gardens.

title: 18 Charged at Protest Against a Deer Hunt
description: Fourteen animal-rights protesters were charged yesterday with trespassing when they arrived at the Yale-Myers Forest to protest the annual deer hunt at the site. Four members of the press were also charged with trespassing. Yale University owns the forest. ''Yale made it very clear through a letter directed to our department that people who were there were subject to trespass charges,'' said Bob Buyak, director of law enforcement for the Department of Environmental Protection.

title: A New Look at East German Tennis
description: For three days last week, Steffi Graf tried to telephone a friend in West Berlin, only to be greeted by his answering machine and its ebullient message.

title: Officers Killed While on Duty
description: Richard J. Guerzon Joined the Police Department in March 1969 . . . 46 years old, a detective . . . In his career, received five excellent police duty awards, seven meritorious service awards and one departmental commendation . . . Served as a narcotics detective from 1975 to 1979 and was transferred to the District Attorney's squad on March 23, 1982 . . . Married, with four children, two from a previous marriage . . . Lived with family in Merrick, L.I. . . . First wife died of cancer. Keith L. Williams Joined Police Department in July 1981 . . . 34 years old, a detective . . . Received two excellent police duty awards . . . Was assigned to the District Attorney's squad last February . . . Lived in Brooklyn with his wife, Berita, and one daughter.

title: Dravecky Announces His Retirement at 33
description: The San Francisco Giants' Dave Dravecky, who made a brief but highly publicized comeback from cancer in his pitching arm this year, announced his retirement yesterday. The 33-year-old left-hander said he did not want to risk further injury.
