title: Trying to Outwit Brazil's Inflation
description: In the face of annual inflation of more than 1,300 percent, Brazil has become a nation of mathematicians.

title: New Kodak Disk
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced an optical computer disk that it said is capable of storing 20 percent more information than the largest capacity disk now on the market. The 14-inch optical disk will be capable of storing 8.2 gigabytes, equivalent to 8,200 megabytes, of information. Kodak said the new disks would be fully compatible with hardware components of the Kodak Optical Disk System 6800. The company said the system's hardware would be able to write to the new disks, as well as read from them. Each disk is capable of holding 2.7 million typewritten pages.

title: Don't Blame Program Trading
description: After the 1929 stock market crash, Congress debated restricting the use of telephones to trade stock. Following the Oct. 13 market plunge this year, Congress is debating similar curbs on the use of computers. Phones did not cause the 1929 crash. And program trading isn't the villain today. The use of computer programs to trigger massive stock trades stabilizes financial markets and benefits investors. Specific abuses exist, but can be individually regulated. Beyond this, program trading need not be broadly curbed, as a House subcommittee proposed last week. The public is better served if Congress slows down.

title: Pension Fund Urges S.E.C. Proxy Review

description: LEAD: If you want to see freedom fighters rack up lefties but good, there is no better place to go now than Mozambique, a self-confessed Marxist state. I've just come back from there.

CINCINNATI (NL) - Appointed Pete Mackanin manager of Nashville of the American Association. METS (NL) - Agreed to terms with Tim Teufel, infielder, on a two-year contract. Appointed Mike Cubbage and Doc Edwards coaches. Moved Bud Harrelson from dugout coach to third base coach. BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Activated Byron Dinkins, guard, and Mike Woodson, guard. title: Dow Is Slightly Higher as Caution Persists

description: Year-ago figures are not available. The company was formed on May 25 after the merger of United Artists Communications and United Cable Television. The results of operations for United Cable Television are included in United Artists Entertainment from that date forward.

description: Rosa and her two daughters have stayed huddled in their small apartment here for three days.

title: 2 Officers Transporting Prisoner Are Slain in Car
description: A murder suspect being returned to jail on Rikers Island killed two New York City police detectives with gunshots to the backs of their heads yesterday in a car parked on the shoulder of a busy highway near La Guardia Airport in Queens, the police said.

title: Kubek Rejoins Yankees
description: Tony Kubek, the former Yankee star who since 1966 has served as an analyst on the NBC Sports ''Baseball Game of the Week,'' will have the same role on Madison Square Garden Network's cablecasts of Yankee games, which begin next season. Kubek, who has also served as a broadcaster on Toronto Blue Jay telecasts during the last 13 seasons, will work with Dewayne Staats, the play-by-play announcer, and also will team with Al Trautwig on the network's pre-game program.(AP)

title: Broncos Go for Attack and the Defense Thrives
description: After the Denver Broncos edged the Chiefs by 16-13 on Sunday at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City to improve to 8-2, someone told Karl Mecklenburg that the Broncos' defense looked like that of an elite National Conference team. Mecklenburg grinned. ''They've had the upper hand over the A.F.C. in the last few Super Bowls, but the A.F.C. plays defense, too,'' said Mecklenburg, an inside linebacker from Minnesota in his seventh pro season. ''The improvement this year on our defense has been incredible. Whatever you want to call it, it's working.''

title: SALVADORAN ARMY COUNTERATTACKS IN CAPITAL CITY
description: The Salvadoran Army used helicopter gunships to attack leftist guerrilla forces in the capital today as heavy fighting continued to rage in many neighborhoods and bedroom communities, mostly on the periphery of the city.

title: Jefferson Ordered a Case of Champagne
description: To the Editor:

title: Michener Says It's Time for Smaller Novels
description: James A. Michener popped a compact disk into the stereo system and suddenly his study filled with the sound of opera. ''Here's ol' Jussi, one of the great ones,'' he said, closing his eyes as the voice of the tenor Jussi Bjorling rang out, singing a Verdi aria. ''I know the world of opera so intimately: historical sweep, sharply defined characters, not too rational an explanation of what's going on. It's a feast.''

title: Pro Bono
description: * Beery Associates Advertising has created a pro bono radio campaign for the 1989 Unicef greeting card drive, with commercials that began last week.

title: Gitano Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Olympian Dies After Accident
description: Victor Davis, the 25-year-old Canadian swimmer who won two medals in the 1984 Olympics, died today from injuries incurred when he struck by an automobile on Saturday. He was 25 years old.

title: Heroes of Information Revolution
description: Tiny portable computers, compact laser printers and innovative software that combines sound, video and text were among the best technical advances in the computer industry in 1989, according to the editors of PC Magazine. The magazine presented its technical achievement awards here tonight at the start of the annual fall Comdex exposition, which is expected to attract more than 100,000 people to the year's biggest display of new personal computer products.

title: Q&A
description: Stammering Q. Why is it that people who stammer don't when they sing? A. ''It is true that stutterers don't stutter when they sing,'' said Grace Privette, a speech pathologist who is director of the Atlanta Rehabilitation Institute, ''and the theory is that it is because speech is a left-brain-controlled function, especially the rate and rhythm, while singing is under the control of the right brain.''

title: Guilty Plea From Boeing In Data Case
description: The Boeing Company pleaded guilty today to two felony charges of ''unauthorized conveyance'' of secret Pentagon budget documents and agreed to pay more than $5.2 million in fines and restitution.

title: Philadelphia Exchange
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange plans to extend its trading day in foreign currency options by six and a half hours to coincide with trading in Far East and Pacific countries. Under the plan, the exchange will remain open for foreign currency options from 10 P.M., its current close of evening trading, until 4:30 A.M., when it now begins its morning session.

title: Portage Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Music; Four Pieces Of Americana
description: Versatility was the order of the day in a concert of music by the American composer Michael Cave at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday evening. In the Sonata (1980) and ''Valse, D.C.'' (1976) for clarinet and piano, Mr. Cave played the piano, Gervase de Peyer the clarinet. In ''Canto'' (1988) and ''Renascence'' (1989), extended arias for voice and chamber orchestra, Mr. Cave conducted, and Mr. de Peyer joined the instrumentalists.

title: M. D. Ketchum, 83, Professor of Finance
description: Marshall D. Ketchum, professor emeritus of finance at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, died of cancer on Sunday at his home in Chicago. He was 83 years old.

title: CR-PL Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $37,255, or 1 cent a share.

title: Auditors Of Lincoln On the Spot
description: As the story of the failure of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association unfolds, Congressional investigators and regulators are beginning to focus more and more on the role of the nation's largest auditing firms in the savings and loan collapse - in particular whether the firms should be held more accountable for giving insolvent institutions clean accounting bills of health.

title: Sabatini Starts Slowly but Wins Big, 6-4, 6-1
description: Gabriela Sabatini's severest competition came from herself last night as she overcame an indifferent start and went on to subdue Gretchen Magers, 6-4, 6-1, in the opening round of the Virginia Slims Championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The list of children enrolled here is classified.'' -Clare Taylor, co-founder of the C.I.A.'s day care center. [ A24:4. ]

title: How to Reduce Stock Market Injury Potential; Foundation Bought
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; The New/Old Shoe
description: Just when many of the famous makers of classics like Hermes and Prada are gearing up to au courant fashion, introducing exciting colors and up-to-date styling, along comes this kink in the cog.

title: 'Shadows,' on Black History
description: The fifth and last segment of ''Roots and Folklore: Episodes in the Development of American Folk Music,'' a suite by the clarinetist and composer John Carter, made an appearance on Saturday afternoon as part of the New Music America festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Entitled ''Shadows on a Wall,'' it brought Mr. Carter's musical story - the movement of black Americans - to an end in the 1960's with the anthemic ''Hymn to Freedom.''

title: 'Unpopular Measures' Urged for Soviet Economy
description: Warning that consumers' trust is ''running dry'' and that the economy is in danger of ''a creeping return backward,'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's chief economic adviser called today for adopting ''strict and unpopular measures'' to invigorate the country's fledgling economic restructuring program.

title: Networks Remain Split Over Who'll Run Voter Poll
description: An unexpected split between NBC News and the Cable News Network has led to a delay in naming either ABC or CBS to control a pool to interview voters after they have cast their ballots. The pool would conduct the polls for all four television news organizations, beginning with next year's elections.

title: Addendum
description: * Publicitas, a Swiss concern, has acquired a majority stake in Russell E. Palmer Inc., an advertising sales representative based in Clearwater, Fla. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Clamor in the East: Legacy of Yalta and Potsdam; Cold War Sealed Germany's Division
description: When the war in Europe ended with Nazi Germany's surrender in May 1945, the victorious Americans, British, French and Soviets did not envision the permanent division of Germany and Berlin.

title: Maximum Sentence In Killing of Parents
description: Oliver Petrovich, who killed his parents because they objected to his girlfriend, was sentenced yesterday to 50 years to life in jail, the maximum.

title: Sri Lanka Government Forces Kill Leader of Sinhalese Group
description: The leader of the Sinhalese group that has been waging an anti-Government campaign of terror was shot to death today by Government forces while in custody, the Foreign Minister said.

title: MCM Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Exxon Spending for '90
description: The Exxon Corporation chairman, Lawrence G. Rawl, said today that the company would have capital spending of about $7 billion in 1990, roughly equal to spending in 1989 excluding its acquisition of Texaco Canada from Texaco Inc. Mr. Rawl made the disclosure here at the annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute.

title: How to Reduce Stock Market Injury Potential
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorola Settles Lawsuits
description: Motorola Inc. has agreed to settle patent-infringement lawsuits against the Tandy Corporation and a Finnish company.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Blessings Corp reports earnings for 12wks to Oct 7
A Hamlet's Wall; Hoping for Fall of Less Known Barrier
description: Twenty-eight years ago, while the world's attention was focused on the new wall dividing Berlin, a 10-foot-high wall was almost simultaneously being built through this tiny farming community that sits astride the border between East and West Germany.

title: Arden Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax gains on sale of property, net of related closing costs, of $1,593,000 and $3,573,000 for the third quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $16,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Ads Reportedly Lost Because of Gay Scene
description: Several advertisers, apparently concerned about a scene depicting a homosexual couple on ABC's prime time show ''Thirtysomething,'' pulled advertising from last Tuesday's episode, costing the network about $1.5 million in lost sales, a source familiar with ABC said yesterday. He declined to identify the advertisers.

title: Computer Horizons reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $961,000 from an accounting adjustment which reflects the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for amortization of recruitment costs.

title: Walton Defends His Quarterback for Not Taking a Dive
description: Coach Joe Walton defended his quarterback today, calling Ken O'Brien ''a pretty tough football player.''

title: Gulf Resources & Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $66,000 for the quarter and $1,183,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,566,000 and $4,194,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said loss from continuing operations in the latest quarter and 9 months included pre-tax charge of $29.5 million related to estimated environmental liability; latest 9 months also included pre-tax gain of $6.6 million from sale of securities and pre-tax gain of $500,000 from foreign currency exchange gain. Year-ago 9 months' loss from continuing operations included a pre-tax gain of $1.4 million from sale of securities. Year-ago figures were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Where Hide and Seek Meets Cloak and Dagger
description: Under the alert eyes of Barbara Bush and the press, the Central Intelligence Agency finally lifted its blanket of secrecy today.

title: Vitronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Prince' Closes
description: ''Prince of Central Park,'' a musical adapted by Evan H. Rhodes from his novel, closed after the evening performance on Saturday at the Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street. The play, directed by Tony Tanner, with music by Don Sebesky and lyrics by Gloria Nissenson, ran for 4 regular performances and 19 previews.

title: Enough Foot Dragging on a Rail Link Vital to New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 FAMOUS NAMES FACE OFF IN INDIA
description: With a small band of enthusiastic supporters and a few vehicles that struggle across the dirt tracks of this sprawling constituency, Rajmohan Gandhi, grandson of Mohandas K. Gandhi, is trying to do the seemingly impossible - defeat Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

title: American Guarranty Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Request for Sea Burial
description: The parents of a 36-year-old crewman who died when he was washed overboard in the Whitbread yacht race from Punta del Este, Uruguay, to Fremantle, Australia, have requested that he be buried at sea.

title: Strong Accusation
description: A Soviet coach contended yesterday that Igor Larionov, the Soviet player now with the Vancouver Canucks, made up charges that Soviet players used performance-enhancing drugs. Larionov made the charge in his new book, ''The Front Line Rebels.''

title: Prudential Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ecogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clamor in the East: View From the Kremlin; As Satellites Stray From Orbit, Moscow Feels Freer to Set Economic Course
description: A consensus seems to be growing in Moscow that the dizzying events in Eastern Europe have brought the interests of East and West more clearly into harmony than at any time since World War II.

title: Clamor in the East: A Gesture to Eastern Europe; Kohl Reassures A Wary Poland On Reunifying
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany told a Polish audience today that Germans alone could not decide the issue of the reunification of their country.

title: Dukakis Calls Ingestion 'Slip'
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today described his wife's recent ingestion of rubbing alcohol as ''a slip'' and said decisions would be made in the next few days about further treatment for her. Kitty Dukakis is a recovering alcoholic who has received treatment for chemical dependency. ''Slip'' is a term used by recovering alcoholics to describe a lapse back into drinking. The Governor also said that he had visited his wife at Brigham and Women's Hospital today and that ''she is feeling much better.''

title: Turner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canadian Satellite Communiations Inc reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,590,000, or 15 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Books of The Times; The Stories Malamud Never Got Back To
description: The People And Uncollected Stories By Bernard Malamud Edited and introduced by Robert Giroux 269 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Germania Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter and 9 months' figures included a third quarter charge of $9.8 million for expected losses on real estate, junk bonds and other assets.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Dr. King's Moral Debit
description: Why'd you do it, Ralph? Anguished, angry leaders of the civil rights establishment have been asking that ever since they learned that the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy confirmed in his autobiography the longstanding rumors that Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. engaged in extramarital affairs.

title: MCA Stock Surges
description: The MCA Corporation's stock rose $5.625 today, to $67.50, on renewed takeover speculation after reports that its chairman, Lew Wasserman, might be willing to consider dropping the company's resistance to a buyout. A spokesman for MCA and some analysts, however, said that a statement by Mr. Wasserman - who reportedly told the columnist Dan Dorfman that he would ''consider anything in the best interest of my shareholders'' - was consistent with past MCA policy. Mr. Dorfman commented on the possibility Friday night on a Cable News Network show.

title: Dallas Corp. Deal
description: The Dallas Corporation, a maker of garage, truck and trailer doors, signed a definitive agreement for the Bessemer Securities Corporation to acquire all outstanding Dallas shares for $24 each in cash, or almost $180 million. Dallas's board of directors has approved the tender offer, which a Bessemer subsidiary said will start by Friday. Dallas's stock surged $9.50 today, to $23.625, on the Big Board.

title: 2 Youths, 17, And 2 Worlds 2 Miles Apart
description: They were raised less than two miles apart, but in almost every way the lives of Donald White and the young man accused of killing him, Michael Allen, could not have been more different.

title: New Whitman Chief Seen in Caretaker Role
description: Moving quickly to replace Karl D. Bays, who died of a heart attack on Nov. 6, the Whitman Corporation of Chicago announced yesterday that it had appointed a board member, James W. Cozad, as chairman and chief executive, effective Jan. 1.

title: New Technique Allows Study of Altered Genes in Offspring
description: SCIENTISTS have developed a technique to introduce altered genes into mouse embryos so that, when the mice mature, some of them pass a functioning copy of the gene to their offspring. The technique offers promise for research on new therapies for a wide range of human genetic diseases.

title: New Evidence of Ecological Damage Brings a Call to Ban Drift-Net Fishing
description: Prompted by new evidence that drift-net fishing is causing ecological havoc in some of the world's most bountiful waters, most nations on the Pacific Rim are calling for a total ban on a practice that is considered to be strip-mining the sea.

title: Co-Operative Bank of Conorde reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included results of Randolph Co- Operative Bank, acquired on Aug. 1, 1989.

title: Westwood Radio Deal
description: Westwood One Inc. said today that it had reached a three-way agreement to sell its half-interest in a New York radio station and use the proceeds to purchase a station in San Diego.

title: Lonvest Corp() reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Mets Sign Teufel And Two Coaches
description: A record total of 90 baseball players were on the free-agent rolls when the deadline for filing passed at 1 P.M. yesterday. But they did not include Tim Teufel, who signed with the Mets for $1.25 million for the next two years with the prediction that ''good things are coming for the Mets.''

title: INSIDE
description: F.D.A. Chief Is Shifted The Bush Administration has shifted Dr. Frank E. Young, the Food and Drug Commissioner, to a less influential job in the Department of Health and Human Services. His agency has been criticized over what some have seen as lax regulation of the drug industry. Page B13. A Correction: On Evolution Advocates of the evolution theory say new California textbook guidelines will improve the teaching of science, despite concessions to evangelical Christians. A front-page article in The Times on Friday was incomplete.

title: DEMOCRATS URGED TO VEER TO CENTER
description: L. Douglas Wilder urged national Democrats today to take a cue from his apparently successful campaign for Governor of Virginia and ''take a plunge into the waters of America's new mainstream.''

title: Clamor in the East: Leipzig's Vanguard; The Earliest Marchers See A Long Road Yet to Travel
description: Leipzig residents by the tens of thousands braved a freezing fog today to sustain their role as the vanguard of East Germany's revolution from below. Their banners set the final assault: ''free elections'' and ''Communists out.''

title: Instant Business Letters; Mix and Serve
description: LAST May, we discussed a program with more than 400 business letters in 13 categories on disk. You load the letter that best suits your needs, edit it as necessary with your word processor, and print it out, with no need to worry about dangling participles, split infinitives and the like. The publisher supplies the literacy, the user supplies the particulars.

title: Dayton-Hudson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Vatican AIDS Meeting Hears O'Connor Assail Condom Use
description: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York opened the first Vatican conference on AIDS today by assailing the use of condoms and the distribution of syringes to addicts as means of stopping the spread of the disease.

title: Market Place; Price Guarantees In Takeover Bids
description: EIGHT years ago, when the stock market was depressed, no company would have considered offering a guarantee of rising prices. But with the Dow Jones industrial average having tripled since then, two big companies are offering what amount to bull market guarantees in connection with takeovers.

title: Orbit Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included 2 cents a share resulting from an extraordinary gain in connection with the company's branded apparel segment from refinance of certain debt obligations. Figures for 1988 are restated to eliminate discontinued operations.

title: Our Towns; Save the Beach: Just How Public Must They Be?
description: When Stanley Smolkin was a small boy growing up in West Hempstead on Long Island, he used to take a bus out to Long Beach to walk on the beach and make sand castles and swim and play in the sea.

title: Valid Logic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: Figures for 1989 are restated to include results from Analog Design Tools and Integrated Measurement Systems.

title: Big O Tires reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ISS Intl Service System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nynex Reaches Tentative Pact With 60,000 Striking Workers
description: The Nynex Corporation and its two unions, the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, reached tentative agreement yesterday on a contract that could end a bitter 100-day strike as early as next Monday.

title: Hagopian to Retire
description: Louis T. Hagopian announced yesterday that he would retire as chairman of N.W. Ayer in January, ending a 29-year career at the agency. Mr. Hagopian, who is 64 years old, stepped down as chief executive in April. He was replaced by Jerry J. Siano, who will assume the title of chairman. Mr. Hagopian is not planning a sedentary retirement: he has been appointed vice chairman of the Media/Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, the nonprofit industry coalition that sponsors anti-drug public service advertising.

title: New-Music Festival; In Progress: 'Angels at the Four Corners'
description: Robin Holcomb offered a sizable chunk of her ''Angels at the Four Corners,'' a music-theater work in progress, on Sunday evening at Dance Theater Workshop. The performance, which was part of the New Music America festival, included 20 songs and connecting instrumental music but nothing in the way of dialogue, and only the barest staging.

title: Challenger International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $877,000 for the quarter and $737,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $235,000 and $722,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Review/Television; 'Midnight Caller' Continues Its AIDS Story
description: NBC's ''Midnight Caller'' got stung last season with an episode about AIDS that triggered, and deserved, the strong protests of gay and other concerned groups. The main character was a bisexual man with AIDS who knowingly continued his promiscuous ways with unsuspecting partners. It was hardly the sort of depiction to calm existing public hysteria.

title: Life-Style Shift Can Unclog Ailing Arteries, Study Finds
description: STRICT changes in diet and life style - can not only prevent heart attacks but can actually reverse the clogging of the arteries, according to a small but pioneering study reported yesterday. The study showed that a vegetarian diet, moderate exercise, and an hour a day of yoga and meditation could produce a reversal of atherosclerosis, a blockage of the arteries that can lead to a heart attack, in men and women who were strict in following the daily regimen.

title: British Retail Sales Fall
description: British retail sales fell a provisional seasonally adjusted seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, compared with rises of six-tenths of a percent in August and September, the Central Statistical Office reported. This provided an annualized rate of increase of 1.3 percent in the three months to October, the lowest in seven years.

title: Tyson Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Associated Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said net income for both periods in 1988 included $1,023,000 from income tax credits.

title: Findings Challenge Ideas of Risk to the Heart
description: Climbing out of bed in the middle of the night can be risky for the heart, but shoveling snow may not be as dangerous as people have long believed, according to two studies made public today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Resorts International confirmed that it had reached an agreement over the weekend with its bondholder groups. Under the deal, Merv Griffin's holding in Resorts will shrink to 22 percent from 100 percent. [ Page D1. ] Nynex and its two unions reached a tentative agreement on a contract that could end a bitter 100-day strike. [ B1. ] The former president of Beech-Nut pleaded guilty to 10 felony counts and admitted he had knowingly sold sugar water to consumers who believed they were buying pure apple juice. [ D1. ] ABB Asea Brown Boveri will pay $1.6 billion to absorb Combustion Engineering. [ D4. ] Great Northern Nekoosa rejected a $3.1 billion cash bid by Georgia-Pacific, saying that the offer was inadequate. [ D5. ] Boeing pleaded guilty to two felony charges of ''unauthorized conveyance'' of secret Pentagon budget documents and agreed to pay more than $5.2 million in fines and restitution. [ D5. ] Several advertisers pulled their ads from ''Thirtysomething,'' apparently concerned about a scene depicting a homosexual couple in bed. [ D21. ] K Mart reported lower profits for the third consecutive quarter, with net income down 17.4 percent. [ D22. ] Hershey Foods is negotiating to buy Ronzoni Foods from Kraft General Foods. [ D4. ] Avon Products sought to repel the unwanted advances of an alliance of powerful investors including the oil heir Gordon P. Getty and a senior executive of Mary Kay Cosmetics. [ D4. ] I.B.M. and Microsoft announced several measures aimed at bolstering sales of the OS/2 operating system. [ D6. ] THE ECONOMY Congressional investigators and regulators are beginning to focus more on the role of the nation's largest auditing firms in the savings and loan collapse. [ D1. ] In a 4-to-4 vote, the Supreme Court upheld an agreement between Detroit's two daily newspapers to merge their business operations. [ D1. ] The Federal Reserve is likely to shun further immediate steps to trim interest rates, many economists said, despite mounting evidence that economic growth has slowed to a crawl. [ D17. ] A panel of three administrative judges recommended that the Seabrook nuclear plant receive an operating license. [ D2. ] Industry consultants gave oil executives a bleak forecast, outlining a wide range of long-term political damage related to environmental worries and public anger over the Exxon spill. [ D11. ] MARKETS The California Public Employees' Retirement System asked the S.E.C. to conduct a broad review of shareholders' rights. [ D11. ] Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in very light trading, a session dominated by auctions of $26 billion of bills and 10-year notes. [ D17. ] The stock market posted a very modest gain, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.82, to 2,626.43. [ D8. ] Prices of precious metals continued to advance on stronger demand for gold in Europe and a resumption of platinum buying by Asian interests. [ D15. ] The dollar drifted lower against most major currencies. [ D15. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Kenneth H. Olsen of Digital Equipment is confident about his company's challenge to I.B.M. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Two big companies are offering bull market guarantees in connection with takeovers. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ] John Doig is talking, eight months after he promised to keep his mouth shut for a full year. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D21. ]

title: Sea Containers Selling Assets
description: Sea Containers Ltd., which recently announced that it would sell assets as part of its alternative to an uninvited takeover, agreed today to sell cargo containers and two ferries for $411.5 million.

title: Slayings Block Traffic Around La Guardia
description: The slaying of two detectives near La Guardia Airport forced police investigators to close Grand Central Parkway to westbound traffic for nearly two hours yesterday afternoon, and the spillback caused traffic jams throughout much of northwestern Queens.

title: Chess
description: It is a disheartening experience to have a bold, intrepid defender produce resistance that you had not expected. It is psychologically difficult to adjust to the changed circumstances; one moment you are pleasantly looking forward to victory but the next it is not there any more.

title: Bridge
description: A star-studded team is favored to retain a major title at the Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League that are being held here this week.

title: James K. Polk, Lawyer, 91
description: James K. Polk, a former Manhattan tax lawyer, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at his home in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 91 years old.

title: Chaparral Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Saving Scraps of the Rain Forest May Be Pointless, Naturalists Say
description: FROM Central Africa to Indonesia to Brazil, the world's rain forests are under attack by chainsaw and by fire. But a study under way here in the heart of the Amazon may help naturalists preserve representative parcels of rain forest for the 21st century.

title: South Africans Arrest 13 Officers and Guards
description: A police officer who had publicly accused riot squad members of brutality was arrested today while leading a protest against orders to transfer him.

title: 10-Year U.S. Notes Sold at 7.94%
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in very light trading yesterday, a session dominated by auctions of $26 billion of bills and 10-year notes.

title: Statues and Other Fendi Classics
description: There's more to Fendi than furs and handbags. They may be what the Italian company is known best for, but Fendi also makes evening dresses, suits, raincoats, gloves, scarfs, shoes, picture frames and even men's shirts and ties. Shoppers in New York can now see all these wares in the new Fendi store at 720 Fifth Avenue (56th Street). It is the only place outside of Rome where all Fendi products are available in one place.

title: N.R.C. Panel Supports A License for Seabrook
description: A panel of three administrative judges at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has recommended that an operating license be granted to the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire, despite objections of the plant's neighbors over the adequacy of emergency evacuation plans, the commission announced yesterday.

title: A Revamped Power Tools
description: Two new guitarists have knocked Power Tools out of alignment. The group made its only album in 1987 with Ronald Shannon Jackson on drums, Melvin Gibbs on bass and Bill Frisell on guitar. But on Sunday evening at the Knitting Factory, its guitarists were Pete Cosey and David Gilmore.

title: UAL Board Meets On Coniston Move
description: The board of directors of the UALCorporation met yesterday to consider what course the company should follow to stave off attempts by Coniston Partners to oust most of the board and come up with a plan to reward stockholders. Coniston also delivered to UAL its first consent solicitation to remove all but two of the 15 board members. UAL's shares rose $3.75 a share yesterday, to $193.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Joseph Resigns After 3 Years As New York's Health Chief
description: Dr. Stephen C. Joseph has resigned as New York City Health Commissioner, effective Dec. 31, when the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch comes to an end.

title: I.B.M. and Microsoft Promote OS/2
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation announced several measures today aimed at bolstering sales of the OS/2 operating system, which has been slow to gain market acceptance.

title: Disturbed Man Held; Mother's Body Is Found
description: A man the police said was emotionally disturbed was arrested last night after hurling an ax at officers sent to his apartment in Brooklyn. The police said that after subduing him, they found the body of his 60-year-old mother inside the apartment.

title: Clamor in the East: No Thaw in Havana; For Castro, More Isolation and Economic Trouble
description: The changes in East Germany and other Eastern European nations appear to be deepening the political isolation of Fidel Castro and Cuba within the Soviet bloc and creating serious new problems for the ailing Cuban economy.

title: Solidarity's Envoy; BUSH GIVE WALESA MEDAL OF FREEDOM
description: Lech Walesa arrived in Washington tonight on his first visit to the United States, looking for funds and support to help build a Poland that he hopes will become ''the America of the East.''

title: Bronx Youth Is Shot Dead In School Hall
description: A 17-year-old student was killed by a single shot while handling a .22-caliber revolver yesterday in a hallway at Alfred E. Smith High School in the Bronx during a break between classes, the police said.

title: Review/Television; Adam Smith Examines Trade With Russia
description: The Soviet Union is no doubt as meager an exporter of consumer goods as the experts on tonight's edition of ''Adam Smith's Money World'' report, but under Mikhail S. Gorbachev it has come up with a couple of hot sellers for America's public affairs programs - glasnost and perestroika.

title: Castle & Cooke Backs Firstfed Deal
description: David H. Murdock, chairman and chief executive of Castle & Cooke Inc., said he supports the proposed acquisition of Firstfed America Inc. by Bancorp Hawaii Inc. Bancorp Hawaii said Friday that it had agreed to acquire Firstfed for $38.50 a share, or a total of almost $140 million.

title: AW Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Berkshire Hathaway reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9-month results included investment gains of $50,722,000 and $130,547,000, respectively. Year-ago quarter and 9 months included investment gains of $8,564,000 and $54,725,000, respectively.

title: Scotsman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: The company said results for the 9 months are pro-forma; Scotsman was spun off from Household International this year.

title: Colonial Commercial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said latest year results included revenues of $23,941,247 and $5,911,713 and net income of $1,987,077 and $748,906 in the 9 months and quarter, respectively, resulting from the acquisition of Devon Stores Inc. in November 1988. The company said share earnings were not provided because earnings benefit preferred holders until preferred shareholders' equity equals or exceeds liquidating value.

title: Bush Pressed to Drop Pick for Weapons Post
description: Five senators have called on President Bush to withdraw his nomination of an official who regulates civilian atomic power plants to head the nation's nuclear weapons program.

title: F.D.A. Commissioner Reassigned In Aftermath of Agency Scandals
description: The Bush Administration has shifted Food and Drug Commissioner Frank E. Young to a less influential job created for him at the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Oil Parley Is Told of Political Cost of Valdez Spill
description: Industry consultants gave oil executives a bleak forecast today, outlining a wide range of long-term political damage related to environmental worries and public anger over the Exxon Valdez spill in March.

title: Acton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $471,000, or 18 cents a share, and $8,557,000, or $3.26 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $224,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $224,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said the 1989 pre-tax earnings of $23,902,692 included $11,252,223 of income realized during the first 6 months of 1989 in connection with the sale of the company's shares of Land of Lincoln by Household International and included approximately $11,910,000 of gain from the sale of the company's cable television system located in Beaufort County, S.C. February 1989. On May 4, 1988, Sunstates Corporation was merged into Acton Corporation. For financial reporting and tax purposes, the transaction was treated as a ''reverse acquisition'' and accordingly, the above results included the operations of Acton for the period subsequent to the merger. Prior to the merger, Sunstates owned 41 percent of Acton and its equity in Acton's earnings prior to the merger are included in operating results. Share earnings amounts reflect both: the recapitalization of the company in connection with the merger with Sunstates Corporation on May 4, 1988; and a provision for dividends on the company's preferred stocks.

title: Savings Official Not Resigning
description: M. Danny Wall, the nation's top savings and loan regulator, said today that he had given no thought to resigning.

title: Robert Gilmor Jr., Executive, Is Dead at 54
description: Robert Gilmor Jr., a vice president of market development for the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, was killed in an automobile accident Sunday in Huntington, L.I. He was 54 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: Maddox Refuses to Appear Before a Disciplinary Panel
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., a Brooklyn lawyer who represented Tawana Brawley, refused yesterday to appear before a judicial grievance committee investigating his conduct in the case.

title: Duramed Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $336,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $16,000. c-Net income d-Net loss

title: Combustion To Merge With ABB
description: After holding discussions in August on ways to cooperate in the power generation business, Combustion Engineering Inc. and ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. agreed yesterday that ABB would buy Combustion Engineering for $1.6 billion in cash.

title: Another Profit Decrease Is Reported by K Mart
description: For the third consecutive quarter, the K Mart Corporation yesterday reported lower profits compared with the similar period in 1988.

title: Adelphia Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Decline Of the East
description: The joyous outpouring of East Germans through the remains of the Berlin wall to the welcoming West was of great importance to all Americans - and perhaps of particular gratification to those of us old enough to remember the threatening time the wall went up, when President Kennedy standing almost in its shadow proclaimed ''Ich bin ein Berliner,'' when it seemed impossible that the two monoliths facing each other across its barbed gray length could avoid mankind's final war.

title: Miami Officer Loses Appeal on Barring Juror
description: Opening the way for the trial of a Miami police officer whose fatal shooting of a black motorcyclist set off rioting here in January, a Florida appeals court today rebuffed defense efforts to remove a juror in the case.

title: Review/Dance; A California Kathak Troupe
description: In recent seasons, New Yorkers have not had many opportunities to see examples of Kathak, one of the major traditional dance forms of northern India. Therefore, the performance by Anjani's Kathak Dance of India on Saturday night at Symphony Space was an event of genuine interest.

title: Picasso Pastel Sells for $4.84 Million
description: Picasso's ''Head of a Woman,'' a pastel on paper from 1921, was sold last night for $4.84 million, the highest price paid in Christie's auction of Billy Wilder's collection of Austrian Expressionist, modern and contemporary artworks. The buyer was Jose Mughabi, an international dealer.

title: Warren Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Robert Penn Warren, the poet and novelist, is to be held at 5 P.M. today at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. Tributes and selections from Warren's work will be presented by Cleanth Brooks, Daniel Hoffman, John Hollander, Stanley Kunitz, William Jay Smith, Mark Strand and Derek Walcott. The service is open to the public.

title: No Matter Which Way They Ran, Giants Found No Hiding Place
description: To beat the Giants, Coach John Robinson of the Los Angeles Rams said today, it helps if you can get a big lead early enough to force the Giants to abandon their running game.

title: PATTERNS
description: Going to Shorter Lengths

title: Amerihost Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A theater review on Wednesday about the Israel Horovitz play ''The Widow's Blind Date'' reversed the descriptions of the personalities of the two male characters. George (played by Tom Bloom) is the more menacing character with the high-pitched giggle and ferretlike grin who starts the violence. Archie (played by Paul O'Brien) is the sensitive one who dissolves in tears at the first hint of savagery but is unable to keep from joining it.

title: Stephen L. Gumport, Surgeon, Is Dead at 75
description: Dr. Stephen L. Gumport, a cancer surgeon in Manhattan for almost 50 years, died of Lyme disease and complications from heart surgery Sunday at New York University Medical Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Argentine Chief Clashes With Labor
description: Saying he is prepared to face ''a thousand strikes'' to rebuild the Argentine economy, President Carlos Saul Menem has entangled himself in a growing dispute with organized labor, the traditional backbone of his Peronist party.

title: American Medical
description: American Medical Inc. said it had agreed to sell the American Hospital of Singapore, which has 136 beds, to National Medical Enterprises Inc. of Los Angeles for an undisclosed amount. The Singapore hospital is the first international hospital to be sold by American Medical since its acquisition by an investor group led by Harry J. Gray, the former chairman of United Technologies.

title: Chicago's Markets: Corrupt to the Core
description: For close to three years, I have served as a public member of the Board of Governors of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Last week, I resigned.

title: John Takawira, Sculptor, 51
description: John Takawira, a sculptor who carved folklore into stone, died on Wednesday after a long illness, it was announced Saturday. He was 51 years old.

title: Jefferies Back On the Stand
description: Boyd L. Jefferies yesterday recounted before a third jury how he helped manipulate the price of Union Carbide stock three years ago at the request of a senior GAF executive.

title: Credit Card Trust's $325 Million Issue
description: A $325 million asset-backed financing from the Citi Credit Card Trust 1989-2 was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Cellular Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit due to early extinguishment of debt of $118,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss d-Included an extraordinary loss due to early extinguishment of debt of $808,000.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Dolores Ibarruri, the Spanish Communist leader known as La Pasionaria, misstated the year of the fall of the Spanish republic and of her departure for Moscow. It was 1939, not 1938.

title: Devcon International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extrarodinary charge of $2,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit from carryforward of net operating loss of $32,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: When Violence and Terror Strike Outside the Schools
description: ''I just walk straight home and I don't look at nobody or talk to nobody,'' said Jackie Peterson, a 15-year-old sophomore at Julia Richman High School on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, describing her afternoon routine. ''People are waiting for people after school to jump on them.''

title: Corporate Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Suspect in Police Killing Has an Assault Record
description: The 25-year-old Queens man arrested last night in the slaying of two police detectives on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens had a record of drug and assault convictions and was awaiting trial on charges that he had murdered a former girlfriend and later - with his mother - had plotted to kill a witness in that case.

title: Kincannon Tops List Of 'Media All-Stars'
description: Marketing & Media Decisions magazine yesterday named Felice Kincannon of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos as top media director in its annual list of ''Media All-Stars.'' As executive vice president and general manager of Hill, Holliday, Ms. Kincannon helped the agency win the Nissan Infiniti account.

title: Brady (W.H.) & Co (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,233,000, or 16 cents a share.

title: Physicians EndorseMore Humanities For Premed Students
description: MOUNTING evidence of the medical profession's estrangement from the public has led many leaders to blame much of the problem on the narrowness of a physician's training. Now many physicians have supported those views in a survey of graduates from three liberal arts colleges in Pennsylvania.

title: O.A.S. Team Calls Noriega's Rule Illegitimate
description: An agency of the Organization of American States issued a report today declaring the Panamanian Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega ''devoid of constitutional legitimacy'' and accusing it of widespread human rights violations.

title: Nekoosa Spurns $3.1 Billion Georgia-Pacific Offer
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation yesterday rejected a $3.1 billion cash bid by a rival paper producer, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, saying that the offer was inadequate and that such a merger would violate antitrust laws.

title: Bulgarian Hearing Heartens Illegal Dissidents
description: If Bulgaria's new Communist leadership means what it says about being prepared to accept greater diversity, it may have sent a signal today in a dark courtroom near Lenin Square in the heart of this capital.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Crown Quest Is Winner: Centennial Farm's Crown Quest withstood a claim of foul by Herb McCauley, rider of the runner-up, Victory Party, to score a neck victory in the $48,200 Tiltalating Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Aqueduct yesterday. Crown Quest, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. and carrying 118 pounds, remained undefeated in three career starts with the victory in 1:11 3/5 for six furlongs over a fast track. The daughter of Chief's Crown-Glorious Quest earned $28,920 and returned $3.00, 2.40 and 2.20 for $2 across the board.(AP) N.B.A. Hawks 112, Magic 104: Dominique Wilkins scored 34 points and Moses Malone had 28 points and 14 rebounds as Atlanta won last night in Orlando, Fla. The Hawks led by 102-99 with 2 minutes 15 seconds left, then outscored the Magic by 10-5 to win their second consecutive game. The Hawks led by 56-47 at halftime, but Orlando opened the third quarter with a 10-3 run to make the score 59-57. The Magic cut the Hawks's lead to 2 points eight times in the third quarter and drew even twice. Orlando never led while losing its third consecutive game. John Battle scored 18 points for Atlanta, getting 8 in the fourth quarter. Orlando was led by Terry Catledge and Jerry Reynolds with 18 points each. Sam Vincent added 17 points for the Magic. Orlando outrebounded Atlanta, 55-46.(AP) Jazz 106, Bullets 93: Karl Malone had 33 points and 16 rebounds and John Stockton added 30 points and 16 assists, leading Utah to victory in Salt Lake City. The Jazz led by 50-44 at the half as both teams shot poorly in the first two quarters, but Utah outscored Washington by 16-7 to start the second half for a 66-51 lead. Stockton had 5 points in the surge, Malone had 4 and Bob Hansen hit a 3-point shot. Ledell Eackles led the Bullets with 24 points.(AP)

title: Ingredients for Killer Storms
description: WHILE scientists have long been able to chart the approximate course of a storm, they have had difficulty determining when a storm would become intense enough to cause widespread damage.

title: Clamor in the East: Implications of the Wall; For a Berlin Novelist, the Plot Has Changed
description: Peter Schneider, Berliner and novelist of Berlin, reflected on a little noted but rather large paradox about the sudden opening of the Berlin wall.

title: Tidioute Journal; An Answer To Prayer In Water Made Pure
description: This picturebook borough, with its white church steeples and suspension bridge across the Allegheny River here in the northwest corner of state, never quite recovered from the Great Depression that wiped out its oil and timber industries.

title: Precious Metals Prices Rise On Gold Demand in Europe
description: Prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday on stronger demand for gold in Europe and a resumption of platinum buying by Asian interests.

title: Harvard Zoologist Wins German Prize
description: A Harvard University zoologist has won one of the richest prizes in science, the $1.6 million Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz award, which is given by a West German research society.

title: Thermedics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $317,000.

title: Family Steak Houses reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After a gain of $146,500, or 2 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Many Economists See Fed Delay on Rates
description: Despite mounting evidence that economic growth has slowed to a crawl, the Federal Reserve is likely to shun further immediate steps to trim interest rates, many economists said today.

title: Schroder Unit Sells Stakes to 3
description: Wertheim Schroder Holdings Inc., the New York-based investment bank that specializes in international mergers, said yesterday that it had sold 15 percent of the company to three financial institutions for about $50 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., said its chemical unit would acquire the water services unit of Olin Corp., Stamford, Conn., a producer of specialty chemicals. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Rights Group Sues Clubs Over Membership
description: A civil rights group filed suit in Federal court here today charging that Holiday Spas, a chain of health clubs on the East Coast, systematically discriminated against blacks by discouraging them from applying for membership.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Charles H. Keating Jr. and the rise and fall of his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association misstated the participation of Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. in meetings on proposed disciplinary actions against Lincoln. Senator Riegle attended the second of two meetings with the regulators; four other Senators attended both meetings.

title: Tejas Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eclipse Gets Early Forecast
description: The Eclipse Award ballots have yet to be printed and they are not due back at the accounting firm until January. But after Brown Bess won the Yellow Ribbon Stakes at Santa Anita two days ago, probably earning the title as the nation's best grass filly, racing's championship season effectively ended.

title: Happy in San Francisco
description: Walking through the streets, I thought how happy I was to be in San Francisco and felt there was no place I would rather be than this city, at this time.

title: Guatemalan Find Alters Theories on Mayans
description: NEW excavations in Guatemala have uncovered the ruins of temples and monuments from what archeologists believe was one of the earliest ceremonial centers of Mayan culture. They say the site is a promising place to investigate the origins of the most complex pre-Columbian society in America.

title: Turning Up McCaffrey's Volume
description: JOHN DOIG had sworn he was going to keep his mouth shut for a full year after taking creative charge of McCaffrey & McCall. Eight weeks later he has broken the vow, he says, to promote his advertising agency to innovative writers and art directors. But one supects the real reason is that the burly New Zealander with twinkling eyes simply likes to talk.

title: Spire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: New York State G.O.P. Splits on Abortion Aid
description: J. Patrick Barrett, who was elected New York State Republican chairman earlier this year, said today that he opposes legislation that would eliminate state financing for poor women's abortions.

title: Chittenden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: BHA Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Xincheng Journal; Far From Beijing, the Good Life Is Still the Goal
description: With the indulgent air of someone who missed a trivia question, but doesn't much care, Li Huifang cheerfully admitted that she could not remember the names of China's leaders.

title: Bensonhurst Judge Calls A Charge Hard to Prove
description: The judge in the Bensonhurst case said yesterday that the prosecution might have a problem proving some defendants guilty of murder in what the authorities have called a racially motivated slaying.

title: Pacesetter Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Title Bout Is Canceled
description: Julian Jackson, the World Boxing Association junior middleweight champion, has been operated on for a detached retina and will not go through with his scheduled title defense Friday against Troy Wortham in Las Vegas, Nev. Jackson had surgery for his injury on Friday, said Debbie Munch, a spokeswoman for Caesars Palace.(AP)

title: Clamor in the East: Little Change in Czechoslovakia; Maintaining Tight Control in Prague
description: Last month, 300,000 people staged a demonstration in Leipzig, East Germany's second city. Five days later, about 10,000 people gathered in Wenceslas Square, this capital's historic cockpit of protest, to call for change.

title: Bloodless Instant Replays
description: There's something a little sinister about the instant replay in professional football: Halt the action, and wait for three men seated in a glass enclosure in the upper deck, half their faces hidden behind two television monitors, to determine the fate of the game.

title: Deng, Retiring, Says He Won't Meddle in Politics
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, pledged today that after his retirement last week he would not ''meddle'' in politics and would no longer hold official meetings with foreign visitors.

title: Careers; Recruiters Refocusing Techniques
description: MERGERS, corporate reorganizations and the elimination of jobs have focused more interest on the recruitment of middle managers, and recruiters are using new ideas like targeted searches and are charging flat fees to clients for finding job prospects.

title: 21 Die as Colombian Rebels Resume Clashes With Army
description: At least 21 were killed over the weekend in renewed fighting between the army and guerrillas, whose attacks had dwindled during the Colombian war on the cocaine cartels.

title: A Puzzle for Zimbabwe: Too Many Elephants
description: Elephant hunting is a big business in this debt-ridden southern African country, a sport indulged in by wealthy Americans able to spend as much as $30,000 for a three-week outing in the bush.

title: Ann H. Rothschild, 86, Interior Designer, Dies
description: Ann Hatfield Rothschild, who helped design the interiors of several well-known New York City buildings, died Thursday at a nursing home in Newton, Mass. She was 86 years old and had moved to North Easton, Mass., last year, from Piermont, N.Y., where she lived for many years.

title: President Names 27 to Newly Created Advisory Council on Drugs
description: A gospel singer from Indiana, the White House physician, the former coach of the Dallas Cowboys and 24 other people were named today by President Bush as advisers for the nation's war on drugs.

title: Pennsylvania Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Harcourt Brace Jovanovich reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $57,163,000, or 78 cents a share, for the quarter and $66,207,000, or 91 cents a share, for the 9 months, and an extraordinary loss of $48,979,000 for the both periods. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $37,232,000, or 61 cents a share, for the quarter and $40,176,000, or 66 cents a share, for the 9 months. Harcourt said in the third quarter it took a charge of about $176 million- -substantially all non-cash items. This amount included $49 million of debt acquisition costs (reported as an extraordinary item); $17 million for insurance acquisition costs and a general increase in insurance reserves; $12 million for the writeoff of certain corporate assets as well as other reserves; $3 million of interest expense as a writedown of deferred interest costs, and writeoffs of $95 million in publishing, including a writedown of inventory, plate and development costs for some elementary and secondary school publications (both published and unpublished), as well as certain school publication rights.

title: O'Keeffe, Once an Icon, Is Now an Industry
description: When Georgia O'Keeffe was young and obscure and teaching in Virginia, she wrote to a friend, ''If I went to New York I would be lucky if I could make a living.'' Yet at her death in 1986 at the age of 98, she was an American legend, known not only for her intense paintings of flowers and desertscapes, but also as a powerful, pioneering woman who had achieved fame, wealth and a life of enviable independence.

title: Savannah Foods & Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oilers Outlast Bengals
description: Tony Zendejas's fourth field goal of the game with no time left capped a fourth-quarter duel between Warren Moon and Boomer Esiason that gave the Houston Oilers a 26-24 victory over Cincinnati tonight.

title: Central Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Acquisition By McKinsey
description: In a meeting in Paris, the 111 senior partners of McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, approved a deal last week to buy the Information Consulting Group.

title: Nordstrom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Trapped Under the Sea
description: Research by scientists at the University of Maine indicates that lobsters trapped in lost or abandoned traps seldom escape, thus diminishing the supply.

title: Aging Parents: Women's Burden Grows
description: Just when they would normally be entering the most productive years of their working lives, more and more women in their 40's and beyond are struggling to cope with the growing burden of caring for elderly parents.

title: Forsyth (John) Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Jacor Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $4,387,000 related to senior debt refinancing. c-Net income Year-ago quarter's net income was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements--no share earnings.

title: HMO America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included income tax benefits of $436,128 for the quarter and $2,713,920 for the 9 months.

title: KEY RATES
Doughtie's Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $59,000, or 6 cents a share, on settlement of litigation.

title: New Lebanese President Names Premier
description: President Rene Moawad appointed a centrist Muslim with long experience in Lebanese politics as Prime Minister today and asked him to form a Cabinet.

title: Worker Is Killed In Shootout in Bar
description: An employee of a bar was shot dead on Sunday, apparently in a holdup, a police spokesman said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 11 A.M.

title: Justice Dept. Shifts; May Allow Iran-Contra Trial
description: In a shift of legal tactics, the Justice Department today appeared to clear the way for the trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency station chief who faces criminal charges in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Rebel Drive Long Planned, U.S. Says
description: The Bush Administration asserted today that the rebel offensive in El Salvador had long been planned and that its goal was the weakening of the Salvadoran Government and a popular uprising in parts of the country.

title: Back Abortion Rights, A.F.L.-C.I.O. Is Asked
description: Cheered by last week's successes of Democratic candidates who supported abortion rights in state elections, six labor unions urged the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today to make abortion rights a top goal of the labor movement.

title: House Approves a Bill For an Indian Museum
description: The House approved unanimously today a bill to transfer a priceless collection of Indian artifacts from New York's Museum of the American Indian to the Smithsonian Institution. The Smithsonian would then display the collection in a new national museum on the Mall here and a new satellite museum in lower Manhattan.

title: Europe Adopts Tobacco Laws
description: Smokers in the European Community will be inhaling less tar and getting stronger health warnings as a result of two laws adopted today by the European Community's health ministers.

title: Washington Talk; Bringing the Outcast In From the Political Cold
description: He decided to bring back Fred Malek, who had been forced to leave the 1988 Presidential campaign under allegations of anti-Semitism. He made a point of reassuring the political world he would not dump Vice President Dan Quayle in 1992.

title: Governments Start Preparing for Global Warming Disasters
description: IN the quickening international debate over global warming, the spotlight has played mostly on the question of how and whether to control the growing emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap heat in the atmosphere.

title: Clamor in the East: A Contrite Government; CONTRITE DEPUTIES SAY PARTY FAILED THE EAST GERMANS
description: The East German Parliament, dormant and docile ever since it called the German Democratic Republic into existence 40 years ago, came to life today, with deputy after deputy agreeing that the Communist Party's failings were so great that it was no longer entitled to the leading role guaranteed in the nation's Constitution.

title: Protest in Czechoslovakia
description: About 1,000 environmentalists demonstrated in Teplice late today and a local Communist Party official promised to meet with them next week, the official news agency CTK said. The agency said the demonstrators assembled outside party headquarters in Teplice, 30 miles northwest of Prague.

title: Airgas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,125,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,187,000, or 32 cents a share, for the 6 months, which included results from Jackson Products Inc., sold Oct. 2, 1988 for both periods. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,207,000, or 19 cents a share, and $2,213,000, or 34 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, which included results from Jackson Products and results from US Cylinders Inc., sold Nov. 3, 1988 for both the quarter and 6 months. Latest and 6 months sales are restated to reflect discontinued operations. The company said share earnings determined using modified treasury stock method, which assumes exercise of all outstanding options and warrants.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-23 East German lawmakers revived, with deputy after deputy agreeing that the Communists were no longer entitled to the leading role guaranteed in the constitution. Page A1 Tens of thousands continue to march in Leipzig A18 East Berlin Communists fear ''the end is coming'' A18 West Europe is called open to trade with East Germany A20 Brandt hails the German people A19 Plot has changed Berlin novelist A20 Hoping to raze another wall A19 Chancellor Kohl told Poles that Germans alone could not decide the issue of reunification. A1 Bush gives Walesa the Medal of Freedom A21 Moscow cut military spending this year, as President Gorbachev promised, U.S. officials say. A14 News analysis: Moscow sees events in Europe as favoring President Gorbachev and putting East and West interests into clearer harmony than at any time since World War II. A19 ''Unpopular measures'' urged for Soviet economy A23 Bulgarian hearing heartens illegal dissidents A22 Tighter control in Prague A21 For Castro, more isolation and economic trouble A20 El Salvador attacked guerrillas with helicopter gunships as heavy fighting continued to rage in many neighborhoods and bedroom communities, mostly by the capital. A1 Salvadoran rebel drive was long planned, U.S. says A12 O.A.S. team says rule by Noriega is illegitimate A13 Argentina's leader is taking on labor, the backbone of his Peronist Party, to restructure state companies, promote exports and hold down inflation. But labor strikes are spreading. A3 Results of mayoral votes hearten Peru's right A11 The grandson of Mohandas Gandhi, Rajmohan Gandhi, is trying to defeat Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi with a small band of enthusiastic supporters and a handful of vehicles. A9 Sri Lanka government kills Sinhalese leader A8 A new Lebanese Prime Minister was appointed. He is Selim al-Hoss, a centrist Muslim and advocate of Christian-Muslim co-existence. A3 Deng, retiring, says he won't meddle in politics A5 Vatican parley on AIDS hears O'Connor assail condom use A10 Puzzle for Zimbabwe: Too many elephants A7 National A24-28, B10-13 The House will vote on a pay raise thursday. The plan couples a 33 percent raise with the first ethics-rule overhaul in more than 10 years. A1 Women are caring for relatives more and more because people are living longer and daughters usually provide hands-on care. Those struggling with their careers make up a new ''daughter track.'' A1 New rules for California textbooks are being praised by advocates of teaching evolution, despite concessions to advocates of teaching the Biblical story of creation. A28 What will the G.O.P. do on abortion? After taking a beating in the 1989 elections, Republicans are beginning to reassess their position. B12 Labor backing of abortion rights was proposed to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. at its convention by six unions. They cited the successes last week of Democratic candidates. B12 Plunge into the mainstream, Wilder tells Democrats B12 Detroit's newspaper pact was upheld by the Supreme Court in a 4-to-4 vote. The ruling allows two daily papers to merge business operations. D1 A health-club chain has been accused by a civil rights group of discriminating against blacks by discouraging them from membership. A25 A trial is likely for an ex-C.I.A. aide charged in the Iran-contra affair. Until now, the Justice Department had tried to stall the case, citing national security secrets. A27 The C.I.A. opened a day-care center for employees with much fanfare. Children who play on a $1.2 million playground are on classified lists, and workers take polygraph tests. A24 Value of child care tax credit is doubted A26 A ban on driftnet fishing is being called for by most Pacific Rim nations because new evidence shows that the practice causes ecological havoc. Japan opposes the ban. A24 The F.D.A. chief has been shifted to a less influential job after a scandal over bribery in the agency's regulation of generic drugs and other controversial regulatory actions. B13 Washington Talk: Bush's taste for redeeming the ostracized A26 Bush named panel of 27 as advisers in drug war B10 Bush is pressed to drop nominee B10 The rescue of a village imperiled by water pollution A24 Regional B1-8 An inmate killed two detectives with gunshots to the backs of their heads in a car parked on the shoulder of a busy highway near La Guardia Airport, the police said. A1 Suspect has assault record B8 Nynex reached a tentative accord with its two unions on a contract that could end the bitter 100-day telephone strike as soon as next Monday. B1 Gangs roaming outside high schools are terrifying New York City students, who say the shadowy posses pick fights with them and steal. B1 A Bronx student was killed between classes, the police say. It is unclear whether the shooting was an accident or caused by a dispute. B1 An ex-H.U.D. official was ordered by a Federal court to turn over his personal records to a grand jury. Alexander Naclerio was the third-ranking H.U.D. official in New York City. B1 Cleanup began at a Bronx dump that was classified a hazardous waste site 20 months ago. Pelham Bay residents fear air and soil contamination from the 81-acre landfill. B3 Some Bensonhurst defendants may be difficult to prosecute for murder, the judge in the case said. He warned that proving that the youths acted in concert would be difficult. B3 Maddox refuses to appear before investigators B4 Vote result upheld in Yonkers B2

title: Clamor in the East: Communists in Crisis; East German Party Fears Its Demise
description: East Germany's ruling Communist Party is in the midst of its most profound crisis since it was founded 43 years ago, according to members of its governing Central Committee.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amvest Corp., Charlottesville, Va., an energy and financial services concern, appointed Charles P. Ancona vice president of administration.

title: Talking Business with Olsen of Digital Equipment; Testing I.B.M. On Mainframes
description: Kenneth H. Olsen, president and founder of the Digital Equipment Corporation, has made a career of doing well the things that International Business Machines Inc. does not do. But in October Mr. Olsen's Maynard, Mass., company introduced its first mainframe computer, moving into a market where growth is slowing and I.B.M. jealously guards its territory. Q. Some people believe that I.B.M. owns the mainframe market, and that this market may become obsolete. Why did you choose to enter it now? A. It is owned by I.B.M. in this country, but the Japanese have a big part worldwide. One of the things that we have that is unique, that makes our VAX popular, is that you can grow it in increments - you don't have to buy the big one to start with. As the job grows and the company grows, you can add to it. That makes it very attractive. Q. What is the place for your VAX computer architecture in the future? A. If you want to tie things together or make a commercial system, then you have to go with VAX or an I.B.M. system; you have no choice. You're not going to put a commercial system on a desk. You're not going to spread your bank's data out on desks. You want absolute reliability and security. Q. Can you look around the economy today and see whole areas of application that haven't existed? A. Oh yes, very much. We've always been a little bored with supermarket retailing. But other areas of retailing badly need computing, and they know it. Q. Are your sales abroad growing more rapidly than here? There's a suggestion that you found Europe and Japan more receptive and dynamic in some ways than the American economy. A. Capital investment in Japan is 18 to 20 percent of their gross national product. In this country it's almost half that. And the thing that is terrifying for the future is the trade balance is going to mushroom in the wrong direction because we're investing less and less, and they're investing more and more. We look at Europe and think they're going to become protectionist in 1992, and if they're protectionist we'll become even more protectionist. Q. How does Digital play its hand? Do you look abroad for your real growth? A. We keep a stiff upper lip. This year we're investing $1.5 billion in research and development and $1.3 billion in capital equipment, most of it in this country. Q. Have you considered participating in I.B.M.'s X-ray lithography semiconductor development program? A. They've talked to us about it, but it doesn't fit in with our plans. My point is that it isn't specific technology. Semiconductor memories are a good example. Semiconductor memories go to the country with the lowest cost of capital. The cost of capital is a major part of the cost of semiconductor memories. When politicians say that they are going to get semiconductor memories in this country, it's like saying we're going to grow bananas in North Dakota. Only a politician would think he could do that, but it ain't going to work. Q. If Japan has a lower cost of capital, and it has a large capital market, why can't you dip into that and even out that advantage? A. I'm not bashing the Japanese when I say this, but we're having a contest with them in which they're generating low interest rates to support their business and we're taxing exports, keeping our interest rates high. Q. Is U.S. Memories, a proposed consortium of chip makers, a little bit like trying to grow bananas in North Dakota? A. No, in terms of being a great success and being competitive. It's more than just getting a few people together and spending a few dollars. But whether it is a good idea to try is another thing. We ought to have the technology here. Q. Are supercomputers a kind of national asset that the United States should do something about? A. Supercomputers are important, but they're not the overwhelming thing. They don't replace guns. Q. Robert Tappan Morris, who in 1988 wrote the program that crashed the national computer network, worked briefly for your company. Do you think he should be punished? A. On different days I say different things. The attitude of many of our people is that it's a shame to ruin such a creative competent human being who did a dumb thing. The other point of view is that you have to make an example of him. I tend toward the view, don't ruin a human being, but I know the weakness of that, too. Q. Do you think there are potential markets in Eastern Europe and Moscow? A. Yes and no. Somebody ought to sell to the Russians because we have a vested interest in their being successful.

title: Court Says Ex-Official Must Yield H.U.D. Data
description: A Federal judge today ordered a former top official with the Department of Housing and Urban Development's New York City regional office to turn his personal records over to a grand jury investigating the agency.

title: International American Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenues and net income from the sale of investment land in the latest 6 months were $4,462,000 and $300,000, or 4 cents a share, respectively. For the year-ago 6 months, revenues and net income were $3,284,000 and $580,000, or 7 cents a share, respectively, from the sale of investment land.

title: Integra-A Hotel/Restaurant Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the quarter and $114,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $813,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,951,000, or 19 cents a share, for the 9 months. d-Net income The company said year-ago results were restated to reflect the spinoff of Showbiz Pizza Time Inc. last year.

title: Results of Mayoral Votes Hearten Peru Right
