title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; G.M. Is Demanding Exclusive TV Time
description: The General Motors Corporation has begun requiring that local television stations not carry advertisements from other auto makers during commercial breaks that include G.M. ads.

title: Cineplex Odeon reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the third quarter loss included a $2,845,000 loss from its distribution activities, partly as a result of the continuing rationalization of the U.S. distribution business, and a tax provision of $1,514,000 due to the fact that certain subsidiaries were required to pay tax in certain jurisdictions without abilitiy of offset.

title: Raytheon Job Enlarged
description: The Raytheon Company, based in Lexington, Mass., has received a $429.5 million addition to a fixed-price contract for production of Patriot antiaircraft missiles, the Army said today. The original contract called for $3.94 billion for production of the missiles in the 1990 fiscal year.

title: Collins Foods International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 15
description: The company said its Sizzler Restaurants International Inc. subsidiary was the primary contributor to the latest quarter's higher earnings.

title: I.C.H.  Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest year figures included after-tax loss for the quarter and 9 months of $99 million on the sale of certain subsidiaries and investment losses of $22,281,000. Investment losses for the year-ago quarter were $8,394,000. Preferred dividend requirements in the year-ago 9 months reduced per share figure to a loss.

title: Applied Power reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included pretax expenses of $234,000 and $4,964,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, for initial allocation of ESOP, and the year also included pretax gains of $6,814,000 on sale of investment in Hein-Werner Corp. and $1,334,000 on pension plan termination. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $650,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Notebook; Last Holyfield Bout Concerns King
description: Don King, just back this week from Munich, West Germany, a potential future site for a Mike Tyson title defense, has some tough decisions to make.

title: Changes Seen At a Top Fund
description: Michael Steinhardt, who since 1967 has achieved one of the best investment performance records managing other people's money in a ''hedge fund,'' is expected to announce soon a restructuring of his almost $1 billion partnership.

title: BREADS BAKED THE OLD-FASHIONED WAY
description: LEAD: Daniel Tubito is 30 years old, works 80 hours a week and lives in this mile-square city that some consider ''the west West Side'' of Manhattan because of the rising number of young professionals who commute from here to New York.

title: Labor Fends Off Likud in Union Vote
description: The Labor Party blocked a major push on Monday by the rival Likud party to gain some control of Israel's huge labor union, the Histadrut, and today celebrated the electoral and emotional lift.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer entry error involving Brigham Young's football record, the College Computer Ranking in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the standing of the teams ranked 15th through 19th. Brigham Young is 15th, Penn State 16th, Texas A&M 17th, Texas Tech 18th and Clemson 19th.

title: Short-Handed Cavs Teach Nets a Lesson
description: The Nets thought tonight was an excellent time to play the injury-riddled Cleveland Cavaliers. The Nets were wrong.

title: Perkin-Elmer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6,600,000, or 15 cents a share.

title: 'Shirley Valentine' to Close
description: ''Shirley Valentine,'' a one-woman comedy by Willy Russell, will close after the evening performance on Nov. 25 at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. The play, directed by Simon Callow and starring Ellen Burstyn, will have run for 8 previews and 324 regular performances.

title: Komori, at 7.7%, Seeks All of AM
description: The Komori Printing Machinery Company, a Japanese concern, requested the right to make an offer to acquire all of the shares of AM International Inc. that it does not already own for $6.25 a share in cash, or a total of about $300 million. The request, which was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, was immediately rejected by AM International, a Chicago-based graphics concern.

title: Ford Recalls 1.5 Million Cars
description: Ford Motor Company is recalling about 1.5 million 1985-87 Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx cars to fix problems with the driver's seat track. The company said Monday a bracket attaching the front of the track to the floor could crack, causing the seat to rock. Ford also said it would provide extended warranty protection for about 343,000 1986-88 Aerostar minivans with three-liter V-6 engines for a potential problem with a crankshaft pulley.

title: Southmark Backs Sale of Integon
description: The Southmark Corporation said its board had approved the previously announced agreement to sell its 89 percent interest in the Integon Corporation, an insurance company in Winston-Salem, N.C., to an investor group formed by Jupiter Industries and Head Insurance Investors L.P. for $109 million in cash and $40 million in debt to be issued by the purchaser.

title: Garrett Family Era Is Coming to a Close
description: Judd Garrett, the Princeton halfback, is so good at evading tacklers rather than running over them that he has been credited with special vision on the football field.

title: Turner Broadcasting System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $7 million and $15.7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss The latest quarter and 9 months' results included a $38.8 million nonrecurring benefit from the settlement of a tax matter which originated prior to the company's acquisition of MGM/ UA Entertainment Co. The company said that the latest third quarter was adversely impacted by a $2.1 million writedown of internally produced programming, compared with a $15.8 million writedown in year-ago period. Certain 1988 accounts have been reclassified to conform to the 1989 presentation. Per share figure for latest 9 months reflected preferred dividend requirements of $34,578,000.

title: Picking Up Litter, and Pride
description: Disappointing city revenues force Mayor Koch to trim his budget proposals - including a depressing reduction in the Sanitation Department's street sweeping force by 188 more positions. Yet New York City's streets and sidewalks remain an unsightly mess. Therein lies a challenge to public discipline and pride.

title: Brazilians Vote Today for President In a Free and Unpredictable Election
description: After a gap of 29 years, Brazilians vote for president Wednesday in the first round of elections expected to set the direction for Latin America's largest nation in the 1990's.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Admirers Honor the Spirit of Robert Penn Warren
description: Robert Penn Warren, the poet, novelist, critic and teacher, was remembered yesterday in a memorial service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine as a man of great warmth, generosity and humor, and as a writer who did not hesitate to address the issues of his time.

title: For NBC News, The Ratings Fail To Reflect Praise
description: NBC News won praise from the critics for having its chief anchor, Tom Brokaw, in Berlin first last week. But it did not win viewers. ABC's ''World News Tonight'' remained the most popular evening news program, with an average rating of 11.1 and 20 percent of the audience. The CBS ''Evening News'' was second, with a 10.3 average rating and 19 percent of the audience. The NBC ''Nightly News'' was third, with a 10.0 average rating and also 19 percent of the viewers.

title: Violent Crime Up 4%, New York State Reports
description: Violent crimes reported in the state increased 4.5 percent the first six months of the year, compared with the first half of 1988, officials announced today.

title: Delta Order For Boeing, McDonnell
description: Delta Air Lines, announcing plans to expand what is already one of the most modern fleets in the industry, said yesterday that it was ordering or placing options on 260 aircraft worth about $10 billion with the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The total is one of the largest orders in the history of the industry.

title: Bhumar Kot Journal; A Cold Wind From India Makes Nepal Life Harder
description: In the eight months that Nepal has been struggling to survive severe trade sanctions imposed by neighboring India, the greatest economic burden has fallen not on King Birendra Bir Bikram Shav Dev and his Government but on villages like this, so poor that they would seem to have nothing left to lose.

title: Senate Passes Indian Museum Bill
description: The Senate unanimously passed a bill today that would establish a Smithsonian Institution museum devoted to the culture and history of the American Indian.

title: One School Confronts A Killing
description: Alfred E. Smith High School has a reputation as a quiet place: no guns, no knives, no nonsense. But a student was shot to death in a hallway two days ago, a fellow student was charged in the death, and the Bronx school has been transformed.

title: Bush Sees More Change Across Czechoslovakia
description: Calling the recent changes in Eastern Europe ''most exciting,'' President Bush today praised the decision by Czechoslovakia to abandon the use of permits for citizens seeking to travel abroad and said he expected a further relaxation of policies in that country.

title: An After-Dinner Jolt
description: To The Living Section:

title: Seal Death Studied in Jersey
description: The results of tests on a seal to determine if it died from the same infection that killed several seals on the East Coast last winter will not be known for about two weeks, officials said today. Robert Schoelkopf, the director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center, said the 2-year-old female harbor seal washed up dead on Sunday in Mantoloking. A necropsy showed the seal died of a common lung infection, but also revealed lesions on the body and an erosion of a cornea, symptoms that Mr. Schoelkopf said were found in several dead seals last winter.

title: CELLS SEEN AIDING PARKINSON'S FIGHT
description: University of California scientists said today that they had injected genetically altered skin cells into the brains of rats suffering symptoms of Parkinson's disease and had reduced those symptoms.

title: Namibia Election Violence Targets Swapo
description: To the Editor:

title: Careercom Offer Is Terminated
description: The Careercom Corporation, an operator of career-training institutes in the United States, said Maiden Lane Associates Ltd. had decided to terminate its agreement to acquire Careercom. The acquisition by Maiden Lane, which was formerly known as the Home Group Investment Corporation, was to have been for $11.50 a share in cash, or a total of about $132 million.

title: More Quakes for Europe
description: East Germany is like the San Andreas fault in the sense that it suddenly sent out shock waves that set the world a-quake. But pressures forcing shifts in the international landscape had been building up for several years, and a few governments had begun to take account.

title: With a Recess Near, Congress Scrambles To Save Tax Breaks
description: In Congress's rush to adjourn before Thanksgiving, the list of important legislative initiatives that will be postponed until 1990 is growing fast. But little on Capitol Hill stands in the way of a popular tax break, especially one that taxpayers already enjoy, and lawmakers in both parties were scrambling today to save nine that have already expired or are due to expire at the end of the year.

title: Mets Grant Carter's Wish
description: Gary Carter received a technical assist from the Mets yesterday when they acceded to his request and released him, as expected, so he could pursue talks with other teams at once.

title: Telephone Workers and Nynex Face Local Issues
description: Striking telephone company workers were ''popping corks all over the state,'' celebrating Monday's tentative settlement of a bitter three-month strike against the Nynex Corporation, Jan Pierce, a vice president of a local district of the Communications Workers of America, said in Manhattan yesterday, but negotiations on a series of local issues were continuing.

title: Shearson Plans Staff Shake-Up
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which just a week ago began a round of layoffs that could total 800 employees, plans to undertake a significant shake-up of senior management in the next several weeks.

title: Look for Orange Pots
description: To The Living Section:

title: MLX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
48-HOUR STOPPAGE PLANNED BY NAVY
description: After a succession of accidents around the world, the Navy announced today that it was suspending routine operations for 48 hours to review safety procedures with each sailor and aviator.

title: Sequa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,505,000, or 14 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,278,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter; the 9 months included a loss from discontinued operations of $654,000.

title: Market Place; Program Trades' Effect On Brokers' Net Is Slight
description: Program trading, for all the controversy it has generated among investors and politicians, contributes much less to Wall Street's profits now than before the market crash of October 1987.

title: Bobbie Brooks reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Economic Scene; Monetary Policy: A New Old Twist
description: FOR nearly a century, monetary theorists have been searching for their Holy Grail: a way to figure just the right amount of money to keep the economy on an even keel. Now two more pilgrim-scholars, David Glasner, an economist at the Federal Trade Commission, and Earl Thompson, a professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, are hot on the trail.

title: Police Storm Brazil Prison
description: State troopers stormed a prison in southern Brazil today and ended a siege by inmates, killing 8 prisoners and freeing 39 hostages, the police said. Fifty troopers rushed into the Curitiba prison firing their guns after prisoners killed one hostage and wounded three others, said Sgt. Ericu Gilberto Cassou Miller. Curitiba is 525 miles southwest of Rio. He also said 13 inmates were wounded during the battle.

title: Chairman Appointed By Stop & Shop
description: Lewis G. Schaeneman Jr., president and chief executive of the Stop & Shop supermarkets since 1980, has been appointed chairman of the chain's parent company, the Stop & Shop Companies, which also owns the Bradlees discount-store chain.

title: Davis, Reliever for Padres, Is Easy Winner of Cy Young Award
description: The era of the relief pitcher reached new peaks of distinction yesterday when Mark Davis of the San Diego Padres scored a landslide victory to win the Cy Young Award as the best pitcher in the National League.

title: Foreign Air Takeovers Benefit U.S. Travelers
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Air Takeovers Benefit U.S. Travelers; Improving the System
description: To the Editor:

title: Nathan Shock, Pioneer on Aging
description: Dr. Nathan W. Shock, a noted gerontologist who was a former director of the Government's pioneering Gerontology Research Center, died of cancer Sunday at the Francis Scott Key Medical Center in Baltimore. He was 82 years old and lived in Towson, Md.

title: Metro Datelines; Track Worker Killed By a Subway Train
description: A subway track worker was killed by a train in Queens yesterday, the Transit Authority said.

title: Metro Datelines; Sharpton Sentenced On Trespass Charge
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, convicted of second-degree criminal trespass for a sit-in at the Helmsley Palace Hotel, was sentenced yesterday to 70 hours of community service at a hospital of his choice.

title: Rear Adm. Oliver F. Naquin, 85; Was a Part of Famed Sea Rescue
description: Oliver Francis Naquin, a retired rear admiral who was one of 33 men rescued by an experimental diving bell when the submarine Squalus sank in the Atlantic Ocean in 1939, died of a pancreatic disorder Monday at the medical center at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland. He was 85 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: Dataproducts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 23
description: b-Net income The company said in spite of incurring a pretax operating loss, a provision for taxes of $2.1 million was required in the latest periods due to certain profitable foreign operations. Included in the latest period losses is a net charge for previously announced restructuring program and other related actions of $4.5 million.

title: Big B Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 21
description: b-Net income

title: Hungary to Return Vehicles
description: East Germans who abandoned their cars and motorbikes in Hungary when they crossed illegally to the West must claim them within a week if they want the vehicles back, the official press agency said today. Before Hungary opened its borders two months ago, East Germans crossing the Austrian border left behind 660 cars, 47 motorcycles, 36 mobile homes and 18 trailers.

title: Management Shifts Set By LaSalle Partners
description: LaSalle Partners, a major real estate owner and manager, announced yesterday that its chairman and founder, William D. Sanders, will become chairman emeritus at age 47, while Stuart L. Scott and C. Gary Gerst will become co-chairmen, effective Jan. 1.

title: International Thoroughbred Breeders Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rematch Felled by Flu
description: Steve McCarthy, the British boxer who in September lost a fight to the shoe-wielding mother of one of his opponents, withdrew yesterday from a rematch with the opponent in London, because of the flu.

title: Pickens Rejects Changes in Mesa
description: T. Boone Pickens has decided not to reorganize his Mesa Limited Partnership into a corporation, even though tax laws have made the limited partnership less attractive, the investor and oil man said. Mr. Pickens acknowledged in an interview that some Wall Street analysts had urged him to change the structure to push Mesa's market value above its current $8 per unit.

title: Shakespeare Troupe Must Vacate Quarters
description: The Riverside Shakespeare Company must vacate its 99-seat space at the West-Park Presbyterian Church on the Upper West Side by the end of the year. Timothy Oman, Riverside's artistic director, said that a new lease had been in the process of negotiation and that the company had expected a six-month grace period.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Nashville
description: LEAD: ON a backwoods road where only the stars light the velvety night sits the little Loveless Motel and Cafe. Almost anyone who has been around Nashville knows this country-food hideaway, but now the secret's out: the Loveless is shipping hams, jams and other Southern specialties north of the Mason-Dixon line, and anyplace else where people crave good country food.

title: Three Inmates Escape From Nassau County Jail
description: Three inmates, including two convicted murderers, escaped from the Nassau County Jail in East Meadow, L. I., yesterday morning, apparently by cutting through a grate and a metal door, the sheriff's office said.

title: Jeffersonville, Vt.
description: IT is a classic case of ''You Can't Get There From Here.'' Each winter, when heavy snow closes the road over Mount Mansfield, residents and visiting skiers from Stowe are deprived of quick access to Le Cheval d'Or, a French country restaurant in this town, just 18 miles north.

title: Harken Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $989,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,783,000, or 5 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $509,000, or 1 cent a share, and $1,413,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Quake Gives an Impetus To Commuting by Phone
description: Many people here go to work in San Francisco the old-fashioned way. They drive or take mass transit, and since the Oct. 17 earthquake, they have been spending two, three, even four hours a day doing it.

title: LSB Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $518,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $1.5 million, or 19 cents a share, for the 9 months. All results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for interest income. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the quality of voter surveys for the elections in New York and Virginia misstated the timing of a poll conducted by The New York Observer. It was published in the Nov. 6 issue of The Observer, distributed to newsstands and subscribers on Nov. 1.

title: Chaus (Bernard) Inc(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Leagues Get Warning on Cable Deals
description: Several senators and members of the House of Represenatatives said today that professional baseball and football risked losing their exemptions from antitrust laws if teams and leagues continued to reduce the number of games available on over-the-air network and local broadcasts in favor of lucrative contracts with cable networks.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Resorts International reversed, in some editions, the payouts that two groups of bondholders would receive in a proposed reorganization. The senior bondholders stand to collect 75 to 80 cents for each dollar of debt they are owed; the junior bondholders should recover 40 to 45 cents on the dollar.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Political Memo article yesterday about assessments of the abortion issue at the Republican Governors Association meeting characterized remarks by Linda Divall, a Republican poll taker, incorrectly. She said that the elections last week did not mean candidates who oppose abortion cannot be elected; they can.

title: Franz Josef of Liechtenstein, 83, A Head of State for 51 Years, Dies
description: Prince Franz Josef II of Liechtenstein, head of state of the tiny principality in a half century that saw it become one of the world's richest nations, died Monday, the Government said today. He was 83 years old. The ruler's death after a long, undisclosed illness came less than a month after his wife, Princess Gina, died at 67. The Prince's poor condition had prevented him from attending her funeral.

title: ANTI-DRUG MONEY VOTED BY SENATE
description: The Senate gave final approval today to an additional $3.2 billion to finance the Administration's war against drugs and sent the measure to President Bush.

title: BEI Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Namibia Rebel Group Wins Vote, But It Falls Short of Full Control
description: The South-West Africa People's Organization, which waged a long guerrilla war against South African rule, was declared the winner today in the first elections in Namibia's transition to independence, but failed to achieve the two-thirds majority needed to impose its own constitution and policies.

title: Reviews/Pop; Jeff Beck's Brand of Arena-Style Guitar
description: In the 1960's, before rock bands routinely toured arenas, Jeff Beck was playing arena-rock guitar - every note a zinger. He drew on the most penetrating blues guitar styles (especially that of Hubert Sumlin in Howlin' Wolf's band) to make notes slide and quiver and wail, trading linear melody for jabbing, snarling phrases that insistently buttonholed listeners. Since the breakup of the Jeff Beck Group in the mid-1970's, his own infrequent albums have been instrumental ones, and he has performed only sporadically. His appearance on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, co-headlining with the Texas blues guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughan, was part of his first tour in nine years.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 'Horrible Series' of Errors Blamed In Slayings of 2 Queens Detectives
description: A defective combination lock and a ''horrible series of little errors'' led to the slayings of two Queens detectives, police officials said yesterday.

title: Three Added to Masters
description: Michael Chang, Andre Agassi and Aaron Krickstein were named yesterday to the field of the $3 million Nabisco Masters championships, raising the number of Americans in the tournament to five.

title: Kohl Recalls Auschwitz And Agrees to Aid Poles
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany ended his visit to Poland today with a wreath-laying ceremony for the victims at Auschwitz and the signing of an agreement to provide Poland with $2.2 billion in economic assistance.

title: Southland Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extra charge from debt exchange of $56,047,000.

title: Bulgaria Offers to Readmit 11 Dissidents to Party
description: Bulgaria's Communist leadership extended a rare olive branch today to its opponents by offering to reinstate 11 former party members who had been purged for anti-Government criticism.

title: VMS, Short on Cash, Shifts Officers
description: In an unexpected announcement, VMS Realty Partners, one of the nation's largest real estate firms, disclosed today that it is suffering cash-flow problems and would replace its top management and lay off some of its 500 employees.

title: Police Are Permitted To Disable Car Alarms
description: To the Editor:

title: Rev. Donald MacLean, Educator, 59, Dies
description: The Rev. Donald I. MacLean, president of St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia from 1976 to 1986, died of cancer Monday in Weston, Mass. He was 59 years old.

title: About New York; Using the Big Top To Put Normalcy In the Lives of 500
description: rrTomorrow morning a group of 500 people have a special invitation to the Big Apple Circus, now playing at Lincoln Center. They will be entertained by death-defying aerialists, stampeding Pekingese dogs, a dancing elephant and much, much more. Most won't see a thing. They're blind. But they will taste the cotton candy, bounce to the rollicking circus music, smell the pachyderms, read a Braille program and feel wind from galloping horses. And, through earphones, they'll hear a running commentary by two sportscasters.

title: Sunday Silence Injured
description: Sunday Silence, who captured the Breeders' Cup Classic 10 days ago and is the probable selection as Horse of the Year, is scheduled to undergo surgery Thursday to remove a bone chip in his right knee.

title: Thoughts of Chairman Krenz
description: Whew! I've been the head man in East Germany for a truly tumultuous few weeks and I'm still here. Bulldozing more holes in the wall worked. Two million people went across; all but 1 in 100 came back to work Monday. And others will come home when they see that life in the West won't be easy.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Flavorful Wild Turkeys

title: New York State Still Helping Injured Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcohol Warning: Impact Is Debated
description: Under a law that is to go into effect Saturday, alcoholic beverages produced after that date will have to have warning labels alerting consumers to the dangers of drunken driving and drinking during pregnancy.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., Savannah, Ga., an aircraft manufacturing subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., offered employees in its Savannah division a voluntary termination incentive program.

title: Profits Scoreboard
The Price Of Finding Role Models
description: rrOf all the required tasks of a Little League season that can make Bonnie Fortney crazy, nothing compares with what's going on this week. In this era of the memorabilia frenzy and high-priced baseball card shows, there is nothing to compare with the organization of the post-season celebration. Not if you'd like a recognizable athlete to attend.

title: No Yen For Zlotys
description: Ladies and gentlemen of the newly freed Eastern European societies, this is the class in ''Mechanics of Democracy.'' Our aim is to help you expedite the replacement of your inadequate old governments with our democratic political institutions. A question, sir?

title: Hopland, Calif.
description: NO one in Hopland, Calif., wonders what happens to all the Halloween pumpkins come November. All month long, they are being cut up, cooked and mixed with freshly ground spices in a little Main Street shop called the Cheesecake Lady.

title: Review/Theater; 'Tempest' With Langella as a Detached Prospero
description: The British director Jude Kelly might have a vibrant ''Tempest'' in her, but the production that opened last night at the Roundabout Theater isn't it.

title: Review/Film; 'Magnolias' Of the Stage Writ Large For Screen
description: Herbert Ross's ''Steel Magnolias'' runs 118 minutes but seems even longer than ''Intolerance.''

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
McCall's-Family Circle
description: LEAD: Five months after acquiring McCall's, The New York Times Company Magazine Group yesterday announced the first joint advertising and promotional campaign involving both McCall's and Family Circle, its two mass-circulation women's service magazines. Advertisers buying space in regional editions of the magazines as part of the ''Time Out for You'' campaign will be cited in circulars distributed by the Osco and Sav-On drug store chains, and will be featured on in-store signs and banners noting the association between the products and the magazines.

title: Selling of India: Tough Ads by Congress Party
description: With a week to go until national elections in India, a series of unusual advertisements placed in Indian newspapers by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party seem to be generating more comment and controversy than the political campaign itself.

title: New-Music Festival; Organized Noisemaking By Percussion Ensemble
description: Nexus, a Toronto-based percussion ensemble, played six contemporary works at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday afternoon in a concert that was part of the New Music America festival. The players - Russell Hartenberger, Bob Becker, William Cahn, Robin Engelman and John Wyre - gave a musicianly demonstration of the art of organized, tightly choreographed noisemaking.

title: Stuffing As You Like It: Tried or Trendy
description: A GROUP of grinches initiated a campaign several years ago to undermine turkey. In full hearing of well-known taste makers, they whispered that the Thanksgiving bird of choice was, in fact, overbred, overrated and dry. Glossy food magazines began proposing capon and pheasant, duck and squab as tasteful alternatives.

title: Navy Accidents: What Has Gone Wrong
description: Incidents reported by the Navy in the last three weeks. Oct. 29: Pilot making his first landing on an aircraft carrier slams into the Lexington in the Gulf of Mexico. Four sailors and one civilian killed. Oct. 30: Pilot of an FA-18 accidentally drops a 500-pound bomb on the guided missile cruiser Reeves in the Indian Ocean. Five sailors injured. Oct. 31: Wave sweeps over deck of the aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower 90 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C. Three sailors are washed overboard; two are rescued. More than three dozen missiles are lost.

title: Review/Film; Japan's Comedy Legend Comes to the United States
description: In Japan, the character of Tora-san is as familiar and popular as Mickey Mouse is in America, as bumbling and endearing as Ralph Kramden, as durable as James Bond. Since 1969, 41 films have centered on this cheerful, middle-aged street vendor who embodies traditional values of family and home life while remaining an unambitious, unattached drifter in an increasingly buttoned-down, economically driven society. Tora-san has become so spectacularly successful that for years sociologists have pondered the cultural roots, class consciousness and moral implications of these decidedly unsophisticated comedies.

title: Savings Agency and Auditor Of Lincoln Blamed by S.E.C.
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission told Congress today that both the S.E.C.'s investigation into the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and its ability to prosecute the collapsed savings institution had been significantly hindered by Lincoln's primary auditor, Arthur Young & Company, and by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: 'Junk Bond' Staff Cut By Drexel
description: In a move indicating financial difficulty at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the firm announced yesterday that it had trimmed the staff of its ''junk bond'' department in Beverly Hills, Calif., by about 11 percent.

title: A Faintly Amused Answer to Fast Food
description: YOU can't turn back the clock, but Carlo Petrini, an Italian intellectual and wine writer, favors unwinding, at least at the dinner table. He is organizing an international movement called Slow Food, in response to the instant gratification of McDonald's, Pizza Hut, Kentucky Fried Chicken and perhaps even the minute steak.

title: Unicorp American reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $37,533,000 and $32,591,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $88,000 and $13,864,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net income Year-ago figures have been restated.

title: Hastily Arranged European Community Summit to Discuss the Extraordinary Changes in East Bloc
description: France has called for a meeting of the 12 leaders of the European Community ''to discuss the recent developments in the situation in Europe.''

title: Western Union Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income of $5.6 million from settlement of negotiations with ITT Corp. in connection with the purchase price paid for ITT World Communications Inc., income of $5.4 million from settlement of liabilities under a pension plan, and a restructuring charge of $5.5 million. c-Included restructuring charges of $200 million for the quarter and $803 million for the 9 months. Revenues for 1988 included $43,779,000 for the quarter and $150,104,000 for the 9 months from revenues from services formerly provided or to be discontinued which are not included in 1989 revenues. The company said share earnings were calculated after undeclared dividends on preferred shares of $12,655,000 in the 1989 quarter and $34,880,000 in the 1989 9 months and declared dividends on preferred shares of $13,289,000 in the 1988 quarter and $39,850,000 in the 1988 9 months.

title: For 4-Day Thanksgiving Cookout, Fowl, Fish and Plenty More
description: EVERY year around the third weekend of November, Stuart Blackburn packs his bags and heads south from his home in Damariscotta, Me. One suitcase contains clothes. The other is heavy with jars of homemade barbecue and basting sauces, country pates and anything else he thinks will enhance the four-day Thanksgiving feast he has been preparing every year since 1984 for William and Ann Ziff and their family at the Ziffs' home near Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Sugar Prices Reach Highs On Lagging Global Output
description: World sugar prices resumed their advance yesterday and posted new contract highs in New York. The yearlong rise in prices of free-market sugar also exerted upward pressure on the controlled domestic market.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day yesterday about M. Danny Wall, who said he would not resign as director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, omitted a necessary explanation of one comment. Mr. Wall said, ''The President is a lawyer by training and clearly he knows that one is innocent until proven guilty.'' The article should have noted that despite Mr. Wall's assertion, President Bush is not a lawyer.

title: Salvador Army Steps Up Raids On Strongholds of Rebel Forces
description: The army stepped up its rocketing and strafing of rebel strongholds in residential areas around the capital today and imposed a 24-hour curfew on six heavily populated towns and communities on the outskirts of the city.

title: Reviews/Music; Kenneth Fuchs Premiere By the Juilliard Symphony
description: For the second concert in its regular series, on Friday evening at Alice Tully Hall, the Juilliard Symphony originally announced an ambitious program: Stravinsky's ''Apollo,'' Xenakis's ''Pithoprakta'' and the premiere of Kenneth Fuchs's ''Reconciliation Elegy.'' However, because of the heavy recent schedules of some players, including participation in the telecast of the New York Marathon, the conductor, Paul Zukofsky, dropped the Xenakis to allow more rehearsal time for the other pieces. The wisdom of his decision became apparent in the performances that remained.

title: Next Wave Festival Names New Director
description: Liz Thompson, the executive director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., has been named director of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Ms. Thompson will take over in January, succeeding Joseph V. Melillo, who was named president and artistic director of the New York International Festival of the Arts in August.

title: Pennsylvania Passes Anti-Abortion Measure
description: The Pennsylvania Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation tonight imposing the nation's toughest restrictions on abortion. The bill, already passed by the State House of Representatives, is expected to be quickly signed into law by Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat who helped draft the legislation.

title: Philadelphia to Pay Damages to Detainees
description: The City of Philadelphia has agreed to pay at least 336 black men a total of $50,000 because they were stopped, frisked, questioned or arrested in a police hunt last year.

title: Dartmouth Divestment Announced
description: Dartmouth College has said it will sell off $11.5 million in investments in companies doing business in South Africa by the end of the year.

title: Cenvill Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Singapore Stock Shift
description: Singapore said today that it would introduce trading in foreign shares to offset the impact of an impending split between the local bourse and the stock exchange in neighboring Malaysia. The Stock Exchange of Singapore plans to establish an over-the-counter trading system to deal in foreign stocks by next January, Richard Hu, Singapore's Finance Minister, told an investment conference. Kuala Lumpur last month directed Malaysian companies to delist themselves from the Singapore exchange by Dec. 31. The departure will reduce the market's capitalization to about $43 billion from about $69 billion.

title: Daniel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a one-time pre-tax charge of $5,375,000 for discontinuance.

title: Reviews/Music; Nouvel Ensemble Moderne Makes New York Debut
description: Le Nouvel Ensemble Moderne seems intent on making its name quickly. The group, a flexible chamber ensemble that specializes in contemporary music, was founded in Montreal six months ago. It gave its first New York concert on Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall, with performances as polished as one would expect from collaboration of much longer standing.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The translation of the adjusted new Israeli shekels into U.S. dollars for both fiscal periods is at the rate of exchange in effect on Sept. 30, 1989 of Nis 1.983 to $1.00.

title: Review/Opera; Soprano Makes Unexpected Met Debut in 'Frau'
description: ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten,'' the seventh of Richard Strauss's 15 operas, did not arrive at the Metropolitan Opera until 1966, but it turned out to be one of the sensations of that first Lincoln Center season. The Nathaniel Merrill-Robert O'Hearn production, the most lavish and mechanically intricate in the Metropolitan's history up to that moment, flabbergasted nearly everyone. And yet the premiere's cast was anything but overshadowed by such visual munificence. How could it have been, considering the names involved: Christa Ludwig, Leonie Rysanek, James King and Walter Berry, with Karl Bohm in the pit.

title: Metro Datelines; 3 Plead Not Guilty In Jail Inmate Beating
description: Two Hudson County correction officers and a former guard at the county jail pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they fatally beat an inmate last March.

title: In Cyprus, the Dividing Line Seems Indelible
description: From the door of the little shop where he sells eyeglasses in designer frames, Michael Theophanides can look about 100 yards down the street. His view then stops at the barrier dividing this city.

title: Farm Couple Charged in Deaths Of Drifters Found Buried in Barns
description: A farm couple who hired drifters to buy cattle on their behalf were charged Monday with killing three former employees whose bodies were found in northern Missouri barns last month.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Advertising's Funniest
description: LEAD: An art director edged out several copywriters to win the ''Funniest Person in Advertising'' contest on Monday. Helene A. Cohn of Geer, DuBois won the competition, sponsored by Stand-Up New York, a comedy club. After six weeks of preliminary rounds, Miss Cohn defeated 30 other contestants to win a booking at Stand-Up New York and an appearance on the syndicated television program ''Everyday With Joan Lunden.

title: Dow Jones Phone Service
description: Dow Jones & Company yesterday joined the competition to offer information by telephone for a fee by introducing an automated line that offers stock quotations, financial and sports news and weather reports.

title: Farm Credit System reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $81 million for the quarter and $168 million for the 9 months, which are related to certain debt repurchases. The results excluded the farm credit insurance fund.

title: U.S. Auto Sales Drop By 23.1%
description: Early November sales of domestically produced cars plunged 23.1 percent, prompting gloomy predictions from industry analysts of more plant shutdowns and layoffs in the near future.

title: McGill in Talks To Avoid SKF Bid
description: The McGill Manufacturing Company said it was in talks with undisclosed third parties about possible alternatives to the hostile offer of $72 a share, or $104 million, from the Swedish concern SKF A.B. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, McGill, a maker of anti-friction bearings based in Valparaiso, Ind., said the third parties had agreed not to move to take control of the company without its permission until April 25.

title: Alaska Reports Earthquake
description: A moderate earthquake felt in Juneau was recorded early Monday west of Haines, but no damages or injuries were reported. The Tsunami Warning Center here recorded the temblor at 4.2 on the Richter scale. The quake, which struck at 5:07 A.M., was centered about 140 miles northwest of Juneau and 70 miles west of Haines, said George Carte, a seismologist at the center.

title: KEY RATES
Elron Electronic Indus Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
City Opera Musicians Delay Vote on Pact
description: The executive board of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians yesterday postponed a ratification vote on a new contract between the New York City Opera and its orchestra. The full 69-member orchestra had been scheduled to vote on the new contract tonight at 6 o'clock at the New York State Theater.

title: In Private Enterprise, East Resembles West
description: To the Editor:

title: Live Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $10,240,000 for the quarter and 9 months, representing other income. c-After an extraordinary credit of $3,030,000 representing a gain from the sale of the VTS videocassette manufacturing facility for the quarter and 9 months.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Discusses Abortion The President met with four Republican Congresswomen, and they said he did not rule out financing abortion in cases of rape and incest. Page A18. Tracing of AIDS Contacts The New York City Board of Health will ask the state to require doctors to report the names of AIDS patients so their contacts can be traced. Page B1. Auto Sales Slide Early November sales of cars made in the United States fell 23.1 percent, prompting grim forecasts of new plant closings and layoffs. Page D1. Hospital Releases Jogger The woman who was raped and beaten in Central Park left a Connecticut hospital after making a ''miraculous'' recovery. Page B1. Curbs on Cambodia Arms Congress is imposing new restrictions on the President's ability to send weapons to non-Communist guerrillas in Cambodia. Page A8. Record Price for a Manet Edouard Manet's ''Rue Mosnier'' was bought by the Getty Museum for $26.4 million at an auction with sales totaling $232.4 million. Page C18.

title: Dow Off 16.18, to 2,610.25, After Early Gains
description: Stocks fell across a broad front yesterday on moderately higher volume.

title: Freer Travel for Czechoslovaks
description: Czechoslovakia's hard-line Government outlined measures that would significantly ease restrictions on travel abroad next year. Page A13.

title: THE PURPOSEFUL COOK
description: FROMAGE fort is a special recipe rooted in my childhood. If you always have little leftover pieces of cheese in your refrigerator, this is the perfect use for it.

title: Film Flam for 'Rocky'
description: Outside the fighter's dressing room, two West Orange, N.J., police officers stood guard. Just a few feet away in the South Mountain Arena corridor, a crowd had gathered behind a wooden sawhorse.

title: When Drugs and Despair Vie With 3 R's
description: At 8:30 A.M., Janet Short plants her feet on the uneven asphalt, scans the playground and rings an old-fashioned brass school bell. She is beginning another day as principal of the Maurice J. Tobin School - and as surrogate parent, social worker and psychiatrist to children from one of Boston's toughest and most drug-infested housing projects.

title: First Step for Human-Driven Copter Is Tiny but in the Right Direction: Up
description: They have yet to set a record or win a prize, but a group of California college students appears to have built the first human-powered helicopter that can get off the ground.

title: Health Board Backs Move To Trace AIDS
description: The New York City Board of Health reached a consensus yesterday to ask the state to require that the names of people infected with the AIDS virus be reported to the health authorities. The purpose would be to trace the people they have had sex with or shared needles with.

title: Praise for Winery in Illinois (Yes, Illinois)
description: A decade after opening the Lynfred Winery in the Chicago suburb of Roselle, Fred E. Koehler, the owner, has heard Chicagoans joke, perhaps a million times, that Illinois wine is a contradiction in terms.

title: Europe Joblessness Dips
description: Unemployment in the 12 European Community countries dipped to 9.1 percent in September from 9.2 percent in August and from 9.8 percent a year earlier, the community said Monday. According to Eurostat, the European Community's statistics agency, 14.2 million people were out of work in August. A figure for September was unavailable because of a new method of counting unemployment in the Netherlands.

title: Ahmanson Picks President
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company, the parent of the nation's largest savings and loan institution, said today that it had named Charles R. Rinehart as president and chief operating officer.

title: Walesa Welcomed at A.F.L.-C.I.O Convention
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, was given a tumultuous and emotional reception today at the annual A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention, where he warned that freedom may not survive in Poland without significant private American investment.

title: Decaffeinated Coffee Tied to Cholesterol Rise
description: Middle-aged coffee drinkers who switched to decaffeinated coffee increased their blood levels of a form of cholesterol that contributes to heart attacks, a study has found.

title: This Case Hits Home for Prosecutors
description: James Quinn, an assistant district attorney in Queens, said yesterday that in his 12-year career he had prosecuted several murder cases in which the victims were police officers. But in those cases ''you never knew them till you got the case,'' he said. ''In this case we knew them before.''

title: Standard Shares reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company earlier changed its fiscal year end to Dec. 31 from Feb. 28, beginning March 1, 1989. The latest year-to-date results include operating results of its 50.1 percent-owned Pittway Corp. unit for 9 months, and Standard for the 7 months ended Sept. 30. The year-ago results include operating results of Pittway for the 9 months ended Sept. 30, and Standard for the 9 months ended Nov. 30.

title: Retail Sales Declined 1% In October
description: Retail sales, held back by a sluggish automobile market, fell 1 percent in October, the first decline in eight months, the Government reported today.

title: Amdura reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $2,144,000 for the quarter and income of $36,742,000, or $5.34 a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $2,113,000, or 33 cents a share, and $5,916,000, or 91 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company reported non-recurring pre-tax charges of $11,921,000 and $14,692,000 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, related to funding for executive continuity agreements and proxxy costs, and inventory valuation, reserve adjustments and relocation costs. The 1988 third quarter was restated to show its Crosby and Harris Groups as discontinued operations.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A Sluggish Outlook for Television
description: LEAD: ROBERT J. COEN, director of forecasting at McCann-Erickson New York, predicts that the four-year slump in television advertising will continue this year and perhaps next year, too.

title: Comcast Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Getty Museum Buys a Manet for a Record Price
description: Edouard Manet's ''Rue Mosnier, Paris, Decorated with Flags on June 30, 1878,'' a poignant study of an aging veteran on crutches limping along a festive street, was bought last night for $26.4 million by the J. Paul Getty Museum of Malibu, Calif.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Kabul Mountain Stronghold Is Reported Taken by Rebels
description: Afghan rebels have captured an important Government stronghold in the mountains west of the capital and repulsed an effort to retake it, Western diplomats and guerrilla radio said today.

title: Review/Film; Andersen's 'Mermaid,' by Way of Disney
description: The heroine of Hans Christian Andersen's story ''The Mermaid'' failed in her bid to become human, and became a disembodied spirit relegated to spending centuries in limbo. ''The Little Mermaid,'' a glorious Walt Disney version of this tale and the best animated Disney film in at least 30 years, is due for immortality of a happier kind.

title: Markets Are Cool To Cineplex Offer
description: A management buyout of North America's second-largest movie chain, the Cineplex Odeon Corporation, is viewed by the stock market as unlikely as a Wednesday deadline approaches for the chairman, Garth Drabinsky, and vice chairman, Myron Gottlieb, to present details of their offer to the Cineplex board. The offer is for $16.40 (Canadian) a share, or a total of $718 million.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Promotions Set at Ayer
description: LEAD: One day after Louis T. Hagopian said he would retire as chairman, the N. W. Ayer agency announced a series of promotions in its senior management and said it would shorten its name to Ayer. Jerry J. Siano, the company's chief executive, said the new name ''is simple, short and to the point.''Mr.

title: J.C. Penney Co reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: The company said 1989 9-month results were impacted by a nonrecurring charge of $20 million, net of taxes, for discontinuing Telaction, a subsidiary that had offered an interactive television shopping service.

title: Metro Datelines;
description: About $3 million was reported missing on Monday from a vault of Hercules Armored Car at 119 West Nyack Road.

title: East Germany's Red Cross Making Plans for Returnees
description: The East German Red Cross is making preparations for up to 10,000 people who might now choose to return after fleeing to West Germany, the official press agency A.D.N. said today.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE greatest challenge to many home cooks at this time of year is roasting a turkey just right so the legs and thighs cook thoroughly but the breast remains moist.

title: Vote on Gains Tax Fails in Senate
description: In a long-awaited test vote on cutting the capital gains tax, Senate Republicans today mustered 51 supporters for reducing the tax rate. That is nine short of the 60 needed to overcome the parliamentary hurdles that have blocked the Administration from winning the reduction this year.

title: Jogger in Rape In Central Park Leaves Hospital
description: The jogger who was raped and nearly beaten to death in Central Park last April 19 was released yesterday from Gaylord Hospital in Wallingford, Conn., after making what doctors said was a ''miraculous'' recovery.

title: Marian Burros
description: AS turkey cold cuts, turkey sausages and turkey parts of all other description proliferate in supermarkets, so do manufacturers' claims about the health benefits of turkey.

title: WINT TALK
description: These are good times for Chateau Lynch-Bages and especially for its 1985 vintage. Voted Wine of the Year in the United States in 1988 by editors of The Wine Spectator, a consumer publication, the 1985 recently won top honors here in the fourth annual wine Olympiad held by Gault-Millau magazine, one of France's pre-eminent wine and food publications.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In this business people make mistakes, as these detectives did, and they paid a terrible price.'' - Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon of New York City. [ A1:5. ]

title: Berry Petroleum Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains from property sales of $450,000 in both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included gains from property sales of $2,028,000 in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 President Gorbachev said the West should show restraint and not gloat about the defeat of Communism or try to ''export capitalism.'' Page A1

title: Yields Down At Banks and Savings Units
description: Yields offered on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week ended yesterday.

title: Factory Operating Rate And Output Show Drops
description: Industrial production tumbled seven-tenths of 1 percent last month to its lowest level in three and a half years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, as an aircraft strike and the California earthquake hammered the economy's already sluggish manufacturing sector.

title: At Last, a Practical Electric Vehicle?
description: In the quest for clean air, the utility industry today introduced a high-technology entry to curb pollution from autos: an electric van that speeds along at up to 72 miles an hour, and can run for more than 100 miles without having to be recharged.

title: U.S. Sees 'No Threat' to Salvador Government
description: Bush Administration officials said today that the latest offensive by Salvadoran guerrillas showed the rebels' ability to sow chaos in selected neighborhoods but was unlikely to overpower the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ACCO World Corp., Old Greenwich, Conn., an office-products manufacturer and unit of American Brands Inc., named Norman H. Wesley chief executive.

title: At Today's Parties, Food Is Decadence
description: AS a jewelry designer who sells privately through friends, Elizabeth Locke goes to parties all over the country. But in places like New York, Los Angeles and Washington, the parties are not what they used to be. ''You stand around eating broccoli and swilling water,'' she said. Mostly, people talk about their work.

title: Horn & Hardart Co reports earnings for 13wk to Sept 30
description: The year-ago results included a restructuring provision of $18.3 million.

title: In 2 Officers' Neighborhoods, A Day of Grief and Memories
description: All day long, cars pulled up to the house where Detective Richard J. Guerzon had lived. Some were driven by friends and neighbors; one was a sleek limousine bearing Richard J. Condon, the New York City Police Commissioner. And for a brief visit in the middle of the day, there was an older car carrying the widow of Detective Keith L. Williams, who was killed alongside Detective Guerzon on Monday in Queens.

title: A Common House, a Common Home
description: My address marks the fourth time that I have had the opportunity to speak publicly in what you call the socialist camp and we call the Soviet bloc. Each time there was an historical coincidence to the timing. The first was in July 1968 in Prague, during the Czechoslovak ''spring.'' The second was two years ago in Budapest, at the beginning of the end of the Kadar era. The third was this year in Poland, a few weeks before the election. This is the fourth time. [ Laughter. ] Change in Europe in recent months has been given a captivating phrase - the ''common European home'' or, as others put it, the ''common European house.''

title: Brae Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,226,000 and $12,747,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $1,175,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and $744,000, or 12 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Longs Drug Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: The company said the latest quarter results included a charge of $700,000 from damages and charitable donations related to the Oct. 17 northern California earthquake.

title: EDUCATION: Lessons; Trying to develop a way to reward good students who don't go to college
description: For students heading to college, the road to success is well marked: Take solid courses in high school, get good grades and do well on the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: U.S. Team Unhappy As Cup Match Nears
description: The failure to score a goal in the last two World Cup qualifying games has not only contributed to putting the United States in the position of needing to beat Trinidad and Tobago on Sunday to qualify for the 1990 World Cup finals, but has also created dissension among the players on the United States team.

title: DQE Inc reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Book Notes
description: Off and Running

title: Youths at Center Chilly To a Reagan Pep Talk
description: Describing his own youth as difficult, former President Ronald Reagan told 160 homeless and runaway teen-agers yesterday at Covenant House in Manhattan that he had compassion for their plight and admiration for their bootstrap efforts.

title: Lebanese Holds Talks on Unity
description: Selim al-Hoss, Lebanon's newly appointed Prime Minister, held extensive discussions today in an effort to bring the country's feuding factions together in a government of national reconciliation.

title: Carter Says Sandinistas Are Trying to Smear Foes
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Sandinista Government was trying to smear opposition candidates in February's elections by tying the leading opposition coalition to military violence by contra forces still fighting in Nicaragua.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about life in Albania misidentified an Albanian-American and the restaurant he owns in Boston. He is Anthony Athanas; the restaurant is Anthony's Pier 4.

title: Israeli Missiles for Pretoria: No.
description: Washington protested when it learned that Israel was helping South Africa develop missiles with a range of 900 miles. But Israel rebuffed the protest. President Bush would serve his nonproliferation policy well if he renewed and strengthened his objections today when he talks to visiting Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: A Vessel to Skim and Recycle Oil Spills
description: rrA huge vessel now on the drawing board could someday serve as what its designers call an environmental battleship, attacking oil spills like the Exxon Valdez disaster in Alaska.

title: Academy Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $261,000 for the quarter and $2,873,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 9 months. c-Included tax credits of $695,000, or 1 cents a share, and $2,985,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, the 9 months also included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,491,000.

title: Fear of Khmer Rouge Success Appears on Rise
description: With the United Nations scheduled to begin its yearly Cambodia debate on Wednesday, there are signs of increasing discomfort among Western countries about even indirect collaboration with the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas, who dominate the opposition coalition that holds the country's United Nations seat.

title: Community Shrinks From Crack's Embrace
description: With its handsomely restored brownstones, well-organized block clubs and political activism, the southern part of Bedford-Stuyvesant contradicts the popular view of it as a crumbling and dangerous ghetto.

title: 3 Weeks of Fun and Sun, in the Israeli Army
description: When most people go on vacation they do not think of staying at an army base, cleaning tanks, eating army food or sleeping in barracks.

title: New I.B.M. Disk Drive Is Ready
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would begin shipping its newest disk drive storage system before most analysts' expectations, improving the company's financial prospects for 1990.

title: Not Satan Worship
description: To The Living Section:

title: Shots Fired at Paper on St. Regis Reservation
description: Gunfire hit the office of a weekly newspaper on the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation on Sunday night or Monday morning in what the state police called an outbreak of violence over gambling.

title: Dykstra and Phillies Agree on 1990 Pact
description: Lenny Dykstra and the Philadelphia Phillies have agreed to terms on a 1990 contract that will pay him $700,000 plus incentives.

title: Knicks Defeated Despite 43 By Ewing
description: Cliff Robinson scored 22 points and Terry Porter added 21 tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers defeated the Knicks, 118-117, despite a 43-point performance by Patrick Ewing.

title: House Bill to Curb Program Trading Is Softened
description: Congressional efforts to curb program trading were set back today. A House subcommittee voted to remove a key section of a bill that would have granted regulators the power to suspend the computer-assisted trading during periods of high market volatility.

title: Kings End Slide Against Flames, 8-6
description: Marty McSorley's first goal of the season snapped a third-period tie tonight for the Los Angeles Kings, who ended a 10-game losing streak against Calgary by beating the Flames, 8-6.

title: Provision to Give Speaker Jet
description: The Defense Department would be required to provide House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington with his own jet under an amendment added to the defense appropriations bill without hearings, debate or notice to members, it was learned tonight.

title: BONN OUTLINES AID FOR EAST GERMANY
description: West Germany made public the outlines of a possible economic aid program to East Germany today, but repeated a warning that the proposal would be adopted only if East Germany carried out a ''thorough change'' of its centralized economy and spelled out the changes it plans.

title: Reviews/Pop; Evolution of a Punky Spirit
description: Deborah Harry was carrying a pink rose when she stepped onstage Sunday night at the World for her encore. In the spotlight, she bit the flower off its stem and spat petals at the audience, showing off the punky spirit of her late-1970's band, Blondie.

title: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: First Amer Fincl reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cookie Mueller Dead; Actress and Writer, 40
description: Dorothy (Cookie) Mueller, an actress, columnist and art critic, died of pneumonia resulting from AIDS on Friday at Cabrini Medical Center. She was 40 years old and lived in the West Village.

title: Egyptian Laborers Are Fleeing Iraq
description: Thousands of Egyptian workers have fled Iraq in recent days after reports of abuse and unexplained deaths, Egyptian officials said today. More than a million Egyptians work in Iraq, mostly as laborers, making up Cairo's biggest group of expatriates in the Arab world.

title: Navratilova Overwhelms An Out-of-Sync Fernandez
description: She huffed and she puffed and she got the job done. Martina Navratilova, a five-time winner of the Virginia Slims Championships, said her head cold left her looking pale and feeling disembodied but well enough to win.

title: A Novice Reigns as Bridgeport Mayor
description: Strange political twists seldom surprise anyone in this gritty city on Long Island Sound. After all, P.T. Barnum, the showman and circus master, was once mayor here. So was Jasper McLevy, a Scrooge-like Socialist who reigned for 24 years until 1957. So was John C. Mandanici, a target of death threats and car firebombings, who, during a failed 1981 re-election bid, often wore a bulletproof vest while campaigning.

title: Famous and Diverse Names Fill Dinkins Transition Team
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins yesterday named a 21-member transition committee that is a ''Who's Who'' of permanently prominent and deliberately diverse New Yorkers to advise him on forming his administration.

title: Bridge
description: The winners had plenty to spare when two major board-a-match team championships were decided here Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: 'Impartial' Juries: Trial By Ignorance
description: On the day a newsworthy criminal trial begins, if not the day after indictment or arrest, we can count on hearing the defense lawyer argue: ''My client can't get a fair trial because the prospective jurors have already been prejudiced by hearing news about the case.''

title: Home Depot Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Aaron's Moment
description: According to votes of about a half-million baseball fans this summer, Hank Aaron's 715th career home run created the greatest moment in baseball history.

title: Raise for Congress Snags on Proposed Ethics
description: The Congressional pay increase-and-ethics package ran into a snag today when a White House official told Congressional leaders that the proposed ethics rules did not go far enough.

title: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: Petitions and Cantatas; A Leipzig Church Mirrors German Past and Present
description: It is in places like old Thomas Church on the edge of the medieval Market Square here that the past nudges up against the future.

title: Review/Television; 'Harold Lloyd: The Third Genius,' on PBS
description: No, he was not Chaplin or Keaton, but ''Harold Lloyd: The Third Genius,'' leaves no doubt that he gave the silent screen many of its funniest moments. The two-hour tribute to the daredevil in a necktie, beginning at 8 P.M. on Channel 13, is filled with laughs from Lloyd's hits of the 1920's. There are car gags and horse gags and horsecar gags; football gags and mothball gags; girder gags, flagpole gags and, of course, the great clock-tower gag, with our hero dangling from a minute hand over the streets of Los Angeles. At his best, Lloyd was a marvel of agility and timing, and his movie moves, some carefully planned, some improvised, raised the stunt to a high form, even when he was flat on the ground.

title: Rangers Provide Penguins With a Bit of Relief
description: For the Penguins, the speculation, as wide ranging as it was unrelenting, had come to a stop on Monday. The jobs that were supposed to be in danger - Gene Ubriaco's as coach and Tony Esposito's as general manager -were temporarily secure.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Roches Single

title: TJX Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $7,074,000. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $190,688,000 and $229,459,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which included loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $166,500,000. Latest 9 months' income from continuing operations included after-tax income of $5.2 million, or 8 cents a share, from repayment of note by Ames Department Stores.

title: Smith International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an unusual charge of $23.4 million from the closing of the company's Irvine, Calif., operations.

title: There's a Time And a Purse For Everything
description: THE telephone was trilling when a visitor entered Elizabeth Ward's East Side apartment recently. Ring, ring. ''Oh, that's my communications purse,'' Ms. Ward said blithely as she headed toward the leather purse above her pillow. It contained her telephone and answering machine.

title: Enscor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Groupe Beaugarte reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: INSIDE
description: Art and the Government: Bernstein Refuses Medal Leonard Bernstein, reportedly angered at the National Endowment for the Arts, refused a Presidential award. An exhibition from which endowment support was withdrawn opens today in New York. Articles and a review, pages C23 and C26. Computers and Job Injuries The rise of computer technology is called a factor in the sharp increase in workplace injuries caused by repetitive motions. Page A28. Gain on Parkinson's Scientists confirmed that a new drug significantly slows the progression of Parkinson's disease. Page B18.

title: Mr. Gasket Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Data General Founder Gives Up Some Duties
description: The founder of the Data General Corporation, Edson D. deCastro, yesterday relinquished the titles of president and chief executive to Ronald L. Skates, who joined the computer maker in 1986 as a senior vice president.

title: Sceptre Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said it has written off $15.8 million following its decision in the third quarter to discontinue its exploration program in Abu Dhabi and the Gulf of Suez. It said the writedown along with increased costs for interest and higher depletion and depreciation charges contributed to the $21.2 million loss for the 9 months.

title: First Bank System Cuts Dividend 50%
description: In the midst of a reorganization that includes layoffs, the First Bank System board voted to cut the Minneapolis bank holding company's dividend by half, to 20.5 cents quarterly. The move was not mandated by banking regulators, First Bank management said.

title: Brawley Lawyer Risks Sanction
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., a Brooklyn lawyer who represented Tawana Brawley, was ordered yesterday to show cause why he should not be suspended from practicing law for refusing to appear before a judicial grievance committee investigating his conduct in the Brawley case.

title: M/A-Com Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Latest fourth-quarter results included an after-tax charge of about $1,500,000 relating to anticipated restructuring measures. Loss in the latest fourth quarter also related to anticipated cost overruns on the development and production of certain long-term complex multi-function assembly programs.

title: Washington Talk; Money Talks, Amid Talk Of Money
description: Representative Guy Vander Jagt thinks that money plays far too large a role in politics. His is one of the loudest voices in Congress calling for a major overhaul of the campaign finance system.

title: U.A.W. Weighs Chrysler Strike
description: The United Automobile Workers union may stage a strike at the Chrysler Corporation in response to the auto maker's plan to shut its Detroit assembly plant, a U.A.W. spokesman said today.

title: Playwriting Prize
description: Jo Carson, the author of ''Daytrips,'' has been named winner of the annual $10,000 Joseph Kesselring Award for Playwrights. The award was announced Monday by the National Arts Club, which administers it. Ms. Carson was sponsored for the prize by the Los Angeles Theater Center. Kesselring, an author, actor and playwright whose works include ''Arsenic and Old Lace,'' died in 1967. The award was set up under the terms of his will.

title: UAL and Japanese Meet on Buyout
description: Executives of the UAL Corporation met with leading Japanese bankers to discuss the collapse last month of a $6.75 billion buyout of the airline company but offered no new buyout plan, the Japanese bankers said. The meetings, held in Chicago, are expected to be followed by further meetings in Chicago Thursday and in New York on Friday, the bankers said. Chicago-based UAL owns United Airlines, the nation's second-largest carrier.

title: Lay Minister Is Slain In a Grocery Holdup
description: A lay minister working nights in a Harlem grocery story was slain yesterday morning during an apparent robbery attempt, the police said.

title: Sigma-Aldrich CorpO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GUN REGISTRATION BEGINS IN DENVER
description: The police here began registering residents' semiautomatic assault weapons today under a new city ordinance, with opponents threatening a court fight.

title: Police Seek 3 Who Fled Jail Through Vent
description: Police officers searched warehouses, lots and vacant buildings today for three inmates, two of them murderers, who escaped from the Nassau County Jail on Tuesday.

title: Toys 'R' Us reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included pretax gain of $2,025,000 on sale of department store division.

title: Letter Bomb Wounds Soldier At His Home Outside Belfast
description: A part-time soldier was wounded today when a letter bomb sent to his home near Belfast exploded as he opened it, the police said.

title: 'Liberated Ladies'
description: To The Home Section:

title: P. M. Ekstrom, Ballet Writer, 81
description: Parmenia Migel Ekstrom, a biographer, ballet historian, exhibition organizer and founder and president of the Stravinsky-Diaghilev Foundation, died of cancer on Tuesday at her home in New York. She was 81 years old.

title: Novo-Nordisk A/S reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Dollar figures are translated for convenience at the Sept. 29 exchange rate of $1 equals 7.29 Danish kroner. Figures for 1988 for the merged company were calculated on a pro forma basis. Novo Industri and Nordisk Gentofte merged effective Jan. 1. Sales represented net turnover.

title: Bush Backs House Plan on Raise and Ethics Rules
description: President Bush today endorsed a package that would raise the salary for House members and top Government officials by more than a third and tighten rules on ethics.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Earnings listing of Business Day on Saturday misstated the performance of the Emerson Electric Company. It had net income for both the 1989 and 1988 fiscal years, not net losses. The corrected figures are shown today in the table, on page D8.

description: b-The loss reflected the quarter's credit loss provision, the charge of $27.7 million, a charge of $50 million from a revision in the carrying value of the capitalized cost of excess service fees, and a $1.5 million charge of discontinued operations. c-Net income and the quarter has a per share loss which reflected preferred dividend requirements on two issues of cumulative preferred stock on which dividends are not currently being paid and which are in arrears following the suspension of dividend payments in July. d-After an extraordinary charge of $1,390,000 which reflects early extinguishment of debt.

description: b-After a loss of $1,345,110,000 from an accounting adjustment, which is related to disallowed costs.
