Electronic Data Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,147,000 and $1,229,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company recently changed its calendar year-end to Sept. 30, from Dec. 31 to coincide with the fiscal year of its parent company, International Game Technology. International Game holds a 45 percent interest in Electronic Data.) Accordingly the year-ended Sept. 30, 1989 included only 9 months, and is compared to figures from the same period a year ago.

title: Review/Music; Maurice Durufle Requiem Opens 3-Part Retrospective
description: In a compositional career that spanned more than four decades, the French organist Maurice Durufle (1902-86) saw fit to publish only 11 works, and he was not entirely sure of some of those. He apparently never liked the last movement of his Suite for Organ (Op. 35, from 1933), and he withdrew his ''Triptyque'' for piano (Op. 1, from 1926) altogether. Since the brunt of this output is more or less tied to the church - settings of sacred texts or organ works based on liturgical tunes - Durufle is not well known to the average concertgoer. Indeed, it says much about the quality of his work that so limited and specialized a quantity has kept the name alive at all.

title: Cannell Buys a TV Station
description: Cannell Communications Inc., one of the largest producers of prime-time television programming, said today that it had acquired a television station in South Carolina and that it intended to buy a signficant number of additional stations.

title: Drugs, Like Therapy, Have Place in Psychiatry
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Sofa Is Ready for Cleaning
description: HAVE you vacuumed your sofa lately? Spot-cleaned it? Turned the pillows? If not, then it might be time to have your furniture professionally cleaned.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Business Day on Tuesday about a new publication called TimesFax, which is to summarize The New York Times for businesses and travelers in the Far East by facsimile transmission beginning in January, misstated the planned number of pages. It is four to six (not six to eight).

title: From Hammer to Vise, the Artist's View of Tools
description: Have you ever looked at hammers, wrenches, vises and screwdrivers as pieces of art?

title: Riney Denies Rumors That It Will Be Sold
description: James D. Travis, the president of Hal Riney & Partners, moved yesterday to quash spreading rumors that the agency is on the verge of selling itself to another advertising company. ''I got a call that said we were sold, and I said, not that I know of,'' Mr. Travis said in an interview yesterday.

title: Petroleum Heat & Power reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Precision Standard reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Comparable year-ago figures are not available because the company changed to a calendar year from an April year. In September 1988 Precision Standard Inc. acquired Hayes International Corp.

title: Techmire Ltd reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Times Plans Law Fellowship for Journalists
description: A new one-year fellowship program for journalists to study law at Columbia University was announced yesterday by the university's law school and The New York Times.

title: Quilting Has African Roots, A New Exhibition Suggests
description: A NEW appraisal of the history of American quilts, holdikng that it reflects the improvisational nature of the music of black Africa, is introduced in a thought-provoking exhibition at the American Craft Museum in Manhattan.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Texas Banker Is Named To Head Banc One Unit
description: LEAD: Mindful of Texans' desire to do business with other Texans, the Banc One Corporation has named Harvey R. Mitchell, a longtime Dallas businessman and banker, to head its banks in that state.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Steel and Wire Corp., Cuyahoga, Ohio, said it received a $9-a-share buyout bid from the Chicago West Pullman Corp., Cincinnati.

title: Palestinians Celebrate Despite Heavy Patrols
description: Palestinians marking a year since the declaration of a Palestinian state held scattered marches and clandestine celebrations today despite heavy concentrations of Israeli soldiers patrolling their streets.

title: Eljer Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: The company said results are pro- forma for all periods except the latest third quarter because of the company's spinoff from Household International Inc. in April.

title: Salvadorans Ask U.S. for Arms Aid
description: The Government of El Salvador has asked the United States for arms and ammunition to help beat back a guerrilla offensive, American officials said today.

title: BankAtlantic Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $969,000, or 52 cents a share.

title: Occidental Issue To Yield 10.2%
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, Los Angeles, is offering $300 million in notes due 2001 through underwriters led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: Asamera Minerals reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $304,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,024,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included extraordinary credits of $91,000 and $1,701,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Bridge
description: Two little-known pairs had big scores at the start of the Blue Ribbon Pairs competition at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Tuesday. But some world-famous players were lurking in the wings.

title: Insituform of North America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quiet Falls on Bases As Navy Asks Itself What's Gone Wrong
description: The sky over this huge training base was without the thunder of A-6 attack bombers late today as the Navy tried to figure out why it sometimes seems to be at war with itself.

title: Those Poor Devils
description: United States Government officials who are charged with estimating the scope of the Soviet threat have told The New York Times they think Moscow's spending on arms in 1989 has been less than in 1988.

title: American Real Estate Parters reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges from early extinguishment of debt of $364,689 for the quarter and $499,874 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months income from operations of $5,581,663 and $19,229,820, respectively, included gains on property transactions of $307,977 for the quarter and $1,633,958 for the 9 months. The year-ago quarter and 9 months income from operations of $6,131,585 and $21,697,872, respectively, included gains on property transactions of $30,765 for the quarter and $3,298,972 for the 9 months. The company said Integrated Resources Inc. is a general partner of American Property Investors Inc., which is in turn, the general partner of American Real Estate Partners.

title: Review/Cabaret; The Taffetas' Brothers In Cardigans
description: ''The Taffetas,'' last year's Off Broadway show spoofing squeaky-clean pop groups like the Chordettes and the McGuire Sisters from the 1950's, was apparently enough of a success to prompt its creators to dream up the Taffetas' male counterparts, the Cardigans.

title: The News Corp Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $61,196,000, or 37 cents a share. The results are in U.S. dollars. Share earnings are in American Depositary Receipts (ADR) with each ADR representing two of the company's ordinary shares.

title: Tyson Bout in February
description: Mike Tyson's next fight will be in February.

title: British Airways reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represented American Depositary Shares (ADS); one ADS equals 10 U.K. ordinary shares. Results are in U.S. dollars; the U.S. dollar equivalent amounts are translated at the exchange rate at Sept. 29, 1989, of $1.62 against the pound sterling for the latest periods, and the year-ago quarter and 6 months U.S. dollar amounts are translated at the exchange rate of $1.69 against the pound sterling.

title: Sore Leg Doesn't Halt Romp By Graf
description: Steffi Graf twisted her ankle last Thursday, settled in as a spectator at Madison Square Garden for a Rangers game on Sunday, and returned there in an active role last night to gallop through her first round-match against Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia in the Virginia Slims Championships.

title: North Stars Triumph On Goal by Donatelli
description: Goaltending was the story in the game tonight between the Devils and the North Stars at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Moody's Lowers Ratings On Debt of Massachusetts
description: The ratings on as much as $8.5 billion in Massachusetts debt have been reduced by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation placed the state under review for possible downgrading.

title: Rogaciano Mercado, Filipino Legislator, 73
description: Rogaciano Mercado, a veteran legislator who served under five presidents of the Philippines, died Monday of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

title: Our Failures As Young Blacks
description: LEAD: I fear that history will judge my generation of African-American youth with an unforgiving eye.

title: Century Medicorp reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $206,224, or 1 cent a share. The company said it financial results were favorably impacted by restructuring, cost containment measures, and aggressive marketing.

title: Bush Aides Call for Higher Airline Liability Limit
description: The Bush Administration urged Congress yesterday to ratify a treaty amendment that would increase airline but bar award of additional damages based on an airline's fault or misconduct.

title: Waban Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share data is not available because the company went public in June. Nine months represented 39 weeks.

title: Saab-Scania Aircraft
description: Saab-Scania A.B. of Sweden said Tuesday that the United States carrier Business Express had placed an order worth 1.7 billion kronor, or about $263 million, for 18 of its commuter aircraft, with an option on a further 10 planes. It said Business Express, a privately owned regional company feeding Delta Air Lines hubs in New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Washington, had already bought 15 Saab 340 B's and was ordering 18 more. The options are for Saab 2000 planes.

title: Emerson Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from Saturday, Nov. 11.

title: 203 Japanese Objects Stolen at Israeli Museum
description: More than 200 miniature Japanese art objects valued at $300,000 were stolen before dawn Monday from the Japanese Art Museum in Haifa, the museum's director said.

title: Europe '92: Wary View
description: Australia is wary about the proposed establishment of a single European market by the end of 1992 because of fears that it may create a ''Fortress Europe,'' the Foreign and Trade Minister, Gareth Evans, said today, addressing the Sydney Institute of Public Affairs. He said Australia's worry stemmed from the European Community's subsidies for farm and mineral exports. With an agricultural and commodity-based economy, Australia has opposed the community's farm subsidies.

title: Super Negotiator; With Borders Open, His Job Is Over
description: After a quarter-century of arranging passage across the Berlin wall for some of the most celebrated prisoners of the 20th century - from spies to C.I.A. pilots to heroes of the human rights movement in the Soviet Union - Wolfgang Vogel may have just lost most of his law practice.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the 50th anniversary of Congregation Habonim, a temple on the Upper West Side of Manhattan founded by Reform Jewish emigres from Germany, referred imprecisely to the founding of another Reform congregation, Temple Emanu-El, on Fifth Avenue. It was established in 1845.

title: Removal of Tompkins Sq. Homeless Is Set
description: Tompkins Square Park will be cleared of tents and lean-to's occupied by homeless people next month under a plan that city officials announced last night.

title: MNH Manufactured Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Treasury Issues Up in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities ground higher in slow trading yesterday as dealers awaited fresh economic data. Reflecting on the recently completed quarterly refunding auctions, market participants remarked on the resilience of Treasury issues.

title: Bazaars And Fairs For Nearly All Tastes
description: THIS is the high season for sales, shows and bazaars in the New York region. Here are a few, lasting from one day to more than a month.

title: Showdown for Congressional Honor
description: President Bush's welcome endorsement enhances prospects for House passage of an ethics package that would begin to break the cozy financial ties between the nation's top lawmakers and government favor-seekers. That shifts the main focus of the ethics debate to the Senate, so far reluctant to act on fundamental reform.

title: Abraham Lincoln Federal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the second-quarter loss resulted from a $4 million loan loss provision to cover potential losses on a subordinated $4 million participation in a construction loan in default.

title: Citicorp Head Urges Argentina to Make a Debt Payment
description: The chairman of Citicorp said today that creditor banks would not talk with Argentina about reducing its $64 billion in foreign debt until they had received a ''good faith'' payment on back interest, estimated at $5.3 billion. No interest has been paid since April 1988.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Catalyst Thermal Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that the loss of Massachusetts General Hospital contributed to revenue declines of $500,000 and $2.2 million in the latest third quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Free Butch Morris Concerts
description: As part of the New Music America festival, Lawrence (Butch) Morris has been working with an ensemble at the Whitney Museum branch at Philip Morris, Park Avenue at 42d Street. The residency has been presenting free concerts and open rehearsals for ''Conduction 15: Where Music Goes II,'' which Mr. Morris calls a ''conducted improvisation.''

title: Griffin Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clamor in the East: Germans' Special Times; Reunification Next?
description: As they swept laughing and dancing through the Berlin wall that Germans over the years had died trying to breach, the East Berliners seemed also to sweep away much of the common wisdom and presumptions of the postwar world.

title: News Corp.'s Net Falls 78%
description: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's international media company, reported today that its first-quarter earnings dropped 78 percent, partly because of revenue lost during a labor dispute.

title: Currents; Creating the Colefax & Fowler Look
description: FOR 50 years, Colefax & Fowler, the London design partnership of John Fowler, Sibyl Colefax and Nancy Lancaster, has been creating cozy, chintz-filled interiors that have come to epitomize English style. ''Our influence on both sides of the Atlantic has been so enormous, and so many people have interpreted our style the wrong way, we thought it was time to set the record straight,'' said Chester Jones, a joint managing director of Colefax & Fowler. Thus he has written ''Colefax & Fowler: The Best in English Interior Decoration'' (Little, Brown & Company, $35).

title: When an It Is Labeled A He or a She
description: The Hall of Flame in Phoenix houses one man's formidable display of fire engines - the largest in the world, according to its brochure. In nearby Scottsdale, the Mouse House is an exhibition of 3,000 mice fabricated from cloth, plastic, wood and other materials that had been collected by the same man's first wife.

title: Blanche Schwartz, Principal, 68
description: Blanche Schwartz, a teacher and public school principal in Manhattan for 46 years, died of a heart attack Monday at the Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Currents; Traveling Eastward
description: ''TAKENOBU IGARASHI is so well known in Japan and on the West Coast, I thought it was about time people in New York knew his work,'' said Yoshiko Ebihara, the director of Gallery 91.

title: Market Place; Tighter Money And Stock Prices
description: A TIGHT money supply has traditionally been a harbinger of coming contractions in the financial markets. When there is less monetary growth or liquidity is low, it is generally believed, there will be less money around to push up the prices of assets, including stocks.

title: 13 Indicted in Bribery Scheme
description: Thirteen people have been indicted on charges that they agreed to dismiss more than $70,000 worth of parking summonses in exchange for cash, the city's Department of Investigation announced yesterday.

title: Death and Diplomacy in El Salvador
description: By infiltrating 1,500 guerrillas into the capital, El Salvador's leftist rebels have shown their continuing strength, at a terrible cost in lives. But they have little realistic chance of defeating the right-wing Government. The battlers in this unending war continue to stagger against each other, neither strong enough to deliver a knockout blow, each unwilling to end the contest.

title: Niagara Exchange reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Nine-month 1988 figures do not include the results of operations of the Old Charleston Insurance Co. for the period Jan. 1, 1988 through March 31, 1988. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect 10-percent stock dividend issued in May 1989. The company said increased losses in the latest quarter are the result of Hurricane Hugo. Niagara said its subsidiary, Charleston Insurance Co., has received in excess of 36,000 claims, mostly from homeowners policies. The estimated pre-tax loss to Niagara Exchange is $6.7 million.

title: Plymouth Rock Is Repaired
description: Plymouth Rock, the boulder marking the spot where the Pilgrims are said to have landed 369 years ago, is in danger of splitting in two. But a mason says he will restore it in time for Thanksgiving.

title: Columbia R.E.I.T.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reagan Warmly Received in Return to Capital
description: In his first visit here since leaving the White House, Ronald Reagan today unveiled his official Presidential portrait and dedicated a $6 million Republican campaign building named in his honor.

title: United Merchants & Manufacurers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $72,000 and $224,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net income Latest quarter results included a $1,742,000 loss from the sale of divisions. Year-ago results included a gain of $41,430,000 from the sale of divisions.

title: Forest Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tigers Win As Jackson Scores 37, In N.I.T.
description: With both of Louisiana State's big men in foul trouble tonight, Chris Jackson took over the scoring burden, finishing with 37 points to lead the Tigers to a 91-80 victory over Southern Mississippi in the first round of the preseason Big Apple National Invitation Tournament.

title: 3 Officers' Deaths Turn Charity Event Somber
description: As New York City and its Police Department reeled from the shock of losing three officers in two days, dozens of widows of other police officers and firefighters and scores of officials gathered last night to pay their respects and share their own sense of suffering. The event was the fourth annual dinner to benefit the New York City Police and Fire Widows' and Children's Fund.

title: Angelica Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Review/Dance; 'Telling a Story,' a Premiere By Garth Fagan's Troupe
description: A choreographer whose company has both wide popular appeal and a cultish following is a highly unusual one. Garth Fagan has managed to operate successfully within this paradox for 10 years, as was obvious again on Tuesday night when Garth Fagan Bucket Dance opened with a premiere, ''Telling a Story.''

title: Reviews/Theater; Fighting AIDS With Humor To Make Teen-Agers Notice
description: Lisa Edelstein's AIDS-education musical, ''Positive Me,'' at La Mama E.T.C., is a buoyant, frisky show whose main purpose is to convince teen-agers that they are not invulnerable to AIDS. In the opening scene, Ms. Edelstein portrays a teen-ager who asks her boyfriend (Thomas Gibson) to use a condom during sex. Refusing, he offers a litany of reasons, including the fact that he is neither gay nor an intravenous drug user. But as the show makes perfectly clear, anyone who is sexually active is at some risk of infection.

title: Julian Rosenberg, 92, Former C.I.A. Officer
description: Julian D. Rosenberg, a retired lawyer and a former officer in the Central Intelligence Agency, died of heart failure Monday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 92 years old and lived in East Haddam, Conn.

title: Richard Foster Dead; Vocal Coach Was 59
description: Richard Foster, a vocal coach for such performers as the sopranos Licia Albanese, Renata Scotto and Rita Hunter, the bass James Morris and the musical-comedy performer Zero Mostel, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: Review/Theater; Honor, Bullying and Conformity In the Trial in 'A Few Good Men'
description: Even if the stage were not a battleground of tables and chairs in gun-metal gray, it wouldn't take long to recognize the terrain in ''A Few Good Men,'' Broadway's new play about a court-martial. ''It's an open-and-shut case,'' goes an early line. ''I suspect there's more to this case than what's reported in the division report,'' goes another. The cast of antagonists includes a sarcastic Navy defense attorney who doesn't want to be a hero (Tom Hulce), a tightly wound commanding officer who insists on being one (Stephen Lang) and some cowed enlisted men caught in the crossfire. Let the scene change, and more than a few good marching men in crew cuts and khaki will sound off, ''One, two, three-four!''

title: CB Pak Buyout
description: A group of minority shareholders of CB Pak Inc., a Montreal packaging concern, said it had given up its efforts to block a $46.5 million buyout of the company by its controlling shareholder, Stone-Consolidated Inc., a Chicago forest-products concern. The group said it would sell about 1.2 million shares under Stone-Consolidated's $11.25-a-share offer, even though it believed the price was unfair.

title: Joy D. Beinecke Dead; Dance Teacher Was 59
description: Joy Dewey Beinecke, a dance teacher and consultant, died of cancer yesterday at her home on Nantucket Island, Mass. She was 59 years old.

title: Dinkins Team Starts Forming Search Panels
description: David N. Dinkins's mayoral transition committee met for the first time yesterday and began to beget five separate search committees - each responsible for a broad area of government - to help find candidates to head New York City agencies.

title: Investigation Of L.A. Gear
description: L.A. Gear Inc., the fast-growing maker of fashion-oriented athletic shoes, said today that Federal prosecutors in Massachusetts were investigating whether it had underpaid duties on imported shoes.

title: Arrow Automotive Industries reports earnings for 14wks to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The 1988 quarter consists of 13 weeks.

title: Sun and Unisys Will Not Join Chip Venture
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it had decided not to invest in U.S. Memories, a company being formed to produce computer memory chips. The Unisys Corporation also said it would not participate, a U.S. Memories spokeswoman said.

title: KEY RATES
Support for Ellison
description: When Pervis Ellison, the No. 1 choice in the draft, made his National Basketball Association debut for the Sacramento Kings, he had a sore foot and was unfamiliar with the Kings' plays.

title: Sudanese Jets Suspected in Raid on Uganda
description: Relief workers in Uganda said a warplane they suspected of belonging to the Sudanese Air Force bombed a town in northern Uganda today, destroying several government buildings but causing no casualties.

title: Home Improvements
description: USING extension cords or multiple-outlet plugs to supplement an insufficient number of wall receptacles can be a fire hazard. A safer solution is to extend a circuit's wiring and install additional electrical outlets. Before beginning, consult a local building inspector to learn whether amateurs are allowed to do the work and whether any methods other than those described here must be used. The wiring may also have to be inspected before use.

title: Nu-West Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $6,700,000 in losses related to Gulf Coast operations, including $3,700,000 in idle plant charges. c-Net income

title: Southland Considers Debt Shifts
description: Saying that slowing sales in its 7-Eleven convenience store chain had raised doubts about its ability to generate enough cash for its debt payments in 1991, the Southland Corporation said it was considering major shifts in its high-debt profile.

title: Reviews/Music; Nascimento at Fisher Hall
description: Milton Nascimento returned to New York on Monday night with an Avery Fisher Hall concert that reaffirmed his place as one of the greatest musicians alive.

title: And Now, in This Corner, Gotti, Drinking Champagne
description: Joe Frazier, Jersey Joe Walcott and George Foreman - all former heavyweight champions - were there. So was Mrs. Jack Dempsey. And, over at the table where everyone was popping the corks and drinking the specially ordered champagne, there was John Gotti, reputed organized-crime boss, in a pin-striped suit.

title: Drugs, Like Therapy, Have Place in Psychiatry; History's Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Douglas & Lomason Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included a gain from an accounting adjustment.

title: VSE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Music; Cleveland Quartet Performs With New First Violinist
description: Since its inception in 1969, the Cleveland Quartet has been one of this country's leading exponents of the quartet repertory. Throughout those 20 years, three members have remained constant: Donald Weilerstein, the first violinist; Peter Salaff, the second violinist, and Paul Katz, the cellist. The viola has been the unstable spot, although it was always well filled - now, by James Dunham.

title: Air Midwest Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary debit of $145,000 which represents a reversal of extraordinary credits previously recorded in anticipation of a reduction of income taxes due to the utilization of tax losses from prior years. c-Net loss

title: Contras Suspend Cease-Fire Talks With Managua
description: The American-backed contra rebels called suddenly for a suspension of the six-day Nicaraguan cease-fire talks tonight and said they should reconvene in Guatemala next week.

title: American Drug Screens reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Aid to Cambodia Non-Communists Is Detailed
description: With growing concern in Congress that any American military aid to non-Communist forces in Cambodia could work to the ultimate benefit of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas, officials have described the way the current system functions.

title: Review/Art; Images of Grief and Rage In Exhibition on AIDS
description: ''Witnesses: Against Our Vanishing'' at Artists Space (223 West Broadway, at White Street) has had a sustained, noisy, contentious and in some respects unwelcome buildup. Now the object of nationwide attention, it began as a low-key cry of grief and outrage from a group of artists, resident mainly on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: BBDO Quits Converse
description: BBDO New York yesterday resigned the account for Converse's Performance Brand athletic shoes, saying it would be better served by an agency closer to the company's headquarters in North Reading, Mass. A BBDO spokesman said the business was worth $4 million.

title: C. Fred Chambers, 71, Texas Oil Executive
description: C. Fred Chambers, a Texas oil executive who was a longtime friend of President Bush, died Monday at his home in Houston. He was 71 years old, and also had a home in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Calendar: Museum Reopens in Newark
description: Opening Exhibition, Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street at Central Avenue, Newark; 201-596-6550.

title: New-Music Festival; A Triple Bill, From Mournful to Raucous
description: Two elegies and a ruckus made up a New Music America triple bill on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The elegies were by Ingram Marshall and Fred Frith; the ruckus came from the music of Edward Wilkerson, a Chicago-based jazz composer whose big band with strings, Shadow Vignettes, was making its New York debut.

title: Moondog Returns From the Hippie Years
description: Anyone who spent time in midtown Manhattan between the late 1940's and the early 1970's is likely to have seen and perhaps puzzled over Louis T. Hardin, better known as Moondog. For nearly 30 years, the gaunt blind musician with a flowing beard haunted the Avenue of the Americas around 54th Street, dressed in a homemade robe and a horned Viking helmet with a long spear at his side. He sold copies of his poetry and music to passers-by who stopped to talk. And he recorded his music on the Mars, Prestige and CBS labels -some of it scored for small wind and percussion ensembles, with a jazzy accent, some of it in a flowing, tonal symphonic style.

title: Ozone Losses Are Reported Wider Than Thought
description: Chemically induced losses of protective ozone in the stratosphere over Antarctica cover a wider area than had been thought, scientists are reporting today in the British journal Nature.

title: Profit Up 30.6% At J. C. Penney
description: Capitalizing on a turnaround this year in the apparel retailing industry, the J. C. Penney Company, the nation's fourth-largest retailer, Tuesday reported continued gains in the third quarter. For the 13-week period ended

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American International Group Inc., an insurance company, appointed Alan H. Fishman senior vice president of the company and president of its financial services group.

title: Sears Plans $815 Million Mortgage
description: Abandoning its yearlong effort to sell its headquarters tower here, Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would instead seek to raise $815 million by taking out a mortgage on the building.

title: Emotionally Ill Pose Growing Burden to Police
description: Bathed in the spotlight of a circling police helicopter, the lone figure, half naked in the night chill, stalked the catwalk of a crumbling tower high above New York Harbor, pretending to shoot a pistol, hurling down debris and threatening to jump.

title: Clay-Mill Technical reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Clamor in the East: Gratitude and a Request; In Talk to Congress, Walesa Urges A Marshall Plan to Revive Poland
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of Poland's Solidarity movement, called for a second Marshall Plan today as he addressed a joint meeting of Congress. He warned that without the sort of commitment that helped rebuild Western Europe after World War II, the situation in his country could become dangerous.

title: 2 Oppose Shift on Photo Satellites
description: Two influential Congressmen yesterday protested what they said was a proposal being considered by the Bush Administration to transfer a financially ailing system of civilian photographic satellites to the Pentagon.

title: Medicare Is Accused Of Damping Innovation
description: Medicare, the Federal program of health insurance for the elderly and disabled, may be discouraging the development and use of new technology, two Boston researchers warn.

title: Ensr Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Rock; The Buzzcocks, Reunited
description: For their first few songs on Friday night at the Ritz, the reunited Buzzcocks sounded like a pushy pop band - tuneful and terse, supporting Pete Shelley's reedy vocals, with only Steve Diggle's rhythm guitar to connect them to punk-rock.

title: Saberhagen Is Near Perfect in Cy Young Voting
description: Dave Stewart and the Oakland Athletics may have swept the prizes and purses of baseball's playoffs and World Series last month. But Bret Saberhagen of the Kansas City Royals snatched the chief personal trophy yesterday when he scored a nearly unanimous victory over Stewart and won the Cy Young Award as the best pitcher in the American League.

title: Parent & Child
description: KAREN LEVIN COBURN and her husband recently visited their daughter Alison, a freshman at Colby College in Waterville, Me., during parents' weekend. Alison greeted them with a two-hour monologue about college life but steadfastly refused to let them sit in on her French class. After much discussion, she agreed that her parents could attend her history class instead.

title: Trump Scraps Shuttle Ads
description: Donald J. Trump has lived up to his self-proclaimed reputation as a temperamental client, scrapping the new advertising campaign for the Trump Shuttle after publicly deriding it earlier this week.

title: TCI International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Health Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's warning that it is too early to talk about restructuring Europe was received with satisfaction in Washington today.

title: Miami Officer on Trial: Heroic or Eager to Kill?
description: Ten months after the fatal shooting of a black motorcyclist set off rioting here, arguments began today in the trial of a Hispanic Miami police officer charged in the case, with the prosecution depicting him as trigger-happy and the defense calling him heroic.

description: After a bitter debate, the House of Representatives capitulated to President Bush today and approved two bills that barred Federal financing of abortions for victims of rape and incest.

description: JEWELRY and porcelain may seem an odd marriage, especially when the combination is displayed at a gallery that specializes in French and Continental furniture and decorative objects. But for Anthony G. Victoria, the president of Frederick P. Victoria & Son, the pairing works well.

description: Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium, said that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell five A310 airliners to Aeroflot, the Soviet airline. Airbus said the agreement included options for five more aircraft.

title: Bolivia Declares a State of Siege After Breakdown in Strike Talks
description: The Government declared a three-month state of siege today and rounded up at least 700 teachers and labor leaders a day after negotiations with striking teachers broke down.

description: Even along the gaudy Strip, with its pulsating neon, attention-grabbing architecture and innumerable exhortations to try one's luck, Golden Nugget Inc.'s new hotel-casino, the Mirage, will be hard to miss.

title: Convictions Reversed In Ohio Bank Failure
description: An Ohio appeals court today threw out the convictions of the former owner of the Home State Savings Bank, Marvin L. Warner, and a co-defendant that resulted from the 1985 collapse of the Cincinnati institution.

title: Heart Groups Reaffirm The Health Benefits Of Lower Cholesterol
description: The American Heart Association and the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute have issued a joint statement seeking to quiet doubts about the need for most people to lower their cholesterol.

title: Ontario League Eases A Rule to Aid Prodigy
description: One of Canada's top three junior hockey leagues this week changed an important rule to lure a 16-year-old prodigy away from other options, including college hockey in the United States.

Farwest Financial said its net income would have been $1,544,000, or 20 cents a share, if the accounting change had not been mandated.

title: Mutual Benefit Appoints Chief
description: The Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company yesterday named Henry E. Kates, who is president, to the additional post of chief executive. He succeeds Robert V. Van Fossan, chairman and chief executive, who died Oct. 29 at the age of 63. The board named J. Lloyd

title: Workplace Injury Is Rising, And the Computer Is Blamed
description: Workplace injuries caused by repetitive motion have increased sharply, the Labor Department said today, and experts called the rise of computer technology a major factor.

title: Cable Giant Hungry for Programs
description: With 11 million subscribers and interests in more than a dozen program distribution services, Tele-Communications Inc. is already the nation's largest cable television operator, a behemoth in its business. But for its president, John C. Malone, that is no longer enough. Like other cable operators, his company is stepping up expansion with an eye on becoming a program producer as well.

title: International American Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The revenues and net income from the sale of investment land in the latest 6 months were $4,462,000 and $300,000, or 4 cents a share, respectively, compared with year-ago period's revenues and net income of $3,284,000 and $580,000, or 7 cents a share, respectively.

title: Metro Matters; After the Tally, Political Puzzles Hang in the Air
description: Who won? The official canvass of New York City's mayoral election, which started yesterday, is unlikely to change last week's unofficial answer.

title: Leonard Bernstein Refuses The National Medal of Arts
description: Leonard Bernstein has declined a National Medal of Arts, the White House said yesterday as it announced the 11 individuals and 1 corporation receiving this year's awards. The medals are to be presented by President Bush on Friday.

title: Bank Award To Economist
description: Larry J. Kimbell, the director of the U.C.L.A. Business Forecasting Project at the University of California at Los Angeles, yesterday received the economic forecasting award presented annually by the Sterling National Bank.

title: Nets' Problems Mount As They Lose to Celtics
description: New Jersey thought it would be a much-improved defensive team when the season began, having added Sam Bowie's shot blocking and Mookie Blaylock's defensive quickness. But tonight, the Nets' defense showed all the resistance of a revolving door.

title: Phone Sex Lines Disconnected After a Ruling
description: Five telephone services offering live conversation about sex were disconnected in the New York metropolitan area last night after a Federal court ruled that the telephone company can prohibit such conversations in certain instances without violating free speech.

Carl Morse, a Builder, Dies at 83; Helped Shape New York's Skyline
description: Carl A. Morse, a New York construction executive whose career spanned more than 60 years, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his office on Madison Avenue. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Big Tax Rise Is Proposed In Westchester
description: The Westchester County Executive proposed a 1990 operating budget today that represents a 12 percent increase in spending and a possible 25 to 30 percent rise in property taxes, the largest in recent memory.

Washington Bank Receives New Bid
description: A group led by a dissident director, Robert B. Washington Jr., has offered to purchase all of the shares of the Washington Bancorporation for $19 a share in cash, or $133 million. Washington Bancorp, a bank holding company, owns the National Bank of Washington.

title: Review/Dance; Debut of d'Amboise Troupe
description: Christopher d'Amboise left a bright career as a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet in 1987 to concentrate on making his own dances. It was a brave decision. But on the evidence of a New York debut performance by his Off Center Ballet, on Nov. 7 at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, Mr. d'Amboise has a long way still to go.

title: Currents; Locating The Basics
description: GOOD reproductions of 18th- and 19th-century furniture and decorative objects are often hard to find, and prices for the real thing have become almost prohibitive.

title: Walter Annenberg Buys a Picasso Painting for $40.7 Million
description: A brooding 1905 self-portrait of Pablo Picasso as a Harlequin standing with a Columbine at the bar of the Paris tavern Au Lapin Agile, after which the painting was named, was sold last night for $40.7 million to Walter H. Annenberg, the former United States Ambassador to Britain.

title: Union Leader Offers Defense For Detectives
description: The president of the New York City police detectives union defended yesterday the actions of two detectives who were slain by a prisoner, saying they were following common, but informal, procedures for gaining information from a ''friendly prisoner.''

title: Athletes Ride East German Wave
description: Among the thousands of East German citizens who have immigrated to West Germany in recent weeks are dozens of coaches and athletes who developed their skills in one of the world's most sophisticated training systems. But few of them, West German officials say, currently participate at the highest levels of international sports, and their departure is not expected to disrupt the East German system in any significant way.

title: Close to Home
description: ''DO you use - - - - - '' my houseguest asked, naming a dishwasher detergent. ''Yes,'' I said. ''Then I guess I can't take this,'' he sighed, and gave me a coupon torn from the Sunday paper. My houseguest is an honorable man.

title: Clamor in the East; Soviets Protest About the Wall
description: The Soviet Government has issued a sharp protest to the East German Government about the opening of the Berlin wall, a high-ranking East German Communist Party official said today.

title: Drugs, Like Therapy, Have Place in Psychiatry; Skewed Sample
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Theater; The Middle East Comedy of Errors
description: By courting controversy, the San Francisco Mime Troupe has remained in the vanguard of political theater during its entire 27-year history. The company's new show, ''Seeing Double,'' certainly must be rated as one of its most outspoken efforts. This is nothing less than a bitterly satiric musical sendup of the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians. The traveling show (presented at the Triplex Theater) is so evenhanded in its criticism as to offend extremists on both sides. At the same time, it has a pronounced moral position.

title: FREE-MARKETEER IS AHEAD IN BRAZIL
description: Fernando Collor de Mello, a former state governor who advocates a free-market path for Latin America's largest economy, led today in voter polls after Brazilians cast their ballots in the first presidential election since 1960.

title: Panel Urges Criminal Inquiry of Ex-Aide to Pierce
description: A House panel today approved a report recommending that the Justice Department open a criminal investigation of a former close aide to Samuel R. Pierce Jr. for possible violations of Federal ethics law, Congressional officials said today.

title: Reviews/Music; Ellada Chakoyan, Soprano
description: Ellada Chakoyan, a soprano who was trained in Armenia and now lives in the United States, offered a challenging and varied debut program on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Jordache Will Not Be Charged by U.S.
description: After a three-year investigation into possible tax and customs law violations, the Justice Department has decided not to bring any charges against Jordache Enterprises or its principals, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Preservation of New York Adirondack Park Wins Wide Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Marine Drilling CoO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Supporters of Government backing for initiatives to maintain American high-technology industries said the Bush Administration plans sharp cuts in Defense Department programs that bolster research and development. Since Monday, reports have circulated in Washington that the Administration has directed the Pentagon to cut back financing for high-definition television research and other high-technology efforts. Such programs are viewed by many as vital to American competitiveness. [ Page A1. ] Sun Microsystems and Unisys said they would not participate in U.S. Memories, a company being formed to produce computer memory chips. [ D1. ] Growth of business inventories outpaced business sales in September, the Government said in a report that analysts said included a warning of the slowing economy. [ D1. ] An Ohio appeals court threw out the convictions of the former owner of Home State Savings, Marvin Warner, and one co-defendant that resulted from the collapse of the savings institution. [ D2. ] Rapidly expanding Federal insurance and credit-assistance programs expose the Government to losses of $5 trillion, an amount equal to the value of the economy's annual output. [ D6. ] INTERNATIONAL Moving to take advantage of change in Eastern Europe, G.E. said it had agreed to buy control of a Hungarian light-bulb maker for $150 million, the largest American investment in Hungary since World War II. The deal represents the kind of payoff that East bloc nations have been seeking as they make political and economic changes more attuned to market forces. [ A1. ] John Reed of Citicorp said Argentina's creditor banks will not talk with Argentina about reducing its $64 billion foreign debt until they get a ''good faith'' payment on back interest. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Abandoning its yearlong effort to sell the Sears Tower, Sears, Roebuck said it would instead seek to raise $815 million by taking out a mortgage on the building. [ D1. ] Northrop named Oliver C. Boileau, a former president of General Dynamics, to oversee its B-2 Stealth bomber program. [ D1. ] Southland is considering major changes, saying that slowing sales in its 7-Eleven stores had raised doubts about its ability to generate enough cash for its debt payments in 1991. [ D5. ] Smith International agreed to be acquired by Dresser, an oil services giant, in a deal valued at $675 milllion. [ D5. ] Airbus said it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell five A310 airliners to Aeroflot, the Soviet airline. Airbus said the agreement included options for five more aircraft. [ D5. ] MARKETS

title: Putting a New Burnish on an Old Burl
description: LEAD: Old household vessels or implements carved from wood were often referred to as treenware, from ''tree,'' although the term is used only by collectors now. Hardwoods were the most popular material, particularly for utensils used to prepare food or to eat it with. An exception was yew, which is considered an evergreen and classified as a softwood, even though it is quite hard.

title: 2 Worlds Meet At a Memorial For Giamatti
description: You really didn't need a scorecard to tell most of the Hall of Fame players on West 57th Street yesterday, but a crib sheet could have helped with some of the Nobel laureates.

title: William T. Harris, 81; Built Grocery Chain
description: William Thomas Harris, who built a grocery store chain, died here Tuesday after collapsing at a state meeting of Southern Baptists. . He was 81 years old and lived in Charlotte.

description: b-Net income

title: Albany Denies Permission For Navy Yard Incinerator
description: New York State's environmental commissioner declined yesterday to grant a permit for the enormous garbage incinerator proposed at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard. He said everything about the project was in order, except for the question of what to do with its ash.

title: Throat Probe Is Giving Physicians A Different Window Into the Heart
description: An increasing number of patients are being asked to open their mouths wide so that doctors can take a look at their hearts.

title: Talking Deals; When Size Lead Is No Advantage
description: THE market leader usually has the competitive edge. But when it comes to mergers and acquisitions, it may be advantageous to be the No. 2 or No. 3 player, two recent cases suggest.

title: First Chicago Offers Securities
description: The First Chicago Corporation is offering $300 million in securities due 1992 and backed by Mastercard and Visa credit-card receivables through its First Chicago Master Trust Series D.

title: 5 CHARGED IN PLOT TO EXPORT ARMS
description: Three South Africans and two Americans have been charged with trying to export American missile technology illegally to South Africa in a case that raises new questions about military ties between South Africa and Israel, according to Federal law enforcement officials and arrest records made public this week.

title: Review/Music; A Flutist and Her Friends
description: Mindy Kaufman, a flutist with the New York Philharmonic since 1979, brought together a group of her colleagues for an evening of expertly played chamber music on Monday at Weill Recital Hall. For the occasion, she chose works from a bit off the beaten path. Most of it was inviting; some was meaningless frippery offered as sugar pill at the beginning and end of the program.

title: A Railroad Yard Where All the Trains Run to Reminiscence
description: A BAY SHORE CENTRAL freight train loaded with timber derailed near a busy signal tower in Brooklyn the other day, scattering logs in the path of a Verrazano line locomotive barreling down an adjacent track.

title: Journal of Commerce by Fax
description: The Journal of Commerce on Monday began facsimile transmission of a summary of the next day's paper that reaches subscribers in midafternoon.

title: Armour G. McDaniel, Air Force Pilot, 73
description: Armour G. McDaniel, a retired lieutenant colonel who was one of the first black pilots in the Army Air Force, died Sunday in Indianapolis, where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of money market mutual funds were mixed for the week that ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds rose while taxables declined.

title: Harare Journal; Students Fail Zimbabwe and Pay a Heavy Price
description: On the surface, Zimbabwe University, a sprawl of low-rise red brick in acres of green, appears a placid academic arena. But these are troubled times for the campus, which has quadrupled in size since Zimbabwe's independence almost 10 years ago and is the most notable in the black African countries that border South Africa.

title: Wild Bill Davison, Jazz Cornetist, Dies at 83 After 70-Year Career
description: William (Wild Bill) Davison, who played jazz cornet in the gangster-run clubs of Chicago in the 1920's and regularly toured Europe and Asia in the decades that followed, died Tuesday. He was 83 years old.

description: The leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization pledged today that it would observe a bill of rights and would practice multiparty democracy unless Namibians chose otherwise.

title: Hambletonian Hearing
description: In the resumption of a public hearing regarding the outcome of the $1,131,000 Hambletonian, the track's racing secretary testified on Tuesday that Park Avenue Joe, the disputed winner, had a summary advantage over Probe entering the raceoff and that a dead heat in the raceoff failed to change that. Joe DeFrank was the final person to testify before Thomas E. Clancy, a New Jersey Administrative Law Judge.

title: Northrop Names New Head For B-2 Bomber Program
description: The Northrop Corporation today named Oliver C. Boileau, a former president of the General Dynamics Corporation, to oversee its $70 billion B-2 Stealth bomber program.

title: Rules Due on Dual Trading
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which regulates the nation's futures exchanges, is set to propose tough restrictions on the controversial practice of dual trading, one of its commissioners said today.

title: Read All About It
description: In an effort to speed up pedestrian movement in midtown Manhattan, a group of city officials will soon announce new regulations for newsstands. Their first effort, two years ago, would have closed down most existing stands and practically prohibited new ones. Ideally, the new rules would protect public access to the newsstands as well as sidewalk traffic.

title: Committee Opens Hearings on Grants to the Arts
description: Lawyers, arts advocates and an educator held forth today on the philosophical question of how to reconcile the rights of freedom of expression for artists and scholars with the right of taxpayers to determine the use of public funds.

title: Philip Morris Ads Anger Congressman
description: A CONGRESSIONAL opponent of tobacco advertising is expected to introduce evidence today that he says indicates that the Philip Morris Companies' ad campaign extolling the Bill of Rights was specifically undertaken to head off further restrictions on tobacco advertising. But the company takes issue with the interpretation by Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio.

title: What Children Need
description: To The Home Section:

title: Braves Waive Sutter Because of Injury
description: Bruce Sutter, the 36-year-old relief pitcher who is third on major league baseball's career save list with 300, was waived by the Atlanta Braves yesterday as chronic shoulder injuries ended his chances of becoming No. 1 in his specialty. Sutter unofficially announced his retirement last March after a complete rotator cuff tear was found in his right shoulder and did not pitch in 1989. He had surgery on a partial tear in 1986.(AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-22

title: Amplicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Infant Death Research Is Questioned
description: New research has been unable to confirm a 1987 study indicating that babies who die from sudden infant death syndrome tend to have high levels of an oxygen-carrying chemical in their blood.

title: A Heist, A Handshake And a Hall
description: Long overdue, the concept of a New York Sports Museum and Hall of Fame is finally off the ground, flapping its wings to attract corporate contributions. As yet, there is no hall for this fame but according to its president, Bill Shannon, a Manhattan site will be announced soon. Early next year, 100 charter members will be selected from some 400 nominees in 30 sports within a rr75-mile radius of the Big Apple. And the quest for historical memorabilia should start now, notably by persuading the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., to return the blue-and-white Brooklyn Dodgers 1955 World Series pennant to its rightful resting place. Therein lies the story of a heist and a handshake.

title: SENATE APPROVES NEW DEFENSE BILL
description: The Senate voted final approval today for a $305 billion defense bill that makes a big cut in President Bush's request for an anti-missile shield but leaves other major projects largely intact.

title: Laidlaw to Get Disposal Company
description: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd. of Ontario won a court battle to take over Canada's largest chemical waste disposal company. Laidlaw, a garbage disposal company and North America's largest school bus operator, won control of Tricil Ltd. in an out-of-court settlement after a three-year legal battle.

title: PANEL HEARS PLEA ON ENERGY NOMINEE
description: Making a rare personal appeal to a Congressional panel to help win Senate confirmation for a subordinate, the Secretary of Energy today asked the Armed Services Committee to endorse a nominee whose work at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has been the subject of three Congressional investigations.

title: New Drug Slows Parkinson's, Study Confirms
description: In the largest study ever of a treatment for a degenerative neurological disease, scientists have confirmed that a new drug significantly slows the progression of Parkinson's disease.

title: Psicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * Bruce G. Silverman has been named president and Ronald W. Herman has been named executive vice president and chief operating officer of Asher/Gould Advertising.

title: Advanced Medical Technoloies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Because the company is a development stage enterprise, no sales figures are provided. The company said the losses of its Fidata Corp. unit for the period to the date of its merger into Advanced Medical Technologies on March 27 (including $354,000 of operating losses) have not been included in the results of operations for the 9-month period ended in September. In addition, the net losses for the three-and 9-month periods ended Sept. 30, 1988 reflect only the operations of the controlled therapeutics unit, which was the only operating entity in existence at that time.

title: Bozell Says G.M. Threat Fails to Move Stations
description: A survey of local television stations by Bozell indicates that they are not succumbing to the General Motors Corporation's threat to remove advertising unless the company's commercials are the only automobile ads broadcast during two-to-four minute commercial breaks.

title: Defense Hopes to Block Park Jogger's Testimony
description: Defense lawyers said yesterday that they would try to block any testimony in court by the jogger who was raped and beaten in Central Park last April.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 8 and a correction in this space on Saturday about the sentencing of five men for an attack in Carl Schurz Park misidentified a victim. He is Stuart Elliott.

title: What Bush Could Say
description: My fellow Americans, You and I share a rare moment in the lives of any people. A new chapter is opening in human history, and we are privileged to see it. I come to you tonight to speak of the great change that is taking place, and of the part I believe our country can play in it.

title: Whittle Distributes Books With Ads to an Elite List
description: Some 150,000 people deemed by Whittle Communications to be leaders of opinion have received free copies of the first book in an unusual series about national and global issues.

title: Pope Asks Global AIDS Effort
description: Pope John Paul II, ending a stormy Vatican conference on AIDS, called today for a global strategy to fight the disease.

title: Dow, in a Rebound, Advances 22.33 Points
description: Stocks rose moderately yesterday, buoyed by a modest increase in bond prices and strength in some takeover-related issues.

title: Clamor in the Easst: Bleak Fiscal Picture; Grim State of East Germany's Economy Is Disclosed to Parliament
description: East Germany's economy, battered by the flight to the West of more than 100,000 workers, many of them highly skilled, is in much worse shape than almost anyone knew, high-ranking Communist officials disclosed this week.

title: Newtel Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Giant Yellowknife Mn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,296,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, from the sale of certain exploration properties and a U.S. exploration subsidiary to an affiliate. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Canadian Manoir reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $435,000, or 9 cents a share, for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included extraordinary credits of $44,000 for the quarter and $240,000, or 5 cents a share, for the 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Quebecor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mexican Debt Status
description: With responses having been received from banks that account for about 60 percent of Mexico's medium- and long-term commercial bank debt, 10 percent have chosen to issue new loans, the Mexican Finance Minister, Pedro Aspe, said today. Outlining economic policy to Congress under the 1990 budget, he said commitments had been received from 223 banks accounting for $31 billion in existing debt. He said 50 percent had chosen o reduce debt principal and 40 percent to cut interest rates.

title: Frohnmayer Says He'll Seek End of Art-Grant Law
description: After visiting the New York art gallery whose $10,000 grant he had suspended, John E. Frohnmayer, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said yesterday that he would work for the removal of the recent law restricting endowment grants for art considered obscene.

title: Stage II Apparel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Federal Realty Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $7.2 million, or 51 cents a share, on sale of property.

title: Secret U.S. War in Cambodia
description: LEAD: The U.S. is waging a secret war in Cambodia against the Hun Sen Government - knowing full well that none other than the genocidal Khmer Rouge are likely to be the ultimate beneficiaries.

title: Seahawks Hope Stouffer Will Stall Giants
description: In the first 10 weeks of the season, Kelly Stouffer of the Seattle Seahawks played in only one game. He completed 2 of 6 passes for 8 yards, with an interception and a sack.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Perhaps you dread being among people you don't know or seek the security of a quiet corner at parties. Or maybe you can speak your mind among people you know well but cannot defend your rights or express your feelings to strangers or authority figures.

title: Police Kill Harlem Gunman; Drug Suspect Shot in Bronx
description: A 44-year-old man who was firing a pistol into the air for no apparent reason on the grounds of a Harlem housing project was fatally shot after he turned the gun on two anti-crime officers from the Housing Police Department, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column of Business Day on Tuesday misstated the relationship between the Ogilvy & Mather agency and the Ogilvy Group. The group is the agency's parent company.

title: Dresser Closes Deal For Oil Drill Concern
description: Smith International Inc., a Houston oil service and drilling systems company, said today that its board had agreed to be acquired by the oil service giant Dresser Industries in a deal valued at $675 million.

title: Inventories Up by 0.2%; Sales Off 0.3%
description: Growth of business inventories outpaced business sales in September, the Government said today in a report that analysts said contained a warning of growing backlogs because of the slowing economy.

title: I Founded a Farm in Nigeria, Not a Prison Camp
description: To the Editor:

title: Clamor in the East: Remarks to Congress; Excerpts From Address by Walesa
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Lech Walesa to a joint meeting of Congress:

title: Review/Theater; 'The Witch': New Life for a Yiddish Staple
description: In addition to own attractions, the production of ''The Witch'' by the Jewish Repertory Theater carries with it a few items of historical hoo-ha that add a dash of significance to this jolly tale, one of the hardiest theater perennials.

title: Home Capital Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Raymond McCarthy, 62, a G.M. Executive
description: Raymond M. McCarthy, president of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the financial arm of the General Motors Corporation and one of the nation's largest lending institutions, died of lung cancer Monday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. He was 62 years old.

title: Pistons Gain Revenge In Rematch With Heat
description: Isiah Thomas and Joe Dumars scored 6 points apiece during a 15-5 second-quarter run tonight, and the Detroit Pistons avoided a second embarrassing loss to Miami with a 130-94 rout of the Heat.

title: Books of The Times; How an Animator Created a Cosmos of Cartoons
description: Chuck Amuck The Life and Times of an Animated Cartoonist By Chuck Jones Illustrated. 302 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $24.95.

title: VMS Strategic Land Fund II reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tiffany & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
William L. Rees, 88, Retired Vice Admiral
description: William Lehigh Rees, a retired Navy vice admiral who commanded the aircraft carrier Enterprise after World War II, died of a heart attack last Thursday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 88 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Where Cheek Meets Jowl, And Both Smile
description: THE Shafers and the Anderses live in a two-family house here. But instead of two front doors and a wraparound porch, their two-family house has one door, five bedrooms, a 110-foot-long living area, 32-foot ceilings, a tower and two wooden bridges. In all, it has 6,500 square feet of space to roam.

title: Salvador Army Is Said to Seize Rebel Positions
description: Heavy Salvadoran Army counterattacks today and Tuesday night appear to have routed leftist guerrillas from several strongholds on the outskirts of this city.

title: Flextronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Reviews/Theater; 'Jacques and His Master,' On a Beckettian Journey
description: At the outset of Milan Kundera's ''Jacques and His Master,'' which is being presented at The New Theater of Brooklyn, Jacques informs the audience that he and his master are on a journey, but he confides that neither has any idea of their destination. ''No one knows where he's going,'' the master points out defensively, and from this Beckettian observation the two men try to find some meaning to their existence.

title: Former Minnesota Official Guilty
description: LEAD: A Minneapolis jury last night convicted Luther Darville, a former academic adviser to athletes at the University of Minnesota, of three counts of theft by swindle.

title: Falcon Oil & Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Misleading Birth Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have heard many beautiful words of encouragement, but, being a worker and a man of concrete work, I must tell you that the supply of words on the world market is plentiful, but the demand is falling. Let deeds follow words now.'' - Lech Walesa. [ A1:4. ]

title: Wholesale Club Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Copley Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Officers' Slayings to Be Part Of Debate on Death Penalty
description: Even though the State Legislature is not scheduled to return here for a new session until January, lawmakers are already invoking the names of Richard J. Guerzon and Keith L. Williams, the detectives slain in Queens on Monday.

title: Dr. Joseph and AIDS Testing
description: The New York City Board of Health favors the idea of contact tracing in cases of AIDS. That would mean, if New York State approves, that people infected with the AIDS virus would have their names reported to health authorities. They, in turn, would try to trace and alert the patients' sexual and needle-sharing partners.

title: Landmark Land Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JACKSON TO PRESS CAPITAL AS STATE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson sought today to define his role in the Democratic Party after last Tuesday's elections elevated several other blacks to prominent office, saying he would make a campaign for District of Columbia statehood a top priority. He said the campaign would include pickets, protests and appearances around the country.

title: China Taking A Harsh Line With Vendors
description: In front of a stall filled with tiny clothes in baby blues, pinks and greens, a man sits on a stool inhaling a cigarette with the intimidating nonchalance that he acquired in prison.

title: Clamor in the East: Speaking Out; KISSINGER EXPECTS A UNITED GERMANY
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has told a foreign policy group that German reunification is inevitable and that NATO's plan for upgrading nuclear weapons in West Germany is now ''out of the question.''

title: Maple Leafs End Blues' Eight-Game Unbeaten Streak
description: Mark Osborne's tie-breaking goal in the second period sparked a five-goal run for Toronto tonight as the Maple Leafs defeated St. Louis, 5-2, and ended the Blues' eight-game unbeaten streak.

title: Sharon Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $1,203,000, or 2 cents a share, and $14,099,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also included an accounting adjustment loss of $92,337,000. c-Net income

title: Mid-State Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results for the year included $2.2 million in special charges and provisions. Changes in the method for accounting for loan origination fees resulted in a $974,000 reduction of income before taxes.

title: Kremlin Faces Conservative Tide Against Change
description: The Gorbachev Government aclnowledged today that it was bucking an ever more conservative tide of public and political resistance as it prepared to press the national Parliament to endorse radical economic reform.

title: Lebanese Group Says It Has Abducted an American and 2 Germans
description: A previously unknown organization said today that it had kidnapped an American journalist and a Lebanese-born West German and his son.

title: VENTURE PLANNED BY G.E. IN HUNGARY
description: Moving to take advantage of political and economic change in Eastern Europe, the General Electric Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy control of a Hungarian light-bulb manufacturer for $150 million, making it the largest Western investment in Hungary since World War II.

title: After 54 Years, River's Quirk Gives Up a Clue in a Killing
description: Cold and violent, the Spokane River runs gray this time of year, concealing quirks of nature and forgotten crimes, mysteries flowing away with the river itself.

title: G.A.O. Sees Losses in Loan Efforts
description: The myriad of rapidly expanding Federal insurance and credit-assistance programs exposes the Government to losses of $5 trillion, equal to the value of the economy's total annual output, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Currents; Handled With Care
description: WHEN she was in Dakar, Senegal, this summer, Susan Vogel, the executive director of the Center for African Art in Manhattan, visited one of the neighborhood studios where artists create paintings on glass.

title: Steve's Homemade Ice Cream reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Why Blister Packs?
description: To The Home Section:

title: CUTS ARE EXPECTED FOR U.S. FINANCING IN HIGH-TECH AREA
description: Supporters of increased Government backing for initiatives to maintain American high-technology industries said yesterday that they believe the Bush Administration plans sharp cuts in Defense Department programs that bolster commercial research and development.

title: MUST BE FLEXIBLE, BAKER TELLS ISRAELI
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel today that the United States was prepared to address some of Israel's concerns about not wanting to negotiate with the Palestine Liberation Organization. But it could not give Israel the sort of airtight assurances it was seeking without undermining the entire Middle East peace process, American and Israeli officials said.

title: Exchange Tests Asked
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a policy statement today urging the nation's stock exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers to monitor and test periodically the vulnerability of their computer systems to internal and external threats.

title: United Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bonn Cabinet Weighs Aid for East Germany
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl conferred today with the 11 Cabinet ministers involved in planning assistance for East Germany.

title: Carter-Menil Rights Award For Israeli and Arab Groups
description: Two groups, one Israeli and one Palestinian, which document human rights violations in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, were selected to share the $100,000 Carter-Menil Rights Award today.

title: At Least 14 Are Killed In an Alabama Tornado
description: A tornado slammed into a shopping district, a residential area and a school here today, killing at least 14 people, injuring more than 400 and trapping many others in their cars and homes, the police said.

title: C3 Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Sensormatic Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Reviews/Music; Cherkassky's Romanticism Jumps Boundaries
description: There are pianists who treat music as a battlefield and their instrument as an enemy to be overcome. Sometimes, with certain artists and in certain works, that can be exciting or elevating. Shura Cherkassky, a serious musician of a different sort, approaches the piano as if it were a device whose principal function is to enhance pleasure. The 78-year-old virtuoso's Carnegie Hall recital on Tuesday evening accomplished that, whether the subject was Handel or Stockhausen.

title: On Field or in News Media, Walton Can't Win
description: It doesn't take much to get Joe Walton discharged these days. Start a rumor, and - presto! - the Jets are looking for someone to replace him. Except that it isn't happening. The constant harping on whether it will happen, however, could have a corrosive effect on players on a club with a fragile psyche thanks to its 2-8 record. Selective Reading

title: Boston Celtics L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 More Indicted In Futures Case
description: Two more futures traders here were indicted by a United States grand jury on fraud charges resulting from the Federal investigation at the Chicago futures exchanges. Danny Scheck and David

title: 2-0 Victory Sends Irish To World Cup at Last
description: Ireland, managed by an Englishman who tasted World Cup success more than 20 years ago, reached the World Cup finals for the first time ever today. And West Germany qualified for the 10th successive time.

title: Slain Archbishop's Tomb Is Now a Shrine
description: Almost 10 years ago, in perhaps the most notorious assassination in a decade of civil strife in El Salvador, a single bullet tore into the heart of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero as he was saying Mass in a hospital chapel in San Salvador.

title: Movie Theme Park Planned For Disneyland in France
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it would open a second park, which will have a movie studio theme, at its Euro Disneyland complex near Paris.

title: National-Standard Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary credits of $401,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,562,000, or 89 cents a share, for the year, from tax loss carryforwards. Latest full-year results included the $7.7 million cost of closing a manufacturing facility and a $4.4 million expense for new product initiatives. The company said latest fourth quarter losses were primarily related to restructuring and new product initiatives. The latest year also included a gain of $3.5 million from settlement of pension liabilities. The prior full-year figures included a gain of $4.7 million from the settlement of pension liabilities.

title: Tokyo Journal; Japan Drinks Up France, With a Beaujolais Chaser
description: The first bottles of 1989 Beaujolais nouveau hit the streets of Tokyo at exactly 1:31 A.M. today, aboard a fleet of racing cars that tore in from Narita Airport. The city was waiting. By 1:32, hundreds of young Japanese computer programmers and stock traders and office workers grabbed for newly filled glasses, ignoring the river of wine that spilled across dinner jackets and dresses as bartenders ripped corks from scores of bottles.

title: Video Is Making Waves in the Art World
description: THE televisions are stacked floor-to-ceiling across the museum wall. A skeletal character who resembles Max Headroom appears on some of the more than 200 sets. The rest show transient images of the rock star David Bowie, a man and woman dancing, piano keys and dozens of other barely perceptible but nonetheless eye-catching stimuli, all accompanied by a blaring soundtrack.

title: Cineplex Buyout Group Fails to Meet Deadline
description: The management of Canada's Cineplex Odeon Corporation, one of North America's largest movie theater chains, said today it had missed its Wednesday deadline for its $613 million buyout offer - $718 million in Canadian funds - after failing to get the financing needed.

title: At the Movies
description: 'E. T.' to 'Valmont'

title: Books of The Times; Of Growing Up in Brooklyn Amid Dodgers and Dreams
description: Brooklyn Boy By Alan Lelchuk 298 pages. McGraw-Hill. $19.95.

title: Together, We Can Control Medical Technology
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
AC&R; Keeps The Faith In Research
description: LEAD: WITH advertising agencies slashing their research staffs and substituting soft surmises for hard data, AC&R; Advertising is a rarity: an ad agency that says it still believes in old-fashioned, quantifiable research.

title: Review/Theater; 'A Whistle in the Dark'
description: The furies are unleashed in ''A Whistle in the Dark.'' Tom Murphy's drama, which is being revived at the South Street Theater, centers on the Carneys of County Mayo, a brawling, brutish pack of street fighters who have been brought up to respect their father and their family honor. The fact that both father and family honor are severely tarnished does not lessen the conviction or the ferocity of the characters.

title: 40 Killed as Afghan Rebel Ammo Dumps Blow Up
description: Explosions destroyed two ammunition dumps belonging to an Afghan guerrilla group and were reported today to have killed at least 40 people and to have set back guerrilla plans for a stepped-up offensive in the northeastern corner of Afghanistan.

title: Todd Shipyards reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
