description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,614,000, or 86 cents a share, and $7,880,000, or $1.88 a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $1,803,000, or 43 cents a share,, for both periods. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,520,000, or 84 cents a share, and $5,523,000, or $1.32 a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. d-Net loss

title: Economic Scene; Did C.I.A. Distort Soviet Outlays?
description: WITH the breakdown of the Communist economies, the United States is facing some critical choices. And a major issue is whether this nation can seize any opportunities to reassert its economic and political leadership without jeopardizing its security interests. Doubts about whether and how much the United States should scale back military spending have been compounded by analyses of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency, which indicate that the Soviet Union has been substantially outspending the United States on military programs for 15 to 20 years.

title: Senate Yields on Abortion Money for Poor
description: Reluctant to prolong an abortion fight with President Bush, the Senate today reversed itself and agreed to drop an abortion financing provision from a $157 billion spending bill.

title: Avatar Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Latest third quarter operations included certain non-recurring adjustments of $1,800,000. The latest 9 months and third quarter revenue figures included $35,823,000 and $11,833,000, respectively, which were deferred for recognition in future periods. The company said it adopted the installment method of profit recognition for homesite sales effective Jan. 1, 1989. This change in accounting does not alter the way Avatar conducts its business nor should it affect Avatar's liquidity; however, it has resulted in a reduction of reported gross revenues from real estate operations. Also, due to this change from accrual basis, results are not directly comparable. Year-earlier figures are under accrual basis.

title: Flower City
description: Coming home to the sidewalks of New York used to be a real come-down for the person who'd just spent a week or so on the streets of Paris: there were no flowers.

title: With America Honoring Walesa, Little Poland Is Filled With Pride
description: In the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, which is known as Little Poland, the ties to the old country remain strong.

title: Stepped-Up Fighting Engulfs Salvador
description: The Salvadoran Army today stepped up its assault on rebel pockets in civilian neighborhoods along the city's periphery, pounding them with rockets, tanks and mortars. Several fires burned out of control.

title: Gerber Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Reviews/Film; Jarmusch's 'Mystery Train,' Vignettes Linked by Elvis
description: ''Mystery Train'' was shown as part of the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway at 66th Street.

title: South Africa Decides to Open All Beaches to Blacks
description: President F. W. de Klerk ordered today that South Africa's beaches be opened to all races. He said that some other public places, including libraries and parks, would be desegregated soon.

title: Hal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jeremy Flint Dies at 61; A Top Bridge Player
description: Jeremy Flint, one of the world's leading contract bridge players, died of cancer Wednesday in London. He was 61 years old and lived in London.

title:
About Real Estate;
Prewar 5th Ave. Building Converted
description: LEAD: A proud prewar apartment house, 1150 Fifth Avenue, at the northeast corner of 96th Street, has belatedly joined many others on the avenue to convert from rental to cooperative status. It is believed to be the last of the large prewar buildings on the avenue above 60th Street to be converted.

title: Storms Bring Death and Cold To East as Air Masses Clash
description: The wave of violent weather that swept across the eastern United States yesterday and Wednesday was the product of the collision of two big storm systems, one carrying unseasonable warmth, the other bone-chilling cold.

title: How About a Real Minimum Wage Increase?
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 in Lebanon Are Free, German Envoy Reports
description: Two Lebanese-born West Germans and an American woman who were said to have been abducted Wednesday in Beirut apparently were never detained, the West German Ambassador in Beirut said today.

title: Financial News Network reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $593,516. The company said Financial News Network's home shopping service was discontinued in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1989; the company's financial statements have been restated to reflect the service as a discontinued operation.

title: Warmth Does Not Mean Support, 41 American Jews Write Shamir
description: A group of 41 prominent American Jews delivered an open letter today to the Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, telling him not to misinterpret a warm welcome for him in the United States as support for his hard-line positions.

title: Turner MGM/UA Bid Seen
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. is considering a bid for the MGM/UA Communications Company, a source close to the proposal said yesterday.

title: Review/Film; 'Valmont,' New Incarnation Of 'Liaisons Dangereuses'
description: Cheese in the marketplace could apparently be bought wrapped in fresh leaves. And in the boxes at the opera house, there were curtains made of netting. Aside from these and a few other comparably cogent details of life in late-18th-century France, Milos Forman's ''Valmont'' contributes virtually nothing to the body of information surrounding ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' the stunningly malevolent, ingeniously multi-faceted novel upon which one hit play and one much better recent film have already been based.

title: CBS/Fox Sues MGM/UA
description: The CBS/Fox Company has sued the MGM/UA Communications Company for $50 million in damages, charging that MGM/UA reneged on an agreement that gives CBS/Fox rights to distribute MGM/UA movies on videotape.

title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
Ferry's Rights Are Traded
description: The Los Angeles Clippers traded the rights to Danny Ferry to the Cleveland Cavaliers today, along with Reggie Williams, for Ron Harper and three draft choices.

title: Chinese Premier Sees No Effect From Europe
description: Prime Minister Li Peng of China said here today that Beijing was watching events in Eastern Europe closely but that the surge of change in East Germany and other Warsaw Pact nations would not weaken China's commitment to Communism.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is a crime of such repugnance that to say that I condemn or deplore seems inadequate. It is a barbaric act that has brought shame to El Salvador. I have difficulty in imagining what sort of animals would, in cold blood, execute priests, and other innocents.'' - William J. Walker, United States Ambassador to El Salvador. [ A12:5. ]

title: Joy D. Beinecke Dead; Dance Teacher Was 59
description: Joy Dewey Beinecke, a dance teacher and consultant, died of cancer Wednesday at her home on Nantucket Island, Mass. She was 59 years old.

title: Smiling Through the Cultural Imperialism
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Backs Measure on Cambodia That Allows Khmer Rouge a Role
description: The United Nations General Assembly overwhelmingly approved a resolution today calling for a comprehensive political settlement in Cambodia. The settlement would give the Khmer Rouge a role in an interim government led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk while internationally supervised elections are prepared.

title: El Paso Refinery L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it assumed refining operations and assets of El Paso Refining Inc. and completed a public offering on Nov. 1, making share earnings unavailable. El Paso Refinery said the results are those of El Paso Refining Inc. from May 1 and the results of its affiliated predecessor El Paso Refining Co. for the period before May 1.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about diamonds misstated the weight of a carat. It is about 0.007 ounce.

title: Hilton Stock Falls; No Buyer Disclosed
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation's stock plunged $5.75 yesterday, to $96, after the company's regular board meeting ended without an announcement of a buyer for the company. Hilton's shares, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange, have been active since May, when Barron Hilton, the chairman and son of the late founder, Conrad Hilton, indicated that he was seeking a buyer for the corporation or its hotel properties.

title: Cheyenne Software Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest quarter results of F.A. Computer Technologies Inc., acquired in March.

title: Dismissal of Choreographer With AIDS Was Illegal and Unfair
description: To the Editor:

title: Helmerich & Payne reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-end results included gains equaled to 5 cents a share for 1989 and 8 cents a share for 1988 from the sale of securities.

title: Beleaguered Nominee Backed
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved Vaughn R. Walker's nomination as a Federal judge, ending a deadlock that had lasted almost two years because of his membership in a club that excluded blacks and women. The vote was 11 to 2.

title: Hijacking Law Is Applied to Suspected Molestation on Jet
description: The crime, the sexual abuse of a child under the age of 12, occurred in March over the Atlantic on a Scandinavian Airlines flight from Copenhagen to John F. Kennedy International Airport, the complaint said.

title: 2 LEFTISTS IN RACE FOR BRAZIL RUNOFF
description: Partial returns from Brazil's first presidential election in 29 years put a center-right former state governor in the lead today, with a virtual deadlock between two leftists for second place.

title: Walesa Warns on Reunification Of Germany, Citing Hitler's Rule
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity movement in Poland, gave a sharp warning today against any early consideration of the reunification of Germany.

title: Richfood Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 14
description: b-Net income

title: TV Weekend; 'A Tale of Two Cities' in a Fresh Version
description: It's not as if there were any urgent need, but television has come up with another dramatization of ''A Tale of Two Cities,'' the story of turmoil in the final decades of the 18th century. The Charles Dickens novel has gone through several film adaptations, reaching back to the 1917 version starring William Farnum. The best of the lot remains the 1935 M-G-M production that supported Ronald Colman with a splendid cast, including Edna May Oliver, Basil Rathbone and Blanche Yurka. Those were the days.

title: Anderson Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $3 million from the sale of investments for the quarter and year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: In New Jersey, New 'Report Cards' Grade the Schools
description: More than one million public-school students and their parents across the state are receiving ''report cards'' this week that for the first time give a measure of the quality of schools and how well they have succeeded in helping children learn.

title: 7 Children Killed Near Newburgh As Wind Shatters Wall at School
description: Seven children were killed, and many others were injured, four critically, in a roar of concrete blocks and flying glass yesterday when a hurricane-force gust of wind blew in the wall of a cafeteria during lunch at an elementary school near Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Knicks Rout Kings By 121-102
description: The Knicks won the first game of their western trip by a point in the final seconds, and they lost the next game by a point in the final seconds. Tonight, they eliminated any suspense early and routed the Sacramento Kings, 121-102.

title: Rose's Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
Three Convicted Of Racketeering Are Imprisoned
description: Three men with ties to the Genovese crime family were sentenced to 20-year prison terms yesterday on Federal racketeering convictions that included the 1986 murder of a police detective in Queens.

title: Chemical Leaman reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included pretax charge of $4,702,314 for environmental cleanup costs. c-After a loss of $1,472,000 from an accounting adjustment which reflects adoption of Financial Accounting Standard No. 96.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE EXPECTED TO OPEN AN ETHICS INQUIRY
description: The Senate Ethics Committee is expected to open formal investigations of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and his dealings with Federal housing programs and of five senators accused of intervening improperly on behalf of a failing savings institution, a Senate official said today.

title: Gorbachev Says It's Not Time For Soviet Private Property
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says the Soviet Union is not ready for private property or competing political parties, but is leaving the door open for both in the future.

title: Commodity Invester to Join Steinhardt Fund's Founder
description: One of the country's most successful commodity investors will join Steinhardt Partners as co-managing director of investments. Bruce Kovner, who already invests $800 million for wealthy individuals, will join the $1.5 billion Steinhardt Fund as the first partner to share joint investment responsibilities with Michael H. Steinhardt, the founder, in almost 10 years.

title: Varitronic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Another Yankee Moves
description: Lou Piniella, hired away from the Yankees this month to serve as manager of the Cincinnati Reds, dipped back into the Yankees' talent pool yesterday and hired Stan Williams as pitching coach.

title: Westbridge Computer reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Adac Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cabot Gets Executive
description: After spending his entire career in New York City, John V. Allen, who has been with Geer, DuBois for 17 years, will head to Boston to become executive vice president and director of client services at Cabot Advertising. Mr. Allen held the same title at Geer, DeBois, where he supervised accounts for Jaguar, Sony, I.B.M. and Brown & Williamson Tobacco.

title: Reviews/Film; 'Times to Come,' Argentine Political Tale
description: ''Times to Come'' is an example of that risky hybrid the avant-garde political thriller. The first feature by an Argentine director, Gustavo Mosquera, it delivers far more atmosphere and promise than accomplishment.

title: Bridge
description: Two New York experts led into the two final sessions of the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today. Bob Blanchard and Jim Krekorian, both of Manhattan, headed a field of 56 pairs who survived yesterday's semifinal play, but world-class players were in close pursuit.

title: Searching For Godliness in a Profession With a Tarnished Reputation
description: Lawyers today face a host of problems, from low public esteem to congested courts to the uneven distribution of legal services. But one religious group believes that before the bar can tackle any of this, what it needs most is a theological pep talk, a cosmic shot in the arm.

title: Westvaco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Latest fourth-quarter results were reduced by five cents a share due to the impact of Hurricane Hugo. The year-ago period results included a 10- cent-a-share favorable tax item.

title: Mr. Frohnmayer's Fumble
description: A young man stares wanly from a hospital bed banked in balloons, flowers and an old straw hat . . . The drawer of a vanity table opens on a row of glass vials, the kind usually used for blood samples . . . A writer rages at ''seeing death coming in from the edges of abstraction where those with the luxury of time have cast it.''

title: Prague Denies Being Warned By Moscow to Speed Change
description: Communist Czechoslovakia disputed a report today that Moscow had formally warned the Prague leadership to speed up change.

title: Card-Carrying Librarians?
description: It sounded at first like the wacky plot of a ''Get Smart'' spy spoof: F.B.I. agents whispering into the ears of librarians, urging them to keep an eye peeled for ''hostile intelligence service activities'' among readers. But the story proved true. Last year the F.B.I. admitted that for more than a decade it had tried to recruit librarians as sentries in the cold war, and F.B.I. Director William Sessions promised to curtail the program.

title: Atlas Consolidated Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,489,000 and $6,240,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss of $6,000 for the quarter and income of $1,990,000 for the 9 months, both from debt of extinguishment. c-Included a gain of $5,258,000 from debt of extinguishment for the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included gains from tax loss carryforwards of $6,240,000. Results are in U.S. dollars. Results are converted at 21.8667 pesos to $1 in latest third quarter; 21.0291 pesos to $1 in year-ago third quarter; 21.5350 pesos to $1 in latest 9 months; and 20.9030 pesos to $1 in year-ago 9 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air France, Paris, will order seven A340-300 airliners from Airbus Industrie on Monday and will take options on four more A340's.

title: Kitty Dukakis at Special Unit
description: Kitty Dukakis, the wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, is undergoing treatment at a hospital unit specializing in depression and related disorders. Mrs. Dukakis, 52 years old, was hospitalized last week after drinking rubbing alcohol.

title: Counting on Vulnerability in 'High Stakes'
description: Amos Kollek's ''High Stakes'' is a romantic comedy about Bambi (Sally Kirkland), whose real name is Melanie Rose, a stripper and whore, and John (Robert LuPone), an Upper East Side-type who makes his fortunes as a Wall Street speculator. They meet cute. Bambi, half-dressed, has just been tossed out of a car by a client, who says she's too old. On the steps outside her bohemian walk-up apartment on West 42d Street, she meets John. He has just been mugged.

title: The Two Countries Are Likely to Join Their Industries Before Their Politics
description: Foreigners who worry about ''reunification'' as an immediate and ominous consequence of the end of the Berlin wall overlook two things. One is that East and West Germany together only constitute about two-thirds of the pre-war territory of the German Reich. Another is that East and West Germany have gradually been extending and broadening ties of all kinds ever since they established diplomatic relations with each other in 1972.

title: Morgan Out for Season
description: Stanley Morgan, the New England Patriots wide receiver, suffered a fractured right leg in practice yesterday and will miss the rest of the season. A club spokesman said that Morgan, 34 years old and in his 13th season in the National Football League, was injured while running hard in rain-swept Sullivan Stadium.

title: Europeans Press Case For Shaping the Future
description: As the European Community prepares to meet over the dramatic developments in East Germany, politicians and commentators say that its 12 member countries hope to make clear the importance of their role in fashioning Europe's future before the meeting next month between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Bulgarians Oust Old Guard As Step to Political Change
description: Bulgaria's Communists swept out much of their old guard today, leaving no doubt that they wished to break from the hard-line orthodoxy followed for 35 years by Todor I. Zhivkov, their leader who was recently removed.

title: Perpetual Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gain of $1,828,000, or 13 cents a share,primary, reflecting a prepayment penalty of $307,000 on borrowings and a gain of $2.1 million from early retirement of debt. Results for 1988 included a net gain of $24.4 million, or $1.79 a share, from the sale of an office building and a net charge of $12.1 million from the writedown of non-performing assets and an increase in the provision for loan losses.

title: Great American CommunicaFtions Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,624,000 for the quarter and $3,720,000 for the 9 months; the discontinued operations for both periods included a $9,090,000 loss from sale of discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $3,808,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $6,381,000, or 21 cents a share, for the 9 months. The discontinued operations for all periods represented earnings from Great American's insurance subsidiary which was sold in September 1989. The loss from continuing operations for the latest 9 months included a $7.2 million gain on the sale of an affiliate. The year-ago periods' revenue figures included $10.1 million and $27.3 million, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, in television distribution. The loss from continuing operations for the year-ago 9 months included a $23 million gain on the sale of 5.3 million shares of United Brands common stock.

title: Review/Film; Of Murphy, By Murphy, And Starring . . . Murphy
description: Do not be put off by the ads for ''Harlem Nights,'' a steal from those for ''The Sting,'' in which the faces of Eddie Murphy and Richard Pryor are substituted for those of Paul Newman and Robert Redford.

title: Campbell Soup Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Dresser in Merger
description: Dresser Industries said its board had approved a merger agreement with Smith International Inc. of Houston. The company said that Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which owns about a third of Smith's stock, had also approved the offer. The acquisition, which must be approved by the Justice Department, would give Dresser more than 30 percent of the American drilling tool and service market. A Dresser spokesman said the agreement was valued at $622 million - $462 million in cash and $160 million in debt.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Mike Smith, pitcher, from Rochester of the International League, and Chris Meyers, pitcher, and Leo Gomez, third baseman, from Hagerstown of the Eastern League. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Mike Erb, pitcher, from Quad City of the Midwest League, and Jeff Richardson, pitcher, from Midland of the Texas League. CINCINNATI (NL) - Named Stan Williams pitching coach and Larry Rothschild bullpen coach. CLEVELAND (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Kevin Bearse, Mike Walker and Joe Skalski, pitchers, from Colorado of the Pacific Coast League, and Carl Keliipuleole, pitcher, from Canton-Akron of the Eastern League. HOUSTON (NL) - Purchased the contracts of Dave Rohde, infielder, and Terry Wells, pitcher, from Tucson of the Pacific Coast League; Mike Simms, first baseman, and Ryan Bowen, pitcher, from Columbua of the Southerm League; Bert Hunter, outfielder, and Harold Allen, pitcher, from Osceola of the Florida State League, and Andujar Cedeno, infielder, from Asheville of the South Atlantic League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Waived Sammy Khalifa, infielder, and Logan Easley and Mike Smith, pitchers. Purchased the contracts of Scott Ruskin, pitcher, and Julio Peguero, outfielder, from Harrisburg of the Eastern League. Dismissed Dom Scala, advance scout, and promoted Lenny Yochim from East Coast scouting coordinator to advance scout. Named Chris Lein pitching coach for Salem of the Carolina League; Tom Dettore manager for Augusta of the South Atlantic League, and Jack Lind manager of Welland of the New York-Penn League. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Signed Kevin Bass, outfielder, to a three-year contract. BASKETBALL DALLAS (NBA) - Announced that Roy Tarpley, forward, had been suspended indefinitely and without pay by counselors in his after-care program after he was arrested Wednesday night and charged with driving while intoxicated. LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS (NBA) -Traded Reggie Williams, guard-forward, and the rights to Danny Ferry, forward, to the Cleveland Cavaliers for Ron Harper, guard, first-round draft picks in 1990 and 1992, and a second-round pick in 1992. LOS ANGELES LAKERS (NBA) -Named John Black public relations director, effective at the end of the month. FOOTBALL NEW ENGLAND (AFc) - Waived Russ Francis, tight end, off the list of those physically unable to perform, and Steve Johnson, tight end, off injured reserve. Announced that Stanley Morgan, wide receiver, would miss the rest of the season after fracturing his right leg. Placed Michael Timpson, wide receiver, on injured reserve. Signed Kitrick Taylor, wide receiver-kick returner, to a two-year contract. TORONTO (CFL) - Dismissed Bob O'Billovich, head coach.

title: Dining Out Guide: Thanksgiving
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Aureole ** (Jan. 6, 1989), 34 East 61st Street, (319-1660) - This airy, cream-and-beige dining room in a converted town house is an attractive spot for a festive Thanksgiving dinner. The special menu starts with an alder-wood smoked salmon followed by poached Maine lobster and sweet corn chowder. The main course choice is between roast turkey with three dressings or saddle of venison with roast pears. Dessert options are pumpkin-and-praline pie or apple tart with crisp streusel. The Thanksgiving dinner is prix fixe at $55. Dinner from 2 P.M. to 8:30 P.M. Ballroom * (June 30, 1989), 253 West 28th Street (244-3005) - This spacious and comfortable dining room, with its rustic, colorful tapas bar, is having its annual Festival of the Birds. The menu for the day starts with a choice of tapas or soup (pumpkin, black bean or wild turkey consomme). Then, as befitting the festival, there is a plethora of main-course choices: roast turkey with corn-bread stuffing, wild turkey with black walnuts, roast Cornish hen with green peppercorns, braised quail with wild thyme, roast pheasant with wild mushrooms, grilled duck with figs, and cassoulet of goose with braised vegetables. This is followed by the mixed greens with raspberry vinaigrette. Prices range from $28.50 to $48.50 (dessert not included). Seatings at 1, 3:30, 6 and 8:30 P.M. Carolina * (Feb. 14, 1986), 355 West 46th Street (245-0058) - One of the prettiest spots on Restaurant Row, Carolina has an arching skylight, comfortable banquettes and wraparound glass walls that multiply a sole palm tree into an urban grove. The ample Thanksgiving menu starts with a choice or seafood chowder or black bean soup followed by an appetizer choice of crab cakes, hot smoked sausages or smoked salmon. Beyond the requisite roast turkey, there is bourbon baked ham, roast pheasant with corn bread and apple stuffing and herb-roasted smoked leg of lamb (all with maple walnut sweet potatoes, mashed potatoes, corn pudding and condiments). A light finale would be pecan fingers or lime pie. Prix fixe at $40. Thanksgiving dinner served from 1 to 8 P.M. Greene Street Restaurant ** (April 29, 1988), 101 Greene Street (925-2415) - This theatrical multi-tier SoHo loft would be a dramatic place to spend Thanksgiving Day, given the bonus of entertainment by the Lynn Bernstein piano-and-bass duo. The chef has provided an enticing selection for the holiday, starting with a choice of pumpkin soup, grilled quail salad or gray sole in a lemon-butter sauce. After a pause for a mixed-green salad, there is a choice of roast turkey with apple-chestnut stuffing, roast partridge in a marjoram cream sauce or loin of venison in a poivrade. Dessert makes for a difficult decision: warm apple-pecan tart, mincemeat strudel with honey-caramel ice cream or frozen rum-pumpkin souffle. Prix-fixe $38.50. Thanksgiving dinner from 3:30 P.M. to 10 P.M. Rainbow Room ** (March 25, 1988), 30 Rockefeller Plaza (632-5000) - This is perhaps one of the most romantic settings in which to spend this festive occasion: a sumptuous Art Moderne dining room evocative of another era of New York with panoramic views of the city. The Thanksgiving menu offers an abundance of temptations. Appetizers include warm seafood sausage on glazed leeks, wild mushrooms in puff pastry and a terrine of game and truffles. After a soup course, there is grilled fillet of salmon on wild rice, crisp duck with tiny wine grapes and lentil flan, medallions of farm venison with toasted barley pilaf and prime rib of beef with Yorkshire pudding. A cranberry cheesecake and a frozen maple souffle with hot chocolate sauce are among the dessert offerings. Prix fixe at $55. Seatings at noon, 12:30, 2:30, 3, 5, 5:30, 7:30 and 8 P.M. What the stars mean, C24.

title: Review/Film; Of Good Dogs, Heaven And, Naturally, Death
description: One reason all dogs go to heaven, a character in the film by that name says, is that ''unlike people, dogs are naturally good and loyal and kind.'' That's nice. Another reason, as children watching Don Bluth's new full-length animated feature are sure to surmise, is that all dogs die. Anyone not wishing to discuss this idea and its greater implications on the way home from the theater would be well advised to think twice before taking a small child.

title: Dismissal of Choreographer With AIDS Was Illegal and Unfair
description: To the Editor:

title: El Paso Electric reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $67,039,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $179,000. The company said the latest net loss and loss from continuing operations included a $15,894,000 after-tax regulatory disallowance and a net after- tax provision for estimated loss of $12,300,000 on various investments. The loss from continuing operations for the latest 12 months included the effect of $30 million, or 85 cents a share, attributable to the company's investment in preferred stock.

title: Smithfield Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net income

title: Hard Times Overtake the Roosevelt Tram
description: In the 14 years since the Roosevelt Island tramway began operating, its admirers say, the twin red cabs have become as much a symbol of New York City as the Brooklyn Bridge and the Staten Island Ferry. And like the ferry, these admirers say, the tram is a bargain; a dollar and a quarter not only gets you from here to there, but also provides a spectacular view.

title: A.T.&T. Plans 1.3% Rise In Long-Distance Rates
description: Eight months after the Government approved a method for setting long-distance rates that was expected to lower consumers' telephone bills, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would raise prices on domestic long-distance service.

title: Eagle Food Centers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $252,000 for the quarter and $1,296,000 for the 9 months. The company said year-ago quarter and 9 months extraordinary charges are due to the writeoff of deferred financing costs. Earnings for all periods are pro forma as the company operated as a partnership until July.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 10 about a dispute over the principal's post at Public School 262 in Brooklyn erroneously paraphrased a comment from Robert C. (Sonny) Carson, a black nationalist from Brooklyn. (The erroneous version first appeared in an Op-Ed page article on Nov. 3 about the New York City mayoral campaign.) Tapes show that at a news conference on Oct. 19, in referring to accusations of anti-Semitism, Mr. Carson said: ''That's absolutely absurd, 'anti-Semitic.' And so that you don't ask the question, I'm anti-white. Don't limit my anti's to just one group of people.''

title: Frederick's of Hollywood reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: The company said share earnings reflect two 3-for-2 stock distributions, effected in March and August.

title: Play Based on the Life Of a Literary Agent
description: A reading of a two-character play based on the autobiography of Audrey Wood, the literary agent, will be presented at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, at 8 P.M. Nov. 27. The work, arranged by Max Wilk and performed by Tandy Cronyn and Jeffrey De Munn, is called ''Mr. Williams and Miss Wood'' and deals with the 30-year relationship between the playwright Tennessee Williams and his agent. The presentation is a benefit for the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, Waterford, Conn., where the play was informally read last summer during the Eugene O'Neill Conference.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Maryland, Baltimore, named Peter J. Campisi chief financial officer and vice president of finance.

title: Raven Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Developer Hopes to Build Housing On Land Owned by New York City
description: Plans for medium-density garden apartments on vacant land owned by New York City have been proposed by a builder who was involved in a cooperative effort that built 1,700 affordable houses in Brooklyn without Federal help.

title: Jewish Heritage Book Fair at the 7th Regiment Armory
description: The many colors of Joseph's coat are not a patch on the infinite variations of theme, style and format that flourish at the Jewish Heritage Book Festival, which makes its fourth annual stand on Sunday and Monday, again at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: Together, We Can Control Medical Technology; Make a Living Will
description: To the Editor:

title: Tele-Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dismissal of Choreographer With AIDS Was Illegal and Unfair
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: At the Royalton Hotel

title: Jamesway Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Jamesway said net income figures included LIFO provisions of $200,000 for the third quarter and $900,000 for the 9 months in 1989 and $1,685,000 for the quarter and $2,285,000 for the 9 months of 1988. The results do not include sales from leased departments.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''SOUVENIRS OF OLD NEW YORK,'' six actors and singers re-enact moments in the lives of famous New Yorkers, 2 P.M. Sundays, through Nov. 26, at the Open Eye: New Stagings for Youth, 270 West 89th Street. Tickets: students and the elderly, $6; others, $8. Information: 769-4143. ''BEAUTY AND THE BEAST,'' a play with music by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1 P.M. and 2:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Admission: $4.50. Information: 772-9180. ''PUPPET FOLLIES,'' a puppet show by Bob Conrad, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''FOOTPRINTS ON THE MOON,'' a musical celebrating the 20th anniversary of man's first steps on the moon, presented by Theaterworks/USA, 12:30 P.M. tomorrow and 10:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Promenade Theater, Broadway and 76th Street. Tickets: $12 and $15. Reservations: 677-5959. ''GOLDILOCKS AND THE THREE BEARS,'' a play by the Little People's Theater Company, directed by Robert Stark, 1:30 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, and ''The Three Little Pigs,'' 3 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: 765-9540. ''THE EARLY SHOW,'' a cabaret for children by children, with singing, dancing and other entertainment; brunch at noon and a show at 1 P.M. every Saturday, at Steve McGraw's, 158 West 72d Street. Cover charge, $6; $6 minimum. Information: 595-7400.

title: Together, We Can Control Medical Technology; The Patient's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Employees To Be Subject to Drug Tests
description: New York City employees in 53 safety-related job categories - from lifeguard to crane operator to juvenile counselor - will be subject to random drug testing under an executive order issued yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch. The order follows a two-year study of the issue by a special mayoral task force.

title: Plenum Publishing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATO Officials See Role in Transition of Europe
description: Playing down its traditional role as a military alliance, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has begun arguing that it is the instrument through which the United States and Western Europe can best manage the political transition of Eastern Europe.

title: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co.  Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated at the rate of U.S. $1 equals 139 yen. The share earnings are in American Depositary Share (ADS) with each ADS representing 10 shares of common stock.

title: J. Emerson Thors, 87, an Investment Banker
description: J. Emerson Thors, a retired investment banker, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Water Mill, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: Kaufman View On a Recession
description: Interest rates are likely to decline as the economy slows, but the beneficial effects of lower rates may not be enough to forestall a recession in the United States, Henry Kaufman, the economist, said yesterday.

title: Allegheny in Shift On Japonica Offer
description: Allegheny International Inc., which had indicated it would not seriously consider a $683.8 million takeover offer from Japonica Partners L.P., has decided to let the New York investment group review its records. ''We're pleased that the board is now apparently cooperating, and we are looking forward to completing a transaction that is in the best interests of creditors and shareholders,'' said Fredric Spar, a Japonica spokesman. An Allegheny spokesman declined to comment. Allegheny, which makes Sunbeam and Oster appliances, has recently maintained that it was not for sale. Japonica has said it may raise its bid for the company, which has spent nearly two years trying to reorganize under Federal bankruptcy laws. Separately, a group led by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs has sold all but a small fraction of its 6.5 percent Allegheny stake, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Officials Investigating Drug's Role in Illness
description: Federal health officials are investigating at least 243 possible cases of a mysterious flu-like illness that appears to be linked to a non-prescription drug, L-tryptophan, and the officials said the number of cases is expected to rise substantially.

title: Kimmins Environmental ServFice Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Kimmins Environmental said its 1989 results included the operations of Kimmins Corp. and K Management Corp., which were merged into Kimmins Environmental in November 1988.

title: Connecticut Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1,269,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: Jackson And the Democrats
description: Is Jesse Jackson, as he claims, entitled to a share of the credit for the recent election victories of David Dinkins in New York and Douglas Wilder in Virginia?

title: Oak Hill Sportswear reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pilgrim's Pride Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $9,580,000, or 42 cents a share, from an effective change in accounting, adoption of FASB 96.

title: Unico American reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Spritz of Perfume Costs $75,000 at Bloomingdale's
description: Whether a long spritz, a short spritz or a steady spritz, the court papers do not say. No one is even suggesting that it was a malicious spritz. And the spritzer is still at large.

title: Sydney Drazen, 76, Galleries Partner, Dies
description: Sydney Drazen, a former president of Tepper Galleries, an auctioneering and appraising concern in Manhattan, died of pneumonia Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 76 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: INSIDE
description: House Votes for a Raise A bill that would tighten House ethics rules while increasing salaries by more than a third was approved on a vote of 252 to 174. Page B5. Arab Gets Israeli's Heart The family of an Israeli soldier slain in the Gaza Strip agreed to donate his heart to save the life of a 54-year-old Palestinian. Page A8. Inquiry on Flu-Type Illness Health officials are investigating at least 243 cases of a mysterious illness that appears to be linked to a non-prescription drug. Page A26. Legislation on Puerto Rico A bill allowing Puerto Rico to decide if it is to be a state, become independent or remain a commonwealth is gaining momentum. Page A24. New Push Against Noriega The Bush Administration is planning another effort to oust Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Page A3. Church Punishes Legislator A California lawmaker has been barred from receiving communion in the Roman Catholic Church because she backs abortion rights. Page A18. Pretoria Integration Step President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa ordered the country's beaches opened to all races. Page A3.

title: German Labor + German Capital
description: East and West Germany may be heading toward closer relations, if not unification. But the fears, and hopes, that such political arrangements would generate are wholly speculative. What's at hand right now is the need to make difficult economic arrangements.

title: Black Driver Aiming for Indy 500
description: The Raynor racing team, which competes on the Championship Auto Racing Teams Indy-car circuit, announced in Manhattan yesterday that it had hired Willy T. Ribbs as its driver in a three-year deal that includes Bill Cosby as a backer. If Ribbs qualifies for the Indianapolis 500 next May, he will become the first black driver to compete in this country's most famous auto race.

title: Review/Art; Franz Kline's Lost Murals, Steps in a Painter's Progress
description: In these days of rising prices and diminishing dissertation topics, the discovery of obscure early works by a great artist can be an especially welcome event. It can also be an exaggerated one. At first glance, ''Franz Kline: Lost Murals,'' now on view at the Baruch College Gallery, falls into the exaggerated category - and perhaps at last glance, too.

title: Keithley Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Integon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflected a $4.4 million pre-tax loss as a result of hurricane Hugo, and realized investment losses of $3.2 million due to increase in reserves for mortgage and real estate losses. c-Net income

title: Review/Theater; 'Gypsy' Is Back on Broadway With a Vengeance
description: If someone asked me to name the best Broadway musical, I'd gladly equivocate on any side of a debate embracing ''Guys and Dolls,'' ''My Fair Lady,'' ''Carousel,'' ''Porgy and Bess'' and - well, you know the rest. But I've always had only one choice in the category of favorite musical. It is ''Gypsy,'' and as I sat at its scorching new revival starring Tyne Daly, once again swept up in its goosebump-raising torrents of laughter and tears,

title: A Queens Board Votes to Honor A Slain Officer
description: A Queens community board has reversed itself and voted to name a Jamaica street for Edward Byrne, the rookie police officer murdered by drug dealers while guarding a witness in South Jamaica last year.

title: Police Capture One of Three Fugitives From a Jail in L.I.
description: One of three inmates who escaped from the Nassau County jail Tuesday morning was recaptured last night in North Bellmore, L.I., the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Six Jesuit priests in San Salvador were killed by what one witness described as a group of 30 men dressed in military uniforms. Page A1

title: Accounting Panel May Alter Ruling on Public Institutions
description: Trustees of the Financial Accounting Foundation indicated a willingness yesterday to abandon a decision requiring government-owned colleges, hospitals and utilities to obey the same standard-setting group as the private sector.

title: U.S. Is Amiable Outsider to European Talks
description: Although it will have no representative at a meeting of the Western European allies this weekend, the Bush Administration plans to follow the talks through diplomatic channels and direct contacts with European leaders, American officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shuffle at Foote, Cone
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications shuffled the executive lineup in its international division yesterday. Craig R. Wiggins, vice chairman of Publicis-FCB Communications, Foote, Cone's joint venture with the French agency Publicis, was named chairman of FCB International. Antonio S. Beja, chairman of FCB Latin America-Pacific, will become president of the international division and vice chairman of Publicis-FCB.

title: Norstan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Paddling The Lords Of Baseball
description: They got the wrong guy, but otherwise it was refreshing to see baseball publicly spanked this week for taking baseball off free television and giving it to the barons of cable television.

title: Lomas Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; Altered TW Deal Angers Holders
description: IF a customer buys a box of corn flakes and finds less than the label promised, a refund can be expected and obtained. But on Wall Street, things are not so easy, and some buyers of new shares in TW Holdings Inc. are furious.

title: International Proteins Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
I Fear What Lies Beyond the Wall
description: LEAD: Like most people who abhor imposed separation and oppression, I am happy for the citizens of East Berlin. And for those of West Berlin. Watching on television the tens of thousands of young Germans celebrate freedom was a moving and rewarding experience. Whenever and wherever liberty is victorious, people everywhere ought to rejoice.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Nov. 7 about Vivian Mercier, an Irish literary critic and teacher, misidentified an American institution where he taught. It was the City University of New York, not New York University.

title: Illicit Pay in Wide Use, Study Contends
description: Nearly a third of the nation's present and former professional football players responding to a survey said they accepted illicit payments while in college and more than half said they see nothing wrong with the practice.

title: For Many in the Law, One Career Is Not Enough
description: The British are accustomed to seeing their lawyers excel in other occupations. James Boswell, who practiced criminal law, chronicled the life of Samuel Johnson. More recently, John Mortimer, formerly Queen's Counsel and eminent senior public service lawyer, has created plays and novels, including ''Rumpole of the Bailey,'' which later led to writing the scripts for the television series.

title: Campbell Posts 20% Earnings Rise
description: The Campbell Soup Company yesterday reported record first-quarter earnings of $83 million, or 64 cents a share, a sharp contrast to its fiscal 1989 full-year earnings, which were hurt by large restructuring costs.

title: Sony and Warner Settle Suit Over Producers
description: The movie producers John Peters and Peter Guber have a glittering string of box-office triumphs to their credit, like ''Batman'' and ''Rainman.'' And the Sony Corporation is betting that the dynamic duo of filmmaking can generate a stream of similar hits in the future, given the size of the investment the Japanese company made yesterday to bring them to its newly acquired Columbia Pictures Studio.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bucks 132, Magic 113: Milwaukee tied a National Basketball Association record last night with 50 points in one quarter and, led by Ricky Pierce's 28 points, routed Orlando in Milwaukee. The 50 points came in the first quarter. Milwaukee made 21 of its 24 field-goal attempts, including 3 for 3 from 3-point range. The Bucks matched the single-quarter point record set by Syracuse in 1962 and tied by Boston and Utah in 1982.(AP) Rockets 94, Clippers 82: Otis Thorpe had 27 points and 10 rebounds for Houston. Akeem Olajuwon had 18 points and 16 rebounds. In his first game since coming off the injured list, Mike Woodson scored 16 points. The game was played in Houston.(AP) SuperSonics 111, Bullets 98: A rookie, Dana Barros, scored 7 of his season-high 25 points in a 17-2 spurt in the third quarter for Seattle, where the game was played. Washington, playing its fourth game in five nights, led, 68-67, with 6:42 left in the third period before the 5-foot-10-inch Barros and Shawn Kemp, a 6-10 rookie, rallied Seattle to an 84-70 margin.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins 8, Nordiques 2: John Cullen had two goals and two assists and Kevin Stevens one goal and three assists for Pittsburgh in a home game last night. Pittsburgh scored four times in a seven-minute span of the second period. Cullen started the outburst with a power-play goal. Mario Lemieux extended his point-scoring streak to eight games.(AP) Bruins 3, Canadiens 2: Ray Bourque, Cam Neely and Glen Wesley scored goals 57 seconds apart late in the third period as Boston rallied. Patrick Roy appeared on his way to his 11th National Hockey League shutout with 35 saves and a 2-0 lead when the Bruins, playing in Boston, erupted. They outshot the Canadiens, 38-21.(AP) Blues 7, Red Wings 2: Paul MacLean and Paul Cavallini scored two goals each in a four-goal second period in Detroit. St. Louis capitalized on four of six power-play chances. Cavallini got his first two goals of the season while the Blues held a man advantage. The goalie Greg Stefan, who replaced the injured starter, Glen Hanlon, 12:20 into the opening period, surrendered five goals on the first seven shots he faced.(AP) Flyers 6, North Stars 3: Pelle Eklund scored twice and Mike Bullard had one goal and assisted on three others as Philadelphia won at home. Minnesota's Mike Modano had tied the score, 3-3, at 8:09 of the second period when he tapped Mike Gartner's shot over the glove of the goalie, Bruce Hoffort. But Eklund soon put the Flyers in front, 4-3, when he took a pass from Bullard and flipped a backhander over the sprawled goalie, Kari Takko. (AP) Flames 4, Sabres 4: Playing in Calgary, Doug Gilmour scored with just 22 seconds left in the game to earn the Flames a tie. Gilmour put the puck behind the Buffalo goalie, Daren Puppa, after picking up a rebound off the goalpost. Buffalo had fought its way back from a 3-1 deficit early in the second period. Calgary put early pressure on Puppa, but the goalie foiled several good scoring opportunities and kept Buffalo alive with key saves throughout the game.(AP) HORSE RACING Weather Closes Aqueduct: Because of bad weather, yesterday's races at Aqueduct were canceled. The track is expected to reopen today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pitney Job for Deutsch
description: Pitney Bowes Inc. sweetened its relationship with Deutsch yesterday, awarding the agency its facsimile machine and copier accounts. Donny Deutsch, the agency's creative director, said the accounts were worth a total of $4 million and raised Pitney's billings with Deutsch to $7 million. The agency also handles the company's Dictaphone account.

title: Dow Rises 3.08 Points, To 2,635.66
description: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.08 points, to 2,635.66.

title: Treasury Issues Stage a Retreat
description: Prices of Treasury securities gave ground in spotty trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits and awaited further developments that might allow the Federal Reserve Board to ease interest rates.

title: Glaxo in Singapore
description: Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. said it would invest up to $250 million (Singapore) to build a pharmaceutical plant in the country. The plant, to be completed by the end of 1991, is expected to begin producing three new drugs in 1992, said Sir Paul Girolami, Glaxo's chairman. Those drugs are sumatriptan, for treating migraine headaches; salmeterol, an asthma drug, and ondansetron, for reducing nausea during cancer treatments.

title: LaFontaine Helps Islanders End Drought
description: The Islanders ended a bleak string of defeats tonight by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-2, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Elsinore Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After provisions for losses of unconsolidated subsidiary of $429,000 and $9,191,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Included gains of $28,757,000, or $2.85 a share, on sale of Hyatt Lake Tahoe and loss of $3,362,000 on extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included a loss of unconsolidated subsidiary of $6,700,000. The company said the 1989 results do not include the operations of Hyatt Lake Tahoe Hotel and Casino, which was effectively sold July 31, 1988.

title: Market Overhaul Bill Gains
description: The Senate Banking Committee today approved a market overhaul package that requires the Securities and Exchange Commission to study whether program trading can be used to manipulate the securities markets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Bongrain International Corp., a subsidiary of Bongrain S.A., to Kirshenbaum & Bond, for its line of Alouette cheeses, with a $1.5 million budget.

title: Moldavian Party Leader Is Ousted After Clashes
description: The Communist Party leader in the Moldavian Soviet Republic, Semyon K. Grossu, was dismissed today after clashes over the weekend between police and nationalist demonstrators in which 200 people were wounded.

title: VMS Hotel Investment Fund reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Our Towns; When Patronage Is King, Contracts Are for the Loyal
description: Seventy-seven-year-old George Van Pelt, a retired industrial worker, was aware that the Mayor, Nicholas J. Cicco, had been indicted and convicted on several counts of bribery, but he voted for him anyway for a second term.

title: New Ford Plants
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would spend $300 million to build three large electronics plants to keep pace with worldwide demand for its advanced automotive components. The company said sales of its electronics division had doubled since 1985 and were expected to do so again by 1997. the first new plant, in Worcester Township, Pa., will be started early next year. It will make electronic engine control devices, anti-lock brake modules and sensors. The other plants will be in Cadiz, Spain, and near Lisbon, Portugal.

title: Hotels Seized in Savings Case
description: More than 60 Federal agents and Phoenix police officers seized control of two luxury hotels that had been crown jewels in the empire of Charles H. Keating Jr., the deposed head of Lincoln Savings and Loan. Page B5.

title: When Jets Meet Colts, Someone Has to Win
description: If ever a game figured to have one team as the perfect foil to snap an opponent out of its misery, it is Sunday night's Jets-Colts affair.

title: Sears Goes to Canada To Fill Retail Post
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, turned again to its Canadian subsidiary yesterday and chose Laurence E. Cudmore, the chairman and chief executive, for the new post of president of retail of the Sears Merchandising Group.

title:
DIALOGUE ON CHANGING SOVIET FORCES - IS MOSCOW CUTTING ITS MILITARY?;
No, It's Building Up
description: LEAD: Under the onslaught of Mikhail Gorbachev's ''peace offensive,''

title: Hungary Asks to Join Group
description: Hungary became the first country in the Warsaw Pact to seek membership in a Western political organization today when it applied to join the 23-nation Council of Europe.

title: Falcons' Quarterback Getting High Marks
description: The Atlanta Falcons have a cornerback, Deion Sanders, whose loose lips are infuriating some of his teammates, a head coach, Marion Campbell, who heard screams for his dismissal this week, and a 3-7 record. There is little hope among the Falcons that they can finish any place but last, once again, in the National Conference West Division.

title: House Approves an Aid Package for Poland
description: One day after hearing the Solidarity founder Lech Walesa appeal for economic aid, the House of Representatives today approved a three-year aid plan authorizing $846.5 million for Poland.

title: 3 Grade I Races on Aqueduct Weekend Card
description: High winds and a tornado watch scratched yesterday's racing at Aqueduct, but the track will reopen today and present its final Grade I races of the year this weekend.

title: Charter Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $2,004,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $8,065,000, or 17 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $45,021,000, or 96 cents a share, and $48,770,000, or $1.03 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $77,000 for the quarter and $7,192,000, or 15 cents a share, for the 9 months. d-Favorable foreign tax settlement increased earnings from continuing operations by $7 million and net earnings by $10.7 million. The company said the latest 9-month income of $14,208,000 (before the extraordianry credit) reflects utilization of tax loss carryforwards.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: U.S. Plans New Effort to Oust Noriega
description: The Bush Administration, with the approval of Congressional oversight panels, is planning another attempt to unseat Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Administration officials said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 478 money market mutual funds decreased by $200.80 million, to $363.61 billion, for the week ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 146 institutional funds increased by $166.60 million, to $87.43 billion. The assets of the 235 general-purpose funds were down by $354.30 million, to $118.79 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased by $13.10 million, to $157.39 billion, the institute said.

title: Cuomo Seizing the Moment To Bring Lincoln to the Poles
description: Somehow ''four score and seven years ago'' does not have quite the same ring in Polish. But the message of liberty and equality is presumably the same in any language. So when Lech Walesa is in New York City on Friday, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo plans to hand him a bust of Abraham Lincoln and the pledge of a Polish translation of Lincoln's writings on democracy.

title: Williams-Sonoma reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Standard Oil & Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Soviets to Liberalize Emigration, Hoping to Gain U.S. Trade Deal
description: Soviet officials here and in Moscow promised today that Soviet emigration laws would soon be revised to permit freer emigration from the Soviet Union. In return, they asked that the United States lift trade barriers against Soviet exports.

title: Prime Motor Inns
description: Prime Motor Inns L.P. said it planned a special distribution of $2 a unit in a conversion of the limited partnership to an open-ended real estate investment trust that had been proposed by the Prime American Realty Corporation, the group's general partner. If the proposal is approved by unit holders, they will receive, in a taxable exchange, one share of Prime Hotel Real Estate Investments Inc., a new real estate investment trust, for each unit held.

title: Fabri-Centers of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Reserves Up At AmSouth
description: The AmSouth Bancorporation, the largest banking company in Alabama, announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be sharply reduced by a special $21 million increase in its reserves to cover possible loan losses on Florida real estate loans.

title: Congress Plans to Put Off Action On Child Care Because of Impasse
description: Several members of Congress said today that they would abandon further work on a landmark child care bill this year because of deep differences over the scope of the legislation and how to pay for it.

title: Legislator Barred From Communion
description: A California State Assemblywoman has been barred from receiving communion in the Roman Catholic Church because of her support for abortion rights in her campaign for the State Senate.

title: 6 PRIESTS KILLED IN A CAMPUS RAID IN SAN SALVADOR
description: Six Jesuit priests, including the rector of a leading university, were killed here before dawn today by what one witness described as a group of 30 men dressed in military uniforms.

title: Reagan Subpoena Ordered in Poindexter Case
description: A Federal district judge today approved a subpoena requiring former President Ronald Reagan to turn over private records and provide testimony in the trial of John M. Poindexter, the former White House national security adviser, in connection with the Iran-contra affair.

title: Throng Mourns La Pasionaria, A War Legend
description: Thousands of mourners filled the center of Madrid today to bid their last farewell to Dolores Ibarruri, known as La Pasionaria, the legendary Spanish Civil War heroine who died of pneumonia on Sunday at 93 years of age.

title: Program Trading Declines
description: Following a historical pattern, the percentage of program trading on the New York Stock Exchange fell in October from the previous month, the Big Board said yesterday.

title: Review/Film; A Girl, a Reindeer and the Christmas Spirit
description: During the school Christmas pageant at the start of ''Prancer,'' the prop boy in charge of sifting fake snow onto the Nativity scene makes a slip and dumps great masses of powdery white stuff on the small wise men. It's amusing, a bit too cute, and the perfect metaphor for John Hancock's mediocre film. ''Prancer'' tries so hard to scatter magic Christmas dust over the ordinary lives of a small farm community that it ends up shoveling it on; even the silver sprinkles on Christmas cookies glitter in the moonlight. ''Prancer'' is thoughtful, sincere and so laborious that adults can see the gears churning out Capraesque themes. For children, that creaky overload may translate into a mild case of the fidgets.

title: Giants Sign Bass For $5.25 Million
description: Kevin Bass became the first of baseball's 90 free agents to be signed as he agreed yesterday to a three-year contract with the San Francisco Giants for $5.25 million.

title: In a Hospital Emergency Room, 'A Lot of Crying and Crying'
description: By 4 P.M., the large white emergency room at St. Luke's Hospital here was filled with hysterical parents, frantic physicians, clergy and seven counselors from the Orange County Department of Mental Health.

title: International Game TechFnology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $261,000, or 3 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $817,000 for the quarter and $971,000 for the year; the year was also after a gain of $1,650,000, or 29 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. The discontinued operations' figures were related to International Game's Electronic Data Technologies subsidiary's discontinuance and sale of a foreign unit. During the latest quarter, International Game Technology recognized a gain of about $10 million on the sale of 1,140,000 shares of its Electronic Data Technologies subsidiary. The gain was offset by recognition of a $10.2 million reserve related to the company's note receivable and investment in Syntech International Inc.

title: Vermont Journal; The Fire For Wood As Fuel Is Cooling
description: There is a closet in John Illick's house where a wood stove used to be. For seven years, he and his wife, Beth, burned wood for primary heat in the long winters here, for economic and esthetic reasons. But the appeal began to wear thin. ''Wood is dirty and it's a lot of work,'' said Mr. Illick, who is a vice president at the Bread Loaf Construction Company. ''I got sick of vacuuming up the dirt and dust and bugs all the time! You end up jamming your fingers in the stove while you're loading it and swearing a lot. My daughter, Adrienne, tripped and burned her face on it.''

title: New-Music Festival; Farafina in the Sounds and Rhythms of African Tradition
description: Bare-bones melodies, layered repetition and propulsive cross-rhythm -the stuff of Minimalist music - have a long history in African tradition. So it was perfectly appropriate for the New Music America festival, founded 10 years ago by Minimalist and other composers, to book Farafina. The eight-man group from Burkina Faso would humble any Minimalist ensemble in a battle of the bands, even without its flamboyant dancing. Using drums, balafons (African marimbas with gourd resonators), voices, a gourd rattle and sometimes a wooden flute - a lineup not too different from Steve Reich's ''Drumming'' ensemble - Farafina played a spectacular set on Wednesday night at the World, piling up riffs and syncopations with ecstatic precision.

title: Restaurants
description: Just when everyone thought the Cajun craze had been interred in that gastronomic Woodlawn where all such fads return to dust, here comes Paul Prudhomme, bounding out of the bayou with his magic spices and magnetic personality. Suddenly, New Yorkers by the score were lined up outside his Broadway restaurant in punishing midsummer heat waiting to be made even hotter by gumbo and jambalaya.

title: Mestek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Final Fling on Nutcracker's Eve
description: THIS is the weekend before ''The Nutcracker'' arrives, like a fond but overwhelming aunt whose visit means that all else must be dropped or put aside. As if to celebrate those last free moments before the holiday classic gathers audiences up into its cheerful bosom, dance companies and soloists are presenting a wide-ranging variety of work in theaters around New York City tonight through Sunday.

title: Jerome J. Ossip, 69; Owned a Steak House
description: Jerome J. Ossip, a restaurateur, died of colon cancer Wednesday at his home in Harrison, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Pratt Hotel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $640,000 due to costs related to early redemption of unsecured notes.

title: A Crash in Westchester Kills Two Near Airport
description: Two people were killed and a third person was critically injured in the crash of a small plane in fog, rain and high winds near Westchester County Airport late Wednesday, officials said. The survivor was found in the wreckage seven hours after the crash.

title: Korea's Trade Surplus Is Criticized
description: The Bush Administration today increased pressure on South Korea to reduce its large trade surplus, warning of possible trade sanctions unless it acted quickly to liberalize its currency and financial markets.

title: On Stage
description: A Will Rogers Musical . . .

title: House Votes to Raise Members' Pay and Ban Fees for Speaking
description: After a year of scandal and internal turmoil, the House of Representatives voted today to raise its members' salaries, tighten its ethics rules and sharply reduce the members' dependence on outside income.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Holly Near

title: Texas Air In 40-Plane Airbus Order
description: The Texas Air Corporation, placing its largest order ever for its Continental Airlines subsidiary, said yesterday that it had ordered 40 aircraft worth about $4.5 billion from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium.

title: St. John's Repels North Carolina A. & T.
description: Sporting new uniforms, its traditional man-to man defense and a seldom-used weapon, the 3-point shot, St. John's held off a late rally by North Carolina A. & T. last night and won a first-round game in the Dodge National Invitation Tournament, 64-57, at Alumni Hall.

title: Schwitzer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: Year-ago third quarter, latest and year-ago 9-month results are presented on a pro forma basis as the company went public in April.

title: U.S. Cellular Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is an 81.8 percent- owned subsidiary of Telephone & Data Systems Inc.

title: Allegre May Be Sidelined With Strained Leg Muscle
description: Raul Allegre, the Giants' kicker, has strained a muscle in his right thigh, his kicking leg, and may miss Sunday's game here against the Seattle Seahawks. Coach Bill Parcells indicated today that Sunday's kicker might be Allegre, Bjorn Nittmo or a hero from the Giants' past, Ali Haji-Sheikh, or a combination of Allegre and Nittmo.

title: The Government Seeks to Stop the Decline In Industry Before It Leads to a Rebellion
description: Czechoslovakia is like a young man who inherits a fortune from his grandfather and fritters it away, dissipating the capital instead of investing it wisely. Two generations ago, at the time of World War I, this was a rich country, with two-thirds of the industrial capacity of the entire Austro-Hungarian Empire concentrated in Bohemia and Moravia, which make up the western two-thirds of Czechoslovakia. The Skoda armaments works and the Bata shoe factories were world famous.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Ed Des Lauriers has been promoted to senior vice president of Campbell-Mithun-Esty.

title: KILLING OF PRIESTS DENOUNCED BY U.S.
description: The Bush Administration today condemned the killing of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador and said it had asked President Alfredo Cristiani to order a full inquiry.

title: Scitex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest and 9-month figures included an unrealized loss of $4,015,000 on its holding of 4,425,000 shares in de la Rue PLC.

title: Luxury Hotels Seized in Predawn Raid in Arizona
description: In the early-morning hours today, more than 60 Federal agents and plainclothes Phoenix police officers descended on two luxury hotels that had been crown jewels in the financial empire of Charles H. Keating Jr. They seized control of the hotels, sealed off Mr. Keating's office and announced that he was being discharged as president of the hotel company.

title: Woodhead Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Wednesday and a related article about Chancellor Helmut Kohl's visit to Auschwitz misidentified Poland's chief rabbi. He is Pinchas Menachem Joskowicz.

title: I.B.M. Admits U.S. Contract Violations
description: For the first time, the International Business Machines Corporation publicly acknowledged wrongdoing today in its handling of Government contracts.

title: Morgan Keegan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
At Budget Hotels, Growing Pains
description: Judging by the jammed parking lot at the Fairfield Inn here, one might think that the budget hotel business is flourishing. But now, with more than 50 such chains in business, the supply of inexpensive rooms is beginning to outstrip even the surging demand for them, and occupancy levels and profits are sliding.

title: Francis Speight, Artist, 93
description: Francis Speight, a landscape artist, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Greenville, N.C. He was 93 years old.

title: Review/Art; Old Masters on a Visit From Fort Worth
description: When Kay Kimbell died 25 years ago, he left his family's collection of European and American paintings, jades and ivories to the city of Fort Worth, where he had settled in 1924 and presided over some 70 corporations. Like the archetypal self-made Texas millionaire, Kimbell only thought big. He said his desire was to create a museum ''of the first class,'' filled with great works of art and housed in a great building. The plan echoed dreams of countless benefactors.

title: Re-evaluation Is Urged on Cutting High-Tech Aid
description: Officials in the White House who favor a Government pullback from financing advanced military research and development programs with commercial applications may need to re-evaluate their position because of the needs of high-technology industries and the political climate, a number of economists and legislators said today.

title: Paramount Pictures Buys 49% of British TV Producer
description: Paramount Pictures said today that it had acquired 49 percent of one of Britain's leading television production companies in a deal that reflects the growing importance of foreign markets to the American entertainment industry.

title: Libel Accord in Pittsburgh
description: An insurance company has reimbursed The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette $2 million of what the paper said was the largest libel judgment ever paid by a newspaper, leaving the paper's publishing company to absorb $270,000 of the judgment.

title: Together, We Can Control Medical Technology; Why They Don't Stop
description: To the Editor:

title: Rivals by Land, by Sea and by Air
description: You have to get up pretty early in the morning to play football on Nantucket, an island 30 miles off the south coast of Cape Cod.

title: 6,000 Officers Mourn Death Of a Detective
description: Standing seven-deep in a line that stretched for three blocks, more than 6,000 police officers today mourned one of the two New York City detectives who were shot to death by a prisoner on Monday in Queens.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Washington at Work; In Quest of a Post-Cold War Plan
description: Dennis Ross, the director of policy planning for the State Department, was musing the other day about the difficulties of doing any kind of advanced strategic planning for the Secretary of State at time when so many things are changing so fast.

title: Slater Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary crdit of $3,970,000, or 49 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: KEY RATES
Administration Gives Momentum To a Vote on Puerto Rico's Status
description: The Bush Administration gave momentum this week to a Senate bill that would give Puerto Rico the right to decide if it is to be the 51st state, an independent country or remain a commonwealth, but with greater control over its own affairs.

title: Environmental Control Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge due to replacement of a credit agreement of $360,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * A new print and television campaign for the National Easter Seal Society portrays disabled people as having the same hopes and aspirations as other citizens. The campaign, created by Campbell-Mithun-Esty, will begin next month.

title: Pettibone Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; P.&G. Donation To Ad Council
description: The chairman of the Proctor & Gamble Company said yesterday that the company would donate $500,000 to the Advertising Council to start a public service advertising campaign for educational reform.

title: National Arts Chief, In a Reversal, Gives Grant to AIDS Show
description: The new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, under heavy criticism from artists and arts leaders, reversed himself yesterday and agreed to restore a $10,000 grant to a New York gallery for an art exhibition about AIDS.

title: Death Toll at 18 in Alabama Tornado
description: This northern Alabama city was digging out today from debris left by a tornado that sliced a path a quarter-mile wide and nearly 25 miles long through a residential and commercial area on Wednesday, killing 18 people.

title: Navratilova Outlasts A Persistent Seles
description: It was a match that evolved into an ordeal, as the embattled Martina Navratilova, who at this stage of her career finds herself fighting off opponents half her age, held fast against an uninhibited challenge from Monica Seles.

title: Actions
description: The artworks auctioned in a 12-day marathon of bidding that ends tomorrow has kept minds reeling with images of paintings and the prices they have realized. Throughout these sales, the artist spoken of most often was Pablo Picasso, whose paintings of the rose period and much later brought some of the highest bids.

title: Temco National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sounds Around Town
description: 1,000 Bands, Sort Of

title: Change at Los Angeles Times
description: The Los Angeles Times has named Thomas G. Plate, the editor of the editorial pages of New York Newsday, to the same position at The Times. He replaces Anthony Day, who had held the post since 1971.

title: Tarpley Is Suspended
description: Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks forward with two strikes against him in the eyes of the National Basketball Association for alcohol and drug problems, was suspended from the league indefinitely yesterday by counselors in his after-care program. The ban came one day after he was arrested in Dallas on charges of driving while intoxicated and resisting arrest.

title: Chrysler Ends Maserati Venture
description: The Chrysler Corporation confirmed today that it would end its troubled venture with the Maserati subsidiary of DeTomaso Industries S.p.A. of Italy. Maserati has been building a two-seater luxury car, Chrysler's TC, that has had disappointing sales in the United States.

title: Soviet Agency to Launch Satellites for U.S. Company
description: An American company has announced the signing of a contract for the launching of as many as eight satellites by the civilian space agency of the Soviet Union. It is the first such contract to be publicly disclosed.

title: Review/Art; At Whitney, a Look Back At Thomas Hart Benton
description: Thomas Hart Benton (1889-1975) is one of the more formidable personalities in American art. He was born in Neosho, Mo., near the Oklahoma and Arkansas borders, and named after his great-uncle, the first Senator from Missouri. His father, Maecenas Eason Benton, originally from Tennessee, was a highly successful lawyer and a populist politician who served four terms in Congress and, according to his son, had ''something like a puritan aversion to images.''

title: Pop/Jazz; Rap Leads to Respectability and Academia for KRS-One
description: Kris Parker's rise from homelessness to stardom, and from stardom to academic respectability, took a mere three years.
