In 1986, the rapper, who uses the name KRS-One professionally and heads the combination performing group and production company known as Boogie Down Productions, was living on the streets of New York. Tonight and tomorrow night, Boogie Down Productions is headlining a show at the Apollo Theater that also includes E.P.M.D. and Redhead and Kingpin. Next month, Mr. Parker will lecture at both Harvard and Yale.

title: Shifts at Boston Concern
description: The New England, an insurance and investment company, said that Robert A. Shafto, president of insurance and personal financial services, had been elected president and chief operating officer. Edward E. Phillips, chairman and chief executive of the Boston-based concern, said Wednesday that Ralph F. Verni had been named president and chief executive of New England Investment Companies Inc., a holding company for the investment subsidiaries. It was also announced that John A. Fibiger, president, chief operating officer and vice chairman, will take early retirement at the end of the year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Gourmet Video
description: Gourmet magazine has chosen London as the subject of a new 15-minute promotional videotape. The video, which is aimed at advertisiers, focuses on pubs, restaurants and cigar shops, restaurants and cigar shops. Richard Barthelmes, Gourmet's publisher, said themagazine had selected London ''because we wanted to show the depth and breadth of Gourmet's coverage,'' Mariel Hemingway and Jerry Della Femina are among those who promote Gourmet in the video. The tape is unusual in that it also features and erstwhile competitor, Peter Diamandis, the head of Diamandis Communications, praising Gourmet.

title: Quake-Struck Cities Celebrate Rejoining
description: They came on foot, in strollers and on roller skates. They wore straw boaters, baseball caps and, in a nod to gallows humor, life preservers. They carried American flags; they carried flowers; they carried brunch.

title: Walesa And Shamir
description: Lech Walesa brought such pleasure, shared such a sense of pride in a nation's achievement, that it was almost impossible to find room in the mind or heart for anything else -even another piece of history being acted out in the city.

title: Thailand Bans Asian Journal
description: The police said today that they were banning local distribution of The Asian Wall Street Journal because of an article that they said had insulted the leader of Thailand's predominant Buddhist faith.

title: Yes, By Necessity
description: State Department analysts have concluded that Soviet military spending will decline in 1989, to between 14 and 16 percent of gross national product, down from 15 to 17 percent in 1988. While this conclusion is disputed by others in the Government, the evidence is overwhelming.

title: Who Runs P.S. 262?
description: Gloria Simmons, assistant principal of a Brooklyn elementary school, continues to defy her superiors for the sake of a dispute over school authority. If she cared about schoolchildren, education or community peace, she would obey orders and accept a transfer.

title: Annual Christmas Fair At St. Luke's School
description: A Christmas fair - complete with a festive dinner - is to be offered today at St. Luke's School, 487 Hudson Street. The fair, which continues through tomorrow, features a variety of crafts, workshops, entertainment and foods. Hours for the fair alone are 5 to 10 P.M. today, and noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Millen Back on Ice
description: Corey Millen, the former United States Olympian and current rookie center for the Rangers, skated again yesterday with the team and could return to action within 10 days. Millen, who injured his left knee in a preseason collision with Bryan Trottier of the Islanders, will probably report to the organization's minor league affiliate in Flint, Mich., next week.

title: MMR Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $550,000, or 10 cents a share, resulting from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes. Revenue represented contract revenue.

title: Trade Gap Is Lowest In 5 Years
description: The nation's trade deficit dropped sharply in September to $7.94 billion, its lowest level since late 1984, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: An Outsider Is Named As Volvo's President
description: Pehr Gyllenhammar, who has repeatedly surprised the Swedish business establishment in his 18 years as the head of A.B. Volvo, did it again yesterday: He paired the announcement of disappointing third-quarter earnings with the news that Christer Zetterberg, the chairman of a state-owned bank, will become Volvo's president and chief operating officer in May and will eventually become chairman and chief executive.

title: Reviews/Film; An Australian Tale of Sex And the Power It Confers
description: On the sunny, manicured playing fields of an exclusive Australian boys' school, an arrangement is being made. It is ratified by secret, almost imperceptible nods from a couple of older men, and it involves an exceptionally handsome golden-blond student who sits basking in his white athletic uniform. Soon thereafter, this young man (Mark Lee) will be excused from his classes and called for by a chauffeur-driven Rolls-Royce. He will be driven to his assignations with its owner, a prominent politician (Arthur Dignam) who is dapper, worldly and, above all else, discreet.

title: B.A.T. Suitor Clarifies Bid
description: Sir James Goldsmith said today that he was providing American regulatory authorities with details about a possible revised takeover bid for the British conglomerate B.A.T Industries.

title: The Six Salvadoran Priests Slain by Uniformed Gunmen
description: Ignacio Ellacuria Beas Coechea

title: Giants Will Try to Prove Last Week Was a Fluke
description: The Giants say they have forgotten last Sunday's embarrassing 31-10 loss to the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Kohl Says Bonn Will Not Press East Germany on Reunification
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl presented today what has evolved into a broad West German consensus on how to approach the new developments in East Germany, declaring that Bonn would not try to influence the East Germans on reunification and would respect whatever path they chose.

title: Heart of Israeli Soldier, Slain By Arabs, Is Donated to Arab
description: The family of an Israeli soldier shot in the head by a Palestinian gunman agreed today to donate the dead man's heart to another Palestinian, a 54-year-old from East Jerusalem.

title: Evans Making a Quick Exit From Supercomputer Field
description: A promising newcomer in the supercomputer business has decided to drop out only four months after introducing its first machine. The decision raises further questions about the ability of American companies to compete in the risky, costly industry.

title: Old Standby, the Corner Bar, Falling Victim to New Values
description: New attitudes about drinking and concerns about liability are leading to dramatic changes in the character of bars across America.

title: British Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. Results are in U.S. dollars; results reported in pounds sterling have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.61 to the pound, the rate prevailing on Sept. 30, 1989, the last date of the reporting period for both the periods for 1989 and 1988.

title: Bush Gives Arts Medals to 12, but Not to Bernstein
description: President Bush presented the National Medal of Arts to 12 artists and arts patrons today in a ceremony marked by the absence of Leonard Bernstein.

title: Dinkins to Play Tennis At Puerto Rican Resort
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins is still searching for talent to fill his administration, but his office announced yesterday that he had ended another search: he will leave tomorrow morning for an eight-day vacation at a resort in Puerto Rico.

title: NEW TIES TO BONN SOUGHT BY PREMIER OF EAST GERMANY
description: Announcing a sweeping program of economic and political change, East Germany's new Prime Minister today held out the prospect of relations ''on a new level'' with West Germany.

title: Mrs. Dinkins Sees Her Crosstown Home
description: Joyce B. Dinkins, who has lived for the last 26 years in a three-bedroom apartment in upper Manhattan, inspected the quarters she is about to inhabit and announced yesterday that Gracie Mansion suited her just fine.

title: Dr. Eric Blackall, 75, Cornell Ex-Professor
description: Dr. Eric A. Blackall, professor emeritus of German literature at Cornell University, died of cardiopulmonary arrest Thursday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Storage Equities reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $435,500 for the latest 9 months and $317,400 for year-ago period, on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Amstar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $5,280,000.

title: Senate Panel Proposing Increase In Tribal Control of Federal Aid
description: Finishing a two-year investigation into corruption and mismanagement of American Indian land and money, a Senate panel today proposed that tribes be given the opportunity for greater control over Federal aid that officials in Washington now administer.

title: Delmed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $2,250,000 charge for the settlement of the company's patent infringement disputes with Baxter International Inc. and a $400,000 charge fpr related attorney's fees. c-After income of $15,000 for the quarter and a loss of $746,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and included in the quarter and 9 months is a $2,000,000 charge in settlement of litigation filed against the company and certain of its directors. The company said income from discontinued operations in the year-ago quarter was less than one cent a share.

title: Dell Computer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Article 883189 -- No Title
description: The General Electric Company, in an apparent effort to increase the price of its stock, announced yesterday that it would purchase up to $10 billion worth of its shares during the next five years. It is evidently the largest such repurchase program ever announced at one time.

title: Move to Stop Betting
description: The National Basketball Association has begun its attack on a move to add pro basketball to a state betting game in Oregon, and there were indications yesterday that the vehement, high-profile objections were being heard.

title: Frunze Journal; Off the List, Into a Lean-To: A Hammer Beckons
description: Amid the deepening gloom about national resurgence, thousands of ordinary Soviet citizens desperate for state housing have begun taking the solution into their own hands. They are seizing Government land and creating vast new urban squatter settlements, building everything from clay hovels to brick houses for their young families.

title: First American Health Conepts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Best Vehicle for Affordable Housing
description: Washington's tax law writers can point to one success: a three-year-old tax credit program to spur investment in low-income housing. But despite its success, it will expire in December. It deserves to be renewed.

title: Grounded Ship Leaks Oil Into Alaska Refuge
description: A Greek cargo ship ran aground Tuesday in a national wildlife refuge in Alaskan waters and is now leaking heavy oil there, the United States Coast Guard said today.

title: Touring the New York of 60 Years Ago in Pictures
description: Like a musician playing variations on a theme, Irving Browning ''played'' New York on his camera. The New York of 60 years ago that caught his eye lent itself to every mood, to every interpretation. He was a professional who did work for hire, and in his off hours he snapped photographs of New York for the sheer joy and art of it.

title: New Mexico & Arizona Land reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dow Up 17 Points, Led by G.E.'s Strength
description: Stock prices posted broad gains yesterday, aided by a rally in high-technology stocks and General Electric's announcement that it intends to buy back as much as $10 billion worth of its stock.

title: Di Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said comparing the current periods' share earnings losses against last year's share earnings is difficult because of the accounting treatment of Di's July acquisition of Holden Rig Co. from Penn Central Corp. in exchange for 70 percent of Di's shares. All figures have been restated, and Holden Rig's financials are included for last year.

title: Bridge
description: A Canadian partnership surged to victory in the Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Thursday. And the pair won in circumstances that are believed to be singular: they were in last place when the day began.

title: Temtex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income and the 9 months was after an extraordinary credit of $261,000, or 11 cents a share. The latest fourth quarter loss included a non-recurring relocation expense of $517,000.

title: Parish Guides Celtics Past the Timberwolves
description: Robert Parish scored 19 points and grabbed 10 rebounds in limited action tonight as the Boston Celtics extended their home unbeaten streak to five games with a 116-99 victory over the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Oshkosh Truck reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,725,000, or 19 cents a share. The latest periods included the motor-home chassis business acquired from Deere & Co. on Jan. 30, 1989.

title: The Suspects in El Salvador
description: Once again the abominable occurs in El Salvador, this time the execution-style murder of six Jesuit priests, their cook and her daughter. Once again a Salvadoran President denounces the crime and promises an investigation. And once again, the barbarous killers are likely to escape. What's different this time is America's horrified impatience. Unless President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador presses a fast, full and credible search for the killers, he risks loss of U.S. aid.

title: Opium War Was Nothing Like U.S. Drug Crisis; The Door Forced Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Clamor in the East; Miners Trapped in Yugoslavia
description: A gas explosion and fire in a coal mine today trapped workers nearly a half-mile underground and about 90 miners were feared dead, the official press agency reported. It reported 73 miners had escaped unharmed. The methane gas explosion and fire started at noon at the Aleksinacki Rudnici mine, 120 miles south of Belgrade, the mine director, Branislav Mandusic, said.

title: Frederick Katz, Lawyer And Philanthropist, 92
description: Frederick Katz, a lawyer and philanthropist, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old and had been active on the Committee on Character and Fitness of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court until he became ill in June.

title: Jets Hope Walker Can Join Toon for Game With Colts
description: Maybe, just maybe, the wide receivers Wesley Walker and Al Toon, two players without whom the Jets usually lose, will be able to play together Sunday for the first time this season.

title: After a Fire at a Bronx IRT Station, a Slow Burn
description: LEAD: The fires of the 60's and 70's ravaged the South Bronx; they continue to be the reigning symbol of the borough's crime and hopelessness. But there is hope that, in the Bronx, the phoenix will rise again if citizens of conscience support its fragile ascent. The closing of the elevated Intervale Avenue train station is a matter of concern to everyone.

title: International Consumer Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Devils, Down by 3 Goals, Rally to Win in Overtime
description: The first confrontation of the season between the Rangers and the Devils reached a high intensity level only in the third period tonight but the sellout crowd at Byrne Meadowlands Arena did not complain.

title: Ivaco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $429,000 and $3,679,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary charges of $756,000 for the quarter and $1,690,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,115,000 for the quarter and $7,232,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Electronic Organizers
description: ''I'm not reordering inserts for my diary this year,'' said Roberta Thumim, a New York publicity agent. ''I'm buying batteries instead.''

title: Lasertechnics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Kansas Upsets L.S.U. To Advance in N.I.T.
description: Kansas went over the top of second-ranked Louisiana State University's big front line and Terry Brown paced a long-range attack that led the Jayhawks to an 89-83 victory last night in the second round of the Dodge National Invitation Tournament.

title: Nambian Rebels Inherit the Problems of Leadership
description: By winning Namibia's elections by a solid majority this week, the South-West Africa People's Organization is inheriting not only a new country but also a new set of problems.

title: Mor-Flo Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net charges reflecting an increase in the provision for the patent infringement damage award against the company of $3,889,000 for the quarter and $3,993,000 for the 9 months, compared with $53,000 and $1,868,000 for the same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Clamor in the East; Albania, Marking Liberation, Says It Plans Some Pardons
description: Albania said today that it would grant a wide-ranging amnesty to prisoners to mark the 45th anniversary of its liberation during World War II.

title: Bush Reassures Gorbachev
description: President Bush has assured President Gorbachev that he wants a ''calm and peaceful'' period in Eastern Europe, officials said. Page 6.

title: Mediq Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $3,731,000 for the quarter and $8,926,000 for the year, and extraordinary credits of $467,000, or 2 cents a share, and $3,916,000, or 17 cents a share, for quarter and year, respectively.

title: Justice in India?
description: To the Editor:

title: New York State to Challenge Disposal Law
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that New York State will challenge the Federal law that requires the state to dispose of its own low-level radioactive waste.

title: Ivy Title And Pride On Line in The Game
description: Harold Sedgwick displayed the remnant of a crimson pennant that has been waved at every Harvard-Yale game since 1884. ''I'm its seventh custodian,'' said Sedgwick, an 82-year-old retired clergyman. ''The custom is to wave it after every Harvard touchdown.''

title: A Cloud Seven Senators Wide
description: The Senate Ethics Committee has finally hired an outside lawyer to look into the suspicious behavior of six more Senators, in addition to one whose case is already in the works. The fact that seven Senators are challenged at once challenges the credibility of the institution itself. That puts a heavy burden on the committee and its counsel to be thorough, honest and open.

title: Paterno Searching for Ways to Knock Off Notre Dame
description: Lou Holtz is a superb football coach. His Notre Dame teams have won 22 straight games. This year's team is ranked No. 1 in the polls of The Associated Press and United Press International. It is No. 2 in The New York Times's computer rating.

title: New-Music Festival; Balancing Exploration and Musical Sense
description: Among experimental singers who improvise their own material, there is always the temptation to forfeit a sense of musical structure in favor of undisciplined free-form warbling. But in their experimental jazz collaboratoins, Ursula Dudziak and Jay Clayton, who performed together at Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday evening, have found a very engaging balance between the urge to explore and the making of musical sense.

title: Manley Facing Suspension From the N.F.L.
description: Dexter Manley, the Washington Redskins' outstanding defensive end, is facing a suspension of indefinite length from the National Football League.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Falling Mortgage Rates
description: The slowing economy has created opportunities in real estate, as a generally depressed housing market has reduced the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage by more than 1.25 percentage points since March. It is now 9.66 percent, a five-year low. Continued soft spots in the economy, including housing, could push that rate down another half-point by spring, many analysts say. If so, delaying a $100,000 mortgage commitment could reduce monthly payments by more than $30, producing savings of more than $12,000 over the life of the loan. Here are examples of savings that could be achieved if rates fall further. $ Rate Monthly Cost Total Cost Savings 9.66 (current) $852.55 $306,918 --- 9.50 $840.85 $302,706 $4,212 9.25 $822.68 $296,165 $10,753 9.00 $804.62 $289,663 $17,255 Source: Bank Rate Monitor, N. Palm Beach, Fla.

title: F.D.A. Chief Says Most Generics Meet Standards
description: Government tests of the 30 best-selling generic drugs show that only 1.1 percent do not meet standards, Food and Drug Administration officials said today.

title: A Pipeline to Petroleum Security
description: Warnings about our growing dependence on imported oil are coming thick and fast these days, and not without reason -imports will soon reach 50 percent of total demand. But in responding to the danger, we risk overlooking an important difference between today and the early 1970's: Key OPEC nations now seem anxious to strengthen America's perceptions of its own energy security.

title: Millicom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Lockheed's $300 Million Mistake
description: The Lockheed Corporation said today that it would subtract $300 million from its pretax fourth-quarter earnings because of a miscalculation it made in bidding for a contract to develop an antisubmarine aircraft for the Navy.

title: HOCKEY
description: Oilers 3, Sabres 0: Esa Tikkanen had one goal and two assists, and Grant Fuhr stopped 30 shots last night as Edmonton won at home and ended Buffalo's unbeaten streak at nine games. Fuhr, who missed the beginning of the season after undergoing an appendectomy in September, won for only the second time in eight starts and recorded the eighth shutout of his career.(AP) SOCCER Egypt 1, Algeria 0: A goal by Hossam Hassan, a forward, gave Egypt a victory over Algeria yesterday in their World Cup qualifying match in Cairo and sent the Egyptians to Italy for the finals next year.(AP)

title: Cato Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $601,000 for the quarter and $938,000 for the 9 months.

title: Todd-Ao Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
New Questions on Aspirin and Heart
description: A new study of elderly people has concluded that taking daily doses of aspirin increases the risk of kidney cancer and heart disease.

title: A Marathoner Thanks New Yorkers for Help
description: To the Editor:

title: HQ Office Supplies Wareouse reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included losses of $1,851,000 associated with an acquisition. There are no year-ago quarter and 9 months results because the company began operations in February 1989.

title: Neco Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Delaware Otsego Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A Lament for New Quarters After 2 Officers' Deaths
description: Law-enforcement authorities said yesterday that two New York City police detectives who were slain on Monday might be alive today if a plan to move their squad into new quarters had gone on schedule.

title: Hewlett-Packard reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Embassy in Salvador Offers to Protect Witnesses
description: The United States Ambassador, William G. Walker, offered protection today to any witnesses to the killing of six Jesuit priests on Thursday.

title: DEFEAT CONCEDED ON BUSH NOMINEE
description: In an embarrassing defeat for the White House, the Senate minority leader acknowledged today that the Republicans lacked the votes to confirm President Bush's choice for the Agriculture Department's leading environmental post.

title: Rent-A-Wreck of America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $79,924 for the quarter and $181,952 for the 6 months.

title: Nightmares and Counselors Descend on Stunned Town
description: Nightmares haunted little Robert Hayes all Thursday night. He dreamed mostly of a friend, C.J. Scotto, one of the seven children who were killed Thursday when a tornado swirled into the cafeteria at East Coldenham Elementary School during lunchtime.

title: Corrections
description: The Business Digest yesterday listed an article about M. Danny Wall, the savings industry regulator, erroneously in some editions. It appeared in early editions, but was omitted from later ones through an editing error. It is reprinted today on page 12.

title: Marine Transport
description: Marine Transport Lines, one of the nation's oldest owners and operators of ships transporting bulk commodities, was acquired yesterday for $128.8 million by two investors, including the Belzberg family of Canada. The shipping company, which is the nation's third-largest owner of such ships, was acquired by the Intrepid Acquisition Corporation, in which Richard T. duMoulin has a large interest as well as the Belzbergs.

title: Books of The Times; How Benny Goodman Became King
description: Benny Goodman and the Swing Era By James Lincoln Collier Illustrated. 404 pages. Oxford University Press. $22.95.

title: Split With Treasury Cited By Fed in Report on Rates
description: Policy makers of the Federal Reserve decided at a meeting last month not to lower interest rates at once in large part because they did not want to be seen as succumbing to pressure from the Treasury, according to a report of the meeting released today.

title: Majkowski Improving
description: The Green Bay quarterback, Don Majkowski, appears to have recovered enough from a knee injury to play tomorrow when the Packers face the 49ers in San Francisco, Lindy Infante, the Packers' coach, said yesterday.

title: U.S. Gold Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Colt Near Sale of Gun Unit
description: Industries, whose firearms division's union workers have been on strike for more than three years, announced today that it was near an agreement to sell the unit. The deal could put 950 replacement workers out of work.

title: Ferranti Charges Fraud in U.S. Deal
description: Ferranti International Signal P.L.C., the British military contractor, said it lost more than $157 million in cash because of fraud in its acquisition of the United States company International Signal and Control. In total, Ferranti said its loss was the equivalent of $338 million as a result of what it called ''a serious fraud'' involving bogus contracts that it unwittingly inherited when it bought the American company in November 1987. Ferranti's deputy managing director, Charles Scott, told a news conference that about half the loss represented cash spirited out of the American concern, the vast majority before the Ferranti takeover.

title: MILITARY TO DRAFT PLAN FOR A 6% CUT IN 1992-94 SPENDING
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered the nation's armed services to draw up plans for cutting $180 billion in projected spending, reflecting the Bush Administration's judgment that Federal deficits and political changes in Europe are leading toward a smaller Pentagon budget.

title: Bulgarian Leader Hints at Future Of Free Voting and Other Changes
description: A week after becoming Bulgaria's Communist leader, Petar T. Mladenov consolidated his hold on power today while saying he favored free elections and a stronger Parliament that could be ''a democratic alternative'' to the present system.

title: Corcap reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $277,000 and $273,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $647,000 for the quarter and $521,000 for the 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the suspension of routine Navy operations for a safety review misidentified Lee McNeil, a spokesman for an installation near Chicago. He is at the Glenview Naval Air Station, not the Great Lakes Naval Training Center.

title: Clamor in the East; Walesa's View of Glemp Irks Jewish Leaders
description: When Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, entered a midtown law office yesterday to meet with about 70 leaders of Jewish organizations, he was enthusiastically applauded. In a scene that has become familiar during the Polish leader's weeklong visit to the United States, many in the audience stood and cheered.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7 The killings of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador were the work of right-wing forces, said a senior American official. He said he felt instinctively about who committed the slayings. Page 1 Protection for any witnesses of the killings of the priests was offered by the United States Ambassador in El Salvador. 5 Major reforms for East Germany, including a new election law, were promised by the new Prime Minister, Hans Modrow. He also held out the prospect for ''a new level'' of relations with West Germany. 1 East German secret police being renamed and reduced 6 Bulgaria's new Communist leader, Petar Mladenov, consolidated his hold on power, and said he favors free elections and a stronger Parliament that could be ''a democratic alternative'' to the present system. 1 An anti-Government rally in Prague, the largest one in more than 20 years, ended in a bloody confrontation when riot police attacked demonstrators trying to march to downtown Wenceslas Square. 7 Three dissident voices from Eastern Europe 6 Lech Walesa met with leaders of Jewish organizations, and significant disagreement arose on the issue of anti-Semitism in Poland and the dispute over a Roman Catholic convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp. 7 Poles seek the jobs left by East Germans 7 President Bush has assured Moscow that he wants a ''calm and peaceful'' period in Eastern Europe and that the United States will not behave provocatively in the region, Administration officials said. 6 Lithuanian Communist officials, who had met with the Politburo, indicated they would not alter plans to form a new Lithuanian party more independent of the Moscow leadership. 3 Frunze journal: Citizens speak out by building houses 4 India's governing party is facing tight election contests in several regions. In the state of Madhya Pradesh, an incumbent of royal lineage is rallying the party. 3 Namibia's liberation movement, Swapo, which won a majority in the new assembly this week, inherits a nation with many illiterate and poor people, and with a foreign debt of $250 million. 3 National 8-12, 28, 33 Plans to cut future military costs by $180 billion were ordered by Defense Secretary Cheney. The order reflects a recognition by the Administration that budget deficits and political changes in Europe are pushing towards a smaller Pentagon budget. 1 House plans inquiry into explosion on Iowa 33 A raise for Congress was passed that would mean smaller pay increases for senators than for members of the House. The Senate rejected the House's planned 1991 ban on outside speaking fees. 1 Repeal of the Medicare expansion was agreed by House and Senate conferees. The 16-month-old Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act was intended to protect older Americans from the high cost of acute illness. 8 The Senate ethics committee voted to use a special counsel to examine complaints about Senator D'Amato's political dealings as well as accusations that five other Senators acted improperly on behalf of a savings institution. 12 Administration said to want savings regulator to go 12 Ex-opponent's complaint prompts D'Amato inquir 12 The President's choice for a top job in the Agriculture Department lacks enough support in the Senate to be confirmed, the Senate minority leader acknowledged. 8 14 workers at the Rocky Flats Plant, the nation's only source of plutonium for nuclear weapons, suffered frequent injuries and radioactive con- tamination over a 30-year period, medical records show. 10 Energy Dept. found paying lawyers fighting U.S. fines 10 The days of the old-fashioned bar that serves only drinks seems to be ending as new attitudes about drinking emerge. Many hotel bars and neighborhood bars are emphasizing food at least as much as beverages. 1 The regular use of aspirin by elderly people increases their risk of kidney cancer and heart disease, according to a new study. 8 F.D.A. chief says most generics meet standards 28 Indian tribes should have the option of exercising greater control over Federal aid that officials in Washington now administer, a Senate panel proposed. 8 35 Chicago journal: Preparing for Walesa 8 Regional 29-32 The policies toward homeless people are becoming tougher in public areas in New York City. Some transportation agencies, for example, are trying to discourage the homeless from staying in their terminals. 1 The deaths of the seven children in a tornado that destroyed their cafeteria has stunned residents, and professional counselors are helping teachers and students. 29 No structural problems seen at school hit by tornado 30 The seizure of a New York farm suspected of being used by drug dealers was unconstitutional, a Federal court decided, in a ruling that may hamper the Government's ability to seize a drug dealer's real estate. 29 Two New York City police detectives who were murdered on Monday might be alive today if a plan to move their squad into new quarters had gone on schedule, law-enforcement authorities said. 31 Gracie Mansion suits Joyce Dinkins just fine. She said that there will be some ''sprucing up,'' but that she will make few major changes in the decor chosen by Mayor Koch. 29 B. Altman & Company, the 124-year-old department store with a flagship establishment on Fifth Avenue, will be closed, a bankruptcy court decided. 35 Should military jets train in skies over a natural wilderness? Residents of Adirondack Park, in upstate New York, say no, but the military says the air routes are an essential part of low-altitude bombing exercises. 29 Board refuses approval for shelter's expansion 31 Supermarket-chain executive is found slain 30 Transit Authority weighs $1.25 fare with a discount offer 31 Jogger case suspect says that confession was coerced 31 Possible drug link is cited in rock fan's death 30

title: Patents; Diagnostic Devices For Fantastic Voyages
description: Medical dreamers have long mused about developing diagnostic devices so small they can travel through a person's bloodstream and transmit medical data to equipment outside the body.

title: Enstar Indonesia Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company does not have common stock trading in the U.S.

title: This Year, Service Plus Bargains
description: When the holiday shopping season begins at Thanksgiving, people can expect to see still more of the heavy markdowns they have seen the last few holiday seasons.

title: Administration Said to Want Wall to Leave Top Savings Post
description: A consensus has developed within the Administration that M. Danny Wall, the top regulator of the savings and loan industry, should leave his post, a senior White House official said Thursday.

title: Andrew Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Doors Closing as Mood on the Homeless Sours
description: As New Yorkers become increasingly disturbed and exasperated by the overwhelming presence of homeless people, more and more public institutions are adopting policies intended to keep out the homeless.

title: Offer for New Hampshire Utility Increased
description: Northeast Utilities sweetened its bid for the assets of the bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire yesterday and said that it had won the endorsement of some secured creditors.

title: Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation has been awarded a $156.6 million contract by NASA to launch the first United States spacecraft to Mars since 1976. The contract, awarded Thursday to the company's Denver Astronautics Group, is seen as an important victory in the competitive commercial space market.

title: Heartland Menu: Nice, But Hold the Trendy
description: The man who transformed Ponderosa Inc. from a company with seven restaurants to a nationwide chain serving budget-priced steaks to millions is now investing in another restaurant idea.

title: Opium War Was Nothing Like U.S. Drug Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: NRM Energy Co.  L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shares outstanding represented average units.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alpha Solarco Inc., Cincinnati, a producer of commercial and industrial solar energy systems, and its joint venture partner, Solectric Corp., Cincinnati, a maker of solar energy equipment, said they had started operation of the largest single photovolataic concentrator unit in the world about 60 miles west of Las Vegas, Nev.

title: About New York; For a Few Hours Bunny and Dizzy Return to Life
description: Once the sun shone golden, the mountain lake sparkled like a million diamonds and summers seemed endless and perfect. This is the memory of Camp Red Wing on Schroon Lake in the Adirondacks that is held by generations of women who went there as lucky young girls.

title: Congress Passes Increase in Pay; 2 Houses Differ
description: Congress voted this morning to raise salaries for House members, Federal judges and top government officials by more than a third and enact new restrictions governing ethics. The bill includes a smaller raise for members of the Senate.

title: Graf Hustles Into Semifinals by Routing Sukova, 6-2, 6-1
description: If Steffi Graf ever tired of being the finest female tennis player in the world and chose instead to become a dancer, the hustle would surely be her forte.

title: Penrod's Rigs Attract Rowan
description: The Rowan Companies, a Houston-based contract drilling company, said today that it had expressed an interest in acquiring the rigs of the Penrod Drilling Corporation, a larger drilling company owned jointly by the Hunt brothers' family estates and a group of banks led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: For Indian, Long Trail For Votes
description: The chant began slowly and rose over the insistent, rhythmic clanging of temple bells.

title: Helen Serger, 88, Dies; Dealer in Modern Art
description: Helen Serger, a dealer in modern art, died Thursday at Cabrini Hospital in Manhattan after a brief illness. She was 88 years old.

title: Citizens Utilities Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Philharmonic; A Cellis Carrying On The Work Of a Master
description: Thanks to notation and, to some extent, recordings, music does not depend entirely on uninterrupted tradition, as folk song and poetry did in primitive times when a pupil's ear was art's only conservator. Still, the value of one-on-one transmission from teacher to student - from one Bach to the next, from Haydn to Beethoven, from Liszt to his phalanx of epigones - can hardly be overestimated. If nothing else, such continuity keeps a worthwhile work in circulation so that each generation of performers need not come to it innocent of how older musicians approached its problems. Sometimes, of course, what is passed on to the next generation is simply the assurance that a difficult work can actually be played.

title: Sunstar Foods reports earnings for Year to Aug 26
description: The net loss figures represented operations that are listed as discontinued because the company is in the process of liquidating.

title: Murderer of Woman Is Executed in Alabama
description: A man convicted of raping and murdering his cousin while he was on a brief leave from prison was put to death in the electric chair this morning, 11 years after the crime.

title: Julia McGuire Blewer, Church Chairwoman, 86
description: Julia McGuire Blewer, a former program chairwoman of the Women's Association of Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, died Thursday at New York Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: If Japan's Socialists Gain . . .
description: LEAD: Pardoxically, a bit of socialism in Japan may further capitalism in the United States!The influence of

title: Transit Leader Asks $1.25 Fare With a Discount
description: The president of the New York City Transit Authority proposed yesterday that subway and bus fares rise to $1.25 in January and that the increase include a discount offer of 18 tokens for $20, reducing the cost of a ride to $1.11. The fare has been $1 since 1986. The president, David L. Gunn, said the 18-pack discount could ''avoid some pretty controversial stuff'' at the turnstiles, such as more people hopping over them to avoid paying.

title: First Financial Caribbean reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $512,000 and $1,537,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which are spinoff expenses relating to the issuance of stock to management. Latest periods' income before items included gains on the sale of servicing rights of $603,000 for the quarter and $1,780,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dual Trading Played Down By C.F.T.C.
description: LEAD: In a long-awaited staff report, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that the controversial practice of dual trading was not a critical ingredient in keeping markets active enough to smooth out fluctuations, as its supporters have argued.

title: Whose Hand Was That, Anyway?
description: So many hands were extended to receive under-the-table payments at the University of Minnesota that Luther Darville, who was passing out the money with his right hand, may not have realized that one of those hands under the table was his left one.

title: Total Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and preferred dividends requirement exceeded net income.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a congressional investigation of June Q. Koch, a former official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, misidentified a report on her activities that is expected to become public next week. It was prepared by a House Subcommittee, not by the General Accounting Office.

title: To Yiddish Speakers, 'Shvartzer' Isn't Hateful
description: To the Editor:

title: Anniversary at Juilliard
description: A free performance by the Juilliard Pre-College Orchestra is to be given in observance of the 20th anniversary of the school's pre-college division on Nov. 21 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. On the program is the world premiere of the ''Anniversary'' Overture by Anthony Aibel, a student in the masters program at Juilliard. Also to be played is Saint-Saens's Violin Concerto No. 3 in B minor, featuring the violinist Gil Shaham; Richard Strauss's ''Don Juan,'' and Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' Suite. Information: 874-7515.

title: KEY RATES
Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Wilfred Amer Educational reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter and 9 months' results included a credit of $544,000 related to an adjustment of the purchase price of a company acquired in 1987.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING
description: Alex Stewart, a heavyweight, underwent surgery Thursday to repair the tendons in his left hand that he injured in his eight-round loss to Evander Holyfield on Nov. 4 at Atlantic City. Stewart, who lost for the first time in 25 fights, tore tendons over the knuckles of the middle and little fingers of his hand. (AP)

title: Conferees Agree to Repeal Disputed Medicare Program
description: House and Senate conferees agreed early this morning to repeal the 16-month-old Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, intended to protect 33 million older Americans from the high costs of extended illness.

title: No Bidder To Rescue B. Altman
description: B. Altman & Company, the 124-year-old department store whose flagship establishment on Fifth Avenue was one of the first to cater to Manhattan's carriage trade, will be closed, a bankruptcy court decided yesterday.

title: The Serious Ends of Comedy
description: Charles Lane, writer, producer, director, actor and fan of early Chaplin movies, sums up his approach to film-making with a maxim of the boxing ring: ''Stick and move.'' It is a strategy - hit your opponent and keep moving - that he finds has parallels in his first feature, ''Sidewalk Stories,'' a study of New York's homeless.

title: Subway Pickpockets Try Helpfulness as a Ploy
description: To the Editor:

title: Armada Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $130,000 from tax loss carryforward for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $80,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $5,835,000 which consists of $975,000 loss from discontinued operations, $4.5 million estimated loss on disposal of business segment, and a $360,000 income tax provision. d-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $7,330,000 which consists of $2,910,000 loss from discontinued operations, the $4.5 million estimated loss, and an $80,000 income tax benefit.

title: Campbell Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary charge of $6,798,000 for the quarter and 9 months. The company said year-ago results included a $58.4 million writedown in the carrying value of resource properties. It said the improved results were due to lower mining costs, higher income from asbestos operations and a gain on the sale of a phosphate deposit. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would say that if the Defense Department suffered only a 2 percent per year annual cut over the next five years, it would be a miracle. There is a general perception in the land that peace has broken out all over. The public will demand, and the Congress will respond in some fashion.'' - Senator Jim Exon, Democrat of Nebraska. [ 33:5. ]

title: Energy Conversion Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included Ovonic Imaging Systems Inc.'s net loss of about $818,000.

title: Possible Drug Link To Rock Fan's Death Cited by Prosecutor
description: A college student's death after a rock concert in the Meadowlands Sports Complex last month may not have been a homicide as authorities originally thought but the result of a fall or jump from a bridge while he was under the influence of drugs, the acting Bergen County Prosecutor said today.

title: Galactic Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included a writedown of producing property assets at the Summitville Gold Mine of about $39.9 million for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said some year- earlier figures have been restated.

title: Only Foul Trouble Slows Down Ewing
description: More and more, it appears that Patrick Ewing's biggest worry is not opposing centers, but foul trouble.

title: British Journalist Slain by Sniper
description: A British journalist, David Blundy, was killed today by a sniper's bullet while covering the military offensive here, colleagues said.

title: Next Stop for Tyson: Feb. 12 Bout in Tokyo
description: James (Buster) Douglas of Columbus, Ohio, will be the next opponent for Mike Tyson, the undisputed heavyweight champion, on Feb. 12 in Toyko. Tyson had been scheduled to meet Donovan (Razor) Ruddock tonight in Edmonton, Alberta, but withdrew after he came down with a lung infection. The fight was rescheduled for Jan. 20, but Home Box Office, the cable network with the television rights, withdrew its support when no assurance could be given that the fight would come off then.

title: Outdoors; Federal Support Awaited for Bluefish Limit Plan
description: If it is approved by the United States Department of Commerce, the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council's bluefish plan will go into effect next year. The plan, already adopted by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, which embraces the coastal states from Maine through Florida, establishes a 10-fish possession limit for recreational anglers.

title: 'Green Bird' Will Use Masks and Puppets
description: An adaptation of ''The Green Bird,'' an example of 18th-century commedia dell'arte by Carlo Gozzi, will open on Nov. 30 at 8 P.M. at New York University, Studio Theater, 32 Washington Place.

title: William N. Deramus, 73, Industrialist, Dies
description: William N. Deramus 3d, the chairman of Kansas City Southern Industries Inc. and once the youngest man to head a railroad company, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Truman Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Prairie Village, Kan.

title: DeOssie Is Anxious To Return to Lineup
description: Steve DeOssie says the last seven weeks have been a waste. But then, he cheerfully admits that his first five years in pro football were more or less of a waste, too.

title: Fight by Nekoosa, Georgia-Pacific
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said it had filed a motion with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to require the Georgia-Pacific Corporation to obtain the commission's approval for the transfer of Nekoosa's hydroelectric projects and licenses in Maine and Wisconsin. In a related action, Nekoosa said it had filed a motion and complaint with the commission to intervene in Georgia-Pacific''s pending hydroelectric license proceedings for its Gilman, Vt., mill. The company said it had taken the actions to provide the commission with information on the anti-competitive effects of Georgia-Pacific's proposed $58-a-share offer to merge with Great Northern Nekoosa.

title: Pet Discipline, on Tape
description: Even the most well-behaved, trustworthy cats and dogs are apt to break the house rules every now and then. This is especially true when there is no one at home to shout ''No!'' or ''Shoo!'' or ''Don't you dare!'' or ''Just you try it!''

title: Clamor in the East; Bush Echoes Gorbachev Plea for Peaceful Change
description: President Bush has assured President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union that he wants a ''calm and peaceful'' period in Eastern Europe and made clear that the United States will not behave provocatively in the region, Administration officials said today.

title: Riverside Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Adirondacks Thundering at Bombing Runs
description: They returned to the northern Adirondacks last week, soaring over Jerry Blanche's house on Upper Chateaugay Lake, then banking up over Lyon Mountain and off to the western horizon.

title: No Structural Problems Seen At School Hit by a Tornado
description: School officials said today that they had found no structural problems in the elementary school cafeteria where seven children died Thursday when a wall collapsed.

title: Energy Dept. Found Paying Fees Of Lawyers Fighting U.S. Fines
description: The General Accounting Office has found that the Department of Energy, which routinely pays all environmental fines and other expenses incurred by its contractors, has sometimes allowed those contractors to run up legal bills fighting the fines that are larger than the fines themselves.

title: Clamor in the East; Riot Police in Prague Beat Marchers and Arrest Dozens
description: The largest anti-Government rally in more than 20 years ended in violence today when riot police officers attacked demonstrators trying to march to downtown Wenceslas Square.

title: Diversicare Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary gains from early extinguishment of debt of $166,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $316,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $700,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Markel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said shares outstanding and share earnings for all periods have been adjusted to reflect the 20 percent stock dividend paid on Sept. 29.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1989
description: Companies

title: Durham Meeting
description: An investment group that holds a 5.6 percent stake in the Durham Corporation said it would meet with senior officials of the Raleigh, N.C., holding company that has interests in insurance and broadcasting. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group, led by Financial Securities Fund, a Nashville investment partnership and Bailey Financial Group, a Rocky Mount, N.C., investment concern, said the purpose of the meeting ''will be to discuss strategies for maximizing shareholder value, including, among other things, a possible business combination.'' The meeting is scheduled for Nov. 29. Durham has 8.4 million shares outstanding.

title: Pathe Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $26,290,000, or $1.43 a share, from early extinguishment of debt. Pathe said its 1989 third quarter results included an expense of $13.3 million from a settlement with a former officer, of which $12.5 million was reimbursed to the company by a major shareholder as a contribution to additional paid-in capital. The company said its revenues for the quarter included $12.5 million in film sales in accord with the settlement. The 1988 results included $49.9 million in non-operating gains from the sale of assets.

title: No Gain Seen as Talks On Nicaragua Recess
description: Peace talks between the Nicaraguan Government and the contra rebels recessed for the weekend today after a two-hour session that participants said failed to narrow differences over terms for a cease-fire. The talks are scheduled to resume on Monday afternoon.

title: Hofstra to Begin Playoffs
description: Hofstra and Montclair State, schools without much to show in their playoff backgrounds, meet today in a first-round Division III matchup at Sprague Field in Upper Montclair, N. J. The 16-team tournament ends Dec. 9 at the Stagg Bowl in Phenix City, Ala. The winner will play next Saturday against the winner of the game between Cortland State (9-1) and Union College (10-0) at Schenectady, N.Y.

title: Grocery Official Is Found Slain By Rural Road
description: An executive of the Pathmark supermarket chain was shot to death early Thursday, several hours after he left his office in Woodbridge, the authorities said today.

title: Nicholas G. Kuhn, Executive, 92
description: Nicholas G. Kuhn, a retired business executive, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92 years old.

title: To Yiddish Speakers, 'Shvartzer' Isn't Hateful
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page on Nov. 1 about the future of Jesuit colleges misstated the number of Jesuits in the United States. It is 5,000, of whom 1,000 are involved in higher education.

title: Oil Tanker and Boat Collide
description: An 80-foot fishing boat collided with a Navy oil tanker nearly seven times its size two miles outside Los Angeles Harbor on Thursday night. The collision resulted in a small oil spill and minor injuries to seven people on the fishing boat.

title: Clamor in the East; East Germany Gives Secret Police a New Name and a Tighter Rein
description: Germany's dreaded Ministry for State Security was given a new name, a new leader and new marching orders today, and put on a rigorous crash diet.

title: Chicago Journal; Preparing For 'Hero' In 2d City Of Poland
description: Standing near a poster of a mustachioed man entitled simply ''The Man,'' a young Polish waitress spoke slowly, searching for the proper English words to describe Lech Walesa.

title: N-W Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago figures have been restated. The company said lower revenue figures reflected the inclusion in the year-earlier figures of the proceeds from the sale of real estate.

title: Land's End Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Seizure of Farm In a Drug Case Is Ruled Illegal
description: In a ruling that could curb the Government's power to seize a drug dealer's real estate, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the seizure of an upstate New York farm suspected of being used by drug dealers violated the owner's constitutional rights because he was not given a hearing beforehand.

title: Clamor in the East; Poles Remove a Hated Statue
description: To the cheers and song of thousands of onlookers today, workers toppled a statue of Feliks E. Dzerzhinsky, the Polish aristocrat who organized the Soviet secret police after the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution.

title: Property Capital Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included gains from the sale of investments of $3 million.

title: Makers Asked to Recall a Diet Supplement
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it would ask manufacturers for the nationwide recall of the dietary supplement L-tryptophan because of evidence linking it to hundreds of cases of a blood disorder and one death.

title: Clamor in the East; Poles Seek Jobs Others Left Behind
description: With hundreds of thousands of East Germans surging through newly opened borders to the West, thousands of Poles are lining up to try to get their hands on the jobs, apartments and even the rickety Trabant automobiles that the East Germans are leaving behind. Or so they say.

title: Your Money
description: Full of the holiday spirit, millions of Americans will start gift shopping next weekend, but for many the bills run up between Thanksgiving and Christmas will be a year-round burden, particularly to those who make only the minimum monthly payments on their credit-card bills. But a bit of planning can help shoppers help avoid this.

title: Race for 2d Narrows in Brazil
description: Brazilians waited anxiously today as the margin between two leftist presidential candidates narrowed to 1 percent of the votes cast. With 53 percent of the votes officially counted, Luis Inacio da Silva led his rival, Leonel Brizola, by 760,000 votes. Authorities said the winner would not be known until Sunday. One of the leftists will face Fernando Collor de Mello, a center-right ex-governor.

title: Jet Crashes; Pilot Is Safe
description: An Air Force F-16 jet fighter crashed into the Atlantic today, but its pilot ejected and was rescued from the water without injury. An Air Force spokesman said Capt. Anthony Montecalvo, 27 years old, was on a training mission when his jet went down five miles east of Homestead Air Force Base about 8:30

title: Ex-Opponent's Complaint Began D'Amato Inquiry
description: The Senate Ethics Committee's examination of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's conduct in office will be carried out in response to a formal complaint filed last summer by Mark Green, a New York Democrat who ran against the Senator in 1986.

title: Technical Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $61,140, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $227,700, or 19 cents a share, for the year.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Agrees to Sale
description: Dunkin' Donuts Inc., which fought off a hostile takeover attempt earlier this year, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the British food and beverage group Allied-Lyons P.L.C. for $325 million in cash.

title: Treasury Issues Continue to Decline
description: Treasury note and bond prices declined further yesterday as the debt market continued to digest the large volume of quarterly refunding and other offerings auctioned this week. Dealers said prices began falling from the opening, after the Government reported that housing starts rose 12 percent in October.

title: Lithuanians Resist Pressure From Moscow on New Party
description: Lithuanian Communist officials summoned to the Kremlin for an unusual 10-hour meeting with the Soviet Politburo indicated today they would not alter their plan to form a new Lithuanian party more independent of the leadership in Moscow.

title: Carolco Pictures Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Jazz; Strings Make the Most of It
description: A crucial problem for a jazz group made up predominantly of strings is its ability to engender a swinging attack. Any group led by Ron Carter, one of the major jazz bassists for the past 30 years, has the basis for just such an attack. So it is not surprising that his string-laden Nonet, which will be at Fat Tuesday's through Sunday, plays with a robust, surging rhythm. Essentially, however, the rhythm comes not from Mr. Carter, who is primarily out front as a soloist, but from a superb rhythm section (Steve Kroon, percussion, Leon Malleson, bass, Lewis Nash, drums, with occasional input from the pianist Steven Scott).

title: Data for Nuclear Arms Workers Cast Light on 3 Decades of Plutonium Peril By KEITH SCHNEIDER
description: Medical records of 14 workers at the Rocky Flats Plant, the nation's only source of plutonium for nuclear weapons, chronicle three decades of frequent injuries and radioactive contamination.

title: Volunteer Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: The company changed its name from Winners Corp. during the latest quarter.

title: House Panel Plans Inquiry Into Explosion Aboard Iowa
description: As members of Congress continued their inquiry into the explosion that killed 47 sailors on the battleship Iowa in April, a House subcommittee chairman said today that new evidence had arisen that demanded further hearings next month.

title: Electrohome reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $428,000. c-Net income d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $271,000 and $485,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $385,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $4,925,000, or 79 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Special Counsel Is Voted in Ethics Case
description: The Senate Ethics Committee voted tonight to hire a special outside counsel to examine complaints about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's political dealings and separate accusations that five other Senators acted improperly on behalf of a failing savings and loan institution.

title: Fitting Airplanes to Passengers
description: The new top executives at Northwest Airlines, who helped redefine what a hotel should be while at the Marriott Corporation, are now preparing to overhaul the airplane passenger cabin.

title: Opium War Was Nothing Like U.S. Drug Crisis; The Long Battle Won
description: To the Editor:

title: Claude H. Nourtier, Travel Executive, 55
description: Claude H. Nourtier, a travel marketing executive, died of cancer Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: Cy Young Award Pays Off for Saberhagen
description: Bret Saberhagen, who this week won his second American League Cy Young Award, yesterday gained a three-year contract extension worth $8.9 million. The agreement between the pitcher and the Kansas City Royals came just a few hours after the Atlanta Braves announced that they had wrested Nick Esasky, a free-agent first baseman, from the Boston Red Sox.

title: Let's Get This Ambassador Thing Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: Horace W. McCurdy, Maritime Builder, 90
description: Horace W. McCurdy, a maritime construction executive whose company built the Mercer Island floating bridge, died Monday. He was 90 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: Antilock Brakes, Once Rare, Emerge as Prime Auto Option
description: DETROIT, Nov. 17 - Antilock brakes, once considered an esoteric device to prevent uncontrolled skidding on slippery roads, are showing up as standard equipment or being offered as optional equipment in many new car, truck and van models. So more new-car buyers than ever before are getting a chance to buy this safety feature. Automotive experts say the proliferation of these specialized braking systems - sometimes called A.B.S. - is likely to continue through the late 1990's, when antilock brakes are expected to become fairly common even on economy models. Some insurance companies are granting discounts to clients whose cars have the brakes. Consumer advocates advise drivers who are shopping for cars now to make antilock brakes an important consideration. A Helpless Feeling The benefits of antilock brakes will be immediately evident to anyone who ever has had the experience of inadvertently braking too hard on a slippery road, only to encounter a frightening loss of control as the car careers or spins toward a possible collision. In this kind of situation, the wheels of the car, having been stopped by the brakes, remain locked while the car continues to skid. The steering wheel is useless: no matter which way it is turned, the vehicle continues to move in the direction it was moving at the moment the wheels were locked. Sometimes the car will turn sideways or begin to spin. Driver-education courses warn against slamming on the brake pedal precisely because it is so easy to lock the wheels on a slippery surface because of the lack of friction between the rubber and the road. Students are taught that on wet or icy roads, they should repeatedly pump the brakes gently then quickly release the pressure until the vehicle slows or stops. The series of short braking actions reduces the chance of lockup. Electronics Take Over In essence, antilock brakes mimic those instructions, automatically applying and releasing pressure even faster than a driver could. As the brakes are applied, an electronic sensor detects when a wheel is about to lock and then releases it, overriding any pressure on the pedal. The driver retains the ability to steer the car and can depress the brakes as hard as possible without releasing pressure: the system will slow the wheels gradually without locking them. In some systems the driver can actually feel the pedal pulsing as the computer is applying and releasing the brakes. The General Motors Corporation is installing antilock brakes as standard equipment in 20 of its 1990 models and will offer the system as optional equipment in 13 models. The most expensive Cadillac models will include antilock brakes, and so will sportier versions of the Pontiac Grand Prix and Buick Electra, as well as the Chevrolet Astro van. Buyers of the Buick Regal, Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme and other medium-sized models can pay $925 to receive them as an option. For 1990, the Ford Motor Company has made antilock brakes standard on the Lincoln Continental, the Lincoln Mark VII, the Mercury Cougar and the Aerostar van, and some versions of the Taurus, the Thunderbird and other models. If ordered as an option, the brakes cost $924 to $1,085. The Chrysler Corporation offers the system as standard on the Maserati TC, and as an option on the Jeep Cherokee and Wagoneer, the Dodge Dynasty, Chrysler Imperial and Chrysler New Yorker for $926 to $998. The brakes are standard on Acuras, and some Mazdas. Toyota, Nissan, , Mitsubishi and Subaru all offer them as an option on a varitety of models; the prices range from $995 to $1,495. They are standard on all BMW's, Jaguars and many models of Mercedes-Benz. G.M., Ford and Chrysler also offer antilock brakes on many pickup trucks. Like many advances in automotive technology, this one has been around for decades. It was first used on airplanes in the 1950's and in large trucks in the 1960's. Only in recent years, however, have auto makers deemed the systems practical and economical enough for industrywide distribution. This follows the pattern of disk brakes, which were introduced in more expensive vehicles and, over time, became commonplace. Josef Mack, a manager for the Robert Bosch Corporation, a leading making of antilock brake systems, estimates that 15 to 20 percent of the cars and trucks on the road will have them in the near future. "Since 1978 we have produced four million systems worldwide, and many consumers who have them say they'll never own another car without them," he said. At present, it is so complicated and costly to retrofit a car or truck with an A.B.S. that it is not practical. Some Practice Needed The brakes take a little getting used to. Deepak Dighe, a G.M. engineer, said pumping them, as many drivers been trained to do with stanbard brakes, will not take full advantage of the antilock technology. Perhaps the greatest potential danger with respect to these systems is that they may imbue drivers with an undue sense of invulnerability when driving on wet or icy pavement. "Antilock brakes improve controllability, but they don't necessarily reduce the stopping distance on slippery pavement," Mr. Dighe said. "You cannot defy the laws of physics. It still takes longer to stop a vehicle on wet pavement than on dry." - CONSUMER'S WORLD

title: U.S. OFFICIAL LINKS SALVADORAN RIGHT TO PRIESTS' DEATHS
description: A senior American official said today that he felt instinctively that right-wing forces were responsible for the killings of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador this week.

title: Patents; A Protein 'Scaffolding' For Repairing Knees
description: Kevin Stone, an orthopedic surgeon in San Francisco, has patented a ''scaffolding'' made of protein to help repair the cartilage of people with knee injuries.

title: Board Refuses Approval For Shelter's Expansion
description: The New York City Board of Estimate has refused to approve retroactively the addition of nearly 300 beds to a homeless men's shelter in the former Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Bush Abandons Victims of Parkinson's Disease
description: LEAD: The Administration has decided to let stand a 20-month-old ban on Federal funding for fetal tissue implant research - a ban that will continue to delay effective treatment and a possible cure for Parkinson's disease.

title: New Talks in Boeing Strike
description: A Federal mediator said today that new contract talks would begin Saturday between the Boeing Company and the union that represents nearly 58,000 striking machinists. The mediator, Doug Hammond, said he had no expectations about the talks, the first in the nearly seven-week-old walkout since bargaining broke down on Nov. 4.

title: Oakwood Homes Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax gains of about $1.1 million recognized on the sale of a manufactured housing community. c-Included an after-tax gain of about $1.1 million on the sale of a manufactured housing community and a parcel of undeveloped land.

title: Clamor in the East; Three Dissident Voices From Eastern Europe
description: Three Eastern Europeans with long careers as dissidents - a Pole, a Hungarian and a Czechoslovak - were asked in separate interviews what surprised them most about the recent events in East Germany, what they thought might be the next step in Eastern Europe and what they considered the greatest dangers. Jan Litynski: Poland

title: Don't Discard Jackson-Vanik
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Beyond 'Sitting Machines'
description: To Isidoro N. Markus, the familiar spring-loaded office chair is unstable, uncomfortable and ugly. ''No matter how much you try to dress them up,'' said the engineer, who was born in Argentina and now lives in Queens, ''they still always look like sitting machines.''

title: Pitiful, Helpless Giants All
description: Suddenly the world seems littered with pitiful, helpless giants. There was Lech Walesa in Washington knocking on the castle door, talking of another Marshall Plan to help make freedom ring in Poland.

title: Framingham Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Suspect Says Detective Told Him to Touch Jogger's Blood
description: One of the defendants in the Central Park rape case testified yesterday that a detective took him to the crime scene and tried to force him to put his hand in the blood of the jogger he and five others are accused of attacking.

title: INSIDE
description: Action in Ethics Cases

title: Jean Holloway Tobin, Scriptwriter, 72
description: Jean Holloway Tobin, a scriptwriter for radio, film and television, died of a stroke Saturday. She was 72 years old.

title: Finding the Esthetic in the Everyday
description: WITH its white walls, track lights and an array of shiny new items like washing machines and electric mixers, the place looks like a showroom at an upmarket department store. There is, for instance, a neatly dressed guard keeping an eye out for shoplifters; all that's missing is price tags.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cold-water faucet in my bathroom sink gives off a loud whistling or humming noise whenever it is turned on. The noise stops when the faucet is turned on all the way. I tried tightening the screw on top of the faucet handle, but this did not help. Can you tell me how to eliminate this noise?

title: B Divisions Enjoy Split
description: The Public Schools Athletic League B Division is where the have-nots of New York City play football. And it's easy not to get too comfortable.

title: Lisa S. Taylor Married to Ellis B. Jones
description: Lisa Stillman Taylor, a daughter of Mrs. Henry Stillman Taylor of Montecito, Calif., and the late Mr. Taylor, was married yesterday to Ellis Bradley Jones, the son of Mrs. H. Bradley Jones of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Jones. The Rev. Ernest D. Pipes Jr., a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Rally of 50,000 Bulgarians Calls for Democratic Future
description: In the largest independent rally in this country's postwar history, about 50,000 Bulgarians filled the broad cobblestoned square of a cathedral here in the capital today to exorcise their repressive past and chart a democratic future.

title: Atlanta's Boom Area or City's Spoiler?
description: From a new skyscraper, Sam Massell presides over the boom town snaking along Peachtree Road that is billed in its own magazine as ''the Cultural Crossroads of the South.''

title: Wendy L. Davidson to Marry Jeffery A. Krieger
description: The engagement of Wendy L. Davidson and Jeffery A. Krieger, both 1986 graduates of Swarthmore College, has been made known by her mother, Barbara A. Davidson of East Hampton L.I. Mr. Krieger is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry A. Krieger of Claremont, Calif.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: Yes, after one-fourth of the season has been played. The team seems to be playing two-way hockey. It's been a long time since 1940. MARTIN ZEIDNER Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies a work in an exhibition at Artists Space, a Manhattan gallery. The cloth sculpture of a couple is Greer Lankton's ''Freddy and Ellen, 1985.'' The picture accompanies an article about a dispute between the gallery and John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, over a grant for the show, which concerns AIDS. On Thursday, after the section was printed, Mr. Frohnmayer restored a $10,000 Endowment grant to the gallery for the show, but stipulated that it could not be used for its catalogue, which includes criticism of public figures.

title: Plan Announced to Cut Auto Insurance Rates
description: TWO former New Jersey insurance commissioners say they have come up with a plan to sell automobile insurance at below the current average market rates.

title: Multilingual Software: Too Crude To Be Useful
description: Robert Addis uses a facsimile machine and a modem at his translation agency in Menlo Park, Calif., but that is as technically advanced as he gets. Computer translation? ''Alchemy!'' he sniffed. Documents translated by a machine, he said, ''end up needing a complete re-translation.''

title:
Springfield Township Journal;
Residents Fight to Preserve a Former Quarry as Open Space
description: LEAD: MARYLIN SCHNEIDER has struggled for six years and appears to be winning the fight to preserve open space in her neighborhood.

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING?
description: The cold war was not a ''worldwide ideological struggle that called forth daring, courage, imagination and idealism''; it was an ad campaign, used primarily to justify the division of the spoils of World War II.

title: Congress Approves Aid Plan Of $852 Million for Poland
description: Congress approved legislation early today to support democracy and private enterprise in Poland with a major new program of economic aid over the next three years.

title: THE REGION: Nathan Leventhal; One Who's Been Everywhere Leads Dinkins's Transition
description: AFTER David N. Dinkins won New York City's Democratic mayoral primary in September, Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center, sent him a congratulatory note. Mr. Leventhal, a former Deputy Mayor in the Koch administration, offered to help in any way he could.

title: Theodore A. Rath, 85, Ex-College President
description: The Rev. Dr. Theodore A. Rath, retired president of Bloomfield College and a Presbyterian minister, died Friday after being hit by an automobile outside his home in Lakeland, Fla. He was 85 years old and a former resident of Sussex, N.J.

title: 2 Die as Team Van Is Hit by Truck
description: A player and a team manager from the Muskingum College women's basketball team were killed and five others were injured in an accident today on an icy interstate highway, college and hospital officials said.

title: Pantelleria
description: To the Editor: The article on Pantelleria by Alan Riding (''A Speck Between Sicily and Africa,'' Aug. 6) brought back memories of a visit I made to the island in July 1943.

title: Ms. Breslow Wed To Michael Vitale
description: Gail Judith Breslow and Michael Ross Vitale were married yesterday at the Endicott Estate in Dedham, Mass., by Mark Ginsberg, a justice of the peace in Marblehead, Mass. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. David S. Breslow of Wilmington, Del., and Mr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Vitale of Saginaw, Mich.

title: Baseball: National Window
description: To the Sport Editor:

title: I.B.M. and Microsoft Try for a Truce
