description: In a city known for its marriage chapels, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation renewed their vows here last week in a public ceremony, hoping to quash recent speculation of their estrangement over the future course of desktop computing.

title: Islanders Return To Losing
description: The Islanders, who gained a rare victory Thursday night, reverted to form tonight. They played just well enough to lose a close game as the Pittsburgh Penguins beat them, 5-3, at the Civic Arena.

title: Charles Greenfield, Disposal Innovator, 75
description: Charles Greenfield, inventor of a dehydration process used in waste disposal, died of pneumonia Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in New Providence, N.J.

title: Taking the Casual Route
description: LEAD: I'M a do-nothing traveler. Club Meds, with their long lists of activities, make me panic. It's not that I don't have an adventurous side. In fact, I'll admit to a week in the Dominican Republic, where I climbed a three-story ladder and completed a ''knee-hang catch'' into the arms of a seasoned acrobat on the flying trapeze opposite mine.

title: New American Cooking in Centerbrook
description: THE hamlet of Centerbrook, near Essex, was put on Connecticut's dining map some years ago by an exemplary French restaurant called Fine Bouche. But now another establishment, 8 Westbrook, provides a second reason for discerning diners to visit town.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Jamaica Estates
description: LEAD: AZALEAS and dogwood that rival those in botanical gardens bring sightseers to Jamaica Estates in the spring, along with wedding photographers who use the community as a backdrop for bridal-party pictures. In autumn, the colors of the foliage on the century-old trees are just as spectacular.

title: Colonialism Isn't All of Philippine Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Building Limits Sought to Protect Tidal Wetlands
description: LEAD: CONSERVATIONISTS are warning that the rising sea level will eventually submerge tidal wetlands and estuaries unless development along the Connecticut coastline is stopped or drastically reduced.

title: Chicken Distress
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: Football

title: Rangers Regain Their Confidence
description: The bus sat just a couple of steps outside the locker room. The Rangers, with an exhilaration that couldn't quite conquer their exhaustion, straggled toward it, arms aching and legs dragging.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: The Rangers are legitimate contenders for the following reasons: (a) The Patrick Division is no longer dominant, and remaining in first place is a distinct possibility. (b) The combination of strong goaltending and Roger Neilson's defensive system of play is most effective in the playoffs. (c) Strong showings against current N.H.L. powers Calgary, Montreal and Chicago, despite having seven key injured players (all of whom will return by midseason), is cause for guarded optimism.

title: Reviews/Music; Speculum Musicae in Takemitsu Finale
description: There are three explanations for Toru Takemitsu's unquestioned status as Japan's best-known composer. First, his music is pretty good, the sonic tip of a deep-probing esthetic and philosophical exploration of the intersections between East and West. Second, he is adept at international composer careerism, which is not so much a cynical dismissal as a dispassionate observation. Third, hardly unrelated to No. 2, he is personaly attractive, mysterious and compelling.

title: Singles' Plight
description: To the Editor: I recall a letter by a single traveler who complained about exorbitant rates. I concur and think it is high time the travel industry recognized that there are many singles out there, and by charging this ridiculous single supplement they discourage us from traveling. For example, I would like to go to Cancun - the double rate is $475, the single rate $865. Is this really fair? For the difference I can spend a weekend in the Catskills and have three meals a day, all facilities, dancing and entertainment. Travel to Europe is a better buy, as the single supplement is far more reasonable.

title: Susan Jane Kerr Planning to Wed A. R. Dragone Jr.
description: Edmund H. Kerr of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Julius H. Sedlmayr of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jane Kerr, to Allan R. Dragone Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dragone of Darien, Conn.; Quissett, Mass., and New York. A February wedding is planned.

title: Get Ready for Our First Woman President; Jackson's Not Dead Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: A Neil Simon Mini-Marathon
description: EVER since Neil Simon tossed off the third semi-autobiolgraphical script in what has come to be known as his ''BB'' plays, one has envisioned the trilogy being presented as a daylong marathon, a sort of long but lightweight day's journey on the road toward making it by nightfall.

title: Messages From Sponsors Become Harder to Detect
description: AMONG its celebrity profiles and essays on male angst, the December issue of Esquire magazine offers an added treat for readers: the winner of the Absolut Story Contest.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Pasta Place Near the Meadowlands
description: LEAD: FANS attending sports events at the Meadowlands are often on the lookout for an eating place nearby that serves good food in a casual setting. Six-month-old I Fratelli in Secaucus should be a new addition to the roster.

title: Brickley Scores Hat Trick
description: Sixty minutes of hockey, after the remarkable comeback against the Rangers a night earlier, was too much to handle for the Devils tonight.

title: FOOTBALL
description: LOOKING DEEP. By Terry Bradshaw with Buddy Martin. (Contemporary, $17.95.) As Susan Sontag once remarked, writing well is the best revenge. Revenge is probably not what Terry Bradshaw had in mind when he wrote ''Looking Deep'' with the Denver Post sports columnist Buddy Martin, but that is what he has got: revenge over the scores of sportswriters who called him dumb during his career as a quarterback with the Pittsburg Steelers and who will never write a book about football as good as this one. Mr Bradshaw knows that even his staunchest fans are not very interested in his life outside of football, so he does not spend too much time on it. In fact, he seems not to have had much of a life off the gridiron; he does not dilute his accounts of high school, college and professioanl jock life with attempts at fitting his experiences into the big picture. If you want to know what is feels like to win a Super Bowl or to get knocked cold by a Dallas Cowboys linebacker, Mr. Bradshaw will tell you. Playing in a SuperBowl is all he ever wanted to do, he says, and the purity of his joy at having been fortunate enough to be on the winning side in four of them rings true. Mr Bradshaw is candid about the bigotry he carried with him out of his natuve rural Lousisana (''I simply had never encountered black culture. ... It didn't take me long to figure out I was prejudiced''). He is mercifully brief about the much-publicized breakup of his marriage to the ice skater JoJo Starbuck and completely without illusions about his own status as a celebrity: ''I guess if it means that people pay you money to hang out with them, play golf, and give speeches, then I qualify.'' We can only hope that Ronald Reagan's memoirs will be so honest.

title: HOW DO YOU TELL A SELLER FROM A RENTER? How Do You Tell a Seller From a Renter?
description: Tallying its dinosaurs, rabbits and, as of last week, bats, the video industry counts a total of some 30 million new cassettes in the stores. On Billboard's most recent best-seller list ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' stood at No. 2, ''The Land Before Time'' was No. 3, and in anticipation of the new ''Batman'' (15 million fresh cassettes), the old ''Batman, the Movie'' was No. 10. All are priced to sell at under $30.

title: Watering Down Clean Fuels
description: With great fanfare, President Bush drove an ethanol car this summer and promised the nation that his clean fuels program would be ''the most innovative and far-reaching component'' of his new clean air proposal. Yet, when the Administration's clean fuels program came before the House Health and Environment Subcommittee last month, the White House looked the other way as big oil and big auto interests eviscerated the package.

title: Manley Barred Indefinitely by N.F.L.
description: Dexter Manley, the Washington Redskins' star defensive end, was banned indefinitely from the National Football League yesterday for having violated the league's substance-abuse policy for a third time.

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING?
description: Francis Fukuyama thinks ''it matters very little what strange thoughts occur to people in Albania or Burkina Faso.''

title: Review/Theater; A Triangle in 'Thin Air'
description: Rose doesn't pick her men very well. In fact, Rose is probably lucky to be alive, given the two psychopaths she is involved with in Glyn Vincent's ''Thin Air,'' a jumble of a play being presented at the Theater for the New City.

title: Off the Record
description: In his post-Beatles career, Ringo Starr has blazed no trails of musical glory, but he maintains that things would look even more bleak if an album he recorded in 1987 ever reached the listening public. Testifying in an Atlanta courtroom last week, Mr. Starr said he and other musicians were under the influence of drink and drugs when they recorded the album, and contended that his musical reputation would be injured if the album's producer, Chips Moman, were allowed to release it. For his part, Mr. Moman contended that he was just trying to help out a fading star and that he had sunk $146,000 into making the album. Mr. Starr conceded that he had not had a hit record in recent years, but denied that he was desperate when he and Mr. Moman made their arrangement. In any case, the world may never know just how bad the record is. The court granted a permanent injunction blocking its release. Still at issue are certain contractural obligations - or lack of same. Mr. Moman said that the disputed album was but the first of three that Mr. Starr had agreed to let him produce. But Mr. Starr said that deal was contingent upon the first record being a hit.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Brighton Beach; A Revised Proposal for the Baths Site
description: A CONTROVERSY over land use has taken a new turn in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. Its roots are in history but the stakes are a community's future.

title: A Melee at Washington
description: While trying to tear down a goal post and throw it in Lake Washington, celebrating students battled Mace-spraying police today after Washington's 20-9 victory over Washington State. The melee lasted more than 30 minutes after the end of the game at Husky Stadium. Police also were seen hitting students with nightsticks. It was not known immediately if there were any injuries or arrests. An unidentified student who was Maced while climbing on the goal post was brought into Washington's dressing room to recover.

title: WHere U.S. Pride Rests on One Game
description: In sports, there are always big games. But the World Cup soccer match Sunday is bigger than a big game.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT:AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. BEACHES - Bette Midler and Barbara Hershey star in a story about friends, pure soap from beginning to end. (Janet Maslin) 1988. Touchstone. $89.95. Laser disk, $29.95. 2 hours 7 minutes. Closed captioned. R. BEDTIME STORY - Marlon Brando and David Niven star in what was the basis for last year's ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels.'' ''Good, crisp fun,'' a critic wrote. 1964. MCA. $59.95. 1:39. Not rated. COUSINS - An American remake of Jean-Charles Tacchella's romantic comedy ''Cousin, Cousine,'' with Ted Danson, Isabella Rossellini and Sean Young. ''Coarse, raucous, furiously misguided.'' (Maslin) 1989. Paramount. No list price. 1:40. CC. PG-13. DREAM A LITTLE DREAM - Corey Feldman and Meredith Salenger play youngsters transformed into older lovers (Jason Robards and Piper Laurie) in this romantic comedy, ''a routine high-school flick.'' (Walter Goodman) 1989. Vestron. $89.95. LD, $39.95. 1:44. CC. PG-13. GONE WITH THE WIND - A 50th-anniversary reissue of the spectacular film version of Margaret Mitchell's epic Civil War-era love story, starring Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh. 1939. MGM/UA. $89.95. LD, $49.95. 3:51. CC. G. HOTEL TERMINUS: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF KLAUS BARBIE - Max Ophuls's ''vivid, harrowing, minutely detailed'' recollection of France under the German occupation. ''Great.'' (Vincent Canby) 1988. Virgin Vision. $99.95. LD, $99.95. 4:27. Not rated. LAWRENCE OF ARABIA - ''It is David Lean's direction, adroitly weaving together music, scenery and the steely force of Larence's personality, that gives the film its transcendent power.'' (Maslin) 1989. RCA/Columbia. $29.95. LD, $49.95. 3:36. CC. PG.

title: For Cost-Wary Businesses: Leased Help
description: THREE years ago, when Brian O'Loughlin started an asbestos-removal company, only two people were on the payroll. But business was so brisk that in two years' time the company - New England Asbestos Control of Brewster - had grown to 10 times its original size in sales volume, and last year, Mr. O'Loughlin said, the company doubled in size again.

title: Economic Watch; Curing the Greenhouse Effect Could Run Into the Trillions
description: World political leaders may be rushing to broad accord on the urgent need to halt global warming, but since the mid-1980's economists have been worrying about the bill. Their misgivings have been deepened by recent estimates of the cost of limiting emissions of carbon dioxide, which is the primary cause of the problem.

title: Foe of Gandhi Stung by Accusations of C.I.A. Role
description: An independent Indian politician believed to be working behind the scenes for Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has accused the leader of the political opposition, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, of collaborating with the United States Central Intelligence Agency and a private American foundation to obtain a $1 million grant.

title: Miss Bohan to Marry Dr. James Bono
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Bohan of Stuart, Fla., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Marguerite Marie Bohan and Dr. James Vincent Bono, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Rudolph F. Bono of Englewood, N.J.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate Capital Gains: One of two procedural votes on a motion to halt debate on a proposal to reduce the capital gains tax rate permanently and to permit tax-free withdrawals from individual retirement accounts. (Sixty votes were needed.) Failed both times, with 51 in favor and 47 opposed, Nov. 14. $ Connecticut Dodd (D) N Lieberman (D) Y New Jersey Bradley (D) N Lautenberg (D) N New York D'Amato (R) Y Moynihan (D) N House Pay Raise: Vote on passage of a bill that would raise the pay of House members, Federal judges and top Government officials by more than a third over the next two years. It would prohibit House members from accepting speaking fees from outside groups and it would tighten rules on gifts, travel and outside earnings. Approved 252 to 174, Nov. 16. $ Connecticut 1. Houghton (R) Y KEY Y Yea; N Nay; (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

title: Nutrasweet's Bitter Fight
description: For a company with such a sweet product, the Nutrasweet Company plays a tough game of corporate hardball.

title: Groups Prod Banks on Aid For Housing
description: LEAD: PRODDED by community organizations and a l2-year-old Federal mandate, six large New Jersey banks have pledged about 75 million in reduced-rate mortgages and home improvement loans, housing grants and other services that the groups say were eliminated as a result of deregulation and mergers.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ADVENTURES OF A PHOTOGRAPHER IN LA PLATA. By Adolfo Bioy Casares. Translated by Suzanne Jill Levine. (Dutton, $18.95.) The future will remember the Argentine writer Adolfo Bioy Casares as the close friend and collaborator of Jorge Luis Borges. It will also acknowledge his novels ''The Dream of Heroes'' and the remarkable ''The Invention of Morel.

title: Old Suffolk Farm Gets a New Life
description: LEAD: TWELVE years ago, Bob and Jean Benner, schoolteachers with romantic ideas about farming, sold their small house in Northport and bought a decrepit, rambling farmhouse on 14 1/2 acres of farmland in Setauket.

title: ON GUARD AGAINST GANGS AT A LOS ANGELES SCHOOL
description: At Jordan High School, in the heart of Watts, it is forbidden to wear brown or green or purple, to sport colored belts or sneakers or a hat of any kind, to display a bandanna or wear braided hair or more than one stud earring.

title: THE ARTS, FOR WHAT THEY'RE WORTH
description: PRICING THE PRICELESS Art, Artists, and Economics. By William D. Grampp. 290 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: 20th-Century Art, $20 Million Prices
description: AFTER a five-year run of higher and higher prices, the art market shows few signs of leveling off. But tastes are beginning to shift from French Impressionism to modern and contemporary art. Even the Japanese, who have shown that they will pay unheard of prices for choice Impressionists, are moving into 20th-century art as the supply of important Renoirs, Manets and Monets is beginning to dry up.

title: FEARFUL SUMMITRY
description: THE GREAT UNIVERSAL EMBRACE Arms Summitry - A Skeptic's Account. By Kenneth L. Adelman. 366 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FOOTBALL
description: LEAD: THE FIGHTING SPIRIT: A Championship Season at Notre Dame. By Lou Holtz with John Heisler. (Pocket Books, $18.95.) On Jan. 1, 1988, Lou Holtz headed to the locker room. He absolutely hates to lose, he tells us, and his team, the fighting Irish of the University of Notre Dame, had just lost the Cotton Bowl.

title: Financial Life Preservers for Disasters
description: The financial aftershocks from last month's California earthquake and Hurricane Hugo in September are still being felt.

title: Livia J. Ling Wed To Dr. R. P. Lee
description: The First Presbyterian Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Livia J. Ling, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William S. M. Ling of New York, to Dr. Ronald P. Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jan Lee of New York. The Rev. John B. Macnab performed the ceremony.

title: Some Tales From a Justice Of the Peace
description: MARY and Rudy went for a bike ride. Along the way, they got married. As a justice of the peace in the town of Kent, I have been called upon to unite couples in matrimony in a wide variety of circumstances and settings.

title: DATA UPDATE: November 19, 1989
Ferry Stays Put
description: The Los Angeles Clippers, the National Basketball Association team Danny Ferry shunned, has traded the N.B.A. rights to Ferry to the Cleveland Cavaliers, a team he admires, but that doesn't mean Ferry will be returning to the United States from Italy any time soon.

title: South Norwalk's Faith in Muralist Repaid with Work of Art
description: LEAD: WHEN Brechin Morgan completed his first mural in Norwalk in 1978, it was not just an artistic start for him, it was also the beginning of South Norwalk's revitalization. Now, as the artist's and the area's reputations have grown, Mr. Morgan has decided to repay the city's earlier faith in him by painting his fourth mural.

title: New Protest in Prague Follows Beating Death
description: Defiant Czechoslovaks staged a fresh protest in central Prague today, and in a new challenge to the Communist authorities, actors began a weeklong strike to protest police brutality.

title: The Last Time Around for Largent
description: Dexter Manley, no longer a member of the Washington Redskins, has joined Pete Rose in the limbo of a lifetime ban. Manley is now a three-time loser to the National Football League's substance-abuse policy. Rose accepted his sentence despite his denials that he bet on baseball as the Cincinnati Reds' manager. And almost daily, other sports personalities are in the headlines for questionable, if not criminal, behavior.

title: Sonya E. Querido Wed
description: Sonya Estelle Querido, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Querido of Sao Paulo, Brazil, and Mark Steven Abrams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Abrams of Providence, R.I., were married last evening at the Community Church of New York. The Rev. George Robinson, a Unitarian minister, officiated. Mrs. Abrams, 30 years old, is a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank; Mr. Abrams, 35, is a vice president of Bear Stearns & Company. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: After the Streets, a Second Chance
description: ELEVEN women ranging in age from the early 20's to the upper 30's gathered recently in Hempstead before an audience made up of judges, probation officers and the women's loved ones. Half a year ago all the women faced various charges - larceny, assault, possession of drugs or drug paraphernalia, or prostitution - and here, now, many of them faced the same judges and probation officers.

title: Lifestyle: Evening Hours; From 5th Ave. to SoHo; A Whirl of Benefit Parties
description: Part of Fifth Avenue was turned into a fashionable block party last Tuesday night when Bulgari at 57th Street and Fendi at 56th Street held gala openings of their new stores. Luciano Pavarotti wore a brocaded cape from the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Rigoletto'' to promenade between the two Roman establishments.

title: Peter Lawson-Johnston Jr. Is Engaged To Wed Karen Gallagher in February
description: Mrs. Joseph L. Gallagher of Milton and Harwich Port, Mass., has made known the engagement of her daughter Karen Ann Gallagher to Peter Lawson-Johnston Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawson-Johnston of Princeton, N.J. A February wedding is planned.

title: A Small Country, Turbulent Decade
description: In the 10-year-old civil war in El Salvador, 70,000 people have died and about one-tenth of the population has been uprooted. Here is a history of the conflict. 1979: Reform-minded Army officers stage coup in hopes of stemming appeal of guerrillas, but new junta's efforts to call elections are thwarted. 1980: Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero is assassinated; killer is never caught, but United States says ''convincing evidence'' links Roberto D'Aubuisson, founder of rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance, or Arena, to the killing. Leftist guerrillas unite. In December, rightist death squads kill six leftist political leaders and three American nuns and a lay worker. Five National Guard members are later convicted of killing the church women. In December, Jose Napoleon Duarte, a Christian Democrat, becomes President in junta. 1981: Killings by rightist death squads increase. In January, a land redistribution official and two Americans working with him are killed; two National Guard members are later convicted. Guerrilla offensive fails to set off insurrection. Army is accused of massacres of civilians. American assistance grows. 1982-3: Elections for constituent assembly are held despite leftist boycott and violence. Rightists win dominance. Human rights worker is murdered in March 1983, and in fall weekly total of murders by death squads exceeds 200. Army has only limited success in subduing guerrilla offensive in southwest. New Constitution goes into effect in December. 1984: Mr. Duarte defeats Mr. d'Aubuisson in voting for President and is inaugurated in June. Initial talks between Government and rebels end in recriminations. 1985-86: Reports of political murders decline; efforts to arrange peace talks fail. An earthquake kills 2,000 people. 1987: El Salvador takes part in Central American peace talks, which begin but are canceled after murder of human rights leader, apparently by rightists. Two leftist political leaders, Ruben Zamora and Guillermo Ungo, return from exile. 1988: Mr. Duarte is told he has terminal liver cancer. His party loses legislative elections to Arena. Rebels assassinate at least eight mayors. 1989: In February, Government and rebels open new negotiations in Mexico. Alfredo Cristiani of Arena wins presidential election and promises to curb party's terrorism. Vice President Dan Quayle meets with Mr. Cristiani and Mr. d'Aubuisson; Mr. Quayle says United States will not tolerate human rights abuses. Rebels launch strongest offensive of war. As fighting subsides, six Jesuit priests are killed by uniformed gunmen.

title: Those Stay-Forever Sidewalk Bridges
description: TEN years after falling masonry killed a Barbard College student and inspired a rigorous new law governing the maintenance of building facades in New York City, vast expanses of Manhattan sidewalk have been covered by scaffolding and protective bridges in a surge of facade repairs.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions last Sunday about changes in Eastern Europe misstated the new name of the Hungarian Communist Party. It is the Socialist Party, not the Socialist Workers Party.

title: Abortion Rights Bill Introduced in the House
description: House supporters of abortion rights have introduced a bill that would write into law the 1973 Supreme Court ruling legalizing abortion.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold $259,000 112 Broad Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 47-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, sun porch, partially finished basement; taxes $2,175. Hamilton $91,500 2330 South Clinton Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $1,080. Jackson $96,000 127 Whispering Oaks Way 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old condominium apartment; w/w carpeting, c/a, monthly maintenance $74; taxes $919. Lakewood $122,000 155 Glenn Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; porch, dining room, c/a, 1-car garage; taxes $1,800. Livingston $188,000 11 Pitcairn Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; den, 1-car garage, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,556. Short Hills $520,000 6 Northern Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; fireplace in the living room, 2-car garage, c/a; taxes $6,531. OTHER AREAS Katonah, N.Y. $351,500 44 Old Aspetong Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 20-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, family room, eat-in kitchen, 3,200 square feet, 0.5 acre; taxes $6,918. Bristol, Conn. $124,000 36 Batt Place 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; office on lower level, fenced yard; taxes $1,400. Massapequa Park, L.I. $175,000 112 Monroe Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300.

title: Pa-Rum-Pum-Pum-Pum
description: IF THERE'S A HUB OF THE ANnual whirlwind that is Christmas in New York, it's probably Rockefeller Center - the famous tree, the skating rink, the strolling carolers and brass, not to mention the likelihood that more tourists carrying more gift-wrapped packages toddle through there than any other place on earth. This season, amid the regular hoopla, there'll be, literally, a different drummer. Two, actually, each made out of fiberglass and standing 10 1/2 feet tall (not including the plumes in their hats). Plus two equally outsized buglers, a flutist and a cymbalist. The six Christmas cadets, as they're being called by the Rockefeller Center Management Corporation, are to be installed on Nov. 28 and 29, on the esplanade above the skating rink, three each on the north and south sides.

title: New Ppularity as Markets Become More Global
description: As an organized industry, the language translation business is an infant on the verge of growing up. Though a huge global market exists - estimates range from $10 billion to $25 billion a year - it is served largely by thousands of freelancers, agencies of five people or fewer and corporate translation staffs. Amazingly, in 1989, the top 10 translation companies worldwide controlled less than 1 percent of the global market, with combined revenues estimated at $100 million.

title: Welcome To Politics
description: Hungarians say proudly, and rightly, that they have gone furthest toward political reform in Eastern Europe. There will be truly free elections by spring, without the restrictions Solidarity had to accept in Poland.

title: Plant Conversion: Technical Pitfalls
description: ENGINEERS are forever telling visitors to places like Shoreham that nuclear plants make electricity the same way that oil- or gas-fired plants do: by making steam, which is converted into mechanical energy in a turbine, which then turns a generator. Much of this is true. But even the non-nuclear side of a plant like Shoreham has substantial differences from a conventional plant, and those differences may become extremely clear in the next two months or so.

title: 'A Day Without Art' to Mark Aids Losses
description: LEAD: THE devastating impact of AIDS on the arts community will be marked in a nationwide event on Dec. 1 entitled ''A Day Without Art: A National Day of Action and Mourning.'' Two county organizations, the Katonah Gallery and the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York at Purchase, are among the more than 400 institutions that will honor friends and colleagues who have died or are dying of AI

title: Woodcarver's Chain Saw Gives Life to Roadside Menagerie
description: KATHLEEN BROUGH, a certified public accountant who lives in Rutherford, wanted something a little different for her birthday. Her husband, David Isralowitz, a physician, ''wanted to be the first on my block to have a seven-foot bear.''

title: Sanctions
description: To the Editor:

title: A Literary Voice Still Vocal After 25 Years
description: LEAD: THE Small Pond, an independent literary magazine published in Stratford, is celebrating its 25th anniversary, and the Stratford Public Library is commemorating the occasion by putting nearly all 77 issues on display throughout November.

title:
FOCUS;
Japanese Influx Buoys Home Sales in Central Ohio
description: LEAD: The influx of Japanese families in the 80's has buoyed the housing market in the northwestern suburbs of Columbus, where they have concentrated, at a time when sales generally have weakened.

title: A Prepared Mind Urged in Sports
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ban on Journal Erodes Thais' Tolerant Image
description: Although Thailand's ban on the import and sale of The Asian Wall Street Journal is likely to be temporary, it is certain to diminish the country's reputation for tolerance. The damage has increased as the Government considers a similar ban on the weekly Far Eastern Economic Review.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Fathers, Daughters And Dancing
description: LEAD: AS I was thinking about what I would say on the topic of ''Daughters and Fathers'' at our yearly Women's Day at the women's college where I teach, I met a young woman who told me that she used to dread high school dances. When I asked her why, she said that her father died when she was young and as a result she had never learned to dance.

title: Preserve the Classic Balance . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Industrial Policy at the Pentagon
description: IN the 1960's and 1970's, a small Pentagon office called the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency helped create an explosion of innovation in computer research that has had an immense impact on the American economy. Acting independently and without the bureaucratic strings that often shackle Government organizations, the agency served as a de facto venture capitalist for the American computer industry. By paying for innovative research in university and corporate laboratories, it almost single-handedly created the field of computer science in the United States.

title: Has Putting on The Glitz Become Passe?
description: Popular culture has always mirrored its times and, as the 1980's draw to a close, efforts are inevitably being made to single out those arts, artifacts and entertainments that perhaps best reflected the spirit and values of the decade. Where was the Reagan Era captured, even if unintentionally, most vividly? As far as television is concerned, an obvious candidate would be the series ''Dynasty,'' with its weekly servings of unbridled ambitions and black-tie-and-gown glamour, all overseen by the ruthless Alexis. Another, certainly, would be any mini-series based on a novel by Judith Krantz. The Krantz formula is an unvarying blend of money, power and conspicuous consumption, spiced heavy-handedly with sex.

title: TO THE HAREM BORN
description: LEAD: REGARDS FROM THE DEAD PRINCESS Novel of a Life. By Kenize Mourad. Translated by Sabine Destree, Anna Williams and Kenize Mourad. 562 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing/ Little, Brown & Company.

title: Gail Ostrove to Marry Robert Kantor
description: Gail J. Ostrove and Robert A. Kantor are planning a March wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ostrove of Roslyn, L.I., have announced. Mr. Kantor is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Kantor of New York.

title: At an Iceless High School, Hockey Team Takes Up Dancing
description: HARRY Streep has been teaching contemporary dance classes for nearly 10 years. He has taught the young, the old, the fit and the unfit, and until the New Rochelle High School hockey team entered his class a couple of months ago he thought he had seen it all.

title: Let's Go Again
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
MUSIC;
Chamber Group Seeks A Broader Audience
description: LEAD: THE All Seasons Chamber Players, now in its eighth year of performing, has worked aggressively to fill the need for chamber music concerts in several local communities. The five-member ensemble, which will play about a dozen concerts this season, wants to make chamber music easily and widely available and, to that end, gives many free concerts.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cold-water faucet in my bathroom sink gives off a loud whistling or humming noise whenever it is turned on. The noise stops when the faucet is turned on all the way. I tried tightening the screw on top of the faucet handle, but this did not help. Can you tell me how to eliminate this noise?

title: Redmen Motivated By Harvey's Debut
description: Inspired by the return of Boo Harvey, St. John's defeated Houston by 76-69 at Alumni Hall last night in the second round of the Dodge National Invitation Tournament.

title: A Better Chance for Minority Students
description: LEAD: GABRIEL AGUILERA is spending his first year out of college in New Canaan helping students in an academic program that helped him get into Stanford University. Mr. Aguilera, who graduated in June, is a resident tutor for A Better Chance, which brings black, Hispanic and Asian students who are in the top 10 percent of their classes to

title: Review/Opera; Monteverdi's 'Ritorno d'Ulisse,' in Two Versions
description: Ignorance is at once the most confining and liberating of intellectual states. Produce ''Parsifal'' today and we know a lot to begin with. Wagner's written wishes for his operas - instruments, tempos, tone, stagecraft - speak sternly and specifically. The way is well marked, allowable deviation made minimal.

title: New-Music Festival; Brooklyn Ensemble And Moondog's Return
description: From either inclination or a lack of opportunity, composers who frequent New Music America festivals do not normally write for symphonic forces. Not all the festivals have even offered such extravaganzas. But this year's 10th-anniversary festival gathered itself together Thursday night for a Brooklyn Philharmonic program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater - which has already proven itself a fine acoustical venue for such events.

title: Yale Deprived Of Outright Title
description: A Harvard team that could do no wrong upset a Yale team doing little that was right today before a crowd of 59,263 in the Yale Bowl. The loss, by a 37-20 score in the 106th contest of the 109-year-old rivalry, deprived the Bulldogs of the outright Ivy League championship. They had to share the title with Princeton, both finishing with 6-1 records in the league.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: JOURNEY TO THE STARS: Space Exploration - Tomorrow and Beyond. By Robert Jastrow. (Bantam, $18.95.) Robert Jastrow is one of a few rare scientists who are accomplished both in their scientific disciplines and in their ability to convey their knowledge and enthusiasm to nonscientists. Mr. Jastrow, a professor of earth sciences at Dartmouth College, is the author of several popular science books, including ''Red Giants and White Dwarfs.

title: How the Wall Was Cracked - A Special Report; Party Coup Turned East German Tide; CLAMOR IN THE EAST
description: The turning point came on Oct. 7, after the Communist Party leader, Erich Honecker, ordered security forces to be prepared to open fire on demonstrators in Leipzig - a ''Chinese solution'' to the rising tide of dissent in East Germany.

title: Lifestyle; If You Don't Bid, It's Pure Theater
description: Nearly an hour before the sale began, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Patlis stood inside the front door at Sotheby's watching dozens of limousines pull up to the auction house at York Avenue and 72d Street. As crowds began flocking into the building, flashbulbs from the paparazzi illuminated people like Walter H. Annenberg, the former United States Ambassador to Britain, and Elle Macpherson, the Australian model, the singer Andy Williams and the writer Tom Wolfe.

title: Susan R. Mankin Wed in Delaware
description: The wedding of Susan Ruth Mankin and Alvaro Bustamante took place yesterday at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del. The Rev. Dr. Adam Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Bustamante, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hart Tiller Mankin of Wilmington, Del. The bride was until recently a food and beverage manager for Continental Companies in Coconut Grove, Fla. She graduated from the Sanford School and the University of Delaware. Her father, who recently retired as a vice president and general counsel of the Columbia Gas System Service Corporation in Wilmington, served as general counsel of the Department of the Navy and of the General Services Administration in the Nixon Administration. He has been nominated by President Bush to be an associate judge of the United States Court of Veterans Appeals in Washington. The bride's mother, Ruth L. Mankin, recently retired as a vice president of the Delaware State Chamber of Commerce in Wilmington.

title: Exxon Valdez's Sea of Litigation
description: Can a bartender in Anchorage claim damages for tips he might have received from fishermen thrown out of work as a result of the Exxon Valdez spill?

title: Graves Matters
description: QUICK, WHEN WAS the last time you drank a white Bordeaux? If it was long ago - or never - don't be upset. Most American wine buffs are no different: they may think of red Bordeaux as the king of wines but of white Bordeaux they rarely think at all.

title: BRANAGH'S 'HENRY V'
description: LEAD: To the Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Clearly we're in a full-blown automotive recession with plenty of implications for the industrial sector. The next three to six months in Detroit are going to be tough.'' Scott Merlis, analyst at Morgan Stanley.

title: Woman Dies in Bus Accident
description: A tourist bus on a foggy Golan Heights highway swerved, apparently to avoid a car, and overturned into a ravine today, killing a West German woman and injuring the bus driver, a guide and 48 West German passengers, the police said. Druse villagers, Jewish settlers, military doctors and emergency medical service workers from the nearby town of Qiryat Shemona helped in the rescue operations. The police said the accident occurred on the Masada-Banias road in the Golan Heights.

title: Cabaret Polishes Its Image As a Solo Act With Attitude
description: For most Americans, the term ''cabaret,'' if it suggests anything at all, probably conjures up movie images of a hyperkinetic Liza Minnelli and an epicene Joel Grey in a squalid Berlin dive on the eve of the Nazi era. In the film ''Cabaret,'' the Minnelli character's invocation of ''divine decadence'' helped stamp the very word ''cabaret'' with intimations of depravity that it unfortunately still carries.

title: U.N. Inquiry Says Iran Still Abuses Human Rights
description: A United Nations investigator says the Iranian Government of Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani is continuing to violate its citizens' basic human rights on the same large scale as Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Government, torturing and executing political enemies.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Use of Historic Princeton Tract Disputed
description: LEAD: A 122.4-ACRE farm where Quakers settled in the 17th century and George Washington sighted the British before the Battle of Princeton is the focus of a dispute between a developer who wants to build housing on part of it and conservationists who want to keep it intact.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Claire Lang von Arnold, Fashion Expert, 91
description: Claire Lang von Arnold, a fashion consultant and retailing executive, died of pneumonia Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

title: Fashion: On the Street; Seeing Double and Triple And Quadruple and . . .
description: Karl Lagerfeld's suits for Chanel and his own KL collection do get around. His red and black Chanel number, for instance, which sells for about $14,000 in Paris, can be seen at right, heading in opposite directions. At that price one wouldn't think the odds were in favor of two of these custom-made suits showing up at the same spot at the same time, but that just goes to show how popular Mr. Lagerfeld's clothes currently are. His ready-made houndstooth check jacket in black and white for KL, below, is a much bigger seller at $1,300. It has velvet-trimmed patch pockets and cuffs, and seven KL buttons running up to a high collarless neck. The designer has also cut the same fabric into a more conventional jacket style, far right, with the velvet limited to the collar and sleeves.

title: Condo Repairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Sandbox, Right to the Box Office
description: This weekend, the most influential filmgoer in your household might just be the one who's mashing Play-Doh on the living-room floor. Children are more eagerly courted by the film industry at Thanksgiving than at any other season. And this year's competition is hotter than ever, bringing three new children's feature films - the Disney version of ''The Little Mermaid,'' Don Bluth's ''All Dogs Go to Heaven'' and the live-action ''Prancer,'' about a girl who befriends a reindeer - in a single week.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ATLANTA;
Tower Due in '90 Now 40% Leased
description: LEAD: THE first new major downtown office building since 1982 - the 50-story, 1.2 million-square-foot 191 Peachtree Tower - is already 40 percent leased, by two law firms, even though occupancy is not expected until late next year. The project is being built at a cost of more than $200 million. Developers of three nearby sites are expected to start construction soon.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: A brief announcement by the American Contract Bridge League in Lancaster, Pa. 10 days ago marked the end of a five-year battle. The League's board of directors did away with simultaneous Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs at future National Championships. ''Instead,'' according to the League, ''there will be an Open Pairs opposite the Women's Pairs.''

title: O'Brien Showing Effects of Pounding
description: If history, and the Jets' offensive line, repeat, Ken O'Brien will be sacked some time tonight at the Hoosier Dome.

title: U.S. Envoy Returns to Lebanon to See New Leader
description: The American Ambassador to Lebanon, John McCarthy, returned here today to present his credentials to the new President of Lebanon, two months after the Ambassador and 29 embassy employees were evacuated from Beirut for security reasons.

title: POSTINGS: Shops, Apartments, Offices; At a Project's Core, an 1840 House and a Barn
description: Five buildings including an 1840 Greek Revival house and its barn are being developed into shops, apartments and offices in the Kings Highway Historic District in Westport, Conn. Called Westport Commons, the $3.5 million project on two acres on Post Road is to be finished next month.

title: Mary A. Krieger, Lawyer, Marries
description: Mary Allana Krieger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Krieger of Summit and Monmouth Beach, N.J., was married yesterday to Dennis Russell O'Brien, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. O'Brien of Elizabeth and Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. William Waters, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. He was assisted by the Revs. James Bouffard and Beatus Lucey.

title:
ART;
Lehman Makes Modernism More Vivid
description: LEAD: MARSDEN HARTLEY'S art always displays a quirky beauty no matter what the subjects or style in which it's painted. His 1916 ''Abstraction,'' an amalgam of pale, rough geometric forms that unavoidably read like a long-necked figure, is no exception. It has recently been donated to the Lehman College Art Gallery collection by Pierre and Dorothy Brodin and is the focal point of a valuable exhibition entitled ''American Modernists: The Paris Experience'' on the

title: A 5th Reason
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Once Again, Vietnamese Are Turned Out to Sea
description: THE irascible Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, recently caused a stir when he used the word ''scum'' to describe Vietnamese boat people who remain here after Western resettlement countries select those among them who qualify as refugees. ''Why should we be responsible?'' Mr. Mahathir asked. ''We did not cause the Vietnam War.''

title: Liechtenstein
description: To the Editor: My husband and I were in Liechtenstein (''What's Doing in Liechtenstein,'' July 23) in June and were very impressed with the country.

title: War on Drugs, Suffolk Steps Up Razing of Houses
description: RESPONDING in warlike fashion to concern about street drug dealing, Suffolk County and the Town of Babylon have stepped up their bulldozing of crack houses.

title:
IN SHORT;
FOOTBALL
description: LEAD: NOSE TO NOSE: Survival in the Trenches of the NFL. By Joe Klecko, Joe Fields and Greg Logan. (Morrow, $18.95.) In this latest as-told-to chroncile of life in the National Football League, two of the last pick-and-shovel men in professional sports get in their final licks. The linemen Joe Klecko and Joe Fields - who anchored the New York Jets's defense and offense, respectively, for more than a decade and helped restore some of the luster of the Joe Namath era to a moribund franchise - were dispatched after the 1987 season with all the ceremony of an oil change.

title: Ways to Combat Dumping in the Parks
description: The article ''Parks Are Becoming Dumping Grounds'' illustrates the many problems the State of New Jersey is facing because of the closing of many municipal landfills.

title: Judy Arlene Katz Wed To Jeffrey T. Hoffman
description: The marriage of Judy Arlene Katz, the daughter of Robert A. Katz of South Orange, N.J., and Colleen Katz of New York, and Jeffrey Todd Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Hoffman of North Brunswick, N.J., took place last evening at Temple Anshe Emeth in New Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Bennett Miller officiated. Mrs. Hoffman, a graduate of Ramapo College, is a programmer at the Chubb & Son insurance company in Warren, N.J., where her husband, a Rutgers University graduate, is a business analyst. The couple, both 27 years old, received diplomas from the Chubb Institute of Computer Technology.

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week:Tidy up the perennial border by cutting to the ground stalks and stems; add them as a layer on the compost pile. Finish sweeping up driveways, walks and patios and rake leaves once more for compost. Store any summer furniture, still outdoors. Winterizing

title: India's Monumental Reliquary
description: INDIA, in the majestic sweep of its long history, has known glory and famine, empire and invasion. There is nothing unusual about that, but India is unique in one respect. Having invented one of the world's great religions, Buddhism, and exported it to most of Asia, it then proceeded to forget about it. Today, while Hindu temples and Muslim shrines are still fully active, one of the earliest and greatest of the world's Buddhist monuments, the Stupa of Sanchi, lies deserted by all except a very few (mostly Japanese) tourists.

title: New-Music Festival; Musica Elletronica Viva In Rare Group Visit
description: South of Houston Street but east of SoHo, five hours of electronic interactions took place on Wednesday night, with New Music America festival concerts at both the Experimental Intermedia Foundation and the Knitting Factory.

title: Edie Fuchs Is Married to John Lewis
description: Edith a'Becket Fuchs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Fuchs of Denville, N.J., was married there yesterday to John BenetLewis, a son of Rachel Benet Lewis of Watertown, Mass., and Peter A. Lewis of New York. The Rev. Robert Maitland, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Saviour.

title: Silver Pieces With Elegant Pasts and Moern Uses
description: IT all started with room service 25 years ago, Ginger Kilbane said. ''I was on business in Italy and stayed at the Excelsior Hotel in Rome,'' she recalled, ''and this chunky little coffee pot was on my breakfast tray every morning. I had to buy that pot.''

title:
ART;
Works From Central Europe
description: LEAD: CENTRAL EUROPE - the region that includes Germany, Switzerland, Austria and parts of Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, although the home of much beloved music and literature is not the most familiar of territories where visual art is concerned. The current offering at the Art Museum, Princeton University, attempts to redress the situation and often succeeds in a beguiling way.

title: Jazz Just Keeps Knocking At the Concert Hall Door
description: Jazz has been a familiar guest in the concert hall over the years, dropping in from time to time, stirring things up, then moving on to let musical life resume its more sedate patterns. Recently, though, the guest shows signs of moving in for good. Today's concertgoers pick up programs to find Ellington and Monk in spots previously reserved for Mozart and Brahms. Repertory ensembles like the American Jazz Orchestra help keep alive past jazz masterpieces. Conductors like Gunther Schuller, Maurice Peress and Marin Alsop champion jazz works as concert fare.

title: Style Makers; Jane Harris, Textile Artist
description: Jane Harris was always interested in tactile things. ''I knitted at 4,'' said the 24-year-old graduate of the Glasgow School of Art.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE NEW EUROPE;
German Integration Will Delay 1992
description: LEAD: The European Community has embarked upon a historic effort to unify the internal market of its twelve member countries, commonly known as Europe 1992. Now, however, Germany has taken center stage. Economic integration of the two Germanys will divert attention from the broader economic and political goals of Europe 1992.

title: Deng Warns Against Own Senility
description: China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, told a small group of top officials that they should not listen to him if he starts to say ''crazy things'' as he gets older and becomes less clear-minded, according to a transcript of a speech he made in September.

title: What Are Europeans Supposed to Do Next, And Who Will Get to Decide?
description: THE latest rush of change in Eastern Europe has left the West in emotional confusion as politicians struggle to interpret events that even the most astute pundits had failed to predict. Delight at the opening of the Berlin wall was followed by fears of a mass exodus of East Germans and then relief when this failed to transpire. Alarm at the prospect of a reunited Germany was followed first by reassurances that it was still years away and then by a worried recognition that it was probably inevitable.

title: 3 British Soldiers Killed in Ulster Blast
description: Three British soldiers were killed and a fourth seriously wounded today when their armored vehicle was blown up by a land mine in Northern Ireland.

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: Last weekend I decided it was time to get my snapshots in order. They were in a terrible mess, some sitting in piles, some still in the envelopes in which the processing lab had delivered them.

title: Study Links Homelessness to Housing Market in New York
description: Most homeless families who seek emergency shelter in New York City have either never had their own apartments or have lost their housing through eviction, and almost all are on public assistance, according to a study released by the city's Human Resources Administration.

title: Fair Question on Clubs
description: After more than two years of acrimony, the Senate Judiciary Committee has approved the judicial nomination of Vaughn Walker despite his longtime membership in the Olympic Club of San Francisco. The club only recently admitted blacks and still excludes women.

title: How Hair Colors One's Outlook
description: ''I HAVE found the Fountain of Youth,'' I announced elatedly to the owner of a local cheese store. The statement puzzled him until I explained that I had found a health food store of that name, which had been recommended by his staff. But as I spoke, I realized I might just as easily have been talking about myself.

title: Garden Party Whatsit
description: ONE OF THE GREAT word-pictures in the American language is >the skunk at the garden party. Think about it: There is the garden party, an elegant institution peopled with perfumed ladies in large hats and gentlemen in blazers and green pants who are holding gin fizzes. An expensive tent called a ''marquee'' is in place in case of showers; a few of the fellows slip off for a slow game of croquet, and into this strawberry-and-cream world meanders a small black animal with a white streak down its back and a bushy tail, with the potential, if it is frightened, of causing such a stink as to render anyone in the neighborhood an object of general repugnance for days. After a moment of silent horror, with the terrified guests and the frightened skunk staring at each other - panic is followed by havoc.

title: Two Magnificats
description: JoAnn Rice will conduct the Florilegium Chamber Choir and Orchestra in two German Magnificats by Heinrich Schutz at the German Church, 315 West 22d Street, at 3 o'clock today. The program also includes Bach's Cantata No. 150 and two works by Hugo Distler - a setting of the chorale ''Wachet Auf,'' to be played on the organ by Walter Hilse, and ''Totentanz,'' for chorus and narrator (the Rev. Sonke Schmidt-Lange). Tickets are $10. Information: 627-9141.

title: For Cashmere, First Stop: London
description: AMERICAN visitors to London have always counted on finding and taking home the best in certain kinds of goods: china crafted according to centuries-old tradition, rain gear that will last a lifetime, wool suits tailored to fit royalty. They also know that here they will find cashmere clothing of exquisite quality and style.

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING?
description: If Mr. Fukuyama's perceptions of the world lead him to think that soon to disappear is ''the struggle for recognition, the willingness to risk one's life for a purely abstract goal . . .'', perhaps he needs to take another look.

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING?
description: Self-congratulation is sometimes another form of ignorance, perpetuated by an unaccountable success, such as the case of Francis Fukuyama's Hegelian treatise in the neo-conservative journal The National Interest (''What Is Fukuyama Saying?'' by James Atlas, Oct. 22). Thus, the publisher Irving Kristol wants to think that his arrival in Washington ''has raised the level of discussion.'' Yet, there is also a touch of disingenuousness in Mr. Kristol's admission that he doesn't ''believe a word'' of Mr. Fukuyama's thesis, a curious comment for a publisher with some responsibility for what gets published in his journal.

title: A Tool for Examining Foreign Patents and Research
description: Translation has long been an after-thought for many American companies. But it may be gaining as cultural chauvinism goes out of style. In fact, as markets grow more global and the competition heightens, translation is becoming part of more companies' competitive artilleries.

title: FOOTBALL
description: NORTH DALLAS AFTER FORTY. By Peter Gent. (Villard, $19.95.) Talk to a football fan about ''North Dallas Forty'' and the fan smiles. It was a novel about the ribald life of a legendary (and fictitious) Dallas football team. Now the football team has grown up. It is 20 years later and Peter Gent, himself a former Dallas Cowboys flanker and tight end, has given us a sequel, this time concerning the team's reunion. Whether the fan will smile after reading ''North Dallas After Forty'' is another matter. Part of the difficulty lies in the nature of a sequel. The author rightly assumes new readers will not have read ''North Dallas Forty,'' so we are given chapter after chapter of then's and now's. The reader is jolted back and forth in time, which creates jarring breaks in the book's rhythm. With the exception of the narrator, who is drawn fully and sympathetically, the characters emerge as stick figures. The book might have benefited from a more detailed portrait of a few of the teammates as they approach their reunion. Instead Mr. Gent adds character after character to a series of improbable plots and subplots. There is the giant Dallas corporation that milks savings and loans, buys politicians, operates a drug cartel and purchases the football team with its profits. There is the Central Intelligence Agency in the form of two inept agents, a district attorney with a $300-a-day cocaine habit, the narrator's wife (who is sleeping with the evil lawyer who is handling her divorce) and the team's former coach, who as Governor of Texas is almost assassinated in a motorcade in Dallas (sound familiar?). To get his characters out of these plot machinations isn't easy, and the author opts for death - by murder, suicide, AIDS and the tumultuous rise of the Purgatory River, which sweeps some of the bad guys away. This may be a good book for those who loved the original and want to read the next installment. But between you and me, it wouldn't have hurt if the river had swept away the sequel.

title: IS DNA GETTING SMARTER?
description: THE WISDOM OF THE GENES New Pathways in Evolution. By Christopher Wills. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with the Stage View column, misidentifies the actor who portrays Maj. Manly Battle in ''Mastergate.'' He is Daniel von Bargen.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GOOD KING SAUERKRAUT. By Barbara Paul. (Scribners, $16.95.) This slight tale will do little to win new readers for the usually reliable mystery writer Barbara Paul. It centers on King Sarcowicz, a man who feels doubly cursed by his own name. King was thrust upon him at birth by a mother who ''firmly believed that a child lived up to or down to his name,'' and Sarcowicz is regularly and derisively corrupted to ''Sauerkraut'' by virtually everyone he meets.

title: Giving Thanks
description: MY daughter Lisa calls to say she will be coming for Thanksgiving. She works with the poor and it's a time some people (who otherwise forget) remember they exist. She isn't sure if she will get away until early on the holiday morning. It's a seven-hour drive but I can't talk her out of it. She is coming. Thanksgiving.

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING?
description: Francis Fukuyama's ''End of History?'' has all the earmarks of one of those intellectual fads that come along whenever academics need something new to talk about at faculty cocktail parties.

title: Rice Leads Irish Attack
description: In the bitter cold of Penn State's Happy Valley, the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame today extended the nation's longest winning streak with a powerful and cool efficiency that established a record for Nittany Lion futility.

title:
RECORDINGS;
A Musical Berlin Diary, Furtwangler-Style
description: LEAD: Most of us collect recordings one at a time, for the music or the performances each preserves. But when they are assembled in groups - as CD producers have increasingly been wont to do - they can acquire further dimensions. The collected disks of a singer tell stories of vocal development, of changing (or, sometimes, unchanging) repertory and personality.

title: WHAT YOU SEE HERE IS CULTURE
description: Museums reflect culture and to some measure control it. They collect and exhibit what their curators find instructive or exceptional. In MUSEOLOGY (Aperture, $39.95), the photographer Richard Ross presents the results of a 10-year exploration of art and natural history museums in the United States, France, England, Egypt and Greece. His delicate color photographs - disquieting images of stuffed animals, ancient torsos and marble women - are identified only by the museums where they were taken. By refusing to label his images with scientific particulars, Mr. Ross subverts the museum's mandate to educate and forces us to reconsider the nature of the institution. An odd spirit pervades rooms crammed with unlikely combinations of creatures. The French glass case holding a rhino's head is mysteriously cracked, for example; a crocodile seems to scale the wall of a shabby Cairo gallery and a young antelope emerges from storage boxes in Vienna's Naturhistorisches Museum. The one sure life sign that he uncovers is decay: lions locked in combat for decades have moth-eaten hides. If Mr. Ross stresses the deadening atmosphere of museums by focusing on sedate rows of framed paintings and encased samples of the world's wildlife, his photographs achieve a vitality of their own through humorous juxtapositions, suggestive light and, sometimes, sheer glowing beauty. The book ends with a series of Mr. Ross's own photographic triptychs, blurry appropriations of art from an earlier period, proving that museums can encourage the creative spirit as well as stifle it.

title: Election Over, the Tax Battle Resumes
description: LEAD: WITH elections over but property taxes still a major issue, political pressure remains high in Nassau and Suffolk Counties for meaningful steps to fit local taxation to the Island's new economic realities.

title: Style Makers; Teddy and Arthur Edelman, Leather Designers
description: Ten years ago, Arthur and Teddy Edelman sold their fashion leather business in Manhattan to Mitsubishi, the Japanese company, and focused exclusively on home furnishings, providing interior designers and architects with high-quality and unusually textured leathers. ''We liked fashion,'' said Teddy Edelman, who is 61 years old. ''But now that we're in the interior design business,'' she said, ''we think that is more intriguing.''

title: Buyouts Urged In a Risky Area
description: AN effort has begun here to have the Federal Government buy out six families who own houses near a coke oven in southeast Chicago where the cancer risk is high. But most of the families have indicated they would resist a buyout.

title: Vandeweghe Blamed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: PRISCILLA L. VAIL;
Making Nanny a Partner in Schooling
description: LEAD: OVER the years, schools have realized that it is not just the children who attend who need to be taught but their parents as well. Hence, more and more schools offer parenting seminars, geared to specific developmental stages of children, in addition to the Parent-Teacher Association meetings and parents nights of old.

title: Sandra C. Newing Is Wed in Capital
description: The marriage of Sandra Cornelia Newing to Peter Braestrup took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Sanford Garner officiated. Mrs. Braestrup, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stuart L. Newing of Binghamton, N.Y., graduated from Syracuse University and was, until September, the assistant to the headmaster of St. Albans Lower School in Washington. Her father, who owned several Binghamton businesses, was a founder of Harpur College, now the State University of New York at Binghamton.

title:
DANCE;
Companies Vie for 'Nutcracker' Space
description: LEAD: ON an imaginary map of the ballet world, the borough of Red Bank is a good candidate for ''Nutcracker'' capital. While New York City, 60 miles away, boasts two companies that perform ''Nutcrackers'' at holiday time, Red Bank has three and a half.

title: NONFICTION
description: CHILI DAWGS ALWAYS BARK AT NIGHT. By Lewis Grizzard. (Villard, $17.95.) Unless you happen to be as faithful a Lewis Grizzard fan as, say, my father, you might read his latest collection of Southern-fried columns from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution and find yourself asking: Who is he? What is he? Why is he? Mr. Grizzard is, in 1989, still japing about leisure suits (lime-green, of course) and ''girls whose first names end in i.'' When he does hit on a contemporary idea, like the Japanese buying up America, he devotes three columns to it, but comes up with only one funny line, that about Vanna White having ''to learn eight zillion character signs in the Japanese alphabet to keep her job.'' (There is another funny bit, on talking in code in a Soviet hotel room to confuse the K.G.B. ''maid.'' ''Roger. The big polar bear walks late'' is translated, ''Dang right. I'm going over to a bar tonight at a hotel where they are supposed to have ice.'') Other than the Japanese, his favorite targets are fat women, women golfers, and liberal Democrats, which raises the question of what exactly Mr. Grizzard stands for. His objections to men wearing neckties would seem to disqualify him from the Grand Old Party. Perhaps, considering his baiting of professional athletes who speak substandard English, he is one of those states' rights Democrats. My guess is that Mr. Grizzard thinks of himself as a good ol' bad-boy, what with his bathroom jokes (see book title) and studied yahooism. But he lacks the demonic inspiration to truly offend anyone. Nor does his heart seem to be in his trademark autobiographical asides about his heart-valve operations, fear of flying, former wives, sex life. He is a curmudgeon with opinions but no conviction, the Andy Rooney of the Sahara of the Bozart.

title: WHAT I OWE TO UNCLE BOB
description: FAMILY PORTRAITS Remembrances by Twenty Distinguished Writers. Edited by Carolyn Anthony. Illustrated. 328 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: 'Breaking the Code': The Enigma Man
description: ''BREAKING THE CODE,'' the Hugh Whitemore drama now being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is about the waste of a natural resource. In this case, that resource was Alan Turing, the English mathematician-cum-British war hero.

title: A Child's Shooting Death Compels His Mother to Action
description: INSIDE the small red house on Hemlock Lane in Naugatuck, Susan M. Kenney tore gently at a tissue as she talked about the morning of June 22.. Around 10:30 A.M., she said, a friend phoned her at work to say that there had been a gun accident involving her 12-year-old son David.

title: Bavaro and Allegre Out for 6 Weeks
description: The Giants placed Raul Allegre, pro football's leading kicker this season, and Mark Bavaro, perhaps the sport's best tight end, on injured reserve today. They activated Bjorn Nittmo, a kicker, from their developmental squad and Steve DeOssie, an inside linebacker, from injured reserve.

title: Abigail Ross to Wed Pierce Sioussat
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Carl Ross of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abigail Hale Ross, to Pierce Stewart Sioussat, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Stewart Sioussat of Cooperstown, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: Collectors seeking a small but expensive collection can turn to the coins of the Aloha State. Hawaii has a limited set of coins, just seven.

title: Ms. Orenstein, Lawyer, To Marry in January
description: The engagement of Sara Orenstein to David Matthew Kober, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kober of Pleasantville, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Florence Orenstein and Arthur Orenstein, both of Great Neck, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: Bent Larsen uttered his pronouncement, ''I don't trust long variations,'' many years ago. Yet every once in a while someone gets caught failing to heed the eminent Danish grandmaster's warning.

title: The Bill of Rights, for Rent
description: Join Philip Morris and the National Archives in celebrating the 200th anniversary of the Bill of Rights. For a free copy of this historic document, call . . .

title: POSTINGS: SoHo Renovation; 24 Cast-Iron Condominiums
description: Four Manhattan developers are renovating two SoHo buildings that originally were built in 1880 as garment warehouses. They will be combined into a common structure with 24 commercial condominiums that would be used for professional purposes such as offices for lawyers and architects. The project, at 20-26 Greene Street between Grand and Canal Streets, is expected to cost $4.4 million and be finished next summer.

title: Hey, Dude, Like NEH-oh Way!
description: I HAVE NEVER MUCH LIKED THE WAY I TALK. IN UPSTATE New York, where I was raised, people said things like ''Lemme have a HEE-am SEEN-wich'' and ''You scared the BEE-JEES-us outa me.'' It had no grace. Nowhere in our local speech was there the hint of a drawl, or any majestic New England tones, or even a trace of downstate Brooklynese - which can sound almost poetic if you are in the right mood. No, up in the lovely glens of New York we went around loudly meowing through our noses, saying ''Everything's gist FEE-an-TEE-astic, FEE-ab-ulos!'' and scaring the bejesus out of one another.

title: Capitalism Arrives in Hungary With a Vengeance
description: The gold rush is on in the new Republic of Hungary, even before the shape of its future government is clear.

title: Building Service Networks to Pleasue Multinationals
description: Few in the translation industry have made the leap from cottage to corporation, but Berlitz and Alpnet are notable exceptions. Both have gone global, mainly through acquisitions, to become among the world's largest translation companies.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: BILL OF RIGHTS

title: Groups Try to Save Woodlands Tract
description: LEAD: With two sets of official wheels slowly turning, the fate of a 49-acre tract of woodlands here has become of urgent concern to many village residents.

title: How to Do Justice to the Native Cranberry
description: FOR many Americans, cranberries are thought of only once a year, as a sauce or condiment to serve alongside turkey. If turkey happens to make it to the dinner table more than once a year, then the cranberries will accompany it on those occasions as well. That does not do justice to the native cranberry.

title: Freedom Danced Before My Eyes
description: LEAD: From the moment the Berlin wall was erected in August 1961, statesmen, journalists, poets and philosophers have struggled to describe the evil of this concrete and steel symbol of oppression. Ultimately, however, rhetorical outrage, no matter how eloquent, was no match for the wall or the twisted sensibilities of its architects.

title: Review/Opera; 'A Precis of Privilege' Concludes Fagan's 'Story'
description: The movements in Garth Fagan's dances resemble beads on a string. Such a statement could be made about the creations of many choreographers. What makes Mr. Fagan's works distinctive is the fact that he likes to string together oddly assorted beads of movement. Just as an unconventional necklace might have a round bead next to a square one and a rough bead next to a smooth one, so Mr. Fagan's dances abound with fragmentary steps and unexpected starts and stops. Watching them, one is impressed not by the harmony of the movements, but by the way they are juxtaposed.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
The Return of the Basic, Levitt-Style House
description: LEAD: BUILDERS of several new projects on Long Island are offering an option that William Levitt made popular in the 40's and 50's - a house with unfinished space, to keep the cost down but provide room for growth. The option was largely discarded by developers during the boom times that followed but now seems to making a comeback.

title: A Capital Gains I.R.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathleen Kelly Becomes Bride of Gary J. Malone
description: Kathleen Anne Kelly, a psychiatric social-work supervisor at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, and Gary J. Malone, an assistant New York State Attorney General, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York. The Rev. Kevin Madigan performed the ceremony.

title: The Treasury's 'Mr. Diffident'
description: Some Treasury Secretaries over the years have dominated their Administration's economic policies with their political skills and their strong personalities. James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary in Ronald Reagan's second term, and John B. Connally, who served two years under Richard M. Nixon, are cases in point. They were glib and outspoken, politically ambitious, familiar faces on television and crafty manipulators of the press - men who caused heads to turn when they entered crowded rooms.

title: FOOTBALL
description: BO. By Bo Schlembeckler and Mitch Albom. (Warner, $17.95.) For 20 years, Bo Schembechler has coached the University of Michigan Wolverines, and if success is to be measured by the number of postseason bowl appearances and Big Ten championships a team earns, he has to be judged one of this country's premier college football coaches. But like other college coaches who have reached the status of demigods - Paul (Bear) Bryant and Mr. Schembechler's mentor, Woody Hayes, leap immediately to mind - he has a reputation for toughness, meanness, bad temper and downright unpleasant behavior both on and off the field. With the help of Mitch Albom, a columnist for The Detroit Free Press, Bo, as he has been known ever since one of his sisters couldn't quite get her lips around the word brother, is out to set the record straight. Beneath this hard-nosed exterior beats the heart of a highly moral, dedicated man, deeply concerned with the best interests of his student athletes. And the funny things is, after readng ''Bo,'' you will likely come away thinking that if you had a son and he had the ability to play college football, you wouldn't mind putting him in the hands of Bo Schembechler. Deservedly or not, Mr. Schembechler has the reputation of being a conservative, predictable coach. He gives a very creditable argument that this reputation is underserved, but in many ways this book follows a conservative, predictable formula. There are wonderful chapters on Hayes and Bryant and some interestng ideas on how to motivate a team, but for the most part the rest of the book is rather hum-drum - no startling revelations here. Nevertheless, if you're sitting around on a Saturday afternoon and there's no game on television, you could do a lot worse than propping your feet up, grabbing a beer and spending a couple of hours with''Bo.''

title: Advice for Hess
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Proper Storage of Equipment for Spring
description: LEAD: AN important but often neglected fall task is that of putting equipment and supplies away for winter in good condition so they will be ready for use when spring arrives.

title: 2 Grandmas Scale High Tor
description: WHILE most families and friends routinely get together on birthdays, Thanksgiving, Christmas and other holidays, for 30 years every fall we have upheld a tradition of climbing High Tor, at 832 feet the tallest peak in the Palisades, towering above the village of Haverstraw.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; A Strategy for Fairfield's Office Vacancies
description: IN the 20-odd years since Fairfield County was initiated into the wonderful world of office buildings, it has taken its lumps for overdeveloping and overpricing. But despite a third-quarter vacancy rate of 21.7 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield Realtors of Stamford, the market survives.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cold-water faucet in my bathroom sink gives off a loud whistling or humming noise whenever it is turned on. The noise stops when the faucet is turned on all the way. I tried tightening the screw on top of the faucet handle, but this did not help. Can you tell me how to eliminate this noise?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WARREN, VT.;
Buyers Calling Ski Condo Tune
description: LEAD: AN overabundance of condominiums in this central Vermont community's Sugarbush Valley ski area has led to a buyer's market in which about a third of the 600 units are up for sale.

title: Katherine Franz Wed To Frank C. Forelle
description: At St. George Roman Catholic Church in Guilford, Conn., Katherine Grace Franz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adolph Franz 3d of Meriden, Conn., was married yesterday to Frank C. Forelle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Forelle of Muttontown, L.I. The Rev. David Williams performed the ceremony.

title: Ghosts: Appearance And Reality
description: As a colleague of Terence M. Hines at Pace University, I would take issue with some of his statements in your Oct. 29 issue Westchester Q&A (''Seeing Is Believing? Not Necessarily''). In answer to the question ''How can we be sure there aren't ghosts?'' he replies ''. . .The burden of proof is always on the proponents to produce something other than vague reports and fuzzy photographs, which are known to have been faked in the past.''

title: Jason, 8, Master of Street Life, Moves On
description: WHEN the Shermans moved last week, Dayton Street lost its promising young leader, Jason Sherman, age 8. An ambitious entrepreneur, imaginative game organizer, keeper of the peace and (inadvertently) creator of street-life drama for those of us too old to play, his skills will be hard to replace.

title: In Case of Fire: Why All Hotels Aren't the Same
description: WHEN Hurricane Hugo struck inland North Carolina, I was in bed in a snug new motel along I-85 listening to the wind build up and tiny branches strike the window. After one howling burst near dawn, the lights on the highway went out, the restaurant in the parking lot went dark, alarms went off in the motel corridor and I knew that the power was gone.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: I'm an avid Ranger fan, so I'd like to think that they are legitimate contenders, but I dare not. FLORENCE MOSS New York

title: Debra Kimelman Wed To Stephen A. Weiss
