description: Debra Merril Kimelman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kimelman of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Andrew Weiss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvyn I. Weiss of Muttontown, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Mordechai Waxman officiated at Temple Israel in Great Neck.

title: As a Million Go West to Shop and Socialize, East German Assembly Accepts Cabinet
description: More than a million East Germans surged into West Berlin and West Germany in the bright sunshine today, jamming the streets, stores and markets in towns from Lubeck to Hof.

title: In Oyster Bay, a Fish Fancier's Haven
description: LONG ISLANDERS seeking country dining at a quaint atmospheric inn will not be enticed by the Mill River Inn's drab exterior. This ill-lighted, undistinguished gray building situated in a less-than-gentrified section of Oyster Bay will attract few walk-ins.

title: Western Europe Pledges Aid
description: At an impromptu summit meeting called by France, the European Community pledged aid to East bloc countries that move toward democracy and agreed to set up a bank for low-interest loans to those nations. Page 28.

title: Children Should See Images Of All People in Coloring Books
description: THERE is such power in the hands of children with crayons. They can play God. They can color the world as they see it, imagine it, will it. The world belongs to them as they wave their crayons like magic wands, bringing new life and possibilities. But it is the coloring book that helps define the parameters of that world, which is why I am concerned about the images my young daughter sees in such books.

title: Reynolds Honored
description: The actor and former running back at Florida State University, Burt Reynolds, was named the 1989 Walter Camp Football Foundation's Man of the Year yesterday. The award is presented annually to an individual associated with football who has attained a measure of success and been a leader in his chosen profession.

title: Bush Has Trouble With Two Parties
description: AT some point in their first year in the White House, Presidents learn a basic truth about the limits of executive power: it often does not extend as far as Capitol Hill.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: MEET LURKEY

title: U.S. CHAMBERMAID, POLISH QUEEN
description: David Margolick exaggerates the contrast between American and Polish perceptions of Basia Johnson (''Lech's American Angel,'' Oct. 8). He writes that ''to Americans she may always be a chambermaid.'' Why would anyone, besides the stepchildren and their lawyers, consider such a highly educated woman always to be a chambermaid, merely because that was the first job she held in the United States? ''But in her native Poland she is treated like a queen,'' he continues. The presumed royal treatment of men kissing Mrs. Johnson's hand and women giving her flowers is not unusual in Poland, a country of eloquent social customs.

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING?
description: Those proclaiming ''the end of history'' remind me of early-19th-century politicians who wanted to shut down the Patent Office because they thought everything of use had been invented.

title: Knicks Get a Test From Timberwolves
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves are a strange team and it required some strange moves last night by the Knicks to defeat the expansion club, 111-96, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Curious Tales, Unconventionally Told
description: Witches, monsters, eerie visions and prophetic dreams have been choreographically much in evidence this autumn. Multimedia productions have mixed dance with music and texts, and the results have been enigmatic parables and fairy tales.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: Until the Rangers consistently defeat their counterparts north of the border, especially the perennial powerhouse Montreal Canadiens, they will never achieve legitimacy as contenders. DON VAN VLIET New York

title: Martha Jane Brackenridge Is Married
description: Martha Jane Brackenridge and Austin Bartholomew Sayre 3d were married yesterday at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N.Y., by the Rev. Theodore Fritsch, a United Church of Christ minister. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Bruce Brackenridge of Bronxville and Bonnieux, France. Mr. Sayre is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sayre Jr. of Westfield, N.J.

title: THE PRODUCERS
description: After I received my Ph.D. some 10 years ago, I doubted that I would ever again find myself sitting in a classroom eagerly awaiting the arrival of a professor. But last year, while I was a visiting lecturer in the University of California at Los Angeles Writing Programs, I sat in on Peter Guber's course. Each week, I joined 300 undergraduate and graduate students to listen to Mr. Guber's mesmerizing tales of the movers and shakers in the entertainment industry and how they used (and sometimes misused) their power in the pursuit of their craft. Diane Shah captured the energy and drive of this dynamic and driven man.

title: Finding New Income for University of Medicine and Dentistry
description: RESOURCES for medical education and health-care research are tightening. As a result, health-sciences universities nationwide have begun to explore new sources of funds in the form of innovative business arrangements with private industry, including the kinds of public-private partnerships that have proved successful in other fields of governmental responsibility.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Poul Anderson has been turning out solid, serviceable science fiction for more than four decades. In THE BOAT OF A MILLION YEARS (Tom Doherty/Tor, $19.95), he aims higher and succeeds admirably.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: The Rangers, if healthy, can definitely make a run at the end of the year. If the Rangers can keep up their strong play until Carey Wilson returns, they'll be in position to win the Patrick Division and possibly contend for the cup. An injury to either Tomas Sandstrom or Brian Leetch would basically eliminate any legitimate chance they'd have, however, since they lack the depth of Calgary or Montreal. MATTHEW HAIES New York

title: The Machines of War And Its Human Drama
description: LEAD: THE heavy iron gates at the entrance to the Imperial War Museum on Lambeth Road in the Southwark district of London open on to a wide circular drive planted with roses as fat and florid as the decorations on the Queen Mother's hat. In among the roses are a pair of 15-inch naval guns trained directly over your head.

title: Artists Experiment With Fiber
description: THREE sentinels stand guard, like faceless robots from a sci-fi film, inside the gallery entrance of the Staller Center for the Arts at the State University in Stony Brook.

title: What Congress has done
description: The contras

title: Abby C. Schultz Marries
description: Abby Cynthia Schultz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Schultz of Allentown, Pa., and Roy Adam Shulman, a son of Morris Shulman of Lake Worth, Fla., and the late Rita Goldberger Shulman, were married last evening by Rabbi Eugene Wernick at Temple Beth El in Allentown. Mrs. Shulman, a certified public accountant, is a tax manager with the Weissbarth, Altman & Michaelson accounting concern in New York. The bridegroom is a corporate lawyer for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York.

title: Ms. Berman Wed To Thomas Helf
description: The marriage of Barrie Debra Berman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Berman of Richmond to Thomas Elliot Helf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Helf of De Witt, N.Y., took place in Richmond last evening at Temple Beth El. Rabbi Sanford Hahn performed the ceremony.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT:NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Adventures of Baron Munchausen 1989. RCA/Columbia. $89.95. Laser disk, $39.95. 2 hours 6 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Terry Gilliam, the American member of the Monty Python troupe, interpreted and directed this fantastic adventure story about the notorious liar of legend. The baron (John Neville) sails off in a hot-air balloon to find old comrades and do battle against the Ottoman Turks. The film is full of ''moments that dazzle, just for the fun of seeing the impossible come to life on the screen,'' thanks to the cameraman (Giuseppi Rotunno), the production designer (Dante Ferretti) and the creator of special effects (Richard Conway). (Vincent Canby) The Dressmaker 1989. Capitol. $79.95. 1:32. No rating. Nellie (Joan Plowright), a seamstress, and her sister, Margo (Billie Whitelaw), share their grim and tidy little house with their 17-year-old niece, Rita (Jane Horrocks), who falls in love with one of the American servicemen in Liverpool in 1944. A small-scale, exquisitely acted film that is ''constructed as if it were some kind of delayed-action explosive . . . . The images and textures have the density of good prose.'' (Canby) K-9 1989. MCA. $89.95. LD. $34.98. 1:51. CC. PG-13. Dooley (James Belushi) is an unconventional San Diego narcotics officer with a book editor girlfriend (Mel Harris). He is teamed with a new partner, a chili-loving German shepherd named Jerry Lee Lewis, and the two have a number of adventures as they try to bring a drug czar to justice. Although the story ''doesn't have a shred of credibility . . . , with its sure-fire dog tricks and breezy pacing [ it ] is at least mildly diverting.'' (Stephen Holden) See No Evil, Hear No Evil 1989. RCA/Columbia. $89.95. LD. $39.95 1:43. CC. R. Wally (Richard Pryor) is blind, but is so desperate to pass for sighted that he pretends to read the newspaper on the subway. Dave (Gene Wilder) is completely deaf and reads lips. Together they witness a murder; that is, Wally hears the shot and smells the killer's perfume, and David sees her legs. The actors ''have never worked better together,'' and ''the performances remain legitimate even at the wildest farcical moments . . . . It would be difficult to imagine a more benign or entertaining mass-market movie.'' (Canby) Ghostbusters II 1989. RCA/Columbia. $89.95. LD. $24.95 1:42. CC. PG. It is the not wildly improbable premise of this sequel to the 1985 comedy that Manhattan, the angriest place on earth, ''is about to blow, like a frog on a hot plate.'' It's a situation that cries out for the help of the Ghostbusters - Bill Murray and his associates, Harold Ramis, Dan Aykroyd and Ernie Hudson. Sigourney Weaver again plays a concerned citizen and Peter MacNicol is the devil's new emissary. This is ''a remarkably cheerful film. It has the weight and stylishness of designer toilet tissue, but it doesn't offend.'' (Canby) The Mighty Quinn 1989. CBS/Fox. $89.98. 1:38. R. Xavier Quinn (Denzel Washington) is an island-born, F.B.I.-trained police detective in a Caribbean country who is called in following the grisly murder of a rich American businessman, in which the prime suspect is his boyhood pal, Maubee (Robert Townsend). All is not as it seems, and as the investigation proceeds, political and economic interests come into play. The story ''manages to be lighthearted without being soft in the head.'' And Mr. Washington ''gives the kind of smooth, funny, laid-back performance that could help make him the first black matinee idol since Sidney Poitier.'' (Canby) Gold Diggers of 1935 1935. MGM/ UA. $29.95. 1:36. No Rating. Dick Powell, Adolphe Menjou and Gloria Stuart, in the role usually occupied by Ruby Keeler, star in this generally amusing screen comedy. The Times critic of the day wrote: ''Busby Berkeley, the master of scenic prestidigitation, continues to dazzle the eye and stun the imagination . . . ,'' noting that ''quite the most breathtaking feature is the 'Lullaby of Broadway' number.''

title: Get Ready for Our First Woman President; Northern Bigotry
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab Dies of Injuries Suffered 3 Weeks Ago
description: A Palestinian man who was kept alive more than three weeks by a hospital respirator died today of head injuries.

title: Booklet Suggests Thinking of Death
description: WHO is your funeral director? Do you want to be cremated or buried? Do you want life-support measures taken if you are terminally ill? Do you want to donate your eyes to science?

title: AMERICA'S RADIATION VICTIMS: The Hidden Files
description: BLUE GLOW SHROUDED THE ROOM FOR AN INSTANT, THEN was gone. In that moment, Louis Slotin knew he had received a lethal dose of radiation from the core of the plutonium bomb he was testing.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Article 673189 -- No Title
description: BY 5:30 on any weekend morning, it is too late to decide to play golf on a public course in the county - unless the hapless player is willing to wait several hours to tee off and 15 to 20 minutes between holes.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;
A British View of the Perennial Craze
description: LEAD: There is a craze for growing perennial plants among gardeners these days. Witness a groundswell in the number of books on the topic and the increase in sales at nurseries and garden centers.

title: Nancy E. Dunn To Wed in April
description: April wedding plans have been announced by Dr. and Mrs. James P. Dunn of Summit, N.J., for their daughter Nancy Ellen Dunn and Steven Bryan Grune, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Grune of Westport, Conn.

title: Getting Even
description: Leonard Bernstein apparently felt that if the people in Washington were going to rescind a $10,000 grant to an art show on AIDS, they could keep their National Medal of Arts too. Mr. Bernstein at first refused to comment on why he turned down the chance to be one of 12 recipients of the arts medal this year, but it was generally accepted that he did so in protest of a decision by the National Endowment for the Arts to withdraw support for the AIDS exhibition at the Artists Space gallery in Manhattan. Days later, however, the new chairman of the National Endowment, John E. Frohnmayer, changed his mind and restored the grant - at the urging of members of the National Council on the Arts - with the proviso that it not be used to pay for the show's rather provocative catalogue. Did this mean that Mr. Bernstein could also change his mind and accept the medal? No. It seems that a replacement recipient had already been selected and, as a White House spokesman put it, ''the President is only permitted to give 12 awards a year.'' At the awards ceremony at the White House on Friday, Mr. Frohnmayer obliquely acknowledged the dispute over the AIDS show, saying, ''I feel like John Kennedy after the Bay of Pigs.'' In yesterday's Washington Post, Mr. Bernstein addressed those who would deny support to artistic expression with which they disagree. ''Dear conservatives,'' he wrote, ''What are you conserving? Democracy and human freedom, I should hope.''

title: DATA BANK: Nov. 19, 1989
Get Ready for Our First Woman President
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; French Violinist in Debut
description: The French violinist Olivier Charlier, who gave his New York debut recital on Tuesday evening, seemed unsure at first that he was attending the right party. His initial reticence contrasted sharply with the camaraderie of the sizable audience that had turned out for the opening of the 29th season of the Young Concert Artists Series at the 92d Street Y, and his first performance, of Robert Schumann's Sonata No. 1 in A minor (Op. 105), failed to elicit even a curtain call.

title: Campus Life: South Carolina; Dorm Test Fails: 2 to Be Reopened To Opposite Sex
description: In the spring, a trustee of the University of South Carolina persuaded other trustees to try an experiment this fall. The university would make two of the six predominantly freshman dormitories off limits to members of the opposite sex.

title: Duke, Virginia In Tie for ACC Title
description: Clarkston Hines caught three touchdown passes, raising his own National Collegiate Athletic Association career record to 38, and became only the second player ever with more than 1,000 yards receiving in three straight seasons, as Duke rolled to a 41-0 victory today over North Carolina.

title: Animal Shelter in Elmsford Faces Charges on Crowding
description: The County Health Department and the Elmsford Animal Shelter are at odds over the enforcement of a new provision of the Sanitary Code that is setting new standards for agencies housing animals.

title: Pennsylvania Abortion Limits Become Law
description: As he promised he would, Gov. Robert P. Casey has signed into law the most restrictive state abortion provisions in the nation.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: From generation to generation, a joyous tradition has brightened the lives of certain women at this time of year. It has nothing to do with Thanksgiving or the Macy's parade or even gargantuan bargains in the stores. These women know better: November triggers the annual migration of fur coats.

title: Q and A
description: Mixed-Use Mortgage

title:
DINING OUT;
Genteel Aura at a Farmhouse in Somers
description: LEAD: L'ELEPHANT is the most recent occupant in a series of restaurants that have plied their not insignificant kitchen skills in this elegantly appointed old farmhouse.

title: AIR FORCE OFFERS TO CLOSE 15 BASES AND SCRAP MISSILES
description: Responding to the Administration's call for major cuts in military spending, the Air Force has proposed closing 15 bases, stretching out purchase of the Stealth bomber and eliminating five fighter wings, Administration officials said today.

title: International Team Ahead in Bridge Event
description: A cosmopolitan squad of contract bridge experts headed the field going into the semifinal stage of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship here this afternoon. Zia Mahmood, who represents Pakistan in world championships, and Michael Rosenberg, a Scot, both Manhattan residents, were teamed with Sam Lev of Israel, Mark Molson, Montreal, and Chris Compton, Houston, in the concluding event of the American Coantract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: Local authorities and a healthy handful of individuals have peppered the world with their own stamp issues. These locals, as they are collectively called, occupy a large slice of the collecting area known as cinderellas.

title: In El Salvador, Extremism Once Again Rules the Day
description: RUBEN ZAMORA, who in 1987 returned from seven years of exile, sat in a small office of his leftist party's headquarters here a couple of months ago and deplored the growing political violence in El Salvador. The problem, he said, was that the governing rightist party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance, had come to power before its time.

title: FOOTBALL
description: RUNNING TOUGH. Memories of a Football Maverick. By Tony Dorsett and Harvey Frommer. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A most intriguing fact in ''Running Tough'' is that Tony Dorsett has accumulated more rushing yardage than anyone in football history save for the recently retired Walter Payton of the Chicago Bears. as lights on the pantheon go, Mr. Dorsett certainly glimmers far more dimly than many runing backs with lesser statistics, from Jim Brown to Paul Hornung to Gale Sayers, even to contemporaries like Eric Dickerson and John Riggins. Mr. Dorsett, despite his statistics, has never dominated the game as others have. The reason for this, he claims in his autobiography, ''Running Tough,'' is that the Dallas cowboys, the team for which he played the bulk of his career, thwarted him in a variety of ways. In fact, there are so many laments against the Cowboys and humanity in general in ''Running Tough'' that the book could have been subtitled ''Feel Sorry for Me, Because I Sure Do.'' No doubt racism, mendacity and other horrors exist in the National football League and on the Cowboys, but Mr. Dorsett sees it as all directed at him. His career has been dotted by accusations of starting fights in bars and other public places, rumors of a drug investigation and severe financial problems despite a seven-figure contract. ''Running Tough,'' written with the sports journalist Harvey Frommer, portrays Mr. Dorsett as an unwitting victim in nearly every case. He claims persecution because he has been outspoken, but there is little evidence that he has been outspoken about anything other than his own persecution. Mr. Dorsett, who is now n the Denver Broncos' injured list and probably will never play again, makes accusation about the Cowboys organization that are hardly new: that there is a preference for white players over black; the Tom Landry, the team's coach until this year, was distant from his players; the the coaches and excutives preferred team loyalty to individual stardom. But these are traits of almost every football team and, in fact, most American corporations. In addition, ''Running Tough'' is poorly written, done in a trite as-told-to style, lacking any eloquence or direction but for the clanging complaints of its subject.

title: Choi Duk Shin, 75, Ex-South Korean Envoy
description: Choi Duk Shin, a former South Korean Foreign Minister and Ambassador to Bonn who moved to North Korea after becoming affiliated with a dissident group that supports the Communist Government, died Thursday. He was 75 years old.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: CRAFTS IN LIMELIGHT

title: Why the Hard Sell Didn't Work For Detroit
description: THE report on car and truck sales released last week was, by most accounts, a grim harbinger for the American auto industry. While foreign manufacturers are suffering, too, the brunt of the decline hit the Big Three automakers, raising new questions about whether Detroit is entering its first recession in almost a decade.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WIDOW OF OZ. By Kathryn Lasky Knight. (Norton, $17.95.) Well-bred, well-heeled, well-educated Dorothy Silver has brilliantly fulfilled her destiny. Married for some 30 years to an internationally known cardiac surgeon, she has raised two successful children: a son who is a paleontologist in Kenya and a daughter who is a ''whiz-kid'' on Wall Street.

title: Palestinian-American Youths Join in the Uprising
description: When Jeanine Amra was 15 years old, her family left the small Minnesota town where she grew up and moved to the West Bank, taking her away from her high school and her friends to a new life that she feared would be primitive and boring.

title: U.S. CUTS OFF ARMS TO AFGHAN FACTION
description: After criticism in Congress and elsewhere, the United States appears to have sharply cut arms supplies to an Afghan guerrilla group that has been accused of attacking other factions in the seven-member rebel coalition.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MIND AND THE BODY POLITIC. By Elisabeth Young-Bruehl. (Routledge, Cloth $42.50, Paper $13.95) Elisabeth Young-Bruehl, who has written well-received biographies of Hannah Arendt and Anna Freud, collects in ''Mind and the Body Politic'' 12 essays, some originally given as lectures, on various aspects of Arendt's philosophy, on history, psychoanalysis, Anna Freud, feminism and the education of women.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: EXHIBITION BASKETBALL

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Sandy Feld;
Helping Women With Child Support
description: LEAD: IN 1981, one month after Sandy Feld separated from her husband, she was in Family Court in Monmouth County attempting to collect delinquent child support for their 10-year-old son.

title: Charity Keeps a Library In South Glastonbury,
description: LEAD: AT the South Glastonbury Library, there is no computer. The return date for books is still rubber-stamped, and borrowers still write their names in longhand on book cards.

title: Social Events
description: Hebrew Home Benefit

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S beaches are quiet now, free of the human press that summer heaps upon them. On any given sunrise, at any surfside location, there might be a gentleman walking a dog, a stubborn fisherman throwing metal or a solitary woman, setting her thoughts adrift on the tide.

title: P. F. Lapeyre Jr.And Miss HodgesTo Wed in March
description: Mrs. Walter James Hodges of Washington has announced the engagement of her daughter, Laurie Lee Hodges, to Pierre Fernand Lapeyre Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lapeyre of New Orleans. The prospective bride is also the daughter of the late Mr. Hodges. A March wedding is planned.

title: LOVING MR. WRONG
description: ELIZABETH COLE By Susan Cheever. 211 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Chicago's Polish-Americans Hail Walesa With a Rally
description: Until today, the Solidarity founder, Lech Walesa, had been celebrated by officials and business leaders at invitation-only luncheons and cocktail parties during his weeklong visit to the United States. Today it was the turn of hundreds of Polish-Americans who streamed into downtown Chicago in a jubiliant mood to hail him in an outdoor rally.

title: Glorious Transit
description: The most exciting view in New York City is the vista of the East River, lower Manhattan and the Queens and Brooklyn waterfronts from the Roosevelt Island aerial tramway. It's yours for $1.25. And it's worth working to preserve.

title: When Motion Pictures Found Their Tongue
description: A current series of film presentations at the Museum of Modern Art, titled ''The Dawn of Sound'' and running through Dec. 4, focuses on what was probably the most decisive period in the development of the movies. During the late l920's, the addition of sound transformed film from a mute mime show into a form of theater with an unequaled range of expressive options.

title: Miss Harris Wed To R. A. Gutman
description: Lynda Gail Harris and Robert Alan Gutman were married last evening at Temple B'rith Kodesh in Rochester by Rabbi Judith Cohen-Rosenberg.

title: BIRDMEN OF HARLEM
description: I AM A NATURE WRITER WHO UNTIL RECENTLY TAUGHT ENGLISH in a classroom without windows. Martin Luther King Jr. High School, near Lincoln Center in Manhattan, is so designed. The students there are predominantly black and Hispanic, and come by subway or bus from Brooklyn, the Bronx and Harlem. They don't complain that they rarely see trees or grass, or that sunlight never enters their classrooms. They do complain when you push them to write a more-than-one-page paper.

title: Lendl Heads Field
description: The world's No. 1-ranked player, Ivan Lendl, and second-ranked Boris Becker top the two pairings groups for the $3,135,000 Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden Nov. 28-Dec. 3.

title: Wall Street's Cutbacks And the Ripple Effect On the City's Economy
description: TWO years after the market collapse, Wall Street has begun another wave of job cuts. The continued weakness of the financial services sector comes as another piece of bad news for Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins and his new administration. The growing loss of Wall Street jobs comes on top of an even greater loss of manufacturing employment in New York City and the increasing exodus of back-office workers from the city.

title: Rushing Mark For N.C.A.A.
description: Ricky Gales rushed for 389 yards today, a National Collegiate Athletic Association record, but Simpson of Iowa still lost, 42-35, in the first round of the N.C.A.A. Division III playoffs to St. John's of Minnesota. St. John's won when Todd Fultz recovered his teammate Mike Ramler's end-zone fumble with 44 seconds to go.

title: SPINNING THEIR WHEELS IN CHINA
description: BEIJING JEEP The Short, Unhappy Romance of American Business in China. By Jim Mann. 333 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster.

title: Susan L. Cohen, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Susan Lea Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Cohen of Brooklyn, and James Evan Schwartz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schwartz of Ardsley, N.Y., were married last evening. Rabbi Paul R. Siegel performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in White Plains.

title: Miss McCausland Weds William Joseph Davis 3d
description: Linda Gamble McCausland and William Joseph Davis 3d were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J., by the Rev. Alfred C. Niese, an Episcopal priest, assisted by the Rev. Patrick Brown, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WAY OF LIFE NATURAL FOODS CO-OP;
Organic Turkey and Berries: A Mainstream Thanksgiving?
description: LEAD: ORGANICALLY raised turkeys and cranberries are among the Thanksgiving items offered by the Way of Life Natural Foods Co-op here. The cranberries are bought from a grower who uses no chemical pesticides or herbicides; the turkeys, from a supplier who feeds them a chemical- and drug-free diet, said Fred Cramer, the cooperative's manager.

title: MEET ME AT THE WALT WHITMAN REST AREA
description: LOOKING FOR AMERICA ON THE NEW JERSEY TURNPIKE By Angus Kress Gillespie and Michael Aaron Rockland. Illustrated by Ruth Strohl-Palmer. 219 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press.

title: When Pictures Dictate The News
description: The bad news is that in some ways television news is getting worse. The reasons why are laid out on ''Illusions of News,'' this week's offering in the new Bill Moyers series, ''The Public Mind.'' Network correspondents, political operatives and critical observers describe how the imperatives of commercial television are overwhelming and undermining efforts at honest journalism. ''Illusions'' is by far the best of the sometimes puffy four-parter.

title: Sag Harbor Yields On Condemnation Plan
description: LEAD: THE painter Susan Rothenberg had no idea of the tribulations that would follow her purchase of a Sag Harbor commercial property in 1986.

title:
WINE;
Making a Selection For the Holiday Meal
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of the wide range of fare served simultaneously at the traditional Thanksgiving Day dinner - often running the gamut from peppery stuffing to sweet cranberry relish - savvy consumers save delicate white burgundies and complex first-growth Bordeaux for other occasions, ones at which single food flavors dominate.

title: Temple Upsets Rutgers By 36-33
description: Roman Hale scored two touchdowns and Temple fought off a 326-yard passing performance by Scott Erney today to beat Rutgers, 36-33. It was Temple's first victory of the season.

title: TWO OF US IS ONE TOO MANY
description: I lost one of my best friends when her husband retired and took over the house. He dictates who she can see and when, how long she can talk on the phone and questions where she goes.

title: President's Proclamation
description: Following is the text of President Bush's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: The White House

title: Horses and Over-Riders
description: Last month, Ed Koch lost his chance to go down in history as the Mayor who rescued New York's carriage horses from heat exhaustion, chill, long hours and terrifying traffic. He vetoed a bill that would protect them from having to work when it is very hot, very cold, very humid or for more than eight hours at a stretch. The bill also confined horse-drawn carriages to Central Park for most of the day, and it required better training for the carriage drivers.

title: Rivals Think A's Have Good Shot at a 'Dynasty'
description: Three weeks into the sports world's latest ''dynasty,'' no one has made any serious moves to challenge the Oakland Athletics. But then, the Athletics haven't done anything to enhance their dynastic status either.

title: Installing Attic Insulation
description: IN many homes, attic insulation is placed at floor level, specifically between the joists that support the ceilings of the rooms below. This is effective and economical; however, if the attic entrance is not insulated, substantial energy loss can occur in both winter and summer.

title: Low Export Prices Hurt Ivory Coast
description: The Ivory Coast, whose fast-growing free-market economy was once held up as a model for other developing nations, has fallen on hard times.

title: Youth, 15, Arrested in Slaying of Two Men
description: A 15-year-old youth was arrested yesterday and accused of killing two men in a Nov. 9 shooting in Queens in which three other people were wounded.

title: 'Pollution Knows No Political Boundaries'
description: JULIE D. BELAGA of Westport, a Republican who lost her bid for governor in 1986, has been appointed Region 1 administrator for the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the Government's top environmental post in New England with a staff of 575 people and offices in Boston.

title: THE JUDGE PLEADS HIS CASE
description: THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA The Political Seduction of the Law. By Robert H. Bork. 432 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: McNally's Plays Take Diverse Paths
description: IN ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' now running Off Broadway, a flamboyant homosexual is desperate to get his hands on a pirated recording of the Verdi opera that Maria Callas sang in Portugal in 1958.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE COURTYARD. By Arkady Lvov. Translated by Richard Lourie. (Doubleday, $22.50.) Arkady Lvov had already written 16 novels in Russian before he left the Soviet Union for the United States in 1976 with a microfilm of ''The Courtyard'' hidden in a shoeshine kit. This novel marks his first major appearance in English.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: THE REV. CHRISTINE GRIMBOL;
Pro-Choice Pastor Defines Her Stand
description: LEAD: THE Rev. Christine Grimbol, who has been pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Sag Harbor for five years, gained wide attention last July when she spoke at a rally in Melville convened by a coalition of abortion rights groups in response to the United States Supreme Court's Webster decision narrowing the grounds for legal abortion.

title: New-Music Festival; Computer Technology by the Hub
description: The five-hour program presented by the Hub at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Thursday evening as part of New Music America got better as it went along. It had to. The beginning - almost half-an-hour late and with various malfunctions in the vast technological apparatus - could not have been more desultory.

title: Your Turkey Or Mine?
description: YOU know those Thanksgiving scenes of the extended All American Family with their heads reverently bowed around a picture-perfect turkey and an array of mouth-watering vegetables? Ever wonder what everyone's praying for?

title: Charity's Plan Helps Poor Become Politically Active
description: After 141 years of lobbying on behalf of New York's poor, the Community Service Society is trying a different approach. It is encouraging the city's 2 million low-income residents to become politically active and plead their own cause.

title:
GARDENING;
Proper Storage of Equipment for Spring
description: LEAD: AN important but often neglected fall task is that of putting equipment and supplies away for winter in good condition so they will be ready for use when spring arrives.

title: Queens Baby Dies as Family Finds His Bedroom on Fire
description: A 2-month old baby died in Queens yesterday afternoon in an electrical fire that started in a wall next to his crib, the police said.

title: The Rumble of the Tumbrels, the Heart of Dickens
description: Can great literature ever be successfully filmed? Does Dickens, in particular, defy even the wiliest adapter?

title: Colorado Romps to Finish 11-0
description: Colorado completed its first unbeaten regular season since 1937 and won its first Big Eight Conference championship in 28 years, routing Kansas State, 59-11, today as Darian Hagan became the fifth player ever to run and pass for more than 1,000 yards in a season.

title:
INVESTING;
Cashing In on a Construction Boom
description: LEAD: After the San Francisco earthquake, many engineering and construction stocks jumped. Speculators quickly concluded that the disaster would provide a big new source of profits. Analysts were less impressed. Most of the cleanup work is likely to go to small private companies, they say.

title: On Adoption By a Gay Couple
description: The article on the adoption of two children with AIDS by a gay couple is an interest commentary on our attitudes (''Gay Couple's Move to Adopt Children With AIDS Stirs Debate,'' Oct. 15).

title: Cyprus-Israel Rift Closes Route to Soviet Jews
description: Embroiled in a landing-rights dispute with Cyprus, El Al Israel Airlines has closed off a transit route for thousands of Soviet Jews seeking to vacation in Israel, Cypriot and Israeli airline officials say.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/-28 East Germany was ready to shoot protesters in Leipzig when Egon Krenz, then security chief, canceled Erich Honecker's order, party officials say. Page 1

title:
ART;
Objects May Be Small, But the Appeal Is Wide
description: LEAD: IN ''Small Wonders,'' the current exhibition at the Temperance Hall Gallery in Bellport, the size of the objects on view may be diminutive, but their scope and variety are large indeed. They range from miniature versions of paintings and sculpture to jewelry, ceramics and other craft items normally produced on an intimate scale.

title: Campus Life: Tulsa; Beauty Contest Wins the Ayes Of the Beholders
description: Early this month, the student senate proposed that the Miss T. U. Pageant be abolished on the grounds that it is sexist and discriminatory. But the student body, to which the proposition was put for a vote last week, doesn't seem to think so. It vetoed the idea 1,050 to 521. There are about 4,000 students at the university.

title: Robert Wunderle, 45, Supermarket Executive
description: Robert E. Wunderle, a supermarket chain executive, was shot to death on Thursday near his office in Woodbridge, N.J. He was 45 years old and lived in Westfield, N.J.

title: Lafayette Spoils Lehigh Affair
description: Joseph Boltz, 90 years old, remembers the first time he saw Lehigh play Lafayette in football. It was 1917 and Boltz, a freshman, played the trombone in the Engineers' marching band.

title: Jody Guariglia to Wed
description: February wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Dominic Guariglia of East Hanover, N.J., for their daughter, Jody S. Guariglia, and Charles Varvaro, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Varvaro of Forest Hills, Queens. Ms. Guariglia is an assistant vice president of the First Chicago Trust Company of New York. Mr. Varvaro is a second vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Iran and Iraq Offer Rival Plans for Peace Pact
description: Iran and Iraq have offered competing proposals for turning their 14-month cease-fire into a lasting peace, but neither side has reported a response from the other.

title: Ski Patrols Get Ready for Season
description: LEAD: THERE was no snow on the ground. The weather had not even been cold enough to turn on the snow-making machine. And although New Jersey's ski resorts will not open for at least two weeks, dozens of volunteer ski patrols packed Great Gorge Lodge one weekend recently to prepare for the season.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Atlanta
description: Atlanta, more than any other city in the South, has always looked forward rather than back - interested in the bustle of commerce rather than the history and lore that's so much a part of many Southern cities. Its charms rest partly on the gorgeous wooded setting it began with and partly on the modern city created by the economic juggernaut of the recent past and almost not at all on what came between.

title: Suspect in Drug Agent's Slaying Found Shot to Death
description: The main suspect in the murder of a Federal drug agent last February was killed in a blaze of bullets fired from a blue van on a Brooklyn street Friday night in what law-enforcement officials said appeared to be an execution by local organized-crime groups.

title: Japan's New Screen Image: Economic Toughie
description: There is one moment in ''Black Rain'' when it is clear that the old film images of Japan are giving way to new ones.

title: Arbitrators Help to Relieve Court Backlog
description: LEAD: CARMEN CORSO said it had been seven years since a bus rear-ended his car and several since an official of the bus company, Domenico Tours, promised to pay him. But a Domenico representative insisted that the company's insurance carrier tried for six years to contact Mr. Corso.

title: Review/Dance; The Joffrey in All-Ashton Bill
description: The Joffrey Ballet's devotion to Sir Frederick Ashton's works was evident again Wednesday night at the City Center (131 West 55th Street), in a splendid all-Ashton bill that featured a spate of debuts.

title: New Hampshire Utility Takeover Agreed On
description: A two-year struggle for control of New Hampshire's largest electric utility apparently ended today when its stockholders and creditors tentatively agreed that Northeast Utilities of Connecticut should take over the bankrupt company.

title:
INVESTING;
Munificent Municipals
description: LEAD: Municipalities seeking to finance new projects have had to pay relatively high interest rates in recent months, giving investors an opportunity to lock in high yields. ''Municipal bonds are very attractive compared with other fixed-income investments,'' said James J. Glynn, executive vice president of Dean Witter

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Nov. 5 about an instrument built by Harry Partch mis-identified the performer because of incorrect information supplied to The Times. The muscian shown playing the instrument was Jeffrey Peyton.

title: Deni Elliott Marries James Peter Cramer
description: Deni Elliott, the acting director of the Institute for the Study of Applied and Professional Ethics at Dartmouth College, and James Peter Cramer, the director of career services at the Vermont Law School in South Royalton, Vt., were married in a Quaker ceremony yesterday at the Hanover (N.H.) Quaker Meeting. The certificate of marriage was read to the witnesses by James Hamilton Cramer, the bridegroom's 8-year-old son from his previous marriage, which ended in divorce.

title: Tigre Separatists in Ethiopia Say They Have Taken a Town
description: Ethiopian rebels say they have captured a small town 85 miles north of the capital of Addis Ababa and halted a Government counterattack.

title: Turning Words Into Works of Art
description: LEAD: IF there is truth in the adage, ''a picture is worth a thousand words,'' then one of Frank Levi's wordgraphics speaks volumes. From ordinary and celebrity birthday gifts to Broadway playbills, these one-of-a-kind creations have delighted recipients and blazed a new trail in the world of art.

title: Supersensitive Satellite Starts Search for Echoes of the Universe's Birth
description: A robot spacecraft swinging high over the earth's poles today began a search for the beginning of time.

title:
FOCUS: Columbus, Ohio;
Japanese Influx Stimulates Homes Sales
description: LEAD: THE influx of Japanese families has buoyed the housing market in the northwestern suburbs of Columbus, where the families have concentrated, at a time when sales generally have weakened.

title: POSTINGS: Rip Van Winkle Country; Awakening in Coxsackie
description: One of the regions of New York State that is undergoing unexpectedly high growth is Greene County south of Albany between the Catskill Mountains and the Hudson River. For a century the county lived up to its fictional reputation as the home of sleepy Rip Van Winkle. Lately, however, it has been emerging as an increasingly attractive area for people working in Albany who want to live in the country and people living in New York City who want to spend their weekends fishing, hiking and skiing.

title: Campus Life: Dartmouth; 100 People Try To Learn More About Refuse
description: When more than 100 members of the Dartmouth College community began walking around campus last week with bags of garbage on their backs, people began to ask questions.

title: Financial Center Arts Series
description: A chorus from Public School 234 in Manhattan will open an arts and events series at the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center with a free performance on Nov. 28 at 6:30 P.M. The concert at the financial center - near Battery Park City between the Hudson River and West Street and Vesey and Liberty Streets - will celebrate the lighting of the Winter Garden for the season.

title: India's Vote Will Test Gandhi and The System
description: THE prophets are silent as India, the world's most populous democracy, comes to the end of the shortest political campaign in 42 years of independence and heads this week into the most unpredictable election in its history.

title: Dinkins Initiates Quest for a Police Commissioner
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins's quest for a police commissioner is to begin in earnest this week with the naming of a search committee.

title: Truce Proposed on Deer Protest
description: EVERY December since 1974, a group of protesters organized by the New Jersey chapter of the Humane Society of the United States have descended upon the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Morris County to protest the opening day of the refuge's annual deer hunt.

title: Dr. Robbyn Sockolow Weds
description: Dr. Robbyn Ellen Sockolow, a fellow in pediatric gastroenterology at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, was married last evening to Brian Keith Maier, a vice president of Goldman Sachs & Company. Rabbi Bernard Schecter officiated at Temple Beth Tikvah in Wayne, N.J. The bride, 28 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Sockolow of Wayne. A graduate of Emory University, she received an M.D. degree from the New York Medical College. Mr. Maier, 30, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Maier of Fort Wayne, Ind. He graduated from Colorado College and received an M.B.A. degree from Northwestern University.

title: Correction
description: A photograph on Oct. 22 of a sculpture, ''Grenada,'' by Melvin Edwards was positioned incorrectly. What appeared to be the floor, on which the work rested, was actually a wall at the right, to which it was affixed.

title: Is It Time Now to Cry for 'Evita'?
description: Political unrest, financial collapse and bruised egos - enough to rival the life of the dramatic Eva Peron herself - have marked the tortured path of ''Evita'' from stage toward the screen. Like so many film projects in Hollywood that go on for years without being made, ''Evita'' is an example of the hazards of the high-stakes marriage between art and commerce. Almost since its London opening in 1978, the Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim

title: Testing Shows Regional Contrasts In the Use of Cocaine by Criminals
description: In Philadelphia and New York, 75 percent of the adult men arrested for serious crimes from January through March tested positive for cocaine use in voluntary screening, the Federal Centers for Disease Control says.

title: In Making Drug Strategy, No Accord on Treatment
description: Even though drug experts cannot agree on how to define ''treatment on demand'' for addicts, there are widespread complaints that neither President Bush's proposed program nor any existing state approach provides nearly enough capacity to treat drug addicts who want to break the habit.

title: 'The Long Gray Line'
description: To the Editor:

title: Design of Suffolk House A War Over Esthetics
description: LEAD: ON the East End, where architecture is taken almost as seriously as beach erosion, an artist's vision of an ecologically sensitive house - possibly the first elliptical house on Long Island - is the subject of an esthetic tug of war.

title: FOOTBALL
description: OUT OF BOUNDS. By Jim Brown with Steve Delshon.) Zebra, $17.95.) For most middle-aged sports fans, Jim Brown is professional football's quintessential fullback, an archetypal strongman in an era when the National Football League was more brutal than it is today. As Mr. Brown observes in ''Out of Bounds'': ''Loose rules. Hard men. Not a lot of cash. It made the old NFL a primitive place.'' Of course, Mr. Brown was more than a bruiser. He was ahead of his time in combining power and speed with grace and artful running. He is also one of the few sports legends to have retired virtually at top form. One wonders, after reading his briskly paced autobiography (written with Steve Delshon, the author of several sports books), if he shouldn't have played a little longer. When Mr. Brown retired from football in 1965 at the age of 29, his skills were still awe-inspiring. Perhaps that is why the tone of his narration is often that of a superstar who retires in the prime of life only to be haunted by his image: a living legend with no field to play on. Mr. Brown, now 53, has spent his retirement years meandering about the periphery of society. He has been in and out of Hollywood as an actor. He was a color analyst for CBS Sports - he was fired after a controversial remark about Jimmy (the Greek) Synder - as well as the manager of a singing group and even a one-time magazine centerfold. His autobiography is frank and usually entertaining. For all of the many thought-provoking points Mr. Brown makes - he discusses the need for economic development in the black community, criticizes the modern black athlete for his lack of politcal awareness and gets to the heart of the problem of drugs in sports - ''Out of Bounds'' will be remembered for its spicy accounts of Mr. Brown's sexual exploits. Indeed, long after the memories of his career have faded, what lingers in the memory will be his tossing women out of balconies and occassionally slapping them around. Mr. Brown tackles his image head-on: ''I get the women who are looking for something different.... I've got this public image.... People think I'm the guy who roughs up women, threw one girl off the balcony.... My reputation has also driven away many women.... When that happens with a girl I have high hopes for, it hurts,'' Mr Brown describes the balcony incident. During an altercation with his girlfriend, he says, the police came over and he slammed the door in their faces. He learned later that ''Eva kind of freaked.... She climbed over the top of our balcony, and then fell, and rolled underneath it.'' He also devotes several pages to defending himself agaisnt charges that he and a female companion raped another woman. Those chages were eventually dropped, though the woman still has a civil suit pending. Mr. Brown is candid about his life and revels in the fact that he has lived it his way - from indulging his preference for 19- and 20-year-old women to attacking racism in society and lethargy within the black community. ''I know my lifestye isn't for everyone,'' he writes. ''By no pretending to be a goody-goody, it's actually been easier on me.... And in a sense, I've beaten the game.''

title: The Floating Dollar Needs an Anchor
description: The United States has paid a high price for the instability of the dollar. A dollar that floats in value against other world currencies confuses markets, distorts supply and demand, and makes it harder for the economy to operate. Long-range investment decisions are clouded by unnecessary short-range uncertainties. Trade is distorted and taxation cannot be fair and efficient if incomes and wealth are miscomputed by fluctuations in prices, inflation and interest rates.

title: Glitz Takes a Powder
description: THE DECADENT DISCO DAYS OF THE late 1970's were a triumph of shiny, high-gloss makeup. Lipstick was sticky and wet; cheeks and eyelids were covered with colors that glinted and glowed.

title: A Surprise From U.C.L.A.
description: Alfredo Velasco kicked a 49-yard field goal with 13 minutes 43 seconds left but missed a 54-yard attempt on the last play of the game today and U.C.L.A. had to settle for a 10-10 tie with Southern Cal in the 59th game between the crosstown rivals. Velasco's final kick hit the crossbar and bounced back onto the field.

title: Lynda Leaman Weds in Pennsylvania
description: Lynda Brown Leaman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Leaman Jr. of Malvern, Pa., was married yesterday to Kevin Angus Macdonald, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Robert M. Macdonald of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Stephen K. Jacobson performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: Roosevelt Library Observes 50th Anniversary
description: The Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here, the nation's first official Presidential library, will celebrate its 50th anniversary on Sunday with special exhibits, a birthday cake and showings of newsreels of the Roosevelt era.

title: Navratilova to Face Graf in Slims Final
description: As if somehow preordained, the top two female players in the world this year, Steffi Graf and Martina Navratilova, will meet in the final today of the last major women's tennis tournament of the year, the Virginia Slims Championships.

title: A Brothers's Death
description: IT COULD HAVE BEEN a parade of Civil War soldiers, wounded and near defeat, marching toward another battle. They stared ahead with eyes from which all joy had been banished.

title: A Rocker Courting The 60's Remains Trapped in the 80's
description: Terence Trent D'Arby, 27 years old, probably remembers the 1960's primarily through souvenirs - photos, film clips and especially music. He's not alone; two decades later, even those who were prime movers during the 60's have had their experiences rerun so many times that they may find it hard to distinguish memories from recordings. And Mr. D'Arby, like other 80's rockers seeking a mass audience, is both a student and a would-be master of media, letting himself be shaped by them while trying to manipulate them to his advantage.

title: Maris Williamson Wed to D. T. Pascal
description: The Old Pine Street Church in Philadelphia was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Maris Elizabeth Williamson, the daughter of Hannah Clymer Williamson of Philadelphia and the late Robert E. Williamson Jr., and Donald Timothy Pascal, the son of Carol Good Pascal of Stamford, Conn., and the late Donald D. Pascal.

title: Border Skirmish: Art and Politics
description: The recent skirmish between John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, and Artists Space, an alternative gallery in Manhattan that is one of the Endowment's constituents, over a $10,000 grant for an art show about AIDS throws into sharp relief the increasing struggle in this country between artists who are straining the boundaries of what is acceptable and lawmakers voicing concern about standards of morality.

title: Q & A
description: Dutch van Gogh Shows

title: One Germany: Not Likely Now
description: No one was prepared for the rush of change in East Germany and the abrupt opening of the Berlin wall. So it's not surprising that the good news is being followed by much disquieting conjecture about a feared old topic: German reunification. Even careful Henry Kissinger calls that prospect inevitable.

title: Yonder $12.80, Wins Remsen
description: Yonder and Rootentootenwooten, who could not keep up with New York's best 2-year-olds earlier in the year, proved yesterday that additional time and distance have moved them along as they scored important stakes victories at Aqueduct.

GARDENING;
Proper Storage of Equipment for Spring

description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Youths Charged With Rape
description: Seven high school students have been arrested and an eighth is being sought in the gang rape of a 19-year-old woman here. The accused are all students at North Miami High School, including seven members of the football team. They are charged with raping the woman Aug. 1 at a North Miami apartment complex.

title: Gina Neville Wed To Paul R. Bauer
description: The wedding of Virginia Ann Neville, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George W. M. Neville of Butler, Ala., and Paul Richard Bauer, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Curtis H. Bauer of Schuylerville, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Nicholas B. Van Dyck officiated. The bride, who is known as Gina and will keep her name professionally, is a producer in New York for ''Crimewatch Tonight,'' a nationally syndicated television program, and also a freelance model and television reporter. She is a graduate of Patrician Academy and the University of Alabama. Her father is the senior physician at the Rush Medical Group in Butler.

title: MAKING LIKE A RAJAH
description: IN THE GOOD OLD DAYS, IT WAS THE MEN WHO GOT to wear the gorgeous stuff. During the heyday of the Mogul era in India, it was the maharajahs who were laden with ropes of pearls and strands of diamonds. Their rings, brooches, belts and sabers dazzled with emeralds and other gems, while thick tassels of pearls and rubies swung against their brocaded robes. Oh, the women wore jewelry, too, but it was much more modest. Naturally, today's women want to imitate the more lavish look. In this period of some pretty excessive fashion statements, imitating a maharajah's booty seems a perfectly normal way to go. Fortunately, this is also a time of prolific costume jewelry production and design. The look can be assembled from a street vendor's tables, or you can move up to the department stores. At Macy's, for instance, a respectably extravagant costume jewelry cache can be acquired for about $500. Add another zero and peruse the glowing cases at such places as Bergdorf Goodman or Kenneth Jay Lane in the Trump Tower. There, one finds such pleasures as cuffs that resemble hammered gold set with half-dollar-sized glass diamonds, collars laden with the same stones and endless ropes of faux pearls. At the very top, of course, is the real thing. Fred Leighton, a Madison Avenue dealer in antique jewelry, is a favorite with women bearing well-known names and plenty of cash. Currently, he is showing a spectacular collection of real Indian gems, many of them from the Mogul era. Here, for, say, $500,000, something very special can be arranged.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Investing Abroad; American Developers Are Now Looking To Europe, East and West, for Opportunity
description: ALTHOUGH the recent attention focused on Japanese and European real estate investment in the United States has tended to obscure the parallel activities of Americans overseas, the internationalization of property ownership and development is becoming a two-way street.

title: WHAT WE HAVE HERE IS A VERY SAD STORY
description: IF THIS WAS HAPPINESS A Biography of Rita Hayworth. By Barbara Leaming. Illustrated. 404 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Miss McKinley Married in Rye
description: Margaret Ann McKinley and Arthur Ryerson Hyde Clarke Jr. were married yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., by the Rev. Edward Johnston. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. McKinley of Greenwich, Conn. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke of Springfield, Center, N.Y., and New York.

ART;
When the Image Incorporates Language
