title: Swimmer to Retire
description: The East German swimmer Kristin Otto, who won six gold medals at the 1988 Seoul Olympics, was quoted yesterday in the Communist youth newspaper Junge Welt as saying she has decided to retire.

title: Sri Lanka Says Army Has Defeated a Tamil Militia in the East
description: Government troops said today that they had defeated a new Tamil militia accused of killing 38 Muslim police officers in the eastern Ampara district.

title: Out of Bounds
description: There was relief all around when it was learned that Deborah Fahrend and her West German companion and his son had not been kidnapped. But there were still a few unanswered questions. The flap began last week when a news agency received a note, purportedly from a previously unknown group called the Organization of Just Revenge, claiming that the three had been abducted ''because of their activities in Lebanon.'' The note was accompanied by photocopies of the trio's passports and visas. But Ms. Fahrend and her Lebanese-born West German companion, Munir Sami, turned up at the West German Embassy in Beirut the next day and asked what all the fuss was about. A Government spokesman in Bonn said the two ''could not explain why it was reported that they were kidnapped.'' There was speculation that they had been robbed, but Ms. Fahrend and Mr. Sami were not talking. Meanwhile, State Department officials said they would like to chat with the California woman, who is variously described as a journalist and a poet. A spokeswoman said Ms. Fahrend did not have the necessary special permisssion to enter Lebanon. ''Our consular officer, wherever she surfaces, will definitely want to meet her,'' she said.

title: Japanese Ceramics From Prehistoric To Exportable
description: Peggy and Roger Gerry, who began collecting Japanese ceramics while living in Japan in the 1950's, have amassed holdings covering 4,000 years of the craft: prehistoric earthenware vessels, late medieval ash-glazed storage jars, 17th-century tea-ceremony wares and colorful 18th- and 19th-century porcelains made for export.

title: NONFICTION
description: EDUCATION OF A WANDERING MAN. By Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $16.95.) A few days before his class in Jamestown, N.D., graduated from high school, Louis L'Amour (then Louis LaMoore) sat in a Singapore bar with his shipmates. He had decided that ''school was interfering with my education.'' This intellectual autobiography details the path that L'Amour traveled to become admirably, refreshingly self-educated. Although described as an account of L'Amour's extensive reading by Daniel J. Boorstin in his introduction, ''Education of a Wandering Man,'' conveys far more about the author's exotic travels and the colorful people he learned from, mostly under the austere conditions of his young adult years when he was hungry, alone, believing in himself when no one else did. L'Amour crisscrossed the third world as a sailor, learning about Asian and African cultures. Sometimes he traveled alone, but inevitably he met interesting storytellers to learn from: hobos, retired gunfighters, old cowboys, ancient miners, rugged individualists with names like Old Doc Yak, Singapore Charlie, Russian Joe Smith and Oriental Slim. Yet always he found time to read, and L'Amour lists what he read during the 1930's, averaging more than 100 books a year: eclectic samplings from Edgar Rice Burroughs to Christopher Marlowe, Marcel Proust to Claude McKay. At times officious and pontifical, certainly repetitive in a way that suggests that more revision was planned before L'Amour's death last year, this memoir rises above its tedious moments to provide the same intriguing historical insight that has won praise for the author's fiction. L'Amour's appealing erudition stems from a conviction that history is ''the story of people and how they lived,'' and long before the final page the reader feels more educated for having listened to this piquant chronicler of frontiers one last time.

title: The Germanys as an Economic Giant
description: LEAD: Most West German economists and business leaders react to the word ''reunification'' as if it were a stick of dynamite with a lighted fuse. But mention instead increasing economic integration of the two Germanys, and the enthusiastic response is talk of potential explosive growth and an economic miracle in East

title: Montclair Sends Hofstra Home Early
description: Hofstra has managed to earn an invitation to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern Regional playoffs five times in the last seven years. And every time, the Flying Dutchmen have gone home early.

title: More U.S. Curbs Urged in the Use Of Fetal Tissue
description: The clamor over the recent extension of a ban on Federal financing for one type of fetal tissue research has obscured an emerging battle over the longstanding use of the tissue in other types of medical research.

title: Tarpley Gets News
description: Two days after he was arrested on charges of drunken driving and resisting arrest, Roy Tarpley, the Dallas Mavericks' forward who was promptly suspended by the team for violating the terms of a drug rehabilitation program, got a glimmer of good news.

title: Ways to Combat Dumping in the Parks
description: The Oct. 8 article ''Parks Are Becoming Dumping Grounds'' highlighted the growing problem of dumping of all sorts of solid waste in New Jersey's parks and wildlife reserves because of the scarcity of landfill space. Certainly the most pressing need is more money to finance greater supervision and patrolling in New Jersey's parks.

title: A Day For Classical Music
description: CLASSICAL concertgoers should pick from among the many appealing programs this afternoon, because little else is available this week. The season will not really fill up again until the end of the month. Today's offerings, however, are impressively varied, beginning with several programs of special interest to piano aficionados. At 2 P.M. a master class at the Hoff-Barthelson School in Scarsdale is to be given by Dorothy Taubman, the noted teacher and director of the Amherst Music Festival (723-1169).

title: London Embraces the Thames Again
description: LONDON has at last decided to face the River Thames, after centuries of turning its back on it. The Docklands, an area of eight-and-a-half square miles covering both sides of the river and once a wasteland of industrial dereliction, is being transformed into a city within a city. All along the Thames, old buildings are being gutted and restored, with Georgian warehouses becoming sumptuous apartments, smart offices and shopping malls. New office buildings and factories, many of them bold architectural statements, are springing up around and between beautifully renovated docks and wharves.

title: INSIDE
description: Lurch Toward Adjournment Congress gave its final approval to raises for its members. Meanwhile, negotiators agreed to repeal outright the new expansion of Medicare, although a Senate fight over the accord may be at hand. Page 30. South African Hit Squad? A former police captain said he led a death squad created to eliminate foes of South Africa. The Government denied the accusation. Page 15. Opera Contract Ratified The New York City Opera orchestra has ratified a contract, but the fall season remains canceled. Page 46.

title: Sly and Family Stone Singer Agrees to Face Drug Charge
description: Slyvester Stewart, the former lead singer and creator of Sly and the Family Stone, has agreed to return to Los Angeles to face a narcotics possession charge.

title: PARTING SHOTS
description: MY TURN The Memoirs of Nancy Reagan. By Nancy Reagan with William Novak. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Random House. $21.95.

title: In El Salvador, Deadly Ironies
description: LEAD: Ignacio Martin-Baro was one of the six priests murdered in El Salvador last week. I met him in April 1985 when he visited the U.S., and I saw him again that June in El Salvador.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Unless we improve the treatment system, simply increasing capacity will only increase the speed of the revolving door.

title: HOW FAR WILL DE KLERK GO?
description: EVEN BEFORE FREDERIK WILLEM DE KLERK BECAME leader of his party and his country, he laid out four options for South Africa's whites: they could surrender to the black majority, which de Klerk contended the liberals were advocating; they could retain minority control at all costs, which the conservatives wanted; they could find a more acceptable way to hold onto power; or, as he proposed, they could make up their minds to share power with the blacks.

title: Batman, Champion of Truth, Justice and P. R.
description: ''Can somebody tell me,'' the Joker wonders, smashing a bright red boxing glove through a television set to curtail the latest report about Batman, ''what kind of a world we live in where a man dressed up as a bat gets all my press?'' Press, of course, is the operative word when you talk about ''Batman,'' which owes so much of its monstrous success to a public relations and merchandising sideshow.

title: Winter Wedding For Jan Sigmon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Marcus Sigmon of Bethlehem, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jan Alison Sigmon, to Andrew L. Dworkin, a son of Ruth Berman Dworkin of New York and the late Bernard Dworkin. A February wedding is planned.

title: HE GIVES ENTHUSIASM A GOOD NAME
description: THE PLEASURES OF THE PAST By David Cannadine. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: Jodi Picoult Weds Timothy van Leer
description: The marriage of Jodi Lynn Picoult, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myron M. Picoult of Nesconset, L.I., and Timothy Warren van Leer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Karl van Leer of Lincoln, Mass., took place last evening at Harrison House in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey officiated.

title: Prospects; How to Fix the New Yorker
description: The 64-year-old New Yorker magazine, acquired by Conde Nast Publications Inc. in 1985 for $200 million, has shown a decline in advertising, although circulation is up. Although it earned $6 million a year at the time of its purchase, many analysts now think the magazine is losing money. Can the New Yorker - famed for its fiction and reportage but now criticized as passe - reverse its fortunes? Four industry experts offer their views. Martin S. Walker President, Periodical Studies Service Inc.

title: Conduct a Test of a Gold Standard
description: In 1971, following President Nixon's repudiation of the agreement at Bretton Woods to redeem dollars in gold bullion, I was one of the first economists on Wall Street to warn that Nixon's ''New Economics'' policy would lead to serious economic and financial problems in the 1970's.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Single-Families Under $200,000
description: LEAD: CARDINAL VIEW, a $30 million development of one-family homes starting under $200,000, is helping to bring young families to rapidly growing Plymouth Township three miles from Philadelphia's northwest border.

title: Kristin L. DeAngelis Weds M. C. Johnson
description: Kristin Louise DeAngelis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John DeAngelis of Huntington, L.I., was married in Naples, Fla., yesterday to Mark Caylor Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Zane Quentin Johnson of Naples. The Rev. Nathaniel Hynson officiated at Trinity-by-the-Cove Episcopal Church.

title: Campus Life: Illinois; Chancellor Rules To Keep Symbol Of Chief Illiniwek
description: After more than a month of debate over whether the University of Illinois' Chief Illiniwek symbol is degrading to American Indians, Chancellor Morton W. Weir announced last week that it wasn't, and that it wouldn't be dropped.

title: Louisiana's New Philosophy
description: Last month, Gov. Buddy Roemer stepped up to the microphone in the towering Art Deco State Capitol to announce that ICI Americas Inc., based in Wilmington, Del., had selected St. Gabriel in southern Louisiana as the site of a new $100 million plant to produce substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, bypassing locations in Texas, Kentucky, New Jersey and Canada.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Forecast: Bridal Showers Ahead
description: LEAD: TODAY'S young woman is practical, career-oriented and beyond flighty pursuits and outdated rituals and traditions. Until she becomes engaged.

title: Campus Life: Oklahoma; War Is Theme For Annual Party And Donations
description: Members of a University of Oklahoma fraternity, long censured by Vietnam veterans, whom they claim to be honoring with an annual party, met less hostility this year than in the past after taking what one veteran called ''concrete steps'' to prove their sincerity.

title: Robin H. Schneider Weds
description: Robin Hilary Schneider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton S. Schneider of Delray Beach, Fla., and Lawrence Weissbratten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Weissbratten of Columbus, N.J., were married yesterday at Temple Avodah in Oceanside, L.I., by Rabbi Philmore Berger. The bride, 37 years old, is an account executive at Rochelle Fabrics in New York. Mr. Weissbratten, 42, is an account manager in Edison, N.J., for Baxter International, a health-care company. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did his wife's.

title: Campus Life: Washington State; Fraternity House Under Scrutiny In Theft of Goods
description: A fact-finding board of faculty members and students at Washington State University is investigating thefts of more than $5,000 in items from around Pullman that have led to the arrest of 17 fraternity pledges. The pledges became suspects after the police recovered several of the stolen items in the Kappa Sigma fraternity house last month.

title: Kelly E. Ashton Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harris J. Ashton of Greenwich, Conn., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Kelly Elizabeth Ashton and the Marchese Carlo Barel di Sant Albano e Lucinge, the son of the Marchese and Marchesa Umberto Barel di Sant Albano e Lucinge, who live in Turin, Italy, and Sao Paulo, Brazil.

title: Of Passion, Politics and Other People's Money STAGE VIEW; Of Passion, Politics and Other People's Money
description: To my way of thinking, which I do not propose as the only way, virtually everything else that's new in town is a relief from ''Orpheus Descending.''

title: Corrections
description: A pie chart last Sunday about foreign ownership of commercial property in New York City was labeled incorrectly. The numbers represented square feet, not percentages.

title: A. Joseph Ferolie, Executive, 86
description: A. Joseph Ferolie, founder and retired chairman of the Ferolie Corporation, a food brokerage, died of heart failure Friday at his home in Cresskill, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: Paula Carsky Is Wed To William D. Rosado
description: Paula Lorence Carsky, a daughter of Mildred L. Carsky of Johnstown, N.Y., and the late Alexander J. Carsky, was married yesterday to William David Rosado, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Luis A. Rosado of Brooklyn. The Rev. Michael J. Flannery performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Irvington, N.Y.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
California Peels Off a New Crop
description: LEAD: DOUG RICHARDSON and Paul Turner, proprietors of the first commercial banana plantation in California, can identify, of the world's 300 varieties of bananas, all 50 that they grow. ''It's like telling your children apart,'' Mr. Turner explains. ''They're that different.''

title: Question Of the Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: I believe that the 1989-90 New York Rangers are legitimate contenders because of their ability to win against teams of higher rank. With the ability of Sandstrom, the experience of Greschner, the liveliness of Granato and Leetch, the power goalie squad of Vanbiesbrouk, Froese and Richter, the Rangers have a shot at this year's Stanley Cup. ANGELO LISI New York

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN TALKS OF HIT TEAM
description: A former South African security police captain says he commanded an assassination team created to track down and eliminate opponents of the Government.

title: Good TV Comes in Small Packages
description: We forgot to think small - at least in television. Recent engineering work has gone mostly into improving the big picture while striving for ever larger screens. Meanwhile, smaller, cheaper sets were bypassed by technical progress.

title: Miss McAndrews Weds R. S. Beatty
description: Susan McAndrews, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. McAndrews of Columbia, Md., and Richard Sharp Beatty, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. A. Beatty of Southport, Conn., were married yesterday at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in Drexel Hill, Pa. Msgr. Victor Burns performed the ceremony.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; Even in New York, Ice Comes With Blue Skies
description: Ice skating indoors is a lot like baseball indoors: it's recognizable, but it just doesn't feel like the real thing. Fortunately for city folk and city visitors, there are opportunities to go gliding in the great outdoors.

title: Once an Ally
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Parties Make Final Effort for Coalition
description: Greece's feuding political parties have embarked on a last-ditch effort to form an all-party government to end the political and economic crises resulting from this month's inconclusive general elections.

title: The World Has Room for African and Greek Achievements
description: To the Editor:

title: Still a Perfectionist, and Delighted to Hear It
description: Sixty-three years ago Rex Harrison made his first appearance on the stage of the Liverpool Repertory Company in the role of an anguished young father:

title: New York Telephone and Union Break Off Talks
description: The Nynex Corporation and striking New York Telephone Company workers failed to sign a tentative agreement yesterday that would have ended a 14-week strike that has disrupted service for 10.5 million customers in seven states.

title: Officers and Teen-Agers Mourn Death of Detective
description: Six thousand police officers, their gleaming gold badges in sharp contrast to the gray skies, stood along a Queens street yesterday to pay their last respects to Detective Keith L. Williams.

title: 'Stand-Up Tragedy'At Hartford Stage LBy ALVIN KLEIN
description: IN its pursuit of eclecticism, Hartford Stage has been a study in extremes of late. Having opened the season with ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' Oscar Wilde's perfectly escapist Victorian comedy of gentility and absurdity, the theater is now shaking up its subscribers with ''Stand-Up Tragedy,'' a tough and loud dose of contemporary urban reality, replete with street talk, rap music and break dancing.

title: New-Music Festival; Bits and Pieces From Kahondo Style
description: Kahondo Style, an English group making its first New York appearance on Tuesday at the Knitting Factory as part of the New Music America festival, revels in references. Its first tune, ''Werewolf Woman,'' hinted at reggae, and throughout the night the group used bits of jazz, rock, Thai and Eastern European folk music, all informed by an experimentalist's sensibility. By letting the audience fill in the blanks, the group seemed to be saying that musical styles, because of the easy transfer of information in modern culture, have become common intellectual property, recognized and understood by all.

title: LIFE WITH LUPUS
description: EMBRACING THE WOLF A Lupus Victim and Her Family Learn to Live With Chronic Disease. By Joanna Baumer Permut. 175 pp. Atlanta: Cherokee Publishing Company. $14.95.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; Sampling Four Cuisines, Traveling Eastward From Italy
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Andiamo

title: New-Music Festival; Negativland's Message
description: ''Media about media about media,'' said a voice on tape, summing up the tactics of Negativland, a California group that performed Thursday night at the Knitting Factory as part of New Music America. Negativland dips into the torrent of broadcast words from the likes of preachers, bureaucrats and advertisers, then turns the found messages into collages with noises and occasional songs. Somewhere between the bleak electronic dance tracks of the Pop Group from England, the jump-cutting comedy of Firesign Theater and the jokey nihilism of current collegiate rock, Negativland can be sophomoric, disturbing, or both at once.

title: TWO OF US TOO MANY
description: I was married for more than 30 years. During that time, my husband and I raised four sons. I worked part-time and, later, full-time. When our youngest child went off to college, instead of facing retirement and time together, I had to face divorce. I felt ''out of it; diminished in an unexpected way.''

title: Case of Seagoing Corruption Embarrasses Greece
description: Pirates and shippers have long found fame and fortune along Greece's coasts, but a new account of robbery by boat has brought this seafaring nation uncommon diplomatic embarrassment.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The cold-water faucet in my bathroom sink gives off a loud whistling or humming noise whenever it is turned on. The noise stops when the faucet is turned on all the way. I tried tightening the screw on top of the faucet handle, but this did not help. Can you tell me how to eliminate this noise?

title: Have Respect for (the Good) Repairmen
description: YOU have probably read about studies suggesting that a monstrous proportion of repair people are dishonest, incompetent, or both. A perfectly healthy car, for example, is taken to a dozen service stations with a question, and 10 of them recommend expensive, mysterious repairs.

title: Fashion; Dress Pumps That Respect Aching Feet
description: Cinderella's glass slipper and Clementine's herring boxes without topses represent the extremes of women's footwear - style versus practicality - but these days most women want both. Lacking any alternative, many women make do by walking to work in clunky-looking athletic shoes and switching to high heels stashed under their desks.

title: New-Music Festival; Premieres From the Pacific Rim
description: The Pacific rim is pretty big, and Friday afternoon's New Music America concert at the Guggenheim Museum of music from that rim actually offered only three pieces from California and one from Japan. Still, the arts that appear under that rubric do tend to differ from the characteristic music made in Europe and the Eastern United States. Pacific-rim music inclines toward the lyrical, the meditative and the exotically Orientalized. Friday's concert, despite obvious differences among the scores purveyed, did not upset that stereotype.

title: Campus Life: Wesleyan; Student's Arrest Leads to Debate On Drug Policy
description: For Wesleyan University, a crackdown of sorts on drugs has led to the arrest of one student and public debate over the university's definition of where its responsibilities end and those of the local police begin.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Task Force to Review Policy on Emergencies
description: Following several weeks of criticism over his decision to keep the University of California campus here open after the Oct. 17 earthquake that rocked the Bay area, Chancellor Ira Michael Heyman has called for the formation of a task force to evaluate the university's emergency preparedness.

title: Dianna Grunske Plans a Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. H. Franklin Grunske of Waukesha, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dianna Lynn Grunske, to Dr. Douglas Victor Brown, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor H. Brown of New Canaan, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Warren, Vt.;
Buyers Calling Ski Condo Tune
description: LEAD: AN overabundance of condominiums in this central Vermont community's Sugarbush Valley ski area has led to a buyer's market in which about a third of the 600 units are up for sale.

title: MOVING DAY: THE BOOKS I LEFT BEHIND
description: I have always thought of books not so much as something to read but as something to live with. Anthony Powell has a novel called ''Books Do Furnish a Room,'' and for me they have furnished a life. They are not bound volumes of pages but companions. In my first apartment, a tenement in Greenwich Village, books were all the furniture I had, except for a bed and a table.

title: New York City Opera Union Ratifies a 5-Year Contract
description: Members of the New York City Opera orchestra have ratified a new five-year contract with the company, officials of their union announced yesterday.

title: TALKING: Mortgages; Tighter Rules for Approval
description: BACK in the era of strong home sales and rising prices, which lasted for most of the mid 1980's, it was becoming progressively easier to get a mortgage. Lenders were offering to qualify borrowers at a low introductory rate of interest - often as little as 7 percent - even though this was only a temporary enticement and the rate was certain to rise later.

title: Orthodox Priest Leads Protestant Group
description: The National Council of Churches, long considered the nerve center of established Protestant Christianity in the United States, has installed a Polish-born Eastern Orthodox priest as its president.

title: Vicenza
description: To the Editor: A ''Palladian Journey in Vicenza'' (Travel, Aug. 13) would be incomplete without a tour of the city's Olympic Theater. Palladio's evocation of classical Greco-Roman design was commissioned by fellow members of the Olympic Academy, a civic organization founded in 1556 to promote humanistic thought and cultural activities in Renaissance Vicenza. Although the architect died in 1580, shortly after construction of the theater began, his plans were carried out with some alterations by his son Silla and his pupil Vincenzo Scamozzi. The result is a celebration of the city's intelligentsia and its civic influence. Visitors can see the fascinating trompe-l'oeil background perspectives of an ideal city that Scamozzi designed for the inaugural performance of ''Oedipus Rex'' in March, 1585. Although made of wood, the background is beautifully preserved - in spite of the perils of candle-lit performances and the ravages of time. DONNA S. BLOOM Ithaca, N.Y.

title: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING?
description: James Atlas describes the plush surroundings of the conservative quarterly The National Interest and contrasts its office to ''the grubby cubicles one associates with political journals on the left (if there are still any).''

title: 'Behold Ye Living Passing By': The Ultimate in Booking Ahead
description: OAKLAND CEMETERY in Sag Harbor is in a felicitous location, 27 acres of rolling high ground in what was once a forest lush with whispering oaks older than any inhabitants in the place. The rhododendrons and azaleas run riot in the spring, cedars and pines stand straight as sentries. George Balanchine, master of the ballet, although not a resident of Sag Harbor, picked Oakland Cemetery because he ''liked the look of it.''

title:
ART;
Emigre Works Reflect Tension of the Journey
description: LEAD: PLAGUED and oppressed by restrictions, a number of Soviet artists fled their country or were expelled in the 1970's and early 80's. The work they created later as members of a different society is now the subject of a sizable exhibition at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island.

title: Norma Terris, Who Won Acclaim In Original 'Show Boat,' Dies at 87
description: Norma Terris, who was catapulted to stardom as a lead in the original production of ''Show Boat,'' died Wednesday after a brief illness at her summer home in Lyme, Conn. She was 87 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
The New Look At South Station
description: LEAD: A RENOVATED South Station reopened in the Financial District here this month with 150,000 square feet of spruced up retail and office space as well as rebuilt tracks, ticket counters and baggage and waiting rooms.

title: AIDS Provokes Theological Second Thoughts
description: THE rapid, devastating spread of AIDS has forced many religious groups to re-examine some of their most basic theological convictions. This was strikingly demonstrated earlier this month when America's Roman Catholic bishops met in Baltimore and drafted an important statement about the disease.

title: Deficit in the Dark
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Stereo Can Be A Bottom-Dollar Experience
description: It's not even Thanksgiving yet, but, as any retailer will happily tell you, it is never too early to think about Christmas. If stereo is on your list, and you worry about the economy - your own economy, that is - it is reassuring that an inviting choice of musically competent components can be had at relatively low cost. Here is a sampling of top designs in the bottom-dollar bracket.

title: Shoreham's Future: Gas May Be Key
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND may end a century warmed and lighted by coal and oil with an abundant new supply of natural gas.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Quick Cranberry Relish
description: There are many things that are worth buying already made not only because making them is time-consuming but also because the commercial versions are good. Cranberry relish is not one.

title: Review/Dance; Osberg's Workwith Company
description: There is a memorable photograph of Sir Frederick Ashton rehearsing a pas de deux from his ballet ''Ondine.'' Two dancers are drawn together in a kiss that will prove fatal, and the choreographer stands beside them, hunching his shoulders and tensing his body in unconscious communion with the lovers.

title:
GARDENING;
Proper Storage of Equipment for Spring
description: LEAD: AN important but often neglected fall task is that of putting equipment and supplies away for winter in good condition so they will be ready for use when spring arrives.

title: On the Lam in Chicago
description: NO historical marker, no plaque, tells what once happened at the corner of Western and 63d Streets, on Chicago's South Side. But there are the bullet holes, small craters in the brick and chips in the terra cotta, that mark the spot where a hood named Frank McErlane opened fire one sunny September morning in 1925 with a submachine gun.

title: Son Killed in Father's Home
description: A 36-year-old man was fatally shot Friday night by his father's roommate five weeks after the son moved to the city to be reunited with his father, the police said. The father had not seen the son since shortly after he was born. The son, Alonzo Colbert Jr., had been arguing with his father when the roommate, Lawyer Meadows, 55, became alarmed and shot him in the chest, the police said. Mr. Meadows was charged with murder. ''Me and my son were totally strangers,'' the father said.

title: THE BIG SELL
description: SATISFACTION GUARANTEED The Making of the American Mass Market. By Susan Strasser. Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95.

title: Two More Cocaine Suspects Are Extradited by Colombia
description: Two more drug suspects under Federal indictment were extradited from Colombia today in that nation's continuing crackdown on cocaine trafficking.

title:
MUSIC;
Founding Fathers Recalled in Concerts
description: LEAD: IT was 10 years ago that James Sinclair dreamed up the idea of re-creating the musical atmosphere of our founding fathers, and Orchestra New England's Colonial Concerts were born. Usually, these annual events have been tied to some historical observance, and on this anniversary occasion, the program recalls George Washington's triumphal tour of New England and, more specifically, his visit to New

title: Western Europe Pledges to Aid East
description: At an impromptu summit meeting called by France, leaders of the European Community nations tonight pledged to provide all possible economic assistance to East bloc countries that move toward democracy.

title: Quebec 'Shadow'
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Quebec'' (Travel, Aug. 13) reminded me of my first experience with the Chateau Frontenac over 50 years ago. I was staying at the Y.W.C.A. ($1 a night) and asked the very British desk clerk to recommend a good place for dinner. She suggested the Shadow, if I could afford it. I told her that was a most startling name for a restaurant. Then the woman superciliously informed me that the Shadow Frontenac was a big hotel, not merely a restaurant. LILIAN McNAIR ALLARD Philadelphia

title: Canine Curriculum, From 'Sit' to 'Stay'
description: LEAD: VICTOR BORGE, the entertainer, explained to audiences why he'd forgotten the names of his children: ''They don't come when you call them anyway.''

title: Correction
description: An article in last Sunday's sports pages on the Williams College football victory over Amherst misstated the number of times in a row Williams has won the annual game. It is three straight years, not four.

title: Saving Programs for Teen-Age Girls
description: LEAD: IN 1980, 63 of 1,000 teen-age girls in Yonkers 15 through 18 became pregnant. By 1987, the number had risen to 91 of 1,000.

title: As U.S. Assesses East-Bloc Policy, Experts Differ on How Bold It Should Be
description: American foreign policy experts interviewed last week differed widely on what steps the United States Government might take to respond to the radical changes under way in Eastern Europe.

title: About Cars; Luxury Car Adds Trimmings
description: There is much truth in the notion that it is folly to tamper with success, and the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln division has made capital of this idea with its Town Car sedan.

title: Carolyn Bransford, Retired Executive, Weds Robert Ian MacDonald, Investor
description: The marriage of Carolyn Leslie-Leonard Bransford and Robert Ian MacDonald took place yesterday at St. Christopher's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. Mary Starrett Anderson officiated.

title: AT TIMES, FINDING FISH BY JUST LOOKING
description: My friends in Louisiana had told me about Bobby Bryan's skills as a fish finder. Even so, I was not prepared for the dazzling display he put on in the muddy waters off Timbalier Island.

title: Miss Lawrence, Executive, Wed
description: Kathryn Gibson Lawrence and Lawrence Frederick Bryan were married in New York yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harding Lawrence of New York, Dallas, St.-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, France, and Mustique, West Indies. The bridegroom is the son of Sir Arthur and Lady Bryan of Tittensor, Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, England.

title: Outsiders Who Specialized in Talking Pictures
description: Every now and then the New York art scene is treated to the sight of raw, irrepressible talent making itself up as it goes along, with little in the way of training or guidance from other art. Sometimes this work is called visionary art, sometimes outsider art. Sometimes it fits into or along the margins of a bona-fide contemporary art movement, like Chicago's Hairy Who, with its tightly wound antic imagery, or like Neo-Expressionism.

title: Towns Worry About Meeting Recycling Date
description: TOWNS around the state are complaining that the General Assembly's recycling plan is still without a system in place to market the materials they are collecting and that without help to process them, the towns will not be able to meet the legal deadline for compliance.

title: Style Makers; Marcia Prins-Kemp, Tile Designer
description: Marcia Prins-Kemp had given up a career in ballet and was on leave as an airline attendant 10 years ago when she walked down Shattuck Avenue here and saw a sign for a ceramics class starting in an hour.

title: Miss Lautenbach Weds Dan Streeter
description: Jennifer Ann Lautenbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terry R. Lautenbach of Darien, Conn., and Edward Daniel Streeter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Streeter Jr. of Laurel Hollow, L.I., were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Charles Smith.

title: Review/Theater; 'Song of Shim Chung,' a Korean Folk Tale
description: As a music-theater adaptation of a traditional Korean folk tale, ''The Song of Shim Chung'' is a change of pace for the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, allowing the company's proficient actors to experiment in an area distant from contemporary naturalism. The brief play, which opens the Pan Asian season at Playhouse 46 at St. Clement's, is earnest but unimaginative in both conception and execution.

title: Architecture View; A Radical Idea: Baseball As It Used to Be
description: The Baltimore Orioles did not make it to the American League pennant last season, but they came close. If major league baseball offered awards for architecture, however, this team would win hands down. For the design for the Orioles' new 46,000-seat stadium in downtown Baltimore, which will begin contruction this spring and be finished in time for the 1992 season, is the best plan for a major-league baseball park inmore than a generation. If it is half as good as the models and renderings suggest, it will represent a return to baseball as it should be; a game played on grass, not turf; under the sky, not a dome; in the middle of a city, not out on an interstate highway. This is a building capable of wiping out in a single gesture 50 years of wretched stadium design, and of restoring the joyous possibility that a ball park might actually enhance the experience of watching the game of baseball.

title: The Age of Now Hear This!
description: What will they say about 20th-century music when it's dead and gone? By ''they,'' I mean the historians whose duty it will be to shuffle the evidence, weigh tendencies, compute the pluses and minuses and play categories. What plausible description could be applied to a period inhabited by such stylistically variegated composers as Elgar and Webern, Stockhausen and Iggy Pop? Wish the historians luck.

title: Wendy A. Charles Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Simpson Charles 3d of Short Hills N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Anne Charles, to Francis Patrick Maguire, a son of Mrs. Michael J. Fives of Hauppauge, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: Karen Leslie Cox to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bert G. Cox of Rye, N.Y., have made known the January wedding plans of their daughter Karen Leslie Cox and John Joseph Mandy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandy of New Paltz, N.Y. Miss Cox, 24 years old, is an administrative assistant in the investment management group at the Bankers Trust Company in New York. The prospective bridegroom, 31, is an institutional bond salesman in the securities division of the Union Bank of Switzerland in New York and a partner at the Mashomack Fish and Game Preserve in Pine Plains, N.Y.

title: BIG DADDY
description: THE HUSTONS By Lawrence Grobel. Illustrated. 812 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

title: Corrections
description: On page 35, because of a production error, a photograph with the Art View column lacks a credit. It is by Timothy Greenfield-Sanders.

title: FAITHFUL TO HIS CLASS
description: HENRY ADAMS By Ernest Samuels. 504 pp. Illustrated. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $25.

title: Brecht Did Too Want to Entertain
description: To the Editor:

title: Town Digs Out From Tumbleweed Invasion
description: Some people may see romance in the vision of tumbleweeds rolling along the prairie, but Mayor Darrell Bender of Mobridge sees only horror stories.

title: Making the Roads Safe for Horse and Driver
description: LEAD: WHAT do you do if you are driving on a curving country road and see a horse and rider? How about a horse withouth the rider?

title: Parents Don't Really Care About Education
description: ON the eve of the President's recent education summit, my wife went to Back to School Night at the high school where she has taught English for more than 20 years. In this annual ritual, parents are invited to meet with their children's teachers.

title: NOTED WOTH PLEASURE
description: That Persistent Sentiment

title: Civil War's Fields Are Intelligence Classrooms
description: Can intelligence officers learn anything from battles fought 125 years ago? Yes, says Walter P. Lang of the Defense Intelligence Agency.

title: Spending Plan Encounters Resistance
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke, fresh from a decisive re-election victory, introduced a county operating budget ''for the 1990's'' last week but quickly learned that he may not be safely out of the 1980's.

title: Quakers Lead Way In Same-Sex Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Megumi Kaneko Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kiju Kaneko of Yokohama, Japan, have made known plans for a February wedding in Tokyo of their daughter, Megumi Kaneko, and Jonathan Andrew Hill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Hill of Rancho Santa Fe and Carmel, Calif.

title: Italians Protest a Proposal To Make Drug Abuse a Crime
description: Thousands of young Italians marched through the center of Rome today to protest proposals to make personal drug use a crime, organizers said.

title: When a Player's Enemy Is His Own Fear
description: Fear. It begins in the mind and will always show itself in some physical way.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article last Sunday about East Germans visiting West Berlin misstated the former position of Vernon A. Walters. He was Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, not Director.

title: 'I SHALL FUFILL HER EVERY WISH'
description: LEAD: RONDO By Kazimierz Brandys. Translated by Jaroslaw Anders. 265 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: Nets Picking Up Old Losing Habits
description: The Nets are beginning to play the way they did last season. And that is a frightening thought to their players, not to mention their fans.

title: Airlines to Seek Child Seats That Fit in Planes
description: The airline industry plans to ask the Federal Aviation Administration to require the manufacturers of child safety seats, which are used mainly in automobiles, to make them smaller so they will fit into airliners' seats as well.

title: The View From: Gozzi's Turkey Farm in Guilford; Where the Rush of Thanksgiving Is Met
description: BILL GOZZI and his cousin Bob will get little sleep in the next few days. They have until tomorrow to get this year's bounty ready to sell. Once that is done, they will have until Wedneday night to fill an estimated 8,000 orders, including 500 for the Southern New England Telephone Company and two for the Guilford family who moved to California 10 years ago.

title: SILENCING THE SPEAKER
description: LEAD: THE AMBITION AND THE POWER By John M. Barry. 768 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: Lost Messages
description: WHAT if no one called? The possibility fills me with dread as I open the front door. After all, I've been away for more than 24 hours.

title: TWO OF US IS ONE TOO MANY
description: I retired last February from a very good job (Hers: ''Two of Us Is One Too Many,'' by Helen Bennett, Oct. 22). My wife was apprehensive about it (I was not). My outlook was similar to that of Mrs. Bennett's husband; I planned to work around the house and the garden, do some photography, go back to the lab occasionally (when they asked me to) and whatever else came up. My wife is an artist who does some teaching, in and out of the house.

title: FICTION
description: ULTIMATE PRIZES. By Susan Howatch. (Knopf, $18.95.) This third novel in Susan Howatch's ecclesiastical series (the first two were ''Glittering Images'' and ''Glamorous Powers'') demands so insistently to be taken seriously that - though it flies in the face of good sense - one is left with no choice but to do so. The story of a spiritual crisis, ''Ultimate Prizes'' is narrated by Neville Aysgarth, an ambitious archdeacon in the fictional English diocese of Starbridge. A brilliant administrator with a firm, practical faith in God and the Church of England, Neville has steadily moved up in life by ''chasing the prizes,'' overcoming his humble birth and troubled youth to win for himself a perfect wife, a flock of delightful children and a powerful position, all before age 40. During his climb to success he has kept his mind as tidy as his diocese by relentlessly ''ringing down the curtain'' - a mental curtain, that is - on disturbing memories and desires. But alas for Neville, his curtain is shortly to be twitched off its rod, first by an infatuation with a young society girl, then by a death in his family. Actually it's fun to watch the stodgy Neville's descent into sin, and the society girl is flakily amusing. Unfortunately, the archdeacon hits bottom around page 160, and the society girl's subsequent appearances are limited to brief cameos. The remaining 224 pages detail, in earnest and repetitive prose, the psychological journey that enables Neville finally to confront and make peace with his unhappy early years. During this expedition, Neville discovers that by re-experiencing rather than denying painful childhood emotions, one can free oneself from undesirable compulsive behavior. Ah. Mr. Aysgarth, meet Dr. Freud. I don't think it will be giving anything away to reveal that the true ultimate prizes of life turn out to be faith, hope and love. Next crisis, please.

title: U.S. Aid for Poland: Long on Incentives, Short on Dollars
description: LECH WALESA, the hero of Poland's democratic revolution, asked Congress last week for a Marshall Plan to revive the Polish economy. But Congress and President Bush have already decided how to help Poland, and their vision is much more modest.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WITTGENSTEIN'S MISTRESS, by David Markson. (Dalkey Archive, $9.95.) Certain that she is the last person on earth, Kate wanders alone through the world's great museums, talking and talking until she self-deconstructs. ''Wittgenstein's Mistress'' is a remarkable technical feat,'' Amy Hempel said here last year. ''It is a novel that can be parsed like a sentence; it is that well made.'' THREE SCIENTISTS AND THEIR GODS: Looking for Meaning in an Age of Information, by Robert Wright. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) ''Personally, I don't like the idea that we're mere specks in a universeJU indifferent to our fates,'' Robert Wright says near the beginning of this book. ''Any hint that life has some meaning, evolution some purpose, would be refreshing.'' And so he sets out on a personal quest, stopping along the way to visit three very introspective scientists, Edward Fredkin, Edward O. Wilson and Kenneth Boulding. Last year The Book Review said the author ''turns his encounters into masterly portraits of three eccentric thinkers [ who invent ] theories so all-encompassing that they serve as the scientists' own personal gods.'' THE GARDEN STATE, by Gary Krist. (Vintage, $7.95.) When these short stories about the stranger aspects of life in the New Jersey suburbs were published last year, our reviewer, Elizabeth Gleick, said Gary Krist ''writes with an honest simplicity and a terrific sense of humor.'' In most of the stories he pays ''such attention to detail and [ has ] such obvious affection for his characters that we get momentarily caught up in new, somewhat absurdist worlds.'' TWO-PART INVENTION: The Story of a Marriage, by Madeleine L'Engle. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) The author of ''A Wrinkle in Time'' tells how she and her husband, the actor Hugh Franklin, collaborated on a marriage that lasted 40 years until his death from cancer in 1986. The story is told in ''a narrative whose painful nature is relieved by intercutting to the full and fulfilling life they led as artists and parents of three children,'' Dan Wakefield said here last year. SCANDAL, by Shusaku Endo. Translated by Van C. Gessel. (Vintage, $8.95.) A distinguished Japanese novelist sleuths around Tokyo's red-light district, trying to discover how a lewd portrait of him (or of a sinister doppelganger) came to be hanging in a local gallery. Last year The Times's John Gross said the novel is suspenseful and ''extremely gripping.'' THE VIENNESE: Splendor, Twilight, and Exile, by Paul Hofmann. (Anchor/Doubleday, $10.95.) Why does Vienna produce so many great artists and writers, then drive them mad or into exile? Last year our reviewer, Mark Anderson, said this book is ''the most comprehensive, informative and lively introduction to the city currently available, a combination textbook, (veiled) personal memoir and guided tour.'' THE HOLLYWOOD STUDIOS: House Style in the Golden Age of the Movies, by Ethan Mordden. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) While Paramount was a showcase for directors, allowing them their individual styles, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer was dominated by producers and its own cast of well-publicized stars. Last year The Times's John Gross called this book ''an analysis rich in example and anecdote, with excursions on everything from the personality of Irving Thalberg to the cinematic career of Tarzan. . . . Mr. Mordden reflects on the folk values of Fox, the Art Deco sophistication of RKO, and the predominant conservatism of Universal.'' THE PARABLE OF THE BLIND, by Gert Hofmann. Translated by Christopher Middleton. (Fromm International, $7.95.) Six blind men are roused from sleep one morning by an artist who wants to paint a picture that includes ''everything he had to say about the world.'' The result is Bruegel's painting, named, like this novel, ''The Parable of the Blind.'' In 1986 our reviewer, Leigh Hafrey, said, ''There is an earthiness to this book, an immediacy of sensory impression that is enhanced by the continuing, very cerebral meditation on the contradictions of art.'' The publisher has also reissued THE SPECTACLE AT THE TOWER ($8.95), Gert Hofmann's story of a couple whose car breaks down in a remote Sicilian village where sundown is marked by a child's ritual suicide. This is ''a timely introduction to English-speaking readers of an important German novelist,'' Harriet Watts said here in 1984. COURTSHIP IN THE ANIMAL KINGDOM, by Mark Jerome Walters. (Anchor/Doubleday, $8.95.) With all the convoluted rigamarole involved in pursuing and attracting mates, some biologists wonder why it wouldn't have been more evolutionarily advantageous for animals to reproduce asexually. ''Mr. Walters uses each colorful case history to illuminate universal patterns in the dance of life, and to raise serious questions,'' Jonathan Weiner said here last year. ''It is clear that the human animal, the snake and the apple tree are part of an experiment that none of them really understands.'' A KILLING KINDNESS, by Reginald Hill. (International Polygonics, $5.95.) Every time the Yorkshire Choker strangles another victim, he calls the local newspaper with a quotation from Hamlet. In 1981 our reviewer, Newgate Callendar, praised Reginald Hill's clearly drawn characters and sophisticated writing. ''The presence of a real writer makes itself felt.'' MARY McCARTHY: A Life, by Carol Gelderman. (St. Martin's, $12.95.) Last year our reviewer, Robert Towers, said the best part of this biography of Mary McCarthy, who died in October, is the story of how she wrote her way into the gang of intellectuals who revived Partisan Review. He called it ''a well-balanced and enjoyable account of a remarkable American life.''

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE BIOGRAPHY OF OTTMAR MERGENTHALER, INVENTOR OF THE LINOTYPE. Edited by Carl Schlesinger. (Oak Knoll Books, 414 Delaware Street, New Castle, Del. 19720, $35.) On July 3, 1886, much of the editorial page of The New York Tribune was set on a Linotype machine, thus signaling a new era in printing technology.

title: Bat Labels Cut to Size
description: If you missed Rickey (''read my bat'') Henderson at the World Series, he was the one wielding a billboard, a big black bat with big white letters that made major league officials see red.

title: The Canadian
description: To the Editor: Some years ago, we took a Canadian National train from Montreal to Vancouver. We found, like Erik Sandberg-Diment (''Crossing the Continent, in Canada,'' Travel, July 16), that the railroad's amenities and the scenery, even across the plains, made a wonderful trip of it.

title: People Either Get the Point Or They Don't
description: One of the most original shows in recent years is ''Dancers on a Plane: Cage. Cunningham. Johns,'' which can be seen through Dec. 2 at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery, 23 Dering Street, London.

title: Salvadoran Asks Pope to Remove 'Some Bishops'
description: In a bluntly worded letter two days after six prominent Jesuit priests were slain by uniformed gunmen here, the Attorney General of El Salvador today warned Pope John Paul II of his ''tremendous concern for the fate and fortune'' of Roman Catholic bishops in the country and urged him to withdraw them.

title: Reviews/Dance; Disparate Motions By Fagan
description: Garth Fagan, the founder and director of the Bucket Dance company, has long been praised as a choreographer of great originality. Mr. Fagan has also been seen as a visionary dance director who molded a group of untrained young dancers into a sleek and eloquent company over the last 20 years. But one of the great pleasures in his work, less frequently celebrated, is its bracing and expressive physicality.

title: Fan Deplores Cable Incursion
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Still Marries Stuart Romanoff
description: Jacquelyn Hilary Still, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Still of Orange, Conn., was married last evening to Stuart Irwin Romanoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Romanoff of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Peter Weintraub officiated, assisted by Cantor Stephen Merckle, at the Waters Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DOLLARVILLE. By Pete Davies. (Random House, $17.95.) Our beleaguered world is in an ecological, political and economic mess for which we may very soon find there are no remedies. Pete Davies shows us what that could mean in ''Dollarville,'' his darkly humorous, faintly futuristic second novel. In this frenetic satire, the world is fast approaching complete destruction; the only question is whether environmental breakdown will trigger it before political violence does.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Leftover Turkey, In Disguise
description: When the second set of turkey sandwiches is served after Thanksgiving, there are usually sotto voce grumblings. So, the remainder of the turkey is set in the back corner of the refrigerator where it languishes until it begins to develop fuzzy white-and-green spots.

title: THE PRODUCERS
description: It is, I am sure, no coincidence that your article on Jon Peters and Peter Guber appeared just a week after this dynamic duo became the subject of a legal tug-of-war between Warner Bros. and Japan's Sony Corporation (''The Producers,'' by Diane K. Shah, Oct. 22). Your article did not take a position on the $1 billion breach of contract suit filed by Warner against Sony and the Guber-Peters Entertainment Company, but I think it is important for Americans to choose sides here.

title: Deficit in the Dark
description: To the Editor:

title: General Electric's Hungarian Deal
description: G.E. is moving into Hungary, taking advantage of liberalization in Eastern Europe. General Electric will pay $150 million for control of the Tungsram Company, a light-bulb maker. The deal is the largest American investment in Hungary since World War II. John F. Welch, G.E.'s chairman, said the purchase would help bolster G.E.'s ''modest position'' in the European lighting market in preparation for the 1992 consolidation of Europe's economies. . . . G.E. said it would buy back $10 billion of its stock during the next five years, the largest repurchase program in corporate history. The company will also increase its dividend by 15 percent. *

title: A Survey Finds Weekenders Aren't Such a Bad Lot
description: LITCHFIELD COUNTY is one of Connecticut's choicest environs, and it has also been a magnet for New Yorkers looking for weekend houses to which to escape their city pressures. But these weekend residents are often blamed for bringing with them a host of problems, from an increase in the price of real estate to a decline in the number of dairy cows.

title: Executive Wed To Miss Cushing, A Boston Broker
description: Katharine Burrage Cushing and Charles Lane Goss 2d were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Oates at the Episcopal Church of Christ in Hamilton, Mass. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, L.I., and Howard G. Cushing Jr. of New York and Newport, R.I. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lane Woodworth Goss of North Andover, Mass.

title: New Haven Theater Runs a Book Drive
description: PEOPLE coming to the Shubert Theater in New Haven to catch ''Les Miserables'' are bringing more than just their show tickets. They are also tucking children's books under their arms to donate to the city's public school libraries.

title: Self-Inflicted Wound
description: ''As to the beating of the man, it was only moderate enough to convince him to accept detention.'' - Yitzhak Rabin, Israel's Defense Minister, in a letter to former President Carter.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Jets 1, Flyers 0: Doug Smail tapped in Dale Hawerchuk's shot with 3:28 left in overtime yesterday, giving Winnipeg a victory over Philadelphia. Smail fired a 15-foot wrist shot over the glove hand of Ken Wregget for the winning goal.(AP) Golf Mize Retains Lead by a Shot: Larry Mize of the United States held off a challenge from Naomichi Ozaki of Japan yesterday to keep the lead after three rounds of the $1.1 million Dunlop Phoenix Tournament in Miyazaki, Japan. Mize posted a third-round one-under-par 71, good enough to stay one shot ahead of Ozaki with a 12-under 204 total for 54 holes.(AP) Australians Ahead by 3 Shots: Peter Fowler and Wayne Grady of Australia overcame intermittent downpours and swirling winds yesterday for a combined even-par 144 and a three-shot lead over Spain after 35 holes of the rain-shortened, 54-hole World Cup tournament in Marbella, Spain.(AP) Cross-Country Jersey Girl Stays Unbeaten: Monal Chokshi, a freshman from Bridgewater-Raritan, concluded an unbeaten season yesterday by winning the girls' title by 17 seconds in the New Jersey State High School championships at Holmdel. Chokshi, 14 years old, took the lead at one mile and triumphed by 100 yards for her 14th consecutive victory. Her time was 19 minutes 13 seconds. The boys' titleholder was Bryan Spoonire, an Asbury Park junior, who ran 16:05 to win by 7 seconds. Horse Racing Scudamore Rides 1,139th Winner: Peter Scudamore yesterday became the most successful steeplechase jockey in Britain, riding Arden to victory at Ascot for his 1,139th career winner. Scudamore beat the record set by John Francombe in 1985 as his mount led all the way in the Kennel Gate Novices Hurdle, beating Athens Gate by a neck.(AP) N.B.A. Pistons 103, Celtics 86: Detroit's Dennis Rodman scored 5 successive points in an 8-2 third-quarter run that helped the Pistons stretch their home-court winning streak at Auburn Hills, Mich., to 25 games last night. Detroit led by 54-39 at halftime but Larry Bird got the Celtics back, scoring 9 consecutive points to pull Boston to 58-50 early in the third quarter. But Boston could not get closer than 10 points in the final 9:40.(AP) Hawks 112, Warriors 96: Dominique Wilkins scored 29 points and Cliff Levingston had 21 in leading Atlanta to the home victory. Wilkins scored 10 points in the third period, helping the Hawks build an 81-67 lead entering the final quarter. Glenn Rivers added 18 for the Hawks. The Warriors were led by Chris Mullin's 28 points. (AP) Magic 116, 76ers 103: Reggie Theus scored 30 points and Terry Catledge added 25 as Orlando ended a losing streak at five games. Philadelphia's Charles Barkley was ejected for his second - and the 76ers' fifth - technical foul with 32 seconds left in the game. Rick Mahorn was ejected after a technical foul on his second elbow foul with 9:50 left. Fred Carter, an assistant coach, also drew a technical and the 76ers got another one for an illegal defense. Catledge had a game-high 14 rebounds and Orlando's Sam Vincent had 16 assists.(AP)

title: Lapses on Duty, And Then 2 Deaths
description: JAY (STONEY) HARRISON is what the police call a career criminal: a suspect in two slayings, he had been in and out of police custody since 1984 for crimes like assault and drug selling. Last week he was in Queens for a lie detector test. As he was being driven back to Rikers Island, the police said, he shot and killed the two detectives escorting him. The police said he stole a service revolver from a police locker room used as a makeshift holding cell.

title: POSTINGS: By a Waterfall; 60 Houses
description: In Rye Brook, N. Y., on 27 acres of what once had been a dairy farm, 60 one-family homes are being developed, with construction paced by sales. Six already have been sold for $545,000 to $635,000. Named Hidden Falls, the project off North Ridge Street has a one-acre pond whose outlet flows over a 30-foot high waterfall into Blind Brook.

title: STREETSCAPES: 139 Greene Street; The Longest-Running Restoration in New York City
description: THINGS just seem to take more time in New York City - like renewing a driver's license, Christmas shopping and, most of all, restoration projects.

title: Army's Runners Set School Mark
description: Army, which had already lost four key starters for the season with injuries, began today's game against Colgate with the starting quarterback, Bryan McWilliams, sidelined with a foot injury. Then the Cadets lost their outstanding left halfback, Mike Mayweather, who reinjured a groin muscle early in the second quarter.

title: Congress Grinds Toward Adjournment
description: Lurching toward adjournment, Congress slapped together agreements on politically difficult issues this weekend, from Congressional pay and ethics to the program to protect the elderly from the costs of extended illnesses.

title: Hospital Tries to Avoid Measles Outbreak
description: Yale-New Haven Hospital has taken steps that it hopes will prevent a measles outbreak at the hospital after the discovery that a resident doctor is apparently infected with the highly contagious virus.

title: Mary E. Murphy Wed in Trenton
description: The marriage of Mary Elaine Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Murphy of Trenton, to John Markert Arnold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Arnold of Summit, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Trenton. Msgr. Joseph C. Shenrock officiated.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: New Passes For European Rail Systems

title: Ex-Chef and His Wife Found Dead in Queens
description: A former head chef at a well-known Brooklyn restaurant who was despondent over his poor health apparently shot his wife and then killed himself in Queens yesterday, the police said.

title: Lifestyle; Buildings of Marzipan, Not Marble, For a Show of Edible Architecture
description: On Tuesday, the chef Frederic Piepenburg examined his croissant, checked his white-chocolate mousse and black forest cakes, put on a clean chef's jacket and walked out of his pastry shop on York Avenue in Manhattan. The 6 P.M. departure was unusual for a 40-year-old man who says he has not missed a minute of any 16-hour workday since he began work as a baker's apprentice in 1963. But then, it was an unusual day. ''Today, I am an artist,'' Chef Frederic said.

title: SCHLEMIEL OF THE GOLDEN WEST
description: THE PEOPLE And Uncollected Stories. By Bernard Malamud. Edited by Robert Giroux. 269 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: In Farmlands Of Nicaragua, Words of War
description: Under a bright moon, contra rebel troops met secretly recently with two dozen farmers who support them in this heartland of the contra war.

title: HOW THE BRAIN WORKS, MAYBE
description: THE EMPEROR'S NEW MIND Concerning Computers, Minds, and the Laws of Physics. By Roger Penrose. Illustrated. 466 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Fashions; A New Martha for a New Generation of Shoppers
description: ''It seemed to me that fashion needed to take a kind of catapult into the next decade,'' Lynn Manulis said to explain why she is opening Martha International just two doors down from Martha Park Avenue, the 55-year-old boutique she runs with her mother, Martha Phillips.

title: Senate Roll-Call on Pay Rise
description: Here is the 56-43 roll-call vote Friday night by which the Senate voted to give itself a 9.7 percent pay raise. On a subsequent voice vote, the Senate approved new Congressional ethics rules and raises of at least 35 percent for the House, Federal judges and top officials of the executive branch. On this vote, a yes vote was a vote to approve the pay package.

title: FOOTBALL
description: MY STORY (AND I'M STICKING TO IT). By Alex Hawkins. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $18.95.) The protagonist of Dan Jenkin's highly acclaimed 1972 pro football novel, ''Semi-Tough,''was a hard-drinking, butt-stomping, womanizing country boy named Billy Clyde Puckett, who Mr. Jenkins said was modeled after Alex Hawkins of the Baltimore Colts. Now Mr. Hawkins has come out with an insightful, often funny autobiography focusing on his activities, on and off the field, with the Colts in the 1950's and 1960's. The former running back and wide receiver writes candidly about teammates, opponents and games played during his professional career, including the Colts' bitter loss to the New York Jets in Super Bowl III. However, the strength of ''My Story (and I'm Sticking to It)'' is in Mr. Hawkins's anecdotes and his abiltity to weave in and out of certain disaster. For example, after zeing arrested in an early-morning poker game with a man who had been arrested 33 times, Mr. Hawkins commented, ''When you're up at that time of the night it's tough enough gettng up a game, much less screening the applicants.'' Though not as gifted a storyteller as his teammate Art Donovan was in his 1987 autobiography, ''Fatso,'' Mr Hawkins can nonetheless spin a yarn or two of which even Billy Clyde Puckett would be proud.

title: UPPITY BEANS
description: UNTIL RECENTLY, A CONVERSATION ABOUT dried beans and lentils usually drew a stifled yawn.

title: Question Of the Week; Are the Rangers Legitimate Contenders?
description: What makes a contender? A stand-on-his-head goalie, a potent power play and, generally, players with a desire to play above and beyond anyone's expectations. The Rangers might just make celebrating 50 years of futility a forgotten memory in June. JOSEPH PISCOPIA Brooklyn

title: ART'S OFF-THE-WALL CRITIC
description: ARTHUR C. DANTO WALKS UP TO ANDY WARHOL'S ''BRILLO BOXES.'' ''Ah, there they are,'' he says, with fond recognition. While the natty, silver-haired philosopher has joyously greeted many old favorites during this (his third) visit to the Museum of Modern Art's enormous Andy Warhol retrospective, for him the ''Brillo Boxes'' are in a class by themselves.

title: The Way It Should Be Remembered
description: CHARLIE HALL HAS BEEN A WEATHERMAN at WCSC-TV in Charleston, S.C., since 1953, when the city's first television station went on the air. A silver-haired man with a rich voice, Charlie is a local celebrity, a highly respected figure, and one of the reasons WCSC-TV's local news programming has dominated the ratings. He is also my friend. At 3 o'clock on the afternoon of Sept. 21, 1989, Charlie Hall's voice broke while he was delivering the forecast.

title: Corrections
description: A map last Sunday showing Germany's 1914 borders mislabeled the territory to the northeast. It was Russia; the Soviet Union was not formed until 1917.

title: Bid Is Raised To $3.8 Billion For Nekoosa
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation yesterday raised its offer for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation to $3.8 billion, or $63 a share, from $3.1 billion, or $58 a share.

title: Optical Radiation reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $300,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Budget Crisis Dominates Race in Massachusetts
description: A wide-open race for Governor is getting under way this month under some of the most unusual circumstances in memory. For the first time in 30 years, the incumbent is not seeking another term.

title: Pickens's Japanese Battle Becomes a Trade Issue
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman and takeover specialist, has become the largest stockholder of the Koito Manufacturing Company, an auto parts maker in Japan. But the company, he says, has refused to provide him with a seat on its board and even its most rudimentary financial and operating information.

title: Ban on Sewer Connections Unnerves Builders
description: James M. Pendry's construction com-pany executive in Westchester County, thought it was finally time for the bulldozers to start rolling. His company had 70 wooded acres. The condominium drawings had the town's approval. And a name had been chosen: Watch Hill.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;; Ads to Join Details in Congressional Quarterly
description: The ghost of Nelson P. Poynter floats over the offices of Congressional Quarterly these days with one eyebrow raised.

title: STV Engineers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest full-year results included a loss equaled to $1.37 a share from the restructuring of a unit.

title: Road Trips Making Teams Homesick
description: A week ago the Indiana Pacers, winners of their first four games, were the only undefeated team in the National Basketball Association. Now they are 4-3. Why? A West Coast road trip. With the exception of the Los Angeles Lakers and the Utah Jazz, who have played mostly at home, each of the other 25 teams have at least three losses.

title: Phone Workers End Strike
description: Workers at the New England Telephone Company voted late today to accept a new contract and end a 15-week strike. Officials for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers said about 18,000 electrical workers in New Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island, Massachusetts and Maine voted 7 to 1 to accept the contract and would return to work Monday. New England Telephone is a subsidiary of the Nynex Corporation, which is being struck by 40,000 workers represented by the Communications Workers of America in New York.

title: Diving for Dollars
description: Ever wonder why your club pro has to stifle a chuckle whenever he sees a disgruntled duffer storming off the golf course cursing the water hazards that swallowed some of his best balls?

title: Datamark Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Town With a Thirst Votes to Stay Dry
description: Lots of people in Argyle enjoy a cold beer and are not ashamed to tell you so. But the townspeople are not about to let a little thirst come between them and history. Argyle has been a dry town since Prohibition, and folks here plan to keep it that way.

title: American Telemedia Network reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said it had no operating revenues in the year-ago periods.

title: Camor in the East; POLICE FORCE USED A 3D DAY IN PRAGUE
description: Czechoslovakia's hard-line Government used force for the third consecutive night against more than 10,000 demonstrators calling for the end of Communist rule, witnesses reported from Prague.

title: Man Who Lived 90 Hours In Quake Rubble Is Dead
description: Buck Helm, the longshoreman who survived for 90 hours in the wreckage of a freeway that collapsed in the California earthquake last month, died Saturday night. He became 58 years old on Nov. 10.

title: Pan Atlantic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest-quarter loss reserve provisions for Hurricanes Hugo and Gilbert amounted to $2.7 million.

title: Stern Targets East Germans
description: The breaching of the Berlin Wall was a momentous political event and to West Germany's leading news magazine, Stern, it was also a marvelous marketing opportunity.

title: Peering to Edge of Time, Scientists Are Astonished
description: In a discovery that could upset theories of cosmic evolution, astronomers have detected a light coming from surprisingly close to the edge of the universe and the beginning of time.

title: Checkrobot reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rocking Horse Child Care Centers of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included one-time charge of $51,468 associated with early extinguishment of debt. The company said that in the latest quarter it entered into a $15 million credit facility with First Pennsylvania Bank. Proceeds from the credit facility have been used for acquisition activity and the refinancing of about $9 million of debt.

title: Bumbling Jets Lose by 27-10
description: Accident-prone, mistake-prone and yielding the big play, the Jets lost tonight in the ways 2-9 clubs usually do.

title: Graf Wins Title in Four Sets
description: Steffi Graf, thanking the ''repairmen'' who doctored her sore ankle and apologizing to a valiant Martina Navratilova after again retaining a championship at her expense, was a tearful victor yesterday as she laid claim to her second Virginia Slims Championship at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. Advances to World Cup
description: Defying a sea of crimson shirts and a scoreless funk of two months, the United States scored the goal it needed today to reach the main round of the World Cup of soccer.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some editions on Saturday, with an article about the reduction in spending that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered the armed services to plan for, misstated the percentage of the reduction. With inflation taken into account, it would average about 5 percent annually for the fiscal years 1992 through 1994.

title: The Hypersonic Plane
description: With a minimum of controversy and a major commitment of money, America has once again tossed its cap over the wall of space.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The U.S. economy is suffering from a severe downturn, perhaps the worst of the last seven years, many economists say. Most economists speak of a quick revival, but there is an undertone of uncertainty in their reassurances. [ Page D1. ] Tax negotiators from the House and the Senate agreed tentatively on about $5.3 billion in revenue-raising measures, including a new tax on international cruises. [ D1. ] Inventors and patent attorneys have reacted angrily to President Bush's nomination of an attorney with almost no patent experience to become deputy commissioner. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Georgia-Pacific raised its offer for Great Northern Nekoosa to $3.8 billion, or $63 a share, from $3.1 billion, or $58 a share. [ D1. ] Japan says the U.S. should upgrade schools, invest in scientific research, close the Federal deficit and take other drastic steps to improve American industrial competitiveness. [ A1. ] The T. Boone Pickens-Koito dispute has become an issue in the trade dialogue between the U.S. and Japan. [ D6. ] Two steel workers union officials and USX were indicted in Birmingham, Ala., charged with collusion in bargaining. [ A1. ] Negotiators from Boeing and its machinists agreed to a tentative contract that could end the 47-day-old strike. [ A12. ] Scandinavian Airlines System is making a most ambitious effort to forge cross-border links with foreign peers. [ D1. ] Alan Greenspan is embarrassed about a four-month consulting job he took in 1984 for Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. [ D1. ] A former Apple Computer engineer says he was served with a grand jury subpeona and told by an F.B.I. agent that he is a suspect in the theft of software used to design the Macintosh. [ D5. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS The book industry is beset by a crisis of confidence. Sales of general-interest books have been in a slump for a year, but publishers continue to pay huge advances for big-name authors. [ D1. ] Congressional Quarterly will begin to accept advertising in January, ending a 53-year tradition. [ D8. ] The Benetton Group is being sharply criticized by people who consider two new advertisements racist. [ D8. ] R. R. Donnelley has perfected a technology for changing the content a magazine or booklet while it is being produced. [ D8. ] Shaw & Landley is getting a former top creative executive of Hal Riney & Partners. Advertising: Randall Rothenberg. [ D9. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The Canadian dollar's strength is a mixed blessing for Canada. It is helping to slow inflation by making imports cheaper, but it is bringing about higher imports and lower exports. [ D10. ] Several industrial companies in India have made public stock offerings since August, with a total value of $1.9 billion - more than was raised in India's stock market in the 1970's. [ D10. ] China reported that its industrial output fell in October from a year earlier. [ D10. ] China has moved to bail out foreign auto ventures suffering because of a Government austerity program. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Ventures with foreign partners are fast, inexpensive ways to expand abroad. But the fallout rate is high and problems do not usually surface right away. Business Scene: Louis Uchitelle. [ D2. ] Analysts see promise in some smaller electronics companies, despite profit declines at Zenith and Motorola. Market Place. [ D6. ] Most of the drop in bond yields has taken place, and the next sustained move, starting sometime next year, will take yields higher, analysts say. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Topics of The Times; When 'Lean' Is Fat
description: A Congress more conscious of public health and nutrition is finally moving to toughen food labeling rules. Legislation just approved by a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee would require more explicit nutrition information on package labels. But the bill would still permit misleading nutrition claims on packages.

title: Clamor in the East; Georgian Legislature Asserts Right to Leave Soviet Union
description: Georgia's legislature declared today that the republic's incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1921 resulted from a military intervention and said it retained the right to secede.

title: Montana to Allow Shooting of Bison
description: The National Park Service says it will try to keep a herd of about 400 bison at Yellowstone National Park from roaming onto Montana rangeland this winter, and Montana state officials say they are ready to have the animals shot if they wander north of the park.

title: Road Builders Confident In Battle With Sinkholes
description: Until an underground limestone cave collapsed beside an unopened stretch of Interstate 78 in September and left a crater 20 feet deep, the sudden emergence of sinkholes had been the bane only of farmers in this rural corner of northwestern New Jersey.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Clamor in the East; Walesa Discusses Poland's Relations With Its Jews
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, told a vast audience of Polish-Americans today that they should not be afraid to acknowledge a troubled historical relationship with Poland's Jews.

title: Semtech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
