description: b-After a gain of $30,000, or 1 cent a share, from an adjustment in accounting. Figures included results of Polycore Electronics Inc., since its acquisition in September 1988.

title: Southwestern Bell Picks Chief
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation has named Edward E. Whitacre Jr. its chairman and chief executive. He will succeed Zane E. Barnes, 67 years old, who will retire on Dec. 31 after leading the company for 16 years.

title: Question Box
description: Rookie to Legend Q. Among all the players voted rookie of the year in the major leagues, how many have gone on to be voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame? A. A total of 86 players have won rookie-of-the-year honors since the award was instituted in 1947, and so far only 7 have fulfilled their promise enough to be enshrined in Cooperstown. The National League has had 44 rookies of the year because it had the first two winners in 1947-48, when only one top rookie was chosen for both leagues. Six of the 44 made the Hall of Fame. The American League, with 42 top rookies, has only one Hall of Famer: Luis Aparicio, a rookie shortstop with the Chicago White Sox in 1956 and an inductee in 1984.

title: Tofutti Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Oilers 5, Blackhawks 4: Mark Messier scored 8 seconds into overtime last night as Edmonton won at home. Messier, who set up three earlier goals, took a long breakout pass from Kevin Lowe and broke in alone on Alain Chevrier. The Blackhawks had tied the game midway through the third period on goals 91 seconds apart by Doug Wilson and Steve Larmer, both set up by Denis Savard.(AP) Canucks 2, Sabres 2: Igor Larionov scored on a power play early in the third period to give Vancouver a home-ice tie with Buffalo. It was the second power-play goal in two games for the Canucks, who had failed to score in their previous 19 manpower advantages.(AP) N.B.A. Lakers 120, Bullets 115: Magic Johnson had 25 points, 14 assists and 10 rebounds, and a reserve center, Vlade Divac, scored 17 points in 17 minutes as Los Angeles beat Washington at Inglewood, Calif. After the Bullets closed to 5 points down, at 105-100, with 6:42 remaining, Divac scored 6 straight points.(AP) Rockets 132, Heat 94: Sleepy Floyd, who did not start for the first time this season after going scoreless in his previous game, had 23 points to go with Mitchell Wiggins's 26 as Houston won at home last night. The Rockets had lost their last three games against the Heat dating back to last season when Miami was an expansion team.(AP) Trail Blazers 119, Sonics 109: Terry Porter and Jerome Kersey each scored 8 points in the third period as Portland built a 24-point lead and then coasted to a home-court victory. Porter and Clyde Drexler each finished with 20 points.(AP) AUTO RACING Wallace Wins Championship: Dale Earnhardt outclassed the field in the Atlanta Journal 500 in Hampton, Ga., yesterday, but Rusty Wallace managed to overcome tire problems and hang on for a 15th-place finish to earn the $1 million Winston Cup championship. The season-ending race at Atlanta International Raceway was marred by the death of Grant Adcox, a 39-year-old driver from Chattanooga, Tenn. Adcox died after suffering head and upper-chest injuries in a one-car crash. He was the first driver to die in a Nascar race since 1984.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;
An Honor for Maxim
description: LEAD: Fifty six years ago in Cleveland, an admirer likened the rat-tat-tat left hand of a 13-year-old amateur boxer named Giuseppe Antonio Berardinelli to a Maxim machine gun. His name, which would have had sportswriters typing out extra syllables and sent announcers and fans stumbling over them, was shortened to the more manageable Joey

title: Production Operators Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clamor in the East; People's Revolt: Will East Berlin Leaders Survive?
description: The people, not their Communist leaders, are still driving the revolution that has seized East Germany, and it is not clear whether they will be satisfied with what the new party leader, Egon Krenz, and his Government have promised so far.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Given the changes today that we see in Eastern Europe, I think it's possible to contemplate the possibility over the next few years that we may indeed be able to reduce the level of our deployments in Western Europe.'' -Defense Secretary Dick Cheney [ A1:6. ]

title: Ms. Oursler Wed To James Veltrop
description: Carroll Grace Oursler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Oursler Jr. of Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to James David Veltrop, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Veltrop of Jefferson City, Mo. Herbert Blinder, a member of the Washington Ethical Society, performed the ceremony at the Oxon Hill (Md.) Manor.

title: Bellwether Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are less than one cent a share.

title: Clamor in the East; A Hungarian Gambles And Reclaims a Legacy
description: From Budapest to Trieste to New York and Chicago, to Milan, Florence and finally back to Budapest, Peter Zwack's life has reflected the twists and turns, the ups and downs, the dreams and nightmares, of his native land.

title: Forum Re Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Washington at Work; For the Chairman of a Powerful Committee, the House Is No Longer Home
description: The insurance company executives who invited the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee to address them on the subject of budget cuts and tax increases last month are still talking about the speech. Few had ever seen Dan Rostenkowski more discouraged.

title: Clinton O. Mayer Jr., Broker, 91
description: Clinton O. Mayer Jr., a broker with Drexel Burnham Lambert who was believed to be the oldest member of the New York Stock Exchange, died of heart failure Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 91 years old, lived in Manhattan, and continued to go to his office each day, his family said.

title: Lebanese Greet U.S. Envoy As He Backs New President
description: Thousands of Lebanese gave a festive welcome today to the United States Ambassador to Lebanon, John McCarthy, as he formally presented his credentials to Lebanon's new President and handed the Lebanese leader a letter of support from President Bush.

title: Notre Dame Line Stands Out
description: Before the football team from the University of Notre Dame began to prepare for its attempt to remain on top of both major news-agency polls for a second consecutive season, there was the question of whether the intense leadership of last year's seniors would be adequately replaced.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bain & Co., Boston, a management consulting firm, promoted Pete Dawkins, the retired Army brigadier general and football star, and Pat Graham to vice chairman posts.

title: Rally's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Epitope Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Theodore A. Rath, a retired president of Bloomfield College and a Presbyterian minister, listed his survivors incompletely. They include his wife, Lottie Mahoney Rath.

title: Review/Music; An Opera by Mascagni, And It's Not 'Cavalleria'
description: Such was Pietro Mascagni's reputation in 1901 that his new opera, ''Le Maschere,'' appeared in seven cities simultaneously. None, it goes without saying, were in America - a fact that was underlined tonight in Tarrytown, where the Westchester Opera presented what it calls this piece's United States premiere.

title: A Creative Wanderer's New Home
description: HAVING resigned as the top creative executive at the New York office of Hal Riney & Partners in August after a disintegrating creative relationship with Mr. Riney, Bob Cox is joining Shaw & Landey, a small New York agency that is changing its name to Cox Landey & Partners.

title: Harmony on Ice in the East
description: College hockey in the East is once again pursuing a love-thy-neighbor theme. The two Division I leagues, the Eastern College Athletic Conference and Hockey East, have ceased their fractiousness and there could be as many as 44 interleague games this season, depending upon the outcome of tournaments.

title: Arkansas Allowing 4 Companies To Explore Public Diamond Mine
description: The State of Arkansas has decided to allow four mining companies to conduct exploratory drilling in the nation's only public diamond mine.

title: A Visit to Shattered School Helps Healing Process Begin
description: Lauren Russo, who is 8 years old, last saw the cafeteria at East Coldenham Elementary School on Thursday, when a tornado showered her and dozens of other children with glass and brick, killing 7 of them and injuring 16.

title: Rangers Top Neilson Ratings
description: Roger Neilson, the coach of the Rangers who spends his rare idle minutes breaking down game video tapes, spends most of his many working hours encouraging his players to break down their season.

title: Question for Catholics; Communion Ban for California Legislator Gives Bishops Choice That Could Backfire
description: Only a week after leading members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy denied that they planned to apply religious penalties to Catholics who support abortion rights, one bishop has done exactly that.

title: Phillips Cables reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Soothe a Bad Back on a Full-Swing Exercise Plan
description: LEAD: JACK NICKLAUS and Lee Trevino, both 49 years old, have at least one thing in common with the average middle-aged American golfer: a bad back.

title: Colin Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Video Age and the Wall That Opened
description: ''It's Batman!'' screeched a little boy named Gregor, whose family joined hundreds of thousands of other East Berliners on a day's outing to the West when the wall that had divided the city for almost three decades was opened. Gregor was excited by a display of Batman dolls. ''It's Batman and Batman and Batman!'' he announced and began humming the ''Batman'' theme song.

title: Calmat Suit Settlement
description: The Calmat Company said Friday that it would repurchase shares and pay a one-time special dividend of at least 10 cents a share under a lawsuit settlement that has received preliminary court approval. Under the settlement, Calmat, a cement maker, said it would immediately begin a repurchase of a million shares and would buy back additional shares in the amount of $30 million. Trading in Calmat's stock was halted before announcement of the agreement. Calmat said the agreement was related to shareholder class action suits filed in California Superior Court. Company executives were not immediately available for comment.

title: U.S. Inquiry Into Theft From Apple
description: A former Apple Computer Inc. engineer has said he was served with a grand jury subpeona and told by a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent that he is a suspect in a theft of software used by the company to design its Macintosh computer.

title: Miss Greenberg Weds Douglas Angoff
description: Robin Beth Greenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Greenberg of Bulls Head, S.I., was married yesterday to Douglas Michael Angoff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Angoff of Princeton, N.J. Rabbis Gerald Sussman and Murray Garber officiated at the Marlboro (N.J.) Jewish Center. Mrs. Angoff, 27 years old, is an associate merchandising manager at Macy's in New Springville, S.I., where her mother, Audrey H. Greenberg, is the store's personnel assistant. The bride attended the State University of New York at Albany and graduated from Brooklyn College. Her father, a vice president of National Westminster Bank USA in New York, is on the board of Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Gymnastics for the 'Ordinary'
description: LEAD: AFTER victory in the 1984 Olympics, the gymnast Mary Lou Retton got her picture on a Wheaties box. It is safe to say that none of the 400 or so gymnasts who work under the tutelage of Drago Mehandzic dream of ever being similarly honored.

title: Packers Shock 49ers, 21-17
description: The Green Bay Packers had every chance to fold here this afternoon, every chance to slip or slide or stumble in the manner that most teams do against the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers: Game on the line. Big-play drive. Joe Montana passing to someone from nowhere. The 49ers win.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this holiday-shortened week is confined to the regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills today. The outstanding three-month bill was bid late Friday at 7.68 percent and the six-month bill was bid at 7.68 percent.

title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Message of Defeat
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo, at Gettysburg, Rails at 'New Slavery'
description: On the 126th anniversary of the Gettysburg Address, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that Lincoln never would have tolerated the ''new slavery'' of homelessness, drugs and despair or the ''national tentativeness and political timidity'' with which those problems are being met.

title: Accord on Utility Takeover
description: A two-year struggle for control of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire apparently ended Saturday night when the stockholders and creditors tentatively agreed that Northeast Utilities of Connecticut should take over the bankrupt company.

title: Making Tritium at Savannah River Now Faces Delays of Up to 2 Years
description: Engineers repairing three nuclear reactors at the Savannah River Site in South Carolina now believe that the first supplies of a radioactive gas vital to atomic bombs will not be available until July 1991 and full production will not begin until the summer of 1992.

title: Pamela Nuytkens Weds F. J. Davis
description: At the Burden Mansion in New York, Pamela Nuytkens, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Nuytkens of Pleasantville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Frederic J. Davis, the son of Helen Davis of East Hampton, L.I., and Clive Davis of New York. The Rev. Timothy Ives, a Congregational minister, and Rabbi Joseph Gelberman officiated.

title: Emerson Buckley, 73, An Opera Conductor
description: Emerson Buckley, a former artistic director of the Greater Miami Opera and the tenor Luciano Pavarotti's conductor, died of emphysema at his home in Miami on Saturday. He was 73 years old.

title: New-Music Festival; The Festival's Finale: 11 Bands on 4 Stages
description: For its finale, New Music America presented ''Night of a Thousand Bands'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night - actually, 11 bands in four hours on four stages, with concertgoers free roam. The lineup was diverse (jazz, rock, Minimalism, African music, Iranian or Cambodian pop and sundry hybrids), and audiences, each member on a self-selected itinerary, were casual but attentive; the offerings made it hard to go wrong.

title: Continental Mortgage & Eqity reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Graphic Scanning reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $621,000.

title: Paul Shyre, 63, Director, Actor And O'Casey Adapter, Is Dead
description: Paul Shyre, a playwright, director and actor who specialized in character anthologies, died of septisimia, infections linked with AIDS, yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: Japan, Weary of Barbs on Trade, Tells Americans Why They Trail
description: In one of the most sweeping critiques of the United States ever offered by an ally, Japan is telling the Bush Administration that it ought to upgrade schools, invest in scientific research, close the Federal deficit and take other drastic steps to improve American industrial competitiveness.

title: St. Francis Keeps Title
description: St. Francis Prep of Queens successfully defended its Catholic High School Football League title yesterday by defeating St. Anthony's, 22-15, at St. John's University's Redmen Field.

title: 3 Are Arrested in Subway Killing
description: Three men and a woman on a Manhattan subway train were involved in the fatal stabbing of another rider yesterday afternoon in what appeared to be a revenge killing, the police said.

title: Ms. Becker Wed To Todd Gardner
description: Barbara Lynn Becker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Becker of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Todd David Gardner, the son of Jane Whitelaw Mason of Port Washington, L.I. Cantor Jacob Yaron performed the ceremony at the North Shore Country Club in Glen Head, L.I.

title: Adams Resources & Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Maxwell Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Turning Restrictions Into Design Benefits For 'Grand Hotel'
description: As the audience enters the Martin Beck Theater for each performance of ''Grand Hotel,'' it is immediately confronted by an enormous and compelling two-level vision of brass and glass that moodily evokes the decaying elegance of 1928 Berlin, the shadowy time and place in which the musical is set.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Vetoes Aid Bill President Bush vetoed a $14.6 billion foreign aid bill that includes new help for Poland and Hungary but also includes aid for the United Nations Population Fund. Page A5. Tentative Pact at Boeing Negotiators for the aircraft manufacturer and its machinists agreed to terms that could end a seven-week strike. Union members are to vote on the package today. Page A12. Leftist Gains in Brazil Luis Inacio da Silva, a leftist labor leader, reportedly won a place in Brazil's presidential runoff, setting the stage for a left-right clash over the nation's future. Page A3. Charge Clouds Steel Deal Union members are upset about concessions that saved a Birmingham, Ala., steel plant after a Federal charge that union negotiators were given big pensions. Page A18. Cuts at Education Board The incoming New York schools chancellor says he will try to trim about $20 million from the board's budget by cutting 200 jobs. Page B1. U.S. Gains in World Cup The United States qualified for next summer's final round of soccer's World Cup by beating Trinidad and Tobago, 1-0. Sports Monday, page C1.

title: Officer Is Shot Twice, But Is Saved by Vest
description: A police officer was saved by his bulletproof vest last evening when somebody took two shots at him from a wooded area on Staten Island, the police reported.

title: D.O.C. Optics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1989 third quarter earnings reflect writeoff associated with the closing of six unprofitable locations and the 1988 quarter reflects a one-time reserve for a lawsuit contingency.

title: Gandhi Seeking the Votes of Women
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, facing a strong challenge in national elections this week, today used the anniversary of his mother's birthday to try to bolster his political standing among India's women.

title: Boeing and the Machinists' Union Reach Accord on Contract Terms
description: The Boeing Company and negotiators for the machinists union agreed to a tentative contract today that could end the 47-day strike by 57,000 workers in nine states.

title: Frito to Tracy-Locke
description: Frito-Lay Inc. awarded its regional advertising and marketing accounts last week to Tracy-Locke, a Dallas agency and subsidiary of the Omnicom Group. A Frito-Lay spokeswoman declined to give the budget of the account, but said that the company would channel more of its overall marketing budget into regional promotions. Frito-Lay, a subsidiary of Pepsico Inc., spent more than $25 million on advertising in 1988, according to Leading National Advertisers.

title: Dinkins Lands in Puerto Rico For 8 Relaxing Days at Resort
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins arrived today at a beach resort here from New York City for an eight-day vacation.

title: International Consumer Names New President
description: When Robert B. Freeman was a bank loan officer, Bruce Hahn came to him for a business loan. ''I laughed at him at first,'' Mr. Freeman recalled last week, but then lent him the money, and the two became acquainted.

title: A.B.C. Names Pearson
description: The Audit Bureau of Circulations named Dan F. Pearson chairman on Friday at its 75th annual conference in New York. Mr. Pearson, who will serve a one-year term, is group director of RJR Media Services, a division of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. James M. Anderson, president and chief executive of McKim Advertising Ltd., and S. Scott Harding, national retail advertising manager of Sears, Roebuck & Company, were elected vice chairmen.

title: S.A.S. Builds on Global Alliances
description: Jan Carlzon is a weary man.

title: Giants Grind One Out
description: The Giants never seem to do things easily. They ground their way to a 15-3 victory over the Seattle Seahawks today while wasting one scoring opportunity after another.

title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Medical Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Action Auto Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Expected Reactions
description: To the Editor:

title: New-Music Festival; 6 Hours of Works That Tick Without a Clock's Evenness
description: The invention of the clock changed our perception of time - and therefore our perception of music. It was as if the pounding of the heart had been exposed to the outer ear. Daily life took on a relentlessness previously less noticed.

title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Pilots Insist a Federal Crackdown Has Led to Overly Harsh Penalties
description: A Government effort to crack down on pilots of small planes who violate Federal rules is meeting widespread resistance and even disregard, and some people in aviation say the effort may have become counterproductive.

title: Canada's Dollar Defies the Trend
description: While the yen, the West German mark and other European currencies have fallen against a strong American dollar this year, the Canadian dollar has been the odd man out: it has risen in value.

title: International Broadcast Sysems Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; Electronic Niches Provide Growth
description: DESPITE problems facing the $42 billion electronics components industry, some smaller companies in high-growth niche markets are showing significant earnings momentum.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11 ?A major Japanese critique of the U.S. says it should upgrade schools, invest in research, close the deficit and take other drastic steps to improve American competitiveness. Page A1 Pickens's Japanese battle becomes a trade issue D6 Czechoslovakia used force for the third consecutive night against more than 10,000 demonstrators calling for the end of Communist rule, witnesses reported from Prague. A1 President Bush vetoed an aid bill that includes money for the new programs just approved by Congress to assist Poland and Hungary. A5 Marches in eight East German cities continued to call for an end to Communist domination. But Egon Krenz repeated his commitment ''to remain a socialist state.'' A11 News analysis: East Berlin's rulers are not driving the nation's revolution, the people are. And it is not clear whether people will be satisfied with what has been promised. A11 For German-Americans, joy and fear A11 Amid hope in Bulgaria, old ways may die hard A10 A Hungarian gambles and reclaims a legacy A10 Walesa discusses Poland's relations with its Jews A11 The Archbishop of El Salvador said that there was a ''strong indication'' that the six prominent Jesuits shot to death last week had been slain by members of the armed forces or people close to them. A1 A Brazilian trade unionist won a place in Brazil's two-man presidential runoff, scheduled for next month, voting analysts said. A3 Moscow assailed a Senate resolution that sides with the Armenians in the regional Soviet quarrel, calling it ''brazen and unwarranted'' and a ''relapse into the cold war.'' A10 China expressed indignation over sanctions passed by Congress last week to protest the supression of the democracy movement in June. A6 Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi promised a $3 billion plan to improve the status of women, a powerful political force, on the anniversary of his mother's birthday. A3 Peshawar journey: More skulduggery A4 National A12-21, B10 The Administration may cut troops in Europe even further than proposed earlier. Deliberations on reductions are being driven by restraints on the Pentagon's budget and the pace of reforms in Eastern Europe. A1 Astronomers have detected a light coming from close to the edge of the universe and hence near the beginning of time. The quasar discovery could upset current understanding of how the universe evolved. A1 Birmingham, Ala., has been shaken by Federal indictments charging that the USX Corporation bought a 1983 labor pact by paying off union negotiators with fat pensions. A18 Boeing agreed to a tentative contract that could end the 47-day-old strike by 57,000 workers in nine states. A12 The Senate rejected a repeal of the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act in a final attempt to salvage part of the program. A1 Washington at Work: Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has been stumbling after tax defeats. A14 Tax writers reach pact to raise revenue D1 Is the U.S. headed for a recession? Data show that the economy is suffering from a severe downturn, and economists are not optimistic about the prospects of quick recovery. D1 Engineers repairing three reactors in South Carolina believe that the first supplies of a radioactive gas vital to atomic bombs will not be available until 1991 and that full production will not begin until 1992. A12 A computer engineer is suspected of stealing and distributing secret software designs. They were taken by a group that said it wanted to see ''the genius of a few Apple employees benefit the entire world.'' D5 News analysis: The Catholic stand on applying sanctions to abortion-rights backers may have to be clarified after a bishop barred a politician from receiving communion. A16 Arkansas will allow mining concerns to conduct exploratory drilling in the nation's only public diamond mine. About 78,000 visitors a year pay $3 a day to dig there. A18 Strategies to prevent pollution before it happens have become the focus of environmental efforts by industry and government. A19 An F.A.A. crackdown on errant pilots of small planes has met wide resistance and disregard. Some aviation experts say the tough new measures may be counterproductive. A20 Privately owned toll roads, the first since the late 1800's, could ease pressure on states to build or repair their roads, bridges and tunnels. B10 Tests indicate that Florida girl, 10, is child of claimants A21 Quake survivor is dead from respiratory failure A12 Lack of experience seen in nominee for patent post D2 Regional B1-8 An ex-drug addict is giving needles to drug users to stem the spread of AIDS. Jon C. Parker's crusade defies the laws of several states, and he goes on trial in Boston in January. A1 Joseph Fernandez has told parents, business executives and labor leaders that he is prepared to eliminate up to 200 jobs at the New York City Board of Education's headquarters in an effort to save up to $20 million. B1 Is Senator D'Amato vulnerable? After recent allegations against his fund-raising practices, the Democrats are maneuvering to take him on in 1992. That has prompted him to build an even bigger war chest. B1 Some Syracuse students are angry at several recent sexual attacks on women and at what one female student called ''a series of sexist and racist incidents on campus.'' B1 A town has voted to remain dry in New York State, defeating by more than 2 to 1 a measure that would have legalized alcohol sales for the first time since Prohibition. B1 Children injured by a tornado in Newburgh last week returned to their boarded-up school building with parents and relatives to try to heal wounds left by the windstorm. B3 In Pennsylvania, Governor Cuomo said Lincoln would never have tolerated the ''new slavery'' of drugs, despair and homelessness. His speech marked the 126th anniversary of the Gettysburg Address. B7 The collapse of underground caves, once the bane of only farmers, now worries engineers building a highway atop uncharted honeycombs of limestone in northwestern New Jersey. B3 Three arrested in fatal stabbing of Manhattan subway rider B3 Moratorium on sewer hookups hampers Westchester builders B6

title: Eastco Industrial Safety Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New-Music Festival; A Lavish Ethnic Potpourri
description: Saturday night's spectacle at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the finale of the New Music America festival, required a good cardiovascular system to take the willing body from theater to theater. This reviewer managed to ingest five shows in four hours; while the bites were small, the cooking was exceptional.

title: Bridge
description: The final day of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals began here this afternoon with a foursome of world champions bidding strongly for a second major title. Steve Robinson of Arlington, Va., Peter Boyd of Falls Church, Va., Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif., won the world team title in Miami Beach in 1986 and the Men's Teams here six days ago.

title: Brazil Labor Chief Gets Place in Runoff
description: Luis Inacio da Silva, a leftist trade unionist known popularly as Lula, won a place today in Brazil's two-man presidential runoff, scheduled for next month, voting analysts said.

title: Donnelley Develops a Way for Magazines to Get Personal
description: Gutenberg he is not, but, oh! can Fred Clarke move type.

title: Review/Television; Garcia Marquez Takes Part In Shaping His Cyrano Tale
description: The Nobel Prize-winning writer Gabriel Garcia Marquez, born in Colombia and now living in Mexico, has a lively interest in television, seeing it as an opportunity to reach a mass audience with ideas and quality, ''the same quality that is brought to literature.'' Going beyond theorizing, he has been directly involved with several television dramatizations based on his writings. One, ''Letters From the Park,'' is the most recent presentation on public television's ''Great Performances'' and is being repeated on Channel 13 at 11:30 this evening. On every level, this is indeed quality. The story, offering a variation on ''Cyrano de Bergerac,'' was inspired by a passing mention in Mr. Garcia Marquez's ''Love in the Time of Cholera.'' The screenplay is credited to him with Eliseo Alberto Diego and to Tomas Gutierrez Alea. The co-production of Television Espanola S.A., and the International Network Group S.A., was made in Cuba and directed by Mr. Gutierrez Alea. The year is 1913 and the scene is Matanzas, not far from Havana. The story is so simple, we are told at the outset, that the main characters are named Juan, Pedro and Maria.

title: Rapes Alter Student Life At Syracuse
description: Like many of her classmates at Syracuse University, MaryEllen DiGennaro was frightened when two students reported being raped in the first two weeks of school. What was even more alarming, she said, is that one of the young women was attacked in the bushes near the home of the school's chancellor.

title: Com Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Senate Spurns Move to Cancel Long-Term Health Care Plan
description: The Senate tonight rejected a conference agreement to repeal the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, intended to protect 33 million older Americans from the high cost of acute, extended illness.

title: Hach Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Indian Companies in Wave of Stock Offers
description: Wary of political change as national elections draw near, more than 10 prominent industrial companies in India have made public stock offerings since August with a total value of $1.9 billion - more than the entire amount raised in the nation's stock market in the 1970's.

title: Fernandez Says He'll Cut Up to 200 Jobs
description: Joseph A. Fernandez, the incoming Schools Chancellor, told groups of parents, business executives and labor leaders over the weekend that he is prepared to eliminate up to 200 of the 5,200 jobs at the Board of Education's central headquarters in an effort to save $15 million to $20 million.

title: China Moves to Aid Joint Ventures in Autos
description: China has moved to bail out foreign auto ventures hurt by a Government austerity program, the official China Daily said today.

title: On Cambodia: Immoral, and Pointless
description: Why won't the world, even now, recognize reality in Cambodia?

title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; Sad World of Heroin
description: To the Editor:

title: China's Industrial Output Declined 2.1% in October
description: In another sign of growing economic difficulties, China has reported that its industrial output fell in October compared with a year earlier. It was the first year-to-year decline in industrial production in a decade, since China revamped its economy.

title: Anna K. Danneman and Dr. Neal Neuman Wed
description: At the Old Mill in Rose Valley, Pa., Anna K. Danneman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Danneman of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Neal S. Neuman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Neuman of King of Prussia, Pa. Rabbi Mayer W. Selekman officiated.

title: Clamor in the East; Moscow Protests to U.S. Over 'Interfering' on Armenia by a Senate Panel
description: The Foreign Ministry summoned the American Ambassador today to protest as ''brazen and unwarranted'' a resolution passed last week by a Senate panel that focuses on Armenian-Azerbaijani tensions in the Soviet Union. The Soviet officials, who are upset that the resolution criticizes the Kremlin's handling of the ethnic clashes, called the panel's move a ''relapse into the cold war'' and chided the panel for ''interfering'' in a delicate ethnic problem.

title: Greenspan's Lincoln Savings Regret
description: In late 1984, Alan Greenspan, then a private citizen, took on a consulting assignment for the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and its owner, Charles H. Keating Jr. Five years later, Mr. Greenspan, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is finding that four-month job a source of embarrassment and regret.

title: Book Industry's Confidence Hurt by Shake-Ups and Cuts
description: For the first time within decades, the book industry is beset by a crisis of confidence. While heads of houses still exude optimism in their public statements, in private it is difficult to find a publisher of general-interest books who has not been shaken in the last year - and especially in the last few weeks.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 20, 1989: MONDAY BancFlorida Finl Corp Genuine Parts Co Baxter Intl Inc PHH Corp Crane Co Tyco Labs Inc First Intst Bancorp TUESDAY Bandag Inc Interlake Corp Briggs & Stratton Corp KN Energy Inc Century Tel Enterprises Marsh & McLennan Cos Coleman Inc Ohio Edison Co Crossland Sv FSB Bklyn Public Svc Enterprise Gp EG&G Inc Service Corp Intl Gap Inc Utd Telecommunications Harsco Corp WEDNESDAY Ocean Drilling & Expl Co Pennsylvania Pwr & Lt

title: Michael Anthony Jewelers reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $19,000 loss from discontinued operations. The company said the latest quarter included a pre-tax gain of $445,000 on the sale of the assets of its Enca division, after providing for an approprate reserve of $450,000.

title: Dallas Sells Rights For Slims to Japan
description: The rights to the Virginia Slims of Dallas have been sold to a Japanese advertising agency, leaving the city without either a women's or men's professional tennis tour event for the first time in 20 years.

title: Campaign on Harmony Backfires for Benetton
description: The Benetton Group is under attack for a double-barreled advertising campaign that has apparently backfired. Its ''United Colors of Benetton'' campaign is cleverly designed to sell the Italian retailer's colorful line of casual clothes - while at the same time creating valuable good will by promoting unity between people of different races and cultures.

title: Milwaukee Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
National Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest periods' results included pre-tax charges of $4.6 million and $6,230,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, for discontinuation of software.

title: Investors Seek Control of Xtra
description: An investment group led by Robert M. Gintel, a senior partner of the Greenwich, Conn., brokerage firm Gintel & Company has acquired a 7.6 percent stake in the Xtra Corporation.

title: Germany's Unity, Europe's Rebirth
description: LEAD: ''I am not afraid of reunification,'' Francois Mitterrand has said. ''If the Germans want to be a single nation in a single state, this must be founded on the will of the German nation, and nobody can oppose it. What counts is what the Germans want.''

title: Oneita Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Oneita said year-ago net income figures are pro forma to reflect income tax adjustments; the year-ago per share earnings is presented on a non pro forma basis.

title: Bush Vetoes Bill Including Aid to East Europe
description: President Bush tonight vetoed a $14.6 billion foreign aid bill that includes money for the new programs just approved by Congress to assist development of free-market economies in Poland and Hungary.

title: China Irate at Congress Sanctions
description: China expressed ''utmost indignation'' today at a Congressional package of sanctions approved last week to protest the crackdown on the democracy movement.

title: A Stand-Down for Naval Justice?
description: ''I have a problem here. I'm not ready yet.'' ''There is a problem in center gun.'' Anxious crewmen uttered those words seconds before the explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard the U.S.S. Iowa last April. As Congress probes the Navy's investigation of the disaster, these still unexplained words haunt the tragedy's aftermath - and dramatize how inconclusive and unjust is the Navy's case against a gunner's mate who died in the blast.

title: Dealing With Pollution Before, Not After, It Happens
description: Dealing with pollution in the United States has generally meant dumping, burning, recycling or treating the millions of pounds of waste that the country spews forth every day. Today, with little fanfare, industry and government are pursuing a new approach: prevention.

title: Weigh-Tronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics of The Times; Congress Steps Ahead
description: Last week, Congress acknowledged what President Bush will not: that galloping population growth merits attention. It voted to contribute to the U.N. Fund for Population Activities.

title: States Turn to Business To Help Build Highways
description: Strapped and hoping to build a road from here to Dulles International Airport, Virginia decided to revive a Colonial-era solution: Let private business build the road and profit from the tolls.

title: MicroAge Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Review/Concert; The Chamber Society Seeks to Prove a Musical Point
description: According to advance publicity, the works the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented in three concerts at Alice Tully Hall over the weekend represented what Fred Sherry, the group's new artistic director, likes to call ''sculptured'' programming. With Charles Wuorinen's String Sextet cushioned between Mozart's String Quintet in C (K. 515) and Brahms's String Sextet in B flat (Op. 18), Mr. Sherry predicted, ''the similarities in compositional techniques, infinitely more significant than the differences in style, will become readily apparent.''

title: Review/Ballet; Not Quite Angelic 'Angels' Abet an Earthly Love Duet
description: If the Joffrey Ballet's eight-day ''Nutcracker'' run, which begins on Friday, is as superbly danced as its repertory season has been, New Yorkers will be in for more of a company performing at its fervently scaled peak.

title: D'Amato Says His Opponents Won't Stop Him
description: ''I need you for this one,'' Alfonse M. D'Amato, the junior Senator from New York, implored on the telephone. ''You know why.''

title: Arizona Land Income Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9-month results are unavailable as the company went public on June 13, 1988. Latest quarter and 9 months included a loan loss of $270,000 relating to a prepayment agreement with the maker of one of its mortgage loans with a principal amount of $3,387,000.

title: Officer Adds Top Post In Pall Corp. Changes
description: The Pall Corporation, which has grown through a singular devotion to one product, the filter, has named Maurice G. Hardy, its president, to the additional post of chief executive in a management changeover.

title: Donaldson Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $176,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Victoria Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lotus Development Chooses Scali, McCabe
description: Saying it had outgrown its current agency, the Lotus Development Corporation awarded its account last week to Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Scali edged out the incumbent agency, Leonard Monahan Lubars & Partners, which was a finalist in a competition that earlier included Lowe Marschalk; Ammirati & Puris; Mullen, and Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

title: From Player To Coach: Bumps in The Ice
description: DURING the 1979-80 season, when he was 26 years old and a rookie head coach in the National Hockey League, Gary Green worried about the major and minor challenges of his profession.

title: Indictment Clouds Deal That Saved a Steel Plant
description: What was once the South's biggest steel city has been shaken by Federal indictments charging that the USX Corporation secretly awarded fat pensions to union negotiators in exchange for the ground-breaking labor concessions that saved its steel works here in 1983.

title: Review/Music; Gilbert and Sullivan as They Were In an Exhibition of Memorabilia
description: Sir Arthur Sullivan once said he thought history would remember him, if at all, as the composer of religious music like ''Onward Christian Soldiers,'' and had he never met Sir William S. Gilbert that might well have been the case.

title: Ivax Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dr. Koniaris Wed To S. L. Georges
description: St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Astoria, Queens, was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Dr. Soula G. Koniaris, a resident in pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, and Steven L. Georges, the director of financial analysis for CBS Inc. in New York. The Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos performed the ceremony.

title: New-Music Festival; 10 Souls Act Out the Mysticism of 'Kabbalah'
description: The composer Stewart Wallace and his librettist, Michael Korie, made quite a splash this year with the premiere of their ''Where's Dick?'' cartoon opera in Houston. Thursday night at the Dance Theater Workshop, as part of the New Music America festival, saw the premiere of a new Wallace-Korie work of musical theater called ''Kabbalah.'' This writer attended the Friday performance, and there will be four more, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday nights at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3. The workshop is at 219 West 19th Street.

title: Review/Music; Accent on the Sacred
description: Rossini had given up opera composition in 1829, three years before he began setting his Stabat Mater. But it was in the opera house that he cut his compositional teeth, and although he couched most of the Stabat Mater in a sacred choral style, he was not entirely able to banish the greasepaint from the music. Every now and then - in the tenor aria,''Cujus animam gementem,'' for example - the operatic impulse cannot be suppressed.

title: Public TV's Plan: Cut Red Tape, Diversify Shows
description: The public television establishment, prodded by an angry Congress, unveiled a plan last week that would streamline its bureaucracy, centralize national programming, redistribute Federal financing and, it promised, bring more diversity to the screen.

title: Ms. Oxorn Weds Leonard Mades
description: Pearl Oxorn and Dr. Leonard Mades were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Rabbi Martin J. Zion. The bride is a daughter of Ida Futterman of New York and the late Samuel Futterman. Dr. Mades is the son of the late Ella Bernstein of Brooklyn.

title: Miles to Go for Test
description: In the two months United States track and field athletes have been subjected to short-notice drug testing, no athlete has produced a positive test result, although problems continue with the collection process.

title: Yes, Toughen Ethics. But Not Quite Yet.
description: A new, tough code of ethics is causing turmoil in the Koch administration's waning days. Some New York City workers worry that the new rules, scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1, will prevent them from getting decent jobs in the private sector if they wait around to find out if Mayor-elect Dinkins wants to retain them.

title: Nominee for Patent Post Facing Heavy Criticism
description: The Patent and Trademark Office is usually one of the quietest wings of the Federal Government. But when President Bush recently nominated an attorney with almost no patent experience to become deputy commissioner, he provoked an angry outburst from groups representing inventors and patent attorneys.

title: National Media reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jail Terms for Negligent Bosses
description: When the history of the 1980's is written, Howard Elliott may get an asterisk -but not for reasons he would like. He is the first person the Government jailed for violating job safety laws.

title: Some Say Rates Are Near Bottom
description: The slow, steady decline in bond yields over the last six months or so has pushed long-term interest rates to within shouting distance of their lowest levels of the 1980's.

title: Municipal Art Society Gives President's Medal to Couple
description: The Municipal Art Society presented its President's Medal to Marian and Andrew Heiskell at a dinner at the Century Club last night.

title: American Financial Enterrises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Emily Rose Wed to James H. Marrow
description: Emily Rose, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Rose of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Prof. James H. Marrow, the son of Helen C. Marrow of Miami Beach and the late Jerome Marrow of New York. Rabbi Hillel Levine, the director of the Center for Judaic Studies at Boston University, performed the ceremony in New York at the Plaza hotel.

title: Tests Indicate That Girl, 10, Is Child of Claimants
description: Genetic tests on a 10-year-old girl who has been at the center of a controversy over possible baby-switching at birth indicate that she is the child of the couple who claim her, not of the man who has raised her, the couple's lawyer said today.

title: Dance Teacher Rallies To Win
description: Dance Teacher, a vastly improved filly since being switched back from grass to dirt this fall, parlayed her newfound sharpness into a Grade I victory yesterday when she rallied from far back to win the $235,200 Ladies Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Profits Flat For Hewlett
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported Friday that its profit was nearly flat in its fiscal fourth quarter, depressed by its acquisition of Apollo Computer Inc. and costs associated with the California earthquake.

title: Rutgers Tops Columbia, 3-1
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Nov. 19 -

title: Japanese Grip the Pentagon in a Chiplock
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; How Too Much Success Undid Speaker Jim Wright
description: The Ambition and the Power By John M. Barry 768 pages. Viking. $22.95.

title: AIDS Battler Gives Needles Illicitly to Addicts
description: Jon C. Parker spent a recent sunny Saturday morning doing what he does most weekends - breaking the law by handing out clean hypodermic needles to drug abusers, hoping to prevent the spread of AIDS.

title: Review/Music; Youth, on Stage and Page
description: The New World String Quartet gave a program at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night that might have been subtitled ''relative youth on the brink of bigger things.'' These young Americans played Beethoven's Quartet in D from Opus 18, Gyorgy Ligeti's ''Metamorphoses Nocturnes,'' and, with Gilbert Kalish as pianist, the Brahms F-minor Quintet.

title: Penta Systems Intl reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $634,000, or 12 cents a share, from the extinguishment and settlement of debt. c-Net loss

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Consumer Price Index Oct. Wednesday Durable Goods Oct. Thursday None Friday None

title: Eagles Plod to 10-9 Victory Over Vikings
description: Cris Carter made a juggling catch of Randall Cunningham's deflected pass with 2 minutes 32 seconds left to give the Philadelphia Eagles a 10-9 victory over the Minnesota Vikings today in a mistake-filled game.

title: Southern Philippines Seems To Reject Autonomy in Vote
description: Voters appeared today to have rejected a measure providing limited autonomy for parts of the southern Philippines, a region rocked by conflict between Christians and Muslim separatists.

title: Comverse Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss All share earnings are less than one cent a share.

title: Metro Matters; Subway Service: Is It Any Better? Or Worth More?
description: A year ago, the Transit Authority revamped schedules and opened new stations in what it touted as the greatest number of service improvements since New York City's subway system opened in 1904.

title: Angio-Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Russell Stanhope, 90; Manufactured Pilings
description: Russell C. Stanhope, the founder and president of R. C. Stanhope, a manufacturer of steel pilings, died Thursday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 90 years old and also lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Tax Writers Reach Pact to Raise Revenue
description: Tax negotiators from the House of Representatives and the Senate have reached a tentative agreement on about $5.3 billion in revenue-raising measures as part of their contribution to a plan Congress is trying to fashion to reduce the deficit.

title: All American Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patriots Rally to Defeat Bills
description: Maurice Hurst put New England ahead on a 16-yard interception return with 2 minutes 49 seconds left as the Patriots came from behind with 20 points in the last 8 minutes and beat the Buffalo Bills, 33-24, today.

title: Clamor in the East; Despite Promises of Reform, East Germans March Again
description: Tens of thousand of people marched in at least eight East German cities today, continuing to press their demands for free elections and an end to Communist domination.

title: Australian Pilot Exodus
description: About 150 Australian airline pilots have left for jobs outside the country as a four-month-old wage dispute with domestic airlines drags on, a pilots' union spokesman said Friday. The spokesman for the Australian Federation of Air Pilots said members had taken jobs throughout Asia, the Middle East and Europe. The 1,647 pilots resigned after the domestic airlines rejected their proposal for a 29 percent wage rise and took legal action against them.

title: Low-Level Nuclear Waste Plan Makes No Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Clamor in the East; Amid Hope in Bulgaria, Old Ways May Die Hard
description: As Bulgaria's National Assembly went through the motions on Friday of naming a president, one lawmaker stood up to praise the preordained choice, Petar Mladenov, the new Communist Party leader.

title: More Delay Seen in Delivery Of New Jet for the President
description: The Air Force had hoped to present President Ronald Reagan with a new Air Force One in time for his Thanksgiving vacation last year. Now the jet probably will not be ready for President Bush before mid-1990, several officials say.

title: We Can Control Drugs, but We Can't Ban Them; For Their Own Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Armand Berard, 85; Was French Envoy To United Nations
description: Armand Berard, a former French delegate to the United Nations, died this morning at his home in Neuilly, a suburb of Paris. He was 85 years old.

title: Peshawar Journal; In Skulduggery's City, Afghan Feuds Find Home
description: In the capital of the Northwest Frontier Province, winter is the season for polo. On fields where officers of the British garrison once sharpened their skills, pilots of the Pakistan Air Force thunder back and forth, as skilled on horseback as they are practicing dogfights at the Khyber Pass in American-made F-16's. Between chukkers, valets move quietly among the players with pots of sugary tea.

title: Data Are Signaling Bad Slump
description: With the release of each week's data, the message is growing clear: the United States economy is suffering from a severe downturn, perhaps the worst of the last seven years.

title: Hot Hands
description: Kombi Ltd., a company based in Naugatuck, Conn., uses heating circuitry in its 1990 line of heated gloves and footwear. The system includes a rechargeable battery, measuring three inches by two inches, to produce heat. The warmth passes into the glove through hairlike conductors that are much finer than wire.

title: Clamor in the East; For German-Americans, Joy and Fear
description: German-speaking New Yorkers in and around the Ridgewood section of Queens, long a center of German-American life, have been having some second thoughts about the tumult in East Germany.

title: Villanova Gains Playoff Slot
description: Villanova was invited and Connecticut spurned yesterday by the selection committee for the Division I-AA football playoffs. Both had 8-3 overall records and shared the Yankee Conference championship with Maine with 6-2 marks.

title: Interfund Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Outdoors: Perfecting the Quiet Art of Still-Hunting for Deer
description: THERE may come a time when the big whitetail buck you are after steps into the open in a forest glade 50 yards away totally unaware of your presence, but don't count on it. Such easy opportunities are rare.

title: Business Scene; Foreign Partners And Compatibility
description: WITHOUT a doubt, a joint venture with a foreign partner is the fastest and least costly way for a manufacturing company to expand abroad. Thousands are being formed, but as they proliferate, American companies are learning, sometimes painfully, that these partnerships require constant revamping to survive.

title: Arts Chief's Potholed Path to a Grants Decision
description: John E. Frohnmayer, the low-key lawyer and arts administrator from Portland, Ore., approached his job as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts with caution when he took office on Oct. 10. But before he had been at his post a month he aroused the wrath of a wide spectrum of artists and arts leaders.

title: 'Have to Kick It Straight'
description: JUST when Raul Allegre was leading the National Football League with 20 field goals, he pulled up with a damaged muscle in his right thigh, his kicking leg. And yesterday, the Giants' kicker was a strange new name: Bjorn Nittmo, a blond baby-faced 23-year-old left-footed rookie who grew up playing soccer in Sweden, never saw a football game until he attended Enterprise (Ala.) High School as an exhange student and was on the Giants' developmental squad as a free agent out of Appalachian State in Boone, N.C.

title: Salvador Bishop Links Military To Killing of 6
description: The Archbishop of El Salvador today accused members of the military of killing six Jesuit priests shot to death last week.

title: Wilshire Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. IS CONSIDERING SHARP REDUCTIONS IN EUROPEAN FORCE
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Bush Administration is discussing proposals for troop reductions in Europe that would go well beyond the cuts now being negotiated in Vienna by NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

title: Rimoil Corp reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Laclede Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
United's Pilots Drop Threat
description: United Airlines pilots have abandoned their threat to stop flying 747-400's, a move that gives some hope to renewed efforts toward an employee buyout of the airline, United's parent company said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Philosophical Look At Skiing by Carroll Raj
description: In its first campaign since being founded in May, Carroll Raj Stagliano has turned to an unlikely figure to evoke the freedom of skiing -Socrates. In the 30-second television commercial for the Rossignol Ski Company, a French manufacturer, a narrator intones, ''Socrates said, 'No man is ever truly free.' '' Then, as a downhill skier slashes across the screen, the narrator adds, ''Socrates never skied.''

title: Lionel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Longtime Foe of Religious Right Urges Schools to Teach the Sacred
description: The television producer Norman Lear, long seen as a firm believer in the separation of church and state, urged public schools today to nurture the sense of the sacred that he says underlies all religions. It was the first time he had spoken out so strongly on the subject.

title: Proposed Accounting-Rule Shift on Valuing Securities Distresses Bankers
description: Bankers and their regulators are distressed by proposed accounting rules being considered by a committee of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. Bankers say the rules, if adopted, could cause bank earnings to fluctuate more widely with changes in interest rates and thus disrupt the bond market.

title: The S & L Scandal's Cruel Truths
description: Charles Keating and his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association illuminate a particularly shady phase of the thrift scandal: lavish political contributions . . . senators meddling in regulation . . . regulators waffling . . . and finally, a $2 billion bailout. But Lincoln is just one chapter in a sorry history that discredits all involved - the industry, regulators, Congress and the Reagan Administration. Unless the lessons of that history are fully grasped, the rot will persist and another crisis will explode.

title: Eastern and AMR Resume Talks
description: Eastern Airlines has resumed talks with the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, about selling Eastern's Latin American routes and other assets.

title: Salvadoran Security Forces Raid Episcopal Church, Arresting 17
description: Stepping up a crackdown on religious workers, Government security forces raided an Episcopal church before dawn today, arresting 17 lay workers, including 6 foreigners, and seizing documents.

title: Coachman Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHH Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,433,000, or 14 cents a share.

title: Basque Legislator Is Slain In Shooting in Madrid Hotel
description: Two masked gunmen entered a hotel today and opened fire on a group of Basque politicians, killing one legislator and wounding another.

title: Trans World Music Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: Latest quarter and 9-month periods included a one-time charge amounting to 6 cents a share for costs associated with termination of its operations in all Crazy Eddie stores. Latest 9-month period also included a charge of 17 cents a share for costs and litigation expense relating to the use of a discontinued service mark.

title: Inmac Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the dedication of a refurbished halftime room at the Yale Bowl in New Haven misidentified the alumni shown. They were, from the left, Blake Walker, Dick Jenkins and Bob Blanchard.

title: Mets Add 8 to Roster
description: The Mets raised their winter roster to 39 players, one short of the maximum, when they promoted eight minor leaguers yesterday, including two sons of well-known former players: Todd Hundley, a catcher, the son of the former Cub catcher Randy Hundley, and Jaime Roseboro, an outfielder, the son of the former Dodger catcher John Roseboro.

title: Careers; An Unusual Background Helps Get Job
description: FEW women could have more anchors to windward than Martha R. Grabowski. At 32 years old, she recently received a $675,000 three-year Government contract to design a software system to help helmsmen steering tankers avoid causing a huge oil spill like that of the Exxon Valdez, which ran aground in Prince William Sound in March.

title: Minven Gold reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Regarding the 1988 results--the company was formed in August 1988 when MFC Mining Finance Corp. and Brohm Resources Inc. merged. The company said comparative figures have been prepared as though Minven was in existence throughout the entire comparable year-ago period. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Browning-Ferris reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ABORTION AT ISSUE IN PRESIDENT'S TRIP
description: Acting after a day of campaigning for two prominent Republicans who advocate abortion rights, President Bush vetoed a budget bill for the District of Columbia tonight because it would permit the use of locally raised money to pay for abortions.

title: Postal Investigators Ask Senators For Power to Stop Mail Deception
description: Federal postal investigators told a Senate panel today that they needed broader enforcement powers to stem deceptive fund-raising mail from private groups whose letters often look like they came from the Government.

title: Two Sides of the Contemporary South: Racial Incidents and Black Progress
description: A rising tide of racial incidents across the South, including attacks and cross burnings, has provided a sour counterpoint to a decade of electoral progress by blacks.

title: Working Rigs Decline
description: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs declined by five last week, to a total of 1,040, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today, It was only the second decline in the last 12 weeks. Nevertheless, there were still 117 more rigs actively exploring for oil as of last Friday than there were a year earlier.

title: How to Reduce Military Spending
description: For some time now, there has been no mistaking the direction in U.S. military spending.

title: Spectrum Information TechFnologies Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $167,930, or 1 cent a share.

title: U.N. Official Assails Curbs on Aid to Afghans
description: The United Nations official in charge of coordinating supplies of aid for Afghanistan expressed concern today that the United States and other countries are withholding donations in order to weaken the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul.

title: New Lasers Pierce Veil Of the Cell
description: NEARLY a decade after the first X-ray laser was triggered by the explosion of a nuclear bomb, a gentler version has been harnessed in a revolutionary new type of microscope capable of revealing the smallest details ever seen inside living cells.

title: 2 Foreigners Resign
description: Nick Faldo of England and Bernhard Langer of West Germany, the respective Masters champions of 1989 and 1985, have resigned their membership in the Professional Golfers Association. An official of the PGA Tour, who asked that his name not be used, said the two golfers had told tour headquarters of their decisions and would play a restricted American schedule in 1990.

title: Parcells Pleased, but Finds Fault
description: Over all, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants was pleased today.

title: Jacobson Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
In Schools, New Emphasis on Environment
description: The group of boisterous 7-year-olds from the Horace W. Porter School straightened up when Tom Callinan strummed the guitar chords. It was a song they had sung before, a song about garbage and the endangered habitats of river and forest animals.

title: Astro-Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
SR Telecom Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax recovery of $195,000. c-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Lottery Told to Abstain
description: David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, yesterday urged officials of the Oregon State Lottery Commission to drop their plan to add professional basketball to the lottery's Sports Action betting game. He said the game would harm the N.B.A.'s reputation by making fans more interested in point spreads than in the performances of the teams. Stern made the remarks in Salem, Ore., where the commission was taking testimony about the proposal.(AP)

title: Britain's Delay Called Costly
description: Britain's European Competition Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, told employers today that Britain's delay in becoming a full member of the European Monetary System is harming the nation's industry.

title: Striker Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Roger F. Nelson, Banker, 59
description: Roger F. Nelson, retired vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died of lung cancer Saturday at his home in Stuart, Fla.. He was 59 years old and lived in Darien, Conn., until he retired.

title: Lifecore Biomedical reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Article 466889 -- No Title
description: The future could be $500,000 richer for the writer who dreams up a story that ends with the survival and prosperity of all life on our planet. That is how much the winner of the Turner Tomorrow Award will receive when selected in the late spring of 1991.

title: 250 Protesters Disrupt Times Square Traffic
description: About 250 demonstrators protesting United States involvement in El Salvador briefly blocked the streets south of Times Square yesterday, snarling traffic during the evening rush hour.

title: Field Set For Finals Of Cup
description: After a two-and-a-half-year qualifying program that ended Sunday, 24 nations have made it to the 1990 World Cup soccer finals in Italy in June. Along with the traditional favorites are several underdogs: South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Costa Rica, Egypt, Cameroon and, for the first time since 1950, the United States.

title: Review/Music; Contrast of War and Strauss's Forgiveness
description: Given Richard Strauss's easy relationship with the warlords of modern Germany, one approaches the idea of ''Friedenstag'' with some suspicion. This ''Day of Peace'' had its Munich premiere in 1938 and was played for Berlin audiences a year later. One could hardly blame many among those first listeners if their minds occasionally wandered from Strauss's message of forgiveness and reconciliation. They were, after all, busy devising the systematic violence that lay just around the corner for the rest of Europe.

title: Vigilance Training For the Big City
description: To the Editor:

title: AIDS Art Show Is Canceled Over a Banner
description: An art exhibition about AIDS that was to open at the Henry Street Settlement House on Dec. 1 has been withdrawn by its curator because of a dispute over the display of a banner on the building. The banner was proposed by Gran Fury, a group of artists and others that designs banners, posters, billboards and other works about AIDS for mass display. The 8-by-12-foot banner was to have carried the words, ''All People With AIDS Are Innocent.''

title: Onex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $2.4 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $5 million, or 22 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $800,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $3.8 million, or 17 cents a share, for the 9 months. Per share figures in both periods are after the effect of a stock dividend in the latest first quarter. The company said lower results in the latest period reflected an accounting adjustment that left out earnings from the Ball Packaging Products Canada Inc. joint venture formed last December. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Chinese Region Uses New Law to Sterilize Mentally Retarded
description: The provincial government in this poverty-stricken region of northwestern China is aggressively enforcing a new law requiring the sterilization of mentally retarded people.

title: KEY RATES
Guilty Plea by Hakim Likely, CBS Reports
description: Albert Hakim, who helped set up the maze of shell companies and overseas bank accounts in the Iran-contra affair, is expected to plead guilty Tuesday as part of a plea bargain with the Goverment, CBS News reported tonight.

title: Ascent From the Heights
description: They have met only seven times - once as collegians with a national championship at stake, the six other times as pros. But theirs is still one of basketball's pre-eminent matchups: Patrick Ewing of the Knicks versus Akeem Olajuwon of the Houston Rockets, unquestionably the dominant big men in the game today.

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The share data adjusted for 5 percent stock dividend paid in May 1989 and for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1989.

title: By Design; High-Style Sweatshirts
description: Once again, let's hear it for bicycle messengers. They may be a menace in city traffic, but they are a continuing source of fashion inspiration. Now, their hooded sweatshirts have become a popular style statement.

title: Baker J.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Crude Oil Prices Advance; Taking of Deliveries Cited
description: Crude oil prices advanced, bolstered by the large number of actual deliveries against the spot December futures contract, which expired yesterday.

title: Social Security Bill Doesn't Lash at the Elderly; No One Gave Us a Thing
description: To the Editor:

title: General Kinetics reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: China to Repay More Bonds
description: China's repayment of loans from its own citizens will reach a peak next year, a Chinese Foreign Ministry official said recently.

title: Army Offering To Cut 200,000 From Its Payroll
description: The Army has proposed eliminating as many as 200,000 civilian, reserve and military employees and giving up on the long-sought modernization of its main battle tank, the M1, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Firebomb in Brooklyn Kills Boy and Burns 2
description: A 4-year-old boy was killed and a man and a woman were critically burned yesterday when a firebomb was tossed into a grocery store in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Princes Caught Off Guard And an Editor Is Sacked
description: The publisher of The People newspaper announced today that its editor had been dismissed for publishing photographs of Princes William and Harry that were deemed be ''not acceptable.''

title: Greece Gets Private TV
description: A commercial television station owned by five newspaper publishers went on the air today in Greece, ending a state monopoly and promising objectivity in news and variety in entertainment programs. At least two more private channels are preparing to go on the air soon. A law was passed last month allowing independent television broadcasts. The new channel will present Greek, European and American movies, television serials, sports and variety and game shows. Until today the state-run Hellenic Radio Television Corporation controlled the nation's only two television stations.

title: A President Beholden
description: By vetoing the foreign aid appropriations bill, President Bush has made clear his blind fealty to the right-wing zealots who he fears will turn against him if he retreats an inch - even an imaginary inch -from his cruel stand against abortion.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Bozell has signed a venture agreement with Korea First Advertising, Seoul, South Korea, to start a new agency, to be called Cheil Bozell.

title: Review/Television; Finding Out What Music Is And How It Really Works
description: ''What Is Music?'' asks tonight's offering of ''Nova.'' Although no conclusive answer is forthcoming, the hour, at 8 P.M. on Channels 13 and 49 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 21, touches many strings. It moves from the synthesizing of sound, to the reproduction of violins that are said to approach the quality of the renowned 17th- and 18th-century instruments, to how performers bring their personalities to bear on musical scores, to what happens when the sounds of music creep in our ears.

title: Shaw Cablesystems reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Results for fiscal 1989 included a loss resulting from the sale of floating-rate preferred shares equal to 5 cents a share. Results for fiscal 1988 included a loss of 12 cents a share from the sale of its investment in Canadian Home Shopping Network Ltd. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Sudden Winds Reach 100 M.P.H. As Storm Sweeps New York Region
description: A severe line of thunderstorms with damaging winds swept through the New York metropolitan area last night, toppling trees, blowing out windows, disrupting some electrical service and causing scattered subway and traffic delays, officials said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Columbia Gas System Service Corp., Wilmington, Del., named Geoffrey L. Pickard vice president of corporate communications.

title: Mauna Loa Macadamia Parters L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Acme-Cleveland reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $315,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,850,000, or 29 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,400,000 for the quarter and year, the quarter and year included liquidation of inventories valued under the LIFO method which decreased net loss by $2.2 million and $4.5 million, respectively. Latest year's income from continuing operations of $5,154,433 included non-recurring other income of about $1 million, or 16 cents a share. Year-ago quarter's loss from continuing operations of $25,150,253 included unusual and non-recurring charges of $25.7 million and the year's loss from continuing operations of $29,491,177 included unusual and non-recurring charges and move-related expenses of $25.9 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 14 headed ''Tidioute Journal,'' about a Pennsylvania town that overcame water pollution problems, understated the sum made available by the state to improve drinking water and waste systems. A state agency, Pennvest, offers grants of up to $500,000 a community and loans of up to $10 million or in some cases more.

title: Slain Suspect Had Hidden On East Side
description: In the last weeks of his life, while being sought as the killer of a Federal drug agent, Constabile (Gus) Farace hid in the East Side apartment of a suspected drug dealer in Manhattan, Federal prosecutors disclosed yesterday.

title: Interim F.D.A. Head Is Named
description: James S. Benson will be named interim commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Secretary Louis W. Sullivan of the Department of Health and Human Services said today.

title: Robert Pace, 85, Dies; Ex-Chief of University
description: Robert S. Pace, president of Pace University from 1942 to 1960, died of respiratory failure Sunday at King's Row Adult Residence in Middletown, N.J. He was 85 years old and had lived in Monmouth County since 1968.

title: Nuclear Metals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Drugs Sought to Halt Damage to Brain Cells After Head Injuries
description: IN experiments that could lead to a dramatic shift in treatment, researchers say they are developing drugs to stave off the irreversible brain damage that typically accompanies strokes and other head injuries.

title: Vestro Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a reversal of a tax-loss carryforward benefit of $16,000.

title: International Power Machines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures for the latest quarter and 9 months included the operations of Lortec, acquired in March, and Modulair, acquired in September.

title: Pop Radio Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Stallings, Set to Leave, Is Instead Dismissed
description: The Phoenix Cardinals dismissed their head coach, Gene Stallings, yesterday and named the running-backs coach, Hank Kuhlmann, as his replacement on an interim basis. The announcement came shortly after Stallings said he would not seek to have his contract renewed at the end of the season.

title: Chess
description: There are times when the research into some opening or other becomes so complex, so tortuous and so chaotic that even those grandmasters who in general favor such severe struggles yearn to return to something more disciplined and more manageable. Every once in a while they are fortunate enough to uncover something that smacks of the cleancut touch of a Jose Raul Capablanca or a Bobby Fischer.

title: Spinnaker Software Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Comparable results are not available; the company went public in June.

title: Business and Health; Benefit in Treating AIDS at Home
description: THOUSANDS of AIDS patients are receiving nursing care and medication in their own homes instead of in hospitals, and experts say this is better for their health and can also be cost-effective. ''Ninety percent of the care of AIDS patients ought to be provided out of the hospital,'' said Dr. David E. Rogers, chairman of AIDS advisory groups for New York State and New York City.

title: Interand Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Skin Troubles May Be Tied To Anxiety
description: LEAD: Scientists at the University of Pennsylvania who are studying the early stages of skin inflammation say they have found indications that stress and anxiety may contribute to such diseases as psoriasis, eczema and acne.

title: Agassiz Resources reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Theater; Rex Harrison Back on Broadway
description: When Rex Harrison makes his long-awaited star entrance, the evening's last, in the Broadway revival of ''The Circle,'' one can't help wondering: Why does he need to do this?
