title: Dr. Israel Sarov, 55; Devised Chlamydia Test
description: Dr. Israel Sarov, an Israeli virologist who developed a test to detect the sexually transmited disease chlamydia that was approved last month by the United States Food and Drug Administration, died of a heart attack on Thursday while attending a medical conference in Honolulu. He was 55 years old and lived in Omer, Israel.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., Nutley, N.J., a pharmaceuticals company and subsidiary of Hoffman-La Roche Ltd. of Switzerland, said a judge in Mississippi had reversed a $1 million grand jury award for compensatory damages that was granted to a former user of the La Roche prescription drug Accutane.

title: Kohl Aide Meets East Berlin Leaders
description: East Germany's new leaders held their first talks today with a senior aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl, while hundreds or thousands of East Germans took to the streets again in Leipzig and several other East German cities to maintain the pressure for change.

title: Deals
description: Football

title: Healthcare International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $768,000. c-Net income and the year included an extraordinary charge of $752,000. The company said the latest fourth quarter loss included a $6.1 million loss from operations and unusual items of $149.7 million. The company has previously said that year-end results would likely include losses from unusual items in excess of $150 million of those items, about $120 million reflect asset writedowns and reserves for loss on disposals.

title: 2 Acquitted in Postal Scheme
description: A Federal District Court has acquitted two former top executives of Recognition Equipment Inc. of charges related to a $400 million procurement scheme involving the United States Postal Service.

title: Review/Music; Spanish Pieces About War By Hesperion XX Group
description: Hesperion XX is an early-music group overseen by two Spaniards, but one that seems to have attracted members from most of the rest of Western Europe as well. These players - led by Jordi Savall playing the viola da gamba and featuring the soprano Montserrat Figueras -came to New York for the first time on Sunday afternoon with a bellicose collection of pieces from 17th- and 18th-century Spain played at the Corpus Christi Church near Columbia University.

title: Review/Concert; From Amsterdam, Early-Music Esprit
description: The battle of the Classical bands continued on Sunday afternoon as Frans Bruggen and his Orchestra of the 18th Century played Mozart at Avery Fisher Hall, where Christopher Hogwood and the Academy of Ancient Music had played Beethoven just two weeks earlier. This was a far more inspiriting affair, though it raised some of the same disquieting questions about the direction the early-music movement has taken of late.

title: Ramsay Health reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $256,000, or 1 cent a share, which included an after-tax gain of about $450,000 from the sale of the company's previously closed Riverwood Hospital. c-Included a tax credit of $111,000.

title: A Giamatti Center
description: A $5.5 million Little League training center, to be built in Bristol in central Connecticut, will be named after the late baseball commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti.

title: Flock Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $465,690 and $447,980 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $105,139 and $83,081 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $193,333, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $27,981, or 2 cents a share.

title: Kaneb Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax benefit of $17,043,000, or 51 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, and extraordinary credits of $1,120,000, or 3 cents a share, and $7,629,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also included a loss of $77,114,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,916,000 for the quarter and $27,655,000 for the 9 months. The income from continuing operations for the latest quarter and 9 months included pre-tax gain of $54,407,000 from sale of partnership units related to Kaneb Pipe Line Partners L.P. The tax benefits represented utilization of tax benefits related to losses on discontinued operations, and the extraordinary credits reflected gains on debt extinguishment. The discontinued operations included a provision of $72.3 million related to its offshore drilling segment. The company said the provision primarily relates to anticipated losses on future operation and the sale of three partnership rigs.

title: Wavemat Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Income Opportunity Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
William Haines, 81, Author and Playwright
description: William Wister Haines, a novelist, playwright and screenwriter whose best-known work was the play ''Command Decision,'' died on Saturday, three days after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 81 years old and lived in Laguna Niguel, Calif.

title: Fay's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend in July 1989.

title: Jury Chosen in Murder Trial Of Man in Crash Fatal to 27
description: Jury selection was completed today in the murder trial a man accused in the deaths of 27 people in a bus accident. The jurors were then taken to view the charred wreckage of the bus and to the crash site.

title: A Ruling On Phone 'Dumping'
description: The International Trade Commission ruled yesterday that American manufacturers of telecommunications equipment have experienced substantial damage because small-business telephone systems from Japan and Taiwan are being sold in this country at unfairly low prices. The ruling paves the way for countervailing duties to be imposed on the imports.

title: Tom Brown Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1988 included an additional charge of $2,422,000 to depreciation and depletion expense for a writedown of costs of oil and gas properties to the estimated value of reserves at Sept. 30, 1988.

title: ABS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Visual Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fighting Spirit Carried Graf to Championship
description: Once again, with a championship at stake, it was Steffi Graf versus Steffi Graf's troublesome health, a familiar predicament for the world's top female tennis player.

title: Methane From Guts of Livestock Is New Focus in Global Warming
description: CARBON dioxide, the heat-trapping gas whose concentration in the atmosphere is rising steadily as humans burn more and more coal and oil, has lately captured the attention of a world that is confronting the question of global warming.

title: Montevideo Journal; Basques Have Lots to Boast of (and at Times Do)
description: From the crack of bare hands driving the ball across the fronton court to the waitresses in green and red serving garlic-laden dishes, a modest downtown club is trying to keep alive an identity brought from the distant Pyrenees.

title: House Bars Salvador Aid Cut
description: The House kept Salvadoran aid intact, but members say it will be cut if the case of six slain priests is not prosecuted vigorously. Page A14.

title: Dow Drops 20.62 Points, To 2,632.04
description: Battered by weakness in military issues, stocks fell broadly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average slumping 20.62 points, to 2,632.04.

title: Critic's Notebook; Kill! Burn! Eviscerate! Bludgeon! It's Literary Again to Be Horrible.
description: Consider these events:

title: Teltronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago net figures are not available; the company had its initial public offering in July.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 In Prague's largest protest since 1968, more than 200,000 marchers called for freedom and a change in government. Page A1

title: U.S. Shoe reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net loss

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Ad Magazine
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies said yesterday that it would publish a quarterly magazine for its members with news and information about the industry. The magazine, called Agency, will be distributed to 50,000 advertising agency employees, with 10,000 more copies going to educators and the news media. The first issue is scheduled for next May. Joe Cappo, the publisher of Advertising Age, said he did not view the new magazine as competition. ''We always look at new publications as a great advertising prospect for us,'' he said.

title: American Medical
description: The private hospital group American Medical International Inc. said it was seeking a buyer for its 65 percent stake in the British concern AMI Healthcare Group P.L.C. Under British rules, any buyer of the stake would be required to make a full offer for AMI Healthcare on the same terms as those offered to American Medical.

title: New York Times Film Wins Business Award
description: ''Taste Ladies and Ink-Stained Wretches,'' a 15-minute film about the history of fashion reporting in The New York Times, has been chosen for an award by CINE, the Council on International Nontheatrical Events, a nonprofit organization that represents international film festivals. The film won a Golden Eagle award in the business and industry category, one of 19 categories in the annual competition.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 12 about immigration fraud referred incompletely to the Government's case against a Newark woman and rendered her name incorrectly. The woman is Sharyn Marval; she pleaded guilty to immigration fraud, a felony, then withdrew her plea. As a second trial on the fraud accusation was about to begin, Mrs. Marval pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was sentenced to three years' probation, 150 hours of community service and a $4,300 fine. The felony charge was dismissed.

title: Lattice Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jobs Are Lost in Plant Shutdown, but So Is Foul-Smelling Air
description: Some people said the odor that hung over Front Royal for almost half a century smelled like money. But that was just an old mill town joke.

title: Carlton B. Lees, Former Official Of Botanical Garden, Dies at 65
description: Carlton B. Lees, a horticulturist and landscape architect who was a retired official of the New York Botanical Garden, died of hepatic cancer on Nov. 12 at his home in Pittsboro, N.C. He was 65 years old.

title: John Adams Life reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Soviet Autonomy Plan Rejected as Too Weak
description: The Soviet Parliament demanded far greater decentralization of economic power today as it firmly voted down a Kremlin proposal to extend only limited economic autonomy to the nation's republics.

title: Campbell Soup Co. Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The company said earnings were lower due to the ''initial dilutive impact'' of financing for its recent acquisitions of the Habitant Brands and Quadelco. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Give Global Warming the Acid Rain Test
description: To the Editor:

title: VSB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $1,208,000 pretax gain from the sale of Student Loan Marketing Association stock. VSB Bancorp was not a public company during the entire period of 1988. Valley Savings Bank converted from the mutual to stock form on Oct. 27, 1988.

title: Homefree Village Resorts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Plan for Small Study Groups in High Schools Needs Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everything we did was fair and accurate. We just couldn't surmount the issue of viewer confusion.'' -Michael Gartner, the president of NBC News, on news dramatizations. [ C24:5. ]

title: Salvadoran Rift: Church vs. Oligarchy
description: When Pope Paul VI named Oscar Arnulfo Romero as the senior prelate in this country in 1977, the wealthy and powerful gave thanks, contributing generously to pay for a consecration ceremony that set a new standard for lavishness.

title: Daka International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said latest quarter results included a net of $300,000 from a change in accounting methods.

title: RUMANIAN LEADER REFUSES CHANGES
description: Using the occasion of a major Communist Party congress, President Nicolae Ceausescu made it clear today that as long as he is in charge, Rumania will not follow other East European countries along the paths toward democracy or capitalism.

title: Slayer of Bellevue Doctor Gets Maximum Sentence: 50 Years to Life
description: Steven Smith, a drifter with a history of psychiatric problems, was sentenced yesterday to 50 years to life in prison for the murder, rape, and robbery of Dr. Kathryn Hinnant at the Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Talks on Wood Yield No Pact
description: Japan and the United States today ended three days of talks on the trade of wood products without an agreement on increasing United States lumber exports to Japan, officials said.

title: Petro-Canada Privatization
description: Petro-Canada, the state-owned oil concern that recently warned it would need a hefty cash infusion and planned to lay off 1,200 workers, may be sold to private investors soon in an offering of stock, analysts said today.

title: Rada Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
From Mere Defense to True Security
description: The Bush Administration seems to be verging on its most farsighted and momentous decision. Defense Secretary Cheney, with apparent White House support, has ordered the military services to produce projected spending cuts of $180 billion-plus in the early 1990's.

title: Galileo Electro-Optics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and the year is after an extraordinary credit of $200,000, or 3 cents a share. The company said the extraordinary item represents cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Article 530189 -- No Title
description: Devora L. has been brain-damaged since birth. Now 7 years old, she is cared for at Mishkon, a Brooklyn residential center for multiply handicapped youngsters. Twice a day, Devora's mother or father comes to visit, to cuddle their little girl and to try to coax her to smile.

title: J. W. T. Ferretti, 63, A Commodities Trader
description: J. W. Todd Ferretti, a self-employed international commodities trader, died of complications from brain surgery Sunday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 63 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Scholars Clash Over Origins of Dead Sea Scrolls
description: MORE than 40 years after a Bedouin shepherd boy discovered the first of the Dead Sea Scrolls in an archeological sensation, scholars who used to argue quietly, if at all, over this or that arcane Hebrew phrase in the documents are now turning on each other in rancorous dispute.

title: Reynolds Joins In Soviet Venture
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said it had entered a joint venture to build a $200 million plant in the Soviet Union to make aluminum foil. It said the plant, in south-central Siberia, is expected to produce 47,000 tons of foil and converted products each year and employ 650 people beginning in 1992.

title: Israelis Fight Over Human Rights Bill
description: The Government of Israel, which often likes to point out that it is the only democracy in the Middle East, is locked in a bruising fight over whether it should enact a law guaranteeing its citizens basic personal freedoms.

title: Transcontinental Realty reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: JLG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
'Legends' Play At the Garden
description: Walt Frazier, Tom Gola, Dick McGuire, Richie Guerin and Johnny Green will don Knicks uniforms again tonight and Red Holzman will return to the sideline at Madison Square Garden to coach in the first Legends Game.

title: Doctors Closing In on Breakaway Cancer Cells
description: CANCER researchers are beginning to make progress in understanding some of their most deadly adversaries, cancer cells that break off from the primary tumor, travel to distant organs and form secondary tumors.

title: Deal Sought For Inquiry Into Lincoln
description: Lawyers for Charles H. Keating Jr., former chairman of the insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, tried to negotiate a deal with the House Banking Committee last week, House staff members said today.

title: Hungarians, Maestros of Ambiguity, Confront a Whole New Political Process
description: Put three Hungarians into a room, people say here, and they'll form seven clubs. So it is as political parties multiply in anticipation of next year's elections for Parliament.

title: Dawson Geophysical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $64,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $123,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: House Rejects Curb on Salvador Aid
description: Heeding an appeal from President Bush, the House of Representatives today rejected Democratic efforts to restrict aid to El Salvador. But legislators warned that aid would be cut next year if the Salvadoran Government does not arrest and prosecute those responsible for the killings of six Jesuit priests last week.

title: BRT Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $230,000 for the quarter and a gain of $379,000 for the year, both on sale of marketable securities. The company said the year-earlier fiscal revenues included $839,000 of discount related to early payoff of a loan.

Seaport Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Sphinx Mining Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the majority of its losses have been non-cash writeoffs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Susan Quirk has been named president and creative director of Quirk & Kramer, Farmington, Conn.

title: Michael J. Jupp, 46, A Children's Advocate
description: Michael John Jupp, executive director of the Washington-based Defense for Children International, U.S.A., died of a heart attack on Saturday at Delaware Valley Hospital, Walton, N.Y. He was 46 years old and had resided in Walton.

title: Hunts Avoid a Liquidation By Settling With Creditors
description: After two weeks of tense negotiations, attorneys handling the personal bankruptcy lawsuits of William Herbert Hunt and Nelson Bunker Hunt and their creditors today averted the scheduled liquidation of one of the former billionaire's estates and paved the way for both to be reorganized.

title: Roanoke Electric Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Progroup Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Zola Helen Ross, Author, 82
description: Zola Helen Ross, the author of dozens of novels and children's books, died last Tuesday after a long illness. She was 82 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: Article 586989 -- No Title
description: Every neighborhood has its givers and takers. In the Canarsie and Flatlands sections of Brooklyn, for years Elaine Stouber was a giver. She dispensed political favors and hinted that she had friends in high places who could get things done. She ran a neighborhood charity and always seemed to be there when people needed help.

title: National Income Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Reviewers Divided on Whittle Move
description: EDITORS of several leading book reviews are divided over how they will treat a new series of books that are sponsored by, and contain advertising from, the Federal Express Corporation. Their decisions could affect the journalistic credibility sought by Whittle Communications, the books' publisher and the creator of several other controversial, advertiser-financed communications vehicles.

title: Krenz Says Party Congress Might Replace Him as Chief
description: Egon Krenz, the East German leader, has held out the possibility that he might be replaced next month as Communist Party General Secretary while retaining his other powerful posts. His remarks came as talk of a possible party split and even of the party's dissolution has spread through the Communist ranks.

title: China Limits Money Moves
description: China has issued new regulations limiting the amount of Chinese money foreigners may change back into hard currency, officials said today. For every $100 a foreigner changes into Chinese currency upon entering, he can leave China with no more than $50.

title: Action at Ford in Britain
description: Union leaders at the Ford Motor Company in Britain today called for a strike vote for 32,000 workers after rejecting a 9.5 percent pay increase. Union officials set no date for the vote. British Ford has offered a 9.5 percent pay rise to workers at its 22 plants for next year, with a rise of 2.5 percent above inflation for the year after.

title: Leon's Furniture reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Noverco Inc. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $6,161,000, or 12 cents a share. Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Sandwich Co-Operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Broncos Reach 9-2 by Stopping Redskins
description: The two teams that played in the 1988 Super Bowl, the Washington Redskins and the Denver Broncos, met tonight, but without their Super Bowl quarterbacks. Doug Williams was on the Washington sideline with a sore back and his Denver counterpart, John Elway, was in the locker room with a stomach virus.

title: 200,000 March in Prague as Calls for Change Mount
description: More than 200,000 marchers called today for freedom and a change in government in the largest and most vociferous public demonstration since the euphoric Prague Spring that preceded the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

title: Books of The Times; Destruction of Young Minds And Some Who Overcame
description: Soul Murder The Effects of Childhood Abuse and Deprivation By Leonard Shengold 342 pages. Yale University Press. $35.

title: 2 More Years for Parish
description: Robert Parish yesterday agreed to a two-year contract extension with the Boston Celtics taking him through the 1991-92 season. Details were not released. But Parish's lawyer, Bob Woolf, said the deal was worth ''close to $3 million a year.''(AP)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Sibra Products, Greenwich, Conn., to Heidelberg & Associates, for its Sinalco and Zeltzer seltzer brands, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Tapes Show Jet Crew Made Proper Checks Before Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today released cockpit recordings showing that the crew of USAir Flight 5050 properly performed all the usual preflight checks before the plane crashed into the East River in New York City after an aborted takeoff on Sept. 20.

title: Rangers Squander Third-Period Lead and Tie Jets
description: It was a game the Rangers had almost stolen, but an inept and infuriating couple of minutes of play in their own end left them reconciled to taking away nothing more than a single salvaged point and a lot of saved face.

title: Margaret Chase Smith Ailing
description: Former Senator Margaret Chase Smith, the first woman to serve in both houses of Congress, was listed in good condition today in a Chicago hospital's intensive care unit after undergoing treatment for chest pains. The 91-year-old Maine Republican, who left the Senate in 1972, was taken to Resurrection Medical Center last week from O'Hare Airport after she became ill on a flight.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a caption on Nov. 14 about the Pelham Bay landfill in the Bronx misidentified a woman who has campaigned for its cleanup. She is Patricia Nonnon.

title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS INDIA-C.I.A. CHARGE
description: Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, today denounced charges printed in an Indian newspaper that the leader of the opposition to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had accepted support from the Central Intelligence Agency and a private American foundation.

title: National Heritage Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter's loss is due primarily to $1.5 million of expenses incurred by the prior National Heritage board and management in the recent contest for control and the proposed spinoff of two subsidiaries. Also, results included a $433,000 charge for the discontinuation of the company's home infusion joint venture.

title: Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results for 1989 included the figures of Glen Culler & Associates since the acquisition of the private computer design and engineering firm in August.

title: Two Red Shifts
description: Just as red stars are being toppled from parliament buildings all over Eastern Europe, astronomers have discovered a quasar with an unprecedentedly large red shift. Are the stars influencing politics or vice versa?

title: Computer Automation reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,947,000 and a loss of $2,670,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $412,000.

title: Angola Rebels Accused of Elephant Kills
description: A retired senior South African Army officer who saw combat in Angola has asserted that guerrillas there have slaughtered thousands of elephants for ivory to help finance their long war against the country's leftist Government.

title: Social Security Bill Doesn't Lash at the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Tecogen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $28,000 and $73,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss of $46,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $11,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: Yount Is Voted M.V.P.
description: It wasn't as close as the 1947 vote when Joe DiMaggio nudged Ted Williams by 1 point in a duel of the titans. It wasn't as close as the 1981 vote when Rollie Fingers won by 11 over Rickey Henderson. And it wasn't even as close as the 1987 vote when George Bell led Alan Trammell by 21 points.

title: Plan for Small Study Groups in High Schools Needs Support; Decentralization Fails
description: To the Editor:

title: Trans-National Leasing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: More Chrysler Cuts Seen by Iacocca
description: The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca, said sluggish car and truck sales might force the company to increase budget cuts beyond a planned $1 billion by the end of 1990. Mr. Iacocca also said additional closings of assembly plants were possible for the nation's third-largest auto maker.

title: For Spring, Patches of Strategically Sited Bare Skin
description: Everybody's doing it. Both established and relatively new designers are carving out new exposures in spring and summer clothes so that evening dresses look like beach clothes in festive fabrics.

title: BGS Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ross Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said it did not report primary share figures for the year- ago quarter and 9-month periods.

title: Market Place; Behind the Military Stock Selloff
description: The outlook for military contractors has grown steadily dimmer since the Reagan Administration's arms buildup peaked in 1985. Still, the news over the weekend that the Pentagon is contemplating deeper spending cuts yesterday sent investors bailing out of virtually all aerospace, shipbuilding and military-technology stocks as Wall Street bet that from a financial perspective at least, the cold war might be over.

title: Immigrant Influx Swells Overburdened New York Schools
description: At the nasal blast of the school bell at George W. Wingate High School, Consuelo Whiskey braces herself for a brisk walk to her next class through throngs of strolling, running, and foot-dragging students: almost 3,200 in a building designed for 2,700.

title: Plexus Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,106,000 and $1,411,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $275,000 and $557,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: Tourists Threaten Buddhist Murals in Ancient Chinese Caves
description: Miles and miles from nowhere, carved into a cliff here in the arid desolation of northwestern China, are 492 caves lined with some of the finest Buddhist art in the world.

title: Results Plus
description: CROSS-COUNTRY Huber Leads Villanova to Victory: Vicki Huber won the individual title and led Villanova to the women's team victory in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships yesterday in Annapolis, Md. Huber, 22 years old, covered the Naval Academy's 5,000-meter course in 15 minutes 59 seconds, a course record. The Wildcats scored 99 points to beat Kentucky, the defending champion, which had 168. In the men's 10,000-meter race, John Nuttall of England and Jonah Koech of Kenya finished 1-2, leading Iowa State to victory over Oregon. N.H.L. Canadiens 3, Flames 2: Andrew Cassels scored his first National Hockey League goal to lead Montreal to a victory at home, extending Calgary's streak without a victory to six games. Also scoring for Montreal were Mike Keane and Bobby Smith, who earned his 600th career assist on Keane's goal. The Flames' goals were by Joel Otto and Doug Gilmour.(AP)

title: Nixdorf Chief Quits Company
description: Klaus Luft, chairman of the troubled Nixdorf Computer A.G., resigned today.

title: Innovative AIDS Drug Plan May Be Undermining Testing
description: The Federal Government's bold new plan to make promising but unproven AIDS drugs widely available at the same time that they are undergoing clinical trials appears to be foundering.

title: Calumet Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Fines Essex $3.4 Million For Not Easing Jail Crowding
description: A Federal judge today fined Essex County $3.4 million for failing to ease overcrowding at the county jail and improve recreational facilities for prisoners there.

title: Setback Is Dealt Nominee for Weapons Post
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today ended the Bush Administration's hopes for obtaining confirmation this year of its nominee to head the Energy Department's nuclear weapons program.

title: Eastern Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Navy Weighs Barring I.B.M. From Contracts
description: The Navy Department is reviewing allegations of procurement irregularities involving the International Business Machines Corporation to determine whether the giant computer company should be temporarily suspended from Navy contracts, a spokesman said today in a telephone interview.

title: Study Cites a Vulnerability to Suicide
description: WHILE media accounts of teen-age suicides alone are unlikely to prompt more suicides, emotionally disturbed teen-agers who have previously been exposed to violence may be more vulnerable to sensational or romanticized representations, a new study has concluded.

title: One Giant Kick for U.S. Soccer
description: In a fitting celebration of America's do-or-die soccer victory over Trinidad and Tobago, the astronaut Manley (Sonny) Carter is taking a soccer ball into orbit this week aboard the spacecraft Discovery. With this stunt Mr. Carter, a onetime college star, later a pro and now a captain in the Navy, is promoting a sport that Americans largely ignore.

title: Merc Expels Franc Trader
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange today expelled a Swiss franc futures trader whose illegal trading was unmasked by an elaborate undercover operation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation earlier this year.

title: ECI Telecom Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Atek Metals Center Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Sherman Plunkett, Former Jets Tackle, 56
description: Sherman Plunkett, an offensive tackle for the champion Baltimore Colts in 1958 and 1959 who starred for the Jets later in his career, died of cancer Saturday at Sinai Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: CONFEREES BACK MAJOR OVERHAUL IN MEDICARE FEES
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed on Monday to overhaul the way the Government pays doctors to treat the 33 million elderly and disabled Americans covered by the Medicare program.

title: Dispatches From the Bus Wars
description: ONE of the major issues at the annual Comdex computer exposition here last week was the rival ''bus architectures,'' or internal data pathways, of personal computers. Until recently the debate has been theoretical.

title: Studies Ask Electronics Aid by U.S.
description: Just as the Bush Administration is reported to be planning cutbacks in support for high technology, two studies issued today warned that the nation faced dire economic consequences unless the Government more actively helped the electronics industry.

title: Ex-President Returns To Job With Stride Rite
description: In 1985, Ronald L. Jackson spent five months as president of the Stride Rite Corporation. He must have made a good impression. Yesterday, Stride Rite brought him back, this time as president and chief executive.

title: Coda Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,977,913 for the latest quarter and $193,202 for the year- earlier period.

title: Plan to Buy New Buses Is Faulted
description: State Senator Franz S. Leichter attacked the New York City Transit Authority yesterday for the proposed purchase of 400 buses, saying they are virtually identical to 1987 models that ''work worse than almost any other buses in the fleet.''

title: Give Global Warming the Acid Rain Test; Go to Nuclear Power
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Plan May Put Man On Mars By 2011
description: A National Aeronautics and Space Administration team has fleshed out President Bush's visions of American outposts on the Moon and Mars with a script that would have four humans arriving on the red planet as early as 2011.

title: General Employment Enterrises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $102,500, or 6 cents a share, from the settlement of certain deferred compensation, and $26,000, or 2 cents a share, relating to the tax benefits on the loss incurred in earlier quarters.

title: VECO Buying Alaskan Daily
description: The Anchorage Times is being sold to an oilfield service company. The sale agreement was signed today by Bob Atwood, publisher and owner since 1935, and William Allen, chairman of VECO International.

title: Q&A
description: Fingernails Q.What causes white spots on the fingernails? And does the half moon at the base of the nail have any function? A.These questions are related, said Dr. Phoebe Rich, a Seattle dermatologist. The commonest cause of the white spots, called punctate leukononychia, is probably mild trauma, such as pushing back the cuticle too hard.

title: Tucson Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Latest quarter results include writeoffs, reserves and adjustments totaling a net charge of $102,337,000. Included in the charge are $64,911,000 from rate order writeoffs; $23,400,000 for reserves related to previously disclosed litigation; and $62,518,000 of investment operations writeoffs and reserves. These items are partially offset by tax adjustments of $48,492,000.

title: Jones Intercable Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jackpot Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in July.

title: Counsel Retires Early; Texaco Successor Set
description: Texaco Inc. yesterday named a new general counsel and said that William C. Weitzel Jr., who led the company through its legal battle with the Pennzoil Company, would take early retirement.

title: Guerrillas Attack in Cambodia
description: About 5,000 non-Communist guerrillas mounted major attacks today to reinforce gains in northwestern Cambodia but met strong resistance from Government troops, a guerrilla official said. The official, from the Khmer People's National Liberation Front led by Son Sann, said 36 Government soldiers had been killed and 26 wounded. Six guerrillas were killed and 36 wounded, he said.

title: Surgery for Worrell
description: The St. Louis Cardinals said yesterday that the relief pitcher Todd Worrell, injured in September, continued to feel pain in his right elbow and would have ligament-transfer surgery Dec. 1. Worrell is expected to need a minimum of five to six months' rehabilitation. Worrell pitched in 47 games last season, compiling a 3-5 record with 20 saves and a 2.95 earned run average.(AP)

title: INSIDE
description: Los Angeles Ethics Plan A Los Angeles panel proposed what it called the toughest ethics code for city officials in the nation. Page A23. NBC Ends Dramatized News NBC News said it would discontinue the use of dramatizations on television news programs. Page C24. The Ecosystem Primer The demand for environmental education is growing in schools across the country. Page B1. Yount Chosen as M.V.P. Robin Yount, the Milwaukee center fielder, is the American League's most valuable player. Page B11.

title: Bonn Aides, in Washington, Say Modernizing Missiles Is Dead Issue
description: The West German Government believes that there is no longer any prospect that NATO will modernize its short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, in light of the movement toward democracy in Poland, Hungary and East Germany, West German officials visiting Washington said today.

title: Helping the Revolution
description: How can we help the great revolution sweeping through the nations escaping captivity? What can we do?

title: McCaw Sweetens Its Offer for Lin
description: In a battle that continues to heat up, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. yesterday sweetened its offer for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation for control of the nation's seventh-largest cellular company.

title: U.N. Assembly Adopts Doctrine Outlining Children's Basic Rights
description: After 10 years of negotiations, it took only two minutes today for the General Assembly to adopt an international Convention on the Rights of the Child.

title: Carl Chambers, 55, Author of Drug Studies
description: Carl D. Chambers, a former research director for the New York State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission, died of complications of a heart attack on Friday at West Pennsylvania Hospital in Pittburgh. He was 55 years old and lived in Athens, Ohio.

title: Walesa in Venezuela
description: Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity movement in Poland, arrived here today after a United States tour, pledging that Eastern Europe and Latin America would work together in improving their debt-ridden economies.

title: Bridge
description: An exciting finish to the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship here Sunday night concluded the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals. A strong finish gave the title to a cosmopolitan group consisting of Zia Mahmood, Michael Rosenberg, both of Manhattan; Sam Lev of Israel; Mark Molson of Montreal, and Chris Compton of Houston.

title: Envirosource Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $40,594,000, or $3.32 a share, for the quarter and $47,469,000, or $3.90 a share, for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $1,510,000, or 12 cents a share. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $19,510,000 and $10,986,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter and 9 months results included $70 million of pretax gains from disposition of discontinued operations. Latest quarter and 9 months losses from continuing operations of $7,804,000 and $13,879,000, respectively, both included a $3.2 million non- recurring charge resulting from the company's decision to retain its envirosafe subsidiary. Year-ago quarter and 9 months figures included a $27 million pretax loss from disposal of discontinued operations, and the 9 months also included a $1.4 million pretax gain. The company said because all of its continuing operations were acquired as part of the March 1988 acquisition of IU International Corp., its results for the latest 9 months period is not directly comparable with the year-ago 9 months.

title: Older Women Lag On Taking Pap Tests
description: Older women were less likely than younger women to have had a Pap test for cervical cancer in the last year, even though the risk of the disease increases with age, the Federal Centers for Disease Control has reported.

title: Supporters of a Trader Anger Industry Critics
description: Testimony by past and present leaders of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in support of a prominent trader who faces disciplinary action has reignited a debate over whether the industry is too rife with cronyism to regulate itself as it does now.

title: Choctaw Has 6.2% of Justin
description: Choctaw Securities L.P., a Kansas City-based investment partnership, has acquired a 6.2 percent stake in Justin Industries and said it believed the shares of the building materials and leather-goods manufacturer based in Fort Worth are undervalued.

title: Contraceptive Vaccine
description: A vaccine injected into female mice prevented fertilization for as long as nine months, and researchers at the National Institutes of Health say similar vaccines may be developed for other mammals.

title: Walton: O'Brien Still No. 1
description: On a team going nowhere, Coach Joe Walton continues to send Ken O'Brien to the football wars. Each week, the quarterback comes back a casualty.

title: South African Draft Resister Fights to Stay in U.S.
description: Craig Demmer, 25 years old, a white South African, is about to spend his fourth winter in New York, far from friends, family and the warm, sparkling beaches of his native Durban. What makes him bitter is not just homesickness but the possibility that he will be forced to return home.

title: Vermont Journal; The Rite Of Autumn Is the Song Of the Rifle
description: A group of red- and orange-clad hunters is grouped around a bloody buck draped across the scales at the weighing station at Junction Sports in New Haven.

title: Patterns
description: The Klein Image

title: Genex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Leonardo Sciascia, 68, A Novelist and Essayist
description: Leonardo Sciascia, an Italian novelist and essayist whose work explored political corruption and crime in his native Sicily, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Palermo. He was 68 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; DeJoseph Joins Deutsch
description: Jeff DeJoseph will be bringing the mystique of account planning, the advertising research system that includes consumer attitudes as a factor in the creative process, to another agency. Mr. DeJoseph, 34 years old, has joined Deutsch as executive vice president and director of strategic services. Trained by Jane Newman, who introduced planning at Chiat/ Day/Mojo in New York, he later joined Lord Einstein O'Neill & part-ners. At Deutsch, he said, ''The job is to make the marketing side as creative as the creative side.''

title: George Washington Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Smoke Detection Sends Jet Back to Boston; 4 Are Hurt
description: An American Airlines flight carrying 165 people made an emergency landing today shortly after taking off from Logan Airport here. Smoke had been detected in a rear cargo bin.

title: Hallwood Energy Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: In the 'New' Europe, Puzzling Out Roles
description: Western diplomats and officials, considering how to encourage liberalization in Eastern Europe, say that the easy thing is deciding to give generous aid to Communist countries that move to hold free elections.

title: Infodata Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Is Reportedly Speeding Talks For Accord on Global Warming
description: The United States is prepared to quicken the tempo of negotiations for an international agreement on how to deal with global warming, the nation's chief environmental official said today.

title: Salvadorans Die, Bush Dawdles
description: LEAD: The history of El Salvador bears consistent witness to the greed and brutality of men who look on compromise as weakness and who regard torture and murder as routine and acceptable methods of coping with dissent. The failure of U.S. policy makers to press for a negotiated end to the war in El Salvador has placed our country in league with a clique of assassins masquerading as an army.

title: Girl Dies After Crash Near Newburgh School
description: A 5-year-old girl injured in a car accident Sunday down the street from the tornado-damaged East Coldenham Elementary School died this afternoon, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: A Trackball for Places Mice Have Roamed
description: A TRACKBALL is an upside-down mouse, with the ball on the top, to be moved with the fingers, rather than on the bottom, to be moved with the whole hand. In either case, the movement of the ball is echoed on the screen, moving a pointer to make selections, draw lines, etc.

title: Rigid Ethics Code Is Urged In Los Angeles Government
description: In a move that supporters hope will be a national model for cleaning up corruption, a special commission proposed a new ethics code today for Los Angeles's city government, calling it the toughest and clearest such measure in the country.

title: U.S. Securities Advance in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday, as market participants failed to follow-through on a rally that began during overnight trading in the Far East.

title: Majors Seeking Player Claims
description: Players who played in the major leagues in 1985 are being asked to submit claims as their share of the $10.5 million an arbitrator says baseball club owners owe players as redress for collusive acts four years ago.

title: Our Towns; Why One Man Delivers Pizzas For His Living
description: Two years ago in October, Harold O'Garra Jr. of Huntington Station, then 29 years old, saw a newspaper advertisement seeking a real estate salesman, and since he had a real estate license and some experience, he decided to apply for the job.

title: Perils Seen In Warnings About Abuse
description: A SHARP dispute is emerging over whether nationwide efforts to educate young children about the dangers of sexual abuse are instilling fears and confusion more often than they prevent such abuse.

title: Concord Computing reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Texas Instruments Taking Write-Off
description: In an announcement that took Wall Street analysts by surprise, Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it would record a special charge of $55 million against its fourth-quarter profits and would eliminate 1,500 jobs.

title: Notebook; Taunts From a Packer Put 49ers in 'Smoke'
description: ''Hey Harris,'' yelled Eric Wright, a San Francisco 49er cornerback. ''How many sacks do you have?''

title: Armand Berard, 85; Was French Diplomat
description: Armand Berard, a former French delegate to the United Nations, died on Sunday at his home in Neuilly-sur-Seine, a suburb of Paris. He was 85 years old.

title: NHI Nelson Holdings Intl Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $1,228,000, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,602,000, or $1.27 a share, for the 9 months. The company recently changed its name from Nelson Holdings International Ltd. following a 1-for-10 share consolidation.

title: NOMINEE ASKS BUSH TO REMOVE NAME
description: President Bush's nominee to the Agriculture Department's leading environmental post asked the White House today to withdraw his name from consideration after it became clear that he faced insurmountable opposition in the Senate.

title: Tax Break for Fuel Additive
description: To bolster the nation's corn farmers, the Treasury Department said today that it planned to give a tax break to a new ethanol-based fuel additive that President Bush brought to public attention last summer.

title: Family Steak Exploring Sale
description: Family Steak Houses of Florida Inc. said it had retained the Paine Webber Group to assist in the review of strategies for the enhancement of shareholder value, including the possible sale of the company.

title: Optimumcare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Amdahl Reduces Work Force by 5%
description: The Amdahl Corporation said it had reduced its work force by about 5 percent, to 8,300 employees. Amdahl said the cutbacks, which are effective immediately, were coming after a period of rapid growth and would return employment levels to about the same as at the beginning of 1989.

title: Hechinger Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said its latest third quarter results included closing costs associated with its Charlotte distribution center of $1,200,000 written off during the quarter. The company also said its latest 9 months results included income of $3,200,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Caligiuri's $10 Million Explosion
description: Paul Caligiuri does not know if he will be on the United States soccer team at the World Cup in Italy next June. Having made the biggest play in the history of American soccer is no guarantee.

title: Msgr. John Heneghan, 80, Diocesan Aide
description: Msgr. John J. Heneghan, a former chancellor of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and pastor emeritus of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Astoria, Queens, died of cardiac arrest Friday at the home of a cousin. He was 80 years old and lived in Queens.

title: U.S. Sues Law Firms on Cash Clients' Names
description: Intensifying a battle between the Internal Revenue Service and defense lawyers, Federal prosecutors in New York have filed legal papers seeking to force two prominent criminal-law firms in Manhattan to disclose the names of clients who paid them in cash.

title: NBC-TV to End Dramatizations of News
description: NBC News said yesterday that it would discontinue the use of the widely criticized technique of dramatic re-creations because they confuse viewers about where reality ends and the re-creations begin.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy

title: Lincoln Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The company said earnings for the latest first quarter included results from Taro Aggregates Ltd.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;
description: The Vitalis Meadowlands Invitational track meet, scheduled for Feb. 9 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, will offer a $100,000 bonus to anyone who sets a world indoor mile record at the meet, the meet director, Ray Lumpp, said. The marks that runners will seek to surpass are the 3:49.78 of Eamonn Coghlan in 1983 and the 4:18.86 of Doina Melinte of Rumania in 1988.(AP)

title: Vicon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Book Publishers Now Look to the Numbers
description: Book publishing, faced with a combination of increasing competition, declining profits and slumping unit sales, is beginning to undergo changes that are likely to alter the shape of the industry in the 1990's, although it may not seem all that different to casual book buyers.

title: Farm Credit Banks In Bond Pricing
description: The Farm Credit System Banks yesterday priced at par a three-part consolidated systemwide bond issue totaling $2.475 billion through the FFCB Funding Corporation and a nationwide group of securities dealers and banks.

title: J.M. Smucker reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Caesars New Jersey reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pentagon Savings Unlikely to Be Spent Elsewhere
description: The reduction in military spending being contemplated by the Bush Administration will not provide much new money for domestic programs over the next several years, Government officials and economists say.

title: The Lincoln Savings and Loan Investigation: Who Is Involved
description: Figures in the House Banking Committee's investigation of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and a related inquiry into five Senators who intervened on its behalf with Federal regulators. The Banker Charles H. Keating Jr.

title: News for a Nose
description: Napoleon said if you wanted to understand America you first had to understand baseball. This made Babe Ruth laugh. Everything about Napoleon made Babe Ruth laugh. Babe Ruth enjoyed baiting Napoleon.

title: Approval Near on Plan to Cut Deficit
description: After nine months of haggling with the Administration, Congress today neared final approval of a plan that relies heavily on new taxes and continuation of across-the-board budget cuts to pare $14.7 billion from the Federal deficit.

title: Nekoosa Urges Bid Rejection
description: The board of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation today recommended that its stockholders reject a sweetened $3.8 billion takeover bid from the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, saying it is still too low and is illegal.

title: Paper Recycling Plan
description: Noranda Forest Inc. said Monday that it had created a recycling unit to develop paper products because of growing concern about the environment. Noranda Forest Recycled Papers Ltd. will initially produce 42,000 tons of recycled paper a year, the company's chairman, Adam H. Zimmerman, said. The unit will begin with the company's Thorold, Ontario, pulp mill, but Mr. Zimmerman said he was studying the possibility of building the world's largest recycling plant, which would produce 115,000 tons of fiber annually.

title: Cranston Journal; Newspaper Carriers Deliver Demands
description: At a recent meeting of one of Rhode Island's new labor organizations, Eamon Shelton, one of its brashest negotiators, was shooting rubber bands across the room.

title: Editor Named At Child
description: Freddi Greenberg, the life-style editor at Working Woman, was named editor in chief of Child magazine yesterday.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: A COOK'S creative wheels never spin so quickly as during the post Thanksgiving weekend. Leftover turkey has inspired countless all-American concoctions like hash, casseroles, soups, stews and fricassees. I often grind up leftover turkey meat and serve turkey burgers seasoned with onions, parsley and nutmeg. These are delicious alone or perhaps with a little melted herb butter.

title: Trying to Make Campuses Civil (and Safe) Again
description: A sense that campus life has markedly deteriorated is prompting colleges and universities to reassert some authority over student behavior, a role most schools virtually abandoned two decades ago.

title: Dr. L. L. Mazzola, 78, Ex-Medicaid Official
description: Dr. Linda L. Mazzola, director of Medicaid services for the New York City Health Department from 1968 to 1977, died of heart failure Sunday at the Bayberry Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 78 years old and had lived for many years in Manhattan.

title: Viceroy Homes reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $33,000, or 1 cent a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Bank Yields Decline Slightly
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Rax Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Job for 500 Million: Choosing a Lower House
description: Nearly 500 million voters in 24 Indian states and 7 federal districts will be eligible to cast ballots from Wednesday to Sunday to choose a new People's Assembly, the lower house of the Indian Parliament.

title: Stables Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included extraordinary benefits of $500,000, or 5 cents a share, and $524,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, from loss carryforwards. c-Net loss

title: Ethnic Listing Costs Officer a Promotion, Appeals Court Rules
description: When Rodolfo Blake, a black who was born in Costa Rica, became a New York City police officer 15 years ago, he described himself as Hispanic. Five years ago he took the sergeant's examination, and when his score was passing for a black but not for a Hispanic officer, Officer Blake sought to have his ethnic status reclassified. Yesterday a state appeals court denied his request.

title: G.E. Engine Order
description: The General Electric Company received an order worth more than $650 million from Evergreen Airways of Taiwan for CF6-80C2 engines for Boeing and McDonnell Douglas aircraft. G.E. said Evergreen, which plans to begin service in 1992, had ordered the engines to power Boeing 747-400's and 767-300ER's and McDonnell MD-11's.

title: U.S. Chip Gets Patent In Japan
description: Texas Instruments Inc., after almost three decades, has won a Japanese patent ruling that analysts say could bring the American company more than $2 billion in royalty payments from Japanese chip makers.

title: Vons Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 8
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $300,000 for the quarter; the 9 months included an extraordinary credit of $1,700,000, or 6 cents a share. The company said the third quarter and year-to-date results primarily reflect the impact of the acquisition of the Southern California Safeway operations acquired in August 1988. The latest quarter's results were affected by overall operating inefficiencies associated with the integration as well as identifiable one-time integration costs of $5.9 million, including severance charges relating to recent administrative staff reductions.

title: Watershed for Europe
description: The impromptu dinner summit meeting of European Community leaders here last weekend can turn out to be a watershed: Western Europe at last pulling together to help Eastern Europe into the future. An extraordinary moment has arrived and it is about assuring the triumph of democracy. In principle at least, The Twelve accepted joint responsibility instead of waiting for somebody (the U.S., West Germany) to do something.

title: Top Magazine Award
description: John Mack Carter, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping magazine, has been awarded the Henry Johnson Fisher Award by the Magazine Publishers of America. The industry group will present the award, its highest honor, in a ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in January. Good Housekeeping, which Mr. Carter has edited since 1975, won a National Magazine Award this year in the special interest category. Mr. Carter is also director of magazine development at Good Housekeeping's publisher, Hearst Magazines.

title: President Seeks a Way to Adapt His Cool Persona to a Hot Medium
description: As George Bush's Presidential style comes to sharper focus on television screens, it is obvious that this chief executive is less interested in being another Great Communicator than in following the advice his mother used to give him: Don't brag; it's in bad taste.

title: Thousand Trails Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,169,000.

title: New York Is Safer From Quakes Than Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: A 100% House - and a 73% Senate
description: What courageous senators America is blessed with! Knowing the public's reluctance to increase Congressional salaries, they have just voted down a big pay raise, agreed to a small one and smiled smug smiles at how virtuously that compares with the House. The sanctimony invites voters, in turn, to curl their lips in disgust.

title: New York Is Safer From Quakes Than Boston; Emergency Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: Potato Museum Seeks a New Home
description: They may be lumpy, dirty and taken for granted, but potatoes have managed to provoke excitement among six states vying for a museum dedicated to their history and social relevance.

title: London Journal; Live From Westminster! It's Parliament Today!
description: Television finally arrived today in the House of Commons. But it was unclear whether Members of Parliament were ready for the television age.

title: New York Is Safer From Quakes Than Boston; Highway Bounce
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; In an Opera House When a Star Cancels, Dominoes Tumble
description: Cancellations rip through classical music like computer viruses, knocking out singers and instrumentalists and conductors with seemingly capricious abandon. If it's not a flu-ridden Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau frustrating thousands of lieder-lovers with his abandonment of five New York concert dates, it's an ailing Rudolf Serkin canceling a long-awaited Carnegie Hall piano recital.

title: Congress Rescinds Long-Term Care Act Before Adjourning
description: Congress voted early this morning to repeal the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, including the politically unpopular surtax that helped finance the 16-month-old program.

title: Koch Estimate of Deficit Is Too Low, Panel Says
description: The State Financial Countrol Board warned yesterday that New York City might be facing a budget deficit as much as $130 million larger than Mayor Edward I. Koch estimated just last month.

title: 5 Senators Struggle to Avoid Keating Inquiry Fallout
description: Five Senators entangled in a fast-growing savings and loan investigation are struggling to devise a public relations and legal strategy to distance themselves from political fallout - and from each other.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL POLITICAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. and 6:30 P.M.

title: Pilot Convicted of Killing Wife In Wood-Chipper Murder Trial
description: Richard Crafts, an airline pilot from Newtown accused of killing his wife and putting parts of her body through a wood chipper, was found guilty of murder here today.

title: Sale of Century! Bits of Cold War, Just $7 an Ounce
description: It was bound to happen. Two salesmen set up a stand on Fifth Avenue yesterday selling what they said were chunks of the Berlin wall - at $7 an ounce.

title: Rider Group Finds Subways In New York Still Below Par
description: New York City's subway service is ''still below basic decent standards'' and does not justify a proposed increase in fares to $1.25, a rider's advocacy group said yesterday in releasing a ''State of the Subways Report.''

title: Bottled Water: Is It Too Pure?
description: AMERICANS who have turned to bottled water as an alternative to what comes out of the tap, who use filters on their faucets or who breast-feed their babies may be depriving themselves and their children of fluoride, which prevents tooth decay.

title: Times Among First Against Vietnam War
description: To the Editor:

title: Crosman Products Sold for $41 Million
description: Crosman Products Inc., an air gun maker, is being sold to Hicks, Muse & Company and an investor group for $41 million in cash, the Dallas-based investment group said. Crosman, based in East Bloomfield, N.Y., was a division of the Coleman Companies, which was recently acquired by McAndrews & Forbes. Crosman was put up for sale because Coleman's new owners want to focus on the company's camping and leisure equipment businesses.

title: Episcopal Head Asks U.S. to Rethink Latin Policy
description: The Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church has called for a complete reassessment of United States policy in Latin America - ''from top to bottom'' - in the wake of killings and arrests of church workers in El Salvador.

title: Review/Piano; A Mix of Ease and Exertion
description: To begin a program including works Beethoven, Scriabin, Debussy and Liszt, a pianist might typically choose, say, a Bach ''French Suite.'' For her New York debut recital at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening, Haesun Paik chose instead a contemporary American work modeled on Bach's ''French Suites'': Donald Martino's ''Suite in Old Form'' (1982). It was a lovely idea. Intended for student performers, the piece is utterly charming without being condescending, and it gave Ms. Paik a chance to ease into the evening's exertions.

title: Jets Get 3 in 3d Period To Overcome Islanders
description: The Islanders led the Jets, 3-1, early in the third period tonight but could not hold on. Winnipeg scored the next three goals at Nassau Coliseum and beat New York, 4-3.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a Navy Department review of procurement involving the International Business Machines Corporation paraphrased the company's spokesman incorrectly on a Baltimore Sun report of a Federal investigation of a $544 million contract. The spokesman said the contract had been awarded to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, not to I.B.M. He did not say E.D.S. was the target of the investigation reported in the article. He said I.B.M. was unaware of such an investigation.

title: NICARAGUAN TALKS FOR PEACE HALTED
description: Peace talks between the Nicaraguan Government and the contras were suspended tonight after the two sides were unable to agree on cease-fire terms.

title: Administration Picks 4 Areas to Receive More Funds in Drug War
description: The Bush Administration plans to designate New York, Miami, Los Angeles and the Southwestern border as having particularly serious drug trafficking problems. It expects to spend up to $40 million in the current fiscal year and up to $100 million next year to speed up Federal law enforcement efforts, Administration officials said today.

title: Dow Rises 7.25, to 2,639.29; Volume Up a Bit
description: With many investors on the sidelines in advance of the Thanksgiving Day holiday, blue-chip stocks made modest gains yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 7.25 points, to 2,639.29.

title: Nureyev Resigns at Paris Opera, Ending Feud
description: A 14-month feud at the Paris Opera ended today when Rudolph Nureyev resigned as director of the opera's ballet company.

title: New York is Safer From Quakes Than Boston; Steel Bolts Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgia Gulf Weighing A Takeover Defense
description: The Georgia Gulf Corporation, a chemical maker, said today that it was considering a debt-financed recapitalization as a defense against NL Industries' unsolicited takeover bid of $50 a share, or $1.1 billion.

title: Maneuvering by South Africa Blacks
description: In the new climate of change promised by President F. W. de Klerk, some black leaders have begun jockeying for the tacit right to take part in any future negotiations with the white-minority Government on behalf of South Africa's black majority.

title: Erly Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $150,000 for the quarter and $447,000 for the 6 months.

title: Inacomp Computer Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Rule at S.E.C. Is Challenged
description: Some of the nation's largest corporations, supported by 13 states, squared off against the Securities and Exchange Commission today in a legal challenge to a Federal regulation that limits a popular anti-takeover tactic.

title: Picture-Perfect Images, Without the Camera
description: Personal computers will soon be able to use sophisticated mathematical formulas to create images as realistic as photographs.

title: Rachel B. Wischnitzer, An Art Historian, 104
description: Rachel Bernstein Wischnitzer, a professor and art historian who specialized in synagogue architecture, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 104 years old.

title: Rax Restaurants Picks New Chief Executive
description: Rax Restaurants, a chain of some 500 company-owned and franchised restaurants mostly in the Midwest, named Ira A. Hermann as its new chief executive yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Mark Shows Its Strength; Dollar Drops
description: The dollar dropped sharply against the West German mark yesterday, closing at its lowest level since early January. The dollar also fell against other leading currencies, including the Japanese yen.

title: For Thanksgiving Jitters, A Strategy Free of Fuss
description: MANY problems of contemporary life have been addressed by self-help strategies. Are you addicted? Phobic? Frenzied? Faltering? Help is a phone call, a meeting, a best-selling paperback book away. There are bootstrap techniques to get rich, get thin, get powerful, get peaceful, get even. But what about the host with a bad case of nerves? According to industry studies, home entertaining is on the rise. Nevertheless, Fear of Entertaining remains an unspoken complex. Hosts secretly suffer its terrors. What if the bird is overcooked! The champagne explodes! The souffle collapses! Grim scenarios leave hosts weak with self-doubt.

title: About New York; A Doctor's Hand For the Old, Poor And Terrified
description: Andrea Fox, M.D., makes house calls to sick old people who cannot leave their homes. The other day she called on Martha in a tattered South Bronx neighborhood.

title: Learning to Read in Vermont, Adults Use an Unusual Tool: Writing Books
description: To try to capture the attention of adults who are learning to read, a literacy program in Vermont has turned to an unusual group of authors: the students themselves.

title: Miami Coach to Leave
description: Bill Foster, the coach who resurrected basketball at the University of Miami in 1985, yesterday announced plans to step down as coach of the Hurricanes at the end of the season. In his four years at Miami, he had a combined record of 65-56, but the Hurricanes have not played a post-season game since 1963 and attendance has been stalled at 3,000 a game in recent years. (AP)

title: Washington Talk; Questions for a Reticent High Court >
description: Secrecy is one of the Supreme Court's best-known attributes.

title: Steam-Blast Evacuees Allowed Back
description: Residents from a Gramercy Park building that was coated with asbestos when a steampipe exploded last summer were told yesterday by Consolidated Edison that they can begin to return to their apartments today.

title: European-Style Sweets
description: SOME new European-style products available in supermarkets may make it easier than ever to turn out cakes, cookies and pastries this holiday season.

title: Treasuries Rise in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved modestly higher in light pre-holiday trading yesterday.

title: Driver Accused of Shooting Co-Workers After Dismissal
description: A truck driver who was fired Monday by the printing company for which he had worked for several years returned this afternoon and shot two former co-workers with a shotgun, critically wounding both, officials said.

title: Clamor in the East; And for Two East Germans in Love, the Changes Spell Bliss
description: The young man with a crew cut and his fiancee held hands at the restaurant table that they shared with a foreigner and, love overcoming timidity, hugged each other and giggled happily while they studied the lunch menu.

title: Burt Ready to Face His Ex-Teammates
description: For eight seasons, Jim Burt helped plug the middle of the Giants' defense, until last July, when the plug was pulled on his career. Burt failed a Giants physical, and though others said he was forced out by management, Burt said the decision to retire was his alone.

title: American Dies in Peru; Identified as Journalist
description: The body of an American was found today near a jungle town and was tentatively identified as that of a reporter for The Tampa (Fla.) Tribune who had been missing five days.

title: Sony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated from yen at the rate of 139 yen equals U.S. $1, the approximate Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of Sept. 29, 1989. Share earnings are in American Depositary Share (ADS) with each ADS representing one share of common stock.

title: Civics Lesson in Namibia
description: After decades of domination by white-ruled South Africa, Namibia may now have a chance at lively pluralistic politics. The Namibian people did their part to assure that earlier this month by electing a constituent assembly in which no party has a majority big enough to impose its will.

title: In Pueblo Food, Deep Respect For the Earth
description: WHEN the aspen trees turn gold on the high ridges of the Sangre de Cristo mountains north of Santa Fe, the people of northern New Mexico know it is time for the harvest to be in.

title: A Common Goal For Oh and Aaron
description: The sluggers were separated by cultures, leagues and an ocean, yet the legendary home run feats of Sadaharu Oh of Japan, who belted 868 career homers, and Henry Aaron, who holds the major league mark with 755, will always be compared.

title: Paul Harris Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Qintex Seeks Receivership
description: Qintex Australia Ltd., the troubled media and resort empire of Christopher C. Skase, went into receivership today to stop a sale to pay $1.6 billion in debts.

title: Albany Must Take Steps to Keep and Attract Manufacturing Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Man is Freed in Hiding of Suspect
description: A Manhattan man accused of hiding Costabile (Gus) Farace, the suspect in the killing of a Federal drug agent, was released without bail yesterday after Federal authorities said he may not have known the fugitive's real identity.

title: Antoinette Quilleret, Executive, 85
description: Antoinette Quilleret, a a co-founder and former president of David Webb Inc., the jewelry concern, died of complications of cancer on Thursday at her home in Marbella, Spain. She was 85 years old.

title: Four Psychologists Face Inquiry For Speculating on Kitty Dukakis
description: Four psychologists here are facing the possibility of state disciplinary action because they speculated about the reasons for Kitty Dukakis's depression and alcohol abuse in newspaper interviews.

title: Clamor in the East; Number of Poles and Hungarians Admitted as Refugees Will Be Cut
description: The United States will sharply curtail the admission of Poles and Hungarians as refugees because most of them no longer have any reason to fear persecution in their homelands, Administration officials said today.

title: Empire of Carolina Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results reflect the acquisition of Clabir Corp. and are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1989.

title: Ovonic Imaging Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Freddie Waits Is Dead; Jazz Drummer Was 49
description: Frederick (Freddie) Dawud Waits, a drummer known for his versatility, died of pneumonia and renal failure Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SALVADOR REBELS TAKE OVER PARTS OF LUXURY HOTEL
description: A group of rebels seized parts of a luxury hotel here today, trapping dozens of foreigners inside for most of the day, including some American military advisers and Green Berets who barricaded themselves at the end of a hallway with their weapons.

title: Coach Resigns
description: Wayne Nunnely, who cleaned up Nevada-Las Vegas's program but failed to produce a consistent winner, announced his resignation yesterday after four years as head coach. Nunnely said he would coach the team in its final game against San Jose State on Saturday before stepping down. Nunnely's Rebels are 4-6 this year.(AP)

title: Wine Talk
description: ''WELL,'' I said, ''it's happened. Old Hugh has finally gone round the bend. It's all those years of undrinkable old claret.''

title: Rose Murphy, 76, Dies; Jazz Pianist and Singer
description: Rose (Chee Chee) Murphy, a jazz pianist and singer whose birdlike high-pitched voice brought her fame, died on Thursday in St. John's Hospital in Queens. She was 76 years old and lived in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Books of The Times; Learning to Wear Poverty Like a Crown
description: He Included Me The Autobiography of Sarah Rice Transcribed and edited by Louise Westling 181 pages. Illustrated. The University of Georgia Press. $19.95.

title: U.S. Panel Will Urge Release of Secret Records on Radiation
description: A special panel will recommend that the Energy Department immediately give a Pennsylvania health group secret medical and radiation exposure records of 300,000 people who have worked in United States nuclear weapons plants, members of the panel say.

title: From Pies and Stuffing, an Identity Crisis
description: It's been building all week: the tightening of the jaw, the precooking jitters, the middle-of-the-night internal debate over the Thanksgiving menu. It happens every year without fail.

title: INVALID ALLOWED TO REMOVE DEVICE
description: Georgia Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a 33-year-old quadriplegic has a constitutional right to withdraw from the breathing apparatus that has kept him alive for four years.

title: Lessons
description: The New York City economy, which once boasted a prosperous manufacturing sector, has become almost entirely oriented around service industries.

title: About Education
description: Children can be hurt by being taught too much too soon. This warning comes from three specialists in child development who found that pushing youngsters too early may retard their learning later on.

title: More Refined Cella Spots Banish Aldo
