description: ''ALDO, ALDO CELLA!'' the ladies would cry, and for years the roly-poly Casanova, the fictional front for Cella wines, would respond with a sly wink that helped to turn Cella into the nation's No. 4 brand of imported table wine.

title: Charles Shipman, A Securities Analyst And Writer, 94, Dies
description: Charles Shipman, a financial analyst and journalist who was active in the Communist Party until he became disillusioned with Stalinism in the 1930's, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 94 years old and had lived for many years in Redding, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Media Business page on Monday about the coming of advertising to Congressional Quarterly reversed the identifications of two men. Wayne P. Kelley, publisher, was at the right and Robert W. Merry, managing editor, at the left.

title: INSIDE
description: Accord Is Reported In Nynex Strike The Nynex Corporation and striking New York Telepone workers reached a tentative settlement on a new contract, union officials and a mediator said.

title: U.S. UNITS ALERTED FOR EL SALVADOR
description: The Bush Administration prepared today to send specially trained military units to El Salvador before receiving reports that the siege of a Salvadoran hotel by leftist guerrillas appeared to be ending.

title: Caesars World reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
National Realty L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $543,000 loss on foreclosure and $800,000 charge for settlement of litigation. c-Included $5,927,000 gain from property sales, $543,000 loss on foreclosure, $2,787,000 gain on the sale of investments and $5,380,000 charge for settlement of litigation. d-Included gains on property sales of $1,480,000 for the quarter and $3,854,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings are in units.

title: Bush Nominee for F.C.C.
description: President Bush will nominate Ervin S. Duggan, a former aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson, as a member of the Federal Communications Commission, the White House announced Tuesday. Mr. Duggan, 50 years old, was national editor of Washingtonian magazine from 1981 to 1986. A published novelist, he has run a communications consulting business in Washington since 1981.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17

title: The Pop Life
description: The Dark Side of Life

title: Clamor in the East; Old Master Spy in East Berlin Tells Why He Backs Changes
description: Among the artists, intellectuals, clerics and other former dissidents at the forefront of those in East Germany calling for changes, Markus Wolf clearly stands out.

title: Why Iraq Attacked Its Kurdish Population
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; Haunting and Boisterous 'Contes d'Hoffmann'
description: It is a wonder that Offenbach's ''Contes d'Hoffmann,'' with its history of textual confusions, ever makes sense on the stage. Despite claims made for competing editions of the score, there still is not - never can be - one unchallengeable version. But come together ''Hoffmann'' generally does, owing to its string of haunting melodies and boisterous ensemble numbers, but also for the possibilities it offers singing actors to portray different characters under one skin. The multiple-role device not only encourages theatrical virtuosity but in the right hands can knit the opera's strands into something like a Freudian case history.

title: May to Buy Back 14 Million Shares
description: The May Department Stores Company said it had agreed to purchase more than 14 million shares of its common stock from May Centers Associates for $663 million. A May spokesman said the agreement also calls for the purchase by May Centers and leaseback to May of department store properties owned by May and valued at $585 million.

title: Greeks Agree on a Broad Coalition Until April
description: Ending a two-week political crisis, the three main political parties set aside their differences today and agreed to a coalition government that will rule Greece until new elections are held in April.

title: Book Notes
description: Report on South Africa

title: An Enterprise Built on Ingenuity, Perseverance and Apples
description: THE traffic-stopping fragrances that emanate from the street level of the Manhattan Plaza apartment building on 43d Street between 9th and 10th Avenues used to be confined to the 43d floor of the building. That's where Arnold Wilkerson, an out-of-work actor, began baking sour cream-apple-walnut pies in 1983.

title: Neiman Marcus Group Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
Charming Shoppes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Jacob's Pillow Festival Names New Director
description: Samuel A. Miller, the managing director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, has been appointed executive director of the festival. He succeeds Liz Thompson, who last week was appointed director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave festival.

title: AGENT IS INDICTED IN H.U.D. THEFTS
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted the Maryland real-estate agent whom investigators dubbed ''Robin HUD'' after she insisted that she stole millions of dollars from the Department of Housing and Urban Development to give to the poor.

title: Clamor in the East; PRAGUE'S PREMIER HAS INITIAL TALKS WITH OPPOSITION
description: Czechoslovakia's Communist leaders held their first talks with representatives of a newly formed opposition movement today, while more than 200,000 people joined in a fifth day of street demonstrations sustaining pressure for political changes.

title: Czechoslovakia: A History of Tumult
description: Oct. 28, 1918: With the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in World War I, the independence of the Czechoslovak state is proclaimed; the following month, Tomas G. Masaryk, the Czechoslovak nationalist leader, is elected the country's first President.

title: New Viewpoint for Harvey
description: One year ago, Greg (Boo) Harvey's life was at a low point.

title: Pact Reached With Nynex Mediator Says
description: The Nynex Corporation and striking New York Telephone workers reached a tentative settlement in their 16-week-old labor dispute shortly after midnight, union officials and a mediator said.

title: 'Junk Bond' Prices Down
description: The prices of high-yield ''junk bonds'' were marked down yesterday by almost a point on average, or $10 for every $1,000 face amount.

title: Wavetek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: A map in some copies yesterday with an article about demonstrations in Prague located the city's old Jewish cemetery incorrectly. It is on the south bank of the Vltava River.

title: Market Place; Insider Charge at Emerson Radio
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation is engaged in a seemingly minor legal squabble in a Brooklyn Federal court that has shed light on a little-known insider-trading suit against the New Jersey company's top management that could have a serious impact on the once high-flying consumer electronics marketer. What has emerged is a story with famous names, allegations of managerial deceit and disgruntled shareholders.

title: American Savings Delays Voting on a Shift in Charter
description: Facing strong opposition from shareholders, the management of the American Savings Bank yesterday delayed until Dec. 20 a special meeting of stockholders to vote on converting the bank from a Federal to a state charter.

title: Steady, Painful Transition To a Humbler Wall Street
description: These are nervous days on Wall Street. As cutbacks mount, more and more investment bankers, brokers and office workers face the year-end prospect of sharply lower incomes or no jobs at all.

title: Suffolk Is Sued to Block Plans For Subdivisions in Pine Barrens
description: An environmental group sued Suffolk County and three of its towns today in an effort to block hundreds of subdivisions planned for Long Island's Pine Barrens.

title: Economic Scene; Sony Wishes Upon a Star
description: ARE the services of Peter Guber and Jon Peters, co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures, the Sony Corporation's latest venture into the entertainment business, really worth a half-billion dollars?

title: Clamor in the East; Gorbachev Endorses Bloc's Transformation
description: As mass demonstrations spread in Czechoslovakia, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev repeated his support today for the sweeping changes under way in Eastern Europe.

title: Florida Woos Spurrier
description: Steve Spurrier, the coach at Duke University who won the Heisman Trophy as a player at the University of Florida in 1966, has been given permission to talk to Bill Arnsparger, the Florida athletic director, about the Gators' head coaching job, according to a statement yesterday by Tom Butters, the Duke athletic director. Spurrier led Duke to an 8-3 season and a share of the Athlantic Coast Conference title, with a berth in the All-American Bowl. (AP)

title: In Move on Cayton, Tyson Appeals to Cuomo
description: In April 1988, when Bill Cayton, Mike Tyson's manager, suspected that the promoter Don King was ''making moves'' to take over the heavyweight champion, Tyson told a reporter: ''There is no way I'm thinking of double-crossing Bill Cayton. Nothing's changed. I don't know why he feels threatened. Bill sounds like he's worried I'm going to leave. I'm not a rat fink or a traitor.''

title: Review/Theater; New York City in the 30's, In Yiddish 'Land of Dreams'
description: There was a special texture to life among working-class Jews in New York during the despairing days of the Great Depression, and there is a taste of it in ''The Land of Dreams,'' Nahum Stutchkoff's play now being staged by the Yiddish-speaking Folksbiene Playhouse.

title: Real Estate; Factory Being Converted in a Depressed Area of Newark
description: A VACANT light-bulb factory that shut down four years ago in an economically depressed section of Newark is being converted by a group of Manhattan investors into rental space for light manufacturing and distribution companies.

title: Renault Shutdown
description: The French state-owned car company Renault said it would close its oldest factory. The company said the 64-year-old plant at Billancourt, an island near central Paris, is considered obsolete and would be closed by 1992. Employment at the factory has dropped from 22,000 in 1969, to its current level of 4,000.

title: The Vinegar That Wants to Be Decanted
description: AT the turn of the century, this city was home to more than 200 vinegar producers. Now there is only one, Martin Pouret, a company that refuses to abandon traditional methods.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Q&A column of Science Times yesterday about fingernail marks gave an incorrect location in some copies for the dermatology practice of Dr. Phoebe Rich. It is Portland, Ore., not Seattle.

title: Savings Executive Won't Testify And Blames Regulators for Woes
description: Charles H. Keating Jr. declined today to answer questions from Congress about the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, but he issued a statement blaming regulators for what may become the largest failure of a savings institution on record.

title: Knicks Win in Overtime And Ewing Is Difference
description: Patrick Ewing scored 33 points last night in his strength-to-strength battle with Akeem Olajuwon but the ones that mattered most to the 7-foot Knick center were his 8 overtime points. They spelled a 114-106 overtime victory over the Houston Rockets before a capacity crowd of 18,212 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Friendly Advice to a Shrinking Military
description: In these last days, the newspapers and television screens have dealt fully and with wonderment with what is happening in Europe and its meaning for Europeans. Let no one doubt that there will also be great and enduring effects on us, especially on our military establishment. This is a word of sympathy, counsel and guidance for that establishment in what promises to be a difficult time.

title: Battle for Avon Intensifies As Basses Disclose 6% Stake
description: A new development in the takeover battle for Avon Products Inc. emerged yesterday as a group led by Robert M. Bass, the Texas businessman, announced that it owned nearly 6 percent of the cosmetics company and might hold talks with Avon's top management.

title: Council Votes To Override A Koch Veto
description: Overriding a mayoral veto for the first time in 20 years, the New York City Council passed legislation yesterday that largely prohibits horse-drawn carriages from operating in midtown Manhattan.

title: Topics of The Times; Cardinal Principle
description: The National Endowment for the Arts's temporary withdrawal of funds for a show focused on AIDS produced a flurry of words - none more sensible than from the object of criticism in the show's catalogue.

title: King World Productions reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,905,000, or 11 cents a share, from the adoption of FASB No. 96. The decrease in the number of shares outstanding in the latest periods compared with year-ago periods was due to share repurchases in fiscal 1988 and the first quarter of fiscal 1989.

title: Giant Food Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 4
American Learning Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Simmons to Lift Lockheed Stake
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who has been accumulating shares of the Lockheed Corporation since last spring, intends to increase his stake in the military contractor to 15 percent or more, Lockheed said.

title: Shuttle Set for Secret Mission With First Night Launching
description: The space shuttle Discovery is set to blast off Wednesday night on a secret military mission to deploy what is believed to be a spy satellite.

title: Medtronic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1989.

title: GW Utilities Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $4,000,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Refugee Commissioner Defends Predecessor at U.N.
description: The new United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees used his first news conference today to defend the special travel and entertainment allowances that led to the resignation last month of his predecessor, Jean-Pierre Hocke.

title: Review/Television; An Actor's 'Quantum Leap' Through Times and Roles
description: At the moment, as star of NBC's ''Quantum Leap,'' Scott Bakula probably has the most demanding, and rewarding, job on weekly television. He plays Sam Beckett, a scientist who, because of a botched time-travel experiment, now spends his days and nights being thrust into the past -anytime between the mid-1950's and the mid-70's - where he assumes other people's identities.

title: 2 Plans by Hunts Approved
description: Attorneys for Nelson Bunker and William Herbert Hunt and their primary creditors today approved two similar plans to reorganize the brothers' estates.

title: Pirate Pacts Extended
description: Despite a fifth-place finish in the National League East last season, the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday extended the contracts of Jim Leyland, the manager, and Larry Doughty, the general manager. Leyland's contract was extended through 1991 and Doughty's through 1990.(AP)

title: Soviet Musical
description: A Soviet rock musical called ''Junon and Avos: The Hope,'' the story of a Russian explorer who visits California in the early 1800's, is heading for City Center, courtesy of Pierre Cardin. It comes from the Lenin Komsomol theater in Moscow and has a cast of 60, a libretto by Andrei Vosnesensky, music by Aleksei Ribnikov and choreography by Vladimir Vasiliev of the Bolshoi. Lucy Jarvis is producing; the five-week engagement is to begin Jan. 5.

title: Turmoil Continues for the Corcoran and Its Chief
description: Five months after its cancellation of a retrospective of Robert Mapplethorpe photographs, the Corcoran Gallery of Art remains in turmoil.

title: James Karr Dies at 32; Danced for Paul Taylor
description: James Karr, a former leading dancer with the Paul Taylor Dance Company, died of AIDS on Nov. 11 at his home in San Diego. He was 32 years old.

title: BRE Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain on sales of investments of $10,434,000.

title: David J. Hertz, Executive, 48
description: David J. Hertz, president of D. J. Hertz & Associates Limited, a personnel placement agency in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 48 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J., and Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: VIRGINIA MILES is at a McDonald's in Englewood, N.J.

title: Police Kill Inwood Man After 6-Hour Standoff
description: An emotionally distraught man who threatened his landlord with a rifle and then set fire to his upper Manhattan apartment was shot and fatally wounded when he pointed the gun at officers last night, the police said.

title: Zygo Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Gunmen Kill Basque Politician in an Attack at a Madrid Restaurant
description: Gunmen killed a Basque politician and critically wounded another here late Monday night, the eve of their swearing-in as members of the Spanish Parliament.

title: Hanover Taking Write-Off
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation has announced a $50 million charge against its fourth-quarter earnings to cover losses resulting from fraud at a branch in Switzerland.

title: NBC Still First In Prime Time
description: NBC held on to first place i prime time last week, with an average rating of 16:0. ABC followed with a 13.2 average; the second part of ABC's television movie, ''Small Sacrifices'' on Sunday night, was the second-ranked program of the week, behind ''The Cosby Show'' on NBC CBS was third, with 11.7.

title: Lifeline Healthcare Accused of Secret Stock Issue
description: A home health-care company, its lawyer and its board were accused yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission of defrauding investors by filing false financial reports and secretly issuing a million shares of stock to corporate officials and advisers.

title: When War Visits a Wealthy Neighborhood
description: At midmorning, the upper-class Escalon neighborhood was a battleground.

title: Siberians Cling to Dream of Change Despite Shabby Lives and Shortages
description: In the shoebox apartment of Yuri and Lyubov Volkov, the color television screen was filled with an unblinking, big brotherly closeup of a popular hypnotist, Anatoly Kashpirovsky.

title: Handleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: All prior year amounts have been restated to reflect the pooling of interests on Jan. 1 with Video Treasures Inc. and its related companies.

title: A Union Folds Its Hand
description: The new union agreement at the Boeing Company, ratified after a 48-day strike, shows that even under the most favorable circumstances the labor movement cannot win the clear-cut victories that were commonplace a decade ago.

title: Psychotherapy Gaining Favor Among Blacks
description: Psychotherapy, long considered a middle-class white solution for emotional problems, is gradually gaining wider acceptance among black Americans.

title: Tsongas Says He Will Not Run for Governor
description: Saying that to run for governor of Massachusetts would mean denying ''my deepest responsibilities to myself and to those I love,'' former Senator Paul E. Tsongas declared Monday that he would not be a candidate for the Democratic nomination.

title: Familiar Territory for U.S. In Early World Cup Events
description: Technically, the World Cup ski season began during the summer, in Las Lenas, Argentina, for the women and in Thredbo, Australia, for the men. But because the racers had not finished training, those events were not taken too seriously. So this week, when the world's best skiers compete in slalom and giant slalom at Park City, Utah, from tomorrow through Sunday, the racing season will begin.

title: New York Is Safer From Quakes Than Boston; Advances in 25 Years
description: To the Editor:

title: In $1 Billion Deal, CBS Locks Up N.C.A.A. Basketball Tournament
description: CBS agreed yesterday to pay $1 billion for the right to broadcast the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament as part of an exclusive seven-year package beginning in 1991.

title: Clamor in the East; PARTY IN MOSCOW CHANGES LEADERS
description: The Communist Party chief of Moscow was relieved of his post today as the party sought to present the change as a promotion rather than a downgrading from one of the nation's most prominent political jobs.

title: Topics of The Times; Weather Words
description: Anyone who went out to lunch in New York yesterday knows it's time to haul out the words, as well as the clothing, of winter.

title: North American Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said latest fourth quarter results included a pre-tax gain of $7.6 million related to the sale of its Premium Financing Specialists Inc. unit.

title: Cubic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,474,000, or 48 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $234,000, or 3 cents a share, and $725,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $608,000, or 8 cents a share. The company sold its G.S. Parsons Co., a distributor of industrial and medical supplies in February.

title: Food Notes
description: Sweet Charity

title: PAKISTAN WORKING TO FREE P.O.W.'s
description: Pakistani officials trying to bring an end to the Afghan civil war have apparently succeeded in saving at least four Soviet prisoners of war whose hopes for survival were considered bleak.

title: Lured by Bonuses, Workers Vote to End Strike at Boeing
description: The second-longest strike in the Boeing Company's history ended today as 57,800 machinists, attracted by holiday cash bonuses, agreed to go back to work at the world's foremost airplane manufacturer.

title: Damage Is Widespread As Storm Gusts All Day
description: Buildings under construction were leveled, planes on the ground were tossed about like toys, and rows of houses were gutted by a wind-whipped fire as the second severe storm front in a week lashed the New York metropolitan area Monday night and early yesterday.

title: A Top Wendy's Official Retires
description: Robert L. Barney, chairman of Wendy's International Inc., announced today that he plans to retire from the company he helped to found 20 years ago. Mr. Barney, 52 years old, said he had no specific plans for the future.

title: Soviet Race: Agent Chosen
description: Although outbid by Japanese rivals, a Boston sports entrepreneur has won a major international business competition to serve as marketing agent for the Moscow Marathon.

title: Culp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net loss

title: C.I.A. Watchdog - or Mole?
description: LEAD: Congress has just passed the spending bill for intelligence agencies, which includes an ill-advised provision to establish a statutory inspector general in the Central Intelligence Agency. We trust that President Bush will veto the measure.

title: Drive for Data on Campus Crime Is Pressed
description: A nationwide effort is under way to compel colleges and universities to publish reports of crimes committed on their campuses.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: The Thanksgiving holiday will be observed tomorrow. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West and heads to Columbus Circle and down Broadway to 34th Street and Seventh Avenue. Government offices: All closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Self-service windows open at the main branch at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation: No collection or street cleanings. Schools: Closed tomorrow and Friday. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule; Long Island Rail Road, holiday schedule; Metro-North and New Haven line, holiday schedule tomorrow through Sunday. NEW JERSEY Government offices: State closed tomorrow and Friday. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed, with option to close Friday. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule, with modified weekday schedule Friday. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, State and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed tomorrow and Friday. Transportation: Metro-North and New Haven line on holiday schedule tomorrow through Sunday.

title: Bush on TV
description: ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN plan to televise President Bush's speech live from Camp David, Md., at 9 P.M. tonight. In remarks planned to last about 15 minutes, the President is expected to offer a Thanksgiving message as well as to discuss his meeting next month with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.

title: Indians Sign Guante
description: The Cleveland Indians yesterday signed Cecilio Guante, a free-agent pitcher, to a one-year contract. Guante, a 29-year-old right-hander, appeared in 50 games in relief for the Texas Rangers last season. He was 6-6 with two saves and a 3.91 earned run average.(AP)

title: OLD FOES MAKE UP NAMIBIA ASSEMBLY
description: A buoyant mood of cooperation, compromise and reconciliation filled Namibia's Constituent Assembly today when former guerrilla commanders and onetime supporters of South African-style apartheid met for the first time as elected officials.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Fall 3.3% on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that short interest had dropped by 17.5 million shares, or 3.3 percent, in the four-week period ended Nov. 15. Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

title: Abdullah Jassim al-Shaker, Bahrain Consul, 60
description: Abdullah Jassim al-Shaker, Bahrain's United Nations representative and its Consul General in New York, died of heart failure yesterday at his home in the Elmhurst, Queens. He was 60 years old.

title: Japan Export Bank Offers 8.35% Notes
description: The Export-Import Bank of Japan is offering $150 million in 8.35 percent guaranteed notes due in 1999 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Top U.P.S. Promotion Comes From Within
description: United Parcel Service, the huge transportation company owned by its management and employees, likes to promote from within, and it did so again yesterday in naming Kent C. Nelson chairman and chief executive.

title: New Chancellor, New Hope for Schools
description: It's a thrill to hear Joseph Fernandez talk about his plans for New York City's failed school system. Not a triumphant thrill, Heaven knows. He doesn't even start as chancellor until Jan. 2; it will be months before his plans are under way and years before they can be measured. Still, even in his initial proposals, Mr. Fernandez prompts a thrill of expectation and offers reason for hope.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The industry is having problems before the economy even slows down. What happens if there is a serious economic downturn?'' - Sanford I. Weill, chief executive of the Primerica Corporation, which owns the brokerage firm Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. [ A1:2. ]

title: Bush Vetoes Funding For State Department
description: President Bush today vetoed the annual bill authorizing State Department operations, and Congress scrambled to pass a version acceptable to the President before adjourning for the year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Cadbury Schweppes Beverages, Stamford, Conn., the United States subsidiary of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., London, appointed Robert C. Zapletal president of Schweppes U.S.A. and David K. Irwin deputy managing director of its Canadian division.

title: Syntex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
James S. Donnelly, 73, Ex-Dean and Editor
description: Dr. James S. Donnelly, dean of the Fordham University School of Education from 1955 to 1962 and later an editor and writer of textbooks and technical publications, died of hepatic cancer Monday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Convent Station, N.J.

title: New-Music Festival; Improvisers Enliven Record Store
description: Davey Williams and LaDonna Smith, two improvisers from Birmingham, Ala., slowed shopping a bit at Tower Records on lower Broadway on Friday. As part of the New Music America festival, the two put on a performance there. Full of yelps and noise and electronic distortion, it had shoppers grimacing.

title: Review/Film; A Sequel of Sequence and Consequence
description: The glee of Dr. Emmett Brown (Christopher Lloyd), the wild-haired mad scientist of the ''Back to the Future'' movies, is easy to understand. The first time around, all his DeLorean time machine did was transport the doctor and young Marty McFly (Michael J. Fox) 30 years back in time. But in ''Back to the Future, Part II,'' it's ready for bigger and better things.

title: Seaman Furniture Revamps Finances
description: The Seaman Furniture Company said it had successfully completed its financial restructuring. The company said its exchange offer to holders of its 15 percent subordinated debentures due in 1999 had been completed, and that the plan had provided more than $40 million in cash reserves and had reduced bank debt from approximately $275 million to $125 million.

title: Why Manley? Why Now?
description: The caller said it was urgent. He had to speak to Bob Woolf right away. Woolf, the noted sports agent, got on the phone to hear the voice of Quintin Dailey, the basketball player, and one of his clients.

title: Hakim Pleads Guilty to One Misdemeanor
description: Albert Hakim, the financial organizer in the Iran-contra affair, today pleaded guilty to a single misdemeanor charge of helping to supplement the salary of Oliver L. North by providing a $13,800 security system for home.

title: Accounts
description: * United States Coast Guard, to Grey Advertising, for advertising and direct marketing, with a budget of $1 million.

title: Consumer Borrowing Could Avert Recession
description: American consumers are laden with debt, but instead of staggering under the burden, they have plenty of borrowing power in reserve -enough, some economists suggest, to help ward off a recession.

title: Universities Are Setting Up Branch Campuses in Capital
description: Hundreds of college students from around the country come to the capital each year to study government and to work as interns in Federal offices. Soon, many of them will have a home away from home: branch campuses of their universities, complete with local faculties, classrooms, dormitories, meal service and extracurricular activities.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The corporate raider Irwin L. Jacobs has made an unsolicited offer for CML Group Inc., which values the company at more than $154 million, CML said. CML's stock climbed $4, to $19.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its gain of 25.8 percent was the best of the day.

title: Yankees Sign Perez To a 3-Year Contract
description: The Yankees, who used 16 pitchers to staff a chaotic five-man rotation last season, plunged into the free-agent market with George Steinbrenner's bankroll yesterday and spent $5.7 million for three years to sign Pascual Perez, a pitcher with a losing record and a history of struggling against drugs.

title: Diasonics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bridge
description: At the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here on Sunday, attention was focused on the Reisinger Board-a-Match teams, and the second-place finish of a dark-horse team from Manhattan. Simultaneously another Cinderella team was winning the six-session North American Swiss Team Championship.

title: India to Begin Voting Today on Fate of the Nation and the House of Nehru
description: Over the next five days, nearly half a billion voters in India will be asked to determine the fate of Asia's oldest political dynasty and the direction of a nation that hopes to be in the ranks of the great powers in the next century.

title: Thornburgh Sees Delay in Gun Curbs
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has announced a plan to prevent convicted felons from buying firearms. But at the same time, the Attorney General angered advocates of gun control by saying the plan would take years to put into place.

title: Interstate/Johnson Lane Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $3.5 million reserve fund to cover any short-fall resulting from the company's 1986 investment in several Georgia nursing home leases. c-Net income The year-ago results are only those of Interstate Securities.

title: After January, It'll Be 'How'm I Suing?'
description: Already committed to lecturing, broadcasting and writing after he leaves City Hall - endeavors in which he is much practiced - Mayor Edward I. Koch will also practice something he hasn't in two decades: the law.

title: Gleeful Nursing Home May 'Evict' Landlord
description: ''If I had my legs, I'd dance the Peabody,'' said Helen Barnes, 76 years old, a patient at the Cobble Hill Nursing Home in Brooklyn and a double amputee. Carmen Santana, head of housekeeping at the home for the elderly, will celebrate with her husband at her favorite Italian restaurant. ''And he's going to pay,'' she said. The directors of the nursing home decided they would move the Thanksgiving Day party ahead one day.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Fashion page yesterday misidentified the designer of a midriff-baring bandeau and trousers. He was Ralph Lauren.

title: Former U.S. Judge Is Paroled
description: Walter L. Nixon Jr. left a halfway house on parole today after serving 20 months of a five-year prison term for perjury. The Senate removed him as a Federal district judge on Nov. 3. In 1986, a jury convicted Mr. Nixon of lying to a grand jury when he denied discussing a marijuana case with a district attorney. Mr. Nixon, 61 years old, of Ocean Springs, Miss., reported to the Volunteers of America halfway house July 17, after serving nearly 16 months in the prison.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Site Preparation to Resume For Atlantic Terminal Project
description: After a favorable ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, the president of the New York City Public Development Corporation, James P. Stuckey, said yesterday that demolition would resume immediately on the site of the 18-acre Atlantic Terminal project in Brooklyn.

title: James River Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
BRIEFS
description: * Armco Advanced Materials Corp., Butler, Pa., a steel products maker, and Acerinox S.A., Madrid, a stainless steel maker, said they would build a $150 million stainless steel plant in the United States.

title: Landlords Win Battle in Court Over Rent Rises
description: Tenants in rent-stabilized buildings may be charged permanent rent increases if their landlords make major improvements, like new windows or heating systems, New York's highest court ruled today.

title: Rival Lebanon Leaders Denounce Each Other
description: The rival Lebanese leaders, President Rene Moawad and Gen. Michel Aoun, separately addressed the nation on Independence Day, denouncing each other and disagreeing on Syria's role in Lebanon and on a peace plan designed to end the civil war.

title: Nets Lead By 10, Then Lose By 30
description: Seattle held New Jersey to a franchise-low 7 points in the third quarter and Xavier McDaniel outscored the Nets by himself with 10 points in the period as the SuperSonics overcame a 10-point halftime deficit and routed the Nets, 114-84, tonight.

title: President Vetoes Legislation For Panel on Eastern Strike
description: President Bush tonight vetoed legislation creating a Congressional commission to investigate and propose solutions to the 8-month-old Eastern Airlines strike.

title: Smelly Train Looks for Dump
description: A train carrying a cargo of sewage sludge is back from the South after failing to find a place to unload. The City of Baltimore had contracted with GSX Chemical Services of Columbia, S.C., to dispose of the cargo at a waste treatment plant at White Castle, La. But officials in Louisiana said the waste was so smelly that they would not allow it to be unloaded. Mississippi would not accept the cargo either.

title: Citicorp Rates Up
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. It was the fourth increase in the last five weeks. The bank holding company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.2181 percent, up from 8.1896 percent last week. Citicorp also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.8822 percent, up from 7.8587 percent.

title: Spot Gold Ends Above $400 For First Time in 10 Months
description: With gold in strong demand, prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday. The spot December gold delivery closed above $400 an ounce in New York for the first time in 10 months, following similar gains in Asia and Europe earlier in the day.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.5%
description: Sizable increases in the cost of housing and transportation propelled the Consumer Price Index up five-tenths of 1 percent in October from September, the biggest rise since May, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Fight on Workers' Compensation in Texas
description: The Texas statehouse in Austin has seen many boisterous confrontations, but few can match the bitter standoff over measures to overhaul the state's system of compensating workers for their injuries.

title: Florida Starter Arrested
description: Tony McCoy, a starting defensive tackle for the University of Florida, has been arrested on charges that he assaulted a 22-year-old female student at knifepoint, the university police said in Gainsville, Fla. The 20-year-old McCoy, a junior from Orlando, was charged with one count of sexual battery and one count of aggravated battery, The Gainesville Sun reported yesterday. McCoy, after making his initial appearance Tuesday, was being held on $25,000 bond. (AP)

title: Air Force Concludes A U.S. Radar System Threatens Its Planes
description: The Air Force has concluded that a powerful radar system built to detect submarine-launched missiles off the southeastern United States poses a potential risk to virtually all military aircraft landing at Robins Air Force Base in central Georgia.

title: Notebook; Early Bowl Deals Include Four Eastern Teams
description: The attempt this year by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's bowl-game committee to impose this Saturday as a common date for extending bids to the teams has failed.

title: Court Gives Fay Leave To Appeal Cup Ruling
description: A unanimous decision of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday cleared the way for Michael Fay to ask a higher court to decide whether New Zealand has the right to the America's Cup. The panel of five judges agreed to allow Fay to petition the New York Court of Appeals in Albany, which has the final say in the matter.

title: Clamor in the East; West German Official Gives Bush Piece of Berlin Wall
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany brought President Bush a chunk of the Berlin wall today and a message that while his Government strongly supported reunification of the two Germanys, it believed that such a union could only come about in the context of a broader reconciliation between East and West.

title: A European Directory For Public Relations
description: The Chester Burger Company, a British communications company, thinks the single European market planned for 1992 will create an unprecedented need for public relations consultants.

title: Linpro Specified Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Mexican Oil for Japan
description: Japanese oil companies have agreed to buy 150,000 barrels a day of Mexican crude oil for the next five years, executives said Tuesday. The contract, which takes effect in January, was agreed to last week by Pemex, the Mexican state oil company, and 20 Japanese oil refiners that have formed the Association of Japanese Importers of Mexican Crude Oil. Prices for the shipments of Isthmus and Maya crude oils will be set each month.

title: Martindale Sold to British Publisher
description: Reed International P.L.C., the acquisition-minded British paper, packaging and publishing company, announced today that its American subsidiary had agreed to buy the legal publisher Martindale-Hubbell Inc. for $303.7 million.

title: East German Leaders Seek Talks With Foes
description: The Politburo of East Germany's Communist Party yesterday proposed discussions with ''other political forces'' about the country's future.

title: Arafat Sends Bush a Message on Talks With Israel
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has sent a message to President Bush expressing a willingness to negotiate peace with Israel, Administration officials said today.

title: Orient-Express Hotels Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1.5 million for the latest 9 months and year-earlier period.

title: Synthetech Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Broadcast International Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $21,300 and $203,900, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $10,711 for the quarter and $37,160 for the 9 months.

title: Reviews/Theater; How the Hysteria of Denial Conceals Fears and Desires
description: Victor Bumbalo's ''Adam and the Experts'' may be the most important play to deal with the AIDS crisis in gay society since William Hoffman's ''As Is'' and Larry Kramer's ''Normal Heart'' sounded their anguished alarms four and a half years ago.

title: Crown Cork Deal For Unit of CCL
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company agreed to buy the Continental Can Canada Inc. unit of CCL Industries for about $330 million. The agreement also calls for CCL to buy 2.5 million Crown Cork shares, or 8.8 percent, after the purchase for $128 million, or $50.50 a share. The company, based in Philadelphia, said the transaction must be approved by Canadian officials.

title: Article 060189 -- No Title
description: The United States started the 1990 fiscal year with a budget deficit of $26.1 billion in October, the Treasury Department said today. It was the biggest gap in seven months.

title: Nets' Losing Streak Now 5 Games
description: Charles Smith scored 26 points and Ken Norman added 25 tonight as the Los Angeles Clippers dealt the Nets their fifth straight loss, 106-97.

title: Lawmakers Tell the Elderly: 'Next Year' on Health Care
description: Hours after Congress voted to repeal the Medicare act covering the high costs of extended illness, House and Senate leaders pledged today to address health care for the elderly next year. But they acknowledged that many political obstacles remained.

title: Nevada Lawmakers Repeal Higher Pension
description: Bowing to public pressure, the Nevada Legislature has unanimously voted to repeal a 300 percent pension increase that it approved for its members last June.

title: Suit Says Police in Boston Carry Out Illegal Searches
description: A group of black men and teen-agers filed suit against the Boston police Tuesday, arguing that the practice of stopping and searching suspected gang members and their friends on sight is unconstitutional.

title: Grandma Lee's reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $260,000, or 2 cents a share, for the latest year and $1,337,866, or 12 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jordanian Senate Appointed
description: King Hussein appointed a new 40-member upper house of Parliament today. The King retained former Prime Minister Ahmed al-Lawzi as speaker along with 15 members of the previous 30-member Senate. Leila Sharaf, a former Information Minister who resigned in 1984 over press restrictions, became the first woman Senator. The Senate complements an 80-member lower house elected on Nov. 8 in the first parliamentary vote in 22 years.

title: American Medical Move
description: American Medical International Inc., the hospital operator recently taken private in a $1.67 billion deal, said on Tuesday that it would relocate to Texas. American Medical, the nation's third-largest hospital chain, said it would move its headquarters from Beverly Hills to the Dallas area next September. ''Dallas represents significant cost savings over Beverly Hills,'' American Medical's chairman, Harry J. Gray, said.

title: Bush Hails the 'New Europe'
description: In a televised address on Thanksgiving eve, the President lauded Mikhail S. Gorbachev and promised ''no surprises'' for the allies at the summit meeting next month. Page A12.

title: Books of The Times; A Year, Not a Good One, For a Team and a City
description: Lost Sundays A Season in the Life of Pittsburgh and the Steelers By Sam Toperoff Illustrated. 223 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Capitals Beat Islanders To End 4-Game Slump
description: Mike Ridley scored twice and Dino Ciccarelli added three assists tonight as the Washington Capitals snapped a four-game streak without a victory with a 5-3 triumph over the New York Islanders.

title: Girl in Baby Swap Case Is Told of Test Results
description: When Robert Mays told his daughter, Kimberly, she was not his biological child, ''she cried and cried,'' he told a news conference here today.

title: Use of Secret Data Barred in Trial; Iran-Contra Prosecution Imperiled
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today barred the disclosure of classified information in the Iran-contra trial of a former Central Intelligence Agency official in a move that could lead to the dismissal of charges.

title: Bronx Hospice, Facing a Chronic Deficit, to Close
description: The budget passed by Congress yesterday includes a long-awaited increase in Medicare reimbursement rates for hospices. But for one hospice in the Bronx, the Federal help is too little and too late.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 16 about an address by Lech Walesa to a joint meeting of Congress described the precedents incorrectly. He was the fourth foreigner other than national leaders to address such a meeting. Winston Churchill was not the second such person; he was Prime Minister all three times he spoke to Congress.

title: Lebanon's Slain Pact
description: The ultimate target of the bomb that killed the new Lebanese President, Rene Moawad, 17 days after his election was the accord reached between Lebanon's Muslim and Christian factions last month in Taif, Saudi Arabia.

title: Sappir Journal; Duel in the Negev: Antennas, Jets and Bird Lovers
description: Though the Negev is a vast, empty place of bleached rocks, scorching sand and sparse, dry trees, it has spawned a friendly but cautious battle over territory, which for a change is not between Arabs and Jews.

title: Bribery Link To Nomura
description: The police on Tuesday arrested an employee of Japan's largest securities firm, the Nomura Securities Company, and a Kawasaki municipal worker on suspicion of bribery in Japan's latest stock scandal.

title: Little Prince Productions Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 478 money market mutual funds increased by $4.65 billion, to $368.27 billion, for the week ended Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 146 institutional funds increased by $2.19 billion, to $89.62 billion. The assets of the 235 general-purpose funds were up by $737.4 million, to $119.53 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.72 billion, to $159.11 billion, the institute said.

title: On This Day, All the Boards Are Groaning
description: SURE, it is hard work, this daylong ritual of basting and stuffing and slicing and dicing. But look at it from another perspective.

title: Home Federal Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 9 months results are restated to reflect merger of Waynesboro Savings Association and a 5 percent stock dividend.

title: 3CI Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest second quarter loss was primarily due to a writedown of software development costs of $1,282,817 and a loss resulting from the disposal of Heterconn Inc., in the amount of $102,892.

title: Tecogen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $28,000 and $73,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss of $46,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $11,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: Vertex Industries reports earnings for Year to July 31
Free The Kurds
description: At a time when we feel special compassion for the homeless, let us consider a whole people without a home - the 17 million Kurdish people, a nation without a country.

title: Stone Container Facility
description: The Stone Container Corporation said Tuesday that it would open a new recycling plant at its mill in Missoula, Mont., that will handle about 144,000 tons of used corrugated boxes in the coming year. The $16 million recycling plant is part of a $42 million capital investment Stone is making to increase its recycling capacity in 1989. The plant is expected to be in operation by January, the company said.

title: Motherhood Can't Always Turn Out as Planned; Age Makes It Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Lafleur's Next Goal a Historical One
description: Guy Lafleur's next goal will be his 545th and will move him past Maurice (the Rocket) Richard into sole possession of eighth place on the National Hockey League's career goal-scoring list. It could take place in an appropriate place against an appropriate team.

title: Puckett Hits the Jackpot: First $3 Million Man
description: Baseball, continuing to experience a renewed salary escalation that began last off season, gained its first $3 million-a-year player yesterday, when Kirby Puckett and the Minnesota Twins agreed on a three-year, $9 million contract.

title: National Health Care Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $12,700 for the quarter and $105,922, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months, from tax loss carryforwards. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary credit of $3,763.

title: Review/Dance; A Web of Intricate Rhythms By Pena Flamenco Troupe
description: The quality of the talent onstage triumphed over the limitations of a printed program on Sunday night when the Paco Pena Flamenco Company appeared at Town Hall.

title: Potomac Electric reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
'Talented Tenth' and 'Sheba' Dominate Theater Awards
description: Richard Wesley's first new stage play in 11 years, ''The Talented Tenth,'' won honors in six categories at the 17th annual Audelco Recognition Awards.

title: Building Good Will Through Guarantees
description: Angry at having to wait in a long bank line? Here's $5 to ease the pain. Second thoughts about that shiny new car? Take it back to the showroom, no questions asked.

title: Emons Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Restated for an accounting change.

title: The Green Berets at the Barricades: 28 Hours at the Besieged Salvador Hotel
description: The 12 Green Berets tensed Tuesday when they heard scraping metal in the concrete stairwell of their hotel here. It could be the sound of rebels planting bombs and preparing to attack.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Unigene Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: After 46 Years, Equity Theater May Have to Close
description: Equity Library Theater, one of New York's oldest continuously operating theater companies and America's first showcase theater, is on the verge of closing because of severe financial problems, members of the company's board say.

title: Rodman & Renshaw Picks Chief Executive
description: Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc., a regional securities firm based in Chicago, has promoted Kurt B. Karmin to chief execuive, 18 months after he joined it as president. He will succeed Ira J. Kaufman, who will continue as chairman. Both men are 61 years old.

title: Torotel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Stifel Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Sphinx Mining Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the majority of its losses have been non-cash writeoffs.

title: Dynamic Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the decline in revenue and earnings reflects reduced merchant-banking activities and lower placement fees from CMP tax-assisted investments. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Police Official Criticized For Action in Drug Case
description: The State Investigation Commission released a report today accusing the Westchester County police commissioner of improperly intervening in a drug case because he knew the defendant's family.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Snapshots of a Vacation: Here Dinkins Warms Up
description: ''Good morning!'' the resort worker said to the gray-haired man who arrived just before 8 A.M. today at a tennis court that was still wet with the residue of a tropical rainstorm. ''Have you heard the coquis, the little frogs at night?''

title: Lester Newquist, 79, Wall Street Economist
description: Lester J. Newquist, a retired partner in the Wall Street firm of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Police Officer Convicted of Beating Prisoner
description: A New York City police officer has been convicted of beating a handcuffed prisoner in a holding cell last year, the Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday.

title: Durable-Goods Orders Dropped 0.6% in October
description: Orders to factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods fell in October for the fourth time in six months, and economists said the decline was further evidence that American industry was facing a sharp downturn.

title: B.A.T. Profits Increase 18%
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., the British conglomerate fighting off a takeover bid by Hoylake Investments Ltd., said today that its profit jumped 18 percent in the third quarter from a year ago.

title: Shuttle Discovery Blazes Into Night on Secret Mission
description: The space shuttle Discovery roared aloft tonight with new daring in the first night launching of a winged spaceship since the space agency began recovering from the Challenger disaster.

title: A Chicago Prep Star Has Future on Line
description: Johnny Selvie is a starting forward for Martin Luther King High School in Chicago, a basketball team that preseason publications rank as one of the finest in the country. When the Jaguars conclude practice, Selvie's coach, Landon Cox, drives him home. Cox also picks Selvie up and brings him to classes in the morning. If the team is not practicing or playing and school is not in session, Selvie does not leave the house. He would be breaking the law. Selvie, a 6-foot-6-inch, 210-pound senior who is regarded as a major college prospect, has been arrested twice in the last six months, on charges of possessing cocaine and selling cocaine and heroin.

title: Homeless Find Shelter in the Bustle at O'Hare
description: With their small canvas tote bags, James Jackson and his family might be mistaken for travelers headed home for Thanksgiving, three more faces among the tens of thousands passing through O'Hare Airport here on one of the busiest travel days of the year.

title: IRT Property reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $209,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $921,417, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months, both on sales of properties, and an extraordinary loss of $97,000 for both periods on the early retirement of indebtedness. c-After an extraordinary credit of $7,061,614, or 59 cents a share, on sales of properties.

title: Miami Witness Says He Saw Officer Aim Gun at Black Cyclist
description: A witness testified he saw a policeman squat by his parked car, aim his gun and kill a black motorcyclist as the prosecution concluded its case today into two deaths that sparked rioting in January.

title: Biotechnology Offers L.I. a Second Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; For H.R.A. Chief, A Sigh of Relief After Hard Years
description: ''Our proposal asks for an increased investment in the welfare of the poor at a time when all levels of government are tightening their respective belts. This investment in the future of our neighbors, their children and our communities should be a high priority.''

title: Last Broadcasts in January For 'USA Today on TV'
description: ''USA Today on TV,'' whose debut on national television in September 1988 followed a barrage of publicity extravagant even by the standards of television, was canceled yesterday by GTG Entertainment and the Gannett Company.

title: La-Z-Boy Chair Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Neither Heads Nor Tails Determines This Outcome
description: The way the Jets and Falcons are playing, they'll mishandle the coin toss on Sunday.

title: Man is Guilty of Murdering Florida Decorator
description: An Australian aborigine who was adopted by missionaries and brought to this country at the age of 7 was convicted Monday of the 1988 murder of an interior decorator.

title: Wedding Information Network reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Jazz; Puente and the Gran Combo Meet in a Battle of the Bands
description: About halfway through his first set, the percussionist Tito Puente motioned to his orchestra members to lower their volume. He blew on his timbales as if they were on fire and then erupted into a solo that brought his 15-piece band into a huge, brassy crescendo. It was a typically exciting moment at Monday night's Salsa Meets Jazz at the Village Gate. The show featured the tenor saxophonist John Stubblefield and a showdown between Puerto Rico's Gran Combo and Mr. Puente's orchestra that was a joyous combination of extraordinary music and showmanship.

title: Diversified Human Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMR Corp., Dallas, an airline holding company, named William J. Burhop vice president of Federal affairs of its principal subsidiary, American Airlines.

title: Talking Deals; Time-Warner Tie: Focus on Closing
description: WALL STREET is keeping a close eye on the closing of the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc., which now seems likely not to be completed by the end of 1989. And so, apparently, is the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is treating the deal as what it calls a ''going private transaction'' and is now reviewing the documents to make sure they comply with disclosure standards. Time and Warner said they had expected the deal to be treated as an acquisition of Warner by Time.

title: Phoenix Technologies Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Included a tax credit of $204,000, or 2 cents a share. Results for 1989 reflected restructuring charges of $3,550,000 and $5,450,000 in the quarter and full year, respectively.

title: Illinois Case on Abortion Settled Prior to Supreme Court Hearing
description: The two sides in a pivotal abortion case before the United States Supreme Court agreed today to settle it out of court.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With grief, rage and a flood of anger, I mourn you, the martyr of Lebanon's unity, the martyr of peace and love.'' - Prime Minister Selim al-Hoss, announcing the death of President Rene Moawad. [ A10:3. ]

title: Horizon Gold Shares Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a foreign exchange loss of $164,294, which consisted principally of an unrealized foreign exchange loss related to the company's subordinated convertible debentures payable in Swiss francs. c-Net income d-Included extraordinary tax credits of $26,000 for the quarter and $43,000 for the 6 months.

title: For Immigrants, a Four-Language Church
description: ''Does anyone here have a Bible?'' the Korean minister called out at the church social last Sunday.

title: Walker a Judge at Last
description: The Senate early today unanimously confirmed Vaughn R. Walker of San Francisco as a Federal District Court judge, ending a two-year controversy over his membership in a club with a record of discrimination. Mr. Walker's nomination was delayed because of his 15-year membership in the Olympic Club of San Francisco, which had no black members until last year and still excludes women. He resigned Feb. 15. The Senate also confirmed John M. Walker of New York, a cousin of President Bush, for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Clamor in the East; East Germans End Long Ban On Novel About 1953 Revolt
description: ''Five Days in June,'' a novel by Stefan Heym based on an abortive 1953 uprising by East German workers, has been published here after a 30-year ban.

title: Canam Manac Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $769,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $2,911,000, or 13 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After extraordinary credits of $87,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $1,538,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 9 months. The company said the decrease in revenue for the latest quarter is the result of a change to the equity method of accounting for the results of subsidiaries Manac and Mr. Steel, which were previously consolidated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Haley Industries reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Norex America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $381,934, or 9 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $1,788,693, or 41 cents a share, for the year-ago period. Both periods included results of Norex America's 80 percent ownership in Norgulf Shipping Ltd. in 1989 and 66.5 percent ownership in 1988.

title: Diana Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 14
description: b-Net loss Figures for the latest quarter included a charge of $3,455,000 for estimated losses of a plan to discontinued toy store operations. Year-ago quarter included a gain of $360,000 related to disposition of operations. Figures for 6 months' period included a gain related to disposition of operations of $11,206,000 in the latest period, compared to a gain of $1,444,000 in the year-ago period. The company said the decrease in revenue is due to the sale of a unit by Farm House Foods Corp. in January and the sale to two units by Entree Corp. in June.

title: Nynex Agrees With Strikers On a Contract
description: The Nynex Corporation and telephone workers tentatively agreed on a contract yesterday that would end a bitter 16-week strike. The workers were scheduled to return to their jobs on Dec. 4.

title: Merieux Pledge On Connaught
description: Eager to win Canadian Government approval for its $942 million (Canadian) takeover bid for the vaccine maker Connaught Biosciences Inc., Institut Merieux S.A. announced on Tuesday an increased commitment to research and development in Canada.

title: Proffitt's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income

title: The Ordeal for Lebanon: 14 Years and 7 Months
description: April 13, 1975 Decades of simmering political and sectarian rivalry are brought to a boil by Christian resentment of the Palestianian state-within-a-state that has sprung up in Lebanon after the expulsion of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Jordan in 1970. Civil war breaks out between the Phalangists, a right-wing Maronite Christian group, and Palestinians after Maronites are killed at a church. Phalangists kill Palestinians in revenge.

title: Bush Introduces a Daily Presidential Citation
description: After a visit to a children's hospital and the bedside of an injured college football player, President Bush announced a new twist to his ''thousand points of light'' voluntarism campaign today: a daily Presidential citation for institutions or people ''who are making a difference.''

title: Review/Cabaret; 'Forever Plaid,' a Spoof
description: ''Forever Plaid,'' Stuart Ross's zany new revue at Steve McGraw's (158 West 72d Street), spoofs the same insipid 1950's pop iconography that recent cabaret shows featuring mythical groups named the Taffetas and the Cardigans have celebrated with a more subdued tongue-in-cheek humor.

title: Calendar: Miniature Railroads On Display
description: Trains and Tracks in Miniature, Atrium at Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street; 212-559-2330.

title: Transcript of President's Speech on Relations Between the East and West
description: Following is the transcript of President Bush's address to the nation last night as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Sodarcan Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Motherhood Can't Always Turn Out as Planned; The Heart's Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: Polymerix Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is a development- stage company.

title: NeoRx Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Propp Has Surgery
description: Brian Propp, the Philadelphia Flyers' right wing, had surgery yesterday to remove a blood clot in his left hand and will be out of action four to eight weeks, the team announced. Propp, 30 years old, is the Flyers' second-leading career goal scorer with 361 in 11 seasons with the club. He also has 471 career assists. . . . Tim Kerr, the top scorer for the Flyers last season, had arthroscopic surgery on his left shoulder Tuesday but could be back playing in four to six weeks, said Dr. James Andrews, who did the operation. (AP)

title: Study Finds Boiled Coffee Raises Cholesterol
description: Does coffee affect blood cholesterol levels? The question has long been a matter of dispute and conflicting results.

title: USR Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clamor in the East; In a Far Corner of East Germany, They Also Serve
description: Here in the Thuringia region, people want it known that even if Berlin and Leipzig have captured all the attention as the centers of the East German upheaval, they, too, are part of what they call ''our friendly revolution'' or ''the gentle revolution.''

title: Prague's Turn
description: It is exquisitely just that the great democratic wave in Eastern Europe now surges in Czechoslovakia. Prague, after all, led the way in trying to liberalize Communism - and the bitter result was the Soviet-led invasion in 1968 that turned spring into winter.

title: Irving Friedman, 74, Economist
description: Irving S. Friedman, an international economist who held high positions in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, died of a heart attack on Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 years and lived in Bethesda.

title: Tesoro Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included for the quarter $14 million of charges resulting from legal expenses, employee termination costs and writedowns among other things; the year included charges totaling $25.8 million. c-Included for the quarter a $27 million charge from the settlement with the Department of Energy, and a $7.2 million gain from the sale of assets; the year included a gain of $39.2 million.

title: Sigma Designs reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
British Water Share Price Cut
description: In an attempt to attract investors, the Government has reduced the price for shares in Britain's water industry.

title: Dubcek Talks to Rally Outside Bratislava Trial Clamor in the East
description: Alexander Dubcek, the leader overthrown in the 1968 Soviet invasion of Prague, spoke in public today for the first time since his liberalizing movement was crushed, addressing protesters who gathered to show support for a dissident who was being tried in court.

title: Lowe's Cos Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ashland Oil to Pay $4.6 Million to Pennsylvania
description: Continuing its financial mop-up of one of the nation's largest inland fuel spills, Ashland Oil Inc. has agreed to pay Pennsylvania $4.6 million in costs and civil penalties.

title: The Iron (and Gold) Curtain
description: Just when it seemed that the entrepreneurial spirit had vanished from this land, two men named David Schwartz and Edmond Howar have come along to show that Yankees still know how to turn a dime into a dollar.

title: Colleges Start Plans For Using CBS Billion
description: With more than a year before the money starts rolling in, several weeks at least before the serious arguments begin and probably months before the knives come out, college athletic officials seemed too stunned to squabble yesterday.

title: Autodesk Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PEACE EFFORTS ARE SET BACK
description: The new Lebanese President, Rene Moawad, was assassinated today when a huge bomb blew up his car. He died after only 17 days in office.

title: Central Cooperative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Survival Is Goal in Eastern Strike
description: Almost nine months since beginning a strike against Eastern Airlines, many machinists and flight attendants who have stayed off the job have become deeply concerned about their economic survival.

title: Clamor in the East; The New Europe: Will It Come Apart as It Comes Together?
description: More than a century ago, the Hapsburg Empire, based in this grand old city on the Danube, stretched across Central and Eastern Europe from the Tyrolian Alps to the Carpathian Mountains.

title: 250,000 Czechs, Hailing Dubcek, Urge Ouster of Hard-Line Leaders
description: More than 250,000 Czechoslovaks who gathered in Wenceslas Square for a sixth consecutive day of protest shouted ''Resign! Resign!'' today when speakers called for the country's hard-line Communist leaders to step down.

title: Liposome Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Listless Knicks Frustrate Coach
description: In the closing seconds of the first half, Stu Jackson, the Knicks' coach, in a moment of frustration at an official's call, grabbed a piece of white play-by-play sheet from the press table, waved it and yelled, ''I surrender, I surrender.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Bounces Back: Steffi Graf of West Germany came back after losing the first set to beat Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-7, 6-1, 6-3, in the opening round of the Nokia Masters women's tournament yesterday in Essen, West Germany. Monica Seles of Yugoslavia breezed by Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-1, and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina struggled before beating Zina Garrison of Houston, 1-6, 6-3, 6-4. Graf, who won the Virginia Slims Championship at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, needed 103 minutes to overcome Maleeva, a late replacement for Pam Shriver, who pulled out with an injury.(AP) Berger Rolls: Jay Berger of Plantation, Fla., rolled to a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Todd Witsken yesterday in a tournament in Itaparica, Brazil, an island city on Brazil's northeastern coast. Other winners were Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay in an upset of Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, Emilio Sanchez of Spain.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page last Friday about legal historians misidentified the group that found the precedent for public use of a walkway in Narragansett, R.I. It was discovered by Save the Bay Inc. of Providence.

title: By the Light Of a Silvery Paper Moon
description: THE sculptor Isamu Noguchi made exquisite paper lamps, which he called Akari, or light. The artist Yumi Kokubo has taken the design of paper lamps a step further. She cuts the paper into wavy strips, allowing the light to shine between. ''I call my work Kami No Akari - light through paper,'' said Ms. Kokubo, who moved from Tokyo to Manhattan in 1972.

title: Prairie Designs, but in Pottery
description: More than three-quarters of a century ago, architects led by Frank Lloyd Wright developed an architectural style that would come to be called the Prairie School. Working with flat, cantilevered surfaces, earth tones and rugged materials like stone, the architects created structures evocative of the Middle West and Great Plains.

title: Gray Is Showing in SoHo's Punk Look
description: Every weekend, thousands of people stroll down West Broadway into SoHo, a former industrial district that is a magnet for the chic and the would-be chic. They pass famous art galleries like Mary Boone and Leo Castelli; they pass bustling restaurants like I Tre Merli, where black-clad women grasp their focaccia with red-painted fingernails.

title: VS Services reports earnings for Year to Sept 28
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A Mass in Manhattan Honors 6 Priests Slain in El Salvador
description: Nearly a thousand people attended a memorial Mass yesterday at the Jesuit Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan to honor six Jesuit priests slain in El Salvador last week.

title: Trial On in Seattle in Deaths of Marcos Foes
description: A civil suit has opened in Federal District Court here in which the survivors of two people slain in 1981 will try to prove that the murders were ordered by the Government of Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines.

title: Man Who Fled to West Is Sentenced for Flight
description: Sheldon Weinberg, who fled just before he was to be sentenced for Medicaid fraud in January and was later recognized by viewers of a television show on fugitives, was sentenced yesterday to two to six years in jail for jumping bail.

title: BUSH CLAIMS ROLE IN HOSTAGE RESCUE IN SALVADOR HOTEL
description: President Bush said today that he had dispatched commandos to San Salvador after rebel forces seized a hotel where American military advisers were staying. He boasted of helping to rescue the hostages in an operation that was launched without seeking approval from the President of El Salvador.

title: Celina Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $820,000, or 49 cents a share, for the quarter and $981,000, or 58 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $27,000, or 2 cents a share, and $235,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Oil-Dri Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Vestron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,400,000 and $9,874,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. For the quarter, discontinued operations represented disposal of discontinued operations, and for the 9 months, included 23 cents a share for disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income and included losses from discontinued operations of $1,089,000 and $2,609,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Income for 9 months of 1988 included a pretax gain of $15.7 million from a settlement in connection with Helmdale Film Corp. and Home Box Office Inc.

title: KRG Management reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: TM Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Free at Last?
description: At no Thanksgiving since 1945 have Americans had such exhilarating reason to celebrate freedom. Overnight, as it seems, tyranny has lost its grip on Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Bulgaria. Czechoslovakia may follow. But there is something else in these events. There is the hope that our own country may be released from a great fear: the fear of Communism that has haunted American society for so long, distorting our law and marring our democracy.

title: Bringing Some Life To Eyewear
description: IN the 50's, people wore their eyeglasses on gold link chains, and in the 80's, eyeglasses dangled on plain cords. For the eyeglasses of the 90's, there are soft cotton sculptures of lobsters, snakes and hands.

title: Pioneer-Discovision Tie
description: Two American units of the Pioneer Electronic Corporation of Japan have completed the purchase of Discovision Associates for $200 million, Pioneer said on Monday. The main business of Discovision, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., is licensing a worldwide patent portfolio for optical disk recording and reproducing technology. Discovision had been a venture between the International Business Machines Corporation and MCA Inc.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LAST week's column described how to plan the extension of a household electrical circuit to supplement existing outlets and how to begin installing an extension using surface wiring. Household electrical projects are subject to local building code regulations in nearly every community. Before beginning this or any electrical project, consult your local building inspector.

title: Review/Dance; Suzanne Farrell's Farewell Week
description: The New York City Ballet staged one of its most unusual opening benefits on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater. Officially announced as the start of the company's 91st season, the performance fired the opening shot for what will obviously be Suzanne Farrell week.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL MINNESOTA (AL) - Agreed to terms with Kirby Puckett, outfielder, on a three-year contract. SENIOR PRO BASEBALL WINTER HAVEN - Announced the retirement of Cecil Cooper, first basemen-designated hitter. BASKETBALL NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION - Fined Charles Barkley, Philadelphia forward, $5,000 for verbal abuse of a referee and failing to leave the court in a timely fashion after he had been ejected from the game on Nov. 18. INDIANA (NBA) - Placed Dyron Nix, forward, on the injured list. Activated Calvin Natt, forward, from the injured list. SAN ANTONIO (NBA) - Signed Johnny Moore, guard. Waived Jeff Lebo, guard. FOOTBALL NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Re-signed Mike Jones, wide receiver. Waived Glenn Antrum, wide receiver. Activated Bruce Scholtz, linebacker, from injured reserve. Placed Tim Jordan, linebacker, on injured reserve. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Signed Todd Wheeler, center, to the developmental roster. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Signed Roger Ruzek, kicker, to a one-year contract. Released Steve DeLine, kicker.
