COLLEGES NATIONAL COLLEGIATE ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION - Suspended Bernard Jackson, Cornell basketball forward, for one game for playing in an unsanctioned game. MONMOUTH - Announced that Harrie Garris, basketball forward, had withdrawn from school.

title: Allied-Lyons Plan
description: Allied-Lyons P.L.C., the British food and beverage concern, said it would explore the sale of Dunkin' Donuts Inc.'s restaurant division after it completes its $325 million offer. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Allied-Lyons said it had not begun negotiations about a possible sale of the division, which holds the right to develop Chili's Grill and Bar restaurants in New England, New York State outside the New York City area and certain Canadian provinces. The unit earned $16.8 million in sales during the nine months that ended in July.

title: African Dance at Pan Am
description: African dance, music and stories will be presented by Lady Gourd Sangoma, a trio, at noon today in the lobby of the Pan Am Building, 45th Street off Vanderbilt Avenue. The performance is the last of this year's series of free entertainment sponsored by Metropolitan Life and the Grand Central Partnership.

title: Retailers Are Wary Of Season
description: Perhaps more than in any year since 1974, when a severe recession started before Thanksgiving, the success of the Christmas shopping season that begins tomorrow is uncertain. But for bargain-hunting shoppers, opportunities may abound.

title: South African Bolstered in Claim He Belonged to Police 'Hit Squad'
description: A team of South African lawyers said today that they had corroborated some of the assertions made by a convicted murderer who said he served with a police assassination squad that killed and terrorized opponents of apartheid.

title: Circle Express Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the revenue decline in the latest 9 months was due to operations sold or discontinued in 1988.

title: Clamor in the East; Soviet Novelist Apologizes to Prague
description: A Soviet newspaper today published a prominent novelist's passionate apology to the Czechoslovak people for the Soviet-led invasion of Prague in 1968, calling the intervention a ''collective murder'' that introduced a Stalinist regime.

title: Therapy Groups Yield Surprising Benefits for Cancer Patients
description: In a new study of women with breast cancer that has spread, researchers were surprised to find that the women who belonged to a psychotherapy group lived almost twice as long on average as those who did not participate in a support group.

title: Petrie Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After loss in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands amounting to about 4 cents a share from Hurricane Hugo. c-Included a gain on the extinguishment of long-term debt of $57,100,000, or $1.22 a share.

title: Harvey's Basket at the Buzzer Lifts St. John's Over DePaul
description: Despite his nickname, Greg (Boo) Harvey does not scare easily.

title: CML Group reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,215,000, or 18 cents a share. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $635,000.

title: Helen Buttenwieser, 84, Lawyer and Civic Leader
description: Helen Lehman Buttenwieser, among the first women admitted to the City Bar Association in New York and a civic leader, died of heart failure yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Wickes Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $150,772,000 and $209,115,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and both periods included gains on retirement of debt of $41,044,000. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,651,000 for the quarter, and the 9 months included income from discontinued operations of $6,380,000. Regarding discontinued operations- -Wickes completed the sales of its furniture division in May and its Elco group of companies in August. Also, the company has entered definitive agreements for the sales of its Heat Transfer group and its A.P.S. subsidiary. Results of these operations are classified as discontinued operations and prior periods have been restated. Included in discontinued operations for the latest quarter and 9-month periods are after-tax gains on disposal of $154,111,000 and $210,165,000, respectively.

title: Arnold Herstand, Art Gallery Owner And Educator, 64
description: Arnold Herstand, a painter, art dealer and former president of the Minneapolis College of Art and Design and the San Francisco Art Institute, died of brain cancer on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 4-Plane Boeing Order
description: Southwest Air Lines of Okinawa, Japan, has ordered four Boeing 737-400's and taken options on four others in a deal worth about $160 million, the Boeing Company said Tuesday. Southwest would become the first Japanese carrier to operate the 737-400, a twin-engine jetliner that can seat 145 to 170 people. The airline already has seven of the older-model 737-200's.

title: Wigglesworth Honored By Composers' Group
description: Frank Wigglesworth, a composer and longtime worker in behalf of concert music, is to receive the second Laurel Wreath of the American Composers Alliance, ''for outstanding contributions to American music.'' The award will be presented on Dec. 15.

title: 2 Sentenced in Rape
description: Nigel Clay and Bernard Hall, former members of the University of Oklahoma team, were sentenced yesterday in Norman, Okla., to 10 years in prison for rape. District Judge Preston Trimble also fined the men $10,000 each. Glen Bell, another former Sooner football player, was acquitted of the same charge.

title: Bond Corp. Trading Halted
description: Alan Bond, the Australian entrepreneur, suffered a double blow today that left his companies' debt downgraded and their shares suspended.

title: Washington Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Intercargo Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The increase in the number of common shares outstanding reflected the initial public offering of 700,000 shares in May 1988. The latest 9-month period included a deferred tax benefit of $91,000, or 4 cents a share, from the adoption of FASB 96.

title: B.I.A. - Bureau of Ignorance and Abuse
description: LEAD: There are many lessons to be learned at Haskell Indian Junior College, a Government school run by the Bureau of Indian Affairs in Lawrence, Kan., but the most important ones are probably being taught by the students. Their teaching is quite simple: Native American college students, like other American citizens, have civil rights that should be respected.

title: Roberto E. Arias, Envoy, Writer And Panama Politician, 71, Dies
description: Roberto E. Arias, a Panamanian lawyer, diplomat and journalist who was the husband of Dame Morgot Fonteyn, the British ballerina, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at Paitilla Medical Center in Panama. He was 71 years old and lived on his ranch in El Higo outside Panama City.

title: Review/Piano; Juilliard Alumna Plays Messiaen And Others
description: Sachiko Hasegawa, a Japanese pianist who has studied at the Juilliard School under Rudolf Firkusny, chose four good, solid works for her New York recital debut at Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon, but failed to make a distinct impression. She showed a certain flair in Chopin's Sonata in B minor (Op. 58), and real fire in ''Regard de l'Esprit de Joie'' from Messiaen's ''Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant Jesus'' - unfortunately the shortest work on the program. More Messiaen, or something else that suited her temperament equally well, would have been welcome.

title: Clement Haynsworth Dies at 77; Lost Struggle for High Court Seat
description: Clement F. Haynsworth Jr., the Federal judge whose nomination to the Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate in 1969 after a tense battle between the Nixon Administration and a coalition of labor and civil rights groups, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Greenville, S.C. He was 77 years old.

title: Pickens Dealt Rebuff by Koito
description: The Texas oilman and investor T. Boone Pickens Tuesday criticized the board of the Koito Manufacturing Company, the Japanese auto parts maker, for rejecting his requests to raise its interim dividend.

title: Wareham Journal; Cranberry Crop of 1989 Is No Cause for Thanks
description: This is the capital of cranberry country, a sandy stretch of earth lapped by Buzzards Bay where the fruit is grown much the way it was a century ago.

title: Farm House Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 14
description: b-Included a loss of $3,455,000 for both the quarter and 6 months related to disposition of assets, and income tax credits of $101,000 for the quarter and $141,000 for the 6 months. c-Included a gain of $360,000 for the quarter and a loss of $6,045 in the 6 months, both related to disposition of assets, and the quarter also included an income tax credit of $38,000.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Clayton & Dublier, an investment firm, said its APS Acquisition unit had completed the purchase of A.P.S. Inc., Houston, which distributes auto parts, from Wickes Cos., Santa Monica, Calif. The price was $200 million.

title: Shaw Cablesystems reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Results for fiscal 1989 included a loss resulting from the sale of floating-rate preferred shares equal to 5 cents a share. Results for fiscal 1988 included a loss of 12 cents a share from the sale of its investment in Canadian Home Shopping Network Ltd. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: For Walls, Childhood Whimsy
description: THERE are no fluffy sheep prancing through meadows or kittens chasing balls of yarn in Karen Skelton's wallpaper and fabric designs for children. Ms. Skelton, a graphic designer, has created ''Classmates,'' a whimsical collection in which birds fly backward and pigs have blue ears and green-and-white bodies.

title: Dollar General reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Nittmo Will Face 49ers
description: When the Giants play the 49ers Monday night in San Francisco, Bjorn Nittmo will be the Giants' kicker again. He received a mild vote of confidence today from Coach Bill Parcells.

title: Barrier Science & Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: A 'Prime Mover' in U.S. Banking
description: The stakes are mounting each day, but I. A. Long has yet to show any sign of sweaty palms.

title: Enzon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Digi International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago full- year net included an extraordinary gain of $23,000.

title: A Leading Art Collector Is Selling, And the Market Wonders Why
description: ''What's he buying?'' used to be the hot question in the art world about the British mega-collector Charles Saatchi. But now the question has turned around to, ''What's he selling?''

title: Barkley Fined $5,000
description: Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star forward, has been fined $5,000 by the National Basketball Association for his conduct during a game against the Magic at Orlando, Fla., on Saturday night.

title: Soviet Scientist Defects on California Visit
description: A Soviet scientist who first visited the United States last year to monitor nuclear weapons tests defected quietly last week during a private return visit and separated from his family to do so.

title: A New Place for Putting Everything in Its Place
description: FOR those who cannot bear a messy house, there is Hold Everything, a store that sells containers for everything from wine to socks. The 12-store chain opened its first Manhattan outlet on Monday at 1311 Second Avenue (69th Street).

title: Bank of Japan's Leader Leaving
description: The governor of the Bank of Japan, Satoshi Sumita, will step down on Dec. 16 at the end of his present term, the country's Minister of Finance, Ryutaro Hashimoto, announced today.

title: Tom Brown Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1988 included an additional charge of $2,422,000 to depreciation and depletion expense for a writedown of costs of oil and gas properties to the estimated value of reserves at Sept. 30, 1988.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: FEW things test the mettle of children more than having a friend who is in trouble. The problem may be drugs, pregnancy, illness or difficulties at home. Deciding if and how to help someone cuts to the heart of some of the most powerful issues of child and adolescent development: empathy, loyalty and responsibility.

title: Time to Sell Scott, Foresman for $455 Million
description: Time Warner Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell Scott, Foresman & Company to Harper & Row for $455 million.

title: Etac Sales reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $343,878, or 4 cents a share, and $364,913, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $1,544,221, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,586,168, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Parker & Parsley reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income of $3.5 million, or 62 cents a unit, related to the gain on the sale of oil and gas properties. c-Net loss

title: United Systems Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Workingmens Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Nuclear Support Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charge of $232,000 reflecting a downward adjustment in the cost of one of the company's investment securities. c-Net income d-Net loss and after a gain of $600,000, or 29 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Top Job Filled By Laventhol
description: Robert Levine, managing director of the San Francisco office of Laventhol & Horwath, will become the accounting firm's next chief executive officer in June, the company announced Tuesday. He succeeds George Bernstein, whose second five-year term expires this year.

title: Chronar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $854,321 as a result of the conversion of debt that occurred on Aug. 31, 1989 for the quarter and 9 months. The latest quarter's continuing operations of a loss of $9,517,485 included a $2.6 million provision resulting from a change in estimate of the cost to complete the Eureka contract. The latest 9-month's loss from continuing operations of $32,062,677 included a provision for inventory obsolescence of $7.9 million; a provision of $4.9 million resulting from changes in estimates of the cost to complete the Eureka contract and delay in the recognition of profits on the Shenzhen contract; losses and reductions in the carrying value of investments in and advances to affiliates of $1.5 million, and a $1.1 million provision for uncollectable amounts from affiliates. The year-ago 9-month's loss from continuing operations of $1,134,516 included a non-recurring gain of $2,012,789 related to the sale of 60 percent of the company's equity interest in Chronar France.

title: Filing by Simmons On Maxxam Stake
description: The Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons said he intended to raise his stake in Maxxam Inc. above 15 percent, possibly as high as 25 percent. His stake now totals 14.6 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Simmons said he had sought antitrust clearance from the Federal Trade Commission to go above 15 percent. The shares of Maxxam, a Los Angeles-based forest products concern, were unchanged today at $41.75 on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Jackson County Fedl S & L reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gain of $387,000 from the sale of $18.3 million of fixed-rate loans and mortgage-backed securities, which was reinvested in adjustable- rate mortgage-backed securities.

title: Triton Group Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $25,488,000, or $2.32 a share, and $28,665,000, or $2.65 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and an extraordinary credits of $33,530,000, or $3.05 a share, and $34,226,000, or $3.16 a share, for the same periods, respectively. The company said the decrease in revenues and current quarter loss was due primarily to its decision to write off $5.7 million relating to preferred stock received in the 1988 sale of Simplicity Pattern Co. The company had concluded that the prospects for any near-term recovery from this stock were extremely limited. Results for the quarter also reflected adjustments to reduce certain cash investments to currently depressed market values as well as budgeted losses at Western Sizzlin and Liquor Barn.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about the Indian elections was incomplete. It should have shown the state of Jammu and Kashmir, in northwest India, bordering Himachal Pradesh and Punjab.

title: A Fourth Person Aided Fugitive, Prosecutors Say
description: A New Jersey woman has been arrested on charges that she helped hide a Staten Island man who was wanted for nine months in the killing of a Federal drug agent, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Gandhi Foes Cite Disruptions In First Day of India Voting
description: As voting began in a national election that will determine the political future of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, opposition politicans asserted today that criminal gangs backed by the governing party were disrupting voting in Mr. Gandhi's own constituency, where independent witnesses also said they had seen policemen stuffing ballot boxes.

title: Motherhood Can't Always Turn Out as Planned; Young Grandparents
description: To the Editor:

title: Trac Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $499,179. The company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Jan. 31. For the five months ended June 30, 1988, the company had net of $45,186, or less than 1 cent a share, on revenues of $2,313,721. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Landmark Savings Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $372,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,522,000, or 64 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $982,000, or 41 cents a share, and $2,774,000, or $1.17 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said new-store pre- opening expenses reduced earnings in the latest quarter and 9-month periods by 2 cents a share, compared with 10 cents a share in the 1988 quarter and 19 cents a share in the year-ago 9 months.

title: Dreco Energy Services reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Arnold Bauman, 75, A Former U.S. Judge And Litigation Chief
description: Arnold Bauman, a former United States District Court judge, a prosecutor and a prominent New York litigator for many years, died of cancer Tuesday night at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Motherhood Can't Always Turn Out as Planned
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Women Who Wrote Verse and Suffered
description: In ''Three Poets,'' Romulus Linney contemplates three women separated by a millennium and by widely disparate cultures. The characters are united by their individualism and artistry - and by the fact that men were their harshest critics.

title: Dow Rises 17.49 Points, To 2,656.78
description: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday in slow pre-Thanksgiving trading. The Dow Jones industrial average finished 17.49 points higher at 2,656.78.

title: Gen. Harry Disston, Retired Executive, 91
description: Brig. Gen. Harry Disston of the New York National Guard, a retired executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in Manhattan, died Tuesday at his home in Keswick, Va. He was 91 years old.

title: Innovex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-18 The Lebanese President was killed when a huge bomb ripped through his motorcade in West Beirut. President Rene Moawad served only 17 days in office. At least 23 others died in the explosion. Page A1 News analysis: The ultimate target in the assassination of President Rene Moawad was the accord between Lebanon's warring Muslim and Christian factions. A10 Rene Moawad: man who sought unity A10 President Bush sent commandos into San Salvador after rebel forces seized a hotel where American military advisers were staying, but the standoff ended before the soldiers arrived, the White House said. A1 The Green Berets at the barricades A3 News analysis: What role should the U.S. play in El Salvador? A2 About 250,000 Czechoslovaks rallied in Prague for a sixth consecutive day of protest, demanding the resignation of hard-line Communist Party leaders. A1 Dubcek makes first public address since 1968 invasion A16 Soviet novelist apologizes to Prague A16 East Germany's Communist Party proposed discussions with ''other political forces'' about the nation's future, but no timetable was set. A17 East German revolution touches every region A17 Lifting of Berlin wall strains telephones and transportation A17 Bush affirms U.S. Commitment to NATO A12 News analysis: Will the New Europe come apart? A16 A South African assassination squad, operated by security police, terrorized opponents of apartheid, according to a convicted murderer who says he belonged to the squad. Lawyers say they have corroborated his assertions. A1 The P.L.O. is willing to negotiate with Israel, Yasir Arafat told President Bush in a message transmitted from Tunis. The message was vague and very general, U.S. officials said. A5 Voting in India was marred by violence instigated by Government-supported criminal gangs, opposition politicians said. Early reports had 20 people dead. A18 NATIONAL A20-28, B13-14 The sides in a pivotal abortion case before the Supreme Court agreed to settle. The Illinois case was viewed as the Court's best chance to overturn the 1973 ruling that established abortion as a constitutional right. A1 In an Iran-contra trial of a former C.I.A. official, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh barred disclosure of classified information. The move could lead to the dismissal of charges in the case. A1 O'Hare Airport has become home to more than 200 homeless people. Officials are now considering a plan to build a homeless shelter close to the airport. A1 Pilots at Eastern airlines voted to end their nearly nine-month-long walkout, agreeing to return to work unconditionally. D1 The space shuttle Discovery roared into space in the first night launching of a shuttle since the Challenger disaster. B14 The health problems of the elderly will be addressed next year, lawmakers said after Congress's decision to repeal the Medicare act covering the high costs of acute illness. A20 Bush introduces a daily presidential citation A13 In the New Orleans mayoral race, the dominant personality, former Mayor Ernest Dutch Morial, is not even a candidate - at least not yet. But his silence is getting attention. A20 Girl in baby swap case is told of test results A20 Australian is guilty of Florida killing A24 Ex-party chief in Florida is indicted in bribery case A21 Fuel-oil barge adrift near Valdez spill site A23 Company to pay millions for Pennsylvania spill A22 Trial on in Seattle in deaths of Marcos foes A28 REGIONAL B1-12 A multilingual church in Queens thrives on its diverse congregation. Prayers are said in English, Spanish, Korean and Chinese in separate, simultaneous services. A1 The bitter 16-week Nynex strike has apparently ended, as telephone workers and the phone company tentatively agreed to a three-year pact. Workers are scheduled to return to work on Dec. 4. B1 An indictment of a state senator was upheld by a New York appeals court 10 months ago. But a ruling on Manfred Ohrenstein's case has been held up because of an unusually long delay in writing the majority opinion, court officials said. B1 David Dinkins is on vacation in Puerto Rico. He relaxes in private much the way he works in public -calmly, coolly and quietly. B2 The chic and mystique of SoHo may be withering as the community enters middle age. Its retail and residential sectors are showing signs of stress. B1 Fund for neediest helps end man's homelessness B1 Bronx hospice, facing a chronic deficit, to close B2 Cuomo orders review of fatal collapse of a wall B3 A fourth aided fugitive, prosecuters say B3 Police official criticized for action in drug case B3

title: Opus Dei Group Has Nothing to Hide
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Is Considering White-Collar Layoffs
description: Facing softening American car sales and increased competition, the General Motors Corporation said today that it was studying staffing levels in its white-collar work force.

title: Devils Start Fast Again, But Finish Strong, Too
description: The Devils apparently learned a lesson after squandering a three-goal lead and losing their previous game. They refused to sit on their advantage tonight and the result was a 6-3 triumph over the Penguins.

title: Eastern's Pilot Union Ends Strike
description: Leaders of the pilots' union at Eastern Airlines voted yesterday to end the union's nearly nine-month-long walkout, but the machinists' union vowed to continue its strike.

title: Ramsay Health reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $256,000, or 1 cent a share, which included an after-tax gain of about $450,000 from the sale of the company's previously closed Riverwood Hospital. c-Included a tax credit of $111,000.

title: Review/Dance; Susan Braham's Celebration of Friendship
description: Intentionally or not, Susan Braham offered a celebration of friendship on Saturday at St. Mark's Church in a program presented by the Danspace Project and shared with Donna Uchizono. In two dances choreographed by Ms. Braham and one created for her by Susan Rethorst, the elucidation of the performers' characters and relationships made for a charming and imaginative evening of dance.

title: Canada Northwest Energy Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary writedown of carrying value of assets of $118,000,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mindy Schulman Is a Bride on L.I.
description: The marriage of Mindy Joy Schulman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome B. Schulman of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., to Jonathan David Roman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Roman of Woodsburgh, L.I., took place last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbis Arnold Marans and Stanley Platek officiated.

title: No Headline
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage, has undertaken an overhaul that is expected to involve the abandonment of several business lines and the dismissal of as many as 1,000 employees, Wall Street executives said yesterday Merrill announced its plans this week in a letter to more than 40,000 employees. The letter did not specify which operations would be terminated or how many employees would be dismissed.

title: New Cardinals' Coach Faces Rebuilding Job
description: Gene Stallings hoped to finish the season as the Phoenix Cardinals' head coach and then resign. Larry Wilson, the Cardinals' general manager, promptly gave Stallings the boot and named Hank Kuhlmann interim coach.

title: Test Clears Gooden For Normal Workouts
description: Dwight Gooden has received another clearance in his return from the shoulder ailment he suffered last season. He was examined by Dr. Arthur Pappas, the Boston Red Sox team orthopedist, last Monday, and had another magnetic resonance imaging test. The Mets said Gooden had been soft-tossing three or four days a week and could now step up his workouts to his normal winter routine.

title: Britain Builds Silver Collection
description: In the days when the British believed the sun would never set on their empire, British leaders and diplomats rarely failed to put on a good show for visiting dignitaries. State dinners were served at tables that nearly groaned under the weight of silver serving pieces crafted for the host's family by the best of the Georgian silversmiths.

title: Kewaunee Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $63,000. c-After a loss of $106,000 from an adjustment in accounting. The latest 6 months' income before items included a tax credit of $63,000.

title: Holiday Today
description: Today is Thanksgiving. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West and heads to Columbus Circle and down Broadway to 34th Street and Seventh Avenue. Government offices: All closed. Post office: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Self-service windows open at the main branch at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: No collection or street cleanings. Schools: Closed today and tomorrow. Financial Markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule; Long Island Rail Road, holiday schedule; Metro-North and New Haven line, holiday schedule today through Sunday. NEW JERSEY Government offices: State closed today and tomorrow. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed, with option to close tomorrow. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule, with modified weekday schedule tomorrow. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, State and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed today and tomorrow. Transportation: Metro-North and New Haven line on holiday schedule today through Sunday.

title: Squanto's Luck
description: Late on a raw November day, Plimoth Plantation is a forbidding place; bare trees groan in the wind rushing off the ocean. As darkness deepens the pervasive chill, the Pilgrims huddle indoors. They draw their layers of English wool tighter as cold steals in through chinks in the walls. Logs glowing in a fireplace warm only a corner of the small room.

title: Neighborhood Stores Must Not Be Driven Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks Resumed By Dataproducts
description: The Dataproducts Corporation said it had resumed discussions with several undisclosed parties interested in seeking control of the computer printer manufacturer.

title: C. C. Beck Dies at 79; Drew Captain Marvel
description: C. C. Beck, a comic book artist who created the character Captain Marvel, died today at Shands Hospital in Gainesville after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Star Center Testifies
description: Alonzo Mourning, the Georgetown sophomore center who was named to the preseason all-America team of The Associated Press, testified yesterday in Washington at the Federal drug trial of Rayful Edmond 3d, a reputed cocaine dealer, and 10 co-defendants.

title: Clamor in the East; East Germany's Free Travel Overloads Rails and Phones
description: East Germany's transportation systems and telephone lines have come under enormous stress as a result of the Communist Government's decision 13 days ago to allow 16.5 million citizens to travel freely to the West.

title: Fuel-Oil Barge Adrift Near Valdez Spill Site
description: An unmanned barge carrying five million gallons of aviation fuel is drifting in Alaska waters and could run aground near the site of last March's Exxon Valdez spill, the United States Coast Guard said today.

title: Cable Applications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $35,000, or 1 cent a share, and $71,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $4,000 for the quarter and $26,000 for the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a gain of $1,010,376, or 41 cents a share, from the reduction of liabilities under the company's plan of reorganization.

title: Sharper Image Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said its results for the latest quarter were adversely affected by the San Francisco earthquake on Oct. 17, which caused the entire toll-free ordering system to be shut down for 3 days, with residual lingering problems. In addition, the three San Francisco Bay area stores were closed for 3 days, and experienced reduced sales in the following weeks.

title: Cuomo Orders Fatal-Collapse Inquiry
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today ordered a broad investigation into last week's fatal collapse of a wall at the East Coldenham Elementary School.

title: General Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago 9 months included income of $22,043,000 resulting from the settlement of certain antitrust litigation.

title: Delayed Court Opinion Stalls Ohrenstein Case
description: Ten months ago, a New York appeals court voted to uphold the indictment of Senator Manfred Ohrenstein, the State Senate Democratic minority leader, but the ruling has been held up because of an unusually long delay in writing the majority opinion, officials of the appeals court said last night.

title: Relief but No Remedy in El Salvador
description: Americans will share President Bush's ''delight and relief'' at the freeing of 12 U.S. military people trapped in a San Salvador hotel. This averts what could have been a confrontation with the Salvadoran guerrillas who escaped unharmed from the same hotel.

title: High-Tech Paint Chips
description: YOU no longer have to discover that the yellow that looked pale and serene on the paint chip is garish on the exterior of your house. This month, Benjamin Moore, the paint manufacturer, introduced its Video Color Planner, a computer that lets you choose pictures of homes, and electronically paint the facade, or the walls, floors, doors and trim with any of 1,800 colors.

title: KEY RATES
Clamor in the East; Germans Clash at 2 Rallies
description: Hundreds of right-wing supporters attending two rallies favoring German reunification clashed with opponents today, the police said. A Republican Party member was hurt when a rally by 350 right-wing supporters in Herleshausen turned into a fight with about 20 opponents. Fights with counterdemonstrators were also reported at a rally by 500 Republicans in nearby Eschwege but no injuries were reported.

title: Some '89 Thank-You Notes
description: On too many other days, the scoundrels of sports are in the headlines. But on Thanksgiving Day, it's appropriate to remember some of the good people who just by being themselves make sports' little corner of the world a better place to be.

title: Virgil Thomson Memorial
description: A free memorial concert for the composer Virgil Thomson is to be held on Saturday at 3 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. The program includes selections from the composer's three operas, ''Four Saints in Three Acts,'' ''The Mother of Us All'' and ''Lord Byron,'' as well as other works.

title: Goal Systems International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Abrams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Planning a Modern City, With Legos
description: Onkal (Duke) Guzey used to have to ask his small children if he could borrow their Lego toys to build his model homes. Now, five years and half a million Lego pieces later, he has built his own city.

title: Egghead Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 14
description: b-Included a reserve of $1.6 million for closure of 20 stores within the next 12 months, three of which were reserved for in the prior year. c-Net income d-Adjusted to reflect the change in accounting principle and after a loss of $617,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle. The company does business as Egghead Discount Software.

title: Treasuries Up on Sign of Fed Easing
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board signaled market participants that it might have sanctioned another modest drop in interest rates.

title: A Lawmaker Who Sought To End Strife
description: Rene Moawad, the President of Lebanon, who was assassinated yesterday in a car bombing in Beirut, was a Maronite Christian who advocated coexistence with Muslims and acknowledged the importance of the Syrian role in Lebanon. He was 64 years old.

title: Review/Dance; Exploring the Art of the Solo In 2 Forms From Japan
description: Suzushi Hanayagi and Suzusetsu Hanayagi are noted interpreters of Jiuta-mai and Kabuki dance. So the program they presented on Friday at the Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium offered an informed look at those two classical dance forms of Japan. But a program of solos also necessarily becomes a commentary on the art of solo dancing, and that was the greatest pleasure and fascination of the evening, which also included dancing by Suzusetsumi Hanayagi.

title: U.S. Rules Out Retaliation In Japan Construction Cases
description: Citing collusive bidding and other restrictive practices, the Bush Administration said today that Japan continued to restrict American bidders unfairly from its $300 billion-a-year construction market, but it ruled out retaliation at this time.

title: SmithKline-T Cell Research Pact Set
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. signed an agreement with T Cell Sciences Inc. to develop a new drug that the small biotechnology company is investigating to limit heart tissue damage because of heart attacks, the companies said.

title: Stairs That Go Beyond the Ordinary
description: EVER since Jacob's ladder, the staircase has symbolized spiritual ascent. In architecture, the notion of a stairway to paradise has inspired everything from the Spanish steps in Rome to the Great Wall of China.

title: Hana Biologics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $12,756,000 from sale of the company's diagnostic and cell biology media product lines to Irvine Scientific, and restructuring costs of $1,640,000 from the company's recent reorganization and work force reduction. c-Net loss

title: G.M. Reward On Release Of Car Photos
description: The General Motors Corporation has offered a reward of up to $30,000 for information about what it suspects was the theft from its design studios of photographs and sketches of its Saturn models and other future vehicles.

title: Personal Health
description: Adults shopping for holiday gifts for children are often overwhelmed by the large and increasingly expensive array of playthings available to entertain and educate from the cradle to college.

title: S.E.C. Budget Plan Dropped
description: House and Senate conferees have removed language from the Federal deficit-reduction bill that would have allowed the Securities and Exchange Commission to increase its budget.

title: Franklin Savings-Kansas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Franklin Savings Association said it recognized a gain to 1988 net interest income of $26.7 million from mortgage loan prepayments in accord with FASB No. 91. Franklin Savings said it realized net gains of $25 million in latest quarter and $23 million in the quarter a year-ago from the sale of assets and financial futures contracts.

title: Sotheby's to Auction The Hunts' Antiquities
description: Sotheby's will auction ancient Greek and Roman coins and bronzes, valued at more than $20 million, from the collections of the Texas oilmen William Herbert Hunt and Nelson Bunker Hunt.

title: Braniff Sues Jet Suppliers
description: Braniff Inc. has filed a lawsuit seeking to stop a group of aviation companies from withholding delivery of 50 aircraft that it says it needs to continue operating while under bankruptcy protection.

title: INSIDE
description: Eastern Pilots End Walkout Ending a walkout of nearly nine months, Eastern pilots said they would return to work unconditionally; the machinists, however, will continue their strike. Page D1. Night Launching of Shuttle The space shuttle Discovery roared aloft with a secret military payload in a nighttime launching that officials said was a sign of growing confidence in the shuttle program. Page B14. Clement Haynsworth Dies The Federal judge, whom the Senate denied a Supreme Court seat in a severe setback to the Nixon Administration, was 77 years old. Page D21.

title: Selectronics Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Shuttle Team for a Military Mission
description: For the flight of the space shuttle Discovery, the space agency chose three military officers and two civilian astronauts. Here are sketches of the five astronauts. Frederick D. Gregory Mission Commander

title: PEC Israel Economic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenues for the 9 months in 1988 have been reclassified. Provisions for income taxes in 1989 were $1,075,467 in the third quarter and $2,145,684 in the 9 months, and in 1988 were $808,198 in the third quarter and $2,764,541 in the 9 months.

title: Katharine Butler, Internist, 91
description: Dr. Katharine Butler, a retired attending physician at New York Hospital and clinical associate professor of medicine at Cornell Medical College, died Saturday at Crosslands, a Quaker life-care community near Kennett Square, Pa. She was 91 years old.

title: Dr. Eleanor Farrar, 50, Writer on Education
description: Dr. Eleanor J. Farrar, an educator, author and education researcher, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Shaker Heights, Ohio. She was 50 years old.

title: Northbay Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago per share earnings were not available because the company was not public.

title: Fund for Neediest Helps Man Leave Homelessness Behind
description: Albert Bishop did not contemplate seeking help until he had been without a home for four years and realized he could no longer help himself.

title: Bridge
description: Many American tournament players have reason to remember Jeremy M. Flint, the British star who died a week ago in London. He spent the year 1966 on the United States tournament circuit in partnership with Peter Pender, and finished second, behind Pender, in the McKenney Trophy race for the most master points won in the year. He also set a record, which still stands, by becoming a life master in 11 weeks.

title: Las Vegas Golf & Tennis reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Sales Start Early At Altman Stores
description: The six B. Altman stores in the New York metropolitan area started their going-out-of-business sales yesterday, advancing the scheduled start from Friday. John Schultz, the chairman and chief executive of B. Altman & Company, said the turnout was excellent despite no advertising. The price reductions were 20 percent.

title: Mainerss Seasonal Labors Yield Bright, Scented Holidays
description: LEAD: Maine is Christmas wreath country, where no house is holiday dressed unless it has a fragrant ring on the door and few logging trucks rumbling out of the north woods are without bright-bowed balsam wreaths on their grilles. Wreaths are the year's final home-grown offering at many farm stands, and on tourist routes peddlers' trucks line the highways: going price, about six bucks plain.

title: Review/Music; 14 Choirs Sing Haydn, Puccini and Liszt
description: Peter Tiboris, a conductor with an entrepreneurial streak, has made a business of bringing young choruses from around the country to New York for concerts in the city's large halls. Typically, these are mammoth affairs in which several choirs join forces for Victorian-scale performances, usually accompanied by Mr. Tiboris's freelance Manhattan Philharmonic.

title: Islam Didn't Influence Egyptian Christianity
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Theater; Chekhov's 'Three Sisters' And the Riddle It Poses
description: From the very first rehearsals of its initial production at the Moscow Art Theater, Chekhov's ''Three Sisters'' has been an enigma to directors and actors alike. The play itself is, in Chekhov's own words, ''dreary, long and awkward'' with ''four heroines and a spirit more gloomy than gloom itself.'' Most of the action seems to take place offstage, and the characters appear to do little but philosophize over the future, longing to be somewhere else while waiting for the samovar to arrive.

title: Margo Nursery Farms reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tribune-Swab-Fox reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,456,000, or 7 cents a share, and $2,520,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which included $2,498,000 gain on sale. c-Included a loss on discontinued operations of $78,000 and $174,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. For 1988, after preferred dividend payments, the company posted a loss of less than one cent a share.

title: Fund Yields Mixed Again
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with tax-exempt funds up and taxables down for the second straight week.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: IT is time to speak again of ''Days of Our Lives.'' But then I am always speaking of ''Days of Our Lives.'' ''Did you tape the show?'' my daughter asks on the days she's forgotten to set her VCR. ''What happened?'' I ask on the days when I've done the same.

title: Clamor in the East; East German Party Proposes Talks With 'Other Forces'
description: The Politburo of East Germany's Communist Party, which is still in charge but under increasing pressure from an angry populace, today proposed discussions with ''other political forces'' on the country's future.

title: Enduring Salvador Issue; Recent Surge in Violence Forces Congress And White House to Re-examine U.S. Role
description: Just as the Bush Administration thought, and hoped, El Salvador was receding as a foreign policy problem, the recent surge of violence there is forcing the White House to grapple once again with the divisive question of what role the United States should play in shaping El Salvador's future.

title: Angeles Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $600,000 loss on sale of oil and gas business and $234,000 income tax benefit.

title: 34 Killed as Transport Plane Crashes in Siberia, Tass Says
description: A plane crashed Tuesday, killing 34 people, as it attempted a landing in bad weather in the Tyumen region of western Siberia, Tass reported today.

title: S.E.C. Filing by Pinnacle
description: The Pinnacle West Financial Corporation, an Arizona-based utility and thrift holding company, said Tuesday that by January 1990 it might run short of working capital because of financial problems largely stemming from its savings subsidiary, MeraBank.

title: Toro Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
Q&A
description: Hot Water Circulation Q.Our master bathroom is about 80 feet from the hot water tank. Would a closed loop on a hot water line that goes from this tank to the bathroom keep the water in the line hot all the time because of natural circulation, or would the water fail to circulate by itself? A.If the bathroom is definitely higher in elevation than the hot water tank, and if all lines slope that way, you would get a certain amount of natural circulation that would keep the water hot throughout the loop. But in most cases some pipes will slope the wrong way and natural circulation is not enough. That is why with most such installations a small circulation pump is installed near the heater to keep the water moving. Painting a Freezer Q.My chest freezer is kept on an unheated but enclosed back porch, and after several years it is now starting to show rust spots. I would like to repaint the freezer. Can you tell me how to go about it and what type of paint I should use? A.First, using fine-grit emery cloth or aluminum oxide paper, sand the rust spots down to bare metal. Then coat these spots with a rust-resistant metal primer, and allow to dry for 24 hours. Sand the entire surface of the freezer with No. 220 paper, and dust thoroughly, then apply a first coat of enamel undercoat. When this hardens, sand lightly with the same grit paper, then finish with two coats of a top-grade high-gloss exterior enamel. Sand lightly between coats with No. 400 paper. Spraying will give you the smoothest finish if done with a reasonable amount of skill, but using a good brush will also give you a smooth finish if you work carefully to avoid drips and runs and use a good enamel that flows on evenly.

title: Moog Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss of $197,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $2,740,000, or 31 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: A Special Touch For Rod or Reel
description: ALL fishermen know the feeling. You have just hooked your first trout of the day and suddenly your reel jams up and the fish escapes. Or you are putting on your waders, so you prop up your rod against the car door. The door slams shut and slices the rod in half.

title: Newport Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Berkeley A. Cater, Executive, 89
description: Berkeley A. Cater, a retired vice president of the Jersey Plastic and Die Company in Irvington, N.J., died of prostate cancer Tuesday at his home in Fair Haven, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Three-Way Race Seen For Post at Van Dorn
description: The Van Dorn Company, a maker of containers and of machines for the plastics industry, plans to name a chief executive in the next 12 to 18 months to succeed its longtime leader, Lawrence C. Jones, and a horse race of sorts is shaping up.

title: Silk and Steel: Softening Hard Edges
description: THREE years ago, when Connie Steensma and Richard Prins discovered they were going to have a baby after 15 years of marriage, they made the usual series of phone calls. First they called their parents. Then they called their architect.

title: Phantom of Mayor's Race Is Talk of New Orleans
description: Here in the land of hot and spicy politics, the New Orleans mayor's race is sizzling with the usual rich language. But the dominant personality is only listening.

title: Reweaving a Chair Seat With Rawhide
description: LEAD: It's a bit unusual, but when removing old seat material from a chair, if you find a half-dozen narrow bands evenly spaced along the four rails, then in all probability the seat was originally covered with a network of rawhide. Abrading along the rails is not confined to tough rawhide: it can be caused by the more usual splint or rush, but the wear marks will be much closer together.

title: Chip Ruling Raises Stock
description: The prospect of future royalty payments in Japan today buoyed the shares of Texas Instruments Inc. by 15 percent, or $4.75 a share, to $36.50. on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Anheuser-Busch Files to Sell Shares
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell about 8.1 million shares for Busch family members. The offering is expected early next month.

title: Bush Affirms Commitment to NATO
description: In a Thanksgiving address to the nation from Camp David, President Bush tonight hailed the emergence of a ''new Europe'' but affirmed that the American commitment to the Atlantic alliance would remain strong and stable ''as long as our friends want and need us.''

title: Rangers Help Sabres Remain Safe at Home
description: The numbers were posted on a handful of bulletin boards at the Rangers' practice facility Tuesday. They read 8-0-1, the record the Sabres had posted as the only team in the National Hockey League not to have lost in their own building.

title: North East Insurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $68,592, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $271,892, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $128,000, or 4 cents a share, and $415,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving. Banks, government offices and most businesses will also be closed. Most stock and futures exchanges will be open tomorrow, but the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the Frozen Concentrate Orange Juice Futures and Options Exchange in New York will remain closed.

title: 2 Boys Fatally Shot in Brooklyn and Bronx
description: Two teen-agers were shot and killed in unrelated incidents last night in New York City, the police said.

title: Shuttle Astronauts Reported To Put Spy Satellite in Orbit
description: Astronauts on the space shuttle Discovery put a Defense Department spy satellite in orbit today, sources said. But there was no confirmation from the space agency or the Pentagon.

title: Power Failure Stalls 3 Rail Lines
description: Thousands of travelers in New York and New Jersey were delayed several hours yesterday afternoon when a power failure temporarily shut down service on Amtrak, New Jersey Transit and PATH trains between Manhattan and Newark.

title: Limiting Partners Isn't Foolproof, AIDS Study Says
description: Women who think they are safe from AIDS because they avoid risky sex ''may have a false sense of security'' if they do not know whether their partners are also safe, say researchers who traced 11 cases of AIDS infection to relations with the same man.

title: Argentine Bank Head Quits
description: The president of Argentina's central bank, Javier Gonzalez Fraga, resigned today, citing differences over policy with Nestor Rapanelli, the Economy Minister.

title: Soviet Computer Deal
description: Electronique Serge Dassault said today that it had signed a contract worth one billion francs, or about $160 million, with the Soviet Union's largest bank to computerize banks and businesses in the Baltic states. It agreed with Sberbank to computerize its operations in Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, and to provide staff training and install a maintenance program, the French company said. Sberbank's operations in the city of Tartu and its eight branches will be provided with automated payment systems for the city's main shops and businesses, Dassault said.

title: Pennsylvania Workers to Look for Drug Labs
description: Nearly 600 utility workers in 41 Pennsylvania counties have been organized into a network to tell the police of possible drug laboratories.

title: SCI Debt Extension
description: The investor George N. Gillett Jr. has been forced to extend the restructuring of $507 million in high-yield ''junk bonds'' for SCI Television Inc. because of a weak response from Wall Street, the company and investors said Wednesday.

title: Election Panel Seeks Builder's Bank Records
description: A state commission has voted to subpoena the personal bank records of a building contractor who claims a former Democratic state chairman gave him a $1,000 check and asked him to make a campaign contribution to Gov. William A. O'Neill.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Dakar Group, Solo

title: Letter Aids Soviet Boy Requiring Operation
description: Zoya Zdanovskaya was alone in her cramped Moscow apartment on the night of Dec. 7, 1988, and desperate about her year-old grandson, Kirill. Believing she had ''nothing to lose,'' she wrote a letter to the Voice of America and sent it to Washington.

title: Helping the Frail Elderly to Cope at Home
description: Severe arthritis makes it hard for Anna Camacho to negotiate her studio apartment, let alone the outside world of steps and heavy doors and traffic. But at the age of 77, with no living relatives, she finds herself not well enough to be independent, but not so sick as to need a nursing home.

title: British Trade Deficit Slows
description: Britain announced today that its foreign trade deficit had narrowed to $:1.54 billion ($2.4 billion) last month.

title: Economic Scene; A Master Plan For Military Cuts
description: THE Bush Administration's decision to start planning for deeper cuts in military spending has come partly in response to dramatic changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and partly as a result of domestic budgetary and economic pressures.

title: Review/Theater; 'Stand-Up Tragedy,' Challenging the Rules
description: Faced with the everyday frustrations of urban education, the playwright Bill Cain responds with ''Stand-Up Tragedy,'' as in the apt title of his corrosive new play. First produced at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, it is now running in revised form at Hartford Stage. It is an angry work, filled with bitterness about the impossibility of amelioration.

title: Richard Goode and Piano Warm Up for a Good Cause
description: ''This past decade has been partly a matter of restoring the balance,'' the pianist Richard Goode said the other day, looking back on his 1978 decision to leave the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and devote himself more fully to solo performance. ''I had done a great deal of chamber music, but I was probably the only pianist on my block who had not performed the Beethoven 'Appassionata' in public. In fact, there were large tracts of the solo repertory that I wanted to get to while there was still time.''

title: In New York, 4 Large Cities Are Growing a Little Smaller
description: Upstate New York's four big cities - Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Albany - all showed population losses from 1980 to 1988, according to estimates released by state and Federal officials.

title: E.P.A. Acts to Stimulate Recycling
description: In a far-reaching effort to stimulate recycling, the Environmental Protection Agency is proposing that incinerator operators around the country be required to reduce the amount of garbage they burn by 25 percent by recycling it instead.

title: Japan Grip Still Seen On Patents
description: Japan's decision to award a lucrative computer chip patent to Texas Instruments Inc. is probably not a sign that the Japanese patent system will be streamlined, patent and trade specialists say. American manufacturers have long contended that Japan's system is rigged against them.

title: Some tips, tricks and trade secrets for lassoing good clients.
description: Learn how to say ''lawyer'' in Serbo-Croatian or Farsi. Practice at an address like Park Avenue or Wilshire Boulevard, or, if you cannot afford that, at least have a mail drop there. If you are toiling weekends or nights for a client, find an excuse to call him because martyrdom can be good business.

title: Injury Sidelines Moyer
description: Paul Moyer, a Seattle Seahawks safety, has a ruptured disk in his neck that will sideline him for the rest of the season and could end his football career, a published report says.

title: Attendants Halt Strike At Eastern
description: The leaders of the flight attendants' union at Eastern Airlines told the members yesterday to return to work, a day after the pilots' union abandoned its nearly nine-month walkout.

title: United Opposition Confronts Ghandi
description: For the first time in more than a decade, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's ruling Congress Party faces a largely united opposition challenge in general elections, which began Wednesday and continue Friday and Sunday.

title: Ex-Officer Denies Using Police for Personal Benefit
description: The former commanding officer of the Nassau County Police Department's personnel bureau has been arraigned on charges that he used police officers for his personal benefit, including driving his daughter to college.

title: Moscow Journal; The Soviet Apocalypse? For Now, It's Just a Film
description: On Gorky Street in central Moscow, a stranger watches ravenous shoppers search vainly for something to buy with the ration coupons that have replaced their worthless money.

title: A New Look at Seton Hall; Memories of Last Season Linger but Team Is Gone
description: P. J. Carlesimo would like to discuss the present and future of Seton Hall basketball, but he cannot escape the recent past. The Pirates took a wonderful journey last spring that stopped in Seattle against Michigan in April, one basket shy of a National Collegiate Athletic Association championship. Like the beard that covers the coach's boyish face, the memories of the season, both happy and sad, cling to Carlesimo.

title: In a Snow-Draped City, Sharing and Giving Thanks
description: Thanksgiving crept up on Delisa Holman and Cheryl-Dawn Dyer, East Villagers who came to New York four years ago from La Marque, Tex. As they celebrated early, a night of fried shrimp and white wine in the cozy roadhouse atmosphere of the Gulf Coast on West 12th Street in Manhattan dissolved into the most American of holidays.

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Theater

title: Moore Back With Spurs
description: Johnny Moore, a former guard for the San Antonio Spurs, has returned to the team, declaring his bout with Desert Fever to be over and pledging to make the most of any playing time he gets.

title: New Casino Produces $4.6 Million Jackpot
description: Barely nine hours after a new casino opened its doors, a 76-year-old customer hit a $4.6 million jackpot.

title: Review/Dance;  Love in Motion, by Robbins and Balanchine
description: Set two people dancing together on stage and after only a few moments they can seem to be either loving or hating each other - or doing both simultaneously. Affections - and the lack of them - can be eloquently expressed in movement. So it is no wonder that choreographers are fond of creating ballets on themes of love.

title: Offer by Argentine Leftist Rebels: Gift of Ransom
description: When Fernando Vaca Narvaja and Roberto Perdia stepped off a hydrofoil boat from Uruguay last month, they looked like two of the well-dressed businessmen who regularly commute to Argentina.

title: Mohawk Police Cost Millions
description: The state spent more than $3 million to keep police officers at the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation for four months after a gambling raid last summer, officials said.

title: South Africa Sends a Signal by Integrating District
description: The South African Government today proclaimed the immediate integration of the business district in Boksburg, a Transvaal town where the far-right Conservatives restored whites-only signs and other trappings of so-called petty apartheid last year.

title: Eagles Shut Down Cowboys
description: Cris Carter made two acrobatic touchdown catches and Philadelphia's defense forced five turnovers today as the Eagles beat the Cowboys, 27-0, handing Dallas its worst loss in 22 Thanksgiving Day games, all at home.

title: Harris Sets a Record As Mountaineers Win
description: The fullback Rico Tyler scored the winning touchdown on a 1-yard run in the third quarter as 17th-ranked West Virginia capitalized on a turnover and beat Syracuse, 24-17, tonight in a game between bowl-bound teams.

title: Poles Burn Lenin Statue
description: A monument to Lenin in the town of Nova Huta was splashed with paint and set afire on the eve of the visit to Moscow by Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a newspaper reported today. The act was carried out by members of the anti-Communist Federation of Fighting Youth, the newspaper Zycie Warszawy quoted an official as saying.

title: Inner-City Youth Start Road to Medical School
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: Catalans have always considered themselves different from other Spaniards - more worldly and sophisticated. They take great pride in their literary, artistic and culinary heritage. Since most Spanish restaurants in New York are oriented toward Castile or Andalusia, the opening of Paradis Barcelona last summer promised an opportunity to sample seaside Catalan cuisine. Recent visits reveal it to be a promise not entirely fulfilled.

title: OPEC Expects Demand to Fall Short
description: Officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries predicted today that demand for the organization's oil would average 21.5 million barrels a day next year, well under its current level of production.

title: Assassinating Hope in Lebanon
description: The powerful bomb that killed Lebanon's President, Rene Moawad, also shattered that country's best hope of peace. The legislators who elected him not three weeks ago speak gamely of choosing a constitutional successor soon. But the long-shot odds of extricating Lebanon from 15 years of deadly civil war have now turned longer still.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Wilmington, Del., named Bruce A. Beardwood vice president of investor affairs.

title: 'Krapp's Last Tape'
description: Samuel Beckett's ''Krapp's Last Tape'' is to be presented by En Garde Arts beginning Thursday at 8 P.M. at what the group describes as ''an intimate, dirt-strewn space on the Brooklyn waterfront,'' at 1 Main Street, off Water Street between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges. The co-production with the Talking Band will be presented Thursday through Sunday evenings at 8 P.M. through Dec. 17.

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Art Galleries

title: Nine Cities Try Housing Voucher Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Carbon Monoxide Found Harmful at Low Levels
description: Levels of carbon monoxide considered safe by Federal air quality standards can create a potentially dangerous oxygen shortage in the hearts of people with coronary artery disease, a study has shown.

title: Showdown in Miami: Irish Tackle Hurricanes
description: The rivalry, not so long ago, was hardly a rivalry at all. A Notre Dame trip to Miami, especially throughout the 1970's, meant a comfortable escape for the Irish from the challenge of nationally competitive teams and the late-autumn chill of northern Indiana. A Miami trip to South Bend was an opportunity for an ambitious but frustrated program to mingle with the elite.

title: Clamor in the East; U.S. Feast for East Germans
description: East Germans starting new lives on the western side of the Berlin wall joined American soldiers for a mess hall Thanksgiving today, feasting on turkey, cranberry sauce and stuffing. Dozens of recent East German immigrants were bused from the city's Marienfelde reception camp to several United States Army dining halls here.

title: Canada Invites Bids for Oil Rights in Arctic
description: For the first time in nearly two decades, the Canadian Government is inviting petroleum companies that had not previously explored for oil in the Arctic Ocean to do so.

title: Greece Installs Government of 3 Major Parties
description: An all-party Government of politicians and technocrats was sworn in here today, putting a formal if temporary end to the political crisis plaguing Greece since its two inconclusive general elections.

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Museums

title: No Blame to Rushdie
description: To the Editor:

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Film

title: The Day Plunkett Took It Easy
description: rrLong before there was Refrigerator Perry, there was Sherman Plunkett, a lineman with a giant paunch but dancing feet.

title: Diplomats at Japan's Embassy Worry About Anti-Tokyo Sentiment in U.S.
description: The Japanese Embassy here is modest, quiet and plain. The unadorned three-story building on a tree-lined street does not look like the outpost of an economic superpower.

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Film

title: Sharp Cut in Serious Birth Defect Is Tied to Vitamins in Pregnancy
description: Women who take over-the-counter multivitamin pills early in pregnancy sharply reduce the risk of having a baby with a type of serious neurological defect, a new study has found.

title: TV Network Provides Help for Enforcing the Law
description: The television program is about a police officer being held hostage by a man with a rifle. The tension builds as the criminal demands the officer's gun. Time seems frozen as the two men glare at each other over their weapons. What is the officer to do?

title: Settlement By Japanese Builders
description: Signaling a major victory against one of Japan's most powerful and closed industries, the United States said today that 99 Japanese construction companies had agreed to pay it $32.6 million to settle accusations that they had rigged bids on a variety of projects at a United States Navy base here.

title: 3 Drown in Plane Crash in Gulf
description: A mother and two young children were presumed drowned in the Gulf of Mexico today after their small plane crashed in heavy seas, the Coast Guard reported. Her husband, who survived, said a wave swept his infant son from his arms as he swam to an oil rig.

title: Zimbabwe Resisting Facts in AIDS Epidemic
description: Ronnie Mutimusekwa, a 34-year-old street vendor who is infected with the AIDS virus, is trying to help educate the public about the disease in Zimbabwe, where people are said to doubt its rapid spread.

title: INSIDE
description: Politician Wounded in India An opposition politician was near death after he was shot in a violent first day of voting in the three-day election in India. Page A15. Lebanese Leaders Meet The members of the Lebanese Parliament, meeting in northern Lebanon, are expected to choose a new President today. Page A3. Eastern Strike Falters Union leaders told the airline's flight attendants to join with the pilots in returning to work. Page D1. Art Dealer Dies Sidney Janis, whose New York gallery helped popularize Abstract Expressionism, is dead at 93. Page D8.

title: Flint Journal; G.M.'s Company Town Goes on Downhill Drive
description: This is a city with a dependency problem, one that is destroying livelihoods, forcing people from their homes and contributing to pervasive crime.

title: Worries About Reaction in U.S., Japanese Assess Investment Policy
description: Fearful of an American reaction to the recent surge of Japanese acquisitions, business and Government leaders here are reassessing their strategy for investing overseas.

title: East German Change Owes No Thanks to Us; Europe Is Hopeful
description: To the Editor:

title: Clamor in the East; Smuggling Curbs By East Germany
description: The East German Government announced a series of measures today that are intended to combat widespread smuggling and speculation with this country's severely battered currency.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Is Arrested In Teacher's Slaying
description: A Manhattan man was arrested and charged with the stabbing of a high school science teacher killed last month on Long Island, Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: TV Weekend; A Victoria Principal Vehicle As Blind Witness to Murder
description: Starring Victoria Principal, ''Blind Witness,'' the television movie on ABC this Sunday at 9 P.M., was produced by King-Phoenix Entertainment in association with Victoria Principal Productions. In other words, it is a star vehicle, the kind of showcase contraption that once used to be constructed for a Katherine Cornell or a Helen Hayes. This being the Age of Television, our star is Ms. Principal, the attractive veteran of several seasons on the prime-time soap ''Dallas.'' Obviously, times have changed.

title: Deals
description: Basketball

title: Australia Trade Deficit
description: The Australian Government reported today that the current account deficit had jumped 33 percent in October, to $2.24 billion (about $1.68 billion in United States dollars). But economists said the underlying figures in the trade data suggested a healthier trend. When the data were adjusted to exclude seasonal factors like a flood of imports before Christmas, the shortfall was $1.66 billion (Australian), down 14 percent from September's seasonally adjusted $1.93 billion, they said. The improvement in the seasonally adjusted figures provides the Government with some evidence that its policy of high interest rates may be succeeding.Business interest rates are above 20 percent and home loan rates are about 17 percent.

title: A Capital Idea for Eastern Europe
description: Westerners are exhilarated by the drama of Eastern Europe but puzzled about how to help. The West cannot alter the fact that it's Eastern Europe's job to break the chains of centralized control and to wean consumers from subsidized prices and producers from guaranteed sales. But the West can ease this painful process and modestly improve the chances for success.

title: Clamor in the East; PRAGUE RIVALS VIE FOR FAVOR ON EVE OF PARTY MEETING
description: On the eve of a pivotal Central Committee meeting that is expected to make major changes in Czechoslovakia's Communist Party leadership, factions inside and outside the party appeared today to be openly jockeying for support from the nation's security forces.

title: 2 Killed in Helicopter Crash
description: A Marine helicopter operating from an aircraft carrier crashed and sank Wednesday in the Mediterranean Sea, killing both crew members. The search for the AH-IT Cobra helicopter and its pilot and co-pilot was called off this morning, said Capt. Elizabeth Kerstens, a Marine Corps spokeswoman. The helicopter was operating from the carrier Iwo Jima off the coast of Spain when the crash occurred.

title: Fourth Woman's Body Found in River Gorge
description: The body of a woman was found today in the Genesee River Gorge, where the bodies of three other women who were slain have been found in the last month, the police said.

title: Cardinals Call on Tupa
description: Hank Kuhlmann, who replaced Gene Stallings as coach of the Phoenix Cardinals on Monday, wasted little time making a major change. He said yesterday that Tom Tupa, a second-year quarterback who has started one game and played in several others, would start in place of Gary Hogeboom for the Cardinals (5-6) in their game Sunday against Tampa Bay.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is our view that things here have gone so far that we need profound changes, including those of personnel.'' - Jan Skoda, head of Czechoslovakia's Socialist Party. [ A16:3. ]

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Jazz

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Pay $5.98 Million to Rabies Survivor
description: Twelve years ago Jerome Andrulonis, a bacteriologist, contracted rabies while conducting a federally supervised experiment in a state laboratory on inoculating wild animals against the disease.

title: Ethiopia-Eritrea Peace Talks
description: Ethiopian and Eritrean peace negotiators settled two more procedural issues today. A spokeswoman for former President Jimmy Carter, who is mediating the talks, said the two sides agreed on a chairman and co-chairman and a secretariate for further talks aimed at ending their civil war. Mr. Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, treated both seven-member negotiating teams to a traditional American Thanksgiving dinner at a Nairobi hotel after three and a half hours of talks today.

title: Review/Music; Durufle's Wife Is Organist in His Works
description: Donald Keene, the organist and choirmaster of the Church of the Ascension, put together a three-concert tribute to the French composer and organist Maurice Durufle in which virtually all of the composer's works were performed. The first two concerts took place at Mr. Keene's church and at the Manhattan School of Music last week.

title: 'Nutcracker' Gives a Dancer A Glimpse of Who She Was
description: Little girls in scrupulously neat ballerina chignons pass through the backstage lobby at City Center on their way to rehearsal for the Joffrey Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker.'' Their well-scrubbed faces glow with a subdued excitement that belies the attempt at casualness in their voices.

title: Wounded India Candidate Is Reported Near Death
description: An opposition leader was near death tonight after armed gangs roamed through the constituency of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, terrorizing voters during the first day of national elections on Wednesday.

title: Hughes Gets Canadian Job
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company has received a $700 million Canadian Government contract to automate the country's air-traffic control system. The job is worth $595 million in United States currency.

title: Review/Concert; Scandinavian Musicians Performing Scandinavian Music
description: More and more in New York these days, one finds performing ensembles, ranging in size from chamber forces to full-scale orchestras, devoted to the repertory of a special-interest group, be it religious or cultural or national or regional.

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Classical Music

title: High Court Modified Malice Requirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing for Williams
description: Carl (the Truth) Williams will defend his United States Boxing Association heavyweight title against Tyrell Biggs, an Olympic gold medalist, on Jan. 11 at Atlantic City. Ira Leibowitz, Williams's manager, said the fighter would appear at a hearing at the World Boxing Association Convention in Philadelphia today to ask that his loss July 21 to Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, be ruled no contest. Williams maintains that a head butt led to a premature decision by the referee to stop the fight after only 93 seconds.

title: Review/Art; 'The Winds of Revolution': French, That Is
description: Is there room for yet another exhibition about the French Revolution? Is the subject not worn out, squeezed out, talked out and argued out? Where are the paintings, the drawings, the prints and the documents that could justify so belated an adventure?

title: MIAMI POLICE TRIAL SHIFTS TO DEFENSE
description: After the appearance of 28 witnesses over six days, the trial of a Miami police officer accused of manslaughter in the killing of two blacks has concluded one stage, the prosecution, and moves into another, the defense, on Friday.

title:
About Real Estate;
