Keeping Down Costs at an Upstate Development
description: LEAD: Building on steep terrain is seldom a problem when cost is not a concern. But in the Ulster County hamlet of Ellenville, the challenge was to use a craggy hillside for affordable housing for local residents.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Sidney Janis, Trend-Setting Art Dealer, Dies at 93
description: Sidney Janis, the doyen of New York art dealers, whose gallery on West 57th Street mounted significant shows of European masters and helped put Abstract Expressionism on the international map, died yesterday after a bout with pneumonia. He was 93 years old and was active in the Sidney Janis Gallery until his 90th birthday.

title: Rachel Wischnitzer, Professor, 104
description: Rachel Wischnitzer, an authority on synagogue architecture and a professor emeritus at Yeshiva University, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 104 years old.

title: Versatile Meggett Sparks Giants
description: The Giants' leader in total offense this year is not a runner or a receiver or a punt returner or a kickoff returner. He is a player who is a combination of all those.

title: Jetliner Hits a Truck on La Guardia Tarmac
description: An American Airlines flight bound for Toronto from New York City was canceled yesterday morning after the airplane struck a catering truck on the tarmac at La Guardia Airport, officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Songs by Black Americans
description: Peter Galenn, a tenor, devoted his Sunday evening program at Weill Recital Hall to works by black American composers. It was an interesting idea, and most of the composers whose music he chose wrote in an idiom so conservative and tuneful that his sequence of song settings and cantata and opera excerpts made for pleasant if not especially surprising or challenging listening.

title: Vancouver Development
description: Vancouver officials have approved a $1.7 billion (United States) development proposed by the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing.

title: Books of The Times; Father Hunted, Mother Retreated Into Self-Pity
description: The Snows of Yesteryear Portraits for an Autobiography By Gregor von Rezzori Translated by H. F. Broch de Rothermann. 290 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Undecided - and Proud of It
description: LEAD: Go to Wall Street,'' my classmates said.''Go to Wall

title: One Killed and One Injured After an Argument in Utica
description: One man was killed and another injured today in a shootout, the police said. Two men were arrested.

title: A Face Lift for Mount Rushmore?
description: Engineers using a helicopter will photograph cracks and other rocky wrinkles in the aging 60-foot-tall Presidential faces on Mount Rushmore next week to determine whether the national memorial needs a face lift.

title: Dollar Up In Europe
description: The dollar was up against all major foreign currencies except the Canadian dollar in quiet European trading today, dealers said. Gold prices finished higher.

title: Queens Boy, 13, Is Killed in a 'Game' With Guns
description: A 13-year-old Queens boy was shot in the head and killed at his home Wednesday night, and yesterday morning the police charged a longtime friend with his murder while the two were ''horsing around.''

title: China's Frontier: The Search for Development
description: This is the ''other China,'' a land of poor peasants and occasional smokestacks, where for some households upward mobility means nothing more grand than moving out of their cave and into a house.

title: NEW DRUG FOUND TO FIGHT CANCER
description: A drug derived from a Chinese tree has proved to be a potent agent against colon cancer in experiments on animals, scientists are reporting in a journal today.

title: East German Change Owes No Thanks to Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: California Reincarnated If you wonder what happened to California cuisine - at least in New York City - you can experience its latest incarnation at Michael's New York, 24 West 55th Street, in the old Italian Pavilion. Michael McCarty, the owner, made a name for himself with Michael's in Santa Monica, Calif., and in recent years has hopscotched across the country opening restaurants called Adirondacks in Denver and Washington.

title: Computer Graphics Aiding Jurors' Recall
description: Jurors hearing a lawsuit over the supposed merits of a new dog food were recently taken, via three-dimensional computer animation, on a journey inside a Labrador retriever's leg to see how its muscles, bones and joints function.

title: Article 467989 -- No Title
description: When Ronald Reagan moved into the White House, the national debt was nearing $1 trillion. Professing horror, he told Congress that a trillion dollars in $1,000 bills would make a stack 67 miles high. Less than a decade later, his imaginary stack has just cleared 200 miles.

title: Clamor in the East: Reporter's Notebook; Legacies by the Wall: Rabbits and Graffiti Bits
description: The crumbling of the Berlin wall was also the end of innocence for untold numbers of rabbits.

title: Venezuela's Offer for Citgo Gives Bankers Indigestion
description: When Venezuela's state-owned oil company announced this month that it would spend $675 million to purchase the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it does not already own, the announcement got the attention of more than the oil industry.

title: Market Place; Sotheby's Stock Loses Some Gloss
description: FOR much of 1989, it seemed as though the only thing rising more rapidly than art prices was the price of auction house stocks. But in the last two weeks, a downdraft hit the price of Sotheby's shares.

title: B.A.T. Buys More Shares
description: B.A.T. Industries, the British conglomerate fighting a hostile $21 billion bid from Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments Ltd., said today that it had acquired more shares under a plan to buy back up to 10 percent of its stock.

title: 7 Protesters Join Parade
description: Seven people received summonses for disorderly conduct yesterday after they briefly joined the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade with a black balloon shaped like a bomb that read, ''Stop U.S. Bombing of El Salvador'' on one side and ''No Vietnam War in El Salvador'' on the other.

title: Dining Out Guide: In Chelsea
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Chelsea Central ** (Nov. 10, 1989), 227 10th Avenue, at 24th Street (620-0230) - This inviting saloon-style restaurant serves consoling American food. A well-aged steak, cooked precisely to order, comes with fried shallots and potato pancakes. On the seafood side is grilled salmon set over braised leeks with a subtle red-wine sauce. A fine starter is moist crab cakes with remoulade sauce. A fitting finale is a flourless chocolate marquise, rich, semisweet and irresistible. Appetizers are $7 to $9, main courses $14 to $21. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 11 P.M. Sunday to Thursday, until midnight Friday and Saturday; Sunday brunch: 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Chelsea Trattoria Italiana ** (Aug. 7, 1987), 108 Eighth Avenue, at 16th Street (924-7786) - This trattoria, with its brick and whitewashed dining room, is friendly and easygoing. Half portions of pastas - a fine way to kick off a meal - include fettuccine tossed with wild mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes. A pan-sauteed fillet of beef is superb, tender and juicy. A simple chicken breast sauteed with white wine, mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes is memorable. For dessert, try the strawberry Napoleon. Appetizers are $7 to $8, main courses $13 to $20. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5 P.M. to 11:30 Monday to Friday, until midnight Saturday. Eze ** (Oct. 7, 1988), 254 West 23d Street (691-1140) - In this rather formal dining room of a town house, the chef serves beguiling Provencal-Mediterranean cuisine. The frequently changing menu now includes, for appetizers, grilled quail with cranberries and wild rice, and polenta with sausage and sage. A reliable entree is the rack of lamb with a garlic-onion jam. The most impressive seafood entree is the whole braised red snapper for two, moistened with a lemony fish stock and ringed with good couscous and a red pepper puree. An outrageously good dessert is the chocolate cake crowned with caramel ice cream. Dinner prix fixe at $49. Dinner: 6 to 10:15 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday. Periyali ** (May 27, 1988), 35 West 20th Street (463-7890) - This trim and clean whitewashed spot offers down-to-earth Greek food. A standout appetizer is the red-wine-marinated octopus grilled over charcoal. Lamb, naturally, is a highlight among entrees, such as an oregano-dusted leg. Seafood entrees change daily: if you are fortunate, there will be grilled porgies swathed with olive oil. Baklava is a relatively light dessert, made with toasted almonds. Appetizers are $5 to $8, entrees $15 to $20. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 11 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Quatorze ** (Feb. 26, 1988), 240 West 14th Street (206-7006) - Quatorze is the sort of place you go to for sustenance, not surprises. . Among the enticing starters are an Armagnac-scented pork-and-chicken terrinewith bacon and pistachios, and marinated herring with onions. A homey entree is the grilled half-chicken with french fries. Grilled fillet of salmon comes with a fine sauce choron (a bearnaise sauce blended with pureed tomatoes). The dessert of choice is the thin, buttery apple tart. Appetizers are $5.50 to $8.50, main courses $16 to $22.50. Lunch: noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 6 to 11:30 P.M. Monday to Saturday, 5:30 to 11 P.M. Sunday. What the stars mean, C20.

title: 2-9 No Laughing Matter
description: Because of their 2-9 record, the Jets have eschewed their traditional Thanksgiving turkey scam, at least officially.

title: Salvador Chief, Claiming Victory, Rejects Rebels' Cease-Fire Offer
description: President Alfredo Cristiani rejected a rebel cease-fire offer today as little more than a trick and asserted that the military had dealt the insurgents a decisive defeat.

title: Lebanese Lawmakers Meet to Plan Election of Slain President's Successor
description: Members of Parliament gathered in a town on the main road to Syria today to prepare for the election of a successor to President Rene Moawad, who was assassinated Wednesday when a bomb blew up his car in Beirut.

title: Unlikely Guests Top N.I.T. List
description: From the looks of the guest list last week as the first round began, St. John's and Kansas would have seemed an improbable pair to meet in the final of the Dodge National Invitation Tournament, which is scheduled tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Florida Escape Spurs Study of Work Release
description: A crime spree by an inmate who walked away from a Florida center where he was living while completing a prison term has led officials to question parts of the state's work-release program.

title: Pop/Jazz; A Banner Weekend for Those Who Love Funk
description: There's a feast of funk available this weekend for anyone with enough stamina and resources. Three longtime exponents of this gritty, syncopated dance music are performing tonight and tomorrow night in Manhattan: a husky-voiced singer who has influenced a generation of soul shouters; a visionary bandleader whose specialty is a solid funk foundation with a psychedelic overlay, and a recently reunited instrumental band that exemplifies the distinctive New Orleans brand of rhythm-and-blues at its finest.

title: FOR NOW, CHANGE MISSES YUGOSLAVIA
description: Outside the Moskva Hotel in Belgrade's pre-winter chill, a group of high school students gathered signatures the other day on a petition calling for a free vote to choose the city's next mayor, a post traditionally filled by political fiat.

title: CHINESE VISA BILL MAY FACE A VETO
description: Congress has passed a bill allowing Chinese students to stay in the United States after their visas expire. But Administration officials said today that President Bush might veto it at Beijing's request.

title: Kronos Quartet
description: The Kronos Quartet - David Harrington and John Sherba, violinists; Hank Dutt, violist and Joan Jeanrenaud, cellist - is to give the world premiere of Astor Piazzolla's ''Five Tango Sensations for Quartet and Bandoneon,'' with the composer playing the bandoneon, at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow evening at 8. The program also includes the world premiere of Yuji Takahashi's ''Poem of the End'' and the New York premieres of Justinian Tamusuza's ''Mu Kbubo Ery'Omusaalaba,'' Carlos Farinas's ''Tatomaite'' and Hamza el Din's ''Water Wheel,'' as well as Kevin Volans's ''White Man Sleeps, Dance 4'' and the group's own arrangement of a motet by Thomas Tallis. Tickets are $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Congress Ends '89 With Long List of Work Undone
description: When the House and the Senate adjourned shortly after 4 A.M. Wednesday, they left behind a formidable agenda of unfinished business to take up after they reconvene Jan. 23, on issues from child care to the Clean Air Act to the more fundamental deficit reduction that many lawmakers hoped for this year.

title: Clamor in the East; Dubcek Says He Backs Protesters
description: Alexander Dubcek threw his support behind anti-Government protesters in his hometown here this afternoon in a short address to about 70,000 demonstrators.

title: Washington Talk; Changing World Implies Changes for the G.O.P.
description: It is beginning to dawn on many Republicans that the changing world order and a shifting public sentiment could spell major political problems for their party.

title: Connecticut Steps Up Effort To Tax Mail-Order Business
description: The State of Connecticut, stepping up its tax battle against mail-order companies, has issued a subpoena against Neiman-Marcus to determine the extent of the company's catalogue business in Connecticut.

title: Metro Datelines; Phone Cable Is Cut; Service Is Disrupted
description: Vandals toppled a pole supporting an overhead phone cable and severed the cable yesterday morning, knocking out long-distance service for thousands of Westchester County customers, a New York Telephone spokesman said.

title: Review/Art; Three French Artists Brought to Light
description: Despite nearly two decades of active cultural exchange, Americans are still insufficiently informed about European art, and the P.S. 1 Museum in Queens is doing something about the situation. Its current exhibition -which is really three one-person shows - focuses on three French artists who are all but unknown here: Catherine Beaugrand, Andre Cadere and Raymond Hains. The artists under scrutiny come from different generations and work in different styles, but all of their work has something of the outsider, of the adversarial stance about it. A bit like three different versions of Don Quixote, they tilt at various art-world windmills, which gives their efforts a common thread.

title: Clamor in the East; In Rumania, Fear Still Outweighs Hope
description: In the soaring speeches at the Rumanian Communist Party Congress this week and in the hyperbolic celebration of President Nicolae Ceausescu's first 24 years in power by the local press, there has been no hint of recognition that the totalitarian regimes of Eastern Europe are crumbling.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Executive at Saatchi Resigns Several Posts
description: Saatchi & Saatchi said Wednesday that Andrew Woods had resigned as deputy chairman, deputy chairman of its consulting division and a member of its board. The resignation came only one month after the British advertising company appointed Robert Louis-Dreyfus as its new chief executive.

title: When Price Is Out, Cavs Are Not Right
description: His size, barely 6 feet and close to 170 pounds, raises doubt about whether he belongs in the National Basketball Association earning more than $1 million a year. His heavy-lidded eyes make it appear as if he just woke up and is not too keen about what is going on. But his peripheral vison and almost inexplicable sense of the game make Mark Price an All-Star playmaker, and the Cleveland Cavaliers would not be the same without him.

title: Sports News Briefs; Matts Scooter Draws No. 3 Post
description: Matts Scooter, with Mike Lachance driving, drew post position No. 3 today as the 4-5 favorite for the William Haughton Memorial Pace at Yonkers Raceway on Saturday night.

title: European Plan On Railways
description: In an effort to upgrade rail services after Europe's economic integration in 1992, the European Community Executive Commission proposed on Wednesday that the European railway sector be opened to private enterprise.

title: At the Movies
description: 'True Love': The Movie

title: Military's Plan to Use More Land Is Criticized
description: The military wants more land for training and war games in four Western states, land that is more than twice the size of Massachusetts. But hunters, ranchers and environmentalists see the plans as a land grab and a menace to wildlife and farming.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, the text of President Bush's speech on Wednesday night was incomplete in some copies on Thursday. Readers wishing corrected copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: New Wave Skater; U.S. Junior Ready for Center Ice As Previous Generation Fades
description: With the passing of the 1988 Winter Olympics, another generation of figure skaters has faded from world consciousness, except for the lucky few, like Katarina Witt and Brian Boitano, who have won large contracts to dress up in sparkly, glitzy outfits to skate professionally.

title: Our Towns; A Recent Pilgrim and His Dreams Of a New Colony
description: Khamsao Keovilay spent a boyhood splashing in rice paddies along the Mekong River near Vientiane, the capital of Laos. The memory, still strong, still fond, is one of the reasons he chose a semi-swampy, 52-acre stretch of woods in this rural town 20 miles east of Hartford as the planned site for New Vientiane, a village of 25 homes, 250 Laotian refugees, a Laotian-American cultural center and a Buddhist temple.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Bruins 6, Maple Leafs 0: Andy Moog stopped 32 shots in Boston last night for his second shutout. Boston pulled away early with three goals in the first period. Toronto's John Kordic and Boston's Michael Thelven started fighting at 12 minutes 36 seconds of the third period. Before the fight was over, Referee Terry Gregson called 124 minutes in penalties and 10 players were ejected from the game. (AP) Blues 5, Jets 2: Sergio Momesso scored twice in 52 seconds as St. Louis got five goals in an 8:16 span of the first period in a game at Winnipeg. Winnipeg dominated the second period, outshooting St. Louis, 13-4.(AP) SKIING Norwegian Wins Giant Slalom: Ole Christian Furuseth of Norway won the World Cup men's giant slalom yesterday after two virtually flawless runs at the Park City Ski Area in Utah. Furuseth did his first run on the 48-gate course in 1 minute 7.3 seconds, and improved to 1:07.26 on his second.(AP) HORSE RACING A New York Shipper in Front: Grecian Flight, a New York-bred ridden by Craig Perret, won the $100,000 Straight Deal Handicap at Laurel Race Course in Maryland yesterday. The 3-5 favorite ran the seven furlongs in 1:24. She earned $60,000 to raise her career earnings to $1,179,353. She paid $3.20 for $2 to win.(AP) YACHTING Four Contending: Four yachts were fighting for line honors late yesterday as the competitors in the Whitbread Round-the-World ocean race neared the end of the second leg. Switzerland's Merit and Britain's Rothmans were 374 nautical miles from the finish in the West Australian port of Fremantle, leading Fisher Paykel of New Zealand and a second New Zealand yacht, Steinlager II, by fewer than 10 nautical miles.(AP) TENNIS Graf Wins Efficiently: Steffi Graf, who had a 5-0 lead 15 minutes into the match, beat Mary Joe Fernandez yesterday, 6-3, 7-5, in the second round of the Nokia Masters in Essen, West Germany.(AP) Berger Advances: Second-seeded Jay Berger beat Mark Koevermans of the Netherlands yesterday, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, in the quarterfinals of the Itaparica tournament in Brazil.(AP) SOCCER Milan and Barcelona Tie: A. C. Milan weathered a second-half onslaught by F. C. Barcelona for a 1-1 tie yesterday in Barcelona, Spain, in the teams' first-leg match in European soccer Super Competition.(AP) GOLF 6 Birdies Aid Leader: Naomichi Ozaki shot a 66 yesterday and led Larry Mize by one stroke after the first round of the World Open tournament in Kaimoncho, Japan. Ozaki shot two birdies on his first nine holes and four on his last nine.(AP)

title: Court Upholds '88 Increase in Thruway Tolls
description: A citizens group lost another round today in its fight to have last year's toll increase on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway ruled illegal.

title: Review/Cabaret; Debbie Shapiro Reminisces
description: In a program conceived and directed by Joe Layton, Debbie Shapiro is doing an exercise in self-effacement at Rainbow and Stars, on the 65th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Her program includes songs introduced by Ruth Etting in the 1920's and a song that Doris Day sang in the film biography of Miss Etting in 1955. On Johnny Mercer's ''Dream,'' she uses the multi-taped vocal backup that helped make Patti Page a star in the 50's. And even when she draws on the material that won her a Tony Award for her performance in ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' last spring, Miss Shapiro uses a short version of the ''bump it with a trumpet'' gimmick that Mr. Robbins devised for ''Gypsy'' in 1959.

title: Clamor in the East; Optimistic of Western Help, Walesa Goes Back to Poland
description: The Solidarity leader Lech Walesa returned to Poland today from his first trip to North America and said he was convinced that he had succeeded in persuading business leaders to invest in his country.

title: Ryan Plans to Pass Up Farm Post, Report Says
description: After leading the major leagues in strikeouts at the age of 42 last season, Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers apparently has no desire to be farmed out. The Houston Post reported yesterday that Ryan would tell the Texas Farm Bureau on Monday that he does not intend to run for agriculture commissioner.

title: EX-H.U.D. OFFICIAL MAY NOT TESTIFY
description: Another former senior official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has indicated he may refuse to answer questions from a House panel investigating fraud and mismanagement at the department, Congressional officials say.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Lois/GGK Contends Its Slogan Was Stolen
description: Never one to shrink from taking credit for famous advertising campaigns, George Lois has now accused an automobile dealer association of passing one of his slogans to a rival agency and giving him neither credit nor compensation.

title: Korean and 10 Others Killed in Sri Lanka
description: Suspected Sinhalese radicals killed a South Korean engineer who tried to stop them from buring his company's vehicles, and 10 other people were killed in ethnic violence, officials said today.

title: Exhibitions on Manhattan as a Port
description: There was a time when no exhibition would have been needed to remind New Yorkers that Manhattan was one of the world's leading seaports. Now, two exhibitions have berthed in downtown galleries, each of them memorializing a different maritime heyday of the port of Manhattan, where today only some cruise ships anchor, and freighters no longer work cargo.

title: Lions Shock Browns on Sanders's 145 Yards
description: Barry Sanders has brought a little gladness to an otherwise dismal season for the Detroit Lions.

title: A White Thanksgiving Sets a Record
description: A Thanksgiving snowstorm, the first in New York City in 51 years, cloaked the metropolitan region in wintry white yesterday, preventing high school football games from being played, horses from running at Aqueduct and Snoopy and Bugs Bunny from making it to the big parade in Manhattan.

title: Lesson From San Salvador: Rebels Come and Go at Will
description: Even as they celebrated the peaceful ending of the hostage crisis at the Hotel Salvador, military experts said the incident reinforced the most striking lesson of the recent rebel offensive here: That large numbers of leftist insurgents can enter and leave the capital at will, even under intense Government scrutiny and bombardment.

title: Sweden Will Not Try Exporter in Arms Sale
description: A Swedish prosecutor said today he would not press charges against five executives of the Government weapons company FFV Ordnance, which was suspected of illegally selling anti-tank guns to Saudi Arabia via Britain.

title: NO RISE IS FOUND IN VOLUNTARISM
description: Despite President Bush's emphasis on the ''thousand points of light'' and the community service they symbolize, the level of charitable giving and volunteering has not increased measureably, a new Gallup Poll shows.

title: Review/Art; A 2d Round of Jakuchu, the 18th-Century Japanese Painter
description: ''The Paintings of Jakuchu,'' Part II, at the Asia Society, may have an even better chance than Part I of changing Americans' perception of Japanese art. This show, like Part I, is a survey of the career of Ito Jakuchu (1716-1800), the son of a greengrocer from Kyoto who became a Buddhist monk and saw painting as a way of being both fully religious and free. Much of his polychromatic and some of his more uneven monochromatic work has an epiphanic freshness that is impossible without virtuosity and inspiration.

title: It Was a Prosperous Summer on the Jersey Shore
description: Business along the New Jersey shore rebounded sharply last summer after a slump in the previous two years caused by reports of medical waste on bathing beaches and garbage slicks floating offshore, a new study reports.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. Banks, government offices and most businesses were also closed. Most stock and futures exchanges will be open today. The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the Frozen Concentrate Orange Juice Futures and Options Exchange in New York will be closed.

title: On Stage
description: Season Scorecard

title: Carol Janeway, 76, Ceramist and Author
description: Carol Janeway, a ceramist and longtime member of Community Board 2 in Greenwich Village, died of pneumonia Wednesday at New York Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17 Factions in Prague vied for support from the nation's security forces on the eve of a Central Committee meeting expected to make changes in the Communist leadership. Policemen supporting hard-liners secured a television station. Page A1 Czechoslovak students ask workers at farms and factories to support their reformist aims. Since 1968, the opposition movements, led by the intelligentsia, have had pratically no input from workers. A1 Dubcek says he backs protesters A16 The East German Government has announced plans to curb widespread smuggling and currency speculation. A17 Reporter's notebook: Legacies of the wall A17 The Rumanian Communist Party has given no hint of recognition that the totalitarian regimes of Eastern Europe are crumbling, but whispers in Bucharest suggest people know of the changes. A17 Region's upheaval misses Yugoslavia A17 Japan's foreign investment policies are being reassessed by business and Government leaders who are fearful of an American reaction to the recent surge of Japanese acquistions. A1 Diplomats at embassy worry about anti-Tokyo sentiment A12 Chinese students in the U.S. would be able to stay here after their visas expire, under a bill passed by Congress. But President Bush might veto it at Beijing's request, officials say. A9 China's frontier: the search for development A8 A cease-fire offer in El Salvador was rejected by President Cristiani as merely a trick by rebels. He said the military had dealt the rebels a decisive defeat. A1 Lesson from San Salvador: Rebels come and go at will A10 Offer by Argentine leftist rebels: Gift of ransom A10 Members of Lebanon's Parliament met to prepare for the election of a successor to President Moawad, who was assassinated Wednesday. No candidates were named, but a vote may be held as early as Sunday. A3 An Indian opposition leader was in critical condition following attacks by armed gangs during voting in India's national elections. The death toll was reportedly near 40. A14 United opposition confronts Gandhi A15 An all-party government in Greece was sworn in, putting a formal if temporary end to the political crisis gripping the country since two inconclusive elections. A11 A business district in South Africa will be integrated, the Government said. The district is in a town where right-wing Conservatives had reimposed whites-only signs and other trappings of petty apartheid. A5 Zimbabwe resisting facts in AIDS epidemic A7 AIDS study warns of false security of ''safe'' sex A6 National A20-36, B22-23 Vitamins may reduce birth defects, a new study has found. Over-the-counter multivitamin pills containing folic acid were found to cut the risk of certain neurological defects, if taken in an early stage of pregnancy. A1 New drug found to fight cancer A29 News analysis: Abortion issues will be argued before the Supreme Court next week in two cases whose immediate issue is parental notification laws but whose broader impact could affect Roe v. Wade. A1 ''An unfinished Congress'' adjourned Wednesday, leaving a long agenda of issues from deficit reduction to child care. A1 Another former H.U.D. official may refuse to answer questions from a House panel investigating the department, officials said. A21 Changing world means changes for the G.O.P. A24 No rise is found in voluntarism A27 Donations to food banks reported in decline A26 Striking Eastern flight attendants were told by their union leaders to return to work, a day after the pilots' union abandoned its nearly nine-month-old walkout. D1 Incinerators would start recycling under an E.P.A. plan to cut emissions of toxic substances and reduce waste destined for landfills. The plan calls for 25 percent of an incinerator's garbage to be recycled. A20 Miami police trial shifts to defense A25 Florida escape spurs study of work release program A36 A face lift for Mount Rushmore? A20 Shuttle astronauts are reported to put a spy satellite into orbit B23 Regional B1-20 The first Thanksgiving snowstorm in New York City since 1938 dropped a record 4.7 inches of snow. The storm, which began Wednesday night, swept across most of the Northeast. B3 In a snow-draped city, sharing and giving thanks B1 Power failure stalls three rail lines B3 An array of elderly support services is being developed across the country to help old people not well enough to be independent, but not so sick as to need a nursing home. Several Westchester towns have extensive programs. B1 A grandmother's letter saves a sick little boy B1 A scientist who contracted rabies as he conducted a federally supervised test in a state lab was awarded $5.98 million by a Federal judge. The judge also ruled that the Government could recover $3.7 million of the award from New York State. B1 Jersey Shore had a prosperous summer, study reports B2 A 13-year-old boy is killed in a ''game'' with guns B5 Ex-commander accused of using police for own benefit B11 Budget office in Connecticut projects $51.5 million deficit B4 Connecticut steps up effort to tax mail-order business B20 Gunpowder blast leads to $240,000 OSHA fine B13 Toll increase on Gov. Thomas E. Deway Thruway is upheld B10 Parks agency is criticized for use of funds B9 Musicians sue transit agencies, charging curb on rights B16 Upstate New York's four largest cities are smaller B12

title: Auctions
description: Tribal Art

title: Tops of the Town: Experts Tell All
description: Eight New York Times Critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment this weekend. It is a good idea to telephone ahead to confirm the schedule. Dance

title: Cambodia Rebels Offer Gold
description: A Cambodian guerrilla leader is offering $1,000 to $40,000 in gold to Cambodian soldiers who defect with Soviet fighter jets or other military hardware or deliver a Vietnamese soldier wearing a Cambodian Army uniform. The rebel leader, Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who commands one of three guerrilla groups fighting the Vietnamese-installed Government, announced the reward offers in a broadcast over the resistance radio Wednesday. The guerrillas assert that tens of thousands of Vietnamese remain in Cambodia, some of them disguised in uniforms of the Cambodian Army.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Eartha Kitt

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Tim Wengerd Service
description: A service for Tim Wengerd, a choreographer who was formerly a leading dancer in the Martha Graham Dance Company, will be held at 7 P.M. next Friday in the Actor's Chapel at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 239 West 49th Street. Mr. Wengerd died on Sept. 12 in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: No Parole in Manson Case
description: For the eighth time, Patricia Krenwinkel, a member of Charles Manson's ''family,'' has been denied parole for her conviction in the murders of the actress Sharon Tate and six other people. In denying parole on Wednesday, a panel of the Board of Prison Terms cited the brutality of the 1969 murders. Ms. Krenwinkel, 42 years old, is serving a life sentence.

title: A Gandhi Aide Resigns After Election Violence
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, facing a strong threat to his leadership in general elections this week, received another setback today with the resignation of his cultural adviser, Pupul Jayakar, who is also one of the oldest friends of his family and held the rank of Cabinet minister.

title: Metro Datelines; One Man Is Linked To Three Sex Attacks
description: New York City police believe the same man was responsible for the rapes this month of two women and the attempted rape of a third in Fort Tryon and Inwood parks in upper Manhattan.

title: A 'Job' In Salvador
description: Suppose a secret cabal of United States military men routed six priests out of their beds, murdered them, then faded back into clandestine silence. Suppose, say, President Mitterrand of France called up the White House and asked President Bush if he had ordered the killings, or knew anything about them.

title: A Lok at the Session: What Congress Accomplished
description: ECONOMIC POLICY Budget: Enacted a $14.7 billion deficit reduction plan that relies heavily on automatic spending cuts and measures viewed as accounting gimmicks to achieve the reduction. Plan also includes a 9-month extension of expiring tax breaks.

title: Chairman of 3 Units Named by Forstmann
description: Forstmann, Little & Company, a leveraged buyout firm, has hired William J. Turner as chairman and chief executive of three of its companies: FL Industries, Lear Siegler Inc. and the FL Aerospace Corporation.

title: Troubleshooter Is Undone by His Troubled Past
description: A growing number of businesses that have found themselves in desperate straits are seeking advice from the Turnaround Management Association. Not many realize that the association has been struggling to sort out a mess of its own.

title: Thinking Long Term Is Costly to Caterpillar
description: Caterpillar Inc., the nation's largest producer of earthmoving machinery, is learning that the costs of international competitiveness are high: $1.5 billion, ill will on Wall Street and a few dollars off its stock price.

title: Clamor in the East; Students Ask Workers' Aid In Czech Rally
description: Jana Markvartova is the daughter of a doctor and a lawyer, a privileged child of Czechoslovakia's elite. Before this week, she had never really talked to any of the hundreds of thousands of people who are this country's manual laborers.

title: A Battler Against Bureaucracy Has Fallen
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday RAILROADING IN MINIATURE

title: Making Money on Wary Investors
description: Harvey Golub, chief executive of the IDS Financial Corporation, is probably one of the few financial-services executives who, when asked about the impact of the October 1987 stock market crash, responded, ''On us, it's really been positive.''

title: Abortion: A New Round; Justices to Hear Cases on Parental Notice, But the Wider Issue, Again, Is Roe v. Wade
description: The out-of-court settlement of an Illinois abortion case on Wednesday did not remove the abortion debate from the Supreme Court's calendar. Two other cases, scheduled for argument before the Justices next Wednesday, provide the Court a chance to clarify or extend its ruling of last July in a Missouri case, a decision that gave the states new latitude to restrict access to abortion.

title: Hunter Is Fatally Shot In 4th Death of Season
description: A man hunting deer on Thanksgiving Day was shot to death, the fourth hunter killed in New York this week, the police said.

title: Chinese Banks Plan to Lend $27 Billion to Aid Businesses
description: Banks in China will lend $27 billion to state-operated enterprises that need cash, a central bank official said on Wednesday, although the Government's tight credit policy will remain in effect.

title: River Polluter Fined $6 Million
description: A judge fined Avtex Fibers Inc. $6.15 million Wednesday for polluting the Shenandoah River and ordered the company to pay to clean the river of a a chemical suspected of causing cancer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Regional Star Risks New York
description: QUICK: Name an advertising agency that opened out of town, built a reputation as an award winner in creative competitions and transformed that reputation into a growing base of national accounts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: U.S Wins a Round on Trade
description: Ninety-nine Japanese construction companies agreed to pay the United States $32.6 million to settle accusations that they had rigged bids on a variety of projects at a United States Navy base near Tokyo. Page D1.

title: Gunpowder Blast Leads to $240,000 OSHA Fine
description: A Roxbury Township gunpowder manufacturer should be fined $240,000 for safety violations that led to an explosion in June that injured 12 people, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration has found.

title: A Drifting Fuel Barge Is Captured Off Alaska
description: An unmanned barge carrying five million gallons of jet fuel drifted for more than a day near the site of the Exxon Valdez oil spill before a tug snagged the vessel today, the Coast Guard said.

title: Organic Farms: Agriwisdom
description: At a time when we celebrate the bounty of our farms, we might give thought to farmers. My friend Tom

title: Budget Office in Connecticut Projects $51.5 Million Deficit
description: The General Assembly's Office of Fiscal Analysis said today that the state could end the fiscal year with a $51.5 million deficit, mainly because of a sharp drop in sales tax revenues.

title: Review/Art; Drawings by Italian Masters From a Spanish Collection
description: The exhibition at the Spanish Institute of 87 Italian drawings from the Biblioteca Nacional in Madrid should not be missed. For a finer overview of Italian draftsmanship during the 17th and 18th centuries, a trip to Rome would be required.

title: Hot Air and the White House Effect
description: Fearful that waste gases may alter the world's climate, European countries have proposed a deadline for limiting worldwide emissions of carbon dioxide. The Bush Administration was heavily criticized when it resisted that idea at a recent international conference. The criticism is partly deserved: despite President Bush's campaign pledges, Washington is still months away from developing a policy on global warming.

title: Parks Agency Is Criticized for Use of Funds
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has criticized the state parks agency for failing to plan how it would spend millions of dollars from the Environmental Quality Bond Act.

title: Deficit-Reduction Bill Changes Many Taxes
description: While nobody in Washington seems eager to use the term tax increase, the $14.7 billion deficit-reduction package approved by Congress on Wednesday is built around almost $8 billion worth of measures that will raise a number of taxes.

title: The Waldheim File
description: We all remember Kurt Waldheim, don't we?

title: Mayor of Perth Amboy Says He Will Fight a Recall Effort
description: A citizens group seeking the recall of Mayor George J. Otlowski has enough signatures to put the matter on the ballot, but the Mayor plans to fight it.

title: Danish-French Insurance Talks
description: Denmark's biggest insurance company, the Baltica Group, said it was negotiating an alliance with the French insurance and finance company Groupe Victoire and Suez.

title: Three Palestinians Are Killed In a Bomb Blast in Pakistan
description: A remote-control bomb exploded in this frontier city today, killing three Palestinians returning by car from an afternoon prayer service.

title: Lobster Boat and Crew Missing in the Atlantic
description: Two Coast Guard cutters, four jets and a helicopter swept a 9,000-square-mile area of the Atlantic off Massachusetts today searching for a Connecticut lobster boat and her five-member crew.

title: Man Held in Killing Of Woman's Brother
description: A 39-year-old Stamford man faces a murder charge in the stabbing of his girlfriend's brother.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the first time in my life that I have been able to say the word freedom and to feel that I am indeed a free man. For 40 years I have lived under the Communist dictatorship. We could not talk freely, we could not think freely, but we became fed up, all of us here. And now, we will never stop saying this word: freedom! freedom!'' - Bohumil Stepon, a Prague truck driver. [ 1:3. ]

title: Bridge
description: Very few women have headed the standings in the New York City and Long Island final of the North American Open Pairs, formerly the Grand National Pairs. Joining that group last month was Gladys Collier of East Hampton, L.I., who qualified with Win Allegaert of Manhattan for the national playoffs in Fort Worth in March.

title: Review/Music; Tuba Gets Its Chance to Sing Solo
description: When a supporting instrument is asked to speak in a solo voice, worrisome decisions must be made. Should it, for example, simply rejoice in its natural, if limited, properties; or should it dare to be what it intrinsically is not?

title: Taping Puts Connecticut in a Legal Thicket
description: Three weeks after the top command of the Connecticut State Police was rocked by revelations about the force's tape-recording of telephone conversations between suspects and their lawyers, the implications of the controversy are spreading downward to affect local courthouses and police departments around the state.

title: Drug Abuse Counselor Held on Crack Charge
description: A drug abuse counselor at a New York City intermediate school was arrested yesterday and charged with possession of four vials of crack, the police said.

title: Police Are Searching For Mother of Infant
description: New Haven police are looking for the mother of a baby girl who was found alone inside a cold apartment on Thanksgiving morning.

title: Is It Time to Buy Your Phone? Maybe
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is planning to raise rental rates for telephone equipment early next year, and consumer advocates are urging people who lease their home phones to buy them.

title: Eastern Talks With Pilots Set
description: Eastern Airlines said today that it set a special meeting with its pilots' union for Tuesday to eliminate any uncertainties about employee status.

title: J.T. Moran Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2 million, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, from debt restructuring. c-Net income

title: What Did Columbus Know, When Did He Know It?; Didn't Bring Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Elias Hrawi; An Earthy Politician Who Makes Both Ends Meet
description: The newly elected President of Lebanon, Elias Hrawi, comes from a wealthy family of landlords in Zahle, a Christian town in the Bekaa, where the bulk of Syria's 40,000 troops in Lebanon are deployed.

title: Imatron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Consolidated Stores Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bounty Accusations In League's Hands
description: He says he still believes the Philadelphia Eagles offered a bounty on two of his leading offensive players, but Coach Jimmy Johnson of the Dallas Cowboys is content to leave matters up to the officials of the National Football League.

title: School Where Homeless Find Haven
description: The word homework has an odd ring for Unjohna Speed, a third grader with a particular academic handicap that is receiving attention in a new program at a local elementary school.

title: MSA Realty Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $471,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,275,738, or 15 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: S.N.L. Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dinkins Moves To Find Names For Chief Posts
description: David N. Dinkins appointed five committees yesterday to look for candidates to head major agencies in New York City, but his transition aides noted that all the jobs will not be filled by the time the Mayor-elect takes office on Jan. 1.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the weather, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Quadrex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,663,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $705,000 for the quarter and $2,032,000 for the 9 months. The company said latest 9-month figures included non-recurring costs totaling about $1 million related to severance pay, two terminated acquisitions, legal fees and start-up costs of Quadrex Transform Services Co.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Seles Beats Sabatini: Monica Seles trounced Gabriela Sabatini yesterday, 6-2, 6-2, to advance to the semifinals of a tournament in Essen, West Germany. Manuela Maleeva beat Mary Joe Fernandez, 6-4, 6-4. Steffi Graf withdrew Thursday with an injured abdominal muscle.(AP) HORSE RACING Nome by a Length: James A. Riccio's Nome won yesterday for the fourth time in five starts, beating Joker's Farce by a length in the $36,000 Personal Flag purse for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Nome covered the mile and an eighth in 1:52 and earned $21,600. (AP) GOLF American Ahead: Hubert Green of the United States shot a 67 yesterday, the day's best score, for a nine-under-par 135 and a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the Casio World Open tournament in Kaimoncho, Japan.(AP) FIGURE SKATING Russian Leads: Viktor Petrenko took the lead yesterday in men's singles and Midori Ito of Japan took the women's lead in a competition in Kobe, Japan. (AP) BOXING A Rallying Fenech Wins: Jeff Fenech of Australia rallied from a sixth-round knockdown yesterday and scored a unanimous decision over Mario Martinez in a superfeatherweight bout in Melbourne, Australia. Fenech (24-0) won the decision, 117-113, 116-112, 120-109.(AP) SKIING Victory for Frenchwoman: Nathalie Bouvier of France won the giant slalom yesterday in Park City, Utah. But she was not declared the leader until after the opening run because of uncertainty over whether she had missed a gate. She had a two-run total of 2:15.97(AP) WOMEN'S BASKETBALL Stanford 73, Michigan State 63: About 250 people watched this season opener for both schools, part of the Communiplex Classic in Cincinnati. Jennifer Azzi led Stanford with 20 points and four 3-point baskets. Stanford will play Ohio University in the championship game today. (AP)

title: Blazers Explode in 3d To Rout Nets, 125-99
description: Kevin Duckworth and Clyde Drexler combined for 11 points as the Portland Trail Blazers opened the third period with an 18-2 burst tonight and trounced the Nets, 125-99.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1989
description: Companies

title: North Stars Move Up By Beating Devils, 7-6
description: Neal Broten's goal 4 minutes 13 seconds into the third period broke a 5-5 tie tonight as the Minnesota North Stars moved atop the overall National Hockey League standing with a 7-6 victory over the Devils.

title: G.M. Reduces Isuzu Stake, But Is Still Main Shareholder
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had sold 20 million shares of Isuzu Motors Ltd., the Japanese auto maker and a longtime G.M. affiliate. The sale reduced G.M's stake percentage to 38.2 percent from 40.2 percent, but G.M. remains Isuzu's largest shareholder.

title: Plumtree Journal; Uncertain Lies the Land of Zimbabwe's Farmers
description: For the first time in 20 years, Max Rosenfels, whose family has toughed it out for almost a century in this arid, wind-swept region of southern Africa, is enjoying a productive season. The rain has been unusually promising and the end of the civil war in Matabeleland, this region of the country, has meant farming without danger.

title: Clamor in the East; No Israeli Ties Yet, Poles Say
description: Poland today denied an Israeli report that it had decided to restore full diplomatic relations with the Government in Jerusalem. ''The information is not true,'' Deputy Foreign Minister Jan Majewski said. ''The Polish Government is considering the possibility of restoring diplomatic relations with Israel in the not-too-distant future, but it has not taken any decision yet.''

title: Adirondack Park Panel Seeks Balanced Future
description: The Adirondack Park, six million acres of forests, mountains and lakes in the heart of New York State, is many things to many people: a slice of wilderness, a livelihood, a home. Members of New York State's Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century have traveled around the state to hear residents discuss their visions of the park. Now the commission must develop a plan for the park's future to present in the spring to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Ogivar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Krone Accepts Ban
description: Julie Krone has dropped her appeal of a 15-day suspension and will sit out the final month of racing in this year's thoroughbred meeting at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: Fretter Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included gain of $900,000, or 5 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Your Money; Retirement-Plan Deadline Looms
description: Many owners of small businesses and professional practices need to act promptly to avoid losing the deductibility of their retirement plans, warns Philip M. Herr, a tax manager with Spicer & Oppenheim, an international public accounting firm.

title: Clamor in the East; Hungary Opposition Splits, Threatening Ballot on Vote
description: A national referendum on Sunday to decide on the sequence of the first free Hungarian elections in 42 years has deeply split the opposition and put the largest of the new parties in the same camp as the governing Socialist Party.

title: Miriam Silman, Therapist, Weds
description: Miriam Silman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Silman of Ardsley, N.Y., and Great Barrington, Mass., was married yesterday in Salyersville, Ky., to David Gardner, a son of Tone Gardner of Salyersville and the late Lillian Gardner. Judge John B. Callaham, county judge executive of Martin County, Ky., performed the ceremony at the Gardner farm.

title: Attwoods to Add Mindis Industrial
description: Attwoods P.L.C., a mineral extracting and waste disposal company, agreed to acquire the Mindis Industrial Corporation, an Atlanta-based recycling company, for up to $65 million in cash and shares. An initial $18 million will be paid in the form of $15 million in 2.21 million new Attwoods shares and $3 million in cash, Attwoods said in a statement.

title: Abuses Seen on 2 Sides in Salvador
description: Rebels who seized working-class neighborhoods killed at least four civilians suspected of being informers for the army or members of death squads, residents of the areas and human rights monitors said today. The monitors also criticized the Government and military for bombing crowded residential areas where the rebels were holed up, leading to the deaths of an undetermined number civilians.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Help for the Sniffles
description: Pollen production declines in the winter, but those susceptible to indoor allergies may find they are still sneezing and sniffling because of mold, dust and other particles that stimulate allergies. If you are one of the 80 percent of allergy sufferers for whom airborne irritants do not take a winter holiday, here is some advice. Cause: Dust containing fabric fibers, hair and house dust mites.

title: Suave Shoe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss Suave said the 1988 year results included a non-recurring charge of $300,000 from the company's October 1987 self tender offer and related class action lawsuit.

title: Credit Markets Shrug Off Fed Move
description: The Federal Reserve made an unexpected move yesterday to arrest the decline in interest rates by draining some of the reserves that it had added to the banking system before the Thanksgiving holiday. The infusion of reserves on Wednesday was taken as a strong signal that the central bank was easing rates.

title: St. Clair Paint reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Providence Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,416,000 for the quarter and $6,491,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $331,000 and $554,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Net income

title: A People's Choice in Brazil
description: Last week's opening round of Brazil's first direct presidential election in 29 years produced two runoff candidates of integrity and conviction. Either is likely to provide more inspiring leadership than the outgoing Jose Sarney.

title: INSIDE
description: Rebels Accused of Killings In San Salvador Offensive

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
Roadmaster Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said latest 9 months' figures included a charge of $723,739 related to the sale of certain assets to Ajay Sports. Roadmaster owns 20 percent of Ajay.

title: Skolniks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Coffee Price Talks Foreseen
description: Talks could start in the first quarter of 1990 on a new pact to bolster world coffee prices, the chairman of the International Coffee Organization said Friday.

title: Too Many Dammed Rivers
description: Of the 3.5 million miles of river that once laced this continent, an estimated 15 percent now lie dead behind 60,000 dams of all kinds. For every river mile preserved under the national Wild and Scenic Rivers Act, 65 have been extinguished.

title: Patents; Propelling a 'Train' Away From the Earth
description: Another approach using a similar electromagnetic tunnel to propel a ''space train'' won patent approval this week. The system was conceived by Alvin M. Marks, a prolific independent inventor who lives in Salem, Mass., and Peter G. Diamandis, a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: National Business Systems reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included $18 million of unusual and non-recurring items. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Bruncor Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in Canadian funds.

title: Trying to Reduce the Auschwitz Body Count Changes Nothing; Gays Weren't Doomed
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Fight on Fund Loss
description: Canadian provinces are squabbling about who should pay compensation to 67,000 investors who lost about $450 million (Canadian) when two Alberta investment companies collapsed.

title: One Germany? First, One Europe.
description: The political earthquakes in Eastern Europe -now including the resignation of Milos Jakes's hard-line Communist regime in Prague - have aroused the long-buried issue of German reunification, a prospect that unsettles both Germanys' allies. Reunification, unlikely to occur soon, will be palatable only in the context of a uniting Europe, not a renascent German nationalism.

title: Hadson Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the third quarter loss included a charge of $7.6 million for provision for an anticipated loss on a fixed-price development contract and for non-reimbursable overhead cost, and a loss of $3.5 million for costs related to certain international exploration blocks.

title: Greenery Rehabilitation Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $368,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $817,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year, both from early extinguishment of long-term debt, net of income taxes.

title: MPSI Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss of $1,470,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago period was restated to reflect change in accounting method.

title: Richton International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The year-ago periods' sales included U.K. subsidiary sales of $3.3 million for the second quarter and $6.1 million for the 6 months. The U.K. subsidiary was sold effective Nov. 30, 1988.

title: Correction
description: A brief article by The Associated Press on Sunday about expanded inspections being ordered for some Boeing 747's misidentified the aircraft model on which 28 cracks were found. It was a 747-100, an older model of the jumbo jet, not a 747-400, the newest.

title: American Stores Co. reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
description: LIFO charges to earnings in the latest periods decreased share earnings by 43 cents in the quarter and $1.09 for the 39 weeks, compared with the same year-ago periods of 46 cents a share and 86 cents, respectively. The latest third quarter included earnings equaled to 26 cents a share from the sale of assets. The year-ago third quarter included earnings of $29,848,000, or 99 cents a share, from the partial recovery of the overfunding in the company's terminated defined benefit retirement plan and a charge of $12,320,000 for self-insurance reserve adjustments at an inactive captive insurance subsidiary.

title: Amy J. Schmitt Married on L.I.
description: At St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in West Hempstead, L.I., Amy Janet Schmitt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Schmitt of Ridgefield, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Neil Thomas McGoldrick, a son of Florence McGoldrick of Garden City, L.I., and the late Francis X. McGoldrick. The Rev. Brian McNamara performed the ceremony.

title: State Plans Ads for New York City
description: The state will try to help New York City bring in tourist dollars with a $3 million advertising campaign using network television, national magazines and direct-mail advertising, Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development, announced Thursday.

title: Crane Seeking Milton Roy
description: The Crane Company said today that it would like to acquire the Milton Roy Company, a maker of analytic instruments and pumps, for $21 a share in cash, prompting a sharp rise in the St. Petersburg, Fla.. company's shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Budd Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Richard C. Gallop, 51, a Lawyer Who Headed Columbia Pictures
description: Richard C. Gallop, former president and chief operating officer of Columbia Pictures Industries, died of a brain tumor Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Gilford, N.H.

title: Patents; An Inflatable Structure And a Space Helicopter
description: Patents covering a space helicopter and an inflatable prefabricated space station come from John Mecca, a home improvement contractor in Kings Park, L.I., who has had a long fascination with space travel.

title: Safety and Solid Waste
description: With New York facing a solid waste crisis, Thomas Jorling, the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, deserves praise for insisting on tough safety standards.

title: Rural Intrigue Is Unearthed With 5 Bodies
description: Ray and Faye Copeland lived in self-imposed rural isolation near here for decades, a quiet farm couple scratching out a living on 40 acres of hard soil in northwest Missouri.

title: Blockbuster Sale By United Artists
description: The United Artists Entertainment Company said it intends to sell the 7.6 million shares of stock it holds in the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, a video store operator. United Artists Entertainment, a cable television and movie theater company based in Denver, obtained the Blockbuster shares earlier this year through the merger of the predecessor company, United Artists Communications, and the United Cable Television Corporation.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-8 Prague's leadership has resigned, yielding to mass protests throughout the country. The Communist Party's beleaguered Central Committee chose a younger, lesser known Politburo member as General Secretary. Page 1 Jubliant Czechoslovaks celebrated the resignation of the Communist Party leadership in Prague's Wenceslas Square, site of a week of protests, shouting ''Svabodu!'' which means freedom. 1 Alexander Dubcek's poltical style has not been affected by 21 years of imposed obscurity following his ouster from power in the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia. 6 Thousands of Rumanians marched, by order of the Government, to celebrate the re-election of President Ceausescu as General Secretary of the Rumanian Communist Party. The crowd, however, showed little enthusiasm. 7 Details of East German corruption and profiteering by top officials of the former Communist leadership are being published by the press. The revelations are shocking a fascinated public. 7 For East Germans, nice place to visit 7 Yugoslavia's hyper-inflation has so devalued its currency that prices have soared into the millions and four-figure bank notes have replaced coins in Belgrade's wishing wells. 8 Gorbachev welcomes Polish Premier 8 Thatcher confers with Bush and is reassured about alliance 8 Hungarian opposition splits, threatening ballot on vote 8 Lebanon elected another President, Elias Hrawi, a wealthy, moderate Maronite Catholic, replacing President Moawad, who was assassinated Wednesday. But prospects for an end to the 14-year civil war seemed remote. 1 Hrawi: An earthy politician who makes both ends meet 4 New curbs on rights in El Salvador will likely be approved by the Legislative Assembly. The legislation, sponsored by President Cristiani's rightist party as ''antiterrorist measures,'' would ban most forms of dissent. 5 Four Salvadorans were executed by rebels who seized working-class areas of the capital, residents said. Rebels, who reportedly suspected those killed were informants or members of death squads, committed many human rights violations, monitors said. 5 Gunmen in India fired three shots at an opposition leader investigating fraud at a polling place, but he was not wounded. At least 30 people were reported killed in the second day of three-day national elections. 3 Four South African communities will be open to all races, the Government declared. But critics of apartheid said the step to recognize ''free settlement areas'' does not go far enough. 3 American securities firms in Japan are discouraging Federal officials from actively negotiating to open Tokyo's financial markets. With a privileged foot in the door, they fear losing what little they have won. 31 National 9-12, 24 An Iran-contra judge dismissed all criminal charges against an ex-C.I.A. official. The judge cited the Attorney General's decision to bar disclosure of classified information in the case. 1 California's insurance revolution, in which voters last year supported a sweeping rate-cutting initiative, may soon bear modified fruits for consumers after months of litigation. 9 For homeless students, homework has an odd ring. An elementary school in Los Angeles has recognized transiency as a learning problem with specific needs. 9 Five bodies found buried in Missouri have led to charges against a quiet elderly farm couple accused of hiring drifters who played a role in a swindle, then disappeared. 9 Devices designed to curb crib deaths were not recalled, even though the maker of the infant monitors suspected they were faulty, two ex-employees charge. 10 A nationwide outbreak of illness linked to a dietary supplement, L-tryptophan, may have been caused by a contaminant in the manufacturing process in Japan, Federal health officials said. 10 Bush weighing citizenship for 10,000 nurses 24 Liquor consumption in U.S. reported at a three-decade low 12 Tiny turtle a major obstacle to Conrail expansion plan 9 Regional 25-28 Fifth Avenue's Christmas season began with a going-out-of-business sale at B. Altmans & Company, an animal rights march protesting fur coats, and what may be the last season of horse-drawn carriage on New York City's most stylish street. 1 The sight and smell of urination in public places has become an increasingly familiar and annoying problem for even the most thick-skinned New Yorkers. 1 David Dinkins began his search for candidates to head major New York City agencies, appointing five search committees composed of labor leaders, lawyers, financiers, ministers and heads of civic groups. 25 The first student to reach Harvard from Murray Bergtraum High School, Javier Eduardo Mateu, returned home for the holidays to his family - and questions. 25 A police tape-recording controversy involving the Connecticut State Police has spread to local forces. Four departments with similar taping systems were subpoenaed by Federal officials, and the first lawsuits have been filed. 25 A line-of-duty disability pension was awarded to a former New York City police officer who suffered an emotional breakdown while working as an undercover investigator. 25 The future of Adirondack Park will be decided by members of a New York State commission, whose task is to balance a wide array of interests, including protecting the wilderness and the economic base of the region. 27 New York State plans ads for New York City 27 Human rights panel restores two officials to anti-bias posts 26

title: Shots Miss India's Opposition Leader
description: Unidentified gunmen fired three shots today moments after the Indian opposition leader, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, made a campaign stop at a polling place. Mr. Singh was not wounded in the incident, which took place in a village in his home constituency in Uttar Pradesh.

title: Clamor in the East; In Rumania, the Old Order Won't Budge
description: In a huge display of government control, tens of thousands of workers were marched to a demonstration here today to celebrate the re-election of President Nicolae Ceausescu as General Secretary of the Communist Party.

title: Benefits for Motorists Prove Elusive In California's Insurance Revolution
description: It has taken more than a year, but Californians may soon finally see some tangible fruits of their insurance revolution.

title: Batco Closing Factories
description: The British American Tobacco Company, a unit of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., said today that it would close cigarette factories in Liverpool in northwest England and in Amsterdam. A total of 599 jobs will be lost.

title: Patents; New Ideas For Travel In Space
description: MICHAEL A. MINOVITCH is the first person to admit that his idea for launching space vehicles by magnetic propulsion from a thousand-mile vacuum-pressure tunnel seems a little surreal.

title: PRAGUE PARTY LEADERS RESIGN; NEW CHIEF, 48, SURPRISE CHOICE; 350,000 AT RALLY CHEER DUBCEK
description: Yielding to mass protests throughout Czechoslovakia, the Communist Party's leadership resigned on Friday, and the beleaguered Central Committee chose a younger, lesser-known Politburo member to replace General Secretary Milos Jakes.

title: KEY RATES
Arkansas Edges Closer To a Cotton Bowl Bid
description: A 2-yard touchdown run by Barry Foster with 2 minutes 52 seconds to play carried Arkansas to a 23-22 Southwest Conference victory over Texas A&M yesterday and an almost certain Cotton Bowl bid.

title: Sugar Quota Is Increased
description: The United States Agriculture Department increased the nation's sugar quota today by 13.5 percent, the second time in three months that the Government has increased imports to combat tight supplies and high domestic prices.

title: Clamor in the East; Thatcher Confers With Bush and Is Reassured About Alliance
description: President Bush met Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at Camp David today and reassured her that there would be no abrupt changes in American foreign policy when he meets in Malta next week with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: In Wenceslas Square, a Shout: Freedom!
description: Word surged through the crowd like a current, and it seemed that within seconds every one of the hundreds of thousands of people in Wenceslas Square learned that the entire Czechoslovak Communist Party leadership had resigned.

title: Westinghouse Unit Makes Reff Offer
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said its Westinghouse Canada Acquisition Corporation had offered to purchase all of the outstanding common shares of Reff Inc. for $12.75 (Canadian currency) each, or almost $115 million. Westinghouse said the four founders of Reff, the controlling shareholders, had agreed to sell their six million shares under the offer. Their holdings represent about 66 percent of Reff's outstanding shares.

title: For Original Holiday Gifts, Practical Gadgets
description: This holiday season, a novel assortment of gadgets and personal-care products is available in stores and from mail-order catalogues. Some are new and some have been around for a while, but there seem to be more of them than ever before.

title: Cinram Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: System Software reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Refected a change in accounting for income taxes which added $300,000, or 4 cents a share, as a result of the adoption of FAS 96 in the first quarter of 1988.

title: 'Banged-Up' O'Brien Wins Jets' Courage Award
description: Out of admiration - and perhaps guilt -Ken O'Brien's teammates today voted O'Brien the most courageous Jet.

title: The Savings Habit
description: Gene Stallings, who was dismissed Monday as coach of the Phoenix Cardinals, is a spokesman for Valley National Bank in Phoenix. Until this week, his mother told him in commercials to save money for potential emergencies. Two days after his dismissal, he taped a new commercial.

title: Case Dismissed In Contra Affair, Clearing Agent
description: A Federal judge dismissed all criminal charges today against a former Central Intelligence Agency official indicted in the Iran-contra affair, citing Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's decision to block disclosure of classified information at trial.

title: Rita Lenihan, 75, Who Led Navy's Women
description: Capt. Rita Lenihan of the Navy, who was the director of the Waves and became chairwoman of the regents at Georgetown University after retirement from the service, died of cancer Thursday at Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived in Washington.

title: GEO International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Lori Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $371,000 for the quarter and income of $904,000, or 29 cents a share, for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary credit of $2,536,000, or 80 cents a share, for both periods, which reflected gain from repurchase of R.N. Koch unit senior notes of $1,539,000 and utilization of tax loss carryforwards of $997,000. c-Net loss and after a loss of $4,724,000 from discontinued operations for the 9 months.

title: Children's Discovery Centers of Amer Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Burt, Unhappy but Motivated, Has Bitter Words for Parcells
description: In his eight seasons with the Giants, Jim Burt had a love-hate relationship with Bill Parcells, his defensive coordinator for two years and his head coach for six.

title: John Kaplan, 60, Law Professor Who Analyzed Social Ills, Is Dead
description: John Kaplan, a law professor and author best known for his legal analyses of some of the country's most distressing and controversial social ills, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 60 years old.

title: Liquor Consumption in U.S. Reported at a 3-Decade Low
description: The average consumption of hard liquor by Americans has fallen to its lowest level in three decades, Federal health researchers reported today.

title: Salvador Moves Toward Broad Curbs on Dissent
description: The Legislative Assembly in El Salvador moved today toward final approval of sweeping new restrictions on individual freedoms, including virtually unhindered Government power to ban dissent and peaceful protest.

title: Trying to Reduce the Auschwitz Body Count Changes Nothing
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting to the Main Event Becomes a Main Event
description: Lou Falcigno cut a deal last April by which he thought he had a 10-year exclusive agreement to promote any fighter from the Soviet Union turning professional. Now he says the arrangement was not all it was cracked up to be.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Burning the Book of Nature
description: The great library of Alexandria in Egypt held the collected wisdom of the ancient world. According to Gibbon, it was reportedly set aflame by its Muslim captor, Amr Ibn al-'As, who explained that the books either agreed with the Koran and were superfluous, or disagreed and were heretical.

title: New Midway Air Flights
description: Midway Airlines today announced additional flights to Florida from Chicago and from Philadelphia, beginning Jan. 8. Additional round-trip flights will be added between Chicago and Tampa, Fla., and between Chicago and West Palm Beach, Fla. From Philadelphia, round-trip flights will be added with Sarasota, Fort Myers and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Clamor in the East; Gorbachev Welcomes Polish Premier
description: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the Polish leader who took office on the strength of popular resistance to Communism, was warmly welcomed today at the Kremlin, with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declaring, ''Our relations have changed for the better.''

title: A School's Pride Is Home for the Holiday
description: Javier's back! As the tall young man with the small gold earring and the megawatt smile bounded through the corridors of Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers, the news spread: Javier Eduardo Mateu, last year's valedictorian, was home for the holiday from college, and not just any college.

title: 4 Are Killed as a Small Plane Crashes on Takeoff in Texas
description: Four people died when their twin-engine plane crashed near the Arlington Municipal Airport after they made a Thanksgiving Day visit to a hospital, the police said today.

title: Rangers Sign Pettis
description: Gary Pettis, the only major league outfielder with more than 300 putouts in fewer than 120 games last season, agreed yesterday to a three-year contract with the Texas Rangers.

title: Central Guaranty Trustco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $546,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $8,628,000, or 15 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $543,000, or 1 cent a share, and $6,820,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: 4-Inch Turtle a Major Hurdle for Conrail
description: The yellow-spotted turtle may be only 4 inches long, but it has become a major obstacle to Conrail plans for a terminal on the reptile's wetlands sanctuary.

title:
For New Yorkers, The Banality of Street Murder;
In Chelsea, Back to Sleep
description: LEAD: On a cool night recently, a woman was murdered in front of my apartment in Chelsea. She was sleeping in her car when someone - evidently trying to steal her car radio -was surprised by her, and slashed her throat with a knife.

title: About New York; Listen, We've Got Another Homer Story
description: Homer Bigart looked out the window of the New Hampshire country house that has been his home for nearly two decades. Trees he planted himself bended in the wind coming down off the Pawtuckaway Mountains.

title: Swiss Bank Adds
description: BSI-Banca della Svizzera Italiana, a leading Swiss bank, said it was taking a 20 percent stake in Cassa Lombarda S.p.A. of Milan, Italy, which specializes in commercial and industrial lending. BSI said the move would develop a contact with Compagnie de l'Occident pour la Finance et l'Industrie S.A. a Luxembourg concern known familiarly as COFI, which serves as a vehicle for Cassa Lombarda's controlling shareholders. BSI and COFI plan to set up a merchant bank in Milan, to be majority-held by BSI.

title: Reminded Of Elvis
description: What went wrong with the cold war? One minute it seemed it would last forever, then suddenly it was old hat, high-button shoes, buggy and horse collar. James Bond seemed an antique, Rambo a tedium in oiled pectorals.

title: Japanese Planning Paris Center Stake
description: Japanese investors are expected to buy a large stake in France's Forum des Halles shopping center, a thriving new complex that is as much a part of the Paris cityscape as the Japanese-owned Rockefeller Center is to New York's skyline. France's Credit Lyonnais bank is about to close a deal to sell nearly a third of the shopping center for 420 million francs, about $68 million, to the Nippon Life Insurance Company, bank sources said. In Tokyo, a Nippon spokesman declined to comment on reports of the deal.

title: Held in Protest Against Abortions
