description: Forty-three anti-abortion protesters were arrested for trespassing yesterday morning after they blocked entrances to several physicians' offices where abortions are performed, the police said.

title: Title Bout Canceled
description: Mike McCallum's World Boxing Association welterweight title defense against Michael Watson in London next Wednesday was canceled yesterday after the British challenger broke his nose while sparring.

title: Allied Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., said it would sell its Williams Brothers Engineering Co. subsidiary to Fluor Daniel Inc., the engineering and construction unit of Fluor Corp., Irvine, Calif., an engineering and energy company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Waste Recovery Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sardi Can Recover Restaurant
description: Vincent Sardi may retake ownership of the famous theater district restaurant he sold three years ago to a Broadway producer because the new owner has failed to keep up with the required monthly payments, a Manhattan judge ruled yesterday.

title: Unigene Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Arts Complexes Are Thriving in Their Maturity in the East and West; At Lincoln Center, A new Building Big Enough for All
description: Even in raw concrete, the outlines are already evident at Lincoln Center of a new cinema for movie buffs, grand studios for ballet dancers and dormitory rooms with views that may make it tough for Juilliard students to study.

title: Clamor in the East; Reports of Corruption in East Berlin Shock Even the Party Rank and File
description: For the last two days, the East German press has been publishing accusations of corruption and profiteering by top officials of the former Communist leadership under Erich Honecker, and the reports are coming as a shock to the public here.

title: Europe Nears Mergers Pact
description: The European Community moved closer today to setting a common policy for investigating the big company mergers that are transforming Europe's business landscape.

title: Altman's Last Sale: Every Memory Must Go
description: In the early morning yesterday, when most of Fifth Avenue was still largely deserted - the steel vault doors in front of Tiffany & Company still tightly shut, a lone man shoveling snow in front of Cartier's - a crowd had already gathered in front of B. Altman & Company.

title: Clamor in the East; Hopes Sink To Bottom In Belgrade
description: There is a fountain here where, as with the Trevi in Rome, people once threw coins to wish their heart's desire. But these days the coins are so devalued that they do not even buy a dream. So the fountain is layered with sodden bank notes in four-figure denominations, destined too for worthlessness.

title: 4 People Killed in Baltimore As Blaze Sweeps Row House
description: A television set started a fire that swept through a row house early today, killing two children, their aunt and their grandmother, fire officials said.

title: Richmond Oil Pact In New Mexico
description: The independent oil company Richmond Oil and Gas P.L.C. said its Richmond Petroleum Inc. unit had received approval from the Jicarilla tribe in New Mexico for an oil exploration joint venture with the tribe.

title: China Report On Ventures
description: Most joint ventures involving foreign investment are reporting profits despite a cloudy business climate after the crackdown on political dissent in June, a Government news report said today.

title: Winter Pointers for Cars
description: It's slush, sleet and snow time. If you are going to do holiday driving in these conditions, or even in clear cold weather, here are several weather tips from the International Car Wash Association:

title: Now, From Brazil, 'Light' Water
description: In these thigh-thickening days after Thanksgiving, consider Edson Queiroz, entrepreneur. He has thought long and hard about Americans' paradoxical love of anything ''light.'' And he has decided it is time for the ultimate in such products - light water.

title: Aryt Optronics Indus reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Senate Dispute Delays Naming of Arts Group
description: A dispute in the Senate is holding up the appointment of members of a Presidential commission that will review the grant-making procedures of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: U.S. Outbreak of Illness Tied to Making of Drug
description: Federal health officials investigating a nationwide outbreak of a serious illness linked to a dietary supplement, L-tryptophan, said yesterday that they were focusing on the way it was manufactured in Japan.

title: Overseas 800 Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Post Broad Gain; Trading Off
description: Stocks gained strongly yesterday in exceptionally slow post-Thanksgiving trading.

title: Former Officer Is Awarded an Injury Pension for Job Stress
description: After four years of legal arguments and anguish, Paul J. Hipple is being compensated for an emotional breakdown he suffered while working as an undercover police officer in New York City.

title: Brampton Brick reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: North Carolina Gets By at the Buzzer
description: King Rice hit a driving scoop shot at the buzzer tonight to cap a 10-0 run by North Carolina over the final minute for an 80-79 victory over James Madison in the opening round of the Maui Classic.

title: Primerica To Buy Unit Of Barclays
description: The Primerica Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the consumer finance business of the BarclaysAmerican Corporation for $1.35 billion in cash.

title: Holiday Movie Audiences Create Box-Office Windfall
description: Smashing records at nearly every showing, Universal's ''Back to the Future II'' is expected to sell between $37 million and $45 million worth of tickets over the Thanksgiving holiday period beginning Wednesday. A Universal spokesman said that snow conditions in the East might reduce box office receipts by as much as $5 million.

title: Barry's Jewelers
description: Barry's Jewelers Inc. said it had made a competing bid to buy the assets of Merksamer Jewelers Inc., a subsidiary of the L. J. Hooker Corporation. Hooker, which is in Chapter 11 proceedings, agreed last month to sell its 80 percent stake back to Merksamer management for an undisclosed amount. Barry's said it had offered an undisclosed amount ''substantially in excess'' of the $55 million it said Merksamer had bid. Barry's offer will be submitted for bankruptcy court approval. Barry's, based in Duarte, Calif., operates 231 jewelry stores in 19 states. Merksamer, based in Sacramento, is a national chain of 80 stores.

title: New Jersey Symphony Settles Contract Dispute
description: The musicians and management of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra reached an agreement in their contract dispute yesterday.

title: Clamor in the East; Dubcek Is Back, With a Humble Face, (His Stalwarts Yearn for a Bit More)
description: When word spread that Alexander Dubcek would come out of the courthouse in Bratislava on Wednesday and actually take up a megaphone, more than 2,000 protesters began to cheer and stomp. After 21 years, many wanted the returning hero to carry them away with visionary words.

title: Stifling a Late Rally, Kansas Wins N.I.T.
description: Kansas began the Dodge National Invitation Tournament as an unheralded and unranked team, expected to lose in the early rounds.

title: Sensibility of New York Offended As a Nuisance Becomes Common
description: On weeknights, between 8 and 9 o'clock, Maria Emilia Dalmeida is likely to be sitting at the dinner table in her apartment at Greenwich and Murray Streets in Manhattan, eating or writing. Most nights, she'll look out the window and spot a taxi driver standing against the open door of his car, relieving himself.

title: An Acquisitive Utility Spreads in the West
description: Pacificorp, the company bidding $2.08 billion for the Arizona Public Service Company, has grown through acquisitions from a little-known Oregon company into the third-largest utility in the West. In the process, it is becoming known as a leader in the trends toward distributing power across many states and diversifying into non-utility businesses.

title: Tons of Toys Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
First Steps in Helping Addicts on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Maxwell Seeks Stake In Clal, Israeli Concern
description: Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, is offering $250 million for a substantial stake in Israel's second-biggest company, the Clal conglomerate, a Maxwell spokesman said Thursday.

title: LEBANESE APPOINT CENTRIST OFFICIAL TO THE PRESIDENCY
description: Lebanon elected another new President today, replacing the leader killed in an explosion two days ago. But the prospects for an end to 14 years of civil strife seemed as far away as ever.

title: Hormel (George A.) & Co.  (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Cities in California and Florida Move Up in Population Rankings
description: San Diego and San Jose, Calif., and Jacksonville, Fla., moved up in the latest population rankings of the nation's 25 largest cities, the Census Bureau says.

title: Bush Weighing Citizenship for 10,000 Nurses
description: A bill that would allow about 10,000 foreign nurses with temporary work visas to become United States citizens has been passed by Congress. President Bush is expected to sign the bill despite reservations in the Labor Department, said Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, the House sponsor.

title: Clamor in the East; Guards Whitewash Berlin Wall
description: Four days after artists painted colorful scenes onto the Eastern side of the Berlin wall, border guards have painted over them with whitewash. East German newspapers said the guards produced paint cans and brushes on Thursday after officers decided that the artists' spontaneous action was illegal despite the relaxed regime at the border. The youth daily Junge Welt said today that the border guards wanted to meet the artists as soon as possible to arrange for them to repaint sections of the wall under supervision.

title: Arts Complexes Are Thriving in Their Maturity in the East and West; Los Angeles Music Center, at 25, Is the Cities Cultural Hub
description: The birth of the Los Angeles Music Center 25 years ago is being celebrated with fanfares and flourishes this fall.Three months of celebration will culminate on Dec. 6, the exact anniversary date, with 25 high school bands and an audience of 5,000 singing ''Happy Birthday.''

title: Rumanian Keeps the Reins
description: Tens of thousands of workers were required to march to honor the re-election of President Nicolae Ceausescu as General Secretary of the Rumanian Communist Party. Page 7.

title: Go Slow on Debt Relief for Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: Farm Exports At $39.7 Billion
description: The nation's exports of farm products in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 came close to the $40 billion forecast by Agriculture Department experts three months ago.

title: Western Gas Processors Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a net of $6.9 million related to receipt of commitment fees plus accrued interest, and a settlement of a lawsuit. The latest 9 months' share earnings reflected payment of about $2.3 million in dividends to preference unitholders in each period. Share earnings are in units.

title: All Is Seemingly Well Aboard Space Shuttle
description: The crew of the space shuttle Discovery worked through the second full day of the craft's military mission today as officials on the ground maintained tight secrecy on what the five astronauts were doing.

title: U.S. Delays Decision on Agent Orange Pay
description: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, Edward J. Derwinski, announced today that he was delaying a decision on whether any Vietnam veterans could receive disability pay for exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: Bicoastal Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Bicoastal is the former Singer Co.

title: Review/Music; A Soloists' Chamber Concert
description: The plan was to combine some of New York's brightest young musical performers into a three-concert, mostly Mozart chamber-music series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But then the pianist Ken Noda, through whom the museum had organized the others, decided at least temporarily to retire as a performer.

title: Haughton Duel Expected
description: Matts Scooter has never been in better condition, but Harry Poulton, trainer of the 4-year-old with nine consecutive victories, is concerned about competition from Armbro Feather in the $250,000 William Haughton Memorial Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway. ''That mare is very strong and we were fortunate to win in a photo last month,'' Poulton said, speaking of a photo finish in Canada.

title: OPEC Seeks Kuwait and Emirate Oil Cut
description: An OPEC majority tried today to persuade two Persian Gulf Arab states, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, to agree to cut oil output, for fear that their excess production could weaken prices early in 1990.

title: 2 Say Company Failed to Recall Crib-Death Monitors Suspected as Faulty
description: Two former employees say a com pany that makes devices intended to prevent crib deaths failed to recall units it suspected were faulty.

title: The Worlds Of Puckett And Selvie
description: On the front page of The New York Times's sports section on Thanksgiving Day, the two leading stories seemed worlds apart, and were, but they were also ironically linked.

title: U.S. Urged To Soften Japan Stand
description: After five years of prodding the United States Government to negotiate to open Japan's financial markets, American securities firms are now discouraging Federal officials from such an activist role for fear of losing what little they have won.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Insects in the Kitchen
description: Now that the weather has turned wintry, insects come in from the cold. And holiday kitchens full of food are special havens.

title: Imasco Predicts Earnings Increase
description: The continued slowing in Canada's economic growth, which is expected next year, will not prevent Imasco Ltd. from increasing net earnings 10 percent to 20 percent, its chairman and president, Purdy Crawford, said in an interview. He said the improvement should come in all divisions, including the underperforming United States operations: the fast-food chain Hardee's and Peoples Drug Stores.

title: FCA International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago first quarter's results were restated. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: What Did Columbus Know, When Did He Know It?; Civilizing Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: Clamor in the East; East Germany's Old Guard Included Veterans of Struggle Against Nazis
description: The broom that swept out the leadership of East Germany's Communist Party earlier this month also pushed away an essential political component - its living embodiment of unswerving opposition to Nazism and total devotion to Stalin, senior officials here say.

title: What Did Columbus Know, When Did He Know It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy Savings Bank reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings were not available because the company converted from mutual to stock form in June.

title: Books of The Times; Prophetic Stories From Mishima
description: Acts of Worship Seven Stories By Yukio Mishima Translated by John Bester. 205 pages. Kodansha International. $17.95.

title: The Winds of Change
description: POLAND June 4, 1989: Solidarity candidates achieve what the Communist Party calls a decisive majority of the popular vote in a parliamentary election, the first free election in almost a half century. Aug. 19: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski designates Tadeuz Mazowiecki, a senior Solidarity official and prominent Roman Catholic layman, to be the first non-Communist Prime Minister of Poland since the early postwar years. HUNGARY May 22, 1989: Janos Kadar, Communist leader for more than 32 years, steps down and is replaced by a centrist, Karoly Grosz. Oct. 7: The Communist Party, which has ruled since 1956, formally disbands. Oct. 17: Parliament rewrites the Constitution to allow a multiparty system and adopts laws allowing free elections in 1990. BULGARIA Oct. 29, 1989: Todor I. Zhivkov, Communist leader of the country since 1954, promises in response to unusual public protest that there will be increased attempts at reform. Nov. 10: Mr. Zhivkov resigns and is replaced by his long-serving Foreign Minister, Petar T. Mladenov, who is regarded as a traditionalist. EAST GERMANY Sept. 10, 1989: Hungary opens its border with Austria to allow East Germans to depart. In the next two months nearly 200,000 poeple will reach West Germany in the largest exodus since 1961. Oct. 18: The Communist Party leader, Erich Honecker, who suprevised the building of the Berlin wall in 1961, is replaced by Egon Krenz, the youngest member of the Politburo. Nov. 9: The East German Government announces the opening of all its borders, including the Berlin wall.

title: Orchestra's Debut
description: The full orchestral version of Aaron Copland's ''Appalachian Suite'' and Charles Wuorinen's ''Bamboula Beach'' will be given their New York premieres on Dec. 14 by the New World Symphony, in a concert at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. The ensemble, which is believed to be the only full-time training orchestra in the United States, will be making its New York debut under the direction of the founding conductor and artistic advisor, Michael Tilson Thomas. Also on the program: Beethoven's Symphony No. 7. Tickets, from $10 to $30, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Management Co. EntertainFment Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Fairfield-Noble Corp.  reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said results of operations reflected discontinuance of its Cathy Hardwick division and revaluation of inventories on a basis consistent with its on-going operations.

title: Human Rights Panel Restores 2 Officials To Anti-Bias Posts
description: New York City's Commission on Human Rights yesterday announced the reinstatement of the director of its AIDS discrimination division and his deputy, who had been dismissed from their jobs last month, touching off protests from AIDS and homosexual-rights groups when the two asserted they had been removed because of their homosexuality.

title: Mexico Sees Problems With Loans
description: Mexico may face short-term problems because of the limited number of creditors expected to offer new loans under the country's most recent debt agreement, the central bank president, Miguel Mancera, said today.

title: Kaufel Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Ethics Courses: Useless
description: LEAD: Let a stockbroker be arrested for shady dealing or a new medical procedure pose unanticipated dilemmas, and there arises a demand for a course in ethics. Law schools, medical schools, business schools - even high schools - are urged to stem a supposed flood of immorality by instituting the study of right and wrong.

title: Clamor in the East; For East Germans, Nice Place to Visit
description: More than eight million East Germans, equal to about half the East German population, have visited West Germany and West Berlin since the East German leaders lifted restrictions on travels to the West on Nov. 9.

title:
For New Yorkers, The Banality of Street Murder;
West Side: Like a Movie
description: LEAD: Lately, my leafy, sedate Upper West Side block in New York City has seemed like a little Hollywood.

title: Dotronix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $166,000 for the latest first quarter and $120,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Status of the Iran-Contra Figures
description: * JOSEPH F. FERNANDEZ

title: Injunction Set In Fraud Case
description: A Federal district judge granted a preliminary injunction Wednesday against two New York investors who in August were charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with defrauding more than 100 brokerages, including Merrill Lynch; Bear, Stearns; Prudential-Bache Securities, and Shearson Lehman Hutton.

title: Monica de Alzaga Becomes a Bride In Buenos Aires
description: Monica de Alzaga, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcello de Alzaga of Buenos Aires, was married there yesterday to Disque D. Deane Jr., a son of Marjorie S. Deane and Mr. Deane, both of New York, Greenwich, Conn., and Tucker's Town, Bermuda. The Rev. Luis Lenzi performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Rosary in the Convent of Santa Domingo.

title: Fronteer Directory reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $192,075 pre-tax gain from sale of a directory. The company said comparable figures for the year-ago quarter were not available because of a change in accounting when Fronteer went public in March 1989.

title: South Africa Opens 4 Areas to All Races
description: The Government today declared four residential areas in South Africa open to all races. But the step was soon assailed by critics of apartheid, who said that it did not go far enough.

title: Margaret Moorman, Writer, Is a Bride
description: Margaret Moorman, a writer, and Harvey Quaytman, a painter, were married last evening at the bridegroom's studio in New York by Rabbi Charles D. Lippman. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Moorman of Arlington, Va. Her husband is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Mark Quaytman of Sunnyside, Queens.

title: Ms. Motley Wed To J. C. Fischer
description: Sarah H. Motley and J. Christopher Fischer were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rt. Rev. William G. Burrill, the Episcopal Bishop of Rochester, and the Rt. Rev. Barbara C. Harris, the Suffragan Bishop of Massachusetts, performed the ceremony.

title: High-Tech Help for Both Buyer and Seller
description: LEAD: The traditional method of selling a house has been to list it with a broker or to place an ad in a newspaper or magazine and then wait for the phone to ring. But sellers, buyers and brokers have in the last few years discovered a new world of high-tech opportunities literally at their fingertips.

title: Review/Dance; A Jazz-Modern Mix From Michiyo Tanaka
description: Michiyo and Dancers, a New York-based company directed by Michiyo Tanaka, a Japanese-born choreographer, shared a program with the Sapporo Seibi Dance Company, a visiting troupe from Sapporo, Japan, on the evening of Nov. 17 at Gould Hall. Both groups combined jazz with various modern-dance styles. Neither made a persuasive case for these mixtures.

title: Keeping an Identity in a World of Hyphenated Surnames
description: IN a world where hyphenated surnames abound, I'm a bit of an anomaly. I'm divorced, and I still have my ex-husband's surname.

title: The Hitter Of the 80's
description: Who had the most hits in the major leagues in the 1980's?

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: With one swipe of his left foot, Paul Caligiuri, a United States midfielder, has brought soccer closer to that goal than ever. With a rooting interest in the World Cup next year, and the prospect of hosting the event for the first time in 1994, the sleeping giant is about to awake. ROBERT GRABILL Hanover, N.H.

title: Guild Hall Honors 3 In the Arts
description: LEAD: THE writer Peter Matthiessen, the architect Charles Gwathmey and the singer-composer Paul Simon are the latest residents of the East End to be cited for Lifetime Achievement in the Arts.
