Solving your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 4 THE OLD FARMER'S ALMANAC 1990. (Yankee Publishing, $2.95.) The 198th annual edition. 5 12 THE NIGHT OF THE MARY KAY COMMANDOS, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) Selections from the comic strip ''Bloom County.'' These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Light Mayonnaise, Light Dogfood, and Now Light Ice Cream
description: Food manufacturers and diet marketers are seeing to it that the demand for low-calorie foods does not go unsated. The selection of ''light'' foods is limitless: mayonnaise, canned fruit, popcorn and dog food. Even Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc., usually a super-rich ice cream, recently announced a new light version.

title: How a Pianist Begins To Build His Career
description: FOR Mark Salman, a 27-year-old concert pianist from Darien, making his Carnegie Hall debut last month was the easy part of building a career.

title: Awestruck
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 118, but Who's Counting?

title:
GARDENING;
Was It Pumpkin? Or Was It Squash?
description: LEAD: PUMPKIN PIE is a fall favorite as well as a tradition for Thanksgiving. When topped by a dollop of whipped cream or a scoop of ice cream, it's hard to beat. But was that really pumpkin pie you had on Thursday?

title: Gorbachev May Seek a Bush Vote of Confidence
description: IN a sense Mikhail S. Gorbachev may be seeking the impossible in his Mediterranean rendezvous with President Bush, trying to project the image of a confident leader as the Communist monolith melts in Eastern Europe.

title: A Question Of Motivations
description: Mathias Rust, the West German who flew his single-engine plane to the edge of Red Square in Moscow in 1987, said his aim then was to talk to Mikhail S. Gorbachev about world peace and to dramatize his utopian goals. Last week, Mr. Rust, now 21 years old, may have had a more mundane goal in mind. The authorities said he stabbed a nurse at a Hamburg-area hospital after she resisted when he tried to kiss her. Mr. Rust, who spent a year in a Soviet prison before he was pardoned in August 1988, was working as a hospital orderly when, the police said, he pulled an 18-year-old student nurse into a changing room and tried to kiss her. When she resisted, the police said, she was stabbed twice in the stomach. Local newspapers said she was in serious condition. Mr. Rust fled but turned himself in two hours later. In a recent interview, Mr. Rust said he was working at the hospital as an alternative to military service because, he said, he was opposed to violence.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. El Salvador Aid: Vote to kill an amendment to a $14.6 billion foreign aid bill that would have placed restrictions on United States aid to El Salvador.

title: Review/Theater; The Varieties of Life's Illumination, in 'Brightness'
description: For Ping Chong, ''Brightness'' is an experiment in light and sound, a surrealistic canvas of nonserial images. This new work (at La Mama Annex) is a small play of sensory but not intellectual stimulation. As such, it should be considered a sidelight to Mr. Chong's venturesome career as an author and director of conceptual theater.

title: 'If There Was Light'
description: These incredible days of November 1989 have been crowded with political wonders. But for me nothing could equal the emotions of the moment when Alexander Dubcek stood before 300,000 people in Wenceslas Square, Prague, and said: ''I am among you again.''

title: Quiet Art Need Not Be Boring or Wimpish
description: The spotlight of the art world is rarely drawn to art that is quiet and discreet. New York is so noisy, so swollen with information, so restless with issues that seem to demand immediate attention, that reticent, self-contained art is easily overlooked or dismissed. There is a general assumption - particularly in New York - that an art of introspection and tact has little or no ability to deal with those pressing issues with which the art world is always concerned.

title: Critics Pick Some Favorites Of the Year; Romantic Norrington And Gelber's Beethoven
description: Roger Norrington's landmark recording of Berlioz's ''Symphonie fantastique'' (Angel CDC-49543) does not obviate every previous performance, nor should it be expected to. Good enough to please even those utterly indifferent to the early-music movement, it owes its distinction to Mr. Norrington's remarkable sensitivity to timbral niceties and to the composer's imagination as shaped by the actual instruments of his day. The record also marks the boldest foray thus far into the heart of 19th-century Romanticism.

title: Let Winter Be Winter
description: To the Editor:

title: Czechoslovakia's Next Step Is Even Trickier
description: ''I'VE been a reform Communist all my life,'' said a party loyalist in his late 50's a couple of weeks ago. ''They've always told me that it was still too early for my kind of thinking. Now I'm afraid it's too late.''

title: The Meaning of Berlin
description: The second World War was plotted in Berlin, and since Germany's defeat its former capital has been at the focal point of most of the serious crises threatening another major war. This underscores the meaning of the opening of the wall and the transformation of Eastern Europe.

title: A Word on Spending In Brodsky Campaign
description: On the front page of the Nov. 12 Westchester section [ ''Election Victory Casts Spallone in a New Role'' ] was a serious error regarding the expenditures of my organization, Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion, on behalf of Richard Brodsky's campaign for County Executive. The Times quoted Andrew O'Rourke's campaign manager, Peter Delaney, about our finances without calling me to verify or comment. I did not authorize Peter Delaney to speak for me.

title: GOODBYE THOREAU, HELLO ASTAIRE
description: I have just resettled on these shores after having spent 20 years in Japan. Robert Goldblum's About Men article ''Goodbye Thoreau, Hello Astaire'' (Oct. 29), has enabled me to better understand a fascinating Japanese ritual that takes place when a man reaches his 60th birthday. Mr. Goldblum writes, ''To wear a tux is to pay tribute to those who came before, to those who decided that there are certain special occasions worthy of special treatment.''

title: RUTGERS GAINS IN OVERTIME
description: Rutgers reached the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament for the second time in its history with a 2-1 overtime victory today over Vermont.

title: J. E. Carsky Wed To Miss Sweeney
description: Madeleine Anne Sweeney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Sweeney of Crestwood, N.Y., was married there yesterday at Annunciation Roman Catholic Church to Joseph Edward Carsky, a son of Katherine S. Carsky of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late James B. Carsky. The Rev. James R. Moore performed the ceremony. Mrs. Carsky, 25 years old and a graduate of Iona College, is a restaurant manager at Riese New York, operator of the T.G.I. Friday's restaurants in New York. Her father is a partner in the White Plains law firm of Cerrato, Sweeney, Cohn, Stahl & Vaccaro. She is a granddaughter of the late Justice John J. Dillon of State Supreme Court for the 9th Judicial District.

title: Helping Troubled Boys Save and Study for College
description: FOR Cesar Alvarez, a senior at Hastings High School, the pressure was intense.

title: Elizabeth Glaser Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Glaser of New York, South Egremont, Mass., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Amy Glaser, to Leslie Philip Lipson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Lipson of Rochester. A February wedding is planned.

title: Marsha Lasker and Edward Nell Wed
description: Marsha Karen Lasker, an administrative assistant at the New School for Social Research in New York, and Prof. Edward John Nell, the chairman of the graduate department of economics there, were married yesterday at their home in Shady, N.Y. Sidney Slayton, a town justice of Woodstock, N.Y., officiated.

title: Learning the Life of a Blacksmith
description: LEAD: WHEN Danielle Brooks of Oxford was kicked in the stomach by a horse, she shrugged it off. ''I jumped back before he could make a good connection,'' she said. As a farrier, or blacksmith, she works hard, knowing that a horse's kick or bite could kill or maim her.

title: 18th-Century Law Snares Vietnamese Fishermen
description: Each morning, hundreds of Vietnamese-born fishermen cast off in refitted wooden boats from piers here and in the harbors of Monterey and Los Angeles to sail far out into the Pacific to cast their nets for kingfish and rock cod.

title: THE GIRL WHO WALKED WITH GHOSTS
description: BABY OF THE FAMILY By Tina McElroy Ansa. 265 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: QUESTIONS FOR THE COSMOS
description: ROBERT GEORGE JAHN HAS A NARROW face, sunken cheeks and a host of eccentricities. His office is crammed with stuffed animals, mainly Princeton tigers, and pictures of a childhood favorite, giraffes. Before heading off to a meeting at one of the half-dozen corporate, foundation and university boards on which he serves, he snaps on his favorite Princeton baseball cap. But there is nothing quirky about Jahn's academic background, nothing idiosyncratic about his intellectual achievements - Phi Beta Kappa at Princeton, dean emeritus of the university's engineering school, leader in aerospace engineering - nothing that explains his affinity for a subject as antipathetic to the scientific community (his community!) as the one that has preoccupied him for the past 10 years. Indeed, the way he tells it, Jahn, 59, is as startled as anyone else that he should be the one to have emerged from a basement lab with claims that ESP - extrasensory perception - really exists.

title:
INVESTING;
Gold Funds That Glitter
description: LEAD: Gold is leaving the skeptics in the dust. They expected its price to continue drifting lower because of the mild inflation outlook and growing bullion production. ''Everybody assumed it would just keep going down and down and down. But it didn't,'' said Frederic S. Bogart, head of precious metals for the Republic National Bank of New

title: A Guide for Hikers, Sunday and Otherwise
description: A CLIMB up steep stone steps in Kent, a walk in the wild near Bethlehem's town center and a hike over glacially formed ridges called eskers are among the outings described in the new edition of ''Country Walks in Connecticut'' by Susan D. Cooley of Middletown.

title: Floating Name Game
description: O.K., EVERYBODY, let's get organized: what are we going to call the get-together of the heads of the two superpowers next weekend?

title: Houston Defeats Texas Tech
description: Andre Ware threw two of his four touchdown passes to Manny Hazard and set an National Collegiate Athletic Association record, and Houston turned 5 turnovers by Texas Tech into 27 points on the way to a 40-24 Southwest Conference victory tonight.

title: Inmate Charged in Pennsylvania Prison Riot
description: An inmate whose sentence was to have expired today was the first to be charged in connection with two nights of riots last month at Camp Hill State Prison in which 123 guards and inmates were injured, the police said today.

title: Miss Schlesinger To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schlesinger of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Joan Schlesinger, to Gary H. Yablon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Yablon of Baldwin, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: Pastimes; Coins
description: Counterfeiters have been around since the birth of coins, faking and debasing currency to make a profit. But the Celts used their skills as metallurgists to produce some of the finest counterfeit coins of pre-Christian Europe. Their counterfeits are all the more interesting because the Celts had little use for money - their economy was based on bartering.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; For Pasta, Creamy Lightness
description: Is it possible to make a cream sauce, flavored with cheese, that comes within a country mile of judicious eating?

title: Ethiopia and Rebels Set Up Framework for Peace Talks
description: The Ethiopian Government and rebels from the northern province of Eritrea have agreed on a framework for peace negotiations, figures close to preliminary talks said today.

title: Durable 'Wiz' Revived On Bridgeport Stage
description: THE transformation of ''The Wonderful Wizard of Oz'' into an all-black, jive-talking pop-rock gospel musical was no mere gimmick. ''The Wiz'' still works, and the festive, amiable production at the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport attests its durability.

title: Constance Kennedy, Teacher, Marries
description: Constance Decker Kennedy and Mark B. Thompson were married yesterday in Philadelphia at the offices of Mark B. Thompson Associates, the bridegroom's architectural firm. The Rev. Dr. Wendel W. Meyer, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: PLANE IN SALVADOR WITH SOVIET ARMS CRASHES AND 4 DIE
description: A light plane carrying two dozen Soviet-made antiaircraft missiles crashed in eastern El Salvador today on what Government officials said was a mission to resupply leftist guerrillas here with weapons from Nicaragua.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TALES FROM MARGARITAVILLE: Fictional Facts and Factual Fictions. By Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) Jimmy Buffett is primarily known for his pop music. And because the Margaritaville of his well-known song is a desultory place, readers may not be prepared for these good-natured tales of free-spirited characters whose affinity for alcohol never interferes with their zest for adventure.

title: By Train to the Middle Of the Amazon Jungle
description: After two loud blasts on the whistle the wood-burning steam locomotive pulls slowly out of the railroad yard, crowded with passengers clad mostly in bathing suits and shorts. But instead of heading for some fancy beach resort, the train is bound for a large pile of rocks in the middle of the Amazon jungle.

title: Cold War's Aftermath: Grumman Gears Up
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND'S largest defense contractor and employer, the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, is seeking permission from the Town of Oyster Bay to become the Island's largest developer.

title: Let's Save Sterling Forest, for the Sake of Mankind
description: WE have mown down, paved over and smoothed out so much of nature that we now think of the few bits and pieces left as delicate curiosities. We have forgotten nature's function.

title: Miss Miner Wed To Thomas Soede
description: Erica Ann Miner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Miner of Westfield, N.J., was married last evening to Thomas Soede, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frans J. Soede of Vienna. Rabbis Charles Kroloff and Marc Disick officiated at the Lotus Club in New York.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: Soccer in the United States will continue to struggle as long as newspapers like The Times continue to give the sport little or no ink. With the United States now qualifying for Italy, and especially with the World Cup being held in this country in 1994, isn't it about time soccer got some expanded coverage? CLIFF GOULET New York

title:
FOCUS: VERMONT;
Ski Resorts Wary About Development
description: LEAD: Despite a rainy, relatively mild season and a softening of the second-home market, Vermont's ski industry last year recorded the third best winter in its history, taking in $330.2 million from all sources, according to the Vermont Ski Areas Association, an industry organization. But higher snowmaking costs cut profit margins.

title: Voice of the Turtle: What to Do With Pets
description: I'd like to answer the question that Linda Martin asked in her excellent ''From an Empty Nest, the Voice of the Turtle'' (Nov. 5). That is, ''What to do with pets when their owners leave for college.'' As the adoption chairperson for the New York Turtle and Tortoise Society, I have had to find numerous homes for turtles like Ms. Martin's. I recommend that someone in the same position as Ms. Martin call local wildlife and humane agencies and find out if there are any organizations that specialize in the animal in question, like the turtle society.

title: Pressure on Drinking Alters Cafe Practices
description: LEAD: INCREASED social and legal pressures against mixing drinking and driving are having an impact on Long Island as restaurants, night clubs and bars report a financial pinch caused by decreased alcohol consumption.

title: Use of Pain By the Police On Protestors Draws Scrutiny
description: LEAD: THE use of so-called compliance techniques by police officers around the state to subdue people being arrested is drawing wide attention and is expected to be the subject of public hearings when the General Assembly reconvenes in February.

title: Lifestyle; New Frequent Fliers: Children Traveling Solo, Often to See a Parent
description: Kristen Coyne still remembers the first time she flew alone, at age 7. Her parents had recently separated, and her mother was sending her from Dallas to Houston to visit her father.

title: Richard TeLinde, 95, Doctor and Educator
description: Dr. Richard Wesley TeLinde, a former chairman of the gynecology department at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine and a former chief of gynecology at Johns Hopkins Hospital, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Baltimore after a long illness. He was 95 years old.

title: 'Letters From a War Zone'
description: To the Editor:

title: Farewells and On to Moscow for Younger Set
description: The Aeroflot flights from here to Moscow were serving a younger-than-usual clientele this week, as dozens of Soviet teen-agers slung backpacks over faded denim jackets and bid farewell to the educational, economic and emotional realities of the United States.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Bizet: Symphony in C With Ravel: ''Ma Mere l'Oye,'' ''Pavane Pour une Infante Defunte.'' Scottish Chamber Orchestra conducted by Jukka-Pekka Saraste. Virgin Classics VC 7 90744; CD and cassette. With Prokofiev: Symphony No. 1; Britten: ''Simple Symphony.'' Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. Deutsche Grammophon 423 624-2; CD only. The performance standard for the Bizet symphony was set some 50 years ago in a pioneering recording conducted by Walter Goehr, who neatly captured the bubbling good spirits and lively animation of the music. Of the latest entries, the Saraste version reveals more of these qualities than does its rival, and is more vividly recorded. The 33-year-old Finnish conductor also deals lovingly with Ravel's ''Mother Goose'' and ''Pavane.'' Best on the Orpheus release is the Britten symphony, delivered with just the right wit and charm. The Prokofiev performance is stodgy and leaden except for the Gavotte, which manages a bracing elegance. - Martin Bookspan Prokofiev: 'Peter and the Wolf' With Saint-Saens: 'Carnival of the Animals'; Mozart: 'Eine Kleine Nachtmusik.' Academy of London conducted by Richard Stamp; John Gielgud, narrator (''Peter''). Virgin Classics VC 7 90786-2; CD and cassette. With Prokofiev: Symphony No. 1, Violin Concerto No. 1. English String Orchestra conducted by Yehudi Menuhin; Christopher Lee, narrator (''Peter''); Hu Kun, violin (Concerto). Nimbus NI 5192; CD only. If ''Peter and the Wolf'' is the principal consideration, the Virgin Classics is the disk of choice. The American-born Richard Stamp conducts an elegant, witty, charming performance, with razor-sharp playing. Mr. Gielgud's storytelling has a fine sense of the dramatic - though his counterpart, Christopher Lee, is not far behind. But Nimbus's all-Prokofiev disk has other strengths, including the introduction of a 26-year-old Chinese violinist on the brink of a major career. Hu Kun plays with technical assurance, a light but penetrating tone and dead-center intonation. Mr. Menuhin and the English String Orchestra are responsive and sure-footed here and in the ''Classical'' Symphony. The Saint-Saens and Mozart performances on Virgin are less distinguished than the Prokofiev. The tempo in the Mozart finale recalls Beecham's perversely slow one in a recording of a generation ago. - M. B. Einem: Violin Concerto, Transcriptions (Mussorgsky, Schubert) Christiane Edinger, violin; NDR Radio Orchestra (Hannover) conducted by Alfred Walter. Marco Polo 8.223138; CD only. Gottfried von Einem (b. 1918) is an Austrian composer best known for his ability to turn compelling dramas (by Buchner, Kafka, Durrenmatt) into stageworthy but less enduring operas. Highly regarded at home, his works have not traveled well, and the release of his Violin Concerto (1967) is not likely to alter things. It is a highly virtuosic work, lengthy (39 minutes) and constructed with an odd symmetry: two long slow movements framing two short fast ones. The composer does not lack ideas, like a promising dialogue between the solo instrument and bongo drums in the third movement, but rarely makes much of them. His idiom is tonal, with mild dissonances, and his melodies are spun out lyrically but unmemorably. Christiane Edinger, a distinguished artist ignored in the notes, performs laudably; the orchestra does its thankless task diligently, and the recorded sound is adequate. - George Jellinek Brahms: Serenades Nos. 1, 2 London Symphony Orchestra conducted by Istvan Kertesz. London Weekend Classics 421 628-2; CD only. These recordings are dismally transferred, insipidly packaged, inadequately documented and unannotated, but it's great to have them back. Kertesz's First Serenade, from 1968, is a treasure, not because the work is a towering masterpiece (though very near) or the performance flawless (though close enough), but because his manner and temperament suit this limpid music superbly. The piece has come into its own a bit recently, but no recording has rivaled Kertesz's. Alas, London's transfer inflicts an abrupt level shift on the first movement and robs the bass line (and much else) of radiant warmth, most crucially in the slow movement. Still, the disk is inexpensive and will have to serve until London decides to do full justice to this gem. - James R. Oestreich 'A Tribute to Jascha Heifetz' Itzhak Perlman, violin; Samuel Sanders, piano. EMI/Angel 7 49604; CD and cassette. Tuneful, lightweight and showy, encore pieces are the musical counterparts of pickles and jam, and though you can't live on them alone, you can't deny the zing they add to a diet of more substantial fare. Jascha Heifetz, who loved to spice up his recital programs with encore pieces by a wide variety of composers, arranged more than 150 of them for violin and piano, and in this masterly tribute, Itzhak Perlman plays with elegance and panache an engaging selection of 19 of these miniatures ranging from Rameau's ''Rigaudon'' to Manuel Ponce's ''Estrellita'' and Gershwin's ''Three Preludes.'' There's sweetness aplenty here, but honeyed, not saccharine, for the music bespeaks the bracing modernity of Heifetz's own taste - note, for instance, the harmonic touches of Debussy he added to the accompaniment of Saint-Saens's ''The Swan.'' - Barrymore L. Scherer POP/JAZZ The Screaming Blue Messiahs: 'Totally Religious' Elektra 60859; all three formats. ''I woke up this morning/ Bent on destruction,'' Bill Carter yowls to open the third album by the Screaming Blue Messiahs, and for the next 38 minutes his band fills the air with mayhem. Mr. Carter uses his guitar as a blunt instrument, slamming out power chords or leads that sound like tires squealing on a blue highway; behind him, Chris Thompson on bass and Kenny Harris on drums stomp and bash. In Mr. Carter's songs, speed and violence are the only alternatives to self-deception and despair - a brutal world view, but one that makes for savage, vital rock-and-roll. - Jon Pareles Michelle Shocked: 'Captain Swing' Mercury 838-878-2; all three formats. The East Texan folk singer's second solo album is a dramatic change of pace, as she moves from spare acoustic folk into a lusty western swing idiom that shades into rockabilly on some cuts and toward the blues on others. Although it is a big stylistic leap, Ms. Shocked makes it feel perfectly natural. Her new songs, like those on her last album, are wry, feisty little vignettes with a populist political edge. Their blend of humor and social commentary as well as down-to-earth amiability give them much in common with Arlo Guthrie's work. ''God Is a Real Estate Developer'' takes a cheerful swipe at religious pieties, while the bitterly funny ''Streetcorner Ambassador'' compares gatherings of the homeless to diplomatic parleys. Her love songs have the same spirit of irreverent, tomboyish bravado. - Stephen Holden Miles Davis: 'Aura' Columbia 45332; all three formats. Since Miles Davis came out of retirement in the early 1980's, most of his albums have been duds that try to accommodate his trumpet playing to mechanical pop. ''Aura,'' recorded in 1984, is different: Mr. Davis sits in on an orchestral suite that Palle Mikkelborg wrote for him as a tribute. The music is eerie, often dissonant, by turns furious, brassy, choppy, floating; it provides windswept, wide-open spaces for trumpet ruminations. Freed by the compositions and nudged by John McLaughlin's electric guitar solos, Mr. Davis once again sounds like his music matters. - J. P. The Pastels: 'Sittin' Pretty' Homestead 144; all three formats. The Pastels, from Scotland, take a basically lazy approach to playing and writing rock and roll. They just plug in their electric guitars, turn up the distortion and barrel through punk-edged pop songs built on repeated riffs that bury Stephen Pastels's petulant vocals (and even the drums) in the fuzz-tone. ''Sittin' Pretty,'' their second album, has melodies as simple as nursery rhymes, cut to shreds by brazen, bullying guitar solos. But if the Pastels are bored with rock's inability to change the world, their brute-force passion is a slap in the face of acknowledged limitations. - Karen Schoemer

title: Psychoanalyzing Vienna and Its Oedipus Complex
description: FIFTY years after Freud died in London, Vienna is dutifully paying respect to its famous son. This fall a stream of exhibits and other commemorations has reminded the Viennese of their association with the founder of psychoanalysis, who lived in this city for 78 years. But psychoanalysts here say that behind Vienna's public acknowledgments is a deep ambivalence toward Freud and his ideas. Sometimes when they speak of the city, they sound as though they are discussing a neurotic patient with feelings of repression, denial and guilt.

title: Zambia's Social Fabric
description: On a wall of the Kafue Textile factory in Zambia there is a hand-drawn sign that proclaims the local design philosophy. ''Quality always wins,'' it reads. ''Quality is the best policy. Quality strengthens the nation.''

title: Behind the Scenes of Fund Raising
description: LEAD: EIGHT years ago at its first benefit dinner, the Tri-County Scholarship Fund raised $70,000. Last month its annual fund-raising event, attended by more than 600 guests, raised $350,000. William M. Kearns Jr., president of the Tri-County board for three years, says the dinner is now the largest nonpolitical single-time fund-raising event in the state.

title: Michigan Is Beaten In Tipoff
description: Shortly after the Michigan basketball team ended an hourlong workout Friday afternoon in preparation for its season opener with Arizona, Rumeal Robinson, the Wolverines' 6-foot-2-inch senior guard, spoke about the pressures of beginning the season as the defending national champion.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: BASIL FILARDI JR.;
The Changing Image of the Party Boss
description: LEAD: WHEN Basil Filardi Jr. first got involved with White Plains politics, Calvin Coolidge was President, women were just getting the right to vote and White Plains residents would not have dreamed of electing any Democrats.

title: Eastern and Union in Dispute Over Bomb Threat on Flight
description: Eastern Airlines blamed striking machinists for bomb threats against a flight today, claiming that their union was trying to frighten travelers.

title: Rather Than Pork, Seafood and Beans
description: PORK and beans is one thing, but fish with beans? Now that people are trying to cut down on fat (even in winter, when we crave sustaining food), there is no reason not to serve seafood instead of the usual pork, duck or ham with dried beans and peas.

title: Pastimes; Chess
description: It makes good sense to reverse the course of a game against the average opponent because the chances are he will either not catch on to the alteration of circumstances or be too slow or timid to react forcefully. But it is a different story if you are up against the world champion.

title: AN ANACHRONISM IN HIS OWN TIME
description: LEAD: HAROLD MACMILLAN Volume Two: 1957-1986. By Alistair Horne. Illustrated. 741 pp. New York: Viking. $27.50.

title: Are Many Salespeople Stumped?
description: In the beginning of the personal computer age, many executives were appalled at the low quality of sales help. Some salespeople could not answer basic questions. Worse, some passed off their wild guesses as expertise. As years went by, salespeople climbed the learning curve along with users, and it became fairly rare to find a dunce selling equipment in the major stores.

title: What Gorbachev Wants From the Pope
description: IT was Stalin who asked derisively how many divisions the Pope had. Now, a successor who would dismantle Stalin's legacy is about to journey to Rome, recognizing that what the Pope may lack in troop strength he compensates for with a moral and political force that even the Kremlin must respect.

title: Tracey B. Ozer Wed To Scott M. Schweber
description: Tracey Brooke Ozer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Ozer of Kings Point, L.I., was married last evening to Scott Michael Schweber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Schweber of Kings Point, at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub.

title: A Sampling of Spas
description: Viewed from afar, Czech and Hungarian spas seem oddly medicinal places. Government-approved brochures come laced with words like ''acidulous'' and ''anti-inflammatory'' and promise rejuvenated muscles, kidneys, blood and heart.

title: Marcos Associate Slips Back Into Manila
description: A business and political associate of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos has slipped into the Philippines in a homecoming that took the Government by surprise and raised the hopes of Marcos supporters.

title: Barbara Crafton, A Priest, Marries
description: The Rev. Barbara Cawthorne Crafton, an Episcopal priest, and Richard Edgecombe Quaintance Jr., a professor of English literature at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Metuchen, N.J. The Rev. Francis S. Cho, an Episcopal priest, officiated, assisted by the Revs. E. Walton Zelley, an Episcopal priest, and Paul K. Chapman, a Baptist minister.

title: The City's New Ethics: Too Strict, Too Loose Or Simply Confusing?
description: POSSIBLY as early as January, or maybe not until July, all New York City employees will come under new ethics rules restricting post-government employment that are stricter than the current rules, or maybe not strict enough.

title: Change in East Allows Earlier Word of Attack
description: Political changes in Eastern Europe, Soviet arms cuts and improved United States intelligence gathering mean that the Pentagon would now have a month or more of warning before a Soviet attack, intelligence experts believe. They previously expected only 14 days.

title: Fashion; Glamorous Comfort in Party Shoes
description: Holiday shoes for men and women are ornate yet practical this season. Women's shoes are lavishly embellished, but designed with low heels and high vamps. For men, the fussy dance pump with its round toe and grosgrain bow is supplemented with daytime styles - lace-up or slip-on - made in elegant materials like faille, satin or gleaming patent leather.

title: DIARY OF A WAR
description: LEAD: THE SECOND WORLD WAR A Complete History. By Martin Gilbert. Illustrated. 846 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $29.95.

title: Unnamed 'Healing Force' Makes Soviet TV Debut
description: Television viewers across the Soviet Union are being startled from their Sunday evening weather-forecast fare by a new program in which the Government has begun inviting them to consider thoughts of eternity and the soul.

title: Krone's Arm Hurt
description: The jockey Julie Krone suffered a fracture of her left forearm near the wrist and a dislocation of the left elbow Friday night when she was thrown from her horse and kicked in the sixth race at the Meadowlands.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
More for Less Coming in Huge Projects
description: LEAD: Among new residential projects on Long Island that are under construction or close to being started are several encompassing 500 units or more, including one that, if approved, will offer up to 12,000 housing units.

title: Nina L. Lobovsky Marries
description: Nina Lynn Lobovsky, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Lobovsky of Woodbury, L.I., was married last evening to David K. Chazen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Chazen of Hackensack, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Fogel officiated at Bob Gilbert's Singers Caterers in Spring Valley, N.Y. A graduate of the University of Maryland, Mrs. Chazen, 31 years old, is a district sales manager for Facit, a manufacturer of computer printers in Manchester, N.H. Her father is a physician in Hicksville, L.I. Mr. Chazen, 34, graduated from Antioch College and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. He practices law with his father in Englewood, N.J.

title: Rosalia P. Cavise, Nurse, to Marry
description: Rosalie Cavise of North Syracuse, N.Y., and Naples, Fla., has made known the engagement of her daughter Rosalia Patrice Cavise to Michael Benjamin Levy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Werner Levy of Forest Hills, Queens. A February wedding is planned.

title: Two Generations Encounter Death
description: A WAKE. Asleep . . . forever. Those images are engraved in my mind as clearly as the words that are etched on her tombstone.

title: WE NEVER UNDERSTOOD THE AYATOLLAH
description: IN THE NAME OF GOD The Khomeini Decade. By Robin Wright. Illustrated. 284 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: BARD OF THE STEWBUMS
description: NELSON ALGREN A Life on the Wild Side. By Bettina Drew. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $27.95.

title: I'd Help . . . If They'd Let Me
description: LEAD: My neighborhood, in Greenwich Village, isn't exactly exclusive, but until recently only a few transvestite prostitutes loitered on the streets. Now, disheveled sleepers are strewn across pieces of sodden cardboard, toxic-looking quilts, discarded couch pillows. Mornings, the security guard has to wake a few addicts in our communal yard.

title:
IN SHORT;
PARENTS AND CHILDREN
description: LEAD: VICKY LANSKY'S DIVORCE BOOK FOR PARENTS: Helping Your Children Cope With Divorce and Its Aftermath. By Vicky Lansky. (NAL Books, $18.95.) If divorce is in your present or near future and you have children, grit your teeth and read ''Vicky Lansky's Divorce Book for Parents'' through your tears and fears.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-29

title: Dr. King and Lord Byron
description: To the Editor:

title: In North Tarrytown, Hope and Fear Greet Development Plan
description: LEAD: The recent unveilng of a plan for new housing and a waterfront park in the dilapidated downtown area has raised both hope and fear from residents of this village.

title: Pastimes; Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If the Thanksgiving Day snow has melted, plant bulbs; they are better in the ground at this late date rather than tossed and forgotten in the back of a garage or toolshed. Be sure the compost pile is securely piled so it does not blow down or away in winter storms. Lightly prune rambler and climbing roses, if their canes are subject to wind damage. Clean and store all of the power equipment. The White Throats

title: From Obscurity to Spotlight, Urbanek Faces the Skeptics
description: Karel Urbanek, a Communist Party functionary unknown abroad and little known in his own nation before he was surprisingly chosen as Communist Party chief, found himself in his first day in office at the center of swelling criticism. He was forced to go on television to appeal to the Czechoslovak nation for understanding.

title: Israelis Hit Rebel Base In Lebanon a 2d Time
description: Israeli warplanes attacked a Palestinian guerrilla base for the second time in three days today, and the Lebanese police said the jets dropped time bombs that exploded as rescuers dug through the rubble.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $434,000 6 Meadow Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; fireplace, family room, rec room, brick patio, 2-car garage, 0.6 acre; taxes $6,116. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $465,000 White Birch Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 44-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, screened porch, pool, flagstone terrace, 5.05 acres; taxes $5,700. Waccabuc, N.Y. $465,000 37 Hunt Farm Road 4-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, year-old colonial; sunken living room, 2 fireplaces, beamed family room, screened porch, deck, 0.5 acre; taxes not yet assessed. Darien, Conn. $510,000 203 Hollow Tree Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; pool, c/a, electronic security, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,086. Farmington, Conn. $127,500 40 Oakland Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 49-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, deck, 2 acres; taxes $900. Wethersfield, Conn. $165,000 15 Edward Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; h/w floors; 4-zone heating, 2-car detached garage; taxes $1,566. OTHER AREAS Brookhaven, L.I. $259,000 5 Beaver Court 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; finished basement, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $3,800. East Massapequa, L.I. $140,000 690 Clark Boulevard 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old high ranch; den, dining room, patio; taxes $3,300. Rockaway, N.J. $177,500 20 Barry Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; full basement, eat-in kitchen, close to mass transit; taxes $3,146.

title: Union Square: Gritty Past, Bright Future
description: The people who live in the vicinity of Union Square are engaged in heated debate about the future of real estate development in their neighborhood. Some equate development with progress, saying that until the last few years the area was regarded by many as having no future at all; others worry that too much development will ruin its social and architectural diversity.

title: THE SAGE OF THE SKYLINE
description: LEAD: LEWIS MUMFORD A Life. By Donald L. Miller. Illustrated. 628 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $24.95.

title: Donna Downing Becomes a Bride
description: Donna Leigh Downing, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dana Duane Downing of Valparaiso, Ind., was married yesterday to Jonathan Conway, a son of Margaret Mary Conway of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Chester Joseph Conway. The Rev. John Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Search for a Missing Lobster Boat Goes On
description: The Coast Guard today expanded its air and sea search for five fishermen and their lobster boat, missing in the Atlantic for three days.

title: Louis Achitoff, 73, Aeronautics Expert
description: Louis Achitoff, a leading expert in aeronautical planning and flight operations, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Guardian Agency For the Retarded
description: LEAD: >HEN Lorraine Buckley began proceedings to adopt her son, Ethan, she was divorced and had no children. Ethan, who is now 18 years old, had Down's syndrome. The judge handling the case asked Mrs. Buckley what would become of Ethan if something happened to her.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ONCE BEFORE I GO. By Wayne Newton with Dick Maurice. (Morrow, $17.95.) Almost from the beginning of his career, the entertainer Wayne Newton has been a figure of fun. His weight (at one point a scale-rocketing 270 pounds), his high-pitched voice, his supposed effeminacy, his squeaky-clean image were all grist for the comic mill.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MARIA ZEF. By Paola Drigo. Translated by Blossom Steinberg Kirschenbaum. (University of Nebraska, Cloth, $24; Paper, $9.95.) Like Maria Zef, its eponymous protagonist, Paola Drigo's novel is, in a sense, an orphan. In 1938, two years after its publication to critical acclaim in her native Italy, Drigo, a short-story writer and novelist, died.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: Distant Secrets Unraveling the Mysteries of Our Ancient Past By Ronald Schiller Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group. 260 pages. $17.95.

title: Claudia Shaheen Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Claudia Elizabeth Shaheen to Jeffrey Sadler Morgan, the son of Mrs. E. Sadler Morgan of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Morgan, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. James William McEnery of Chapel Hill, N.C. A January wedding is planned. Miss Shaheen, also the daughter of the late Richard A. Shaheen, graduated from DePauw University. She is a vice president in the municipal bond department of Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. Her father was a broker of transactions involving media companies.

title: How to Beat Prepay Charge For Air Tickets
description: More and more airlines are assessing penalties, known as prepay charges, for travelers who book an advance-purchase seat through a travel agent but get the ticket issued at the airport. There is a way to get around the penalty, which is usually about $25, but it requires a bit of planning.

title: Shiitakes and Stress Down on the Farm
description: LEAD: A WET autumn is a boon to people who pick mushrooms in the woods, because moisture aids the growth of the tasty morsels. But it complicates life at Franklin Mushroom Farms in North Franklin, the largest above-ground mushroom producer in the nation.

title: A Short, Tragic Reign in Lebanon
description: WHATEVER hopes remained for Lebanon's new peace accord grew even darker last week as the country mourned one President and elected another.

title: IT GETS STARK EARLY
description: ANIMAL ACTS By Cris Mazza. 163 pp. New York: Fiction Collective. Distributed by Sun & Moon Press, Los Angeles. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Neo-Nebuchadnezzar
description: THE RESTORATION OF THE CITY of Babylon is likely the most long overdue project in history. It is the desire of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to restore from 2,000-year-old rubble (above, lower right) the glory of the city at its most glorious. The was during the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, Babylonia's ruler from 605 to 562 B.C.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: Yes, but it will have to wait until some of the more interesting and exciting sports like shuffleboard have had their day. WILLIAM R. SERPE New York

title: Masters Starting Its Last Stand
description: A prominent casualty of the war between past, present and future managers of men's tennis, the $3.1 million Nabisco Masters, will be played for the final time this week at Madison Square Garden. It will be the end of an era that spanned a dozen years in New York.

title: Jones Beach Shows: A Local Decision
description: In a comprehensive article about the Jones Beach theater contract [ ''Major Promoters Vying for Jones Beach Shows,'' Nov. 12 ] , an important point about the process by which New York State selects the entertainment for the theater appeared to have escaped your correspondent.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Begins 78th Appeal
description: The Christmas decorations that appeared everywhere last week, the throngs of shoppers, the anticipation of a joyous holiday season - none of this can camouflage the poverty and pain in the metropolitan area.

title: Scarsdale Bridal For Ellen Glaser
description: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., Ellen Glaser, a reporter for The Federal Times in Springfield, Va., was married last evening to Scott Rafshoon, a political reporter for The Free Lance-Star in Fredericksburg, Va. Rabbi Jack Stern and Cantor Stephen Merkel officiated.

title: CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
description: David Baltimore is well known to me and to many other scientists as an eminently honorable man (''Conduct Unbecoming,'' by Philip Weiss, Oct. 29). His scientific work on the enzyme reverse transcriptase is of enormous significance and may be a critical step in our ability ultimately to control AIDS. Now, because of some indiscretion of a colleague working in another laboratory, Dr. Baltimore has been dragged through the mud. Where is the sense of proportion? If Dr. Baltimore is outraged by this treatment, it is entirely justified. I am outraged for him.

title: Prospects; The Fed's Rate Dilemma
description: The consumer price index jumped 0.5 percentage points in October, indicating a 5.9 percent annual rate of inflation. The Federal Reserve Board has said it wants to keep inflation low. But with a weakening economy, its ability to stem inflation is limited. Four economists assess inflation and the Federal Reserve's next move. Francis Schott Chief economist, Equitable Life Assurance Society.

title: A Novel Competition
description: Many a benefactor of mankind would have been content with colorizing ''Casablanca.'' Not Ted Turner. The chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System last week announced a plan to set the world's most vivid imaginations to pondering how, as time goes by, the survival and prosperity of all life on earth can be assured. In the spring of 1991, the Turner Tomorrow Award - and a check for $500,000 - will go to the author of the winning work of fiction rrwith that happiest of endings. Four runners-up will receive $50,000 each and all five books will be published by a Turner subsidiary. In addition to a cash award that eclipses the Nobel Prize for Literature, the grand-prize winner will receive full screen credit if TBS makes a movie of the book. But there may be a catch: If the winner comes up with a workable plan for earth's survival, will Mr. Turner own the exclusive rights to its use?

title: A Ballet Is a Ballet Is a Masterpiece
description: No one makes ballets like ''A Wedding Bouquet'' anymore. Even Sir Frederick Ashton, who choreographed this beguiling business in 1937, never created another work that stood so apart - in its multiplicity of meaning, mix of hilarity and poignancy and, most unexpectedly, its amalgam of a modernist text by Gertrude Stein with the 300-year-old classical dance idiom.

title: Suppose the Town Was Promoting Insurrection
description: To the Editor:

title: The World of Endless Labels
description: There is another world out there - a recording world of totally unfamilar artists and record labels (and some familiar ones, too), and esoteric and specialized repertory. It is a world beyond what the major international companies generally turn out, a world where almost anything in sound can be found. Unfortunately, as a result in part of the staggering number of recordings sparked by the introduction of the compact disk, it is also a world too often only sparingly represented in most record stores around America, which can carry only a limited number of labels.

title: U.S. Said to Protect Witness to Killing of 6 Jesuits
description: A woman described as a witness to the killings of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador has come to the United States for her own safety, American officials and Jesuit leaders say.

title: Legal 2-Family Homes: The Time Is Now
description: Hurray for the Town of Huntington and Kenneth A. Christensen (''Restricting Illegal Apartments,'' Sept. 24), leaders in the legalizing of two-family dwellings.

title: Fright Mail
description: More than a fib but less than a fraud - that's how one member of Congress describes a postal phenomenon known as ''fright mail.'' These are solicitations sent out by organizations with names like the ''Social Security Protection Bureau'' or the ''Internal Review Service,'' often in official-looking envelopes bearing the notice: ''Official Business.''

title: Susan Morris Is Engaged
description: Susan Elaine Morris and Steven Smith, a son of Mr. and Stanley Smith of the Bronx, plan to marry in July, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Morris of Pittsburgh, have announced. Miss Morris, 25 years old, is an administrative assistant for employee benefits at the Burson Marsteller public relations company in New York. She attended the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Smith, 25 and a graduate of Queens College, is a payroll checker at The New York Times.

title: Pro Tennis Spurred by the Diversity of Its Stars
description: WHEN Billie Jean King thrashed

title: Restaurant Meals Going Door to Door for the Working Public
description: WHEN Duncan MacLaine and Charles Carafiello began Chefs' Express, a restaurant meal-delivery service, they said they thought their focus would be on food. The partners have discovered, however, that their three-month-old Hartsdale-based business fills more needs than the merely dietary.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
FONTS ANDPOINTS AND BITS AND BYTES
description: LEAD: Good typographic design, according to Edward Gottschall in TYPOGRAPHIC COMMUNICATIONS TODAY (MIT, $75), should achieve an artful balance between functional clarity and expressive vitality. This is easier said than done in an era of cultural pluralism. Today, designers must address multiple constituencies and work with rapidly evolving technologies.

title: Fashion; Fluffy Outerwear Invades City Streets
description: Retailers of haute couture for the outdoors say the vibrantly colored plush garments made by the nation's largest manufacturers of ski and camping wear have outstripped woolens as the insulation of choice not only on the slopes but also on city sidewalks.

title: A HEATED RIVALRY IN THE 80's
description: A generation ago, the big rivals for the Giants were the Cleveland Browns. After that, the Giants' main rivalries were with the Dallas Cowboys and then the Washington Redskins.

title: Review/Cabaret; Chita Rivera a la Vaudeville
description: Chita Rivera, at age 56, personifies the tough-as-nails show-business trouper determined to stay on the boards as long as she can kick up her heels and play the raucous life of the party.

title: PRESSURING PERDUE
description: HENRY SPIRA WORKS FROM home, a roomy rent-controlled apartment on Manhattan's Upper West Side that looks like an office first, a cat playground second, and his residence only as an afterthought. One room is dominated by word-processing equipment. A second is filled with floor-to-ceiling shelves laden with files. And in the living room, where an immense worktable stretches along one wall, the furniture consists of an old couch and two chairs covered in Naugahyde (leather is not an option here). Pictures of Siamese cats hang over the fireplace and a cat jungle gym dominates the hall. From this Spartan dwelling Spira (pronounced SPEE-ra) has run a major command post in this country's rapidly growing animal-rights movement. The burly 62- year-old ex-seaman and former high school teacher says he first became interested in animal rights in the early 1970's, after a girlfriend left him with her cat: ''I began to wonder about the appropriateness of cuddling one animal while sticking a knife and fork into another,'' recalls Spira, who since then has always had one or two cats in his house.

title: THE KIMBELL MUSEUM
description: A Kahn Favorite

title: U.S. Aide Sees Unification
description: The reunification of Germany is inevitable, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said in an interview published today.

title: A Correction
description: The name of one of the writers of a letter published Nov. 19 under the subheading ''Northern Bigotry'' did not appear correctly. He is Michael J. Graetz, Justus S. Hotchkiss Professor of Law at Yale University.

title: Risks of Betting On Your Team
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Where Foster Children Become Family
description: LEAD: EVERY couple of hours, Barbara Kenyon uses a plastic tube from a portable suction unit to loosen the phlegm in her adopted son's windpipe. The boy, Ian Michael, 4 years old, who wears a plastic necklace with a circular opening at the base of the throat, also needs a controlled household temperature in order to thrive.

title: New Japan Car War Weapon: A 'Little Engine That Could'
description: Having attracted American buyers for years with high quality and reliability, Japanese auto makers are now moving to win sales with a new competitive edge: technically advanced engines that burn fuel more efficiently and produce more power than most American engines.

title: THIS IS NOT REAL
description: Smoke issued from vents, as a kaleidoscope of lights flashed wildly. Two hulking figures brimming with human meanness, with painted faces and Mohawk haircuts and encased in black vests decorated with metal studs, commenced an ominous walk down a black ramp toward the ring. Thumping rock music bounced off the ceiling, and as the pair neared the ring, fireworks exploded over their heads.

title: A Potpourri of Questions From Readers
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Soon after we moved into our new home, a wood toilet paper roller was accidentally flushed down the toilet. All attempts to remove this with a snake have failed. Sometimes the toilet flushes O.K. and other times not. Do you know of anything that would dissolve the roller?

title:
Critics Pick Some Favorites Of the Year;
 Revelatory Americana By Two Masters
description: LEAD: Any pick of the last year's best cannot ignore Roger Norrington's ''Symphonie Fantastique,'' which provides compelling evidence of the historical-performance movement's new maturity. Mr. Norrington treats this archetypal Romantic work to a performance every bit as surprising and dramatic as his reading of the Beethoven symphonies.

title: James Casey Engaged To Kathleen McMahon
description: Mr. and Mrs. William McMahon of Roselle, N.J., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter Kathleen Marie McMahon and James Michael Casey, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Casey of the Bronx.

title: Critics Pick Some Favorites Of the Year; New Energy From Pop By Droll Rappers
description: Cold fusion may not have worked in science labs this year, but late-1980's popular music has been happily knocking together genres to release new energy. De La Soul's ''3 Feet High and Rising'' (Tommy Boy 1019) sets three calm, droll rappers amid unexpected borrowings; its loopy playfulness and peace-symbol graphics were quickly dubbed ''hippie-hop.'' Caetano Veloso's ''Estrangeiro'' (Elektra/Musician 60898) is a collaboration between a great Brazilian songwriter and the New York-based Ambitious Lovers, its producers; it brings a hint of North American noise to his supple melodies. ''Poi Dog Pondering'' (Columbia 45335), founded in Hawaii and now based in Austin, Tex., turns pop, rock and Caribbean music into a kind of post-modern skiffle with an irrepressible, unforced optimism. And Kanda Bongo Man's irresistibly infectious ''Kwassa Kwassa'' (Hannibal 1343) shows what happens when Zairean traditions - sweet voices, long-lined melodies and circular riffs - are plugged in to high-tech sound and gleaming electric guitars.

title: A Town Where the Mayor Oversees Crime
description: The real crime capital of the world may be a small town nestled in a rural Virginia forest where bank robberies, kidnappings and deadly extortion plots are running rampant. The town's mayor shrugs it off with a serene smile.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Bruce Cohen was astonished. Here it was, a week still to go until Thanksgiving, and there he was, that hefty, white-bearded, familiar-looking fellow sporting the red suit, sitting smack in the center of the East Brunswick (N.J.) Mall, surrounded by dancing elves. Dancing elves before Thanksgiving? Someone out there is jumping the cap-gun again, and not just in New Jersey.

title: BERN
description: The Bernese may have a reputation for staidness, but they did noticeably rejoice when a female among the brown Alpine bears that are kept in a pit near the Nydegg Bridge whelped early this year. There had been no cubs in 1988, and the happy event was felt to augur well for Switzerland's capital. The bear is Bern's emblem; the city's name is believed to be derived from the German word for bear. Bern's yellow-red coat of arms shows the totem animal marching upward, its red tongue jutting out of a black head.

title: Critics Pick Some Favorites Of the Year;  Luminous Mendelssohn Led by Mackerras
description: The record that gave me the greatest pleasure and demanded the most repeated listening this year was Sir Charles Mackerras's second CD outing with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment, a luminous Mendelssohn ''Italian'' Symphony paired with a light-textured, elfin performance of eight extracts from the ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' incidental music (Virgin VC 7 90725). I also admired Yo-Yo Ma's collaboration with David Zinman and the Baltimore Symphony in Barber's lyrical Cello Concerto and the Britten Cello Symphony (CBS MK 44900), and the Emerson Quartet's gripping but warm-toned traversal of the Bartok String Quartets (Deutsche Grammophon 423 657).

title: Jordan Leads Bulls to 104-91 Victory
description: Michael Jordan's 29 points, 14 rebounds and 9 assists led the Chicago Bulls to a 104-91 victory over the Golden State Warriors today.

title: CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
description: Representative John Dingell's singular ambition has been to expand his power base by grabbing any issue that is related to energy and commerce and letting loose his army of investigators. Issues that do not interest the news media are discarded. Mr. Dingell needs to be taken down a peg, but none of the Democratic leadership has had the courage to rein in this modern day McCarthyite. MARK G. MAZZIE Scottsdale, Ariz.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;
Small Plants Become Big Business
description: LEAD: Indoor plants are becoming smaller. Growers are finding that scaled-down replicas of larger-size flowering plants have appeal and they are meeting the demands.

title:
The View From: Scarsdale;
Paddle Tennis, a 'Social Game,' Is Getting Revived Support
description: LEAD: PADDLE, anyone?

title: Legislators Take First Step to Change Leadership
description: THE Board of Legislators, seeking what some members said was a much-needed bipartisan spirit, took steps to change its leadership last week as it began work on reducing the county's first $1 billion budget.

title: Review/Opera; New Leads In 'Frau'
description: Bare competence does not harm operas like ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten,'' but the three new singers in the Metropolitan Opera's current production of Strauss's opera hardly did it much good.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
2d Upscale Rental Tower for Hackensack
description: LEAD: Over the last two decades, a legion of high-rise residential condominiums and cooperatives has sprung up in Hackensack, with many along a four-block stretch of Prospect Avenue on a ridge overlooking the city. Now work is about to begin on an upscale 18-story rental apartment tower, an almost-twin to one completed last year.

title:
RECORDINGS;
The Two Sides of One Man's Music
description: LEAD: Don't try to tell John Adams that a refined, understated work like ''The Wound Dresser'' is intrinsically more worthy than a raucous, irreverent one like ''Fearful Symmetries.'' He would disagree, claiming to prefer the nose-thumbing aspect of his compositional psyche. ''The vulgar side of my musical personality is what I consider to be the really healthy part,'' he says.

title: Campus Life: Washington; Fans and Police Clash as Goal Post Is Uprooted, Prompting an Inquiry
description: A clash between fans who tore down a goal post after a University of Washington football victory and campus police officers who tried to stop them has left the police defending their actions and the university's president calling for a committee to review the incident.

title: U.S. May Cut Dues to U.N. Over Arab Resolution
description: The United States will drastically cut funds to the Rome-based United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization if the agency agrees next week to cooperate with the Palestine Liberation Organization on agricultural development in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Administration officials say.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DOUBLESPEAK. By William Lutz. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) Disguising a tax increase as ''revenue enhancement'' fools no one these days. But do you know what a ''portable, hand-held communications inscriber'' is? or a ''hexiform rotatable surface compression unit?'' How about a ''manually-powered fastener-driving impact device''?

title: Charter Fishing Boats Feeling the Pinch
description: LEAD: AFTER a disappointing summer season, the skippers of many charter fishing boats at the eastern tip of Long Island are apprehensive about next year and the seasons after that.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DANIEL J. CENSULLO;
At the Helm of Improvements to PATH
description: LEAD: DANIEL J. CENSULLO is known at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as ''The Builder.'' His construction skills were learned as a student at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken. He got his degree in mechanical engineering there in 1960, and the same year, he went to work for the Port

title: State's Elderly Gain Influence As Lobby Group
description: WHEN the House of Representatives approved a measure to expand the Medicare program to protect older Americans from the high cost of acute extended illness, all 14 members of the New Jersey delegation voted for it. But when the House voted to repeal or curtail the Catastrophic Coverage Act last month, all 14 largely abandoned it.

title: Leonard Boudin, Civil Liberties Lawyer, Dies at 77
description: Leonard B. Boudin, a civil liberties lawyer who in more than 50 years of practice defended a number of controversial clients, including Julian Bond, Paul Robeson, Benjamin Spock and Daniel Ellsberg, died at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan late Friday after a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: Apartheid Foes Are Tear-Gassed
description: The police fired tear gas today into a church hall where four recently released anti-apartheid campaigners were about to give speeches. None of the four was injured, but two other people were shot dead at the scene, the South African Press Association said.

title: The Vietnam War Is A Newsletter's Focus
description: LEAD: THE Vietnam War ended more than 15 years ago, but thousands of veterans across the country continue to read about postwar issues in a newsletter and mail-order book service run by Thomas Hebert of Burlington.

title: A Look at Fuji's Expanding U.S. Role
description: WHEN Osamu Inoue was an undergraduate majoring in business administration at Kobe University in Japan, he set his sights on a career that would take him beyond the borders of Japan into international markets.

title: N. Carolina Defeats Villanova
description: Rick Fox scored 23 points, including the 3-pointer that gave North Carolina the lead for good as the Tar Heels beat Villanova, 78-68, in the semifinals of the Maui Classic.

title: East Europe Mostly Likes Our Life Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Sour Column
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ms. Babits to Marry Dean M. Vogel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steven L. Babits of Cranford, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan N. Babits to Dean M. Vogel, the son of Adelene Hall Vogel of Cranford, N.J., and Grafton, Vt., and Harold A. Vogel Jr. of Bedminster, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: Timeless Tales for Older Audiences
description: LEAD: AS the audience filed in for a storytelling program in New Milford recently that was billed as adult-only entertainment, Carol Birch was surprised by the questions several people asked her. ''Five people asked me if I was going to tell X-rated material,'' said Ms. Birch, a storyteller from Southbury.

title: At Nurse's Trial, Questions of Intent
description: LEAD: Since Oct. 19, when Richard J. Angelo, a former nurse, went on trial on charges of murdering four patients and assaulting three others at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip two years ago, a parade of witnesses has given volumes of testimony.

title: Correction
description: A headline last Sunday about the Rev. Leonid Kishkovsky, an Orthodox priest, described the National Council of Churches incorrectly. It links 32 Christian denominations, not just Protestants.

title: Cayton Welcomes Tyson Inquiry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pennsylvania County Rejects Displaying of Nativity Scene
description: Officials of Allegheny County have decided not to set up a Nativity scene this year, even though the Supreme Court of the United States ruled that a display surrounded by reindeer and Santa Claus would be permissible.

title: Despite Rocky Season, 49ers Take Firm Stand
description: Bubba Paris is planning a way for you to become more familiar with the San Francisco 49ers. Paris said that you can soon do this by dialing a 900 number that he will answer.

title: Basque In It
description: AS I WAS DRIVING THROUGH Nevada recently, a highway billboard proclaimed ''Winnemucca -If You Don't Visit, Who Will?'' That pessimistic plea did not prepare us for the extraordinary Basque meal we had in a restaurant tucked off the main street of this small town in the northern part of the state.

title: Veteran Is Helping Others to Get Benefits
description: WHETHER he is helping them find jobs or cutting through red tape to expedite benefits long overdue, Bill Howard says that New Jersey veterans today are in need of extraordinary help.

title: IN THE CELLAR, STELLAR MATCHUP
description: The bangled, baubled rookie Falcons' cornerback, Deion Sanders, and the cool, no-frills Jets' wide receiver, Al Toon, get together at Giants Stadium today.

title: PANEL THROWS OUT VOTE RESULT IN GANDHI'S DISTRICT
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's chances of remaining in power after this week's national election were set back today when India's Election Commission ordered new polling in 97 stations in Mr. Gandhi's constituency because of rigging and intimidation by his ruling Congress Party.

title: New York City Faulted on Slow Construction
description: Less than one-tenth of New York City's municipal construction projects are completed on schedule, and more than half are not even under construction when they should be finished, according to a report by a private civic group.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Carol Heher Wed To David Peters
description: The marriage of Carol Anne Heher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Heher Jr. of Princeton, N.J., to David Lamborn Peters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Landon Peters of Princeton, took place yesterday at the Edith Memorial Chapel of the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School. The Rev. Patrick Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Peters, 28 years old, is a graduate of the Stuart Country Day School and Clark University. She is a leasing consultant for the Linpro Company, a real-estate development concern in Plainsboro, N.J. Her father is a partner in the Princeton law firm of Heher, Clarke & St. Landau. Her mother, Marian D. Heher, is a reading teacher in the Trenton public schools. The bride is a granddaughter of the late Justice Harry Heher of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Maria Lambros,Violist, Marries
description: Maria Daniel Lambros, a violist with the Ridge String Quartet in New York, and Michael Steven Kannen, a cellist in New York, were married last evening at Bargemusic in Brooklyn by the Rev. James Grant, a Unitarian minister.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: OF SUCH SMALL DIFFERENCES, by Joanne Greenberg. (Signet/New American Library, $4.50.) John Moon, a young poet who is both deaf and blind, falls in love with an actress. As in her earlier book ''I Never Promised You a Rose Garden'' (written under the name Hannah Green), Joanne Greenberg ''calls attention to the slow, painful movement that charts our struggles from isolation toward connectedness,'' Richard Perry said here last year. PARTING THE WATERS: America in the King Years 1954-63, by Taylor Branch. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) In his Pulitzer Prize-winning historyJU of the civil rights movement, Taylor Branch tells how J. Edgar Hoover persuaded Robert Kennedy to let him tap Martin Luther King's telephone by agreeing to keep quiet about President John F. Kennedy's affair with a suspected spy. ''Mr. Branch's wide-ranging search into the details of King's life converges with the onrushing tide that swept up both King and country for a few years of concentrated time,'' Eleanor Holmes Norton said in The Book Review in 1988. ''Mr. Branch, with painstaking research, has reached into the crevices where much of the change occurred. There he has found human dramas of heroism and pettiness, of determination and bewilderment.'' THE RISK POOL, by Richard Russo. (Vintage, $8.95.) When it is time for college, Ned Hall chooses a school as far as possible from his hometown of Mohawk in upstate New York, where his father is a drunk and his mother is strung out on Librium. ''This is a superbly original, maliciously funny book, peopled by characters that most of us would back away from plenty fast if they ever lurched toward our barstool,'' Jack Sullivan said here last year. Vintage has also republished Mr. Russo's first novel, MOHAWK ($8.95), about life in the same dying town. In 1986 The Times's Michiko Kakutani said the story ''has the lonely, melancholy feel of an Edward Hopper painting come to life.'' ABRAHAM LINCOLN: A Press Portrait, edited by Herbert Mitgang. (University of Georgia, $17.95.) Drawing from articles in nearly 100 newspapers and magazines, a New York Times reporter assembled an account of Abraham Lincoln's career as seen through the eyes of reporters. The same publisher has reissued two other journalistic views of Lincoln and his time, also edited by Herbert Mitgang. WASHINGTON, D.C., IN LINCOLN'S TIME ($14.95) is based on the observations of Noah Brooks, who used his friendship with the President to gain entry to the White House. In SPECTATOR OF AMERICA ($14.95), a British journalist, Edward Dicey, tells about a six-month swing through the country during the Civil War. When these books were published as a set in 1971, our reviewer, Gerald Carson, said they ''illuminate as only contemporary writings can the character of Lincoln and his America.'' THE KING OF THE FIELDS, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) In prehistoric Poland, the Lesniks, a tribe of cave-dwelling hunters and gatherers, fight the farmers, who call themselves Poles after pola, the word for field. Last year our reviewer, Ewa Kuryluk, called this ''a truly absurd fairy tale of sex and violence. . . . The strength of I. B. Singer's novel comes from the language.'' RACIAL HYGIENE: Medicine Under the Nazis, by Robert Proctor. (Harvard University, $14.95.) Defining Nazism as applied biology, the scientists and doctors of the Third Reich set out to cure the German ''folk body'' of people they considered infestations. ''Mr. Proctor's carefully argued book not only forces us to reassess the dynamics of Nazism but also challenges pervasive notions about the political neutrality and objective value of science and the moral innocence of scientists,'' Mary Nolan said in The Book Review last year. THOUGHT REFORM AND THE PSYCHOLOGY OF TOTALISM: A Study of ''Brainwashing'' in China, by Robert Jay Lifton. (University of North Carolina, $14.95.) In a new introduction to his case studies about victims of Chinese ''thought reform,'' Robert Jay Lifton says the lessons can be applied to American religious cults. In 1961 our reviewer, C. M. Wilbur, predicted that the book would become ''a classic in social-science literature because the problems with which it deals so well extend far beyond . . . China in the early 1950's.'' THE ELEPHANT AND MY JEWISH PROBLEM: Selected Stories and Journals 1957-1987, by Hugh Nissenson. (Edward Burlingame/Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) In a collection of short pieces, some fictional, some true, Hugh Nissenson writes about the difficulties of believing in a God who created such a messy world. Mr. Nissenson's prose ''often serves to heighten the emotional and physical violence it describes,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. AMERICA OBSERVED: From the 1940s to the 1980s, by Alistair Cooke. Edited by Ronald A. Wells. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) Alistair Cooke's essays give a British perspective on the Watts riots, Frank Lloyd Wright, Chappaquiddick and other American topics. ''The subjects are often the ones you would expect, but the pictures themselves . . . are usually taken from an angle that is all the more revealing for being idiosyncratic,'' John Gross said in The Times last year. THE OLD CAPITAL, by Yasunari Kawabata. Translated by J. Martin Holman. (North Point, $8.95.) A young Japanese woman learns that as an infant she was left on the doorstep of the man she now considers her father, a kimono maker in Kyoto. In 1987 our reviewer, Mary Jo Salter, said this novel would be most appreciated by readers already familiar with the Nobel Prize-winning author's other work, which includes ''A Thousand Cranes'' and ''Snow Country.''

title: At 50, Museum Shows Off Wares
description: LEAD: THE Museums at Stony Brook is celebrating its golden anniversary with ''Fifty Years of Collecting,'' an exhibition with a dual purpose:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing; A DazzlinHoliday Show, Free
description: The holiday season is, of course, a time for shopping - and window shopping.

title: ACROSS THE KREMLIN'S BACK FENCE
description: LEAD: VOICES OF GLASNOST Interviews With Gorbachev's Reformers. By Stephen F. Cohen and Katrina vanden Heuvel. Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: W.W. Norton. $19.95.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: On the very first page of THE TITAN GAME by Niven Busch (Random House, $17.95), it is clear that we are in the presence of a real writer. The topic is weapons. ''Never before in history had there been such a glut of weapons of all kinds: weapons lurking with eyes agleam in the black holes of outer space; weapons that could pop out of the void and kill at ten times the speed of sound; weapons as small as pinheads and as big as cathedrals; . . . weapons that could be slung on dogs, elephants, mules, goats, dolphins, or even children; weapons. . . .'' And so on for another hundred or so well-chosen words.

title: Plan for Sun-Hogging Tower Angers Kenyans
description: The construction of the tallest office tower in Africa on a sprawling, tree-studded city park here has provoked unusual popular hostility in a country where opposition to official projects is voiced with care.

title: Knicks Roll to Easy Victory Over Bucks
description: There is a new coach, and a new emphasis on halfcourt offense and defense instead of on the press. But the Knicks' homecourt supremacy, which helped them attain their best record since the 1972-73 season last year, continues.

title: FICTION
description: THE PARADISE MOTEL. By Eric McCormack. (Viking, $17.95.) Eric McCormack's brilliant and unsettling first novel steeps itself in mystery, horror and suspense to tell a story about the very art of storytelling. Each character in ''The Paradise Motel'' is a teller of tales, which makes them all liars, and no one's words are to be trusted. As one of these fabulists puts it, words are the most dangerous weapons: ''They penetrate, like skewers, and they can kill.'' Ezra Stevenson is not so much the narrator of the events as the gatherer of the tales, the keeper of the weapons. He receives this calling from his grandfather, who delivers on his deathbed a gruesome story of domestic violence in which four young children are hideously victimized. Feeling compelled either to verify or to disprove the appalling facts of the case, Ezra embarks on a mythic journey to faraway lands, searching for the lost children and finding, instead, more stories and more storytellers. From such mysterious characters as Dr. Yerdeli of the Institute for the Lost and an ''intellectual boxer'' named Pablo Renowsky, Ezra hears poisonous anecdotes about murder, suicide, torture, self-immolation, sadism and ecstasy. In the end, it is the shapers of these stories who become the true subjects of the novel, and it is these poets of the perverse who suffer most from their own creations. The reader should not be surprised, then, that when Ezra finally finds the lost children of the original story, their meeting at the ironically named Paradise Motel becomes the storyteller's ultimate nightmare.

title: ITALY COMMUNISTS WILL CHANGE NAME
description: Swept by the tornado of events in Eastern Europe, the Italian Communist Party, largest in the West, has formally decided to change its name and its identity, down to the hammer-and-sickle emblem.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: OFFICIALLY it is New Jersey State Prison, but more often than not it's called Trenton, the end of the line, the toughest maximum-security prison in New Jersey, a place from which, it is said, there are only two ways out: over the wall or with a toe tag.

title: Gifts Worth Their Weight in Your Luggage
description: Travel-related gifts clog shop counters and leap off the pages of countless catalogues, especially around Christmas. Finding ones that are worth their weight in your luggage is the trick. Here are a few good ideas for this year, some from exotic sources.
