title: A Century's Worth Of Decoys Alight At the Peabody
description: The most memorable carved and painted ducks, geese and shorebirds exhibited in ''Tollers and Tattlers: Massachusetts Waterfowl Decoys 1840-1940,'' at the Peabody Museum here, are rarely the prettiest or most realistic renderings. Of the 193 decoys shown, the most compelling are the working varieties made for hunters, to pull birds from the sky. The show, the museum's largest on this subject in its 190-year history, is to remain for three years.

title:
IN SHORT;
PARENTS AND CHILDREN
description: LEAD: THE CASE AGAINST DIVORCE. By Diane Medved. (Donald I. Fine, $18.95.) Breaking up ought to be much harder to do, says Diane Medved. Using breathless magazine-style prose, the author, a clinical psychologist, advances a prefeminist ideal of matrimony in ''The Case Against Divorce,'' an ideal in which women nest and nurture (and sometimes get to have great jobs), are grateful for stability and protection and quit their jobs when their men get too insecure.

title: The U.S. Shouldn't Abdicate Leadership
description: The startling changes sweeping across Eastern Europe have evoked two inconsistent reactions in Washington, an exhilarating sense of historic opportunity and a debilitating sense of the limits of our resources and power.

title: Hopping Mad
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Ties
description: A dispute over who gave birth to 11-year-old Kimberly Michelle Mays has ended. A point was proved, but nobody won. Genetic tests showed 10 days ago that Kimberly was not the biological daughter of Robert and Barbara Mays, the Sarasota, Fla., couple who raised her from birth. Mr. Mays, whose wife died of cancer in 1981, broke his silence on the issue last week, saying that when he told Kimberly of the test results, ''She said, 'Daddy, daddy, what does this mean?' '' It meant that Kimberly was born to Ernest and Regina Twigg of Sebring, Fla., in the same hospital where, three days earlier, Mrs. Mays also gave birth to a daughter. Just before the child they reared died of heart failure last year, the Twiggs learned through blood tests that she was not theirs. They contended that the hospital had switched babies. Mr. Mays consented to the genetic tests provided that the Twiggs agree not to seek custody. Now, he said, ''It's over. It's time for both sides to just think of her.''

title: Paying for Oil-Troubled Waters
description: The wreck of the Exxon Valdez eight months ago in Alaska's Prince William Sound caused America's largest oil spill and may yet turn out to be America's most costly environmental disaster. But it has yielded a measure of redemption, jolting Congress into writing credible legislation that would greatly increase the cost of carelessness by shippers and producers of oil.

title: DATABANK: Nov. 26, 1989
CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
description: If, as Philip Weiss states, Margot O'Toole was ''highly regarded'' as a scientist, why doesn't she get a job in Walter Stewart's or Ned Feder's lab? Or with one of the professors at Rockefeller University who opposed David Baltimore's appointment?

title: Streetscapes: U.S. Rubber Company Building; Restoring Luster to a 1912 Lady
description: The 20-story headquarters Carrere & Hastings created in 1912 for the U.S. Rubber Company at 1790 Broadway, at 58th Street, is a building of discreet qualities. It cannot claim any superlatives, and most of the guidebooks omit it, but it has what many better known buildings lack, good manners.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Soon after we moved into our new home, a wood toilet paper roller was accidentally flushed down the toilet. All attempts to remove this with a snake have failed. Sometimes the toilet flushes O.K. and other times not. Do you know of anything that would dissolve the roller?

title: The Met on Radio And Its Impact On American Taste
description: When America - or at least opera-loving America - hunkers down before the family radio console this Saturday afternoon, it will be celebrating more than the advent of yet another national broadcast season of the Metropolitan Opera. This season marks the 50th anniversary of Texaco's sponsorship of the broadcasts, an astonishing span in the flighty history of American corporate arts support, and the period in which the broadcasts took on the well-loved form they retain to this day.

title: That Other Time Censorship Stormed Into the Corcoran Gallery
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CHORUS TO SING BLOCH

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Baby Struck With Metal Pipe
description: A 4-month-old boy was in critical condition last night after he was struck on the head with a metal pipe during an argument between two men in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the police said. The baby was taken to Coney Island Hospital after the argument in an apartment at 3081 Cropsey Avenue. One man was apparently holding the baby when the other swung the pipe, a police spokesman, Sgt. Edward Burns, said. One man was treated for a minor head wound, while the other was being questioned at the 60th Precinct.

title: A New Breed of Dieter Watches Weight at the Workpalce
description: Men are more likely to join weight-control programs held at their workplace than those that meet in their community. That is what the Diet Workshop branch in Dayton, Ohio, which is considered the fattest state, has discovered. Males account for 33 percent of the 400 people enrolled in its workplace programs, but make up only 9 percent of the 3,200 dieters in its standard program. ''If it becomes hot on a particular floor or within a department, there is camaraderie,'' said Joyce Kasprzak, the director of the Dayton branch. ''All it takes is the first man.''

title: Ruth Michelson, Law Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mark Michelson of Brookline, Mass., have announced January wedding plans for their daughter Ruth Leah Michelson and David Kahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kahan of Brookline.

title: No Drug Found in Falcon
description: Medical investigators said today that the Falcons' rookie offensive tackle Ralph Norwood had apparently not taken drugs or alcohol before he was killed in an automobile crash eight miles from the Falcons' training center.

title: Outdoors; Unusual Repasts With Foragers
description: I have before me a series of snapshots of a mink trying to yank a pickerel from an angler's hand.

title: Slumping Rangers Stumble in Toronto
description: The Rangers squandered an early 2-0 lead and lost, 7-4, to Toronto tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens.

THE PEOPLE: And Uncollected Stories, by Bernard Malamud.

title: Correction
description: A chart last Sunday about Vietnamese refugees arriving in three Asian countries was incorrectly labeled. The numbers were in thousands.

title: A Stellar Quartet Offers Brahms
description: ISAAC STERN, Jaime Laredo, Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax are scheduled to record the two Brahms Piano Quartets, but before that they have decided to play the towering masterworks in concert. One of the concerts will be at 8 P.M. Friday in Woolsey Hall in New Haven (432-4159). The other will be at 3 P.M. next Sunday at the Stamford Center for the Arts (325-4466).

title: Frank Southard, 82, Economist
description: Frank A. Southard Jr., a former senior official of the International Monetary Fund, died of cancer today at a hospital near his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Project Tailored To Space Limits
description: SEATTLE'S largest developer, Martin Selig, has come forward with the first major project proposed under new building-size restrictions. Mr. Selig, who has erected more than 6 million square feet, or about a third of the downtown office market, is proposing a $25-million, 10-story building with 268,000 square feet of offices, retail space and restaurants.

title: DICK SCHULTZ FOLLOWED HIS IDEALS
description: Not everybody could sign a $1 billion television contract and chill out the beer industry at the same time, but Dick Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, managed that feat last week.

title: Cautious Slovaks Yearn for a Bit of Breathing Room
description: Unlike their Czech countrymen in Prague, 175 miles to the northwest, few Slovaks in this city of 500,000 on the Danube rushed into the streets singing and dancing last night when the resignation of the party leadership was announced.

title: Law Professor Takes Soviets by Storm With Crisp Oratory and Hard Work
description: The fastest rising political star in the Soviet Union is not a Communist Party luminary, flamboyant populist, angry dissident or smoldering nationalist.

title: The Bishop and the Truce of Tolerance
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of San Diego has denied communion to Lucy Killea, a state Assemblywoman, because as a candidate for California's Senate she strongly advocates the pro-choice position in the abortion debate.

title:
GARDENING;
Was It Pumpkin? Or Was It Squash?
description: LEAD: PUMPKIN PIE is a fall favorite as well as a tradition for Thanksgiving. When topped by a dollop of whipped cream or a scoop of ice cream, it's hard to beat. But was that really pumpkin pie you had on Thursday?

title:
IN SHORT;
PARENTS AND CHILDREN
description: LEAD: MY ONE AND ONLY: The Special Experience of the Only Child. By Ellie McGrath. (Morrow, $16.95.) This is a comprehensive look at the single-child family, an increasingly common phenomenon among those who want it all - career, family, marriage, achievement and one college education to pay for. Ellie McGrath aims to set the record straight: only children are not necessarily spoiled, overly dependent, obnoxiously precocious, lonely people freighted with unrealistic parental expectations.

title: One-Man Effort to Attract Engineers
description: SEVERAL years ago, the daughter of Arthur Freed, chief of operations for the County Department of Public Works, told a high school guidance counselor that she wanted to be an engineer like her father.

title: Art Museum Without the Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Liquid Protein: The Diet of the Stars
description: Baby boomers may prefer the concept of weight control to the diet, but they still love a good fad. Among the fastest-growing crazes to fight fat is the liquid protein diet, or very-low-calorie diet, as it is also known. Sales of these liquid proteins have grown to $5 billion a year since the late 1970's. The most explosive growth, the industry says, has occurred in the last year, and has attracted several new contenders to the field.

title: Foul-Ball Damages
description: Few legal principles are as established as the one that holds that when you go to a baseball game you accept the risk of being hit by a foul ball. Courts have held so over and over. But that particular judicial word has not gotten through to a court in Chicago. Last week, a Cook County Circuit Court jury awarded a 16-year-old boy, Delbert Yates Jr., $67,500 of Cubs money for damages suffered when he was hit by a foul ball at Wrigley Field in 1983, when he was 10 years old.

title: Dragging The Ocean For Winter's Bounty
description: AFTER spending more than a month overhauling and winterizing his fishing boat, ET, Tony Sougstad is ready for the rugged season.

title: Invest at Home for Influence Abroad
description: The United States is acting like a poor country when it is not one. Washington sits virtually paralyzed as the world is stunned daily by events in East Europe. Paris called a conference among its European colleagues and West Germany has already announced plans to spend billions of dollars on investment in East Germany. The Japanese will not be far behind, and some conjecture they will soon be ahead. By contrast, the leaders of the country that is still by far the richest in the world - the United States - are consumed by cutting a few billion dollars of spending from a $5 trillion economy.

title: Perez's $5.7 Million Pact Is Only at Tip of Iceberg
description: Fifty-nine pitchers earned more money than Pascual Perez did last year.

title: Miss Kuehn Plans a Winter Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernd P. Kuehn of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Westerly, R.I., have announced February wedding plans for their daughter Catherine Elizabeth Kuehn and Malcolm Keith Price, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Price of Ballarat, Victoria, Australia.

title: Georgia Southern Subdues Villanova
description: Joe Ross rushed for 190 yards and two touchdowns as Georgia Southern defeated Villanova, 52-36, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.

title: Salo W. Baron, 94, Scholar of Jewish History, Dies
description: Prof. Salo Wittmayer Baron, who was recognized as one of the century's great historical scholars for his sweeping multivolume history of the Jews, died of congestive heart failure early yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
description: Representative Dingell's ''most feared'' reputation derives from his low tolerance for deceipt, and his unceasing efforts to protect whistleblowers like Ms. O'Toole.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Brunch; On Upper East Sid Or in SoHo
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been mentioned in Diner's Journal, followed by the date of original publication in The New York Times. The restaurants have not been rated. Prices are current. Madeline's

title: Schisgal's 'Twice Around the Park'
description: IN ''Twice Around the Park,'' two one-act comedies by Murray Schisgal now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, human relationships are not explored so much as they are mugged.

title: A Graceful Fall?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Warehouse Tenant's Show of Endurance
description: A FEW hours after audiences leave evening performances at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, trucks arrive to unload meats and produce at the warehouses of the New Haven Food Terminal which surround the theater. By the time the theater's administrative staff returns to work the next day, the trucks are gone.

title: PITTSBURGH CLEANS UP ITS ACT
description: BILL JOHNSON KILLS THE ENGINE OF HIS RUBYRED Mercury Astro and lets the sleek fiberglass bass boat drift along the steep northern shore of the Monongahela River, into the heart of Pittsburgh.

title: A Quake History, by San Franciscans
description: For most of her working life, in musty library stacks and record rooms, Gladys Hansen has been researching the 1906 earthquake, correcting an official account that she says set out to minimize the death and destruction.

title: Alleged Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Audrey Zissu to Wed Gerald Hensley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Kellner of New York and Frankfurt have made known the engagement of Mrs. Kellner's daughter, Audrey Lynn Zissu, to Gerald Austen Hensley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Hensley of Wellington, New Zealand. A May wedding is planned.

title: Zoe A. Topsfield, Lawyer, Married
description: The marriage of Zoe Ann Topsfield and David Raymond Garcia, both New York lawyers, took place yesterday at the Chapel of Gray's Inn, one of the Inns of Court in London. The Rev. Canon Eric James, a minister of the Church of England, officiated. The bride, 30 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Topsfield of London. Her husband, 35, is the son of Rita Z. Garcia of Tampa, Fla., and the late Raymond Garcia.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley; Crying 'It's War!' Protesters Disrupt Job Recruiting
description: Calling for an end to the University of California's sponsorship of recruitment presentations by corporations that they say promote war, student groups are waging a campaign of demonstrations disrupting events at the campus's Career Planning and Placement Center.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Is There Bounty Hunting in The N.F.L.?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Stacey Cohen Weds
description: Stacey Cohen and Alan Faske, graduates of the University of Hartford, were married last evening at Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbi Burton Mindich. Mrs. Faske, 24 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Cohen of New Hempstead, N.Y. She is an account supervisor at the AD Group, a sales promotional firm in Wayne, N.J. Mr. Faske, 25, is the vice president for marketing and sales at Tri-City Insulation Distributors in Linden, N.J. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Faske of Lawrence.

title: ABOUT MEN
description: LIVING IN THE MIDDLE of the woods in upstate New York, I am sometimes reminded that a gun can be a useful tool in the normal course of country life. As serene and pastoral as it all appears from the white Adirondack chair - a big house, porches, stream, barn, ducks, dogs, cats, a pickup truck, basketball hoop and seven kids of various sizes and shapes - there is a perilous world beyond the periphery of the lawn, where deer are often seen grazing on the long grasses.

title: Northern Italian Food With a View
description: IN a brief, earlier life, Rapallo was called the Restaurant at Stamford Landing, facing the water in a new marina and office development on an inlet in Stamford that leads into Long Island Sound. In that first incarnation, the restaurant featured seafood, a sushi bar and an Oriental flavor.

title: INSIDE THE INTIFADA
description: Joel Brinkley portrays the Intifada as the shebab - as masked young men - who throw stones at Israeli soldiers and settlers (''Inside the Intifada,'' Oct. 29). In April, I was part of a delegation of lawyers and medical professionals who spent two weeks in the West Bank and Gaza. The Intifada is, indeed, stone throwers, but, more significantly, it is the resistance to Israeli occupation.

title:
Pequannock Journal;
At a Small Restaurant, Customers Are Treated Like Family
description: LEAD: PETER VAN DUFFELEN, owner and chef of a little restaurant called Hot Diggity Dogs, wanted a place his customers could call their own. For anyone sitting at the counter in the restaurant, it is easy to tell the occasional visitor from the regulars. The regulars are those who have their own coffee mugs and step behind the counter to pour their coffee.

title: Santa Fe's Spicy Cultural Mix
description: Out here in the West where old means almost anything that happened before World War II, Santa Fe is the exception. It was established in 1610 by settlers from New Spain to the south. And although residents like to talk about ''descendants of the conquistadors,'' the folks who came up the Camino Real from Mexico City in the train of Juan de Onate were already two or three generations removed from their Spanish antecedents and their blood was thoroughly mixed with that of the Mexican natives their fathers and grandfathers had conquered.

title: INSIDE
description: Panel Orders New Vote In Gandhi's Own District

title: Salvador Rebels Lose Touch, But Still Show Their Strength
description: WITH something approaching awe, the rebel looked at the hotel room - a double bed, a carpet, a private bath and a tiled shower. That may be standard in any motel in the United States, but it is unfathomable luxury for most Salvadorans. ''I'm from the countryside,'' the guerrilla said. ''I've never been in San Salvador before. I've never seen wealth like this.''

title: POSTINGS: TriBeCa Warehouse; From 4 Buildings, One
description: Four 100-year-old buildings that had stood vacant for a decade on the eastern end of the block bounded by Laight, Vestry, Varick and Hudson Streets in TriBeCa have been renovated into a warehouse intended primarily for household goods. Called the New York Security Mini Storage, the six-story facility near the Manhattan end of the Holland Tunnel that incorporates the adjacent buildings will have 28 Laight Street as its address. It is due to open next month.

title: LAW AND ORDER COME TO PARADISE
description: THE POWERS THAT BE By Mike Nicol. 176 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: Yes. Not all sports can be judged popular according to a professional standard. Soccer is a game played by millions of youngsters and adults across America. The United States doesn't need a professional soccer league to make the game popular. All we need are the youths to play the game, a few experienced coaches and a baseball outfield on which to play. ROBERT E. SHEA Red Bank, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
Was It Pumpkin? Or Was It Squash?
description: LEAD: PUMPKIN PIE is a fall favorite as well as a tradition for Thanksgiving. When topped by a dollop of whipped cream or a scoop of ice cream, it's hard to beat. But was that really pumpkin pie you had on Thursday?

title: New Supervisor Sets Goals for Southampton
description: LEAD: THE agenda for Southampton's next two years will focus on taxes, housing and the environment, according to George Stavropoulos, the town's Supervisor-elect.

title: SOUND
description: According to John Keats, beauty is truth and vice versa. Some recording artists disagree.

title: Style Makers; Scott Barrie, Fashion Designer
description: Scott Barrie, who was known for designing sexy matte jersey dresses in the 1960's and 70's, has a new line and a whole new look. After five years in Milan, working for Krizia, the Italian high-fashion house, he is now doing a collection of sportswear, knits and leather clothes under his own name.

title: PARENTS AND CHILDREN
description: GROWING UP WRITING By Arlene Silberman. (Times Books, $18.95.) I wish this book had been available when my son came home from kindergarten last year, eagerly starting stories with the invented spelling he had learned through his school's ''Writing to Read'' program. Despite my professional writing credentials and parental desire to see him enjoy writing as much as I do, in my compulsion to ''correct'' spelling and grammar I reacted like the benighted parents and educators Arlene Silberman indicts in her provocative and important new book. At a time when the national educational agenda has increasingly focused on why Johnny can't write, Ms. Silberman, an education writer, explores the observation that while most children come into this world eager to write and tell stories, by the time they have gone through elementary school that delight has disappeared. All too often, she argues, the writing product has been emphasized at the cost of the writing process. And in the collective zeal to restore ''basics'' in the nation's schools, too many teachers have used the emphasis on the writing product as a straitjacket to stifle children's creativity, rather than as a tool to provoke self-expression. ''Even these well-meaning teachers make the mistake of emphasizing early basic skills at the expense of encouraging ideas,'' writes Ms. Silberman. In ''Growing Up Writing,'' which is based on her extensive journeys through the country's classrooms, Ms. Silberman offers examples of innovative solutions to the problem of getting children to write, and to enjoy writing, from kindergarten through high school. Some of it shows up in ''writing across the curriculum'' programs, in which writing is as much a part of a mathematics or science class as of composition or English literature. It's encouraging to hear about teachers who willingly read through many drafts of student papers; students who eagerly dispatch letters to younger classes; and parents who recognize that they have a fundamental role to play at school as well as at home. Ms. Silberman argues that parents are the most important ''writing educators'' their offspring will ever have. This role goes beyond reading aloud or talking with children. Whether it's letting a child sort through junk mail, paint and draw, take down phone messages, draft memos to other family members or write out grocery lists, the writing process can - and should - be easily incorporated into daily life. ''Growing Up Writing'' should be required reading for new parents, along with Benjamin Spock and T. Berry Brazelton, and certainly will be included in the basket of books I routinely send to friends upon the birth of a first child.

title: FICTION
description: EARTHLY REMAINS. By Peter Hernon. (Birch Lane/Carol Publishing, $18.95.) In 1947, the British were pulling out of Palestine, leaving the region's Jews, in their struggle to create an independent state of Israel, to fight the Arabs. At the same time, a startling discovery of a group of ancient scrolls was made by a band of Bedouin tribesmen in a cave located in Trans-Jordan, little more than a stone's throw from the Dead Sea. This much is fact, and it is from here that the journalist Peter Hernon has let his imagination take over - the result of which is a fascinating ''what if?'' novel. What if other scrolls were also found, also written by the Essenes, ''an obscure Jewish sect that was thought to have first existed in Palestine some two hundred years before Christ''? And what if, along with these scrolls, two other discoveries were made: the skeleton of a headless man, suspected to be John the Baptist, and the mummified corpse of a crucified man who might be Jesus Christ? Paul Davoren, a journalist assigned to cover the war, finds himself sucked into a thrilling theological treasure hunt and detective story, the ramifications of which could shake the foundations of modern Christianity. The risks in a novel like this are many. Fortunately, Mr. Hernon is not just a skillful storyteller; his eye for detail and the clever way he entwines fact and fiction do not allow the reader to doubt his premise. Mr. Hernon only falters infrequently, with love scenes between Davoren and a beautiful young scholar that fall rather flat - and at the end, when his tale turns into a more conventional thriller. Otherwise, ''Earthly Remains'' is a well-written, exciting and thought-provoking novel.

title: POSTINGS: Center Rising on Route 10; For Homework
description: A $5 million commercial center for specialty companies selling home furnishings and decorations is under construction on Route 10 in the Township of East Hanover in Morris County, N.J. Scheduled to be completed next summer, the two-story building will contain 22,000 square feet of space intended for use by companies selling furniture, wallpaper, paints, windows, tiles, fabrics, hardware and the like.

title: Q and A
description: House Swapping Services

title: The Big Battle Over Eyewear
description: Dr. Alan H. Leventhal can remember when life was a lot easier. That was in the late 1970's, when the Federal Trade Commission said it was okay to advertise eyewear prices. Dr. Leventhal bought some lens processing equipment, advertised one-hour service for glasses and contact lenses, and waited. ''People went nutso. Our phones were ringing like crazy,'' recalled Dr. Leventhal, who owns 10 eyewear outlets in southern California.

title: County to Begin Tests of 70 Private Wells
description: LEAD: THE County Department of Health will be sampling water from 70 wells in North Salem, Bedford, Pound Ridge, Lewisboro and Somers this month. The study is being described by Robert Wasp, assistant commissioner of the division of environmental quality of the County Health Department, as the first ''non-reactive'' one of its kind.

title: Islanders' Slide Grows Deeper
description: The organist plays as if at a respectful recital. The numbers on the scoreboard change only in that they become uglier by the game. Hope is usually gone by the start of the third period, and the crowd almost invariably has followed before the end of it.

title: Smithtown Vote Set on Landfill Referendum
description: LEAD: WHEN Smithtown voters went to the polls on Election Day, they looked at the ballot and discovered that, no matter how they voted, they were likely to be re-electing their Town Supervisor, Patrick R. Vecchio, since he had been endorsed by both the major parties.

title: Census Confronting Worker Shortness
description: A FEW months ago Donald R. Byrnes was cautiously optimistic. Even a month ago, he was only ''mildly anxious.'' These days, he is still trying to keep his cool, he says, but it is getting more and more difficult.

title: Feeding Raccoons: Other Viewpoints
description: I'd like to point out to Janet Pollak (''My 7 Visitors and How They Really Love to Eat,'' Opinion Page, Oct. 22) that one person's raccoon food is another person's decaying garbage. I don't want to be labeled a curmudgeon, so I won't write about the human need for the unconditional love given by pets.

title: Notes on China; Beijing Hopes To Stamp Out The '6 Evils'
description: China has started a new campaign against ''six evils'' in its latest attempt to restore a glow of revolutionary virtue to the national complexion.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about AIDS omitted a word in quoting Dr. Peter C. Welch, senior vice president for medical affairs at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. He said the hospital's patients had ''not'' included many children with AIDS.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FESTIVAL OF TREES

title: Union Advances In Rout of Montclair
description: Brett Russ threw for three touchdowns and ran for another today as unbeaten Union College crushed Montclair State, 45-6, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III East Regional final.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: No. The American sports mentality simply does not have the patience or attention span for a continuous-play game. Half the fun of football, baseball, basketball, etc., is the time when there is no action. During these breaks we argue over the pros and cons of our team's performance, go to the refrigerator, mull our ineptitude in this week's pool picks, and on and on. PAUL J. LAGAS Binghampton, N.Y.

title:
GARDENING;
Was It Pumpkin? Or Was It Squash?
description: LEAD: PUMPKIN PIE is a fall favorite as well as a tradition for Thanksgiving. When topped by a dollop of whipped cream or a scoop of ice cream, it's hard to beat. But was that really pumpkin pie you had on Thursday?

title: England's Unheralded Gems
description: LEAD: For me the charm of an old country largely consists in its historic cities, cathedrals, palaces and mansions. But England has a large number of lesser historic towns, some of them with special associations for Americans. Each of the following is worth a visit, and easily accessible from London.

title:
MUSIC;
'Christmas Story' Told In Song
description: LEAD: MUSIC and history go hand in hand for Michael Jaffee, director of the Waverly Consort since its formation 25 years ago. Most of the 10 members of his ensemble, which performs Baroque music and that of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, are music historians and researchers, whether formally or informally.

title: After 30 Years, Japan Patents Chips
description: Japan granted a patent that Texas Instruments Inc. had been seeking since 1960. The patent covers the basic semiconductor chip, which the company's researchers invented in 1958. The Tokyo decision requires all Japanese chip makers to pay royalties to Texas Instruments. Japanese chip makers have about 90 percent of the Japanese chip market and 80 percent of the United States market. Texas Instruments would not comment on the money involved, but analysts estimated that the patent rights, which are valid for 12 years, could bring in a total of $2 billion. Texas Instruments shares jumped on the news after having fallen earlier in the week when the company announced a $55 million charge against earnings and the elimination of 1,500 jobs. The company has about 50,000 employees. *

title: County Arts Groups See No Threat to Gains
description: DESPITE the growing national uncertainty over future financing decisions by the National Endowment for the Arts, leaders of county arts organizations have continued to express confidence in the agency's peer-panel grants-making process and said Federal grants for their own programs are not threatened.

title: INSIDE THE INTIFADA
description: Your article fails to mention the numerous actions on the part of the Israeli Government to move many of the residents of these refugee camps into permanent housing. Some of this housing already is built and sits empty, because of threats made by the Palestinian Liberation Organization against any Arab who tries to improve his physical conditions. HARVEY D. WOLINETZ Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Driver Shows His Sensibility
description: The press conference on Nov. 17 that was called to announce Willy T. Ribbs's Indy-car ride for next season featured numerous references to his struggle to reach the top level of American racing.

title: MAMMALMANIA
description: FREEING THE WHALES How the Media Created the World's Greatest Non-Event. By Tom Rose. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing Group.

title: Feeding Raccoons: Other Views
description: It's always heartening reading something good on wildlife (Janet Pollak's ''My 7 Visitors and How They Really Love to Eat''), as well as a gustatory risible riot.

title: Pastimes; Bridge
description: The result of the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship that concluded the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals in Lancaster, Pa. last weekend represented one minor surprise and one major one.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Agent Is Bitter
description: Joseph F. Fernandez says his superiors approved of his secret efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels but remained silent while he took the blame in the Iran-contra affair. Page 31.

title: At Last, an 'Event' That Really Is an Event
description: We have learned to cringe from superstar personal appearances, but when Kathleen Battle and Placido Domingo gave a joint operatic concert during the Metropolitan Opera's Tokyo engagement last year, something was going right. Maybe the plan to issue a Deutsche Grammophon recording (427 686; CD and cassette) made it special; maybe the participation of James Levine (appearing for the first time in Japan) added a sense of occasion and pride. Certainly it sounds as though the pieces had been rehearsed, and everybody had a good night.

title: When a Joan of Arc Addressed Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Czechoslovakia's Opulent Spas
description: For centuries, Carlsbad and Marienbad - the German names for Czechoslovakia's most famous spa towns, Karlovy Vary and Marianske Lazne - drew Europe's most prominent political and artistic figures.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The caption with a photograph of a home that accompanied an article on Jamaica Estates on Nov. 17 gave an incorrect location for the house. It is on Midland Parkway.

title: Firefighters' Test in December
description: New York City will resume its physical examination for prospective firefighters early next month even though the City Health Commissioner has warned that it can cause kidney failure, officials said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; The Backfire From Buddy Ryan's 'Bounties'
description: As if the National Football League weren't violent enough and its players weren't solvent enough, Buddy Ryan, the coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, has been accused by Jimmy Johnson, the Dallas Cowboys' coach, of putting a ''bounty'' on the helmets of a quarterback and a kicker. It's time Ryan was called on the carpet to explain these charges and others that circulated long before this controversy flared.

title: Reviews/Music; New-Sounding Oldies In Contemporary Series
description: Series titles are often meant to be only loose indications of the music to be offered. But at the first of this season's Music Today concerts, on Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, a listener was struck by the freedom with which the temporal part of the series' title has been stretched. All four of the works on the program were by living composers, but only one of the pieces was written this year - or, for that matter, in the 1980's. The others were composed in 1979, 1950 and 1922.

title: Review/Dance; It's 'Nutcracker' Season, And the Joffrey Is First
description: ''The Nutcracker'' is back. This year's first production of the winter holiday classic was that of the Joffrey Ballet, which danced it Friday afternoon and evening at the City Center Theater.

title: In Europe, the Return of History
description: LEAD: The piercing of the Berlin Wall symbolizes a historical turning point. Those who emphasize ideology in interpreting world events call such events the ''end of the cold war'' or, more extravagantly, the ''end of history.'' For those who focus more on the changing power of nations, the current period might more aptly be termed the return of history.

title: Disasters Challenge Our Sense of Values
description: WITHIN days of the devastation wrought by the California earthquake, the President of the United States urged Americans to contribute to the Red Cross as ''the only organization chartered and authorized by Congress to act at times of great national calamity.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I try to work in a way so I can always look into people's eyes.'' - Karel Urbanek, the new Communist Party leader in Czechoslovakia. [ 1:5. ]

title: Thatcher Says She'll Lead Tories Two More Times
description: Only weeks after she indicated that she was likely to step down in a few years as leader of the Conservative Party, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has announced that she is willing to lead the party into two more general elections.

title: Julia Robertson, Student, to Wed
description: Announcement of the engagement of Julia Marie Robertson to Ian M. Kasman has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Robertson of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Schneider Captures Slalom: Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, the defending World Cup champion, who fell on her first run of the season Friday, turned in two flawless runs to win the women's slalom yesterday at Park City, Utah. Schneider, who won 14 times last year, negotiated the 427-meter course at the Park City Ski Area in 47.77 seconds on her first run and in 46.88 on her second for a total of 1:34.65. She easily beat Monika Maierhofer of Austria, who was timed in 1:35.97. The Austrian team took the next three places and placed six skiers among the top 10 finishers. Kristi Terzian of Salt Lake City was the leading American, placing seventh in 1:37.03.(AP) Cross-Country Pennsylvanians Northeast Winners: Mike McWilliams and Carole Zajac, both of Pennsylvania, outraced opponents from 11 states to win the boys and girls races yesterday at the Kinney High School Northeast Regional cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. McWilliams, a senior from Grove City, ran 15 minutes 49.9 seconds on the snow-covered, 5,000-meter course to triumph by 20 yards over Mike Going of Wheatley High in Old Westbury, L.I. Zajac, a senior from Baldwin High in Pittsburgh, ran 18:17.8 to win by 150 yards. The top eight finishers in each race earned berths to the Kinney national championships Dec. 9 in San Diego. Other qualifiers included Kevin Hogan of Westhampton, L.I., the New York State champion, and a pair of freshmen, Monal Chokshi, the New Jersey State girls titleholder from Bridgewater, and Elizabeth Mueller, the Connecticut state champion from Waterford. Golf Strange Sinks $60,000 Birdie: Curtis Strange, shut out for 22 holes over two years, broke through with a $60,000 birdie putt yesterday in the first nine holes of golf's Skins Game at La Quinta, Calif. ''It wasn't anything fantastic, but it was nice to get that first one,'' Strange said after his six-foot putt found the cup on the fifth hole at the Stadium Club at PGA West. That putt, which followed a five-minute delay while some television equipment was repaired, made him the big winner over the first nine holes of the two-day, 18-hole event. Jack Nicklaus, who has played in all seven Skins Games, won two holes worth a total of $55,000 and Ray Floyd, the big winner last year with $290,000, won $25,000. Lee Trevino was shut out and $25,000 was left on the table when the ninth hole was halved. That money will be carried over to today's play, when $310,000 will at stake. (AP) Green Leads by a Shot: Hubert Green birdied the final hole yesterday to complete a round of 69 for a 204 and a one-shot lead after three rounds of the $714,000 Casio World Open tournament at Kaimoncho, Japan. Green, winner of this tournament in 1985, rolled in a 3-footer for birdie to break a deadlock with Larry Mize and Japan's Isao Aoki. Green's score is 12 under par. (AP) Figure Skating Ito Takes Ladies Title: The world champion, Midori Ito of Japan, displaying six kinds of triple jumps in perfect form during free skating yesterday, won the ladies singles title in the 1989 International Free Skating Competition NHK Trophy in Kobe, Japan. The 18-year-old Ito was awarded four perfect 6.0's and five 5.9's in the technical merit and picked up one 6.0 and six 5.9's in the artistic impression.

title: The Revenge of the Leaf Blowers
description: I DON'T know why, but I usually rebel against buying gardening gadgets. I still don't own a weed whacker.

title: All 54 Aboard Survive Crash of a Jet in Seoul
description: Twenty-one people were injured when a Korean Air Lines jet with 54 people on board crashed and caught fire on takeoff today from Kimpo Airport in Seoul, a spokesman said.

title: As the Wall Came Tumbling Down
description: THE FOLLOWING IS THE RECORD OF a recent visit to East Berlin, at a time when the burst of freedom that greeted the opening of the borders to the West on Nov. 9 was still an anxiously held breath; when even the most optimistic could not imagine such a swift and fortunate denouement. The drama, of course, is just beginning. Already, its first great act is being credited to politicians whose only part, to this day, has been one of forestalling and then adapting to the inevitable. Here is a portrait of a few of the principal, though unknown, players - ordinary men and women whose passion and imagination are the real engines of revolution.

title: NABBED ON THE DATA HIGHWAY
description: THE CUCKOO'S EGG Tracking a Spy Through the Maze of Computer Espionage. By Clifford Stoll. 326 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Michael Harwood, 55, Naturalist
description: Michael Harwood, an author and naturalist, died of an embolism Friday at the University of California at San Diego Medical Center, where he had undergone arterial surgery. He was 55 years old and a resident of Washington, Conn.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Portsmouth, N.H.;
Bankruptcy Halts Conversion
description: LEAD: An effort to convert a 722-unit low-income apartment complex into a condominium complex called Spinnaker Point-Mariner's Village has fallen victim to a troubled housing market. Portsmouth Coastal Development Partners, sponsor of the project, has halted sales and renovations and is trying to revamp plans.

title: The City Council Finds Its Elbows
description: FOR years, the New York City Council has mostly labored in the political shadows, spending a lot of its time dealing with such matters as new names for city streets, parks and ball fields. At the other end of City Hall the Board of Estimate, dominated largely by the mayor, has held the limelight, making many important decisions on municipal affairs.

title: A Victim's Appeal
description: Moral suasion may occasionally move a politician to tears, but it rarely moves a gun control measure toward enactment in the face of gun lobby opposition. Thus an emotional appeal to a Senate panel last week by James Brady, the former White House press secretary, seemed unlikely to win passage of a new gun control measure. Mr. Brady, who has used a wheelchair since he was shot during the 1981 assassination attempt on President Reagan, said he understood that many in Congress ''are intimidated by the gun lobby.'' He said that opponents of a proposed seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases ''should try being in my wheels for just one day.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said he was for banning handgun sales to felons, but the necessary record-checking ''would impose an unreasonable burden on legitimate gun purchasers.''

title: Pastimes; Camera
description: Watching the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade - from the comfort of my armchair, thank you - reminded me of the years I used to venture out early in the morning to capture the parade on film. It never snowed, like it did this year, but it always seemed to be either bitterly cold, raining or both.

title: In Italy, a Brooder Takes a Break
description: Traveling alone has its pluses: you can go where you want when you want, and you are spared that runaway irritation that comes of suddenly spotting all the little flaws in your companion (who alone seems to be detaining you from perfect enjoyment) and the tension of having to keep that knowledge secret. However, the minus is that you will have no one to blame but yourself for the occasional rotten mood. To travel is to brood, and especially if you are your sole company. I would go so far as to recommend traveling alone as an excellent way of catching up with all the poor opinions of yourself that you may have had to suppress during the busy, camouflaging work-year when it is necessary to appear a self-approving, winning member of society.

title:
INVESTING;
Garnering the Gold
description: LEAD: For some investors, gold stocks or mutual funds never seem as precious as the metal itself. Gold is volatile, but less so than gold stocks.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Fare in a Club Setting in Somers
description: LEAD: ALMOST a half-dozen restaurants dot the short strip of Route 100 between Katonah and Somers. The addition of the sprawling complexes of International Business Machines and Pepsico have changed the demographics of this once-sleepy area, bringing in new residents who might find most of the local eating spots that were established to serve a different clientele in another time pretty bleak pickings.

title: Ms. Rich Engaged To M. D. Einson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin D. Rich of New York and Fair Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Brenda L. Rich to Matthew D. Einson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Neal M. Einson of New York. They are to be married next year. Ms. Rich, 26 years old, graduated from Oberlin College and received a master's degree in environmental education from Montclair State College in August. Mr. Einson, 29, is an associate at Charles T. Main, an environmental consulting concern in Boston. He is a graduate of the State University of New York at Buffalo, and he received a master's degree in meteorology from Pennsylvania State University.

title: Ms. Yeiser Weds Thomas Danahy
description: Elizabeth Ann Yeiser, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Yeiser Jr. of West Nyack, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas V. Danahy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Danahy of New City, N.Y. The Rev. Dennis Fernandes officiated at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Nyack, N.Y.

title: A Yankee Upstart Sprouts in Thatcher's London
description: The scale of Canary Wharf is immense: 24 buildings on 71 acres, its centerpiece a 50-story, 800-foot-high skyscraper by Cesar Pelli that when finished will be the tallest building in Britain. This is most assuredly not the London of Christopher Wren or of John Nash. Nor is it the London of Prince Charles, who has made it clear that he expects this huge tower to be a desecration of the city's skyline. If it is anything, Canary Wharf is really the London of Margaret Thatcher. The whole of this vast project is not due to be finished until the end of the century. It will fill the central section of the Isle of Dogs, an industrial peninsula along the Thames opposite Greenich, two and a half miles east of the City of London, the old, dense square mile that has served as London's financial center for hundreds of years. But its first phase, which includes the central tower, six other office buildings, a train station and retail space, is expected to be finished at the end of 1990. Right now the site is filled with dozens of construction cranes, and there is no place that more clearly exemplifies the changing nature of London: Canary Wharf is an American-style development, on the scale of American rather than European cities, designed mainly by American architects and built by a Toronto development firm, Olympia & York, that is best known for such huge American projects as the World Financial Center at Battery Park City.

title: Why Sondheim's Women Are Different
description: Everything's coming up roses This time for me for me for me!

title: ENVY, THE WRITER'S DISEASE
description: It used to be like a fever with me, a compulsion, a madness: to go into a bookstore, head straight for the brand-new books, flip right to the back of the jacket and see if the author was young or old, my age or even - rats! - younger. Envy is a vocational hazard for most writers. It festers in one's mind, distracting one from one's own work, at its most virulent even capable of rousing the sufferer from sleep to brood over another's triumph.

title: Tackling the N.F.L. Labor Impasse
description: Union-management relations in football are the worst among the professional team sports. The two sides barely exchange civilities, much less negotiate issues.

title: PARENTS AND CHILDREN
description: WHY KIDS LIE: How Parents Can Encourage Truthfulness. By Paul Ekman with Mary Ann Mason Ekman and Tom Ekman. (Scribners, $17.95.) This thoughtful and provocative book is much better than its title suggests. Mr. Ekman, a research psychologist, has spent years studying the phenomenon of truth and its distortion, and he's taken all that he's learned and applied it to young people learning to be adults and to the parents struggling to help them. What makes this work especially valuable is Mr. Ekman's decision to travel beyond the behavioral aspect of lying to the larger questions that plague us all, especially in these post-Watergate days. In simple and clear prose, Mr. Ekman deals with the function of the less-than-true, the fear and anxiety that generate lies, and the reasons why our culture sometimes supports that fear instead of the truth. He's also remarkably helpful in offering methods for dealing with a child who lies. The basic respect for children that informs this whole book is reflected especially well in Mr. Ekman's decision to invite his stepson, Tom, to write a chapter. At the age of 14, the boy is a perceptive and forthcoming spokesman. Describing a crisis in his own life, one dealt with by his stepfather in an earlier chapter, Tom is able to give the reader insights into his transgression and into his parents' choice of punishment. He is also refreshingly candid in his support of punishment for lying, and in his suggestion that parents continue ''lecturing your kid on what is right and wrong. . . . Although many kids in America are going to hate me for saying this, the truth of the matter is that repeated lecturing does work and is effective.'' Once again the old saws about structure and expectations are borne out by this perceptive young man, and provide an effective center to his stepfather's compassionate examination of truth and lying in children. ''The main difference in the way that my parents and I saw the lie,'' he reports ''lay in the loss of trust.'' It is to Mr. Ekman's credit that his book also reminds us that these issues are still, even at the end of the hypercynical 80's, worthy of consideration.

title: Pacifism Motivated Holocaust Deeds
description: In Judy Chicurel's thorough article on the people of Le Chambon, France, who saved thousands of Jews during World War II (''Film Recalls 'Conspiracy of Goodness''' Oct. 29) one amplification is necessary if we are to understand why those French villagers took such enormous risks.

title: In an Autumn Storm, Thoughts of a Hard Rain
description: I WAS sitting in the grass high above Long Island Sound. For nearly a week the North Fork area had been intensely humid, with squalls building throughout each day, and striking, usually by night, leaving in their wake immaculate skies that lasted into bright dawns, the air hot but dry.

title:
FOCUS: Ski Resorts;
Taking the Development Trail Cautiously
description: LEAD: Despite a rainy, relatively mild season and a softening of the second-home market, Vermont's ski industry last year recorded the third best winter in its history, taking in $330.2 million from all sources, according to the Vermont Ski Areas Association, an industry organization. But higher snowmaking costs cut profit margins.

title: Hospital to Open Drive for Hospice
description: THE financial drain of a terminal illness is devastating. Too often there is no money for the small luxuries that might make life a little more bearable for a terminally ill patient.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Falling Into Life

title:
DINING OUT;
A Casual, Modern California-Style Place
description: LEAD: THE first few months after a restaurant has opened are often experimental. The owner has an idea of the type of restaurant he or she wants to create, but frequently finds that local diners do not accept that vision. So the menu is re-done, prices sometimes fall and even decor can undergo a change.

title: CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
description: Dr. Baltimore showed considerable hubris in asserting that, by confronting Representative Dingell, he was ''acting in the best interests of all scientists. . . .'' As one trained in the sciences, I do not want him speaking for me.

title: In 5 Towns District, A Teacher Impasse
description: LEAD: TEACHERS in the Hewlett-Woodmere School District have been working without a contract for six months, and the stalled negotiations, they say, can be attributed not only to the recent Long Island phenomenon - taxpayer revolt - but also to their contention that both school administrators and the school board are caving in to a minority in the community that wants to hold teachers' raises down.

title: Collecting Objectivty
description: FREUD DESCRIBED COLLECTORS AS MISERLY, PEDANTIC, STUBBORN and compulsively tidy. And indeed, most do confess their boundless penchant for objects is, well, a little eccentric. ''Anybody who collects is obsessed,'' says Sue Railey, an international representative for Christie's who has spent most of her life scouring flea markets and junk shops around the world. ''Those who haven't caught the bug are missing a lot of fun.''

title: Collecting Sure Things
description: IT'S NOT THAT THEY'RE PACK RATS EXACTLY, IT'S JUST THAT THEY HAVE idees fixes about certain kinds of clothing. So they collect them. ''I am not a collector,'' the writer Fran Lebowitz says emphatically. Nevertheless, she has 25 pairs of jeans. She also owns about 100 men's shirts: ''Ninety-eight of them from Brooks Brothers.'' Lena Horne does not consider herself a collector, either. Yet she has kept every dramatic evening gown the late Giorgio di Sant'Angelo designed for her stage and concert appearances. The other day, Miss Horne counted them up - the total was 125. The socialite Anne Slater fell in love with a pair of cat's-eye-shaped, deep-blue glasses 25 years ago. She ordered three-dozen pairs in her prescription. She is still wearing them. Classics, the luxurious variety with famous labels like Hermes, or just plain pullovers and kilts have a hold on scores of women. Shoes are the mania of many. Surveying her own booty, Kim Hastreiter, editor and publisher of PAPER Magazine, says, ''You can tell the most about people by their shoes.'' Men, too, tend to horde their favorite haberdashery. The product designer Larry Laslo, for instance, keeps 1,000 pairs of socks stored in fake alligator boxes. But more about men another time. Here, five women spill the contents of their closets.

title: Doing a Number on Opera Companies
description: I've been thinking a lot lately about what is wrong with the world, and I have finally decided: data overload. Because of the proliferation of computers and of people capable of running them, we are awash in information that nobody needs - or worse, that nobody believes. Gatherers of statistics have great power, but they usually operate quietly. I don't mean those busybodies who phone you when you are in the bathroom and want to ask how you feel about mouthwash. I refer to the media-oriented statisticians, the ones who deal in politics, sports, culture and diseases. These statisticians operate like the Wizard of Oz, behind a screen that disguises fallibility. They speak to us in tongues - of probabilities, sampling techniques, growth patterns and percentages of probable error. Their conclusions are read but not questioned, simply because most of us hated arithmetic in grammar school.

title: Where It's Always a Day for Turkey
description: LET'S talk turkey. If you have not had enough of it by now, head straight for Stony Brook. Thanksgiving still lives at the Three Village Inn, where every Sunday a $19.95 turkey dinner with all the trimmings is served (children, $9.95.) Even those who cannot stand to look at turkey after three days of leftovers will find something to like here. The quaint Colonial village, views of Stony Brook Harbor, antique-filled dining rooms and servers in period costumes evoke a more tranquil era. The wood-paneled Sand Bar, with its nooks, crannies and cozy corners full of memorabilia, is especially appealing.

title: In Moscow, Support for Pole Is Moral but Not Financial
description: Poland's Prime Minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, said today that he had achieved ''complete unanimity'' with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on key issues of European security, but he evidently won no immediate help from the Kremlin in dealing with his economic crisis.

title: 3 Children Killed in an Apartment Fire in Brooklyn
description: Three children were killed and their mother critically injured in an early-morning fire yesterday that devoured their first-floor apartment in Brooklyn.

title: Come One, Come All To the Christmas Tree Mall
description: IT is that time of year again. Men, women and children pile into cars and head for wildernesses of spruce, fir and hemlock. Their goal is to find the perfect Christmas tree.

title: Andrew Young Going Afield to Run for Governor
description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta is aggressively traveling the state these days, buttonholing all who will listen to his plans for a run at the Governor's mansion in 1990.

title: The Intrepid King of Elephants Finds a Home in Middletown
description: BABAR, the dapper king of the elephants, has happily resettled from France to Middletown. Laurent de Brunhoff, the author and illustrator of more than 30 Babar storybooks, now makes his home on the Wesleyan University campus with his companion, Phyllis Rose, an author and English professor.

title: A View of Warhol Surfaces From The Old Underground
description: ''Andy was a person. Just like we are. Just like you are.'' Perhaps. But so many people have taken credit for inventing Andy Warhol that Lou Reed's observation sounds less obvious than it should. Warhol himself apparently liked nothing better than having fake Andys all over the place. And he generally delighted in whatever myths about him might be in circulation.

title: Dr. Gregory Hack To Wed Dr. Kelly
description: The engagement of Dr. Barbara Anne Kelly and Dr. Gregory Adrian Hack, the son of Cornelius Hack of North Smithfield, R.I., and the late Ann W. Hack, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kelly of Tenafly, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Times Sq. Shooting Wounds 3
description: A police officer, a suspect and a passer-by were wounded in Times Square early yesterday in a gunfight that started when the officer spotted a young man with a handgun and told him to drop it, the police said.

title: Illegal Apartments And Realtor Profits
description: If Bill Cook (''Illegal Apartments: Let's Face Facts,'' Letter, Oct. 22) was really interested in stating statistics, they should be the amount of profits Realtors (like himself) are raking in at the expense of the taxpayer.

title: Shannon Duffy to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Duffy of Marlborough, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shannon Mary Duffy, to Peter Guyon Weiland Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Weiland of Chappaqua, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College, Miss Duffy teaches English at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School, where her fiance teaches chemistry. He graduated from Lawrenceville and Princeton University.

title:
IN SHORT;
PARENTS AND CHILDREN
description: LEAD: CHILDREN OF FAST-TRACK PARENTS: Raising Self-Sufficient and Confident Children in an Achievement-Oriented World. By Andree Aelion Brooks. (Viking, $18.95.) In an oft-misquoted phrase, Sigmund Freud once said that people need only experience ''achievement and enjoyment'' in life. According to Andree Aelion Brooks, it is when one outstrips the other that trouble begins, especially among children whose parents are ambitious achievers.

title: Dr. King and Lord Byron
description: To the Editor:

title: Polls Find Their Way to a Bigger Role in India
description: As India moves into its fifth decade of regular democratic elections, opinion surveys and the polling of voters are beginning to play bigger roles in political reporting and analysis.

title: Review/Music; Don Pullen's Pianism
description: It wasn't until the end of the pianist Don Pullen's last tune of his first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night that it became clear how unusual his compositional ideas are. Launching into a conventional blues piece, he made the previous hour of music seem carefully premeditated. Every tune had its own rhythm from which to work; one piece functioned as a suite, another had a pop-gospel sunniness, while another was essentially a ballad played as piano solo.

title: Dialing for Dollars: Not an Easy Task
description: FREQUENTLY, I forget to turn the phone off from 6:30 to 7 P.M. That's when we have our dinner - and that's when the hordes (or so it seems) begin their evening solicitations. My husband calls them the money beggars.

title: EX-AGENT IS BITTER OVER IRAN AFFAIR
description: The former Central Intelligence Agency official whose Iran-contra case was dismissed on Friday by a Federal judge said today that his superiors fully approved of his secret efforts to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: NONFICTION
description: WISDOM AND STRENGTH: The Biography of a Renaissance Masterpiece. By Peter Watson. (Doubleday, $21.95.) ''An Allegory of Wisdom and Strength'' was painted by Paolo Veronese in 1576 near Venice and now hangs in the Frick Collection in New York City. In this richly detailed book, Peter Watson traces the painting's remarkable existence through four turbulent centuries and illustrates the major developments in the collecting of old masters since the Renaissance. The painting's owners have included the Holy Roman Emperor Rudolf II; Sweden's Queen Christina, who stunned 17th-century Europe with her abdication and conversion to Roman Catholicism; and Philippe Egalite of the French house of Bourbon-Orleans, whose political aspirations ended on the guillotine. It was looted from Prague amid the wholesale despoliation of art in the Thirty Years' War and later, during the French Revolution, found its way to England as the ancien regime sought to shift assets to safety in that country and elsewhere. Finally, ''An Allegory of Wisdom and Strength'' crossed the Atlantic along with other great works when rich American industrialists, including the Pittsburgh coke and steel baron Henry Clay Frick, formed their collections, beginning in the late 19th century. Mr. Watson, who writes about art for The Observer of London, has a flair for drama and is fascinated with the exotic milieus in which artists have so often thrived. ''Wisdom and Strength'' will bring pleasure to anyone even remotely interested in art and art collecting in the period.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PHILADELPHIA;
Low-Income Compromise
description: LEAD: THE renovation of 128 apartments for low-income residents has begun on Christian Street in southwest Philadelphia after a developer and the city government agreed to steps to moderate neighborhood objections.

title:
Style Makers;
 Maryvonne de Follin, Silk Painter
description: LEAD: Maryvonne de Follin's neck-craning art was born when she considered what else she could do with her paintings on silk besides hanging them on walls. ''So I made a ceiling,'' said the self-taught artist, who painted dreamy pink and icy blue clouds floating on the lofty ceiling of her apartment in Neuilly, an affluent suburb of

title: Michigan Gains Rose Bowl Slot
description: The evidence was clear: Michigan had the better team today against Ohio State. But it took the Wolverines almost forever to prove that and to confirm their reservations for the Tournament of Roses.

title: Pastimes; Stamps
description: Few people other than philatelists know the location of Alaouites or Zil Elwannyen Sesel. Who but a stamp collector would track down 52 cancellations used in Titusville, Pa.?

title: In a Dry China, a Huge Grain Crop Is Not Enough
description: When severe drought threatened his crops this year, Qu Binshen stretched a hose up a dry mountainside and pumped water onto the parched wheat on his allocated land. But the drought was so severe that despite his efforts, he lost a third of his grain crop this year.

title: A One-Act Dialogue Starring Tom Stoppard
description: ''Artist Ascending an Airplane,'' an interview drama in 11 scenes. The action takes place over a little more than an hour in Conference Room B in the first-class lounge of British Airways at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York. Scene 1: Nov. 14, 8:30 P.M.

title: RITES IN LEBANON FOR SLAIN LEADER
description: Much of Lebanon shut down today as President Rene Moawad was buried in his hometown in the country's north.

title: Another Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Yesterday's Villains, Today's Heroes
description: The formula is sturdy, no doubt about it. A head of state has been targeted for assassination. Word of the plot leaks out. A small band of Good Guys has less than three days to prevent a murder that could change the course of history. In the 1973 film version of Frederick Forsyth's best-seller ''The Day of the Jackal,'' the villains were out to get Charles de Gaulle of France. In Home Box Office's ''Red King, White Knight'' - which had its premiere last night and will be rebroadcast Wednesday at 8 A.M. and 8 P.M., as well as on other dates next month - their target is someone whose death will ''bring on winter again all across Europe.''

title: The Steel Band Goes Mainstream
description: Conrad Jordan has a proprietary interest in the steel drum, which he describes as ''the only musical instrument invented in this century and the only musical instrument invented in the Western Hemisphere.'' For more than 25 years Mr. Jordan has been tuning steel drums and has made a life's work out of studying how the drum - also known as a pan or steel piano - is made. His is a very specialized profession, and he has been summoned at times from his home in Brooklyn to Boston, Baltimore, Florida and New Jersey to tune steel drums by fire and hammer.

title: A Spring Ceremony For Sandy Weinberger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Weinberger of Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sandy Weinberger to Steven Sloane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sloane of Forest Hills, Queens. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Manley Owns Up
description: A week after he was banned from the National Football League for a third violation of the league's substance-abuse policy, Dexter Manley owned up to his lapse yesterday. At a news conference in Washington, the 30-year-old Redskin defensive end admitted he had used cocaine, accepted his punishment and said he would do everything in his power to work for reinstatement when he becomes eligible to apply next November. Manley ruled out any legal challenge of the tests. ''The tests were not wrong,'' he said, ''I was.''

title: Miss Simon Wed To Marc Bender
description: Leslie Ann Simon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Simon of New York, was married yesterday to Marc Bender, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Zel Bender of Cheltenham, Pa. Judge Isabel Cohen of the Van Nuys, Calif., Municipal Court officiated at the Orcutt Ranch, a historic site in Canoga Park, Calif.

title: Will Cuts Help the Deficit?
description: REDUCTIONS in military spending will not produce a pot of money for domestic programs any time soon. Nor will the cuts make it easier for President Bush and Congress to lower the budget deficit next year. The deficit problem is simply too daunting and potential Pentagon cuts too gradual to make much short-term difference.

title: Meg Coffee Wed To O. W. Smith In Connecticut
description: Meg Adair Coffee, a daughter of Phyllis M. McDowell of New Haven and Fenwick, Conn., and the late Edward I. McDowell Jr., was married yesterday to O. Whitman Smith, a son of Olcott Damon Smith of Farmington, Conn., and the late Lucy Brainerd Smith. The Rev. Stephen Chinlund, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Greens Farms Congregational Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Clinton Beats Lincoln, 25-22
description: DeWitt Clinton, behind the strong running of Dan LiSanti, defeated Lincoln yesterday, 25-22, and advanced to the Public Schools Athletic League championship game. LiSanti carried 18 times for 131 yards. Clinton (10-1) will meet

title: INSIDE THE INTIFADA
description: I looked carefully at the pictures that accompanied your article, and saw young men, their faces covered, armed with stones and firebombs. They seemed well-dressed, in blue jeans and sweat shirts. I did not see torn clothing; indeed, the general impression was one of strength and good health.

title: Talking: For Sale Signs; Imposing Viable Controls
description: Until recently, few people made a fuss when a neighbor posted a ''For Sale'' sign on his front lawn, since it usually remained there for a just few weeks. Moreover, the right to do so seemed - like the right to decorate a front yard at Christmas - indisputable. It was, after all, a personal act on private property.

title: The Action Is Spirited At Public Bike Auction
description: LUIS ROLDAN, an 8-year-old third grader from Highland Park, clenched a $10 bill in a fist thrust deep in his pocket. He stood before a blue and white Scrambler Duracycle lying on its side; ''Item No. 44, minimum bid - $2,'' a tag on the handlebars read. Luis was convinced that the bike would soon be his. A few feet away, Burchin Killic, a 16-year-old Turkish immigrant, eyed the same scarred two-wheeler from a different angle. Neither boy seemed to notice the other, but both had decided to stake claim to the Scrambler.

title: DATA UPDATE

ART;
When Abstraction Prevails
description: LEAD: DURING this month and next, members of the B. J. Spoke Gallery, a cooperative in Sea Cliff, have turned over their premises to another artists' group, ''14 + 1,'' an informal association formed in 1986.

title: Navy Steps Up Its Hunt For Mislaid Explosives
description: The Navy, under pressure from state officials, has stepped up plans to retrieve live and deactivated explosives accidentally dropped onto public lands outside the service's Nevada bombing ranges.

title: Admirers Honor Virgil Thomson With His Music
description: Some 2,000 friends and admirers of Virgil Thomson, the composer and critic who died on Sept. 30, gathered yesterday afternoon in Manhattan for a memorial concert in his honor at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Yesterday would have been Mr. Thomson's 93d birthday.

title: Fashion: On the Street; The Mundane Soars On Flights of Fancy
description: The fall fashion accessory is often much more than just a scarf, a handbag, a bracelet or a pair of earrings. It can also be the takeoff point for flights of fancy that lift the ordinary, the humdrum, the everyday, into what Rod Serling used to call ''another dimension.''

title: Krenz Is Trying to Turn On the Charm
description: The East German leader, Egon Krenz, made a surprise visit to Leipzig this morning, strolling confidently through the reform movement's stronghold just one day after announcing that the Communist Party wants to surrender its constitutional monopoly on political power.

title: Audrey L. Silver Becomes Bride Of Henry Levin
description: Audrey Lynn Silver, a daughter of William Silver and a stepdaughter of Mrs. Silver of New York, and Henry L. Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Levin of New York, were married in New York last evening. Rabbis Charles Kroloff and Martin Zion officiated at the Pierre.

title: APPLE POLISHING
description: I don't understand how Marcia Adams can say that the Apple Cake With Hot Caramel Sauce ''will keep for a week'' (Food: ''Apple Polishing,'' Oct. 8). Only part of mine ever made it into the fridge, and that lasted only until the next day. Thank you for a delicious recipe. JOLA JAKIMIK Evanston, Ill.

title: Commercial Property: Long Island City; Ambitious Projects Delayed as Conversions Proceed
description: Two New York City agencies - the Planning Commission and the Public Development Corporation - are preparing blueprints for the brighter future that seems to be in store for Long Island City now that Citicorp has planted a striking Manhattan-style office tower there.

title: A Portrait of Richard Burton Probes His Psyche MICHAEL BILLINGTON: Michael Billington is drama critic of The Guardian.
description: Like Ken Russell, John Schlesinger and John Boorman, Tony Palmer is a graduate of the British Broadcasting Corporation in the 1960's: what has come to be seen, in retrospect, as the Golden Age of British television. But where many of his former colleagues have become movie directors, Mr. Palmer is best known as a maker of musical documentaries (including studies of Maria Callas, Benjamin Britten and William Walton) and feature-length portraits of composers (most recently Shostakovich in ''Testimony''). Mr. Palmer has directed 70 films in the last 23 years, and, if any thread runs through them it is his abiding obsession with music, whether rock, pop, operatic or symphonic, and the people who make it.

title: Correction
description: The Prospects column last Sunday about the New Yorker magazine misidentified the magazine's purchaser and misstated its purchase price. Advance Publications Inc. acquired the magazine for $168 million.

title: PARENTS AND CHILDREN
description: I WANT TO GROW HAIR, I WANT TO GROW UP, I WANT TO GO TO BOISE: Children Surviving Cancer. By Erma Bombeck. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) It's hard to imagine a more well-intentioned book. Erma Bombeck has put her considerable talent as a humorist in the service of changing people's attitudes toward children with cancer. Banishing pity and pessimism, she takes a look at the light, triumphant side of fighting the disease. Ms. Bombeck undertook ''I Want to Grow Hair, I Want to Grow Up, I Want to Go to Boise'' on the urging of a cancer camp director who hoped it would help combat the isolation felt by young cancer patients and their families. The royalties will be donated to support cancer research. Though her motives are laudable, the uncomfortable truth is that Ms. Bombeck is in over her head. Having interviewed many children who are surviving cancer, she struggles valiantly to convey their plucky insights. But she isn't able to build a narrative or even tell a sustained anecdote, and her customary shtick is simply not equal to the task. The few laugh-out-loud lines in the book tend to be about kids as kids, not about children battling cancer.

title: Agent for the Past Worries About the Future
description: LEAD: IN this tight fiscal year, the State Archeologist, Nicholas F. Bellantoni, has been traveling the state in his four-wheel-drive truck, hoping he can uncover history before the backhoe does.

title: Four 'Liaisons,' But Only One Is Dangereuse
description: At a cocktail party full of jazzy music, tinkling ice cubes and an aura of boozy flirtation, a French diplomat named Valmont stalks the room, making eyes at women wearing little black dresses. His wife, Juliette, has plotted this event as part of her ambitious campaign to further her husband's career, but her sultry eyes are also on the lookout for desirable men. They are cold-blooded opportunists with a notorious open marriage, these Valmonts, played by Jeanne Moreau and Gerard Philipe in a world-weary manner. But, directed by the less-than-artistic Roger Vadim, this first screen version of ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' was hardly a timeless triumph.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We've often said fantasy becomes reality. But fantasy is a dream, it's not real, at least not until today.'' Steve Wynn, on the opening of his Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas, a $630 million casino complex complete with working volcano.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: FIFTY years after Hardie Gramatky wrote the now classic ''Little Toot,'' a story beloved by children the world over, the posthumous publication of his sequel, ''Little Toot and the Loch Ness Monster,'' represents for his family a triumph of art and spirit.

title: Shopping Firefighters Put Out Macy's Blaze
description: An arsonist set fire to a bedding display in a crowded Queens department store yesterday, but two off-duty firefighters who were shopping independently with their wives put out the flames before their on-duty comrades got there, the Fire Department said.

title: Preservationists Battle Bailey House Project
description: LEAD: The Somers Historical Society is suing the Town Planning Board over a redevelopment plan that would make a 120-year-old house in a historic district part of a 30,000-square-foot office and retail center.

title: A-Hunting They Will Go
description: AT 5 A.M. on the William Floyd Parkway in Suffolk, no creatures are stirring, not even a raccoon. It is so dark, so still, you don't know if it's morning or evening, and your body begs not to find out.

title: SHE WAS BETRAYED BY FAME
description: AMELIA EARHART A Biography. By Doris L. Rich. Illustrated. 322 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. $19.95. THE SOUND OF WINGS The Life of Amelia Earhart. By Mary S. Lovell. Illustrated. 420 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $22.95.

title: INSIDE THE INTIFADA
description: Hamdi Farraj, who was born in a tent in the Dheisheh refugee camp in 1956, says that his family ''lived for 25 years without electricity, without water.''
