Does he realize that for 19 of those 25 years the area was under Jordanian rule? Will he acknowledge that when water and electricity finally were brought to the camp it was under Israeli auspices?

title: Tracy Shiland Weds A. C. Kemper Jr.
description: Tracy Hedges Shiland was married yesterday to Antoine Claude Kemper Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kemper of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The bride is a daughter of the late William McAlpin Shiland and the late Harriet Manice Shiland.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: EARLY FROM THE DANCE. By David Payne. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Adam Jenrette is an ''almost rich and almost famous'' New York artist who attributes his faltering career to the malign influence of an important critic, who has attacked him in ''some blind fit of inexplicable distemper.'' Jenrette is consoling himself with cocaine and casual sex when the funeral of a great-aunt lures him back to his childhood home in North Carolina, hoping for a legacy.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Owings Mills, Md.;
Lake Plan Left High and Dry
description: LEAD: Tightened Federal standards governing wetlands and trout streams have delayed plans for a 100-acre lake as the centerpiece of large-scale new home development here. The delay has left at least one developer dangling while another has renamed and restructured a 5,500-home project once called Lakeside.

title: Carol Bassok Marries
description: Carol M. Bassok, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Bassok of West Hartford, Conn., was married last evening to Michael B. Lowenstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lowenstein of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Mrs. Lowenstein, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, is a vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. Mr. Lowenstein graduated from the Hackley School and Penn and received an M.B.A. from Northwestern University. He is a vice president of the Mutual Shares Corporation, an equity mutual fund in Short Hills, N.J.

title: This 'Nutcracker' Is a Family Affair
description: LEAD: THE dancer, choreographer and teacher Alfredo A. Corvino speaks softly, and while he does not carry the proverbial big stick when directing his dancers, he knows what he wants and he knows how to get it.

title: Homeless, Helpless Neediest
description: New Yorkers have learned to avert their eyes. There may now be 90,000 homeless people in New York City, and many of them have been on the streets so long they blur into the cityscape, regarded more and more as nuisance rather than tragedy. But their misery endures, and it presents only the most visible dimension of urban degradation.

title: Tension Easing, but Miners' Strike Against Pittston Goes On
description: The mood has lightened in Virginia's coal country.

title: April Ann Oliver To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wade Hampton Oliver of Columbia, S.C., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter, April Ann Oliver, and Dr. Jay Jeffrey Schulkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schulkin of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: In Bulgaria's House of Humor, Satirists Seem to Miss a Beat
description: The imposing bronze statue of Racho the Blacksmith stands on rocks in the middle of the Yantra River, a somewhat isolated spot for this city's legendary founder.

title: Where the Brokers Are Still Smiling
description: It's business as usual at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. and, considering the cutbacks on Wall Street these days, that is pretty remarkable. Take the branch near here in suburban Frontenac. One recent day, as the markets remained lackluster, there was the hum of business in the air. Phones were ringing, brokers were chatting up clients and plans were being made to find desks for people who had just been hired.

title: Campus Life: Texas; Crusade to Protect Bull Mascot's Ears Ends in Failure
description: Although previous Longhorn mascots have been barbecued and branded by teams from rival colleges, the last thing University of Texas students wanted representing their school was a hearing-impaired steer.

title: Evidence Points to Aluminum's Link With Alzheimer's Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Evening Hours; At Charity Galas, Ballet, Samba And Lots of Food
description: Elegant evening dresses and the sparkle of jewels brought grace and glitter to a week of charity galas. On Tuesday the New York City Ballet's opening night performance was followed by a supper dance on the promenade of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. Patty Davis Raynes organized the evening. Guests were ushered into the party by a Brazilian samba band, which made for a merry entrance.

title: SHOREHAM: A BAD IDEA THAT WON'T GO AWAY
description: LONG ISLANDERS who opposed the operation of Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear plant at Shoreham have been taken to task several times during the last year in the pages of newspapers.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Soon after we moved into our new home, a wood toilet paper roller was accidentally flushed down the toilet. All attempts to remove this with a snake have failed. Sometimes the toilet flushes O.K. and other times not. Do you know of anything that would dissolve the roller?

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Brookhaven $259,000 5 Beaver Court 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; finished basement, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $3,800. East Massapequa $140,000 690 Clark Boulevard 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 9-year-old high ranch; den, dining room, patio; taxes $3,300. Hauppauge $225,000 8 Allison Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old split ranch; den w/fireplace, deck, 0.6 acres, on cul-de-sac; taxes $3,800. Head of the Harbor $227,000 21 Three Sisters Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 300-year-old Colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace, screened porch; 0.2 acre; taxes $1,600. Lake Grove $192,000 14 Russet Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; den, dining room, fireplace, patio; taxes $3,200. Levittown $130,000 24 Heather Lane 4-bedroom, l-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, 60- by 100-foot lot; taxes $3,100. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. $465,000 White Birch Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 44-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, screened porch, pool, 5.05 acres; taxes $5,700. Darien, Conn.$510,000 203 Hollow Tree Ridge Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; pool, c/a, electronic security, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,086. Lakewood, N.J. $125,000 3 Central Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, h/w floors; taxes $1,825.

title: Sampson Sidelined
description: The Sacramento Kings placed Ralph Sampson, acquired just two months ago, on the injured list yesterday so the 7-foot-4-inch center can rehabilitate his weak knees.

title: In Its Final Days, Altman's Has Crowds at Last
description: SHOPPERS began lining up very early on Friday outside the B. Altman & Company store in Manhattan. The first day of the Christmas shopping season was also the second day of Altman's going-out-of-business sale. And while the prices may have been beatable - 20 percent was the standard discount -thousands wanted to get in on the last days of the retailer that for 124 years set a high standard for elegance, service and merchandise.

title: ANY WOMAN IS AN OUTSIDER
description: COMPOSING A LIFE By Mary Catherine Bateson. 241 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: Article 333889 -- No Title
description: THE SNOWS OF YESTERYEAR Portraits for an Autobiography. tr,br1 By Gregor von Rezzori. Translated by H. F. Broch de Rotherman. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Young Dancers Starring in Holiday Productions
description: THANSKGIVING is just behind us but the Christmas musical season has opened in the county. For starters, there are several Nutcrackers; the Tchaikovsky classic receiving four separate productions over the next two weeks.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Soon after we moved into our new home, a wood toilet paper roller was accidentally flushed down the toilet. All attempts to remove this with a snake have failed. Sometimes the toilet flushes O.K. and other times not. Do you know of anything that would dissolve the roller?

title: For 'Clown Ministry,' Laughter Is Gospel
description: CLOWNING around is not tolerated in most houses of worship. But at the Shore Christian Center Church here, it is heartily encouraged through a ''clown ministry'' that helps with everything from baby-sitting in church during services to visiting the sick and elderly at hospitals and nursing homes.

title: A Horse of a Different Stature
description: To the Editor:

title: Selling Crack: The Myth of Wealth -- A Special Report: Despite Its Promise of Riches, The Crack Trade Seldom Pays
description: The crack business, it turns out, is a modern, brutalized version of a 19th-century sweatshop.

title: 'I REMINDED EVERYBODY OF LYNDON'
description: THE LONE STAR The Life of John Connally. By James Reston Jr. Illustrated. 691 pp. New York: An Edward Burlingame Book/Harper & Row. $25.

title: Parents Debate Roles in AIDS Education
description: A NEW state law that requires AIDS education in public schools is getting mixed reviews from parents. Some say that such lessons should be taught at home and that the classes should stress abstinence rather than safe sex. Other parents say they are relieved that the schools are offering AIDS classes.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SAPPHO EXHIBITION

title: MONTREAL DEFEATS BRUINS
description: Mike McPhee, playing in only his second game since returning from a lengthy injury, scored his first two goals of the season as the Montreal Canadiens ended Boston's unbeaten string at nine games by recording a 5-3 victory over the Bruins tonight.

title: Wedding PlansFor Joan Fuld
description: Mr. and Mrs. James J. Fuld of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter Joan Fuld to Frank Strauss, the son of Dr. Dorothy Stanley of Virginia Beach, Va., and the late Walter Strauss. A January wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Low-Income Compromise
description: LEAD: The renovation of 128 apartments for low-income residents has begun on Christian Street in southwest Philadelphia after a developer and the city government agreed to steps to moderate neighborhood objections.

title: Gorbachev Is a Bit Cool Toward the Rumanians
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has sent a relatively cool telegram to the Rumanian leader, Nicolae Ceausescu, congratulating him on his re-election at a Communist Party conference in Bucharest, the Rumanian capital.

title: Stephanie Mehl Becomes Bride of Gary Seidman
description: Stephanie Mehl, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Mehl of Hackensack, N.J., was married last evening to Gary Seidman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Seidman of Wayne, N.J. Rabbi Linda Goodman officiated at 45 Downing Street in Manhattan.

title: Europe's Changes Mean Earlier Word of Attack
description: American intelligence experts have concluded that the United States is likely to have about a month or more of warning of a full-scale Soviet attack in Europe, or far more than it previously thought, Administration officials say.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SILVIO IN THE ROSE GARDEN. By Julio Ramon Ribeyro. Translated by Maria Rosa Fort and Frank Graziano. (Logbridge-Rhodes, Cloth, $20; Paper, $7.) The four stories in this slim collection by Julio Ramon Ribeyro, a Peruvian writer living in France, are tales of nemesis. Mr. Ribeyro's characters are lonely, aging, solitary men who are gradually and inexorably drawn to their terrible fates, which are determined not by the gods but by their private obsessions and secret fantasies.

title: California Musters Scientific Forces to Halt Fruit Fly Invasion
description: Experts are again using pesticides, traps and swarms of sterile flies to put down an infestation by the Mediterranean fruit fly in Southern California.

title:
FILM;
WHEN SAMURAI WARRIORS DID BATTLE IN CANADA
description: LEAD: The film director Haruki Kadokawa stands on the edge of 300-foot cliff, binoculars and megaphone at the ready, looking down on an army of 3,000 Canadian extras - 700 on horseback - dressed in the color-coded armor of 16th-century Jpanese warriors. The actors, unrecognizable as Westerners because of their masks and helmets, are gathered in a vast undeveloped river valley on the Stoney Indian Reserve, adjoining th Trans-Canada Highway 40 miles west of

title: Salvador War: Errors on Both Sides
description: The Salvadoran Army defeated the guerrillas in the battle for the cities but missed an opportunity to destroy a decade-old enemy.

title: THE 'G' WORD ISN'T GOVERNMENT
description: BUSYBODIES By Patrick Anderson. 256 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Review/Dance; Acerbic View of Society In Victoria Marks Trio
description: Victoria Marks called it ''Force of Nature.'' But her thought-provoking program of three dances on Monday night at Performance Space 122 could also have been called ''Social Problems.''

title: Miami Snaps Streak By Irish
description: On one frenzied evening in the Orange Bowl, the University of Miami ended Notre Dame's hope for a second consecutive perfect championship season, placed what had been the longest current major-college winning streak into the past and created a new set of contenders for the top of the final football polls.

title: INSIDE THE INTIFADA
description: The reference to Arabs lining up to find day work in '' 'slave markets' in Jerusalem'' is beneath contempt. When longshoremen are picked out to unload ships in the United States, is this a ''slave market''? If Arab contractors pick up laborers, is this a ''slave market''? And at what hour would one expect laborers to line up if they expect to do a full days' work, if not before 8 A.M.? This is, in fact, the starting time for most construction work, so it behooves laborers to be there well before 8, and 6 A.M. is not too early. HOWARD HIRSCH South Orange, N.J.

title: Erick Hawkins: Still Tapping Into The Sap of Spring
description: ''To characterize youth,'' Erick Hawkins said recently, ''you must have achieved a certain point of experience.''

title: R. A. Hoff Weds Jennifer Ablard
description: Jennifer Ann Ablard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles David Ablard of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Robert Alan Hoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Preston Hoff of Wilmington, Del. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Maria Eddy in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Alexandria.

title: Bringing Basic Health Care to the Poor
description: WITH the approach of winter, New York City's hospitals are bracing for what is fast becoming a sorry seasonal ritual: huge numbers of patients, many with preventable illnesses, packed double to a berth or spilling into emergency room hallways, waiting hours for treatment and, when needed, admission to scarce beds.

title: Again They Drink From the Cup Of Suspicion
description: ''The Crucible,'' written in 1953 by Arthur Miller, is produced constantly all over the world. On Thursday the play, which links the Salem witch trials of the 1690's to McCarthyism in the 1950's, will open at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, where Arvin Brown will direct a cast that includes John Braden, Charles Cioffi, Frank Converse and Virginia Downing. In March the Roundabout Theater in New York will also stage a production, directed by Gerald Freedman. In this essay the playwright discusses the origin and nature of his work.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: REGULATING THE MARKETS;
It's Time to Put Brady's Plan Into Effect
description: LEAD: On Friday Oct. 13, almost two years to the day after the crash of 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points. The sheer irrationality of both market collapses revealed fundamental infirmities in our market and regulatory system. A number of comprehensive market reform proposals - some of which contain important improvements in clearing mechanisms - are pending before the Congress.

title: Housing Over Aquifer: The Developer's Side
description: As the developer of the parcel that was the subject of ''Housing on Aquifer Opposed'' (Oct. 29), I'd like to make the following comments.

title: Campus Life: Wellesley; Sorority Applies For Recognition, Stirring a Debate
description: The distinction between a ''society'' and a sorority has sharply divided students at Wellesley College, since a national sorority applied to be recognized on campus. If accepted, the Lambda Upsilon chapter of Alpha Kappa Alpha, a predominantly black public-service sorority, would be the first national Greek society established at the 114-year-old women's college.

title: Same Language, But Not the Same
description: As I read ''Are We Speaking the Same Language?'' by Dorothy C. Judd (Opinion Page, Oct. 15), I felt as though I could have written it. I was born and raised in Boston; my late husband, in Maine (he never did sound like a ''State-o'-Mainer'' though his older sisters did, and still do, even after 50-plus years in Boston).

title: Amy Gantzel Wed To Mark Godfrey
description: Amy Frances Gantzel and Mark Holland Godfrey were married yesterday by the Rev. Gregory Floyd at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Aspen, Colo. The bride, 25 years old, is the daughter of Roberta Robson of Victoria, British Columbia, and Steen Gantzel of Aspen. Her husband, 27, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Gray Godfrey, was reared by his uncle and aunt Mr. and Mrs. John Schuhmacher Jr. of Aspen.

title: Social Events
description: Wild West Hoedown

title: BIG 'ANGER VOTE' IS SEEN IN PUNJAB
description: In the prosperous state of Punjab, homeland of Indian Sikhs, an embittered and divided electorate will choose only 13 of India's 545 members of Parliament. But among those 13 may be the widow of one of Indira Gandhi's assassins and two men now in prison, charged with complicity in her murder.

title: L. A. Hyland, Radar Pioneer, 92; Howard Hughes's Top Executive
description: Lawrence A. (Pat) Hyland, a pioneer in radar technology and aircraft communications who made the Hughes Aircraft Company an industrial giant, died at Antelope Valley Hospital here Friday after suffering a heart attack earlier in the week. He was 92 years old and lived in this Los Angeles suburb.

title: CONDUCT UNBECOMING?
description: If the controversial paper by Dr. Baltimore et al. that appeared in the journal Cell is so important, have any other laboratories tried to repeat their results and publish them? Surely, three years is more than enough time for others to confirm this data. FRANK ULRICH Medfield, Mass.

title: A Revival of 'Camelot,' An Old-Style Musical
description: TO no one's surprise, An Evening Dinner Theater is at its best with musicals that are tradition-bound, rather than technologically up to the minute or innovative in form. And if ever there was an old-style musical that is worth pondering every now and again, for message as well as music, it is ''Camelot.''

title: The Nuclear Industry Tries Again
description: Right now, the American nuclear power industry appears headed for extinction. Every plant of the more than 100 ordered since 1973 has been canceled, and many others are approaching retirement. But reactor manufacturers say that fears of global warming - the greenhouse effect - are giving them a second chance.

title: Soaking in the Pashas' Pools
description: Budapest is a bather's dream city. Nowhere else in the world will you find this combination of a rich cultural life, magnificent architecture and good restaurants with endless possibilities for bathing and swimming in pools fed by thermal springs.

title: Thieves Get Rich in Scrap Metal Boom
description: Over the past two years, this city has stuggled with a new form of highway robbery: Thieves have ripped out $120,000 worth of underground copper wires from street lights, knocking out the lights and leaving roads dangerously dark.

title: Deadline Looms
description: They haven't been built in a day, and at the rate construction has been going on 12 Italian soccer stadiums for the 1990 World Cup, there is some question as to whether they can be built at all, at least in time for the May deadline.

title: Atlantic Beach Split By Sabbath Border
description: LEAD: TO be able to carry small articles and push wheelchairs or baby carriages to the synagogue on the Sabbath, Orthodox Jews must extend the boundaries of their homes symbolically by establishing an ''eruv'' in the outer community.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner; From Pizza to Seafood, All Around Manhattan
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Canal Bar

title: Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Late Kick Lifts Penn State
description: A quarterback suspended earlier in the season and a place-kicker returning to the scene of a 1987 nightmare propelled Penn State to a 16-13 victory over Pitt today at Pitt Stadium.

title: Puzzling Claim About Function
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: No. The best American athletes play the more popular and lucrative American sports. Furthermore, there are not enough coaches and officials to teach and control soccer games. ROBERT E. MILLER New York

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:Armonk
description: LEAD: In the mid-19th century the railroads bypassed Armonk, and this picturesque hamlet survived the first six decades of the 20th century without a major highway. But now growth pressures are imposing themselves on the community, which covers six square miles of valley surrounded by ridges in east-central Westchester

title: Cuba Rights Advocates Sentenced for Slander
description: A Havana court sentenced three Cuban human rights advocates to prison after convicting them of giving false information to foreign journalists during a drug trial last summer, the Cuban government press agency reported.

title: Style Makers; Yan Basel, Decorative Artist ARTIST
description: On a visit to New York this month, Yan Basely thought about the artists who inspired his decorative designs, paintings that lend themselves to fabric, wallpaper and carpet. ''Watteau was always important,'' he said. Right now he is thinking of Thomas Hart Benton.

title: A Token of a Purposeful Life
description: MANY years ago, I inherited my father's pocket watch, a timepiece that had significance well beyond its practical use as a monitor of moments. It was a symbol of passage, an engraved token of termination, awarded 45 years ago by the management of the Soluble Coffee Division of General Foods at the culmination of a lifetime of service.

title: Wallpaper Without Tears
description: APPLYING wallpaper is no longer the tricky, messy task it once was. Although stronger paper and slower-drying adhesives have eased the job considerably, achieving smooth-surfaced results still depends on preparing the wall carefully before applying the paper.

title: Just One Holiday at a Time, Please
description: IT had been on my mind since Labor Day, but I put it off by doing important jobs that could not wait, like rearranging the towels in the linen closet. Finally I came to grips with it and sat at my sewing machine, searching for the instruction booklet that explains how to wind the bobbin and thread the needle.

title: POSTINGS: 21 Upscale Houses; Banker's Estate
description: Part of the estate of Percy H. Johnston, a millionaire banker who died in 1957, is being developed into 21 upscale homes in Montclair, N.J. Mr. Johnston's five-bedroom home, which was built in 1940, was sold earlier this year for $400,000 and the 21 houses are to be built on eight surrounding acres. Two model homes have been built, but none of the houses has been sold.

title: Why Groovy Isn't Groovy Anymore
description: By the end of 1990, record companies are saying, the vinyl LP will be mostly a memory. Statistics are piling up: According to the Recording Industry Association of America, which monitors the larger companies, in the first half of 1989 LP's accounted for only 4 percent of the value of recordings shipped; in units, LP's were outnumbered 12 to 1 by cassettes and nearly 6 to 1 by CD's. Some new albums, Billboard magazine reports, are being issued only as cassettes and CD's, with LP's to follow if they sell well.

title: Everything Goes Right as a Vintage Musical Is Restored
description: As a never-ending barrage of movies, television docudramas, and contemporary recordings of pop standards attests, it's easy to re-create the decor of another era but difficult to capture its spirit.

title: Hearing at Hand for Captain In Oil Spill in Alaskan Sound
description: Lawyers for the tanker captain accused of allowing the nation's worst oil spill to occur will seek to have his case thrown out of court on claims of immunity, a flawed sobriety test and other grounds, in a hearing that begins Monday.

title: Elizabeth O'Brien Married in West
description: Elizabeth Larkin O'Brien and John Charles Paxton were married yesterday in San Francisco by the Rev. Richard Fowler at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

title: Photojournalism: Heroism Meets Esthetics
description: Photojournalism, as it has been defined by its practitioners and mythologized by their admirers, is a discipline that combines aspects of social reform, individual heroism and emotional compassion. It also aspires to be recognized as art. But like photography as a whole, photojournalism does not slip seamlessly into the realm of the esthetic.

title: A Clinic To Visit Before You Go Abroad
description: LEAD: A DECADE ago, when Michele Barry, an associate professor of medicine at the Yale University School of Medicine, began working with refugees at the university's Southeast Asia Refugee Clinic, she noticed that many of the children had small, round burn marks on their bodies.

title: In the Streets of Prague, The Mood Is Victorious
description: Even before the sun rose this morning, the people of Prague began gathering to celebrate the resignation on Friday of the country's long-entrenched and conservative Communist Party leadership.

title: Dr. King and Lord Byron
description: To the Editor:

title: For Kremlin, Afghanistan Is No Europe
description: As they gathered by the glow of a 40-watt bulb here one evening this week, a group of Afghans opposed to the Soviet-backed Government of President Najibullah found hope in the recent events that have unseated Communist leaders in Eastern Europe. Government officials and Soviet diplomats, however, say the situations are not comparable.

title: The Bitter Legacy of Yalta: Four Decades of What-Ifs
description: ALMOST 45 years after Franklin D. Roosevelt returned from the Yalta conference, his heady vision of self-determination in Eastern Europe may finally be coming to pass, though in a manner quite different from the one he foresaw. In the intervening decades, ''Yalta'' has been one of the most charged words in the American political vocabulary - a potent symbol that critics have used to conjure sins from gross naivete to outright treason.

title: MORE GERMAN LESSONS
description: LEAD: THE SELECTED STORIES OF SIEGFRIED LENZ Edited and translated by Breon Mitchell. 225 pp. New York: New Directions. $19.95.

title: PRAGUE OPPOSITION MOUNTS HUGE PROTEST, DENOUNCING NEW LEADERSHIP AS 'A TRICK'
description: Opposition leaders redoubled their pressure on the tottering Communist regime in Czechoslovakia today, staging an immense protest rally and insisting that the shuffling of the Politburo on Friday night and further resignations this morning had failed to move the nation far enough toward democracy.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NANCY Written and illustrated by Karen Barbour. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE RISE AND FALL OF ANNE BOLEYN: Family Politics at the Court of Henry VIII. By Retha M. Warnicke. (Cambridge University, $29.95.) Retha M. Warnicke, a professor of history at Arizona State University, reinterprets Anne Boleyn's story from a feminist perspective and provides the most plausible explanation to date for her abrupt fall from royal glory to the block.

title: William Crawford Jr., Lawyer, Is Dead at 90
description: William Randall Crawford Jr., a lawyer in New York City, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 90 years old.

title: Q & A
description: Question: About 12 years ago my husband and his partner, who were both bachelors at the time, bought a co-op apartment. The shares are held in joint tenancy with a right-of-survivorship clause in their contract.

title: We're Sounder Than We Think
description: NEWSWEEK recently published an issue on the family of the future. The headline on the first article was, ''What Happened to the Family?'' I guess we have all wondered that from time to time.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: Frankly, I find soccer as exciting as watching ice melt. The sport has evolved into a series of 0-0, 1-0, and 2-1 games. Unless the rules and strategy open up to the point where a single goal is not something to riot over, I doubt the sport will ever capture the hearts and imagination of the American sports fan. PAUL M. WEISS New York

title: New Details Emerge on South African Death Squad
description: Fresh details of an alleged assassination squad operated by the South African police have emerged from a third man identifying himself as a squad member, and Government critics have continued to call for an independent judicial inquiry into the scandal.

title: POSTINGS: West of Broadway; Rialto Rehabs
description: Cleaning and dressing up the exteriors of two theaters just west of Broadway in Manhattan's rialto is costing their owner about $900,000. The facade of the Ritz Theater, at 219 West 48th Street, has just been cleaned and renovated for $400,000 and the Virginia Theater, at 245 West 52d Street, is undergoing a more extensive facelift that will also replace the marquee and doors at a total cost of $500,000.

title: 'They're Sold on Patriotism'
description: DAVID R. WALLACE of New Haven, a lieutenant colonel in the Army and a Vietnam combat pilot decorated seven times for heroism, has had a new challenge for the past year, as the Army's chief recruiter in Connecticut.

title: Class Consciousness: The Pros and Cons
description: The scrapbook-ready 1980's moment in ''Immediate Family,'' the film about a comfortable middle-class couple seeking to adopt the baby of an unwed lower-class teen-ager, is the one in which the prospective parents look at snapshots of the pregnant girl's family. Her late mother, a lank-haired hippie, is seen standing beside a clothesline; her stepfather, a truck driver, is positioned in front of a small house with a factory in the background. Seeing all this, the yuppies actually recoil in horror. The film allows them to respond this way without any hint of criticism or irony.

title: Diversity of Works In Clay and Glass
description: ADVICE to museumgoers: When you visit the exciting new skylighted atriums and expanded gallery space of the renovated Newark Museum, do not miss the two outstanding craft exhibitions.

title: Fewer Women Elected in Nassau
description: LEAD: THE number of women running and winning local, county and town elections in Nassau County declined this year from preceding years. The falloff was particularly noticeable in the Republican Party, which has an overwhelming edge in registration in both counties.

title: PLAN FOR HOMELESS IS CALLED MODEST
description: Advocates for the homeless welcome the Bush Administration's plans for helping homeless people as important and symbolic steps, but they say the proposal is too modest to have much impact on the growing problem.

title: How Freud Shaped the 20th-Century Mind
description: SCIENTISTS and philosophers still debate where Sigmund Freud's theories of psychoanalysis fit into the jigsaw puzzle of disciplines studying the brain and mind.

title: Reluctantly, the Military Embraces New Politics and Tighter Budgets
description: BUDGET officials were working late at the Pentagon last week as the Red Army Chorus launched into its program onstage at Kennedy Center, just across the river.

title: Cowboy Music, but No Horse
description: DOES anyone remember ''The Strawberry Roan,'' ''The Saginaw Trail'' and ''Texans Never Cry''?

title: Question Of the Week; Will Soccer Ever Be Popular In the U.S.?
description: No, for the following reasons: no sponsors or companies risking money to buy soccer franchises; no television coverage or rights money; no timeouts for television commericials; not enough United States players; salaries too low compared with baseball, football, etc., etc. ISMAEL R. ESCOBAR Flushing, Queens

title: Miss Jones Weds Johan Maitland
description: Lynda Kathryn Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Jones of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Johan Willem Edward Maitland, the son of Caro Maitland of Houston and the late Edward J. Maitland. The Revs. Richard B. Martin and Michael A. Drake officiated at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TO OPEN MINDS: Chinese Clues to the Dilemmas of Contemporary Education. By Howard Gardner. (Basic Books, $21.95.) After several trips to China to observe that country's nurseries, kindergartens and elementary schools in action, Howard Gardner writes: ''If there is too great a stress on untrammeled creativity - the American risk - the child may end up without skills and thus be able only to communicate or fantasize with himself.

title: Lifestyle; A Detachable Ponytail Puts Men in 2 Worlds
description: Karl Lagerfeld for a day. Marc Jacobs for the weekend. Robert DeNiro on location.

title: The High Price of Smiling
description: ALMOST everyone I know has a driver's license, yet none of my friends have ever shown theirs to me. Perhaps they are as ashamed of the photograph on it as I am of mine. People usually don't show them around, proudly, like baby pictures. Instead, they are carefully hidden in billfolds or handbags, retrieved only when identification is required.

title: More and More, Prison Is America's Answer to Crime
description: OFFICIALS in California expect this week to open a new 1,000-bed maximum security prison at Pelican Bay in the northern part of the state and to open another 1,200-bed wing there soon afterward, increasing the capacity of the country's largest state prison system to 49,767 inmates.

title: COLD FUSION CONFUSION
description: We are writing to correct Wade Roush's letter (Nov. 4) in response to our article ''Cold Fusion Confusion'' (Sept. 24). Although Brookhaven National Laboratory is a distinguished, multipurpose facility with many programs in numerous areas of science, it is not, as Mr. Roush claimed, ''an important center of conventional fusion research.'' Thus, the charge that the article was self-serving is misplaced. America's major fusion facilities are at Princeton and Lawrence-Livermore. ROBERT P. CREASE N. P. SAMIOS Brookhaven National Laboratory Upton, L.I.

title: The Real Superpower At the Summit Will Be The Force of History
description: PRESIDENT BUSH and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet each other off the coast of Malta next week at one of those rare moments when you can hear the pages of history turning - a moment when the 40-year-old arrangements of the postwar world are coming to an end and demanding redefinition. But Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will not be meeting to unfurl blueprints or draw lines on maps. The future is not theirs to define, as it was for Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin at Yalta in 1945.

title: U.S. JEWRY: IS THE MOMENTUM GONE?
description: THE JEWS IN AMERICA Four Centuries of an Uneasy Encounter: A History. By Arthur Hertzberg. 428 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: PattiSue Plumer Plans a Wedding
description: The engagement of PattiSue Plumer, a member of the 1988 United States Olympic track and field team, to Steven David Levere, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Levere of Wesley Hills, N.Y., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Thomas Purcell of Laguna Beach, Calif., and the Rev. Frederick Plumer of Irvine, Calif. A December wedding is planned.

title: SHOWDOWN AT WINDOW ROCK
description: UNDER THE BRILLIANT BLUE ARIZONA SKY, AN air-conditioned GMC Sierra bumps along a weed-choked wagon track near the main road to Kaibito, just south of Many Waters Lake, at the foot of the Peak Where the Wildcats Stretch. In the back seat, Peter MacDonald, the embattled leader of the Navajo nation, peers through the tinted glass window at a distant figure on horseback.

title: From the Ashcan School Tradition, City Scenes at the Bronx Museum
description: ARTISTS of the same generation, Isabel Bishop and Reginald Marsh both followed the tradition established by the Ashcan School and both gentrified it. Marsh's female archetype appears to be a floozie but she is essentially a Rubenesque creature, and his crowds, though they lounge on Coney Island, are not far removed from those of Rubens and other Baroque painters.

title:
ART;
Works With Stories to Tell
description: LEAD: THE opening exhibition at the handsomely renovated Mercer Community College Art Gallery in West Windsor brings together seven figurative artists in a show that tells us what narrative art is like right now.

title: A Market Mushrooms as Motivations Change
description: Dieting is no longer an obsession of women in search of a thinner profile. There is a growing national consensus that being overweight is unhealthy - as well as unattractive. The burgeoning weight-control business is bound to grow fatter.

title: Federal Plan for Police Corps Divides Officials
description: BESIEGED by crime and eager to attract top-quality officers, New Jersey police agencies are intrigued by a Federal proposal that would offer scholarships to college students willing to wear a badge after graduation. But some law-enforcement officials have expressed skepticism over the proposal.

title: Can Movies Teach History?
description: Something strange - not new, but ever more conspicuous - haunts the cultural landscape. Movie makers and television producers have become our most powerful, though perhaps not our most careful, historians. It seems fair to say that more people are getting their history, or what they think is history, from the movies these days than from the standard history books. The phenomenon is probably unavoidable, yet, if the history as presented by the movies turns out to be a muddy blur of fantasy and fact, the consequences cannot be good. In the 16th century, Francis Bacon said that history makes men wise. It follows that bad history, trivialized history, history distorted and sensationalized, can make them foolish.

title:
Critics Pick Some Favorites Of the Year;
A Flawless 'Onegin' With Mirella Freni
description: LEAD: Deutsche Grammophon's recording of Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin'' with Thomas Allen, Mirella Freni, Neil Shicoff and the Staatskapelle Dresden conducted by James Levine (423 959) is about as flawless an opera recording as I have recently heard. Mr. Levine emphasizes the instrumental beauty of the score and does so with sensitivity to his singers.

title: Scholars Say Veneer of Nonchalance Masks Worry on German Unification
description: Experts at American universities say anxiety about the prospect of German reunification is widespread in Europe and the United States despite declarations by Western leaders that they are unconcerned and that the issue should be resolved by the Germans themselves.

title: Residential Resales

title: Jill Renaud Plans March Wedding
description: The engagement of Jill Renaud to Richard MacDonald Jones, the son of Thomas Henry Jones of Ashland, Ore., and the late Elizabeth Hopkins Jones of Weston, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Gertrude Yang Renaud of New York. A March wedding is planned.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: COVINGTON, KY.;
Riverfront Rival For Cincinnati
description: LEAD: THE opening next March of RiverCenter, an $89 million office, hotel and entertainment complex along the southern shore of the Ohio River, will complete the first phase of a 10-year commercial development agenda for Covington's two-mile-long riverfront.

title: 10 Questioned Over Bomb Found on Saudi Jet
description: The police questioned 10 passengers today about a bomb found on Thursday aboard a Saudi jumbo jet carrying 339 people. The bomb failed to go off, and the plane returned safely to Pakistan.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: TRIBUTE TO HARRY JAMES

title: A Museum That Exhibits The Lives of Workers
description: THE Dog Museum in Manhattan proved long ago that nothing is immune to preservation. Still, there always seems to be room for one more educational institution, and the latest to be developed in Connecticut is the Windham Textile and History Museum, at the corner of Union and Main Streets in Willimantic, which used to be known as Thread City.

title: Japan Will Help Poland and Hungary
description: Responding to appeals from the Bush Administration and European nations, Japan has announced that it would provide $150 million in loans to Poland as an initial step to help both Poland and eventually Hungary deal with their financial crises and break loose from the Soviet bloc.

title: Lifestyle; Learning to Be a Beer Connoisseur
description: Raspberry ale? Is this man serious?

title: A New Industry Springs Up: Europe 1992
description: While many American businesses are still trying to figure out how to take advantage of the 12-nation European Community's move to a single market economy in 1992, others are already profiting from it.

title: Homeless Man Gets Boost in Life
description: SOMETIMES in the evening Stephen Pearman and his wife, Helena, jog along the boardwalk near their Asbury Park apartment. They lean against the rail and watch the waves spill onto the jetty.

title: Tokyo Journal; An American Is Enthroned and Japan Is Shaken
description: Japan's ancient art of sumo wrestling rumbled and shook today when a 490-pound 25-year-old Hawaiian named Konishiki, easily the most instantly recognizable American in the Japanese islands, pushed, slapped and shoved his way to the country's most coveted sports prize, the Emperor's Cup.

title: Urging Reforms, Youth Organization in East Germany Announces It Is Leaving the Communist Fold
description: East Germany's national youth organization, the training ground of the country's elite, severed its formal ties to the Communist Party over the weekend and endorsed democratic change.

title: Hope Is Seen for Poor of 7-State Delta
description: In many ways geography has wrought a common destiny for much of the lower Mississippi River delta as the centuries-old rhythm of flooding and receding waters made the agricultural bottomland fertile, attracting farmers and thousands of laborers to work the land.

title: It's All Untrue: Lendl Spurns The Lendl Myth
description: It hardly comes as a surprise that the house Ivan Lendl lives in is made of stone, great slabs of gray and beige stone, and is protected from the rest of the world by two fences: a natural baffle of hemlocks backed up by a no-nonsense span of chain link. Protecting himself - on the job with a dentist's drill of a forehand, at leisure with a battery of sarcasm that passes for cocktail-hour banter, at home with a meticulously trained quartet of brainy German shepherds - has long been a top concern of the world's top tennis player.

title: EL SALVADOR HALTS TIES TO NICARAGUA
description: President Alfredo Cristiani today suspended diplomatic and commercial relations with Nicaragua and accused the Sandinista Government of instigating the recent rebel offensive here to divert attention from its own internal problems.

title: ELECTION IN INDIA APPEARS TO DENY GANDHI A MAJORITY
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party appear to have lost their majority in the Indian Parliament and will be out of power unless they form a coalition government, according to early results in the country's most violent national election, which ended on Sunday.

title: Chip Operation In U.S. May Go To the Japanese
description: In a deal that would leave the United States almost wholly dependent on Japan for the chief tools used to produce future generations of computer chips, Japanese companies are negotiating to acquire one of the last American makers of the highly sophisticated equipment used to etch circuits on chips.

title: PRAGUE PREMIER SEES TOP FOES, SHARES PLATFORM WITH DUBCEK; PARTY CALLS SPECIAL CONGRESS
description: The caretaker Prime Minister in Czechoslovakia's Communist Government met today for the first time with leaders of the foremost opposition grouping and then joined Alexander Dubcek at another rally of 500,000 cheering people, who continued to demand democratic changes.

title: Question Box
description: Crow the Cardinal

title: Advice to Sherpas
description: One practical question is burning in the minds of the President and his pre-summit sherpas: What will it take to get the Red Army completely out of Eastern Europe?

title: A Blow From a Pipe Kills a 4-Month-Old As 2 Fight Over Him
description: A 4-month-old boy was killed in Brooklyn on Saturday night when a pipe-wielding man struck another man who had grabbed the infant and claimed to be his father, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Slater Hanft Martin has accepted an assignment to create public service advertising for the National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis. The foundation has designated the 1990's the ''Decade of the Cure'' for the chronic intestinal illnesses.

title: Tinker Looks Beyond 'USA Today on TV'
description: GTG Entertainment, the production company formed by Grant A. Tinker and the Gannett Company almost three years ago, has yet to come up with a hit program, although it has taken several hits itself.

title: 3d and 44: Play to Remember
description: Somewhere in southern Florida, not far from the Coral Gables campus of the University of Miami, the T-shirts and bumper stickers may have already gone into production.

title: Pressures Unabated, Both in East and West
description: Marxism will be revived in the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said, responding to conservatives.

title: Ms. Wolff Weds Clayton Gordon
description: Laura Ann Wolff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Wolff of New York, was married yesterday to Clayton W. Gordon, a son of Mrs. John Krug of Mott, N.D., and the late Wallace Gordon. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridien Hotel in New York.

title: Czech Riddle: Who'll Lead?
description: The sign on the wall said ''Old Play, New Cast,'' reflecting the dissatisfaction of most people here with the pace of political change, even as all semblance of unity within the Communist Party vanished in a welter of resignations, demands, concessions and emergency meetings.

title: Braniff Can Keep Its Jets
description: A judge in Federal Bankruptcy Court ruled on Saturday that Braniff Inc.'s agreements to lease and buy new jets are valid, allowing the troubled airline to keep its most valuable asset.

title: Cut Expected In Prime Rate This Week
description: The prime lending rate, which most commercial banks have held at 10.5 percent since late July, is likely to be lowered by half a percentage point this week, some credit market analysts and economists said.

title: A Clean Political Background Helps Official Rise in Tumult
description: Czechoslovakia's caretaker Prime Minister, Ladislav Adamec, has emerged as a central figure in the political ferment set off by demonstrations against political repression.

title: William Murphy, 67, Vice President's Uncle
description: William C. Murphy, an uncle of Vice President Dan Quayle and a former executive of Eli Lilly and Company, died Wednesday. He had been hospitalized for a heart ailment and he was 67 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: A Threat in Lebanon The nation's new President, Elias Hrawi, threatened to use military force against Gen. Michael Aoun, the hard-line Christian military commander, who disputes the presidency and controls sizable forces. Page A14. Companies Look Abroad With some reluctance, small American companies are expanding overseas operations, moving beyond shipping goods to setting up operations in foreign countries. Page D1. Whose Right to Die? The Supreme Court will hear arguments Dec. 6 on whether a Missouri couple can remove a feeding tube from their comatose daughter so she can be allowed to die. Page B9. Hearings on Fare Increases Proposed increases in the prices of commuting by train, riding a subway or taking a cab in New York City all come up for public hearings or final votes this week. Page B1. Five Dollars an Hour!?! A profusion of babies and a shortage of teen-agers has left parents hoarding sitters' names and getting into bidding wars. Page B1.

title: Review/Music; Exotica From Kronos
description: Say what one might about the Kronos Quartet's deficiencies in ensemble polish and tone - and there is much to be said on those matters - it must be granted that few quartets offer programs as inventive, varied and exotic as the Kronos consistently does. On Saturday evening, in the first of its three concerts this season at Alice Tully Hall, the group gave premieres of works by Ugandan, Sudanese, Cuban, American and Argentine composers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Doner Wins Account
description: Maryland's largest bank awarded its advertising account last week to W. B. Doner, a Baltimore agency. Maryland National Bank said the switch had come after its recent merger with Equitable Bank and an extensive agency search. Doner would not disclose the budget of the account, which has been reported by the advertising trade press as being $5 million to $7 million.

title: Review/Television; The Twilight of 'America's Century'
description: ''America's Century,'' Lewis H. Lapham's dour and dire view of the decline of American power and confidence over the last 100 years, comes to its gloomy conclusion tonight with a litany of events that have shaken the nation's sense of itself.

title: East Berlin Fills Void: Road Map of the West
description: East Germany is about to publish its first road map of West Germany since the 1950's.

title: Outracing Death Aboard Ambulance 18-Y
description: Numbed by a long night of drinking, Carlos Williams seemed hardly fazed early Saturday by the knife slash opening up the left side of his face.

title: Japanese Banks' Profits Slip
description: Japan's five leading banks, the biggest in the world, all reported lower interim profits last week because of rising interest rates that increased their borrowing costs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Sports World Specials: HOCKEY; Tournament of Ages
description: Sometimes there are advantages to getting older or even approaching middle age. This past weekend age was a prerequisite to getting into the Ingalls Rink in New Haven to see the Yale Hockey Classic, a tournament involving Yale, Air Force, Colgate and Northeastern.

title: Bahrain Tubing Factory
description: Bahrain plans to build a $37 million copper tubing plant, the first of its kind in the region. Abdulla al-Kobaisi, head of the Bahraini company behind the project, said Saturday that the plant would have an initial capacity of 12,000 tons of tubing a year and that output could expand to 20,000 tons.

title: India Looks to Its President After an Indecisive Election
description: With neither the Congress Party of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi nor the opposition heading for a clear majority in Parliament, attention turned today to President Ramaswamy Venkataraman, a former Gandhi aide who now apparently has the power to tap either side to form a coalition Government.

title: A Fallen Star Continues Fight For Top Status
description: LEAD: HIWASSEE COLLEGE, a small two-year school that takes its name from the Cherokee word for rolling meadows, is an island of tranquillity nestled in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains. Yet for Eric Manuel, who longs to return to big-time college basketball, it is purgatory.

title: Roughriders Take Title
description: David Ridgway kicked a 35-yard field goal with 2 seconds left to give the Saskatchewan Roughriders a 43-40 victory over the Hamilton Tiger-Cats in the Grey Cup game tonight at the Skydome.

title: University Press Becomes Big Distributor for Small Publishers
description: Within hours after a Federal Bankruptcy Court released the books of several dozen small publishers last summer from a Connecticut warehouse, where they had been impounded after their distributor filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, the first of a dozen moving vans began streaming toward this one-time mill town between Baltimore and Washington.

title: Excerpts From Addresses by Premier and Czech Dissident at Prague Rally
description: Following are excerpts from addresses by the caretaker Prime Minister, Ladislav Adamec, and the dissident playwright Vaclav Havel at an opposition rally here today, as translated by The Associated Press: Remarks by Adamec

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week. Monday Automobile Sales ... Mid-Nov. Tuesday Merchandise Trade ... 3d Qtr. Wednesday G.N.P. (Revised) ... 3d Qtr. Corporate Profits (Rev.) ... 3d Qtr. Thursday Personal Income ... Oct. Farm Prices ... Nov. Friday Leading Indicators ... Oct. Construction Spending ... Oct. Purchasing Managers' Index ... Oct.

title: De Lorean Wins a Round
description: Lawyers for John Z. De Lorean, whose Belfast-based car company went bankrupt in 1982, won a High Court order on Friday setting aside an earlier court order against him for more than $51 million.

title: Jets Overwhelm Falcons by 27-7
description: As the bleak skies turned into sunshine at Giants Stadium this afternoon, so did the Jets' fortunes turn for the better. Jet receivers began clutching passes. Jet backs began breaking tackles. Jet kickers began clicking. Jet defenders became stout.

title: Strike Set at Detroit Papers
description: Members of newspaper unions here voted today to authorize a strike against The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press, which were to merge their business operations on Monday.

title: Hungarians Hold First Free Vote In 42 Years, Shunning a Boycott
description: In the first free national vote in 42 years, Hungarians went to the polls today for a referendum on when a presidential election will be held.

title: Edged Out of Spotlight, Kohl Endures
description: It seems almost tempting to pity Helmut Kohl these days. With history being made all around him, the limelight seems to be everywhere but on the West German Chancellor.

title: Riders Want Subway Rules of Conduct Enforced
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy, 12, Is Killed Playing on Elevator
description: A 12-year-old boy was found dead Saturday on top of an elevator where had been playing in a Harlem building, the Housing Authority police said.

title: Gorbachev Article Excerpts: 'A New Aspect of Socialism'
description: Following are excerpts from an article by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, as translated by the official press agency Tass, from yesterday's edition of the Communist Party newspaper Pravda. The article, titled ''The Socialist Idea and Revolutionary Perestroika,'' was described by Pravda as having synthesized and developed ideas set forth by Mr. Gorbachev in a number of recent speeches.

title: Ill Pupils As Poets: New Hope
description: In his poetry, 7-year-old Mario Burgos flies to the moon and New Jersey, where he eats hamburgers and has a magic wand to make the stars disappear.

title: British Will Return Exiles to Vietnam Despite U.S. Plea
description: Despite strong objections by President Bush, British Government officials said today that they planned to go ahead with the forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong, probably starting within the next few months.

title: Prince Puts Humanity Before Architects
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman Is Named At NCNB Texas Bank
description: LEAD: Timothy P. Hartman, the vice chairman of the NCNB Texas National Bank since it was set up by the NCNB Corporation 15 months ago, will become chairman of the unit on Jan. 1.

title: Review/Ballet; Sentiment Flavors Lightheartedness
description: The New York City Ballet offered four lighthearted works by George Balanchine on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: New York Health Chief Goes Wrong on AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Parental Consent Could Justify Forced Abortion; Public Shouldn't Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Both Sides Hopeful In Contract Talks
description: For the last 18 years, the score reads: Strikes 4, Lockouts 2. Beginning tomorrow, labor representatives of baseball's club owners and players will try to avoid adding to that score on either side.

title: Julie Spira Wed To Robert Campi
description: Julie Spira, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hillard Spira of Glen Rock, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert J. Campi, a son of Thomas Campi of New York and Sally Campi of Malibu, Calif. Rabbi Hyman Krantz officiated at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: Performing Arts Library for the West
description: The growth of the performing arts in the Bay Area, from the days of the gold rush to the present, is documented in a collection of memorabilia that is soon to be open to the public for the first time. The 50-year-old collection, once known as the San Francisco Dance Archives, will make its debut Friday as the San Francisco Performing Arts Library and Museum in new quarters on Grove Street, near the Performing Arts Center.

title: Foreign Aid for Manila
description: Foreign governments have committed $2 billion to a five-year Philippine aid plan intended to help the economy recover, Roberto Villanueva, chairman of the aid program coordinating council, said last week. He said the money, part of a $3.5 billion package promised by foreign governments in Tokyo in July, was covered by signed agreements.

title: Nazi Refugee Returns for Ph.D. Final
description: When Nina Rubinstein fled Nazi Germany 56 years ago, she escaped to France with few possessions except her books and the doctoral dissertation that she had just completed - on political emigres. She never had a chance to defend her thesis before faculty members or to receive a degree.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Transitions; Graffiti Memory
description: An indisputable improvement in New York City's quality of life in the last decade was the eradication of graffiti from subway cars. So Transit Authority employees were understandably upset when, on a recent visit to the new Disney-MGM Studios at Disney World, they saw a graffiti-smeared subway car in a stage set for a movie that is set in contemporary New York.

title: Demonstrators Support Ukrainian Church
description: Tens of thousands of Ukrainians demonstrated in three cities in the vast southern republic today to demand the legalization of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, banned since the rule of Stalin, campaigners for religious rights reported.

title: O.E.C.D. Is Optimistic On American Economy
description: The United States can avoid both a recession and excessive inflation next year, so long as the Federal Reserve keeps an even grip on credit, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development says in a report to be released on Monday.

title: Longer Putter Aids Golfers Who Misalign
description: A putter that was designed as a golf training device is being marketed for tournament play as well.

title: Why Slippery Rick Is No. 1
description: BACK in the old days before computers, assorted wags and pundits used to prove that Slippery Rock State from Pennsylvania was the best college football team in the country.

title: Parental Consent Could Justify Forced Abortion; Who Has Authority?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tool Orders Fell 32.3% In October
description: Orders for American machine tools dropped 32.3 percent in October from the September level, largely because the auto industry cut back its orders, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said in a monthly report released today.

title: Business and the Law; Product Liability's 'Quiet Revolution'
description: TWO professors at Cornell Law School report that a ''quiet revolution'' in the area of product liability is sweeping across the nation.

title: Washington at Work; Tale of Two Yuris: For Soviet Ambassador, These Are the Best of Times
description: Yuri Vladimirovich Dubinin calls himself ''a popularizer of perestroika,'' a salesman of the new Soviet thinking that brings Red Army watches to Bloomingdale's and blasts holes in the Berlin Wall.

title: U.S. Shift On Subsidies
description: Agriculture Department officials say they will change an export subsidy program to insure that it furthers American trade goals without harming countries that do not subsidize exports of commodities.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Stanislaus M. Shibinsky has been named senior vice president and executive creative director of BBDO Detroit.

title: Cheney Encourages Soviets To Make Greater Arms Cuts
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney encouraged the Kremlin today to go beyond the cuts in conventional arms that it has already agreed to in talks in Vienna, suggesting that the United States would reciprocate with further reductions in its forces in Europe.

title: Sports World Specials: MARATHON; Fancy Soviet Footwork
description: Eyebrows were raised last week when Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club and the director of the New York City Marathon, emerged as the key figure in a drive to upgrade the nine-year old Moscow Marathon into a premier event.

title: Accounts
description: * Six Flags Great Adventure theme park to Bozell, with a budget of $3 million to $4 million.

title: Review/Television; An Updated Mary Richards in 'Murphy Brown'
description: She's bright and beautiful and not married. She works in television news. With a ''family'' consisting largely of colleagues at the office, she heads the kind of acting ensemble that, periodically and magically, can make the much-abused sitcom format memorable. Nearly 20 years ago, she was the adorably spunky Mary Richards on CBS's ''Mary Tyler Moore Show'' (Sept. 19, 1970 to March 19, 1977). Now, Mondays at 9 P.M. on the same network, she's ''Murphy Brown,'' played with marvelously stylish elan by Candice Bergen. The sitcom doesn't get any better than this.

title: Tokyo Faults Bid Practice
description: The Fair Trade Commission of Japan said Friday that two Japanese computer manufacturers might have engaged in unfair trade practices by bidding one yen on local government projects.

title: Books of The Times; A Christmas Gallery of Wonderlands to Dream In
description: '' 'What is the use of a book,' thought Alice, 'without pictures or conversation?' '' There may not be many conversations in the following selection of books to give for Christmas, but there is material galore to get a conversation going. And there are pictures in such glorious profusion that to Alice they would have offered new Wonderlands to dream in.

title: With 3 Hits Now on Broadway, Stephen Sondheim Writes On
description: It's not that everything's coming up roses these days for Stephen Sondheim. It's that everything's coming up roses and daffodils. And sunshine and Santa Claus.

title: Rights Unit Accuses U.S. on Salvador
description: Americas Watch, a New York-based human rights organization, has accused the Bush Administration of trying to cover up abuses by the Salvadoran Army during this month's offensive by guerrillas.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Programs Get Youths to Shape Up
description: LEAD: WE have heard the bad news: American youths are out of shape and overweight and becoming more so.

title: Parental Consent Could Justify Forced Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Maria Sanchez, 63, Connecticut Legislator
description: Maria C. Sanchez, a Connecticut State Representative who built a political base from a small convenience store in Hartford, died on Saturday at her home there. She was 63 years old and died of natural causes, said Robert Clark, director of the DeLeon Funeral Home in Hartford.

title: Scaling the Heights Has Moved Indoors
description: HIDDEN in the heart of Manhattan is a new recreational amenity: an indoor wall used by amateur rock and mountain climbers to simulate outdoor conditions and practice their hobby.

title: Placer Dome QPX Stake
description: Placer Dome Inc. said on Friday that it had bought more than a million shares of QPX Minerals Inc., raising its stake in the Vancouver-based company to 25 percent from 15.2 percent.

title: New Lebanese President Warns Renegade General
description: The new President of Lebanon, Elias Hrawi, threatened today to use military force against Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian Army commander who claims to be President and controls a sizable armed force based in and around East Beirut.

title: New Magazine Planned To Challenge TV Guide
description: The publisher of the monthly Cable Guide plans to challenge the 30-year dominance of TV Guide and local newspapers in providing a weekly roadmap to the ever-expanding landscape of television.

title: Man Killed in Dispute in Times Square Store
description: A 28-year-old man was shot and killed in a Times Square convenience store early yesterday, and a man who said he was the killer surrendered soon afterward, the police said.

title: Lawmakers Say Pentagon Hasn't Thought Through Its Cuts
description: Members of Congress who deal with military policy say the Pentagon is scrambling to propose cuts in troops and weapons for budget reasons without thinking through the altered strategic needs dictated by political upheaval in Eastern Europe.

title: Legalizing Drugs: Failures Spur Debate
description: The idea of legalizing drugs is emphatically rejected by the Bush Administration, by Congress and by huge majorities of Americans in opinion surveys. But it has gained surprising force in recent months, propelled by growing doubts that the Government can win its war on illicit drugs.

title: Hours Before Scheduled Return, Shuttle Landing Is Put Off a Day
description: High winds in the California desert today delayed the return of the space shuttle Discovery from its classified military mission until Monday.

title: Rams Top Saints; Mark for Anderson
description: Willie Anderson set a National Football League record for single-game receiving with 336 yards as the Los Angeles Rams beat the New Orleans Saints, 20-17, in overtime tonight.

title: Giants vs. 49ers: Is It a Big Deal?
description: The coaches, as coaches like to do, call it just another game. But when the Giants and the 49ers meet Monday night before a sellout crowd at Candlestick Park and a national television audience, it will be something special, as at least one person involved was willing to admit.

title: On Feeling Underpaid at $1 Million
description: In the movie industry, where status is everything, the roughly three-quarters of a billion dollars Sony paid to have Peter Guber and Jon Peters run Columbia Pictures has made almost every other executive feel like a second-class citizen.

title: Bridge
description: Two experts probably thought that winning a world title in September was the high point of their year. But Kerri Shuman and Margie Gwozdzinsky, both of Manhattan, are having second thoughts.

title: Pride of the New Leader's Hometown
description: In this Moravian village of 7,000 the men often drop by the local cafe after Sunday Mass while their wives go home to prepare the traditional afternoon meal. The conversation tends to be about squabbles at work, sports or the weather. But today the talk was about the tumultuous events that brought Karel Urbanek, a hometown boy, to head the Communist Party.

title: Outdoors: Still Life and Wildlife on Lush Anticosti
description: THE usual visitor to Quebec's remote Anticosti Island goes there in quest of deer or Atlantic salmon. But an effort has been started to attract summer tourists: hikers, campers, bird-watchers, fossil hunters and part-time anglers who would enjoy an offbeat sojourn in a wild and lovely spot.

title: Suburbs Trying Alternatives To Hotels for Their Homeless
description: By bending Federal reimbursement rules, state and county officials in the suburbs around New York City have found a way to channel millions of dollars away from welfare hotels for homeless people and into the creation of permanent low-cost housing.

title: Oregon: Put Through the Mill
description: LEAD: Imagine New York City without Wall Street. That is what Oregon would be like without the wood products industry. Four of every 10 dollars that Oregonians earn are made from the harvesting and cutting of trees.

title: At the Summit, Bush's Turn to Act
description: LEAD: President Bush needs to start responding positively to Mikhail Gorbachev, beginning with the upcoming summit meeting.

title: Johanna M. Hopkins, Educator, 94
description: Johanna M. Hopkins, who was a schools superindendent in the northwest Bronx from 1942 to 1964 and the first woman to hold such a post in New York City, died Thursday in the Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. She was 94 years old and lived in Kings Park, L.I.

title: If the Party Has Its Back to the Wall, It's a Wall With New Posters on It
description: The underground press is thriving in Prague these days. The rare clandestine documents of previous generations have given way to a flood of homemade handbills and posters that adorn the city's walls and windows, subway cars and stations.

title: Correction
description: An obituary in some editions Saturday about John Kaplan, a law professor and author, omitted the name of a survivor. He is a brother, Benjamin, of Brooklyn.

title: Another Big Day for Goalie
description: The first indication that things were different for Tony Meola today was the number of people in the University of Virginia stadium when he walked onto the field to warm up. There couldn't have been more than several hundred, and by game time, no more than about 2,800, all of them bunched together on one side.

title: The Limits of Medicare
description: In last week's rush to adjourn, Congress took a bold step forward and a giant leap backward on medical insurance for the elderly. The step forward was a system to control total physician billings. The leap backward was repeal of catastrophic health insurance - which protected the elderly against bankrupting medical bills.

title: Honduras Votes for a Leader To Tread Between Two Wars
description: Voters in this nation stuck between two civil wars voted today for a president who will have to deal with the sticky questions of how to get rid of thousands of Nicaraguan rebels and what to do with half a million war refugees.

title: Market Place; Troubled Stock Backed a Loan
description: IT may go down as the case of the gullible banker. Just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission halted trading in shares of Lifeline Healthcare Group Inc. last summer and expressed concern about the accuracy of the company's accounting, company executives managed to arrange a $1.5 million loan from the Bank of New England, secured by such shares.

title: Quotas Now Matter Less, But They Still Divide OPEC
description: After four days of talks here, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continues to scramble for an agreement on new production quotas. But the dispute among its 13 members is not expected to have a significant effect on world oil prices.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; An Award Winner Awaits the Big Break
description: THE founders of Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein seem like talented Broadway understudies waiting in the wings for the parts that will finally make them stars.

title: Small Companies Going Global
description: Small American companies, which already account for a fifth of United States exports, are increasingly taking the next step to becoming global businesses: they are setting up operations overseas, not just shipping their goods abroad.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Strange Is Big Winner: Curtis Strange chipped in with a 9-iron from 35 feet on the 13th hole for a $135,000 prize and capped the Skins Game with a $70,000 putt on the final hole yesterday in La Quinta, Calif. Strange, shut out of money winnings in his first Skins Game appearance last year, emerged as the big winner this time, collecting $265,000 from the total purse of $450,000. Jack Nicklaus won $90,000 - $35,000 of it on a routine, two-putt par-5, in the 18-hole, two-day event at the P.G.A. West Stadium course. Ray Floyd won $60,000 and Lee Trevino avoided a shutout with a 3-foot birdie putt on the 14th hole worth $35,000. (AP) Aoki Edges Mize: Isao Aoki birdied the 16th hole yesterday and won the $714,000 World Open tournament in Kaimoncho, Japan, by one shot over Larry Mize. Aoki shot a three-under-par 69 for the day, giving him a total of 274 on the 7,014-yard, par-72 Kaimon course of the Ibusuki Golf Club in southern Japan. Mize finished with a 70.(AP) N.B.A. Lakers 132, Spurs 112: Magic Johnson and Byron Scott scored 24 points each as the Lakers overpowered the San Antonio Spurs in Inglewood, Calif., for their ninth victory in a row. David Robinson, the Spurs' rookie center, had 23 points and 17 rebounds. (AP) Clippers 120, Bulls 96: Ron Harper had 36 points and Gary Grant added 17 assists as the Clippers beat the road-weary Chicago Bulls. Charles Smith added 23 points for the Clippers, who enjoyed their biggest victory margin of the season. Michael Jordan scored 26 points for the Bulls, who were playing their seventh straight road game.(AP) Trail Blazers 102, Pistons 82: Clyde Drexler had 27 points, 10 rebounds and 9 assists as Portland beat Detroit at home for its fifth straight victory.Portland took the lead for good in the game's first six minutes and led 41-30 at halftime. The 30 points tied a Portland franchise record for lowest scoring half by an opponent.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 4, Whalers 2: Phil Housley, Dave Andreychuk and Uwe Krupp scored within a 5-minute span in the second period as Buffalo beat Hartford last night to remain the National Hockey League's only unbeaten team at home. Buffalo is 10-0-1 in Memorial Auditorium this season.(AP) North Stars 5, Blackhawks 3: Dave Gagner snapped a 2-2 tie early in the second period and Mike Gartner followed with two goals within a span of 3:11 in the period as Minnesota improved to 13-1 at home.(AP) Tennis Seles Takes German Final: Monica Seles of Yugoslavia beat Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-1, 7-5, yesterday to win the $500,000 Nokia Masters tournament in Essen, West Germany. (AP) Horse Racing Sir Richard Lewis Is First: Sir Richard Lewis beat Fifteen Gold Stars by a neck yesterday in the $200,000 New York Stallion Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct. Sir Richard Lewis, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. and carrying top weight of 119 pounds, won for the third time in six starts this year. He covered a mile on the fast track in 1:39 2/5 to earn $120,000 for Regents Farms and paid $3 for $2 to win. Fifteen Gold Stars was 5 1/4 lengths ahead of Skate's Honor.(AP)

title: Offshore Banks For Mauritius
description: Mauritius, which wants to become a financial center for Africa, said Friday that it had approved two more applications to set up offshore banks.

title: Parental Consent Could Justify Forced Abortion; The Law Has Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: Fodor Performs Benefit In Massachusetts
description: The violinist Eugene Fodor gave a benefit performance on Saturday across the street from the courthouse where he was sentenced last month on a drug-related charge.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Celebrating A Loss of Independence
description: EXACTLY three years ago, shortly after he had become president of the Hicks & Greist agency in New York, Hank Seiden said in an interview that he was ''fiercely independent'' and that he would never allow his agency to be swallowed up by a larger company.

title: Kenya Recalls Canada Envoy
description: President Daniel arap Moi has announced that he is recalling Kenya's envoy to Canada to protest demonstrations there against his Government by people of Somali descent.

title: Thankful Ex-Refugees Help the Neediest
description: Out of sight does not mean out of mind for contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Though the books were closed on last year's campaign on Feb. 28, and articles about it stopped appearing in March, donors continued to send contributions throughout the year.

title: Plans to Raise M.T.A. Fares Go to Hearings
description: Public hearings or final votes on proposed increases of 11.5 percent or more in the cost of commuting by train, riding a subway or taking a taxi will be held this week.

title: Parents Fight for Right To Let a Daughter Die
description: In a modest frame house on Main Street, Joyce and Lester L. Cruzan quietly wait for their appointment with history.

title: Candid Comment From Tokyo
description: When the Bush Administration charged Japan with unfair restrictions on imports from America last spring, it also wisely proposed that the two governments sit down and air complaints about each other's economic systems. That opened the way for Japan to pick at America's faults, instead of just taking it on the chin from Washington. Tokyo has responded with a cogent critique.

title: Futures Exchange Sets New Curbs on Volatility
description: The Chicago Board of Trade says it plans to tighten circuit breakers for its stock index futures contract on the Major Market Index, in another move to reduce stock market volatility.

title: Educators Belittle New Jersey's 'Report Cards' on Schools
description: By giving all of New Jersey's public schools ''report cards'' recently, state education officials had hoped to create a dialogue between parents and educators that would, over time, make schools more accountable and improve education.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Transitions; Sandler & Schwartz
description: Shortly before 9 A.M. on Nov. 15, New York City traffic officials got a nightmare phone call: a truck had struck a pedestrian bridge in the Bronx, knocking it onto the Bruckner Expressway. It was the sort of accident that could have gummed up traffic for days.

title: Metro Matters; Symbols Abound, But Real Power Is Hard to Find
