description: Robert F. Wagner was the last New York City Mayor without a telephone in his official car. Mr. Wagner didn't want one, he recalled, because ''anything I had to say could wait until I got there.''

title: Skipper Is Relieved of Duty After Destroyer Is in Collision
description: The Navy has reassigned the skipper of a destroyer based here following a collision two weeks ago off Malaysia that killed one sailor and injured five others.

title: Apple Computer Loses One of Its Pioneers
description: Delbert W. Yocam, who held several key posts as Apple Computer Inc. rose from a perky startup concern to a multibillion-dollar computer vendor, left the company Friday after 10 years.

title: Britain to Keep Inflation Rein
description: John Major, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that the Government would not abandon its anti-inflation policy of high interest rates to curry popularity for elections that must be called by mid-1992.

title: Ms. Spett Is Wed To James Ruskin
description: Judith Rose Spett, a product manager for the Dreyfus Corporation in New York, was married yesterday to James Philip Ruskin, a securities analyst at Dreyfus. Rabbi Fabian Schonfeld performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Rangers Top Nordiques, 3-1
description: Lindy Ruff, scratched from the lineup for the Rangers the night before, suffered the indignity quietly, professionally. There would be no storm of protest, no public griping, just a silent promise made to himself when, last night, he was told he would be on the ice to start the game at the Garden against the Nordiques.

title: August Wilson Has a Hit in London
description: London seems to have at last discovered August Wilson.

title: India Empire That Stands Apart
description: In the 50 years that J. R. D. Tata has led the sprawling industrial giant that bears his name, he has molded it into India's most diverse and respected industrial empire under the slogan ''growth with ethics.''

title: Uruguayans Elect a President; Victory Is Seen for Centrist Lawyer
description: One of Latin America's most deeply rooted democracies went to the polls today, and a middle-of-the-road lawyer appeared on the way to becoming its next president. Voters opted for a leftist coalition to run the Montevideo city government.

title: Ms. Brodnitz Wed To M. J. McNally
description: Caroline F. Brodnitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest W. Brodnitz of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael J. McNally, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. McNally of Denville, N.J. Msgr. John Corr performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

title: Treasury to Sell 2-Year and 5-Year Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, tomorrow's sale of two-year notes and Wednesday's sale of five-year notes.

title: State Judge Approves Sale of Bing's Assets
description: A state judge has approved the sale of Sir Rudolf Bing's assets to pay for his nursing home care.

title: The Worm and the Apple: Transitions; Not-So-Fine Print
description: New York's Offtrack Betting authorities know full well that gambling can be a devastating addiction. Their current subway advertising cautions, in the lower-left corner: ''Bet with your head . . . not over it.'' But the type is so tiny that only the most searching straphanger can read it.

title: Can Poland's Steel Dinosaur Evolve?
description: The Communists built the hulking Lenin Steelworks here in the 1950's as a monument to their industrial ambitions for Poland, but today the sprawling mill symbolizes another set of yearnings and challenges: to transform the fossilized hulks of a burdensome Communist economy to more efficient market-oriented enterprises.

title: First U.S. Liver Transplant From Live Donor Is Set
description: Surgeons at the University of Chicago are to perform the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor today, ushering in what is widely expected to be a new era in transplantation.

title: Montedison Financing Is Set
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana announced yesterday that it had successfully completed the syndication of $600 million of financing for Montedison USA Inc.'s tender offer for all outstanding common shares of Himont Inc. not already owned by the Montedison group.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Prague's caretaker prime minister, Ladislav Adamec, met for the first time with opposition leaders and then joined Alexander Dubeck at another rally of 500,000 people demanding democratic changes. Page A1

title: Marxism Will Revive, Gorbachev Insists
description: Faced with a growing clamor from Communist Party conservatives, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev published a manifesto today insisting that Marxism will be revived in the Soviet Union, and under the leadership of the Communist Party.

title: Israel Plan to Sell Banks
description: An Israeli Cabinet committee has approved a plan to equalize the voting rights of shares in all major Israeli banks, a crucial step toward selling them, a Finance Ministry spokesman said today. There are currently two kinds of bank shares: normal shares with no control rights and special voting shares that have little financial value but give the owners control over the banks. The Government bought the normal shares from the public in 1983. Equalizing the voting rights of all shares will give control to the Government and allow it to sell the banks to the highest bidder. Finance Minister Shimon Peres said the Goverment was negotiating to sell Bank Igud then Bank Hamizrahi and Bank Discount.

title: Youth, 19, Is Killed And 3 Are Wounded
description: One Bronx youth was shot and killed and his brother and two friends were wounded last night in a dispute with four other youths over a girl, the police said.

title: Ban Endorsed On Drift Nets
description: Representatives from 20 South Pacific nations on Friday endorsed a pact aimed at banning the use by fishermen of the 60-mile-long drift nets that environmentalists say are robbing the ocean of marine life.

title: Louisville Holds Off Villanova
description: Jerome Harmon scored 21 points tonight and Louisville staved off a Villanova rally for an 83-69 victory and third place in the Maui Classic.

title: Richard Pfizenmaier Dies at 69
description: Richard Pfizenmaier, a developer of international operations of the pharmaceutical house of Smith Kline and French Laboratories, died of blood cancer Thursday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 69 years old.

title: Peter, Paul and Mary
description: Peter, Paul and Mary are to give the first of six performances of holiday songs on Dec. 12 at 8 P.M. at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street. The New York Choral Society and Orchestra is to appear with the trio for the annual concert of Christmas and Hanukkah music. Other concert dates are Dec. 13 to 16 at 8 P.M. and Dec. 17 at 3 P.M. Tickets: $35 and $40. Information: 246-0102.

title: 21 Kurds Are Reported Slain In a Reprisal Raid in Turkey
description: Kurdish guerrillas killed 21 people, 6 of them women and 13 of them children, in a reprisal raid on a pro-Turkish Kurdish village near the Iraqi border, officials said today.

title: Panel Warns of Failings In Efforts to Halt AIDS
description: Although the public's knowledge of AIDS has steadily increased in recent years, many myths and misunderstandings about the disease continue, a privately financed commission on AIDS concludes in a report to be released today.

title: WHEAT CROP FACES THREAT OF DROUGHT
description: Signs of yet another drought are spreading fear among farmers like Larry Kern and Jerry Ireton, who say they could be facing their second straight disastrous harvest of winter wheat.

title: Bird Not Bringing Celtics Much Magic
description: The news of Larry Bird's return was trumpeted in every National Basketball Association city and beyond in the days leading up to the start of the 1989-90 season.

title: Review/Music; Handel's 'Acis and Galatea' Offers Smiles Among Arias
description: In format, Handel's ''Acis and Galatea'' resembles ''Friedenstag,'' the Richard Strauss antiwar polemic that surfaced at Carnegie Hall last week. Both occupy a halfway house between the theater and the concert stage. Both tell a story in music that might be acted out onstage but is just as well apprehended with closed eyes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People will judge us by our ability to overcome the past.'' - Prime Minister Ladislav Adamecof Czechoslovakia. [ A10:5. ]

title: Review/Music; Arlo Guthrie: A Holiday Gathering
description: A couple of years ago, Arlo Guthrie announced that he was retiring his most famous song, ''Alice's Restaurant,'' from his concert repertory. The long and winding story of how his arrest for littering in Stockbridge, Mass., prevented him from being drafted is a quintessential Guthrie composition in the way it turns a true story into an amusing folk tale, using roughly four parts narration to one part music.

title: Sports World Specials: TENNIS; Giant Serve for Youths
description: Ricky Hammond, his eyes opened wide, lips sealed tightly, sat courtside yesterday in a gymnasium at the Essex County Community College in Newark.

title: A Razor-Thin Victory, Taken at Face Value
description: Douglas Wilder, the apparent winner of Virginia's gubernatorial election, has taken descriptions of his ''razor-thin'' victory margin at face value, shaving off his mustache while he awaits official vote totals on Monday.

title: Miami Beach Journal; Jews Leaving a City, And a Piece of History
description: For four decades, Miami Beach has been known as much for its Jewish flavor as for its sun and sand. As recently as seven years ago, three-quarters of its population was Jewish.

title: Quest for Baby Sitters Is Fiercely Competitive
description: Alison Granger considers herself a generous, even selfless person. But lately the 31-year-old mother has caught herself hoarding something very dear: the names of her favorite baby sitters.

title: Kelly on Target as Bills Defeat Bengals
description: Jim Kelly threw three touchdown passes as Buffalo took advantage of both physical and mental mistakes for a 24-7 victory today over Cincinnati, the team that beat the Bills out of a Super Bowl trip last season.

title: Holding in IPCO
description: The Canadian financier James A. Pattison and a group of companies that he controls have acquired a 9.37 percent stake in the IPCO Corporation, which operates the Sterling Optical eyewear chain. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Pattison group said that the IPCO shares had been bought as an investment but that it intended to talk with IPCO's management about the company's recent history and general business outlook.IPCO shares were unchanged today at $11 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the compay a market value of more than $55 million.

title: Deals
description: PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Placed Lanard Copeland, guard, on the injured list. Signed Dexter Shouse, guard.

title: Our Towns; Where 2 + 2 Can Open Eyes To a New World
description: In many ways, the beginning sessions of Bill Granville's Granville Academy resemble an introductory class in business administration, with the emphasis on accounting. Indeed, the class is held in a large lecture room at Rider College here, in the glistening new business administration building.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise by 2.8% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 2.8 percent rise in the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered, in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks ended Nov. 15.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * HDM Worldwide, in a joint venture with South Korea's second-largest agency, Oricom, has established an agency called HDM Korea.

title: C.I.T. Group Notes To Yield 8.62%
description: C.I.T. Group Holdings Inc., a subsidiary of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, yesterday priced $200 million in notes due 1994 for offering to the public, through underwriters led Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Needed: A Stretcher For Soccer
description: rrThe United States soccer team's incredible, improbable and wildly implausible 1-0 defeat of Trinidad and Tobago recently, was viewed by this chronicler as America's greatest international triumph since the invasion of Grenada.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Acquisition by Bozell
description: Bozell last week acquired a majority interest in Palmer Bonner Inc., a $40 million agency in Toronto whose clients include Borden Inc. and Molson beer. The agency will be merged into Bozell's existing Toronto operation, creating a new agency, Bozell Palmer Bonner, with combined billings of $60 million. ''It will give us a combined staff of 75 or 80 and the size that we feel certainly makes us more competitive in the marketplace,'' said Charles D. Peebler Jr., Bozell's chief executive.

title: OPEC Seeks Output Deal
description: Oil ministers of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries continued today to seek a production quota they can all abide by.

title: Supreme Court Won't Review S.R.O. Ruling
description: New York City lost one of its major weapons for preventing the spread of homelessness yesterday as the United States Supreme Court decided not to tackle a city law aimed at saving single-room-occupancy hotels.

title: Clamor in the East; MILLIONS OF CZECHOSLOVAKS INCREASE PRESSURE ON PARTY WITH 2-HOUR GENERAL STRIKE
description: Millions of Czechs and Slovaks walked off their jobs and into the streets at midday today, bringing Prague and the rest of the country to a standstill. It was a powerful demonstration of national solidarity in support of free elections and opposition to Communist domination.

title: Let's Stop Landfilling and Start Composting
description: To the Editor:

title: Soccer Final At Rutgers
description: The semifinal and final games of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament will be played at Rutgers University Stadium in Piscataway, N.J., Saturday and Sunday.

title: City Opera Announces Some Changes of Plan
description: Christopher Keene, the general director of the New York City Opera, announced his plans yesterday for 1990 and beyond, which include fewer, better-prepared productions with more cohesive casts and an emphasis on innovative repertory and direction.

title: Moscow Hits the Brakes on Syria
description: LEAD: The upcoming superpower summit meeting in the Mediterranean will no doubt be dominated by talk of Eastern Europe. But while in the neighborhood of the Middle East, President Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev should also take a few minutes to discuss Moscow's readiness to cooperate in advancing the Arab-Israeli peace process.

title: Indiana Back Honored
description: The Indiana running back Anthony Thompson, who set three National Collegiate Athletic Association scoring and rushing records this season, was named yesterday as the Walter Camp Player of the Year.

title: Urcarco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company, which operated used car retail lots, said increases in revenues and net were the result of start- ups, acquisition of new sales locations and growth in same-lot sales.

title: How Japanese Undercut U.S. Companies
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Chief Takes Office
description: Jerry R. Curry took office today as Administrator of the National Highway TrafSafety Administration, the nation's top highway safety official. He said he would seek to reduce highway deaths by emphasizing seat belt use and curbing drunken driving. Mr. Curry, 57 years old, a retired Army major general, was nominated by President Bush for the post and the Senate confirmed him this month.

title: United Illuminating reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
description: b-Net income United Illuminating attributed its 1989 loss to non-cash writeoffs in excess of $112 million to recognize reductions in the recoverable cost of Seabrook Unit 1. The company said the loss also reflected non-cash charges ordered by the Connecticut Department of Public Utility to reduce its 1989 earnings. It said those charges consisted of a writeoff of bond repurchase premiums of $4.6 million and additional depreciation charges related to Millstone Unit 3 of $8.3 million.

title: Colorado Is Now No. 1
description: For the first time, the football team at the University of Colorado has been voted to the No. 1 spot in the polls conducted by The Associated Press and United Press International.

title: Moves to Oust Nekoosa's Board
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said it was seeking to oust the board of directors of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation., which has advised shareholders to reject Georgia-Pacific's $3.6 billion buyout offer. Georgia-Pacific said it was soliciting shareholder consents for a special meeting at which Great Northern shareholders would vote on whether to remove the board.

title: Paribas Lifts Bid
description: The merchant bank Compagnie Financiere de Paribas said it had raised its formal offer price for Compagnie de Navigation Mixte, a holding company with interests in insurance and banking, to 1,887 francs a share from the initial 1,850. Francois Morin, Paribas's vice chairman, said the 2 percent increase was automatically initiated under French takeover rules after the financial group bought Mixte shares on the open market for more than its formal bid price this morning. Paribas's offer for Mixte, which has a value of more than $3.5 billion, has stood at 1,850 francs since it was made on Oct. 23. French rules require an increase of at least 2 percent in the value of the bid if open market purchases are made above the formal offer.

title: Award Urged for Gorbachev
description: A group of Italian politicians, scientists and writers said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union should be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for inspiring a new concept in international relations. Among those signing the appeal, made through an Italian-Soviet friendship association, were the novelist Alberto Moravia and Rita Levi-Montalcini, a neuroscientist who won the Nobel Prize for medicine in 1986.

title: How Medical Detectives Identified The Culprit Behind a Rare Disorder
description: THE first call was from a physician in Sante Fe, N.M., puzzled about a 39-year-old woman with mouth ulcers, severe muscle pain, liver problems and extraordinarily high numbers of a type of white cell in her blood.

title: Lone Star to Sell Several Assets
description: Lone Star Industries, the nation's largest producer of cement, concrete and gravel, said yesterday that it intends to sell several businesses, real estate and interests in some of its joint ventures. The move is seen as a response to declining earnings in recent quarters.

title: Fortune Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Clamor in the East; Polish Leader Prays at Katyn Monument
description: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland led prayer services Sunday in a snow-covered forest where 4,300 Polish officers were killed during World War II in a massacre that most Poles attribute to the Soviets.

title: A Different Kind of Vietnam Veteran, and Her Healing Mission
description: Le Ly Hayslip, a Vietnamese woman who was forced by the hardships of war to collaborate with the Vietcong, dabble in the black market and sell her body, is now presenting hersin a book and perhaps a movie as the face of her country's victimized peasantry.

title: Apple Bancorp Proxy Fight
description: A New York real estate developer, Stanley Stahl, who holds a 30.3 percent stake in Apple Bancorp Inc., said today that he planned to wage a proxy fight for control of the New York City-based savings bank holding company.

title: Owens Leads Syracuse In Opener
description: Syracuse, which earlier in the day earned a No. 1 ranking, beat Rutgers by 95-79 tonight as Billy Owens scored 18 of his career-high 33 points in the final eight and a half minutes.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie, France, plans to build a two-engine short- to medium-range aircraft that could carry 186 passengers.

title: Benton Oil & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said comparable figures were not available; the company was formed in September 1988 and had its initial public offering in March.

title: Shamir Again Says No To Talks With P.L.O.
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said today that he is prepared to talk to Satan, but not the Palestine Liberation Organization, to bring peace to the Middle East.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $152,000.

title: Prehistoric Pottery
description: Anthropologists have concluded that the Stone Age people who invented ceramic technology about 26,000 years ago probably designed clay figurines to explode when fired rather than intending the statuettes to be artistic works.

title: The Sky Is Falling, Just for Fun
description: THEY call it a game. I call it an obsession.

title: Metro Cable Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $76,482 from the sale of securities. The company said the latest quarter's loss resulted primarily from a decrease in oil production income along with costs associated with a well work-over. c-Net loss

title: Disputed Nuclear Nominee Gets Lower Post
description: Faced with strong opposition in the Senate, the Bush Administration gave a second-level appointment yesterday to a nuclear expert whom it had nominated to take charge of the nation's nuclear bomb complex.

title: Market Place; Depository Skirts Bank Middlemen
description: IN a move that is likely to put pressure on a lucrative line of business at big-city banks, the Midwest Securities Trust Company, a depository in Chicago, has decided to start selling its services directly to large investors.

title: Tech Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Let's Stop Landfilling and Start Compostin; Say, 'Paper, Please'
description: To the Editor:

title: F. G. Walton Smith, 80, an Oceanographer
description: F.G. Walton Smith, an oceanographer who founded the Marine Labora tory at the University of Miami, died of heart failure Sunday at Mercy Hospital in Miami. He was 80 years old and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Historic House May Get New Life at Last
description: In the more than 200 years that it has stood on the East River waterfront, the home of Capt. Joseph Rose has endured few periods as trying as the last decade, while New York City officials have tried and tried and tried again to salvage what has become little more than a brick shell.

title: Noxso reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Realism Takes Henderson to Top
description: Forget the hushed significance of the leading designer collections. Bag the socialite-in-my-dress hyperbole. For Gordon Henderson, a designer many are calling the first important new talent of the 1990's, fashion is not something to make a big to-do about.

title: Finnish Footwear Sale
description: Nokia A.B. said today that it had agreed to sell its footwear operations and production facilities to the managers of its footwear unit. The footwear unit is part of Nokia's rubber division. The Finnish company said it is the biggest manufacturer of rubber boots in Western Europe. Terms were not disclosed. The management buyout agreement also covers the marketing of protective footwear and gloves, Nokia said.

title: Sale by Bowater
description: Bowater Industries P.L.C. agreed to sell the R. S. Means Company division of its United States unit Norton-Opax Inc. to the Canadian company Southam Inc. for $52 million in cash. R. S. Means, which is based in Kingston, Mass., publishes a comprehensive data base of construction cost data. Norton-Opax is in Baltimore.

title: Panel Replaces Senate Counsel In H.U.D. Case
description: The Senate Ethics Committee said today that it had appointed a new outside counsel to investigate accusations that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato may have improperly lobbied Federal housing officials on behalf of campaign contributors.

title: Pacificare Health Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Galagraph Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Honco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A 'New Wave' for the Office
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company will announce on Tuesday a set of computer programs to allow people to work together electronically even if they use different types of computers and different brands of software.

title: Donations to Neediest Cases Are as Diverse as the Givers
description: The messages that come folded around contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which opened its 78th annual appeal on Sunday, are as diverse as the people who send them.

title: Review/Dance; Suzanne Farrell's Last Waltz With City Ballet
description: Dance lovers did much loud cheering - and, surely, some quiet weeping - on Sunday night at the New York State Theater when they greeted Suzanne Farrell in her last performance with the New York City Ballet. The ballerina appeared in two works, Peter Martins's ''Sophisticated Lady'' and George Balanchine's ''Vienna Waltzes,'' which concluded the evening.

title: National Technical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Daily News Appoints A Managing Editor
description: Matthew V. Storin, editor of the weekly Maine Times and a former executive at newspapers in Boston and Chicago, was named managing editor of The Daily News today.

title: U.S. Satellite Is Dropping From Orbit
description: he orbit of Solar Max, a 5,000-pound satellite that collected information on solar flares for nine years, has deteriorated to the point that the spacecraft should crash back to earth late this week, the space agency said today.

title: Clamor in the East; New Politburo in Prague
description: Retained Karel Urbanek: The new Communist Party leader, he is a little-known figure from Moravia, the smallest of the three components of the Czech region. The country is made up of two main groups or republics, the Czechs and the Slovaks. (His name is pronounced KAH-rel OOR-bahn-ek.) Ignac Janak: He is the party secretary in Slovakia, which makes up the eastern part of the country, with its capital in Bratislava. (IG-natz YA-nahk.) Ivan Knotek: The government leader in Slovakia, he was considered an advocate of change but is thought to have allied himself with the hard-liners in recent Politburo votes. (IH-vann KHNO-tek.) New Members Josef Cizek: The head of a farm cooperative. (YO-zef CHEE-zhek.) Miroslav Huscava: Identified as a miner. (MIR-o-slav HOOS-chava.) Miroslav Zajic: An agricultural economist, known as a good manager with some free-market tendencies. (MIR-o-slav ZA-yeets.) Vasil Mohorita: The party's youth leader, who is considered a reformer with a good chance to play a major role in negotiations with the opposition over the next few days. (VA-seel MO-hor-ita.) Miroslav Valek; The chief of the Writers' Union. (MIR-o-slav VA-lehk.) Bretislav Benda: A scientist. (BRET-o-slav BEN-da.) Anton Mlady: (AHN-ton MLAD-ih.) Valeria Petrincova: (VAL-er-eeya PAY-trin-tsova.) Ondrej Saling; (ON-drey SAH-ling.) Anna Kozesnikova: (AHN-a KOZ-ess-nik-ova.)

title: Germans to Buy Morgan Grenfell
description: In its boldest move to expand investment banking operations outside West Germany, Deutsche Bank A.G. has agreed to buy Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C. in a friendly deal that values the big British merchant bank at $1.48 billion, the companies announced today.

title: Long-Secret History of C.I.A. Sheds Light on Battles Over Authority
description: The State Department, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the military hampered the Central Intelligence Agency in its infancy by bickering about authority, according to a long-secret history of the agency's early years.

title: Boy, 10, Killed by a Golf Ball
description: A 10-year-old boy who was struck in the head by a golf ball has died of his injuries. The boy, Richard Wayne Perry of Fairhope, was struck in the head Friday when a golfer teed off at the Quail Creek Golf Course, Sgt. Thomas Garrick of the Fairhope police said. The boy died Saturday at University of South Alabama Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Genovese Drug Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 10
All 107 Aboard Killed as Colombian Jet Explodes
description: A Colombian passenger jet crashed on the outskirts of Bogota shortly after takeoff today, and all 107 people aboard were killed. A caller to a radio station asserted that drug traffickers had bombed the plane.

title: Aequitron Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: On the Job With New York City's Police Commissioner
description: The unmarked black sedan shot into the garage under One Police Plaza, giving the sentry barely enough time to leap to attention and snap off a crisp salute.

title: Clamor in the East; Scholars Expect Prague's Bosses to Go
description: Czechoslovakia's Communist old guard may try to hang on with delaying tactics and promises of reform, but their replacement at the helm is virtually assured, experts on Eastern European affairs say.

title: Trade Zones Are Criticized
description: Foreign trade zones, which are supposed to create jobs in the United States by increasing exports, are instead bringing in more imports, mostly auto parts, according to a Congressional report released today.

title: Jurors Partially Clear Three in Sedition Trial
description: Three avowed revolutionaries were cleared today of trying to overthrow the Government, but the jury was still undecided about racketeering charges against the defendants.

title: Surgeons Complete Historic Transplant
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 27 - The nation's first liver transplant using a living donor had an unexpected complication today as surgeons removing one-third of the donor's liver accidentally nicked her spleen, making it necessary for them to remove it.

title: Morgan on Fame Ballot
description: Joe Morgan, a two-time National League most valuable player, and Jim Palmer, who won the Cy Young Award three times, headed 21 first-time candidates on the 1990 Hall of Fame ballot distributed yesterday to members of the Baseball Writers Association of America.(AP)

title: How a British Ford Plant Became Productive Again
description: In the early 1980's, the sprawling Ford Motor Company factory here was a microcosm of Britain's industrial ills. There was so much turmoil at the inefficient and strife-ridden plant that the local newspaper, The Liverpool Echo, made daily calls to check for trouble. When nothing happened, it was front-page news. ''Smooth Night Shift at Ford,'' one headline proclaimed.

title: Rebel Rockets in Kabul Are Reported to Kill 31
description: Rockets fired by Afghan rebels killed 31 people and wounded 96 in Kabul on Sunday, the Government radio said today, reporting the highest day's death toll in guerrilla bombardments in almost two months.

title: Little Fraud Found In Migrant Amnesty
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Capital reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $37,702,000 and after income from disposal of discontinued operations of $128,078,000, or $21.52 a share. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $121,375,000, income of $5,395,000, or 98 cents a share, from disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $5,450,000, or 99 cents a share. Security Capital said the 1989 income from disposal of discontinued operations reflected a non-cash gain from the write-off of its investment in Benjamin Franklin Savings Association. The company said that figure represented losses from Franklin previously recorded by Security Capital in excess of its investment in Franklin. Security Capital said its 1988 income from disposal of discontinued operations reflected the sale of its real estate investment advisory business. The company also said the extraordinary item represented early extinguishment of debt. The company said 1988 results were restated to reflect the discontinued operations.

title: Deerfield Federal S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POPE SEES OFFICIAL OF RUSSIAN CHURCH
description: A leader of the Russian Orthodox Church met with Pope John Paul II today, asserting that extremists in the Ukrainian Catholic Church have been causing violence and endangering reconciliation talks between the two faiths.

title: Review/Music; A Critic and Composer
description: Kenneth LaFave, a music critic for The Kansas City Star, is also a composer, and on Sunday afternoon he presented a program of his vocal works at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Florio's Influence Seen in Vote for Speaker
description: Governor-elect James J. Florio demonstrated his influence in the Legislature and indicated that he intends to exert more, Democrats said today, when the incoming Democratic Assembly majority passed over its current leader and instead chose a member backed by Mr. Florio to be Speaker of the Assembly.

title: Careers; Management Of Facilities a Growth Area
description: FACILITIES management has become a fast-growing profession, so much so that 8,000 specialists belong to the International Facility Management Association, formed in 1980 with headquarters in Houston.

title: Chess
description: Precision conservative play was the dominant theme in Gary Kasparov's triumph at the Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, the competition where his 10-2 score in a powerful, all-grandmaster field enabled him to achieve the highest International Chess Federation rating ever.

title: Western Union Loses A Credit Line
description: In what could damage the Western Union Corporation's attempts to revive itself, the Columbia Savings and Loan Association has said it will pull out of a deal to provide an additional $51.4 million to purchase Western Union securities, Brooke Partners L.P. said yesterday.

title: Teresa S. Reardon, Judge, 60
description: Teresa S. Reardon, an administrative law judge in the New York City Parking Violations Bureau, died of cancer Thursday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S.-Soviet Makers Plan Supersonic Business Jet
description: In a striking example of commercial glasnost, a Soviet state enterprise that made the planes that bombed Afghanistan has joined an American company to build the ultimate capitalist status symbol: a supersonic jet for business executives.

title: Chevron Stock Plan Adopted
description: The Chevron Corporation, which has been rumored to be vulnerable to a takeover, said today that it had created an employee stock ownership plan and that it intended to buy back about 5 percent of its shares on the open market.

title: Grandma Lee's reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Advertising; Agencies Get Mixed Signs From Shifts in Big Accounts
description: About $100 million in account transfers yesterday - involving five of the nation's largest advertising agencies - proved that while some clients are willing to overlook the past, others steadfastly stick to tradition.

title: INSIDE
description: 107 Die on Colombian Jet A Colombian jet crashed after takeoff, killing 107. A caller said drug traffickers planted a bomb, but this could not be confirmed. Page A9. Liver Transplant Completed The nation's first liver transplant from a live donor was completed, although the donor's spleen had to be removed. Science Times, page C10. CUNY Chancellor to Resign Joseph S. Murphy, who has headed the nation's third largest university system for seven years, is stepping down. Page B1.

title: By Design; Braving the See-Through
description: Instead of wearing a sheer blouse over a camisole, put it over a brassiere that is meant to be seen. If you have the figure - and the nerve - forget the blouse. You will be expressing the newest version of the see-through style.

title: Witness Links Killers of 6 Priests to Salvador's Armed Forces
description: A woman described as a witness to the slayings of six Jesuit priests this month has provided the first sworn evidence linking the killers to the Salvadoran armed forces. The judge investigating the slayings said today that he also thought that they had been committed by members of the armed forces.

title: International Consumer Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from Saturday, Nov. 18.

title: Clamor in the East; 'Replay' in Prague: Popular Uprising Echoes the Experience of Neighbors
description: It seemed at times almost a replay of East Berlin, only a month later and a bit faster.

title: Bridge
description: One of the English sea stories by Capt. Frederick Marryat describes a three-cornered battle in which A fires at B, B at C, and C at A. This is roughly what happens in many Double Knockout finals, which for technical reasons have to come down to three teams rather than two.

title: Clamor in the East; From Malcontents to Power Brokers: Civic Forum Takes Hold in Prague
description: When Civic Forum, the umbrella group mounting Czechoslovakia's opposition to Communist rule, was formed eight days ago, the Government authorities tried to dismiss it as a group of feckless, isolated intellectuals.

title: Review/Pop; More Somber Moments By Marianne Faithfull
description: Marianne Faithfull's concert on Sunday at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights had an aura of deja vu for anyone who heard the singer two years ago at the Bottom Line. In December 1987, she ended a six-year hiatus from performing with lambent live sets that marked the release of an album, ''Strange Weather.'' Her parched, scarred voice, set off by an ominously subdued band, gave bleak songs a harrowing intimacy. On Saturday and Sunday, she reconvened most of that band and reprised much of her 1987 repertory in concerts that were recorded for a possible album.

title: U.S. Threatens to Halt U.N. Payments
description: The Bush Administration threatened today to cut off all American financing for the United Nations if this year's General Assembly agrees to any upgrading of the status of the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission at United Nations headquarters here.

title: Greenwhich Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the decline in latest quarter income was due to the implementation of FASB 91, which requires the deferral of loan origination and commitment fees and certain related costs.

title: Heroux Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: For Top 8 Men, the Masters Means Time to Settle Score
description: When the Nabisco Masters, the tournament that functions as the final proving ground for a year's worth of contention and competition among the world's top eight male tennis players, opens tonight at Madison Square Garden there will be no shortage of score-settling going on.

title: Case of the Shrinking Docket: Justices Spurn New Appeals
description: The Supreme Court may not have set a precedent today, but it did do something very unusual. It did not accept a single new case.

title: Uruguay's Mixed Election Result May Lead to Conflict
description: After national elections on Sunday in which a centrist, Luis Alberto Lacalle, was elected President while a Marxist coalition gained control of the Montevideo city government, Uruguayans now say the stage is set for a sharp conflict.

title: Southland Decides Not to Sell Division
description: The Southland Corporation, the owner of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, said it had decided not to sell its distribution and food processing group, which had been put up for sale in March. A spokeswoman said the company believed it would better maximize the value of these assets by owning them and profiting from their growth.

title: Fed Signals No Easing; Bonds Sag
description: The Federal Reserve Board sent an extraordinary signal to credit market participants yesterday that it had not eased monetary policy last week, as had been commonly thought. As a result, prices of Treasury securities sagged and short-term interest rates rose sharply.

title: Trade Pact For Soviets And Europe
description: The Soviet Union and the 12-nation European Community reached agreement today on a 10-year trade pact that would ease European quotas for Soviet goods and increase technical cooperation.

title: New Drug Measures Are Getting Tougher
description: Two of the most common excuses used by American track and field athletes to avoid penalties for having used performance-enhancing drugs would no longer be accepted if proposals to tighten the appeals process are approved this week by The Athletics Congress.

title: Federal Official Faults Public Cholesterol Tests
description: Public cholesterol screenings at such places as shopping centers, health fairs and supermarkets should be discouraged without tighter regulation because of widespread problems with accuracy and safety, a Federal health official and a Congressman said today.

title: First Lady Scheduled For Eye Exam Today
description: Barbara Bush will be examined on Tuesday by eye specialists at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., for a thyroid disorder that continues to give her vision problems, her office said today.

title: Artra Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $30,916,000 and $34,352,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain from purchases of Koch senior notes of $1,539,000, or 49 cents a share, for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $81,000 for the quarter and $6,605,000 for the 9 months which included net charge of $3.6 million because of financial irregularities discovered at a unit, partially offset by a net gain of $3,282,000 on sale of a business. The latest quarter and 9 months losses from discontinued operations of $30,916,000 and $34,352,000, respectively, both included a net loss of $29,750,000 to cover writedowns associated with the Sargent-Welch subsidiary. The company will receive a tax benefit of about $17 million when the sale is completed, thereby reducing the total loss on sale of the unit, and the 9 months also included net gain of $904,000 on sale of Lori unit's Park Lane subsidiary. Year-ago results are reclassified to reflect discontinuance of Sargent- Welch Scientific subsidiary, effective Aug. 31, 1989.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Family Media Reorganization
description: Family Media, a magazine publisher whose titles include Discover and Golf Illustrated, yesterday announced a large reorganization that includes two new magazines, a change in the publishing schedule of two others and the appointment of two editorial directors.

title: President of Comoro Islands Is Assassinated
description: Rebels in the Comoro Islands attacked the presidential palace and killed the longtime ruler of this island nation off the East African coast, the state radio reported today.

title: Albertson's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Belmoral Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge from a writedown of investments of $15,662,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and included a tax credit of $697,000. d-Included a $635,000 writedown. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Topics of The Times; Adult Behavior
description: A New York City mother who braved airport crowds to visit relatives in New Mexico returned with a fair complaint about the conduct of her fellow passengers.

title: Ombalantu Journal; Now Some Cold Air From Canada Would Be Nice
description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police are patrolling a new kind of northern frontier, dressed more for a performance of ''Desert Song'' than ''Rose Marie. ''

title: Whitman Medical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Terry Coveny has been named executive creative director of Ehrlich Manes Associates of Bethesda, Md.

title: Fiat Accord With Soviets
description: Fiat S.p.A. said today that it would sign an agreement on Tuesday to build a new line of cars in the Soviet Union, on the eve of a visit by the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to Italy.

title: Let's Stop Landfilling and Start Composting; Reuse and Reuse Again
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH MAY DISCUSS TROOP REDUCTIONS
description: The Bush Administration acknowledged for the first time today that it was prepared to discuss future deployment of American and Soviet troops in Europe when President Bush meets this weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: A Singer Brings Back the Spunk of 40's Women
description: Among the dozens of young singers who performed last month at the First Cabaret Convention's galas at Town Hall, Mary Cleere Haran was the one who walked off with the audience's heart.

title: Henderson Reported Close to Deal With A's
description: The Oakland Athletics traded Rickey Henderson to the Yankees five years ago because he was approaching free agency and they did not want to pay what it would have taken to keep him. They got him back earlier this year, and they are not going to let him get away again.

title: Dow Up 19.42 Despite Bond Market Slump
description: Stocks advanced yesterday despite falling back from early highs after a slump in the bond market.

title: John Wiley & Sons reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $8.9 million reflecting gains on sale of the occupational and certain nursing publishing lines. The gain was offset by about $17 million of pretax charges relating to the restructuring and rationalization of certain product lines, including the write-off of product development costs. The after-tax effect of the unusual items amounted to a net gain of $98,000, or 2 cents a share, due to lower tax benefits attributable to the unusual charges. c-Net income The company said the decline in latest quarter earnings is primarily attributable to the reduced contribution from the domestic educational sector and costs related to the acquisition of the Alan R. Liss Life Sciences publishing division in June.

title: Christian General Readies Beirut Forces
description: Gen. Michel Aoun, who refuses to recognize the presidency and Government of Elias Hrawi, today ordered the full mobilization of the military force he commands in Christian sectors of central Lebanon.

title: Abu Nidal Is Reportedly Placed Under House Arrest by Libyans
description: Abu Nidal, the Palestinian widely considered one of the world's most dangerous terrorists, has been placed under house arrest by Libya, officials of the Palestine Liberation Organization here and Arab diplomats in Paris say.

title: Lincoln Savings Bank Says President Has Left
description: The Lincoln Savings Bank, which operates in the New York area, said yesterday that its president, Wayne J. Stemmer, had resigned and that Thomas J. Ogletree had been named to succeed him.

title: Books of The Times; Changes in Culture Caused by Technology
description: Disappearing Through the Skylight Culture and Technology in the 20th Century By O. B. Hardison Jr. Illustrated. 389 pages. Viking. $22.95.

title: Dionne Textiles reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Clamor in the East; Hungarians Reject Election Timetable Of the Ruling Party
description: Voters rejected the election timetable of the ruling party by the narrowest of margins in a referendum on Sunday, forcing it to abandon its plan to elect the first President of the republic while it retained full control of the Government.

title: Bronco Rookie Gets Reprieve
description: The Denver Broncos' star rookie tailback, Bobby Humphrey, was arrested on charges of driving under the influence of alcohol and speeding Friday night in Aurora, Colo., but was not suspended from the team because the arrest occurred before 1 A.M., the club's coach, Dan Reeves, said.

title: 2 Men Charged in Death of Boy Shot in Car
description: A gunfight between relatives of two women feuding over boyfriends killed a 3-year-old boy whose mother tried to shield him from the gunfire.

title: Pena Goes to Red Sox
description: Tony Pena signed a three-year, $6.4 million contract with the Red Sox yesterday as Boston sought to solve its catching problems. Pena, who spent the last three seasons with St. Louis, will receive a $600,000 signing bonus and salaries of $1.5 million in 1990, $2.1 million in 1991 and $2.2 million in 1992. He earned $1.1 million last season.(AP)

title: Talks on European Forces
description: President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are likely to discuss troop deployments in Europe at their meetings this weekend, Administration officials indicated. Page. A7.

title: BellSouth Adopts Anti-Takeover Plan
description: The BellSouth Corporation said its board of directors had adopted a shareholder rights plan to protect the company against a possibile hostile takeover. The move comes as BellSouth continues a bitter fight with McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. for control of the cellular telephone properties of the Lin Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Billionaires in Duel Over a Hog Farm
description: A battle among billionaires has broken out along the South Platte River here at the western edge of the Great Plains, where the nation's largest hog farm is being built.

title: A Matter of Honor
description: Suddenly the sound of machine-gun fire is heard on the edges of Wenceslas Square in Prague. The huge crowd of peaceful demonstrators packed into the great open space begins pushing and screaming.

title: Chancellor of CUNY to Resign After 7 Years
description: Dr. Joseph S. Murphy, chancellor of the City University of New York for the last seven years, announced yesterday that he intended to resign.

title: 40% of AIDS Cases Go Unreported in Carolina
description: AIDS cases, especially among blacks, have been grossly underreported in South Carolina and could be more numerous nationwide than records indicate, researchers say.

title: Disease and Destruction of Habitat Are Killing Off Koalas
description: THE koala, a furry marsupial that lives almost exclusively in eucalyptus trees in the wilds of Australia, is at risk of becoming an endangered species, environmentalists and zoologists say.

title: WILDER CERTIFIED WINNER IN VIRGINIA
description: Lieut. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder was declared the Governor-elect of Virginia by the State Board of Elections today, based on the board's canvass of the votes cast Nov. 7 in the hard-fought, narrowly decided contest.

title: Clerics Advised on AIDS Preaching
description: He is known as a ''preacher's preacher,'' and the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr. of the Riverside Church in Manhattan lived up to his reputation last week when he sounded an eloquent call for compassion in advising other ministers how to preach on AIDS.

title: Correction
description: An article published Saturday about a murder in New York City misspelled the author's name. She is Suzanne Falter-Barns.

title: Director to Retire From Harvard Press
description: Arthur J. Rosenthal, the director of the Harvard University Press for the last 17 years, said yesterday that he will retire from that position in May and will join Farrar, Straus & Giroux as publisher of its Hill & Wang division. A search for his successor at Harvard will soon begin.

title: Minoan Culture Survived Ancient Volcano, Evidence Shows
description: A LONGSTANDING theory of archeology, linking a devastating volcanic eruption to the sudden collapse of the Minoan civilization at its peak of splendor, has apparently been demolished by new excavations on a tiny island off the north coast of Crete.

title: Brandon Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Manhattan School Benefit
description: The opera department of the Manhattan School of Music is to give three performances of Stravinsky's ''Rake's Progress,'' on Dec. 6 and 8 at 8 P.M. and on Dec. 10 at 2:30 P.M., to benefit the scholarship fund. The opera has a text by W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman. Stage direction is by Lou Galterio, and Louis Salemno will conduct. The school is at Broadway and 122d Street. Tickets are $8 and $12; information (weekdays 10 A.M. to noon and 2 to 4 P.M.): 749-2802, extension 497 or 498.

title: Two Are Killed by a Subway
description: Two young men carrying cans of spray paint were struck and killed early this morning by a train near the 59th Street subway station, the Transit Authority police said. The bodies of the two youths, who were 17 and 20 years old, were found on the tracks about 50 feet south of the station beneath a northbound No. 1 train, a spokesman for the transit police, Officer Joseph Ciociola, said. He said cans of spray paint were found on both bodies and in the area, indicating that the youths may have been there to paint graffiti. He declined to identify the youths until their relatives had been notified. The two were struck at 12:35 A.M., Officer Ciociola said.

title: Topics of The Times; America First
description: Americans worried about losing out to Japan can take heart. Last weekend an American won the prized Emperor's Cup in Japanese sumo wrestling, and Americans were named Most Valuable Player in both Japanese baseball leagues.

title: America and the Electronic Future
description: Japan is not always right in its policy of betting on a few promising growth industries, like high-definition television. As the report in Science Times today suggests, the Japanese may have prematurely locked themselves in, leaving others free to leapfrog to newer TV technology.

title: Domestic Car Sales Show Drop
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers suffered serious sales declines in mid-November, while the so-called Japanese transplants posted sharp gains on far fewer sales. Over all, sales of domestically produced cars slumped 6.1 percent, and light-truck sales dropped 1.7 percent, not quite so dismal a trend as during the early part of the month.

title: Business Digest
description: International

title: Most at Board of Ed Are Devoted and Contend With Difficulties
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Foreign Exchange
description: This year's perfect Christmas gift appears to be a piece of the Berlin wall. Assorted department stores have committed themselves to a gross or so of chunks; K-Mart is rumored to be preparing its order.

title: Denning Mobile Robotics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Shuttle Finally Lands After Winds Subside
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 27 - The shuttle Discovery finally landed here late today after gusting desert winds twice forced the spacecraft to delay its return.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For decades, my generation has been waiting and wondering when we would have a chance to be free human beings.'' - Antonin Sykora,a Czech bricklayerwho took part in thegeneral strike yesterday. [ A12:5. ]

title: Jets Achieve Things That Work Out Well
description: The Jets had a problem Sunday: The Atlanta Falcons had the National Football League's worst rushing offense and worst rushing defense and the Jets didn't want to do anything to change that. Happily, for them, they didn't.

title: Review/Music; A Whimsical Paean to Lewis Carroll From Del Tredici
description: Playing with the New York Philharmonic Ensembles has been a way for orchestra members to step out of their accustomed anonymity, but the latest in this chamber series at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday showed a certain augmentation of ambition. Included was David Del Tredici's ''Haddocks' Eyes,'' soon to be part of a New World Records release of this composer by these players.

title: Clamor in the East; Moscow Condemns Party Leaders In Lithuania Over a Move to Split
description: The Soviet Communist Party has issued a stinging criticism of party leaders in Lithuania for failing to contain that wayward republic's drive for independence.

title: Oakland Journal; Where More Than A Highway Collapsed
description: Each time the wrecking ball pounds the concrete remains of the Nimitz Freeway, the streets of West Oakland vibrate and the residents of the neighborhood shudder anew.

title: Lechters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Children as Neighbors? Elderly Are Worried
description: A new Federal law that prohibits most housing discrimination against families with children is causing great concern at thousands of retirement communities and adult condominium developments, whose residents have developed a world of their own.

title: A Pre-holiday Tribute To the African Heritage
description: Festivities for Kwanzaa, a weeklong African-American celebration that begins on Dec. 26, had an early start over the weekend with performances, other cultural events and a bazaar at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. The annual celebration, initiated in 1966 by Dr. Maulana Karenga, a black-studies teacher in California, seeks not only to celebrate, but also to reinforce a sense of African heritage and of old-fashioned values like work, creativity and faith.

title: U.S. Counts o Computer Edge In the Race for Advanced TV
description: DESPITE a slow start by the United States in the race to build television sets with razor-sharp pictures, a growing group of scientists and engineers say there is hope for a comeback. Indeed, some believe conditions are ripe for America to vault over the international competition in a field seen as vital to economic success in the 1990's and beyond.

title: Momentum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Aircoa Hospitality Services reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said 1989 third quarter revenues and share earnings increased from the year-ago largely as a result of higher transaction fees earned from the termination of a management contract and from a disposition fee. These fees were earned in connection with the sale of a property owned by Aircoa Hotel Partners L.P., a limited partnership, of which the company is the general partner.

title: Koch to Join Ethics Panel
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch, whose re-election quest was hurt by corruption scandals in his administration, was named today to a special panel that will advise local governments on ethics.

title: Overnight, a Hindu Leader Becomes a King-Maker
description: As bargaining for coalition partners begins among India's political parties, attention is riveted on an intense, soft-spoken man who, overnight, has become a kingmaker.

title: Rosen, Jacket Named
description: Mel Rosen, the track and field coach at Auburn since 1963, and Barbara Jacket, the women's coach at Prairie View A&M, have been selected by The Athletics Congress to coach the United States men's and women's 1992 Olympic teams. Both served as head coaches for the American team in the 1987 world championships in Rome.

title: American Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $713,000, or 5 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Terminal Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Opportunity Knocks, And a Ram Responds
description: Sunday night was not the first time that Willie (Flipper) Anderson had taken complete advantage of an opportunity created by a teammate's injury.

title: American Realty Trust Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains on sale of properties of $84,000 and $170,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included a loss of $62,000 for the quarter and a gain of $172,000 for the 9 months, both on sale of properties.

title: Paintings That Sing to Us
description: LEAD: When I was recently in New York City, I went to see the paintings of Velazquez at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and those of Pablo Picasso, side by side with works by the French artist Georges Braque, at the Museum of Modern Art. As a Spaniard, I am so proud of the galaxy of painters that my country has produced, who have brought so much beauty and happiness to the world.

title: Baseball Owners' Negotiator Out
description: Barry Rona, the chief labor negotiator for baseball's club owners, has vacated that role - apparently involuntarily - on the eve of the start of negotiations with the players for a new collective bargaining agreement. The negotiations are scheduled to begin today.

title: Chinese-Owned Steel Plant Is Accused of Bias in Hiring
description: The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board today accused a Chinese-owned steel plant in Delaware of unfair labor practices after the steelworkers union charged China with ''suppressing workers'' in the United States.

title: U.S. Experts Hopeful About Advanced TV
description: A growing number of scientists and engineers say there is hope that the United States can overcome a slow start in the international race to build television sets with razor-sharp pictures.

title: Mutual Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Timminco reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $178,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Net loss and included an extraordinary credit of $194,000, or 2 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Home Resales Hold Steady
description: As mortgage interest rates continued to fall, sales of existing homes remained steady in October, at their highest level since January, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Daiwa Admits Taking Loss for Large Clients
description: Small investors reacted angrily today when the Daiwa Securities Company, Japan's second-largest brokerage house, confirmed a newspaper report indicating that large institutional customers had received preferential treatment.

title: Surgery for Treasury Secretary
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady will undergo elective surgery to replace his hip on Dec. 14 and will be out of the office for three to six weeks, the Department of the Treasury said today. While he is recuperating, Deputy Secretary John E. Robson will be in charge of the department. Mr. Brady, 59 years old, has suffered from arthritis in his right hip for years, and has recently walked with a pronounced limp.

title: Q&A
description: Too Many Carrots?

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. uf90 Solitec Inc Qtr to Sept 30 1989 1988 Revenue 3,296,000 3,576,000 Net loss 1,634,000 1,973,000 Yr rev 16,990,000 16,661,000 Net loss 2,412,000 3,620,000 The company said its latest fourth quarter included $545,000 of one-time expenses related to conversion of certain debt and an inventory writedown of $200,000.

title: Rights vs. Testing
description: A suggestion appeared in this space on Oct. 3 that a ''war on drugs'' emphasizing ''combat, arrests and jailings'' could produce a ''wartime mentality'' - the spirit that ''anything goes,'' including the sacrifice of constitutional freedoms, in the battle against drugs. Here are two reader responses (names and addresses on request) only somewhat more extreme than others:

title: Bank Fraud Guilty Pleas
description: Two former Tennessee financiers pleaded guilty today before the start of a scheduled Federal trial on charges of bilking an Orlando bank of $3.9 million.

title: Walter Hoving, Punctilious Head Of Tiffany for 25 Years, Dies at 91
description: Walter Hoving, the sometimes imperious, always self-confident head of Tiffany & Company from 1955 to 1980, died yesterday morning at Newport (R.I.) Hospital, where he was admitted Nov. 14. He was 91 years old.

title: KEY RATES
Opponents of Fare Increases Dominate M.T.A. Public Hearing
description: More than 130 people gave the Metropolitan Transportation Authority a piece of their minds at a noisy public hearing yesterday, denouncing proposed increases in bus and subway fares as an unfair burden for the middle class and an impossible one for many others.

title: Liechtenstein Dismissal
description: The top financial adviser to Liechtenstein's royal family has been dismissed for insider trading, a banking spokesman said today.

title: Scientists Cite Gains On Sickle Cell Disease
description: AFTER years of slow, steady progress against sickle cell disease, scientists have recently reported a flurry of research advances and potential new treatments for the crippling blood disorder.

title: Clamor in the East; Kohl to Outline Plan for German Unity
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will call for a form of confederation with East Germany as an interim step toward reunification, senior West German officals said today.

title: COALITION TALKS BEGIN AS GANDHI LOSES A MAJORITY
description: As election returns erased any chance that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party would keep its majority, Parliament was dissolved tonight and two opposition political parties began discussions toward a coalition that would exclude the Congress Party from government for only the second time since India became independent 42 years ago.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Connecticut Weekly on Sunday about AIDS education misstated the response of a New Canaan public school official to a parent's charge that condoms had been distributed in a pilot program at New Canaan High School. The official, James Comer, district health education coordinator, said students had never been given condoms. He did not say they ''would no longer'' be given condoms.

title: Patterns
description: Marvin S. Traub, the chairman of Bloomingdale's, flew to Japan over the weekend. One can be certain he is not scouting the country for a storewide promotion. He is on a quest for ''financial support to help us purchase the store,'' said a store executive involved in the management's plan to buy Bloomingdale's from the Campeau Corporation. No doubt the calculators are clicking madly.

title: Opposition in Honduras Claims Victory in Presidential Election
description: The opposition presidential candidate in Honduras, Rafael Leonardo Callejas, an American-trained economist, claimed victory today in elections held on Sunday. Official returns were incomplete.

title: Script Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Television; Harlem to Congress With Warts and Halos
description: The brave and blemished career of Adam Clayton Powell Jr. is treated appreciatively yet candidly on tonight's edition of ''The American Experience.'' The hourlong documentary, at 9 P.M. on Channel 49 and 10 P.M. on Channel 13, captures the high style that made the preacher-politician-playboy so popular among his Harlem parishioners and consitutents, so irritating to many of his reluctant colleagues in Washington and such zippy copy for newspapers everywhere.

title: Salick Health Care reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: The company said improved results are attributable to the continued strong operating performance of its network of comprehensive outpatient cancer centers and its dialysis centers.

title: Citizens Savings Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $801,000, or 26 cents a share. c-After extraordinary charges of $290,000 and $920,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the extraordinary item in the year-ago quarter and 9 months represented a gain on the assumption of certain below market- rate Federal Home Loan Bank advances of Citizens Federal Bank, offset by the write-off of the balance of unamoritzed issuance costs of subordinated debt redeemed during the three months and 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Miller & Rhoads
description: The failing Miller & Rhoads department store chain abandoned a plan to reorganize under Federal bankruptcy law and said it would seek to sell its assets. The reversal came just four months after the century-old regional department store sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors and sought to reorganize as a smaller company.

title: Cezanne Sells for $17.3 Million, a Record
description: Paul Cezanne's ''Apples and Tablecloth,'' a still life from 1879-80, was sold last night in London for $17.3 million to a collector who was not identified. The price was a record for a work by the artist.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Oilfield Services Head Named at Halliburton
description: LEAD: The Halliburton Company, one of the nation's largest providers of oilfield, engineering and construction services, has promoted Alan A. Baker to head its diversified oilfield services group.

title: Tie/Telecom Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $1,062,000 for the quarter and $1,448,000 for the 9 months of non- recurring charges related to a program designed to reduce operating assets and operating costs. c-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: U.S. Issues Protest to Soviets On Arms to Salvador Rebels
description: The United States has told the Soviet Union that it holds Moscow indirectly responsible for what the State Department described today as the recent ''outrageous'' attempt by Nicaragua to ship advanced Soviet-made weapons to the leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: Blue Jays Sign Wilson To Two-Year Contract
description: The Toronto Blue Jays announced yesterday they had signed Mookie Wilson to a two-year contract worth $2.95 million that includes an option year. The deal calls for a $450,000 signing bonus and salaries of $900,000 in 1990 and $1.4 million in 1991. The option year calls for a salary of $1.45 million or a $200,000 buyout. If Wilson is traded before opening day 1991, his salary would increase by $100,000. The 33-year-old Wilson joined the Blue Jays from the Mets last August as the player-to-be-named-later in a trade that sent the pitcher Jeff Musselman to New York on Aug. 1.

title: Clamor in the East; Unshackled Czech Workers Declare Their Independence
description: Soon after the strike began today, Zdenek Janicek, a brewery worker in grimy overalls, rose on a platform and began to speak.

title: Democracy Speaks in India
description: What most distinguishes a democracy is the people's right to reject those in power. In India, the world's largest democracy and the third world's most durable, voters have done just that, denying a majority to Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party. They gave no clear mandate to any single political force but everywhere vented their anger at incumbents for corruption, inequality, religious discord and a variety of local failures.

title: Talking Business; with Purcell of Dean Witter Reynolds; Cutting Volatility To Help Investors
description: In a few short weeks this month, many of the trading rules on Wall Street were changed in reaction to calls to end index arbitrage and other forms of computerized trading. But even before the debate was a central issue on Wall Street, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, announced that it would abandon all forms of program trading. In a recent interview, Philip J. Purcell, the chairman and chief executive of Dean Witter, explained the firm's decision and discussed actions he believes may still be needed.

title: Clamor in the East; Where East Berlin's Elite Lived It Up
description: For the last three decades, the ladder to the top of what might sarcastically be called a workers' paradise ended here in a heavily wooded compound surrounded by a 1.5-mile concrete wall. The compound was the home of the 23-member Communist Politburo that ruled this country until six weeks ago.

title: Pressure Grows for Cuts in Intelligence Spending
description: Senior Pentagon officials' decision to consider substantial cuts in the military budget over the next few years has intensified pressure on intelligence agencies to take an equal share of the reductions.

title: 64% of Swiss Vote to Keep Army
description: Swiss voters have rejected an attempt to abolish the country's army by the year 2000, but the measure won much more support than expected.

title: Let's Stop Landfilling and Start Composting; Search for Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: McNeil Mantha Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $3,814,255, or 46 cents a share. The income from continuing operations in the latest year included a tax recovery of $528,480 and the 1988 year's loss before extraordinary item included a tax recovery of $3,442,164. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Land Is Losing to the Poor's Fight for Short-Term Survival
description: ACTING out of desperation, many of the poorest people in the world are cutting down forests, razing grasslands and slowly destroying fragile ecosystems to survive, environmental researchers say.

title: 3 Civic Groups Oppose Delay on New Ethics Rules
description: Three civic organizations said yesterday that they opposed any delay in new ethics rules that are to go into effect for New York City municipal employees on Jan. 1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: Boatmen's Bancshares Inc., St. Louis, to TBWA Kerlick Switzer, with a budget of $6 million.

title: Carl C. Dauterman, Art Curator
description: Carl C. Dauterman, curator emeritus of Western European art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died of lymphoma on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Clamor in the East; Chronology of Events in Czechoslovakia Under Communism
description: 1946: The Communists emerge as the strongest party in elections. Klement Gottwald, a party leader, heads the coalition Government and Eduard Benes, a non-Communist and President before and immediately after World War II, is re-elected President. 1948: The Communists force the resignation of Mr. Benes and Mr. Gottwald becomes President. Jan Masaryk, the Foreign Minister and son of the country's chief founder, dies in Prague under mysterious circumstances. A People's Republic is established in June. 1950: A Communist Party purge, seeking Stalinist ideological purity, brings the dismissal and, two years later, the execution of Vladimir Clementis, the Foreign Minister. Executed with him as anti-state conspirators are 10 other high party officials, most of them Jewish, including Rudolf Slansky. 1967: Demands grow, particularly among students and the intelligentsia, for a higher standard of living, greater personal freedom and an end to the police state. January 1968: Alexander Dubcek replaces Antonin Novotny as First Secretary of the Communist Party. The period known as Prague Spring, or ''socialism with a human face,'' begins. The Soviet Union expresses deep misgivings about liberal tendencies in Czechoslovakia. August 1968: The Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies invade Czechoslovakia. Mr. Dubcek is stripped of power and a year later is formally deposed as party chief. He is succeeded by hard-liners led by Gustav Husak. January 1977: Intellectual dissent erupts again with the signing of Charter 77, in which members of the intelligentsia air grievances against the Government of Mr. Husak, who became President in 1975. The Government cracks down harshly on the dissenters. December 1987: Mr. Husak keeps the largely ceremonial post of President but resigns as General Secretary of the party and is replaced in that post by Milos Jakes. Nov. 12, 1989: Amid the political turmoil sweeping Eastern Europe, Jakes tells a Communist youth conference that the party will not tolerate street protests or relax control of the country. Nov. 17: In the largest anti-Government rally since 1968, tens of thousands of demonstrators take to the streets. The protest is crushed. Nov. 19: Tens of thousands of Prague protesters denounce police brutality. Opposition groups, including some Communist allies, coalesce into the new Civic Forum and demand the resignations of the leaders responsible for the 1968 invasion. Nov. 20: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in Prague demand free elections and the resignations of the hard-line Communist leaders. Protests also break out in other cities. Nov. 24: The Communist leadership, headed by Mr. Jakes, resigns and Karel Urbanek, a little-known party official, replaces him as General Secretary of the party. Mr. Dubcek returns triumphantly to Prague and addresses a huge crowd in Wenceslas Square.

title: Mitterrand Cites Drug Threat
description: President Francois Mitterrand opened a new Interpol headquarters today with a warning on the peril generated by the international drug traffic. ''Every state must fight back if we do not want to collectively record a failure for civilization,'' the French President said. The annual General Assembly of Interpol, the International Criminal Police Organization, starts on Tuesday in Lyons, where Interpol moved its headquarters from its Paris base.

title: Genetic Errors Repaired in the Cell
description: SCIENTISTS have discovered that proteins that correct errors in genetic sequences resulting from DNA replications also may serve to maintain evolutionary divergence.

title: CD-ROM for the Common Man
description: THE Headstart Technologies Company of Great Neck, L.I., has introduced two new personal computers equipped with CD-ROM drives, becoming the first maker of personal computers to offer low-cost CD-ROM technology to the home, education and small-business markets.

title: Montana Too Much As 49ers Beat Giants
description: Late in the first half tonight, the Giants trailed the 49ers, 24-7, and their most talented defender, Lawrence Taylor, was out of the game with a sprained right knee and ankle.

title: LDDS Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,267,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net income The year-ago share earnings are pro forma because prior to Aug. 12, 1989 the company had warrants which had a put feature. The company said it no longer has exposure to buying back its warrants.

title: New Answer Proposed for Tektites: a Comet
description: A SOVIET scientist has concluded that the small glassy tektites strewn across much of the Eastern Hemisphere fell far more recently than had been thought, throwing doubt on timing of the great catastrophe responsible for their deposition.

title: Thousands Buried in Old Graves, Investigators in Kentucky Report
description: The remains of up to 48,000 people were buried in graves that were already occupied at two cemeteries in a practice believed to have begun in the 1920's, investigators for the State Attorney General's office say.

title: French Conduct Nuclear Test
description: France today set off its largest underground nuclear blast this year, at Fangataufa in French Polynesia, New Zealand Government scientists said. The 90-kiloton explosion was the fourth since testing resumed on Oct. 24. It brings to 111 the number of underground tests at sites near Tahiti.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
