description: * Dyncorp, Reston, Va., a technical services concern, named William J. Rodriguez vice president of finance of its Dynair Services Inc. unit.

title: Knicks Breeze to Victory As Protege Beats Mentor
description: Opposing coaches usually exchange pleasantries before a National Basketball Association game. But last night, the ritual was more than just that formality as a smiling Stu Jackson, the Knicks' coach, shook hands with Dick Harter, his counterpart with the Charlotte Hornets.

title: Oil Rig Count Dips by 3
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by 3, to 1,037, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. It was the second weekly decline after a string of gains. But the total number of working rigs still reflects 126 more than for the corresponding week a year ago.

title: Armatron International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $97,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $260,000, or 10 cents a share, for the year. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $22,000, or 1 cent a share, and $33,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Aircoa Hotel Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on early extinguishment of debt of $876,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Martha Wallace, 61; Business Consultant Led Big Foundation
description: Martha Redfield Wallace, a management consultant who was a director of many corporations, died of a heart attack Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 61 years old. She was the founder in 1983 of a consulting business, Redfield Associates, which helped to raise money for many causes. Its headquarters were in River House at 435 East 52d Street.

title: Housing Ruling Is Let Stand
description: New York City lost a way to stem the spread of homelessness as the Supreme Court decided not to rule on a law protecting single-room-occupancy hotels. Page B1.

title: More on Tyson-Cayton
description: Robert Hirth, an attorney for Don King, Mike Tyson's promoter, said yesterday that he had filed an amended complaint with the New York State Athletic Commission against the heavyweight champion's manager, Bill Cayton. The complaint is part of a counterclaim King brought earlier this year after Cayton asked the commission to investigate King on grounds he acted as a manager without a license.

title: Lincoln Cited On Bond Sale
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Henry Gonzalez, said today that the now-bankrupt Lincoln Savings had violated state and Federal regulations by selling bonds issued by its parent, the American Continental Corporation.

title: Too Soon to Slash Defense
description: Is anybody listening out there?

title: Merchants Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,445,000 for the quarter and $15,447,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses of $751,000 and $7,233,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations. The latest loss from continuing operations included a charge of $100,000 from reversal of a tax-loss carryforward. The year-ago 9 months' loss from continuing operations included a writedown of goodwill amounting to $2,589,000. The losses from discontinued operations in the latest quarter and 9 months included an estimated loss of $2,670,000 from the sale of mortgage banking assets. The loss from discontinued operations in the year-ago quarter included a charge of $350,000 from reversal of a tax benefit. The loss from discontinued operations in the year-ago 9 months included a writedown of goodwill totaling $7,854,000.

title: Pacific Aqua Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company did not have any operations in the year-earlier periods. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Almost a Year Later, Manning Starts Over Again
description: It is only the second quarter of the game and the score is still close, but the crowd has suddenly risen to its feet. At one end of the basketball court, the ball has been stripped from Michael Jordan's grasp, and now, in a furious fast break by the Los Angeles Clippers, it is headed in the opposite direction.

title: Soviet Author's Humor Has a Bitter Aftertaste
description: Vladimir Voinovich, standing a bit uncomfortably in front of a camera, gently reprimanded himself for smiling. ''Satirists should be gloomy,'' he murmured in his Russian-accented English. ''Gogol,'' he said, his smile disappearing, ''was gloomy.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Utah Coach Let Go
description: Jim Fassel, whose teams compiled a 25-33 record in his five years as head coach at the University of Utah, was dismissed yesterday, three days after the Utes completed a 4-8 season. ''Unfortunately, we have not made the progress that we have expected in the football program,'' Athletic Director Chris Hill said. (AP)

title: >Review/Theater; Oh, to Be Rich and Famous
description: In the interminable first act of Joe Sutton's new drama, ''Black Market,'' JoAnn (Elaine Rinehart) and Hatch (Bruce McCarty), an absurdly naive young married couple who have recently moved to Manhattan, sit around their tenement and dream of being rich and famous.

title: In Talks With China, Don't Forget the Chinese; Anxiety in Hong Kong
description: To the Editor:

title: First Gibraltar Predicts Earnings
description: First Gibraltar Savings Bank, which was formed after the takeover specialist Ronald O. Perelman merged five failed Texas savings institutions last year, is expected to earn $130 million in 1989, Gerald Ford, its chairman, said. He attributed the projected earnings to First Gibraltar's efforts to cut costs and gain new business. The institution has $12.2 billion in assets, and it is the largest savings and loan association in Texas.

title: Detroit Paper Strike Averted
description: The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press reached a tentative agreement with five unions today, preventing a strike in the first week of the newspapers' long-delayed business merger. The agreement came after more than 11 hours of talks that began Monday.

title: 'Day Without Art' to Mourn Losses From AIDS
description: Nearly 600 arts institutions throughout the United States plan to observe ''A Day Without Art'' on Friday to draw attention to the effects of AIDS on the arts community.

title: Conakry Journal; New Hope in Guinea, a Land That Hope Forgot
description: When Col. Lansana Conte seized power in Guinea five years ago, he vowed to restore law and order to a nation that had endured nearly three decades of nightmarish repression, purges and bloodshed.

title: Oppenheimer Capital L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. Awards Computer Contract
description: The Thinking Machines Corporation said today that it had received a $12 million contract from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to develop the first supercomputer capable of speeds of a trillion operations a second, the level of computer performance researchers believe will be necessary to solve the most difficult scientific problems.

title: 20 Papers in Britain Agree to an Ethics Code
description: Hoping to head off more Government restrictions and to rebuild public trust in their industry, editors of 20 national newspapers in Britain have agreed to an ethics code and a system to deal with complaints.

title: Judge Is Censured Over Remark on Homosexuals
description: A state judicial panel today censured a Dallas judge who said he had given a lighter sentence to a killer because the victims were ''queers'' looking for teen-age boys.

title: Terrorist Link Doubted in Colombian Crash
description: A Colombian jetliner lost cabin pressure before it was destroyed by an explosion on Monday and the 107 people aboard had time to don oxygen masks before they were killed, investigators said today.

title: McCaw Offers to Sweeten Its Bid for Lin
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said today that it would make its offer for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation more attractive, if the New York-based cellular telephone company would accept a friendly transaction. Lin, trying to fight off McCaw's advances, has agreed to merge with the BellSouth Corporation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Biocontrol Technology Inc., Indiana, Pa., a biotechnology concern, named T. J. Feola vice president and director of marketing and sales.

title: ONE COUNT DECIDED IN TRIAL ON ABUSE
description: The jurors deliberating in the longest criminal trial in the nation's history returned their first verdict under seal today and said they were deadlocked on another of the 65 charges against the defendants, Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey.

title: Lessons; Beyond 'rocks for jocks': Colleges strive to foster scientific literacy.
description: Kris Beck is a political science major at the University of Chicago who plans to become President of the United States. That's why he signed up for Natural Science 104.

title: The Short Life of 'Little Man,' A 14-Year-Old Drug Peddler
description: The life and death of Preston (Little Man) Simmons, a 14-year-old marijuana peddler who was shot and killed last Thursday, is a story that has become dismally familiar in his part of the world.

title: 'General Winter'
description: Quite literally, the weather this winter can change history. That has happened twice in Europe since World War II, once for the worse and once for the better.

title: We're Going to the Seashore by the Billions
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Of Mrs. Woolf's Husband And a Multi-Faceted Life
description: Letters of Leonard Woolf Edited by Frederic Spotts 616 pages. Illustrated. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: The Cholesterol Thing
description: One of the many things I have never been able to get interested in is what's going on in my arteries, which may explain why my attention always wanders when the conversation turns to cholesterol.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Staples Inc., Newton, Mass., an office-products manufacturer, to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos/Boston, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Layer on Layer Of Sweetness, Southern Style
description: I returned to the table and she brought me the cake, and I had my first felicitous meeting with Lady Baltimore. Oh, my goodness! Did you ever taste it? It's all soft, and it's in layers, and it has nuts -but I can't write anymore about it; my mouth waters too much.'' From the novel ''Lady Baltimore'' by Owen Wister

title: Trade and the Pope Await Gorbachev in Italy
description: Italy completed preparations today for a visit by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that will feature not only diplomatic open arms but also an important helping hand for the Soviet Union's troubled economy.

title: At Least 5 People Are Killed as Crane Topples in Downtown San Francisco
description: At least five people were killed here this morning when a construction crane collapsed in the financial district, slamming into two nearby buildings, crushing several cars and two buses and leaving the area strewn with twisted metal, crushed concrete and shattered glass.

title: Wherein Balloons Teach the Learning Process
description: Try this: Place a tiny mirror flat against a wall and guess where two people must stand so each can see the other's reflection. Then explain why.

title: Siberian Chemical Plant
description: Soviet and American partners, led by Combustion Engineering Inc. of Stamford, Conn., signed an agreement today to build and operate a $2 billion petrochemical complex in western Siberia. The first phase is to be finished by 1993.

title: Toshiba, NEC Post Big Gains
description: Toshiba and NEC, leading Japanese electronics companies, today announced large rises in profits because of global demand for computers.

title: Economic Scene; Shifting Spending To Public Works
description: THE upheaval in Eastern Europe, with its greater openness to the West, means to many Americans that the United States no longer needs a huge military establishment. The Bush Administration, in fact, is beginning to shrink the $300 billion military budget. But if billions of dollars are diverted from military spending over the next decade, how should the money be spent?

title: Delta Natural Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: LESS than a week after Thanksgiving, you would expect that most people would not even want to think about turkey. So how do you explain the unflagging popularity of Turkey King, a white- and blue-trimmed box of a building five blocks north of the Atlanta Civic Center on the outskirts of the city's downtown business area?

title: Claiborne Resigns
description: Jerry Claiborne, whose 6-5 record this season capped a 41-46-3 record in eight years as Kentucky's head coach, resigned unexpectedly yesterday, saying his heart was no longer into recruiting players.

title: Richard D. Irwin, 84, A Textbook Publisher
description: Richard Dorsey Irwin, a retired publisher, horse breeder and philanthropist, died of pneumonia Sunday at Ingalls Memorial Hospital in Harvey, ill. He was 84 years old and lived in Flossmoor, Ill.

title: On Being a Hostess With the Leastest
description: THE generous of heart who entertain have a recurring fantasy. ''One opens one's refrigerator and inside is Zabar's,'' as Nora Ephron puts it.

title: Mortgage Ceiling Lowered
description: The ceiling on the size of single-family home loans purchased by the nation's largest secondary mortgage-market agency is declining by $150, to $187,450 next year, the first drop in at least a decade, the agency said today.

title: Ex-Judge Leaves for Prison From a Court He Once Ran
description: Francis X. Smith, once one of the most powerful judges in New York City, walked yesterday into one of the courthouses he used to supervise, escorted by his son, his lawyer and a friend. When he left, he was escorted to jail.

title: American Woodmark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company attributed the decline in income in the latest quarter to the decline in sales and to a reduced production rate which resulted fb23,221,000 c24,004,000 Share earns 1.34 1.38 b-Included an extraordinary credit due to gain on the disposal of assets of $3,000,000, or 17 cents a share. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $942,000 for the quarter and $4,994,000 for the 9 months.

title: Ogrodnick an Outcast No Longer; His Dramatic Scoring Revival Has Spurred the Rangers
description: Perhaps it was during those many mornings he spent with his face buried in The Wall Street Journal that John Ogrodnick mastered the expressionless stare. Ogrodnick, the veteran left wing for the Rangers, won't say how heavily he was into the stock market a couple of years ago. Suffice it to say, he was an active trader and thus an inveterate worrier.

title: Baseball Talks Begin Cordially
description: On the same day they officially announced the departure of their longtime chief labor lawyer, representatives of baseball's club owners opened talks with the players' bargaining team yesterday calling for an end to the hostility that has raged between them.

title: In Talks With China, Don't Forget the Chinese; Let the Students Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Neediest Cases Drive Is Off To Better Start Than in 1988
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign for 1989-1990 opened on Sunday, and $1,303,381.21 has been collected. That is a substantial increase over the $1,168,040 that had been collected by the same time last year.

title: Met-Pro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Japan Vehicle Export Dip
description: Japan's car, truck and bus exports in October tumbled 11.4 percent from a year earlier, to 462,548 units, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. ''The drop was mainly from a sharp decrease in shipments of vehicles to the United States, where sales have been sluggish,'' an association official said. Vehicle shipments to the United States plunged 24.3 percent. An increase in production by foreign subsidiaries of Japanese auto makers also lowered exports from Japan.

title: Reviews/Music; Stravinsky By Youth Symphony
description: In youth-orchestra programming, hard experience has taught, discretion is the prime virtue. Samuel Wong's valiant program for the first concert of his second season as music director of the New York Youth Symphony on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall seemed, therefore, to carry the likelihood of failure and the potential for disaster. In particular, it was hard to imagine that the youngsters' attempt at Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring,'' looming after the intermission, could amount to more than a talking-dog affair - a marvel if they were able to negotiate it at all.

title: Eliana Martinez, 8; Won AIDS Court Test
description: Eliana Martinez, an AIDS patient whose mother successfully fought a court ruling that the child be in a glass cage in school classes, died of the disease on Monday. She was 8 years old.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Flyers 6, Penguins 3: Ilkka Sinisalo and Mark Howe scored twice and Mike Bullard had his 300th goal as Philadelphia won at Pittsburgh last night. The Flyers scored four goals on 17 shots in the first period to chase Wendell Young, the Penguin goalie. Mario Lemieux had two assists for Pittsburgh, extending his point-scoring streak to 13 games. (AP) Sabres 4, Whalers 2: Phil Housley and Christian Ruuttu had a goal and an assist apiece to lead Buffalo to the victory at Hartford. Housley, who reached the 500-point milestone with an assist in the first period, scored a goal in the second period as Buffalo, atop the league with a 16-5-4 record, improved its record to 9-2-1.(AP) Bruins 5, Blues 1: Cam Neely extended his goal-scoring streak to a league-high eight games and Bobby Carpenter and Ken Linseman each scored twice as Boston gained its eighth victory in its last nine games. Peter Zezel scored for the Blues, whose six-game home unbeaten streak came to an end. (AP)

title: U.S. Threatens to Quit U.N. Unit
description: The United States has warned that it may pull out of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization if the agency extends any new measure of recognition to the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: 300 Vietnamese Leave Hong Kong for West
description: More than 300 Vietnamese refugees who had waited two years in this British colony boarded a plane today for their journey to the West.

title: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Dip
description: Yields offered on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Poindexter, in Mailing, Solicits Money
description: With the help of former Navy colleagues and a direct mail specialist, John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser facing trial in the Iran-contra affair, is making an unusual public appeal for money to help pay his mounting legal bills.

title: Shearson Said to Consider Outside Investor
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is examining the possibility of bringing in an outside investor to put additional capital into the troubled brokerage firm, people close to the plan said yesterday.

title: Tests on First Lady Find Eye Condition Remains Unchanged
description: Barbara Bush learned today after two hours of tests at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., that her thyroid disease is not improving, although it has not worsened, her spokeswoman said.

title: SYRIA MOVES TANKS NEAR AOUN'S BASE
description: Dozens of Syrian tanks, supporting President Elias Hrawi, moved within easy striking distance today of the military stronghold of Gen. Michel Aoun, who has refused to recognize the new President and has said he expects a Syrian attack.

title: Bank Rescinds Cut in Prime
description: The Southwest Bank of St. Louis, which three weeks ago was the first to announce a cut in its prime lending rate to 10 percent, said yesterday that it was raising the rate back to 10 1/2 percent ''at least on a temporary basis.''

title: Turner Broadcasting Seen In Talks to Buy MGM/UA
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. is still negotiating to acquire the MGM/UA Communications Company, several executives close to Turner said today, despite some reports to the contrary. They added that the deal, as it was now being discussed, could be for stock.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Investcorp to Acquire 700-Shop Carvel Chain
description: LEAD: Thomas Carvel, the 83-year-old chairman of the Carvel Corporation, agreed yesterday to sell a controlling interest in the private Yonkers-based ice-cream store chain to Investcorp, an international investment bank.

title: Change in S.&P. Index
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said this week that it would remove the Noxell Corporation from its 500-stock index at the close of trading tomorrow. Noxell is being acquired by the Procter & Gamble Company. St Jude Medical Inc. will be added to the index.

title: WINE TALK
description: IF you suspect that some generous admirer is planning to give you a case or two of 1985 Chateau Margaux this Christmas, hint around to your less affluent friends that you'd like a copy of Jancis Robinson's ''Vintage Timecharts'' to go with the wine.

title: Southern Union Co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,000,000. Preferred dividend requirements reduced net income to a per-share loss. The company said latest third quarter results reflected a $1.2 million reduction in the quarter's federal and state income tax benefit. The reduction is the result of a restatement of the tax benefit associated with the fourth quarter 1988 writedown of the company's Forest Central Office Park project.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Good Health Channel Set for Doctors' Offices
description: Whittle Communications is not the only company angling for the captive audiences in doctors' waiting rooms. Fred Doner, son of the founder of W. B. Doner and a former partner in the Baltimore advertising agency, said he would introduce an advertiser-supported television service in waiting rooms next week.

title: Woman Held on Arms Charge in Salvador Is Defended as Neutral Idealist
description: Friends and associates of Jennifer Jean Casolo depict her as an idealistic and deeply religious woman who thought she could help end the decade-old civil war in El Salvador by bringing people to see the horror of the conflict first hand.

title: Parkway Honors Clara Barton
description: President Bush today signed legislation renaming the Maryland and Washington parts of the George Washington Memorial Parkway the Clara Barton Parkway. The name change is intended both to honor the Civil War nurse who organized the American Red Cross in 1881 and to help motorists who confused the Maryland-District stretch of the parkway with the longer, better known portion of the George Washington Memorial Parkway on the Virginia side of the Potomac River.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''How a reunited Germany would ultimately look, no one today knows. That unity will come if the people in Germany want it, of that I am certain.'' - Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. [ A1:4. ]

title: Gunnar Hedlund, Swedish Politician, 89
description: Gunnar Hedlund, the longtime leader of the Swedish Center Party and a former Interior Minister, died on Sunday after a long illness. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was not made public.

title: Market Place; Added Troubles At Western Union
description: BENNETT S. LEBOW seemed to be Western Union's savior when he swooped in, with backing from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., to put fresh money in the ailing telex company in December 1987. But now Western Union has new troubles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Prominent Rightist Slain in El Salvador
description: The former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, one of this country's most prominent right-wing politicians, was shot to death today outside a fast-food restaurant here.

title: Stake in Avon Increased to 8%
description: A limited partnership that includes Gordon P. Getty said today that it had increased its stake in Avon Products Inc. to 8 percent.

title: McCartney Sees Chance Of Beatle Get-Together
description: Paul McCartney says the way may be clear for a reunion of the three remaining ex-Beatles.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: LADISLAV ADAMEC, Prime Minister: LAH-dyih-slav AH-dah-mets MARIAN CALFA, a minister without portfolio: MAH-rih-ahn TSAL-fah JIRI DIENSTBIER, a dissident leader: YIHR-zhee DEENST-beer ALEXANDER DUBCEK, a former party leader: AH-lehk-sahn-dehr DOOB-chehk VACLAV HAVEL, playwright and opposition leader: VAHTS-lahv HAH-vell JIRI HAYEK, a former Foreign Minister: YIHR-zhee HAH-yeck JOSEF HORA, a party spokesman: YOH-zef HOH-rah GUSTAV HUSAK, the President: GOOS-tahv HOO-sahk ALOIS INDRA, a former Parliament leader: AH-lo-yis IN-drah MILOS JAKES, a former party leader: MEE-lohsh YAH-kesh VALTR KOMAREK, an economist: VAHL-truh KOH-mah-reck BOHUSLAV KUCERA, the Socialist Party leader: BOH-hoo-slahv KUH-cheh-rah MILAN KUNDERA, a writer: MIH-lahn KUHN-deh-rah PAVEL LANDOVSKY, an actor: PAH-vell LAHN-dohv-skee VACLAV MALY, an opposition leader: VAHTS-lahv MAH-lee JAN PALACH, who committed suicide to protest the 1968 invasion: YANN PAH-lah JAROMIR SEDLAK, head of a reformist faction within the party: YAH-roh-meer SEHD-lahk LUBOMIR STROUGAL, a former Prime Minister: LUH-boh-meer STROH-gahl KAREL URBANEK, the party leader: KAH-rell OOR-bahn-eck JAROMIR ZAK, Deputy Prime Minister: YAH-roh-meer zhak

title: Lendl Has an Easy Time; Becker Squeaks By
description: Michael Chang looked across the net last night and saw, in addition to the No. 1 player in the world, a giant of a man with an ax to grind and just the weapon to do it.

title: Corrections
description: A chronology on Saturday about developments in Eastern Europe dated several political events in Hungary incorrectly. Janos Kadar, the Communist leader, stepped down on May 22, 1988, not 1989; the Communist Party was formally disbanded on Oct. 7, 1989, not 1988, and the constitution was amended to allow a multiparty system on Oct. 17, 1989, not 1988.

title: Montana, L.T. in a Tale Of 2 Blocks
description: The quarterback couldn't take a deep breath without wincing. The linebacker couldn't walk without crutches. Joe Montana was wearing a towel as he stood at his locker in the 49ers' dressing room. Lawrence Taylor was wearing a scowl as he hobbled on crutches to the bus that would take the Giants to the airport Monday night after a 34-24 loss in the essence of the National Football League: its two best teams at their best.

title: Ralph S. Purdum Actor, 63
description: Ralph S. Purdum, an acxtor who ap-peared in many plays, television programs and commercials, died of pancreatic cancer on Monday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 63 years old and lived in Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: INSIDE
description: Tensions Rise in Lebanon The Christian commander, Gen.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; McCann Opens In Yugoslavia
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide yesterday became the first international agency to open a branch in Yugoslavia -underscoring the industry's growing conviction that there is opportunity in the political and economic tumult of Eastern Europe. The agency, called Jadran

title: Secrecy vs. Truth on Iran-Contra
description: Dismissal of the indictment against Joseph Fernandez, a former C.I.A. station chief in Costa Rica, sets back the pursuit of those culpable for illicit U.S. aid to the contras in Nicaragua. The special prosecutor has good reason to ask higher courts to reinstate charges of lying to investigators.

title: KEY RATES
Great Western Expecting Loss
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation said today that it would add $200 million to a reserve against possible losses on bad real estate loans. The savings and loan company said the move would reduce its after-tax earnings in the fourth quarter by as much as $150 million, causing a loss for the period of about $75 million.

title: 'Messiah' as It Once Was
description: Handel's ''Messiah,'' in the version for men's and boys' voices in which it was originally performed more than 200 years ago, will be given two performances by the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys on Dec. 12 and 14 at 7:30 P.M. at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53d Street. Tickets are $20 and $50 for reserved seats; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: 757-7013.

title: Birago Diop, 83, Poet, Novelist and Diplomat
description: Birago Diop, a Senegalese poet, novelist and diplomat and a founder of the Negritude movement in the 1930's, died on Saturday in Dakar, according to an announcement on national television in Senegal. No cause of death was given. He was 83 years old.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Emerges as Leading Candidate for U.S. Rights Post
description: A former New York State Senator has emerged as the leading contender for the nation's top civil rights enforcement job, Administration officials and New York Republicans said today.

title: Polaroid Venture
description: The Polaroid Corporation said it was developing electronic medical imaging equipment for hospitals. The company said the products, which are to be available in 1991, would record images from electronic diagnostic tools, quickly giving doctors pictures of internal organs and other body parts.

title: Abortion and Freedom: Fine Line for Catholics
description: A growing number of Roman Catholic universities are debating whether advocacy of abortion rights and the distribution of condoms on campus are compatible with their identity as Catholic institutions.

title: Merrill Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After writedown of marketable equity securities of $1,792,000, or 48 cents a share. c-Net income

title: Citicorp Rates Off
description: Interest rates declined yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, capping a month of up-and-down swings. The bank holding company sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.1855 percent, down from 8.2181 percent last week. Citicorp said it also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an average rate of 7.8648 percent, down from 7.8822 percent.

title: Emergency Flare Is Spotted In Hunt for Five Lobstermen
description: For the second night in a row, Coast Guard searchers spotted a flare tonight in their search for five crew members from a lobster boat that disappeared a week ago off Massachusetts.

title: Trial Is By a Defendant In Police Slaying
description: Howard (Pappy) Mason, described by the authorities as a drug boss, refused to attend his Federal racketeering trial yesterday as a jury heard testimony that he ordered, from jail, the murder of a New York City police officer because he felt the police had shown him ''disrespect.''

title: Girl Reported Doing Well With Liver From Mother
description: A 21-month-old girl was doing well today after receiving the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor on Monday and undergoing surgery this morning to stop bleeding from the transplanted organ.

title: Defendant's Emotion Forces Pause in Trial for 27 Deaths
description: A man accused of killing 27 people when his pickup truck crashed into a school bus broke down sobbing today as a coroner told a court of the fire in which the victims died.

title: Clyde F. Kohm, 81, Geographer and Author
description: Clyde F. Kohn, a geographer and author, died of multiple myeloma on Wednesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 78 years old.

title: Despite Best of Plans, the Fare Dispute Lives Again
description: The script for this year's subway fare increase was written here in the state capital three years ago, and, in a departure from the usual plot, no fight scene was planned for the final act. But now it turns out that the drama will end much as it always has -with a boisterous battle at the close.

title: Manhattan Man Held in Sex Abuse of Girl
description: A Manhattan musician was arrested yesterday and accused of sexually abusing the 11-year-old daughter of his common-law wife, the Housing Authority police said.

title: Pretoria Decentralizes Security System
description: President F. W. de Klerk announced today that he was scrapping a system that gave the army and the police a dominant role in regional and local government.

title: ABS Shows Win, But Network Is 2d
description: ABC's ''Roseanne'' returned to first place in the network ratings race last week, and ABC had 6 of the top 10 shows. But NBC still won the week easily. ABC was second and CBS third.

title: Bonds for Hawaii Airports
description: The Hawaii Department of Airports yesterday tentatively priced through negotiation a $100 million issue of airport system revenue bonds.

title: OPEC Sets New Policy On Quotas
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided tonight to revise its quota system in a fundamental way that would give Persian Gulf oil producers a firm grip on prices and production in the next decade.

title: Critic's Notebook; Soane's Rooms and the Lessons in Them
description: This is a tale of two rooms, and one city. The rooms are the latest works of Sir John Soane -the latest to be seen by the public, that is, not the latest to be designed, since Soane, the genius known for his brilliant contortions of neo-classical space, died in 1837. At his death Soane left a rich array of buildings, including two unquestioned masterworks: the headquarters of the Bank of England, which was altered beyond recognition by Sir Herbert Baker in 1925, and his own house and office at 13 Lincoln's Inn Fields, which remains essentially as he left it, open to the public as Sir John Soane's Museum.

title: Victorian Era: Holiday Images For All Times
description: HOLIDAYS reinforce links to the past, and not necessarily one's own. As December rolls around, the bygone era most often dusted off is the 19th century, especially as it unfolded in Victorian England. This season the image seems more pervasive than ever.

title: Frank Fools Crow, a Sioux Tribal Leader
description: Frank Fools Crow, a Sioux Indian spiritual leader who helped to negotiate the end of a 68-day insurrection at Wounded Knee, S.D., in 1973, died Monday at the home of his grandchildren. Mr. Fools Crow, whose exact age was not known, was believed to be 99 years old.

title: 4 One-Ring Circuses In Library Photo Show
description: One-ring circuses from the United States, France, Switzerland and Canada are the subject of a photography show that will be on view through Jan. 27 at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

title: Commuter Plane With 8 Aboard Disappears on Flight From Island
description: A New England Airline commuter plane with eight people aboard was feared missing in the Atlantic Ocean after it vanished tonight on a night flight from Block Island, the authorities said.

title: ...And Naval Arms Control
description: LEAD: To the dismay of the Bush Administration, Mikhail Gorbachev may raise the subject of naval nuclear weapons at the upcoming summit meeting. He could hardly have picked a better setting: The salons of the U.S.S. Belknap and the Soviet Slava, two cruisers with important nuclear histories.

title: Nikon Says It Is Not in Talks With Perkin-Elmer
description: The Nikon Corporation said this morning that it was not in negotiations with the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, although it acknowledged for the first time that it had held such talks several months ago about acquiring the American company's semiconductor equipment operations.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL COMMITTEE -10 A.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 and 8 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS - 10 A.M.

title: After Eastern Europe's Spring
description: The end of history? The remarkable uprisings in Eastern Europe are more like a resumption of history. As Hungarians plan their first free elections since World War II, demonstrators in Czechoslovakia quote Thomas Jefferson and chant the name of Alexander Dubcek, who failed heroically in 1968 to bring reform. And now, astonishingly, Prague's hard-line rulers have agreed to form a new coalition government by Sunday.

title: In Talks With China, Don't Forget the Chinese
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Rises 7.04 as Light Trading Continues
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing above 2,700, after languishing in a slightly higher range throughout most of the session.

title: Cleveland Journal; Young Swimmers Race For a Better Way of Life
description: It is an idle school-day afternoon on the rugged East Side of Cleveland. Groups of children hang out on the street corner, while a couple of dozen others gather around a swimming coach in an inner-city gymnasium and plot their path to the big time.

title: Bridge
description: As New Yorkers are well aware, the most challenging job in the city is about to change hands. In the bridge community the same switch has already occurred; on Oct. 5 Richard Reisig took over from Tom Snow as secretary of the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan. He will administer the world's most famous bridge club, whose members include many world champions and whose activities include the annual Invitational Charity Pairs event.

title: Murder Charge Renewed in Reporter's Death
description: Saying he had turned up new evidence, the Attorney General has reinstated a murder charge against a man in the 1976 car-bomb slaying of a newspaper reporter. Don Bolles.

title: Boskin Sees Lower Rates
description: Michael Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he expected interest rates to fall a bit further, spurring increased consumer demand for durable goods.

title: Kentucky Wins Opener
description: Reggie Hanson scored 24 points tonight to lead Kentucky past Ohio University, 76-73, giving Rick Pitino a victory in his debut as coach of the Wildcats after leaving the Knicks.

title: Aging Baths In Brighton Face Demise
description: These days Jose Ruiz eyes his neighbor across the street, an aging recreational complex sprawled over 15 acres of Brooklyn's Brighton Beach waterfront, and can hardly wait for it to die.

title: Signing With Athletics, Henderson Has Top Pact
description: Baseball's spiraling salary structure reached a new plateau yesterday when Rickey Henderson, traded by the Yankees to his hometown Oakland Athletics last June 21, agreed to a four-year contract with the A's worth $12 million.

title: Water Club's Ex-Manager Guilty of Embezzlement
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a former manager of the Water Club restaurant in Manhattan embezzled at least $485,000 while he ran the restaurant from 1983 to 1986.

title: Loral to Acquire Honeywell Unit
description: Honeywell Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Electro-Optics division to the Loral Corporation, a New York military electronics company, for undisclosed terms.

title: Australia Move To Ban Insiders
description: Australian legislators today called insider traders ''corporate spiders'' who prey upon ordinary shareholders and said they should be wiped out.

title: The 4 Personalities Of Jose van Dam In Met 'Hoffmann'
description: ''The difficulty in portraying the four villains in 'Les Contes d'Hoffmann' is not in changing the characterizations, but in changing the costumes, the makeup and the wigs,'' said Jose van Dam, the Belgian bass-baritone who has been singing the quadruple role at the Metropolitan Opera. ''After all, the four characters are fundamentally the same.''

title: Claudio Teehankee, 71, Philippine U.N. Envoy
description: Claudio Teehankee, the representative of the Philippines at the United Nations and former Chief Justice of the nation's Supreme Court, died of cancer Monday in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: Camacho Finds a Foe: Trainer for Pazienza
description: Hector Camacho never met a spotlight he didn't like.

title: ABC Surpasses CBS in Evening News Ratings
description: ABC's ''World News Tonight'' has taken over as the top-rated network evening newscast, displacing the CBS ''Evening News'' in the most tightly contested continuing ratings race in the television industry.

title: Harvey Hart, Director, 61
description: Harvey Hart, a Canadian film and television director, died of a heart attack on Nov. 21 in Toronto. He was 61 years old.

title: Fluorocarbon reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 4
description: b-Included a gain of $1,049,000, or 12 cents a share, on the sale of assets.

title: Gen. Alva Fitch, 82, an Intelligence Official
description: Lieut. Gen. Alva R. Fitch, a survivor of the Bataan ''death march'' in the Philippines in 1942 who later became a deputy director of the Defense Intelligence Agency, died of a kidney ailment on Friday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Campbell Steps Down As Coach of Falcons
description: Marion Campbell ended a 28-year National Football League career as an assistant or head coach yesterday by retiring as coach of the Atlanta Falcons, who are in last place in the N.F.C. West with a 3-9 record.

title: Treasury Issues Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday as dealers placed bids at an auction of $10 billion worth of two-year notes.

title: Judge Upholds a Ban On Hinckley Interviews
description: The man who shot President Ronald Reagan was turned back in a Federal district court today from his effort to be interviewed by news organizations.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about Health magazine misidentified an editor who announced her resignation. She is Dianne Partie Lange.

title: Limited Partner at Firm
description: John C. Whitehead, former Deputy Secretary of State, is becoming a limited partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the firm announced yesterday. As a limited partner, Mr. Whitehead's personal investments will be managed by the firm, but he will have no operational or administrative responsibility, a spokesman said. Mr. Whitehead was co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs until he joined the State Department in 1985. He left the Administration in January and has since been named the chairman of AEA Investors Inc., a New York investment firm.

title: Trade Gap a Bit Wider As Export Growth Lags
description: The United States trade deficit, after improving for six months, deteriorated slightly, to $27.75 billion, in the third quarter, reflecting flat exports and the nation's appetite for imported goods.

title: Book Notes
description: Foreign Competition

title: Canada Leader Wins a Vote for Abortion Curb
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney won a crucial vote in Parliament today for legislation to restrict access to abortions after speaking in support of the bill.

title: Chicago
description: JUST mention soul food, and to many people that will invoke images of salty greens and heavy, fatty meats - delicious but, in short, unhealthy, artery-clogging fare. But it does not have to be that way. One need only ask Avis Piper.

title: PLANE CRASH KILLS A SAFETY OFFICIAL
description: Joseph T. Nall, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, was killed Monday in the crash of a small plane in Caracas, Venezuela, board officials said today.

title: Long Term in Gay Man's Death
description: A high school football star was sentenced today to 40 years in prison for his part in the beating death of a gay man from Wethersfield.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Review/Ballet; 'Nutcracker' Lets Dancers Move From Role to Role
description: ''The Nutcracker'' is a holiday classic that offers the opportunity for dancers to move into new roles, often with the eagerness with which the battalions of mice take over the stage in the dream of toys and a candy paradise that is at the heart of the ballet. And on Sunday afternoon at City Center, Meg Gurin and Pascal Benichou danced the roles of the Sugar Plum Fairy and the Nutcracker Prince in the Joffrey Ballet's cosy, pretty production of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: Kohl Offers an Outline to Create Confederation of the 2 Germanys
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl presented an outline to Parliament today for creating a German federation that would eventually lead to the reunification of the two German states.

title: Dr. Marcus David Kogel, 86, Dies; Headed Einstein Medical College
description: Dr. Marcus David Kogel, the founding dean of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University and a former Commissioner of Hospitals in New York City, died of pancreatic cancer yesterday at his daughter's home in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: After 16 Years, Chief Gives Up Hardee's Job
description: At Hardee's Food Systems Inc., a chief executive with one of the longest tenures in the fast-food industry is stepping down.

title: Gandhi Steps Aside, Boosting Rivals' Bid To Assume Power
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi submitted his resignation to the President of India this morning, opening the way for an opposition coalition to try to form a government.

title: New Jersey Sets Guidelines on Video Terminals
description: With almost half of the 500,000 public employees in New Jersey spending time in front of video-display terminals, the State Health Department today issued guidelines intended to eliminate hazards that can cause injury and stress.

title: Severely Disabled Gain School Aid
description: The Supreme Court has refused to let public schools cut off educational help to severely handicapped children even though they may not be able to benefit from such services.

title: Parrish Is Free Agent
description: Lance Parrish was declared a free agent yesterday by the arbitrator George Nicolau and has until Jan. 8 to negotiate with all clubs. But the California Angels, his team this past season, said they were seeking to retain the veteran catcher.

title: Excerpts From Kohl Speech On Reunification of Germany
description: Following are excerpts from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's speech today on German reunification, as translated by Reuters:

title: Taylor Likely To Sit Out Eagle Game
description: Bill Parcells expects Lawrence Taylor's sprained right ankle to prevent the Giants' All-Pro linebacker from playing Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Washington Talk; Afghanistan Frozen Out In a Superpower Thaw
description: The Afghan rebels were a lot more popular in Washington when they were winners. Theirs was a classic geopolitical battle: bearded, turbaned ''freedom fighters'' with their divine mission and American-made weapons against the well-trained, heavily armed Red Army.

title: George S. Pettee, 85, Military Analyst, Dies
description: George Sawyer Pettee, a research analyst, educator and author who wrote extensively on national security issues, died of Parkinson's disease on Nov. 17 at the Kensington Gardens Nursing Home in Maryland. He was 85 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: IMMUNITY AN ISSUE IN ALASKAN SPILL
description: Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood's contention that he is immune from prosecution for sailing the Exxon Valdez onto the rocks of Prince William Sound last March is being fought out in a state court here, two months before his trial is to start.

title: Czech Students Rejoice At News of Concessions
description: Hundreds of philosophy students crammed into the second floor at Charles University today to discuss with their deans and professors how the department's curriculum could be changed to make it less doctrinaire.

title: PRAGUE PARTY TO YIELD SOME CABINET POSTS AND DROP INSISTENCE ON PRIMACY IN SOCIETY
description: The Communist Government, with the approval of party leaders, all but surrendered to its opposition today by pledging to give up its 41-year monopoly on political power and to allow non-Communist ministers into a new Cabinet to be named by Sunday.

title: Czech Intellectuals, Underemployed, Ponder Their Future
description: All over Czechoslovakia, intellectuals who have spent two decades assigned to such demeaning jobs as window washer, bathroom attendant and coal stoker for their involvement in the liberal experiments of the Prague Spring 21 years ago are wondering whether their fortunes and positions may improve.

title: Braniff Officials Answer Creditors
description: Braniff Inc. officials told creditors the airline was operating as a ''limited charter carrier'' while seeking a buyer and was continuing to run up expenses under bankruptcy proceedings. Howard T. Glassman, a Braniff lawyer, told the creditors in one of a series of meetings conducted by the bankruptcy trustee that there was no clear picture of the airline's future. But officials said they do not expect Braniff to go into liquidation and sell its assets.

title: Havel, Often-Jailed Dramatist, Became Symbol of Dissent
description: If proof is needed that the pen is mightier than the sword, then Vaclav Havel is a veritable smoking gun.

title: Disney Seeking to Extend Success to Making Records
description: Having succeeded with its theme parks and movie making, the Walt Disney Company wants to see if its golden touch extends to the recording industry.

title: Don't Give Rockets to Rebels, Kabul Tells U.S.
description: In the aftermath of a weekend attack on Kabul that killed at least 38 people and wounded more than 100, the Soviet-backed Government here has renewed demands that the United States stop supplying Muslim rebel groups with Egyptian-made rockets that have become their primary weapon in attacks on Afghan cities.

title: Carlos Arias Navarro, Spanish Official, 80
description: Carlos Arias Navarro, the last Prime Minister appointed under Franco, died of a heart attack on Monday, his family said today. He was 80 years old.

title: Colt Plans to Sell Firearms Division
description: Colt Industries said today that it would sell its firearms division to an investor group in a deal that could end a long strike by the United Automobile Workers union.

title: Why Foreign Air Takeovers Are Unthinkable
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate; At Columbus Circle, Better Is Smaller
description: A SMALL office building that has just opened on Columbus Circle seems to belie the prevalent mind-set that bigger is better in Manhattan real estate development.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Reviews/Theater; A Play About a Play And Writer's Block
description: In ''Kate's Diary'' by Kathleen Tolan, characters comment on the deficiencies of a play in progress, indicating that it is melodramatic or self-indulgent or that it causes ''the audience's presumed discomfort.'' The comments are intended to be disarming, but one ends with the belief that the playwright has been astute in her self-criticism.

title: Priscilla Robertson, 79, Historian and Teacher
description: Priscilla Robertson, an author, a historian and a teacher, died of a stroke on Sunday at Humana Hospital-Suburban in Louisville, Ky. She was 79 years old.

title: Excerpts From Statements by Czech Leaders and Opposition
description: Following are excerpts from statements issued by the Czechoslovak Government and by Civic Forum and the Public Against Violence, two leading Czechoslovak opposition groups, after Prime Minister Ladislav Adamec met with the opposition groups today. The Government statement was translated by The New York Times; the opposition issued an official translation. GOVERNMENT STATEMENT

title: Moscow Gives Disputed Area Back to Azerbaijan
description: The Supreme Soviet today restored Azerbaijan's control over the territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, the center of a prolonged and violent dispute with neighboring Armenia.

title: Easing Seen In Food Costs
description: Consumer food prices will rise at a much slower pace in 1990 as farmers continue to expand their crop production, a senior Agriculture Department economist predicted today.

title: EATING WELL
description: DR. JEAN MAYER has been the president of Tufts University for 13 years, but he is still well known as a nutritionist. He secured his place in the nutrition hall of fame when he was chairman of the first White House Conference on Food, Nutrition and Health in 1969. At the time, the French-born, much-decorated World War II artillery officer with the Free French forces was a professor of nutrition at Harvard University.

title: Reviews/Music; Austrian Violinist In Recital
description: Thomas Zehetmair, a 28-year-old Austrian violinist, is known in the United States mainly through a handful of recordings (on the Teldec label) that show him to be an iconoclastic interpreter with a solid technique. At his New York debut recital, on Sunday afternoon at the Frick Collection, he demonstrated that the recordings are faithful representations of his work.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon referred incorrectly in some copies to the other man shown. He was Joseph Borrelli, the Chief of Detectives.

title: Official's Trips Home Cost T.V.A. $172,700
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority paid $172,700 to fly a top manager between his home in Virginia and his office in Tennessee over a one-year period, a Congressional report says.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FEW dishes are more satisfying in late fall than poached chicken with vegetables. This one-pot meal can be prepared quickly and is excellent as a leftover.

title: High Court in Maine Outlaws Riverblocks
description: The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that armed state officials who were trying to stop illegal and rowdy conduct on the popular Saco River in southern Maine had no right to set up a ''riverblock'' last year to stop and search canoeists there.

title: 'Christmas Story' on Stage
description: The Waverly Consort will present a fully staged version of ''The Christmas Story'' on Dec. 14, 15 and 16 at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West 46th Street. There will be two performances each night, at 7 and 9:15. The work is based on medieval manuscripts from Spain, France, Italy and England, with music composed over a period of 400 years. Eight singers and five instrumentalists - playing reproductions of medieval instruments - will perform.

title: U.S. Will Start Over on Planning For Nevada Nuclear Waste Dump
description: The Government has abandoned a two-year effort costing $500 million to plan the nation's only dump for highly radioactive nuclear waste because it lacks confidence in its work thus far, officials said last night. It has decided to start over.

title: Van Sinderen Lindsley Jr., Executive, 83
description: Van Sinderen Lindsley Jr., a retired advertising executive, died Sunday at a nursing home in Suffern, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: Niatross Is Sold
description: Niatross, one of the greatest harness racing horses, fetched $1.35 million in a United States Bankruptcy Court auction. Niatross was owned by Saratoga Standardbreds, which filed for bankruptcy last year.

title: For the Gift-Giving Season, Improvements on Old Favorites
description: AN early peek into this year's Christmas sack of kitchen equipment reveals few innovative products. Instead, one sees familiar tools that have been considerably improved.

title: Hero's Ashes Scattered at Sea
description: The crew of a Navy frigate named for a Vietnam War hero, Lieut. Comdr. Wilmer Paul Cook, performed a solemn mission Monday, scattering the commander's ashes at sea 22 years after he died in battle.

title: Retarded Slayer Faces Execution for Killing at 17
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer denied clemency today for a retarded man scheduled to go to the electric chair on Thursday for killing a state trooper, a crime committed at the age of 17.

title: Trident 2 Test Threatened
description: Members of the anti-nuclear protest group Greenpeace will try to halt the launching of a Trident 2 missile from a submarine off the Florida coast, a spokeswoman said today. The spokeswoman, Shannon Fagan, said the launching was set for Friday, but the Navy declined to confirm or deny it. Greenpeace was successful in stopping a Trident 2 test from a submarine last July, maneuvering small rafts close enough to the vessel to attach protest banners to its hull and mast.

title: Muscular Chips With a Lighter Price
description: rrUsing an advanced computer technology like RISC to power a cellular telephone or a compact disk player sounds a bit like using a supercomputer to balance a checkbook. But Microchip Technology Inc. says it has found a way to make the chips inexpensive enough for such uses.

title: Giants Are Not Downcast
description: The Giants wanted to keep Joe Montana from making the big play Monday night, and they did. They did not want to fall behind early and be forced to pass, but they did.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ambrit Inc., St. Petersburg, Fla., a novelty products maker, agreed to a new exchange ratio in its proposed merger with Empire of Carolina Inc., Tarboro, N.C., a toy maker. Each Ambrit share will be exchanged for three-tenths of an Empire share.

title: Which Is Cheaper, $1.11 or $1.15?
description: In a kinder world, New York's present $1 bus and subway fare would stay right there. But that's neither realistic nor prudent. The cost of living has gone up 22 percent since the last fare increase, in 1986, and so has the cost of operating the transit system. That means fares or government transit subsidies must go up.

title: Czechoslovakia's Moment in Time
description: It seemed somehow appropriate that when the old regime in Czechoslovakia formally agreed to cede its monopoly on power, the deed was done between a caretaker Prime Minister and an opposition lacking even a formal headquarters.

title: Dinkins Group Considering 11 Candidates for Police Post
description: David N. Dinkins's committee to seek nominees for police commissioner decided yesterday to interview 11 candidates, including the incumbent, Richard J. Condon, and to report back to Mr. Dinkins by Dec. 11, people close to the search said.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Vashon Island, Wash.
description: LEAD: PETE and Judy Shepherd didn't set out to produce some of the best jam in the Northwest.

title: Medieval Book of Kells Printed in Switzerland
description: The Book of Kells, a medieval masterpiece that ranks as one of the world's most beautiful illuminated manuscripts, has been printed almost 12 centuries after it was created.

title: Oil, a Foundation of Alaska, Works to Rebuild Its Image
description: For four days last month, the State of Alaska refused to allow an oil tanker to discharge her cargo at a refinery 100 miles south of here in Kenai. In a state that owes its prosperity and indeed its existence in large part to oil, the event was a jarring one.

title: Knicks Back Out West
description: The Knicks yesterday flew to the West Coast, where they will open a four-game trip tonight against the Golden State Warriors in Oakland, Calif. Going into their game with the Nuggets in Denver last night, the Warriors, who posted a 43-39 record last season, a 23-game improvement over the year before, were off to a 3-8 start.

title: About New York; 5 Beaten Women Reunite at Home Away From Hell
description: It had been at least six months since the last of the five women had moved out of this large house that was their home after their lives became living hells. And now, on a sunny morning, they had returned. There were hugs and laughter and chatter about how fast children grow up. The women cooed over a set of twins not yet born when they lived together.

title: Wisconsin Coach Out
description: Don Morton, who managed only six victories in his three seasons, was dismissed yesterday as coach at the Wisconsin. The school's Athletic Board voted, 10-0, with one abstention to remove Morton, who has two years left on his five-year contract.

title: Small College Shifts Focus To Minorities and the 90's
description: Working in a factory alongside his father was an option that Luis Rivera of Passaic always had but never wanted. His dream was to go to college, learn all he could about computers, work for a big corporation and, someday, own the business.

title: Bush Pledges 'No Surprises' At Malta on Cuts in Troops
description: President Bush declared today that he does not intend to strike a deal that would sharply reduce troop levels in Europe when he meets this weekend with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President.

title: Benefit for Homeless
description: Christine Lahti, Debbie Shapiro, Liliane Montevecchi, George Hearn, Ruth Brown and Victor Garber are among the artists scheduled to take part in a benefit performance for the homeless on Dec. 11 at 8 P.M. at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Proceeds are to benefit the Partnership for the Homeless. Tickets to the performance and a reception afterward are $250; for the show alone, $100, $25 and $15. Information: 764-0899.

title: Europeans Ask U.S. Not to Reach Understanding on Troop Cuts Yet
description: Western European defense ministers asked the Bush Administration today not to reach any understandings about American and Soviet troop cuts when President Bush meets this weekend with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sweet-Tooth Specials

title: Overriding a Chinese Veto
description: Chinese leaders, quick to complain when foreigners question their conduct of internal affairs, have now presumptuously interfered in the American legislative process. They demand that the Bush Administration veto a bill allowing Chinese students to remain in the U.S. after their visas expire. Even more offensive are signs that the White House might capitulate.

title: Lower East Side Squatters Block Community Housing Projects
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 U.S. Towers At Foley Sq. Will Avoid Review Steps
description: Worried that full public review might seriously delay or even derail their plan to build two large civic buildings in lower Manhattan, the Federal Government and New York City have agreed to sidestep that process.

title: The Pop Life
description: New by Caetano Veloso

title: Max Low, Hospital Supplies Executive, 88
description: Max M. Low, a founder of the IPCO Hospital Supply Corporation, died of heart failure Monday at Albert Einstein Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Summit Goals: Nicaragua's Election . . .
description: The rebel offensive in El Salvador, punctuated by the crash of a plane laden with Soviet arms apparently bound from Nicaragua for the Salvadoran rebels, will force the subject of Central America onto the agenda of this week's summit. While President Bush will rightly press President Mikhail Gorbachev to halt the flow of arms to Nicaragua, his main focus ought to be the Nicaraguan election scheduled for February.

title: Philips Industries Accepts New Bid
description: Philips Industries, a maker of components for the building and transportation industries, agreed to a new lower price of $24 a share in its proposed buyout by members of management and Merrill Lynch & Company. Philips had originally agreed to be acquired for $25.50 a share. The company's shares rose $1 today, to $23.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: As Summit Talks Near, Maltese Mean Business
description: For centuries, Mediterranean powers bartered, seized or bullied this little archipelago because it sat at the center of what was long the world's most vital sea route. The affronts continue to this day, with a recent survey by travel agents finding that many people think Malta is a drink, a place in the Caribbean or a suburb of London.

title: Leslie Bruce, Financier, 91
description: Leslie Combs Bruce, a retired financier, died Saturday at the Doylestown (Pa.) Nursing Facility. He was 91 years old and had lived in Greenwich, Conn., before moving to Doylestown in 1984.

title: Allegheny's New Reorganizing Plan
description: Allegheny International Inc. said it had filed a revised reorganization plan with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Western Pennsylvania.

title: Soviets Pardon Veterans Accused In Crimes During the Afghan War
description: The Soviet Legislature granted an unconditional amnesty today to all former servicemen who committed crimes while serving in Afghanistan, including more than 2,000 prisoners serving time on charges ranging from petty theft to premeditated murder.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Prague's Communist Government all but surrendered to its opposition by pledging to yield its 41-year monopoly on political power and to allow non-Communist ministers into a cabinet to be named by Sunday. Page A1

title: Aristech Rejects Huntsman Offer
description: The Aristech Chemical Corporation said its board had voted to reject a proposal by Huntsman Holdings Inc. of Salt Lake City to acquire Aristech for $25 a share. Aristech's chairman, Thomas Marshall, said, ''The board does not consider it in the best interests of our stockholders to react favorably.''

title: Everex Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Justices Uphold U.S. Right to Fee for Deciding Claims Against Iran
description: In a legal footnote to the Iran hostage crisis, the Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the Federal Government's authority to keep for itself a small part of the compensation won by American companies in a special court set up to handle claims against Iran.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Past Is Now the Latest Craze
description: A booming market in nostalgia is turning yesterday - when all our troubles seemed so far away - into the latest craze in the communications and consumer products industries.

title: Cuomo to Urge Plan to Treat Drug Addicts
description: The Cuomo administration is planning a major push to expand New York State's drug treatment network to treat 10,000 more addicts, state officials said today.

title: From the Outback, a Cuisine for Australia
description: LEAD: ROASTED witchety grubs, sauteed mangrove worms and green ant juice may not soon replace shrimp on the barbie as Australia's most popular fare, but these delicacies are bringing new recognition to the long-neglected culture of Australia's aborigines.

title: New England Bank Forecasts a Loss
description: The Bank of New England Corporation said that it expects to add substantially to its reserves this year and that the fourth quarter would show a substantial loss. The company's earnings have been seriously depressed by a sluggish New England economy and a soft real estate market.

title: Hungarian Says Trade Will Double
description: Hungary's Minister of Trade predicted today that the United States' recent decision to grant most-favored-nation tariff treatment to Hungary would contribute to a doubling of two-way trade, to $1 billion a year, by the early 1990's.

title: A 'Reindeer' Is Killed in Error
description: Fred Kreig, who plays Santa for handicapped and poor children, lost a mock reindeer to a hunter last week. Mr. Kreig runs Santa's Cottage, a Chenango County farm that gives tours and holiday events. A hunter shot one of the 12 European fallow deer posing as reindeer after it had escaped from its pen. The deer was shot after the hunter had apparently mistaken it for a wild deer. The hunter offered to pay for the deer, which was valued at $800.

title: Debentures From Utility in Quebec
description: Hydro-Quebec, the electric utility owned by the Province of Quebec, is offering $500 million, up from $400 million, in debentures due in 2029 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Hard Choices for Arms Makers
description: Spending cuts being contemplated by the Pentagon for the 1990's could bring profound changes in the weapons business.

title: M/A-Com Goes Outside In Picking New Leader
description: M/A-Com Inc., facing uncertain times as a maker of electronic components for the military market, yesterday named Thomas A. Vanderslice, 57, as chairman and chief executive to succeed Thomas F. Burke, 60, who suffered fatal injuries in an auto accident in September.

title: Edith S. Stevens, 90, Volunteer for Agency
description: Edith S. Stevens, a volunteer for Planned Parenthood of Union County, N.J., died of a stroke on Nov. 22 at her home in Plainfield, N.J. She was 90 years old.

title: Rockets Win and Stop Lakers' Streak at 9
description: Four free throws by John Lucas helped the Houston Rockets stop a late Los Angeles rally tonight and gain a 110-104 victory that ended the Lakers' winning streak at nine games.

title: Filmstar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said comparable results are not available; the company went public in March 1988.

title: Witness Denies Payoff in Westchester
description: When Morgan Hughes, an amusement park concessionaire, came to Westchester County in 1982 to negotiate leasing rides at the county-owned Playland Amusement Park in Rye, his lawyer took him directly to Republican Party headquarters.

title: Hopeful of New Cancer Treatments, Companies Team Up to Study a Gene
description: A day after two researchers at the University of California at San Francisco received the Nobel Prize for the discovery of normal genes that can cause cancer when they go awry, a tiny New York biotechnology company received the first Food and Drug Administration approval for a diagnostic test based on such genes.

title: For Foreign Workers, American Life 101
description: LEAD: DR. ROBERTA SERET calls herself a relocation specialist. To explain, she recounts the story of a Japanese business executive transferred to the United States who was invited to a Sunday barbecue by one of his American clients.

title: Kentucky Struggling To Reform Its Schools
description: Five months ago, the Kentucky Supreme Court broke new ground in education when it declared the state's entire public school system unconstitutional.

title: Devils Sink Islanders in Overtime
description: John MacLean's 13th goal of the season, 3 minutes 30 seconds into overtime, gave the Devils a 3-2 victory over the Islanders tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena and saved the home team an embarrassment.

title: Amid New Famine Worry, Ethiopia Talks Advance
description: The Ethiopian Government and one of the rebel groups opposing it said today that they had agreed on procedures for substantive peace talks to begin early next year.

title: Bottom-Line Thinking Won't Save Our Climate
description: To the Editor:

title: Kysor Vote Urged
description: An investment group led by the Enstar Group Inc., once known as Kinder-Care Inc., said it had submitted a shareholder proposal for a vote at the Kysor Industrial Corporation's next annual meeting that would require its directors to seek a buyer for the company. Enstar, an operator of day care centers based in Montgomery, Ala., controls 12.1 percent of the six million shares outstanding of Kysor, a refrigeration equipment and truck-part maker in Cadillac, Mich.

title: Search for Plane Suspended Off Block Island
description: Evidence mounted today that a twin-engine commuter plane with eight people aboard plunged into the cold waters off Block Island on Tuesday night.

title: Laser Industries Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included inventory writedown in the amount of $4,080,000.

title: Paul Mellon Is Given Public Service Award
description: Paul Mellon, the president and chairman of the National Gallery of Art, has received this year's Benjamin Franklin Award for public service from the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia.

title: Bridge
description: Earlier this week this column fell victim to an ambiguity and understated the role of women in the last three decades in the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship. The Official Encyclopedia record lists John Solodar, who went on to become a world champion, as a runner-up in 1974, but it was actually his wife at the time, Judi Solodar, who as Judi Radin has since won three world titles. The editor had confused two J. Solodars.

title: Clamor in the East; U.S. Officials Believe Gorbachev No Longer Wants Control of East
description: On the eve of the Malta summit meeting, Administration officials have concluded that the Soviet leader, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has in essence written off Eastern Europe and no longer feels that direct control there is essential for Soviet security.

title: Three Men Use Rope Ladder To Escape Jail in Jersey City
description: Three inmates, including one charged with murder, escaped overnight from the Hudson County Jail by descending a homemade rope ladder in view of a major thoroughfare, the authorities said today.

title: Dinkins Asks for Time in Filling City Hall Jobs
description: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, facing conflicting suggestions and second-guessing about whom he should name to his administration and how soon, pleaded yesterday in gently Biblical tones for faith, hope, charity and a bit of patience to give him time to do the job well.

title: Fiat Called Set For Bid to Saab
description: Fiat S.p.A., the Italian car maker, is prepared to offer more than five billion kronor, or about $780 million, for 51 percent of the car division of Sweden's Saab-Scania A.B., Swedish Radio reported today. Quoting unnamed sources, Swedish Radio said the Wallenberg family, which is Saab's largest single shareholder, was willing to let Saab sell a majority stake in the division. But unspecified issues must still be overcome and no agreement appears imminent, according to the report.

title: INSIDE
description: MX Missiles Shifting Seven states have been selected as sites for 50 nuclear missiles that will be removed from silos and placed on trains in an attempt to make them less vulnerable to attack. Page B20. East Cool to Kohl's Plan East Germany reacted coolly to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's proposal for a ''confederative structure'' joining the Germanys. Page A19. Economic Growth Revised The G.N.P. grew at a slightly higher rate from July to September than previously estimated but is expected to be weaker this quarter. Page D1. Nighttime Pediatrics The increasing number of working mothers is prompting more pediatricians to offer evening hours. Page C1.

title: 3 Linemen Are Finalists
description: Moe Gardner, a nose tackle from Illinois; Mohammed Elewonibi, an offensive guard from Brigham Young, and Michael Tanks, a center from Florida State, were named finalists yesterday for the Outland Trophy as the country's top lineman. The winner will be announced Dec. 6. The voting is by the Football Writers Association of America. (AP)

title: KEY RATES
Microlog Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bottom-Line Thinking Won't Save Our Climate; Air-Conditioning Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: LADISLAV ADAMEC, Prime Minister: LAH-dyih-slahv AH-dah-mets

title: Help the Homeless Off the Street; New Calcutta: An occasional series.; For the Homeless: New Old Hotels
description: The soft real estate market that darkens New York City's economic future opens a bright window of opportunity for New York State and City governments seeking ways to develop more housing for the homeless mentally ill.

title: Where Secondhand Is Better Than New
description: LEAD: VISITORS often admire the furniture and decorative objects in Jeanne Taylor's Greenwich, Conn., house, which was built in 1929 in the style of a small French chateau. From the gilded Federal mirror in the foyer to the pair of carved fruitwood 18th-century French chairs on the stair landing, everything looks as if it has been inherited or painstakingly collected from antiques shops.

title: Proposed West Side Project Attacked
description: A plan to build a two-block, four-tower apartment complex on West End Avenue was attacked yesterday by residents and community leaders from the Upper West Side, not only for its size but also for its potential impact in connection with the nearby Trump City proposal.

title: Just What Does Congress Do to Merit a Raise?
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Chief Is Selected For Panhandle Eastern
description: LEAD: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation, a Houston pipeline company that acquired the Texas Eastern Corporation in a takeover battle earlier this year, said yesterday that Philip J. Burguieres had been named president and chief executive, effective Jan. 1.

title: Banks Are Upheld on Insurance Business
description: Efforts by independent insurance agents to keep commercial banks out of the insurance business were set back yesterday in a decision by the United States Court of Appeals in New York.

title: Close to Home
description: SUDDENLY, it seemed to me that I needed a change of scene, if only for a few days. That I couldn't bear to look any longer on dirt and disorder, that I wanted to bathe in some sea of tranquillity. So I went to a little island and wandered along beaches and boardwalks lined with deer so tame they all but asked for a pat on the nose. I stared at them, they stared at me: we might have been babies, playing at peek-a-boo.

title: Claudio Teehankee, 71, Philippine U.N. Envoy
description: Claudio Teehankee, the representative of the Philippines at the United Nations and former Chief Justice of the nation's Supreme Court, died of cancer on Monday in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: O'Rourke Sees 'Blurred Lines' On Donations
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke today told a state panel investigating links between political contributions to the Republican Party and the granting of government contracts that some county officials ''appear to have blurred lines between the party's business and the people's business.''

title: Market Place; Flight From 'Junk Bonds' Appears to Be Losing Steam
description: The flight from ''junk bond'' funds seems to be slowing, some mutual fund managers said yesterday as industry figures showed that about 9 percent of the assets in those funds was withdrawn in the four months through October. Indeed, October was the worst month ever for junk bond funds as $1.2 billion poured out of the funds.

title: Cimco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Book Awards Honor Novelist and Journalist
description: ''Spartina'' (Alfred A. Knopf), by John Casey, about a man who is in love with his wife, his mistress, his sons and his boat, won the 1989 National Book Award for fiction lastnight. The nonfiction award went ''From Beirut to Jerusalem'' (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), by Thomas L. Friedman, an account of the Middle East conflict by the correspondent who won two Pulitzer Prizes for his reporting from that region for The New York Times.

title: Transact International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
