description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $45,474, or 1 cent a share, and $53,880, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: PBS to Broadcast Israeli Side of West Bank Story
description: In January the Public Broadcasting Service will present an independently produced documentary examining the uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza from Israel's point of view. An executive with WNET, the New York public television station that is producing the program for PBS, said no attempt would be made to offer a Palestinian perspective on the film.

title: Don't Tread on (or Privatize) the Postal Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Oblique Clash Between 2 Justices Mirrors Tensions About Abortion
description: For a few electrifying moments, two Supreme Court Justices, one of whom holds the constitutional future of abortion in her hands, conducted their own oblique debate today over how far states can go to assure that parents learn about their teen-age daughters' abortions.

title: Review/Theater; Father and Son's Sentimental Bluegrass Musical
description: ''Feast Here Tonight'' is a Kentucky blend of bluegrass music and tales about stranded turtles, lazy dogs, pumpkin pies and angels that speak to mules. The atmosphere is congenial, almost everyone plays a fiddle or a guitar and the sentiment is as thick as the elderberry jam that figures so prominently in the text.

title: Aer Lingus Switch
description: Aer Lingus, the Irish national airline, yesterday switched its advertising account from Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos to the New York office of Campbell-Mithun-Esty. Bernie Lynch, the passenger marketing manager of Aer Lingus, would not disclose the budget of the account or say why it had been moved. He said Aer Lingus would continue to have a limited relationship with Hill, Holliday because the agency handles advertising for the Irish Tourist Board. Aer Lingus participates in several tourist board campaigns.

title: Wallace Computer Services reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Holiday Sales: Mixed Pattern
description: Sales in the early part of the Christmas shopping season ''have been pretty good but nothing exceptional,'' with a mixed pattern and regional differences, Rosalind Wells, chief economist of the National Retail Merchants Association, said at a news conference yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21

title: Nathan Derecktor, 95, Real-Estate Developer
description: Nathan Edward Derecktor, a retired lawyer and real-estate developer, died on Saturday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 95 years old and lived in Katonah, N.Y.

title: Designs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income The company said results for the latest quarter and 9 months periods reflect the impact of sales promotions and shortfall in comparable stores sales.

title: Clamor in the East; Gorbachev, Visiting Italy, Urges Talks on Naval Arms
description: Striding triumphantly through Rome on his first state visit, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev criticized the West today for not discussing naval arms control, and proposed talks on American and Soviet naval bases in the Mediterranean.

title: Jogger Returns to Limited Work at Salomon
description: Nearly eight months after being raped and beaten so severely that the attack was initially listed as a probable homicide, the woman now known to the world as the Central Park jogger has returned to work at Salomon Brothers Inc., company executives said yesterday.

title: Rangers Lose on Ashton Goal With 0:11 Left
description: The play of his teammates in front of him had swung from the incompetent to the accomplished, and the scoreboard had correspondingly flicked from the grim sight of a 3-0 deficit to the remarkable vision of a 4-3 lead.

title: Judge Says Pittston Co. Violated Securities Rules
description: A Federal district judge ruled Tuesday that the Pittston Company violated securities regulations by voting proxies against three proposals submitted by striking miners at the company's annual meeting.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Acme Steel Co., Riverdale, Ill. said Lawrence W. Hicks, president and chief executive of Lone Star Steel Co., Dallas, was joining Acme as executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Banner Dispute Over, AIDS Show Will Open
description: An art exhibition about AIDS at the Henry Street Settlement that was withdrawn two weeks ago in a dispute over a banner will open tomorrow.

title: Wyle Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Commercial Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $166,000 from the sale of a subsidiary. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Odors From Plant Anger Many in Harlem
description: The unfinished $1.1 billion North River Sewage Treatment plant that the city regards as state of the art has developed a serious odor problem that angers residents of West Harlem and annoys some motorists who use the West Side Highway.

title: Books of The Times; The Best Picture Books Of the Year for Children
description: The challenge of picking the year's best children's picture books is daunting. As Ralph Waldo Emerson once observed, ''St. Peter's cannot have the magical power over us that the red-and-gold covers of our first picture book possessed.'' None of the following 11 books have an exclusively red-and-gold cover, nor can I swear that any of them will surpass the power of a work of Renaissance architecture in the eye the young beholder. But they seemed the best of a very good batch. They are arranged approximately in order of increasing sophistication.

title: Arizona Guard Quits
description: Only two days before the Arizona State Sun Devils open their basketball season tonight at Oregon State University, Adrian Brown, a 6-foot-1-inch sophomore guard, quit the team. Coach Bill Frieder said the guard, who is from Tucson, Ariz., had been troubled by minor knee injuries and sagging grades. (AP)

title: Litton Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FCMI Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the second-quarter loss was mostly due expenses involved in the organization and development of its real-estate syndication subsidiary. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Shift Urged In Controls On Exports
description: Business and labor advisers to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, called on the White House today to give the ''highest priority'' to streamlining its export controls.

title: Pauley Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $7,268,000 and $11,726,000 on the sale of assets for the quarter and year, respectively, and the same periods included income tax benefit of $5,451,000 and $6,098,000, respectively. c-Net loss The company said losses in the first quarter were offset by positive results in subsequent quarters reflecting improvements in oil and gas prices.

title: General Parametrics reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
12 Suspended as Fight Halts Game
description: A dozen players from Merrimack College and Northeastern University were suspended yesterday after a brawl terminated the game between the two schools Tuesday night.

title: Child World reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Dorothy Bowles, Social Worker, 86
description: Dorothy Stebbins Bowles, a social worker and former chairwoman of the Board of Education in Essex, Conn., died yesterday at her home in Essex. She was 86 years old. A 1928 graduate of Smith College, Mrs. Bowles was the widow of Chester B. Bowles, who served as Ambassador to India and Governor of Connecticut.

title: HEAD OF NAVAJOS PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: The suspended chairman of the Navajo tribe pleaded not guilty today to 107 criminal counts filed against him by special tribal prosecutors.

title: B. Altman Falls Prey To Corporate Jackals
description: To the Editor:

title: Contributions To Neediest Honor Many
description: A check for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund arrived the other day with a note from the donor that said: ''Please do not acknowledge or send a receipt. Postage rates at 25 cents take too much of a bite overall.''

title: Rotech Medical reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Autopsy Set for Operator of Crane That Collapsed
description: The investigation of the fatal construction accident here on Tuesday will include an autopsy to determine whether a crane operator suffered a heart attack just before his equipment snapped apart 16 stories above the ground, carrying four workers crashing to their deaths and crushing a bus driver.

title: Reviews/Dance; Sheer Energy and Moral Character
description: Bebe Miller implied that physical energies may be signs of the presence or absence of moral character in the two new works that she and her company danced Tuesday night as an attraction of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: U.N. Group Backs a P.L.O. Role
description: The Bush Administration warned of ''grave consequences'' for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization after it voted overwhelmingly today to strengthen cooperation with the Palestine Liberation Organization, despite American threats of financial sanctions.

title: Talking Deals; A Buyout Firm Becomes Friendly
description: FORSTMANN, LITTLE & Company, a leading leveraged buyout firm, has been trying to persuade its investors that it should also offer companies some friendly alliances.

title: Kellwood Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Money Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for a third consecutive week, increasing slightly for tax-exempt funds and falling for taxable funds in the week that ended yesterday.

title: Review/Television; Inventing Las Vegas In 'The Neon Empire'
description: Showtime's two-part, four-hour movie ''The Neon Empire,'' which will have its premiere on the pay-cable service at 9 P.M. on Sunday and Monday, is an ambitious package with a promising subject: the creation in the 1940's of glittering Las Vegas out of a dusty Nevada town on the road to Los Angeles. With Larry Peerce as director, Pete Hamill's script is loosely fashioned, so to speak, on real-life figures.

title: U.S. Won't Oppose Ford-Jaguar Deal
description: The Ford Motor Company's acquisition of the British luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C. will not be opposed by the Federal Trade Commission. The commission and the Justice Department agreed on Nov. 21 to waive the remainder of a 30-day waiting period begun after Ford and Jaguar announced the plan on Nov. 2, said John M. Sipple, the chief of the F.T.C.'s Pre-merger Notification Office.

title: 2D DISTRESS FLARE SEEN IN HUNT FOR 5
description: Coast Guard searchers looking for five lobstermen whose boat disappeared last week moved farther out to sea this morning after spotting a distress flare for the second consecutive night.

title: Mullin 'Doing Good Things For Myself'
description: He still talks like a Noo Yawker and he still looks like one. Instead of a California tan, his skin is as white as the towels in the St. John's University locker room. During Chris Mullin's first few seasons with the Golden State Warriors, he couldn't wait to be traded to the Noo Yawk Knicks. Every so often the Knicks talked to his attorney, Bill Pollak, about fitting his contract into the their salary cap. But the deal was never completed.

title: Filmstar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said comparable results are not available; the company went public in March 1988.

title: Landry Rates Cowboys
description: After winning only one of his first dozen games as coach of the Dallas Cowboys, Jimmy Johnson came under indirect criticism yesterday from his predecessor. Tom Landry, the only coach the Cowboys had in their first 19 years before he was dismissed by Jerry Jones, the new owner, spoke to a gathering of the Fellowship of Christian Athletes in Greenville, S.C.

title: Clamor in the East; Malta, Speck Among Nations, Ends Military Links to Libya
description: After being bartered, seized or bullied by almost every power in the Mediterranean, Malta has turned another page, this one peaceful, in its history. On Sunday, it formally ended its military cooperation agreement with Libya.

title: G.N.P. Rate In Quarter Put at 2.7%
description: The nation's economy grew at a moderate rate of 2.7 percent in the July-September quarter, slightly higher than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today.

title: For the Holidays, A Grab Bag of Sales
description: Holiday sales, many of them philanthropic, are in full swing this weekend. Here are a few.

title: Treasury Official Seen As Choice for Fed Seat
description: David W. Mullins Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, is the front-runner to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said today.

title: Penney Officer Gets New Role
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that Robert B. Gill, a vice chairman, would become chief operating officer of Penney stores and the company's catalogue division on March 1.

title: Hanson Plc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $79 million for the quarter and an extraordinary income of $465 million for the year. c-Included extraordinary income of $346 million and $718 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents 5 ordinary shares. Share earnings for the latest quarter and year-ago quarter were not available. Results are in U.S. dollars; the exchange rate used to translate the U.S. dollars was Sept. 30, 1989, rate of $1.615 equal to one pound sterling. The company said the results for 1989 included a two-month contribution in respect to Consolidated Gold Fields Plc and a full year's contribution in respect to Kidde (1988 - 11 months).

title: 50 MX Missiles Are to Be Shifted to Trains in 7 States
description: The Air Force announced today that seven states had been selected as sites for the 50 MX nuclear missiles that will be removed from silos and placed on trains to make them less vulnerable to a surprise enemy attack.

title: Bottom-Line Thinking Won't Save Our Climate; Solar Thermal Machines
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Asks Britain to End Cambodia Plan
description: The United States has asked Britain to lay aside its plan to send a diplomat to Cambodia to supervise the distribution of British aid, American and British officials said today.

title: Bank of Montreal reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Results are in U.S. dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Bush 'Talking Points' at Malta
description: When President Bush sits down with Mikhail Gorbachev on Saturday, he will have in his briefcase a set of ''talking points'' from his top advisers suggesting what issues to raise and how to raise them. Here are proposed talking points that could help him seize the initiative from Mr. Gorbachev:

title: A Moment of Decision At the Kennedy Center
description: The announcement last month by the board of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts that it would not renew the contract of Ralph P. Davidson, the center's chairman and president, underlines the special problems of that gleaming culture palace on the banks of the Potomac.

title: Loss at American Medical
description: American Medical International Inc. today reported a $52.4 million loss, after taking a $100.2 million charge against earnings.

title: Topics of The Times; Where Do Men Come From?
description: To some it is a redundancy, to others a logical necessity and to still others an excrescence on higher education. It is called ''men's studies,'' and it is said to be enjoying growing popularity on the campus.

title: Warsaw Pact Alliance to Meet
description: The Warsaw Pact military alliance will meet in Moscow after the Soviet-American summit meeting this weekend, a Polish Government spokesman said today. Solidarity officials said Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, would brief Warsaw Pact members on his talks with President Bush.

title: Frederick Kingsbury, Banker, Is Dead at 82
description: Frederick Hutchinson Kingsbury Jr., a general partner in the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: Arab Foreign Ministers Meet On P.L.O.'s Call for Support
description: Arab foreign ministers met in Tunis tonight at the request of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which wants them to renew the broad Arab commitment to the P.L.O. as a central player in Middle East diplomacy.

title: Three Wrongs in Salvador
description: An ultra-right Government in El Salvador seems indifferent when its soldiers are accused of murdering priests. Cuba and Nicaragua are believed to arm guerrillas who kill civilians in the name of peace. A planeload of arms destined for the rebels but captured by the Salvadoran Army includes surface-to-air missiles - devastating evidence, so the Salvadoran Government contends, that Managua, Havana and Moscow have violated a regional embargo.

title: The Lavoro Scandal
description: A parade of F.B.I., I.R.S. and Customs agents, accompanied by Justice Department lawyers and the Inspector General of the Department of Agriculture, have been descending on the office of the U.S. Attorney in Atlanta to help with what Federal lawmen say is a ''long-term investigation'' into what international bankers call ''the Lavoro affair.''

title: Freeport-McMoran in Asset Sale
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc., a diversified natural resources company, said today that it would sell about a third of its $3.8 billion in assets. The company said the sale was expected to bring $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday headed ''The Military Market,'' showing the Pentagon budget and the value of contractors' prime contracts, described annual Defense Department budget figures incorrectly.

title: Witness Recalls Talk of Desire To Kill Officer
description: A convicted drug dealer testified yesterday that three months after a New York City police officer was shot to death someone told him that Howard (Pappy) Mason wanted ''another cop killed'' to show ''we ain't playing.''

title: More Traders Subpoenaed
description: Federal agents delivered subpoenas to eight more futures traders this week, defense lawyers said today. The lawyers said traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures pit were the targets of the latest step in the investigation of the Chicago futures exchanges.

title: Lovelorn Hope Movies Have Just the Right Words
description: At the crazy crossroads where the movies meet real life, these lines have recently appeared in the personals columns:

title: A Bomb in the Baggage? No, a Video Game
description: Explosives experts at Los Angeles International Airport today blew up a suitcase bound for Bogota, Colombia, that was suspected of containing a bomb.

title: Lottery Ads to Dailey
description: After a review that included three other agencies, Dailey & Associates retained the $50 million advertising account of the California State Lottery. The Los Angeles agency, a unit of the Interpublic Group, edged out Chiat/Day/Mojo and the Los Angeles offices of BBDO and J. Walter Thompson after a review process mandated by state law, said Phillip Joanou, the agency's chairman.

title: Crowley, Milner & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-Net income

title: NATO Defense Ministers Fail to Agree on Conventional-Arms Cuts
description: Western defense ministers ended two days of meetings here today without reaching a consensus on where NATO should go in cutting conventional arms in Europe.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Northgate Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: The Capital Wonders Again At Mayor Barry and Drugs
description: Once again Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has been accused of using drugs. Once again he has denied the charge. And once again the city of Washington has been left to ponder a set of titillating questions about its Mayor, questions that, if the past is prologue, will not soon, if ever, be answered.

title: Clamor in the East; For East Germany's Border Squad, a Hole Has Become a Crater
description: Life has become a lot harder for East Germany's 8,000 customs service officers since the Berlin wall and other crossings were opened earlier this month.

title: The Fall of Gandhi; Nehru's Grandson, Many Indians Say, Was Never Quite One of the People
description: When Rajiv Gandhi went to the President on this cool, clear morning to resign as Prime Minister of India, he was in almost every sense a man alone. The defeat of the grandson of Jawaharlal Nehru was a personal defeat.

title: Visions of Europe; The View From Moscow - a special report: Clamor in the East; Gorbachev's Hope for Future: 'A Common European Home'
description: When it comes to the future of Europe, no one accuses President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of lacking vision.

title: Toyota Plant Starts
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said its automobile plant in Georgetown, Ky., began producing engines for its Camry models, which in the future would be exported to Japan. Toyota, Japan's largest auto maker, said annual production at the plant would rise to 300,000 vehicles in 1992. The plant has 3,000 employees and produces 200,000 Camry sedans a year. A total of 40,000 right-hand-drive vehicles and 100,000 engines will be shipped to Japan beginning in 1992.

title: Insects Found in Imported Foods, Stein Says
description: Insect infestation was found in 6 of 17 samples of imported food products bought in New York City stores, City Council President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.

title: New York Awarded Title Meet For 1991
description: After unsuccessful bids in the last three years for the national outdoor track and field championships, New York City today was awarded the 1991 event.

title: John F. Grady, Surgeon, 87
description: Dr. John F. Grady, a retired surgeon, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 87 years old. He practiced in Manhattan from 1933 to 1974, when he retired. He had been an attending surgeon at the French Hospital in Manhattan and a director of the French Polyclinic Hospital. Dr. Grady, who was born in Jersey City, graduated from Fordham University and the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.

title: Mallon Resources Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Because of a business combination completed Dec. 21, 1988, results for 1988 periods are not comparable.

title: Shuttle Sensors Are Focus Of Inquiry by a Grand Jury
description: A Federal grand jury met yesterday in Birmingham, Ala., to hear charges that improperly inspected and possibly inaccurate sensors on booster rockets made by the Thiokol Corporation were used on the first flights of the space shuttle after the Challenger disaster.

title: Posey Quest Splits in Two
description: Posey Quest Genova, a small Connecticut agency, said yesterday that it had dissolved, with TBWA Advertising buying a share of the agency to merge into its New York office.

title: 97 by Sooners Set Mark (for a Half!)
description: Oklahoma missed four chances at college basketball's first 100-point half before settling for a record 97 tonight on the way to crushing U.S. International, 173-101.

title: THORNBURGH'S AIM: PLUG NEWS LEAKS
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that unauthorized disclosures to reporters had prompted him to order a complete review of Justice Department press guidelines to tighten the release of information.

title: Makela Goes to Kings
description: Mikko Makela, the right wing who scored 95 goals and was credited with 124 assists in 307 National Hockey League games for the Islanders since he was a fifth-round draft choice in 1983, was traded to the Los Angeles Kings yesterday for Ken Baumgartner, a defenseman, and Hubie McDonough, a rookie center.

title: Topics of the Times; The I.R.A., You Say?
description: For several months rumors have circulated in Britain and the U.S. that McDonald's, the fast-food chain, has given financial support to the Irish Republican Army through Noraid, the I.R.A.'s North American fund-raising group. McDonald's itself couldn't figure where the implausible charge came from, and denied it flatly at every opportunity. But the rumor, and the mystery, persisted.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Mattel Names Heads For 2 New Divisions
description: LEAD: Hoping to capitalize on the success of such products as Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels, Mattel Inc. yesterday divided its domestic operations into a girls division and a boys division, and named two of its executives to head them.

title: Man Finishing Training At a School for Nannies
description: Another cultural stereotype is about to be destroyed. The New England School for Nannies should graduate its first male nanny next month.

title: Heisman Committee Prepares For Race Down to Final Vote
description: When it comes to football, Bill Esposito is a basketball man who sleeps better when he has all the bases covered.

title: Follow-Up Drive Starts in an Area Swept by T.N.T.
description: In a move to safeguard gains made by undercover narcotics officers, the Police Commissioner of New York announced yesterday a pilot project for a team of uniformed officers to patrol drug-infested street corners after the undercover Tactical Narcotics Team has swept through a neighborhood.

title: U.S. Staff Told To Take Refuge In San Salvador
description: In the face of a new rebel attack here in the capital, the United States Embassy today urged its officers, contract employees and dependent families to leave their homes for safer quarters on embassy property. It also offered to grant special leaves to diplomatic personnel who wished to leave the country.

title: Government of Laws?
description: In the tumult of our joy at what is happening in Czechoslovakia, a small cold irony is passing almost unnoticed. Just as the Czechs move toward democracy, we have taken a step toward arbitrary, unaccountable government power.

title: Beth Israel Nurses Win Raises in 3-Year Pact
description: The Beth Israel Medical Center yesterday announced a new contract for its nurses that hospital officials said would make its nursing staff the highest paid in New York City.

title: South Carolina Federal reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest fourth quarter figures included special loan loss provision of $11,170,000 for real estate and other loan losses related to Hurricane Hugo.

title: Clamor in the East; Nadia Comaneci Said to Flee Rumania for Hungary
description: The Rumanian gymnast Nadia Comaneci, who earned the first perfect score awarded in Olympic gymnastic competition during the 1976 games in Montreal, has fled to Hungary and gone into hiding, Hungarian officials said today.

title: Canadian Home Shopping NetFwork Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $16,200,000 which represents a reduction in the carrying value of computer software and a write-off of all remaining goodwill. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $12,700,000 which represents a reduction in the carrying value of certain assets. The company said some year- earlier figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sunrise Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gandhi Resigns as Prime Minister; His Party Gives Up Power for Now
description: Rajiv Gandhi resigned as Prime Minister of India today, saying that ''in all humility'' he had accepted the verdict of the people, who defected from his Congress Party in droves in national elections that ended on Sunday.

title: Hasbro Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Several Parties Said to Be Interested in Buying Big Stake in Shearson
description: At least seven parties have expressed interest in buying a large part of the American Express Company's stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. as part of a deal to inject capital into the investment house, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Site of Golden Horse Is No Longer a Puzzle
description: The mystery of the golden horse has been solved.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Italian Wins Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy won the second slalom of the World Cup season yesterday by 1.73 seconds in Waterville Valley, N.H. Tomba easily won both heats in times of 57.96 and 58.28 for a total of 1 minute 56.24 seconds. His closest challenger in each test was Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, who was more than one second behind after a first run of 59.15 seconds.(AP) N.H.L. Capitals 5, Red Wings 3: Calle Johansson's goal with 2 minutes 53 seconds left in regulation spoiled a Detroit comeback bid and lifted Washington to victory in Detroit. Johansson beat the Detroit goaltender, Sam St. Laurent, with a wrist shot from the slot for the game-winner after Detroit had exploded for three goals in a 3:23 span midway through the period to tie the score.

title: Meridian Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Labor Talks Recessed
description: Negotiators for the Players Association and the 26 major league clubs met for three and a half hours yesterday, the second day of talks on a new collective-bargaining agreement. The two sides then recessed the talks until Dec. 12, when the talks will resume in Los Angeles.

title: TAIWAN PREPARES FOR OPEN ELECTION
description: In 1950, Xie Zhuizhen made the terrible mistake of winning an election here, defeating a candidate endorsed by the governing Nationalist Party.

title: Teacher Seized In Concealing Of Sex Cases
description: A New York City public school gym teacher with a criminal record, including a conviction for public indecency involving a minor, was arrested yesterday in the Bronx, prompting an investigation into how he was hired for a system that is supposed to run extensive background checks on new teachers.

title: American Toxxic Control reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Icahn Move on USX Stock
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., said yesterday that he had asked the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission for antitrust clearance to buy more than 25 percent of the USX Corporation.

title: School District Is Ordered to Assist Deaf Parents
description: A school district must supply a sign-language interpreter for deaf parents at school-sponsored conferences involving their children, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: DRUG CAN CONTROL HEPATITIS C VIRUS, RESEARCHERS FIND
description: For the first time, a drug has been shown effective against the form of hepatitis that most frequently infects Americans.

title: Washington Talk; Diplomacy Minuet: First Lady Is Ready
description: Raisa Gorbachev always seemed to get the best of Nancy Reagan. No matter how Mrs. Reagan steamed or stewed or sulked, the Soviet First Lady managed to outmaneuver her and dominate the spotlight. ''Arrogant,'' Mrs. Reagan called Mrs. Gorbachev in her new memoir.

title: Yale Disciplines Two Over Gay-Protest Clash
description: Two Yale police officers will be disciplined for using ''poor judgment'' in arresting two people during a clash with the police at a conference on gay and lesbian studies in October, university officials said today.

title: Court Bias Seen in New Jersey
description: New Jersey's judicial system subtly discriminates against black and Hispanic defendants and those of other racial and ethnic minorities, a state Supreme Court task force said in a report today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The economy grew at a moderate rate of 2.7 percent in the July-September quarter, slightly higher than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said. Most private analysts predicted a sharply weaker performance in the final three months of the year and the first quarter of 1990. A few even said they feared that the nation's longest peacetime expansion, which enters its eighth year in December, could be in jeopardy. [ Page D1. ] The White House science adviser said the Bush Administration did not endorse a recommendation to provide Federal subsidies for the semiconductor and consumer electronics industries. [ D1. ] David W. Mullins Jr. is the front-runner to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said. Mr. Mullins, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was an architect of the Administration's plan to rescue the savings industry. [ D2. ] The people who invested in now-worthless securities offered by Lincoln Savings and Loan are paying a price that is emotional as well as financial. [ A22. ] COMPANIES In a decisive step toward ending the two-year bankruptcy of Public Service of New Hampshire, all major parties in the process have agreed to a plan filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the utility to be acquired by Northeast Utilities. [ D1. ] Seven potential bidders have expressed interest in buying a large percentage of the Shearson Lehman Hutton stock held by the American Express Company, Wall Street sources said. [ D5. ] Drexel Burnham Lambert's commercial paper was downgraded by Standard & Poor's. The move will raise the cost of a small percentage of the firm's financing. [ D5. ] Attempts to bring Japanese investors into a Bloomingdale's buyout continue, with several new twists. Marvin Traub, the store's chairman, called talks in Tokyo ''serious and constructive.'' [ D17. ] Freeport-McMoran will sell a third of its $3.8 billion in assets to concentrate on recent discoveries of sulfur off the shore of Louisiana and copper in Indonesia. [ D4. ] Fiat is prepared to offer about $780 million for 51 percent of the car division of Sweden's Saab-Scania. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL Business and labor representatives called on the White House to assign the ''highest priority'' to streamlining export controls, warning that if the U.S. does not move rapidly enough, Europeans will buy fewer American high technology products and cut American companies out of cooperative research projects. [ D6. ] MARKETS Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading, and dealers said an auction of $8 billion worth of five-year Treasury notes went as anticipated, with prices rising significantly. [ D17. ] Yields of money market mutual funds were mixed for a third consecutive week, increasing slightly for tax-exempt funds and falling for taxable funds. [ D8. ] Stock prices fell across a broad front as traders concluded there was no possibility of an imminent cut in interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 13.23 points, to 2,688.78. [ D10. ] The dollar turned in a mixed performance as the mark continued to dominate the foreign exchange markets. [ D18. ] Gold prices fell sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York. [ D18. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The flight from ''junk bond'' funds seems to be slowing this month, after the funds had their worst month ever in October. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D1. ] Forstmann, Little has been trying to persuade its investors that it should offer companies some friendly alliances. But it is meeting resistance. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The Mingo Group, among the best-known black-owned agencies, is at a crossroads. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: Guillevin International reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Clamor in the East; Bush Hoping to Use Malta Talks to Speed Strategic Arms Pact
description: President Bush wants his meeting this weekend with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to speed up talks on reducing long-range nuclear weapons, possibly by giving negotiators a timetable for dealing with the remaining obstacles to a treaty before the next Soviet-American summit meeting in 1990, senior officials said today.

title: Executive at Union Camp Promoted to Top Positions
description: W. Craig McClelland was promoted yesterday to president of the Union Camp Corporation, and he was also named its chief operating officer, a new title at the Wayne, N.J., diversified paper company.

title: Ewing and Knicks Pound Warriors
description: Patrick Ewing scored a season-high 44 points and grabbed a career-high 24 rebounds as the Knicks started a four-game Western trip with a 129-111 victory over the Golden State Warriors tonight.

title: Reviews/Dance; The Protean Whirl of an Artist's Evolving Gifts
description: The Erick Hawkins Dance Company opened its weeklong season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) on Tuesday night with an exhilaratingly upbeat program of new and recent dance. The lives of artists may be all too brief, but their particular art can grow and change in remarkable ways during those life spans. That was the message of the season's premiere, ''New Moon,'' and Mr. Hawkins's ''Cantilever Two,'' created last December.

title: Pirates Sign Terrell
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, whose chief off-season goal was to sign a starting pitcher, reached terms yesterday with Walt Terrell, a free-agent right-hander, on a three-year, $3.6 million contract.

title: Doubts on Japanese Deal for Bloomingdale's
description: Several new twists have been added to the attempts to organize a buyout of Bloomingdale's with Japanese investors. The American retail store's chairman said all was going well, but two potential buyers expressed misgivings about the price being asked.

title: Bye, Bye, Bus Industry
description: LEAD: The guarantee of ''equal access to transportation'' in the proposed Americans with Disabilities Act is simple to explain. It means many Americans will stay at home -equally denied access to affordable intercity, charter and tour transportation.

title: Slumping Mavericks Dismiss MacLeod
description: John MacLeod, who brought the Mavericks to the brink of the National Basketball Association finals two years ago, was dismissed as the Dallas head coach yesterday, after a late-morning practice. Management said he failed to motivate the stumbling club.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. POLITICAL AND SECURITY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SOCIAL, HUMANITARIAN AND CULTURAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Julius Kass, 84, Retired Labor Lawyer, Dies
description: Julius Kass, a prominent labor relations lawyer in Manhattan for many years and a former senior partner of Bandler & Kass, died of a heart ailment Tuesday at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Collapse of Lincoln Savings Leaves Scars for Rich, Poor and the Faithful
description: Much has been made of the $2 billion that it will cost taxpayers to bail out Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. But for the people who were persuaded to invest their life savings in now-worthless securities, the cost is emotional as well as financial.

title: Odyssey Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oneida Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The company said latest 9-month results included a gain of $1,433,000, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of facilities in Bangor, Northern Ireland. Per-share figures reflected a 10-percent common stock dividend that was effective this month.

title: Clamor in the East; Rumania Getting an Unfamiliar Cold Shoulder in the West
description: Having been treated with sympathy by Western Governments over most of the last two decades, Rumania's hard-line Communist Government seems both surprised and confused to find itself suddenly under attack from the West for its human rights record.

title: Groundwater Technology Inc. reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 28
Meyer Pesin Dies at 88; Ex-Jersey City Official
description: Meyer Pesin, a former corporation counsel for Jersey City and a former president of the Jewish National Fund of America, died Tuesday in Caracas, Venezuela. He was 88 years old and had lived in Teaneck, N.J., before moving to Caracas four years ago.

title: Review/Theater; Hollywood Parable About Evil in America
description: Halfway through Peter Parnell's new play, ''Hyde in Hollywood,'' a malevolent 1930's gossip columnist named Harry Babylon tells the audience his nightmare. Harry has dreamed of a phantasmagoric movie premiere at which the stars he helped make famous are all scrambled: Gary Cooper sounds like Marlene Dietrich, Adolphe Menjou is made up like Rita Hayworth, and Deanna Durbin sings ''My Bill'' to Helen Morgan, who is dressed like Hattie MacDaniel in ''Gone With the Wind.'' Soon the stars turn on Harry and devour him, until finally he finds that his tongue has landed in Bette Davis's purse and that he is ''nowhere . . . nothing . . . not anything.''

title: French Rightists Visit Lebanon to Support Renegade General
description: As preparations for war continued around the capital today, a group of 30 right-wing French legislators flew into the country to show support for Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian armed forces commander.

title: E & B Marine Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $4,889,810, or 44 cents a share, which represents gains of $4,764,810 from extinguishment of debt and $125,000 from carryforward of prior year operating losses. c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a dispute over a huge hog farm being built in Colorado misstated the holdings of Philip Anschutz, an opponent of the development. He owns the Eagle's Nest ranch; he does not own a hog farm.

title: Metall Mining reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,096,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Included a tax extraordinary credit of $1,018,000, or 2 cents a share, and $6,604,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said it had no revenues in the year-ago quarter and 9-month periods. Income in those periods arose solely from the company's equity accounting of its investments in Teck Corp. and Cominco Ltd. The company also said discussions are continuing with its major shareholder, Metallgesellschaft AG, to acquire its remaining mining interests and properties. The transaction is expected to be finalized early next year.

title: Bottom-Line Thinking Won't Save Our Climate; Clean Air Tax Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Killed in New Violence in Disputed Soviet Area
description: At least two people were killed today in violence that broke out after a Soviet parliamentary decision to change the status of the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh, an official in the southern territory said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't want the monopoly of one party to continue.'' - Vasil Mohorita, a new member of the Czechoslovak Communist Politburo. [ A1:6. ]

title: U.S. Plane Aiding Guerrillas In Angola Reported to Crash
description: A C.I.A. plane carrying military and other equipment from Zaire to American-backed rebels in Angola crashed this week, killing at least five Americans and an undetermined number of insurgents, Government officials said today.

title: Kemp Shifts Residency To Home in Maryland
description: Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack F. Kemp has given up his residency in New York, ending any chance of his running for governor next year against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, state Republicans said today.

title: Foresbec Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $236,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sanderson Farms reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included $1,250,000, or 13 cents a share, from accounting adjustment.

title: Europe 'Dumping' Move
description: The European Community's Executive Commission said today that it was investigating a complaint of ''dumping'' by China of silk used to make typewriter ribbons. The community's only producer of the silk, Spinnhuette G.m.b.H. of West Germany, contended that the China National Silk Import and Export Corporation sold the material at artificially low prices. The complaint says Chinese silk imports rose to 250,000 square meters the first nine months of the year, from 150,000 square meters in 1986, giving the country nearly 25 percent of the community's market.

title: Importance of Test-Driving Skis
description: Test-driving a pair of skis before laying out $300 to $500 would seem to be a sensible idea, but most skiers base their buying decisions on such superficial things as color, price or a friend's recommendation. Equipment manufacturers have for several years been trying to counter this method by providing skis for free tests.

title: Boom Times for Army Base and Its Region
description: On 2,000 bleak acres here in northern New York, the Army has opened a computerized firing range to hone the skills of 21st-century warriors. At a time of glasnost, the opening of the Berlin wall and talk of troop cutbacks in Europe, an M-60 tank demonstrating at the range's dedication on Tuesday fired at mock Soviet tanks and plastic soldiers called ''Ivans.''

title: S.&P. Drops Rating for Drexel Paper
description: Responding to the weakening financial position of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday downgraded the firm's commercial paper. The move will raise the costs of some financing for the firm.

title: Walter T. McLaughlin, Athletic Director, 83
description: Walter T. McLaughlin, the athletic director at St. John's University for 39 years until he retired in 1973, died on Tuesday at his home in Largo, Fla., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Metro Matters; Cleanup Drive With a Heart Alters Midtown
description: Daniel A. Biederman is emerging as the mayor of midtown Manhattan.

title: Lecture on Fred Astaire
description: John Mueller, a film archivist and author, will speak on Fred Astaire's film solos and duets on Wednesday at 3:10 P.M. in Room 615 in the Hunter West Building of Hunter College, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue. Mr. Mueller is the author of ''Astaire Dancing: The Musical Films.'' A discussion will follow the lecture, which is open to the public. Admission: $3. Information: 772-4551.

title: Taylor Is Sidelined For the Eagles Game
description: Lawrence Taylor, who has missed only one regular-season game because of injury in his nine professional seasons, will miss the Giants' important game against the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday in Giants Stadium.

title: Survey Finds Split on Abortion Persisting
description: Americans remain sharply divided over the abortion issue, with 41 percent saying abortion should be ''generally available'' and 42 percent supporting stricter limits than currently exist, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey.

title: Topics of The Times; Floating Anchors
description: What's an anchorman? The term, also rendered as the gender-neutral anchor, has won dictionary recognition; it refers to a television personality who coordinates all the reports on a news broadcast. But even as the word wins formal acceptance, events are draining away its meaning. This has become the era of floating anchors. In the last few days the anchors of the television network news programs have been broadcasting from Berlin, Prague, Frankfurt and Rome, with Malta to come -anywhere but from headquarters in New York. By tonight, ABC's Peter Jennings will have broadcast from the road 31 times in the last six months, one out of every four broadcasts; Tom Brokaw of NBC and Dan Rather of CBS have logged similar mileage.

title: Study Finds Possible Link Of Cancer and Power Lines
description: A new study has found a statistically significant link between cancer and human exposure to electromagnetic fields from the network of electrical wires that crisscross the nation.

title: Trusthouse Forte Quits Savoy Battle
description: Trusthouse Forte P.L.C., a British catering and roadside hotel company, abandoned a bitter eight-year-long battle for control of the elegant Savoy hotel chain. The quest by the Forte family for the Savoy, Claridges, the Connaught and the Berkeley - some of London's most celebrated hotels -has been described in British news coverage as a class struggle for a slice of tradition.

title: Talks on Cyclops ESOP Plan Fail
description: Cyclops Industries ended its plans to sell its specialty steel unit to its employees under a stock ownership plan. The company declined to comment on what caused the negotiations, which began in June, to fail.

title: Shift Sought From 'Black' To 'Urban'
description: THE black advertising industry is at a crossroads, and in the middle of it stands the Mingo Group.

title: Ernesto Civardi, Cardinal, 83
description: Ernesto Cardinal Civardi of Italy died on Tuesday in Rome. He was 83 years old. The cause of death was not made public.

title: Poor Management at Agencies Expected to Cost U.S. $100 Billion
description: The Comptroller General told Congress today that the Federal Government, riddled with serious management problems at every large agency, faced more than $100 billion in losses.

title: Soprano's Debut Recital
description: Darynn Zimmer, the winner last spring of the annual Joy in Singing competition, is to give her first New York recital on Dec. 14 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The soprano is to sing groups of songs by Gabriel Faure, Claude Debussy, Felix Mendelssohn, Hugo Wolf, Richard Hundley and Ricky Ian Gordon, and a group of cabaret songs by Arnold Schoenberg. Tickets are $10, or $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 362-8719.

title: Vornado Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
White House Won't Back Chip Subsidy
description: The White House's science adviser said today that the Administration does not endorse an advisory committee's recommendation to provide Federal subsidies to rebuild the nation's semiconductor and consumer electronics industries.

title: Ultrak Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
House of Fabrics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dangers of Barring Lawmaker From Rite
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Faulted On Taping In Connecticut
description: A state report issued today said that the Connecticut state police bungled policies and ignored warnings about tape-recording telephone conversations at police barracks, which led to a ''complete disregard for the concepts of privacy and attorney-client confidentiality.''

title: Currents; Designer as Street Art
description: WHEN many people who know the interior designer Andree Putmansee her larger-than-life-size image on the Gap advertisements at bus shelters around New York, their first reaction is that they can't remember ever seeing her in jeans.

title: Sports-Tech International Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss The 1988 period was from the company's inception in Nov. 1987 through Aug. 31, 1988.

title: Expanding the Atlantic Air Lanes
description: In talks that could intensify competition among European and American carriers and clear the way for trans-Atlantic travelers to fly directly to myriad new destinations, the United States is negotiating new treaties governing international airline service with its four biggest European trading partners.

title: Socanav Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter results included the results of Steinberg Inc. since Aug. 22. The latest quarter results do not include those of Steinberg's Ivanhoe Inc. unit. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Duty Free International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said share earnings figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed last month.

title: Continental Health Affiliates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soviets Deny A.F.L.-C.I.O. Request for Visit
description: Soviet officials have denied a request by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to send the first official delegation in its history to the Soviet Union to meet with striking coal miners.

title: Whiting Petroleum Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Locker Group reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $11,500, or 1 cent a share. The company said the decrease in latest 9 months earnings is attributable principally to increasing the reserve for remedial environmental work.

title: Clamor in the East; CZECH PARTY AIDE SEES FREE BALLOT WITHIN NEXT YEAR
description: Responding to an opposition demand, a member of the new Czechoslovak Communist Politburo said today that free elections could be held within a year.

title: Double Helix Films reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said net income for the 1988 third quarter and 9 months included an extraordinary gain of $12,552 from utilization of tax loss carryforwards.

title: Clamor in the East; On Course for Malta: Three Decades of Statecraft
description: September 1959: President Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. The talks result in the ''Spirit of Camp Daivd,'' an effort to press for scientific and cultural exchanges and disarmament. May 1960: Eisenhower and Khrushchev go to Paris. But the Soviet leader, angry after his country sights and downs an American U-2 spy plane over the Soviet Union, cancels the meeting. June 1961: Khrushchev and President Kennedy have heated exchanges in Vienna. There are no formal agreements. A year later, the Soviets send nuclear missiles to Cuba; the United States forces their removal. June 1967: President Johnson meets in Glasboro, N.J. with Alesksei N. Kosygin to discuss the Middle East, the Vietnam War and nuclear arms. They come to no terms on those issues. may 1972: President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, in Moscow, sign the first treaties setting limits on strategic nuclear arms, known as SALT I, and on curbing anti-ballistic missile systems. They agree to keep negotiating on arms, but regional issues divide them. June 1973: Nixon and Brezhnev meet in Washington. They agree to try to complete a new arms treaty by 1974. June-July 1974: Nixon and Brezhnev meet in Moscow and Yalta. They agree to a treaty banning underground nuclear-arms tests with yields exceeding 150 kilotons, and they arrange a 10-year economic accord. November 1974: President Ford and Brezhnev, in Vladivostok, reach a tentative deal limiting missile launchers and bombers and lay a base for a second strategic arms treaty. The treaty is not completed before President Carter takes office. June 1979: Carter and Brezhnev, in Vienna, sign the second treaty limiting strategic arms, or SALT II. Although the Senate never approves the treaty because of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in December of 1979, both sides agree informally to observe the limits. November 1985: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet in Geneva for wide-ranging talks on arms control and other subjects. They agree to revive cultural exchanges and to enhance air safety, but no arms-control agreements are acheived. October 1986: Reagan and Gorbachev meet in Reykjavik, Iceland, to provide momemtum to arms-control talks. The two sides speak of vast cuts in strategic arms and medium-range missiles, but the accord falls through because of disagreements over the American plan for a space-based missile defense system, or Star Wars, and over Moscow's insistence on putting all arms issues in one package. December 1987: Reagan and Gorbachev meet in Washington. They sign a treaty to destroy intermediate-range nuclear forces, known as I.N.F., and agree to seek a treaty cutting long-range nuclear arsenals. But Star Wars remains a sticking point. may-June 1988: Gorbachev and Reagan, in Moscow, ratify the intermediate-range weapons treaty but make no breakthrough on cutting long-range nuclear forces. Reagan says important work has been accomplished but Gorbachev complains of ''missed opportunities.'' December 1988: Gorbachev says farewell to Reagan and greets President-elect George Bush at a two-hour luncheon on Govenors Island in New York harbor. Reagan assures Gorbachev of continuity under Bush.

title: NUI Corp. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,193,000, or 24 cents a share.

title: Arthur J. Emma, Executive, 68
description: Arthur J. Emma, chairman and chief executive officer of G. Fox & Company, the Hartford-based department store chain, from 1972 until his retirement in 1980, died Monday at Pardee Hospital in Hendersonville, N.C., after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived in Hendersonville.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misstated the availability of terms for the acquisition of the Safeskin Corporation by Daltex Medical Sciences Inc. The terms were available on Tuesday; under them, Daltex will issue 16 million shares of its common stock to Safeskin.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bowater Industries, London, which acquired the Norton Opax P.L.C. printing group in September, sold Norton's 3 percent stake in De La Rue Co., a security printer. The price was $:13 million and no buyer was disclosed.

title: Parent & Child
description: TED ESELGROTH vividly remembers receiving a call a few years ago from a man who announced that he wanted to marry Mr. Eselgroth's widowed 70-year-old mother. The man, an old friend of the family who was a widower, was unsure of the response he would hear.

title: Dow Drops By 13.23, To 2,688.78
description: Stock prices fell across a broad front yesterday as traders concluded there was no possibility of an imminent cut in interest rates.

title: McEnroe Whines, Baits, Stalks And Wins
description: The Masters was treated last night to its first dose in three years of its favorite - if irreverent - son, John McEnroe, and the great gesticulator did not disappoint.

title: Court Blocks Execution of Slayer With I.Q. of 76 Who Killed at 17
description: The Supreme Court today blocked the execution of Dalton Prejean, who was due to die early Thursday in Louisiana for killing a state trooper when Mr. Prejean was 17 years old.

title: California Water Negotiations Will Consider Environment
description: Under strong political pressure, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. announced today that environmental factors would be taken into account when the Federal Government negotiates the renewal of water supply contracts with farmers in California's Central Valley.

title: Clamor in the East; Spirit of 1968 Is Still Alive, Still Distinct
description: ''You remember the spirit of 1968,'' said a science writer who left her country that year for exile in West Germany. She came back last weekend for three days, bringing her young daughter, so that she, too, could see ''our second revolution.''

title: Next Inc. Outlook
description: Steven P. Jobs, the president of Next Inc., said that his company was shipping thousands of its work stations this year and that it expected to ship tens of thousands of them next year. He told industry officials that half of the 100 largest American companies had been testing the new machines and that a half-dozen new applications programs were expected by next spring at $600 to $700 each. Mr. Jobs said the computers were unlikely to be sold for much less than $10,000, although machines without optical disk drives have been sold for $7,995.

title: Boa Vista Journal; This Is El Dorado? Gold and Death in the Jungle
description: The streets of this jungle city may not be paved with gold, but Albert Dunbar Beckers finds it worthwhile to sweep the sidewalks.

title: Public Service's Takeover Appears Near
description: In a decisive step toward ending the two-year bankruptcy of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, all major parties in the process have agreed to a plan filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the utility to be acquired by Northeast Utilities.

title: Steep Polish Path to Free Markets
description: Poland, which pioneered the political transformation taking place in most of Eastern Europe, is facing a tougher time leading the way to replacing its crumbling Communist economic system with something resembling market-oriented industry.

title: Finally a Tenant for Governor's Mansion
description: Eight years after it was designated the official residence of New Jersey's governors, the 19th-century Greek Revival mansion called Drumthwacket will soon have its first tenants.

title: Yankees Seek Langston and Valenzuela
description: The Yankees will carry their annual need for pitching into the winter meetings next week in Nashville, but it is likely that the players they covet most are available now, without the burden of having to make a trade to get them.

title: Review/Television; Profiles of Burton and Gary Cooper
description: Having rerun most old movies, whether classic or trash, to the point of exhaustion, television is exploring new ways to market or repackage the same material. There is, for instance, coloring black-and-white movies. And increasingly there are the biographical essays that focus on one personality. Mixing film clips with fact, interviews with speculation, these collections offer the subjects and their lives as metaphors for our times, indeed our century. Some exaggeration is inevitable. Two typical examples are at hand, reviewing the careers of Gary Cooper and Richard Burton.

title: Treasury Securities Fall Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light, featureless trading yesterday.

title: No Forced Layoffs Seen in I.B.M. Cuts
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, stung by product delays and increasing competition, wants to reduce costs further, but it remains committed to its 40-year-old policy of no forced layoffs, George H. Conrades, an I.B.M. senior vice president, said in an interview.

title: CHIEF SAYS C.I.A. CAN'T AFFORD CUTS
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that intelligence agencies should be spared deep cuts in spending because political change in Eastern Europe and the possibility of new arms treaties are heightening the need for information.

title: Again, Cuomo Whisper Is a Boom at City Hall
description: As Governor Mario M. Cuomo proved by hinting and hedging his way through New York City's Democratic mayoral primary, even the subtlest suggestion of favor from the Governor's mansion can send a booming echo through City Hall.

title: Empire State Life Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Seven Oaks International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $76,000 and $105,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $418,000 and $919,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Daisy Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included non-operating charges of $133,817,000 primarily representing intangible assets and other Cadnetix acquistion related costs. c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $1,585,000, or 9 cents a share for both the quarter and year. The company said the latest year figures included results of Cadnetix Corp. for all of the fourth quarter and for the last months of fiscal 1989.

title: Monmouth Real Estate InvestFment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company did not release a figure for average shares outstanding in the quarte. The company said it expects to maintain its 70-cent annual dividend rate during its fiscal year 1990.

title: Where to Find It; Finials, Elaborate and Custom-Made
description: MICHAEL ZEGOS takes a square block of wood and puts it on a wood lathe. He cuts off the edges, making the block hexagonal. Next he takes gouging tools and, as the wood turns, starts to carve.

title: Maverick Restaurant Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Liver Recipient Is Reported Awake
description: A 21-month-old girl who received a portion of her mother's liver in a rare operation was awake and improving today, doctors said.

title: Gisele Birnbaum, 79, Immigration Lawyer
description: Gisele Blankstein Birnbaum, an immigration lawyer for the International Rescue Committee in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Doctor's Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MTS Systems reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
C.I.A. Document Said to Contradict Waldheim
description: A document indicating that President Kurt Waldheim of Austria was an intelligence officer in the German Army in the Balkans at the end of World War II and not a law student in Vienna, as he had asserted, has been in the files of the Central Intelligence Agency for 42 years, officials of the World Jewish Congress said yesterday.

title: Club's Limit on Women Upheld, Grudgingly
description: A judge said today that a golf club's policy to restrict women's tee-off times was repugnant and offensive but legal. The judge, Edward McCarty of Nassau County Court, said he was powerless to order a change because the club, Cedar Brook in Old Brookville, is private.

title: Warming of Earth Is Slowed, Scientist Says
description: The major climate changes that may result from the warming of the earth's atmosphere are being delayed by 20 years because the use of the gases thought to cause the warming has been reduced, a space agency scientist says.

title: People
description: * Daniel Langdon has been named senior vice president of public relations at the Ad Council.

title: NAVY FIXES BLAME IN SHIP GROUNDING
description: A Navy report says a junior officer who ignored advice from a lower-ranking navigator was to blame for the grounding of the Navy destroyer Spruance on a reef off the Bahamas in January.

title: Techdyne Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $38,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $199,000, or 11 cents a share for the 9 months. c-Net loss The company previously reported that its parent, Medicore Inc., said it would begin a tender offer within the next few days for up to 350,000 shares, or 19 percent, of the company's outstanding stock, exclusive of the 61 percent already owned by Medicore. The offering price per share is anticipated to be $2.50.

title: Nets Crushed in 9th Straight Loss
description: Less than a month into the season, the Nets are already trying to salvage some respect.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS (NBA) -Activated Danny Manning, forward, from the injured list. Waived Carlton McKinney, guard. FOOTBALL NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Waived Undra Johnson, running back. Signed Bobby Morris, running back.

title: SL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included after-tax charges of $128,000, or 2 cents a shae, for amortization of non-compete covenants and patents resulting from acquisitions. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for 6-percent stock dividend paid this month.

title: Jersey Moves to Protect Parking for Disabled
description: Able-bodied motorists who decide to save a few steps by parking in a spot reserved for the handicapped are more likely to find their cars towed away under a law signed today by Gov. Thomas H. Kean.

title: Medicore Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $22,800 and an extraordinary credit of $119,400, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Clamor in the East; East Germans React Coolly To Kohl Plan for Closer Ties
description: The Communist leadership of East Germany reacted coolly today to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's proposal on Tuesday for a ''confederative structure'' joining the Bonn and East Berlin Governments. But it did not reject the Kohl plan out of hand.

title: Prescribing the Symptom: Psychologists Say Its Power Lies in the Paradox
description: For some insomniacs, psychotherapists prescribe an unorthodox treatment: They are told to try to stay awake. Similarly, some procrastinators are instructed to put off getting to work.

title: Judge Declares Mistrial for 3 in Sedition Case
description: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today after a jury deadlocked on racketeering charges against three avowed revolutionaries already cleared of plotting to overthrow the Government.

title: Information International reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a gain of $775,000 from litigation settlement for both the latest and year-ago periods.

title: Personal Health
description: For a minute there, as the latest cholesterol controversy began to rage, you may have thought: ''I knew it all along. How can something as wonderful as steak and eggs, pumpkin pie and ice cream, sausage and gravy, really be bad for me?'' Maybe at Thanksgiving dinner you went overboard on foods rich in fats and cholesterol just to prove you wouldn't keel over with a coronary on the spot.

title: Clamor in the East; Party Orthodoxy Falters In a Yugoslav Republic
description: Milan Kucan and Joze Pucnik share the sense that something basic needs to change in Yugoslavia. And though they came to this view from divergent poles of power and oppression, they have drawn conclusions that evoke one of Eastern Europe's most tantalizing dilemmas: can Communist rulers instill reform without reforming themselves into oblivion?

title: Ex-General Emerging as a Force in Argentina
description: A tough-talking retired army general with a platform defending the counterinsurgency campaign that killed an estimated 9,000 Argentines a decade ago has emerged as a powerful political force in the impoverished northwestern province of Tucuman.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday, about stock custody services for investors, referred incorrectly in some editions to the fee typically charged by a bank for this service. It is generally 2.5 basis points of the portfolio value. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) A portfolio worth $500 million, therefore, would have a bank fee of $125,000.

title: Cup Seedings Revealed
description: Argentina, Belgium, Brazil, Italy, Spain and West Germany will be the seeded teams for the 1990 World Cup, the president of soccer's world governing body said in an interview published today.

title: A-PLANT IS CLOSING FOR SAFETY REVIEW
description: The Energy Department announced today that it was temporarily shutting down the buildings at the Rocky Flats Plant in Colorado that are the nation's only source of purified plutonium for nuclear weapons. The department said it would use the time to take an inventory of plutonium and to resolve safety, management and environmental problems.
